response_text: Ireland’s 2026 Presidency can play a transformative role in strengthening the EU’s sustainability, public-health and food-policy agenda. Driving forward an EU Strategy for Plant-Based Foods to support the green transition The European Commission has publicly committed to presenting a Protein Strategy. Denmark has already demonstrated, through initiatives such as Danish Plant-Based Diplomacy, how plant-based food strategies can support climate goals, food security, and economic innovation. Ireland should adopt the promotion of plant-based foods as a cross-cutting Presidency priority, building up on previous European Council presidencies. An EU-wide strategy would advance the work already in place, empower farmers through diversification, support public health and meet consumer demand for sustainable diets. The Blueprint for an EU Plant-Based Action Plan, endorsed by many actors, provides a solid foundation for EU-level action. Safeguarding ambition in negotiations on the Regulation on Animal Transport Given Ireland’s central role in farmed animal movements and live exports, the Presidency must protect the scientific integrity of the transport reform. This means defending strict journey-time limits, banning long-distance live exports (particularly to non-EU countries), and prohibiting transport of vulnerable animals, such as pregnant and unweaned animals. Ireland can ensure that EFSA’s scientific recommendations remain the backbone of the reform, and more generally, that EU policy making remain embedded in the latest, pair-reviewed scientific knowledge. Upholding democratic commitments, including the ‘End the Cage Age’ ECI Ireland should help ensure that the European Commission delivers an ambitious proposal on laying hens, ending the use of cages and including a ban on day-old chick culling across all sectors. This is essential to uphold the democratic mandate of the ECI. Integrating animal welfare into EU trade policy Ireland should champion policy coherence by advancing legislative discussions on applying EU-equivalent welfare standards to imports, following previous European Commission statements on the matter. This protects both animals and EU farmers and responds to clear public demand. Reinvigorating the EU’s animal welfare agenda The Presidency should prioritise continuity in the revision of the EU animal welfare acquis. This includes ensuring that the Commission delivers ambitious proposals and that the Council maintains progress on files aligned with One Health and One Welfare principles. Ireland should carry forward the work initiated by Denmark and Cyprus, especially around AMR and welfare improvements. Together, these priorities would allow the Irish Presidency to lead on animal welfare, sustainability, innovation, while contributing to a competitive and resilient European agriculture sector.

EU Animal Transport Regulation Ireland should aim to defend high welfare ambition throughout the trilogues by: • maintaining strict journey-time limits • banning long-distance live exports and sea transport to non-EU countries • prohibiting transport of unweaned and vulnerable animals • embedding EFSA’s species-specific recommendations • improving enforcement Legislative proposal on laying hens (ECI follow-up) Ireland should encourage the Commission to deliver an ambitious draft text that: • ends caged housing for laying hens • bans day-old chick culling across all sectors • ensures species-specific, science-based standards • includes transition support for farmers EU Strategy for Plant-Based Foods Ireland has a unique opportunity to advance the European Commission’s upcoming strategy on Protein diversification. The Presidency should: • initiate Council discussions on an EU-wide strategy for plant-based foods • build on Denmark’s pioneering work on the Danish Plant-Based Diplomacy • support the adoption of an Action Plan aligned with the Blueprint for an EU Action Plan for Plant-Based Foods, accompanied by a dedicated fund • integrate plant-based food promotion into climate, health and CAP agendas Council Conclusions on AMR The Presidency should build on Danish and Cypriot leadership by adopting new conclusions linking reduced antimicrobial use to improved animal welfare, reinforcing public health and resilience, and work together with the European Commission to put the topic higher in the European agenda. Legislative follow-up on import equivalence Ireland should advance discussions on aligning import requirements with EU animal welfare standards, including: • establishing equivalence criteria in trade agreements and European trade policies • integrating welfare into trade agreements • supporting farmers through a level playing field

A Presidency that champions animal welfare, sustainable food systems and plant-based innovation would create substantial benefits for EU citizens, rural economies and public health. Lower costs and improved public health An EU strategy for plant-based foods would help citizens access healthier and more affordable food options. Diversifying protein sources supports better nutrition and reduces the long-term costs associated with non-communicable diseases. Stronger, more resilient farming sectors Promoting plant-based diversification and higher-welfare systems strengthens farmers’ resilience to volatile markets, climate shocks and disease outbreaks. Transition support and innovation funding create new value chains and income streams. Reduced antimicrobial resistance and improved food safety Linking animal welfare improvements to AMR reduction delivers benefits across society. Better farm conditions reduce the need for antibiotics, protecting public health and reducing healthcare burdens. Fairer trade and protection for EU farmers Advancing import-equivalence rules ensures that EU farmers are not disadvantaged by competing against products produced under lower welfare standards. This supports rural livelihoods and strengthens internal-market fairness. Climate and environmental benefits Plant-based food strategies reduce pressure on land, water and emissions. Higher-welfare, extensive or agroecological systems similarly deliver environmental gains. These benefits flow back to communities through cleaner air, healthier soils and more sustainable local economies. Innovation, jobs and economic opportunities The plant-based sector is one of the fastest-growing in European agri-food markets. By supporting an EU strategy, Ireland can foster economic opportunities for SMEs, food innovators and farmers transitioning to new markets. Strengthening public trust Delivering on citizen expectations on animal welfare, sustainability and fair trade helps rebuild confidence in EU decision-making. A Presidency that responds to citizens’ concerns fosters unity across diverse communities and strengthen the European project.

Ireland’s Presidency will be an important opportunity to show citizens how EU action delivers practical benefits in areas that matter to them. Communicating this effectively means focusing on outcomes. When policy advances lead to safer food, reduced antibiotic use, improved animal welfare standards or clearer trade rules, these are tangible improvements that citizens can immediately recognise. The development of a European Strategy for Plant-Based Foods offers a positive and accessible narrative through which Ireland can showcase its leadership. The strategy reflects a wider shift already underway across Europe: consumers seeking healthier and more sustainable choices, and businesses investing in innovation. Highlighting Ireland’s role in moving this file forward shows that the EU can respond to societal demand and economic opportunity at the same time. It also shows the coherence of European Council engagement at a long-term scale, building up on previous Presidency, notably the Danish one. Equally important will be demonstrating responsiveness to democratic participation. Delivering credible progress on animal welfare reforms, including the follow-up to the End the Cage Age European Citizens’ Initiative, provides a clear example of the EU acting on citizens’ expectations. Emphasising this connection can help counter the perception of distance between institutions and the public. Communication should also reflect Ireland’s own strengths. Ireland combines a strong agricultural identity with a growing reputation for food innovation and high production standards. Showcasing farmers who are improving welfare, reducing antibiotic use or exploring diversification can illustrate how EU priorities align with national values and long-term rural resilience. By focusing on concrete outcomes, demonstrating responsiveness to citizens, and highlighting Ireland’s contribution to shaping a forward-looking European food system, the Presidency can build a strong sense of shared ownership and reinforce the understanding that EU action supports both people and communities across Europe.

In an era marked by rising authoritarian tendencies, disinformation and the erosion of civic space, the European Union stands at a critical crossroads. The EU must remain a stronghold for research, democracy and policy-making grounded in scientific knowledge, and avoid the deregulation agenda, when what we need is public trust and support. The EU must reaffirm itself as a bulwark of democratic integrity, science-led policymaking, transparency and plurality. Now is the moment to safeguard civic space and champion transparency, so the EU remains a model of citizen-led democratic law-making.

Economic, Social and Territorial Cohesion as a fundamental objective of the European Union translated on a nation level to - Balanced Regional Development the overarching priority of Project Ireland 2040.
Ensuring that in the EU Budget MFF that territorial cohesion remains a central pillar as part of negotiations on further budget.

By ensuring that policies relating to territorial cohesion are accelerated and have a real impact such that ‘leaving no one behind’ becomes a reality. This should include the twin objectives that climate policies are allied to ensuring that there is a fair and just transition to a carbon neutral society.

By ensuring the citizen is at the centre of communication, ensuring that the language is understandable, coherent, accessible and that the impacts are tangible. Being clear on the overall benefits that EU membership brings. Having a focus on young people who in the long term will be most impacted by strategic decisions made at a European level. By making events and activities accessible to all citizens through, for example hosting meetings on a regional basis.

The Southern Regional Assembly are a key EU delivery agency are very happy to assist the Government in relation to activities, programmes and events relating to the Irish Presidency. In partnership with the Department of Housing, Local Government and Heritage the SRA are organising ESPON week in Cork as part of the Irish Presidency of the EU.

respondent_type: Individual, and on also behalf of Asso.CEL.L, an association of non-national lecturers(Lettori) set up to campaign against persistent discriminatory working conditions in Italian universities.
response_text: A priority should be the reform of the procedures for the conduct of infringement proceedings for violations of the EU Treaties. Member States who signed the Treaties ceded national sovereignty for the sake of a greater good. To safeguard Treaty rights and for the rule of law to prevail, it is imperative that infringement proceedings should provide a proper remedy for EU citizens whose Treaty rights are being denied. The power to open and conduct infringement proceedings is vested in the European Commission. The proceedings may be own-initiative or based on evidence of Treaty violations from complainants. In the latter case the complainants do not become parties to the proceedings, which remain exclusively between the Commission and the Member States in perceived breach of Treaty obligations. Over the course of infringement proceedings, complainants are debarred from seeing and contesting information furnished by the Member States to the Commission. For their part, the Member States may see the evidence from complainants, should the complainants so agree. The complainants possess certain limited procedural rights such as the right to contribute information to the infringement file, to have meetings with Commission officials responsible for the file, to be consulted in advance for their observations should the Commission plan to close an infringement case. These rights are in no way absolute and their exercise is very much at the discretion of the Commission. The Commission is not accountable for its conduct of the infringement proceedings. It can ignore or evade pertinent questions placed on its conduct of an infringement case by MEPs on behalf of their constituency complainants. It can also ignore evidence of Treaty violations supplied by complainants. That the procedures for the conduct of infringement proceedings are heavily weighted in favour of the Member States to the disadvantage of complainants is demonstrated by the foreign language lecturers(Lettori) case, the longest running case of discrimination in the history of the EU. The Commission in July 2025 closed the third of its infringement cases against Italy for discrimination against Lettori. As the case had been referred to the Court of Justice in August 2023, a hearing was imminent. In the context of fair conduct of infringement proceedings, an important point needs to be made here. This is that the Commission closed the case without consulting with the complainants and without considering important evidence of persisting discrimination which they had furnished. The Commission also declined to address important legal points raised in 4 parliamentary questions by Irish MEPs on its conduct of the case. A fifth question to the Commission requesting the withheld information is pending. A third infringement case for the same breach of a Treaty provision is unprecedented. The Treaty of Rome provided for a one-phase infringement procedure. Subsequently the Treaty of Maastricht provided for a second-phase enforcement procedure with fines for non-implementation of Court of Justice first-phase infringement rulings. Together these two provisions were intended to ensure Member State compliance with Treaty obligations.

respondent_type: Individual, and on also behalf of Asso.CEL.L, an association of non-national lecturers(Lettori) set up to campaign against persistent discriminatory working conditions in Italian universities.
response_text: The Irish Presidency should seek to reform the procedures for the conduct of infringement proceedings for violations of the Treaty. The proceedings should be more open and transparent. In particular, exchanges between the European Commission and Member States in perceived breach of their Treaty obligations should no longer remain confidential. Complainants should have the right to see and, if necessary, contest documentation from Member States. Similarly, the Member States ought to have an automatic right to view documentation from complainants, a right which at present is subject to the consent of complainants. As well as being unfair and disadvantageous to complainants, existing procedures for the conduct of infringement proceedings are inefficient and time-consuming. The Commission has offices in the capitals of the Member States of the EU. Consequently, it could easily host meetings at these offices and hear the contending claims and evidence of the complainants and the Member States. Such an open conduct of its duties is appropriate for the Commission in the discharge of its role as Guardian of the Treaties. As things stand, the confidentiality requirement prolongs proceedings, and the attendant and time-consuming bureaucracy represents a great waste of resources.

respondent_type: Individual, and on also behalf of Asso.CEL.L, an association of non-national lecturers(Lettori) set up to campaign against persistent discriminatory working conditions in Italian universities.
response_text: To answer this question, it is appropriate to return to the point made in response to Q.1. This is that Member States who signed the Treaties ceded national sovereignty for the sake of a greater good. However, it is not for the greater good of citizens of the EU that the arrangements in place to enforce their Treaty rights can work to the advantage of Member States violating their Treaty obligations. EU citizens should have the right to have evidence they submit of denial of their Treaty rights included in Commission depositions in infringement cases. Equally, they should have the right to check the evidence of the Member States in perceived breach, evidence which after all concerns their welfare and the exercise of their Treaty rights. Further, the Commission should not be immune from accountability for its conduct of infringements proceedings. An instructive parallel here is that of how parliamentary questions are handled in the parliaments of Member States and how questions from MEPs are handled by the European Commission. Questions put down in Dáil Eireann, for example, receive a full and civil answer. However, the record shows that the European Commission can choose to evade or ignore questions put down by elected representatives of European citizens on behalf of their constituents. Accountability to parliament and to the citizens that parliamentarians represent are the rudiments of the democracies of the Member States. Unfortunately, these rudiments have not been carried over into the arrangements for the enforcement of the EU Treaties. So, if the procedures for the conduct of infringement proceedings were reformed to correct the disadvantages inherent in present arrangements, this would certainly have a positive impact on the lives of citizens subject to the Treaties and would be perceived by EU citizens as such.

respondent_type: Individual, and on also behalf of Asso.CEL.L, an association of non-national lecturers(Lettori) set up to campaign against persistent discriminatory working conditions in Italian universities.
response_text: In a sense the response to Q.3 carries over here. The improvement of arrangements to defend their Treaty rights and the requirement to have questions placed on their behalf to the Commission in the European Parliament properly addressed would certainly make citizens feel more a part of the Union and more represented by Union institutions. This in turn would make EU citizenship more of a reality and create a sense of vested interest in the good functioning and in the future of the Union.

respondent_type: Individual, and on also behalf of Asso.CEL.L, an association of non-national lecturers(Lettori) set up to campaign against persistent discriminatory working conditions in Italian universities.
response_text: As the longest-running discrimination case in the history of the EU, the Lettori case has attracted considerable media coverage over the years. The litigation for parity of treatment predates the present century and began in 1987 with the reference of the landmark Allué case to the Court of Justice by the Pretura di Venezia for ruling. The first of the Commission’s three infringement cases against Italy was opened in 1996 following representations from the Joint Committee on EU Affairs of Dáil Eireann under the chairmanship of the late Michael Ferris, who had invited testimony before the Committee on the breach of the parity of treatment provision of the Treaty. Over this long period many distinguished Irish journalists and broadcasters have covered the case, including the [REDACTED UNDER GDPR]. All the major national Irish titles have covered the case at one point or another. Local Irish titles have covered it too. Parliament Magazine, the “inhouse” magazine of the European Parliament has reported on the case. So too has The European Times. Examples of coverage in the more specialist press include articles in the Law Society Gazette. In the sources and additional information for which Q.5 makes provision I have included only a selection of material from the current year. I would make one final point about the unprecedented number of infringement proceedings to which the discrimination against Lettori has given rise. The Treaties make provision for one infringement case and a follow-on enforcement case, if necessary. In the Lettori enforcement case, Case C-119/04, the Grand Chamber of the Court of Justice declined to impose fines on Italy as the Commission depositions did not include evidence from the Lettori to contest Italy’s claims that last-minute legislation had ended discrimination against Lettori. It was to prevent a repeat of such a situation that [REDACTED UNDER GDPR], in the context of the third infringement proceedings, called on the Commission to check with the Lettori that the correct settlements due to them for discriminatory treatment had been made. The Commission declined to address the point in its reply and did not carry out the checks requested. The overarching theme might usefully include the ideas of ‘a secure home’ which can be understood in a range of specific and metaphorical ways – for instance as ‘Towards a Secure home for all Europeans’. One of the three priority themes should be: “Building homes, developing communities and ending homelessness” Given the growing engagement of the EU in the issue of housing, the scale of the housing challenge facing Ireland, and the particular phase of EU policy work in late 2026, it would be important for Ireland to proactively make Housing a key thematic priority. We would propose that rather than address Housing Supply in isolation, that the Government situate the issue within the broader issues of building secure, inclusive communities and reducing housing precarity and homelessness. This theme would bring together a range of important strands where the EU can play more than a rhetorical role but genuinely effect real change, reflecting both the major housing and anti-poverty strands in current EU work programme. This approach allows some of the social tensions emerging across the EU as result of housing scarcity to be addressed, making the theme more accessible to the concerns of citizens, and less of a technical discussion of ‘return on investment’, land values etc – while still allowing room for these important elements. This holistic approach also reflects the approach taken in the Government’s own new strategy, so that the priority theme grows out of existing and developing Government thinking, rather than being imposed upon it.

The priority from our perspective would be to see a formal resolution on homelessness adopted by the EPSCO Council. Such a recommendation would build on the Lisbon Declaration. Agreeing such a resolution in Ireland would reflect on-going Irish commitment to this work, including The European Federation of Homeless Organisations (FEANTSA) was founded at a conference in Ireland (Cork) in 1989 During the last Irish presidency, the first meeting of EU Homeless Ministers was convened and there was an agreed set of recommendations that could be reviewed and revisited. The key note speaker at the Lisbon Conference which launched the Declaration was Prof Eoin O’Sullivan, of Trinity College, who is recognised as one of the leading experts on homelessness in the EU Elements that might be included in such a resolution would be: A commitment to continuation of the EPOCH programme, with an operational budget Commitment to a monitoring report on progress in homelessness every two years; bringing homelessness data collection and analysis under Eurostat; Housing First and other housing led approaches to be delivered at scale in member states Adoption of a framework to guide work to prevent homelessness

During its Presidency, Ireland needs to be seen to take on the major themes emerging at across member states, but also needs to be seen by its own citizens to be bringing our own key challenges to the fore. Some commentators have suggested that Ireland should shy away from discussion of housing and homelessness because our own current situation on these issues is problematic. This would be a mistake, not least in respect of public perceptions of the process. Citizens and voters do not want their leaders to spend time applauding themselves for problems solved but rather to see them acknowledging and trying to solve the problems they really face. Ireland is in a uniquely strong position to lead in this area, with clear publicly acknowledged challenges, along with experiences of approaches which have worked as well as one which have not worked. It also has a new strategic framework at a stage where the key questions of implementation and funding are being considered.

Value are best expressed by being applied to real challenges faced by citizens. At the forefront of these is the housing and homelessness crisis. In doing this it is crucial to include the human perspective, expressing the voice of ‘lived experience to be heard’. As part of this initiative Government could work with homeless NGOs to establish a panel of people with lived experience of homelessness and housing precarity who could engage with a range of events during the Presidency.

Ireland’s Presidency should focus on accelerating the renewable energy transition across Europe in order to reduce our emissions and to meet our climate action targets. Enhancing our energy security and independence is also essential after Europe’s recent energy crisis, triggered by Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, exposed the risks of heavy reliance on imported fossil fuels. Ireland is particularly vulnerable because of its dependence on imported gas for electricity generation, which leaves us exposed to global price volatility and supply shocks. This underscores the urgency of building a resilient, renewable-based energy system that reduces reliance on external sources. By prioritising domestic renewable generation, flexible technologies, and storage solutions, Ireland can strengthen security of supply while delivering on climate commitments. Statkraft believe accelerating renewable energy should be prioritised through: Energy Security and Competition A resilient energy system underpins investment confidence and long-term growth. The Presidency should ensure that market reforms under the Electricity Market Design and Clean Industrial Deal strengthen competition, maintain investor confidence, and deliver affordable energy. Energy security must remain central, accelerating renewables and interconnection reduces reliance on imported fossil fuels and shields consumers from price volatility. Focussing on the Delivery of Renewable Energy Projects: Wind and solar remain the cornerstone of Europe’s decarbonisation strategy, and Statkraft is proud to be at the forefront of this transformation. According to Statkraft’s Green Transition Scenario, global wind capacity is projected to grow by 8.3% annually and solar by 10.7% through to 2050, but we must ensure Europe and Ireland are at the forefront of that growth. In Ireland, Statkraft is already delivering on this ambition. We currently manage over 1,200 MW of renewable energy projects and have more than 1 GW built or under construction, making us one of the leading contributors to Ireland’s clean energy future. Our experience spans the full project lifecycle, from development and permitting to construction and operation, giving us a deep understanding of what it takes to turn policy into real-world results. As Ireland prepares to assume the EU Council Presidency in 2026, Statkraft stands ready to assist the Government in showcasing the country’s leadership in renewable energy. We would be delighted to facilitate site visits to operational wind and solar projects or share insights from our development experience to demonstrate how ambitious targets can be delivered on the ground. Delivery of Offshore Phase One Projects Ireland is already off track to meet its 2030 offshore wind targets, with the Department now indicating that construction on Phase One projects will only begin by 2030. This means the original ambition of having significant offshore capacity operational by 2030 will not be achieved. This is a serious credibility issue for Ireland as an EU climate leader. If we cannot deliver on our own targets, it undermines investor confidence and our influence during the Presidency. We must use this period to provide absolute clarity and certainty for the ORESS Phase One projects, including timelines, grid connection plans, and permitting, to protect Ireland’s reputation and demonstrate commitment to accelerating offshore deployment across Europe. Planning Reform Delays in planning approvals remain one of the biggest obstacles to meeting Europe’s 2030 climate targets. The Irish Presidency should make faster, more efficient planning a core theme, ensuring renewable projects are prioritised. Across Europe, many countries have not yet fully implemented the Renewable Energy Directive III which sets rules to speed up approvals. The Irish Presidency should lead efforts to make sure all Member States apply these rules. This includes giving renewable projects “overriding public interest” status so they are prioritised, introducing clear timelines for decisions, and creating digital systems to make applications easier. Ireland’s Planning & Development Act 2024 and the introduction of Renewable Acceleration Areas (RAAs) under the National Planning Framework show how legislative progress has been made in Ireland. Grid Infrastructure Investment Strong electricity networks are essential for delivering renewable energy to homes and businesses. Grid constraints are now a critical bottleneck across Europe. The Presidency should champion investment in modern, resilient grid infrastructure that can handle high levels of wind and solar generation, reduce curtailment, and support cross-border interconnection. Future-proofing the grid also means enabling flexibility through technologies like energy storage and demand-side solutions, ensuring stability as the energy system becomes cleaner and more decentralised.

The Irish Presidency should focus on the continued implementation and delivery of Europe’s clean energy framework including implementation of the European Green Deal and Fit for 55 measures. We should also prioritise the European Grids Package and RED III reform to unlock renewable projects faster while keeping up ambition. It will be essential that the upcoming work on the Energy Security Framework revision and the post-2030 framework keeps the momentum for an accelerated energy transitin in Europe – essential to deliver on security, competitiveness and climate. The presidency is an unique opportunity for positioning Ireland as a hub for clean energy focusing on reforms that accelerate renewable deployment, strengthen energy security, and maintain competitiveness. Grid Infrastructure Development Even when projects are approved, they cannot deliver power without strong electricity networks. The Irish Presidency should push forward the European Grids Package, which aims to upgrade and expand Europe’s electricity networks and improve cross-border connections. This will make the system more resilient and reduce costs. In Ireland, our Price Review 6 regulatory framework is a good example of planning ahead for future grid needs which proposes €14.1 billion baseline funding package 2026–2030 period, potential to rise to €19 billion, marks an unprecedented level of investment in the grid. For context, PR5 involved approximately €4 billion in capital investment. Supporting Renewable Energy Auctions To keep investment flowing, renewable energy auctions need to be regular and predictable. These auctions decide which projects get support and at what price. Under the Net Zero Industry Act, new rules will introduce “non-price criteria” such as sustainability or supply chain requirements. These should be phased in gradually so they do not delay projects or make auctions unworkable. Auction design should also allow for innovative projects, such as those combining wind, solar, and storage on the same site. System Flexibility and Energy Storage As more wind and solar come online, Europe needs ways to balance supply and demand when the weather changes. This means investing in energy storage and flexible technologies. The Presidency should promote EU-wide plans for long-duration storage, clear targets for how much storage is needed, and contracts long enough to attract investment. Updating market rules so storage and demand-side solutions can compete fairly will help keep the grid stable and costs down. Statkraft has been leading the way on this in Ireland. We produced Ireland’s first four-hour battery storage facility which is co-located with a wind farm, demonstrating how innovative hybrid solutions can maximise grid flexibility and renewable integration. Our early DS3 battery projects at Kilathmoy and Kelwin were among the first to deliver grid-scale battery storage in Ireland, supporting system stability and enabling higher renewable penetration. Statkraft is also pioneering the integration of synchronous condensers and hybrid grid solutions, with four LCIS Phase 1 contracts currently under construction. These technologies help stabilise voltage and inertia on the system, ensuring that as renewables grow, the grid remains secure and resilient.

The Irish Presidency can make a real difference by focusing on actions that deliver tangible benefits for citizens and businesses while advancing Europe’s climate and energy goals. This means prioritising measures that lower costs, create jobs, and strengthen energy security. Lower Energy Costs and Greater Stability Accelerating renewable energy deployment and upgrading grid infrastructure will help reduce Europe’s reliance on imported fossil fuels, which have driven price volatility in recent years. We know that renewable energy is the cheapest form of energy in Europe which is why a more resilient, interconnected energy system will stabilise prices and protect households and businesses from future shocks. Economic Development and Job Creation Investing in clean energy infrastructure creates thousands of skilled jobs across Europe, from construction and engineering to operations and maintenance. Renewable energy projects, and grid upgrades can revitalise regional economies, particularly in coastal and rural areas, while supporting local supply chains. Ireland also has an opportunity to unlock further economic benefits by passing Private Wires Legislation as well as a framework for Large Energy Users. These measures would attract significant industrial investment, reduce energy costs for businesses, and create high-value jobs in manufacturing, technology, and services. By prioritising these policies during the Presidency, Ireland can showcase how clean energy supports competitiveness and regional growth while contributing to Europe’s climate goals Community Benefits and Public Engagement Statkraft and our partners alone have contributed over €3 million to over 500 community groups through the Community Benefit Fund. Promoting these models during the Presidency will strengthen public trust and demonstrate that the energy transition is not just about climate targets but about improving lives locally. Energy Security and Climate Leadership Reducing dependence on imported fossil fuels enhances Europe’s security and resilience. At the same time, faster delivery of renewables and flexibility solutions will keep the EU on track to meet its 2030 and 2050 climate targets, reinforcing Europe’s leadership in global climate action.

The Irish Presidency offers a unique opportunity to show citizens that EU membership delivers real benefits for people, communities, and businesses. Communication should be simple, transparent, and focused on outcomes that matter to everyday life. Highlight Ireland’s Role in Europe’s Future Position Ireland as a driver of positive change, leading on climate action, energy security, and competitiveness. Framing the Presidency as a chance for Ireland to shape Europe’s future will foster pride and engagement. Focus on Delivery People want to see progress, not just promises. Publishing clear, easy to understand updates on key achievements, such as faster planning approvals, new renewable projects, and grid upgrades, will demonstrate that EU action leads to real improvements. Visual tools like maps showing where projects are happening can make this relatable. Connect to Everyday Benefits Explain how EU policies translate into lower energy bills, cleaner air, and secure energy supply. Use practical examples: offshore wind powering homes, rooftop solar reducing school energy costs, and storage technologies keeping the lights on during peak demand. Engage Communities Directly Organise regional events, site visits, and town hall meetings where people can see renewable projects in action and ask questions. These activities create a sense of ownership and show that the Presidency is not just about Brussels, it’s about local impact. Statkraft place so much importance on Community Engagement and listening to genuine concerns. Statkraft and our partners alone have contributed over €3 million to over 500 community groups through the Community Benefit Fund. Our dedicated project websites ensure transparency and easy access to information, reinforcing our commitment to keeping communities informed and involved throughout every stage. By bringing communities into the conversation and making projects visible and accessible, Ireland’s Presidency can show that EU action is rooted in local realities.

If you would like to follow up in relation to our submission, please do not hesitate to contact [REDACTED UNDER GDPR]. We would be delighted to assist in any way to ensure Ireland has a successful term of the Presidency of the Council of the European Union.

respondent_type: National Office of Healthy Ireland Local Government- supporting implementation of Healthy Ireland Programmes across the 31 Local Authorities
geography: Local, Regional (Regional Assemblies), National and EU wide
response_text: Ireland’s upcoming Presidency of the Council of the European Union in 2026 provides a crucial opportunity to champion a forward-looking, resilience-focused, and community-centred policy agenda. As the level of government closest to people’s daily lives, local authorities—working through the Healthy Ireland framework—offer a unique vantage point on how EU policies translate into meaningful improvements in wellbeing, cohesion, and sustainability. In the context of accelerating climate impacts, rapidly evolving digital information environments, and heightened geopolitical uncertainty, it is essential that the Presidency Programme is grounded in approaches that strengthen trust, empower communities, and build the capacity of society to anticipate and withstand future challenges. The themes highlighted in this submission—societal resilience, sustainable and secure food and energy systems, connected and cohesive places, and a holistic One Health approach—represent areas where Ireland can provide leadership informed by practical experience across local government. By prioritising resilience and citizen empowerment, the Presidency can help shape an EU agenda that supports communities in navigating misinformation, safeguarding democratic participation, and enhancing preparedness for future shocks. Emphasising localised solutions to food and energy security will not only contribute to climate and biodiversity objectives but also bolster equitable social and economic resilience across Member States. A renewed European focus on place-based working can help counter polarisation, strengthen social connectedness, and ensure that the benefits of EU membership are felt in tangible, everyday ways across diverse communities. Through participatory approaches and meaningful community engagement, public institutions can build trust and improve the design and delivery of services. Embedding a One Health lens throughout the EU policy environment will further ensure that human health, environmental health, and animal wellbeing are considered collectively, supporting integrated solutions to complex modern challenges such as antimicrobial resistance, environmental degradation, and future pandemics. Ireland’s Presidency Programme should therefore emphasise policies and practices that create healthier, more resilient, and more cohesive communities. This includes championing collaboration across sectors and levels of government, encouraging innovation and sharing of best practice, and ensuring that EU ambitions translate effectively at local level. In doing so, Ireland can reinforce the EU’s core values of solidarity, inclusivity, and unity—values that are essential to navigating the years ahead. The Healthy Ireland Local Government National Office is willing to support the development and delivery of a Presidency Programme that places wellbeing, resilience, and community empowerment at its core. We welcome further engagement as priorities are refined and look forward to contributing to a Presidency that delivers practical, people-centred benefits across Ireland and the European Union

response_text: 1. respondent_type: National Office of Healthy Ireland Local Government- supporting implementation of Healthy Ireland Programmes across the 31 Local Authorities
geography: Local, Regional (Regional Assemblies), National and EU wide
response_text: Ireland’s Presidency offers a valuable opportunity to shape a Council agenda that strengthens resilience, wellbeing and cohesion across Europe. By emphasising community-centred approaches, local empowerment and the One Health framework, the Presidency can help ensure EU policy delivers visible benefits for people, businesses and communities. A central contribution will be advancing coordinated EU action on societal resilience. Strengthening information integrity, countering misinformation and supporting digital and health literacy will help protect democratic participation and improve crisis preparedness. For businesses, a more trusted information environment reduces operational risks and supports consumer confidence. The Presidency can also drive impact by promoting secure, sustainable and localised food and energy systems. Supporting shorter supply chains, community food initiatives and local energy cooperatives will increase affordability and reliability for households, while creating economic opportunities for SMEs, social enterprises and rural communities. These measures also enhance climate resilience and reduce dependence on volatile global markets. Ireland is well positioned to champion a renewed EU focus on place-based policy. Embedding participatory tools—such as the Place Standard Tool—into EU programmes can strengthen social cohesion, reduce polarisation and ensure initiatives reflect real community priorities. This also supports more predictable and supportive environments for local businesses. Promoting the One Health approach across Council work will align health, environment and agriculture policy, strengthening preparedness for future public health threats and safeguarding ecosystems essential to economic and social wellbeing. This integrated approach can also stimulate innovation in green, agri-tech and health sectors. Finally, Ireland can highlight the essential role of local authorities in implementing EU objectives. Ensuring coherence between EU policy and local delivery—particularly in climate adaptation, public health, resilience and social policy—will help guarantee that EU investments translate into tangible improvements in everyday life. Through these priorities, the Irish Presidency can help build communities that are more resilient and connected, businesses that are more secure and competitive, and citizens who are healthier, better informed and more engaged in Europe’s future.

respondent_type: National Office of Healthy Ireland Local Government- supporting implementation of Healthy Ireland Programmes across the 31 Local Authorities
geography: Local, Regional (Regional Assemblies), National and EU wide
response_text: Ireland’s Presidency of the Council of the European Union in 2026 provides an important opportunity to strengthen public understanding of the EU and to foster a deeper sense of connection, ownership and participation among citizens. Achieving this requires engagement that is rooted in local experience, delivered through trusted structures, and grounded in meaningful, two-way dialogue. Ireland is uniquely positioned to do this through its strong participatory infrastructure, particularly the Public Participation Networks (PPNs), which represent thousands of community and voluntary groups nationwide and provide one of the most inclusive civic engagement models in Europe. To achieve this, communication must move beyond national-level messaging and be rooted in the lived experience of communities—both communities of place and communities of interest—across the country. These networks, whether geographic or thematic, already serve as essential hubs of engagement, identity and local democracy, making them ideal platforms for grounding the Presidency in meaningful, accessible dialogue. Working with communities of place—villages, towns, neighbourhoods and cities—allows the Presidency to highlight how EU membership shapes local development, infrastructure, resilience and wellbeing. Locally hosted discussions and engagement events can make EU impacts more visible by showcasing familiar examples: active travel routes, biodiversity projects, energy cooperatives, digital hubs or community health and wellbeing initiatives. When people see how EU policies manifest in their everyday surroundings, the value of membership becomes tangible and relevant. Equally important are communities of interest—groups organised around shared experiences, identities or concerns such as youth organisations, migrant communities, environmental groups, older persons’ networks, farming communities, cultural groups or disability advocates. Engaging with these networks ensures that the Presidency reflects a wide diversity of lived realities and supports a fuller understanding of how EU policy intersects with different aspects of society. These groups are also powerful storytellers, able to articulate how EU programmes have supported innovation, inclusion, environmental stewardship and community resilience. Trusted local infrastructure such as libraries, community centres, schools, Family Resource Centres, cultural venues and digital community spaces can play a central role in sharing accessible information about the EU and promoting digital and information literacy. This supports informed civic participation and strengthens resilience against misinformation, reinforcing the wider objective of building trust in public institutions. Youth engagement should be prioritised through partnerships with schools, youth groups, student bodies and creative communities, ensuring younger generations have a visible role in Presidency activities. Similarly, outreach to marginalised and minority communities helps broaden participation and strengthens the sense that the Presidency, and EU membership more broadly, belongs to everyone. By embedding the Presidency within the everyday life of communities of place and communities of interest, Ireland can communicate the values and benefits of EU membership in ways that are relatable, authentic and inclusive. This approach strengthens democratic engagement, builds social cohesion, and fosters a shared sense of belonging to the European project—rooted in local identity, community wellbeing and collective resilience

respondent_type: National Office of Healthy Ireland Local Government- supporting implementation of Healthy Ireland Programmes across the 31 Local Authorities
geography: Local, Regional (Regional Assemblies), National and EU wide
response_text: Capacity Building at Local Level The success of Ireland’s Presidency of the Council of the EU in 2026 will ultimately be measured not only by high-level policy achievements but also by the tangible benefits delivered to citizens and communities across Europe. Local and regional authorities are central to this, as they are responsible for implementing a wide range of EU-funded and EU-aligned initiatives, including those relating to planning, public health, climate adaptation, community development, energy, and social cohesion. Ensuring that these authorities have the capacity, skills, and knowledge to translate EU priorities into meaningful local action is therefore critical. Capacity building at the local level involves enhancing both technical and strategic capabilities. Technical capability includes understanding the complex regulatory, funding, and reporting requirements associated with EU programmes, such as Horizon Europe, Interreg, the Cohesion Fund, and future frameworks for sustainable food systems and energy initiatives. Strategic capability involves aligning local priorities with EU opportunities, identifying synergies across sectors, and integrating European policy objectives into local planning, development, and service delivery. Strengthening these competencies enables local authorities to maximise the impact of EU investment and ensures that citizens experience real, visible benefits in their communities. The Presidency could highlight the importance of coordinated programmes that support local government in developing these capabilities. This might include tailored training, peer-to-peer learning networks across Member States, and the development of practical guidance or toolkits to assist in navigating EU processes. Facilitating access to best practice case studies—both from within Ireland and across Europe—can accelerate the adoption of innovative approaches, particularly in areas such as community-based climate adaptation, local energy initiatives, participatory planning, and health promotion. Investing in local capacity also enhances resilience and responsiveness. Authorities that understand EU frameworks are better equipped to anticipate emerging challenges, access funding rapidly, and design interventions that are evidence-informed, sustainable, and locally relevant. Furthermore, well-informed and capable local authorities can play a critical role in fostering citizen engagement, by translating complex EU policies into tangible, community-level projects, increasing awareness of the EU’s value, and promoting civic participation. By placing local government capacity building at the heart of its Presidency programme, Ireland can demonstrate that EU policy is not an abstract or distant set of rules but a practical tool for empowering communities, driving local innovation, and improving quality of life. This approach ensures that EU priorities are embedded effectively at the local level, that opportunities for funding and collaboration are fully realised, and that communities, businesses, and citizens across Ireland—and by extension across the EU—experience meaningful, measurable benefits from their membership.

geography: National with possible extension to EU wide.
response_text: Ireland’s forthcoming Presidency of the Council of the European Union in 2026 presents a strategic and timely opportunity to protect and advance the EU’s commitment to equality, human rights, and inclusive social and economic development. Sightsavers Ireland believes that in the current political climate the protection of international development and advancement of global social development, disability inclusion, and human rights has never been more crucial. In line with Ireland’s longstanding leadership in development cooperation, humanitarian action, and social inclusion, this submission strongly recommends that the Presidency of the Council include a focus on the overall protection of development cooperation as a high level thematic priority with a specific focus on disability inclusive development as a flagship priority theme. The upcoming Presidency offers a key moment to examine future funding and the long-term direction of development cooperation. Ireland should strive to keep attention on securing adequate resources for development efforts, emphasizing inclusive, rights-based, and sustainable financing that prioritizes people.

geography: National with possible extension to EU wide.
response_text: Broadly speaking, the main policy area we would advocate for a concerted focus on, is the ongoing MFF negotiations of which the Global Europe Instrument (the European Union's main financial tool for international cooperation) must be protected at all costs. In the upcoming MFF, the Global Europe Instrument should remain a primary focus, as it is likely to face pressure for cuts to accommodate other budget priorities. Ireland must ensure this issue is firmly on the Presidency’s agenda to ensure the safeguarding of the proposed budget. The Global Europe Instrument aims to uphold the EU's values and principles globally, aligning with the objectives of the EU's external action, but its funding needs to be guaranteed. Linked to this focus, as a disability rights organisation, Sightsavers Ireland is advocating for Disability Inclusive Development to be an additional priority for Ireland’s Presidency of the EU Council. The rationale which for selecting Disability Inclusive Development as a priority theme is as follows: Alignment with EU Values and Legal Commitments - The European Union and all its Member States—including Ireland—are State Parties to the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (UNCRPD). Integrating disability inclusion across EU external action, development policy, and humanitarian response is not only a moral imperative but a legal one. A Presidency priority centred on social development and reaching the furthest behind would reinforce the EU’s commitment to non-discrimination, accessibility, and leaving no one behind, as articulated in: The UN 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development The European Consensus on Development The EU’s 2021–2030 Strategy for the Rights of Persons with Disabilities Global Need and Opportunity - An estimated 16% of the world’s population lives with a disability, with disproportionate representation among those experiencing extreme poverty, conflict, and climate-related vulnerabilities. Despite global commitments, persons with disabilities still face systematic exclusion from education, health services, decent work, humanitarian assistance, and political participation. Ireland has a strong track record in promoting human rights, gender equality, inclusive education, and principled development action. Irish Aid has been recognised for building partnerships with grassroots organisations, advancing inclusive education, and championing the needs of marginalised groups. Ireland’s Presidency provides an opportunity to galvanise momentum for transformative, cross-sectoral implementation of disability-inclusive policies across EU institutions, Member States, and partner countries. By choosing to focus on disability inclusion as a Presidency priority, Ireland would build on this leadership and position the EU as a global standard-setter for disability inclusion in development and humanitarian policy.

geography: National with possible extension to EU wide.
response_text: Through the prioritisation of disability inclusion there would be a number of anticipated benefits for communities across the EU including: More effective and equitable development outcomes through inclusive policy design Strengthened global leadership from Ireland in this space and credibility for the EU in human rights and sustainable development Greater economic participation of persons with disabilities, contributing to poverty reduction and resilience Improved humanitarian effectiveness through inclusive preparedness and response Alignment with global best practice and the UN’s call for disability inclusion across all sectors Furthermore, disability inclusive development as a priority theme could make a substantial cross-sectoral impact in the following areas: Strengthened Policy Coherence - embed disability inclusion explicitly across EU external action instruments, including NDICI-Global Europe programming, humanitarian frameworks and climate finance policies Enhanced Accountability and Data, by promoting the systematic use of disability-disaggregated data and inclusive monitoring frameworks across EU-funded programmes Increased Meaningful Participation for Persons with Disabilities and ensure Organisations of Persons with Disabilities (OPDs/DPOs) are resourced and empowered to engage in EU policy processes, programming design, evaluation, and monitoring Improved Accessibility of EU Cooperation by setting high accessibility standards across EU embassies, delegations, events, information, and digital platforms Scaling Inclusive Education, Health, and Livelihoods using evidence-based approaches to inclusive education, universal health coverage, social protection, climate adaptation, and disability-inclusive humanitarian response A High-Level EU Declaration on disability inclusive development and financing for disability inclusive development Deliver a politically significant Presidency conclusion to guide and accelerate EU action through 2030

geography: National with possible extension to EU wide.
response_text: Communicating the values and benefits of EU membership requires more than sharing facts—it demands fostering a sense of belonging and shared responsibility. Global Citizenship Education (GCE) offers a powerful framework to achieve this by equipping citizens with the knowledge, skills, and values to engage critically and constructively with European and global issues. Through GCE, we can highlight how EU membership promotes peace, equality, inclusion, sustainability, and human rights—principles that resonate with everyday life. Interactive campaigns, school programs, community dialogues and public engagement can encourage citizens to see themselves not just as beneficiaries of EU policies but as active participants shaping Europe’s future. By linking EU initiatives to local priorities—such as climate action, economic competitiveness and social inclusion—we make the benefits tangible and relevant. For Ireland’s Presidency of the Council of the EU, GCE can create a sense of ownership by involving citizens in discussions, consultations, and cultural events that celebrate Ireland’s leadership role. Storytelling, participatory projects, and youth-led forums can amplify voices across society, reinforcing that the Presidency is not a distant political process but a shared national achievement. In doing so, GCE transforms EU engagement from abstract governance into lived citizenship.

geography: National with possible extension to EU wide.
response_text: Ireland’s upcoming EU presidency is a strategic moment to demonstrate its commitment to global solidarity and sustainable development. By showcasing our strong values on development cooperation—such as human rights, equality, and climate action—Ireland reinforces its credibility as a principled leader within the EU and internationally. This stance helps shape EU policies that prioritize poverty reduction, resilience, and inclusive growth, aligning with the UN Sustainable Development Goals. It also strengthens Ireland’s partnerships with low income countries, amplifies its voice on international development issues, and reflects national identity rooted in fairness and global responsibility. Furthermore, placing development cooperation and in parallel disability inclusive development at the heart of Ireland’s 2026 EU Presidency would catalyse meaningful and lasting progress across the EU’s external action and help ensure that persons with disabilities—too often left behind—are centred in the EU’s global agenda. Ireland given its current leadership in this space is uniquely positioned to lead this ambitious, transformative, and urgently needed initiative during the Presidency period in 2026

respondent_type: Writers’ Guild of Ireland Executive Director
response_text: In terms of thematic priorities, we believe that Ireland should focus on the importance of investing in and nurturing a sustainable and vibrant creative sector both in Ireland and across the EU. Though there is much more that can still be done, we do believe that as Ireland has a long history of supporting the Arts and artists, it is perfectly positioned to address the various challenges and threats faced by writers working in the industry today. We also believe that Ireland has a duty as Presidents of the Council, to protect the freedoms of writers and creatives to express themselves. There is much evidence to suggest that far-right political parties in power across the EU are engaging in the active censorship of writers, while in other cases, writers are self-censoring to protect their livelihoods. As presidents of the council, we would ask that Ireland be a powerful voice for protecting the right to free speech and expression across the EU.

respondent_type: Writers’ Guild of Ireland Executive Director
response_text: The Content / AVMS Levy: The review of the AVMS directive will take place during Ireland’s Presidency term. We believe that this must be a vital focus of work for the Irish Presidency. EU countries such as Germany, Spain, France, Italy, Portugal, and the Netherlands have already placed a content levy or investment obligation on streaming services. However, others, including Ireland have so far failed to do so. As Presidents of the council, Ireland can show leadership in highlighting the importance of the AVMS directive, and the levy, with an EU wide approach to protecting and promoting European content in an era of global streamers. Generative AI: Writers’ work is already being used to train LLM’s, which means that wholesale breaches of EU copyright Law occur every minute. It is imperative that the legal and moral rights of humans are prioritized over technology, and that if generative AI is to be adopted as a tool within the creative industries, authors must be in full control of how the technology is used. When it comes to using writers’ work to train LLM’s, only an opt-in system can ever be acceptable. There must be fair and proportionate remuneration for writers whose work (as explicitly agreed in a contract) will be used to train LLM’s. There must also be mechanisms to secure payment for writers whose work has been mined, and their copyright breached, without their consent. Issues have also arisen regarding the EU AI Act, especially around the exploitation of limitations and exceptions provided in the Copyright Directive. These exceptions were intended for educational purposes, and designed for libraries, archives and universities, but are now being exploited by tech companies with a view to accessing, exploiting, and mining authors’ work. Ireland must show strong leadership in not allowing these exceptions to be exploited in such a way across the EU. Collective Negotiation: For many years writers (and other authors) across the EU have faced difficulties in securing the right to collectively negotiate. The ability to collectively negotiate is a vital way to improve the rights and working conditions of writers, most of whom are classified as self-employed. EU legislation was brought in and then refined over several years to clarify the circumstances under which self-employed people could collectively negotiate without breaching competition authority rules. However, in Ireland, gaps in the law have been identified, meaning that writers, via their Guild, are still some way off being able to collectively negotiate without falling foul of competition authorities. We believe that Ireland can be used as a case study to highlight the EU wide imbalance between writers and, in most cases, producers. We urge Ireland, during their EU presidency, to show leadership to comprehensively address these imbalances. An EU Charter for Artists has also recently been announced - and as part of that charter, we need to ensure that, moving forward, artists across the EU are able to negotiate their rights and working conditions robustly but fairly.

respondent_type: Writers’ Guild of Ireland Executive Director
response_text: We believe that the Council must do all it can to support writers and artists in general. The value of art can often be downplayed, but the contribution that writers make to society must not be understated. Their work enriches lives. Their work generates income. Their work across film, TV, theatre, radio, and the games industry creates jobs. Though we exist in a global economy, we must fully embrace indigenous stories from all member states and see the value in stories from different cultures being told and shared. Ireland have already shown themselves to be not just EU leaders, but global leaders when it comes to valuing the Arts. We have an Artists’ tax exemption, and the ‘Basic income for Artists’ has gone from being a pilot scheme to a permanent fixture. Both these initiatives encourage and incentivise artists and writers to forge careers in the creative sector and are respected across the EU. This means Ireland has a huge opportunity during their Presidency to make the implementation of these schemes an EU wide priority.

respondent_type: Writers’ Guild of Ireland Executive Director
response_text: In terms of creating a sense of ownership over Ireland’s presidency, we would encourage regular engagement and consultation with industry stakeholders – including the WGI - on topics that are relevant to their industries. When it comes to forming policies, or communicating these policies to its citizens, these stakeholders’ expertise and skillsets will prove vital, and it’s important that creatives - and not just producers’ bodies - are part of the conversation. By engaging with these stakeholders, and using them as a resource, it will show that the EU is open to new ideas from outside of the usual decision-making groups and foster a sense of ownership among those who have been invited to contribute to these discussions.

respondent_type: Writers’ Guild of Ireland Executive Director
response_text: We thank you for taking the time to read the thoughts of the WGI and would welcome any follow-up questions you may have.

As Hydrogen Europe we consider security of Europe’s energy supply as one of the top issues for European leaders to work on, and as such, one of what should be the main thematic priorities for the Irish Presidency. Through the proposal from the European Commission on phasing out Russian natural gas imports, the European Union has made strides in reducing its reliance on Russian gas, but it remains exposed to external shocks. Furthermore, as Europe’s energy system is progressing on its path to resilience and decarbonisation by increasing the shares of renewable energy, challenges such as grid congestion and curtailment emerge. In our view, Irish Presidency should focus on strengthening the energy security by ensuring the integration and the overall resilience of the energy system. Clean hydrogen can play a significant role in reducing Europe’s vulnerability to geopolitical shocks and increased technical challenges by supporting the uptake of renewables and providing them with much needed flexibility and long-term storage capacities. At the same time, the translation of the EU’s 2040 climate targets into the existing regulatory framework will be critical to ensure policy coherence and investment certainty, in particular on clean energy and industrial decarbonization projects. The Irish Presidency should therefore aim to provide Member States’ input to the Commission’s work on the new framework for renewables after 2030 [provisionally scheduled to be unrolled towards the end of 2026] and ensure the regulatory coherence, clarity and predictability necessary for long-term investments that support the transition towards climate neutrality. In this respect, demand creation and lead markets for clean domestic products will be essential to unlock investments in key industries, ensuring early offtake, predictable prices and providing financial predictability. For instance, lead markets for steel can help sectors like the automotive or construction to integrate clean steel at minimal cost while providing substantial volumes for early deployment. The upcoming Industrial Accelerator Act (IAA) could be a key element contributing to market creation, boosting the European industrial competitiveness and reducing strategic dependencies by streamlining different instruments such as targets, quotas, and public procurement in relevant sectors. An agreement on the EU long-term budget and notably on the Competitiveness fund and its interplay with other instruments would be key to support the new European industrial policy and lead markets in clean products. It should be designed to provide access to public funding and number of de-risking instruments for technologies with capacity to contribute to Europe’s resilience and competitiveness.

As the first Member State of the upcoming Presidencies Trio, Ireland has the chance to set the scene and define longer-term priorities. Considering the European Commission Work Programme for 2026 and the EU Strategic Agenda for 2024-2029, several clusters stand out as particularly timely and strategic for the Irish Presidency: Flexibility and integration of energy systems. The Presidency should prioritise system integration to support cost effective and secure energy transition. The Grids Package is a key legislative file, with the Irish Presidency being in the position to potentially reach the General Approach and open the trialogues. It would provide the Presidency with an opportunity for strengthening Europe’s infrastructure backbone and tackling curtailment issues. The issue of finding the right toolbox to de-risks investments in networks will be essential as it will condition the progress towards and achievement of sector integration. Resilience of energy system. In the current geopolitical context, improving the EU’s preparedness and crisis response capabilities could likely be a shared Trio Presidencies priority, reinforced by the Commission proposals on energy security and strategic supply chains. The Irish Presidency should advance negotiations on the Energy Security file with a view to reaching a General Approach. In parallel, Council Conclusions on the European energy resilience would allow to look into various option of how to reduce dependencies. The future of mobility. The Irish Presidency will work on the light-duty vehicles CO2 standards, corporate fleets and the review of the Alternative Fuels Infrastructure Regulation. The objective could be to secure meaningful and achievable decarbonisation pathways and strategic corridors. Industrial policy for Europe and derisking investments in clean lead markets. The Irish Presidency will deal with key legislative files under the Clean Industrial Deal implementation, such as the Industrial Accelerator Act or the European Decarbonisation Bank, and it will lead on negotiations on the European Competitiveness Fund and the Multiannual Financial Framework. Future of Europe’s competitiveness. The Presidency will lead the work on Horizon Europe FP10 which is expected to prioritize clean technology innovation aiming to support the EU’s industrial resilience, strategic autonomy and technological leadership. This approach is aligned with the Commission Work Programme and the EU’s Strategic Agenda focused on strengthening innovation and strategic industries to boost the EU’s long-term competitiveness and resilience. Future of European energy post 2030 framework for RES. The Irish Presidency could play a key role in defining the future European energy framework for the post 2030 period ensuring that RES deployment is matched with the needed flexibility, infrastructure and market reforms.

Energy affordability and security remain top concerns for households and businesses. The Eurobarometer survey conducted in April-May 2024 revealed that energy prices are the most important aspect for EU citizens regarding energy. Further, a survey commissioned by the European Parliament and conducted in early 2025 confirmed that overall cost of living is the primary concern for EU citizens. Curtailment of renewable electricity—the forced reduction of renewable generation due to grid limitations—is a growing challenge across Europe contributing to increased grid fees and prices of electricity for individual and industrial customers. This has a direct impact on the cost of living. It is already costing European taxpayers and governments billions of euros annually, while reducing the decarbonization and resilience capacities of the renewables. Curtailment remains a considerable problem in the Republic of Ireland where dispatch-down of renewables reached 9.5% in 2023 and is expected to rise drastically as more wind and solar come online. Thus, the system as it is now, is more expensive for energy consumers than it should be, or than it needs to be. To reduce energy costs and make a substantial impact for people, businesses and communities across the EU, the Irish Presidency could champion storage and sector coupling solutions, including those provided by hydrogen electrolysers, to absorb excess renewable electricity and convert it into a valuable energy carrier. To unlock systemic savings and contribute to the reduction of cost of energy, the Irish government could work with the European Commission on the new EU Strategy on Flexibility.
Go raibh míle maith agaibh agus go n-éirí an t-ádh libh leis an Uachtaránacht Comhairle

Competitiveness & Innovation: Across all policy areas, advancing a European Union that can compete globally, and empowering European and Irish companies to do so. Relationships and trade links with other economies worldwide are essential in this regard, as is cutting unnecessary bureaucratic burdens and red tape on business. The Presidency should place a strong emphasis on proposals to improve the competitiveness of EU companies and SMEs, including though burden reduction measures. The work should be guided by the Dragi Report on the Future of European Competitiveness - A Competitive Strategy for Europe. Simplification of existing legislation via Omnibus proposals is a key part of this work. Completing the Single Market, especially in Services and Digital, guided by the 2024 Lette report “Much more than a market” is necessary. We should work towards ensuring a competitiveness check on all new EU legislation, with a specific SME test and a net reduction in reporting burdens. An emphasis on innovation and encouraging start-ups is need. Access to finance for start-ups, scale-ups and established enterprises need deeper more liquid capital markets. The Presidency should promote the free movement of capital in the EU for the benefit of citizens and businesses. The Savings and Investment Union proposal is key to achieving this objective. Competitive EU businesses can in term benefit from existing and new trade deals. The Presidency should work towards the delivery of a CAP budget that will ensure agricultural competitiveness and help that industry to thrive. To ensure that Europe remains competitive and secure, we need to advance innovation in AI, digital, bioeconomy, defence, sustainability, agriculture and provision of infrastructure can build the Europe and Ireland of the future. Security: In an increasingly fragile global context, advancing the security of Europe and Ireland is essential. Investing in capabilities for cyber defence, food security, security of critical infrastructure, combating disinformation as well as traditional defence capabilities will be essential to Europe and Ireland’s future. Ireland should prioritise a coherent European security and defence industrial policy, stronger protection of the Union’s external borders, and enhanced cooperation against organised crime and terrorism. Democracy & Values: We need to fully embrace the values of the European Union. As we see fragmentation in the EU, the EU becomes weaker economically and vulnerable to other markets. Strengthened Democracy ensures a strengthened union. We see many threats to free speech and the rule of law, this needs to be addressed. Misinformation and disinformation impact public debate and democracy negatively. During its Presidency the government should engage very actively in support of the Irish Commissioner, Michael McGrath, and his work developing and promoting the EU Democracy Shield.

Completion of the Multiannual Financial Framework: Ireland has a proud history in being tasked with negotiating and concluding the most complex of files. By concluding negotiations on the MFF 2028-2034 in good time to allow for implementation to advance smoothly would send a strong political signal as to Ireland’s capabilities, as well as ensuring certainty for our citizens. With the Danish Presidency setting an ambitious pace, Ireland should work with the Cypriot Presidency to encourage such a pace to continue and be absolutely adamant that it will do whatever it takes to conclude the MFF negotiations by the European Council in December 2026. Furthermore, this MFF should prioritise competitiveness, security, migration management, cohesion, agriculture and strategic infrastructure, ensuring that Europe shifts spending towards performance, results and conditionality on reforms, in line with responsible, centre-right budgetary discipline. The MFF should add value to member state. CAP: Negotiations will be nearing completion for the end of the Irish Presidency, it is important that we seek re-instatement of the CAP Budget and the delivery of a fair deal for farmers and for our regions. The Common Agriculture Policy is a major component of the MFF and reform of the CAP and the budget Allocated to it will be an important determinant of EU food production. Savings & Investment Union: Ireland should work to progress this union, free movement of capital is the key to unlocking money that is inactive for the benefit of all citizens. Today EU citizens save, but few invest and they lose out on making their money work for them. The Presidency should work hard to break down the barriers to the free movement of capital in the EU Single Market. These funds can allow us to support European start-ups in Europe rather than requiring US funding. The Savings and Investment Union will allow us to do more with our own money. Health – Critical Medicines Act & Biotech Act: Considering the importance of the pharmaceutical sector to the Irish economy, Ireland should seek to conclude as many health related files as possible to give certainty to pharmaceutical companies operating in that sphere. In addition, Ireland is very well aware that US based pharmaceutical companies are essential to the efforts to combat existing shortages of medicines and medicinal products. Therefore efforts to exclude US companies from European systems should be rebutted strongly by Ireland. In addition, Ireland should pursue a central objective of promoting an open but resilient health industrial base – including diversified supply chains, faster and more predictable regulatory approval, and strong incentives for R&D and clinical trials in Europe, especially in rare diseases and advanced therapies.
