We should also seek to focus on prevention within key therapeutic areas like HIV, diabetes, cardiovascular and brain health. Technology: The Presidency should seek to advance legislation that boosts European innovation, bringing Europe to the fore of competitiveness globally. Advancement of the proposed Chips Act 2.0 for example would send a strong message that Europe can act quickly when required and when needed to boost its global and economic position in the world. Security & supporting Ukraine: There is a war taking place on the European continent and while Ukraine is fighting its invasion by Russia in a very obvious and concrete way, hybrid warfare is being waged against all European countries and the EU as a whole. As such, Ireland must absolutely prioritise ongoing work and essential actions to continue to support Ukraine, as well as advancing work on promoting European security overall. Enlargement: For too long, the EU has delayed on enlargement plans, during the Presidency we should look to the accession of new member states such as Montenegro and Ukraine. Countries such as Montenegro, Ukraine and others have shown their dedication to becoming a member of the EU and worked closely with the EU to make this a reality. Ireland should use its Presidency to fast-track the EU accession process while safeguarding EU standards. We need clear public diplomacy communicating that enlargement strengthens European security.

Results: Within its remit in leading the Council during the Presidency and while acting as an honest broker, Ireland can best make a substantial positive for people, businesses and communities across the EU by quickly advancing legislation that will make Europe more competitive, secure and prosperous. Ireland should encourage the Council and Commission to communicate and measure EU policies in terms of real-world impact, for example, numbers of jobs created; hours of red tape saved; reductions in waiting times or improved security, rather than only focusing on legal jargon and related outputs. A Presidency that yields tangible results is what will make a difference for people and businesses. This is especially true for the MFF negotiations, as money from the EU budget goes to every corner of the union. A good deal on the MFF will provide certainty for the coming year for investment in research, innovation, cohesion, Erasmus, agriculture and rural development. Build Consensus: The EU is currently dealing with a number of issues in which there are differing views within its Member States – from enlargement to budgetary allocation to how best to build a sustainable future. At this time of global uncertainty, any division will be exploited by those who do not wish to see Europe succeed. Ireland can make a substantially positive impact by investing in quiet, behind-the-scenes, diplomacy and efforts to build a European consensus on difficult issues, thereby securing Europe in a different yet crucial way. Ensuring practical delivery: While adoption of critical legislation is important, how it is implemented is essential. The Irish Presidency should be uncompromising in holding the European Commission and other stakeholders to account in the delivery of the legislative and political promises that are made. The Irish Presidency should invite the European Commission to the different Working Party configurations to receive updates about implementation plans and actions, and absorption rates of EU funds, to promote and advance the importance of delivery of legislative commitments which will ultimately promote simple, stable rules and predictable timetables, especially for SMEs, farmers and our local authorities who bear the brunt of complex regulations.

What do people care about?: The EU is often intimidating to its own citizens because the decision-making process so complicated and difficult to understand, as well as not always being seen as relevant to the individual. All communication activities should take a “people first” approach – and should communicate outcomes as opposed to processes. While communications within the EU system is important (i.e. the technical outcome of a meeting), the high level communication should stick to core messages and key outcomes. Furthermore, communications should be truthful about both the limits and the achievements of EU action. By avoiding over-promising, speaking plainly and listening carefully, Ireland can demonstrate that a pro-European, centre-right politics is also a politics of integrity. In Ireland, bring the Presidency home: For the Irish people, the Presidency shouldn’t be just happening in Dublin or Brussels, but rather in every town and village, bringing the EU closer to the Regions. The Government should take an overall approach and all government Ministers, TDs, Senators and Councillors should have a responsibility for bringing the Presidency to their constituency. This could be done through town hall engagements, visits by Ministerial colleagues from across the EU to local companies or community groups and a social media strategy that engages with individuals and community groups. In addition, the Presidency should partner with local authorities, trade associations, farming organisations and other companies, showcasing how EU decisions support local jobs, infrastructure and services. Ireland is one of the older member states and there is strong awareness of the EU. The Presidency is an opportunity to re-energise the debate Europe - from the budget to security. The presidency should also be linked in with schools through inclusive competitions, school workshops or contribution forums to bring both the presidency and the European Union closer to our youth. The Blue Star Programme is highly effective in bringing the EU to the class rooms and the presidency can provide an added impetus to the Programme in 2026. Encouraging, supporting and funding wider and deeper relationships between Irish Universities, other Irish third level colleges and universities across Europe should be undertaken by the Department of Higher Education and Training. A module on the EU should be prepared by the Department of Education for all transition years students which could become a permanent feature of transition year. A promotional campaign should be undertaken to encourage every student to reach a reasonable level of competence in a European language Stories: Stories are what wins narratives. Ireland has a great story to tell in Europe, from being in the first group of enlargement countries, to benefitting from EU cohesion and Common Agricultural Funds to being the high tech economy we are today, boosted by European social directives and becoming a net contributor. Our citizens benefit from EU Membership every day – let’s share it with the rest of the European Union and beyond. Geopolitics is likely to dominate EU discussions in the coming years and bringing citizens into these hot topic debates should form a key platform for the Irish Presidency.

Ireland’s Presidency comes at a pivotal moment: the first full year of a new Commission and Parliament, negotiations on the next Multiannual Financial Framework (2028–2034), and early Council work on the newly proposed EU 2040 climate target. To keep Europe on a fair, sustainable and democratic path, Ireland should ground its agenda in environmental justice, social equity, intergenerational fairness and strong governance. Ireland should prioritise the following themes: A Fair, Just and Equitable Transition for All People and Regions Ireland should place fairness at the heart of its Presidency by ensuring climate, energy and industrial transitions reduce inequalities. The Presidency should champion: Stronger Social Climate Plans that protect low-income households as ETS2 begins; Integration of social safeguards across transition policies; Commitment to territorial cohesion so no region is left behind; Shared vision of a just transition connecting climate ambition with social protection, decent work, affordable energy and community resilience. This aligns with Ireland’s national focus on just transition and will resonate strongly across Member States. A Climate-Neutral, Nature-Positive and Resilient Europe Delivering the 2040 target will require a coherent, long-term policy framework. Ireland should prioritise: Steering early Council work on the 2040 climate target and preparing the framework for its implementation; Protecting the integrity and financing of the Nature Restoration Law; Strengthening climate adaptation and resilience, including through fairness-centred approaches to risk management; and • Embedding emissions reductions, energy security and biodiversity recovery across Council work. This positions Ireland as a leader in ensuring climate and nature commitments translate into real implementation once legislation is adopted. A Long-Term EU Budget (MFF) that Delivers for Climate, Nature, Social Equity and Democracy As the MFF will be the Presidency’s most consequential file, Ireland should promote a budget that: Safeguards climate and biodiversity ambition; Protects cohesion and strengthens regional participation; Embeds robust social-justice conditionalities; Upholds environmental governance, rule of law and the Do-No-Significant-Harm principle; Ensures meaningful civil-society participation in the new funding architecture. This frames the MFF as a tool for long-term public value rather than financial administration. Protecting Environmental Democracy and Civic Space Ireland should champion a Presidency priority on strengthening democracy, participation and rights. This includes defending NGO participation and funding, safeguarding access to information and justice, and resisting deregulatory pressures that weaken environmental protections. This is particularly timely given the implementation of the new EU Civil Society Strategy and the role of Commissioner McGrath. In addition, Ireland has committed to deliver better regulation (rather than deregulation) – this is a particularly important theme for the Presidency to champion. Embedding Intergenerational Fairness in EU Decision-Making Ireland can highlight long-term thinking as a core European value by promoting: Systematic long-term impact assessment across Council work; A strong mandate for the new EU Commissioner for Intergenerational Fairness; Dialogue with youth and civil society on the futures that EU policy choices shape. Strengthening North–South Environmental Cooperation on the Island of Ireland Ireland should promote a theme ensuring EU decisions support environmental cooperation, minimise regulatory divergence risks and protect citizens’ rights across the island.

EJNI recommends prioritising the following policy areas and legislative files: The Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) 2028–2034 The MFF will reach its decisive negotiation phase during Ireland’s Presidency. Ireland should focus on ensuring that the long-term EU budget: Raises climate and biodiversity ambition, including a credible climate–environment spending target and visible, ring-fenced biodiversity investment; Protects cohesion and territorial justice, ensuring National and Regional Partnership Plans (NRPPs) uphold multilevel governance and meaningful civil-society and regional participation; Embeds strong social conditionalities across programmes, ensuring workers, SMEs and lowincome households are protected as transition policies tighten; Safeguards civic space, including structural funding for civil society; and Upholds environmental governance, including robust application of the Do-No-Significant-Harm principle and strong monitoring rules. The Presidency must secure a Council position that aligns the MFF with the scale of Europe’s climate, biodiversity and social-equity challenges. Implementation of the EU 2040 Climate Target Following agreement of the 90% net-reduction target, the Commission will table multiple legislative and governance proposals in 2026. Ireland should prioritise early Council work on: ETS governance and rules on removals, ensuring the target accelerates real domestic decarbonisation and does not rely excessively on credits or sinks; LULUCF legislation, to protect nature-based removals while ensuring environmental integrity; Industrial decarbonisation measures under the Clean Industrial Deal; and Energy-system and energy-efficiency reforms required for a resilient, secure and decarbonised economy. The Presidency should aim to strengthen coherence across these files, emphasise fairness, and ensure the target becomes a driver of domestic transformation rather than an accounting exercise. PFAS Restriction under REACH A major legislative proposal to restrict PFAS (“forever chemicals”) will move into Council negotiations during the Irish Presidency. Ireland should aim to: Defend a strong, science-based restriction with no unjustified exemptions or delays; Promote a fair transition for affected workers and SMEs, including EU support for safer alternatives; and • Prioritise environmental justice, ensuring monitoring, remediation and transparency obligations protect communities affected by contamination. Nature Restoration Law Implementation Member States’ National Restoration Plans will enter scrutiny and discussion phases in 2026. Ireland should aim to: Protect the integrity of the NRL, resisting dilution through deregulation or weakened obligations; Ensure adequate financing, particularly within the MFF; and Promote strong enforcement and stakeholder participation across all ecosystems. Cohesion Policy, NRPPs and the Fair Transition Framework Ireland should focus on: Ensuring NRPPs uphold multilevel governance, participation, and territorial balance; Embedding fair transition safeguards across Cohesion Policy, SCPs and the Clean Industrial Deal; Mitigating household impacts from ETS2 through strengthened Social Climate Plans. Island of Ireland Environmental Cooperation The Presidency should ensure that legislative negotiations consider post-Brexit divergence risks and protect mechanisms for cross-border environmental cooperation.

The Irish Presidency has an opportunity to deliver lasting benefits for people, communities, businesses and the climate and environment that sustains them. The question of societal impact cannot be separated from environmental impact. Europe’s prosperity, health and competitiveness depend on a stable climate, thriving ecosystems and a fair and socially transition framework. A Presidency that strengthens social equity and environmental ambition will deliver benefits across all parts of society. Driving joined-up policymaking that connects social, economic and environmental objectives Europe’s major challenges (rising living costs, climate instability, nature loss, industrial restructuring and regional disparities) are all interconnected. The Irish Presidency can make the greatest impact by ensuring Council work is integrated, so climate, competitiveness, cohesion and social protections are treated as mutually reinforcing. This will improve policy coherence, reduce unintended burdens on households, and strengthen the resilience of communities and regions. Embedding Fairness as a Guiding Principle across Council Work Fairness is central to EJNI’s work and essential for public trust in transition policies. By ensuring that every major Council discussion considers distributional impacts on regions, low-income households, marginalised communities and small businesses, the Presidency can help prevent widening inequalities and reduce the risk of social pushback. A fairness-focused approach will deliver tangible benefits, including reduced energy poverty, more predictable and socially balanced transition pathways, and tailored support for vulnerable groups. It also helps maintain political stability and public consent for climate and environmental action. Ensuring environmental integrity and climate stability underpin economic opportunity Even when not explicitly referenced, the environment must be positioned as the foundation of prosperity. By consistently highlighting the economic and social dividends of clean air, restored nature, resilient infrastructure and reduced pollution, Ireland can shift Council discussions toward long-term value creation rather than short-term cost minimisation. This strengthens competitiveness by lowering long-term risks, creating clearer policy signals and reducing regulatory uncertainty for businesses, investors and local authorities. Strengthening democratic participation and civic space Effective policies require trust, legitimacy and public ownership. The Presidency can improve decisionmaking quality by: ensuring meaningful and inclusive participatory processes around major files; protecting civic space, independent expertise and access to information; promoting transparency in negotiations and implementation. These measures lead to better-designed policies that reflect real community needs and are easier to operationalise on the ground. Building long-term certainty through a future-generations perspective A Presidency that frames decisions around future wellbeing can help shift the Council beyond short-term political cycles. By elevating intergenerational fairness and long-term risks, Ireland can support EU investments that deliver durable benefits: safer infrastructure, stable energy systems, healthier environments and more resilient local economies. 6. Modelling cross-border cooperation and bridge-building Ireland’s experience with cross-border cooperation positions it to help bridge divides between Member States, regions and political groups. By convening informal Councils and expert dialogues, the Presidency can reduce polarisation around climate, nature and social policy, strengthen mutual understanding and build the foundations for stable EU legislation. Overall, EJNI believes that the Irish Presidency can make the most substantial positive impact by how it leads on the following: integrating climate, social and economic objectives; embedding fairness and environmental integrity; protecting democratic participation; • strengthening long-term thinking; and building consensus. This approach will deliver benefits for communities while protecting the climate and environment on which Europe’s future prosperity depends.

Ireland’s Presidency is a real chance to bring the EU closer to people’s everyday lives. For many, the EU may feel distant or abstract, yet its influence can be felt in very tangible ways. The more we can make these connections clear, human and relatable, the easier it becomes for people to see the EU as something they are part of and that can have a positive impact on their lives and communities. Here are some ways that EJNI believes Ireland can help create that sense of understanding and ownership Begin with the issues that directly shape people’s lives and communities Citizens engage most when they can clearly see how EU decisions affect matters of daily importance such as clean air and water, affordable and secure energy, accessible nature, social prosperity and equality, and resilient communities. Framing the Presidency’s work through these concrete and relatable outcomes, rather than exclusively through institutional or procedural language, can help demonstrate the EU’s value in practical terms and reinforce the relevance of EU membership to people’s wellbeing and overall environmental wellbeing. Create meaningful opportunities for public participation and be transparent about how these opportunities shape the Presidency A sense of ownership can emerge when communities feel that their voices are welcomed and taken seriously. The Presidency can support this by facilitating structured and meangingful engagement across the island, though, for example, dialogues with communities, civil society organisations, young people, farmers and marginalised and vulnerable groups. Ensuring that these perspectives inform and shape the Presidency’s narrative will help make the EU feel more accessible, more transparent, and more reflective of the diversity of experiences within Ireland. Highlight the EU’s tangible contributions to public welfare and environmental protection Many of the EU’s most significant achievements may not be widely known, despite their impact – from, for example, cleaner rivers and coastlines, to consumer, environmental and labour standards, to investment and funding in regional development and restored nature. Communicating these successes clearly and consistently can strengthen public understanding of how EU membership delivers tangible benefits for communities, businesses and the environment. Demonstrate how EU cooperation supports stability, solidarity and shared progress The island of Ireland provides a particularly powerful example of the benefits of cooperation. Showcasing how EU frameworks have enabled cross-border environmental protection, strengthened community links and supported economic and social development should help citizens and communities appreciate the broader value of collective action within the Union. This should reinforce the idea of the EU as a partnership that enables stability and opportunity. Ensure young people are active contributors Young people will inherit the outcomes of the decisions taken during the Irish Presidency. Therefore, their meaningful involvement such as through structured youth dialogues, advisory mechanisms, co-designed events or opportunities to influence Presidency priorities will demonstrate a commitment to intergenerational fairness and strengthens democratic legitimacy. It will also build long-term engagement with the EU among future generations. Use narrative and lived experience to make EU impacts visible While policy language is essential, real-world stories may convey impact more effectively for communities. Sharing examples such as communities benefiting from EU-funded projects, local ecosystems recovering due to EU legislation, or businesses supported through EU standards, should make the EU’s role more tangible and comprehensible and citizens. Communicate transparently about both progress and challenges Trust is strengthened when institutions are open about the complexity of policy choices and the trade-offs involved. A Presidency that presents both achievements and difficulties openly will help foster a more informed public debate and help build confidence amongst citizens in EU decision-making.

This submission is accompanied by EJNI’s Position Paper on Ireland’s 2026 Presidency of the Council of the European Union, which provides an analysis of the opportunities for Ireland to strengthen environmental justice, democratic participation and intergenerational fairness during its term. The following summary outlines the cross-cutting messages and additional considerations that underpin EJNI’s recommendations. First, the paper emphasises that Ireland’s Presidency takes place at an unusually consequential moment for the Union. The negotiation of the 2028–2034 Multiannual Financial Framework, the start of implementation of the EU’s new 2040 climate target, and the early stages of the EU Civil Society Strategy together present an alignment of files that will shape the trajectory of Europe’s social, economic and environmental transitions for at least a decade. The Presidency therefore carries a responsibility not only to manage negotiations efficiently, but also to ensure that these reforms strengthen rather than weaken democratic accountability, social fairness and environmental ambition. Second, the full document highlights that environmental justice must be a unifying lens. Many of the challenges facing communities such as rising living costs, energy insecurity, biodiversity loss, declining water quality, pollution, and uneven regional development are all interconnected. A Presidency that integrates climate, nature, cohesion, and social protection into a coherent approach will deliver more durable and equitable outcomes than one that treats these issues in isolation. EJNI argues that Ireland is well-placed to champion this integrated perspective, drawing on its national experience of social dialogue and cross-border cooperation. Third, the paper stresses the critical importance of safeguarding civic space and environmental democracy. At a time when civil society organisations across Europe report increasing pressure, reduced funding, and weakened participation pathways, the Presidency has an opportunity to ensure that participatory governance is protected and strengthened across key legislative files. Meaningful participation will improve policy quality and strengthen implementation and public trust. Fourth, the document underscores Ireland’s potential to promote intergenerational fairness as a guiding principle of EU decision-making. With the establishment of the EU Commissioner for Intergenerational Fairness, the Presidency can help embed long-term thinking across Council work, ensuring that fiscal, climate, agricultural and industrial decisions do not undermine the rights and wellbeing of future generations. Finally, the Position Paper highlights Ireland’s role in supporting environmental and cross-border cooperation on the island of Ireland. The Presidency provides a platform to reinforce the importance of regulatory stability, shared environmental monitoring, and coordinated responses to ecological and climate challenges that do not respect borders. Together, these themes reflect EJNI’s key message: Ireland’s Presidency can deliver lasting benefit for people, communities, businesses and future generations if it champions social justice and fairness, environmental integrity, democratic participation and long-term stewardship.

We would like to thank the Ireland for preparing so well for his Presidency time, as well as for having welcomed VinylPlus for an introductory meeting at its Permanent Representation offices in Brussels on 2 December 2025. We take this opportunity to submit some of the contents shared during this meeting through this Submission Form. As discussed on 2 December, VinylPlus believes the high-level thematic priorities to deliver a visionary and ambitious resources management strategy for the EU, in the EU should be: EU’s Competitiveness, the EU Single Market and circularity. The specific policies related to these three priorities are many and currently quite disconnected. We provide my information on how to bring them closer together in Question 2.

Market surveillance and trade defence: Accelerate processes and measures to implement trade defence instruments to address unfair competition threatening chloro-alkali and PVC sectors. One of the priorities for a prosperous and competitive Europe put forward in the European Council’s Strategic agenda 2024-2029 is to reduce harmful dependencies, and diversify and secure strategic supply chains. The chloro-alkali industry produces caustic soda, chlorine and hydrogen. These supply and enable essential consumer, professional and industrial needs and products such medical devices, pharmaceutical, hygiene, food protection, cleaning, water treatment, crop protection, paper and metal production, electronics, construction products, etc. (Cf. https://trees.eurochlor.org/wp- content/uploads/2021/04/chlorine-tree-v4-typo-legend.pdf and https://trees.eurochlor.org/wpcontent/uploads/2021/04/sodium-tree-v2-typo-legend.pdf). This is why these chemicals have been put forward as critical chemicals for the EU (similar to the critical raw materials for the energy and digital transition of Europe). Critical chemicals are key to the strategic autonomy and independence of Europe. Made of 50% chlorine, PVC consumes 30% of the European annual production of chlorine, supporting the economic viability and resilience of this critical industry. PVC is chemically interdependent with chloro-alkali. Because of the chemical properties of chlorine, production of chlorine and chlorine-containing products should be geographically co-located. This means that is the chloro-alkali or the PVC sector weaken or disappear, it is an entire pyramid of interrelated industries and products lost by the EU. By safeguarding the chloro-alkali and major chloro-alkali consuming industrial sectors, the EU avoids harmful dependencies on raw materials and finished products, and secures strategic supply chains. Industrial Accelerator Act, Circular Economy Act: Ensure waste becomes EU’s resource (urban mining) and this resource is managed through coherent product and waste legislation by addressing e.g., ecodesign and recycled content needs, harmonization of EPR and EoW requirements at EU level, obsolete waste classification system, excessive burden preventing efficient transport of wastes destined for recycling in the EU, etc. Europe needs an industrial strategy where decarbonisation goes hand in hand with retaining a competitive industry and cleantech (re-)industrialization. A strong industrial policy also needs controlled energy and compliance costs, as well as regulatory efficiency and certainty, including on possible future restriction needs. Practically speaking, for PVC specifically, this increased regulatory certainty can be improved by removing “PVC and PVC additives” from the REACH Restriction Roadmap. The conclusions of the ECHA’s Investigation Report (2023) and follow-up regulatory developments tackling remaining concerns related to microplastics, flame retardants, organotins and medium chain ortho-phthalates, demonstrate that the “PVC and PVC additives” entry should be removed from the Roadmap. The Roadmap needs to remain up to date to remain relevant; otherwise, it is just another of regulatory inefficiency causing uncertainty for investors. Reigniting market growth and demand for European products: In addition to the above key priorities, competitiveness, the single market and circularity can be delivered by accelerating the implementation of (revised and secondary legislation under) ecolabels, public procurement, housing and construction policies, water resilience strategy, etc. Ireland can help giving hard funding signals supporting immediate investment and demand for “Made in Europe”, low carbon, circular and affordable construction and infrastructure products, with PVC construction products ticking all such boxes.

Ensure Member States can deliver the EU ambitions, several of which fall under national competence (e.g., ecolabels, public procurement, housing, market and trade surveillance). The Single Market starts with an aligned Member State positioning and support, and the overall EU competitiveness can only be achieved if we act as a single and united region. Under its uniting phrase or slogan, Ireland can hopefully inspire Member States to support and implement a constructive “Made in Europe” vision.

Because it is led by the EU, 450 million Europeans can pool their waste into one regulated Single Market for secondary raw materials, creating a scale and certainty for circular investments that no Member State could achieve alone. Only EU-wide rules for ecolabels, public procurement, housing, construction and water resilience can guarantee that a product or technology proven in one Member State instantly gains access to the entire Single Market, turning national innovation into European demand. EU trade defence instruments combine the economic weight of all Member States, enabling Europe to confront unfair trade practices with a credibility and impact that individual countries, acting alone, simply do not have. In all these areas, only EU membership offers the full package of benefits: a legally integrated Single Market, common high standards, shared enforcement and solidarity funding, turning national efforts into a collectively stronger, more competitive European economy.

Ahead of Ireland’s upcoming Council Presidency, ITI urges Ireland to champion an ambitious agenda that supports technological innovation by strengthening Europe’s competitiveness, driving regulatory simplification, and preserving openness to global collaboration. The incoming Presidency will take office at a time of intensifying global competition, geopolitical uncertainty, and accelerating technological change. A fully functioning and integrated Single Market – supported by pro-innovation regulation and high rates of technology adoption – remains the essential foundation for Europe’s competitiveness, resilience, and long-term prosperity. While our detailed submission outlines specific recommendations across AI, data, cybersecurity, platforms, telecoms, sustainability, and standards, ITI recommends that the following three horizontal recommendations should guide Ireland’s approach to technology policy before and during its Presidency. First, ITI urges Ireland to continue the EU’s Competitiveness Agenda and ensure institutions consistently consider the impact of new and existing policies on Europe’s competitive conditions. Europe’s ability to compete globally depends on maintaining a policy and regulatory environment that enables innovation, investment, and technological leadership. Achieving the EU’s competitiveness goals and its Digital Decade targets will require not only simpler and more coherent rules but also solidifying the Single Market, making concerted efforts to attract and facilitate investments in new technologies like AI, ensuring access to affordable and reliable energy, and building the EU’s tech talent pool. Europe’s competitiveness will equally depend on boosting technology adoption – ensuring that businesses, institutions, and individuals across the EU can access and deploy cutting-edge digital tools. Second, ITI encourages Ireland to advance a robust simplification agenda, starting with the swift adoption of the Digital Omnibus Package and extending toward a more ambitious effort to streamline the EU digital rulebook. The EU's technology regulation has become increasingly dense, fragmented, and overlapping – spanning AI, cybersecurity, data, sustainability and sectoral rules. This complexity undermines legal certainty, slows commercial decision-making, and deters investment – which in turn has an impact on the EU’s competitiveness. The Digital Omnibus represents an important first step toward restoring clarity and predictability, and we urge Ireland to ensure its swift adoption – hopefully ahead of the start of the presidency. Beyond the Omnibus, greater ambition is needed for simplification of EU tech rules, particularly in relation to cybersecurity and data rules. ITI urges the Irish Presidency to support wider rationalization of overlapping legal obligations, including through the upcoming Digital Fitness Check, promote clearer and more consistent implementation across Member states, and strengthen coordination among enforcement authorities. Finally, ITI calls on Ireland to ensure that Europe’s pursuit of technological sovereignty remains rooted in openness, choice, and cooperation with trusted international partners. Sovereignty should be defined by functional capabilities that allow Europe to act independently when necessary – not by restrictive approaches that close markets or exclude trusted global technology providers. In areas such as AI, cloud, semiconductors, cybersecurity, and data, policies must avoid non-technical restrictions that fragment markets, limit access to cutting-edge solutions, or weaken resilience. Europe should instead adopt transparent, risk-based criteria that support collaboration with trusted global technology providers and ensure access to state-of-the-art technologies for European innovators and users.

Ireland should use its 2026 Presidency to champion a people-centred, community-focused EU that supports resilient rural and urban life and sustainable local economies. As the consultation document notes, the Presidency should articulate a “people-centred and future-oriented vision for the EU”. The Irish Presidency should prioritise three high-level themes: 1. A Social and Connected Europe Across the EU, rural communities face declining services, depopulation and the erosion of essential social infrastructure. Pubs, cafés and small hospitality venues play an outsized role in combating isolation and sustaining local life. Ireland can lead in shaping an EU agenda that values social infrastructure as critical to wellbeing, cohesion and democratic resilience. Ireland should promote EU-wide frameworks encouraging Member States to protect and invest in rural and community assets, drawing on UK, French, Spanish and German policies that recognise pubs and social venues as essential “third places”. 2. A Fair, Competitive and Diverse Rural Economy Ireland should place rural SMEs, including hospitality, food, tourism and cultural enterprises, at the centre of EU discussions on competitiveness. EU policy often focuses on large-scale industry; rural microbusinesses need proportionate regulation, targeted supports, and easier access to EU funding. Ireland should promote policies that encourage entrepreneurship, digital transformation and local job creation, recognising that hospitality remains a major employer, particularly for young people and those with limited mobility.

Ireland’s Presidency should focus on EU actions that strengthen communities, support SME competitiveness, and enhance rural resilience across the Union. 1. Rural Services, Social Infrastructure and Community Spaces Ireland should encourage Council work on the European Commission’s rural development and cohesion programmes, with an emphasis on protecting social infrastructure. Other countries have acted, the UK’s “Pride in Place” programme, France’s rural licensing reforms, Spain’s subsidies for village bars and Germany’s “third place” funding all recognise the need to preserve social meeting spaces. Ireland can champion EU policy that acknowledges community venues (pubs, cafés, cultural spaces) as contributors to social cohesion and wellbeing. 2. SME Competitiveness, Proportionate Regulation & Hospitality Sector Support Hospitality SMEs account for millions of jobs across Europe. The EU’s SME Relief Package and REFIT initiatives should be advanced to ensure regulation is proportionate for small operators. Key issues include: reducing administrative burden, supporting digital transition, ensuring fair access to labour and skills programmes, strengthening EU funding streams for hospitality as part of the tourism ecosystem. 3. Rural Mobility and Transport Reliable late-evening rural mobility remains a major barrier to participation in social, cultural and economic life. Ireland should lead discussions on EU support for rural mobility pilots, smart-taxi solutions and digital transport innovations. 4. Green Transition for SMEs Ireland should prioritise negotiations on energy-efficiency legislation affecting small businesses, ensuring EU programmes provide financial support rather than simply compliance obligations. A specific focus should be placed on small hospitality venues that require capital support to invest in retrofitting, refrigeration efficiency and renewable power. 5. European Year of Community Spaces (proposed initiative) Ireland could propose that the EU designate a future year as the European Year of Community Spaces, highlighting policies to preserve rural and urban social infrastructure. This aligns with Ireland’s strengths and the EU’s cohesion objectives.

Ireland’s Presidency can deliver meaningful benefits for people, businesses and communities by focusing on areas where EU policy touches daily life. Three approaches would yield significant positive impact: 1. Make EU policy more relevant to rural citizens Ireland can highlight the everyday challenges facing rural communities: declining services, loss of social spaces, restricted mobility and rising operating costs for small businesses. By advocating for EU measures that protect and revitalise rural social infrastructure, as seen in other Member States’ policies, Ireland can champion an EU agenda that is felt in towns and villages, not just capitals. 2. Prioritise SMEs and community-level enterprises Hospitality, retail, tourism and cultural SMEs are major local employers. Council work on competitiveness, tourism, cohesion and social policy should explicitly integrate the needs of small service-sector businesses. Strengthening access to EU funds, simplifying regulatory requirements, and promoting workforce development will directly help communities across Europe. 3. Promote an EU framework for mobility, connectivity and community wellbeing Ireland can use the Council Presidency to emphasise practical measures that improve quality of life: better rural mobility solutions, digital innovation accessible to small businesses, community-centred regeneration, green-transition supports that are realistic for small operators. These measures support the EU’s commitment to cohesion and balanced development, ensuring no community is left behind. Across all configurations, Ireland can reinforce that a strong Union depends not only on its cities and industries but on the resilience of its rural and regional communities.

To build ownership and trust, communication must be practical, local and people-centred. 1. Ground EU policy in real community examples Citizens rarely associate the EU with local improvements. Ireland should highlight how EU funding affects everyday life: town-centre renewal, rural broadband, community venues, skills programmes, supports for SMEs and hospitality businesses. Case studies - including pubs that have benefited from EU-supported regeneration or training programmes - can illustrate the EU’s relevance. 2. Engage civil society and local businesses Publicans, small hospitality businesses, cultural venues and local volunteers often have strong community networks. Ireland should leverage these networks through: local events during the Presidency, EU “roadshows” in towns and villages, partnerships with SMEs to promote stories of EU impact. 3. Make the Presidency accessible Efforts should be made to demystify EU processes. Interactive digital content, plain-language summaries and community-level discussions will help. Highlighting the Presidency as a national achievement, reflecting Ireland’s diplomatic role and commitment to European values, will build pride and ownership.

A key theme Ireland could champion throughout its Presidency is the importance of social infrastructure in maintaining strong, cohesive and resilient communities across the EU. Numerous countries, including France, Spain, Germany and Belgium, are now implementing policies to protect or revive local pubs, cafés and community spaces because they recognise the severe social impact of their decline. These international examples demonstrate a shift toward treating pubs and similar venues as community assets, not simply commercial entities. They play a vital role in tackling loneliness, sustaining rural economies, supporting tourism, and providing accessible employment. Ireland has the opportunity to bring this perspective into EU policy discussions during its Presidency. A European conversation on rural social infrastructure would be timely and impactful, aligning with the EU’s cohesion goals, rural development priorities and Green and Digital transitions. Ireland’s Presidency can help ensure that future EU policy recognises that vibrant communities require vibrant social spaces and that safeguarding these assets strengthens democracy and wellbeing throughout the Union.

Putting human rights, gender equality, sustainable development, cooperation and solidarity at the heart of the EU’s external action, rooted in the international human rights framework, the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development and the Paris Agreement. Safeguarding the development mandate within the new Global Europe Instrument and MFF and ensuring that external funds will support partner countries and local CSOs over EU competitiveness and economic interests will be critical. Regulation of corporations with respect to human rights and the environment. Ireland should use the presidency to urge the EU to restore ambition in sustainability and human rights protections; reject deregulation disguised as simplification; defend democratic decision-making and resist undue corporate influence; reaffirm EU leadership in the global movement for integral ecology and social justice. The experience of the Corporate Sustainability Due Diligence Directive and the Omnibus I legislation should be treated as a cautionary tale as it involved: a sophisticated influencing campaign by a small number of US multinationals and business associations that contradicted the preferences of most EU businesses; an opaque and undemocratic process that the EU Ombudsperson declared ‘maladministration’; common cause between centre right and extremist groups in the European Parliament, obliterating the cordon sanitaire. This undemocratic and captured policymaking process must not become a model for future deregulatory measures, or it will result in loss of public faith in EU democracy, the enhanced power of extremists, deepened injustice and unsustainability. Ireland must correct the narrative around “competitiveness” and “simplification” and ensure that business interests do not continue to be prioritised over essential protections for workers, communities and the environment. Defending the Green Deal from further deregulation and capture by private interests, in line with the wishes of the overwhelming majority of European citizens as outlined in opinion polling. Climate justice and equity: Another key priority for the Irish Presidency should be the climate policy framework; in particular the definition of the post-2030 climate and energy policy architecture to deliver on the 90% net EU 2040 climate target, ensuring this architecture is environmentally robust, socially just, and upholds the EU’s obligations to the principles of equity and CBDR-RC. In the context of recent COP outcomes that have failed to address the glaring gap on climate action and ambition, it is essential that Ireland prioritises the upholding of international obligations including the principles of equity and CBDR-RC, and obligations as clarified by the International Court of Justice Advisory Opinion July 2025, and ensure that the EU meaningfully commits to multilateralism to address the climate crisis with urgency and justice. Advancing Just Transitions to deliver on the COP30 outcome on Just Transition, including the elements related to building resilient food systems. Broader reforms of the international financial architecture will also be required. Championing the vital role of civil society – in particular Human Rights Defenders – in promoting democracy, protecting the environment and advancing human rights to the benefit of all, not narrow particularistic interests or profits.

Global Gateway: Global Gateway has seen minimal participation by European civil society in project design or implementation, and even less by social actors in the Global South. The potential for projects to contribute to closing civic space, human rights and environmental abuses, increased debts and for prioritising private interests over human needs mean that a root-and-branch review of the strategy is required. Ireland should facilitate this process, which should involve civil society in Europe and project countries in decision-making. The EU-Israel Association Agreement: The EU must suspend the EU-Israel Association Agreement, as well as ensuring appropriate accountability measures to be taken in light of the genocide, war crimes and human rights violations committed by Israel in the occupied Palestinian territory. Furthermore, in line with the advisory opinion of the International Court of Justice of July 2024, a European trade ban is necessary to bring EU policy back into compliance with international law. Global Europe Instrument: The Global Europe Instrument should safeguard an ambitious budget. It is imperative that grant based funding is prioritised and aid conditionality is rejected, along with the rejection of provisions that would allow the ODA target to be adjusted during the course of the budget cycle. A clear and explicit reference to poverty reduction should be included, along with minimum funding levels for strategic investments, including humanitarian assistance. International legally binding instrument to regulate, in international human rights law, the activities of transnational corporations and other business enterprises: The EU should positively engage with the process to create a legally binding instrument at the UN and to adopt a position based on the primacy and protection of human rights and the environment. Ireland should model this approach by adopting its own public position as outlined in this briefing by the Irish Coalition for Business and Human Rights. EU Climate Policy Architecture post-2030: Considering recent developments on the EU’s 2040 target are still below the EU’s fair share of climate action, key priorities should include the review of the EU Emissions Trading Scheme 1, the post-2030 Effort Sharing Regulation, and the establishment of high-quality criteria for problematic international credits which could weaken EU climate ambition. Climate resilient food systems: Key priorities should include the UN Committee on World Food Security's process on Building Resilient Food Systems which will unfold throughout 2026. A further priority should be the development of an EU climate action, agriculture and food security position which recognises the imperative of addressing the agriculture climate finance gap and supports accessible grant-based actions for transformative agriculture and food systems, and which includes a formal decision to continue work on climate action on agriculture and food security post the Sharm el-Sheikh joint work programme, due to culminate at COP31. Civil Society Space: Establish a clear implementation plan for the EU’s Civil Society Strategy in collaboration with civil society. Via the EU’s External Actions, ramp up support for autonomous civil society via public funding and provide financial and technical supports to EU delegations to safeguard their important role.

The EU Presidency is an opportunity to emphasise the importance of protecting human rights and those who defend them, including by ensuring the principles of human rights and freedoms form the basis of agenda setting, prioritisation and decision-making within the Council. Additionally, make clear commitments to democracy and demonstrate this commitment by prioritising issues that enjoy significant public support, including climate and environmental justice and holding corporations to account for abuses. Ireland should also seize the opportunity to highlight the importance of the principle of public funding for autonomous civil society, and to counter mis and dis information regarding civil society in Europe. At a time of EU member states looking increasingly inward, closing space for civil society, and increased fragmentation of society within Europe, we must strongly champion the critical role of civil society and support efforts to foster global solidarity. Ireland can also work to ensure that transparency measures are applied equally to all actors, including the for-profit sector, using a risk-based approach. Finally, Ireland can and should make clear that advocacy is a legitimate and indeed essential component of civil society and a valid use of funds. While delaying climate action will imply dramatic costs for society and the economy across the EU and within EU Member States, and this has been highlighted by the European Climate Risk Assessment, acting promptly and decisively will bring a wide range of benefits: following a more ambitious pathway, the EU could gain at least €1 trillion by 2030. Furthermore, this action is supported by society, the latest EU barometer confirmed that European citizens regard climate action as a key priority. During the Irish Presidency, the European Commission is expected to put forward the legislative proposals shaping the post-2030 climate and energy policy architecture. The Irish Presidency’s role will thus be key to make sure this work stream is prioritised by the Council and to make sure that these discussions include human rights, environmental integrity and just transition at the core of the policy framework. Science-based, equitable and socially just EU climate policy is essential to ensure societal wellbeing and a sustainable economy on a healthy planet, both in the EU and in the rest of the world. The Irish Presidency can play a decisive role by ensuring that Council discussions prioritise workers and communities affected by corporate harm, and those most vulnerable to climate breakdown and environmental degradation. A rights-centred Council agenda will help ensure that EU law offers protection for individuals negatively impacted by the activities of corporate actors.

European democracy is facing a critical juncture. Data from the CIVCUS Monitor’s Global Findings found “a worsening environment” for civil society in the EU, with three prominent member states – France, Germany and Italy – all being downgraded from ‘narrowed’ to ‘obstructed’ civic space. According to the 2025 ITUC Global Rights Index, Europe has experienced the biggest decline in respect for fundamental rights and freedoms seen in any region in the past ten years. This situation is partly explained by the increasingly remote manner of governing, growing capture of decision-making processes by large corporations (at both EU and member state level, as highlighted by Irish media) and, in turn, a generalised failure to prioritise policy areas that enjoy significant public support, such as decisive climate action, or strong legislation to hold corporations to account. Civil society plays a vital role in safeguarding the public good. Unlike private actors that are mandated to maximise the particularistic interests of their shareholders, civil society represents the collective interests of citizens, advocating for human rights, social justice, environmental protection, and fair labour standards. As one of the EU member states that has protected an open civil society space, Ireland can and should use the presidency to democratise the presidency, both in terms of procedures - through enhanced dialogue with citizens and civil society, platforming those that defend human rights and the planet, sharing information publicly and trialling deliberative decision-making processes - and substance – by adopting a focus on policy action that reflects their desires and meets the true socio-economic and planetary challenges we face.

Ireland should champion policies that strengthen Europe’s global competitiveness in an era of rapid technological change. This requires two complementary priorities: deepening the Single Market as an enabler of innovation and growth, and boosting the EU tech ecosystem. Deepening the Single Market as an enabler of innovation and growth First, Ireland should prioritise the implementation of the EU’s 2025 Single Market strategy, including by proposing legislation that harmonizes rules for urban transport services. The Single Market remains the EU’s greatest asset. However, today, there is no Single Market for key sectors—such as ride-hailing, which is fragmented by national regulations and outdated taxi laws. While the EU has regulated platforms on labour and taxation, it has failed to create a functioning market for urban mobility services. Despite the Commission’s 2022 guidance, which recognises that challenges faced by the Private Hire Vehicles sector in the EU, such as the return-to-garage rules and mandatory waiting times. In 2023, the European Court of Justice also reaffirmed that national restrictions must be justified by overriding public interests and cannot amount to unjustified barriers to market access. Despite the guidance and the ECJ ruling, no legislative action has followed. Today, ride-hailing remains banned or severely restricted in nine Member States. This creates barriers that limit supply, raise costs, and stifle innovation. Removing these obstacles and enabling market-based pricing will expand supply, lower prices, and spur innovation—just as EU liberalisation did for aviation and rail. This is not just about ride-hailing, it is the foundation for Europe’s future mobility. Autonomous Vehicles (AVs) will scale first through ride-hailing platforms, but Europe cannot build a Single Market for AVs without fixing ride-hailing. A harmonized framework will accelerate AV deployment, reduce emissions, and make urban transport more efficient—supporting President von der Leyen’s ambition to make self-driving mobility a European success story. Harmonization is therefore critical for both today’s shared mobility and tomorrow’s autonomous transport ecosystem. Boosting the EU tech ecosystem Second, Ireland could help boost the EU tech ecosystem by advocating for a dedicated EU funding framework that supports the scale-up and commercial deployment of European tech champions—particularly in autonomous vehicles (AVs) and deep tech. Europe produces world-class innovators, yet they lack late-stage capital, raising ten times less than the U.S. and China. This funding gap leaves European companies vulnerable to acquisition or being outcompeted. Strategic EU investment is essential to turn promising startups into global leaders. AVs illustrate this urgency: the global AV market is projected to reach €400 billion by 2035, and ride-hailing will be the first major application. However, Europe still lacks a dedicated funding stream for deployment. EU support must move beyond fragmented research and pilots, focusing instead on de-risking high upfront costs and backing companies ready to scale commercially.

In line with the response provided to the first question, Ireland should prioritise delivering on the EU Single Market Strategy (2025) and the 2030 Consumer Agenda, ensuring these strategies translate into tangible outcomes. A key focus should be the creation of a Single Market for ride-hailing services, which remains fragmented. The 2025 Single Market Strategy envisages applying EU rules and principles to the taxi and private hire vehicle sector. The European Court of Justice’s 2023 ruling confirmed that national restrictions must be justified by overriding public interests and cannot amount to unjustified barriers to market access. Yet, no legislative action has followed, and ride-hailing remains banned or severely restricted in nine Member States. This regulatory fragmentation undermines mobility innovation and Europe’s competitiveness. The need to apply Single Market principles to taxi and private hire vehicle sector was also reiterated in the 2030 Consumer Agenda. Ireland should encourage the Commission to advance a legislative initiative aimed at harmonizing rules for urban transport services, fostering regulatory consistency, reducing unnecessary barriers, and supporting fair, market-driven pricing. This will unlock supply, lower costs, and accelerate innovation—critical for scaling autonomous vehicles (AVs), which will first deploy through ride-hailing. Without fixing ride-hailing, Europe cannot build a Single Market for AVs, jeopardizing President von der Leyen’s ambition of making self-driving mobility a European success story. Beyond mobility, Ireland should focus on: ο Simplification Package & Digital Fitness Check: ensure smooth adoption of the Digital Omnibus proposals and support the Digital Fitness Check the Commission plans to conduct in 2026. ο 28th Regime: advance discussions on optional harmonized frameworks to support cross-border business models. Having a dedicated regime for company law, taxation and insolvency can help create new EU companies. We are interested in what the 28th regime could mean EU scaleups - such as Bolt - who have reached a certain size. We need measures that help companies reach all 450 million European consumers. ο Corporate Fleets Proposal: the shift to zero-emission vehicles remains a major hurdle for professional drivers who face barriers such as limited urban charging infrastructure, high energy costs, and substantial upfront investment. Because these obstacles vary widely across EU Member States, imposing uniform electrification mandates on corporate fleets without considering these disparities could hinder progress and penalize certain actors, especially ride-hailing fleets with unique operational needs. To ensure shared mobility drives the green transition, Ireland should advance EU policies that focus on tailored incentives, infrastructure development, and realistic timelines rather than one-size-fits-all mandates.

The Irish Presidency has an opportunity to make a lasting impact by listening, engaging, and delivering policies that reflect the needs of citizens, businesses, and communities across Europe, actively considering stakeholder perspectives while taking decisive action to strengthen the Single Market and position Europe as a global leader in innovation and mobility. Bolt stands ready to support the Irish Presidency as a constructive partner, offering insights and collaboration to help ensure that the Council’s work translates into practical, forward-looking solutions for Europe.
N/A
N/A

organisation: University College Dublin  and the European Financial Planning Association (However, I am making my submission in a personal capacity.)
sector: Finance academic and professional engagement with European financial advisers
response_text: I welcome the opportunity to respond to this consultation. I am framing my reply in terms of being a finance professor , an educationalist, and through my professional association with European financial adviser networks. My comments can be contextualised by reference to advancing the implementation of the recommendations of the EU Draghi report on ‘The Future of European Competitiveness- A Competitiveness Strategy for Europe’, published in 2024. Progress could be a lot faster on its implementation, in particular given the current international geopolitical environment. The Draghi Report key recommendations focus on closing the innovation and productivity gaps with other global competitors by simplifying the regulatory burden, unlocking private capital through a deeper capital markets union and savings and investment union, and aligning the green agenda and digitalisation with competitiveness and innovation and simplifying the extant rules in relation to securitisation. These recommendations are mutually interdependent and complementary. For instance, as a practical example, deeper and more integrated capital markets could act as an effective financing mechanism for green and sustainable initiatives (with a greater number of these initiatives unlocked through simplifying the ‘technical taxonomies’ associated with the Climate and Environmental Delegated Acts). My concern is though there are initiatives taking place associated with these themes the pace of implementation is too slow and should be rapidly accelerated. As Ireland does not take its role up until mid-2026 there may be a pressing need to be very proactive if there are delays in implementation in the first half of 2026.

organisation: University College Dublin  and the European Financial Planning Association (However, I am making my submission in a personal capacity.)
sector: Finance academic and professional engagement with European financial advisers
response_text: Though many initiatives are in train in relation to the implementation of the Draghi Report progress is sub-optimal, and, if the impetus stalls in the first half of 2026 I would emphasise pushing hard in accelerating the momentum on: Simplifying regulations in the Single Market, focusing on those that hinder speedy and flexibility thus strengthening the innovation and growth agenda. Deepen Capital Markets Union (CMU) by reducing the barriers to integrating European capital markets: This is critical, inter alia, for scale and breadth in venture capital funds Lead in creating a Savings and Investments Union (SIU), making capital markets more accessible to channel private sector investment (institutional and retail) in key areas like digital and green initiatives, whilst simultaneously expanding the range and depth of European portfolio pension fund investment opportunities. This will require better supervisory convergence in relation to MiFID 2, MiFIR, EMIR and the Markets in Crypto-Assets Regulation (MiCA). (These are some of the items on the agenda of ESMA but they need to move faster). Relatedly, from an educational perspective momentum needs to be sustained in terms of the EU’s new strategy on financial literacy focusing on co-ordination and sharing best practices across Member States. Boost digitalization, including digital sovereignty by addressing the lack of digitalization as a primary reason for lower productivity compared to other global blocs. This would include accelerating, inter alia, the proposed and anticipated Cloud and AI Development Act, the Quantum Act, and the Innovation Act. These will provide support of capital markets and VC and private equity funding for emerging and innovative technologies. From an educational perspective, parallel comments to my comments on financial literacy can be made in terms of the implementation of the Digital Literacy Action Plan (DEAP) which is currently forecast to fall short of its target of having 80% of adults with basic digital skills by 2030. In relation to venture capital, momentum needs to be sustained in the enactment of changes to the European Venture Capital Funds Regulation to make to easier for venture capital funds to invest on a pan-European basis. Align the green transition with competitiveness by simplifying the climate change and environmental taxonomies, hence expanding the range and depth of investment opportunities associated with the green transition, as some sectors (such as agriculture) and firms (based on size) are currently not formally in scope. There are current EU consultations on these technical taxonomies, but effective speedy implementation actions need to take place.

organisation: University College Dublin  and the European Financial Planning Association (However, I am making my submission in a personal capacity.)
sector: Finance academic and professional engagement with European financial advisers
response_text: By making rapid progress on the CMU, Savings and Investment Union and Banking Union agendas this will go a long way towards implementation of the recommendations of the Draghi Report, and consequently enhance the economic growth potential of the EU at a critical time in geopolitical terms.

organisation: University College Dublin  and the European Financial Planning Association (However, I am making my submission in a personal capacity.)
sector: Finance academic and professional engagement with European financial advisers
response_text: From a geopolitical perspective, Ireland, given its unique cultural and economic ties with the United States, where more than 30 million people are of Irish descent, can play a key role in its Presidency of the Council of the European Union, as a bridge between the European Union and the United States during a pivotal time for global cooperation.

sector: Unite the union organizes workers across the economy, in private and public sector employments
response_text: Unite argues that the three priority themes for the Irish presidency should be: Quality Jobs Unite notes that the Quality Jobs Roadmap announced on 4 December prioritises the following issues: Algorithmic management and artificial intelligence (AI) at work; Health and safety at work, including psychosocial risks; Regulation of subcontracting; A just transition, anticipation and management of change; Labour inspection and enforcement; These are all priority issues for Irish and European workers, and progressive EU legislation in the form of a Quality Jobs Act would not only protect working conditions but also prevent ‘social dumping’ where companies seek to escape stringent regulation in one EU jurisdiction by moving their operations to another EU jurisdiction with inferior protections. Unite also welcomes the explicit endorsement of workers’ right to bargain collectively throughout the Roadmap, in particular this statement: “Collective bargaining, when promoted through social conditionalities in public funding, allows workers to benefit from the support provided to industry”. We note that the Roadmap also states that, as part of the 2026 revision of public procurement directives, the Commission will: “explore how to better promote socially responsible public procurement, including the wider use of the Best Price Quality Ratio and of collective bargaining”. Unite represents construction workers throughout Ireland and we regularly encounter employers in receipt of significant public contracts who disregard workers’ rights and engage in anti-union activity. It is Unite’s view that a successful Irish presidency must lead by example. In order to effectively promote the Quality Jobs Roadmap and Act, with its welcome focus on collective bargaining, the Irish government must fully transpose the EU Directive on Adequate Minimum Wages by enacting legislation providing for the right of workers to bargain collectively through the trade union of their choice. Just Transition and Climate Change Europe is a major contributor to global warming and is also the fastest-warming continent Workers are paying the price for climate change not only in terms of necessary decarbonisation and its impacts on employment and living costs, but also resulting from the increasing incidence and severity of heatwaves, storms, floods and other extreme weather events. Ireland supports the call by the European Trade Union Confederation for a European Just Transition Directive. We also urge the Irish presidency to push for a review of relevant Occupational Safety and Health Directives to ensure that workers’ health, safety and incomes are protected during and after extreme weather events, and for a new Directive on preventing occupational heat risks. Unite’s proposals are available here. EU Anti-Poverty Strategy Unite urges the Irish presidency to drive forward the EU Anti-Poverty Strategy, which cleared its first European Parliament vote in December. In addition to measures to end in-work poverty by ensuring wage increases, higher statutory minimum wages and stronger collective bargaining, the Strategy should include an EU Minimum Income Directive, a Child Guarantee for children most in need, a ban on no-fault evictions, action to end child homelessness and investment in affordable childcare and early education. [500 words]

sector: Unite the union organizes workers across the economy, in private and public sector employments
response_text: Supplementing our response to Question 1 above, we would urge the Irish presidency to focus on: Public procurement In the event that the revised Public Procurement Directive has not been finalized during the Cypriot presidency, this should be progressed by the Irish Presidency as a matter of urgency. The new Directive should: Ensure that public money goes to companies that respect workers’ rights, negotiate with trade unions and are covered by collective agreements; Eliminate ‘price-only’ contract awards; Ensure supply chain accountability and limit sub-contracting chains; Ensure that in-house provision of public services is not undermined. Housing in line with Principle 19 (housing and assistance for the homeless) of the European pillar of social rights, and with the cohesion policy objectives 2021-2027, the EU Affordable Housing Plan due to be announced at the end of 2025 must be progressed by the Irish presidency with a focus on increasing social and not-for-profit housing while safeguarding the terms and conditions of the workers delivering the housing. Gender Equality The Irish presidency should progress the 2026-2030 Gender Equality Strategy due to be announced in early 2026 with particular regard to action on gender-based violence and ensuring full access to reproductive healthcare throughout the EU. [Continues on next page] (4) Vindicating migrant workers’ rights Migrant workers in Ireland, as well as Irish nationals of minority ethnicities, are exposed to increased hostility and racism as a consequence of longstanding national policy failures in a range of areas, from housing to healthcare. By improving the rights, working and living conditions of all those working in the EU, regardless of origin, EU policy can help push-back against those attempting to stoke division. EU policy in respect of labour migration must promote decent work, equal treatment and inclusion. It must also protect migrant workers from exploitation and abuse. Unite notes that repressive immigration policies may drive precarious work, irregular forms of employment and exploitation. In this regard Unite would urge the Irish presidency to push for a Directive on subcontracting and labour intermediaries. We would also urge that the mandate of the European Labour Authority be extended to include seasonal workers and violations of the EU Anti-Trafficking Directive. [413 words]

sector: Unite the union organizes workers across the economy, in private and public sector employments
response_text: It is Unite’s view that strengthening workers’ rights across the EU – including ensuring that all workers in the EU have the right to bargain collectively with their employer – would not only have a positive impact on workers and their communities, but would also be of benefit to businesses. Robust collective bargaining provisions together with workplace democracy and worker participation, are key to an innovative productive economy, whether at national or EU level, and can help insulate European economies from external shocks – a point reinforced by the Council Recommendation of 12 June 2023 on strengthening social dialogue in the European Union, which noted that economies with wide collective bargaining coverage are more resilient and competitive. The right to bargain collectively is a central tenet of the European Union, enshrined in Article 28 of the EU Charter of Fundamental rights. We note that the benefits of collective bargaining are explicitly recognized in the texts of a number of Directives, most recently the Directive on Adequate Minimum Wages and the Pay Transparency Directive, and that the EU’s commitment to workers’ right, the role of trade unions and collective bargaining was restated in the 2024 La Hulpe Declaration, notwithstanding the Irish government’s regrettable statement restating the ‘voluntarist’ nature of the Irish industrial relations system. [210 words]

sector: Unite the union organizes workers across the economy, in private and public sector employments
response_text: A Eurobarometer survey in June 2024 found that 88 per cent consider a ‘Social Europe’ to be important to them personally, while 60 per cent were aware of at least one EU initiative to improve working and living conditions, including: the Directive on Adequate Minimum Wages, the Work Life Balance Directive and the European Social Fund Plus. Strengthening the European Pillar of Social Rights with particular regard to Chapter II on Fair Working Conditions and in particular Principle 8 on social dialogue an involvement of workers, and driving other measures which improve the working and living conditions of all those living in the EU, would help underline the benefits of EU membership to workers. By focusing on policy elements which reinforce a ‘Social Europe, in addition to progressing policies to help alleviate the crisis facing workers in Europe, including the cost-of-living and housing crises, the Irish Presidency can help ensure that working people feel their concerns are reflected and addressed by EU policymakers. [163 words]

sector: Unite the union organizes workers across the economy, in private and public sector employments
response_text: Unite would urge the Irish Presidency to argue against, and not promote, any proposed legislation which could undermine the working and living conditions of people in Europe, in particular deregulation measures such as the so-called 28th Regime which could undermine workers’ rights and, thus, reduce public support for the EU in general and the Irish presidency in particular.

sector: Vigilance on anaphylaxis in general, food allergy.
response_text: Taking into account the current geopolitical and socioeconomic context in Europe, we recommend that Ireland prioritise Health Protection, Citizen Safety, and Resilient Societies as core themes of its 2026 Presidency. Serious allergies and anaphylaxis are rising across Europe and place a growing burden on individuals, schools, workplaces, and public services. Addressing them fits naturally within broader objectives to protect citizens’ wellbeing and reduce preventable health risks. . A R e s i l i e n t an d P r e p a r e d E u r o p e The EU must be equipped to respond to emergencies—whether acute health events, natural disasters, or public safety threats. This requires harmonised emergency response systems, stronger community level preparedness, and cross-border cooperation. Ireland is one of the few Member States that has taken concrete steps to improve preparedness for serious allergic reactions, including allowing pharmacists to supply emergency medicines without a prescription during anaphylactic events. This national practice demonstrates effective emergency readiness and provides a model for EU-level policy coordination, which could inform upcoming initiatives under the European Health Union framework aimed at strengthening preparedness, prevention, and rapid response across Member States. . A P e o p l e -C e n t r e d U n i o n t h a t P r o t e c t s Embedding people-centred principles into EU policymaking ensures that vulnerable populations and individuals at risk of medical emergencies are not left behind. The Presidency could advance reducing health inequalities across the EU, highlighting uneven access to diagnosis, specialist care, and emergency response protocols. Positioning timely care for serious allergies and anaphylaxis within this agenda demonstrates a commitment to practical, measurable improvements in patient safety and inclusion, while protecting citizens’ rights to safety in everyday environments such as schools, childcare centres, workplaces, and public venues. 3 . A F u t u r e -O r i e n t e d E u r o p e B u i l t o n I n n o v a t i o n a n d C o l l a b o r a t i o n Ireland’s strong reputation in digital innovation offers an opportunity to promote Digital Innovation for Health, leveraging the European Health Data Space and interoperable, patient-centred tools. For individuals at risk of serious allergic reactions, seamless access to medical information across borders can prevent emergencies and support the free movement of people. The Presidency can also prioritise harmonised awareness-raising, institutional readiness, and capacity building, ensuring schools, businesses, and public institutions are equipped and trained to respond effectively to life-threatening health incidents.

sector: Vigilance on anaphylaxis in general, food allergy.
response_text: Ireland could use its Presidency to champion health resilience, citizen protection, and emergency preparedness, leveraging its national leadership in anaphylaxis response as a model for EU coordination.
