Key priorities include: Health Protection and Emergency Preparedness Serious allergies and anaphylaxis present a growing public-health challenge. The Presidency could: •Promote timely access to emergency medicines, building on Ireland’s approach where pharmacists can supply life-saving treatment without prescription. •Encourage harmonised school and public-venue preparedness, using Ireland as an example. Relevant upcoming EU initiative: •Global health resilience initiative (non-legislative, Q2 2026) – to strengthen EU capacity for rapid response to health crises. Digital Innovation for Health Cross-border emergencies require seamless access to patient data: Promote the European Health Data Space for secure, interoperable sharing of health information, enabling faster response to anaphylactic events across borders. Support digital tools for citizen-centred care, enhancing emergency response and patient safety. 3. Reducing Health Inequalities and Strengthening Citizen Rights The Presidency could advance equitable access to emergency care and citizen-centred policy: Link preparedness to strengthening the Child Guarantee (non-legislative, Q2 2026) and Citizens omnibus (legislative, Q4 2026), ensuring children in schools, childcare centres, and communities are protected and have their rights effectively enforced. Promote intergenerational fairness through the Intergenerational fairness strategy (non legislative, Q1 2026), ensuring emergency preparedness and health access benefit current and future generations equally. Highlight Ireland’s model as a practical, replicable approach for other Member States. Objectives Establish a model for EU-level anaphylaxis and emergency response coordination, based on best practices of Ireland. Ensure equitable access to life-saving treatments across the EU. Promote digital innovation for preparedness, information sharing, and cross-border patient care. • Strengthen citizen rights and intergenerational fairness, ensuring public health policies reflect social equity. Position health resilience as a pillar of EU citizen safety and social cohesion, demonstrating tangible improvements in public health readiness. By focusing on these targeted initiatives, Ireland can use its Presidency to deliver practical, measurable impacts on citizen safety, health equity, and cross-border emergency preparedness while reinforcing the EU’s social and legal frameworks.

sector: Vigilance on anaphylaxis in general, food allergy.
response_text: The Irish Presidency has the potential to deliver significant, tangible impact for EU citizens by advancing health resilience and consumer safety. For individuals with serious allergies, policies that improve emergency response, access to medicines, and accurate allergen information can be life-saving. For people, expanded access to emergency treatment, including pharmacy-enabled emergency supply across the EU, enhances safety in daily life. Citizens with serious allergies would be better protected in schools, workplaces, sports facilities, cultural venues, and during cross-border travel. For businesses, harmonised allergen-labelling and staff-training expectations reduce regulatory uncertainty, simplify compliance, and improve consumer trust by fostering safer public environments. For communities and institutions, EU-supported readiness measures ,such as common school protocols, public-venue guidelines, and accessible training ,would significantly reduce preventable emergencies, supporting all three Alliance objectives. Replicating Ireland’s best practice on emergency medicine access would ensure that life-saving intervention is available regardless of where a reaction occurs, reducing inequalities across Member States.

sector: Vigilance on anaphylaxis in general, food allergy.
response_text: Ireland has a strong opportunity to communicate the value of EU membership by focusing on everyday benefits and practical improvements that resonate directly with citizens. The 2026 Presidency can show how EU cooperation protects people, strengthens communities, and makes daily life safer—particularly in areas such as emergency preparedness for serious allergies and anaphylaxis. Highlight Practical Examples of EU Solidarity Citizens understand the EU best when they see clear, relatable outcomes. Ireland can communicate EU values by highlighting how cooperation improves safety and wellbeing, for example: Safer environments in schools, restaurants, transport and public venues. Shared health information that makes travel within the EU safer and more predictable. • Harmonised allergen-labelling rules that protect consumers wherever they are. • More consistent access to emergency support for serious allergic reactions. Ireland’s own approach—allowing pharmacists to supply emergency treatment during a serious allergic reaction—provides a concrete example of national leadership that improves citizen safety. Propose Council Recommendations on Emergency Readiness To strengthen public understanding of the EU’s benefits, Ireland could lead on a visible, citizen-centred initiative: Develop Council Recommendations on broader readiness and access to emergency treatment for serious allergy and anaphylaxis. This would help encourage Member States to: Improve preparedness in schools, public venues, workplaces, and transport hubs. Ensure trained responders are available across community settings. Reduce inequalities in access to time-sensitive, life-saving care. Such an initiative is easy for citizens to relate to, directly improves safety, and demonstrates EU cooperation in a human, practical way. A simple message: the EU protects people By showcasing initiatives that make everyday life safer, including better emergency preparedness for serious allergic reactions, the Irish Presidency can reinforce a clear message: EU cooperation delivers real, practical benefits for families, children, workers, and communities. This people-centred framing will strengthen public trust, build ownership, and demonstrate the concrete value of Ireland’s leadership at EU level.

respondent_type: Network of civil society organisations and education stakeholders
sector: Education - Focus: Development and Humanitarian Aid, Human Rights, UN Mechanisms
geography: Focus includes national, EU wide, and international
response_text: True Partnership with Civil Society: Ensure civil society has a seat at the table, with its expertise and perspectives not only heard but actively acted upon in EU policy and decision-making. Human Dignity at the Core: Place human dignity at the centre of the EU's global partnerships, foreign policy, geopolitical influence, and development cooperation and humanitarian aid. Trust-Based Global Partnerships: Build genuine, equitable partnerships, ensuring the EU's leadership in reliable, principled and impactful development and humanitarian aid. Education in the EU’s Foreign Policy: Secure and champion coherent, ring-fenced and meaningful funding for education, particularly girls' education, in the EU's development, humanitarian, gender equality, and climate engagement, recognising education as driver of upholding and promoting EU values. Education at the UN: Champion education as a human right within the EU and in UN negotiations, steering the EU's support for initiatives that advance this principle globally, including the Optional Protocol for free education and an impactful UN Framework Convention on International Tax Cooperation.

respondent_type: Network of civil society organisations and education stakeholders
sector: Education - Focus: Development and Humanitarian Aid, Human Rights, UN Mechanisms
geography: Focus includes national, EU wide, and international
response_text: Education as a Core Priority in EU Foreign Policy, Development, and Humanitarian Aid For the Irish EU Presidency, education, particularly girls' education, must be a central priority across EU foreign policy, development, and humanitarian aid, with several concrete actions to advance this commitment: First, we urge that coherence across EU funding instruments that support education in emergencies and development contexts is a key consideration for the EU Presidency. Despite EU Policy outlining the importance of coherence across instruments, implementation is inconsistent across protracted crises contexts, restricting the potential for complementary support to Education, to ensure the best outcomes for children and learners. Second, we welcome INTPA’s commitments to education and the 10% ringfencing of the humanitarian budget for Education in Emergencies (EiE), but note concerns about the continuation of this commitment. The Presidency will offer two key opportunities to reinforce this commitment: 1. The renewal of the Non-Legislative Communication on Humanitarian Aid, with Council conclusions and a possible resolution from the European Parliament on the Communication likely to occur during Ireland’s presidency. It is integral that education is integrated into the broader resilience-building strategies and supported through flexible, multisectoral financing. 2. Ireland will also have an opportunity to ensure prioritisation of the development and the humanitarian aid and resilience components in the negotiation on the 2028−2034 multiannual financial framework (MFF) and the introduction of the Global Europe instrument. It is critical to secure a commitment to maintain adequate education funding across both development and humanitarian budgets beyond 2027, including continuing the 10% of humanitarian budget for Education in Emergencies (EiE) and committing to ringfencing adequate funding for Education across INTPA and other instruments. Third, the Presidency should support measures to address the global teacher crisis, including prioritising teacher wellbeing, fair salaries, manageable workloads, and structured career development. This can only be achieved by ensuring that education-focused NGOs and trade unions are actively included in policy dialogue. Education in EU Climate Policy, Financing, and Cooperation Our members stress the need to integrate education into all relevant EU climate policy processes and long-term strategies, particularly in development cooperation and humanitarian responses to climate crises worldwide. Efforts should prioritise protecting learning from climate shocks and recognising education as a key driver of climate awareness, mitigation, and adaption in EU foreign policy approaches. Climate financing must explicitly support education, addressing both immediate and long-term needs. EU Investing in Global Citizenship Education A priority for the EU Presidency must be to invest in and strengthen Global Citizenship Education (GCE) both within and outside the EU, securing investment within the 2028−2034 multiannual financial framework (MFF). GCE is at the core of helping people understand the root causes of injustice and inequality, engage with complex global challenges—such as crises, climate change, and threats to democratic values — and appreciate why the EU and governments investments in development, humanitarian aid, and the SDGs, including education, are essential. Strengthening GCE is critical to fostering informed, engaged citizens who support multilevel and multilateral approaches to global challenges. Shaping EU Positions in UN Negotiations on the Right to Free Education and a Fair Global Financing 1. Negotiations on a new Optional Protocol to the UNCRC on Free Education: For millions of children around the world, the cost of education remains one of the most significant barriers to education. While nearly 90% of children complete primary education, only 59% complete secondary education, and only half of pre-primary aged children attend preschool with the youngest children (under age of three) having almost no access to high-quality early childhood care and education. The Irish EU Presidency should use its leadership to ensure that EU positions in UN negotiations actively support the initiative at the United Nations Human Rights Council to adopt a new optional protocol to the Convention on the Rights of the Child, strengthening the right to free education under international law. This new addition would address a gap left by the convention, which guarantees all children a right to free primary education, but says nothing about early childhood education or pre-primary education, and does not require governments to make secondary education free for all children. A particularly important opporunity, will be the Second Intergovernmental Working Group meeting on the protocol in August/September 2026. 2. Fair Financing Architecture and the UN Tax Convention Development, humanitarian, and climate financing are important, but insufficient to achieve SDG 4. The world urgently needs a fairer and more sustainable financing architecture that guarantees adequate funding for public services, including education. Through its EU Presidency, Ireland must ensure that the EU supports meaningful global reforms, including the development of an impactful UN Framework Convention on International Tax Cooperation, which should explicitly include a UN Global Asset Register and provisions linking tax policies to financing for quality public education, to secure predictable, equitable, and rights-based funding.

response_text: For our submission relating to the above questions, please see the attached pdf file “2025-12-12 Irish EU Presidency - INEW Submission”. (Word count for the whole submission: 1,437 - the below are extracts.) In the submission of the Irish Network for Education Worldwide - a network of civil society actors and education stakeholders in Ireland advocating for inclusive, equitable, and safe quality education for all worldwide, with a commitment to reaching the furthest behind - we are urging the government to consider the following key points during the Irish EU Presidency: The Irish EU Presidency must prioritise above all else the values on which the EU was built: Human Dignity, Freedom, Democracy, Equality, the Rule of Law, and Human Rights. These values are non-negotiable and must find a confident, principled, and vocal champion in the Irish EU Presidency, ready to defend and to advance them. As High-Level Thematic Priorities for the Irish EU Presidency, we recommend the following: True Partnership with Civil Society: Ensure civil society has a seat at the table, with its expertise and perspectives not only heard but actively acted upon in EU policy and decision-making. Human Dignity at the Core: Place human dignity at the centre of the EU's global partnerships, foreign policy, geopolitical influence, and development cooperation and humanitarian aid. Trust-Based Global Partnerships: Build genuine, equitable partnerships, ensuring the EU's leadership in reliable, principled and impactful development and humanitarian aid. Education in the EU’s Foreign Policy: Secure and champion coherent, ring-fenced and meaningful funding for education, particularly girls' education, in the EU's development, humanitarian, gender equality, and climate engagement, recognising education as driver of upholding and promoting EU values. Education at the UN: Champion education as a human right within the EU and in UN negotiations, steering the EU's support for initiatives that advance this principle globally, including the Optional Protocol for free education and an impactful UN Framework Convention on International Tax Cooperation. For recommended key actions for an impactful Irish EU Presidency and concrete particular policy areas and legislative proposals to focus on, please consult our full submission.

Sky connects and entertains millions of people across Europe, through TV, mobile and broadband. As such, Sky urges Ireland to focus its Presidency on a competitive and culturally strong digital Europe, where possible prioritising enforcement over new regulation: deliver binding anti-piracy measures for live content, implement AI rules that protect copyright, maintain territoriality and AVMSD stability, and - ensure fair treatment of regulated media. Through this. Europe can safeguard investment, pluralism and consumer trust. In parallel, Ireland should uphold the fundamentals of the EU telecom framework—SMP rules and ex-ante regulation—to keep networks open and competitive, resist blanket deregulation that favours incumbents, and reject any proposals for network fees or mandatory dispute-resolution mechanisms that would undermine the Open Internet and consumer choice.

(1) Digital Networks Act Maintaining the fundamentals of the existing regulatory framework(SMP rules and ex-ante approach) is key to ensure the electronic communications sector in Europe remains open, fair and competitive. Attempts to ‘simplify’ by substantially deregulating in favour of incumbents would be to the detriment of the sector’s competitiveness and consumers’ choice. The current framework already provides national regulators with enough flexibility to deregulate where necessary. We would also caution against the introduction of dispute resolution mechanisms and/or payment of fees between content providers and internet services, as this would be unjustified (as BEREC itself proved repeatedly) and would risk impacting the stability of the Open Internet and of the interconnection market. Most importantly, this would also negatively impact consumer choice and prices. We would also encourage continued support from the Irish Presidency towards the work of BEREC in ensuring legal guidance for businesses and a consistent implementation of European rules. Consumer protection Were the Digital Fairness Act be published during the Irish Presidency, we would caution against a onesize-fits-all approach for businesses across sectors when it comes to issues such as ‘addictive designs’, ‘subscription traps’ and ‘dark patterns’. The audiovisual and electronic communications sectors are already heavily regulated around the issues identified by the European Commission – often way beyond already existing horizontal consumer protection rules. There is no evidence that audiovisual services are problematic or harmful for consumers. Anti-piracy Move from soft law to hard law against live piracy: near-immediate takedown (≤30 minutes), dynamic blocking (including IP blocking) in all Member States, and robust Know-Your-Customer obligations across intermediaries. Non-binding approaches have shown minimal impact while organised criminal networks continue to exploit gaps. Audiovisual Media Services Directive Prioritise a stable, flexible framework for audiovisual services that supports investment and scale, avoids reopening AVMSD for new quotas/levies, and preserves contractual freedom in IP allocation. Keep country-of-origin; support principles-based guidance on prominence; resist prescriptive, harmonised solutions that add burden and reduce investment. Stability and flexibility are essential for broadcasters and VOD services to invest, adapt and serve audiences. Artificial Intelligence Support trustworthy AI that respects copyright and creativity. Operationalise the AI Act with enforceable transparency on training data, EU-level voluntary licensing tools for rightsholders, and clear responsibility on AI developers—not rightsholders—for copyright breaches.

Where possible, by shifting the focus from new rules to effective enforcement through practical guidance and rapid redress—reducing uncertainty, accelerating remedies for consumers and businesses, and improving trust in lawful services.

I support the call for Resilience as the overarching theme for Ireland’s 2026 Presidency, expressed through a slogan such as “Resilient Together.” This theme reflects growing environmental, social and economic volatility across Europe and highlights the need to strengthen the natural, social, territorial and democratic systems that sustain wellbeing. Across the EU, citizens are already experiencing the consequences of climate change, biodiversity collapse, pollution and unstable supply chains. Communities affected by storms, flooding and environmental degradation continue to demonstrate solidarity, adaptability and creativity. These experiences show that resilience emerges from strong ecosystems, empowered communities and effective public institutions working together. Ireland’s Presidency can therefore provide leadership by advancing a positive, future-oriented programme grounded in three mutually reinforcing priorities. 1. Environmental and Ecological Resilience Healthy ecosystems underpin climate stability, food security, water quality and economic prosperity. Strengthening environmental resilience should therefore be a core priority of the Presidency. Ireland should champion full implementation of the European Green Deal, including nature restoration, clean water, zero-pollution objectives, climate adaptation and biodiversity protection. A resilient Europe requires robust environmental law, grounded in scientific evidence and applied consistently across Member States. As political pressure grows to weaken EU environmental rules, Ireland can lead by ensuring that regulatory “simplification” enhances clarity and enforceability rather than reducing environmental safeguards. A Presidency focused on ecological resilience also provides an opportunity to embed nature-based solutions, sustainable land-use planning, climate-proofed infrastructure and long-term adaptation across all sectors. This reflects the growing recognition that environmental protection is central to societal and economic security. 2. Democratic, Community and Territorial Resilience Environmental resilience depends on strong democracies, engaged citizens and transparent decision-making. Communities must be supported to participate meaningfully in shaping the transitions affecting them. Ireland should use its Presidency to strengthen public access to environmental information, participation and justice, in line with the Aarhus Convention. Protecting civic space, supporting environmental defenders and ensuring open governance across the EU are essential for building trust and enabling fair, science-based decision-making. A community-centred approach also requires recognising the crucial role of local and regional authorities in delivering climate action, nature protection, spatial planning, sustainable mobility and place-based development. Strengthening multi-level governance and territorial cohesion will improve environmental outcomes, support healthy placemaking and reinforce democratic legitimacy. 3. Economic and Just Transition Resilience A resilient Europe requires a fair, well-funded and legally certain transition to a sustainable economy. The Presidency should support adequate EU funding for climate action, biodiversity restoration, rural development, innovation, skills and community-led transition. Rather than deregulation, Europe’s businesses and communities need predictable, science-based rules that support innovation, competitiveness and long-term planning. Ireland can play a leadership role in ensuring the next Multiannual Financial Framework and EU packages—such as the Circular Economy Act and the 2040 climate framework—maintain environmental integrity while delivering visible benefits for people. A Just Transition focused on fairness, participation, regional opportunity and community wellbeing will strengthen Europe’s social fabric and economic stability.

FIE propose a particular focus on the following policy and legislative areas and outcomes: Simplification must reinforce, not weaken, EU standards The Commission’s current focus on simplifying EU regulation presents a genuine opportunity to improve clarity, accessibility and administrative efficiency. As recognised in EU Treaties and recent jurisprudence, however, simplification must remain entirely consistent with the Union’s obligations under Articles 3(3) TEU, 11 and 191 TFEU, and Article 37 of the Charter to ensure a high level of environmental protection and continuous improvement. Any reform must therefore maintain or strengthen environmental integrity and legal certainty. Regulatory certainty supports innovation and competitiveness Clear, evidence-based standards benefit responsible businesses, investors and citizens. While some actors use the political moment to advocate broad deregulation, EU institutions and experts continue to underline that weakening standards increases uncertainty, rewards laggards and penalises those already investing in the transition. Judicial findings across Europe also show that vague or diluted criteria lead to inconsistent and often unlawful decision-making. Simplification should therefore enhance the clarity, enforceability and scientific grounding of rules rather than dilute them. A leadership opportunity for the Irish Presidency The Irish Presidency has both a responsibility and an opportunity to uphold the EU’s tradition of forward-looking, high-quality standard-setting. By supporting simplification that improves usability while preserving environmental integrity, Ireland can help safeguard public trust, provide regulatory certainty for businesses, and reinforce the EU’s long-term sustainability and competitiveness. A future-proof Multiannual Financial Framework The next MFF must ensure adequate, dedicated funding to meet existing legal obligations and societal needs. This includes: Nature restoration, delivered in partnership with farmers, communities and environmental stakeholders; Economically, socially and environmentally sustainable agriculture, including fully funded rural development programmes; Active citizenship and civil society, including continued support for LIFE, recognising the value of public participation affirmed in recent ECtHR jurisprudence These investments enhance resilience, compliance and community-led transition. Circular Economy Act: Practical benefits for people and business A well-designed Circular Economy Act can deliver visible gains: reducing built-in obsolescence, strengthening the right to repair, enhancing supply chain security, and supporting more sustainable resource use. Clear, measurable, science-based criteria—aligned with existing EU law—will help ensure the Act drives innovation and consumer confidence. 2040 Climate Package: Continuity, clarity and fairness The 2040 climate framework will shape Europe’s pathway to climate neutrality. Consistent with recent rulings such as Klimaseniorinnen, EU climate governance must rely on quantified pathways, timely action and structured engagement with scientific evidence. The package should therefore preserve the integrity of the existing regime, avoid creating new loopholes, and deliver a fair, transparent transition that addresses citizens’ material concerns—both legally and socially essential.

The most substantial positive impact the Irish Presidency can make is to ensure that EU decision-making is grounded in the lived realities of Europe’s people, regions, and local communities. This requires embedding the principles of subsidiarity, territorial cohesion, environmental resilience, and democratic participation across the Council’s work. When local and regional actors are involved early and meaningfully, EU policy becomes more effective, better implemented, and more trusted. A priority should be strengthening multi-level governance. Local and regional authorities are central to delivering the EU’s climate, biodiversity, spatial planning, mobility, water, housing, and public service objectives. The Presidency can champion their systematic involvement in shaping national and EU positions, ensuring that territorial expertise informs negotiations. This would help produce legislation that is practical, proportionate, implementable and responsive to different regional starting points. Supporting structured dialogue with civil society, social partners, community organisations and business networks will further embed democratic legitimacy and improve policy outcomes. The Presidency also has an opportunity to reinforce environmental and ecological resilience as foundations of long-term wellbeing and economic stability. Council processes should uphold the EU’s high environmental standards and avoid any dilution that would undermine public health, biodiversity, climate mitigation or adaptation. Clear, science-based and enforceable rules provide regulatory certainty—benefiting responsible businesses, investors and communities—and support a fair and competitive internal market. Embedding environmental integrity across all Council work will help safeguard water resources, restore nature, improve air quality and strengthen Europe’s ability to withstand growing climate risks. A third area of impact is advancing a fair, well-funded and legally predictable transition. The Presidency should work to secure an ambitious Multiannual Financial Framework that provides sufficient resources for climate action, nature restoration, sustainable agriculture, regional development, innovation, skills and community-led transition. Adequate, targeted funding enhances resilience, supports competitiveness, and ensures that no region or community is left behind as Europe accelerates towards climate neutrality. The Presidency can also add value by promoting coherence across EU initiatives—particularly the Circular Economy Act and the 2040 climate framework—to ensure they reinforce rather than undermine one another. This means championing policies that reduce waste, strengthen the right to repair, enhance supply chain resilience, and deliver climate action in a way that is fair, transparent and attentive to people’s material concerns. Finally, the work of the Council can make a major difference by reinforcing open governance, transparency and access to information. Ensuring strong public rights to participation and justice strengthens trust, supports evidence-based decisions, and empowers communities to play an active role in shaping Europe’s future. By combining territorial expertise, strong environmental governance, subsidiarity, and a fair transition, the Irish Presidency can help deliver EU policies that produce meaningful, lasting benefits for people, businesses and communities across all regions.

The most effective way to communicate the values and benefits of EU membership is to demonstrate how EU law and policy have already tangibly improved life in Ireland and other countries. The upcoming Presidency should highlight concrete, relatable examples that show the EU as a practical force for cleaner environments, stronger rights, and healthier communities. Environmental protection offers some of the clearest examples. EU nature legislation has transformed how Ireland safeguards its bogs, woodlands and coastlines, protecting landscapes that are central to national identity. The Birds and Habitats Directives have created binding duties to protect important species and habitats, resulting in stronger oversight, clearer standards, and greater accountability when environmental rules are not followed. The new Nature Restoration Law goes further by requiring the active repair of damaged ecosystems, offering long-term benefits for biodiversity, climate resilience, and community well-being. Another significant achievement is the improvement of water quality. EU water and marine laws have raised expectations for Ireland’s rivers, lakes and coastal waters, driving investment in wastewater treatment and requiring action on pollution sources. These directives have helped revive rivers, make beaches safer, and protect drinking water, ensuring that environmental quality is not a luxury but a legal right. EU planning rules have also empowered people and communities. Requirements for Environmental Impact Assessments (EIA) and Strategic Environmental Assessments (SEA) ensure that major projects are properly evaluated before they proceed. These rules embed sustainability into infrastructure and land-use decisions and guarantee public participation, with courts reinforcing that communities must be meaningfully heard. This helps citizens understand that the EU is not distant—it is shaping decisions that affect towns, housing, transport and local environments directly. Equally important is the EU’s role in promoting transparency. The Access to Information on the Environment Directive enables anyone to request environmental information from public bodies. This right has strengthened accountability, supported investigative journalism, and empowered communities to identify environmental issues, challenge poor decision-making, and demand better outcomes. It exemplifies the EU’s commitment to openness and democratic participation. The EU has also driven major improvements in waste management. Past shortcomings in Ireland’s waste and landfill practices were addressed only after EU intervention, resulting in stricter regulations, safer waste handling and cleaner communities. This demonstrates that EU enforcement can turn local concerns into national progress, making visible improvements in environmental quality and public health. Communicating these successes should rely on accessible storytelling, not technical language. Using real locations, communities, and stories will show that EU action has shaped Ireland’s natural environment, public services and democratic rights. Citizen ownership can be deepened through regional events, workshops, school and university engagements, cultural initiatives, and public dialogues that invite people to participate in shaping Ireland’s Presidency priorities. Ultimately, the message should be simple: EU membership has delivered cleaner water, protected nature, strengthened public rights, improved planning, and supported transparency. Ireland’s Presidency is an opportunity to highlight these achievements and involve citizens directly in shaping the next chapter of Ireland’s place in Europe.

As Ireland prepares to assume the Presidency of the Council of the European Union in 2026, we must strengthen domestic compliance and governance with EU environmental law. Ireland is currently subject to a significant number of infringement proceedings for failures to fully transpose, implement, or enforce EU directives. These include active referrals to the Court of Justice concerning wastewater treatment obligations, delays in revising river basin and flood risk management plans, and insufficient protection of priority habitats. Additional proceedings remain ongoing in areas such as renewable energy permitting, environmental assessment, nature conservation, and water pollution control. The scale and persistence of these actions highlight structural shortcomings that require urgent and coordinated attention. A Member State entrusted with chairing the Council’s legislative work must demonstrate adherence to the Union’s legal framework. Effective stewardship depends on credibility: a Presidency that guides negotiations on climate, nature restoration, pollution prevention, and circular-economy measures must be seen as upholding these same standards at home. Continued non-compliance risks undermine Ireland’s influence, erode trust in environmental governance, and expose the State to financial penalties and reputational harm. Strengthening compliance should therefore be considered an integral component of Ireland’s Presidency preparation. Key actions include reinforcing administrative capacity within departments and regulatory bodies; improving coordination with local authorities responsible for implementation; ensuring transposition processes are timely, complete and scientifically robust; and embedding transparency, public participation and access to justice, consistent with the Aarhus Convention. Many of Ireland’s current infringements reflect delays, inconsistent application of standards, or gaps in monitoring and enforcement—issues that can be effectively addressed through clearer governance structures, proactive planning and adequate resourcing. Enhanced compliance will also produce tangible benefits for communities, businesses and the environment. Full and consistent implementation of EU environmental law supports cleaner water, healthier ecosystems, climate resilience, and a predictable and fair regulatory environment. It reduces long-term public expenditure by preventing environmental degradation, protecting health, and avoiding litigation. Moreover, a coherent compliance framework underpins a just transition by ensuring that environmental rules apply equally and transparently across sectors and regions. As Ireland enters a period of heightened responsibility within the EU, demonstrating leadership through strong domestic governance is both necessary and advantageous. By resolving long-standing infringements, improving enforcement systems, and ensuring that environmental decisions are grounded in clear evidence and meaningful public participation, Ireland can show its commitment to the Union’s values and reinforce the legitimacy of its Presidency. The 2026 Presidency will offer Ireland a critical platform to highlight the benefits of ambitious, enforceable environmental standards and to advance resilient, science-based policymaking across the Union. To use that platform effectively, Ireland must ensure its implementation framework fully aligns with EU law and meets a high standard of environmental protection. Strengthening domestic compliance is therefore essential to the credibility, authority, and success of the Irish Presidency.

Irish Rural Link (IRL), national network organisation representing rural communities and UCD School of Agriculture – believe that rural communities, social inclusion and balanced regional development should be one of the key priorities on the agenda for Ireland’s EU Presidency. The Rural Pact, launched by the EU Commission in 2021, as part of its Long-Term Vision for EU’s rural areas, provides a framework for cooperation between public authorities, civil society, businesses, academia and citizens, at the European, national, regional and local level. It aims at fostering mutual inspiration between all levels of governance and mobilise public authorities and stakeholders to act on the needs and aspirations of rural residents and rural matters. The Presidency offers a unique opportunity to ensure EU policy better reflects the needs of those living in rural communities, beyond agriculture, who continue to face structural disadvantages in accessing services, employment, infrastructure, and climate-transition support. While security, defence, and competitiveness are currently high on the EU agenda, they must not come at the expense of social cohesion, civil society, or the support provided to community and voluntary organisations that work with marginalised people and hard-to-reach communities. Rural communities across Europe, and in Ireland in particular, also play a vital role in ensuring both energy and food security. Rural households face higher living and transport costs, limited access to health and social services, and growing pressure from inflation. Many older people, low-income families, and isolated communities are particularly vulnerable. As Ireland is still a very rural country, it should champion an EU commitment to equitable access to services, enhanced social protection, and targeted supports for disadvantaged rural regions. A specific strand of the Presidency could highlight rural proofing of EU social policy to ensure no person or community in rural areas is left behind. A core priority should be to advance rural infrastructure and connectivity across Europe. Rural prosperity requires affordable housing, high-quality broadband, reliable public transport, and access to key services such as health, education, childcare, and community supports. Many rural areas still lack adequate digital connectivity and public transport options, leading to exclusion and depopulation. The Presidency should push for the EU to prioritise investment in rural digital and transport infrastructure, support the revitalisation of rural towns and villages, and encourage sustainable, community-based service provision. Ireland’s Presidency is a way to champion the 'right to stay' in rural areas. This gives citizens the ability to live and work in the community they call home. Given Ireland’s history of leading rural development practices and processes in Europe, and that we are one of the few countries in Europe with a dedicated Ministry for Rural Development and a rural development policy – Our Rural Future. It is an opportunity for Ireland to promote rural communities and the many benefits of living and working in rural areas.

IRL and the School of Agriculture, UCD believe that Ireland’s EU Presidency should champion policy priorities that strengthen rural communities, promote balanced regional development, and ensure that EU legislation supports a fair, sustainable and inclusive rural future. The Presidency offers a key opportunity to shape EU social, economic and environmental policymaking at a critical moment for rural areas across Europe. A central priority should be advancing social inclusion, improving access to essential services and embedding rural proofing across EU policy. This includes driving implementation of the European Pillar of Social Rights, addressing persistent service deficits in rural and remote areas, and tackling poverty and cost-of-living pressures. Digital inclusion must also remain at the core of EU social policy. Ireland should work to strengthen requirements for rural proofing within major EU social and economic initiatives, progress legislation that guarantees universal access to public services, both in-person and digitally, and promote minimum service standards across all Member States. The Presidency should place rural equality at the centre of EU social policy, committing the EU to better regional and rural impact assessments and enhanced investment in rural public services, transport and digital infrastructure. Improving rural infrastructure, mobility and connectivity is essential to enabling full participation in economic and social life. Key areas for action include implementation of the Trans-European Transport Network (TEN-T), progress towards the EU Digital Decade 2030 targets, and ongoing reforms within EU Cohesion and Regional Policy. The Presidency should prioritise more flexible cohesion-funding rules to support small-scale rural infrastructure projects. Ireland should also highlight the importance of rural mobility solutions, community-based transport initiatives and digital deployment mechanisms that benefit rural towns, islands and remote regions. The Multi Financial Framework and CAP Post 2027 – must ensure that sustainable agriculture, food systems and the Just Transition continue to be funded and Ireland’s Presidency should work to ensure that EU legislation supports food security, viable farm incomes and effective climate and biodiversity action. This includes engaging actively with CAP Strategic Plan reforms, Farm-to-Fork and biodiversity legislation, and transition mechanisms affecting agriculture, energy and land use. Priority actions should include protecting small and family farms in any CAP revision through simplified schemes and fairer payments, alongside promoting workable, community-centred nature restoration and climateadaptation measures. The Presidency should aim for balanced policy outcomes that support farming livelihoods while advancing environmental commitments, ensuring fairness, flexibility and meaningful rural community involvement. LEADER is recognised as a valuable mechanism for supporting communities, the environment, and enterprises in rural areas. It should remain a core element of the CAP post-2027, and the Irish Presidency can help reinforce the importance of LEADER in promoting rural development and social inclusion. Improving rural participation and democratic engagement should be a cross-cutting priority. Ireland should promote stronger mechanisms for rural involvement in EU decision-making, including through the Rural Pact, local development structures and improved civil-society participation channels.

Ireland’s EU Presidency presents a major opportunity to advance policies that deliver long-term benefits for EU citizens, especially those in rural and disadvantaged communities. To achieve the greatest impact, the Presidency should encourage stronger social cohesion, sustainable economic opportunity, fair climate action and improved access to essential services. These priorities both reflect Ireland’s strengths and respond to the needs of rural communities across Europe. The gap between urban and rural areas remains a challenge in EU member states. Many people living in rural areas still face barriers in accessing healthcare, childcare, education, broadband and social supports. The Irish Presidency can use this opportunity to advance regional balance and rural equality, embed rural proofing across EU legislation, expand access to public services, both in-person and digitally, and strengthen social protection systems that reflect the higher costs of rural living. It should also promote measures to combat social isolation among older people, people with a disability, migrants, low-income households and remote communities. Improved connectivity is essential for employment, education, mobility and business development. The Presidency can accelerate progress on high-speed broadband for underserved regions, ensure fair and flexible implementation of transport networks, and expand investment tools suited to the needs of small towns, villages and islands. By prioritising practical, community-focused infrastructure, the Irish Presidency can help unlock economic potential, reduce regional disparities and make rural areas more attractive places to live and work. Sustainable rural economies depend on thriving small businesses, farms, social enterprises and community organisations. The Irish Presidency can strengthen these sectors by promoting simplified EU funding and regulatory requirements for SMEs and micro-enterprises, supporting community-led local development models such as LEADER, and fostering rural entrepreneurial ecosystems that include remote-working hubs, innovation supports and circular-economy initiatives. Policies that enhance food security and protect the viability of small family farms will further contribute to stable jobs, resilient supply chains and vibrant communities. Climate and biodiversity policy has a deep impact on rural regions, and many communities feel insufficiently supported as they try to make the necessary changes. Ireland can play a leadership role by prioritising a Just Transition that protects rural livelihoods, advancing climate measures co-designed and co-implemented with communities, and promoting pragmatic nature-restoration and land-use policies that balance environmental goals with local realities. A fairer transition will build public trust, support farmers and rural workers, and ensure environmental progress benefits all in society. Strengthening democratic participation is essential to effective policymaking. The Presidency can deepen citizen engagement by supporting strong civil-society involvement, by engaging with existing networks; C&V Pillar, CAP Network, PPN, EESC and the EU, while improving mechanisms that allow local communities, young people and marginalised groups to shape EU policy. Encouraging cross-border cooperation and knowledge-sharing among rural regions will further enhance inclusion and innovation. By leading with fairness, rural inclusion, sustainable development and community participation, Ireland’s Presidency can deliver lasting positive outcomes for people, businesses and communities across the EU.

Ireland’s EU Presidency will resonate more with people and communities if they are active participants in the Presidency and can see directly the benefits of EU funding and the work of EU Institutions. Communication in advance and during the Presidency must be transparent, inclusive and rooted in everyday realities, particularly for rural communities that often feel distant from EU institutions. The Presidency offers a unique opportunity to bring Europe closer to people by making EU impacts visible, accessible and meaningful. With the new President of EESC, Seamus Boland, being Irish, it is also a good opportunity to bring civil society closer to the EU. A core priority should be showing how EU policies deliver tangible benefits at local level. People engage more when they can see results within their own communities. Communication should highlight EUfunded rural and social projects and initiatives; broadband delivery, community centres, transport improvements, LEADER initiatives, Just Transition, environmental restoration and supports for small businesses and farms. Sharing personal stories from those whose jobs, training, services or family farms have been strengthened by EU policies and funding, gives a better understanding of the work of the EU and demonstrate its value. Clear explanations of how EU rules protect consumers, workers, small producers and the environment further strengthen trust. Reaching every region requires using the existing strength of community networks. Organisations like IRL, CAP Network, PPNs, local development groups, youth services, libraries and community and voluntary organisations are trusted at the local level, especially in remote areas. Working with these networks, the Government can facilitate community information events and targeted outreach using rural communication channels, not just national media. Trusted local voices help ensure that Presidency themes and EU opportunities reach older residents, low-income households and those without strong digital access. Communication must be clear and concise, using plain English and Irish. While digital outreach is important, many rural areas still face weak broadband and some cohorts of people still do not have adequate digital skills or access to digital devices, so offline methods such as local papers, radio, and community newsletters remain essential. This inclusive approach reduces the perceived distance between citizens and EU institutions. Ireland’s EU Presidency should create opportunities for people to shape discussions, not just listen to them. Participatory events involving rural youth, older people, community volunteers, farmers and migrants can capture diverse priorities. A national “Rural Voices for Europe” dialogue could gather perspectives from communities nationwide and feed them into EU-level forums. Community organisations should be supported to host local Presidency-related events that reflect their interests and identities, reinforcing that the EU belongs to its citizens. As part of this participatory approach, the EU Rural Pact could host an event in Ireland during the Presidency, with the Department of Rural and Community Development working alongside organisations such as Irish Rural Link. This event should be located outside of Dublin – in a rural setting. This would provide a high-profile platform to discuss rural and community issues beyond agriculture, showcase innovation, and strengthen Europe-wide cooperation. Supporting IRL and similar organisations to coorganise public sessions, workshops and community dialogues would ensure broad engagement and meaningful outcomes. By making EU benefits visible, empowering local networks and communities, communicating clearly, involving citizens directly and leveraging existing EU platforms such as the Rural Pact, Ireland can ensure its 2026 Presidency feels inclusive, relevant and genuinely owned by the people it represents.

organisation: [REDACTED UNDER GDPR], Irish Museum of Modern Art
response_text: Ireland’s Presidency offers a unique opportunity to articulate a forward-looking, people-centered, vision for Europe, rooted in imagination, democratic resilience, and cultural well-being. As a National Cultural Institution, working at the intersection of public engagement, artistic practice, and civic dialogue, IMMA proposes three high-level thematic priorities: NURTURING DEMOCRATIC PARTICIPATION AND CIVIC IMAGINATION At a time of democratic fatigue, polarisation and declining trust, Ireland can champion the idea that democratic life must be continuously renewed. Culture, through storytelling, shared experience, and critical reflection, plays a distinct role in strengthening social cohesion and building a sense of collective purpose. The Presidency offers and opportunity to foreground initiatives that support civic education, citizen assemblies, cultural participation, media literacy, and the arts as spaces for imaginative public dialogue across Europe. A HUMAN-CENTRED GREEN AND DIGITAL TRANSITION Europe’s twin transitions will only succeed if they are socially just, culturally embedded, and accessible to all communities. Ireland can lead a Presidency programme that places people and cultural meaning at the heart of these transitions: supporting creative climate communication, cultural approaches to environmental stewardship, and ethically grounded digital innovation. This includes the role of the creative and cultural sectors in designing inclusive technologies, centring human agency, and ensuring that technological change aligns with European values. BUILDING A EUROPE OF PEACE, CULTURE, AND SHARED FUTURES While the Presidency must remain neutral, Ireland’s history of peacebuilding, reconciliation, and cultural diplomacy positions it well to highlight Europe’s ongoing work in sustaining peaceful societies. Cultural expression is a cornerstone of this effort, helping people confront difficult histories, supporting communities through transition, and widening democratic imagination. Without making peace a standalone theme, the Presidency can highlight Europe’s shared commitment to pluralism, intercultural dialogue, memory work, and collective resilience. PROPOSED OVERARCHING PHRASE “Imagining Europe Together” This centres people, shared futures, and Europe’s cultural foundations, while remaining broad, neutral, and aligned with the Presidency’s expectations.

organisation: [REDACTED UNDER GDPR], Irish Museum of Modern Art
response_text: STRENGTHENING DEMOCRATIC RESILIENCE AND CULTURAL RIGHTS Relevant Council configurations: GAC, EYCS, JHA Ireland can help advance work related to: Promoting civic participation and citizen engagement across Member States Ensuring equitable access to culture, including digital cultural resources Supporting the cultural and creative sectors as essential contributors to democratic life • Advancing anti-disinformation and media literacy measures, particularly for young people. The Presidency should aim to foster alignment across Council configurations that strengthen the cultural conditions in which democratic resilience can flourish. SOCIALLY JUST GREEN AND DIGITAL TRANSITIONS Relevant Council configurations: ENVI, TTE, COMPET, EYCS Ireland can contribute to progressing legislative efforts that reinforce the social and cultural dimension of the green and digital transitions, including: Policies that support creative ecological communication and public engagement Measures that promote digital inclusion, cultural data rights, and ethical AI Cultural heritage and creative-sector approaches to sustainability The aim should be to foreground culture not as a peripheral add-on but as an enabler of behavioural, societal, and systemic change. 3. CULTURE, PEACE, AND EUROPEAN COHESION Relevant Council configurations: EYCS, FAC, GAC Drawing on its own experience and cultural leadership, Ireland can help progress dialogue and measures that encourage: Cross-border cultural cooperation and exchange Cultural approaches to memory, conflict transformation and democratic transition Support for artistic freedom and cultural workers across the EU While remaining neutral, Ireland can emphasise Europe’s shared responsibility to sustain peaceful, inclusive societies. IMMA’s forthcoming programme “Technologies of Peace: Art and Transition in Contemporary Europe” reflects the wider cultural sector’s capacity to support these ambitions.

response_text: EMBEDDING CULTURE AS AN ENABLER OF SOCIAL COHESION AND ECONOMIC WELLBEING Culture is one of Europe’s strongest assets: it supports local economies, attracts visitors, strengthens communities, and fosters belonging. The Presidency can support work that: Improves access to cultural participation across Member States Recognises cultural and creative workers as an essential part of Europe’s future workforce Strengthens cross-border cultural mobility and collaboration Links culture to skills, wellbeing, and regional development ENSURING THAT TRANSITIONS ARE PEOPLE-CENTRED, INCLUSIVE AND UNDERSTANDABLE Both the climate and digital transitions require deep behavioural and societal shifts. Cultural organisations, working through storytelling, creativity, and imagination, can help people navigate these changes in accessible, meaningful ways. The Presidency can emphasise policies that bring people into these transitions. SUPPORTING YOUTH ENGAGEMENT AND FUTURE FACING PUBLIC DIALOGUE Young people will inherit the outcomes of the next decade of EU decision-making. The Presidency can amplify initiatives that give young people an active role in shaping Europe’s future, including youth assemblies, cultural internships, digital participation platforms, and creative sector pathways. 4. REAFFIRMING EUROPE’S COMMITMENT TO PEACE, PLURALISM AND SHARED FUTURES At a time of geopolitical instability, communities benefit from platforms that foster cultural exchange, understanding, and civic imagination. Through its convening role, the Council can champion work that deepens solidarity across Member States and strengthens Europe’s social fabric.
