response_text: LEAD WITH CULTURE, PARTICIPATION AND STORYTELLING Citizens engage most deeply when policy is made tangible. Highlighting EU-funded cultural projects, cross-border collaborations, residencies, festivals, youth programmes and local initiatives can help communicate what Europe feels like in everyday life. BRING EU CONVERSATIONS INTO PUBLIC SPACE Ireland can mobilise its cultural institutions, community organisations and creative networks to host EUthemed events, exhibitions, dialogues, and participatory activities during the Presidency. These initiatives should be open, accessible, and inclusive, inviting people to encounter EU questions through creative imaginative formats. PRIORITISE YOUTH-CENTRED COMMUNICATION Dedicated youth outreach, co-designed digital content, climate-focused initiatives, and creating partnerships with schools and universities can help cultivate a sense of European belonging among younger citizens. USE CULTURAL DIPLOMACY TO STRENGTHEN EUROPEAN IDENTITY Showcasing Ireland’s cultural leadership, including international collaborations such as IMMA’s Technologies of Peace programme, can help communicate the EU as a space of shared values, artistic freedom, and peaceful cooperation.

organisation: [REDACTED UNDER GDPR], Irish Museum of Modern Art
response_text: Culture can play a powerful role in shaping Europe’s future, strengthening democratic participation, supporting inclusive transitions, building trust in institutions, and fostering peaceful, pluralistic societies. As Ireland prepares to assume the Presidency, cultural organisations across the country stand ready to contribute to this work by offering spaces for dialogue, creativity, and civic imagination. In this context, IMMA highlights that its forthcoming programme, Technologies of Peace: Art and Transition in Contemporary Europe, taking place during Ireland’s EU Presidency, will exemplify the contribution cultural institutions can make to European cooperation, public engagement, and democratic reflection. While not offered as a Presidency priority, it illustrates the potential of culture to support Europe’s shared commitment to peace, solidarity, and inclusive futures. Ireland’s Presidency can leave a meaningful legacy by ensuring that cultural participation, imagination, and civic dialogue remain at the heart of Europe’s policy conversations, bridging institutions, and citizens, and strengthening the shared European project for years to come.

Ireland should choose diaspora connectivity and the social integration of mobile EU citizens as a high-level thematic priority for its 2026 Presidency because it addresses a significant but under-recognised gap in the EU project. While free movement is a cornerstone of EU membership, millions of EU citizens living in other Member States lack access to meaningful community networks, civic participation, and reliable integration support. In practice, many rely on informal third-party social media groups to navigate work, housing, healthcare, language, and rights. This weakens social cohesion, labour market integration, and democratic engagement across the Union. Ireland’s own history of emigration and long-standing experience with diaspora engagement give it particular credibility to elevate this issue in a European, non-national way. Addressing what happens after mobility aligns directly with EU objectives on cohesion, democracy, and inclusion.

The Irish Presidency should focus on practical areas where progress can realistically be made within a six-month term, rather than attempting to introduce major new legislation. This means concentrating on issues that affect the everyday lives of people who have moved from one EU country to another and are living outside their home country. Key priorities should include helping EU citizens better understand and exercise their rights, supporting diaspora communities to settle into work and local life, encouraging participation in cultural, educational and civic activities, and making public information and services easier to find and use online. While many rights and supports exist in theory, in practice people often struggle to access them without local knowledge or informal help. There are already EU programmes that can help address these challenges, including funding for citizen engagement, education and training, cultural projects and democratic participation. However, many people living abroad are simply unaware of these opportunities or do not know how to access them. The Presidency should therefore focus on making better use of what already exists, improving coordination between EU institutions, national authorities and local organisations, and ensuring these supports reach diaspora communities directly. This is more effective than setting up new systems from scratch. The Irish Presidency should also aim to secure formal acknowledgement from EU governments that many people who live and work in another Member State struggle to fully settle in or take part in community and civic life. These difficulties are often invisible at policy level and are left to individuals to manage on their own. To address this, the Presidency should encourage the development of clearly identifiable and easy-to-find diaspora support networks, especially in cities with large and diverse EU populations. These networks should act as first points of contact for newcomers, helping them understand local systems, find reliable information, connect with others, and navigate work, housing and community life. Importantly, they should also create opportunities for people from different EU backgrounds to meet and interact, rather than remaining isolated within nationality-based groups. The Presidency should support small-scale pilot projects and practical exchanges between Member States and cities with established diaspora populations. These should focus on measures that genuinely help people settle and participate, such as welcome hubs, peer mentoring for new arrivals, joint cultural events, and civic initiatives that bring together different EU communities. Successful approaches should be documented and shared so they can be adapted elsewhere. Progress should be measured by whether the challenges faced by people living outside their home country are clearly recognised at EU level, whether authorities and diaspora organisations work more closely together, and whether EU citizens abroad have realistic and accessible ways to take part in social, cultural and democratic life where they live.

By focusing on the everyday experiences of diaspora communities, the work of the Council can make a real and practical difference. Better support can help people who have moved from one EU country to another find work that matches their skills and understand how local labour markets operate, instead of feeling left to figure things out alone. Stronger diaspora and cross-diaspora networks can also reduce loneliness and isolation, particularly for people who arrive without an existing community to turn to. Creating spaces where people from different EU backgrounds can meet helps break down social silos and encourages a stronger sense of belonging. When diaspora communities are better informed about their rights and about EU-funded opportunities, trust in EU institutions increases, because people can see and feel the benefits of EU membership in their own lives. Overall, this approach supports diaspora individuals in settling and contributing, helps employers connect with a more confident and integrated workforce, and strengthens host communities by building connections across different European backgrounds.

Ireland should communicate this priority by putting the experiences of diaspora communities at the centre of its Presidency. This means highlighting real stories from people who live and work in another EU country — how they found their footing, where they struggled, and what helped them feel part of their new home. Public events, cultural programmes and local partnerships during the Presidency should actively involve diaspora groups and take place in cities with large EU communities. These activities should show how EU membership makes it possible to move, work and build a life across borders, while also recognising that people need better support to truly belong. By focusing on the everyday realities of diaspora life rather than EU institutions, Ireland can help people see themselves reflected in the Presidency. This approach would strengthen a sense of shared ownership, particularly among EU citizens living abroad, and reinforce the idea of the EU as something that is lived and experienced through communities, not just governed from Brussels.

sector: Light Pollution and dark sky restoration
response_text: We present a proposal for the high-level thematic priorities that align with more-than our own vision as an NGO but that incorporate the people centered, future focused vision for the EU. We propose a theme of “Under One Sky” as the overarching high level theme. This offers a unifying metaphor to share challenges and opportunities across member states and beyond borders. This theme emphasizes equality, interconnectedness and is future oriented for stewardship, sustainability and strategic thinking. The sky is one resource literally shared by every European citizen. Whether in rural, remote or urban regions; every community lives “under one sky”. As a slogan, it resonates with themes of solidarity, belonging, equality and accessibility, all of which are central to the EU’s core values. The concept provides a narrative frame to articulate EU citizenship: freedom of movement, mobility, connectivity, cultural exchange, research collaboration, and the idea that European decisions have a common impact on all of us. The proposed theme “Under One Sky” reflects core themes within the EU’s Strategic Agenda 2024–2029 and the Nature Restoration Law, which requires action plans from Member states during the period when Ireland will be hosting the Presidency such as: Upholding the protection of nature and the reversal of ecosystem degradation. Connection of citizens in a thriving future oriented society of equality and inclusion. Strengthen Climate Action maintaining just transitions and human and planetary health.

sector: Light Pollution and dark sky restoration
response_text: The Irish Presidency can advance EU-wide coordination on policy areas pertaining to the regulation of light pollution, a recognised environmental pollutant (noted for its impact on biodiversity, energy/climate objectives, human health as well as scientific and cultural heritage). Several Member States, including Czechia and Spain, advanced this work during their Presidencies, demonstrating its significance as a pan-European issue for coordinated EU action. Building on this momentum would reflect Ireland’s role as a neutral facilitator while responding holistically to EU Member State needs. Including a focus on light pollution would draw directly on the scientific and policy recommendations set out in the Horizon Europe PLAN-B Policy Brief on Light Pollution Mitigation issued in 2025. Ref: https://zenodo.org/records/15707106 Nature Restoration Law: Light pollution is explicitly referenced in the texts of the Nature Restoration resolution, which calls on Member States to identify and mitigate artificial light pressures in their national restoration plans. The Irish Presidency could facilitate progress by: Hosting an expert-level discussion/meeting on integrating light pollution mitigation into the implementation phase of the Nature Restoration Law. Supporting work toward harmonised indicators for monitoring Artificial Light at Night (ALAN), aiding comparability across Member States and aligning with the EU Biodiversity Strategy and Global Biodiversity Framework 2030 to reduce light pollution. • Encouraging uptake of international guidance, such as the International Light Pollution Guidelines for Migratory Species (CMS) https://www.cms.int/publication/international-light-pollutionguidelines-migratory-species, to ensure EU legislation reflects current scientific consensus. Sustainable Use of Space & the Dark & Quiet Skies Movement: Dark and Quiet Skies is a global theme that raises awareness about the urgent need to preserve night skies from the negative impact of satellite constellations on ground-based optical and radio astronomy. Excessive light affects astronomy infrastructure including EU-supported observatories and satellite calibration. These concerns were central to the international IAU–UNOOSA “Dark & Quiet Skies ”initiative: https://www.eso.org/public/about-eso/dark-skies-preservation/ & https://www.iau.org/Iau/Iau/News/Ann2025/ann25010.aspx Following recent meetings: UN/SKAO Workshop on Dark and Quiet Skies for Science and Society in Vienna, and the Transnational Political Networks Workshops on Dark and Quiet Skies in Dublin, the Irish Presidency could facilitate further dialogue with scientific institutions, industry specialists and policymakers to enable both astronomy programmes (including cultural astronomy) and satellite projects to find mutually beneficial policy solutions. The Presidency could aim to achieve: An expert meeting or ministerial roundtable on Light Pollution, enabling knowledge exchange and preparing future EU initiatives building on work initiated in Czechia and Spain. A shared EU roadmap, to mitigate, monitoring and reduce Light Pollution and the impacts of ALAN across Europe. Support for including light pollution in the Commission’s 2026–27 work programme, within the frameworks zero-pollution, urban environment or biodiversity frameworks. Advance discourse within EU Member states on policy objectives for the Dark and Quiet Skies movement pertaining to the sustainable use of space. These actions show the Irish Presidential commitment to protect our shared environment across Europe, benefiting biodiversity, enhancing energy efficiency, improving health and wellbeing and preserving the night sky we all live under.

sector: Light Pollution and dark sky restoration
response_text: Light pollution is one of the few environmental pressures that can be reduced rapidly, cost-effectively, and with immediate positive outcomes. Reducing light pollution brings the following benefits to people, businesses and communities across the EU For people: improved sleep, wellbeing, access to nature, and restored views of the night sky as a shared cultural and scientific resource. For communities: safer, well-designed lighting solutions; enhanced public spaces; reduced municipal energy costs; and stronger engagement with environmental protection. For businesses: best practice European guidance on sustainable lighting; development opportunities for lighting and design industries in the EU; and innovation in satellite-friendly, astronomy-compatible technologies. For biodiversity and ecosystems: improved conditions for pollinators, migratory species, and nocturnal wildlife, supporting implementation of the Nature Restoration Regulation. These benefits reflect EU-wide priorities under the European Green Deal, Zero Pollution ambition, Biodiversity Strategy, and energy-efficiency objectives. Reducing light pollution strongly resonates with citizens across countries and cultures. The night sky is universally accessible; improvements are immediately visible; and improved access to dark sky parks and reserves for stargazing events and public-science activities is a growing issue of social justice.

sector: Light Pollution and dark sky restoration
response_text: This proposal to host an expert meeting or ministerial roundtable on Light Pollution follows the recent Artificial Light at Night Conference (ALAN) 2025, which we co-hosted (together with Mayo Dark Skies & NPWS) in Westport in October. The event was attended and officially opened by Minister Dara Calleary and was supported by Minister Christopher O’Sullivan. The recent iteration of ALAN 2025 was the first time this global event had been hosted in Ireland and it also facilitate the launch of the European Light Pollution Coalition which seeks to develop policy for light pollution measures across Europe. The European Light Pollution Coalition has a mandate to follow up. pertinent discussions arising from ALAN on policy and legislation at the next EU Presidency Meeting and seeks to follow up on Ireland’s agenda as a matter of urgency.

For its 2026 EU Presidency, Ireland should prioritise sustainable energy, rural resilience, and community-centred governance. In particular, the rapid scaling of biomethane under REPowerEU highlights the urgent need for independent impact assessments, strict environmental safeguards, and oversight of public subsidies to prevent unsustainable industrial-scale biogas projects. Ireland can lead by embedding legally binding rules on feedstock use, digestate management, and spatial planning, ensuring local communities have a real voice in decision-making rather than bearing disproportionate social and environmental costs. By championing a model that balances climate, biodiversity, and rural development goals, Ireland can set a European benchmark for fair, sustainable energy transitions. Prioritising transparency, equitable benefit-sharing, and preventative regulation will help avoid repeating mistakes seen elsewhere in Europe, reinforcing trust in decarbonisation policies. These thematic priorities will position Ireland as a leader in creating energy strategies that are both ambitious and socially responsible.

The European Commission’s REPowerEU action plan has set biomethane production on a course of massive upscale as part of efforts to increase EU energy independence, fixing a target of 35 billion cubic meters (bcm) per year by 2030 – up from 4,1 bcm in 2023. However, until this day, no Impact Assessment was carried out on the target. As biomethane production continues to grow rapidly both in Ireland and Europe (with a currently 21% year-over-year growth), so do concerns about its associated environmental and social risks as well as the irresponsible use of taxpayers money. While biogas production from sludge or collecting the gas that is produced in landfills is appropriate, there are particular concerns about the effects of large-scale biogas production on the use of limited agricultural land, the continuation of polluting industrial animal production, harm to local communities, and the effects of methane leaking from biogas facilities. Further concerns arise when looking closer at promoted use cases for biomethane such as heating or transport which are often inefficient, expensive, and lock Europe into existing fossil infrastructure. The Irish Presidency should therefore prioritize conducting an independent, interdisciplinary impact assessment to evaluate the feasibility and sustainability of this target, ensuring it aligns with climate, biodiversity, and rural community goals. Emphasis must be placed on implementing strict economic, environmental, and social safeguards for biogas and biomethane production. With reference to the Commission’s 2026 Work Programme as well as the wider EU Strategic Agenda that highlights the need to secure Europe’s energy independence, we therefore encourage the Irish Presidency to: Advocate for an independent impact assessment of the EU’s 35 bcm biomethane target, as a prerequisite to develop further any expansion of biomethane production as part of relevant policy files in 2026, such as the Circular Economy Act, Bioeconomy Strategy, Livestock Strategy, Energy Union Governance Upgrade, and Common Agricultural Policy. This includes prioritizing truly sustainable feedstocks, efficient use cases, and avoiding lock-ins of fossil infrastructure. Include the voices of local communities in the debate. In order to expand biomethane production rapidly, the 2025 REPowerEU roadmap foresees a “tripartite contract to better address the diverging needs in different areas of the EU and include national and local stakeholders”. However, a focus has been set on facilitating dialogue between the EU Commission, EU Member States’ governments as well as industrial stakeholders; and no commitment has been made to give a role to local communities themselves that are affected by such projects. In line with its “people-centred” approach, the Presidency should therefore intensify its efforts to give the Irish people and local communities across Europe a greater say in the development of fair and sustainable biomethane strategies. Scrutinise public subsidy schemes for unsustainable biomethane production. This is critical to prevent perverse incentives that undermine the EU’s climate, food security, and energy independence goals. Current subsidies often favour industrial-scale biogas projects reliant on unsustainable feedstocks - such as manure from factory farming or energy crops competing with food production - which lock in polluting practices as well as animal welfare violations, and divert resources from truly circular solutions. Without strict oversight, these subsidies risk distorting markets, inflating demand for unsustainable livestock farming, and sidelining local, community-led projects that deliver genuine environmental and social benefits.

Ireland’s presidency provides a unique opportunity to develop and promote a gold standard indigenous biogas industry that is sized and scaled to meet community needs. Learning from EU countries with an established biogas industry, Ireland can avoid the pitfalls of social acceptance that are consistently documented as barriers to bioenergy projects across the EU (Mancini & Raggi, 2022). Current regulatory gaps and weak planning assessments underestimate the cumulative impacts on rural infrastructure. Public health and safety questions about hazardous gas storage, particular emissions and emergency service access are heightened when regulatory oversight is perceived as reactive rather than preventative. Research has highlighted that digestate management and changes in feedstock mixes are critical risk vectors that demand much stronger regulation than is currently applied (Piadeh et. al, 2024). Ireland, through its presidency, can set the standard by developing industry-specific planning regulations that include community engagement at its core. The National Biomethane Strategy points directly to a highly industrialised model aimed at rapid development across rural Ireland. Within this model, revenue accrues to outside multi-national agri-investors while costs are borne by host communities in terms of road damage, odour, environmental degradation, and reduced property values. Communities demand transparent environmental impact assessments, accessible monitoring data and enforceable operating limits. The development of industry-specific planning regulations aligned with benefit-sharing mechanisms has the potential to provide a blueprint for use across the EU, while maintaining community engagement and the highest environmental standards. Meaningful community engagement, spatial planning that respects local carrying capacity, strict feedstock limits, alongside legally binding digestate management plans, are safeguards that would increase local acceptance. Rapid roll-out risks polarising rural communities, undermining trust in decarbonisation policy, and producing environmental and social harms that outweigh local benefits. Ireland has an opportunity through its EU presidency to either lead and develop new industry standards or to repeat mistakes already impacting the rural communities and the environment across Europe.

sector:
Rural and community transport  
 
Mayo Community Transport T/A TFI Local Link Mayo plays a pivotal role in delivering rural and community transport services across County Mayo under the TFI Local Link brand. Operating on behalf of both the National Transport Authority (NTA) and the Health Service Executive (HSE), the company ensures that people in rural and remote areas are not left behind when it comes to accessing essential services and opportunities.
response_text: As an overall theme: “Mobilizing all of Europe’s citizens and communities as active participants in the European Union”. The rationale for this theme is that the stated priorities in successive Presidencies, and in the programs of the Commission, focus on the “big ticket” items and are oriented to the institutions, corporations, business, opinion-formers and high achievers. Of course, these are important and drive Europe’s prosperity and security. But there does not seem to be much consideration to the “ordinary” people, places and businesses that constitute the vast majority of Europe, and indeed are its “foundation layer”. Large swathes of Europe’s people and places have lesser opportunities, especially rural areas (83% of the territory, 140 million people), lower-income suburbia, and second-/third-tier cities. These are increasingly being left behind and become disengaged. For many, it is difficult to see their part in Europe’s future, or to see positive prospects for themselves or where they live, or that policies of the Union are for their benefit rather than imposing burdens. Three priorities are proposed. These are consistent with the policy programmes of recent Presidencies, the Strategic Agenda for the Union and the Work Programme of the EC, but until now they have not been articulated or developed. Equalising Opportunity throughout the European territory. Much of Europe’s people and places not only have lesser opportunities, but perceive that gaps will only get wider, resulting in a two- or multi-tier society. This is unlikely to end well. More attention is needed to establishing a sense of balance and fairness, and improving prospects, in all parts of Europe. Accelerating the European Long-Term Vision for Rural Areas. The LTVRA is for a “Stronger, Connected, Resilient and Prosperous” Europe by 2040. The core pillars are not advancing equally, and some areas lack either obligations on the Member States and their region to deliver specific outcomes, or a structured program with funding to enable delivery. The physical connectivity part of the Connected pillar is especially lacking in plans, actions or funding. A fresh urgency is required to transform the “vision” to measurable “commitment”. Prioritising climate-related measures that can be delivered during 2027-2030. Much of Europe’s climate and decarbonisation strategy is based on technology, infrastructure, major investments, regulation and phasing out. These will only deliver at scale in the 2030’s and 2040’s. Many require significant cost for citizens. There are very many ordinary and pragmatic measures that can be delivered in the immediate term, by local-level organisations, communities and citizens. This is especially the case for rural mobility, where low-cost local measures can be rapidly deployed Europe-wide. These urgently need to be mobilised.

Mayo Community Transport CLG

Mayo Community Transport T/A TFI Local Link Mayo plays a pivotal role in delivering rural and community transport services across County Mayo under the TFI Local Link brand. Operating on behalf of both the National Transport Authority (NTA) and the Health Service Executive (HSE), the company ensures that people in rural and remote areas are not left behind when it comes to accessing essential services and opportunities.
response_text: This submission proposes that Rural Mobility is adopted as a work area under the Irish Presidency, and continued into the Lithuanian and Greek Presidencies through 2027. For clarity, “rural mobility” refers to the ability of people to move about and access whatever is relevant to them. It is about the full diversity of people in Europe being able to live their daily lives, and access all that they need, without being dependent on personal ownership and use of private cars. It also incorporates dimensions of accessibility to places and their businesses/amenities, and to tourism. The SMARTA project (2018-2020), initiated by the European Parliament and commissioned by DG MOVE, identified the lack of rural mobility policy through Europe’s Member States, or at the European level itself. By “policy” is meant defined goals, specified targets, assigned responsibility to deliver, and sufficient funding to achieve the agreed targets. The consequence is low/no provision of mobility service in most of Europe’s rural areas, despite Member States having all required competence, powers, organizational capacity and financial capacity. This is in stark contrast to the commitment, high quality and major funding of mobility for the urban areas of Europe. What should be the focus of the work for the Irish Presidency? The policy priority is to establish a requirement for all Member States to develop a Rural Mobility Policy, and to assign sufficient resources to deliver their policy. Key aspects to be incorporated in policy include: That citizens have reasonable physical access to avail of a broad defined range of opportunities and services, regardless of where in the Union they are resident; That rural mobility is explicitly integrated with rural development, population retention, restoration of services at local level, and the social/business fabric of rural areas; That mobility is measured, mobility deficits are identified and remedied to a committed standard; That GHG reduction and decarbonisation is an explicit part of rural mobility policy, and goes beyond electrification of vehicles, with particular focus on reducing Vehicle-Kilometres Travelled (VKT); That EU and national programs, such as the Social Climate Fund, are directed to improvements, and not towards compensation for problems that are not remedied. What should the Presidency aim to do and achieve? Convene workshops and other interactions to (i) define and dimension the issue; (ii) identify good practice and further options at policy, program and deployment levels; (iii) understand the regulatory, institutional and deployment frameworks around Europe and how they enable or inhibit development of rural mobility; (iv) explore why Member States and their regions have not to date acted to develop rural mobility to the level required by their citizens. Recognising the subsidiarity principle that local mobility is a competence of Member States, and that most (or all) Member States have to-date failed to plan and act to deliver adequate mobility throughout their territories, identify mechanisms at European level that will persuade or oblige Member States to act. Prepare recommendations for TRAN Committee to consider it as a work item.

response_text: The Council can guide the Member States to bring the organization, provision and quality of rural mobility to the level required and deserved by Europe’s citizens who live in rural areas, including smaller towns, villages and areas of dispersed population. By their nature, much of what is needed by the inhabitants of smaller towns, villages and rural areas of dispersed population is located elsewhere. Increasingly, services, amenities and employment has been concentrated in larger urban areas, so that even local towns are now being hollowed out. People in rural areas have to travel further and more often to access what they need. This includes services and amenities to which by are entitled under public policies - including healthcare, training social services, and access to the administration – but they cannot reach them or can only do so at high cost, due to the lack of public or other collective transport. The local businesses and amenities are impacted by the reduced customer base who can only reach them by car, while communities become increasingly isolated. The Council can reverse these trends and deficits by encouraging, and ultimately requiring, the Member States to implement sufficient and consistent levels of public and collective transport. It begins with defined goals and specific targets, which must then be followed up by deployment measures and funding allocation. For rural mobility/transport, this has a very short pipeline since there is only minimal infrastructure required (if any), vehicle fleet is readily available throughout rural areas, and it only takes some months to procure mobility services. Most importantly, the delivery structures are already in place through municipality administrations, rural development organisations (e.g. TCU’s, LEADER Action Group), the communities themselves and transport operators. The main requirement is political will and leadership. This is where the Council is ideally placed - and indeed may be the only entity – to give the needed push throughout Europe. This will have an immediate positive impact on the quality of life and opportunities for Europe’s rural residents. It will give those without the use of a car access to much of what they need. Rural youth will be better able to access opportunities and choose to remain, combatting depopulation trends. People of all ages will have better access to healthcare, which will also improve earlier detection for various conditions. Households will be under less pressure to purchase additional cars and be better off by reducing motoring costs. Rural businesses can access a larger customer base, while neighbouring rural villages and communities can form stronger clusters by having local connectivity. Rural tourism will be strengthened by enabling visitors to arrive and move within areas without their car. From the environmental perspective, there are major immediate gains in reducing carbon emissions by reducing vehicle-kilometres travelled (VKT). More people using people and collective transport leads to less vehicles converging on urban areas, thereby relieving pressures on the main access roads and demand for parking.

response_text: The best way to communicate the values and benefits of EU membership to its citizens is to make visible improvements to their daily lives, to overcome long-standing deficits and social exclusion, and to demonstrate a genuine interest to strengthening the places where they live. The best way to create a sense of ownership among citizens is to actively engage them and their immediate representative bodies (local-level administrations, NGOs, community groups) in shaping and delivering what is needed in the places where they live. As already noted, the institutional and community infrastructures are already in place throughout Europe to deliver rural mobility. It has already been amply demonstrated throughout the European rural development programs that the local-level is well able to develop a sense of ownership and responsibility for a very wide range of innovative and traditional initiatives. If they are empowered and given access to funding, developing the required operational and technical capacity for rural mobility is straightforward, as demonstrated in the SMARTA-NET project or the US Rural Transport Assistance Program. Benefits of European membership are very evident in cross-European networking, peer-to-peer engagement and know-how exchange. In the domain of rural mobility, this has been amply demonstrated in the SMARTA-NET project, in which over 70 rural municipalities and other stakeholders from 15 EU countries participated in the European Rural Mobility Network (ERMN). As a result of the high appreciation of the participants, the ERMN has now been established on a permanent basis to provide rural municipalities and stakeholders with a shared platform to develop their capacities.

response_text: This submission is based on continuity from previous programmes for the Irish Presidency to deepen these priorities for Europe’s rural areas, and carry them forward into subsequent Presidencies. The Programmes of recent Presidencies (e.g. Poland, Denmark) emphasise a Europe of equality and opportunity, in which “no-one is left behind”; access to healthcare; social and territorial cohesion; the climate emergency and commitments toward a net-zero Europe, and reduced dependency on imported fuels. These are also emphasized in the Strategic Agenda for the Union and the Work Programme of the EC. Under the Spanish Presidency, the Barcelona Declaration on “Mobility for people: advancing social and territorial cohesion” adopted in September 2023 recognises the importance of sustainable rural mobility needs as well as the need to increase investments in road infrastructure and public transport systems. https://www.lamoncloa.gob.es/lang/en/gobierno/news/Paginas/2023/20230922_barcelonadeclaration.aspx “Connected” is one of the four pillars of the European Long-Term Vision for Rural Areas, which deals with both physical connectedness (mobility) and digital connectedness. https://ruralvision.europa.eu/index_en However, the Commission’s own March 2024 report identifies the SMARTA-NET project as the only achievement in this area, and has no reference to actions on policies, programs, funding, or even anything beyond SMARTA-NET which ended in December 2024. https://eur-lex.europa.eu/legalcontent/EN/TXT/PDF/?uri=CELEX:52024DC0450 SMARTA project (2018-2020) identified that none of the EU Member States has an effective policy on rural mobility, backed by responsibilities and sufficient resource to deliver it. It made a set of Policy Recommendations on who to address the issue. https://ruralsharedmobility.eu/wpcontent/uploads/2021/03/Smarta-Policy-Recommendations_Final-Version_web.pdf The SMARTA-NET project (2022-2024), among other things, established the European Rural Mobility Network (ERMN). At the Final Conference held in the Berlaymont, the ERMN proposed a diagnostic on the key issues for rural mobility, and a set of policy recommendations, they key being: I1) assign the same importance to rural mobility as to urban mobility; (2) rationalize VKT to achieve European and national goals for accessibility and decarbonization; (3) convince Member States to develop policy and targets for rural mobility; (4) assign sufficient resources to deliver enhanced rural mobility, at scale; and (5) mobilise and empower the local level to deliver solutions. See chapter 5 of the ERMN report at https://op.europa.eu/fr/publication-detail/-/publication/084a5f52-6dc2-11f0-bf4e01aa75ed71a1/language-en The European Committee of the Regions report “Combatting transport poverty to strengthen European cohesion and competitiveness“ highlights the increasing prevalence of transport poverty and that “connectivity is essential for the economic, social and territorial cohesion of EU territories”, the “differentiated impact on women, single-parent families, young people, elderly people, people with disabilities and low-income groups”. It “highlights the role of publicy-funded public transport in creating accessibility and in connecting urban and rural areas”, but notes the “recurring lack of budgetary resources”. It notes that the Social Climate Fund will not be enough in itself to eradicate transport poverty. https://webapi2016.cor.europa.eu/v1/documents/cor-2025-02437-00-00-pac-traen.docx/content The POLIS Network provides a more blunt message that the Social Climate Fund must be used for measures to solve underlying problems rather than as a compensation mechanism, and not make matters even worse by further entrenching personal car ownership and use. https://www.polisnetwork.eu/document/fighting-transport-poverty-with-the-social-climate-fund/

geography: The UK’s relationship with the EU
response_text: Ireland is uniquely positioned to be able to promote greater cooperation between the EU and the UK, with mutual benefits in a time of serious and growing challenges to the whole European continent. The Review of the UK-EU Trade and Cooperation Agreement is expected to be concluded in 2026, probably during the Irish Presidency, and this could be an important moment to create new positive momentum for the EU’s relationship with the UK. The EU-UK Summit of 2025 concluded with a declaration of a Common Understanding of the way forward for the two parties. The Summit largely reached agreements in principle rather than legally operational text and the Common Understanding is limited in its ambitions, but nevertheless a platform has been established for improving the UK’s interactions with the EU. The Summit achieved significant progress on an SPS Agreement and some initial steps on Security and Defence, but nothing of substance on Mutual Recognition and Professional Mobility. The Conservative European Forum is concerned that the positive (if limited) outcomes of the May Summit have not been realised in concrete agreements and little progress has been made since then. It calls on both the EU and the UK to engage constructively with greater urgency. An ambition of the Irish Presidency could be to achieve operational texts completing the Review of the TCA and fulfilling the goals of the Common Understanding by the end of its term. As priorities, the CEF urges the EU and the UK to make rapid progress on; Enhancing the EU-UK Security and Defence Partnership Securing a Sanitary and Phytosanitary (SPS) Agreement Negotiating a Mutual Recognition Agreement (MRA) on Conformity Assessment Bodies Improving Professional Mobility Establishing a Youth Mobility or Experience Programme The majority of the provisions of the existing Security and Defence Partnership Agreement relate to enhanced dialogue and information sharing. Under the Irish Presidency this dialogue should be deepened and orientated towards actions. The provisions of the Understanding indicate that a comprehensive Common Sanitary and Phytosanitary Area agreement is envisaged, leading to the free movement of agricultural products. On issues of mobility between the UK and EU, the Common Understanding’s focus was on young people and students, touring artists and the management of eGates. However, the Understanding stated that a dialogue on individual travel for business purposes should be initiated. Although there is a lack of transparency about the status of talks, a Youth Mobility Programme appears to be under active discussion. With clear benefits for both sides, any outstanding points should be quickly resolved with flexibility and goodwill on both sides. While resolution of some of these issues may occur before the commencement of the Irish Presidency, there are still likely to be areas where Ireland can make a significant contribution to achieving greater understanding between the two sides. Ireland’s familiarity with the details of the EU-UK relationship through its experience of the Northern Ireland Protocol and the Windsor Framework means that it will be well placed to achieve new agreements and deepen cooperation.

geography: The UK’s relationship with the EU
response_text: The Common Understanding states at three points that its conclusions should be acted upon “swiftly”. While many of the issues under consideration are complex, negotiations between the parties should be expedited and urgent attention given to more areas where expanded cooperation can bring benefits to both the UK and the EU. In particular, the CEF suggests that the Irish Presidency should focus on the following areas of work. Given the security challenges facing Europe from Russia and the apparent isolationism (if not hostility) from the United States, it is overdue that the EU and the UK should move on from dialogue to actual cooperation on security and defence issues. Despite the Common Understanding declaring that the EU’ s rearmament fund (Security Action For Europe) creates “possibilities for mutually beneficial enhanced cooperation” it is disappointing and concerning that negotiations over UK participation in SAFE have broken down. It is hoped that both sides can move quickly to define the process under which participation can take place in the areas identified by the Security and Defence Partnership. Although the UK has stated that it is willing to participate selectively in Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP) missions, this would be facilitated by a Framework Participation Agreement that would define the scope of participation more closely. The Irish Presidency can assist the UK and EU to • Conclude a Framework Participation Agreement (FPA) to enable the United Kingdom’s selective participation in missions and operations. • Finalise an Administrative Arrangement (AA) with the European Defence Agency (EDA), allowing UK involvement in key projects under the Permanent Structured Cooperation (PESCO) framework. Although CEF seeks a comprehensive and evolving reset of the EU-UK relationship it sees no reason why the SPS Agreement should be delayed by negotiations on other aspects of the Common Understanding. • To maintain the progress achieved with the Common Understanding, if not already concluded the Irish Presidency should enable the UK and EU to finalise and implement an SPS Agreement as soon as possible. The absence of any reference to Mutual Recognition in the Common Understanding is a missed opportunity to develop cooperation in this important area. This could be achieved on the basis of the previous MRPQ Directive and the historic degree of regulatory alignment rather than sector-by-sector negotiations. The CEF hopes that the Irish Presidency may • Negotiate a comprehensive UK–EU Mutual Recognition of Professional Qualifications (MPRQ) Agreement to restore widespread recognition of UK professional qualifications across the EU. Enhanced mobility can bring mutual benefits, especially in many aspects of professional and business services. The Common Understanding makes provision for dialogue in these areas but as yet there is no clarity about this process. The Irish Presidency could lead a dialogue between the UK and EU on how to • Expand the range of short-term business activities permitted without a visa, including client meetings, training, and project delivery.

geography: The UK’s relationship with the EU
response_text: People, businesses and communities across the EU can benefit from closer engagement with their UK counterparts. Increased economic and cultural exchanges can provide a new impetus for growth and create new opportunities, especially for young people. These exchanges will build enhanced trust, as a basis for even closer integration in the future. In an age of geopolitical insecurity, binding the UK into a range of relationships with the EU can strengthen the Union’s strategic and economic autonomy. The UK can be of use to the EU for many issues, especially defence, and the EU should continue to build a framework of agreements within which the UK can contribute to the EU meeting its goals. The Irish Presidency can be the occasion to improve and formalise economic and trade relationships in key sectors of interest to the EU, through the establishment of Joint Industry Cooperation Discussion Bodies.

geography: The UK’s relationship with the EU
response_text: Ireland’s Presidency can be the occasion to communicate a positive vision for the EU, as a realistic but confident player on the global stage. The EU during the Presidency should be seen as actively defending and promoting its values in all its interactions with its neighbours and partners. Citizens should experience an EU that both resolutely defends its and their interests from adversaries and cooperates positively and generously with partners.

geography: The UK’s relationship with the EU
response_text: The Conservative European Forum (CEF) recognises a significant opportunity to build on the Trade and Cooperation Agreement (TCA) and forge a strengthened partnership with the European Union in the context of the new spirit of cooperation represented by the Windsor Framework. Due for review in 2025/26, the TCA is a free trade agreement that ensures zero tariffs and quotas on goods moving between the UK and EU but contains fewer provisions for services, an area critical to the UK economy, and little in the way of foreign and defence policy cooperation. On 27 February 2023, the Conservative European Forum (CEF) initiated an Inquiry into the Trade and Cooperation Agreement (TCA), led by Sir David Lidington and Stephen Hammond MP. Throughout the following year, CEF conducted nine evidence sessions with over 40 witnesses from business, industry, and non-governmental organisations. The Inquiry highlighted that there exists considerable potential to implement practical, industry-driven solutions both within and outside the TCA framework, to strengthen UK-EU relations in areas of mutual self-interest. The Windsor Framework, established in February 2023, resolved disagreements over the Northern Ireland Protocol, fostering a cautious re-building of trust. The TCA’s upcoming review in 2025/26 coincides with the expiration of several key provisions, presenting an opportunity to reassess the relationship in light of geopolitical shifts. Despite remaining widespread scepticism, there is now some initial interest in discussing access to the Customs Union or Single Market. Any changes must be navigated within the existing framework of the TCA or through the negotiation of supplementary agreements. The Inquiry categorised recommendations for enhancing UK-EU cooperation into two primary areas: economic and political. Economically, the emphasis is on reducing trade barriers, while politically, the focus is on strategic collaboration, particularly in foreign and defence policy as outlined in the Political Declaration. Priority should be given to recommendations that provide the greatest benefit, either politically or economically, and that have a realistic opportunity to be agreed.

geography: Rural. Mannok is located on the border between the Republic (Cavan) & Northen Ireland (Fermanagh)
response_text: Mannok as a group is a leading supplier of essential innovative building products such as bulk and bag cement, aggregates, Insulation, precast, roof tiles and concrete blocks (light/heavy) to ROI/NI & GB markets. Mannok Pack is a standalone business providing sustainable packaging solutions to both local and international markets. As one of the largest employers in the region (800 No.) aspiring to be a leader in sustainability, Mannok would like to see a strong focus on mobility decarbonisation using hydrogen which cannot be electrified i.e. heavy long-range trucking (Heavy Goods Vehicles - HGVs). As an Island nation with an underdeveloped rail network, nationally Ireland is heavily dependent on HGVs to move goods both around and in/out of the country. Trucks or HGVs have a disproportionately large impact on emissions due to their weight and average mileage. Mannok owns its own large fleet of trucks, 200 No. They all currently operate on diesel, which is atypical for all fleet operators across the E.U. Mannok is currently developing an ambitious and innovative green hydrogen project where the primary off taker is the fleet to displace its diesel equivalent. The fleet consumes over 4 million liters of diesel a year, which is equivalent to nearly 11,000t/CO2eq. Mannok is just one of many such fleet operators. The HGVs are used to transport products, fuels and raw materials daily on the Island of Ireland. Local haulage companies deliver our products to G.B. Additionally at least 40-50 HGVs arrive daily at Mannok either as a supplier or a customer. This demonstrates significant off-taker potential, economies of scale and will help support the Government in meetings its obligations under the Climate Action Plan and national emissions targets. Mannok is technology agnostic whether the HGV’s platform is based on hydrogen fuel cell, combustion engine or re-power option. The key criteria is for cost parity with its diesel equivalent. This will require significant investment and collaboration across the entire value chain. Ireland’s E.U. presidency in 2026 offers a unique opportunity to advocate for businesses, hydrogen mobility and decarbonisation. Mannok believes our objectives align very well with that of the Department of Transport (& Department of Infrastructure in NI) desire to see hydrogen refuelling stations (HRS) built in Dublin and Belfast as part of an All-Ireland energy project and the European Union's mandate under the Alternative Fuels Infrastructure Regulation (AFIR) to build a widespread hydrogen refuelling network – One every 200 km on the Trans European Transport Network (TEN-T) core network and in urban nodes by 2030. Mannok is located on the border c100 miles or 160km from the nearest port. The ability of a company like Mannok to decabonise its fleet at scale and deliver its products to the market cost competitively is existential to the future of the business, its employees, customers and the community it serves. Let’s keep Ireland moving and the E.U., sustainably.

sector:
Drinks Ireland is the Ibec sector organisation representing drinks manufacturing, export and supply businesses across the island of Ireland. 
We represent all categories of alcohol products in one umbrella organisation through our various groups. 
Drinks Ireland | Beer 
Drinks Ireland | Cider 
Drinks Ireland | Spirits 
Drinks Ireland | Wine 
Irish Whiskey Association
response_text: The Irish Presidency will take place at a pivotal time and Ireland has a leadership opportunity to influence the EU agenda and strengthen its role into the future through driving discussions on key policies. Drinks Ireland, the Ibec sector organisation representing drinks manufacturing, export and supply businesses across the island of Ireland, welcomes the opportunity to contribute to this Government consultation and outlines below the highlevel thematic priorities, we believe, Ireland should focus on during this period. Single Market Integrity The Single Market is one of the EU’s most valuable assets. Despite its benefits for the European economy, the Single Market remains incomplete and is delivering well below its potential. With the European Commission’s recent Single Market Strategy and the Single Market Roadmap to 2028, we call on the Irish Presidency to turn those ambitions into action and remove barriers fragmenting the free movement of goods, services, labour and capital. Effective Single Market governance will be key through greater harmonisation, coherent implementation and shared responsibility for enforcement. Likewise, maintaining a level playing field for businesses and ensuring fair competition must remain a central tenet of the Single Market while improvements are made as outlined in the Ibec paper on the Single Market and Simplification: Turning Ambition Into Action. Competitiveness To strengthen the EU and react to the challenges facing business and society, we need to put competitiveness at the forefront. The Presidency must act as a leading voice for a rulesbased trading system, advance the EU-UK relationship and act as a bridge to strengthen the vital EU and US relationship. EU policymakers should also move away from over-reliance on legislation and adopt stronger investment and proactive growth measures to address challenges faced by business. Underpinning competitiveness through practical, evidencebased legislation, which is approached on an EU harmonised basis, is also critically important. Trade openness must also be at the core of the Irish Presidency’s agenda. With 85% of future economic growth predicted to take place outside of Europe, a proactive, outwardlooking common trade policy, paired with the ability to attract investment, remains among the EU’s most powerful assets. Digital Solutions To support the further development of the Single Market, the Irish Presidency should help deliver a meaningful framework and programme to support digital-first solutions such as digital labelling. A stable, predictable, effective and coherent digital regulatory framework will facilitate EU competitiveness, investment and growth, creating conditions for digital innovation.

response_text: For the Irish business community, it is positive that the European Commission’s 2026 Work Programme places emphasis on enhancing competitiveness and pushing forward with legislative simplification. The simplification agenda remaining at the forefront is in line with calls from business for a pause in the introduction of new legislation in order to ensure proper implementation of new rules from the previous mandate. Drinks Ireland outlines below the policy areas that the Irish Presidency should consider prioritising during its term. Harmonised approach across sectoral product legislation (labelling) The Irish Presidency should ensure a general harmonised approach across sectoral product legislation, where necessary, to avoid fragmentation of the Single Market and creation of an additional cost burden for business. The emergence of national schemes and additional labelling and packaging requirements disrupt the trade of goods across the EU. National measures such as labelling requirements and bans on EU approved substances are particularly prevalent in the food and drink sector. When such measures are introduced, they undermine EU harmonisation efforts, result in trade distortions in the Single Market and create an additional cost burden for business. Recent legislation requiring the unilateral introduction of new alcohol labelling provisions in the Irish market is a key example of this. We welcomed the two-year deferral of these provisions. Moreover, we fully agree with the comments made by the Taoiseach, Tánaiste and a number of Government Ministers that such labelling requirements should really be pursued ‘in concert’ with the EU as a harmonised EU approach maintains the integrity of the EU Single Market and avoids unnecessary trade disruption. We are equally cognisant in the context of restoring trade relations with the US, that the US Administration has identified such unilateral member state legislation as a non-tariff trade barrier, undermining its exporters to efficiently serve the EU market. Action in this area, as part of the Irish Presidency, will address the key themes of Single Market Integrity and Competitiveness. Trade, Market Development and Diversification In the absence of long-term stability and predictability, the Irish Presidency must support the strengthening of existing bilateral partnerships, while delivering new agreements that simultaneously enhance trade cooperation with third countries and deliver new market diversification opportunities for business. The delivery of actions agreed at the 2025 EU-UK Summit and the 2026 review of the EU-UK Trade and Cooperation Agreement offers significant opportunities to advance the EU’s relationship with its third-largest trading partner accounting for the realities of the all-island economy. The EU-US Joint Statement can also provide concrete opportunities for business. The Irish Presidency period could be crucial to making further progress towards restoring trade relations with the US, in particular, to delivering as extension of tariff exclusion for the drinks sector and restoring zero for zero tariff trading position. Ireland will have an important role to play in supporting the advancement of new free trade agreements and EU enlargement. Our industry needs ambitious trade agreements that encourage trade relations through reduced tariffs, removal of non-tariff barriers, protection of our Geographic Indications for Irish Spirits and safeguarding our All-Island cross-border supply chains through appropriate rules of origin. Concluding a meaningful and competitive EU-India free trade agreement is a high priority for the Irish drinks sector. Digital-first (e.g., eLabelling) approach Digital labelling should be embraced to improve the functioning of the single market and reduce compliance costs for economic operators. It allows for the enhanced provision of information to consumers, accommodating additional information and the ability to provide and make changes in different languages in a more efficient manner.

response_text: Ibec’s broader priorities for Ireland’s Presidency of the Council of the EU in the second half of 2026 are set out in Making a Resilient, Competitive EU a Reality: The Business Ambition for Ireland’s EU Presidency. Ibec recognises this leadership opportunity, and during the Presidency we will champion a European approach that makes resilience the foundation of competitiveness, an outward-looking, confident, and investment-ready Europe that delivers stability and opportunity for business and citizens alike.

response_text: Use the unifying slogan as the narrative anchor, “Ní neart go cur le chéile / There is no strength without unity” See unity as an achievable aim and find ways to promote same. Highlight real-life stories of how EU action protects rights, livelihoods and communities. Champion Consequential Participation Work with schools, youth organisations, migrant groups, women’s organisations, disability advocates, rural networks, and faith communities to ensure broad participation. Develop an interactive online portal with accessible multilingual content. Create real-time feedback loops e.g.“You said → We did.” C) Transparency and visibility Publish schedules, livestream events, summarise outcomes plainly, and show how citizen input changed positions or priorities. Include national parliaments, media, community and faith groups, amongst others, as partners. Honest and accessible communication Explain benefits and trade-offs clearly using examples that mamer to daily life: consumer protections, digital rights, women’s equality, workplace standards, environmental safeguards, and freedoms linked to mobility and education. Sponsor programmes in Irish schools This could include things like neighbourhood or school based art competitions based on showing how belonging to the EU throughout the 70s and 80s, changed the lives of more than half of the population of Ireland. Namely women. There is plenty of information available on the before and aaer. Visits to EU institutions would also be educational and memorable for young people.
