In light of the increased EU military spending, growing tensions and the apparent absence of peace initiatives from the EU, it is imperative that the theme of the Irish Presidency should be one of PEACE

Foreign Affairs Proper communication channels, where both sides in a conflict could be heard by unbiased intermediaries, is an enlightened way to resolve conflict. I would therefore propose the immediate establishment of a European Peace Centre, where mediation in situations of current conflict could occur; additionally, it could be a centre for peace studies and work in the prevention of conflict. There is growing apprehension in the people of the EU, of an entity such as NATO which has a militarized response to threat. I would therefore propose that neutrality be seen in a positive light, and the preferred stance of EU countries.

Ireland is a peaceful nation, and has never colonized another country. We have a long and well-respected history as peace-keepers with the United Nations, and the Good Friday Agreement in Northern Ireland is a testament to our ability to resolve a long standing conflict. We are well positioned to shed light on troubled relations between the EU and other countries, and therefore to guide the leaders to ways of resolving conflict peacefully.

A sense of ownership of the values and benefits of EU membership among Irish citizens will only occur when people want to own these values. Opinion poll after opinion poll has shown that Irish people want to be peacemakers and to have our government act as such. Therefore the EU must move away from strategies such as “Rearm Europe” and begin to take peace seriously. In addition, the influence of the arms trade on EU foreign policy must be seriously questioned.

The Irish Constitution states that “1 Ireland affirms its devotion to the ideal of peace and friendly co-operation amongst nations founded on international justice and morality. 2 Ireland affirms its adherence to the principle of the pacific settlement of international disputes by international arbitration or judicial determination.” I hope that the Irish Presidency will uphold these values for the sake of peace in Europe and beyond.

This submission encapsulates the EU Long-Term Vision for Rural Areas 2040 goals of building stronger, connected, resilient, and prosperous rural areas, while championing the 'right to stay' in rural areas - the ability of citizens to live, work, and thrive in the rural places they call home. Given Ireland’s history of leading rural development practices and processes in Europe, and that we are one of the few countries in Europe with a dedicated Ministry for Rural Development (the Department of Rural and Community Development and the Gaeltacht), the Presidency of the Council in 2026 is happening at an apt time and opportunity to continue this leadership role. The EU Rural Pact has particularly highlighted the key role the dedicated Government Department plays in its leadership of one of Europe’s few National Rural Strategies: ‘Our Rural Future’. A high-level rural policy thematic focus is important and necessary during Ireland's 2026 Presidency, primarily serving to translate the high-level Long-Term Vision for Rural Areas (LTVRA) into concrete action and secure its future funding. This directly aligns with the EU Strategic Agenda for 2024-29, which prioritises a Europe that is free and democratic, strong and secure, and prosperous and competitive. It also builds on previous Member States’ contribution to rural policy during their Presidencies, such as Spain’s High-Level Rural Policy Forum in Siguenza, September 2023. By furthering the goals of the LTVRA, Ireland’s Presidency can contribute concretely to bolstering competitiveness, supporting innovative rural territories, and developing green and digital transitions. As part of this, three high-level thematic priorities are identified here that address the core socio-demographic challenges of depopulation and inequality faced by rural areas, rooted in the LTVRA's four action areas (Stronger, Connected, Resilient, Prosperous Rural Areas). Strengthening Territorial Cohesion and the 'Right to Stay': This priority makes the 'right to stay' a central political theme, focusing on the fundamental living conditions needed to retain and attract rural populations. It addresses the persistent socio-economic gaps and aims to reduce disparities between rural and other areas, a key objective under Article 174 TFEU (https://eurlex.europa.eu/eli/treaty/tfeu_2008/art_174/oj/eng). Connecting Rural Europe: Connectivity, both physical and digital, is cited as a most urgent need by rural citizens. The focus should be on practical, sustainable solutions, advancing legislative work on digital infrastructure while promoting innovative integrated rural mobility plans that ensure essential access to services, employment, and education for all rural inhabitants. Empowering Local Communities and Economic Diversification: This theme highlights the need for a truly bottom-up approach to development. It supports the Prosperous and Resilient LTVRA pillars by fostering new, non-traditional economic activities beyond the primary sector. It champions Community-Led Local Development (CLLD/LEADER), the social economy, and remote work, ensuring that local communities have the capacity and resources to innovate and manage their own transitions.

Considering Vice-President Fitto’s ‘Right to Stay’ Initiative, which he outlined in a speech on September 16th, 2025, to the Rural Pact Conference in Courtrai, Belgium, Ireland is particularly well-placed in its Presidency to develop this policy and related legislation in 2026. As a predominately rural country, and as leaders in rural policy in Europe, Ireland can focus work on the following themes that would help to address the Right to Stay initiative, and keep the Long-Term vision central: Driving the Transition from Vision to Concrete Action The Long-Term Vision for Rural Areas (LTVRA) and the Rural Pact have established a vision for rural policies and areas, but it requires continuous, high-level political push to move from planning to implementation. A Presidency focus is necessary to: provide a platform to advance Council priorities (such as rural housing and mobility/connectivity), ensuring these issues are discussed at the Ministerial level. Establish a 'Right to Stay' Mandate by championing the right of citizens to live and thrive in their home communities. This focuses the entire rural agenda on addressing depopulation and service access. Ensuring Policy Coherence and 'Rural-Proofing' Rural policy challenges, such as connectivity and access to services, cut across multiple EU policy areas (agriculture, cohesion, transport, digital, etc). The Council Presidency has a unique role in coordination, by supporting a high-level forum to bring together key Ministries and Directorate-Generals (DGs) to coordinate efforts and enhance the coherence and synergies between policies and funding instruments (such as the new proposals for Cohesion Policy and the Common Agricultural Policy). Influencing the Post-2027 Financial Framework The second half of 2026 is a crucial period for influencing the debate on the next EU Multi-Annual Financial Framework (MFF) and the structural funding programmes (post-2027). The Presidency provides a high-profile platform to advocate for adequate, ring-fenced financial support for non-agricultural rural initiatives, such as Community-Led Local Development (CLLD/LEADER). Ireland will also have the opportunity to define the next programme of the EU by building on previous events such as the Siguenza High-Level Forum (2023; under Spain’s Presidency), by serving as a key step in defining the direction of rural and cohesion policies post-2027, ensuring that the new budgetary cycle is fit for the LTVRA goals. Amplifying Local Voices and Promoting Ownership Focus on Multi-Level Governance by listening to the voices of rural actors, in particular Local Action Groups (LAGs), civil society, and regional authorities, and members of the Rural Pact community. This participatory approach is essential for legitimacy.

The Irish Presidency can make the most substantial positive impact by translating the goals of the LTVRA into concrete, people-centred outcomes that demonstrate the EU's commitment to Territorial Cohesion, Rural Development, and the ‘Right to Stay’. This can be done by directly addressing the cost of living and quality of life for those living in or wishing to return to live in rural areas. By prioritising rural housing, the Presidency can directly tackle a critical barrier to the 'right to stay.' In addition, supporting rural areas by championing CLLD/LEADER, the Presidency can amplify rural voices and ensure that local communities and civil society organisations are seen as essential partners, not just recipients, in policy implementation. This strengthens local capacity and creates a sense of ownership over EU initiatives. Finally, there can be an impact on future-proofing rural economies, by focusing on economic diversification, the social economy, and digital upskilling, ensuring that rural areas are positioned to benefit from the Green and Digital Transitions. This creates new, quality job opportunities, particularly for young people and women, thereby combating depopulation and making rural life a viable, attractive choice for future generations. Based on the above, a key focus could be: Rural Housing - contribute to the EU focus on housing by launching an EU-level Initiative/Expert Group on Rural Housing, addressing the demographic and housing challenges identified in the LTVRA. Aim to inform the post-2027 Cohesion policy framework by identifying policy flexibility and best practices to unlock funding for affordable, quality rural housing development. Community-Led Local Development (CLLD/LEADER) - As part of the Post-2027 Financial Framework Discussions, secure a strong political statement, reaffirming the necessity of CLLD/LEADER as a mandatory, bottom-up governance model for all Member States. Specifically, advocate for ring-fencing of an adequate, visible budget share from relevant EU Funds (Cohesion, CAP) to protect this successful participatory model from budgetary cuts. Rural Mobility & Services - Drive progress on transport, energy and digitalisation to incorporate a ruralproofing requirement, ensuring new EU infrastructure legislation explicitly addresses the needs of sparsely populated areas. Focus on the deployment of digital solutions to ensure equitable access to public and private services (health, education) across rural territories.

Host a Major Event in a Rural Location: Instead of holding all major events in Dublin, the Presidency should host a High-Level Rural Policy Conference (building on Siguenza 2023) in a prominent Irish rural town or regional city (e.g. in the West or North-West). This would symbolise the Presidency's commitment to rural Europe and grants citizens outside the capital direct involvement and ownership. The EU Rural Pact – there is an opportunity to host a meeting of the Rural Pact Coordination Group in Ireland during the Presidency. The RPCG holds approximately three meetings per year, usually in Brussels, but there is now a shift in focus under the continuing mandate of the RPCG, whereby it is envisaged that one of those meetings per year, will be held in a member state. Ireland could therefore be the first Member State to host a meeting of the RPCG, which is comprised of representatives from DG AGRI and DG REGIO, the European Parliament, civil society, research agencies, and social enterprise. Translate Policy into People's Stories: Communication should shift from bureaucratic legislative summaries to showcasing real-life stories and local project successes. Highlight how an EU Cohesion/Structural Fund investment leads to a new local service, an affordable housing scheme, or a community transport solution. This links the abstract values of solidarity and cohesion to the tangible benefits of EU membership. Amplify Rural Pact Voices: The Presidency should actively use the established networks of the Rural Pact Support Office and local groups to share information, host webinars, and provide capacity-building on new legislation. By engaging directly with the 2,350+ members of the Rural Pact community, the Presidency demonstrates that it is listening to, and acting on, the needs of the rural electorate.

There is an opportunity during this Presidency to move the agenda of the LTVRA forward. This can be done in collaboration with Rural Pact Support Office (RPSO), the Rural Pact Coordination Group (RPCG) of which the author of this submission is a member, and the Rural Pact Framework Ireland (RPIF) which is being led by University College Dublin (UCD). RPCG: https://ruralpact.rural-vision.europa.eu/RPCG_en Rural Pact Framework Ireland (RPIF): https://ruralpact.rural-vision.europa.eu/commitments/rural-pactireland-framework-rpif_en

We propose that the overarching theme of the Irish EU Presidency should be a growing, competitive and inclusive Europe. This theme reflects Ireland’s ambition to contribute to a Union that is resilient, forward-looking, and capable of delivering prosperity for all its citizens. In particular, these priorities directly reinforce the EU SME competitiveness agenda by equipping small and medium enterprises with the skills and capabilities needed to thrive in digital transformation and the green transition. Within this overarching vision, a key priority stands out: investment in education and training. Our conversations with employers and partners consistently highlight two key areas of acute skills shortages (i) digital and responsible AI adoption, and (ii) sustainability. This priority and these skills areas are directly aligned with the EU Strategic Agenda 2024 – 2029, specifically under the heading “A Prosperous and Competitive Europe.” The Agenda highlights the need for: “Investment in people’s skills, training and education throughout their lives and encouragement of talent mobility within the European Union and beyond.” This priority underlines the importance of equipping citizens with the right blend of skills to thrive in a rapidly changing labour market. It also reflects the urgency of addressing talent shortages, as evidenced by the 2024 Eurobarometer survey and ACCA’s Global Economic Conditions Survey (GECS) in 2025, both of which identify skills gaps as the most pressing risk for businesses. The draft EU Talent Pool Regulation further recognises the accountancy profession as one of 42 critical shortage professions, underscoring the need for targeted investment in education and training. (i) “Digital and responsible AI adoption” Ireland’s Presidency should highlight the responsible use of digital technologies and artificial intelligence. Innovation and digitalisation are essential drivers of competitiveness. While the importance of an ethical governance frameworks that safeguard citizens and businesses and the need for a clear legal foundation have been expressed elsewhere, there is also a need for training in the development and implementation of digital technologies and artificial intelligence. This is particularly relevant as their use is extended to support the implementation of legislation such as the Omnibus Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive (CSRD). (ii)“Sustainability” Delivering on Europe’s twin transitions is central to long-term prosperity. The Presidency should promote policies that help citizens and businesses adapt to sustainability requirements, while ensuring that the workforce has the skills and knowledge to support these changes. A diverse and inclusive workforce is essential to achieving this, and professions such as accountancy play a pivotal role in guiding companies – particularly SMEs – through evolving EU rules and compliance obligations. Accountancy also play a key role in assisting SME and larger businesses in achieving the competitive advantage that being sustainable brings. By framing Ireland’s Presidency around these priorities, the Council can help deliver a Europe that is competitive, inclusive, and sustainable. This approach not only reflects the EU’s strategic vision but also addresses the immediate challenges of talent scarcity, digital transformation, and the green transition. It ensures that citizens, businesses, and communities across the Union experience the benefits of EU membership in tangible and lasting ways.

While impartiality is a defining feature of any Council Presidency, Ireland has an opportunity to shape discussions in ways that reflect both national priorities and the wider needs of the Union. Education and training stand out as particularly important areas. Ireland’s ranking of 33rd out of 35 economies in the Hays Global Talent Tracker highlights weaknesses in talent value, labour market flexibility, and education and training systems. This poor performance points to under-investment and misalignment in preparing the workforce for future needs. Supporting evidence from the Future Skills challenge report by Skillnet Ireland and the ACCA Global Talent Trends Europe report 2025 report reinforces these findings, emphasising the need for modular training, micro-credentials, bootcamps in high-demand areas, enhanced apprenticeship schemes, and stronger partnerships between industry and education providers. Against this backdrop, the Irish Presidency should aim to advance several related initiatives under the European Commission’s Work Programme 2026. These initiatives will help address Europe’s talent shortages, strengthen competitiveness, and prepare the Union for future challenges. First, under A new era for European Defence and Security, the Presidency should support measures to attract and retain talent that contributes to EU economic growth. This includes advancing reforms to the EU visa strategy and exploring a “28th regime” to foster SME innovation and entrepreneurship. Such measures will help ensure that Europe remains a hub for innovation and entrepreneurship, while addressing critical workforce gaps through access to training. Second, under Supporting People and strengthening Europe’s social model, Ireland should champion proposals such as the Quality Jobs Act, the Fair Mobility Package, Skills Portability Initiative. These initiatives, alongside a comprehensive Education Package, will strengthen lifelong learning frameworks and ensure that citizens can adapt to changing labour markets. By promoting fair mobility and skills recognition, the Presidency can help create a more inclusive and resilient workforce across Member States. Finally, under Preparing for the Union of tomorrow, the Presidency should advocate for a modern, flexible, and well-funded EU budget. Clear communication and accessible funding streams for upskilling, reskilling, and training will be essential to ensure that citizens and businesses can take advantage of opportunities created by the green and digital transitions. By making EU funding more transparent and easier to access, the Presidency can help bridge the gap between policy ambition and practical implementation. Taken together, these policy areas directly advance the Commission’s Work Programme 2026 and respond to Europe’s most pressing challenges. By focusing on talent development, fair mobility, and accessible funding, Ireland’s Presidency can help deliver a Union that is competitive, inclusive, and prepared for the future.

The Irish Presidency can deliver the most substantial positive impact by ensuring that Council work translates into tangible improvements in skills, competitiveness, and inclusivity across the Union. Building on the EU Strategic Agenda 2024–2029, the Presidency should focus on three interlinked areas: Empowering people through lifelong learning: By prioritising Council discussions on education, training, and skills portability, the Presidency can help citizens adapt to the green and digital transitions. This includes advancing modular training, micro-credentials, and apprenticeships, ensuring that workers at all stages of their careers can retrain and remain employable. Such measures directly address the EU’s talent shortages and strengthen resilience in communities. Supporting businesses in compliance and innovation: The Presidency can facilitate smoother implementation of EU legislation such as the Omnibus CSRD. By encouraging dialogue between policymakers and professions like accountancy, businesses - especially SMEs - will gain clarity and confidence in meeting new reporting and compliance obligations. This builds transparency and trust in capital markets, while also enabling innovation and competitiveness. Strengthening communities through inclusivity and mobility: The Presidency should champion initiatives that promote fair mobility, skills recognition, and inclusive labour markets. Communities benefit when citizens can move freely, transfer skills across borders, and access quality jobs. This strengthens the social fabric of the Union and ensures that no region is left behind in the twin transitions. By focusing Council work on these areas, Ireland can help deliver a Presidency that is not only impartial but also impactful - ensuring that EU citizens, businesses, and communities experience the benefits of membership in their daily lives.

To foster a sense of ownership, communication must be visible, relatable, and personal. Citizens engage most when they see how EU membership directly improves their lives. The Irish Presidency should therefore highlight initiatives that deliver tangible benefits: Visibility through skills and training programmes: Just as EU structural funding is made visible through signage on infrastructure projects, EU-supported training and skills programmes should be clearly branded and promoted. Citizens participating in upskilling or reskilling initiatives will see the EU’s role in their personal development, creating a lasting connection between membership and opportunity. Storytelling that connects values to everyday life: Communication should emphasise how EU values - solidarity, sustainability, and inclusivity - translate into practical benefits. For example, showcasing how EU-backed training enables mid-career transitions and makes abstract policy real and relatable. Engagement through local and digital platforms: The Presidency should leverage community organisations, universities, and professional bodies to co-host events and campaigns. Digital platforms can amplify these stories, ensuring that citizens across Europe feel part of the Presidency’s work. Celebrating professional contributions: Professions and trade association provide the framework for qualifications and also provide the training opportunities and as such play a pivotal role in providing training and upskilling opportunities for EU citizens. Highlighting their contribution demonstrates how EU membership empowers trusted professions to support businesses and communities. Transparency through corporate reporting: Companies should include disclosures in their annual reports highlighting investments in education and training, and specifying which areas were supported by EU funding. This practice would encourage organisations to reflect on their overall education strategy while making the EU’s contribution visible to stakeholders. By making EU initiatives visible, personal, and connected to citizens’ aspirations, Ireland’s Presidency can strengthen public trust and foster a genuine sense of ownership over both the Presidency and EU membership itself.

Ireland should choose Health as a central theme for its 2026 Presidency, with a specific focus on allergy preparedness, public awareness and emergency response training. Allergies are now one of the fastest-growing public health concerns across Europe, and the scale of the issue underscores the need for coordinated EU action. A Presidency focused on this area would deliver clear, practical benefits to millions of European citizens. The rise in allergic conditions is well documented. The prevalence of peanut allergy among children in Western countries has doubled in the past 10 years (Du Toit, 2015). Across Europe, severe reactions are becoming far more common, and food allergies alone now affect an estimated 11 to 26 million European citizens (Pawankar et al., 2013). These are everyday realities for families and schools, and the trend is moving in only one direction. Yet preparedness and awareness vary widely between Member States. Many individuals carry emergency medicines but are unsure when or how to use them. Many schools and community organisations lack clear training pathways or have inconsistent procedures for responding to anaphylaxis. These gaps increase the likelihood of delayed treatment and unnecessary medical escalation, placing additional strain on healthcare systems already facing significant pressures. - Establishing EU-wide minimum standards for allergy and anaphylaxis training, ensuring that training is affordable, accessible and delivered consistently in all Member States. -Launching a coordinated EU allergy awareness campaign, aimed at increasing recognition of allergic reactions, improving public confidence in responding to emergencies and reducing preventable harm. -Supporting Member States to expand access to emergency medicines training in schools, workplaces and community settings, accompanied by harmonised EU guidance so organisations can act confidently and lawfully.

Ireland’s Presidency should focus on practical health measures that can be delivered quickly, especially those that strengthen emergency preparedness, raise public awareness and create more consistency across Member States. Allergy readiness fits well here because it affects schools, workplaces, food safety and public health, and it is an area where EU-level coordination can make a real difference without needing new complex legislation. The first priority should be to make better use of existing EU health frameworks. The EU already supports training, capacity building and exchange of best practice, but allergy preparedness is not built into this work in a meaningful way. Ireland can use its Presidency to ensure that allergy awareness and basic emergency response skills are included in the wider health security and prevention agenda. A second area should be improving consistency in training and preparedness. At the moment, every Member State has its own way of training teachers, childcare staff and people working in public spaces. Some have clear systems, others do not. Ireland can encourage agreement on shared minimum standards for responding to allergic emergencies and promote access to accredited training that can be recognised across the EU. From here, Ireland can put forward a straightforward principle: workplaces and schools across the European Union should be equally prepared to deal with allergic emergencies. Right now, the level of readiness varies a lot. Some places have trained staff and proper procedures, while others have very little in place. Ireland can use the Presidency to highlight the need for simple EU-level guidance that helps Member States build reliable systems for schools, employers and community organisations. This can include promoting access to online training that can be used across the EU. Online options would make training easier for staff and volunteers in every country, giving organisations of all sizes a practical way to build confidence and ensure that people know how to recognise and respond to an allergic reaction.

The Council can make a real and practical impact by helping ensure that schools, workplaces and community settings across the EU are equally prepared to deal with allergic emergencies. At the moment, the level of training and awareness varies widely between Member States, which leaves gaps in safety for people who rely on others knowing how to respond. Ireland’s Presidency can push for simple, shared standards on allergy awareness and basic emergency response, along with easy access to recognised training, including online options. This would give teachers, employers and community groups clear guidance and the confidence to act when needed. Making allergy preparedness consistent across the EU would improve safety for millions of European citizens and provide a straightforward, positive legacy from Ireland’s Presidency.

The best way to show the benefits of the EU is by taking actions that improve people’s everyday lives. If Ireland focuses its Presidency on practical issues that citizens can clearly recognise, such as safety, health and community wellbeing, people will see the EU’s value in a real and personal way. Keeping messaging clear, involving schools and community groups and highlighting direct results will help citizens feel connected to the work of the Presidency and confident that EU membership delivers for them.

Ireland’s focus during its Presidency of the Council should be placed on health policies to ensure the Union’s security and preparedness for emerging health threats, as well as ambitious Single Market policies, both in line with the Commission work programme for 2026. Making the Single Market Work - The work programme outlines a focus on “unleashing the full potential of the Single Market by 2028”. According to the Commission, this would mean removing barriers and making doing business in Europe easier for all companies, including startups and SMEs. The Irish Presidency’s thematic priority on the Single Market should reiterate Member States’ commitment to the internal market and include more active enforcement policies and infringement procedures where violations of Single Market rules and unjustified internal trade barriers are detected in Member States. Health Policies - Such actions on the Single Market also relate to the quality of health policies – when the Single Market works as it is intended for all products, medicines included, it improves the resilience of health systems’, mitigates shortages and improves patients’ access to needed therapies and affordable medicines. When it comes to health policy, we believe that health and the accessibility of medicines must be part of the overall security and preparedness agenda and should therefore be part of the thematic priorities of the Irish Presidency. Well-functioning health systems, sustainability in costs of healthcare and ensured access to the therapies needed for patients are prerequisites to stable societies and health systems that also work in times of crisis.

We would like to see a focus on the Single Market-related policies outlined in the Commission work programme for 2026 and swift progress on these legislative negotiations. European Product Act - It is important to ensure that the biggest Single Market initiative of the work programme, the European Product Act, including the principles of open competition and removal of internal trade barriers such as unjustified export restrictions on goods, are strongly pursued. This is particularly important for pharmaceutical products, given that their free movement is heavily disrupted in many parts of the Union due to the restrictive measures being implemented by some Member States. Public Procurement Act – The Public Procurement Act, expected in Q2 of 2026, is an equally important piece of legislation that has the potential to further ensure fair competition and the equal standing of different legitimate actors in the market, and we would like to see this legislation advanced promptly. Critical Medicines Act - If the trilogue negotiations of the Critical Medicines Act are still on-going during the Irish Presidency of the Council, it would be important to reach an agreement and ensure that the final agreement on the Critical Medicines Act protects the principles of the Single Market, including open competition and reasonable procurement criteria. Medical Devices - Equally, quick progress on the revision of the medical devices rules, the proposal of which is expected from the Commission by the end of 2025, would be vital to ensuring predictability and harmonization in the market.

In general, we believe the most impactful policies for all EU citizens derive from a clear commitment to EU-wide actions in all policies. When working on health policies and the Single Market, the emphasis should be placed on EU-wide angles and harmonising actions, instead of separate national actions that could then considerably differ from one Member State to another. When it comes to Single Market policies especially, separate national actions are often counterproductive to the objectives of the Single Market. A Single Market Focus - The single most effective action to make the most substantial positive impact for people, businesses and communities alike would be a strong focus on the Single Market and policies that improve the functioning of the internal market, and its enforcement. The Single Market is indeed European Union’s greatest achievement because it facilitates the everyday life of European businesses and consumers and fosters growth. Unfortunately, until recently, it has been ignored in European decision-making. The Single Market Strategy, published in May 2025, was a good start, but not yet enough. There are still products, medicines being one category, for which a true Single Market does not exist. Intra-EU trade barriers, export restrictions and other actions that hinder the functioning of the Single Market remain strongly in place. This is an issue that both undermines business operations and the lives of consumers who ultimately are the ones suffering from poor enforcement of the Single Market rules, be it in the form of higher prices, lower quality products, medicine shortages and poorer access to affordable medicines and health therapies.

We believe a campaign to increase awareness of the Single Market, communicating its benefits for citizens, would increase knowledge about the European Union and how it functions and impacts the lives of EU citizens for the better. This would also create a sense of ownership and commitment to the Single Market and the wider Union among citizens. Single Market Mitigating Shortages of Medicines - This campaign should provide concrete examples of the functioning of the single market for medicines, including examples of how the Single Market in medicines is helping to mitigate shortages of individual medicines in different EU Member States and provide citizens with improved access to affordable medicines. Concrete examples such as this (impacting the lives of ordinary citizens) would help increase commitment to the European Union project and understanding its benefits among citizens.

In this section, we wish to provide additional information on our association to clarify our role in the pharmaceutical market. About Affordable Medicines Ireland - Affordable Medicines Ireland is an association that represents the entire volume of the independent distribution of medicines industry in Ireland. Its member companies are all privately owned small- to medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). Affordable Medicines Ireland is affiliated to its European counterpart, Affordable Medicines Europe, the association representing the independent distribution of medicines in numerous EU and EEA countries. Within the European Single Market, independent distributors can buy pharmaceuticals in any EU/EEA country and then - under strictly regulated conditions – transport, repackage and resell them in another Member State. By redistributing medicines between countries at prices lower than standard local rates, independent distribution boosts competition and generates savings for patients and healthcare systems. Parallel distribution also helps alleviate shortages and improves access by supplying markets affected by availability problems, marketing delays, nonlaunches, or withdrawals. By utilising the Single Market, the parallel distribution of medicines saves approximately 5-7 billion euros to healthcare systems in Europe every year. Affordable Medicines Europe General Assembly Dublin, November 2026 - Affordable Medicines Europe is governed by its Board and General Assembly, taking place twice a year. During the Irish Presidency of the Council of the EU in November 2026, Affordable Medicines Europe will organize its General Assembly in Dublin in close cooperation with Affordable Medicines Ireland. In the context of this event, we would be happy to explore collaboration possibilities, for example organizing an event in collaboration with the Presidency of the Council on access to affordable medicines and sustainability of healthcare systems. To learn more about Affordable Medicines Ireland, please go to www.affordablemedicinesireland.ie To learn more about Affordable Medicines Europe, please go to www.affordablemedicines.eu

Ireland should frame its 2026 EU Presidency around a people-centred, future-focused vision of the Union that strengthens democratic participation, builds resilience, and deepens the connection between citizens and the EU’s work. I recommend three high-level themes: 1. “A Union Citizens Understand” – Strengthening Trust, Transparency & Engagement Public understanding of EU policymaking remains limited across Member States. Strengthening the link between citizens and European decision-making should be a core Presidency priority. Ireland is well placed to lead initiatives that make EU decisions clearer, more accessible, and more connected to daily life. This includes simplifying communication around Council outcomes, legislative negotiations, and the reasoning behind Ireland’s positions. As someone who recently spent a year on Erasmus, I saw first-hand how exposure to European institutions builds awareness and belonging, and how essential it is for young Europeans to understand the EU’s role in shaping their future. 2. “A Resilient, Fair Transition” – Climate, Digital, and Social Preparedness Europe faces simultaneous transitions: climate neutrality, digitalisation, demographic change, and geopolitical uncertainty. Ireland’s Presidency should emphasise fairness and social inclusion across these transformations. Priorities could include accelerating implementation of the Green Deal, strengthening Europe’s digital governance, progressing files linked to energy security, and ensuring that vulnerable communities, rural regions, young people, and workers in transition sectors, are supported. 3. “A Europe that Works for Young People” – Skills, Mobility & Opportunity Ireland should champion youth voices across the Presidency. Building on Erasmus, mobility programmes, and Europe’s Skills Agenda, Ireland can highlight how the EU improves opportunities for education, work, and participation. Including young people in Presidency events, consultations, and Ministerial conferences would strengthen the intergenerational legitimacy of the Presidency. Across all three themes, Ireland can build a Presidency that is accessible, ambitious, and rooted in strengthening trust in the European project.

Ireland’s Presidency should prioritise progress in areas where the EU faces significant shared challenges and where Ireland can act as an honest, credible broker. Key areas include: 1. Climate, Energy & Environmental Transition Progressing ENVI and TTE files linked to: Fit for 55 implementation, renewable energy integration, energy security, circular economy initiatives, sustainable agriculture. A focus on fairness, particularly for rural regions and young workers, will help maintain public support for the Green Deal. 2. Digital Regulation, AI, and Cybersecurity The Competitiveness Council will continue to handle: AI governance, platform accountability, digital competition rules, data flows and cybersecurity. Ireland’s position as a tech hub gives it credibility to steer consensus while prioritising public trust and fundamental rights. 3. Education, Skills, Youth & Mobility Under EYCS, Ireland should advance initiatives that strengthen student mobility, mutual recognition of qualifications, youth participation in EU processes, and Europe-wide skills development. This aligns with Ireland’s strengths and supports Europe’s long-term competitiveness. 4. Health & Crisis Preparedness Progress under EPSCO should include HERA, cross-border health cooperation, and digital health tools, building on lessons from the pandemic. 5. Economic & Financial Coordination Under ECOFIN, Ireland can support efforts to strengthen economic resilience, foster innovation, and ensure coherent implementation of fiscal rules in line with the Union’s long-term stability. Across these areas, Ireland’s aim should be to act impartially while ensuring progress on major legislative files that benefit the whole Union.

Ireland’s Presidency can create substantial positive impact by prioritising clarity, fairness, and accessibility. 1. Make EU policymaking more understandable Many citizens struggle to understand what the EU decides and how it affects them. Ireland can address this by: publishing simple explainers on Council outcomes, translating complex legislation into everyday language, using social media and Irish regional media to communicate key decisions, hosting public dialogues linked to Presidency milestones. Increasing transparency strengthens trust and counters misinformation. 2. Support fair and inclusive transitions Climate and digital transitions disproportionately affect rural regions, young workers, and small businesses. Ireland can help shape files that ensure support mechanisms, reskilling pathways, and regional development tools reach these groups. This enhances cohesion and economic resilience across the EU. 3. Bring the Presidency to communities Ireland should organise Presidency events not only in Dublin but across the country. Regional discussions, local authority events, and campus engagements would allow people to feel included in Europe’s work and encourage participation. 4. Promote innovation & competitiveness Businesses will benefit from progress on digital legislation, innovation incentives, cybersecurity frameworks, cross-border data flows, and simplified access to EU funding. By focusing on communication, inclusion, and transparency, Ireland can ensure the Presidency brings real value to people across Europe.

To strengthen citizens’ sense of ownership over the EU Presidency, communication must be clear, relatable, and accessible. 1. “EU Weeks” on every major campus Ireland should host EU Presidency Weeks across universities and institutes of technology. These events could include: interactive sessions with Ministers, MEPs, EU officials, workshops on Erasmus+, mobility, and EU careers, simulations of Council negotiations, panels explaining how EU laws are made and how Ireland shapes them. As an Erasmus alumnus, I saw how proximity to EU programmes builds belonging, this should be replicated at home. 2. Make EU decisions easy to understand Ireland should publish short, visual summaries explaining: the decisions made in each Council formation, Ireland’s priorities, why these decisions matter for citizens. Clear communication is essential for strengthening democratic legitimacy. 3. Local community engagement Town hall events, regional Presidency roadshows, and local authority partnerships can connect the EU’s work to everyday life, from farming and transport to education and digital skills. 4. Highlight real people’s stories Sharing stories from Erasmus participants, apprentices, small business owners, or community groups shows the EU’s benefits through lived experience. These actions would build trust, visibility, and ownership over Ireland’s Presidency.

Ireland’s Presidency is an opportunity not only to steer major EU files, but also to strengthen Ireland’s identity as a constructive, outward-looking Member State. Young people should have a meaningful role in Presidency events and consultations. Building opportunities for youth participation, especially those with Erasmus or cross-border experience, will support intergenerational trust in the European project.

respondent_type: Professional membership body for the HR profession
sector: Professional accreditation body – recognised by QQI
response_text: Skills, Lifelong Learning & Workforce Mobility To ensure that workforce competitiveness is maintained and progressed across the EU and that the workforce is fit for the AI and digital driven landscape ahead. A focus on supporting skills, lifelong learning and workforce mobility would ensure that workers gain access to upskilling and reskilling opportunities, which would increase career mobility across borders and sectors. Supporting older people to update their skills and stay in the labour market or pass on their experience can create shared prosperity. The Quality Jobs Roadmap Ensuring that the fundamentals of good quality jobs are in place will lead to higher productivity and increased labour market participation, along with strengthening economic and social cohesion. This requires high labour standards which need clear regulatory framework that is easy to work with and promotes innovation so that further good quality jobs can be created, which attracts further investment and the best talent. The AI opportunity Embracing the digital and AI opportunity will boost labour productivity and address skills and labour shortages. Adopting and integrating AI into jobs design will also positively impact work-life balance and flexibility, with tasks being performed faster through the use of AI, allowing workers to focus on higher-value tasks, contributing to better quality jobs, whilst ensuring human-centric digital transformation.

respondent_type: Professional membership body for the HR profession
sector: Professional accreditation body – recognised by QQI
response_text: Strengthening Collective Bargaining in the workplace Ireland success and competitiveness has been long built on the principle of voluntarist tradition and collaboration between government, workers and employers. Empowering and encouraging all stakeholders in way this has enhanced trust and transparency and supports better work and working lives. Security and defence to protect all citizens Cyber security measures need to be at the forefront which should be based on further development of the European Cybersecruity Framework. Furthermore, evolution of the principles on data access, digital identity and protections needs to be collaboration by all stakeholders, providing frameworks for ethical people analytics, privacy, algorithmic decision-making which supports EU principles of human-centric, compliant digital workplaces. Skills, Mobility & EU Labour Market Data Supporting skills framework interoperability will enable EU talent mobility and enhance a data-driven approach to strategic workforce planning and the commensurate infrastructure and support service required. Understanding the talent gaps enables all stakeholders to develop upskilling models. Cross Border Remote Work & Social Security Co-ordination By promoting rules for cross border social security and tax alignment, this will support the right to stay and citizens remaining in the workplace for longer. By providing practical tools for employers and policymakers, this supports mobility and reduces administrative barriers. EU Pay Transparency Directive (2023/970) By harmonising pay reporting, pay gap analysis, transparency rules, through providing employer readiness tools, templates, evidence on pay equity. This will build the EU’s reputation in gender pay equity and fair remuneration. Directive on Adequate Minimum Wages (EU 2022/2041) Support continued implementation across Member States; promote social dialogue and wage-setting frameworks balanced with competitiveness. Providing evidence on wage-setting practices, productivity links, and how employers manage cost pressures, so that the EU is seen as a fair, balanced mediator between worker protection and business competitiveness.

respondent_type: Professional membership body for the HR profession
sector: Professional accreditation body – recognised by QQI
response_text: As Ireland prepares to hold the EU Presidency in 2026, CIPD Ireland has a unique opportunity to help shape an agenda that prioritises people-centred, sustainable and future-ready policies. By acting as a strategic adviser, thought leader, convener and capacity builder, CIPD Ireland can ensure that the Presidency delivers meaningful benefits for workers, employers and communities throughout Europe. First, CIPD Ireland can embed the voice of people professionals directly into EU policy discussions, ensuring that employment, skills and workplace issues are approached with robust evidence and practical insight. The Presidency will accelerate negotiations on critical files ranging from digital transformation and AI governance to social rights, labour mobility and equality. CIPD Ireland can support Irish officials by producing timely policy briefs, research summaries and impact assessments that clarify how proposed EU measures will affect workplaces. This enables Ireland to champion policies that balance competitiveness with fairness and wellbeing, setting a people-focused tone for the Presidency. Second, CIPD Ireland can act as a leading hub for workforce intelligence, generating research that addresses Europe’s most pressing labour challenges. This includes shortages in critical skills, the need for large-scale digital and green upskilling, the changing psychological contract, and the impact of technology on job quality. Through partnerships with European HR bodies, academic institutions, Eurofound, and industry groups, CIPD Ireland can publish cross-national insights and propose scalable solutions. These outputs can inform EU strategies and help policymakers design interventions that support inclusive labour markets. Third, CIPD Ireland can maximise positive impact by convening dialogue among employers, unions, civil society, communities and policymakers. Hosting Presidency-aligned conferences, HR summits, workshops and community outreach events will foster shared understanding across stakeholder groups and ensure that diverse voices are heard. Such forums can focus on themes like decent work, sustainable leadership, community resilience, workplace innovation, and the role of HR in the green transition. By nurturing constructive social dialogue, CIPD Ireland can contribute to more balanced and socially grounded EU outcomes. Fourth, CIPD Ireland can empower organisations across the EU to implement new policies effectively. As EU legislation advances particularly around pay transparency, AI in HR, platform work, and occupational wellbeing employers will require guidance. CIPD Ireland can develop practical toolkits, professional development programmes, compliance workshops and case studies that support businesses in translating policy into effective practice. In doing so, it ensures that EU ambitions lead to genuine improvements in working life and organisational performance. Fifth, CIPD Ireland can showcase Ireland as a model for innovative, ethical and community-centred people management. Highlighting examples from Irish organisations particularly those excelling in sustainability, employee voice, hybrid working, skills development and inclusion can inspire peers across Europe and reinforce the Presidency’s emphasis on high-quality work and resilient communities. Finally, CIPD Ireland can champion an overarching Presidency narrative focused on people, purpose and prosperity. By connecting workplace policies to broader societal goals social cohesion, community wellbeing, climate resilience and long-term economic success the organisation can help ensure that Ireland’s Presidency leaves a legacy of more human-centred, future-proofed policy across the EU

respondent_type: Professional membership body for the HR profession
sector: Professional accreditation body – recognised by QQI
response_text: A multi-media approach to storytelling and socializing the values and benefits of EU membership is the most optimal way to communicate to the citizens of Ireland, nationwide. A tv campaign like the “My future Fund” advertisement would be particularly effective. Given the level of radio listenership in Ireland – radio teasers are very impactful. Bus stop, train station and motorway billboards reach all parts of Ireland. Flyers delivered to households would ensure reach to multi-occupancy dwellings. Regional Citizens Information gatherings in local neighbourhood municipal venues where everyone can benefit from hearing at first hand the values and benefits of EU membership would ensure total inclusion.

respondent_type: Professional membership body for the HR profession
sector: Professional accreditation body – recognised by QQI
response_text: As Ireland assumes the EU Presidency in 2026, the Chartered Institute of Personnel and Development (CIPD) in Ireland is well positioned to play a strategically important role in shaping European discussions on work, skills, labour markets and organisational practice. The CIPD’s optimal contribution involves acting as a thought leader, policy influencer, research partner, and convenor of practitioners across Europe. First, CIPD Ireland can position itself as a leading voice in shaping EU-level employment and social policy debates. The Presidency period will bring heightened attention to themes such as the future of work, digital transformation, AI regulation, labour mobility, social dialogue, and workplace equality. CIPD Ireland can provide evidence-based policy recommendations to Irish government departments, particularly the Department of Enterprise, Trade and Employment, to inform Ireland’s negotiating positions at Council meetings. This includes publishing concise policy briefs summarising HR and people-management implications of key EU dossiers, offering comparative European insights, and ensuring the voice of the HR profession is embedded in policymaking. Second, CIPD Ireland can act as a knowledge hub on workforce skills and talent development, aligning its research and thought leadership with EU policy priorities such as the European Skills Agenda, the Green Transition, and digital upskilling. During the Presidency, it could launch special reports developed with universities, employers, and European HR bodies on cross-border talent flows, workplace innovation, and the impact of emerging technologies on jobs. By providing data-driven insights, CIPD Ireland can support policymakers in making informed decisions that enhance Europe’s competitiveness and social cohesion. Third, CIPD Ireland can strengthen social dialogue by facilitating collaboration between employers, trade unions, government, NGOs, and HR professionals. Hosting high-profile forums, roundtables and summits timed to coincide with official Presidency events would elevate Ireland’s leadership on employment issues. Such gatherings could explore themes like inclusive workplaces, sustainability-driven workforce change, and the evolving psychological contract. Through these events, CIPD Ireland can help translate EU-level policy goals into practical implications for organisations. Fourth, CIPD Ireland can promote Ireland as a centre of HR excellence within Europe. The Presidency presents an opportunity to showcase innovative Irish people-management practices, particularly in sectors with strong European relevance such as technology, pharmaceuticals, financial services and climate-related industries. CIPD-led case studies, site visits and practitioner exchanges with counterpart organisations (e.g., National College of Ireland and other collective membership bodies) would deepen international cooperation and highlight Ireland’s capabilities. Fifth, CIPD Ireland can support organisations operating in Ireland in understanding and preparing for EU regulatory changes. As policy discussions accelerate during the Presidency, employers will need clear guidance on upcoming directives whether related to platform work, AI governance, pay transparency, or worker protections. CIPD Ireland can provide timely briefings, compliance guides and training programmes to help HR teams navigate evolving standards. Finally, CIPD Ireland can act as a champion for ethical and sustainable people practice across Europe. By emphasising evidence-based HR, wellbeing, diversity, ethical AI adoption, and long-term workforce resilience, CIPD can help ensure that the Presidency’s legacy includes a more human-centred, future-ready European labour market.

Community Food Projects, specifically community gardens and allotments. According to the international federation of allotments gardens, there are over 3 million allotment gardens families in Europe, across 14 European member countries. The allotment garden movement in Europe has been tied to social life for more than 100 years. The allotment garden movement offers space for humans and for nature. These spaces are a component of European culture. As such, promoting community food projects throughout the Presidency of the Council in 2026 would be an EU-wide theme centred on people, sustainability and integration. https://www.jardins-familiaux.org/pdf/E_INFO_2016.pdf
How best to support community food projects throughout Europe.
Supporting and promoting community food projects throughout Europe.
Through the development of policies that support and promote community food projects throughout Europe.
