Ireland’s Presidency of the Council presents an opportunity to champion a policy agenda that reinforces the EU's role as a global leader in healthcare and pharmaceuticals. GSK proposes the theme of Better Health, Stronger Europe (rooted in prevention and health security) which centres on securing Europe’s long-term health and economic sustainability Ireland should prioritise Prevention to address the growing ageing population and its associated public health challenges during the Presidency. This demographic shift, mirrored across the EU, is projected to accelerate, with those aged 65+ expected to constitute 32.5% of the EU population by 2100, up from 21.6% in 2024. This ageing population is increasingly affected by chronic diseases, posing significant challenges to healthcare sustainability and economic stability. More generally disease prevention as a policy tends to cost less than treatment. Ireland should focus on life course immunisation, which involves protecting health at every stage of life—from infancy to older age. This approach can reduce healthcare costs, maintain workforce productivity, and ensure a healthier, more resilient society. Vaccination also plays a critical role in combating antimicrobial resistance (AMR), with increased vaccine coverage potentially preventing thousands of deaths annually. Ireland should champion the prevention of respiratory infections such as influenza, COVID-19, pneumococcal diseases, and Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV). These infections are leading causes of comorbidities, hospitalisation, and death across the EU. Despite the availability of effective vaccines, immunisation coverage remains below target in many EU countries. The Presidency presents an opportunity to reaffirm the EU’s commitment to health security and full implementation of SDG 3.3: ending HIV, tuberculosis (TB), viral hepatitis, and other sexually transmitted infections (STIs) as public health threats by 2030. In the European Union/European Economic Area (EU/EEA), nearly 800 000 people are living with HIV (PLHIV) and over 24 000 new HIV diagnosis occurred in 2024. Half of those diagnoses were at a late stage of infection (48%) (ECDC 2025) which highlights major gaps in prevention, testing and treatment across Member States. Furthermore, one in six of all PLHIV (17%) has not achieved viral suppression (ECDC 2025). Effective treatment that can address barriers related to adherence and stigma, such as Long Acting Injectables (LAIs), can play a crucial role in maintaining viral suppression, thereby preventing HIV transmission and contributing to ending the HIV epidemic (Parczewski et al., 2025). An Office of Health Economics report (OHE 2025) warns that, without intervention, new HIV cases could cost EU health systems €57 billion by 2030. In Ireland, the number of PLHIV is projected to rise, with the cost of inaction expected to increase by 17%, to €125 million. Ireland is positioned to get Europe back on track to achieve SDG 3.3. HIV remains a critical yet under-prioritized dimension of Europe’s communicable disease landscape. Ireland should reaffirm its 2004 HIV leadership by hosting a high-level conference to renew the Dublin Declaration and establish clear priorities for ending HIV in Europe, including expanding community-based testing, improving EU-wide surveillance, and investing in innovative LAIs for HIV treatment and prevention.

Ireland is a leader in immunisation and a key supporter of the UNAIDS 2030 targets and should lead by example in both areas to develop Council Conclusions and Recommendations: A conclusion calling for Member State action and urging the Commission to develop an updated EU Action Plan on HIV and AIDS. A recommendation on the prevention of respiratory infections The timing of the Presidency also facilitates promoting legislative initiatives to mitigate against unforeseen consequences of the General Pharmaceutical Legislation and progress proposals for regulatory flexibility and the provision of EU Health Funding. Developing Conclusions & Recommendations: Ireland’s leadership on HIV, reflected in its National Sexual Health Strategy 2025-2035, positions it well to champion renewed EU action. A core priority should be the adoption of Council Conclusions calling for Member State action and urging the European Commission to develop an updated EU Action Plan on HIV and AIDS. To support this, Ireland could leverage the high-level Presidency conference to forge consensus on coordinated action. Ireland is a leader in immunisation driven by high vaccine uptake- meeting the WHO 75% target for flu vaccine in older adults, through evidence-driven decision-making, and early adoption of new preventive measures. Therefore, Ireland could develop Council Recommendations on the prevention of respiratory infections to send a strong signal of EU commitment to disease prevention, health system resilience, and preparedness. GSK supports the Steering Group on Prevention of Respiratory Infections’ call on the Council to make a new recommendation to Member States calling on them to: Invest in immunisation to meet current and future public health needs. Implement an annual EU-wide coverage target for COVID-19, RSV and pneumococcal disease using the influenza 75% target as a benchmark strengthen integrated surveillance and data collection by expanding influenza surveillance systems to include COVID-19, pneumococcal disease and RSV. Address vaccine miS/disinformation to strengthen vaccine confidence. Legislative Initiatives As the GPL is finalised it is imperative that a balanced, innovation-friendly regulatory framework, underpinned by sustained EU investment in biomedical research is supported. Such a framework will be essential for mobilising the scientific and industrial capacity needed to accelerate progress toward treating diseases e.g., ending HIV in Europe by 2030. Yet, under proposed changes to the GPL, innovators face fragmented regulation, uncertainty around incentives and rigid market access obligations, including disproportionate paediatric market-launch requirements for low-volume products like paediatric HIV treatments. The EU Biotech Act presents an opportunity for the Irish Presidency to address these barriers and improve regulatory flexibility by supporting needs-based market access pathways and offering alternatives to mandatory paediatric launches across all Member States with adult indications. Sufficient EU-level health funding should be a priority. The Presidency should ensure that the forthcoming Horizon Europe (Framework Programme 10) and European Competitiveness Fund within the next Multiannual Financial Framework allocate adequate resources for treatment, prevention, testing, and care services, including community-led responses for HIV, TB, hepatitis, and STIs. Securing sustained investment in health will be critical to protecting health, human rights, and social stability.

The Presidency should promote health equity, inclusion, and community leadership with a focus on reducing inequalities in HIV, cardiovascular, respiratory and other infectious diseases. It can demonstrate how EU-level decisions translate into real benefits for citizens, businesses and communities. A Presidency narrative focused on prevention and health security will help citizens see the tangible value of EU cooperation HIV disproportionately affects marginalised groups, including LGBTIQ+ communities, migrants and women. Yet all along the prevention and treatment cascade key populations face significant barriers to accessing HIV services. (Lancet, 2020). Black women encounter particularly low access to PrEP due to stigma and systemic mistrust (Whelan et al., 2023). In 2023, migrants accounted for over half of new HIV diagnoses in the European Union (ECDC, 2025) , with an estimated 30% of these infections acquired post-migration (Mann et al., 2024). Reducing these disparities, including by investing in innovative, non-stigmatising options such as LAIs for HIV treatment and prevention, would improve health outcomes, strengthen workforce participation, and reduce healthcare costs. Embedding civil society and communities in policy development must also be a central pillar of the Presidency. Communities are best placed to design effective interventions, and their involvement leads to more accountable policymaking. The Presidency should therefore embed these principles and values in its policy agenda. Building on Spain’s 2023 Presidency, which placed HIV stigma elimination at the core of its health agenda, Ireland could go further by embracing a “nothing about us without us” approach. This would include embedding HIV considerations within broader EU frameworks such as the EU Gender Equality Strategy and the European Pillar of Social Rights. It could also encourage Member States to conduct equity impact assessments across health programmes, ensuring that EU policies actively reduce inequalities. A core impact of the Irish Presidency could come from actions that reduce time-to-treatment gaps and support predictable, efficient regulatory pathways. Embedding patient voices in HTA and regulatory processes ensures that innovation reaches people who need it most. Strengthening life-course immunisation will deliver major benefits—protecting citizens, reducing hospitalisations, preserving workforce productivity and supporting AMR strategies. The Adult Immunisation Board (a group of experts on Adult Vaccination) will hold their country meeting in Ireland during the Presidency; Ireland should support the Board meeting with a positive impact on adult vaccination. In addition to HIV, progress on disease-focused initiatives such as cancer, respiratory and cardiovascular health will drive earlier diagnosis, reduce health inequalities and support innovation ecosystems across Europe. Patient Advocacy Groups and industry could collaborate on events and position papers to achieve these aims and ensure the voice of the patient is heard throughout the Presidency. Ireland has an opportunity to demonstrate the regional impact of the life sciences sector, showcasing how the EU supports jobs, training and research capacity in all communities. Regional site visits during the Presidency and a Presidency associated event on cross-sectoral strategic resilience would further highlight how coordinated European action strengthens supply security, digital reliability and societal preparedness practical benefits citizens can understand and value.

An effective Presidency will require clear communication of how EU membership improves daily life, strengthens health systems and supports economic opportunity. Citizens should see the Presidency not as a technical process, but as something that supports better health and stronger communities. Ireland should therefore adopt a clear narrative: “Better Health, Stronger Europe.” This connects EU cooperation with visible improvements in care, access, security and competitiveness. Regional engagement will be essential. Therefore, the government should consider site visits to pharmaceutical and life-science facilities, particularly in rural and regional areas, which will demonstrate how EU membership supports investment, employment and innovation across the country. Ireland should also facilitate citizen and patient-centred dialogues, including patient roundtables that highlight lived experiences and bring policymaking closer to the public. The Adult Immunisation Board meeting scheduled to take place in Ireland during the Presidency should be leveraged as an opportunity to progress dialogue with citizens and in Government on the multi- faceted benefits (health, social, economic) of immunisation and how Ireland can pioneer the establishment of a comprehensive adult immunisation programme. Digital storytelling can showcase practical examples such as improved vaccination coverage, earlier cancer diagnosis, AI-driven clinical decision support and secure medicine supply chains, helping people see how EU cooperation directly benefits their families and communities. Communicating the Presidency’s work on topics like Adult immunisation, HIV and strategic resilience will also help citizens understand how the EU safeguards critical supply systems, digital infrastructure and societal stability. An associated event grounded in resilience would offer a strong communications anchor for explaining the relevance of EU action. Working with stakeholders (including industry, clinicians, and patient organisations) will ensure the Presidency’s outreach is inclusive and nationally owned.

Ireland’s 2026 Presidency comes at a pivotal moment as the European Union works to secure long-term competitiveness, productivity and prosperity in an era shaped by rapid technological transformation driven by AI. Europe must both (1) simplify and harmonise its digital rulebook so businesses can scale across borders, and (2) amplify AI adoption, ensuring citizens, public services and especially SMEs can deploy AI responsibly at scale. These two priorities should jointly underpin the focus on competitiveness, productivity and prosperity, and serve as the organising logic of the Presidency. Ireland’s Presidency should therefore adopt high-level themes that are future-oriented, people-centred and firmly aligned with these European Union-wide objectives. In alignment with the EU Strategic Agenda 2024-2029 and especially its Prosperous and Competitive Europe chapter, we recommend Ireland adopt the slogan: “Simplify & Amplify: Boost Skills, Innovation and Competitiveness”. Under this umbrella we propose three interlocking themes: i) Skills for a Future-Ready Europe: Building a competitive and cohesive Europe begins with people. Ireland can lead a Presidency theme focused on EU-level enabling actions that support and complement national efforts to equip citizens with digital and AI skills. Under this theme, the Irish Presidency could champion EU-supported frameworks for AI literacy and workforce reskilling, including: EU guidance on shared definitions and basic competency levels for AI Literacy that Member States may voluntarily adopt, champion ambitious, measurable targets for AI literacy and workforce reskilling, digital inclusion and mutual recognition of micro-credentials mapped to the European Qualifications Framework (EQF) to ease cross-border skills mobility. ii) SME-Led Growth and Innovation: Europe’s long-term economic strength will depend on its ability to stimulate productivity, support innovation across all EU Member States, and unlock the benefits of technological transformation. Ireland can lead a Presidency theme focused on creating the conditions in which European firms, particularly its SMEs, can innovate, scale and compete globally. Under this theme, the Irish Presidency could champion SME-oriented guidance, mentoring networks, public-private programmes to ensure broader access to compute and public data, and modernised and open public procurement to spur demand. iii) A Coherent, Competitive Digital Single Market: Europe’s long-term competitiveness depends on a Digital Single Market that works smoothly across borders and supports innovation in every EU Member State. Ireland can champion a theme focused on making Europe’s digital landscape more coherent, interoperable and predictable for citizens, businesses and public administrations. Concrete deliverables under this theme should include championing horizontal and vertical simplification across GDPR, NIS2, Cyber Resilience Act, Data Act, DGA and the AI Act to name a few, and assert Europe's leadership in fostering international convergence of AI standards to reduce fragmentation while safeguarding European values and safety. In addition, we recommend that, if the Irish Presidency considers advancing new legislation, such as the Digital Fairness Act (DFA), it prioritizes a proportionate and targeted approach that addresses clearly identified gaps, while avoiding duplication or overlap with recently adopted EU legislation governing the online services ecosystem. The focus should remain on effective implementation and enforcement of existing rules, in line with Council conclusions calling for regulatory coherence and minimized administrative burden.

The EU has set a clear ambition to lead on AI and secure competitiveness, productivity and societal benefits as reflected in the AI Continent Action Plan, the Apply AI Strategy and the Strategic Agenda 2024-2029. Ireland’s Presidency of the Council in 2026 provides a timely opportunity to support delivery of this ambition across the European Union. Ireland has particular strengths in digital skills, SME support, and innovation ecosystems, and is well positioned to drive progress in these areas for the benefit of all EU Member States. The Presidency should therefore prioritise two pragmatic, mutually reinforcing policy objectives: 1) Simplification and Regulatory Coherence; and 2) Amplification: Scaling Adoption, Skills and Infrastructure. 1. Simplification and Regulatory Coherence • Make 2026 the year of simplification: drive a Digital Fitness Check preparatory programme through a clear harmonisation mission to align definitions and reporting obligations. • Organize a “Simplification & Competitiveness Summit” in October 2026 (~ two-year anniversary of the Draghi Report) focused on delivering on the Digital Fitness Check and convene EU Member States, regulators and industry to fast-track commitments. Examples include a Single Reporting Portal, harmonised templates and a Digital Compliance Passport. • Advance vertical simplification: support a mandatory national Competitiveness & Consistency Assessments to limit gold-plating, create National Digital Regulation Helpdesks for SMEs, and stronger regulatory cooperation mechanisms. • Push for international convergence on HRAI and certification standards so European certification maps to ISO/NIST/CEN standards and the EU’s schemes are interoperable with like-minded partners. B. Amplification: Scaling Adoption, Skills & Infrastructure • Support voluntary, audacious EU-supportive targets the Presidency can champion: 100 million EU citizens provided with basic AI literacy including tools, open curricula and exchanges, and 10 million EU SMEs mentored/supported on their AI journey (targets to be advanced for the 2028-2034 budget cycle). • Champion an EU AI Productivity, Prosperity and Progress Summit in late 2026 (aligned with the EU Digital Summit) to align economic and social agendas: convening business, labour, academia and civil society to translate experimentation into measurable productivity gains. • Anchor Presidency initiatives in evidence-based policymaking by leveraging real-world data, assessing needs and outcomes, including adoption rates, productivity impacts, skills gaps and trust indicators to guide policy design, prioritisation and evaluation, and to ensure AI policies deliver tangible benefits for people and communities. • Coordinate EU Member States and EU AI Observatories and create a shared EU AI Readiness Index to benchmark skills, infrastructure, adoption and regulatory preparedness across Member States. Ireland should encourage national observatories to align metrics and share private-sector data. • Tackle infrastructure and access: mutual recognition of AI micro-credentials mapped to EQF; priority permitting for AI infrastructure; targeted public investment/subsidies to increase EU compute capacity; and fair access programmes so SMEs and public administrations can use shared compute resources. • Use AI as a tool for simplification: pilot GovAI sandboxes, AI-powered compliance assistants and multilingual regulatory triage tools for administrations across EU Member States. Cross-cutting measures should include: • Public procurement modernization to accelerate public-sector deployment of safe, effective AI. • A €1bn AI Accelerator Fund to support SME adoption, shared compute pools, regional AI hubs and reskilling. • AI Act: focus on proportionate, harmonised implementation with a strong emphasis on harmonising HRAI standards and certification.

Ireland can maximise impact by ensuring that good digital policy translates into real economic growth, scientific progress and social benefit, boosting its global attractiveness and competitiveness. A central challenge during the Presidency will be navigating the evolution of Europe’s digital sovereignty agenda as it crystallises into concrete instruments, especially around the upcoming Cloud and AI Development Act (CAIDA) and the different initiatives to refine the definition of a sovereign cloud more broadly. Europe can and should strengthen resilience and local value-creation without closing markets or imposing nationality-based exclusion. As the European Parliamentary Research Service paper on the CAIDA noted, data centre capacity in the EU is insufficient, due to legal and financial constraints. Rigid, exclusionary rules could harm innovation and investment in Europe. Policy criteria should be capability, compliance and partnership, not ownership alone. Failing to do so or poorly designed measures would create a real risk of fragmentation of the Single Market, raising costs and weakening of Europe’s competitiveness. Key elements of how Ireland approach under its Presidency could include: Championing Council Conclusions that reject nationality-based exclusion as a default and affirm that sovereignty objectives should be pursued through objective, technology-neutral, capabilities and risk-based criteria. Promoting interoperability and equivalence pathways within EUCS and CAIDA so any trusted providers that meet EU technical, contractual and operational safeguards can participate without discrimination. Supporting procurement guidance that discourages blanket European preference rules and instead focuses on transparent scoring based on compliance, data governance, local partnerships and measurable local value. Facilitating policy dialogue with like-minded partners, drawing on models such as the “coopetition” approach to ensure digital sovereignty policies reinforce, rather than undermine, Europe’s openness and competitiveness. Ireland is uniquely positioned to act as an honest broker. A dedicated and open Digital Sovereignty & Innovation Forum during the Presidency could convene Member States, EU institutions, international partners, industry and civil society to define workable, objective criteria that balance resilience, competitiveness in a spirit of partnership and openness.

The most powerful way to demonstrate the value of EU membership is by showing citizens how Europe equips them, and future generations, to thrive in a rapidly evolving economy. Ireland’s Presidency should place education, skills and opportunity at the centre of its public narrative. This includes: Framing the EU as a practical enabler of lifelong learning, mobility and opportunity through programmes that support digital skills, AI literacy and workforce transitions across all EU Member States. Highlighting concrete EU investments in education, research and innovation that deliver local benefits in schools, universities, SMEs and public services. In communicating the value of EU membership, the Presidency should acknowledge and celebrate the role of national education systems, and highlight how EU cooperation supports Member State leadership in skills development. Engaging young people directly through Presidency-branded initiatives focused on AI literacy, digital citizenship and future careers. Using accessible, citizen-focused storytelling to show how EU cooperation improves everyday life: better public services, safer technology, new job opportunities and global influence. We recognize that key policy areas such as formal education and workforce training primarily fall within Member State competence. Ireland’s Presidency should therefore focus on EU-level coordination, guidance, harmonization and support mechanisms that respect national prerogatives while enhancing cross-border cooperation and shared outcomes. By linking Europe’s values to tangible outcomes - skills, jobs and opportunity - Ireland can foster genuine ownership and confidence in the EU project.

This submission summarises key messages from OpenAI’s EU Economic Blueprint and its contribution to the Digital Omnibus to AI regulation Proposal. Together, these contributions set out a practical agenda to strengthen EU competitiveness and productivity through AI, while ensuring responsible adoption and maintaining a coherent, innovation-friendly Single Market. First, both papers emphasise that Europe’s ability to capture AI-driven growth depends on scaling the foundations of AI-enabled prosperity: compute capacity, chip access, data availability, sustainable energy and talent. While the EU has made important early investments (e.g., EuroHPC, AI Factories and national infrastructure initiatives), the Blueprint argues that Europe must accelerate scale to meet rising demand. It proposes, among other measures, a major expansion of EU compute capacity by 2030, improved access to chips among democratic partners, faster growth in renewable energy to support digital infrastructure, and pan-European investment in AI education, research and workforce transition support. A central recommendation is to significantly expand AI literacy through scholarships, reskilling programmes and an “AI Erasmus”-style initiative, to ensure citizens and workers can benefit from new tools and jobs. Second, the papers argue that infrastructure investment must be matched by regulatory simplification, coherence and proportionality. Europe’s digital framework is increasingly complex and fragmented, creating a high compliance burden, especially for SMEs, and slowing cross-border scaling. The “Harmonizing” paper proposes five pillars for an ambitious simplification agenda. It calls for horizontal simplification to reduce duplication across regimes such as GDPR, NIS2, the Cyber Resilience Act, the Data Act, DGA and the AI Act, including a one-year harmonisation mission to align definitions and reporting, a Single Reporting Portal, harmonised templates, minimum implementation periods, and a Digital Compliance Passport to reduce repeated documentation. It also calls for vertical simplification to address divergent national implementation and enforcement through competitiveness and consistency assessments to limit gold-plating, national digital regulation helpdesks for SMEs, stronger regulatory cooperation, common open-data standards, and faster rollout of High-Value Datasets and Common European Data Spaces. Third, both papers underline that Europe’s economic opportunity depends on widespread adoption, not just technological leadership. The EU Economic Blueprint notes that AI uptake among European firms remains low relative to EU ambitions and stresses the importance of targeted SME incentives, modernised public procurement, and public-sector deployment to improve services and create demand. It proposes tools such as a European AI Readiness Index, mechanisms to share best practice, and an AI Accelerator Fund to support adoption, skills and regional ecosystems. Finally, both papers stress the importance of responsible, values-aligned AI. The Blueprint highlights safety and governance approaches (including preparedness and privacy-by-design) and proposes measures to strengthen youth protection, AI literacy and user empowerment, such as an EU Code on Child-Centric AI Design. The “Harmonizing” paper adds “SimplifAI”: using AI to make regulation and public administration more efficient through compliance assistants, multilingual support, and GovAI sandboxes. Taken together, these recommendations offer a coherent framework for Ireland’s Presidency to advance competitiveness, regulatory clarity and responsible innovation across the EU in 2026.

Ireland should frame its Presidency around the overarching goal of protecting democratic space in the digital era, leveraging both its place within the European community and its unique role mediating American Big Tech. As a small, open state deeply integrated into global digital markets, Ireland occupies a position unlike any other EU member: it is simultaneously a steward of European regulatory ambitions and the primary European host to major U.S. technology firms. This dual identity gives Ireland both the credibility and the responsibility to guide a balanced approach to safeguarding democratic participation online. A Presidency built on this theme would allow Ireland to articulate a vision that prioritises transparency, , and the preservation of open civic discourse, while resisting approaches that risk narrowing democratic space through excessive centralisation or overbroad regulatory intervention. By emphasising the need for proportionate, evidence-based digital governance, Ireland can champion a practical middle path—one that protects citizens from genuine harms without undermining the innovation ecosystem that sustains European competitiveness. Moreover, Ireland’s established relationships with U.S. companies allow it to act as an honest broker at a moment of increasing transatlantic tension over digital regulation. Rather than treating technology platforms solely as actors to be constrained, Ireland can encourage a cooperative model in which they are engaged constructively in achieving democratic resilience, supporting electoral integrity, and ensuring that content moderation systems respect fundamental rights. Embedding this vision across Council workstreams—ranging from internal market policy to justice, security, and foreign affairs—would position Ireland as a forward-looking, principled leader on digital democracy. Such an agenda would resonate with partners who share concerns about authoritarian influence, information disorder, and declining civic trust, while also reaffirming Ireland’s long-standing commitment to pluralism, openness, and rule-of-law governance.

Ensuring that the Digital Services Act (DSA) is implemented throughout 2026 in a manner that safeguards free expression and fundamental rights. This includes securing full transparency from platforms and national regulators regarding the rationale and mechanisms behind content removals and algorithmic demotion; preventing bias or politicisation in the operation of Trusted Flaggers; and monitoring potential misuse of the DSA’s cross-border takedown procedures and its provisions related to electoral processes. Opposition to overreach in the proposed “ChatControl” framework, particularly as negotiations intensify during the Irish Council Presidency in 2026. This includes resisting any measures that would mandate client-side scanning or undermine end-to-end encryption; ensuring that child-protection objectives do not justify mass surveillance practices incompatible with fundamental rights; and promoting a Presidency-led approach that protects privacy, digital security, and the constitutional norms of free expression across the Union. Scrutinising forthcoming disinformation strategies and any renewed EU-level hate-speech initiatives—especially those expected to advance in 2026—to ensure they do not encroach upon legitimate expression. This includes guarding against vague or expansive definitions of “harmful” or “illegal” speech, preventing administrative overreach in enforcement, and maintaining clear protections for political speech, journalistic work, and civil-society activity. The above primarily fall under Justice and Home Affairs (JHA) Transport, Telecommunications and Energy (TTE) at a Council level. Together, these policy areas will shape the Union’s digital public sphere for years ahead. Ireland’s Presidency can meaningfully contribute by promoting legal clarity, proportionality and robust safeguards for free expression and secure communication.

Ireland’s 2026 Presidency can deliver a substantial positive impact for people, businesses, and communities by steering the Council toward a digital and economic agenda grounded in rights, security, and competitiveness. First, Ireland can strengthen public trust in the digital environment by guiding the implementation of the Digital Services Act and related legislation in a way that protects free expression, ensures due-process guarantees, and enhances transparency in content moderation. Clear, rights-based implementation will benefit citizens by maintaining an open online sphere for debate, while giving businesses—especially SMEs—predictable, proportionate rules and reducing compliance uncertainty. Second, progress on secure digital infrastructure should be a central Presidency objective. Supporting the development of interoperable, privacy-preserving technologies—particularly in communications, cloud services, and data flows—would enhance competitiveness across the single market. By shaping negotiations on files such as the CSAM Regulation to avoid weakening encryption or imposing disproportionate surveillance obligations, Ireland can help safeguard cybersecurity for individuals and enterprises, enabling innovation rather than chilling it. Finally, the Presidency offers a strategic moment to reinforce Europe’s commitment to fundamental rights as the foundation of prosperity and stability. Embedding these principles across Council work—whether on digital policy, justice and home affairs, or economic files—will help ensure that technological progress and market integration translate into tangible improvements in daily life.

Ireland should build public ownership of its EU Presidency by making decisions transparent and enabling open, consequence-free debate about EU policy, in line with democratic values for the digital era. Trust grows when citizens can and shape the conversation rather than receive scripted messaging.

Free expression has become one of the central pressure points in the transatlantic culture wars, shaping how societies understand democracy, dissent, and the boundaries of public debate. Europe and the United States share a long tradition of valuing open discourse, yet they increasingly diverge on how speech should be governed in the digital era. This divergence is most visible in regulatory frameworks like the EU’s Digital Services Act, which seeks to manage online content through extensive obligations on platforms. While well-intentioned, such rules can create systemic pressure on legitimate political speech and place private companies in the role of arbiters of truth—an approach viewed with deep suspicion in the U.S., where First Amendment protections run far deeper.
N/A.

Cardiovascular health will be a major policy theme in the field of healthcare policy during the Irish Presidency. The European Commission is expected to present its EU Cardiovascular Health Plan in midDecember 2025. Consequently, the Irish Presidency will lead efforts in the Council resulting from the Cardiovascular Health Plan. As Cardiomyopathies Matter, we would like to see the Irish Presidency help in bringing attention to cardiomyopathies and other inherited cardiac conditions in the context of the EU’s cardiovascular agenda. Cardiomyopathies remain significantly underdiagnosed, unevenly managed, and insufficiently supported across Member States, despite affecting an estimated 1.5 million Europeans and often leading to severe complications such as heart failure, arrhythmias, and sudden cardiac death at young ages. The Irish Presidency has a strategic opportunity to elevate these issues within broader EU health policy. As an initiative, we advocate for stronger actions on early diagnosis and detection of inherited cardiac diseases like cardiomyopathies. The Irish Presidency should ensure that cardiomyopathies are explicitly referenced in the EU Cardiovascular Health Plan. The Irish Presidency could also encourage the Commission and Member States to expand professional education on cardiomyopathies, deploy targeted awareness initiatives, and increase the use of cardiac imaging and genetic testing, especially in cases of sudden cardiac arrest or unexplained death in young individuals, where underdiagnosis remains a critical gap. Legislative work related to the implementation of the European Health Data Space (EHDS) should be used to ensure that interoperable, privacy-compliant genomic and imaging data can be used to strengthen early detection across borders. Second, in the area of disease management and quality of care, the Presidency could push for EU-level benchmarking, improved data collection, and consistent application of clinical guidelines. Cardiomyopathies Matter calls for incentivising guideline-recommended management and integrating cardiomyopathies into broader EU cardiovascular monitoring frameworks. A flagship initiative could be progress toward a Cardiovascular Health Observatory, ensuring that rare and inherited cardiac conditions are visible within EU data systems and health indicator sets. Third, the Presidency could emphasise holistic patient support and empowerment. This includes supporting psychosocial services, rehabilitation, palliative care, peer networks, and digital tools that facilitate shared decision-making and access to personal health data. Strengthening patient involvement in Health Technology Assessment (HTA) and research governance should also form part of Council-level work on patient-centred care models. Finally, the Irish Presidency should prioritise research and innovation, ensuring that existing EU projects and upcoming strategic research agendas embed cardiomyopathy-specific needs. A European Cardiovascular Health Data Knowledge Centre could be advanced through Council discussions on the European Health Data Space (EHDS) to unlock real-world evidence generation and address current fragmentation in registries and data infrastructures. The Presidency should also explore political support for establishing a long-term EU Cardiovascular Health Mission, modelled on the Cancer Mission, ensuring sustained funding and visibility for conditions that are not preventable but are highly treatable with coordinated action By leading on these priorities, the Irish Presidency can drive meaningful progress in cardiovascular health and significantly improve outcomes for people affected by cardiomyopathies across Europe.
N/A.

must provide a summary of the additional information under the ‘Any other comments’ question. This summary should also be limited to a maximum of 500 words.

sector: We work with those living in persistent poverty to build a just and inclusive society.
geography: We are based in North Inner City Dublin where we build relationships and work with people living in persistent poverty locally.  However, we work towards the eradication of poverty across the island and often work with local groups in urban and rural areas across the country.
response_text: At ATD Ireland we believe the Presidency of the European council is an apt opportunity to build on the work carried out through the development of the EU anti poverty strategy and ensure its full implementation. The high level thematic priorities should include upholding the European Pillar of social rights and working towards the realization of the Sustainable Development Goals Agenda 2030. In particular, the eradication of poverty across Europe should be a high level thematic priority for its presidency of the council in 2026. The Irish Presidency of the EU will start just after adoption of the EU Anti-Poverty Strategy in Spring 2026. The Irish Presidency has a valuable opportunity to take a leading role in raising awareness of this new strategy, in promoting it and calling on commitments of all member states for its full adoption. This should include; ending homeless and ensuring access to adequate housing for all, ending all forms of discrimination including socio- economic discrimination, ending homelessness and ensuring equal access to quality services such as healthcare. It should also commit to genuine opportunities in education and employment, and ensuring a minimum standard of income which enables all to have their physical, social and psychological needs met. In order to achieve this Ireland should prioritise including the voice of lived experience during its presidency in policy, development, implementation and monitoring through diverse modes of inclusion and through the support of civil society organisations. To acknowledge the commitment to eradicate persistent poverty across Europe, the Council of Europe should recognise the UN International Day for the Eradication of Poverty- 17th October. 2025 marked 25 years of commemorating this day in Ireland.

sector: We work with those living in persistent poverty to build a just and inclusive society.
geography: We are based in North Inner City Dublin where we build relationships and work with people living in persistent poverty locally.  However, we work towards the eradication of poverty across the island and often work with local groups in urban and rural areas across the country.
response_text: Ensuring the advancement of the EU Anti Poverty strategy should be a focus of work for the Irish presidency. See above for further details on what this should include. An effective anti poverty strategy is key to ensuring a free and democratic Europe, in line with the EU Strategic Plan 2024- 26. The EU council, should focus on supporting and development mechanisms for participation and consultation with civil society. Participative structures including diverse modes of inclusion, and genuinely listening to the voices of those experiencing exclusion is fundamental to strengthening democratic reliance and debate. It should be ensured that the digital transition and policies concerning the adoption of new technologies does not leave anyone behind. This can include older people and families and individuals experiencing poverty. A minimum essential standard of living for all across Europe is needed to ensure social and economic wellbeing. Further, to ensure a strong purchasing power of all citizens and tackling the cost of living across Europe. To achieve this, the called for directive on minimum income should be advanced. Ireland should prioritise EU action on housing and homelessness during its Presidency. Legislative action should be implemented which ensures quality, appropriate and safe and secure housing/ accommodation for all. Quality public services in healthcare, education, electricity and quality accommodation for all is essential to responding to crises. The importance of this was seen during the Covid 19 epidemic during which some groups were left further behind.

response_text: The Council can make the most substantial positive impact during the term of the Irish Presidency by focusing on the people and communities most left behind across the EU. This includes those experiencing persistent poverty and those experiencing intersectional forms of exclusion. Mainstreaming the SDG’s across the work of the Council of the EU and putting the Agenda 2030 ‘Leave No One Behind’ Promise at the heart of all EU decision making is crucial to making the most positive impact for all.

sector: We work with those living in persistent poverty to build a just and inclusive society.
geography: We are based in North Inner City Dublin where we build relationships and work with people living in persistent poverty locally.  However, we work towards the eradication of poverty across the island and often work with local groups in urban and rural areas across the country.
response_text: Participatory methods of dialogue and inclusion with a commitment to reaching those most at risk of being left behind is necessary for communicating the values and benefits of EU membership to its citizens. Participatory policymaking is also essential for ensuring a sense of ownership and inclusion of Ireland’s Presidency of the Council of the EU. This could include giving citizens, including those experiencing hardship and exclusion, opportunities to meet with Members of the Council of the EU.

The Fair Seas supports the Environmental Pillar’s proposal that the Irish Government adopt “Resilience” as a core theme for Ireland’s Presidency of the Council of the European Union in 2026. Resilience is a unifying concept that cuts across many areas of EU work including climate and environment, energy security, social cohesion, economic stability, and democratic governance. It captures a growing recognition across Europe that, in a period of rapid change and increasing shocks, we must become more robust, more self-reliant, and better able to sustain progress within our own means. We believe that “Resilience” provides a comprehensive, constructive and forward-looking framing for Ireland’s EU Presidency. It reflects the need to strengthen the systems, institutions and infrastructure that support people’s ability to cope with rising uncertainty and volatility. It also aligns closely with the spirit of solidarity and community that citizens across Europe continue to demonstrate. Alongside “Resilience”, Fair Seas proposes “Ambition” as a second pillar of Ireland’s Presidency theme. Ambition is an essential thread running through the EU’s objectives across climate and environmental action, trade, defence and security, and the protection of democracy and European values. Together, Resilience and Ambition form a compelling and credible foundation for Ireland’s Presidency, one that would empower Ireland to lead confidently within the EU institutions in the period leading up to, and throughout, its term. In relation to the wider environment and particularly the marine environment, Resilience and Ambition offer a strong basis for genuine implementation, delivery and progress during the coming 12 months. These themes provide a clear mandate for Ireland to champion and support Member States in key areas of ongoing environmental work, including the development of ambitious National Nature Restoration Plans. They also underpin the collaborative efforts needed to meet the targets set out in the EU Biodiversity Strategy for 2030, including the commitments to protect 30% of EU waters by 2030, with one third of that (10%) under strict protection. By embedding resilience and ambition at the heart of its Presidency, Ireland can help drive the transformative changes required to restore and safeguard Europe’s marine and wider natural environment, while also speaking to the need for “Resilience and Ambition” across other important work priorities for the Council.

A priority focus area for Ireland’s Presidency of the Council in 2026 should be the stewardship of nature, with a particular emphasis on the marine environment. Ireland is well placed to encourage the effective implementation of existing EU marine and environmental legislation, including the Marine Strategy Framework Directive (MSFD), Water Framework Directive (WFD), Maritime Spatial Planning Directive (MSPD), the Nature Restoration Regulation (NRR), and other related instruments. Ireland’s Presidency can help drive a renewed EU effort to translate these policies into tangible, positive conservation outcomes. By promoting a narrative that highlights the links between healthy, resilient seas and healthy, resilient communities, including benefits for well-being, coastal economies, climate mitigation and adaptation, and thriving marine industries, Ireland can demonstrate real leadership. This approach would support the delivery of ambitious environmental targets and commitments that all Member States, including Ireland, have already endorsed but have yet to fully achieve. In terms of specific policy areas, Fair Seas recommends that Ireland focus on the delivery of the EU-wide commitment to establish a coherent network of Marine Protected Areas (MPAs) across 30% of European waters by 2030. Although this target has already been agreed, many Member States including Ireland, are falling behind. Ireland’s upcoming national MPA legislation, currently being drafted to meet these obligations, provides a timely opportunity to align national ambition with EU-level leadership during the Presidency. If the EU is to achieve its 30x30 ambition, one area in need of urgent attention is the often poor implementation of the Habitats and Birds Directives by Member States, and failure to deliver a network of Natura 2000 suites to properly protect species and habitats. Lack of effective management including the development of management plans, conservation measures, monitoring, enforcement and good governance represents a lost opportunity for the EU to take care of its marine ecosystems, species and habitats. In addition, the drafting of the EU Ocean Act, announced by Commissioner Sinkevičius and signalled in the EU Ocean Pact, may fall within the period of Ireland’s Presidency in 2026. This presents a unique opening for Ireland to demonstrate leadership on the effective protection and restoration of Europe’s marine biodiversity. Ireland can help shape a strong Ocean Act that provides the legal foundation, framework and statutory onus to effectively implement marine conservation policy nationally across Member States, something that has proven difficult to realise in the EU to date. Lastly, Ireland’s Presidency offers a chance to advance one of the most critical elements of the EU Biodiversity Strategy: achieving 10% strict protection of EU seas. This target is expected to be reinforced within the forthcoming EU Ocean Act. Championing strict protection would allow Ireland to signal its environmental priorities clearly, accelerate domestic progress, and inspire other Member States to raise their level of ambition.

Ireland should place the progression of marine conservation and Marine Protected Area policy at the heart of its focus on the environment during the EU Council Presidency in 2026. Ireland has already made significant commitments in this area, both at EU and global level, and the Presidency provides a crucial opportunity to demonstrate leadership, credibility and delivery. Ireland has committed to protecting 30% of its marine area by 2030, with this target embedded in the EU Biodiversity Strategy, which Ireland has endorsed, and which are reaffirmed in the Kunming-Montreal Global Biodiversity Framework (COP15). Ireland is also a signatory to the EU Ocean Pact, a political commitment to strengthen marine action across the Union. It is noteworthy that the Ocean Pact was first signposted on Irish soil during European Maritime Day in May 2025. Ireland’s Taoiseach highlighted its importance in his opening remarks in Cork, and travelled to France a short time later in June to officially publish the Ocean PAct alongside Commissioner Sinkevičius and President Emmanuel Macron. Ireland is therefore closely associated with the momentum behind this new EU-wide marine ambition. However, delivering on these commitments requires meaningful progress at national level. Despite repeated commitments over the past five years, Ireland currently ranks among the lowest-performing EU Member States in both the designation and effective management of MPAs. This gap between commitment and implementation undermines Ireland’s credibility at a time when the EU is looking for concrete action to match political pledges. For Ireland to hold the Presidency with authority on marine issues, it is essential that the Government advance strong, fit-for-purpose national MPA legislation in advance of 2026. Such legislation is critical to ensuring that Ireland can meet its 30x30 obligations, and it will provide a solid foundation for shaping wider EU policy conversations during the Presidency. Equally important is the need to improve the management and conservation effectiveness of Ireland’s existing Natura 2000 marine sites under the Birds and Habitats Directives. Without significant enhancement of implementation and enforcement within these existing sites, achieving a meaningful 30% MPA network will not be possible. Progressing MPA designation, management and wider marine conservation reforms is not simply a matter of compliance. It is an opportunity for Ireland to demonstrate genuine leadership at both national and EU levels, to build credibility as an advocate for ocean protection, and to show that Ireland can deliver on the commitments it has championed publicly. Doing MPAs properly, i.e., their designation and management is grounded in science, community engagement and effective and ongoing management, would position Ireland as a respected and ambitious leader during its EU Presidency. For these reasons, Fair Seas strongly urges the Government to prioritise marine conservation and MPA implementation as a core workstream in the lead-up to, and throughout, Ireland’s EU Council Presidency in 2026.

organisation:
Community Law & Mediation and the Centre for 
Environmental Justice

geography: Both national and EU wide. CLM is based in Dublin and Limerick and its services are available nationwide across Ireland. However, our work is shaped by decisions of the European Court of Human Rights and our environmental justice work increasingly engages with EU law and policy.
response_text: Community Law & Mediation, like many, has observed a worrying increase in division, racism and antiimmigrant sentiment in the communities in which we work and across broader society. This has been accompanied by a hardening of government rhetoric, and efforts to roll back on and erode the protections enshrined in human rights frameworks, including the European Convention on Human Rights. This is evident most recently in the call by 27 Council of Europe members to weaken key protections under the European Convention on Human Rights. In parallel with this, and despite the significant, urgent and complex climate and environmental challenges facing the EU and wider world, there has been a concerted effort to weaken EU climate ambition and climate governance. In Ireland, this has most recently been reflected in moves to restrict access to justice in environmental matters. Ireland’s Presidency of the Council of the European Union presents an opportunity to champion bold measures that advance fundamental rights and promote a socially just, ecologically sustainable society. In this context, and in line with the Strategic Agenda 2024-2029, we believe the high-level thematic priorities for Ireland’s Presidency should be as follows: The rule of law, with a focus on promoting and upholding the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union and the European Convention on Human Rights, respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality and respect for human rights, including the rights of persons belonging to minorities. Housing and homelessness, with a focus on progressing the commitment to effectively and urgently tackle the homelessness and housing crisis in Ireland and across Europe, by making affordable, sustainable, and decent homes available to everyone, and ensuring European social fairness. • Climate justice, with a focus on ambitious and measurable actions to reduce the EU’s reliance on fossil fuels and delivering long term solutions to our shared climate and social justice challenges; and promotion of access to information on the environment, public participation in environmental decision-making, and access to justice in environmental matters in line with the Aarhus Convention.

organisation:
Community Law & Mediation and the Centre for 
Environmental Justice 
(www.communitylawandmediation.ie)
geography: Both national and EU wide. CLM is based in Dublin and Limerick and its services are available nationwide across Ireland. However, our work is shaped by decisions of the European Court of Human Rights and our environmental justice work increasingly engages with EU law and policy.
response_text: Rule of Law In a speech last month (November 2025), the Council of Europe Commissioner for Human Rights, Michael O’Flaherty, warned of a global rise in authoritarianism worldwide, a decline in democracy and the sidelining of the United Nations. Reflecting on how to navigate these challenges, he identified human rights law as the only credible roadmap for safeguarding human dignity. He noted that Ireland “has been transformed by judgments of the European Court of Human Rights” and “that the Court and the Convention have been the primary drivers for Ireland's social transformation into the confident and outward-looking society that it is today.” We call on Ireland to lead by example during its Presidency by: Upholding and affirming Ireland’s and the EU’s commitment to the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union and the European Convention on Human Rights. Advancing the essential reforms highlighted in the 2025 Rule of Law report, including reform of Ireland’s civil legal aid system to ensure access to justice for those who need it most. Protecting access to information on the environment, public participation in environmental decision-making, and access to justice in environmental matters in line with the Aarhus Convention. Recognising the unique rights held by children and young people under the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child by supporting child rights-based access to justice. Housing People across Europe are struggling to find an affordable place to live, work, raise their families, and go about their daily lives. The housing crisis across the EU was expressly mentioned by President von der Leyen in her State of the Union Address 2025. Affordable housing has been identified as a top priority for the European Commission. In this context, Ireland’s Presidency of the Council of the European Union must prioritise: • Progressing the commitment to effectively and urgently tackle the homelessness and housing crisis in Ireland and across Europe, by making affordable, sustainable, and decent homes available to everyone, and ensuring European social fairness. Climate Justice Climate change is one of the greatest threats to human rights, posing a serious risk to life, health, food and an adequate standard of living of individuals and communities across the world. Ireland and all EU states have a legal and ethical duty to adhere to their obligations on climate change, to protect children, citizens and future generations from the most dangerous impacts of the climate crisis and to prevent the need for more abrupt and forceful action later. In April 2024, the European Court of Human Rights (ECtHR) found that Article 8 of the European Convention on Human Rights encompasses a right to effective protection by State authorities from the serious adverse effects of climate change on lives, health, well-being and quality of life. With all 27 EU member states bound by the Convention, EU action must reflect this judgment. In this context, Ireland’s Presidency of the Council of the European Union must prioritise: • The EU’s 2040 target: CLM has called upon the EU to adopt a 2040 target which aligns with the best available science and the EU’s obligations under the Paris Agreement, and to avoid reliance on carbon credits. CLM recommends that the EU continue its practice of achieving its binding climate targets domestically for the 2040 goal, as already enshrined in the EU Climate law for the 2030 target and the 2050 climate neutrality goal. The EU has already faced significant challenges in regulating carbon credits due to poor quality, a lack of transparency, and potential for double-counting (where a credit is sold more than once). Carbon credits are increasingly subject to litigation – earlier this year, Energy Australia acknowledged that carbon credits do not mitigate dangers caused by greenhouse gas emissions and apologised to their customers for misleading advertising. CLM supported GLAN and CAN-Europe in its challenge to the adequacy of the EU’s 2030 climate targets as implemented by the EU Effort-Sharing Regulation. Judgment in this case is awaited. Adopting a 2040 target that aligns with climate science, as proposed by the European Scientific Advisory Board on Climate Change, is critical to ensure an adequate target for 2040. It can furthermore provide long-term certainty for communities and Member States governments (at all levels), as well as the private sector and investors. Most importantly, it will ensure the delivery of a Just Transition, by protecting the rights of those most at risk from the worst impacts of the climate crisis. • Resource the Transition via the MFF: to ensure the effective and timely implementation of the European Climate Law, the transition must be adequately resourced across all member states. The European Commission has proposed that 35% of the proposed Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF), which runs from 2028-2034, be ringfenced for climate and environmental measures. In its role as President of the Council of Europe, Ireland should use its leadership position to ensure that EU spending is aligned with the targets set out in the EU Climate Law, and that it drives a fast and fair transition.

organisation:
Community Law & Mediation and the Centre for 
Environmental Justice 
(www.communitylawandmediation.ie)
geography: Both national and EU wide. CLM is based in Dublin and Limerick and its services are available nationwide across Ireland. However, our work is shaped by decisions of the European Court of Human Rights and our environmental justice work increasingly engages with EU law and policy.
response_text: In the broadest sense, during the term of the Irish Presidency, the Council can make its most substantial positive impact by demonstrating firm and consistent leadership in its commitment to human rights and climate justice. The protections enshrined in the Charter and the ECHR must not be weakened. The message must be clear: that all people are equal in terms of the universality of human rights. Regarding our shared climate goals, the adoption of a 2040 target which is fully aligned with the best available climate science and consistent with the EU’s obligations under the Paris Agreement, supported by the effective resourcing of the EU’s transition across all Member States via the MFF, establish the foundation for a fast and fair transition. Ensuring that all member states are equipped to reduce their emissions at the scale and pace required could enable, for example: The equitable delivery of decarbonised homes that are cheaper and safer to heat; Improved public and active transport that prioritises connectivity and accessibility for all; An energy system that is resilient, sustainable and more cost-effective for all homes around Ireland; Food and water system transformation that protects human health and biodiversity; The creation of employment in the development of domestic renewable energy. Such action would lead to cleaner indoor and outdoor air, healthier water, and reduced environmental degradation. It would improve health outcomes particularly for those most at risk of energy poverty, air pollution and the effects of biodiversity loss.

organisation:
Community Law & Mediation and the Centre for 
Environmental Justice 
(www.communitylawandmediation.ie)
geography: Both national and EU wide. CLM is based in Dublin and Limerick and its services are available nationwide across Ireland. However, our work is shaped by decisions of the European Court of Human Rights and our environmental justice work increasingly engages with EU law and policy.
response_text: The benefits of EU membership may effectively be communicated by promoting the rights protected under the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the EU, the ECHR and the Aarhus Convention, to promote these essential protections and environmental democracy as core European values. Central to this is the protection of civil society and its funding. As the new EU Civil Society Strategy enters its implementation phase during the Irish Presidency, Ireland should champion an “enabling environment for civil society.” This should prioritise the protection of the right to: Access to information on the environment. Ireland should encourage transparent and proactive provision of environmental information across the EU and its member states. Meaningful public participation in environmental decision-making, to ensure that those most impacted are heard. Access to justice to ensure that the EU’s climate and environmental laws remain effective, and that decision-makers are held to account for their full and timely implementation.

Ireland’s Presidency should adopt a unifying vision such as: “Recommitting Europe to Peace, Democracy and Global Responsibility.” This vision is crucial because Europe is increasingly targeted by external actors—state and non-state— who actively seek to undermine its unity, institutions and democratic cohesion. Disinformation, destabilisation tactics and geopolitical coercion directly threaten the stability of the Union. The strongest defence is not militarisation but a recommitment to the founding principles of the EU after the Second World War: peace, cooperation, democracy, human dignity and the rule of law. From this, three thematic priorities follow: Peace, Neutrality and the EU’s Global Credibility As a neutral state constitutionally committed to the peaceful settlement of disputes (Article 29), Ireland can place peace-building, mediation and preventive diplomacy at the heart of its Presidency. Peace is the foundation of prosperity and democratic stability. The EU must also apply international humanitarian law consistently and universally, both internally and in its external action. Selectivity weakens credibility; consistency strengthens it. Human Rights, International Law and Accountability A Europe that defends human rights and the rules-based order strengthens its own security. The Presidency should emphasise that the EU must hold itself to the same standards it expects worldwide. Consistent application of IHL—across all conflicts and regions—is essential to maintaining moral authority and global legitimacy. 3. Democracy, Transparency and a Free, Independent Media Democratic resilience requires a free media, open public debate and strong safeguards against disinformation and foreign interference. These tools protect the Union from external actors seeking to weaken democratic institutions. Ireland should champion the Media Freedom Act, journalist safety, and digital information integrity. Together, these priorities reaffirm the EU’s founding values at a moment when they are under unprecedented external pressure.

Ireland should prioritise policies that reinforce peace, rights, democratic resilience and the EU’s coherence in the face of external threats. Promote EU leadership in mediation and conflict prevention. Strengthen cooperation with the UN, embedding IHL and international law at the core of EU external action. Reaffirm that consistent application of IHL is essential to counter claims of bias and to strengthen the EU’s position when confronting destabilising external actors. Advance rule-of-law conditionality and transparency mechanisms to protect the Union from internal corrosion. Strengthen tools to ensure all Member States comply with human rights, judicial independence and IHL obligations. Drive implementation of the Media Freedom Act and EU anti-SLAPP measures, essential for protecting democracy against foreign interference and malign influence. Advance EU-wide strategies on disinformation resilience and media literacy, recognising that external actors are actively targeting European societies. Promote open data, transparency and citizen participation. Ireland can use its Presidency to show that a neutral, principled approach—centred on peace, law and democracy—is the strongest defence for Europe’s unity.

The Irish Presidency can deliver meaningful benefits by centring peace, rights and democratic accountability. Peace and Stability Prosperity depends on stability. Prioritising diplomacy, conflict prevention and the consistent application of IHL strengthens regional and global security, creating predictable conditions for businesses and communities. Protection of Rights and the Rule of Law Strong rule-of-law standards protect citizens from corruption and abuses of power, creating a fairer, more trustworthy environment. This also strengthens Europe’s resilience against hostile external actors who exploit weak democratic institutions. A Strong Information Environment A free media ecosystem improves public debate, reduces vulnerability to disinformation and builds societal resilience—essential given the volume of foreign interference targeting European democracies. Economic Confidence Clear governance, transparent decision-making and predictable legal frameworks attract investment, support SMEs and strengthen cross-border activity. Through these priorities, Ireland can help ensure that Europe remains a safe, stable and prosperous place to live and work.

Ireland can communicate the values and benefits of EU membership by showing how the Presidency reconnects with Europe’s founding principles. Explain How EU Values Improve Daily Life Show how peace, stability, rights and economic opportunity stem from cooperation. Link these to Ireland’s identity as a neutral state committed to diplomacy and international law. Highlight Ireland’s Role as a Neutral Honest Broker Ireland’s history of peacekeeping and commitment to IHL positions it as a trustworthy facilitator. Emphasise that consistent application of international humanitarian law reflects what citizens expect: fairness, justice and principled leadership. Promote Citizen Participation Use town halls, schools, civil society partnerships and localised outreach to involve people directly in EU decision-making. Partner with Independent Media and Civil Society Promote fact-based communication and regular transparency updates. This models the democratic values Ireland is championing. Counter Disinformation Through Clarity and Openness Proactive, transparent communication counters foreign influence and builds public confidence.

Ireland’s 2026 Presidency is an opportunity for the EU to reconnect with its foundational purpose: securing peace, protecting human dignity, and building prosperity through cooperation rather than conflict. Europe now faces escalating attempts by external actors to weaken its institutions, divide its societies and undermine its values. The most effective response is not to depart from the Union’s founding principles, but to return to them: peace, democracy, the rule of law, human rights and accountability. As a country with a long-standing policy of military neutrality and deep experience in peacekeeping and mediation, Ireland can help lead this re-centering. The EU’s credibility depends on acting consistently with its stated values—especially through the universal, impartial application of international humanitarian law. Selective adherence to humanitarian principles damages trust at home and undermines the EU’s global authority. Ireland can champion coherence, accountability and principled leadership at a moment when the international order is under strain. By prioritising peace, rule-of-law protections, democratic resilience and media freedom, Ireland can help strengthen the Union internally while reinforcing its global standing.

Ireland should prioritise the Circular Economy as a cross-cutting theme, with a particular focus on extended producer responsibility (EPR), electrical and electronic equipment (EEE), and batteries. This reflects the EU’s climate and resource security objectives. It positions Ireland as a leader in sustainable innovation, supported by a 2nd Whole of Government Circular Economy Strategy and an established Waste Electrical and Electronic Equipment (WEEE) and Battery Producer Responsibility framework, both further developed and informed by recent public consultations on these topics.

The Presidency should focus on the EU Circular Economy Act, expected to be proposed in Q3 2026. Ireland should aim to: Prepare the Council for co-legislative deliberations on the Act. Highlight priority issues such as o harmonised EPR frameworks, o realistic collection targets with a standards-based and all-actors approach, o compliance management of online sellers and o Implement measures to encourage CRM recovery. Promote dialogue on circular electronics, batteries, and emerging technologies, ensuring alignment with the Critical Raw Materials Act, Eco-Design Regulations, and other parallel frameworks.

By supporting the 6th International WEEE Forum Conference in Dublin (17–18 September 2026), Ireland can highlight practical solutions, foster collaboration, and demonstrate how EU membership drives innovation and sustainability. This event will bring policymakers, industry leaders, and civil society together to address the significant and growing e-waste challenge and accelerate circularity. Delivering progress during the Presidency, in the further implementation of the European Batteries Regulation, Revision of the WEEE Directive, and harmonisation of these and other EPR systems through a framework Circular Economy Act. This will provide certainty, clarity, and a roadmap for the sustainable future of EEE and batteries sectors, and for the businesses and people who use and apply technology, devices, battery-containing mobility, and energy systems to power everyday living across the EU.

We warmly welcome Ireland’s support for the 6th International WEEE Forum Conference, scheduled for 17–18 September 2026 in Dublin, as a flagship event to showcase Europe’s progress on circularity and e-waste management. The 1st International WEEE Forum conference was first held and hosted by WEEE Ireland in Dublin 20 years ago, focusing on the original 2002 Directive. Since then, Ireland has been named by the European Commission in its 2017 Compliance Promotion exercise, as an exemplar small country implementing the 2012 WEEE Directive. The 2026 event promises to deliver meaningful opportunities for collaboration, knowledge-sharing, and the advancement of innovative solutions that support the EU’s transition to a circular economy. The Dublin conference offers a tangible example of EU cooperation delivering real benefits. Through inclusive dialogue, media engagement, business and citizen-focused narratives, Ireland can highlight how a collective and harmonised EU approach to WEEE EPR enables shared learning, and delivers accessible and tangible developments in resource efficiency, and circularity in action. WEEE and Battery EPR systems in Ireland have 20 years of successful implementation under European Directive and Regulation frameworks, with a value chain and collaborative network that demonstrate ownership and progress in meeting complex environmental challenges. WEEE Irelands Membership of more than 1800 industry Producers, range from large multinationals to local importers and wholesalers. Thousands of retail shops provide extended takeback for recycling services to the Irish public, supporting the network of 100+ Civic Amenity Sites across Local Authority Areas, and public collection events and other business, school, and community recycling programmes we have established since 2005. Investment in indigenous logistics and environmental management operators including KMK Metals Recycling In Tullamore and Kilbeggan and Irish Lamps in Athy, supports significant Irish employment and innovation in the green economy, while Pan-European co-operation with WEEE Forum and other networks including EUCOBAT, and CIRCULÉIRE in Ireland, ensure best practice through knowledge sharing and a standards-based quality approach. Examples of WEEE Ireland’s extensive public communications on meeting the e-waste challenge and circular economy development can be found on our website www.weeeireland.ie and activities detailed in our annual report WEEE Ireland Annual Report 2024. The WEEE Forum website www.weee-forum.org showcases the scale of the network across all Member States and beyond and the range of research, development and innovation projects and campaigns the Forum is involved in with and on behalf of the EPR Schemes can be seen at Projects and campaigns | WEEE Forum including the annual International E-Waste Day consumer campaign.

Circular Economy & WEEE Directive Revision On behalf of the WEEE Forum and WEEE Ireland, we welcome the opportunity to contribute to Ireland’s Presidency priorities for the Council of the European Union in 2026. We strongly urge that the Presidency places the Circular Economy at the heart of its agenda, recognising its role in delivering climate neutrality, positive environmental impact, resource security, and competitiveness across the EU. This aligns with Ireland’s forthcoming Second Whole of Government Circular Economy Strategy and the EU Strategic Agenda 2024–2029, which prioritises sustainability, resilience, and digital transformation. In particular for our sectors, the ongoing revision of the WEEE Directive under the forthcoming EU Circular Economy Act is a critical legislative milestone. This review must address persistent challenges such as not fit-for-purpose collection targets, harmonisation of Extended Producer Responsibility (EPR) schemes including online sales, and incentivising recovery of critical raw materials, while enabling innovative circular business models and recognising advanced repair and reuse initiatives already being led by our industry Members. Ireland’s leadership during its Presidency offers a unique opportunity to accelerate these reforms and champion policies that make circularity practical and scalable for all Member States. Finally, we warmly welcome Ireland’s support for the 6th International WEEE Forum Conference, scheduled for 17–18 September 2026 in Dublin, as a flagship event to showcase Europe’s progress on circularity and e-waste management. The 1st International WEEE Forum conference was held in Dublin 20 years ago focusing on the original 2002 Directive, and since then Ireland has been named by the European Commission in its 2017 Compliance Promotion exercise as an exemplar small country implementing the 2012 WEEE Directive. The 2026 event promises to deliver meaningful opportunities for collaboration, knowledge-sharing, and the advancement of innovative solutions that support the EU’s transition to a circular economy. We remain available to provide further evidence and collaborate on shaping an ambitious, future-oriented Presidency programme. Sincerely, [REDACTED UNDER GDPR] Is mise le meas, [REDACTED UNDER GDPR]

organisation:
We Care Alliance, on behalf of the RESIL-Card consortium. [REDACTED UNDER GDPR]
See Website: https://www.wecareabouthearts.org/resilcard/the-project/
response_text: For its Presidency of the Council of the European Union in 2026, Ireland should prioritise “Health, crisis preparedness and resilience” as one of the high-level thematic pillars. This aligns closely with the Council of the European Union's 2024–2029 Strategic Agenda, which prioritises building a strong and secure Europe, and the European Commission’s recently launched Union Prevention, Preparedness and Crisis Response Plan (28 November 2025), which places resilience, security and crisis readiness at the forefront of the EU’s future direction. In particular, Ireland should champion efforts that strengthen resilience, preparedness, crisis prevention and response capacities across the Union, ensuring that the provision of essential care services is safeguarded and that citizens and societies are better protected against a broad spectrum of crises — from natural disasters to public health emergencies of any cause.
