The experience of the COVID-19 pandemic demonstrated the significant and deleterious impact of healthsystems’ unpreparedness on essential care delivery. For cardiovascular disease — the leading cause of mortality in Europe — disruptions to care pathways resulted in severe consequences to patients, healthcare systems and wider society, as reported by We Care (Lunardi M et al. Eur Heart J Qual Care Clin Outcomes. 2024 Jan 12;10(1):25-35. doi: 10.1093/ehjqcco/qcad025. PMID: 37286294). Building on these lessons, the RESIL-Card consortium has developed a resilience assessment tool designed to help European cardiovascular systems improve their preparedness, thereby ensuring the continuity of lifesaving care during future crises. By identifying vulnerabilities and supporting Member States in strengthening their healthcare pathways, this initiative will contribute directly to the broader EU objective of reinforcing health system resilience. With the roll-out of the RESIL-Card tool scheduled for Q1 2026, Ireland’s Presidency would come at a pivotal moment to promote EU-wide measures that enhance crisis preparedness in healthcare. In an era marked by increasing uncertainty and interconnected threats — any of which could trigger cross-border health emergencies — prioritising resilience under the theme of a “strong and secure Europe” would be both timely and strategically sound.

organisation:
We Care Alliance, on behalf of the RESIL-Card consortium. [REDACTED UNDER GDPR]
See Website: https://www.wecareabouthearts.org/resilcard/the-project/
response_text: To advance a stronger and more secure Union, the Irish Presidency in 2026 should prioritise policy areas that reinforce health system resilience, crisis preparedness and the continuity of essential care pathways. A key focus should be the development and implementation of EU-level policies that strengthen Member States’ ability to maintain lifesaving treatment during crises — particularly within high-burden disease areas such as CVD. The Irish Presidency could play an important role in ensuring that preparedness and care pathway resilience are systematically integrated into ongoing and future EU health initiatives, including those stemming from the Union Prevention, Preparedness and Response Plan and the broader European Health Union agenda. This includes encouraging progress on legislative proposals aimed at improving crossborder health-threat coordination, supporting national health system preparedness assessments, and embedding resilience considerations into EU funding programmes and national health reforms. Within this framework, Ireland could champion the uptake of tools that enable evidence-based preparedness planning. The RESIL-Card tool, which will be rolled out in 2026, offers actionable insights to improve the robustness of cardiovascular care pathways. By promoting the incorporation of the RESILCard results into policy discussions and Council conclusions, the Irish Presidency could help stimulate wider adoption across Member States, accelerating the strengthening of cardiovascular care systems capable of withstanding future shocks and rapidly adapting to emerging threats. In addition, the methodology underpinning the RESIL-Card tool provides an opportunity for broader system transformation. Demonstrating its applicability to other clinical specialties would support the development of a blueprint for system-wide health resilience, helping the EU move towards coherent, harmonised approaches to preparedness across different areas of care. The Irish Presidency could therefore encourage the Commission and Member States to explore pathways for scaling such a methodology beyond cardiovascular diseases, facilitating long-term EU cooperation on resilience planning. By prioritising these areas, Ireland could deliver concrete progress toward a more resilient European Health Union — one in which essential care remains uninterrupted, health systems are better prepared for crises, and citizens are better protected regardless of the challenges ahead.

organisation:
We Care Alliance, on behalf of the RESIL-Card consortium. [REDACTED UNDER GDPR]
See Website: https://www.wecareabouthearts.org/resilcard/the-project/
response_text: During the Irish Presidency, the Council can deliver substantial and lasting benefits for people, businesses and communities across the EU by prioritising preparedness and resilience of essential care pathways within national health systems. Advancing policies that strengthen the continuity and quality of lifesaving services — particularly during crises — would help protect patient outcomes while minimising the broader societal and economic consequences of disrupted care. Promoting preparedness in areas such as cardiovascular care, Europe’s leading cause of mortality, would support the development of more integrated and patient-centred healthcare systems across Member States. Such systems are better equipped to ensure equitable and timely access to treatment, even under severe strain. This approach would not only prevent avoidable deaths among those with existing conditions or heightened risk factors but would also reduce the long-term disease burden that constrains workforce participation, productivity and social cohesion. Businesses and communities would benefit from the increased stability that resilient health systems provide. Fewer disruptions to essential services mean fewer workforce absences, lower healthcare-related costs, and greater capacity for rapid recovery after emergencies — all of which enhance economic resilience and competitiveness. Strengthening care pathway preparedness therefore represents both a public-health priority and a strategic investment in Europe’s social and economic well-being. By placing health-system resilience at the centre of its agenda, the Irish Presidency can help the Council drive forward initiatives that tangibly improve the lives of citizens, reinforce the stability of communities, and support sustainable economic growth across the Union.

organisation:
We Care Alliance, on behalf of the RESIL-Card consortium. [REDACTED UNDER GDPR]
See Website: https://www.wecareabouthearts.org/resilcard/the-project/
response_text: During its presidency of the EU in 2004-2005, Ireland has implemented the ban for smoking in public places with immediate and long-term benefit on health care. This initiative was initially driven by the European Affairs Committee (chaired by Prof. J. Martin and W. Wijns) of the European Society of Cardiology and has triggered the adoption of the ban in one European country after the other leading to massive benefit for the health of European citizens. A similar impact can be anticipated from the implementation of the RESIL-Card tool for preparedness, even beyond the cardiovascular sector through increased awareness, stakeholder engagement and activation of crisis management teams as well as stimulating resilience of the patient care pathways. Significant progress has already been made within the RESIL Card project and the tool is ready for dissemination for maximum impact. Engagement with key stakeholders has been established already in a number of countries including Ireland. The consortium met with Prof. Mary Horgan and team members on November 06,2025. Followup joint working sessions are planned and we believe that there is buy in to roll out the RESIL-Card tool at a regional level in Ireland, leveraging support on a national level through the NIPC. The best-practice example of proactive preparedness in Ireland would support the endorsement and dissemination of strategies that strengthen resilience, preparedness, crisis prevention and response capacities across the Union under the leadership of Ireland during its upcoming EU Presidency.

organisation:
We Care Alliance, on behalf of the RESIL-Card consortium. [REDACTED UNDER GDPR]
See Website: https://www.wecareabouthearts.org/resilcard/the-project/
response_text: At a time when preparedness, resilience and crisis response are at the heart of the agendas of both the Council of the European Union and the EU Commission, the RESIL-Card project, with its resilience assessment tool for cardiovascular care pathways, stands out as a timely and highly relevant contribution to bolstering Europe’s health preparedness and resilience. Drawing on lessons from the exposure of critical vulnerabilities in cardiovascular care delivery during the COVID-19 pandemic, the RESIL-Card consortium has, over the past two years, successfully designed and tested a practical, evidence-based resilience assessment tool for cardiovascular care pathways. Developed through an inclusive and stepwise approach, as described in the appended methodological publication (https://medrxiv.org/cgi/content/short/2025.09.01.25334825v1), that fostered a strong sense of ownership among participants while ensuring the tool focused on actionability, the RESIL-Card tool empowers cardiovascular professionals to assess, strengthen and sustain the preparedness of their care pathways in order to withstand shocks and maintain continuity of lifesaving care during future crises, such as pandemics, climate events, resource constraints, and others. The pilot phase evaluated the functionality, usability and applicability of the RESIL-Card tool in real-world healthcare settings. Based on valuable feedback from European cardiovascular professionals regarding their experience of testing the tool, the consortium is now refining and optimising it in preparation for its widespread rollout across Europe in Q1 2026. Next year, targeted dissemination and engagement activities will reach the European cardiovascular community, public and patient organisations, as well as policymakers at both national and EU levels with the objective to foster the tool's broad adoption and integration into European health systems. As early results and stakeholder engagement have revealed a high level of interest in adapting the RESILCard tool for use in other clinical specialties - underscoring its potential as a model for system-wide health resilience - the RESIL-Card consortium is ready to engage in a collaboration with the relevant European stakeholders, and/or others, to extend the RESIL-Card approach to care areas other than CVD, thereby supporting the broader vision of making European health systems future-proof. On behalf of the RESIL-Card consortium, [REDACTED UNDER GDPR]

organisation: International Institute of Peace Studies and Global Philosophy (IIPSGP); Irish Chapter
response_text: Peace and Peace Research and Promotion through the establishment of the European Peace Agency (EPA) on the model of the European Space Agency, based in Dublin.

organisation: International Institute of Peace Studies and Global Philosophy (IIPSGP); Irish Chapter
response_text: International Relations within the EU and between the EU and the rest of Europe and the Wider World, with dedicated focus and effort in the promotion of peace and diplomacy and adherence to international law, in keeping with Article 29 of our own Constitution, Bunreacht na hÉireann. The Irish Government should aim to use its presidency to strive for peace in Europe and the world; to end the normalization of war; and to improve international diplomacy and statecraft.

organisation: International Institute of Peace Studies and Global Philosophy (IIPSGP); Irish Chapter
response_text: Set up the European Peace Agency (EPA) with a view to promoting and establishing just and permanent peace within the EU and between the EU, the rest of Europe and the Wider World.

organisation: International Institute of Peace Studies and Global Philosophy (IIPSGP); Irish Chapter
response_text: The EU was established as a Peace Project. On the assumption that it is still a peace project, the proposed European Peace Agency (EPA), based in Dublin, will facilitate the communication and promotion of the EU’s principles of peace and peaceful international relations to the people of the union. The study, research and promotion of Peace at the Institute will support the maintenance of peace and the ideology of peace throughout the EU and beyond.

organisation: International Institute of Peace Studies and Global Philosophy (IIPSGP); Irish Chapter
response_text: European Peace Agency (EPA) Vision Document — Comprehensive Summary Edition Executive Summary The European Peace Agency (EPA) is proposed as a treaty-based, professional, non-military peacebuilding and mediation institution, modelled on the successful architecture of the European Space Agency (ESA). Its mission is to prevent, resolve, and transform conflicts across Europe and neighbouring regions through expert mediation, research, and rapid-response diplomacy. Distinct Value Proposition UN: EPA offers regional specificity and rapid mediation, avoiding global gridlock. NATO: EPA is non-military, focused on prevention and resolution. EU: EPA includes non-EU states and operates with neutrality beyond political entanglements. Implementation Roadmap (First 36 Months) Treaty drafting working group Provisional Secretariat in Dublin (Venice subsidiary) Selection of inaugural mediators (10 per member state, gender parity) Pilot mediation in a low-risk regional dispute Success Metrics (10-Year Horizon) Number of disputes resolved Trust index surveys Member participation rates Reduction in regional instability indicators Cost-Saving Argument The EPA’s €7.6B budget is less than 0.5% of the cost of a major European war. Peacebuilding saves trillions in reconstruction, refugee support, and military expenditure. Cross-Party Benefits Labour and Social Democratic Parties: provides extra funding for social investment Conservatives: Stability, reduced military burden, scientific expertise enhancement Liberal Democrats: Diplomacy, international cooperation, global solidarity, humanitarianism-in-action, intercultural harmony, educational advancement Greens: Non-violence, environmental protection, generating funding for eco-investment Populist Identity politics: Reducing over-immigration by creating international stability Communist and Marxist Parties: Advancement of the ideal of ending class and social conflict through the sublimation of violence towards common cooperation for the universal good. European Intellectual Heritage: The EPA embodies Europe’s humanist, philosophical, intellectual, and spiritual traditions — a shared Classical and Christian heritage, Erasmus, the Quakers, Kant’s Perpetual Peace, and the post‑war integration vision — fostering cooperative sovereignty through a shared will‑to‑peace, affirming multicultural complexity as strength, not weakness. Please see full proposal attached separately.

Ireland’s Minister of State at the Department of Enterprise, Tourism and Employment Niamh Smyth stated at Forum Europe’s International AI Conference on 11 December 2025 that investment in people and technology are to be priorities of the Irish Presidency of the Council in 2026. The Centre for Future Generations (CFG) believes Europe faces a narrow window to shape emerging technologies for intergenerational fairness and therefore fully endorses Ireland’s chosen approach. Our more detailed suggestions below serve Ireland’s two agreed high-level themes. Ireland’s Council of the EU Presidency falls at a key six month juncture for shaping the next iteration of the EU’s key instrument for financial investment in people and technology, the Multiannual Financial Framework, FP10. For funding, research, policy and regulatory development consistency, Ireland and its Presidency Trio’s work programme should be underpinned by cross-cutting and silo-breaking approaches to the existing European strategies on industrial competitiveness and intergenerational fairness. EU leadership in technology should be based on talent development, inclusive and strategic infrastructure investments. Intergenerational fairness in a tech-forward Europe requires more comprehensive and future-looking technology governance. The Irish Presidency would be ideally placed to leverage any stocktaking opportunities across EU Council configurations to better join up EU approaches to research ethics, standards and institutional design, which CFG sees increasingly spotlighted within high-level political agreements across defence, security, climate planning and more.

To serve the high-level thematic priorities listed above, the Irish Presidency should focus on the Intergenerational Fairness Strategy, addressing the needs of all generations and looking at emerging technologies’ transformative effects on the European economy. For intergenerational fairness to become a cross-cutting principle, pursue a coordinated, mainstreaming approach that avoids siloing it within the Education, Youth, Culture and Sport (EYCS) Council. Instead, intergenerational fairness should serve as an anchoring principle for decisions across multiple Council configurations. EPSCO, ECOFIN, Competitiveness, Research and Environment Councils would each apply this lens within their policy domains, allowing the principle of intergenerational fairness to gain traction where decisions with generational consequences are made. Advance the Cloud and AI Development Act (CAIDA) and relevant funding instruments such as Horizon Europe and the Competitiveness Fund, both critical for strengthening Europe's AI capabilities and supporting breakthrough innovation in AI development and deployment. At the High-level Summit on AI that Ireland will convene in October 2026—"Enabling AI to Power Innovation-Led Growth in Europe" : secure political commitment to prepare for the AGI-related risks and governance challenges expected in the coming years, ensuring Europe can navigate the AGI technological shift safely. Coordinate progress on Biotech Act I and Biotech Act II across relevant Council configurations (EPSCO for health and regulatory issues; the Competitiveness Council for industrial and research aspects). The EU Innovation Act should retain a strong biotech focus, drawing on Ireland’s regulatory expertise in the HPRA and its role within the EMA. Deepen EU cooperation with like-minded partners (UK, Canada, the African Union), creating the conditions to address climate-security challenges while leveraging Ireland and EU’s diplomatic strengths. The Presidency should launch early technical and informal discussions on the Energy Union governance revision, preparing member states ahead of the Commission's Q4 2026 proposal and aligning with the Green Deal goals on energy security and fossil fuel phase-out. Advance the Digital Fairness Act, launching early technical discussions and framing Council priorities ahead of the Commission's Q4 2026 proposal, ensuring consumer protection and democratic accountability are embedded in digital governance regulation. Strengthen effective enforcement of the key regulatory instruments enforced EU-wide: the Digital Services Act, Digital Markets Act, Data Act and AI Act. The Presidency could meet this objective by following up on previous Presidencies’ efforts with broad political high-level stocktake on implementation (e.g. this Danish Presidency effort) to inform Council discussions and complement the EU Democracy Shield. Relatedly, facilitate discussions across COREPER I and COREPER II on combating disinformation and misinformation - phenomena which impact European security at large and jeopardise trust in democratic instruments and institutions. • Facilitate progress on the 28th regime as part of broader and long-term competitiveness with careful consideration by EPSCO Council on labour rights implications. An efficiently designed, inclusive, and promptly implemented 28th regime would reduce regulatory fragmentation for European startups, enabling them to scale across the single market effectively and with a longerterm perspective.

The Irish Presidency should deliver concrete progress on emerging technology policies that balance Europe's competitiveness with safety and intergenerational fairness for citizens. Given Ireland's unique positioning in the global tech sector, it can demonstrate that Europe can lead in evidence-based decisionmaking and innovation while protecting people and businesses from the risks of rapidly evolving technologies through an approach that considers the long-term interests of European citizens. Developing effective policy for emerging technologies is inherently difficult, given their broad and often unpredictable impacts on people and businesses. To address this challenge, Ireland can actively facilitate broader stakeholder-led drafting of implementing rules as the preferred approach for technical provisions, building on the GPAI Code of Practice model that delivered clearer, more workable, and inclusive standards. For example, in Digital Omnibus trilogues, this method can resolve contested provisions by deferring technical detail to expert-led processes, ensuring workable outcomes that serve both innovation and public interest. The emerging trend among Member States to embrace tech diplomacy and science diplomacy and embed these within Council Presidency working party chairmanships as we saw under the Danish Presidency can unlock significant positive impact for the EU: it can build technology-based consensus in EU decisionmaking that carries through back in national capitals, to assure Council Presidency legacies in subsequent years. The European Framework for Science Diplomacy, co-created by scientists and diplomats, is a product worth further consideration by the Irish Presidency. The Framework’s specific recommendations merit attention during the latter months of 2026, milestone moments in MFF and Horizon Europe negotiations.

Ireland's 2026 Council Presidency can build a sense of ownership by showing citizens how Ireland's regulatory and institutional framework for digital services actively shapes EU rules that ultimately protect people's rights, strengthen competitiveness, and support a sustainable, secure tech future. Recent developments, such as growing tensions with the current US administration, highlight the need to reinforce this legacy, making it even more important to communicate Ireland's contribution to fair, safe, and climate-aligned digital and emerging tech markets across Europe. The Irish Presidency should communicate EU membership benefits through concrete examples of responsible innovation that directly impact citizens' lives. To create genuine citizen ownership, Ireland should strategically guide the thematic focus of Eurobarometer surveys to ensure policy prioritization reflects citizens' real concerns, demonstrating that the Presidency responds to what matters to people. Measuring public urgency around climate interventions and perceptions of different climate technologies, informing the development of governance frameworks for climate intervention technologies. Gauging citizen views on neurotechnology applications to identify governance development opportunities that balance innovation with ethical safeguards. Assessing public understanding and support for SME-driven biotech innovation versus corporatedominated approaches.

As emphasised throughout this submission, Ireland's 2026 Presidency should establish intergenerational fairness as the guiding principle for Europe's approach to emerging technologies. This principle needs to actively shape agenda-setting and guide discussions within the Council across different policy and regulatory procedures, from AI governance and biotechnology frameworks to digital infrastructure standards. Intergenerational fairness principles will ensure today's decisions on emerging technologies create opportunities rather than vulnerabilities for current and future generations. This is particularly important for Europe's competitiveness as Europe can be competitive only if it ensures that emerging technologies serve the long-term interests of future generations. With Europe facing a narrow window to shape emerging technologies for intergenerational fairness, CFG advocates for three big, bold commitments requiring political will by consensus: embedding future generations into policymaking, building anticipatory governance capacity and making strategic choices about which technologies to accelerate. CFG stands for governing innovation - enhancing competitiveness today, and through long-term governance, securing fairness and progress for future generations. We believe these objectives to be aligned with Ireland’s approach to its upcoming Presidency of the Council of the EU, and we look forward to working with the Irish Presidency and the Trio programme it will lead on advancing this vision.

A renewed focus on the central role of the European social model in improving the working and living conditions of all citizens is one way the Irish Presidency could have substantial impact on all communities and sectors throughout the EU. It would also help build strong support for the European Project at a time when the EU’s capacity and commitment to fairness and equality is coming under increasing scrutiny. Negotiations on the Multi-Annual Financial Framework (MFF) will be continuing, if not concluding, negotiations during the Irish Presidency. We share the concerns of civil society organisations regarding the change from dedicated allocations and negotiations of the European Social Fund Plus, to a flat 14% threshold for ‘social funding’. There is a strong correlation between well-designed social expenditure and economic competitiveness. For this reason, sound social spending should not be viewed as compensation or an optional add-on but as a positive investment in the future that will create prosperity. The failure to ring-fence budgets for social inclusion, child poverty and material deprivation threatens accountability and impact. The Irish Presidency will occur at a critical time in the negotiations, and we hope will be able to resolve outstanding issues to ensure that the EU Budget will underpin the rights of its most vulnerable citizens. A strong focus on disability during the Irish Presidency resulting in EPSCO Council Conclusions/Recommendations would signal the EU’s commitment to advancing the rights of people with disabilities across the EU. An EU Council event in Ireland on the employment of people with disabilities would provide an important platform to engage with business and communities on the matter of inclusive employment.

Despite a rise in Euroscepticism across Europe, the latest Eurobarometer survey shows that a majority of Irish people (59%) remain supportive of the EU. Given the current geopolitical climate of crisis and instability globally, it is crucial that the European Union remains rooted in and true to its founding values. The EU is often characterised as distant from the everyday lives of Irish people, and EU citizens more broadly. The Irish Presidency provides an opportunity to restate and reaffirm the benefits of our EU membership. Disability remains a prevalent issue in Ireland and across the EU. The inclusion of disability matters in the priorities of the Irish Presidency would be a strong signal of the EU’s commitment to vindicate the rights of some of our most vulnerable citizens. The involvement of civil society organisations on an ongoing basis throughout the Presidency would ensure participation and engagement of citizens across the broad spectrum of Irish society. Civil society organisations bring a diverse range of opinions, economic backgrounds, and social circumstances. They can also help shape the political agenda for the Presidency and the EU by grounding the EU in the political desires and aspirations of its communities and citizens. A collaborative process of involvement between civil society, governments, and EU institutions would serve to strengthen support for the EU. It would assist in showing the EU to be transparent and engaging with citizens. Civil society could also help communicating the benefits of EU membership and of the priorities of the Irish Presidency. Where possible civil society organisations should be included and involved in official events organised throughout the Presidency. This would help ensure that planned events are relevant to the communities and sectors involved. Moreover, Presidency events should be organised across the four provinces of Ireland with a fair regional distribution. We understand that a number of Presidency Side Events are also planned. Again, the involvement of civil society organisations in such events will be central to their success. We would like to see several of these side events with a disability focus. The Communicating Europe Fund should be increased to enable more civil society organisations and local authorities organise specific events during the Irish Presidency. The Presidency must be inclusive and accessible at all levels to all people. Events should only take place in accessible venues and accommodation should be made for visually and hearing-impaired people. Communications/social media campaigns should be accessibility proofed.

As one of the largest providers of disability services in Ireland, Rehab Group would be interested to participate and/or assist in the organisation of events during the Presidency on the theme of disability. Rehab Group is an independent voluntary organisation that has supported adults and children with disabilities for more than 75 years. As a campaigning and advocacy body, we represent the voices of the 12,500 individuals who currently access our services, as well as their families. Our mission is to empower those we support to live more independent lives and to participate fully in their communities. We achieve this through the delivery of high-quality, flexible, and sustainable services in care (RehabCare), education and training (National Learning Network) and employment (Rehab Enterprises). All across Ireland, RehabCare offers anyone living with a disability or disadvantage – young and old alike – the personalised, individual support they need to live their lives as fully and independently as possible. With more than 210 community-based services across the country, RehabCare provides personalised support for people of all ages and all abilities across a range of service models including accommodation services, respite, Day-services, outreach and home support National Learning Network (NLN) is a provider of inclusive education, training, and employment support for disabled people or people with additional support needs in every country in Ireland. NLN offers Universal Design informed, person-centred programmes that enable people to develop transversal skills, achieve qualifications, progress to further education and training, higher education, and get jobs. NLN is one one of eleven organisations to receive funding from the Government’s Digital and Assistive Technology Fund Rehab Enterprises is one of the largest non-governmental employers of people with disabilities. We work with a range of public and private sector partners in providing dynamic business solutions. Rehab Group can put forward people with lived experience of disability from across our three divisions to speak at Presidency events. Our advocates have experience presenting at local, national and EU events. They have appeared before Oireachtas Committees on Education, Employment, Transport and Disability Matters. Our Voter Education programme won the Aontas Star Award in the Learner Voice category in 2025 and recently featured in the European Association for the Education of Adults (EAEA) Enhance Podcast series. We have a number of subject matters experts available to speak on a range of disability matters including Care and Social Services, housing (including supported housing), education, training and skills development, assistive technology and employment. We have campaigned strongly on the issue of employment of people with disabilities. Our 2026 International Day for Persons with a Disability campaign “More than a Job” focussed on the issue of inclusive employment and the campaign video features staff from Rehab Enterprises, students from National Learning Network and a range of employers that we work with such as Mr Price, Gaelite Signs and Mitie in Dublin Airport. We would greatly welcome the opportunity to participate in Presidency events taking place across the country throughout 2026.
Ireland should ensure that health is embedded within its high-level thematic priorities, such as resilience and competitiveness (see response to Question 2).

Proposed Theme: "Driving Competitiveness, Delivering Climate Action". Rationale: Competitiveness: The Draghi Report identifies high energy costs (2-3 times higher in the EU than the US or China) as a critical threat to European industry. Rapidly deploying indigenous renewables is the only viable solution to lower these costs and restore competitiveness. This Presidency must therefore pivot from setting targets to removing the barriers, specifically grid bottlenecks and permitting delays that prevent the deployment of clean energy. Climate Action: This theme directly reflects the urgency highlighted by the Minister for Climate, Energy and the Environment, Darragh O'Brien, in his statement following the conclusion of COP30. Noting that the COP30 text "falls short of meaningful ambition," the Minister emphasised that the fight for a "fair, effective, and ambitious global response" must now be taken forward to COP31 under the Irish Presidency. He stated clearly that "that work begins now" to deliver a credible roadmap for the phase-out of fossil fuels. Benefit for Ireland: Leading this agenda positions Ireland as a pragmatic leader in the global energy transition. It ensures that the EU policy direction aligns with Ireland's national objective to achieve energy independence and directly addresses the electricity price volatility caused by our reliance on gas.

We propose four priority areas, each backed by specific legislative files and Presidency actions: Priority 1: Upgrading Europe’s Electricity Grids Legislative Focus: The European Grids Package (expected late 2025) and TEN-E Regulation. Presidency Actions: o Binding Timelines: Secure agreement on the Grids Package with binding permitting deadlines to resolve the bottlenecks currently stalling renewable deployment. Anticipatory Investment: Champion reforms to allow grid build-out ahead of demand rather than lagging behind. IPCEI for Grids: Lead a coalition to establish an Important Project of Common European Interest (IPCEI) for electricity grids to unlock large-scale cross-border investment. Benefit for Ireland: Grid congestion is the single biggest barrier to Irish renewables. A strong EU Grids Package will unlock projects like the North-South Interconnector and allow Ireland to export its surplus wind energy, turning a potential waste of resources into a revenue stream. Priority 2: Accelerating Electrification Legislative Focus: The Electrification Action Plan (Q1 2026) and Guidance on Network Tariffs. Presidency Actions: o Tariff Reform: Drive the adoption of dynamic, time-varying network tariffs that reward consumers for using clean energy when it is abundant. Flexible Connections: Promote the implementation of flexible connection agreements (under Directive EU 2024/1711) to faster connect heat pumps and EVs. Benefit for Ireland: Electrification is key to reducing Ireland's €3.3 billion annual spend on imported fossil fuels. It will also support the competitiveness of Irish industry by enabling them to access lowercarbon, lower-cost power – increasingly important for attracting FDI. Priority 3: Accelerating Permitting Legislative Focus: RED III Implementation and the Omnibus Package. Presidency Actions: o Best Practice Conference: Host a high-level EU conference on "Permitting Best Practice," showcasing solutions like One-Stop Shops and digital permitting platforms. Implementation Drive: Support the Commission in monitoring RED III compliance to reduce the administrative burden that currently delays projects. Benefit for Ireland: Faster permitting de-risks the project pipeline for onshore and offshore wind, ensuring Ireland meets its 2030 climate targets and maintaining investor confidence in the Irish market. Priority 4: Embedding Flexibility Legislative Focus: Electricity Market Design (EMD) and the 2026 White Paper on Market Integration. Presidency Actions: o Flexibility Assessments: Lead by example by delivering Ireland’s National Flexibility Needs Assessment early. Engagement on this must start now. o Future Market Design: Shape the Council’s debate to ensure market rules value non-fossil flexibility services like Long Duration Energy Storage. Benefit for Ireland: Flexibility prevents waste. Energy storage could save Irish consumers up to €85 million annually by 2030 and reduce the "dispatch-down" (curtailment) of wind energy, ensuring we get maximum value from our natural resources.

We recognise that the Presidency must act as an "honest and neutral broker" and cannot prioritise specific national interests over the Union’s needs. However, the challenges of high energy prices and infrastructure deficits are shared by every Member State. Therefore, while respecting the constraints of the office, we encourage Ireland to push ambitiously for delivery on the following shared European goals, which will have a substantial positive impact on citizens and businesses: Cutting Bills, Not Just Carbon: The most tangible impact for citizens is reduced energy costs. Renewable electricity saved Irish consumers nearly €1 billion between 2000 and 2023 and cut bills by €320 per person during the energy crisis. By focusing the Council’s work on delivery (specifically grids and permitting), the Presidency can structurally lower prices across the EU, replicating these savings for families Europe-wide. Energy Security: Accelerating the build-out of indigenous energy infrastructure reduces exposure to volatile global fossil fuel markets. Gas prices dictated electricity costs 80% of the time in Ireland during the crisis, despite only generating 40% of our power. Breaking this link through rapid infrastructure delivery is the most effective way to protect EU citizens from future geopolitical shocks. Competitiveness: For businesses, a focus on the Clean Industrial Deal and affordable power is essential for survival. As the Draghi Report highlights, European electricity prices are 2-3 times higher than in the US or China. Lowering these costs through grid upgrades and electrification will prevent de-industrialisation and support the creation of green jobs across the continent. Benefit for Ireland: Protecting Irish households from future global energy price shocks is a primary national interest. Additionally, a secure, green energy system makes Ireland an attractive location for energy-intensive Foreign Direct Investment (FDI). While we understand the limitations of the Presidency role, we urge the Government not to view "neutrality" as passivity. Ireland should confidently lead the charge on Grids, Permitting, and Electrification, knowing that this agenda is not just a national priority, but an existential necessity for the entire European Union.

Mirroring Pillar 4 of the Accelerating Infrastructure Action Plan (Public Acceptance), the Presidency should highlight how EU policies fund local wins. Here are a few ways in which this could be done: Interactive "Action" Events: Instead of abstract policy meetings, the Presidency should host a major "Accelerating Permitting" conference involving civil society to discuss how renewable projects deliver local benefits. Local Benefits Focus: Communication should highlight how EU directives support Community Benefit Funds and how renewable projects contribute local rates to County Councils, directly funding community services. Showcasing Irish Success: Use the Presidency to Host "Energy Innovation Days" to showcase local success stories and progress being made in across the energy transition. Benefit for Ireland: Increased public engagement fosters "social licence" for essential infrastructure. By clearly linking EU policy to local economic wins (jobs, community funds), we can reduce local opposition to the grid and renewable projects required for Ireland’s future.

Our attached document provides a comprehensive Presidency agenda focused on strengthening EU competitiveness through clean, affordable energy. It outlines four priority areas: grids, electrification, permitting and flexibility, each matched to upcoming EU legislation and concrete Presidency actions. We welcome continued engagement with the Department as preparations advance and stand ready to support the development of a focused, ambitious and deliverable Presidency programme.

geography: Uber and Uber Eats operate in 3,000 cities across 24 Member States.
response_text: Uber welcomes the beginning of the Irish Presidency, and is delighted to contribute to this consultation. Uber is proud to operate in Ireland with both taxi services and food delivery with Uber Eats. At Uber, our mission is to create opportunity through movement across Europe. With operations in 24 EU countries,including Ireland, and over 3,000 cities, we enable millions of people to move, earn, and access the goods they need daily—linking passengers and consumers with hundreds of thousands of drivers, couriers, and local merchants. In 2024, Uber and Uber Eats generated over €24 billion in economic value in the EU, supporting entrepreneurship, SMEs, and local communities across the continent. The 2026 Commission Work Programme clearly underscores the need for Europe to strengthen its competitiveness, and accelerate the green and digital transitions. In order to deliver on these ambitions, it is vital that the EU can harness the true potential of the Single Market to secure its future prosperity Uber recommends that during its Presidency, Ireland focuses on realising the recommendations of the Letta and Draghi reports, and prioritises three interconnected efforts to boost the competitiveness of the EU’s Single Market and emphasis measures which break down barriers holding economic growth, improved consumer choice, and technological innovation and uptake. Specifically, we suggest that Ireland further addresses regulatory fragmentation within the Single Market, fostering the consistent and uniform enforcement of regulation across the EU, and continue to explore regulatory simplification efforts to address inconsistencies, duplication and overlaps in regulation and reporting requirements. By leveraging its Presidency, Ireland can help steer Member States toward examining potential domestic Single Market barriers to competition, especially those within the “Terrible 10.” Ride-hailing and taxi are already governed by a comprehensive body of EU legislation designed to ensure fairness, transparency, and strong consumer protection in the digital economy. However, these services have also been regulated through a patchwork of municipal and regional rules across Europe. Many of these regulations are disproportionate, discriminatory, outdated in the context of rapidly developing technologies and pose barriers to the Single Market. This fragmentation prevents innovative companies, start-ups, and investors from benefiting from the scale, level playing field and legal certainty that the EU Single Market should provide, limiting their ability to grow and offer a seamless service to citizens. This will impact the 190 million Europeans expected to use ride-hailing services by 2030. The Irish Presidency is best placed to advocate for the removal of intra-EU barriers in order to ensure modern economic governance frameworks which can help reinforce the productivity and prosperity of millions of Europeans. The cost of inaction is clear: regulatory uncertainty and fragmentation slow or prevent frustrates the development of innovative services, deters investment, and diverts valuable resources away from innovation to compliance, ultimately raising the costs for producers, operators and consumers, and damaging Europe’s economic competitiveness. A 2025 Ricardo plc study shows that harmonising rules for the ride-hailing sector could deliver significant benefits, including job creation, lower emissions, and higher revenues: Up to 219k new jobs across six cities alone Up to 29% reduction in CO₂ emissions by removing rules that cause empty rides ● 11% increase in trip revenues by lifting price restrictions While the European Commission has committed to address the issues ride-hailing and private hire vehicles are facing in 2 out of 3 Member States, we ask that the Irish Presidency to call for the sector to be a priority to bridge the gaps of the Single Market. At Uber, we look forward to collaborating with the Irish Presidency on these important issues.

geography: Uber and Uber Eats operate in 3,000 cities across 24 Member States.
response_text: As a pioneering Member State fostering technological innovation, Ireland is well placed to guide the Council’s work in delivering on efforts to futureproof our economic, develop the future of European industry, to support startups, scaleups and small businesses to thrive in our Single Market, and to protect citizens from the impacts of climate change. The Irish Council Presidency can play an important role in encouraging coordinated progress among Member States and ensuring that work across these critical files contribute to a more competitive, resilient and dynamic European economy. We at Uber would highlight the below two policy priorities as particularly relevant for the upcoming work of the Irish Presidency. Streamline digital regulation. Uber is proud to offer shared mobility and delivery services, providing opportunities to hundreds of thousands of drivers and couriers to generate revenues, to restaurants to grow their business, and safe convenient travel for passengers and customers. As a hyperlocal player on the ground providing services for millions of EU citizens, we operate under a broad evolving set of regulations, spanning digital policy, sustainability, labour, cybersecurity, data, AI, and safety, giving us a unique regulatory perspective. The ongoing EU focus on simplification, as underscored in the 2026 Commission Agenda and the Digital Omnibus, offers a timely opportunity to reinforce the Single Market and spur on digital innovation in Europe. Specifically, we would call on Ireland during its Presidency to continue to work on addressing regulatory misalignments, such as the contradictory definition of “automated systems” between the GDPR, AI Act, and the Platform Work Directive (Chapter III), overlapping reporting obligations, and the need for better coordination among supervisory authorities to ensure consistent enforcement, avoid conflicting requirements, and provide legal certainty for businesses. Simplification will help ensure strong consumer protection while preserving business agility, resilience, and boosting innovation. Prioritise the electrification of professional fleets. Setting clear, binding targets for corporate fleets in the forthcoming EU Clean Corporate Vehicles proposal, will help to stimulate demand and create a virtuous cycle across the broader European automotive ecosystem. Decarbonisation is a team effort, and it is only through establishing unambiguous objectives that all stakeholders, including ride-hailing platforms, can we reach our common goal. This approach will allow for a shared responsibility across the value chain, ensuring that all companies operate under the same clear targets as part of a broader level-playing field within the Single Market. Time is of the essence to meet European environmental and economic goals, and Ireland’s Presidency will be crucial in delivering on this legislation to help realize the significant emissions reductions needed by the transport sector by 2030. Without a unified EU framework, the existing patchwork of national approaches risks creating uneven progress across the internal market and an uneven playing field for companies investing in decarbonisation.

geography: Uber and Uber Eats operate in 3,000 cities across 24 Member States.
response_text: Under Ireland’s Presidency, we would suggest that the Council focuses its efforts on measures which will have material benefits for consumers and citizens and help to deepen the Single Market. A practical example could be shepherding measures in Council to realise the recommendations of the 2030 Consumer Agenda such as completing the Single Market for Consumers, in particular with actions to address the private hire vehicle sector. Harmonised rules for the ride-hailing sector would concretely improve European consumers experience, notably: reduced waiting times when booking a trip; convenience and reliability thanks to consistent experiences in all cities they visit; ● affordable prices and ability to compare mobility options upfront; ● more accessible mobility options when travelling. Moreover, the Irish Presidency can also have a crucial role in shaping the debate around the presentation of the upcoming Digital Fairness Act and the revision of the Consumer Protection Cooperation (CPC) regulation. Preserving a balance between further protecting consumers and enabling businesses to develop pro-consumers innovative features will be key. The DFA should focus on harmonisation and simplification, instead of duplicative or prescriptive rules that could restrict innovation in favor of consumers. For example, further restrictions on personalisation or app design could impact features that consumers love: these practices are necessary to recommend restaurants or discounts on Uber Eats.

geography: Uber and Uber Eats operate in 3,000 cities across 24 Member States.
response_text: The Irish Council Presidency should prioritise areas where coordinated EU action can deliver visible benefits which materially improve people’s lives and reinforce Europe’s economic competitiveness, and communicate these benefits clearly. Ireland should leverage proposals such as the 2025 Consumer Agenda as part of broader public engagement which goes beyond capitals, and engages local and community organisations. Policy-focused roadshows across Ireland and the EU hosted in conjunction with local authorities, universities, youth organisations, and business networks during the Presidency can help to foster a greater sense of ownership where citizens can contribute and be involved in policy debates. Moreover, formal and informal public consultations can help to ensure that citizens’ inputs are acknowledged and reflected in policy positions. Ireland is a pioneer in this field with the Citizens’ Assembly models, which could be replicated across the EU. In addition, a Presidency that communicates openly over timelines and implications for potentially critical files for citizens and business, and which can demonstrate progress step-by-step will further reinforce the clear value of EU membership for citizens. By keeping citizens at the centre and delivering visible results, Ireland’s 2026 Presidency can strengthen public confidence in the EU and cultivate a genuine sense of shared ownership and pride.

geography: Uber and Uber Eats operate in 3,000 cities across 24 Member States.
response_text: under the ‘Any other comments’ question. This summary should also be limited to a maximum of 500 words. 2025 Ricardo plc study: Green Lights for Growth: How Smart Ride-Hailing Rules Can Accelerate Europe. The Impact of Uber in the European Union Economic Impact Report 2024

Ireland should adopt Regulatory Simplification, Competitiveness and Openness as central high-level thematic priorities for its 2026 Presidency of the Council of the European Union. Europe needs to focus on addressing its competitiveness. Occurring at the midpoint of the legislative cycle and two years post-Draghi report, this Presidency offers a strategic opportunity to correct Europe’s trajectory by shifting focus from creating new rules to implementation, coherence, and enforcement. Regulatory Simplification and Excellence: Ireland must continue to champion the spirit of the "Digital Omnibus" process to keep the focus in Europe on supporting innovation and addressing the unprecedented volume of over 100 recent digital laws. New proposals must be evidence-based, risk-based, and accompanied by economic impact assessments. Regulation should only be introduced where proven gaps exist. The Presidency should ensure the EU continues its efforts towards clarifying overlaps in files like the AI Act, Data Act, and NIS2.0, and addresses enforcement overlaps between national authorities and the Commission, particularly regarding the Digital Markets Act (DMA). Enforcement over Legislation: The focus should shift to strengthening the application of current law rather than adding to the acquis. Please note that Technology Ireland has submitted an additional paper to the Department of Foreign Affairs in relation to this consultation which is summarised in Question 5.

Ireland should ensure the EU regulatory framework prioritises innovation and competitiveness to support businesses operating in Europe, taking the following position on the below files: Digital Omnibus Package & Fitness Check: The European Commission’s Digital Omnibus Package is a positive step toward supporting business, but the Council must go further. Drawing on the call from 20 Heads of State, the Council should ensure EU digital rules are effective, proportionate, and fit for the future. The EU AI Act: A balanced copyright framework is vital for a thriving AI ecosystem. The EU’s current approach, while less permissive than the US, Japan, or Singapore, offers a reasonable balance between innovation and rights protection. Existing exceptions for text and data mining are critical for competitiveness and must be maintained. However, European leaders like Christine Lagarde and Mario Draghi are questioning the current trajectory. A renewed approach is essential to prevent Europe from falling behind. The EU AI Act must mandate regulators to promote innovation. The current High-Risk framework draft is confusing and lacks legal certainty. Furthermore, the General Purpose AI Model regime is redundant as it duplicatively regulates both upstream and downstream activities. Online Safety: The Irish Presidency must ensure proportionate, harmonized rules for children's online safety to ensure enforceability and avoid Member State fragmentation across files like the DSA and AVMS Directive. The proposed Digital Fairness Act (DFA) should not create new burdens but complement existing rules. Ireland should promote harmonized age assurance methods that balance risks to minors with user privacy and rights. Privacy Framework (GDPR & e-Privacy): Data Protection Authorities (DPAs) should promote a balanced approach supporting both data protection and economic growth. The confirmation that ‘legitimate interest’ is a legal basis for AI training is welcomed, aligning with recent guidance and providing predictability. However, concerns remain regarding drafting elements that contradict Large Language Model (LLM) technical limitations (e.g., unconditional right to object). The Digital Omnibus should better incentivize Privacy-Enhancing Technologies (PETs). Regarding cookies, the current proposal for browser-level consent is unworkable and fails to meet GDPR standards. Article 88b creates uncertainty for ad-funded models and should be deleted. Instead, Article 88a should be expanded to exempt low-risk data uses (e.g., contextual ads) to reduce banner fatigue. Digital Fairness Act (DFA): The proposed DFA contradicts simplification efforts by introducing rules in areas already covered by existing laws. Ireland should advocate for "self-restraint" in new legislation, as called for by 20 Heads of State. The DFA risks over-regulation and duplicating efforts in areas like personalized advertising. The Commission should focus on enforcing rules against proven unfair practices rather than creating a complex regulatory patchwork that threatens the ad-supported internet. EU Quantum Act Ireland should advocate for a European Quantum Act modelled on the Chips Act, prioritizing funding, infrastructure, and supply chain monitoring rather than regulating the technology itself. The focus should be on R&D investment, facilitating industrialization, and streamlining funding access. EU Batteries Regulation: To avoid a compliance shock in 2027, strengthened engagement with stakeholders is needed. A targeted delay in the application of Article 11 is supported to allow time for processing derogation requests and for manufacturers to incorporate requirements into product cycles. Please note that Technology Ireland has submitted an additional paper to the Department of Foreign Affairs in relation to this consultation which is summarised in Question 5.

The Council of the European Union should ensure it pushes further on the work ongoing in terms of regulatory simplification to support European competitiveness. It should also ensure that in relation to files such as the Digital Fairness Act (DFA), duplication of regulatory efforts is avoided especially when proposals are already contained within the scope of existing rules. Business needs a predictable, consistent regulatory approach which supports innovation. The EU’s digital rulebook has become a barrier to investment due to complex, overlapping rules and fragmented interpretations across Member States. The Council should leverage the Digital Omnibus process to progress the review of this framework, ensuring that competitiveness and innovation are embedded in the legislative process. Rather than introducing new burdens, the focus should be on clarifying existing legislation and addressing the "patchwork" of national interpretations. The Presidency should host thematic discussions within the Council Working Party on Competitiveness and Growth to resolve issues like overlapping enforcement between national authorities and the European Commission, particularly regarding the Digital Markets Act (DMA). New regulation should be introduced only where gaps are proven and must be subject to a high threshold of necessity. Europe should avoid over-regulation in future proposals, such as the Digital Networks Act (DNA), by resisting unnecessary rules on cloud services or interconnection where competitive markets already exist. Conversely, the New Legislative Framework (NLF) offers an opportunity to modernize compliance by digitising product labels, maintaining standards while simplifying information for consumers and businesses. Despite the Draghi report’s pro-competitiveness recommendations, a significant gap remains between political commitment and implementation. Future proposals must be evidence-based, risk-based, and proportionate, accompanied by rigorous economic impact assessments. The priority must shift from adding to the acquis to enforcing existing rules, allowing Member States time to implement recent files like the AI Act, Data Act, and NIS2.0. Addressing the confusing intersection of these rules is vital for a predictable environment. Furthermore, legislative reviews should clearly distinguish between B2B and B2C risks. Finally, regulatory simplification must be paired with financial reform to unlock innovation and the Council has a role here. A lack of investment is a major barrier for EU SMEs. Ireland should advocate for a Capital Markets, Savings, and Investment Union to diversify funding beyond bank lending. Unlocking savings, pension funds, and private wealth is essential to financing the twin green and digital transition and improving the EU's economic resilience. Please note that Technology Ireland has submitted an additional paper to the Department of Foreign Affairs in relation to this consultation which is summarised in Question 5.

Ireland can demonstrate the positives of openness and cooperation by leveraging international partnerships and bringing likeminded countries and its international partners together for an AI Summit during its Presidency term. Ireland should leverage partnerships including the D9+ to advocate for a focus on enforcement of existing rules, an emphasis on allowing business space to innovate and on forbearance when it comes to designing new digital regulatory rules. Ireland should retain the D9+ focus on openness as a driver of EU competitiveness and innovation, including in relation to an open model for digital sovereignty, resisting protectionist policies and creating the conditions for European industry to access and partner with the best technology solutions in AI and cloud. We welcome Europe’s outward-looking approach to digital sovereignty, as seen with the recent Berlin Declaration, which seeks to strengthen Europe’s digital capabilities while preserving access to open markets, interoperability and international collaboration with partners who share European values. The emergence of the D9+ has been a welcome development in the past few years in advancing the needs of digital front-runner nations at an EU-level. The Dublin D9+ Declaration in April 2024 reinforced the need for coherence, innovation and implementation for the EU’s digital rulebook. The broader EU-US economic relationship should be prioritised during Ireland’s Presidency, particularly in fast-moving areas like AI. Ireland has a unique relationship with the US and should ensure this is brought to the fore during its Presidency term to strengthen EU-US ties. Brings together policymakers and industry during its planned AI Summit to focus on AI opportunity. This will be positive for business, citizens and society across Ireland. On an all-island basis, Ireland and Northern Ireland are home to so many of the world’s leading technology organisations and with their deep links to the EU, US and a wider global network of pro-enterprise minded regions, are in the perfect position to convene an international summit on AI. We understand that, along with a number of other plans, Government now intends to host an AI Summit in October 2026 during the period of Ireland’s Council of the EU Presidency. Industry remains available to support with making this a success. The summit should look at how regulation can work with innovation and opportunity to ensure Ireland and Europe keep pace with global partners on AI adoption. Government should promote the integration of Europe’s semiconductor capabilities into the emerging technology frontiers of AI computing, to reflect the latter's critical dependency on the former’s capabilities. Coordinating AI developments and roadmaps with Chips Act 2.0 will be essential to building a coherent, resilient, and globally competitive European technology ecosystem. The planned AI summit would be an excellent opportunity to address this dependency. Government should recognise that essential to embedding AI adoption is ensuring access to upskilling and reskilling opportunities across the country. This includes leveraging the National Training Fund to bolster digital and AI skills across the workforce and ensuring additional funding for the industry-led Skillnet networks training model. To accelerate adoption and innovation, we propose the creation of an AI Transformation Fund (AITF). Moreover, support for sectoral AI sandboxes will be crucial for training regulators and industries to develop products and services that are ready for the AI Act. Please note that Technology Ireland has submitted an additional paper to the Department of Foreign Affairs in relation to this consultation which is summarised in Question 5.

Technology Ireland has provided our full view on this matter in an additional paper submitted alongside this response to the Department of Foreign Affairs. Technology Ireland views the 2026 Presidency as a critical "inflection point" for the EU. Occurring two years after the Draghi report and at the legislative cycle's midpoint, the Presidency must correct Europe’s trajectory by pivoting from creating new rules to supporting implementation, simplification, and coherence. Following an "unprecedented volume" of over 100 recent digital laws, the EU digital rulebook has become a barrier to investment. Ireland must act as a "regulatory hub," championing the ongoing Digital Omnibus process to review this framework. New rules should only be introduced where gaps are proven. Use the New Legislative Framework (NLF) to digitize product labels, simplifying compliance. Focus on enforcing existing laws rather than adding to the acquis. The Presidency should address overlapping enforcement between national authorities and the Commission, particularly regarding the Digital Markets Act (DMA). Ireland should convene an AI Summit in 2026, bringing together policymakers and industry. Ireland must advocate for a Capital Markets Union and create a domestic AI Transformation Fund (AITF). Leverage the National Training Fund to bolster digital skills. Mandate ENISA to conduct independent cybersecurity impact assessments for all new legislation. Regarding the Digital Networks Act (DNA) and other future proposals, avoid introducing over-regulation, such as proposals for regulating cloud services or introducing interconnection rules where a competitive market already exists. The DNA should also strive to sustain and strengthen the EU Single Market through the Country-of-Origin principle, particularly for services that are already offered on a pan-European basis. Ensure Chips Act 2.0 funding is accessible to Northern Ireland-based companies. AI Act: Maintain the current copyright balance (text/data mining exceptions). Regulators must have a mandate to promote innovation. The redundant "General Purpose AI Model" regime should be addressed. Privacy (GDPR/e-Privacy): Support "legitimate interest" as a legal basis for AI training. Digital Fairness Act (DFA): The DFA is an example of over-regulation that duplicates existing rules (GDPR, DSA) and creates uncertainty. Online Safety: Promote harmonized age assurance methods to prevent Member State fragmentation. Quantum: Advocate for a European Quantum Act modelled on the Chips Act. It should focus on infrastructure and funding, not on regulating the technology itself. • Batteries Regulation: Support a targeted delay of Article 11 to prevent a 2027 compliance shock, allowing manufacturers time to adapt.

Iarnród Éireann welcomes the opportunity to engage with the DFA to identify EU-wide issues, themes, and policy areas that may be prioritised during the term of Ireland’s presidency. The presidency provides strategic political direction on policies and objectives for the common good of the EU 27 members and its residents, and this shall align with the EU Strategic Agenda 2024 – 2029. Iarnród Éireann suggests the following priorities should be included and progressed across the EU27, with Ireland well placed and experienced to provide direction and leadership in these matters. Housing Focusing and aligning the delivery of housing around rail corridors with high frequency, reliable and fast services which support densification, Transport Orientated Development, and sustainable living. This is a key priority across many European countries, as like Ireland, they seek to respond to housing demand. Connectivity The EU has ambitious plans to better connect across the continent through fast, comfortable, safe, and reliable rail services, with more and enhanced connections to bring us closer together. These include the development of a comprehensive network of high-speed rail corridors across Europe, as launched by the European Commission in November 2025, reducing bottlenecks, enhanced cross-border connections along TEN-T corridors, air and seaport connections and improved systems in urban nodes. European Rail Traffic Management System (ERTMS) Upgrading and replacing multiple national rail systems to a single standard across European transport corridors is a priority for EU stakeholders. This allows trains to cross borders without changing signalling equipment, enhancing safety, interoperability, and competitiveness, while promoting a single European railway area. Rail Electrification Accelerating the electrification of railways will assist Europe with the objective to become the world’s first climate-neutral continent by 2050 and a commitment to reducing net greenhouse gas emissions by at least 55% by 2030. Ireland can champion that climate leadership during its presidency. This will require leading by example to address the historic underinvestment in electrification of railways in Ireland, whereas less than 3% of our railway is electrified compared to an EU27 average of 57%. Powered by a pan-European renewable energy network and realising the ambition of the EU Strategic Agenda to invest in infrastructure for energy, water, transport and communications for a strong and secure, democratic Europe, an expanded electrified rail network provides connectivity, communication and resilience for all member states. Investment Sustained multi-annual funding at an increased level is integral to rail delivering on all desired outcomes with a need to secure the proposed €51.5 billion budget for the Connecting European Facility III Programme 2028 – 2034, as the primary funding programme for rail, in the Multiannual Financial Framework to be finalised and agreed in 2026. Surety of funding will enhance cost efficiencies across the rail projects portfolio in Europe. Concluding Remarks Iarnród Éireann is of the view, that future proofing the railway infrastructure will underpin a secure Europe and a competitive and green Europe. Iarnród Éireann would welcome the opportunity to engage further with the DFA and the DoT to elaborate on this submission.

To provide a national context with Iarnród Éireann projects which align with our submission. Electrification Iarnród Éireann’s CONNECT Project, seeks to electrify and modernise Ireland’s rail infrastructure, reduce emissions, and deliver faster, frequent, and sustainable services for passengers and freight. CONNECT is backed by the EU Connecting Europe Facility and the National Development Plan, is a cornerstone of Ireland’s long-term transport strategy and aligns with the All-Island Strategic Rail Review (AISRR). The AISRR highlights that delivering electrification will take time and investment. A rolling programme of electrification will require skills, capacity, robust supply chains, and certainty of long-term investment. Experience from overseas suggests a ‘stop-start’ approach to electrification yields significantly higher unit costs than a rolling programme. Iarnród Éireann has begun advancing several projects recommended within the AISRR, including assessments on four-tracking on the Northern Line, electrification and line speed improvements of the Dublin-Cork corridor and capacity enhancements on the Dublin-Galway line. Iarnród Éireann, the Port Authority for Rosslare Europort, has submitted a planning application for the development of the Rosslare Offshore Renewable Energy Hub, the State’s largest ever purpose-built port facility dedicated to offshore renewable energy (ORE). This investment in clean energy will help to support the future electrification of the rail network. The project has been co-funded to planning stage by the EU Connecting Europe Facility. Train Protection System Iarnród Eireann is investing in its Train Protection System (TPS) to provide a modern, Class A standard system called European Train Control System (ETCS) Level 1. The national roll out of the TPS maintains and improves safety, ensuring that as the railway continues to expand and further major investments are made, safety is at the heart of the network. It also ensures that a robust supply chain for train protection equipment exists as the current systems operating on parts of the network become obsolete and increasingly expensive and difficult to maintain. Transport Orientated Development Iarnród Éireann is working with the Forward Planning system at regional and local authority level to assist planners with aligning housing objectives and transport infrastructure delivery for our growing population. Rail investment plans for the Greater Dublin Area, Cork, Limerick and Galway could unlock land for hundreds of thousands of homes up to 2040, providing affordable, sustainable and reliable transport for new and existing homeowners living close to a railway line. AISRR recommendations The European Investment Bank has also been engaged by the Department of Transport to assist in planning and prioritisation of AISRR recommendations. Iarnród Éireann suggests that the proposed priorities in our submission would benefit the following national objectives: DART+ Programme Cork Area Commuter Rail Navan Rail Line National Train Protection System - Trackside and Onboard ECTS Level 1 Enterprise Fleet Replacement Four North Limerick area and Limerick to Limerick Junction line service improvements Western Rail Corridor (Athenry to Claremorris) Dublin – Cork Rail Line Upgrade (electrification, line speed enhancements, new fleet and new/upgraded depot) Rail Freight Development (including new wagons and depots) Double tracking from Portarlington-Athlone and Athenry-Galway

By mid 2026, it’s anticipated there will be a number of legislative and policy priorities that encompass measures on biotechnology, data and digital policy, as well as competitiveness and economic resilience. Within this content, the Irish Government has the opportunity to prioritise legislative proposals that enhance competitiveness and support world-leading research, development, and innovation. A central element of this agenda will be the EU Biotech Act, a key component of the EU Competitiveness Compass. The European Commission is preparing this initiative as part of the broader European Life Science Strategy. The Biotech Act is expected to shorten approval timelines for clinical trials, facilitate EU-wide multi-country trials through clearer, harmonised procedures, and reduce unnecessary administrative burdens in trial setup and conduct. By removing barriers to clinical trials and promoting integrated, pan-European approaches —especially for rare diseases—this can help make the EU a more attractive environment for R&D investment. Leveraging European Reference Networks (ERNs) and adopting ERN-like models for clinical trial coordination would enhance collaboration, accelerate access to new therapies, and support the EU’s strategic goals in science, medicine, and innovation. Overall, Ireland can help the Biotech Act operate as an instrument that supports competitiveness and simplification, by making clinical development pathways in the EU more predictable and efficient, supporting cross-border research, and encouraging Europe’s competitiveness agenda. The European Health Data Space (EHDS) aims to create a secure, interoperable framework that allows health data to be used and shared across Member States for better patient care, research, innovation, and health policy-making. As such, we recommend Ireland focus on digital health policy, including interoperable datasets, trusted AI deployment, and robust IP and data-governance frameworks. These measures could help support evidence generation, improve care coordination, and support innovation ecosystems across Europe. Beyond specific legislative files, Ireland can also maximise the Council’s efforts by leading key policy initiatives that align with these priorities. This could include convening a multistakeholder forum on Europe’s pharmaceutical and biotech ecosystem to guide a considered, long-term approach to investment, research, development and manufacturing in the EU. Ireland could furthermore sustain an EU level focus on rare diseases by hosting a high-level conference to integrate research and innovation into clinical pathways, disseminate best practice on early diagnosis, digital tools and patient empowerment. Experiences such as the Nordic Rare Disease Summit and Nordic Rare Disease Roadmap provide a template for structured, cross sector collaboration, supported by memoranda of understanding between patient organisations and industry. Takeda has been part of organising and funding the Nordic Rare Disease Summit and is a lead partner. Taken together, this package of legislative and policy work would support the Council, under Ireland’s Presidency.

The Irish Presidency offers an important opportunity to create meaningful benefits for people, businesses, and communities across the EU. To make the most of this moment, three areas of focus can help deliver practical and lasting impact: Encouraging Investment By promoting clear and predictable policies in life sciences, streamlined regulatory processes, and strong intellectual property frameworks, the Presidency can support competitiveness, encourage investment and build resilience which will have a positive impact for people, businesses and communities. Increasing Research and Innovation Through Clinical Trials Working towards greater harmonisation of trial approvals and encouraging multi-country trials can reduce delays and complexity, particularly for rare and specialised conditions. Simplifying processes and initiatives like the European Biotech Act provide an opportunity to further support innovation and research in the EU. Translating Science into Innovation Turning scientific progress into real-world solutions requires responsive regulatory systems. By advocating for streamlined approvals and embracing data-driven approaches, including real-world evidence, the Presidency can help ensure innovation is realised quickly.

To communicate the values and benefits of EU membership and create a sense of ownership over Ireland’s Presidency of the Council, it is important to make the impact of EU decisions tangible and relatable. Showcasing successful Irish initiatives—such as pharmaceutical achievements, EU-funded research projects, and patient-centred innovations—can illustrate how collaboration at the European level translates into better care for citizens. In addition, Ireland could support a “roadshow” of life science examples of excellence across the country, showcasing leading research, manufacturing and digital health initiatives to EU stakeholders. Such a programme would bring to life how EU policy choices translate into research, and stronger regional economies, while highlighting Ireland’s role as a trusted, innovation driven partner in Europe’s health and life sciences ecosystem.

Takeda is focused on creating better health for people and a brighter future for the world. We aim to discover and deliver treatments in our core therapeutic and business areas, including gastrointestinal and inflammation, rare diseases, plasma-derived therapies, oncology and neuroscience. As a leading values-based, R&D-driven biopharmaceutical company headquartered in Japan, we are guided by our commitment to patients, our people and the planet. Our employees in approximately 80 countries and regions are driven by our purpose and are grounded in the values that have defined us for more than two centuries. In Ireland, we operate four sites including two manufacturing facilities in Bray and Grange castle as well as offices in Citywest and Baggot street, Dublin. Thank you for your consideration, and we remain open to further engagement at any stage.

respondent_type: Statutory body under the aegis of the Department of Health.
