response_text: Slogan: Health Security through Solidarity or Healthier Together Ireland’s 2026 Presidency presents an opportunity to strengthen the EU’s resilience in the face of emerging health, demographic and geopolitical pressures. As the EU continues to address lessons learned from COVID-19, respond to supply chain vulnerabilities, and adapt to the evolving bio-medical landscape, Ireland is well positioned to champion a Presidency agenda centred on the thematic priority of Health Security, with particular emphasis on the security of supply of Substances of Human Origin (SoHO)—including plasma and plasma-derived medicinal products (PDMPs). Ensuring a stable, ethically sourced, and strategically coordinated supply of these essential materials is critical for patient care, health-system resilience, and European strategic autonomy. Within this thematic priority, the strategic focus should be on: Building a Sustainable and Secure SoHO Ecosystem in Europe. Ireland can advocate for coordinated EU-level measures to enhance plasma collection capacity, reduce dependence on third-country imports, and promote innovation in SoHO processing and testing. The recently adopted SoHO Regulation provides a strong foundation, but effective implementation will require ongoing political leadership. Ireland’s Presidency could drive Council work to develop common standards for donor protection, quality and safety, and long-term supply planning. This would strengthen public trust and create a predictable, resilient supply chain for plasma and PDMPs across all Member States. Health Supply Chain Resilience. The EU’s experience during the pandemic revealed structural vulnerabilities across key medical supply chains. By focussing on supply chain resilience for plasma and PDMPs, Ireland can support progress on the EU’s Health Union package, reinforce the mandate of Health Emergency Preparedness and Response, and promote diversification and transparency in global health-related supply networks. Within this context, the high reliance on imported plasma— particularly from the United States—poses a strategic threat. Ireland could lead discussions on developing a coordinated EU plasma strategy, encouraging Member States to publish Plasma Action Plans and expand domestic collection capability, invest in donor recruitment, and support European PDMP manufacturing capacity. Equity, Solidarity and Public Trust in European Health Policy. Ensuring equitable access to PDMPs across Member States, establishing enabling frameworks to support collaborative procurement and EU partnerships to support supply capacity expansion and supply continuity will reinforce the EU’s Mandatory questions commitment to solidarity. Ireland can also highlight the role of community engagement and public awareness in sustaining voluntary, safe and sufficient donation systems. Through focus on health security—and specifically on securing a stable, sustainable supply of plasma and PDMPs for patients across Europe —Ireland can contribute meaningfully to building a more resilient, and strategically autonomous European Union., while delivering tangible benefits for patients and health systems across the EU. This thematic priority also aligns with: The Commission’s planned Global Health Resilience Initiative, which seeks to strengthen global health preparedness; The EU Strategic Agenda 2024 – 2029, priority 1) a strong and secure Europe - through strengthening resilience, preparedness, crisis prevention and response capacities to protect citizens and societies against health emergencies and 2) a prosperous and competitive Europe – through reduced dependencies and diversified and secure strategic supply chains.

respondent_type: Statutory body under the aegis of the Department of Health.
response_text: The Irish Presidency in 2026 will have a critical opportunity to advance EU health-security objectives, particularly in relation to the resilience of plasma collection and the supply of plasma-derived medicinal products (PDMPs). Several legislative and policy areas are central to safeguarding Europe’s strategic autonomy in essential medicines. Ireland should therefore prioritise the following areas: Implementation and Consolidation of the Critical Medicines Act (CMA) The CMA provides the framework for strengthening Europe’s resilience against medicine shortages by identifying critical medicines, mapping vulnerabilities, and supporting strategic manufacturing capacity. Under the Irish Presidency, work should focus on: Operationalising the Critical Medicines Alliance to ensure coordinated action on plasma and PDMPs, which are uniquely vulnerable due to the EU’s structural plasma deficit. Driving progress on strategic EU investments in plasma collection capacity—recognised as essential to reducing dependence on third-country imports. Ensuring PDMPs feature clearly within EU critical medicines lists, reflecting their clinical significance and the lack of readily substitutable therapies. Promoting incentives for innovation and capacity expansion, including targeted funding, and streamlined approvals for expanded collection and fractionation infrastructure. By the end of the Presidency, Ireland should aim to have advanced a concrete implementation roadmap for CMA actions related to biological starting materials, including plasma. Effective Roll-Out of the SoHO Regulation (Substances of Human Origin) With the SoHO Regulation entering implementation phase, the Irish Presidency can ensure that its Mandatory questions objectives—safety, quality, availability, and donor protection—are translated consistently across Member States. Article 62 of the SOHO Regulations place a duty on all Member States to make all reasonable efforts to ensure there is a sufficient, stable and resilient supply of critical SOHOs, so that people needing tratements have access when needed. Key priorities include: Harmonised application of donor-protection provisions that facilitates sustainable plasma collection while avoiding barriers that could exacerbate the EU plasma shortfall. Development of guidance on risk-based oversight to support innovation in donor recruitment and new collection models. Strengthening supply-security monitoring mechanisms, ensuring the SoHO Coordination Board captures detailed data on plasma supply, demand, and national collection performance. Ireland should aim for Council conclusions endorsing coherent EU-wide implementation and reaffirming the need to improve self-sufficiency in plasma-derived therapies. 3. Industrial Policy and Strategic Health Security Initiatives Health security is increasingly linked to industrial resilience. The Irish Presidency should focus on: Advancing EU strategic autonomy efforts under the Single Market and Industrial Strategy, ensuring biological starting materials—especially human plasma—are treated as strategic assets. Integrating PDMPs into emergency preparedness frameworks, including stockpiling strategies aligned with HERA and cross-border health-threat coordination. Conclusion The Irish Presidency should use this period to reinforce Europe’s health security by ensuring that the CMA, SoHO Regulation, and wider industrial and pharmaceutical policies deliver a sustainable, resilient plasma and PDMP ecosystem—ultimately supporting EU self-sufficiency and patient access to lifesaving therapies.

respondent_type: Statutory body under the aegis of the Department of Health.
response_text: Hundreds of thousands of Europeans depend on plasma derived medicinal products (PDMPs). PDMPs are used for the treatment of a variety of conditions including immune disorders, neurological disorders, blood disorders and infectious diseases. Anti-D immunoglobulins are PDMPs and are currently the only available treatment for the prevention of RhD immunisation during pregnancy. RhD immunisation happens when a pregnant person with RhD-negative blood type is exposed to RhD-positive blood from their foetus. This can lead to an immune reaction that can seriously impact the health of the foetus, and later of the newborn, and have potentially fatal outcomes. These medicines can only be made from human plasma. As recently as 2011, enough plasma was collected in the EU to meet the needs of EU patients. Since then, however, despite increases in both public and commercial plasma collections, the increasing demand for plasma has exceeded supply. EU countries do Mandatory questions not currently collect enough plasma to meet the needs of EU patients, who have experienced shortages of plasma medicines (plasma-derived medicinal products, or PDMPs). Anti-D immunoglobulins are only produced in a limited number of countries, all located outside the EU creating a significant supply chain vulnerability. Europe’s insufficient collection and its subsequent reliance on plasma imports, primarily from the United States, endangers patient access and thus undermines the health security of EU Member States and Europe as a whole. Experiences during the COVID-19 pandemic and times of increased geopolitical tensions show the dangerous consequences of relying heavily on imports of plasma to manufacture these essential plasma medicines. Europe must address this strategic vulnerability to protect its citizens from supply shortages of these critical medicines. Countries with plasmapheresis programmes (public and/or commercial) contribute proportionally more plasma to the manufacturing of PDMPs than countries without such programmes. The new Regulation on Substances of Human Origin (SoHO) urges Member States to increase their collection capacity and donor base for plasma by investing in non-profit and public plasmapheresis programmes. We strongly believe that by increasing their funding towards public collection programmes, EU Member States will greatly improve the prospects of delivering a secure and resilient supply of plasma medicines for their patients in the coming years. The Irish Blood Transfusion Service is an active member of the European Blood Alliance who are driving the Commit to Plasma Campaign. This campaign calls on National and EU authorities to increase their political support and funding to public plasma collection programmes with a view to increase the public collection of plasma for fractionation in Europe by 40%, and at a minimum by 25%, by 2030. This would mean increasing the plasma contribution from Europe from 9 million litres in 2022 to at least 11 million litres in the next 5 years. Specifically, the campaign calls on European Commission, the European Parliament, as well as other relevant institutions such as EDQM, to: Work towards equipping Europe with a European Plasma Coordination Plan by 2027, building on the National Plasma plans and to be reviewed regularly. Urge national authorities to commit to increasing public plasma collection, as above, through all means at their disposal, be it through the future European Plasma Coordination Plan or more formal instruments at their disposal such as communications, reports or hearings; Collect and share national data and practices to accompany plasma-collection progress of Member States and Europe as a whole. Reliable, publicly accessible data is missing today; and Engage with other regional and global organisations to exchange data, policies and establish a dialogue to address plasma shortages at a global level. Since 2001, Ireland has imported plasma for therapeutic use to reduce the risk of transmission of variant Creutzfeldt Jakob Disease. However, in 2024 the Irish Blood Transfusion Service re-introduced whole blood derived plasma for large scale human therapeutic use. The Irish Blood Transfusion Service is now planning to commence plasmapheresis collections to secure increased supply of plasma derived medicinal products Mandatory questions for patients in Ireland.

Ireland’s Presidency will likely be shaped by a challenging geopolitical context. Many of its thematic priorities must be viewed through the lens of the EU’s security architecture, of which food and agriculture play a critical, yet underappreciated role. Prosperity – for people and planet – will stem from having a cohesive European Union, able to stand on its own two feet internationally. The Biocontrol Coalition therefore suggests that the Irish Presidency prioritise strengthening Europe’s security architecture holistically. Looked through the prism of strengthening the agrifood pillar of EU’s security architecture, the Biocontrol Coalition suggests the following action areas under the overarching theme: Strengthening the functioning of the Single Market to improve predictability, reduce administrative fragmentation and support innovation across the EU’s strategic sectors. Promoting proportionate, future-oriented regulatory approaches that enable safe tools and technologies, including biological ones, to reach users, in particular farmers, in a timely manner, and send a clear signal to European and international innovators that the EU rewards innovation. Enhancing the competitiveness of EU SMEs and innovation ecosystems, particularly in areas that contribute to internal resilience and reduced external dependencies, such as food security, including agricultural inputs. Supporting Europe’s capacity to adapt to climate pressures, by providing the drivers of resilience for essential sectors – such as agriculture – to remain stable and productive. Building consensus around long-term preparedness, ensuring that EU frameworks evolve with scientific progress while maintaining high safety and environmental standards. Placing these priorities at the centre of the Presidency programme would allow Ireland to guide constructive discussions that help Europe remain adaptable, cohesive and prepared for future challenges. Ireland’s tradition of inclusivity and consensus-building positions will play this role while acting as an impartial broker on behalf of all Member States.

The Biocontrol Coalition encourages the Presidency to help ensure a dedicated, fit-for-purpose regulatory framework exists for the assessment and authorisation of biocontrol solutions. Since 2019, there has been a net loss of biological active substances on the EU market. The major drivers of this are long, unsuitable assessment processes and approval times. It takes on average two to three years in key international markets to approve a biocontrol solution, but seven to nine years in the EU. The persistent delays, maladapted aspects of the regulatory framework, and uncertainty undermine the ability of Europe’s farming community to control pests (therefore hampering Europe’s food security), and pushes products researched and developed in Europe to be launched in other markets first (decreasing the Union’s competitiveness). In terms of a holistic concept of security, that erodes Europe’s capacity to meet its own agricultural demands and increases its dependency on trade partners who may or may not remain friendly. Furthermore, climate change, which is increasingly being seen as playing a role in security also influences pest and disease patterns and agricultural resilience. Ireland’s Presidency can help advance work on regulatory modernisation in this key sector, essential for maintaining productivity and supporting farmers, consumers and communities. During its Presidency, Ireland will likely inherit work on the simplification on Food and Feed Safety framework (Regulation 1107/2009). The Biocontrol Coalition welcomes the indicative measures it has seen proposed by the Commission, which will streamline certain procedures, provide some clarity, and help fill current gaps in regulatory expertise. However, while targeted revisions to the existing framework will provide some improvements, they will not address the fundamental issue driving the long approval times: the authorisation process in 1107/2009 is not fit for purpose when it comes to biocontrol products. It will represent a good simplification delivery but not enough to tackle the sector competitiveness gap. The need to put forward a dedicated legislation for biocontrol has been acknowledged by EU Parliament in its recently adopted an own initiative report (INI) on Ensuring Faster Registration and Uptake of Biological Control Agents. Besides other resolutions, this positive political sign from the Parliament has called for the Commission to consider creating a dedicated, fit-for-purpose framework for biocontrol products. It is not the first time that recognition is set it out. In December 2022, the European Commission’s Fit4Future platform has adopted report on Biosolutions and concluded that “there is a need to further develop the legislative framework for biological control products and streamlined provisions.” Dealing with parallels initiatives is not unusual in the EU Commission. The Cosmetics Regulation (EC) No 1223/2009 is a good example as there are provisions included in the Chemicals Simplification Omnibus that was published in July, but it is also currently undergoing the Better Regulation process for more fundamental reform with consultation closed in July 2025. With that in mind, we encourage the Presidency to work with the other Member States and EU Institutions to ensure that a proposal for a dedicated, fit-for-purpose regulatory framework for biocontrol product is tabled as soon as possible, and ideally in 2027 at the latest to ensure closure of the dossier before the next European elections. Given the worrying net loss of biocontrol active substances, and the increasingly volatile situation exerting pressure on our farmers and EU food security, this should be a top priority for the Presidency.

The Council’s work during the Irish Presidency can benefit communities across the EU by helping ensure that essential sectors remain dependable and adaptive. For farmers and rural economies, predictable access to safe and effective tools — including biological options — helps maintain productivity and stability even during difficult conditions. This supports livelihoods, market confidence and long-term planning. Enhancing the efficiency of the Single Market and improving regulatory clarity also strengthens the position of SMEs and innovators, many of whom contribute significantly to local economies. The Presidency should focus on measures that (i) reduce delays or complexity, (ii) bolster Europe’s readiness to handle future pressures, and (iii) reinforce the EU’s security architecture by ensuring continuity in areas that citizens rely on every day. Ultimately, the Presidency has its role to set an agenda where debates on priorities happen. Besides enabling the progress of the Food & Feed omnibus, it will be of great support to consider including access to innovation and farmers’ toolbox gaps in its Programme by leveraging the topic in Informal meetings and/or events, so the Council can deliver its message towards the EU COM work programme for 2027.

Clear communication that shows how EU cooperation improves everyday life can help citizens feel more connected to the Union. Demonstrating how streamlined processes and shared standards allow safe innovations to reach farmers, consumers and businesses more quickly illustrates the practical value of membership. Highlighting stories of local SMEs, research initiatives and community impact can make EU work relatable and accessible.

must provide a summary of the additional information under the ‘Any other comments’ question. This summary should also be limited to a maximum of 500 words. Biocontrol technologies provide farmers with additional safe and effective tools that complement existing practices. The need to address farmers’ competitiveness is urgent and requires transformational approach that goes beyond simplification measures. A more tailored and proportionate regulatory environment would help ensure that such innovations reach users in a timely manner, supporting productivity, sustainability and competitiveness across the Union. Because these tools are developed largely by European SMEs and rely on internal supply chains, improving their regulatory pathways also strengthens Europe’s internal capabilities. In doing so, it contributes indirectly to the EU’s wider security architecture by supporting continuity in food production and reducing exposure to external disruptions. Ireland’s Presidency can help advance balanced discussions that modernise existing systems while respecting high safety standards and ensuring a level playing field for all technologies.

organisation: European Public Prosecutor’s Office (EPPO) – but I am submitting this form in my personal capacity. I am an Irish prosecutor/lawyer employed by the EPPO as a senior legal officer.
sector: European criminal law (as an Irish prosecutor/lawyer employed by the EPPO).
response_text: The Commission’s White Paper on 16.7.2025 COM(2025) 546 final for the Anti-fraud Architecture Review complements the preparatory work on the next multiannual financial framework (the MFF). The Irish Presidency coincides with the review of the EPPO, OLAF, Eurojust and Europol as well as the effectiveness of national control systems for the Recovery and Resilience Facility (RRF). The review of the ‘PIF’ Directive is also key, namely, the Directive on the fight against fraud against the EU’s financial interests. Also noteworthy is the establishment of AMLA and the proposed EU Customs Authority. The Irish Presidency should focus on legislative proposals and measures to enhance EU criminal justice including enhancing the EPPO’s powers and budget to tackle cross-border serious crime, in particular corruption that impacts Union funds and cannot be handled alone by Member States. By the Irish Presidency focusing on strengthening the Anti-fraud Architecture for EU funds – and focusing on Rule of Law and anti-corruption measures – through EU criminal law policy priorities, this will go hand in hand with achieving the best possible outcomes for the next MFF.

organisation: European Public Prosecutor’s Office (EPPO) – but I am submitting this form in my personal capacity. I am an Irish prosecutor/lawyer employed by the EPPO as a senior legal officer.
sector: European criminal law (as an Irish prosecutor/lawyer employed by the EPPO).
response_text: By taking the above actions, people, business and communities across the EU can be reassured that EU money is being directed to the correct places – and indeed more EU money can be disbursed to build a resilient and strong Europe – without giving way to negativity and cynicism about the EU if people, businesses and communities across the EU were to believe that fraud, corruption and cross-border serious crime is prevailing.

response_text: Wishing the Irish Presidency the best for a successful strong focus on justice and the values of democracy, rule of law and equality at the heart of the EU project.

Valero Energy (Ireland) Limited (VEIL) is a major supplier of petroleum products, as co-owner and operator of the Dublin Joint Fuels Terminal. VEIL is a subsidiary of Valero Energy Corporation, the world’s largest independent refining company and one of the world’s largest producers of renewable fuels, including Hydrotreated Vegetable Oil (HVO) and Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF). Ireland’s 2026 Presidency of the Council of the European Union presents a strategic opportunity to advance key priorities aligned with the EU Strategic Agenda 2024–2029, particularly in the areas of climate action, energy security and strengthening the EU’s global partnerships. VEIL believes that in order to do so, Ireland should support improving Europe’s access to critical renewable energies, such as HVO and SAF, which are critical to both Ireland’s and the EU’s decarbonization ambitions. Ireland’s Programme for Government and national climate policies place strong emphasis on the role of renewable liquid fuels such as HVO and SAF in reducing emissions from transport, heating, and aviation. These fuels will also be critical to meeting the wider EU’s climate goals helping meet emissions reduction targets under the Green Deal and Fit for 55. However, current EU anti-dumping and anti-subsidy duties of approximately €0.34 per litre on U.S.-origin HVO significantly restrict access to the world’s largest HVO market, which now accounts for over 50% of global production. These measures inflate costs for Irish and EU suppliers and consumers, undermine supply security, and conflict with EU climate goals. The limited or indeed absence of any domestic HVO production in many Member States means these tariffs offer little protective benefit to Ireland and to many other Member States. Recent amendments by the European Commission have extended these trade measures to U.S.-origin SAF, despite no investigation or consultation with Member States or industry. Notably, the EU has exempted Chinese SAF from similar treatment, raising concerns about discriminatory policy application and inconsistency with the EU-U.S. energy cooperation agreement of August 2025, under which the EU committed to procure $750 billion in U.S. energy products by 2028. Ireland’s Presidency should therefore prioritize tariff reform on strategic energy products such as HVO and SAF. This aligns with the EU’s broader goals of energy security, climate neutrality and transatlantic trade stability. Ireland can use its Presidency to set the agenda, build coalitions with Member States with little or no domestic HVO production, and engage with the European Commission to encourage a formal proposal for tariff re-evaluation. Coordination with the preceding Presidencies of Denmark and Cyprus will be essential to ensure continuity and momentum. This priority should be advanced through relevant Council configurations, particularly the Energy Council and Trade Council, and supported by informal ministerial meetings and the European Political Community summit. Ireland should promote tariff reform as part of implementing the EU-U.S. strategic energy agreement and advocate for zero tariffs on renewable fuels essential to meeting EU climate targets.

Ireland’s 2026 Presidency of the Council of the European Union should prioritize policy areas and legislative proposals that address the strategic challenges posed by current EU trade measures on U.S.origin HVO and SAF. These measures directly impact energy affordability, supply security and climate targets for Ireland and other Member States, and are misaligned with the EU Strategic Agenda 2024–2029 and the European Commission’s 2026 work programme. The EU Strategic Agenda calls for a stronger Europe in the world, a green transition and a more resilient economy. However, the continued imposition of anti-dumping and anti-subsidy duties on U.S.-origin HVO and SAF of approximately €0.34 per litre undermines these goals. Ireland’s transport sector alone will require up to 730 million litres of HVO annually by 2030, and with limited domestic production Ireland is mostly reliant on imports. The U.S. is the world’s largest HVO producer, accounting for over 50% of global supply. Current EU trade measures restrict access to this market, inflating costs and threatening supply security. The European Commission’s 2026 work programme is expected to include legislative proposals supporting the Green Deal and Fit for 55 package implementation. Ireland should use its Presidency to ensure that trade policy complements – not contradicts – climate legislation. This includes advocating for the reevaluation or removal of tariffs on U.S. HVO and SAF, particularly in light of the EU-U.S. strategic energy agreement of August 2025, which commits the EU to procure $750 billion in U.S. energy products by 2028. Ireland should also focus on the discriminatory treatment of U.S. SAF compared to Chinese SAF. In February 2025, the Commission exempted Chinese SAF from anti-dumping measures, while extending such measures to U.S. SAF without consultation. This inconsistency undermines the EU’s credibility and risks disrupting aviation fuel supply chains. Relevant Council configurations for advancing these priorities include the Trade Council and Energy Council. Ireland should seek to place tariff reform on the agenda of Council working parties and informal ministerial meetings. It should also coordinate with Denmark and Cyprus, the preceding Presidencies, to build momentum and ensure continuity. In conclusion, Ireland’s Presidency should focus on aligning EU trade policy with its climate and energy goals by prioritizing legislative and policy work that removes barriers to U.S.-origin HVO and SAF. This will support Ireland’s decarbonization strategy, enhance energy security, and reinforce the EU’s commitment to strategic transatlantic cooperation.

Ireland’s 2026 Presidency of the Council of the European Union offers a unique opportunity to deliver tangible benefits for people, businesses and communities across the EU by addressing the trade barriers currently imposed on U.S.-origin Hydrotreated Vegetable Oil (HVO) and Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF). These measures directly affect energy affordability, supply security and climate progress – issues that resonate across Member States. The EU Strategic Agenda 2024–2029 calls for a Union that is greener, more resilient and globally engaged. Yet, the continued imposition of anti-dumping and anti-subsidy duties on U.S. HVO and SAF of approximately €0.34 per litre runs counter to these goals. These tariffs restrict access to the world’s largest HVO market, inflate costs for consumers and undermine supply security, particularly in Member States like Ireland with insufficient domestic HVO production to meet its needs. With demand for HVO set to rise by up to 730 million litres in Ireland alone by 2030, the inability to access U.S. supply threatens the affordability of low-carbon fuels for households and businesses. The contrast with the EU’s treatment of Chinese SAF, which was exempted from similar measures, highlights the inconsistency and potential inequity of current policy. Ireland’s Presidency can make a substantial positive impact by prioritizing tariff reform on strategic energy products. This would benefit consumers through lower fuel prices, support businesses in meeting sustainability targets, and enhance energy security across the EU. It would also reinforce the EU’s commitment to its August 2025 agreement with the United States to procure $750 billion in U.S. energy products by 2028. Ireland should use its Presidency to place this issue on the agenda of relevant Council configurations, including the Energy and Trade Councils. It should lead coalition-building among Member States that would benefit from improved access to U.S. HVO and SAF and engage with the European Commission to encourage a formal legislative proposal. Informal ministerial meetings and the European Political Community summit offer further platforms to elevate the issue. In conclusion, by championing reform of EU trade measures on U.S. HVO and SAF, Ireland can help deliver lower energy costs, greater fuel security, and accelerated climate action – making a meaningful difference for citizens and businesses across the European Union.

Ireland’s 2026 Presidency of the Council of the European Union presents a powerful opportunity to demonstrate the tangible benefits of EU membership to citizens, businesses, and communities. A key way to foster public ownership of the Presidency is to focus on policy areas that directly impact daily life, such as energy affordability, climate action, and trade fairness. One such area is the reform of EU trade measures on U.S.-origin HVO and SAF. These renewable fuels are critical to Ireland’s and the EU’s decarbonization goals, yet current anti-dumping and anti-subsidy duties of approximately €0.34 per litre significantly restrict access to the world’s largest HVO market. This inflates costs for consumers and businesses, undermines supply security, and limits progress on climate targets. By prioritizing tariff reform on HVO and SAF, Ireland can showcase how EU-level action can deliver real benefits: lower energy costs for households, enhanced fuel security for communities and support for businesses transitioning to low-carbon operations. These outcomes align with the EU Strategic Agenda 2024–2029, which emphasizes a greener and fairer Europe, and with the European Commission’s 2026 work programme, which is expected to advance the Green Deal and energy transition. Ireland’s Presidency can champion transparency, fairness and citizen-focused outcomes by advocating for inclusive decision-making and evidence-based policy reform. This would resonate with citizens who value accountability and equitable treatment within the EU. To create a sense of ownership, Ireland should communicate how its Presidency is working to reduce energy costs, improve supply resilience and support climate goals. Public engagement campaigns should highlight how EU decisions such as removing disproportionate tariffs can directly benefit Irish and European households, particularly in rural and off-grid areas where heating and transport costs are highest. Ireland should also leverage its role in relevant Council configurations, including the Energy and Trade Councils, to build coalitions with Member States similarly affected by these trade measures. By leading efforts to align EU trade policy with climate and energy objectives, Ireland can demonstrate the power of EU cooperation to solve shared challenges. In conclusion, Ireland can best communicate the values of EU membership by using its Presidency to deliver concrete improvements in energy affordability and sustainability. By focusing on reforming trade measures on HVO and SAF, Ireland can show how EU leadership translates into real-world benefits— fostering pride, engagement and ownership among citizens across the Union.

Ireland’s Presidency of the Council of the European Union in 2026 comes at a pivotal moment for the EU’s energy and climate agenda. VEIL strongly encourages Ireland to use this opportunity to advocate for a more coherent and forward-looking approach to trade policy on renewable fuels – specifically U.S.-origin HVO and SAF. The EU Strategic Agenda 2024–2029 calls for a Union that is climate-neutral, resilient and globally engaged. Yet, current EU trade defence measures on U.S. HVO and SAF are counterproductive to these goals. These tariffs restrict access to the world’s largest HVO market, inflate costs for consumers and businesses and undermine supply security, particularly in Member States like Ireland that lack sufficient scale of domestic HVO production in the EU. The European Commission’s decision in late 2025 to extend these measures to U.S.-origin SAF – without consultation or investigation – further highlights the need for reform. The contrast with the Commission’s treatment of Chinese SAF, which was exempted from similar measures, raises serious questions about fairness and strategic coherence. Ireland’s Presidency should focus on aligning EU trade policy with its climate and energy objectives. This includes advocating for the re-evaluation or removal of tariffs on U.S. HVO and SAF and encouraging the European Commission to develop a formal legislative proposal that reflects the EU’s commitment to transatlantic energy cooperation. The August 2025 EU-U.S. agreement to procure $750 billion in U.S. energy products by 2028 provides a strong foundation for such efforts. Relevant Council configurations—including the Energy and Trade Councils—should be leveraged to place this issue on the agenda. Ireland should also coordinate with Denmark and Cyprus, the preceding Presidencies, to ensure continuity and build momentum. Informal ministerial meetings and the European Political Community summit offer additional platforms to elevate the issue and foster consensus. In conclusion, VEIL urges Ireland to use its 2026 Presidency to lead on reforming EU trade measures that hinder access to strategic renewable fuels. Doing so will support climate targets, reduce energy costs, and enhance supply resilience – delivering meaningful benefits to citizens and businesses across the EU while reinforcing the values of fairness, transparency and cooperation that underpin EU membership.

organisation: RCSI University of Medicine and Health Sciences
geography: Access to essential health care for rural and underserved populations, with an international focus
response_text: As Ireland assumes the Presidency of the Council in 2026, it has a unique opportunity to shape the EU agenda around values at the heart of its national and international identity. Central to this should be gender equity and inclusion, ensuring equal opportunities and dismantling barriers that prevent full participation in political, social and economic life. Equally, Ireland can highlight the right to health as a fundamental human right, promoting access to quality healthcare, preventive services, and mental health support. By framing health as a right, Ireland can guide EU policies that protect the most vulnerable and strengthen resilience across member states. Drawing on its longstanding tradition of global health leadership and respected international standing, Ireland can advance inclusive, rights-based policies that reflect both justice and solidarity. Integrating these principles across the EU’s agenda reinforces the Union’s role as a global actor committed to equality, human dignity and international cooperation.

organisation: RCSI University of Medicine and Health Sciences
geography: Access to essential health care for rural and underserved populations, with an international focus
response_text: Personally, I would encourage Ireland, in its 2026 Presidency, to prioritise policies that strengthen gender equality and inclusivity within health systems, both at home and globally. Disparities in health outcomes are growing, particularly for women and marginalised communities, and I believe the Presidency offers a real opportunity to address these inequities. This means ensuring universal, affordable healthcare that actively reduces these gaps. Ireland’s strong tradition in health diplomacy can be leveraged to champion rights-based, inclusive policies that promote equitable access and gender equality in partner countries. I would also emphasise the importance of practical implementation. Policies must be backed by clear resources, targeted funding and mechanisms that deliver measurable impact. By linking domestic reforms with international engagement, Ireland can show how inclusive, gender-responsive health systems benefit both EU citizens and the wider world.

organisation: RCSI University of Medicine and Health Sciences
geography: Access to essential health care for rural and underserved populations, with an international focus
response_text: The Council, under the Irish Presidency, can make a substantial positive impact across the EU by ensuring that gender equity, social inclusion, and evidence-based health policy are central to its work. Among other things, this means addressing persistent gaps in health research and data, particularly on conditions that disproportionately affect women. Strengthening programmes such as Horizon Europe, EU4Health, Joint Actions, the European Health Data Space Regulation, and Digital Europe will generate the research and data needed to inform targeted policies, improve healthcare delivery, and reduce disparities. Routine collection of disaggregated data will ensure policies respond to the needs of all populations. Similarly, integrating gender budgeting across EU funding streams can support inclusive workforce participation and innovation. Evidence-based health policies and social inclusion initiatives create healthier, more resilient communities, which in turn foster stronger economies and sustainable growth. For communities, making the elimination of gender-based violence an EU priority, backed by dedicated funding and research, strengthens social cohesion and safety, empowering individuals to participate fully in society.

organisation: RCSI University of Medicine and Health Sciences
geography: Access to essential health care for rural and underserved populations, with an international focus
response_text: To best communicate the values and benefits of EU membership and foster a strong sense of ownership among citizens over Ireland’s Presidency of the Council, the narrative must connect EU membership with issues that resonate deeply at the personal and societal level. Framing public health as central to social justice, economic resilience, and democratic stability offers a compelling way to achieve this. Universal access to quality healthcare is not only a fundamental human right but also a reflection of core EU values such as solidarity, equality, and inclusion. Communicating this clearly helps citizens understand how the EU directly improves their lives and protects their well-being. At the same time, it is important to acknowledge growing concerns about rollbacks in women’s health and rights, which threaten hard-won gains in equality and social progress. Ireland’s Presidency can spotlight these challenges, positioning the EU as a visible and committed leader in defending equity and inclusion. This active leadership reassures citizens that the EU is responsive to their needs and values. Creating a sense of ownership requires more than just communication - it demands genuine engagement. Ireland should promote the systematic involvement of civil society in policymaking throughout its Presidency. Encouraging co-creation, broad consultation, and ongoing monitoring fosters transparency and trust, making citizens feel heard and valued.

response_text: I recently took part in the two-day international conference IGHNxEU – Empowering Women for a Healthier Europe, held in Dublin on 14–15 November 2025. I’d like to submit this brief as supporting evidence for my submission: https://globalhealth.ie/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/IGHN-EIWH-Policy-Brief-FINAL_TOC-Dec-9.pdf

respondent_type: NGO – UNICEF Ireland is a national committee of the United Nations Children’s Fund (UNICEF)
sector: UNICEF Ireland works in the child rights, humanitarian and development sector, focusing on: promoting and protecting the rights of children under the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child; policy advocacy relating to children’s well-being in Ireland, the EU and globally; public engagement and education on child rights; supporting UNICEF’s global humanitarian and development programmes.
geography:
UNICEF Ireland’s submission is informed by the national context of children’s rights and well-being in Ireland; EU-wide child rights priorities, particularly under the EU Strategy on the Rights of the Child and the European Child Guarantee; the global perspective of UNICEF’s work in humanitarian, development and fragile contexts, where EU policy and financing decisions have significant impact on children.
While our organisational mandate is national, our evidence base and policy expertise are relevant across Ireland, the EU, and partner countries globally.
response_text: Ireland’s 2026 Presidency comes at a pivotal moment for the European Union and for children. Only 17% of SDG targets are currently on track, and more than one-third are stagnating or regressing—trends closely linked to deteriorating outcomes for children, both globally and within the EU. Against this backdrop, Ireland could consider framing its Presidency around three interconnected themes that align with the EU Strategic Agenda 2024–2029 and support rights-based, sustainable development across the Union. 1. Reducing Child Poverty and Advancing Social Inclusion in Europe Despite Europe’s prosperity, almost one in four children in the EU are at risk of poverty or social exclusion. Child poverty is closely linked to poorer health, educational outcomes and long-term economic participation. It is also strongly associated with unhealthy food environments and unequal access to nutritious diets. A Presidency emphasis on child poverty reduction, quality early childhood services, mental health supports and equitable access to education—alongside stronger public-health approaches to child nutrition—would support implementation of the EU Strategy on the Rights of the Child and the European Child Guarantee, while strengthening Europe’s human capital and social cohesion. 2. Protecting Children in Situations of Fragility, Crisis and Displacement By 2030, fragile contexts will host 86% of the world’s extreme poor, with children most exposed to conflict, hunger, climate shocks and forced displacement. The EU’s external action is a critical lifeline: ODA focused on children has proven highly effective, with returns such as 54:1 for immunisation and strong evidence that child-focused development investments contribute to stability and economic opportunity. In this context, the Presidency could encourage coherent, rights-based approaches across JHA, FAC and development discussions, including principled humanitarian action, predictable and needs-based ODA, and child-sensitive asylum and migration procedures. Maintaining attention to human development and the SDGs would help safeguard the EU’s credibility as a global leader on human rights and multilateralism. 3. A Child-Centred Green and Digital Transition Children bear disproportionate risks from pollution, climate change and unsafe digital environments. In 2019 alone, air pollution contributed to the deaths of 472 children and young people in the EU, and close to one-third of children cannot assess the trustworthiness of online content. With COP31 taking place during Ireland’s Presidency, there is a unique opportunity to centre intergenerational equity in EU climate diplomacy. The Presidency could promote clean air standards, child-sensitive adaptation and resilience measures, and safe digital ecosystems, while ensuring young people acquire the green and digital skills required for Europe’s future competitiveness. Linking ENVI, TTE, COMPET and EYCS agendas would reinforce the Union’s commitment to a fair and inclusive transition. Across all areas, meaningful, safe and structured participation of children and young people—consistent with the UNCRC—could reinforce democratic legitimacy and public trust in EU institutions.

respondent_type: NGO – UNICEF Ireland is a national committee of the United Nations Children’s Fund (UNICEF)
sector: UNICEF Ireland works in the child rights, humanitarian and development sector, focusing on: promoting and protecting the rights of children under the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child; policy advocacy relating to children’s well-being in Ireland, the EU and globally; public engagement and education on child rights; supporting UNICEF’s global humanitarian and development programmes.
geography:
UNICEF Ireland’s submission is informed by the national context of children’s rights and well-being in Ireland; EU-wide child rights priorities, particularly under the EU Strategy on the Rights of the Child and the European Child Guarantee; the global perspective of UNICEF’s work in humanitarian, development and fragile contexts, where EU policy and financing decisions have significant impact on children.
While our organisational mandate is national, our evidence base and policy expertise are relevant across Ireland, the EU, and partner countries globally.
response_text: Several policy areas on the 2026 agenda present opportunities where the Irish Presidency could help advance coherent, rights-based outcomes for children. These areas align with ongoing EU processes, the Strategic Agenda 2024–2029, and global trends affecting children. 1. Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) and EU External Action The next MFF (2028–2034) will shape the EU’s capacity to support human development, stability and crisis response. Child-focused investment is consistently among the most effective uses of public funds and is essential to progress on the SDGs, particularly where outcomes for children are stagnating or regressing. The Presidency could support Council discussions that: preserve predictable, poverty-focused ODA and grant-based funding for human development, particularly in fragile contexts; reinforce the EU’s commitment to the SDGs, including health, education and nutrition; and explore child-sensitive tracking approaches, such as a child marker, to improve transparency and accountability of EU spending affecting children. 2. Implementation of the EU Strategy on the Rights of the Child Across EPSCO and GAC, the Presidency could help maintain momentum on implementation of the EU Strategy on the Rights of the Child and the European Child Guarantee. This could include: reviewing progress on Child Guarantee National Action Plans, including adequacy of resourcing; strengthening monitoring of access to quality early childhood education and care, mental health supports and basic services for vulnerable groups; and promoting the use of comparable data to identify and address disparities. 3. Public-Health Approaches to Child Nutrition Unhealthy food environments are increasingly shaping children’s diets across Europe, contributing to long-term health inequalities. Addressing child nutrition through a public-health and child-rights lens is therefore an important preventive priority. The Presidency could support Council discussions that reinforce evidence-based approaches to nutrition policy, aligned with WHO guidance. A particular priority is the effective regulation of the marketing of breast-milk substitutes, in line with the International Code of Marketing of Breast-milk Substitutes, to protect breastfeeding and optimal early nutrition. More broadly, action to reduce children’s exposure to the marketing of unhealthy foods and to safeguard public-health policymaking from conflicts of interest would support EU objectives on prevention, well-being and equity. 4. Child-Sensitive Responses to Migration, Climate and Crisis Children are disproportionately affected by forced displacement, climate impacts and environmental harms. The Presidency could encourage coherence across JHA, ENVI, TTE and EPSCO discussions to: ensure child-rights safeguards in the implementation of the Pact on Migration and Asylum; integrate child-centred adaptation, clean-air measures and disaster-risk reduction into climate and environmental policies; and strengthen coordination between humanitarian, development and peacebuilding tools to support children in fragile and crisis-affected contexts.

respondent_type: NGO – UNICEF Ireland is a national committee of the United Nations Children’s Fund (UNICEF)
sector: UNICEF Ireland works in the child rights, humanitarian and development sector, focusing on: promoting and protecting the rights of children under the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child; policy advocacy relating to children’s well-being in Ireland, the EU and globally; public engagement and education on child rights; supporting UNICEF’s global humanitarian and development programmes.
geography:
UNICEF Ireland’s submission is informed by the national context of children’s rights and well-being in Ireland; EU-wide child rights priorities, particularly under the EU Strategy on the Rights of the Child and the European Child Guarantee; the global perspective of UNICEF’s work in humanitarian, development and fragile contexts, where EU policy and financing decisions have significant impact on children.
While our organisational mandate is national, our evidence base and policy expertise are relevant across Ireland, the EU, and partner countries globally.
response_text: A Presidency that reinforces child rights across Council work can generate lasting benefits for people, communities and businesses across the EU, supporting both social cohesion and economic competitiveness. 1. Strengthening Human Capital Through Investment in Children Investing in children is among the highest-return strategies available to governments. For example, every additional year of schooling raises lifetime earnings by about 10 per cent, and early childhood investments deliver significant long-term gains in productivity and wellbeing. Preventive public-health measures—such as protecting breastfeeding and reducing children’s exposure to harmful food marketing—can further reduce long-term healthcare costs, support better educational outcomes, and help address persistent health inequalities across Member States. Prioritising social investment supports the EU’s demographic resilience, labour-market participation, and long-term competitiveness. 2. Embedding Child Rights in EU Policymaking Systematically integrating child-rights assessments into relevant Council configurations - EPSCO, ENVI, COMPET, JHA - could help anticipate unintended impacts and support policymaking that is preventive, not reactive. This contributes to more cost-effective policies in health, social protection, environment and digital safety. 3. Supporting Stability and Security Through Coherent External Action Stable societies depend on educated, healthy and protected children. Investments in children abroad - especially in fragile contexts - serve both EU values and strategic interests. Evidence shows ODA focused on children: Prevents conflict by strengthening social cohesion, Improves stability through inclusive services, Reduces future displacement and irregular migration. By supporting principled, needs-based humanitarian action and predictable development cooperation, the Presidency could help reinforce the EU’s global credibility and security interests. 4. Advancing a Just Green and Digital Transition A child-sensitive approach to the green and digital transitions can deliver immediate community benefits: Reduced air pollution and improved respiratory health, Lower household energy burdens, Safe online environments (especially relevant given that one-third of 10-year-olds cannot assess online trustworthiness), Skills needed for participation in the green and digital labour markets. These measures support the triple transition (green-digital-social) and help ensure no child is left behind. 5. Strengthening Participation and Trust in EU Institutions Meaningful participation increases young people’s sense of agency and belonging. Mechanisms such as youth advisory panels, targeted consultations, and school-based engagement programmes can help ensure EU policies reflect young people’s lived experiences. Involving children in a youth-included rather than youth-led model—recognising they do not need to provide full solutions to contribute meaningfully—supports democratic legitimacy and strengthens trust in public institutions.

sector: UNICEF Ireland works in the child rights, humanitarian and development sector, focusing on: promoting and protecting the rights of children under the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child; policy advocacy relating to children’s well-being in Ireland, the EU and globally; public engagement and education on child rights; supporting UNICEF’s global humanitarian and development programmes.
geography:
UNICEF Ireland’s submission is informed by the national context of children’s rights and well-being in Ireland; EU-wide child rights priorities, particularly under the EU Strategy on the Rights of the Child and the European Child Guarantee; the global perspective of UNICEF’s work in humanitarian, development and fragile contexts, where EU policy and financing decisions have significant impact on children.
While our organisational mandate is national, our evidence base and policy expertise are relevant across Ireland, the EU, and partner countries globally.
response_text: Effective communication during the Presidency should highlight the EU’s foundation in human dignity, equality and rights, while fostering a sense of inclusion and ownership among all citizens—particularly children and young people, who will live longest with the consequences of EU decision-making. 1. Communicate through a rights-based lens Storytelling that centres on how EU action protects and advances children’s and families’ rights—for example through safer online environments, affordable childcare, healthier environments, cleaner air, and crisis response—can help make the Union’s values tangible and trusted. Demonstrating how EU legislation contributes to the realisation of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child can deepen public understanding of the EU as a guarantor of rights and well-being. 2. Ensure meaningful participation of children and young people Creating structured opportunities for children and young people to contribute to Presidency-related discussions reinforces the EU’s commitment to democratic participation and the rights set out in Article 12 of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child. Mechanisms such as youth advisory panels, consultation forums, and school-based engagement activities can ensure processes are youth-included rather than youth-led, recognising that young people do not need to provide definitive solutions in order to share valuable perspectives. Ireland can build on established initiatives such as the Blue Star Programme, while also drawing on complementary rights-based approaches such as UNICEF Ireland’s Child Rights Schools programme to support democratic literacy and participation. 3. Strengthen civic education and media literacy Communications should support children and young people to understand how EU decisions are made and how they can engage with democratic processes. Partnering with education systems, youth organisations and civil society can help counter disinformation, strengthen rights awareness, and promote active citizenship, in line with the EU Strategic Agenda. 4. Highlight intergenerational responsibility in the context of COP31 With COP31 taking place during Ireland’s Presidency, there is a strong opportunity to communicate EU leadership on climate action as an expression of solidarity, sustainability and intergenerational justice. Framing climate action in terms of children’s health, safety and future opportunities can resonate strongly with younger generations and the wider public. 5. Demonstrate transparency, accessibility and inclusion Open briefings, accessible materials, multilingual communication and child-friendly explanations of EU processes reinforce the message that the Presidency is conducted on behalf of all citizens and help build trust in EU institutions.
