response_text: UNICEF Ireland welcomes the opportunity to contribute to the development of Ireland’s 2026 EU Presidency Programme. In addition to the points outlined above, we note three cross-cutting considerations that may support effective implementation across Council work during the Presidency: 1. Supporting coherence across internal and external EU policies affecting children Many of the issues shaping children’s lives—poverty reduction, climate resilience, migration, digital safety, health and education—span multiple Council configurations. A Presidency emphasis on coherence and cross-sectoral coordination could help ensure that the EU’s commitments under the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child and the EU Strategy on the Rights of the Child are reflected consistently across policy areas. 2. Making use of existing evidence and tools to support decision-making UNICEF, both globally and at EU level, maintains extensive evidence and technical guidance across social policy, humanitarian response, climate, education, migration and child protection. These resources may support Presidency teams in preparing briefings, progressing negotiations and assessing the implications of legislative proposals for children. 3. Opportunities to collaborate on child and youth participation initiatives Ireland’s Presidency offers opportunities to involve children and young people in accessible and meaningful ways. UNICEF Ireland would welcome engagement on child- and youth-participation activities during the Presidency, including through child-friendly communication, structured consultation approaches and education-based initiatives that support inclusive, rights-based engagement. UNICEF Ireland remains available to provide further information or facilitate access to relevant UNICEF expertise as preparations advance for Ireland’s 2026 EU Presidency.

geography:
From NEIC Dublin to EU wide contexts. 
The response below is based on discussions and feedback from work within youth and community projects and within research networks as part of ongoing communities of practice.
response_text: Ireland’s Presidency should champion “Building Inclusive Community Resilience: Empowering People and Places Across Europe.” This overarching theme positions resilience not merely as a crisis response, but as the sustained capacity of all communities, especially underserved and hard-to-reach ones, to thrive amidst social, economic, environmental, and digital transitions. It should be underpinned by three interlinked priorities: Social and democratic resilience: Strengthening social cohesion, civic participation, and trust in democratic institutions from the ground up. This prioritises inclusive and restorative dialogue, combating disinformation, and supporting the civic actors (youth workers, community organisers) who are the foundations of civic engagement and local democracy. Economic and territorial resilience: Ensuring a just transition that leaves no community behind. This focuses on quality local employment, social economy development, equitable access to services (education, healthcare, transport), and addressing regional disparities, particularly in rural, peripheral, and deprived urban areas. Climate and environmental resilience with a just transition at its core: Advancing climate action in a way that is fair and community-led. This emphasises local green initiatives, community energy projects, and building adaptive capacity, ensuring the most vulnerable are supported through change. Centring this theme on underserved communities ensures the Presidency tackles inequality meaningfully, framing resilience as a prerequisite for a secure, prosperous, and united EU.

geography:
From NEIC Dublin to EU wide contexts. 
The response below is based on discussions and feedback from work within youth and community projects and within research networks as part of ongoing communities of practice.
response_text: The Presidency should drive work in areas where EU policy directly impacts local resilience: Youth and inclusion: Progress the European Year of Youth legacy agenda, focusing on youth mental health, quality employment, and structured mechanisms for youth voice in policy-making. Strengthen the Child Guarantee implementation to combat child poverty. Leargas recently hosted a “Europe Goes Local” event where youth workers from across Ireland came together to share ideas and strategies for working together and working with our European colleagues. Greater support and visibility and take up for such initiatives can lead to transformative outcomes for young people in underserved communities. Social economy and cohesion: Advance the Social Economy Framework to channel funding and support to community enterprises. Champion using EU cohesion funds for integrated community development, with simplified access for smaller, local actors. Just Transition and energy poverty: Within the Green Deal, focus on legislation and funding instruments (like the Social Climate Fund) that proactively mitigate energy poverty and support community-led renewable projects. Push for a “Community Resilience Test” for major legislation to assess local impacts. Digital Inclusion: Advance the Digital Decade targets with a strong focus on universal digital literacy, affordable connectivity, and safeguarding against the digital exclusion of vulnerable groups. Sharing ideas through European programmes, exchanges and initiatives has provided success stories and examples to schools, community and youth organisations. Further promotion and visibility of such opportunities can support teachers, youth and community workers to build digital resilience with their young people. The aim should be concrete outcomes: tangible legislative progress that embeds community-focused principles; Council Conclusions mandating the mainstreaming of a community resilience lens; greater visibility and understanding of shared European approaches and initiatives; and fostering peer-learning platforms for our local authorities and civil society across the EU.

geography:
From NEIC Dublin to EU wide contexts. 
The response below is based on discussions and feedback from work within youth and community projects and within research networks as part of ongoing communities of practice.
response_text: To maximise impact, the Council’s work must translate high-level policy into local reality. For People: Demonstrate that EU policy improves daily life. By foregrounding the Just Transition and social protection, the Presidency can show how the EU shields citizens from shocks and empowers them in transitions. Creating visible channels (e.g., youth panels and community dialogues feeding into Council formations) will foster a tangible sense that the EU listens and responds. For Communities: Empower local actors as key partners. Youth and community organisations are ready to engage. Through a range of ongoing initiatives, there are young people across the country interested and willing to get stuck in to such work of communicating and sharing the power of European youth work and associated practices. The Presidency should champion funding mechanisms that are accessible to grassroots organisations and promote EU-wide networks for sharing best practices in community development, directly strengthening civil society capacity. For Businesses (especially Social Enterprises): By advancing the Social Economy Framework and supporting the digital and green transition for Social Enterprises, the Council can foster a more resilient, diverse, sustainable and locally rooted business ecosystem. The substantial impact lies in connecting the EU to the local: ensuring Council discussions are informed by authentic grassroots voices and that resulting policies are designed for, and with, communities.

geography:
From NEIC Dublin to EU wide contexts. 
The response below is based on discussions and feedback from work within youth and community projects and within research networks as part of ongoing communities of practice.
response_text: Communication must be participatory, local, and values-based. “EU in My Place” narrative: Shift from institutional messaging to storytelling spotlighting how EU-funded local projects (sports clubs and community centres in the NEIC, youth programmes across Ireland, especially those already engaging with Leargas) build resilience. Feature the voices of workers, volunteers, and beneficiaries. Promote and share how others can get involved. A National “conversation on resilience”: Coordinate a structured, inclusive consultation across Irish towns and cities, feeding directly into Presidency events. Involve Local Authorities, sports associations, Family Resource Centres, and schools. Community and intergenerational trauma are topics being discussed right now by community and youth workers across the country and they are examining creative ways and new resources and tools that are giving a voice and language to people affected. Partnerships with trusted messengers: Empower teachers, coaches, youth and community workers, and healthcare professionals as communicators, providing them with simple resources to connect EU policy to their work. Symbolic and inclusive events: Host major Presidency events not just in Dublin, but in regional hubs. Stage flagship youth and community summits in areas of disadvantage, where young people and their families are disconnected and unaware of the potential benefits of EU initiatives, ensuring participants directly engage with ministers and officials. Creating ownership means making the Presidency a platform for the people of Ireland to showcase their communities and shape an authentic European conversation about resilience. It is about demonstrating that Ireland’s role is to amplify local voices on a European stage, making the EU feel closer and more relevant.

geography:
From NEIC Dublin to EU wide contexts. 
The response below is based on discussions and feedback from work within youth and community projects and within research networks as part of ongoing communities of practice.
response_text: This submission emphasises that authentic community resilience cannot be designed top-down. The proposed approach offers Ireland a unique, values-driven Presidency legacy: reaffirming the European project’s fundamental commitment to solidarity, equality, and human dignity. By placing hard-to-reach communities at the centre, Ireland can steer the EU toward a more participatory and impactful model of governance. Success should be measured not just by files closed, but by the depth of grassroots engagement and the establishment of enduring frameworks that prioritise community well-being in EU policy-making. The Presidency is a powerful opportunity to bridge the gap between the Union and its citizens, fostering a more resilient Europe for all.

Thematic Priority: Leadership in Accelerating Climate Adaptation and Resilience. Grid congestion, high energy prices and infrastructure delivery deficits are some of the most pressing contemporary issues facing Ireland, yet these are difficulties are also shared by most Member States across the European Union. The Presidency thus offers an opportunity to pursue solutions for our most pressing energy issues. One on hand, Ireland has one of the greatest wind resources in Europe. On the other, our lengthy permitting processes and limited grid availability pose significant barriers to harnessing the full extent of our resources and their associated benefits in reducing both consumer costs and carbon emissions. Ireland is therefore positioned to embark as a pragmatic leader in revolutionizing the energy regulation and legislative landscape, in the aim of rapidly accelerating renewable energy infrastructure delivery to capitalize on our natural resources and deliver affordable, secure and clean energy to people and businesses.

areas? To unlock Ireland’s clean energy potential, BnM proposes the following priority policy areas: Upgrading the European Commission’s European Grids Package: This package will provide Member States with frameworks for permitting and investments. We would strongly urge the Council to pursue a robust developments to the package, including binding permit deadlines, guaranteed anticipatory investment and coordinated regional infrastructure planning. This must be supported by improved access to finance and clear regulatory rules for the transitioning needs of the grid. Accelerating a Revolutionised Permitting Process: Given the magnitude of delays to renewable energy projects due to permitting bottlenecks, we would welcome a concerted effort to establish Ireland as a leader in this field. We propose a specific initiative to meet this objective. We also advise a targeted effort to support the Commission in monitoring RED III compliance regarding administrative delays, alongside developing best practice approaches to permitting with a focus on digital permitting platforms, transparent environmental procedures and showcasing ‘One-Stop Shops’. Accelerating Flexibility and Embedding It Within the System: Another adverse result of Ireland’s grid limitation is the significant amount of energy lost to curtailment and dispatch down, due to the grid’s inability to carry the amount generated. As such, leading by example in accommodating flexible technology to allow the grid to store and flexibly deploy energy should be a paramount priority. BnM would encourage the Council to ensure accommodating market rules for renewable flexibility technologies and services. Recapturing lost energy will significantly reduce consumer cost and ensure optimum efficiency of natural resources.

As stated, high energy prices and infrastructure delivery deficits are major issues faced across the European Union. Pursing a honed focus on revolutionizing energy transition policy and driving delivery on energy infrastructure entails a magnitude of gains for businesses and consumers across the Union. These include reduced energy bills, heightened energy security and increased competitiveness. We believe that Ireland should confidently position itself as a leader on Grid Expansion, Permitting, Flexibility and Electrification. As well as being national priorities, these focus areas are also essential for the entire European Union.

For its 2026 EU Presidency, Ireland should prioritise sustainable energy, rural resilience, and community- centred governance. In particular, the rapid scaling of biomethane under REPowerEU highlights the urgent need for independent impact assessments, strict environmental safeguards, and oversight of public subsidies to prevent unsustainable industrial-scale biogas projects. Ireland can lead by embedding legally binding rules on feedstock use, digestate management, and spatial planning, ensuring local communities have a real voice in decision-making rather than bearing disproportionate social and environmental costs. By championing a model that balances climate, biodiversity, and rural development goals, Ireland can set a European benchmark for fair, sustainable energy transitions. Prioritising transparency, equitable benefit-sharing, and preventative regulation will help avoid repeating mistakes seen elsewhere in Europe, reinforcing trust in decarbonisation policies. These thematic priorities will position Ireland as a leader in creating energy strategies that are both ambitious and socially responsible.

The European Commission’s REPowerEU action plan has set biomethane production on a course of massive upscale as part of efforts to increase EU energy independence, fixing a target of 35 billion cubic meters (bcm) per year by 2030 – up from 4,1 bcm in 2023. However, until this day, no Impact Assessment was carried out on the target. As biomethane production continues to grow rapidly both in Ireland and Europe (with a currently 21% year-over-year growth), so do concerns about its associated environmental and social risks as well as the irresponsible use of taxpayers money. While biogas production from sludge or collecting the gas that is produced in landfills is appropriate, there are particular concerns about the effects of large-scale biogas production on the use of limited agricultural land, the continuation of polluting industrial animal production, harm to local communities, and the effects of methane leaking from biogas facilities. Further concerns arise when looking closer at promoted use cases for biomethane such as heating or transport which are often inefficient, expensive, and lock Europe into existing fossil infrastructure. The Irish Presidency should therefore prioritize conducting an independent, interdisciplinary impact assessment to evaluate the feasibility and sustainability of this target, ensuring it aligns with climate, biodiversity, and rural community goals. Emphasis must be placed on implementing strict economic,environmental, and social safeguards for biogas and biomethane production. With reference to the Commission’s 2026 Work Programme as well as the wider EU Strategic Agenda that highlights the need to secure Europe’s energy independence, we therefore encourage the Irish Presidency to:  Advocate for an independent impact assessment of the EU’s 35 bcm biomethane target, as a prerequisite to develop further any expansion of biomethane production as part of relevant policy files in 2026, such as the Circular Economy Act, Bioeconomy Strategy, Livestock Strategy, Energy Union Governance Upgrade, and Common Agricultural Policy. This includes prioritizing truly sustainable feedstocks, efficient use cases, and avoiding lock-ins of fossil infrastructure. Include the voices of local communities in the debate. In order to expand biomethane production rapidly, the 2025 REPowerEU roadmap foresees a “tripartite contract to better address the diverging needs in different areas of the EU and include national and local stakeholders”. However, a focus has been set on facilitating dialogue between the EU Commission, EU Member States’ governments as well as industrial stakeholders; and no commitment has been made to give a role to local communities themselves that are affected by such projects. In line with its “people-centred” approach, the Presidency should therefore intensify its efforts to give the Irish people and local communities across Europe a greater say in the development of fair and sustainable biomethane strategies.  Scrutinise public subsidy schemes for unsustainable biomethane production. This is critical to prevent perverse incentives that undermine the EU’s climate, food security, and energy independence goals. Current subsidies often favour industrial-scale biogas projects reliant on unsustainable feedstocks - such as manure from factory farming or energy crops competing with food production - which lock in polluting practices as well as animal welfare violations, and divert resources from truly circular solutions. Without strict oversight, these subsidies risk distorting markets, inflating demand for unsustainable livestock farming, and sidelining local, community-led projects that deliver genuine environmental and social benefits.

Ireland’s presidency provides a unique opportunity to develop and promote a gold standard indigenous biogas industry that is sized and scaled to meet community needs. Learning from EU countries with an established biogas industry, Ireland can avoid the pitfalls of social acceptance that are consistently documented as barriers to bioenergy projects across the EU (Mancini & Raggi, 2022). Current regulatory gaps and weak planning assessments underestimate the cumulative impacts on rural infrastructure. Public health and safety questions about hazardous gas storage, particular emissions and emergency service access are heightened when regulatory oversight is perceived as reactive rather than preventative. Research has highlighted that digestate management and changes in feedstock mixes are critical risk vectors that demand much stronger regulation than is currently applied ( Piadeh et. al, 2024 ). Ireland, through its presidency, can set the standard by developing industry-specific planning regulations that include community engagement at its core.The National Biomethane Strategy points directly to a highly industrialised model aimed at rapid 12 development across rural Ireland. Within this model, revenue accrues to outside multi-national agri- investors while costs are borne by host communities in terms of road damage, odour, environmental degradation, and reduced property values. Communities demand transparent environmental impact assessments, accessible monitoring data and enforceable operating limits. The development of industry- specific planning regulations aligned with benefit-sharing mechanisms has the potential to provide a blueprint for use across the EU, while maintaining community engagement and the highest environmental standards. Meaningful community engagement, spatial planning that respects local carrying capacity, strict feedstock limits, alongside legally binding digestate management plans, are safeguards that would increase local acceptance. Rapid roll-out risks polarising rural communities, undermining trust in decarbonisation policy, and producing environmental and social harms that outweigh local benefits. Ireland has an opportunity through its EU presidency to either lead and develop new industry standards or to repeat mistakes already impacting the rural communities and the environment across Europe.

sector: All-island Economy, Cross-Border Trade, Entrepreneurship, Investor Readiness, Innovation,
response_text: InterTradeIreland welcomes the opportunity to contribute to the development of the 2026 Presidency programme. From an all-island economic perspective, Ireland’s Presidency should prioritise the themes which strengthen the Single Market, support SMEs, and improve the functioning of cross-border trade and innovation networks. This is a unique opportunity for Ireland to demonstrate leadership on the key challenges facing Europe, and to do so in a way that supports the delivery of key policy priorities and economic imperatives on the island of Ireland. Recent initiatives and experiences in areas such as the cost of doing business, regulatory complexity, skills pipelines, and market diversification position Ireland as a voice of authority on these complicated challenges. Proposed overarching theme: ‘A Connected, Competitive, and Collaborative Europe’ Priority Theme 1: A More Competitive and Innovation-Driven Single Market for SMEs The Strategic Agenda commits the Union to bolstering competitiveness, removing barriers in services and essential goods, and accelerating the Capital Markets and Banking Unions. For SMEs on the island of Ireland, especially those operating cross-border, these reforms are essential to scaling, accessing finance, and low-friction trading. Ireland’s Presidency should highlight the contribution of SMEs to Europe’s economic resilience. Priority Theme 2: Strengthening All-Island and Cross-Border Connectivity and Cohesion Cohesion, regional balance, and inclusion are central to the Strategic Agenda. The Commission Work Programme reinforces the need for territorial strategies, water resilience, and strong regional development instruments. Ireland is uniquely placed to demonstrate how cross-border cooperation can drive productivity, innovation diffusion, all-island trade, and inclusive growth, thereby supporting EU objectives for upward convergence and balanced regional development. Priority Theme 3: Delivering a Just and Future-Ready Green and Digital Transition SMEs face specific challenges in adopting digital tools, AI, and green technologies. Ireland should use its Presidency to lead on initiatives such as the European Innovation Act, Cloud and AI Development Act, and Circular Economy Act, which would reinforce a practical, SME-focused approach to Europe’s transitions and harness economies of scale.

sector: All-island Economy, Cross-Border Trade, Entrepreneurship, Investor Readiness, Innovation,
response_text: 1. Single Market deepening and SME competitiveness InterTradeIreland recommends prioritising the European Innovation Act, Cloud and AI Development Act, Quantum Act, and proposals to simplify doing business across borders. These legislative proposals directly support the Strategic Agenda’s ambition to create a more innovation-friendly and entrepreneurship-driven Europe and will particularly support innovative and ambitious SMEs. 2. Capital access and financial integration Progress on Capital Markets Union and Banking Union would significantly improve SME access to finance and support scaling by firms in small and peripheral markets. Scaling successful start-ups is an important means of driving productivity and competitiveness, and raising capital to scale is a common challenge. Presidency focus on these areas would therefore be strongly welcomed. 3. Cross-border services and mutual recognition of qualifications InterTradeIreland’s research and stakeholder engagement demonstrates that SMEs in tradable services rely on clear and consistent regulatory environments. Presidency emphasis on skills mobility initiatives, professional recognition, and the movement of service providers would have tangible impact across the island and the Union. 4. Circular economy and clean tech adoption Ireland has made remarkable progress in the circular economy. However, complex regulations around end of waste and transfrontier shipments prevent the Union harnessing the benefits of economies of scale in the circular economy and restrict the majority of activity to individual member states. Advancing the Circular Economy Act, clean-tech markets, and simplified permits for infrastructure aligns with the priorities of many all-island sectors, particularly manufacturing, logistics, agri-food, and construction. 5. Better regulation and burden reduction The Commission intends to cut administrative and regulatory burdens significantly in 2026, with major simplification packages across automotive, taxation, environment, and food systems. Drawing on domestic experience, Ireland’s Presidency should emphasise the robust implementation of these packages and an overall approach of SME-friendly regulation.

sector: All-island Economy, Cross-Border Trade, Entrepreneurship, Investor Readiness, Innovation,
response_text: 1. Reduce complexity and support cross-border trading SMEs A Presidency focus on regulatory simplification and improved Single Market functioning will directly benefit SMEs facing compliance, reporting, and permitting challenges. This is particularly important where small firms operate on a cross-border basis across the island and will make a significant impact to Union-wide challenges on the costs of doing business, regulation, and the associated impacts on competitiveness. 2. Accelerate access to skills, innovation and finance InterTradeIreland’s research and engagement clearly demonstrates that skills mobility, innovation funding, digital infrastructure and access to capital remain central barriers for SMEs. Progress in these areas would significantly enhance productivity and competitiveness, supporting the Strategic Agenda’s call to mobilise investment and unlock innovation ecosystems. 3. Strengthen regional convergence and cohesion The island of Ireland is one of the clearest examples of how cross-border regions gain outsized benefits from EU cohesion policy. Focusing on multi-member-state collaboration, water resilience platforms, and cross-border connectivity can ensure communities on the periphery share fully in the Union’s prosperity. 4. Support for green and digital adoption Clear, consistent frameworks that support SMEs in adopting digital tools, AI, energy-efficiency measures and circular business models will deliver long-term competitiveness and quality job creation across Member States.

sector: All-island Economy, Cross-Border Trade, Entrepreneurship, Investor Readiness, Innovation,
response_text: 1. Use real-world stories of SME and community benefit Ireland’s experience with the all-island economy allows it to showcase practical examples of EU-enabled cooperation from innovation vouchers and cross-border clusters to SME export success and shared skills programmes. 2. Highlight the Union’s role in stability, opportunity, and prosperity The Strategic Agenda foregrounds Europe’s founding values of democratic resilience and the benefits of open mobility and trade. Communications should translate these into concrete impacts that align with domestic priorities and the issues that matter to citizens across the Union: better jobs, safer communities, more resilient supply chains. 3. Amplify regional voices Engagement with businesses, chambers, universities and civic organisations, particularly in border regions, can help to demonstrate how EU membership enables cooperation that would not otherwise occur. 4. Youth and SME engagement as a communication pillar Events involving young entrepreneurs, start-ups, and cross-border innovators can create a sense of ownership and visibility over the Presidency.

sector: All-island Economy, Cross-Border Trade, Entrepreneurship, Investor Readiness, Innovation,
response_text: 1. Ireland’s Presidency will allow it to demonstrate leadership on globally significant issues, and particularly the economic system, in a way that is consistent with Irish and European values. It is also an unparalleled opportunity to highlight the unique strengths of the all-island economy, demonstrating how cross-border trade, innovation and SME networks can contribute to wider EU goals. InterTradeIreland particularly supports: A strong focus on implementation, simplification and impact, consistent with the 2026 Work Programme. Progress on Single Market deepening, Capital Markets Union, cross-border services, and digital adoption. Recognition of the role that cross-border collaboration, shared clusters and all-island networks can play in delivering cohesion, competitiveness and a just transition. A Presidency framed around practical benefits for citizens and SMEs, reinforcing Ireland’s reputation as a constructive, facilitative, and solutions-focused Member State. 2. InterTradeIreland’s unique statutory remit is to promote cross-border trade and innovation in support of a competitive all-island economy. Over 25 years, we have supported SMEs in accessing new markets, adopting innovation, and securing investment. More than 61,000 SMEs have benefitted directly from our programmes, and our entrepreneurship and investor-readiness supports have helped early-stage firms secure more than £350 million in investment. We believe Ireland’s Presidency offers a valuable opportunity to highlight how practical cooperation between jurisdictions can deliver real economic impact for businesses and communities, in line with EU priorities on competitiveness, cohesion, and regional convergence. For instance, our Innovation Boost programme is an exemplar of enabling SMEs to access cross-border academic expertise and supports the employment of a dedicated graduate to implement innovation projects that drive competitiveness. InterTradeIreland maintains a comprehensive research portfolio that aligns with EU priorities on evidence-based policymaking. The quarterly All-Island Business Monitor provides one of the most comprehensive real-time indicators of SME sentiment, costs, and operational challenges. Research projects on the circular economy, offshore wind, business supports, and cross-border trade dynamics support wider policy learning. The Trade Hub and Technical Trade Forum help policymakers to understand emerging opportunities and regulatory challenges. Given our statutory mandate, evidence base, and close engagement with SMEs across both jurisdictions, InterTradeIreland would welcome the opportunity to contribute to the Irish Presidency by: Showcasing the economic benefits of cross-border cooperation and collaborative innovation for SMEs; Sharing insights from the All-Island Business Monitor, the Trade Hub, and our wider research portfolio; Demonstrating how practical, place-based cooperation supports EU competitiveness, cohesion, and the functioning of the Single Market; Engaging with Council, working groups and Presidency events where SME experience and cross-border evidence can support better EU policymaking. Ireland’s Presidency provides a timely platform to highlight the real-world value of cooperation, evidence and SME-centred policy design; these are principles that InterTradeIreland works to deliver in practice every day. We would particularly welcome the opportunity to formally present our 26 years of experience in areas such as clustering, collaborative information, and enterprise development to a European audience who can benefit from it.
