organisation: Food Allergy Centre Padua University Hospital  Padua Italy
response_text: Taking into account the current geopolitical and socioeconomic context in Europe, we recommend that Ireland prioritise Health Protection, Citizen Safety, and Resilient Societies as core themes of its 2026 Presidency. Serious allergies and anaphylaxis are rising across Europe and place a growing burden on individuals, schools, workplaces, and public services. Addressing them fits naturally within broader objectives to protect citizens’ wellbeing and reduce preventable health risks. . A R e s i l i e n t an d P r e p a r e d E u r o p e The EU must be equipped to respond to emergencies—whether acute health events, natural disasters, or public safety threats. This requires harmonised emergency response systems, stronger community level preparedness, and cross-border cooperation. Ireland is one of the few Member States that has taken concrete steps to improve preparedness for serious allergic reactions, including allowing pharmacists to supply emergency medicines without a prescription during anaphylactic events. This national practice demonstrates effective emergency readiness and provides a model for EU-level policy coordination, which could inform upcoming initiatives under the European Health Union framework aimed at strengthening preparedness, prevention, and rapid response across Member States. . A P e o p l e -C e n t r e d U n i o n t h a t P r o t e c t s Embedding people-centred principles into EU policymaking ensures that vulnerable populations and individuals at risk of medical emergencies are not left behind. The Presidency could advance reducing health inequalities across the EU, highlighting uneven access to diagnosis, specialist care, and emergency response protocols. Positioning timely care for serious allergies and anaphylaxis within this agenda demonstrates a commitment to practical, measurable improvements in patient safety and inclusion, while protecting citizens’ rights to safety in everyday environments such as schools, childcare centres, workplaces, and public venues. 3 . A F u t u r e -O r i e n t e d E u r o p e B u i l t o n I n n o v a t i o n a n d C o l l a b o r a t i o n Ireland’s strong reputation in digital innovation offers an opportunity to promote Digital Innovation for Health, leveraging the European Health Data Space and interoperable, patient-centred tools. For individuals at risk of serious allergic reactions, seamless access to medical information across borders can prevent emergencies and support the free movement of people. The Presidency can also prioritise harmonised awareness-raising, institutional readiness, and capacity building, ensuring schools, businesses, and public institutions are equipped and trained to respond effectively to lifethreatening health incidents.

organisation: Food Allergy Centre Padua University Hospital  Padua Italy
response_text: Ireland could use its Presidency to champion health resilience, citizen protection, and emergency preparedness, leveraging its national leadership in anaphylaxis response as a model for EU coordination. Key priorities include: Health Protection and Emergency Preparedness Serious allergies and anaphylaxis present a growing public-health challenge. The Presidency could: •Promote timely access to emergency medicines, building on Ireland’s approach where pharmacists can supply life-saving treatment without prescription. •Encourage harmonised school and public-venue preparedness, using Ireland as an example. Relevant upcoming EU initiative: •Global health resilience initiative (non-legislative, Q2 2026) – to strengthen EU capacity for rapid response to health crises. Digital Innovation for Health Cross-border emergencies require seamless access to patient data: Promote the European Health Data Space for secure, interoperable sharing of health information, enabling faster response to anaphylactic events across borders. Support digital tools for citizen-centred care, enhancing emergency response and patient safety. 3. Reducing Health Inequalities and Strengthening Citizen Rights The Presidency could advance equitable access to emergency care and citizen-centred policy: Link preparedness to strengthening the Child Guarantee (non-legislative, Q2 2026) and Citizens omnibus (legislative, Q4 2026), ensuring children in schools, childcare centres, and communities are protected and have their rights effectively enforced. Promote intergenerational fairness through the Intergenerational fairness strategy (non legislative, Q1 2026), ensuring emergency preparedness and health access benefit current and future generations equally. Highlight Ireland’s model as a practical, replicable approach for other Member States. Objectives Establish a model for EU-level anaphylaxis and emergency response coordination, based on best practices of Ireland. Ensure equitable access to life-saving treatments across the EU. Promote digital innovation for preparedness, information sharing, and cross-border patient care. Strengthen citizen rights and intergenerational fairness, ensuring public health policies reflect social equity. Position health resilience as a pillar of EU citizen safety and social cohesion, demonstrating tangible improvements in public health readiness. By focusing on these targeted initiatives, Ireland can use its Presidency to deliver practical, measurable impacts on citizen safety, health equity, and cross-border emergency preparedness while reinforcing the EU’s social and legal frameworks.

organisation: Food Allergy Centre Padua University Hospital  Padua Italy
response_text: The Irish Presidency has the potential to deliver significant, tangible impact for EU citizens by advancing health resilience and consumer safety. For individuals with serious allergies, policies that improve emergency response, access to medicines, and accurate allergen information can be lifesaving. For people, expanded access to emergency treatment, including pharmacy-enabled emergency supply across the EU, enhances safety in daily life. Citizens with serious allergies would be better protected in schools, workplaces, sports facilities, cultural venues, and during cross-border travel. For businesses, harmonised allergen-labelling and staff-training expectations reduce regulatory uncertainty, simplify compliance, and improve consumer trust by fostering safer public environments. For communities and institutions, EU-supported readiness measures ,such as common school protocols, public-venue guidelines, and accessible training ,would significantly reduce preventable emergencies, supporting all three Alliance objectives. Replicating Ireland’s best practice on emergency medicine access would ensure that life-saving intervention is available regardless of where a reaction occurs, reducing inequalities across Member States.

organisation: Food Allergy Centre Padua University Hospital  Padua Italy
response_text: Ireland has a strong opportunity to communicate the value of EU membership by focusing on everyday benefits and practical improvements that resonate directly with citizens. The 2026 Presidency can show how EU cooperation protects people, strengthens communities, and makes daily life safer—particularly in areas such as emergency preparedness for serious allergies and anaphylaxis. Highlight Practical Examples of EU Solidarity Citizens understand the EU best when they see clear, relatable outcomes. Ireland can communicate EU values by highlighting how cooperation improves safety and wellbeing, for example: Safer environments in schools, restaurants, transport and public venues. Shared health information that makes travel within the EU safer and more predictable. • Harmonised allergen-labelling rules that protect consumers wherever they are. • More consistent access to emergency support for serious allergic reactions. Ireland’s own approach—allowing pharmacists to supply emergency treatment during a serious allergic reaction—provides a concrete example of national leadership that improves citizen safety. Propose Council Recommendations on Emergency Readiness To strengthen public understanding of the EU’s benefits, Ireland could lead on a visible, citizencentred initiative: Develop Council Recommendations on broader readiness and access to emergency treatment for serious allergy and anaphylaxis. This would help encourage Member States to: Improve preparedness in schools, public venues, workplaces, and transport hubs. • Ensure trained responders are available across community settings. Reduce inequalities in access to time-sensitive, life-saving care. Such an initiative is easy for citizens to relate to, directly improves safety, and demonstrates EU cooperation delivers real, practical benefits for families, children, workers, and communities. This people-centred framing will strengthen public trust, build ownership, and demonstrate the concrete value of Ireland’s leadership at EU level.

organisation: Irish Regions European Office (National Coordinator for the Irish Delegation)
response_text: Economic, social, and territorial Cohesion is a fundamental objective of the European Union (EU), aiming to reduce disparities between regions and ensure balanced development across all territories. Achieving this goal requires the active involvement of local and regional authorities, who are best positioned to respond to the specific needs of their communities. The Irish Delegation to the EU Committee of the Regions (CoR) encourages the Irish Presidency to focus on the following priorities, in line with the overall objectives of the CoR and issues in relation to local authorities and Regional Assemblies in Ireland. Affordable and sustainable housing Balanced and effective regional development and enhanced subsidiarity EU budget / MFF Resilience Competitiveness

organisation: Irish Regions European Office (National Coordinator for the Irish Delegation)
response_text: Sustainable and Affordable Housing While housing remains largely a national competence, the EU’s Affordable Housing Action Plan can be advanced in Ireland’s Presidency to: Promote exchange of best practice on sustainable construction, land use management, and public housing delivery models. Support EU initiatives on construction sector productivity, skills shortages, and innovation in retrofitting, which directly influence housing supply and affordability. Balanced and effective regional development and enhanced subsidiarity The Irish Delegation to the CoR would like to see the Presidency undertake to focus on balanced regional development across the EU and to share experiences on how enhanced subsidiarity can ensure political accountability. The regional structure of local government in Ireland is weak in comparison to other EU countries and the Irish Delegation to the CoR would welcome a strengthening of the role of regional government in Ireland. The lack of linkage between local authorities and regional assemblies and the Committee of the Regions leads to a deficit in the structures to enable political accountability and legitimacy. Political legitimacy is a key element in a democratic society. There are huge opportunities to examine and review best practice of a cross section of functions from County, city and town councils with administrations across the EU. EU Budget / MFF Central for the Irish Delegation is that the Irish Presidency leads the way on negotiations on the post-2027 Cohesion Policy framework, ensuring an appropriate place based, regionally balanced allocation of funding for Irish and EU regions. The Irish Delegation is calling for balanced and effective regional development and opposes the ‘nationalisation’ of cohesion policy. A clear, distinct and ring-fenced European budget for Cohesion policy as outlined below is required; The definition, at EU level, of indicative regional allocations of resources based on the current consolidated methodology that takes into account social and economic indicators, as well as territorial specificities, thus ensuring a dedicated budget for each category of regions. A safety net allocation, in comparison to the 2021-2027 period, should be granted. A European budget safeguarded to support rural development, which keeps CAP separate from Cohesion policy ensuring that these are not competing with each other. The recognition of the urban aspect and the special role of urban areas. The full respect of the principles of partnership and subsidiarity by granting Europe’s regions a paramount role in the programming and implementation process, through shared management, multilevel governance, ensuring direct negotiation between regions and the European Commission without the need for prior authorisation by the Member State. The Irish Delegation also supports cross-border and transnational cooperation, including the Peace Plus legacy for Border Region of Ireland and Northern Ireland and the continuation of European Territorial Cooperation programmes that Irish local and regional authorities can avail of. Another important priority for the Irish Delegation is to strengthen rural, island, coastal and peripheral regions (important in the context of the Atlantic Strategy) and also to ensure that the LEADER programme is retained, with less of an administrative burden. The Connecting Europe Fund should also be retained to ensure connectivity to rural and peripheral areas. Resilience Resilience is the ability to react to crises, be it climate-related disasters like floods or droughts or security threats. Local and regional authorities are at the forefront when it comes to managing major transitions and crisis impacts. Their role must be strengthened, so that they can adequately address challenges in areas like energy and food security, water management or climate action. A key issue is to improve connectivity, particularly in rural, remote and island regions. Competitiveness On this issue, the Irish Delegation seeks to ensure that the Irish Presidency focuses on the following issues: Accelerating clean energy deployment (offshore wind, grid interconnection, storage). Supporting sustainable agriculture and food security with a pragmatic CAP. Promoting green industrial competitiveness—EU manufacturing of net-zero technologies. Advancing circular economy legislation and nature restoration in a balanced way. Advancing the Single Market 2.0/SME competitiveness agenda as well as supporting strategic autonomy through open trade, especially with stable transatlantic ties. Focusing on digital innovation, AI governance, cybersecurity and trusted data flows. Strengthening Europe’s innovation capacity, university–industry cooperation and startup ecosystems. Securing supply chains for digital infrastructure and semiconductors. The Irish Delegation would like the Presidency to showcase Ireland’s 3 Regional Innovation Valleys (3 Regional Assemblies). RIVs bring together less innovative regions with more innovative ones to address the most burning challenges facing the EU. The competitiveness agenda can only be successful by ensuring appropriate social measures to support social and economic cohesion. These include: Addressing demographic challenges and labour shortages Delivering on the European Pillar of Social Rights, via the European Social Fund Future-proofing the workforce: skills, lifelong learning, digital literacy Strengthening youth mobility and cultural cooperation Other Issues - Relationship with Third Countries THE Irish Delegation would also like to note a number of important topics, in relation to the EU’s relationship with third countries and note that these are important for the Irish Presidency: Strengthening the EU–UK relationship, including implementation of Windsor Framework and Trade & Cooperation Agreement updates. Advancing development partnerships, particularly in climate finance and humanitarian responses, using the CoR’s Cities and Regions for International Partnerships Forum. Enhancing the EU’s role in global conflict prevention and multilateralism. Supporting EU enlargement (Western Balkans, Ukraine, Moldova, Georgia). Managing migration through humane, coordinated mechanisms.

organisation: Irish Regions European Office (National Coordinator for the Irish Delegation)
response_text: The Irish Presidency can deliver the greatest positive impact for people, businesses and communities across the EU by focusing on practical outcomes that strengthen competitiveness, resilience and social cohesion. By prioritising legislative delivery, improved implementation and consensus-building, the Presidency can help ensure that EU policies translate into tangible benefits across Member States. 1. Leaving no one behind - Putting people and communities at the centre of EU policy A Presidency focused on inclusion can make EU policies more meaningful in daily life. It must delivee on housing. Supporting initiatives on skills, education and labour mobility will help people adapt to economic change and access better job opportunities. Strengthening the implementation of the European Pillar of Social Rights can improve working conditions, access to social protections and equal opportunities. Progress on humane and coordinated migration and integration policies will help communities manage demographic and labour-market needs while ensuring social cohesion. 2. Delivering a fair and achievable green transition The next phase of climate and energy policy must be designed to support communities as well as meet EU climate goals. By prioritising affordable clean energy, grid interconnection, energy efficiency and renewable deployment, the Presidency can help reduce household costs and strengthen energy security. A balanced approach to sustainable agriculture, food supply chains and rural development will ensure that farmers and peripheral regions benefit from new opportunities. Early progress on cohesion policy for the post-2027 period can improve targeted support for regions in transition and help reduce territorial disparities. 3.Ensuring effective, transparent and citizen-focused governance Finally, the Presidency can promote practical improvements in how EU programmes are delivered. Simpler funding rules, better regulatory coherence and stronger monitoring of results can reduce burdens on administrations and allow businesses and communities to benefit more quickly from EU initiatives. Clear communication of EU actions during the Presidency can also help citizens better understand and engage with the Union. By advancing these priorities in an open, constructive and pragmatic manner, the Irish Presidency can help deliver real improvements in prosperity, security and opportunity across Europe. Advancing a more competitive and innovative Europe The Presidency can drive measures that directly support SMEs, entrepreneurs and workers. Progress on the renewal of the Single Market—particularly in services, digitalisation and reducing administrative burdens—would lower costs for businesses and expand opportunities for cross-border activity. Advancing responsible AI governance and improved cybersecurity will give citizens confidence and create a stable environment for innovation. Work on research cooperation, skills and a supportive investment framework will help businesses scale and ensure Europe remains at the forefront of technological development. Strengthening security, stability and resilience Citizens need to feel protected in a rapidly changing world. By improving coordination on cybersecurity, tackling hybrid threats and strengthening the resilience of critical infrastructure, the Presidency can contribute to safer digital and physical environments. Supporting a credible EU enlargement policy—based on democratic standards and institutional readiness—can enhance stability in the EU’s neighbourhood. Constructive engagement in the evolving EU–UK relationship will also help secure smoother cooperation for border regions and businesses.

organisation: Irish Regions European Office (National Coordinator for the Irish Delegation)
response_text: Communicating the values and benefits of EU membership—and building genuine citizen ownership of Ireland’s Presidency—requires combining clear messaging, visible local impact, and meaningful participation. The goal is not only to inform citizens but to involve them in the story of Ireland’s role in Europe. The Irish Delegation to the CoR, are locally elected ‘ambassadors for the EU’ in every town, city and rural area of the country and stand ready to assist in communicating the positive messages about the work of the EU and its impact on citizens. A number of ideas on how to do this effectively are listed below: 1. Make EU benefits tangible and local and use plan accessible language Citizens engage most when EU membership is linked to everyday life, so the Irish Delegation would like to see the following actions as part of Ireland’s Presidency. Highlight more of the specific, place-based examples of EU-funded projects—transport links, research centres, broadband roll-out, environmental restoration, youth programmes. The 3 Regional Assemblies, as Managing Authorities for EU programmes have many examples of projects that can be used. Use data, case studies and storytelling to show how EU policies lower costs, create jobs, support farmers, expand consumer rights and strengthen security. • Map Ireland’s Presidency priorities to issues the public cares about: affordability, housing, climate resilience, digital safety, opportunities for young people. Technical EU language can distance the public. Communication should be clear, direct and free of acronyms and focused on “what this means for you”. Information can be delivered through short formats—videos, infographics, social content—rather than lengthy institutional text. Framing should connect EU values to Irish values: fairness, solidarity, opportunity, openness and respect for community. The Irish Delegation suggests that the Presidency should support training for elected members to clearly communicate the benefits of the EU to citizens. Put citizens and communities at the heart of the Presidency narrative Citizens should feel that the Presidency is not an elite or institutional event, but a moment of national participation and the Irish Delegation believes this can be done effectively by creating a unifying Presidency slogan that speaks to shared European and Irish values. Also, it is important to promote stories of Irish people who shape Europe—researchers, small businesses, students, cultural figures. The Irish Delegation calls for measures and funding to encourage local authorities, schools, universities and community groups to hold Presidency-linked events, debates and cultural activities across all regions. This could be similar to DFAT’s Communicating Europe programme. In addition, the EU Network of Local Councillors has over 100 Irish Members, based across the country who can assist with promotion of messaging to citizens. Similarly, the CoR’s Young Elected Politicians can support this work. Activate young people and strong messaging Young people are among the most positively disposed toward the EU but often feel least engaged in EU processes. It is important to expand youth dialogues, panels and competitions connected to Presidency themes. There may be scope to use schools and universities as multipliers by providing toolkits, learning modules and engagement grants. Perhaps the use of young digital creators for digital media campaigns would help with messaging. The Irish Delegation would welcome two-way engagement over the course of the Presidency and stand ready, in conjunction with the CoR to organise regional citizen dialogues and online consultations on topics relevant to the Presidency. In addition, organisations such as the NYCI, Foróige, Comhairle na nÓg and the National and European Youth Forum could be involved. It is important that this feedback is used to shape messages or highlight public concerns in Council discussions. The CoR can be used as an important EU institution to get messages across to the public and the Irish Delegation will support the Irish Presidency in this regard. The Irish Presidency can use open days, livestreamed events, interactive exhibitions and behind-thescenes videos to demystify EU decision-making and should highlight Ireland’s role as a consensus-builder, emphasising how the Presidency serves all Europeans—not just institutions.

organisation: Irish Regions European Office (National Coordinator for the Irish Delegation)
response_text: must provide a summary of the additional information under the ‘Any other comments’ question. This summary should also be limited to a maximum of 500 words. EU Local Government Support Service The Irish Delegation calls for the Government to take a decision on the proposal which has been submitted to DHLGH on an EU Local Government Support Service. The strategy also seeks to build a network of EU funding officers across local government in Ireland and it would provide local authorities with a one stop shop approach to navigating the EU policy and funding arena, ensuring complementarity, to best suit the needs of each local authority, in line with their corporate and strategic plans and the availability of the range of funding programmes (ERDF / ESF/ ETC / Other Competitive Funding Programmes). The Irish Delegation to the CoR believe that this proposal is timely in light of Ireland’s Presidency of the EU and sends a positive message to Europe that Irish local government is fully engaged in the EU. It is also an opportune time to raise the awareness and engagement regionally and locally in EU policy matters and participation in EU funding programmes. CoR Presidency Events The Irish Delegation to the CoR, together with the IREO, the Perm Rep and Govt Departments will be involved in the organisation of several high level meetings for the Presidency including: Welcome reception – ‘Projects and Produce’ from Ireland’s Regions – 1st July, CoR building, Brussels External ECON Commission, Galway (date tbc) External Bureau, (location and date tbc) The Irish Delegation to the CoR would welcome engagement and the opportunity to propose suitable locations for the External Bureau meeting and encourage DFA to engage fully with Members on the detail of this meeting. The Irish Delegation to the CoR are calling for extra and increased support to the Irish Regions European Office to ensure the effective delivery of the above work – ensuring that the Irish local and regional government can deliver for Ireland during these important months for the country and for Europe. The Irish Delegation would welcome ongoing and detailed engagement with DFAT during the upcoming stakeholder discussions on issues for Presidency referrals to the CoR.

Our Europe: free, resilient, democratic Caught between a military threat from Russia and a United States project to undermine liberal democracy, the EU is facing an uncomfortable reality. As a small, open economy with a strong human rights record, history of colonialism, deep commitment to peace and credible international voice, Ireland can guide the EU during these turbulent times by engaging in principled international diplomacy that signals protection of the values- and rules-based European order that the block was founded on (in line with Art 2 of the Treaty on European Union). This will project a resilient Europe willing to act to protect democratic values, freedoms, laws and institutions against current threats, an approach that is anchored in the rule of law and respect for human rights, as the block’s primary strength and selling point within Europe and globally. The democratic decline in Europe is stark. Eastern Europe is experiencing a “particularly steep decline” and Western Europe a surge in popularity of far-right parties. This has led to significant pressures on the rule of law, and attacks against civic space and civil society, including in countries (e.g. such as France and Germany) that were, until recently, considered bastions of liberal democracy. The decline is expected to continue during and beyond the Irish Presidency and current negative trends risk becoming normalised, presenting unprecedented opportunities for authoritarians. Washington’s overwhelming control of Europe’s technology and media is an important element of the current threat to democracy. While this issue is particularly sensitive for Ireland because of its reliance on foreign direct investment and presence of Big Tech and social media platforms in Ireland, the interest in preserving European democracy during the Presidency must be overriding, as part of its “honest broker role”. Furthermore, it must be recognised that the EU has incurred significant reputational damage associated with the genocide in Gaza (due to European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen’s position and inaction as a bloc leading to accusations of complicity coupled with active facilitation of the violence by individual Member States). Ireland can provide direction on the strategic need for a values-based, forward-looking, inclusive, people-centred Europe and European foreign policy, to restore confidence in European institutions and values on the international stage. This will require ambition and going against the tide on occasion but Ireland is in a unique position to provide vision and leadership.

Protecting civil society and civic space Ireland should focus on ensuring the EU’s Civil Society Strategy is well-funded and implemented during its Presidency as part of defending European democracy. During negotiations on the Multiannual Financial Framework Ireland should ensure maximum funding is negotiated for the AgoraEU programme, specifically €3.6 billion for CERV+ as a baseline investment in civil society as the backbone of European democracy. The bulk of the negotiations will take place during Ireland’s Presidency and there is a unique opportunity for Ireland to defend the budget, including against attempts from other Member States to undermine it. More broadly, Ireland should push for support at a European level to facilitate greater philanthropic engagement with civil society and connect pro bono legal resources with civil society organisations to facilitate their work, as per commitments in the Civil Society Strategy. Promoting and safeguarding multilateralism and the rule of law International justice, international humanitarian law, the human rights system (including the Special Procedures) and multilateralism have come under unprecedented attack as part of recent geo-political shifts. To counter this Ireland should leverage its position during the Presidency to reaffirm and champion multilateral institutions that defend rules-based order and provide leadership on how to enforce international law. This will necessitate an ambitious, principled and forward-looking approach. In partnership with like-minded states, Ireland can provide leadership in key areas by e.g: working to protect the International Criminal Court and those that engage and co-operate with it as a means of fighting impunity for international crimes; going beyond recognition of Palestine to take concrete steps to ensure its territorial integrity and legal personality (as a follow-on to Ireland’s recognition of Palestine on 28 May 2024 and formal endorsement of the Two-State Solution); protecting and strengthening Palestinian civil society and journalists working for the protection and upholding of human rights; - pushing for robust EU-level action to end the genocide, if ongoing, and implement a recovery plan for Gaza. 3. Protecting children’s online safety Ireland’s Presidency should highlight children’s vulnerability in the digital age and prioritise the protection of children from harmful content (e.g. self-harm, self-loathing and suicide) being pushed into their online feeds by digital platforms’ recommender algorithms. As the regulatory epicentre of the digital world, Ireland is in a unique position to do this. It has responsibility for all of Europe for supervising how children’s data are used by YouTube, TikTok, SnapChat, etc. and ensuring that they are protected. During the Presidency, Ireland should lead the Council in preparing a Manifesto Against Child Harm Online that defines what enforcement to protect children should look like across the Union. Continued below in the “Any other comments” section. The above will deliver concretely on objectives listed in the Strategic Agenda’s focus on “a free and democratic Europe” (e.g., strengthening democratic resilience; protecting free and pluralistic civil society; safeguarding the rule of law).

Ensure that the Civil Society Strategy’s emphasis on strengthening “effective and meaningful engagement with civil society as a partner” in law/policymaking is implemented in a concrete and meaningful way. This includes allowing the necessary time for consultation, debate on, and oversight of the lawmaking process. Ireland has an opportunity to proactively defend civil society’s participation in such democratic processes, while working to protect civic space and ensuring CSOs are empowered to contribute safely. Ensure that law/policymaking during the Presidency does not undermine fundamental rights, in line with the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the EU. This includes any encroachment by state and corporate actors and necessitates ensuring that law-making is evidence-based, transparent, inclusive and includes comprehensive rights impact assessments, as relevant and where fundamental rights may be under threat. It is particularly important that the voices of marginalised and minority groups are sought out and listened to as part of a Europe where everyone’s human rights are respected. The EU Fundamental Rights Agency (FRA) has documented how fundamental rights impact assessments are not carried out for all legislative files where they are needed and how these assessments are “often superficial”. The EU deregulation agenda for digital rights has also been accused of undermining democratic processes (in addition to digital rights) in recent weeks. It is essential that Ireland uses the Presidency to push back against such trends.

By publishing a summary of the inputs received for this consultation as quickly as possible and a substantive response, and taking a similar approach to any other consultations or public engagements around the Presidency. By proactively communicating in an accessible way about what Ireland is seeking to achieve on the EU stage during the Presidency: Having a coordinated, strategic communications plan for the Presidency which operates across all media and speaks directly to the public of Ireland. Using accessible, plain language to clearly communicate about the Presidency. Using all communications channels and touchpoints available to the Presidency to ensure your message reaches people of all ages in all parts of Ireland, e.g., print and broadcast media, social media, public buildings, invitations, events, partnerships. Ensuring that newer media forms, e.g., social media channels, podcasts, etc. are firmly integrated in all communication plans. Proactively working with content creators and influencers to open up the Presidency, and related events and discussions, to a wider audience. By moving beyond rhetoric to deliver concrete outputs i.e. by showing what being a member of the EU delivers for people. By showing leadership on issues that Irish people care about, including complex issues where there is a lack of consensus e.g., using the full force of its diplomatic powers, with like-minded states, to achieve progress on Palestinian rights; by calling out and providing values-based leadership on protecting rights (e.g., of minorities, civil society) that are under attack. By facilitating the involvement of different stakeholders in Presidency activities e.g. events, launches, town halls, awareness-raising, including at community-level and across the country. By engaging people through awards and prize-giving, thereby celebrating Ireland’s contribution to the Presidency and Europe’s place in the world. By engaging in targeted outreach on the Presidency in creative ways to youth, marginalised and minority communities in Ireland.

As part of protecting democracy and Europeans’ digital rights, Ireland’s Presidency should prioritise implementation of existing EU law to protect Europe’s information environment from interference and harm, including: the removal of US control of recommender algorithms that determine what news and debate appears in Europeans’ social feeds; the removal of US control of online advertising systems that dominate Europe’s news market; enforcement against unlawful US use of European personal data to train Large Language Models. In parallel, the Presidency should prioritise measures to enable European alternatives to grow and scale across the entire Union.

sector: Child Rights – dual mandate humanitarian and development organisation.
response_text: Ireland’s Presidency of the Council of the European Union offers a unique opportunity to shape Europe’s global leadership on issues that matter most to vulnerable communities worldwide. From a World Vision perspective, Ireland should champion a Presidency agenda rooted in people-centred values, global solidarity, and climate justice, aligning with the EU Strategic Agenda and Ireland’s own tradition of principled diplomacy. We would suggest a number of themes that Ireland should prioritise during its Presidency. Firstly, climate justice and resilience must be a flagship priority. As climate impacts intensify, Ireland can lead efforts to operationalize the Global Goal on Adaptation agreed at COP30, ensuring that EU climate action integrates adaptation financing, nature-based solutions, and intergenerational equity. This is not only about reducing emissions but about safeguarding lives and livelihoods in fragile contexts, where children are disproportionately affected by climate shocks. Ireland should elevate child rights and social inclusion as a core theme, reinforcing the EU’s commitment to human dignity and equality. With millions of children facing violence, exploitation, and disrupted education due to conflict and displacement, Ireland can advocate for stronger EU external action on addressing child poverty globally. Investing in children is one of the most powerful and cost-effective strategies for building resilient societies and sustainable economies. From World Vision’s standpoint, this means prioritizing policies and resources that ensure every child has access to health, nutrition, education, protection, and participation. Evidence shows that interventions in early childhood, such as adequate nutrition, quality education, and safe environments yield lifelong benefits, breaking cycles of poverty and inequality. Sustainable food systems and nutrition deserve high-level attention, given the intersection of climate change, biodiversity loss, and global hunger. Sustainable food systems and nutrition must remain a central EU priority which are fundamental to achieving health, equity, and climate resilience. The EU’s leadership in this area is critical for addressing the triple burden of malnutrition/undernutrition, micronutrient deficiencies, and obesity while transforming food systems to be fair, healthy, and environmentally sustainable. Ireland can lead on advancing the EU Green Deal globally, promoting nutrition-sensitive agriculture and climate-smart food systems to end child malnutrition. Fragile and conflict-affected contexts with a coherent approach across CODEV and COHAFA, ensuring a full humanitarian-development-peace nexus and advocating for their inclusion in MFF, Global Europe, and Global Gateway negotiations with appropriate funding levels and flexible modalities. In parallel, given escalating violations of International Humanitarian Law (IHL) and the EU’s ambition to strengthen humanitarian diplomacy, Ireland should make IHL a headline commitment, advance reflections on the Humanitarian Reset, and align with the upcoming EC Humanitarian Communication to reinforce EU leadership in protecting civilians and upholding humanitarian principles. These priorities reflect Ireland’s values and the EU’s strategic objectives while responding to urgent global challenges. By framing its Presidency around “A People-Centred Europe: Leading on Climate Justice, Child Rights, and Global Solidarity,” Ireland can position itself as a champion of fairness and sustainability, reinforcing Europe’s role as a trusted global partner. This is an opportunity to advocate for policies that protect children, empower communities, and deliver climate-resilient futures, ensuring that the EU’s influence translates into tangible improvements for those most at risk.

sector: Child Rights – dual mandate humanitarian and development organisation.
response_text: Ireland’s Presidency of the Council of the European Union in 2026 presents a strategic opportunity to influence legislative priorities that advance justice, resilience, and solidarity. Ireland’s EU Council Presidency in 2026 should play a pivotal role in shaping the Multiannual Financial Framework (2028–2034). Ireland should act as an honest broker to secure a balanced budget that reflects solidarity, sustainability, and global responsibility. This means protecting strong allocations for humanitarian aid, development cooperation, and resilience-building under Heading 6 (Neighbourhood & the World), while ensuring climate adaptation and biodiversity funding remain central to national and regional plans. Ireland should prioritize predictable financing for child-focused programmes, education, and social protection, and push for policy coherence linking food systems, nutrition, and climate resilience. By embedding child rights and climate justice into the MFF negotiations, Ireland can ensure EU resources deliver tangible benefits for vulnerable communities globally, positioning Europe as a leader in fairness and sustainability. In addition, Ireland must maintain CSO space within the context of the MFF this means transparency (of information, on programming, around consultations etc.), adequate aid modality in which CSOs are included etc. Ireland should ensure meaningful space (and funding modality) for civil society in the Global Europe Regulation. In line with the Presidency’s stated prioritisation of civil society, it would be valuable to continue regular exchanges with Brussels-based humanitarian INGOs, particularly around the margins of the monthly COHAFA meetings. These meetings have proven useful during the Danish presidency for ensuring information-sharing and exchanges on topical issues. Denmark has encouraged the next EU Presidencies to continue this format. The Presidency should prioritize policy areas that protect vulnerable populations, address climate impacts, and strengthen global partnerships. Climate and environmental legislation must be at the forefront. Ireland should lead negotiations on the implementation of the Nature Restoration Law and the post-2030 climate framework, ensuring that adaptation financing and just transition principles are embedded in EU law. This includes operationalizing commitments under the Global Goal on Adaptation agreed at COP30, with a strong emphasis on nature-based solutions and resilience for communities most affected by climate shocks. Ireland should also champion child rights and social inclusion within the EU’s equality agenda. Legislative proposals linked to the European Child Guarantee and the EU Strategy on the Rights of the Child offer a platform to strengthen child protection systems, inclusive education, and gender equality. The Presidency should aim to secure Council conclusions that integrate these priorities into both internal and external EU policies, ensuring that development cooperation reflects a child-centred approach. On sustainable food systems and nutrition should be a key legislative focus, building on the Farm to Fork Strategy and CAP reform. Ireland can drive progress on proposals that promote climate-smart agriculture and nutrition-sensitive approaches, addressing global hunger and child malnutrition. The EU has made ambitious commitments at the Nutrition4Growth Summit; EC services are presently reflecting on how the targets will be quantified and programmed, of course in alignment with the Global Gateway approach. The EU needs to ensure meaningful programming of its nutrition commitments, with clear targets and measurement. Ireland can play a central role in delivering on these.

sector: Child Rights – dual mandate humanitarian and development organisation.
response_text: Ireland’s EU Council Presidency in 2026 offers a unique platform to embed meaningful child and youth participation in EU decision-making, reflecting Ireland’s strong tradition of championing rights-based approaches. Ireland should ensure that the Global Dimension of the EU Child Rights Strategy is implemented in a meaningfully manner. The Presidency should go beyond symbolic engagement and create structured, impactful opportunities for youth voices to influence policy. Ireland can convene a Youth Forum linked to the Presidency agenda, ensuring representation from diverse backgrounds, including marginalized and vulnerable groups. This forum could feed directly into informal ministerial meetings and Council conclusions, giving youth perspectives real weight in shaping priorities such as climate action, digital transformation, and social inclusion. In addition, the Presidency should integrate child and youth consultations into legislative discussions on files like the European Child Guarantee, education, and digital rights, using accessible formats and child-friendly language. Ireland can champion participatory mechanisms at EU level, advocating for the institutionalization of youth engagement in Council processes—building on the EU Youth Strategy and aligning with the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child. Communication efforts should highlight stories of youth leadership, framing the Presidency as a moment where young people help shape Europe’s future. Finally, Ireland should ensure that participation is safe, inclusive, and meaningful, providing feedback loops so children and youth see how their input influences outcomes. By embedding these practices, Ireland can set a precedent for a Presidency that not only listens to young voices but acts on their ideas—strengthening democracy, fostering trust, and advancing policies that reflect the needs and aspirations of the next generation.

sector: Child Rights – dual mandate humanitarian and development organisation.
response_text: To foster a strong sense of ownership among citizens during Ireland’s EU Council Presidency, communication must be inclusive, transparent, and values-driven, highlighting how EU membership delivers tangible benefits for people, communities, and businesses. emphasize that Ireland’s Presidency is not just about managing legislative files but about shaping Europe’s future in ways that reflect Irish values—fairness, compassion, and global responsibility. By framing the Presidency as an opportunity for Ireland to lead on issues that matter; climate justice, child rights, and inclusive growth, we can create a sense of ownership rooted in purpose and shared benefit. This means ensuring that communication reflects the human dimension of EU membership: protecting children, empowering communities, and building a sustainable future for all. The narrative should emphasize shared values of solidarity, justice, and sustainability, connecting EU policies to everyday lives. By focusing on human stories showing how EU initiatives improve education, protect children’s rights, and support families during crises. Demonstrating that EU membership enables Ireland to influence global decisions on climate action, humanitarian aid, and social protection reinforces the idea that Ireland’s voice matters in shaping a fairer world. Communications should leverage community engagement and participatory platforms such as town halls, schools, and civil society dialogues which invite citizens into the conversation, making the Presidency feel like a national project rather than a distant political event.

Ireland’s Presidency offers an opportunity to champion a vision of Europe in which rural competitiveness, environmental ambition and technological innovation reinforce one another. A priority should therefore be the construction of a future-oriented, digitally enabled agricultural model that is both economically viable and environmentally resilient. A second priority should be the development of an environmentally-responsive approach to land use that recognises targeted grazing as a nature-based solution. Irish experience demonstrates how precise control of livestock movement can restore under-grazed habitat, reduce fire risk, protect vulnerable plant species and improve soil structure. As we know, 2025 has been the worst year on record for wildfires across Europe. Faced with ever-rising temperatures, the frequency of such natural hazards will continue to rise. Ireland can frame precision grazing not simply as a sector to be promoted, but as an ecological tool that, when guided by modern technology, can accelerate wildlife protection, biodiversity recovery and climate adaptation. Moreover, the EU must address the acute challenge of generational renewal in agriculture and in particular, livestock grazing. It is increasingly clear that labour demands, physical strain and inflexible management systems deter younger farmers from entering or remaining in livestock farming. Virtual fencing is an example of a technology that is already allowing farmers across Ireland and other EU countries to reduce daily physical workload, manage farming operations more productively, respond faster to issues through real-time alerts and, crucially, achieve a better balance between work and family life. A Presidency that champions more accessible and attractive farming careers would be directly responding to an EU-wide concern.

The Irish Presidency will coincide with several major legislative moments that will shape European agriculture for a decade or more. Ireland should use its role to ensure that the Union’s evolving frameworks fully embrace practical innovation, farmer wellbeing and environmentally responsible grazing. The 2028–2034 CAP proposal already identifies digitalisation, competitiveness, and generational renewal as core objectives. A robust, dedicated CAP budget is therefore the essential starting point. Irish experience shows that when CAP funding is clearly ringfenced in the EU’s financial framework and supported across both Pillar I and Pillar II, it underpins farm incomes, rural employment and investment in innovation and environmental schemes. If that budget is eroded or diluted into more general funds, farmers lose a crucial safety net and the capacity to invest in the transition that policymakers are asking of them. Within that budgetary framework, Ireland should work to ensure that the CAP and the Generational Renewal Strategy reinforce each other. The Commission rightly stresses that younger farmers need lower entry barriers, reduced labour demands and access to modern tools. Ireland should advocate that the CAP’s legal text and implementing guidance explicitly recognise digital tools that enable farmers to enhance sectoral resilience, support environmental ambitions and reduce the stress associated with livestock management as eligible investments under modernisation, digitalisation and agri-environmental measures. Building on this, Ireland is well positioned to shape EU-level discussions on Member State implementation of domestic generational renewal strategies by 2028. It is imperative that the urgency of generational renewal is recognised and openly acknowledged through steering EU discussions toward practical means of addressing barriers to a competitive and resilient EU agriculture sector. By promoting access to enabling technologies such as virtual fencing, encouraging CAP instruments that reduce day-to-day workload and capital costs, and supporting Member States in integrating these tools into their domestic generational renewal strategies by 2028, Ireland can drive EU-wide sectoral change to the benefit of all farmers. Moreover, shaping the forthcoming EU Livestock Strategy will be important in ensuring that the strategy reflects the need to overcome the declining demographic in livestock grazing across Europe. Digital grazing control has enabled farmers to safely graze previously inaccessible lands, restore uplands, reduce wildfire risk and protect vulnerable habitats. The strategy should emphasise not only technology’s role in addressing low demographic turnover in livestock farming by reducing physical strain, but also recognise precision grazing as a core method for delivering biodiversity and climate-adaptation objectives.

The Irish Presidency should promote policies that unlock the productive potential of land that is currently under-utilised or economically marginal. In Ireland, virtual fencing has allowed farmers to reintroduce grazing to steep slopes, commonage land and areas where physical fences are impractical or contentious. This has led to ecological gains through breaking up overgrazing of pastures, thus restoring heather soil as well as improved economic efficiency. If Ireland uses its position to emphasise precision grazing as a valuable tool for land management, it can help Member States meet biodiversity and climate obligations in ways that reduce, rather than increase, burdens on rural enterprises. Digitalisation more broadly is another area where the Council’s work can have a transformative effect. When rural digital infrastructure is strengthened, the benefits extend well beyond agriculture. Local businesses gain new opportunities, schools and healthcare facilities benefit from improved service delivery, and remote regions become more attractive for residence and investment. By advocating that EU connectivity programmes prioritise rural regions, Ireland can ensure that the long-term social and economic dividends of digitalisation are felt by the communities that need them most. Ultimately, the Council’s work during Ireland’s Presidency can have the greatest impact by elevating solutions that combine economic pragmatism with environmental responsibility. Technologies such as virtual fencing embody this balance, enhancing welfare and sustainability while reducing costs and labour demands. Ireland can help show that Europe’s climate ambitions are achievable when policies support the practical tools that make sustainable farming both feasible and rewarding.

Virtual fencing has allowed more than 1,200 Irish animals to graze safely on difficult terrain, enabled farmers to reduce labour and infrastructure costs, and supported ecological restoration in areas previously considered too sensitive or inaccessible for livestock. A critical step for the EU will be ensuring that digital livestock technologies are treated as distinct and complementary tools within agricultural funding frameworks. As seen in Ireland, scheme design matters. Where investment catalogues favour traditional infrastructure such as permanent fencing, farmers have limited ability to adopt virtual fencing even when it delivers higher welfare standards, and improved environmental and economic outcomes. It is important to recognise that digital boundaries achieve fundamentally different results. Ireland can help make this distinction clear at EU level by raising awareness among policymakers of the tangible benefits these tools bring to rural communities and by encouraging funding approaches that support innovation rather than unintentionally constraining it.

sector: AONTAS are the National Adult Learning Organisation of Ireland, founded in 1969 and passionately working ever since to make education equal and accessible for all. Backed by our robust research and focussed community work, we advocate and lobby for quality education for all adults, and raise awareness of the impact of adult learning on people’s lives and on society. We work on behalf our members, who connect with all communities across the island of Ireland. Our members and adult learners inform all our research and campaigns for social change.
geography: Our submission covers recommendations for EU policy to advance this agenda, while advocating for activities at a national level to raise the profile of Ireland as a leader in education and a champion of EU’s social values.
response_text: Ireland’s Presidency of the EU in 2026 must put education, and especially adult learning, at the heart of its agenda. Adult learning is the foundation of inclusion, democratic resilience, and sustainability, all of which underpin Europe’s competitiveness. It is a strategic lever to advance key policy objectives across many domains. The recognition of the value of adult learning in the objectives for the Presidency is not just an economic necessity but a social and democratic imperative. The integral importance of adult learning to the themes proposed by the Community and Voluntary Pillar are outlined below: Theme 1: Strengthening the Vision of a Social Europe Adult learning is a social right under Article 9 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union and Principle 1 of the European Pillar of Social Rights. Ensuring access to lifelong learning is essential for tackling poverty and social exclusion. Upskilling and reskilling for disadvantaged groups including migrants, older adults, and low-income workers, supports income adequacy and employability, reducing reliance on minimum income supports. Education as social infrastructure: Investment in adult learning, alongside housing, childcare and health, creates inclusive pathways for participation in economic, social, and cultural life. Theme 2: Enhancing Civil Society Participation and Deepening Democracy Adult learning fosters democratic resilience: Citizenship education and critical thinking skills help counter disinformation and strengthen civic engagement, aligning with initiatives like the Democracy Shield and the EU Civil Society Strategy. Inclusive governance requires inclusive learning: Adult learning empowers marginalised communities to engage in policy dialogue, ensuring their voices shape EU decisions. Community-based learning models and participatory structures (e.g., the AONTAS National FET Learner Forum) exemplify participatory education that builds trust and social cohesion. Global Citizenship Education: In today's globalised and interdependent, interconnected world, citizenship has a global dimension. A focus on Global Citizenship Education can ensure that people are informed, aware and empowered to take action on pressing social issues to support more just, peaceful, secure, sustainable, tolerant and inclusive societies. Theme 3: Renewed Emphasis on a Just Transition Skills for sustainability: Adult learning equips workers and communities for green and digital transitions, reducing vulnerability during economic restructuring. Lifelong learning as a climate and social justice tool: Education enables informed participation in sustainability initiatives and supports equitable access to new opportunities in the green economy. SDG alignment: Promoting lifelong learning (SDG 4) underpins progress on other SDGs, reinforcing Ireland’s proposed Presidency theme of “Delivering the SDGs: A Sustainable Europe for Future Generations.” In today's globalised and interdependent, interconnected world, citizenship has a global dimension. A focus on Global Citizenship Education can ensure that people are informed, aware and empowered to take action on pressing social issues to support more just, peaceful, secure, sustainable, tolerant and inclusive societies. Theme 3: Renewed Emphasis on a Just Transition Skills for sustainability: Adult learning equips workers and communities for green and digital transitions, reducing vulnerability during economic restructuring. Lifelong learning as a climate and social justice tool: Education enables informed participation in sustainability initiatives and supports equitable access to new opportunities in the green economy. SDG alignment: Promoting lifelong learning (SDG 4) underpins progress on other SDGs, reinforcing Ireland’s proposed Presidency theme of “Delivering the SDGs: A Sustainable Europe for Future Generations.”

sector: AONTAS are the National Adult Learning Organisation of Ireland, founded in 1969 and passionately working ever since to make education equal and accessible for all. Backed by our robust research and focussed community work, we advocate and lobby for quality education for all adults, and raise awareness of the impact of adult learning on people’s lives and on society. We work on behalf our members, who connect with all communities across the island of Ireland. Our members and adult learners inform all our research and campaigns for social change.
geography: Our submission covers recommendations for EU policy to advance this agenda, while advocating for activities at a national level to raise the profile of Ireland as a leader in education and a champion of EU’s social values.
response_text: 1. Adult Education and Lifelong Learning Ireland should prioritise advancing the New European Agenda for Adult Learning (NEAAL) 2021–2030, which emphasises governance, accessibility, quality, and inclusion. AONTAS are the National Coordinators for NEAAL and are positioned to help drive action on this policy area. Policy and legislative proposals linked to the European Skills Agenda (2020), including Upskilling Pathways, Individual Learning Accounts, and Micro-credentials, should be actively progressed. Driving progress on these key policy and legislative areas aligns with Ireland's track record of leadership in the field of education, and a global vision of learning as a tool for social transformation rather than solely economic competitiveness. Aim: Strengthen and position adult learning as a driver of social cohesion and democratic participation. Ireland should advocate for increased investment in lifelong learning and ensure that marginalised groups, migrants, older adults, and low-skilled workers, are prioritised in EU funding and policy frameworks. 2. Democratic Citizenship and Civic Education EU Commissioner for Democracy, Justice, the Rule of Law, and Consumer Protection, Michael McGrath, has played a pivotal role in advancing initiatives like the Democracy Shield. The rise of populism and democratic backsliding across Europe highlights the urgent need for education that nurtures democratic values. Ireland should position its EU Presidency to champion the Charter on Education for Democratic Citizenship and Human Rights Education (Council of Europe, 2010) as a guiding framework for adult learning on this theme. While not legally binding, its principles offer a powerful foundation for shaping Council conclusions or resolutions during Ireland’s term. Aim: Secure Council endorsement for integrating democratic and civic education into adult learning strategies. This could include a declaration linking lifelong learning to the European Democracy Shield initiative, reinforcing education’s role in combating disinformation and promoting active citizenship. 3. Social Inclusion and Cohesion Ireland’s Presidency should frame adult learning within the broader EU agenda on social fairness and resilience. Legislative proposals under the European Pillar of Social Rights, particularly Principle 1 on lifelong learning, should be highlighted. Ireland can leverage its unique position as a high-growth economy to advocate for inclusive education policies that address structural barriers faced by disadvantaged groups. Aim: Push for measurable targets on participation by marginalised populations in EU Council conclusions, ensuring that the 60% adult learning participation goal by 2030 is met equitably across member states. 4. Skills for Green and Digital Transitions Action 6 of the European Skills Agenda and the Digital Action Plan provide a key basis for action in the forthcoming Presidency. The Union of Skills initiative and the Action Plan on Basic Skills provide legislative pathways for Ireland to advance a skills agenda that balances competitiveness with inclusion. Ireland should ensure that these proposals incorporate non-formal and community education models, reflecting a vision of education for social transformation. Aim: Advocate for flexible, learner-centred approaches, and recognition of non-formal learning, within EU policy frameworks.

sector: AONTAS are the National Adult Learning Organisation of Ireland, founded in 1969 and passionately working ever since to make education equal and accessible for all. Backed by our robust research and focussed community work, we advocate and lobby for quality education for all adults, and raise awareness of the impact of adult learning on people’s lives and on society. We work on behalf our members, who connect with all communities across the island of Ireland. Our members and adult learners inform all our research and campaigns for social change.
geography: Our submission covers recommendations for EU policy to advance this agenda, while advocating for activities at a national level to raise the profile of Ireland as a leader in education and a champion of EU’s social values.
response_text: 1. Convene an Informal Council Meeting on Adult Learning and Skills Action: As Ireland’s national coordinator for the New European Agenda for Adult Learning (NEAAL), AONTAS, working in collaboration with DFHERIS and the Department of Foreign Affairs, has an opportunity to take on a leadership role. Under NEAAL, action is urgently needed to increase participation in adult learning in all its forms (formal, non-formal, and informal) whether to acquire new work skills, foster active citizenship, or support personal development and fulfilment. Convening a dedicated informal meeting under the Irish Presidency could bring together representatives from the Employment, Social Policy, Health and Consumer Affairs Council (EPSCO), the Education, Youth, Culture and Sport Council (EYCS), the wider network of National NEAAL coordinators, and other key sectoral stakeholders to share information and identify areas for collaboration. Such an initiative would build on the priorities of previous EU Presidencies, reinforce Ireland’s commitment to collaboration in adult education and skills development, and position lifelong learning as a central pillar of Europe’s social and economic resilience. Purpose: Showcase Ireland’s leadership in promoting inclusive education and align discussions with the New European Agenda for Adult Learning (NEAAL) and European Skills Agenda. Outcome: Secure Council conclusions committing to increased investment in adult learning and recognition of non-formal learning pathways. 2. Launch a Presidency Declaration on Education for Democracy Action: Issue a joint declaration linking adult education to democratic resilience, referencing the Charter on Education for Democratic Citizenship and Human Rights Education and the European Democracy Shield initiative. Leverage Commissioner McGrath’s leadership and work in this area. Purpose: Position education as a tool to combat disinformation and strengthen civic engagement across member states. Outcome: Establish a framework for integrating democratic and civic education into EU lifelong learning strategies. 3. Advocate for an EU Action Plan on Inclusive Upskilling Action: Propose an EU-wide action plan under the European Pillar of Social Rights to close participation gaps for marginalised groups (migrants, older adults, low-skilled workers). This initiative would mainstream the learning from the EU project; PartnerUp: Upskilling Pathways into EU policy. Literacy learning can be a key feature of this action. Purpose: Ensure that the 60% adult learning participation target by 2030 is met equitably, with measurable indicators for marginalised populations. Outcome: Embed social inclusion as a core principle in EU skills and education legislation, reinforcing Ireland’s commitment to cohesion and fairness.

sector: AONTAS are the National Adult Learning Organisation of Ireland, founded in 1969 and passionately working ever since to make education equal and accessible for all. Backed by our robust research and focussed community work, we advocate and lobby for quality education for all adults, and raise awareness of the impact of adult learning on people’s lives and on society. We work on behalf our members, who connect with all communities across the island of Ireland. Our members and adult learners inform all our research and campaigns for social change.
geography: Our submission covers recommendations for EU policy to advance this agenda, while advocating for activities at a national level to raise the profile of Ireland as a leader in education and a champion of EU’s social values.
response_text: The Programme for Government (2025) points out the need to “bring some of the high-level meetings of our Presidency to cities and counties across Ireland, ensuring the entire country benefits from the profile the Presidency brings.” Ireland’s 2026 Presidency is a unique opportunity to strengthen public understanding of EU membership and foster a sense of shared responsibility. The approach should combine clear messaging, inclusive engagement, and visible impact. However, the Presidency is not just a government event, it’s a national moment to reaffirm Ireland’s role in shaping a democratic, inclusive, and competitive Europe. By framing the Presidency as a shared project, Ireland can turn EU policy into a story of citizen empowerment. Understanding the benefits of EU membership and the value of the Irish Presidency in 2026, is a matter of adult learning- AONTAS stands ready to support the DFA in this task. 1. Outreach and Engagement Collaborate with organisations like AONTAS, and other sectoral stakeholders to co-host events and amplify messaging. Engage NGOs, and community leaders as ambassadors for EU values. Link Erasmus+ Key Action 1 activities which focuses on Learning Mobility of Individuals to the promotion of knowledge sharing as part of presidency activities. 3. Use Education and Civic Engagement as Anchors Link to Democratic Education: Tie messaging to initiatives like the European Democracy Shield and the Charter on Education for Democratic Citizenship, emphasising education’s role in combating disinformation and strengthening democracy. Link to Education for Sustainable Development: Link in with projects such as Saolta, a global citizenship education strategic partnership programme for the adult and community education sector in Ireland. This will promote the role of adult education in supporting awareness and generating solutions to the challenges of a just transition. Community Learning: Develop Presidency-themed learning resources for adult education centres, reinforcing EU values and Ireland’s leadership role. This should be linked to projects that use European funding to drive inclusion and innovation. Regional Inclusion: Organise Presidency-linked events across Ireland, not just Dublin, to ensure nationwide visibility 4. Leverage Digital and Media Campaigns Storytelling Campaigns: Share real stories of Irish citizens benefiting from EU education programs (e.g., Erasmus+, AONTAS Learners as Leaders programme). Engage AONTAS Learners as Leaders participants as campaign ambassadors: Develop their capacity through learning opportunities. Social Media Engagement: Use hashtags like #IrelandInEurope and #EU2026Presidency to encourage dialogue and visibility. Emphasise EU Principles: Highlight democracy, human rights, social fairness, and solidarity as core EU values. Link these to tangible benefits, peace, mobility, economic stability, and rights protections. Use relatable examples such as Erasmus+, inclusion, and digital rights to show how EU decisions affect citizens positively. 6. Demonstrate Impact Partner with organisations like AONTAS, Leargas, Saolta and others to communicate clear outcomes from Presidency initiatives, such as progress on adult learning, skills for green/digital transitions, and democratic participation. Publish progress and success stories to show how Ireland’s leadership benefits citizens and strengthens the EU.

sector: AONTAS are the National Adult Learning Organisation of Ireland, founded in 1969 and passionately working ever since to make education equal and accessible for all. Backed by our robust research and focussed community work, we advocate and lobby for quality education for all adults, and raise awareness of the impact of adult learning on people’s lives and on society. We work on behalf our members, who connect with all communities across the island of Ireland. Our members and adult learners inform all our research and campaigns for social change.
geography: Our submission covers recommendations for EU policy to advance this agenda, while advocating for activities at a national level to raise the profile of Ireland as a leader in education and a champion of EU’s social values.
response_text: AONTAS is the national coordinator for the New European Agenda for Adult Learning (NEAAL) 2021-2030. The main objective of the next programme cycle in 2026, Futures in Focus: Strengthening Adult Learning for a Changing World is to place adult learning at the centre of a future European Society that is inclusive, just, and democratic. This can only be achieved by cross-sectoral collaboration between policy and practice. AONTAS’ role as National Coordinator of the NEAAL programme positions us a key resource to promote this programme during the EU presidency. Across Europe, Ireland is seen as a leader in education- the Presidency offers us the opportunity to focus attention on the power of adult learning to create positive social change and tackle our most pressing challenges. By focusing on adult learning, democratic citizenship, social inclusion, and skills for future transitions, Ireland can use its Presidency to position education as a cornerstone of a democratic, cohesive, and competitive Europe. Currently, participation in lifelong learning across Europe falls significantly short of the 60% target, and remains deeply stratified along socio-economic lines (OECD, 2025). This gap threatens not only individual opportunity but also the collective resilience and competitiveness of the European Union. We strongly urge the Department of Foreign Affairs to actively engage with the Department of Further and Higher Education, Research, Innovation and Science to champion Ireland’s leadership in upholding the core values of the European Union while promoting adult learning. Strategic collaboration with the adult education sector is essential to: Promote best practice across Europe Drive innovation in lifelong learning Respond effectively to shared policy priorities Integrating the recommendations in this document directly contributes to the EU’s strategic pillars: A free and democratic Europe strengthening democratic resilience and debate protecting free and pluralistic media and civil society upholding the UN Charter and promoting global peace, justice and stability A strong and secure Europe strengthening resilience, preparedness, crisis prevention and response capacities to protect citizens and societies against different crises, such as natural disasters and health emergencies A prosperous and competitive Europe the green and digital transitions, including a genuine energy union and investment in game-changing digital technologies in Europe through in skills, training and education.
