We have developed a thorough consultation response, which is attached along with the form. The U.S. Chamber of Commerce welcomes the opportunity to provide input on Ireland’s upcoming Presidency of the Council of the EU in 2026, emphasizing Ireland’s role as a bridge-builder between Europe and the U.S. The Chamber recommends three overarching priorities: competitiveness and regulatory simplification, digital transformation and innovation, and strengthening transatlantic partnership and economic security. It outlines specific legislative and policy areas for focus, including trade facilitation, AI Act implementation, energy security, sustainability measures, life sciences regulation, and defense cooperation. The submission stresses evidence-based policymaking, stakeholder engagement, and transparent communication to ensure that Ireland’s Presidency delivers tangible benefits for businesses, citizens, and communities across the EU while reinforcing trust in EU governance.

Ireland’s Presidency of the Council of the EU in the second half of 2026 will come at a pivotal moment, in which the EU is transitioning from an ambitious regulatory cycle toward one focused on implementation, simplification, and competitiveness. DPE welcomes the opportunity to share our views on key focus areas for the Irish Presidency, and stands ready to actively support its priorities throughout the mandate. Simplification of the European Digital Rulebook Ireland is uniquely positioned to focus on enhancing Europe’s competitiveness by improving the coherence and implementation of the EU’s digital rulebook. The Digital Omnibus and upcoming Digital Fitness Check are valuable opportunities to streamline requirements, enable consistent enforcement, and reduce complexity for businesses and authorities alike. In recent years, the EU has developed a comprehensive set of frameworks governing digital platforms, including those facilitating local commerce, through landmark legislation such as the AI Act, the Platform Work Directive (PWD) and the GDPR. These rules form a strong foundation, yet their rapid accumulation has also created complexity and occasional overlaps. We welcome the focus on simplification as it enhances regulatory clarity, boosts certainty for businesses, and enables the sustainable growth of local economies across Europe. DPE strongly supports prioritising digital regulatory coherence through the upcoming Digital Omnibus and the wider Digital Fitness Check, to reduce fragmentation across the existing rulebook, promote consistent enforcement among Member States, and deliver a more competitive EU digital framework. Promote a targeted and evidence-based approach in upcoming flagship files Ireland’s Presidency will coincide with the negotiation of several major files shaping the environment in which local commerce platforms operate, including the EU Delivery Act (Q3 2026), the Digital Fairness Act (Q4 2026), and the recently published Digital Omnibus. We invite the Irish presidency to approach these and other key files in a targeted, evidence-based manner to support digital growth, investment and entrepreneurship. Sound impact assessments and evaluation of practical implications help ensure that new rules address genuine gaps without duplicating obligations already covered under the current EU framework. Furthermore, constructive and structured dialogue with industry experts should complement the process by grounding policy choices in real-world experience and operational realities. DPE stands ready to provide insights that support balanced, future-proof outcomes for businesses, consumers and local economies across Europe. Enable local commerce to thrive across the EU Ireland can position itself as a strong advocate for Europe’s local economies by prioritising policies that empower SMEs to thrive in an increasingly digital marketplace. Last-mile delivery and local commerce platforms are considered essential by a large share of European SMEs. Platforms like DPE members allow small businesses to reach new customers, access digital storefronts without costly expansion, and stay competitive in a rapidly changing retail environment. By fostering proportionate, innovation-friendly rules and reducing unnecessary administrative burden, the Irish Presidency can strengthen Europe’s local commerce ecosystem. Ensuring regulatory coherence across borders and recognising the role of digital platforms in providing flexible earning opportunities and supporting proximity-based commerce will be key to building resilient, vibrant local economies across the EU.

The Irish Presidency can play a key role in advancing major pieces of legislation which will greatly impact the competitiveness and productivity of the EU Single Market. From DPE’s perspective the Irish Presidency should focus on: 1. Digital Omnibus and Digital Fitness Check The Irish Presidency will play a decisive role in preparing and developing the Council's negotiating mandate for the Digital Omnibus proposal, presenting a unique opportunity to spearhead the simplification and streamlining of key parts of the digital acquis. In parallel, the Digital Fitness Check will require thorough assessment of remaining gaps and inconsistencies across the broader digital framework. Ensuring that these two processes reinforce one another, rather than introduce additional uncertainty, will be essential to futureproof the overall framework. Thus, DPE invites the Presidency to: Strengthen the harmonisation of the EU data acquis by addressing remaining inconsistencies between recent data sharing and privacy legislation and the GDPR, which currently create bottlenecks and undermine legal clarity for companies and users. Uphold the horizontal nature of the GDPR when implementing sectoral laws such as the AI Act or Platform Work Directive, ensuring that core definitions and safeguards remain aligned to avoid duplicative obligations and enable streamlined, effective compliance. 2. Delivery Act The EU Delivery Act will be presented by the Commission in Q3 2026. DPE is of the view that the Act should focus on the needs of postal operators and avoid extending its scope to fundamentally different business models, such as local commerce platforms, that operate hyper-locally, do not use postal networks, and already comply with extensive EU consumer protection and digital regulations that provide comprehensive user protections. Broadening the scope would risk regulatory duplication and undermine the Commission’s stated aim of simplifying postal and parcel rules as well as the Commission’s broader ambition to reduce regulatory complexity across the Single Market. DPE maintains that broadening the current postal framework to all types of delivery models, regardless of their nature, would result in overlaps and conflicting obligations, ultimately reducing clarity for all stakeholders. This would be detrimental for consumers and businesses alike, weakening safeguards and slowing down innovation. 3. Digital Fairness Act Another major legislative initiative to be presented during the Irish Presidency will be the Digital Fairness Act (DFA). This proposal is likely to introduce new rules and obligations in an already dense and overlapping regulatory framework. Given the extensive consumer protection safeguards already embedded in the EU’s digital acquis, the Irish Presidency has an opportunity to advance the EU’s simplification agenda by ensuring that the DFA builds on existing legislation and streamlines obligations rather than creating new layers of complexity. Strengthening enforcement by competent authorities, through consistent interpretation, coordinated oversight, and clear guidance, will be essential to achieving their effective application across the Union.

The Irish Presidency can make a substantial positive impact across the EU by championing an agenda focused on simplification, competitiveness and evidence-based policymaking. As several key legislative files advance, Ireland has a unique opportunity to reduce regulatory complexity, streamline overlapping frameworks and ensure that new obligations are proportionate and grounded in real-world needs. By prioritising these principles, the Presidency can support the economic growth of local commerce platforms, key drivers of proximity-based commerce, as well as digitalisation of SMEs. DPE members help local economies thrive by connecting consumers with neighbourhood shops, fostering a dynamic ecosystem that drives local growth and fuels innovation, job creation, as well as broader economic prosperity. Ensuring a clear, coherent and future-proof regulatory environment will benefit businesses, consumers and communities across the whole EU. By reducing red tape, promoting cross-border regulatory coherence and safeguarding space for digital entrepreneurship, Ireland can position itself as a champion of Europe’s local economies. A Presidency focused on enabling local commerce platforms to grow responsibly will contribute directly to strengthening competitiveness, empowering SMEs and delivering tangible advantages for citizens in their daily lives.

Looking ahead to the Quality Jobs Act expected in Q4 2026, DPE welcomes the Commission’s recognition that self-employed work is vital for inclusive economic growth, enabling flexibility and access to specialised expertise. In local commerce and last-mile delivery, DPE members have long offered flexible work opportunities that match people’s needs and availability, and we hope the Irish Presidency similarly sees that these are essential pillars of a modern, resilient labour market. At the same time, experience with the Platform Work Directive, AI Act and GDPR shows that well-intended legislation can unintentionally burden core aspects of the highly flexible work arrangements it aims to protect, and we therefore encourage careful consideration of practical impacts as the Act develops. In this context, we are rather concerned about the risk of additional AI or algorithmic management obligations being layered on top of the aforementioned policies, especially while Member States are still busy transposing and implementing obligations on a national level, and further clarifications from the Commission are needed. We urge the Commission and Presidency to prioritise consistent national implementation, legal certainty and the avoidance of regulatory duplication that could undermine sustainable, flexible job models across Europe.

organisation: International Federation of Library Associations and Institutions
response_text: Support Europe’s competitiveness through taking a coherent, targeted and ambitious approach to supporting research. Realise the potential of Europe’s (public) libraries as drivers of success across a range of policy areas, based on the results of the OMC process taking place as part of the Culture Work Programme.

organisation: International Federation of Library Associations and Institutions
response_text: European Research Area Act – this should be published during the Presidency, but will also need to be coordinated with the European Innovation Act, Digital Package and more. The Presidency should drive forwards Council Conclusions that underline the need for policy coherence, and in particular explore how to advance towards universal uptake of Open Science and Open Access. Digital Fairness Act, and in particular how to ensure that the consumer-type protections available for individuals and companies are also available to libraries and research institutions. The Presidency could usefully build on work being carried out around research and copyright in order to explore how universities, research centres and libraries can best be enabled to fulfil their missions Culture – building on the proposals in the Culture Compass as well as the Council Work Programme on Culture, launch wider discussions that bridge different policy areas, exploring how culture and libraries contribute to policy effectiveness.

organisation: International Federation of Library Associations and Institutions
response_text: The Council has a key role to play both in setting the agenda more broadly, and in steering legislation that is already on course. Ireland’s leading role in Open Science, notably as a leader when it comes to open science monitoring, as well as its exemplary public library network are strengths that should be celebrated. In particular, we therefore believe that the Irish Presidency can help: Ensure that the ERA Act achieves its goal of supporting the fifth freedom and the ‘Choose Europe’ agenda by taking an ambitious but targeted approach. Issues such as copyright should not be left out of the Act because of inter-service issues, but rather addressed from the perspective of what will best serve Europe’s research performance. Correct the anomaly that currently exists in EU law that offers protections both to individual consumers and businesses when seeking to access data and knowledge, but not the libraries and research institutions on which researchers, learners, educators and readers depend. Build on the successful OMC process on libraries under the Culture Work Programme in order to engage policy leads in other areas in reflection on how best to mobilise public libraries.

organisation: International Federation of Library Associations and Institutions
response_text: Crucially, people need to be able to see the benefits of the EU’s action for them. The priorities proposed in this submission aim to do just this, through: Enabling students, researchers and staff at universities and beyond to face lower administrative burdens and make a reality of a European Research Area. Such reforms will help demonstrate the benefits of EU membership in the academic and research community. Ensure that library users – from public library users in towns and villages to researchers in major institutions – are no longer faced with the non-availability of books or sub-optimal access because of a failure to regulate digital content markets for libraries. This should trigger better services, as well as better use of public sector resources, and be easily communicable at local level. Promote a public event celebrating the results of the OMC process on libraries under the Culture Work Programme. With sufficient media attention, this has the potential to show citizens that the EU is supporting the work of intensely local institutions – something that is a reality for them.

For its 2026 EU Presidency, Ireland should prioritise sustainable energy, rural resilience, and community-centred governance. In particular, the rapid scaling of biomethane under REPowerEU highlights the urgent need for independent impact assessments, strict environmental safeguards, and oversight of public subsidies to prevent unsustainable industrial-scale biogas projects. Ireland can lead by embedding legally binding rules on feedstock use, digestate management, and spatial planning, ensuring local communities have a real voice in decision-making rather than bearing disproportionate social and environmental costs. By championing a model that balances climate, biodiversity, and rural development goals, Ireland can set a European benchmark for fair, sustainable energy transitions. Prioritising transparency, equitable benefit-sharing, and preventative regulation will help avoid repeating mistakes seen elsewhere in Europe, reinforcing trust in decarbonisation policies. These thematic priorities will position Ireland as a leader in creating energy strategies that are both ambitious and socially responsible.

The European Commission’s REPowerEU action plan has set biomethane production on a course of massive upscale as part of efforts to increase EU energy independence, fixing a target of 35 billion cubic meters (bcm) per year by 2030 – up from 4,1 bcm in 2023. However, until this day, no Impact Assessment was carried out on the target. As biomethane production continues to grow rapidly both in Ireland and Europe (with a currently 21% year-over-year growth), so do concerns about its associated environmental and social risks as well as the irresponsible use of taxpayers money. While biogas production from sludge or collecting the gas that is produced in landfills is appropriate, there are particular concerns about the effects of large-scale biogas production on the use of limited agricultural land, the continuation of polluting industrial animal production, harm to local communities, and the effects of methane leaking from biogas facilities. Further concerns arise when looking closer at promoted use cases for biomethane such as heating or transport which are often inefficient, expensive, and lock Europe into existing fossil infrastructure. The Irish Presidency should therefore prioritize conducting an independent, interdisciplinary impact assessment to evaluate the feasibility and sustainability of this target, ensuring it aligns with climate, biodiversity, and rural community goals. Emphasis must be placed on implementing strict economic, environmental, and social safeguards for biogas and biomethane production. With reference to the Commission’s 2026 Work Programme as well as the wider EU Strategic Agenda that highlights the need to secure Europe’s energy independence, we therefore encourage the Irish Presidency to: Advocate for an independent impact assessment of the EU’s 35 bcm biomethane target, as a prerequisite to develop further any expansion of biomethane production as part of relevant policy files in 2026, such as the Circular Economy Act, Bioeconomy Strategy, Livestock Strategy, Energy Union Governance Upgrade, and Common Agricultural Policy. This includes prioritizing truly sustainable feedstocks, efficient use cases, and avoiding lock-ins of fossil infrastructure. Include the voices of local communities in the debate. In order to expand biomethane production rapidly, the 2025 REPowerEU roadmap foresees a “tripartite contract to better address the diverging needs in different areas of the EU and include national and local stakeholders”. However, a focus has been set on facilitating dialogue between the EU Commission, EU Member States’ governments as well as industrial stakeholders; and no commitment has been made to give a role to local communities themselves that are affected by such projects. In line with its “people-centred” approach, the Presidency should therefore intensify its efforts to give the Irish people and local communities across Europe a greater say in the development of fair and sustainable biomethane strategies. Scrutinise public subsidy schemes for unsustainable biomethane production. This is critical to prevent perverse incentives that undermine the EU’s climate, food security, and energy independence goals. Current subsidies often favour industrial-scale biogas projects reliant on unsustainable feedstocks - such as manure from factory farming or energy crops competing with food production - which lock in polluting practices as well as animal welfare violations, and divert resources from truly circular solutions. Without strict oversight, these subsidies risk distorting markets, inflating demand for unsustainable livestock farming, and sidelining local, community-led projects that deliver genuine environmental and social benefits.

Ireland’s presidency provides a unique opportunity to develop and promote a gold standard indigenous biogas industry that is sized and scaled to meet community needs. Learning from EU countries with an established biogas industry, Ireland can avoid the pitfalls of social acceptance that are consistently documented as barriers to bioenergy projects across the EU (Mancini & Raggi, 2022). Current regulatory gaps and weak planning assessments underestimate the cumulative impacts on rural infrastructure. Public health and safety questions about hazardous gas storage, particular emissions and emergency service access are heightened when regulatory oversight is perceived as reactive rather than preventative. Research has highlighted that digestate management and changes in feedstock mixes are critical risk vectors that demand much stronger regulation than is currently applied (Piadeh et. al, 2024). Ireland, through its presidency, can set the standard by developing industry-specific planning regulations that include community engagement at its core. The National Biomethane Strategy points directly to a highly industrialised model aimed at rapid development across rural Ireland. Within this model, revenue accrues to outside multi-national agri-investors while costs are borne by host communities in terms of road damage, odour, environmental degradation, and reduced property values. Communities demand transparent environmental impact assessments, accessible monitoring data and enforceable operating limits. The development of industry-specific planning regulations aligned with benefit-sharing mechanisms has the potential to provide a blueprint for use across the EU, while maintaining community engagement and the highest environmental standards. Meaningful community engagement, spatial planning that respects local carrying capacity, strict feedstock limits, alongside legally binding digestate management plans, are safeguards that would increase local acceptance. Rapid roll-out risks polarising rural communities, undermining trust in decarbonisation policy, and producing environmental and social harms that outweigh local benefits. Ireland has an opportunity through its EU presidency to either lead and develop new industry standards or to repeat mistakes already impacting the rural communities and the environment across Europe.

organisation: National Institute for Prevention and Cardiovascular Health (NIPC)
response_text: NIPC recommends that Ireland adopt a people-centred, prevention-first vision for its EU Presidency, grounded in equity, integrated care, and digital innovation. These thematics support the European Council’s Strategic Agenda for the Union 2024–2029, which calls for strengthening resilience, promoting healthier societies, and accelerating the digital and green transitions. Cardiovascular disease (CVD) prevention contributes to all three thematics by reducing chronic disease burden, supporting sustainable health systems, and leveraging digital innovation, including AI and health data infrastructure. The proposed focus areas also align with the European Commission Work Programme for 2026, which prioritises health security, digital transformation, implementation of existing legislative frameworks (including the European Health Data Space), and action on the growing burden of chronic diseases. Ireland’s Presidency can further advance priorities expected to be reflected in the Joint Declaration on Legislative Priorities for 2026, particularly improving access to healthcare, reducing inequalities, and strengthening the public health dimension of EU policy. CVD remains the leading cause of mortality across the EU, yet up to 80% of these deaths are preventable through population level strategies in combination with primary prevention, early detection of disease and secondary prevention and rehabilitation. Reversing metabolic risk factors in young adults through development of healthy choices and improved awareness will build resiliency. Ireland’s Presidency offers a timely opportunity to lead on Europe-wide prevention policy through the implementation of the forthcoming EU Cardiovascular Health Plan, reinforcing the EU’s Strategic Agenda 2024–2029. 1. “A Healthier Future for All” – Embedding Prevention Across the EU Policy Agenda Champion prevention as a cross-cutting EU priority. Drawing on Ireland’s experience with the Integrated Prevention and Management of Chronic Disease, the Enhanced Community Care programme, and established chronic disease pathways, Ireland is well positioned to support EU-level consensus on system-wide prevention measures. NIPC has a strong track record in the design, delivery, and evaluation of preventive cardiology programmes across both primary and secondary prevention, working in close partnership with the HSE and clinical services nationwide. Ireland, through NIPC, has also made a sustained contribution to EUwide prevention intelligence and benchmarking through participation in major ESC-led surveys, including EUROASPIRE and INTERASPIRE, providing robust real-world evidence on cardiovascular risk factor management, implementation gaps, and health inequalities across Europe. Key elements include: Life-course approaches to cardiovascular and metabolic health Strong EU action on tobacco, alcohol, nutrition, environmental exposures, and physical activity, with a focus on chronic disease management and CVD co-morbidities, including obesity and diabetes Strengthened health literacy and public engagement across Member States 2. “Equity and Access” – Reducing the EU’s Cardiovascular Health Inequalities Inequities based on socioeconomic status, gender, region, and immigration status continue to shape cardiovascular outcomes across Europe. Ireland should prioritise EU-level policies that: Embed equity in CVD prevention, screening, rehabilitation, early diagnosis and access to treatment Support gender-sensitive approaches to women’s cardiovascular health Strengthen access for vulnerable, rural, and multimorbid populations 3. “Data, Innovation, and Integrated Care” – Enabling Europe’s Transition to Modern Preventive Health Systems Ireland can lead by championing: Implementation of the European Health Data Space for real-time monitoring, benchmarking, and research Ethical integration of AI in prevention, early detection, and care delivery Digital–in-person hybrid models for cardiac rehabilitation and chronic disease management Strengthened multinational research networks These priorities reflect approaches showcased by Irish and international experts at national prevention conferences and are strongly aligned with the European Society of Cardiology’s advocacy agenda, with which NIPC maintains a close strategic partnership across prevention, research, education, and policy. Ireland also has a proven track record in preventive health leadership, including the world-leading 2004 smoking ban and the early establishment of chronic disease community hubs as a “third way” of delivering integrated care. Together with NIPC’s prevention delivery expertise and ESC collaboration, these achievements demonstrate Ireland’s readiness to lead the implementation phase of the EU Cardiovascular Health Plan, which aligns with NIPC’s ongoing collaboration with national stakeholders, the Department of Health, the Chief Medical Officer, the HSE, and Ministerial priorities, positioning Ireland as an exemplar in cardiovascular prevention.

organisation: National Institute for Prevention and Cardiovascular Health (NIPC)
response_text: The policy areas proposed below align with the European Council’s Strategic Agenda 2024–2029, the European Commission Work Programme 2026, and anticipated priorities in the forthcoming Joint Declaration on Legislative Priorities for 2026. The focus on early detection, digital transformation, chronic disease management, equity, and workforce capability corresponds closely to the EU’s strategic direction for the next legislative cycle. Ireland should use its Presidency to champion and operationalise the adoption of the EU Cardiovascular Health Plan at EU and national levels. NIPC recommends prioritising EU-wide progress in the following areas: 1. Establish EU Standards for Early Detection of CVD Ireland should lead negotiations on the development of: EU protocols for cardiovascular health checks Early detection pathways for high-risk individuals AI-enabled risk prediction tools integrated with clinical pathways A structured EU approach would significantly improve early detection and treatment and reduce preventable morbidity. 2. Advance Legislation Supporting Population-Level Prevention Ireland should work with EPSCO to strengthen or initiate EU policy action on: Tobacco control (including novel nicotine products) Alcohol minimum pricing alignment and cross-border restrictions Nutrition labelling reform and food-system measures Urban design and physical activity promotion These align with EU Green Deal priorities and Healthy Lifestyles initiatives. 3. Promote EU-wide Access to High-Quality Secondary Prevention & Cardiac Rehabilitation Ireland should seek Council conclusions or policy agreements that: Mandate equitable access to evidence-based CVD prevention and rehabilitation programmes Encourage menu-based, flexible models (including digital options) Support Member State capacity-building for multidisciplinary care 4. Support Implementation of the European Health Data Space (EHDS) for Cardiovascular Health Ireland should prioritise: Harmonised data standards for cardiovascular outcomes EU-wide CVD registries and benchmarking tools Real-world evidence frameworks Cross-border research infrastructure 5. Workforce & Training: Advancing Preventive Cardiology in Europe Ireland should highlight: The absence of accredited preventive cardiology training pathways Workforce shortages in prevention across Member States The need for an EU-level competency framework This will support long-term system resilience and implementation of the EU Plan. In parallel, NIPC emphasises that Ireland must advance its own national Cardiovascular Health Plan and Strategy to ensure alignment between domestic priorities and EU-Presidency ambitions.

organisation: National Institute for Prevention and Cardiovascular Health (NIPC)
response_text: Ireland’s Presidency will have the greatest EU-wide impact if it reinforces not only the adoption of the EU Cardiovascular Health Plan but its implementation across Member States. Ireland’s leadership will be strengthened through collaboration with national stakeholders with a vested interest in prevention, including the Department of Health, the HSE, the National Heart Programme, prevention sub-groups, NIPC, the Irish Cardiac Society, Croí, the Irish Heart Foundation, and patient communities. Together, these partners provide clinical, public health, implementation, and patient-centred expertise. A unified Irish position signals to the EU that Ireland can convene, coordinate, and accelerate Member State readiness for implementation. This multi-stakeholder model directly benefits EU citizens by driving: Faster detection of high-risk individuals Increased access to rehabilitation services Reduced health inequalities Lower system-level costs over time Stronger alignment between national and EU public health strategies Ireland’s demonstrated ability to deliver population-level health reforms (e.g., smoking ban, integrated care hubs, shift-left prevention policies) underscores its readiness to serve as a European exemplar in implementing the EU Cardiovascular Health Plan and a national Cardiovascular Health Strategy. By championing cardiovascular prevention through these collaborative, people-centred approaches, Ireland will advance goals identified in the EU Strategic Agenda 2024–2029 and strengthen implementation of initiatives foreseen within the Commission Work Programme 2026—ultimately maximising the impact of Ireland’s Presidency for citizens, communities, and health systems across the Union.

organisation: National Institute for Prevention and Cardiovascular Health (NIPC)
response_text: Ireland’s Presidency can engage citizens by focusing on a universal, relatable theme: the EU is working to keep people healthier for longer. Recommended communication strategies: “Health in Every Community” – Localised EU engagement Showcase how EU-level cardiovascular prevention benefits local communities: Early detection programmes Access to rehabilitation Cross-border research collaboration National and EU-wide storytelling anchored in real lives Share lived experiences from patients, clinicians, and communities—including those featured in national conferences and patient engagement platforms. Youth-focused campaigns on lifelong cardiovascular health Partner with schools, universities, and youth groups to improve CV health literacy and awareness. 4. Position Ireland as a bridge between citizens and EU institutions Use public dialogues, townhalls, and regional forums to strengthen understanding of the Presidency’s value. 5. Leverage digital platforms to make EU action visible and tangible Clear, accessible messaging on how EU initiatives address everyday concerns—cost of care, ageing, chronic disease, patient empowerment—will reinforce trust and participation. Such communications will reinforce the core messages expected in the Joint Declaration on Legislative Priorities 2026—namely the EU’s commitment to improving lives, reducing inequalities, and delivering tangible health benefits to citizens.

organisation: National Institute for Prevention and Cardiovascular Health (NIPC)
response_text: NIPC emphasises that Ireland’s 2026 Presidency presents a rare opportunity not only to help shape the EU Cardiovascular Health Plan but to lead its implementation across Europe. NIPC wishes to highlight the following additional points for consideration: Ireland is uniquely positioned to lead on cardiovascular prevention at EU level. Ireland’s experience in integrated community care, chronic disease programmes, national audits, and digital innovation provides a strong foundation for shaping the EU Cardiovascular Health Plan. The EU Cardiovascular Health Plan should reflect the principles outlined in NIPC’s evidence submission. These include: Life-course approach to prevention Structured CVD screening and early detection EU-wide standards for secondary prevention and rehabilitation Embedding equity as a core pillar Workforce development in preventive cardiology Leveraging research, data, the EHDS, and AI Robust evaluation and continuous audit frameworks Ireland’s 2026 Presidency can serve as a launchpad for EU-wide health transformation. A strategic focus on prevention will: Reduce the burden of chronic disease Strengthen health system sustainability Promote innovation and digital health adoption Improve outcomes across all socioeconomic groups Enhance Ireland’s international leadership profile Integrating learnings from national and international experts. Insights from the National Prevention & Integrated Diabetes Care Conference—including those on multimorbidity, digital rehabilitation, women’s health, AI, lipid and hypertension management, and upstream prevention—support a contemporary roadmap for EU action. To achieve this, a unified national voice is required. NIPC strongly recommends that Ireland’s Presidency response is explicitly aligned with: NIPC Croí Heart & Stroke Irish Cardiac Society (ICS) Irish Heart Foundation • These organisations previously collaborated on the NIPC/ICS/IHF position paper “Advancing a Prevention Agenda for Cardiovascular Care in Ireland,” which called for a coordinated National Cardiovascular Prevention Strategy. The absence of such a strategy remains the single biggest barrier to Ireland fully implementing—and credibly championing—the EU Cardiovascular Health Plan. This approach is consistent with the wider ambitions of the EU Strategic Agenda 2024–2029, supports effective implementation of legislative commitments in the 2026 Commission Work Programme, and anticipates the shared priorities to be endorsed in the Joint Declaration on Legislative Priorities for 2026. By aligning national efforts with these EU-wide strategic orientations, Ireland can help ensure that cardiovascular prevention becomes a central pillar of Europe’s health and social policy agenda. With a national Cardiovascular Health Plan and Strategy—adapted from the EACH CV Health Plan blueprint, and aligned with Department of Health and Ministerial priorities—Ireland can again lead Europe, just as it did with the 2004 smoking ban and, more recently, with its shift-left wellness agenda and investment in integrated care hubs and chronic disease structures. Ireland is well placed to serve as a European exemplar for modern prevention-led cardiovascular policy during its EU Presidency.

respondent_type: NGO – LDCN is the national representative body for Local Development Companies in Ireland
sector:
Local and Community Development. 
This included (inter alia): 
social inclusion and poverty reduction 
supporting social enterprises and local community groups 
supporting the development of enterprise and local economies, particularly in rural areas 
the provision of health and wellbeing supports 
just transition, particularly through grassroots climate and environmental actions.
geography: LDCs operate in all 26 counties of the Republic of Ireland, where their work extends into every town, village and community. Through the programmes that they deliver (including LEADER and PeacePlus), many LDCs also work in partnership with other community organisations in Northern Ireland and across Europe.
response_text: Ireland should make “Partnership” a high-level thematic priority of its Council Presidency. In an era in which multilateralism is becoming eroded and social cohesion is coming under increased pressure, Ireland is uniquely placed to position itself as “Experts in Partnership”, and to illustrate the “Power of Partnership” to achieve positive and lasting change. In particular, we encourage a focus on the role that Partnership plays in making local communities in Ireland and across Europe more vibrant, cohesive, and sustainable. In this context, Partnership involves collaboration across multiple levels (local, national, EU) and sectors (government, civil society, and the private sector), but in all cases should involve – and revolve around the needs of – people and communities. Ireland has an excellent track record in this area, exemplified by the work of the Local Development Companies, who are eager to support Government in using the upcoming presidency to showcase the important role that the EU plays as an enabler of local and community development. This role will be illustrated through the work of programmes like LEADER and SICAP, both of which are co-funded by Ireland and the EU and delivered at a local level by the LDCs. Please follow the following links for an overview of some of the projects and initiatives that these programmes support: LEADER / SICAP. Why the theme of “Partnership”? “Partnership” speaks directly to the international persona that Ireland has long worked to project – in the EU and at the UN, Ireland aims to be an “honest broker”, leveraging its long-standing neutrality and diplomatic record to promote peace, unity, and multilateralism. “Partnership” speaks to our cultural history – one in which the spirit of meitheal underpins a strong collective ethos within communities. The concept of meitheal continues to resonate as a rallying call for communities to stand together, as was proven during Covid-19 and following the Storm Eowyn response. “Partnership” speaks to the overarching need to bring the EU closer to its citizens and to its communities – and this presidency presents an opportunity to show how EU supports (e.g., LEADER and SICAP) are having a real and visible impact in people’s lives. “Partnership” and the EU Council’s Strategic Agenda The theme of “Partnership” can be used as a connecting thread to bind together a number of key strands of the EU Council’s Strategic Agenda. These are set out below. Across these pillars and themes, the theme of “Advancing Together” is the one that speaks most directly to the concept of Partnership, both in a general sense and in the more specific context of local and community development. Some of the central precepts of this theme are: That economic growth should benefit all citizens. That the green and digital transitions should be equitable and inclusive. That the EU and its members will invest in the skills, training and education of its citizens. That the EU and its members will commit to social dialogue, uphold equal opportunities, and reduce inequalities.

the provision of health and wellbeing supports 
just transition, particularly through grassroots climate and environmental actions.
geography: LDCs operate in all 26 counties of the Republic of Ireland, where their work extends into every town, village and community. Through the programmes that they deliver (including LEADER and PeacePlus), many LDCs also work in partnership with other community organisations in Northern Ireland and across Europe.
response_text: The EU Commission is set to launch its first EU Anti-Poverty Strategy shortly before or during Ireland’s Presidency of the Council. This Strategy will be accompanied by a Child Guarantee that will include investments and reforms aimed specifically at tackling child poverty. Ireland is well-positioned to play a leading role in these areas, given 1) that Ireland has always been regarded as a prominent international voice in the area of poverty reduction and 2) the Child Poverty and Well-being Programme Office, which is housed within the Department of the Taoiseach, was established to achieve the same basic objective as the Child Guarantee – the elimination of child poverty – and learnings from Ireland’s experience should be disseminated and embedded in the policies of our European peers. Ireland’s next Roadmap for Social Inclusion will be published in advance of our Presidency commencing; making poverty a central plank of our Presidency will generate important early momentum for that policy. Ireland’s presidency will coincide with a pivotal phase of negotiations for the next EU Multiannual Financial Framework, and it should use the platform afforded by the presidency to make the case for its policy and budgetary priorities. Rural Development – specifically the LEADER programme – should be a central focus of these advocacy efforts. Under the MFF Proposals set out by the European Commission last summer, no provisions are made for funding for LEADER/Community-led Local Development (CLLD) to be ringfenced, creating the possibility of much-diminished LEADER programmes across EU member states post-2027. LEADER is an established and effective tool for rural development, and any further diminution of LEADER would represent a significant blow to rural communities, and an effective abandonment of the EU Long-term Vision for Rural Areas, which was intended to serve as a framework for rural development in Europe through 2040. A key objective of Ireland’s Presidency – aligned to the Programme for Government commitment to “engage at EU level to increase funding for the next LEADER programme” – should therefore be to ensure that funding for LEADER/CLLD continues to be ringfenced within the MFF. Given that LEADER is both an enabler and an embodiment of the kind of community-led partnership which we hope will serve as an overarching theme of Ireland’s EU Presidency, we hope that Ireland will use its presidency to argue not only for the retention of LEADER programme, but for the mainstreaming of the LEADER methodology (characterized by bottom-up, community-led development) across other strands of EU policy, e.g., green transition, food security, demographic renewal.

response_text: Ireland’s Presidency should not be about bringing the values and aspirations of the EU to communities; it should instead be about supporting communities in their efforts to bring those values and aspirations to fruition in ways that are meaningful to them. It is through this approach that “Europe” shifts from something that people regard as cold, bureaucratic and remote to something that people can see, value, and feel part of. Ireland has the institutional infrastructure to do this – much of which has been touched upon already in this submission. Over the past 35 years or so, Ireland has developed an area-based development model, with LDCs to the fore, which is holistic, professional, and community-led. Although programmes like LEADER may be just as important in other European countries as they are in Ireland, Ireland is unusual in that the entities tasked with delivering LEADER (the LDCs) also deliver a broad range of complementary programmes, enabling them to take a much broader view of the needs and capabilities of the communities that they serve. These programmes are predicated on the trusted partnerships that LDCs have forged with a diverse array of government departments, statutory agencies, civil society organisations, and community groups. In this way, grassroots supports can be delivered across a range of thematic areas – including employment and training, enterprise and social enterprise, health and wellbeing, migrant integration, and climate and the environment – in a way that is cohesive and symbiotic. Ireland should use the platform of its presidency both to strengthen this model and to showcase it – as an exemplar of “Partnership in Practice” – to its EU peers.

response_text: must provide a summary of the additional information under the ‘Any other comments’ question. This summary should also be limited to a maximum of 500 words. In using the word “citizen” in this submission, we are mindful that not all of those currently residing in Ireland and Europe are European citizens. Indeed, it is important that Ireland’s vision for the presidency takes account of the needs and circumstances of those that are not citizens. Through the Cork Declaration (1996) and the Cork Declaration 2.0 (2016), Ireland has earned a unique place in the history of the EU’s rural development policy. Ireland’s presidency will fall ten years on from the second Cork Declaration, and – given the uncertainty that the MFF proposals have generated for LEADER and other rural development instruments – consideration could be given to re-affirming Europe’s commitment to its rural areas via a Cork Declaration 3.0. About LDCN Local Development Companies Network (LDCN) is the national representative body for Local Development Companies (LDCs) in Ireland. LDCs were first established by government in 1991. Since then, their geographical coverage has expanded to the entire 26 counties, and the range of services and supports that they deliver has grown and evolved alongside the needs of the communities that they serve. However, their collective mission has remained consistent: to build a more just, inclusive, and equitable society. They share a vision of an Ireland in which everyone – regardless of where they live, their economic situation, their disability status, or their gender, ethnicity, or age – can build a life of dignity, fulfilment, and connection. They pursue this mission across multiple strands of work, including social inclusion, education, training and employment supports, early years and family supports, urban and rural development, and just transition. Each year, their programmes and services directly benefit more than 150,000 people and over 6,000 community groups and social enterprises.

response_text: The enlisting of European citizens in a ground-level response to the challenge of climate change and biodiversity loss through the development of a necklace of ‘Climate Houses’- one in every member state.

sector: Promotion of Climate Action and Sustainability
geography: Just Transition Region- Midlands of Ireland
response_text: The ongoing challenge of climate change and biodiversity loss has become a divisive issue. Governments, agencies and companies have invested heavily to implement actions at a high level. However, citizens in Ireland and across Europe remain confused about the actions they should take and have been manipulated by misinformation and polarization in the public domain. A new opportunity now exists with the development of Climate Houses across Europe. These attractions combine, in different ways, immersion in nature and future sustainability showcases in a manner that catches the public mood. Climate Houses engage the public and those on the margins about the impact of the changes that are coming and about the personal agency they have for a life in harmony with nature. Climate Houses are doing this using fun, immersive experiences, practical activities and showcasing of solutions that takes judgement out of the debate while promoting systemic and collective responses. Numerous examples of this approach exist and a comprehensive proposal has been developed for a site in the Irish midlands modelling world-class engagement and behavior change methodologies.

sector: Promotion of Climate Action and Sustainability
geography: Just Transition Region- Midlands of Ireland
response_text: Ireland can trigger this movement by initiating the establishment of a network of Climate Houses (some already in existence and others under development) across Europe – and indeed across the world. This action would have a galvanizing effect on each country and recognize that citizens need to be brought on board as change makers and advocates. Citizen engagement is vital if the Union is to achieve tipping points in adoption of new approaches to renewable energy, transport, food, consumption, and the built environment.

The development of this network across Europe will promote lasting cohesion across the EU and form a legacy for Ireland’s 2026 European presidency.

As Ireland prepares for its 2026 Presidency of the Council of the European Union, it has an opportunity to advance priorities that strengthen public health, drive innovation and support resilient, sustainable healthcare systems across Europe. In light of the draft EU Cardiovascular Health (CVH) Plan, three interconnected themes stand out as strategically important: (1) Leadership on cardiovascular health and early detection, (2) Enabling innovation through modernised MedTech regulation, and (3) Advancing value-based, innovation-friendly procurement. 1. Leadership on Cardiovascular Health and Early Detection Cardiovascular disease (CVD) remains the leading cause of mortality in the EU, with significant inequalities in prevention, screening and access to care. The draft EU CVH Plan identifies prevention, early detection and improved care pathways as core EU-level priorities. Ireland’s Presidency can play a central role in accelerating these efforts by championing a high-level focus on early detection and screening, including for Structural Heart Disease, an area where underdiagnosis is widespread. A presidency priority centred on cardiovascular health would support: Implementation of the proposed EU Protocol on Health Checks, enabling harmonised, scalable approaches to blood pressure, lipid, diabetes and structural heart assessments. Support the establishment of an EU Network of Centers of Cardiovascular Excellence to improve patient access, enhance efficiency and capacity in care, and strengthen clinical and innovation excellence in Europe Develop EU Guidance for patient pathways to improve access to referral, treatment and monitoring for enhanced patient management and care. A focus on equity, ensuring screening and prevention reach underserved and ageing populations. Such a priority would align the Presidency with the EU’s targets for 2035, including reducing CVD mortality by 20% and ensuring 70–80% detection and control rates for major risk factors. 2. Enabling Innovation Through Modernised MedTech Regulation Europe’s ability to deliver on the CVH Plan depends heavily on an innovation-friendly regulatory ecosystem. The draft Plan acknowledges the essential role of medical technologies in prevention, early detection, minimally invasive treatment and rehabilitation. Ireland—home to one of Europe’s largest MedTech clusters—is well positioned to lead on: Ensuring revisions to the Medical Device and IVD Regulations to simplify procedures and accelerate access to high-value cardiovascular technologies are progressed as swiftly as possible. The adoption of the new breakthrough device pathway, particularly relevant for implantable and structural heart interventions; that will ensure predictability and certainty. This focus would improve patient access, reduce regulatory bottlenecks and reinforce EU competitiveness in life sciences. 3. Advancing Value-Based Health Procurement The CVH Plan explicitly highlights the need to align financial incentives with prevention, early detection and improved long-term outcomes. Ireland can help modernise procurement approaches by prioritising: Expansion of value-based procurement frameworks that reward outcomes and lifecycle value. More effective joint procurement models for high-impact technologies. Greater inclusion of SMEs and innovative suppliers. Such reforms would accelerate adoption of life-saving cardiovascular innovations and support sustainable healthcare spending across Member States.

Ireland’s 2026 Presidency presents a timely opportunity to advance policies that strengthen health system resilience, support innovation and improve patient outcomes across the EU. In line with the draft EU Cardiovascular Health (CVH) Plan, four policy areas should be prioritised: (1) EU-level leadership on cardiovascular health and early detection, (2) targeted modernisation of MedTech regulation, (3) reform of procurement frameworks toward outcomes and innovation and; (4) Support these policy areas with funding from the MFF. 1. Advancing EU Action on Cardiovascular Health and Early Detection The draft CVH Plan proposes major EU initiatives—including a Council Recommendation on health checks, a screening protocol, and digital and AI-enabled detection tools—to reduce CVD mortality and achieve ambitious 2035 detection and control targets. Ireland can accelerate political agreement on these elements. The Presidency should aim to: Secure Council Recommendation endorsing the EU Protocol on Health Checks and encouraging Member States to implement harmonised approaches to detecting hypertension, and Structural Heart Disease. Including setting framework for patient pathways guidance and the creation of cardiovascular centres of excellence Support scalable community-based detection models, including mobile screening units. Advance discussions on interoperable cardiovascular registries, supporting the CVH Plan’s digital and data flagship initiatives. Support EU4Health and Horizon Europe funding streams focused on early diagnosis. These steps would reduce inequalities across Member States and anchor cardiovascular disease firmly within the broader European Health Union framework. 2. Strengthening and Modernising MedTech Regulation The draft CVH Plan recognises the essential role of medical technologies in diagnosis, treatment and personalised care, and highlights forthcoming reforms to the Medical Device and IVD Regulations to simplify procedures and improve patient access. Ireland’s Presidency should prioritise: Secure a Council position on targeted revisions to the Medical Device Regulation (MDR), including clearer timelines, proportionate requirements and improved pathways for breakthrough cardiovascular devices. Advancing measures to expand and strengthen notified body capacity, ensuring more consistent and timely assessments. Facilitating implementation of the new Critical Medicines Act and forthcoming Biotech Act where relevant to cardiovascular health technologies. These actions would improve predictability for manufacturers, reduce bottlenecks and enhance Europe’s global competitiveness in life-saving innovation. 3. Public Procurement Reform to Support Value-Based and Innovative Care The CVH Plan emphasises the need for financial frameworks that reward long-term prevention, early detection and efficient care pathways. Current procurement models—often centred on lowest price—limit the uptake of high-value technologies. Ireland should therefore aim to: Consider a specific section for public procurement of healthcare goods and services in the upcoming revision of the directive, that address the need to timely deliver healthcare to EU citizens, with a dedicated process for breakthrough implantable devices. Enhance strategic procurement and early dialogue with MedTech Innovators together with relevant stakeholders to jointly define the need to procure and establish true partnership through co-creation of medical solutions. The recommendations of the EU4Health project PROCURE should be leveraged in this regard. Foster Value-Based procurement and Public Procurement of Innovation to reflect patient’s outcomes and healthcare efficiency gains, leveraging HTA bodies to assess holistic value of breakthrough implantable devices, and enhance capacity and resilience of healthcare systems. Simplify procurement procedures and flexibility to incorporate value breakthrough implantable devices into tender lifecycles to reflect innovations lifecycles, by linking adoption to RWD/RWE. These reforms would accelerate equitable access to early detection tools, digital health solutions and evidence-based treatments. 4. Support the policy initiatives with funding from the MFF The new MFF will commence in 2028 and the Irish Presidency supports an opportunity to place the building blocks for the new EU Budget. It is an opportunity to ensure funding for the initiatives to support the EU CVH can be put in place at an early stage and so that the plan can deliver on its ambitions.

The 2026 Irish Presidency can deliver meaningful and lasting benefits for people, businesses and communities by prioritising initiatives that strengthen public health, enhance innovation capacity and support more sustainable and resilient healthcare systems. Aligning with the draft EU Cardiovascular Health (CVH) Plan, three areas stand out as offering the greatest potential impact: improved cardiovascular prevention and early detection, a modernised and innovation-enabling regulatory ecosystem and procurement systems that reward better outcomes and long-term value. 1. Improving Health Outcomes Through Prevention and Early Detection Cardiovascular disease remains the leading cause of mortality in the EU, driving health inequalities and significant economic losses. The draft CVH Plan outlines an EU-wide shift towards prevention, screening and personalised care. The Irish Presidency can help turn this vision into measurable progress by advancing: The EU Protocol on Health Checks, promoting harmonised screening for hypertension, diabetes, lipid disorders, obesity and Structural Heart Disease—conditions that often go undetected until serious events occur. Support for mobile and community-based screening models, improving access for rural, ageing and underserved communities. Implementation of digital and AI-enabled tools for early detection and personalised risk prediction, as prioritised in the CVH Plan’s data and digital flagship initiatives. Delivering progress in these areas would reduce premature deaths, support healthier ageing and narrow outcome gaps across Member States—clear and visible benefits for communities. 2. Strengthening Innovation and Supporting Europe’s MedTech Ecosystem The MedTech sector is essential to Europe’s competitiveness, but current regulatory bottlenecks—especially in the Medical Device Regulation (MDR) framework—risk slowing innovation and patient access. The draft CVH Plan highlights the importance of simplifying regulatory processes, accelerating access to breakthrough devices and supporting digital tools. During its Presidency, Ireland can make a substantial contribution by progressing: Secure a Council position on targeted revisions to the Medical Device Regulation (MDR), including clearer timelines, proportionate requirements and improved pathways for breakthrough cardiovascular devices. Advancing measures to expand and strengthen notified body capacity, ensuring more consistent and timely assessments. Facilitating implementation of the new Critical Medicines Act and forthcoming Biotech Act where relevant to cardiovascular health technologies. These initiatives will strengthen Europe’s life sciences sector, protect high-quality jobs and enable faster introduction of technologies that improve patient outcomes. 3. Advancing Value-Based, Innovation-Friendly Procurement Procurement reform is a powerful lever to improve efficiency, accelerate adoption of innovation and promote long-term health system sustainability. The draft CVH Plan recognises the need to align financing mechanisms with prevention and improved care pathways. Ireland can help shape a more forward-looking approach by promoting: Value-based procurement frameworks that reward quality, outcomes and lifecycle value rather than lowest price. Strategic and joint procurement for high-impact cardiovascular technologies, reducing disparities across Member States. Greater participation of SMEs and innovative suppliers in EU tenders. These improvements would support innovation, make health systems more efficient and ensure patients receive the best available care.

Communicating the values and benefits of EU membership to citizens—and fostering a sense of ownership over Ireland’s Presidency of the Council of the EU—requires a proactive, inclusive and citizen-centred approach. The Presidency year provides a unique platform to demonstrate the EU’s practical impact on daily life, highlight Ireland’s leadership within Europe and strengthen citizens’ confidence in the EU as a force for stability, prosperity and shared progress. 1. Make EU Benefits Tangible and Locally Relevant Citizens engage most strongly when they see the EU’s value in concrete terms. Communication efforts should highlight clear, relatable examples of how EU membership improves quality of life in areas such as healthcare, consumer protection, workers’ rights, digital security, climate action and regional investment. Ireland should: Use case studies and real stories to show how EU policies have delivered benefits—from cheaper mobile roaming to improved healthcare access, reduced air pollution and investment in Irish towns, universities and public services. Highlight how the Irish Presidency’s priorities—such as improved health outcomes, innovation in MedTech and value-based public services—directly impact communities. Emphasise how EU membership amplifies Ireland’s influence globally and supports our economic resilience. By bringing EU achievements into local conversations, citizens can better see the relevance of EU action in their everyday lives. 2. Create Opportunities for Citizen Participation and Dialogue Ownership grows when citizens feel heard and included. The Irish Presidency should champion open, participatory engagement that encourages discussion, feedback and involvement from people of all backgrounds. Key actions include: Organising regional townhall events, school engagement initiatives and community dialogues to discuss EU priorities and gather citizen views. Partnering with universities, civil society organisations and youth groups to host debates, innovation challenges and policy workshops during the Presidency. Promote EU-funded training opportunities and illustrate how EU membership supports personal and professional development. Creating accessible online platforms where citizens can learn about Presidency activities, contribute ideas and follow policy discussions in real time. This participatory approach helps citizens recognise their role in shaping Ireland’s contribution to the EU’s future direction. 3. Communicate Through Trusted, Diverse Channels Effective communication requires reaching people through channels they trust. A mix of traditional and digital media, creative content and targeted outreach will be essential. Ireland should: Use social media strategically to share short, engaging content explaining EU decisions, their benefits and Ireland’s leadership role. Work with local radio, regional newspapers and community organisations to broaden reach and connect with citizens in rural and urban areas alike. Develop clear, jargon-free messaging to demystify EU processes and explain what the Presidency actually entails. Highlight the Irish Presidency as a national achievement, showcasing Irish expertise, diplomacy and influence. 4. Celebrate Ireland’s Place in the European Story Finally, the Presidency period should reinforce the idea that Ireland is an active, shaping member of the EU—not simply a beneficiary of it. Showcasing Irish leadership, cultural contributions and values within Europe strengthens pride and ownership.

sector: Pobal works on behalf of Government to support communities and local organisations toward achieving social inclusion and community development. We provide grant management and support services to 41 programmes in the areas of Social Inclusion and Employment, Early Years and Young People and Peace and Reconciliation, including 11 EU Co-Funded Programmes.
response_text: Ireland could frame its 2026 Presidency around the theme: “A More Inclusive Europe: Empowering People, Strengthening Communities” The Irish Presidency of the Council in 2026 can make a strong positive impact by ensuring that people at risk of marginalisation and social exclusion are prioritised and that social inclusion is embedded across all major EU policy areas. High Level Priorities 1.) Focus on Social Inclusion and Implementation of European Pillar of Social Rights Action Plan leading to a more inclusive Europe. A key opportunity is to advance implementation of the European Pillar of Social Rights (EPSR) , pushing Member States to reduce poverty and address important issues via the following mechanisms: Progress EU Anti-Poverty Strategy. Prioritise Child Poverty and Reinforce the EU Child Guarantee. Progress EU Affordable Housing Plan and Combatting homelessness. Support implementation of EU Disability Rights Strategy (2021-2030) and address the Disability Employment Gap. Support Rural & Regional Inclusion See further details on these priorities in response to Question 2. 2) Implementation of EU Green Deal and Ensuring a Just Transition Support the acceleration of climate action and advancing the just transition, circular economies, and sustainable production and supply chains.  Ensure a Just Transition through a comprehensive Just Transition Policy framework ‘To ensure that nobody is left behind by the Green Deal and ensure a just transition, there needs to be greater attention given to the impact climate change legislation will have on women, persons with disabilities, ethnic minority groups, elderly, children, people living in poverty and young people. The European Commission should promote a full impact assessment of green legislation on marginalised groups to mitigate the detrimental social impacts and see how they are connected to the European Pillar of Social Rights.’ Enhancing the Social Climate Fund Social Climate Fund - Employment, Social Affairs and Inclusion would help to make the green transition more inclusive by supporting vulnerable people and small businesses who are most affected by rising energy and transport costs, as Europe moves towards climate neutrality. Supporting the implementation of the European Council recommendation on the fair transition to climate neutrality EUR-Lex - 32022H0627(04) - EN - EUR-Lex would also support achieving the Just Transition objectives. It may be worth considering using the Environmental Protection Agency’s framework as a mechanism for assessing impact of the Just Transition. This would entail examining: a)Distributional justice (allocation of costs and benefits) b)Procedural justice (who participates in decision-making) c)Recognitional justice (respect for, engagement with and fair consideration of diverse cultures and perspectives) See Delivering justice in sustainability transitions | Publications | European Environment Agency (EEA)  Mainstream Climate across all EU spending and invest in Climate Capacity Building Consideration should be given to making climate conditionalities more ambitious in Cohesion Policy post-2027 to build on the progress of the Just Transition Mechanism 21-27 and investment in climate capacity building. From managing several climate and social inclusion programmes, Pobal believes that not all potential stakeholders are viewing their work through the climate lens or recognising new climate funding streams as potentially relevant for them. From our experience of grant administration, we see a real need for investment in climate capacity building at a local level. This could occur through knowledge exchange and exploration to ensure the full range of relevant partners are engaged. Specifically, we should not assume that all local actors see the relationship between social inclusion and climate justice, or that they can seamlessly integrate climate considerations into existing local economic development or social inclusion plans and initiatives. There would also be value in considering the following:  JUST TRANSITION: SUPPORTING PEOPLE AND REGIONS Expanding the Just Transition Fund scope post-2027 o Extending beyond coal regions to include carbon-intensive industrial areas, regions with high energy poverty and remote and rural areas vulnerable to energy shocks. Protecting workers and communities o Funding reskilling into renewable energy, digital services and circular economy industries. Affordable energy for households o Supporting energy-poor households through deep renovation grants, heat pump schemes and community power projects. A recent research report commissioned by Pobal indicates that households in the most disadvantaged areas are almost five times less likely to use renewable energy than those in more affluent communities. The findings reveal a need to address inequality gaps across Irish communities to support a fairer energy transition. See link Disadvantage Communities Almost Five Times Less Likely to Benefit from Renewable Energy at Home - Pobal A recent report from the European Commission Joint Research Centre indicates that European rural areas face higher levels of energy poverty, so energy poverty is clearly an issue which needs to be tackled across the EU JRC Publications Repository - Exploring rural energy poverty and needs 3.) Socially Responsible Public Procurement A conference focused on Buy Social and socially responsible public procurement (SRPP) would strongly reinforce Ireland’s social-inclusion priorities and help position Ireland as a leader in building a fair, sustainable and peoplecentred Single Market. As Public procurement accounts for around 14% of EU GDP, using it strategically can have major social impact. Please see further detail in response to Question 5.

sector: Pobal works on behalf of Government to support communities and local organisations toward achieving social inclusion and community development. We provide grant management and support services to 41 programmes in the areas of Social Inclusion and Employment, Early Years and Young People and Peace and Reconciliation, including 11 EU Co-Funded Programmes.
response_text: By 2026, many EPSR targets—employment, skills and poverty reduction—will still need strong political momentum. Ireland could aim to: Advance Council conclusions that reinforce Member States’ commitment to reducing poverty and child deprivation and support the development of the forthcoming EU Anti-Poverty Strategy to address the root causes of poverty. According to the Social Platform which is the leading network of EU civil society organisations working for a more social Europe 93.3 million people / 21% of the population in the EU were at risk of poverty and social exclusion in 2024 and for children this figure was 24%. It is therefore extremely important that efforts on the poverty reduction target are accelerated. Support Commission initiatives to tackle cost of living increases. Promote investment in social services, housing, and quality jobs. EU Affordable Housing Plan & EU Platform on Combatting Homelessness Ireland could play an important role in supporting greater EU investment in social and affordable housing and also: Enhance supports for the EU Platform on Combatting Homelessness. Push for an EU-wide target to reduce homelessness by 2030. Strengthen access to EU investment mechanisms for social housing such as using ERDF + EIB loans to address the housing crisis. Full Implementation of the EU Child Guarantee Ireland could aim to: Secure Council conclusions urging increased national funding for childcare, education, healthcare, nutrition, and housing supports. Create an inter-country dialogue on best practices in Early Childhood Education and Care, providing an opportunity to share Ireland's work on the Equal Start model. Encourage Member States to address intergenerational poverty and inequalities early.  EU Disability Rights & Accessibility Legislative actions: Implementation of the EU Disability Rights Strategy 2021–2030 Reviewing progress on the European Accessibility Act Ireland could aim to: Advance Council work on stronger accessibility standards (digital public services, transport, built environment). Promote equal labour-market participation for persons with disabilities. Push for EU funding streams to be more disability inclusive.  Labour Market Inclusion & Skills (Green & Digital Transitions) Relevant proposals: Updates to EU Skills Agenda – right to training and lifelong learning. Legislation linked to the Digital Decade targets to create a digitally empowered Europe. • Green transition employment supports Ireland could aim to: Prioritise inclusive upskilling programmes for low-skilled workers, migrants, persons with disabilities, and older workers. Promote Council progress on fair working conditions during automation and digitalisation. o Strengthen EU support for Just Transition regions to prevent regional economic exclusion.  Gender Equality & Work–Life Balance Relevant legislation: Pay Transparency Directive Possible updates to anti-violence or equality frameworks Ireland could aim to: o Drive forward consistent application of pay-transparency rules across Member States. o Encourage progress on EU measures addressing gender-based violence and workplace discrimination. o Promote expansion of family-leave and flexible-work measures.

sector: Pobal works on behalf of Government to support communities and local organisations toward achieving social inclusion and community development. We provide grant management and support services to 41 programmes in the areas of Social Inclusion and Employment, Early Years and Young People and Peace and Reconciliation, including 11 EU Co-Funded Programmes.
response_text: The Irish Presidency can deliver meaningful benefits for individuals, businesses, and communities by using its agenda-setting and negotiation role in the Council to drive practical progress on inclusion, equality, and full participation in society. Highlight the Importance of EU Funding The Presidency presents an opportunity to highlight the tangible positive outcomes that can result from the flow of EU funding to communities most in need, which is evident to Pobal through the EU Co-funded Programmes which we support, and to ensure that such EU funding is recognised as critical for enhancing social inclusion. The national Social Inclusion and Community Activation Programme (SICAP) co-funded by the Department of Rural and Community Development and the Gaeltacht (DRCDG) tackles poverty and social exclusion at a local level through local engagement and partnerships between disadvantaged individuals, community organisations and public sector agencies. SICAP is a targeted, holistic programme, for those who are most disadvantaged and less likely to access mainstream services, which provides supports directly to beneficiaries and links them into existing services. In 2024 alone the SICAP Programme supported over 3,000 Community Organisations throughout Ireland including 2,368 Local Community Groups and 473 Social Enterprises in addition to over 32,000 disadvantaged individuals. This EU Co-funded programme which has been running for many years has demonstrated enormous social impact. The Workability Programme co-funded by the Department of Social Protection (which supports people with disabilities to access the labour market) commenced in 2024 and over 13,000 people with a disability are expected to benefit from the programme over its lifetime and so far, 4,585 people have engaged with the programme. Since programme commencement, 1,091 participants have exited the WorkAbility Programme - accounting for 24% of all participants. For those who have exited: 380 (35%) participants found employment. 193 (18%) participants commenced training. Pobal has supported several iterations of the Peace Programmes since the inception of Peace 1 in the early 1990s and sees the enormous benefits that the projects have brought to Northern Ireland and the border counties, which would not have been possible without EU funds. Pobal is currently supporting actions in the PEACEPLUS Changemakes Programme in addition to partnering in the Victims and Survivors and YouthImpact Programmes. Some recent statistics from the Special EU Programmes Body (which demonstrate the value of PEACE funding) on outputs from the PEACE Programmes: 261,662 hours of guidance/counselling sessions 44,037 people attended 1,887 events assisting victims and survivors 25,429 people attended 2,184 conflict resolution workshops 42,540 participants in reconciliation projects 189,007 people attended 8,393 events that addressed sectarianism and racism or dealt with conflict resolution 121,868 children participated in cross-community contact through shared class activity 7-8,000 employment projects delivered 77,652 individuals entered or progressed into education or training Please see suggested priorities for the term as per Question 2 response and additional priorities outlined below: Strengthen Social Economy ecosystems in Europe Address societal challenges and support inclusive societies by strengthening social economy ecosystems and social enterprises in Europe. See recent report from the European Commission & OECD Social Economy in Europe | OECD . Promote Integration and Inclusion in Migration Policy Helping migrants to contribute socially and economically, would reduce exclusion, and lead to more cohesive communities, better labour-market outcomes, and improved social harmony. Overall Added Value of the Irish Presidency The most substantial impact of the Presidency will come from pushing forward existing EU commitments, ensuring that they translate into real improvements on the ground, and fostering consensus on policies that have a strong focus on social fairness. By championing the priorities outlined, the Irish Presidency could deliver substantial positive impact through: A more inclusive and competitive EU economy Linking social inclusion with economic growth ensures that businesses, workers and communities all benefit. Better access to essential services Improved housing, childcare, healthcare and social services strengthen social cohesion. Fairer opportunities for all Targeting vulnerable groups—children, persons with disabilities, migrants, and low-income households helps to build a more equitable society. Stronger communities and regional balance Focusing on rural and urban disparities helps to create a more unified Social Europe.

sector: Pobal works on behalf of Government to support communities and local organisations toward achieving social inclusion and community development. We provide grant management and support services to 41 programmes in the areas of Social Inclusion and Employment, Early Years and Young People and Peace and Reconciliation, including 11 EU Co-Funded Programmes.
