response_text: Effectively communicating the values and benefits of EU membership, and building a sense of ownership over Ireland’s Presidency, will require a transparent, accessible and participatory approach rooted in people’s everyday experiences. There would be value in helping citizens to understand not only what the EU does, but how Ireland shapes it and how it impacts their lives, communities and opportunities. Some suggested mechanisms: Make the EU Relevant to Daily Life Citizens engage more when they see concrete benefits. Ireland could emphasise how EU membership delivers in areas people care about by highlighting: The significant impact of EU funding on social inclusion and supporting the most marginalized by demonstrating the tangible positive outcomes that have resulted from the flow of EU funding to communities, as indicated in response to Question 3. Impact of EU funds including investments in infrastructure, regional development and rural areas. Workers’ rights, equality laws and social protections. Lower travel costs, consumer protections and roaming rules. Climate action, clean air, food safety and environmental protections. Student mobility, Erasmus+ and job opportunities across the EU. Communicate the Irish Presidency as a National Opportunity Instead of presenting the Presidency as a technical or diplomatic event, it could be framed as: A moment where Ireland leads and sets the agenda. An opportunity to shape Europe’s future on issues that matter to Irish people. A source of national pride, responsibility and influence. Clear, Accessible, Story-Driven Communication Short videos explaining “What the Presidency means for you”. Real stories of people and communities benefiting from EU projects. Visual explainers on how Council decisions work and Ireland’s role. Engage Young People Directly Young citizens are among the most pro-EU groups but may be less informed about its workings. Ireland could : Expand school and university outreach programmes. Use social media platforms popular with young audiences. Promote Erasmus+, EU careers, internships and youth exchanges. Support youth parliaments, model councils and debating events. Bring EU Discussions into Communities Host local events and conversations outside Dublin: Town-hall meetings, community forums, rural dialogues using community buildings and social enterprise services where possible. Exhibitions or EU information roadshows in regional centres. Collaboration with libraries, community groups schools and local media. Partner with Civil Society, NGOs and Business Networks These sectors can amplify messages and ensure inclusiveness. Partnerships could involve: Chambers of commerce (to highlight business benefits). NGOs working in social inclusion, youth, disability or environment. Universities and think-tanks for public seminars and citizen briefings. Use the Presidency to Highlight Irish Priorities If citizens see national priorities on the EU agenda—such as social inclusion, housing, digital skills, rural development—ownership will increase. Ireland could: Communicate clearly why these priorities matter. Show that Presidency work aligns with the challenges people face. Provide updates on progress in simple, relatable language. 8. Promote Transparency and Two-Way Communication Ireland could: Create public consultations on Presidency themes. Invite citizens to propose questions or topics for EU discussions. Maintain a transparent Presidency website with updates, timelines and results. Overall Strategy To create genuine public ownership of Ireland’s EU Presidency, it would help to ensure that communication is : People-focused — emphasising everyday benefits. Irish-led — highlighting Ireland’s influence and leadership role. Inclusive — reaching all regions, ages and communities. Participatory — involving citizens in shaping and discussing EU priorities. This approach would not only strengthen trust in the EU but would also reinforce Ireland’s position as an engaged, outward-looking member state with citizens who understand and value the role they play in Europe’s future.

sector: Pobal works on behalf of Government to support communities and local organisations toward achieving social inclusion and community development. We provide grant management and support services to 41 programmes in the areas of Social Inclusion and Employment, Early Years and Young People and Peace and Reconciliation, including 11 EU Co-Funded Programmes.
response_text: How a Buy Social / Socially Responsible Public Procurement Conference Could Support Ireland’s EU Presidency Priorities A conference focused on Buy Social and Socially Responsible Public Procurement (SRPP) would strongly reinforce Ireland’s social-inclusion priorities and help position Ireland as a leader in building a fair, sustainable and peoplecentred Single Market. According to the European Commission Public procurement accounts for around 14% of EU GDP, so using it strategically could have major social impact. Pobal has significant experience in this area and supported the DRCDG in overseeing the production of a report on Socially Responsible Public Procurement which reviewed best practice from 10 countries worldwide and entailed mapping, analysing and distilling SRRP policy successes, challenges, and trajectories within various local and regional contexts. See link 'Buy social' and Socially Responsible Public Procurement report . Pobal is very active in this space and is a member of a Social Procurement Working Group under the DRCDG’s Trading for Impact Strategy. Hosting such a conference during the Presidency would support Ireland’s agenda in several key ways: Advance Social Inclusion A conference would allow Ireland to highlight procurement as a practical tool to reduce poverty and strengthen labour standards across the EU. This would advance social inclusion goals by showing how public spending can create jobs for disadvantaged groups, support people with disabilities, integrate migrants, and improve access to work for long-term unemployed and young people. SRPP can promote fair working conditions, equality, skills development, and social inclusion which are central pillars of Ireland’s Presidency goals. It would also promote the European Pillar of Social Rights, demonstrating procurement as a practical tool to improve working conditions, equality, skills, and fair access to economic opportunities. Promoting the use of reserved contracts for social enterprises and inclusive employment models would strengthen the social economy and social enterprise sector, aligning with Ireland’s priorities for community development, inclusive labour markets, and local service delivery. Ireland could spotlight social enterprises as key partners in delivering community services, upskilling and local development. A conference could help build momentum for future EU initiatives on the social economy and implementation of the EU Social Economy Action Plan. Enhance Regional and Rural Development and Support the Green Transition Demonstrating how Socially Responsible Public Procurement can direct investment toward SMEs, rural communities, and underserved regions and promoting approaches that reduce regional inequalities and increase local economic participation would be beneficial. Highlighting procurement as a driver of low-carbon projects, circular economy solutions, and accessible digital services that leave no one behind would support green and digital transitions and would reinforce Ireland’s messaging that fairness and sustainability should go together. Build Member State Capacity and Increase Visibility of the Presidency Sharing best practices and practical tools that help contracting authorities integrate social value consistently across the EU would build Member State capacity and prepare the ground for future EU policy work, feeding into Council conclusions and potential updates to procurement guidance or legislation. A conference would allow Ireland to facilitate knowledge exchange, sharing best-practice and capacity-building for contracting authorities which would strengthen Ireland’s profile as a facilitator of practical, solutions-focused EU cooperation. A conference could also prepare the ground for stronger EU guidance or updated directives on socially responsible procurement and feed into Council conclusions Ireland may wish to steer which could strengthen political commitment among Member States to integrate social criteria consistently. A high-profile conference would demonstrate the Presidency’s focus on fairness, opportunity and community benefit as procurement affects jobs, local development, environmental standards and community services— tangible issues the public understands. It would help to communicate Ireland’s EU priorities in a clear, accessible way to citizens and stakeholders. Hosting such a conference would boost visibility and public engagement in Ireland’s Presidency by focusing on a tangible, easy-to-understand policy area that directly affects communities, businesses, and workers. Overall Added Value A conference on Buy Social and SRPP would support Ireland’s EU Presidency by: Promoting social inclusion through practical economic tools. Strengthening the social economy and local communities. Aligning procurement with green, digital and regional development priorities. Creating EU-wide momentum for fair and responsible public spending. Enhancing Ireland’s leadership and policy influence. In essence, it would turn one of the EU’s biggest spending instruments—public procurement into a powerful driver of social fairness, community benefit and sustainable development, directly reinforcing Ireland’s Presidency goals. Overall, such a conference would position Ireland as a leader in using public funds strategically to deliver fairness, inclusion, and sustainable community impact across the EU.

Europe should focus on equity in prevention and early detection, data that unlocks better care and research, and timely, equitable access to innovation. TBCT supports a people‑centred, performance‑driven approach in which screening participation, stage at diagnosis, time‑to‑treatment, quality of life and return‑to‑work are measured transparently. This aligns with Europe’s Beating Cancer Plan (EBCP). Close inequalities in prevention and early detection of breast cancer: EU data show large gaps in organised screening participation and outcomes. The EU screening scheme’s target of 90% of eligible citizens by 2025 has not been met, and the updated guidelines recommending screening for all women aged 45-74 remains under‑implemented in many Member States. Ireland’s own experience of declining screening number post‑COVID reinforces the need for action. The Presidency should drive implementation of prevention and early detection of breast cancer, focusing on equity and quality assurance and reaching underserved groups. Unlock health data for people and science: Deliver European Health Data Space (EHDS) implementation so patients and professionals have interoperable records and e-prescriptions across borders, while leveraging the secure secondary use of data for research and public health reasons. TBCT asks that the EHDS explicitly supports harmonised breast cancer registries that capture metastatic breast cancer and relapse, which would improve monitoring, close knowledge gaps, and help plan more equitable services. Secure access to innovation and reduce shortages: Time-to-access for oncology therapies remains long and uneven: EU average approx. 578 days from EMA approval to patient access; Ireland approx. 502 days, with lower shares of reimbursed new oncology medicines and biosimilars compared with EU peers. Under Ireland’s Presidency, the Council should conclude the Pharma Package to require supply obligations, enable earlier entry of generics and biosimilars, and strengthen environmental safeguards. At the same time, it should preserve incentives for innovation in unmet‑need areas and reduce patient time‑to‑access across the EU.

European Health Data Space (EHDS): The Presidency should focus on finalising the core implementing acts and technical specifications, and help each Member State establish and operationalise its national Digital Health Authority and Health Data Access Body so citizens and clinicians can use interoperable records across borders and researchers can access high‑quality data. From a breast‑cancer perspective, the Presidency should also champion harmonised breast‑cancer registries, to include data on metastatic breast cancer and relapse. Council Recommendation on Cancer Screening: Ireland should drive the implementation of the recommendations on cancer screening and ensure full adoption of the 45-74 breast‑screening age range with appropriate 2-3‑year intervals, complemented by models that raise uptake (e.g mobile breast units). Meanwhile, tailored approaches should address underserved groups and ensure quality assurance and public reporting aligned with European Commission Initiative on Breast Cancer (ECIBC) guidelines. Pharmaceutical Package: The Presidency should conclude trilogues (if still applicable) on a balanced text that improves access and resilience: make supply obligations enforceable to prevent shortages; enable earlier market entry of generics and biosimilars; and reinforce environmental safeguards. TBCT’s priority is to expand access to biomarker testing (IHC/FISH/NGS, liquid biopsy), workforce training and reimbursement, and to cut time‑to‑access for oncology therapies, so each patient receives the right treatment at the right time. European Beating Cancer Plan (EBCP): TBCT also urges accelerated delivery of EBCP and the Mission on Cancer by expanding the EU Network of Comprehensive Cancer Centres, promoting multidisciplinary staffing, adherence to standards and cross‑border collaboration.

For people, Earlier diagnosis saves lives and reduces treatment intensity. The Presidency should help Member States raise participation in organised screening by scaling approaches are tailored to specifically address local and national challenges and ensure equity of treatment and access across Europe. Patients and clinicians should benefit from the EHDS as soon as possible. Interoperable exchange of patient summaries, imaging, lab results and e‑prescriptions across borders cuts duplicate tests, speeds referrals, and supports continuity of care. The reform of the Pharma Package should translate into shorter time‑to‑access and fewer shortages. Concluding the Pharma Package with enforceable supply obligations, earlier market entry of generics/biosimilars, and clear environmental safeguards will help reduce the current EU average of approx. 578 days from EMA approval to patient access and raise availability and affordability of oncology medicines. For businesses and communities, EHDS standards and simpler performance reporting lower administrative burden and stimulate SME innovation (digital health, AI decision support), while wider availability of biosimilars and community‑based diagnostics reduces travel and cost burdens for families.

The Presidency should focus making EU added value tangible and people centred. The Presidency’s communications should show, in plain language and real stories, how EU health policy improves daily life for people living with breast cancer and their families. For instance, explaining the EHDS as something citizens can use: your records, imaging, lab results and e-prescriptions are accessible and portable when you travel or receive cross-border care (always highlighting the strong privacy and security safeguards). Clinicians benefit too, because data exchange reduces repeat tests and speeds referrals. Screening should also be showcased through practical solutions that raise uptake (e.g. mobile screening units), alongside patient-reported experience feedback that improves logistics and confidence. The aim should be for citizens to see where their country stands and where the gaps need to be closed.

Breast‑cancer policy must address long‑term support and survivorship. TBCT urges legislative measures recognising workplace rights and reintegration into the job market, including EU‑level adapted work environment guidelines for employers and prompt follow‑up to studies on job retention/return‑to‑work for cancer patients and survivors. TBCT also calls on the EU to protect the EU4Health budget and ensure funding lines for long‑term symptom management and survivorship services are sustained and expanded, consistent with EU4Health’s objectives to strengthen health systems, improve access and deliver EBCP.

The EU Presidency year in 2026, led by Cyprus in the first half and Ireland in the second, presents a strategically important moment for Ireland’s regions and business communities. From a Galway Chamber of Commerce perspective, the Presidency priorities closely align with issues of competitiveness, innovation, skills, infrastructure and regional resilience that are central to the future growth of Galway and the wider West of Ireland. A core EU-wide priority in 2026 shoud be competitiveness and economic resilience. For Galway Chamber, this translates into advocating for a stronger Single Market that supports indigenous SMEs, high-growth scaling companies and export-oriented firms. Reducing regulatory complexity, improving access to finance through deeper capital markets, and supporting innovation-led growth are critical for Galway’s diverse enterprise base, including medtech, life sciences, digital technology, creative industries and tourism. The Presidency agenda offers an opportunity to highlight the importance of regional ecosystems in driving European competitiveness. Skills, talent and workforce development will be another key theme. The EU’s focus on the green and digital transitions aligns strongly with Galway Chamber’s priorities around skills pipelines, lifelong learning and industry–education collaboration. Ensuring that EU policy supports reskilling, upskilling and talent retention in regional cities is essential to sustaining growth and addressing labour shortages across sectors. The emphasis on digitalisation and emerging technologies is particularly relevant to Galway’s role as a hub for innovation and R&D. From artificial intelligence and data to advanced manufacturing and health technologies, Galway Chamber supports EU initiatives that enable businesses to adopt new technologies while maintaining proportionate and business-friendly regulation. Digital infrastructure investment, including connectivity and cybersecurity, will be essential enablers for regional competitiveness. Sustainability and climate transition will remain cross-cutting priorities throughout 2026. From a Chamber perspective, the focus must shift towards practical implementation that supports businesses to decarbonise while remaining competitive. This includes access to finance for green investment, support for energy transition projects, and recognition of the role of regional innovation in delivering climate solutions. For Galway, opportunities exist to link sustainability with growth in sectors such as renewables, marine innovation and sustainable tourism. EU enlargement and geopolitical stability also matter for Galway businesses. A stable and secure Europe underpins trade, investment and supply chain resilience. Galway Chamber supports a merit-based enlargement process and strong EU external relations, recognising their importance for export markets and international collaboration. Finally, the EU Presidency will advance discussions on EU funding, governance and cohesion. From a regional perspective, it is vital that EU programmes continue to support balanced regional development, infrastructure investment and innovation outside capital cities. Galway Chamber will advocate for policies that recognise the contribution of regional cities as engines of national and European growth. In summary, the EU Presidency priorities in 2026 closely align with Galway Chamber’s strategic focus on competitiveness, skills, innovation and sustainable regional development. The Presidency provides a platform to ensure that EU policy reflects the needs and potential of regions like Galway, enabling businesses to thrive in a more competitive, resilient and inclusive Europe.

A primary policy focus should be competitiveness and the functioning of the Single Market. Legislative attention should be directed towards simplification measures, regulatory burden reduction and the removal of barriers to cross-border activity, particularly for SMEs and scaling enterprises. Progress on initiatives linked to the Capital Markets Union and access to finance will be critical. The Presidency should aim to deliver tangible improvements in the business environment, ensuring that EU regulation supports entrepreneurship, innovation and regional enterprise, rather than adding complexity. Innovation, digitalisation and emerging technologies should form a second core pillar. While much of the EU’s digital regulatory framework is now in place, the legislative focus in 2026 should shift towards implementation, clarification and proportionality. This includes ensuring that digital, data and AI-related legislation enables adoption and scaling by businesses of all sizes. The Presidency should aim to strike a balance between safeguarding citizens and fostering innovation, providing certainty for firms investing in research, development and advanced technologies across regional innovation ecosystems. A third priority area is skills, labour markets and the social dimension. Legislative and policy initiatives should focus on workforce adaptability, skills development and talent mobility, particularly in the context of the green and digital transitions. The Presidency should support measures that strengthen lifelong learning, reskilling and upskilling, while improving alignment between education systems and labour market needs. The objective should be to ensure that businesses across Europe, including in regional economies, can access the skills required to grow and remain competitive. Sustainability, climate action and the energy transition will remain central themes. Rather than introducing significant new regulatory frameworks, the Presidency should prioritise the effective implementation of existing Green Deal legislation. Legislative focus should be on coherence, investment frameworks and practical supports that enable businesses to decarbonise without undermining competitiveness. The Presidency should aim to ensure that climate policy is economically realistic, innovation-led and supportive of regional development. Migration and demographic resilience should also feature prominently. Legislative efforts should concentrate on the implementation of the EU Migration and Asylum Pact alongside broader discussions on legal migration and labour mobility. The Presidency should aim to promote a more strategic, economically informed approach to migration, recognising its role in addressing labour shortages and supporting growth. Finally, EU funding, cohesion and governance will be an important cross-cutting area. The Presidency should work to ensure that EU financial instruments and budgetary discussions support balanced regional development, infrastructure investment and innovation capacity. The overarching aim should be to reinforce the role of regions and regional cities as key contributors to Europe’s economic and social resilience. In summary, the 2026 EU Presidency should focus on delivering a more competitive, innovative and resilient Europe, with policy and legislative progress that is practical, inclusive and supportive of regional business communities.

The work of the Council of the European Union during Ireland’s Presidency in the second half of 2026 presents a significant opportunity to deliver tangible benefits for people, businesses and communities across the Union. To make the most substantial positive impact, the Council’s work should be guided by a strong focus on delivery, inclusion and long-term resilience, ensuring that EU policy translates into real-world outcomes. A first priority should be turning policy into practice. Much of the EU’s legislative framework in areas such as digital regulation, climate action and migration is already agreed. The Irish Presidency can make a meaningful difference by focusing the Council’s work on effective, consistent and business-friendly implementation. By prioritising clarity, proportionality and coherence in Council negotiations, Ireland can help ensure that EU legislation delivers certainty for businesses and practical benefits for citizens, rather than unnecessary complexity. Competitiveness and quality employment should be central to the Council’s agenda. The Presidency can drive progress on strengthening the Single Market, reducing administrative burdens and improving access to finance for SMEs and scaling companies. This will directly benefit businesses while supporting job creation and regional economic vitality. A strong focus on competitiveness is also essential to sustaining Europe’s social model, as thriving enterprises underpin investment in public services and community development. For people and communities, the Council’s work should prioritise skills, inclusion and opportunity. Ireland’s Presidency can champion Council initiatives that support reskilling, lifelong learning and labour market participation, ensuring that the green and digital transitions are inclusive and fair. By promoting policies that align education and training systems with labour market needs, the Council can help individuals adapt to change and access quality employment, particularly in regions facing demographic or structural challenges. Regional balance and cohesion should be a defining feature of Ireland’s approach. The Council plays a key role in shaping EU funding, governance and policy direction. Ireland can use the Presidency to ensure that regional voices are reflected in Council discussions and that EU programmes continue to support infrastructure, innovation and services in regional and rural areas. This will help strengthen trust in the European project by ensuring that growth and opportunity are widely shared. The Presidency can also make a positive impact by promoting a pragmatic approach to sustainability and climate action. Through the Council, Ireland can help ensure that climate policies are implemented in a way that supports communities and businesses, balancing ambition with economic and social realities. Emphasising investment, innovation and local solutions will help communities transition sustainably while maintaining competitiveness. Finally, the Irish Presidency can add value by fostering a culture of consensus and constructive dialogue within the Council. Ireland’s reputation as an honest broker positions it well to bridge differing perspectives among Member States. By encouraging collaboration and compromise, the Council’s work can progress more effectively, delivering outcomes that benefit citizens and businesses across Europe. In essence, the greatest impact of the Council’s work during Ireland’s Presidency will come from focusing on implementation, competitiveness, inclusion and regional cohesion ensuring that EU policy improves everyday life for people, strengthens businesses and supports resilient, thriving communities across the Union.

Ireland’s Presidency of the Council of the European Union offers more than a diplomatic role; it presents a rare opportunity to reconnect Europe with its citizens and to strengthen a shared sense of ownership in the European project. At a time when trust in institutions is fragile and global uncertainty is growing, how we communicate the values and benefits of EU membership matters as much as the policies we advance. The starting point must be a simple but powerful shift in perspective: the European Union is not something that happens to people, but something they actively shape. For Ireland, EU membership has always been rooted in values that resonate deeply with our national identity solidarity, fairness, opportunity and cooperation. From peace-building and regional development to workers’ rights, research innovation and climate action, the EU has been a quiet but constant partner in Ireland’s social and economic progress. However, benefits that feel distant or abstract risk being taken for granted. During the Presidency, communication should focus on making Europe visible in everyday life. This means telling local stories how EU investment has supported broadband in rural communities, research in universities, small businesses exporting for the first time, or young people studying and working across borders. When citizens can see the European Union reflected in their own town, workplace or family experience, the EU becomes real and relevant. Equally important is moving beyond one-way communication towards genuine participation. A sense of ownership grows when people feel heard. Ireland’s Presidency should create space for citizen dialogue that is inclusive and accessible, engaging young people, rural communities, workers, entrepreneurs and civic groups. Crucially, these conversations must close the loop, showing how citizen perspectives inform priorities and decision-making at European level. Participation without feedback risks deepening cynicism rather than trust. Trusted messengers also matter. People are more likely to engage with stories told by peers than by institutions. Farmers, researchers, apprentices, artists, sports clubs and community leaders can all act as authentic voices of Europe, sharing how EU membership supports their ambitions and values. By equipping these networks with simple tools and narratives, Ireland can amplify a diverse and human picture of Europe. Ireland’s strengths in culture, creativity and sport offer further opportunities to connect emotionally with citizens. Cultural expression and shared sporting experiences transcend politics and speak directly to values of inclusion, respect and cooperation. Embedding these elements into the Presidency programme can help communicate Europe not just as a political entity, but as a shared social and cultural space. Finally, honesty is essential. Communicating the value of EU membership does not mean ignoring challenges or trade-offs. Acknowledging concerns whether around cost of living, climate transition or migration while explaining how Ireland advocates for fairness within Europe builds credibility and trust. Ireland’s Presidency should be guided by a clear message: Europe works best when it works for people. By making the EU tangible, participatory and grounded in shared values, Ireland can help strengthen citizens’ sense that Europe is not only something we belong to, but something we actively build together.

Please ensure that there is a spread of EU meetings around the country to reflect the offering that we have. Do not let regional access impact decisions. As a region that has sustained a lack of investment over decades relative to infrastructure and with 2 regional airports anchoring it, it should not be by passed in favour of an easier option. The West offers an authentic meeting experience, rich in history, heritage and innovation that is unparalleled. Galway Convention Bureau are only delighted to help with any meeting enquiries and work with Failte Ireland on a complimentary basis to support meetings in Galway. Chambers of Commerce provide a unique insight into the business community and can be a great vehicle for message delivery. Please do engage and keep us informed and included where possible.

Sport Ireland supports a Presidency that champions a healthy, inclusive, and sustainable Europe, where policies promote wellbeing, equality of opportunity, and community participation. Ireland can use its Presidency to highlight how sport and physical activity contribute to these goals, strengthening social cohesion, supporting mental and physical health, and advancing the EU’s broader sustainability and inclusion agenda.

Sport Ireland can recommended that the Presidency give priority to areas where sport and physical activity can add value to European cooperation, including: initiatives supporting health-enhancing physical activity (HEPA) across Member States; gender equality and inclusion in sport; the contribution of sport to youth development, volunteering, and education; and the role of sport in environmental sustainability and green transition. Ireland’s Presidency can also help ensure that EU policies recognise the cross-cutting impact of sport in achieving health, social, and environmental objectives.

Ireland’s Presidency can drive positive impact by advancing policies that promote active, connected, and resilient communities. Through engagement in EU-level sport and health initiatives, Ireland can support collaboration among Member States on increasing physical activity participation, addressing health inequalities, and using sport as a tool for inclusion and community development. A focus on wellbeing and participation aligns with the EU’s vision of a healthier, fairer, and more sustainable future.

Sport Ireland can help communicate the EU’s values in tangible, people-centred ways by showcasing how EU cooperation supports grassroots sport, community programmes, and opportunities for young people. Through campaigns, events, and partnerships, Sport Ireland can demonstrate how European collaboration improves everyday life by enhancing wellbeing, inclusion, and shared purpose across communities.

EWOS: Sport Ireland, as the national coordinating body for the European Week of Sport (EWOS), will explore opportunities to align EWOS 2026 with Ireland’s EU Presidency. In this context, Sport Ireland intends to host an activity/event on the Sport Ireland Campus during the Week to highlight the role of sport and physical activity in supporting European objectives around participation, wellbeing, and inclusion. Planning for EWOS 2026 will continue to evolve in line with the broader Presidency programme, and Sport Ireland will remain flexible to ensure that any activity delivered complements the Government’s priorities and the overall calendar of Presidency events. Inaugural Sport Ireland Inclusion Games As part of Ireland’s upcoming EU Presidency in 2026, the Ethics and Integrity Unit requests permission to host a landmark initiative to launch the sport-related aspect of the Presidency—the Inaugural Sport Ireland Inclusion Games. This event is envisioned to take place in the latter half of July 2026 at the National Indoor Arena (Date to be confirmed). The primary aim of the Inclusion Games / Sport for All Festival / Together through Sport Event (TBC) is to celebrate and promote inclusion in sport, showcasing the rich diversity of minority groups actively participating in sport across Ireland. This event will highlight successful inclusive programmes and initiatives, while providing an engaging platform for participants and attendees to experience the variety of sports and physical activity in Ireland today. The event will be a highly interactive, full-day event featuring practical “Come and Try” sessions led by NGBs, LSPs, ESF Officers and specialised groups including ADI. There will also be live music and dance interactive sessions showcasing inclusive physical activities and information stands signposting clubs and organisations currently providing inclusive sporting opportunities. The event will allow participants to engage directly with a wide variety of sports and activities, fostering community engagement and raising awareness around inclusion in sport. The Event will focus on engaging marginalised and underrepresented groups who face barriers to accessing mainstream sport, including people with disabilities, new neighbours and ethnic minority groups including Traveller and Roma communities, older adults, members of the LGBTIQ+ community and individuals living in disadvantaged areas. The event will aim to have over 1000 attendees and will be relevant and accessible to a broad audience including families, classes, groups, students, volunteers, coaches and anyone passionate about inclusive sport. By hosting the Inaugural Sport Ireland Event during the EU Presidency, Sport Ireland will demonstrate its leadership in promoting ethics, integrity, and inclusion within Irish sport. This event will serve as a powerful catalyst to foster greater participation, enhance community cohesion, and inspire ongoing inclusive initiatives nationwide.

Ireland’s 2026 EU Presidency takes place at a time when Europe faces a defining challenge: sustaining global competitiveness while building resilience in the technologies that underpin economic growth, industrial capability, and societal wellbeing. Ireland should anchor its Presidency around a strategic, future-oriented theme: “Strengthening Europe’s Competitiveness and Technological Resilience.” Three high-level priorities should shape the Presidency’s agenda: 1. Securing Europe’s Leadership in Strategic Technologies Semiconductors, digital health, AI, advanced manufacturing, and clean-energy systems form the backbone of Europe’s competitiveness. Ireland is well positioned to lead on this agenda, drawing on five decades of industrial partnership with global semiconductor, medtech, and digital companies. As home to the EU’s only IPCEI-funded semiconductor design and manufacturing project in Ireland, Ireland can bring practical experience to Council discussions on the semiconductor value chain, AI adoption, supply-chain resilience, and research collaboration. This theme aligns directly with the EU’s 2024–2029 Strategic Agenda. 2. Driving Innovation and Skills to Support Industrial Competitiveness Europe’s long-term performance depends on its capacity to innovate and develop a highly skilled workforce. Ireland’s Presidency should prioritise policies that enhance Europe’s design and engineering capabilities, expand access to critical research infrastructure, and promote mobility and training pathways in microelectronics, AI, data science, and advanced manufacturing. Ireland’s experience with programmes such as ISE and iBio provides a strong basis for European-level discussion on how to scale residency-based and industry-engaged learning models across Member States. 3. Enabling Digital Transformation with Clear Societal Outcomes A Presidency priority should be meaningful progress on digital health, where Europe can significantly improve healthcare quality, system efficiency, and patient outcomes. Ireland has deep industrial and research strength in semiconductors, sensing technology, connected health, and digital platforms. Prioritising the European Health Data Space, AI-enabled diagnostics, secure medical-device connectivity, and cybersecurity in clinical environments will demonstrate Europe’s commitment to delivering benefits that citizens can see and experience. Signature Proposal: EU–Industry Digital Healthcare Forum Ireland should propose establishing an EU–Industry Digital Healthcare Forum, bringing together leading European companies across semiconductors, medtech, pharmaceuticals, digital health, and AI with EU Commissioners and health authorities. The Forum would serve as a structured mechanism to advance digital health interoperability, accelerate innovation adoption, address systemic barriers, and ensure alignment between regulatory frameworks and technological progress. The initiative reflects Ireland’s strengths and offers a high-impact, future-orientated legacy for the 2026 Presidency. Together, these themes provide a coherent framework for a Presidency that enhances Europe’s competitiveness, strengthens resilience in critical technologies, and supports innovation-led growth across all Member States.

Ireland should focus its Presidency on policy areas that are central to Europe’s technological competitiveness, economic resilience, and long-term strategic autonomy. Four areas are particularly relevant: 1. Implementation and Review of the EU Chips Act (“Chips Act 2.0”) Ireland should guide Council discussions that support a balanced and effective evolution of the Chips Act. Priorities should include: Strengthening Europe’s design sovereignty, including shared EDA infrastructure, IP libraries, and cross-border design collaboration. Ensuring value-chain balance, with support not only for leading-edge manufacturing but also analogue, mixed-signal, power, and mature-node technologies essential to Europe’s industrial base. Enhancing accessibility for companies with significant European operations, recognising global business structures and avoiding rigid localisation requirements. Clearer coordination among IPCEI ME/CT, the Chips Joint Undertaking, and national programmes to reduce fragmentation and administrative complexity. Ireland’s experience as a major semiconductor design and manufacturing location provides practical insight into how Europe can strengthen its competitiveness in this strategic sector. 2. AI Adoption and Innovation in Strategic Sectors The Presidency should support effective implementation of the AI Act while enabling rapid, responsible deployment in sectors where Europe has strong industrial capability, including: Healthcare and medical technology Pharmaceuticals and bioprocessing Energy and grid intelligence Automotive and industrial automation Semiconductor design and test Clear guidelines and harmonised practices will support innovation and help European companies compete globally. 3. Digital Health and the European Health Data Space Ireland should focus on advancing the Health Data Space Regulation and associated digital health initiatives. Key priorities include interoperability, secure data exchange, cybersecurity in healthcare, regulatory clarity for AI-enabled devices, and alignment across health, digital, and industrial policy. These areas directly impact quality of care and are essential enablers of a high-performing European health ecosystem. 4. European Competitiveness, Skills, and Industrial Strategy The Presidency should prioritise: Alignment between the European Competitiveness Fund and EU industrial strategy Targeted investments in microelectronics, systems engineering, and AI talent Strengthened industrial data spaces and digital infrastructure Fast, predictable regulatory pathways that support innovation and capital investment Closer EU–US cooperation in technology, supply-chain resilience, and standards Signature Initiative: EU–Industry Digital Healthcare Forum Ireland is well positioned to propose a long-term EU–Industry Digital Healthcare Forum as part of the Presidency programme. This structure would enhance coordination between policymakers, clinicians, global industry leaders, and research organisations to accelerate Europe’s digital health transition.

The Irish Presidency can deliver tangible, long-lasting impact by focusing on areas where technological progress directly supports economic resilience, industrial growth, and improved public services. Highlight success stories of EU-backed innovation in Ireland and across Europe ADI’s €630 million investment in Limerick, supported through Ireland’s first participation in an IPCEI, provides a concrete example of how EU industrial cooperation delivers jobs, skills, and long-term technological capability. Showing how EU action enables semiconductor research, medical innovation, cleaner energy systems, safer vehicles, and digital manufacturing will make the benefits visible and relatable. Strengthening Europe’s Strategic Technology Base Semiconductors, AI, digital health infrastructure, and advanced manufacturing systems underpin Europe’s industrial performance and societal resilience. Accelerating work on the Chips Act, AI deployment frameworks, and innovation ecosystems will support businesses across all sectors, enabling stable supply chains, improved productivity, and greater competitiveness. This work directly benefits communities by supporting high-quality employment and ensuring access to critical technologies. Advancing Digital Health to Improve System Outcomes Digital health represents one of the most impactful ways EU policy can support citizens. Progress on secure health-data interoperability, AI-enabled diagnostics, and connected medical systems will improve patient outcomes, reduce clinical inefficiencies, and expand access to care. These improvements bring clear and measurable benefits across all Member States, from large healthcare systems to rural and remote communities. Supporting Industrial Competitiveness and Sustainability Policies that strengthen Europe’s industrial base—through advanced manufacturing capabilities, clean-energy systems, and resilient supply chains—create positive impact for businesses of all sizes. The Presidency can ensure that EU initiatives such as the Competitiveness Fund, Horizon Europe, and Skills Agenda are aligned to support innovation, capital investment, and the transition to more sustainable industrial practices. Prioritising Skills and Workforce Development Skills are a strategic determinant of long-term prosperity. Europe faces persistent shortages across microelectronics, AI, software engineering, data analytics, and digital manufacturing. The Presidency can promote mobility schemes, postgraduate programmes, and industry-integrated models that accelerate workforce development. Ireland’s experience with sector-focused programmes, including its residency-based models, provides a relevant example of scalable approaches. Facilitating Effective Public–Private Collaboration Complex challenges—such as digitalising healthcare, decarbonising industry, and transitioning to AI-driven systems—require coordination between industry, academia, and policymakers. The Presidency can support these partnerships by promoting co-creation frameworks and by encouraging cross-sector collaboration on research, regulation, and deployment of key technologies. Cross-Cutting Opportunity: EU–Industry Digital Healthcare Forum A permanent EU–Industry Digital Healthcare Forum would deliver structural impact by aligning clinical needs, industry capabilities, and regulatory priorities at European scale. This initiative would support rapid and responsible adoption of digital health innovations and represent a meaningful, citizen-focused legacy for the Irish Presidency. By focusing on strategic technologies, digital transformation, workforce development, and collaborative innovation, the Presidency can deliver benefits that will be felt across European industries, communities, and public systems.

Ireland’s Presidency provides an opportunity to demonstrate the practical value of EU cooperation in strengthening Europe’s competitiveness, technological resilience, and industrial capacity. Communication should focus on clarity, substance, and the strategic outcomes enabled by coordinated European action. Emphasise Europe’s Competitive Strength in Strategic Technologies Communication should highlight how EU-level initiatives—such as the Chips Act, AI frameworks, and digital health infrastructure—support industrial capability, supply-chain stability, and long-term economic wellbeing. This approach aligns with the priorities of European businesses and demonstrates the functional value of EU cooperation. Demonstrate Ireland’s Capability as an Effective Industrial Partner As ADI marks 50 years of operation in Ireland in 2026, Ireland’s track record of industrial collaboration, research excellence, and technology leadership underscores its ability to convene strategic discussions at EU level. The Presidency can communicate its strengths in sectors such as semiconductors, medtech, digital innovation, and advanced manufacturing, areas where Ireland contributes meaningfully to Europe’s competitiveness. Highlight Cross-Border Collaboration and Research Impact Showcasing successful European partnerships - IPCEI ME/CT, semiconductor research networks, digital health pilots, and cross-border innovation projects—will demonstrate how EU membership enhances the collective capabilities of Member States. These examples reinforce the core value proposition of coordinated European action. Engage Through Institutional and Sector-Relevant Channels Industry and research communities engage most effectively through focused, technical, and policy-relevant communication. Council briefings, sectoral dialogue platforms, Presidency events, and engagement with industrial alliances will ensure that key messages reach stakeholders who can act on them. Reinforce the Strategic Value of EU Cooperation At a time of rapid technological change, coordinated European action is essential to maintain global competitiveness, ensure supply-chain resilience, and deliver high-quality public services. The Presidency offers a platform to communicate the strategic benefits of EU membership through the lens of technological capability, economic stability, and shared opportunity.

Analog Devices strongly supports Ireland’s ambition to position the semiconductor sector at the heart of its economic and technological strategy, as reflected in the Market Diversification Plan, Competitiveness Action Plan, Programme for Government, and the IDA Strategy. ADI’s own footprint, spanning advanced R&D, large-scale manufacturing, and nearly €1 billion in recent Irish investments, demonstrates the value of long-term partnerships between industry, government, and the EU. As Ireland’s only IPCEI recipient to date, ADI is committed to supporting European innovation and supply chain resilience. Our investments help accelerate advances in healthcare, pharmaceuticals, industrial automation, mobility, and next-generation semiconductor technologies. We encourage the Presidency to emphasise strategic resilience as a defining theme, advancing a policy programme that strengthens Europe’s technological capabilities, maintains competitiveness, and ensures the EU remains an attractive destination for international investment. ADI also encourages Ireland to highlight the importance of AI adoption across critical sectors and to champion an approach that combines trust, innovation, and real-world deployment. Ensuring that Europe leads in high-value applications of AI – in healthcare, energy, semiconductors, pharmaceuticals, and mobility – will deliver long-term benefits for citizens and industry alike. Skills are a fundamental enabler of resilience and competitiveness. Europe faces material shortages in semiconductor engineering, AI, digital health, and advanced manufacturing. The Presidency should encourage targeted programmes that support talent mobility, industry-integrated learning models, and postgraduate pathways in strategic technologies. Ireland’s experience with residency-based learning systems such as the University of Limerick ISE and iBio programmes offers a practical blueprint. Proposed Legacy Initiative: EU–Industry Digital Healthcare Forum Digital health is a major opportunity to improve healthcare performance and strengthen Europe’s leadership in medical technologies. Ireland is well positioned, given its industrial base and research strengths, to propose the creation of a permanent EU–Industry Digital Healthcare Forum, bringing together senior EU policymakers and leading companies across semiconductors, medtech, pharmaceuticals, digital platforms, and AI. The Forum would align regulatory frameworks, accelerate the adoption of digital health solutions, and ensure Europe remains globally competitive in this important sector. By focusing on semiconductor leadership, digital transformation, industrial innovation, and workforce capability, Ireland can deliver a Presidency programme that makes a measurable contribution to Europe’s competitiveness and resilience. This would reflect the practical value of EU cooperation while building on Ireland’s five decades of experience as a partner to global industry and research.

IAIM is acutely aware of the volatile geopolitical situation the EU finds itself in and perhaps because of that (and not despite it) our members consider one priority should be a focus on financing the strategic aims of the EU (e.g. innovation, green transition, defence, digitalisation) through mobilizing capital and working to realize the stated aims of the EU's Capital Markets Union (CMU) and Savings and Investment Union (SIU). Ireland should use its presidency to ensure the urgency of the Draghi and Letta reports on the need to ensure we have an effective internal single market and remain competitive should remain high on the agenda, as there are signs that confidence may be waning (a recent survey of CEOs showed some are reconsidering plans to invest in Europe or invest less[1]). President of the ECB Ms Lagarde, in a recent speech[2]. stated more "…years of inaction – and lost growth – would not just be disappointing. It would be irresponsible". While successful in the past, Europe's "growth model [is] geared towards a world that is gradually disappearing". We think that financial services can be both a means to engage citizens in the EU's capital markets as part of the SIU and be future-oriented given the pressing need for the EU to execute on these ambitious plans and unlock its potential for innovation and global competitiveness.

We support the aims of the SIU as part of the broader aim of ensuring the competitiveness of the EU. Ireland should be at the forefront of delivering on the aims of SIU in ensuring citizens have access to the best, most efficient products to encourage putting their savings to work in the real economy in order to (i) support European businesses to succeed and innovate and (ii) to grow household wealth and plan for retirement. In particular the aim of improving cross-border provision of funds and reducing operational barriers facing asset managers is key to realizing the aims of SIU. The recently announced Market Integration Plan, to address market fragmentation, has much to recommend it[3] to help increase scale and efficiency (notwithstanding regulatory change brings operational challenges and costs). Implementing the key measures in a timely deliberate and effective way, led by the Irish presidency liaising with the co-legislators, other member states and stakeholders, will be important so the improvements are not delayed or watered down. (IAIM would observe at this point that proposals ESMA supervisory overlay for large cross-border managers, if it progresses, should be proportionate and not affect the clarity or finality of national regulators' decisions and approvals. We further note centralized supervision of asset managers has not been proposed.) The key policy areas include: Harmonising authorisation processes for EU UCITS managers and AIFMs Reducing regulatory and reporting obligations for EU groups Improve trading and settlement: less fragmented market infrastructure is important for efficient and liquid markets which is in the interests of European investors Streamlining cross-border distribution of funds and removing barriers to 'passporting' Bring a more flexible, proportionate approach to innovation related to distributed ledger technology (DLT) – noting tokenization of shares in funds is a huge focus for the UCITS ETF and MMF markets, which are regulated and available to EU retail investors The EC has announced an initiative on European venture and growth capital funds reform "to improve operating conditions for EU venture and growth capital fund managers as well as increase their competitiveness in order to further support the EU economy and innovative companies. The initiative could bring about a simplified and more proportionate, cost-effective set of rules for EU venture and growth capital fund managers to operate and to achieve a greater scale, boosting the financing available in the EU"[4] In a recent speech[5] Commissioner noted the initiative will issue around Q3 2026 and "the reform will seek to enable our asset managers to operate more efficiently and on a broader scale across the EU Single Market, reduce administrative burdens, boost incentives to operate larger funds and invest into the EU real economy, including infrastructure projects". This could be an exciting development for Ireland to help progress, as not just new or improved private fund products (e.g. ELTIF) but an appropriately regulated type of manager in the private space could greatly assist unlocking and deploying capital in Europe.

We would reiterate the need to ensure as a matter of priority the relevant and competitiveness of the EU and its capital markets as flagged by Draghi and Letta, and as expanded on by the European Commission and Commissioner Albuquerque on the importance of the SIU in the context of the role financial services can play (and noting the recent release of the Market Integration Plan proposals). These are crucial to support the EU's ability to finance its key strategies and provide for a sustainable, safe, stable and prosperous future for its citizens

IAIM does not express a view on this matter but across its membership and their employees the benefits of EU membership - not least the four freedoms - are key to the success of the financial services industry. On a broader note beyond the Irish presidency, and in the context of financial literacy and citizens holding a stake in the EU and its economy, the recent recommendation of the European Commission[6] for a "Savings and Investment Accounts with Simplified and Advantageous Tax Treatment" ("SIA") sets out a blueprint for an SIA to boost retail participation in the capital markets (e.g. equities, bonds, UCITS funds). While not comparable necessarily, the Special Savings Incentive Account introduced in 2001 in Ireland saw large scale retail interest and take up. If Ireland could lead by example in having a national trusted SIA brand, leveraging European best practice, it could give impetus and be an example for other member states as a practical means of implementing SIU's goals and funding our strategic priorities.

On a broader note, globalised markets enable better opportunities for financial services. As the EU works towards (i) fostering competitiveness and innovation and (ii) strengthening economic security, the development of the CMU and SIU cannot be decoupled from global markets. Ireland can be a voice for balancing the EU's legitimate strategic goals with the worth aim of preserving access to global markets.

Ireland should choose animal welfare as a thematic priority for its upcoming Presidency of the Council. Article 13 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the EU stipulates that, as sentient beings, full regard should be paid to animals’ welfare requirements. Since 1974, when the first EU legislation on animal welfare was adopted, animal welfare requirements have evolved based on sound scientific knowledge, improving the quality of animals’ lives in accordance with citizens’ expectations and market demands. However, EU animal welfare legislation has not kept pace with the evolution of these requirements. New legislation which ensures that the welfare of animals is properly protected is urgently required and needs to be prioritised by Ireland.

The Irish Presidency must significantly advance negotiations on the proposal relating to the protection of animals during transportation. This proposal needs to contain and retain provisions which meaningfully improve conditions for transported animals and ensure that their welfare needs are fully met. We understand that the European Commission is aiming to present its proposals to modernize other welfare rules for farm animals by the end of next year. If these proposals are issued prior to the end of Ireland’s presidency, we would urge that Ireland take all possible steps to progress these proposals also.

The Council should follow the One Health-One Welfare approach. Human health and animal health are interlinked so by improving animal welfare humans will benefit. Intensive farming is not only a breeding ground for disease, and zoonoses, but the overuse of antibiotics to keep animals alive until slaughter weight has reduced their effectiveness to dangerous levels. By prioritising animal welfare, the Council’s work would be at the heart of sustainability, as a good level of animal welfare is linked to less antibiotic use, healthier animals entering the food chain and reduced transmission of diseases from animals to people. It also has the potential to prevent a future pandemic like Covid 19 which wreaked havoc all around the world just a few short years ago.

Title II Article 8A.3 of the Treaty of Lisbon states that “Every citizen shall have the right to participate in the democratic life of the Union. Decisions shall be taken as openly and as closely as possible to the citizen. "The ‘End the Cage Age’ European Citizens’ Initiative (ECI) was signed by almost 1.4 million EU citizens. In addition, a Eurobarometer survey in 2023 showed that a large majority of Europeans (84%) believe that the welfare of farmed animals should be better protected in their country than it is now. A similar number (83%) support limiting the transport time of animals. Therefore, it is clear that EU citizens do indeed want better protections for animals. For the Council to ignore their wishes is an affront to democracy and the Treaty of Lisbon. In light of the above, it is imperative that the Council acts in accordance with the wishes of its citizens with respect to animal welfare, and that it progresses animal welfare proposals in a meaningful way. By attempting to water down or prevent new animal welfare proposals, and continuously pushing back on promises made in this regard, this does not show that the EU has value, quite the opposite. Each member of the Council should also be made aware of the importance of enforcing existing animal welfare legislation. The poor level of enforcement that currently exists and which allows serious animal welfare breaches to occur on a massive scale does not instill confidence in EU citizens. We would also suggest that an animal welfare conference is organised during the Irish Presidency which discusses the progress of new animal welfare proposals and sets out how they will improve animal welfare when enacted (and properly enforced). Such a conference should include meaningful participation by animal welfare NGOs that campaign on the particular aspects of animal welfare in question.

organisation: Friends of Mayo Dark Skies Community Group
response_text: We support the submission presented on this theme by Dark Sky Ireland; our National NGO for the reduction light pollution across Ireland (and in this case Europe). We support the voice of Dark Sky Ireland in that the proposal for thematic priorities and responses to this consultation are set out below and these incorporate the people centered, future focused vision for the EU. We support the proposed theme of “Under One Sky” as the overarching high level theme. This offers a unifying metaphor to share challenges and opportunities across member states and beyond borders. This theme emphasises equality, interconnectedness and is future oriented for stewardship, sustainability and strategic thinking. The sky is one resource literally shared by every European citizen. Whether in rural, remote or urban regions; every community lives “under one sky”. As a slogan, it resonates with themes of solidarity, belonging, equality and accessibility, all of which are central to the EU’s core values. The concept provides a narrative frame to articulate EU citizenship: freedom of movement, mobility, connectivity, cultural exchange, research collaboration, and the idea that European decisions have a common impact on all of us. The proposed theme “Under One Sky” reflects core themes within the EU’s Strategic Agenda 2024–2029 and the Nature Restoration Law, which requires action plans from Member states during the period when Ireland will be hosting the Presidency such as: Upholding the protection of nature and the reversal of ecosystem degradation. Connection of citizens in a thriving future oriented society of equality and inclusion. Strengthen Climate Action maintaining just transitions and human and planetary health.

organisation: Friends of Mayo Dark Skies Community Group
response_text: The Irish Presidency can advance EU-wide coordination on policy areas pertaining to the regulation of light pollution, a recognised environmental pollutant (noted for its impact on biodiversity, energy/climate objectives, human health as well as scientific and cultural heritage). Several Member States, including Czechia and Spain, advanced this work during their Presidencies, demonstrating its significance as a pan-European issue for coordinated EU action. Building on this momentum would reflect Ireland’s role as a neutral facilitator while responding holistically to EU Member State needs. Including a focus on light pollution would draw directly on the scientific and policy recommendations set out in the Horizon Europe PLAN-B Policy Brief on Light Pollution Mitigation issued in 2025. Ref: https://zenodo.org/records/15707106 Nature Restoration Law: Light pollution is explicitly referenced in the texts of the Nature Restoration resolution, which calls on Member States to identify and mitigate artificial light pressures in their national restoration plans. The Irish Presidency could facilitate progress by: Hosting an expert-level discussion/meeting on integrating light pollution mitigation into the implementation phase of the Nature Restoration Law. Supporting work toward harmonised indicators for monitoring Artificial Light at Night (ALAN), aiding comparability across Member States and aligning with the EU Biodiversity Strategy and Global Biodiversity Framework 2030 to reduce light pollution. • Encouraging uptake of international guidance, such as the International Light Pollution Guidelines for Migratory Species (CMS) https://www.cms.int/publication/international-light-pollutionguidelines-migratory-species, to ensure EU legislation reflects current scientific consensus. Sustainable Use of Space & the Dark & Quiet Skies Movement: Dark and Quiet Skies is a global theme that raises awareness about the urgent need to preserve night skies from the negative impact of satellite constellations on ground-based optical and radio astronomy. Excessive light affects astronomy infrastructure including EU-supported observatories and satellite calibration. These concerns were central to the international IAU–UNOOSA “Dark & Quiet Skies ”initiative: https://www.eso.org/public/about-eso/dark-skies-preservation/ & https://www.iau.org/Iau/Iau/News/Ann2025/ann25010.aspx Following recent meetings: UN/SKAO Workshop on Dark and Quiet Skies for Science and Society in Vienna, and the Transnational Political Networks Workshops on Dark and Quiet Skies in Dublin, the Irish Presidency could facilitate further dialogue with scientific institutions, industry specialists and policymakers to enable both astronomy programmes (including cultural astronomy) and satellite projects to find mutually beneficial policy solutions. The Presidency could aim to achieve: An expert meeting or ministerial roundtable on Light Pollution, enabling knowledge exchange and preparing future EU initiatives building on work initiated in Czechia and Spain. A shared EU roadmap, to mitigate, monitoring and reduce Light Pollution and the impacts of ALAN across Europe. Support for including light pollution in the Commission’s 2026–27 work programme, within the frameworks zero-pollution, urban environment or biodiversity frameworks. Advance discourse within EU Member states on policy objectives for the Dark and Quiet Skies movement pertaining to the sustainable use of space. These actions show the Irish Presidential commitment to protect our shared environment across Europe, benefiting biodiversity, enhancing energy efficiency, improving health and wellbeing and preserving the night sky we all live under.

organisation: Friends of Mayo Dark Skies Community Group
response_text: Light pollution is one of the few environmental pressures that can be reduced rapidly, cost-effectively, and with immediate positive outcomes. Reducing light pollution brings the following benefits to people, businesses and communities across the EU For people: improved sleep, wellbeing, access to nature, and restored views of the night sky as a shared cultural and scientific resource. For communities: safer, well-designed lighting solutions; enhanced public spaces; reduced municipal energy costs; and stronger engagement with environmental protection. For businesses: best practice European guidance on sustainable lighting; development opportunities for lighting and design industries in the EU; and innovation in satellite-friendly, astronomy-compatible technologies. For biodiversity and ecosystems: improved conditions for pollinators, migratory species, and nocturnal wildlife, supporting implementation of the Nature Restoration Regulation. These benefits reflect EU-wide priorities under the European Green Deal, Zero Pollution ambition, Biodiversity Strategy, and energy-efficiency objectives. Reducing light pollution strongly resonates with citizens across countries and cultures. The night sky is universally accessible; improvements are immediately visible; and improved access to dark sky parks and reserves for stargazing events and public-science activities is a growing issue of social justice.

organisation: Friends of Mayo Dark Skies Community Group
response_text: This proposal to host an expert meeting or ministerial roundtable on Light Pollution follows the recent Artificial Light at Night Conference (ALAN) 2025, which we co-hosted (together with Dark Sky Ireland & NPWS) in Westport in October. The event was attended and officially opened by Minister Dara Calleary and was supported by Minister Christopher O’Sullivan. The recent iteration of ALAN 2025 was the first time this global event had been hosted in Ireland and it also facilitate the launch of the European Light Pollution Coalition which seeks to develop policy for light pollution measures across Europe. The European Light Pollution Coalition has a mandate to follow up. pertinent discussions arising from ALAN on policy and legislation at the next EU Presidency Meeting and seeks to follow up on Ireland’s agenda as a matter of urgency. Therefore we support the proposals by Dark Sky Ireland for an Expert Workshop/Meeting on Light Pollution to take place within the agenda of the Irish Presidency of the EU under the Regional meetings (as discussed in the aforementioned text).

I propose the following: Position gender equity and inclusion as a central thematic priority Focus on inequalities in health and healthcare leadership affecting women and minority groups Emphasise the right to health as a fundamental human right Build on Ireland’s tradition of human rights leadership and global health action Link this priority to Ireland’s international commitments and UN Human Rights Council ambitions Highlight Ireland’s role in promoting inclusive, rights-based EU policies

I propose the following; Prioritise proposals that strengthen gender equality in health systems Support diversity in healthcare leadership and governance Focus on universal, inclusive and affordable access to healthcare Aim to reduce health disparities for women and marginalised communities Emphasise practical implementation and measurable progress across Member States Call for accelerated legislative progress and political alignment

I propose the following during this Highlighting the timing of Ireland’s Presidency during Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) negotiations Advocate for gender equity and social inclusion as core principles of EU funding Emphasise rights-based investment in health, social protection and community resilience Stress the importance of protecting and advancing human rights in a changing global context Link equitable policies to economic stability and business sustainability Reference key themes from the main policy recommendations in the brief

I propose the following • Frame public health as essential to social justice, economic resilience and democratic stability Emphasise that universal access to quality healthcare reflects core EU values Highlight concerns about rollbacks in women’s health and rights Stress the importance of visible EU leadership on equity and inclusion Promote systematic involvement of civil society in policymaking Include participation of: o Women’s rights and women’s health organisations o Gender equality organisations o Migrant and Roma communities o LGBTIQ+ groups o Disability and carers’ organisations Emphasise co-creation, consultation and ongoing monitoring Highlight that inclusive participation builds trust, ownership and democratic engagement

I participated in the two-day international conference IGHNxEU – Empowering Women for a Healthier Europe, held in Dublin on 14–15 November 2025. As a contributor to the policy discussions, I helped inform the development of the below linked policy brief. I wish to submit this policy brief as supporting evidence for my submission: https://globalhealth.ie/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/IGHN-EIWH-PolicyBrief-FINAL_TOC-Dec-9.pdf

organisation: Early Years - the organisation for young children
response_text: We urge that, through the Presidency of the Council in 2026, Ireland should centre its high-level thematic agenda on quality early learning and childcare as a cornerstone for long-term societal prosperity, social cohesion, and peacebuilding. In particular, we propose the following priorities: 1. Early learning as a driver of sustainable economic prosperity and competitiveness Investing in accessible, high-quality early learning lays strong foundations for lifelong learning, boosting human capital from the earliest years. We recommend championing an EU-wide roadmap that supports affordable, high-quality services. Ensuring that more families have access to reliable early learning and care not only supports parents’ labour market participation (especially women), but helps build a more skilled, adaptable future workforce. This can contribute directly to the competitiveness and long-term economic resilience of the EU. Early education and childcare as part of quality of life and social fairness Under Ireland’s Presidency, we recommend that policies be explicitly integrated into the work programme under these social priorities. By doing so, the EU can promote equality of opportunity from the start of life - offering children from all socio-economic, ethnic and migrant backgrounds access to quality early learning. This helps reduce inequalities from the earliest stages and strengthens social cohesion across Member States. Early learning as a tool for peacebuilding, inclusion, and democratic values Under the strategic ambition of “a free and democratic Europe,” early childhood services can play a subtle but powerful role in building shared European identity, social inclusion, and intergenerational solidarity. Ireland’s Presidency could, for instance, promote cross-national exchange and cooperation on curricula that foster mutual respect, democratic values, inclusion of minorities and migrants, helping prevent marginalisation and social fragmentation. High-quality early learning and care can be a stabilising force in communities, particularly states facing economic or demographic pressures, and can contribute over time to peaceful, cohesive societies. A European ‘Early Years Pact’ embedding early learning and care in long-term EU policy frameworks We propose that Ireland use its 2026 Presidency as a catalyst for agreement among Member States around an ‘Early Years Pact’. This would commit the EU to measurable targets: universal or nearuniversal access to quality early learning, staff training and professionalisation, funding mechanisms, inclusivity and equity, and monitoring/quality assurance systems. Leveraging early learning and care to support demographic and social changes across the EU. Many EU states face demographic shifts, ageing populations, gender labour-market gaps, and growing inequality. High-quality early learning services help address these challenges by supporting childhood development, enabling workforce participation, and promoting gender equality. Under Ireland’s Presidency, a renewed focus on early education and childcare could be positioned as key to tackling demographic, social, and economic challenges, consistent with the Commission’s ambition for sustainable prosperity and social fairness.

organisation: Early Years - the organisation for young children
response_text: 1. Embedding early learning and childcare under “Prosperous and Competitive Europe” Under this umbrella, the Irish Presidency should: Advocate for a European-level framework or strategy to support universal access to affordable, high-quality early learning and care across Member States. Such a framework could help to unlock full workforce participation, especially among women, thereby boosting labour supply and economic productivity. Encourage recognition and support for early education and childcare as a foundational investment in human capital - equipping future generations with skills, social and cognitive development, and long-term societal benefit. Promote policies that integrate early learning and care funding and support mechanisms into EU recovery and cohesion funds, making early learning part of broader social investment rather than a national afterthought. Advancing “European Social Fairness” and “Quality of Life / Social Cohesion” The Irish Presidency could champion: Legislation or non-legislative EU guidance setting minimum standards for staff qualification, educator-child ratios, inclusivity, and quality assurance in early learning and childcare to ensure that early learning is not just available, but of genuinely high standard. Initiatives targeting equal access for children from disadvantaged, migrant, or minority backgrounds, ensuring early learning and care contributes to reducing inequality from the earliest stages of life. Cross-national cooperation and exchange of best practices for early learning and care, enabling smaller or under-resourced Member States to build capacity and benefit from shared learning and EU support. A Means of Social Cohesion, Inclusion, and Peacebuilding - contributing to “A free and democratic Europe” Under its Presidency, Ireland should: Encourage embedding values of inclusion, tolerance, diversity, and democratic citizenship into early learning curricula across the EU. High-quality early learning and care can nurture respect for human rights, mutual understanding, and long-term social cohesion - contributing to peacebuilding and stable communities across the Union. Use the Presidency to launch or support an EU-wide “Early Years for Inclusion and Cohesion” initiative - encouraging Member States to adopt early learning policies that foster social integration, reduce marginalisation, and build shared civic values from early childhood onwards. What Ireland Should Aim to Achieve by End of 2026 By the close of its Presidency, we would like to see Ireland deliver: A clear, strategic European commitment to early learning - e.g., a Council Conclusions document endorsing early education and childcare as a priority for social investment, economic growth, and social cohesion. Agreement among Member States on minimum quality standards and equity of access for services.
