Commitment to mobilising EU funding (e.g., through cohesion, social, recovery or structural funds) to support expansion, workforce professionalisation, and inclusion - especially in underserved regions or communities. An EU-wide network or platform for sharing best practices, data, and monitoring outcomes - to promote continuous improvement and ensure accountability. Recognition of early learning and care as a cross-cutting policy: contributing not only to education or social policy, but to labour market participation, gender equality, demographic resilience, integration, and long-term social stability. We stand ready to provide detailed proposals, data, and partnership to support these ambitions.

organisation: Early Years - the organisation for young children
response_text: We believe the Irish Presidency can deliver tangible, cross-cutting impact by putting high-quality early childhood education and care at the heart of its Programme. 1. Driving competitiveness and productivity through early years investment Ireland’s Presidency can make a concrete difference for businesses by treating early learning and care as essential economic infrastructure: Prioritise full implementation and strengthening of the EU Early Childhood Education and Care ‘Barcelona’ targets. Children Aged 3 to Primary School: At least 96% participation. Children Under 3: At least 45% participation Duration: Services ideally accessed for at least 25 hours per week. Frame early learning and care expansion as a labour-market and productivity measure, supporting parental employment, entrepreneurship and skills, not just a “social” cost. EUSocialCit Promote the use of EU funds for childcare infrastructure, workforce development and innovation in early learning, particularly in underserved rural and cross-border regions. This approach supports SMEs and local economies by improving workforce availability, reducing absenteeism and fostering a more skilled future workforce. Advancing social fairness and quality of life via the European Child Guarantee We recommend that Ireland: Makes implementation of the European Child Guarantee a flagship Council priority, emphasising free and effective access to quality early education and childcare as a core service for children in need. Encourages Member States, via Council debates and conclusions, to use Child Guarantee National Action Plans to reduce child poverty, address regional inequalities in early learning, and embed minimum quality standards (staff qualifications, ratios, inclusion, child-centred pedagogy). Alliance for Investing in Children+1 Champion “child-rights budgeting” so that fiscal and structural reforms under EU economic governance are assessed for their impact. UNICEF Strengthening democracy, cohesion and peacebuilding from the earliest years Ireland’s Presidency could: Lead Council discussions and conclusions highlighting the role of early learning in social cohesion and peacebuilding, especially in communities marked by conflict legacy, polarisation, migration pressures or socio-economic divides. Promote EU-level support for early years curricula and educator training that explicitly foster empathy, non-discrimination, gender equality, conflict resolution and respect for diversity. First Years First Priority+1 Encourage cooperation on cross-border early years projects and exchanges, particularly in border regions or areas with a history of tension, showcasing how shared services for young children and families can build trust and shared identity over time. What the Irish Presidency should aim to deliver 1. Strong Council Conclusions that: o reaffirm early learning and care as a strategic priority cutting across competitiveness, social fairness and democracy; o call for ambitious implementation of the European Care Strategy, Barcelona targets and Child Guarantee. A concrete “Early Years implementation track” within ensuring that early childhood is reflected in economic, social and territorial cohesion debates. A political signal that investing in quality early learning is one of the EU’s most effective tools for: o boosting productivity and innovation; o reducing poverty and inequality; o building inclusive, peaceful and democratic societies. We stand ready to support Ireland in shaping a Presidency that recognises the early years as the bedrock of Europe’s future.

organisation: Early Years - the organisation for young children
response_text: We believe that the most powerful way to communicate values and benefits and to build genuine ownership of Ireland’s 2026 Presidency is to show, in concrete and local ways, how the EU shapes children’s lives, families’ prospects and community cohesion from the very earliest years. Tell a simple story: “The EU in your child’s early years” The Presidency could use early learning and childcare as a storytelling lens for EU membership: Highlight how initiatives such as the European Child Guarantee, cohesion policy and the European Pillar of Social Rights support access to quality early childhood education and care, especially for disadvantaged children. Show that early learning and care is not just a social good but a driver of prosperity and competitiveness: enabling parents to work or train, supporting local businesses and developing the future skilled workforce. Campaigns, short videos and local case studies from early years settings across Ireland and the wider EU can humanise EU policy: “This is how Europe is investing in your child, your job, your community.” Use early years spaces as democratic and social hubs Early years settings could become front-line communication hubs: Support preschools, crèches and community early years centres to host “EU in the Early Years” weeks – simple activities, displays and conversations with parents about how EU funding and cooperation benefit local services. Provide accessible materials in multiple languages explaining EU values of solidarity, social fairness and equal opportunities, and how these underpin investment in early learning. Involve early years practitioners as trusted community messengers, equipped with clear, nontechnical information on EU policies affecting families (child poverty, parental leave, work–life balance, inclusion). Highlight peacebuilding, inclusion and democracy from the earliest years Protecting democracy and upholding our values – could be communicated through the lived experience of young children learning to live well together: Showcase cross-border and cross-community early years projects on the island of Ireland as practical examples of EU-supported peacebuilding, demonstrating how shared provision for young children builds trust, reduces prejudice and strengthens long-term social cohesion. Promote early years curricula that nurture empathy, respect for diversity, conflict resolution and participation, and communicate these as the roots of democratic culture and European values. Ensure that Presidency communication materials emphasise children’s rights and participation, aligning with EU child-rights and fundamental rights frameworks. 4. Co-create the Presidency with citizens, families and children To build ownership over Ireland’s Presidency: Involve parents, early years educators and young children in designing logos, stories or local events linked to the Presidency. Fund small community projects in early years and family centres that explore “Our lives in the EU,” feeding their outputs into Presidency exhibitions and digital platforms. Communicate in plain language, via local media and community networks, how Presidency decisions connect back to these everyday realities. By putting quality early learning services at the centre of the story of EU membership, Ireland can communicate that the EU is about the wellbeing, opportunities and peaceful future of every child, family and community across Europe.

organisation: Early Years - the organisation for young children
response_text: Early childhood care and education is an essential public good that upholds children’s rights to care and education and supports them, their families and the wider economy. The importance of early learning and care & school-age childcare and the vital role it plays in the economy and society was evident during the Covid pandemic. Throughout the pandemic providers ensured continuity of care and education to children, supported parents, played a special role in caring for the children of essential workers, and enabled the economy to reopen at a time of unprecedented crisis. Global research shows that learning starts in infancy and in the early years, and this is the optimal stage where basic abilities can be altered. The most economically efficient time to develop these skills and abilities is in the very early years (0-5) when developmental education is most effective. Additionally, ability gaps between the advantaged and disadvantaged open up early in the life of the child. If society intervenes early enough, it can affect cognitive and socio-emotional abilities and the health of disadvantaged children. Early interventions have much higher returns than other later interventions such as reduced pupil-teacher ratios, public job training, convict rehabilitation programmes, tuition subsidies or expenditure on police. Countries that invest well in early learning and care recognise improvement in: The economy: both short-term, by facilitating labour, in particular of working women (mothers and grandmothers), and long-term through the upskilling of the future workforce Mental and physical health for children and families, including less at-risk behaviours Social welfare and criminal justice, less family violence and social crime Educational achievement, including better outcomes of young children at-risk Earlier identification of and support for special educational needs and disabilities.

sector: International education; language learning; skills development
response_text: Ireland’s 2026 Presidency presents an opportunity to advance a people-centred and future-oriented Europe, grounded in skills, inclusion, and balanced economic development. We suggest three interconnected thematic priorities: 1. Skills for a Competitive and Inclusive Europe Language and communication skills underpin labour mobility, lifelong learning, and economic competitiveness. The Presidency should highlight skills development as a cross-cutting enabler of the EU’s green, digital, and social transitions, with language learning recognised as foundational to participation in education, training, and employment across borders. 2. Cohesion, Regional Development and Community Resilience EU growth must be geographically balanced and socially inclusive. Education and mobility initiatives that bring international learners into regional and rural communities deliver tangible economic and social benefits while strengthening European cohesion. Ireland is well placed to champion policies that connect education, regional development, and local employment. 3. European Cooperation through Education and Mobility Cross-border cooperation in education strengthens shared European values, intercultural understanding, and economic integration. The Presidency should reinforce the role of Erasmus+ and complementary mobility pathways as engines of social cohesion, youth opportunity, and European identity. Together, these themes reflect Ireland’s strengths while serving the wider interests of the Union, supporting a Europe that is skilled, connected, and resilient.

sector: International education; language learning; skills development
response_text: The Irish Presidency should prioritise progress in the following policy areas: Education, Youth, Culture and Sport (EYCS): Strengthen implementation and future planning for Erasmus+, with particular attention to language preparation, inclusion, and access for learners from diverse socio-economic backgrounds. Advance recognition of non-formal and short-term learning pathways, including language education, as part of lifelong learning and skills strategies. Competitiveness and Skills (COMPET / EPSCO): Support initiatives that link education, skills, and workforce mobility, recognising language competence as a prerequisite for effective labour mobility and productivity. Encourage coherence between education policy, skills agendas, and SME development. Regional Development and Cohesion: Highlight the role of education-related activity in supporting regional economies, tourism, housing demand management, and local employment. Promote evidence-based approaches to measuring the regional economic and social impact of education and mobility programmes. The Presidency should aim to build consensus around education and mobility as strategic investments in Europe’s long-term competitiveness and cohesion, rather than solely social expenditure.

sector: International education; language learning; skills development
response_text: The Council can deliver meaningful impact by ensuring that EU policies are experienced locally by citizens and communities. For individuals, accessible education and mobility pathways enhance employability, confidence, and cultural understanding. For businesses—particularly SMEs—language skills support trade, recruitment, and cross-border collaboration. For communities, international learners contribute to local economies, sustain employment, and foster intercultural exchange. The Irish Presidency can champion policy coordination that: Connects EU education and mobility programmes with regional development objectives. Supports SMEs and local service providers that enable education and mobility ecosystems. Encourages data-driven policymaking to demonstrate the tangible benefits of EU initiatives at community level. This approach reinforces public trust by linking EU decision-making to everyday economic and social outcomes.

sector: International education; language learning; skills development
response_text: Communication should focus on real people, real places, and real outcomes. Ireland’s Presidency can highlight stories of students, educators, workers, and communities who directly benefit from EU cooperation. Education and mobility programmes provide visible, relatable examples of EU value: young people studying abroad, skills gained, local jobs supported, and lifelong connections formed. Practical measures could include: Presidency-linked events showcasing EU-supported education and mobility in regional locations. Clear, accessible messaging connecting EU policy decisions to lived experiences. Engagement with schools, learners, and communities as active participants in the Presidency narrative. This approach strengthens citizen ownership and reinforces the EU as a shared project.

sector: International education; language learning; skills development
response_text: English Education Ireland would also like to note that we are currently chairing and coordinating an informal working group of national representative bodies for language education across several EU Member States. This group brings together counterparts from different linguistic and geographic contexts, including associations representing English, Italian, Spanish, French and other language education providers. The objective of this collaboration is to develop a shared, evidence-based narrative on the contribution of language education to European economic growth, skills development, mobility, and regional cohesion. The group is working to align data on student numbers, economic impact, regional distribution, and participation in EU mobility programmes, and to identify common policy challenges and opportunities at EU level. This cooperation reflects the inherently cross-border nature of language learning and international education, and demonstrates the capacity of the sector to engage constructively with EU institutions in a coordinated and solution-oriented manner. It also mirrors the broader objectives of the EU Strategic Agenda 2024–2029 in strengthening cooperation, competitiveness, and social cohesion across Member States. As Ireland prepares for its Presidency of the Council of the European Union in 2026, this existing EU-level collaboration offers a practical foundation for informed dialogue with policymakers and institutions. Our association, together with our European counterparts, would welcome the opportunity to support the Presidency through data-sharing, stakeholder insights, and structured engagement aligned with the priorities of the Council configurations on education, skills, competitiveness, and regional development.

The criticality of Skills for a competitive European economy: The September 2024 publication of Mario Draghi’s report on European Competitiveness has raised existential questions around the future of the European economy and business competitiveness which will continue to dominate policy debates when Ireland assumes the rotating EU Presidency in 2026. Among Draghi’s recommendations is the need for a fundamental rethink of the EU’s approach to upskilling and skills policy. Draghi argues that EU competitiveness and the success of the EU’s social model requires a labour force endowed with the correct knowledge and skills, and that skills are the foundation of a thriving and competitive economy. The availability of a highly skilled workforce is fundamental to Ireland’s and Europe’s shared competitiveness and the achievement of the green and digital transitions. At present the EU is experiencing a skills shortage in strategic sectors which is hampering businesses’ ability to compete at the global level and the Draghi report highlighted that 54% of European businesses consider skills shortages to be among their most pressing challenges. The launch of the Union of Skills within the first 100 days of the new European Commission term by Commissioner Minzatu, alongside the formation of a dedicated Intergroup on Skills policy in the European Parliament, demonstrates the growing importance of Skills on the EU policy agenda. Access to a highly skilled workforce is a long-standing feature of Ireland’s economic success. Over decades, Ireland has demonstrated how sustained investment in education and workforce development can serve as the foundation of national prosperity and driving force behind FDI. Across Europe, businesses face growing difficulty accessing the skills they need to scale, innovate, and compete globally. Key sectors include AI and digital technologies and green and renewable energy industries. These shortages constrain productivity, delay critical infrastructure and climate projects, weaken innovation performance, and reduce Europe’s strategic autonomy. The Irish Presidency can play a transformative role by placing access to skills at the core of the EU’s competitiveness agenda. Ireland is unique among EU member states in having the dedicated workforce development agency, Skillnet Ireland, which focusses on boosting economic competitiveness through upskilling, with over 25 years' experience. In 2024, Skillnet Ireland was accredited as ‘International Best Practice’ across upskilling agencies from 47 countries by the European Commission as part of the ‘Pact for Skills’ initiative for the organisation’s impact on boosting economic performance through upskilling and its impact on the individual learner and green and digital transitions. Throughout the EU Presidency term, Ireland can draw on our country’s leading reputation in forging higher education partnerships between industry and academia to develop flexible learning pathways, with a view to shaping a European approach to upskilling that is accessible to learners and aligned with the needs of business. For Ireland, ensuring continued access to a skilled, adaptable workforce is central to maintaining its economic prosperity, increasing productivity levels in existing industries, and maintaining growth into the future. Championing a skills-driven competitiveness agenda, Ireland can help steer the EU toward a stronger, more dynamic, and more resilient economic future, while reinforcing one of Ireland’s enduring strategic advantages.

A central priority for the Irish Presidency of the Council in 2026 should be to secure an ambitious outcome in the negotiations on the next Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF), with a clear and protected allocation for skills policy. Skills are the backbone of Europe’s competitiveness, resilience, and social cohesion. Ensuring that the next MFF provides stable, predictable, and ring-fenced funding for skills is essential not only for Ireland but for the long-term strategic capacity of the European Union. Why skills must be ring-fenced in the next MFF: As Europe works to meet the challenges of the green and digital transitions that require unprecedented investment in the European workforce, access to employees with the necessary skills remains one of the most pressing challenges facing European businesses according to the Draghi report. Concerningly, Europe’s skills shortage is most pressing in critical sectors such as renewable energy, construction, AI and digital technologies, cybersecurity, health, and advanced manufacturing. The upcoming Multiannual Financial Framework will set Europe’s path to meeting these challenges over the coming years and without necessary funding, member states will struggle to deliver the workforce development initiatives at the necessary scale. Ring-fencing funding for upskilling within the MFF will ensure programmes such as the European Social Fund+, Erasmus+, the Just Transition Fund, and digital skills initiatives have the financial capacity to deliver real impact. For Ireland, where economic success has long depended on a strong and adaptable talent base and constant access to upskilling opportunities, securing this outcome is fundamental to preserving the country’s competitiveness and continued attractiveness to investment. As part of the MFF agenda, the Irish Presidency should focus on advancing files that underpin Europe’s talent pipeline, including the strengthening of ESF+ as the primary EU instrument for skills and employment. The overarching objective should be to secure a robust MFF that secures protected funding to skills policy, ensuring that long-term EU policy priorities translate into meaningful national action. Specifically, the Irish Presidency should aim to: Guarantee ring-fenced funding for skills within ESF+ and other relevant programmes. Ensure that skills funding is flexible enough to respond to labour market needs. Prioritise funding mechanisms that support upskilling in SMEs and regional development particularly those which incorporate industry need in order to maximise their relevance to European businesses. • Embed skills as a cross-cutting requirement in all major EU funding programmes from cohesion to climate action to digitalisation. By championing protected investment in skills, Ireland can shape an MFF that strengthens Europe’s competitiveness, supports sustainable growth, and ensures all access to upskilling across the EU over the coming years.

sector: Animal Rights, Irish Food System, Transition to a healthy, sustainable plant based food system.
geography:
National Organisation with some links to EU vegan organisations including the European Vegetarian Union and ProVeg.
The European Vegetarian Union (EVU) is the umbrella association of 48 civil society organisations in 29 countries. The EVU represents the voice of the growing number of European consumers shifting towards a more plant-based diet. As such, we advocate for a favourable food environment that makes it easier to choose as well as produce more plant-based foods. www.euroveg.eu  

ProVeg International, member of EVU, is a food awareness organisation working to transform the global food system by promoting plant-based foods and meat alternatives.
response_text: We believe that Ireland should focus on the following inter-connected high-level thematic areas. Animal Rights We call on the Irish Government to for Animal Rights to be enshrined in EU legislation which would prevent the use of other species by to exclude, as far as is possible and practicable, all forms of exploitation of, and cruelty to, animals for food, clothing or any other purpose Food System Climate Action – Creating an EU Plant Based Action Plan. 38% of Irelands GHG emissions comes from the Agriculture Sector while the primary sectors of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry generate only about 1.2% of Ireland’s GDP. The agri-food sector generates about 8-10/ of Ireland’s GDP. Ireland needs to transition away from beef and dairy production to a veganic (organic plant based) agricultural system. Ireland needs to set up a start up fund for Plant Based Companies and create a EU Plant Based Action Plan. Food security and Food System Productivity is a second critical Priority. While Ireland exported about €19 billion in agri-food products we also imported about €13.5 billion. Irish tillage farmers produce 30 times the food calories of its beef farmers, which is an incredibly inefficient way to produce protein. Ireland and the EU need to transition to plant proteins and away from animal derived protein sources. Ecosystem Restoration – Ireland has one of the lowest Biodiversity Intactness Index in the world. Many species continue to go extinct and the two biggest impacts are farming and fisheries. Ireland should return 40% of the current agricultural land area back to bogs, wetlands and forest. Ireland and the EU have committeed to 30% of land and marine area being fully protected. This is a critical area of focus. Protein Diversification The development of an EU Plant-Based Action Plan was also included in the program of the Danish Presidency of the Council. We hope Ireland can continue and develop the discussions towards this Plan and include protein diversification as a key thematic priority.

sector: Animal Rights, Irish Food System, Transition to a healthy, sustainable plant based food system.
geography:
National Organisation with some links to EU vegan organisations including the European Vegetarian Union and ProVeg.
The European Vegetarian Union (EVU) is the umbrella association of 48 civil society organisations in 29 countries. The EVU represents the voice of the growing number of European consumers shifting towards a more plant-based diet. As such, we advocate for a favourable food environment that makes it easier to choose as well as produce more plant-based foods. www.euroveg.eu  

ProVeg International, member of EVU, is a food awareness organisation working to transform the global food system by promoting plant-based foods and meat alternatives.
response_text: Enshrining Animal Rights in EU Law Enshrining animal rights in EU law is a key step for a truly sustainable future for the EU. This is the main goal of the VSI as enshrined in its constitution. EU Plant-Based Action Plan Billions of animals are imprisoned and slaughtered in the EU Agricultural and Fisheries sectors. A shift to healthier, more sustainable, affordable and whole food plant based dietary pattern is essential for a successful transition to a more sustainable food system. In this sense, the Strategic Dialogue on the Future of Agriculture expressly recommended the EU Commission (EC) to “develop, by 2026, an EU Action Plan for Plant-based Foods to strengthen the plant-based agri-food chains from farmers all the way to consumers”. For more information on this topic, you can find the EU Policy Blueprint here. This was endorsed by 130+ organisations representing farmers, consumers, health, animal welfare and environmental interests Common Agriculture Policy and Common Market Organisation Regulation The discussions on the next Common Agriculture Policy (CAP) and revision of the Common Market Organisation(CMO) will take form during the Irish Presidency. This presents key opportunities to influence the agri-food sector at the EU level, and support EU Farmers, Producers and Consumers. Under the next CAP framework, we strongly call on the upcoming Presidency to hold discussions on the topics of protein diversification and creating opportunities for farmers producing, or looking to produce plant-based foods. We see some potential in the following proposals by the European Commission: Diversification support under agri-environmental and climate actions; Transition help under agri-environmental and climate actions; Capping of direct payments and redistribution with a focus on smaller holdings and more sustainable farming models; Investment support focusing on contribution to the overall resilience of European agriculture; New support schemes for young farmers, including a starter-pack; The creation of a mandatory protein sector under the Common Market Organisation (CMO) Regulation (recognition of producer organisation, access to sectoral interventions, marketing standards, promotion policy) Public Procurement Public procurement policies, accounting for 15% of the EU GDP, can play a central role in leveraging public money to shape a more sustainable EU food system. Overall, we strongly believe that by prioritising plant-based options in public procurement (PP) policies, demand will be driven towards more sustainable food products, thereby supporting EU farmers and fostering innovation in sustainable agriculture. This approach would also benefit public health, food security, farmers’ competitiveness, and the environment. EU School Scheme We would call for the phasing out of providing dairy in the EU school scheme. As a first step we call for widening the scope of eligible products under the school scheme, by including unsweetened and fortified plant-based milk alternatives. Plant based milks cater to those who cannot or choose not to consume cow's milk for medical, ethical, environmental, or taste reasons. Unsweetened and fortified plant-based milk alternatives can be a healthy part of a nutritionally varied and well-planned diet, serving as a great nutritious alternative to cow’s milk.

ProVeg International, member of EVU, is a food awareness organisation working to transform the global food system by promoting plant-based foods and meat alternatives.
response_text: An EU Action Plan for Plant-Based Foods would help to deliver on EU climate and environmental targets, improve health, profitability, resilience, and overall policy coherence while also saving costs and strengthening the EU's strategic autonomy. At the same time, innovating and investing in plant-based foods could position the EU as a global leader in competitive, resilient, and sustainable agri-food systems and provide opportunities for European farmers, businesses and SMEs. Based on the success of Denmark, which adopted a similar plan in 2023, a whole value chain approach needs to be adopted, targeting the production, consumption and financing of the EU plant-based value chain.

response_text: Currently the food system represents European Values of domination over others. Europe has a long history of colonizing other countries and now it imprisons and exploits domesticated animals and wildlife. Membership of the EU has led to an intensification of the farming and this is undermining the water quality and biodiversity of EU ecosystems. The best way to show the benefits of EU membership would be to demonstrate leadership in the critically important Food System sector. So far the EU has completely failed in this regard and the leadership is coming from countries like Denmark and the Netherlands who are encouraging a Plant Based Food System and Ecosystem Restoration.

response_text: Overall, a shift towards more plant-rich diets has untapped potential for farmers in the EU, as increasingly environmental constraints are becoming a major threat to farming livelihoods. Farmers have an important role to play in supporting protein diversification and the development of EU plant protein crop production. The above four policy interventions will be important steps in this transition, by creating a stable demand of EU-grown plant protein crops (soya, peas) for farmers (in schools and other public institutions-. Expanding the range of eligible products is also a key step towards promoting easier access to healthier and more sustainable foods.

From the energy perspective, it should embody “Advancing a Fair, Flexible, and Affordable Clean Energy Future”. This would reflect upon the progress across the European Union (EU) to date in deploying renewables, through a range of mechanisms to meet climate and energy targets, while recognising the role of the energy citizen in the energy transition. The energy-related high level thematic priorities should highlight some of the core EU objectives: developing clean, home-grown sources of electricity and the associated grids and storage capacity to bolster EU competitiveness.

Given that the legislative schedule is effectively pre-determined for the duration of the Presidency (i.e. EU Grids Package, EU Energy Security Framework), there is merit in highlighting some of the core EU energyrelated objectives. Accelerating Infrastructure – deployment of renewables, accelerating grid development, promoting flexibility and a secure, resilient electricity system. [Related proposals: European Grids Package, Connected Europe Facility] Energy Efficiency & Electrification – reduce fossil fuel consumption by promoting affordable energy efficiency and supporting electrification in transport, heating, and other sectors. [Related proposals: Heating and Cooling Strategy, Electrification Action Plan, Setting up the energy efficiency and renewable framework post-2030] Affordability (equitable and affordable transition) – with reference to the Draghi Report and the Multiannual Financial Framework negotiations, emphasise practical approaches for an affordable transition—such as joint gas purchasing, targeted subsidies, grants, tax incentives for low-income and vulnerable groups (e.g., via the Social Climate Fund), progressive cost allocation, and public infrastructure investment—to lower transition costs. [Related proposals: Multi Annual Financial Framework (MFF), European Grids Package]

The Council can most effectively influence outcomes by guiding EU initiatives toward achieving established objectives rather than setting additional targets, including but not limited to measures to enable the delivery of renewables, grids, storage, and electrification clusters. The existing legislative framework is clear in its objectives. For example, the Net-Zero Industry Act (NZIA) is a cornerstone of the EU’s Green Deal Industrial Plan, designed to accelerate the clean energy transition and strengthen Europe’s industrial base for net-zero technologies. This, along with other legislation, such as the Renewable Energy Directive, and the European Grids Package, will aim to remove bottlenecks, bolster energy security, enhance competitiveness and advance the EU’s clean technology capabilities. The timely agreement of the MFF will be key to unlocking opportunities. The two major energy files/packages likely to feature during Ireland's Presidency are of critical importance for several reasons. With respect to the European Grids Package, grids are critical to achieving climate neutrality by 2050. The investment is crucial given that electricity demand is projected to increase by 60% by 2030. The revised EU Energy Security Framework aims to strengthen the resilience and adaptability of Europe’s energy system considering new geopolitical, technological, and climate realities. It will be key to enabling the energy transition: decarbonisation and electrification increase system complexity and interdependence, requiring more robust integration of renewables, grid development, and energy storage. Notwithstanding Ireland's role as Chair tasked with advancing dialogue and compromise among Member States to progress legislative proposals, agreement on these major initiatives will modernise and expand energy infrastructure, support the clean energy transition and strengthen competitiveness within the EU.

ESB, approaching 100 years in operation, was established to manage Ireland's electricity – following the successful development of the Shannon Scheme at Ardnacrusha. In this time, Ireland’s energy landscape has transformed, with Ireland’s membership of the EU resulting in large scale investment, cleaner electricity, and greater levels of interconnection opening Ireland’s participation in an integrated energy union. The benefits of increasing levels of renewable electricity should be showcased. The continued energy transition from fossil fuels to renewables will be regionally balanced, and it is important that the scope and reach of Presidency related activities are regionally focused and encompass the breath of Ireland’s electricity landscape. There is an opportunity to showcase Ireland’s electricity generation infrastructure alongside accredited events, to host Attaché visits and Informal Ministerial events. This should also be accompanied with energy citizen outreach activities and engagement, building upon the strong, existing community engagement projects. Given the importance of continued renewables and energy infrastructure development in unlocking energy security, cost competitiveness and decarbonisation, this engagement should continue beyond the duration of the Presidency.

Simplification - to unlock Europe’s growth and competitiveness, including reviewing third party litigation funding Level playing field in financial services to enable innovation for consumers and businesses - Cybersecurity Enabling SMEs to start and scale through digital technology and innovation Enabling financial inclusion across Europe Strengthening the EU’s framework on access to data (Open Data) - Regulating AI

Review of third party litigation funding should be a key priority in order to prevent abuse of class action lawsuits. Current practices often cause costly and cumbersome class action lawsuits, which ultimately benefit the funders of these lawsuits and not the interests of consumers or SMEs, while also placing significant burden on the companies that are being targeted and the judiciary system.

Simplifying EU legislation and driving competitiveness in Europe is key, in order to keep Europe relevant in the current geopolitical landscape. In addition, both consumers and business need protection, especially as our economies become increasingly digitized. Cybersecurity is paramount, as is the protection against harmful aspects of AI, such as loss of jobs and degradation of higher education.
EU citizens need to see that policy is addressing their main needs and concerns in a meaningful way. Problems such as housing, cost of living, cyber security need to be addressed in a meaningful way.

Prevent further climate change by ending the exploration, production and use of fossil fuels. 2024 was the hottest year on record, with temperatures exceeding 1.5 degrees above pre-industrial levels for the first time (1). 2025 saw the seventh of the nine planetary boundaries which define “a safe operating space for humanity” being crossed (2). The Lancet Countdown Report 2025 states that “the health threats of climate change have reached concerning, unprecedented levels”, with delays in climate action resulting in millions of excess deaths every year (3). Climate change has been unequivocally linked to the use of fossil fuels (4), yet the fossil fuel industry continues to thrive. As well as record temperatures, 2024 saw record levels of gas emissions. At the current rate of production of fossil fuels, the world is headed for a catastrophic 2.7°C temperature rise by the end of this century. Despite decades of science-based warnings, fossil fuel production is not slowing down, to the contrary, it’s speeding up. In response to the energy crisis precipitated by Russia’s invasion of the Ukraine in 2022, governments have funneled tax-payer’s money into subsidies to keep energy affordable, amounting in some cases, to more than the entire health budget (3). In 2023, Ireland paid €4.9 billion in fossil fuel subsidies (5), coming close to the Health Service Executive’s spend on the pay and pensions of its entire clinical staff (€5.4bn) (6). Ironically, we support practices harming human health almost as much as those who work to benefit it. The energy crisis also led to a backslide of climate commitments, with some EU countries restarting the exploration of fossil fuels to reduce reliance on imported liquefied natural gas. Last month, Greece issued its first offshore oil and gas exploration license to a consortium of fossil fuel companies, paving the way to the exploitation of an estimated 200 billion cubic metres of natural gas in the Ionian Sea. Italy is also considering renewing offshore oil and gas exploration, as is Poland, following the discovery of a major offshore oil field (7). Meanwhile, the COP 30 summit could be seen as a coup for fossil fuel companies and their beneficiaries, who successfully lobbied for an agreement that failed to mention a phase-out of fossil fuels at all (8). Europe’s historic legacy of colonialism has led to deep divides that persist in modern society (9). The people of the global south suffer disproportionately from climate change, despite having contributed the least to the problem (10). With the current US administration endorsing climate denialism and withdrawing from the Paris agreement, it falls to the EU to stand in solidarity with those at the frontline of climate change, reverse the current backslide, reinvigorate commitments to climate action, and end our reliance on the consumption of fossil fuels. The injustices of the past cannot be allowed to prevail again. The world is at a crossroads, and the actions taken now will impact future generations for centuries to come.

End fossil fuel subsidies. This would release billions of euro which could be reinvested in renewable energy and sustainable public transport systems, ending our reliance on fossil fuels. While a short-term increase in fuel prices is inevitable, this may be offset by financially supporting communities in a transition to safe and renewable energy sources. Eliminating EU country’s reliance on fossil fuels and empowering countries to develop domestic renewable energy sources will enhance energy security for Europe during this and future times of instability. Renewable energy sources are about 50% cheaper than fossil fuels – so short-term costs can be offset by longer-term savings (11). The funds to support the transition are already available too – stimulus packages released by the worlds’ governments in response to the COVID pandemic amounted to 10 times what would be needed to achieve net zero emissions for the entire world by 2050 (12). Ban the exploration and production of fossil fuels. An immediate ban on the exploration of fossil fuels is imperative if we are to halt climate change, mitigate the damage already done and prevent the impending climate disaster predicted to occur by the end of this century, within the lifespans of our children and our children’s children. The first climate tipping point of no return – widespread diebacks of warm water coral reefs – has already been reached. Other tipping points – ice melt, the destruction of the Amazon rainforest, and the circulation of vital ocean currents – will follow. The collapse of the Atlantic Meridional Overturning Current (AMOC) could plunge north-west Europe into an ice-age, with a catastrophic impact on millions of lives (13). We already have everything we need to achieve this. Renewable energy sources are all around us, and there is more than enough potential to meet the world’s energy needs (11). There are also ample raw materials to support the transition to clean, renewable energy and while the extraction of materials will have its own environmental impact, it will still be a fraction of the damage being caused by burning fossil fuels (15). We are not lacking the technology or resources to transition to safe, renewable energy; what we are lacking are the political structures that could prevent bad actors from exploiting the planet and jeopardizing all our futures. What is needed is bravery, vision, and commitment. Ireland, a small country with a big voice, has an opportunity to step up and meet the defining health challenge of the 21st century, as recognized by the WHO (15). The time to act is now: in the words of former Uachtarán na hÉireann, Mary Robinson, “Climate change is a fundamental problem that we must solve and not merely pass on to the generations to come… We can’t let our children and our grandchildren look back on this critical period and say that we failed them”.

The work of the Council can positively impact the health and wellbeing of populations across the EU by conveying the urgency of the climate crisis as a health crisis and designing initiatives around such framing. Communicating the necessity in the interest in public health to shift away from fossil fuels, coupled with a transparent redirection of released funds into greener measures will not only positively impact health, but ensure awareness of said impact. Transparency and communication surrounding funds released by ending fossil fuel subsidies, and their redirection into green initiatives (supporting public and active transport schemes, renewable energy projects) ensures public buy-in and facilitates a just transition towards a sustainable lifestyle fostered by EU presidency. Certain initiatives could be implemented to fully engage communities in a just transition away from fossil fuels. These could include increasing urban green space in cities and investing in the 15-minute walkable city, which improves social, mental and physical wellbeing, in addition to economic benefits from the resulting increased commerce. This would also reduce traffic congestion and air pollution in cities, resulting in shorter commutes and cleaner air for all. Retrofitting schemes for existing housing would also assist in preventing fuel poverty from rising fuel prices. Including marginalized groups in decision-making will be key to optimizing positive impact. Low-income and migrant demographics, the elderly, are the most vulnerable to the effects of climate change, and are most often overlooked when transition policy and measures (e.g. carbon taxes) are implemented.

Underserved groups Prioritise intersectional approaches that address the needs of women most affected by inequities—including migrant women, minority ethnic groups, LGBTQ+ women, women with disabilities, older women and those experiencing socioeconomic disadvantage.. Strengthen data systems to enable disaggregation across multiple characteristics and use this evidence to design targeted interventions addressing systemic inequities. Prioritise intersectional approaches that address the needs of women most affected by inequities—including migrant women, minority ethnic groups, LGBTQ+ women, women with disabilities, older women and those experiencing socioeconomic disadvantage. Women in Leadership Ensure gender-balanced and diversity-inclusive leadership across all health governance and funding sstructures at EU, national and local levels. Establish targeted leadership pathways for women from underrepresented communities, including mentorship and professional development programmes. Introduce monitoring mechanisms to track women’s leadership representation and publish transparent annual progress reports. Young Women’s Health Develop comprehensive strategies for adolescents and young women encompassing mental health, SRHR, digital health literacy, healthy relationships and violence prevention. Promote evidence-informed, comprehensive sexuality and relationship education that supports autonomy, safety and well-being. Increase investment in early prevention and early intervention programmes tailored to young women’s needs. Ensure meaningful youth representation in policymaking and advisory processes, particularly for young women from disadvantaged backgrounds.

Page 16 of the linked policy brief (screenshot above) details the issues at stake and the EU tools to be used as instruments to influence policy: https://globalhealth.ie/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/IGHN-EIWH-Policy-Brief-FINAL_TOC-Dec-9.pdf

Ireland’s Presidency of the Council of the EU will take place at a pivotal moment, coinciding with negotiations on the next Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF). This creates a unique opportunity for the Council’s work to deliver lasting, positive impact for people, businesses and communities across the Union. By championing gender equity and social inclusion as core principles of EU funding and policymaking, the Presidency can help ensure that investments reach those most in need and strengthen social cohesion across Member States. A focus on rights-based investment in health, social protection and community resilience would improve wellbeing, reduce inequalities and support more stable, productive societies. At a time when human rights and access to essential services are under pressure globally, the Council can play a critical role in safeguarding and advancing these values within the EU. Equitable and inclusive policies also support economic stability and business sustainability by creating healthier workforces, stronger consumer confidence and more resilient local economies. Aligning Council priorities with the main recommendations of the policy brief — including embedding women’s health across the life course, strengthening inclusive data and governance, and supporting underserved communities — would help translate EU commitments into practical, measurable outcomes that benefit people and businesses alike.

The values and benefits of EU membership are best communicated when Irish citizens and the EU citizens in general can see tangible improvements in their daily lives. Public health should be framed as a cornerstone of social justice, economic resilience and democratic stability across the European Union. When people experience access to high-quality, universal and affordable healthcare, they are more likely to recognise the EU as a positive force that protects their wellbeing and promotes fairness. Universal access to quality healthcare reflects the EU’s core commitment to solidarity, equality and human dignity. At the same time, it is important to openly acknowledge growing concerns about rollbacks in women’s health and rights, both within Europe and globally. Addressing these challenges transparently, and demonstrating visible EU leadership on equity and inclusion, can build public confidence in European institutions and policy processes. A strong sense of ownership over Ireland’s Presidency can be created through the meaningful involvement of civil society in policymaking. This should include structured participation from women’s rights and women’s health organisations, global health networks such as IGHN, gender equality organisations, migrant and Roma communities, LGBTIQ+ groups, and disability and carers’ organisations. These groups bring lived experience and practical expertise that can improve the relevance, fairness and effectiveness of EU policies. Co-creation should be embedded at every stage of the Presidency, from agenda-setting to implementation and evaluation. Open consultations, participatory forums and accessible feedback mechanisms can ensure that diverse voices are heard and that policies respond to real needs. Ongoing monitoring and transparent reporting will help demonstrate accountability and build public trust in outcomes. Inclusive participation fosters trust, strengthens democratic engagement and helps citizens feel that EU decisions are not imposed from above but shaped with their involvement. By visibly embedding these principles in the work of the Council, Ireland’s Presidency can help citizens connect EU values to their own lives, increase public understanding of the benefits of EU membership and create a genuine sense of shared ownership across communities.

This submission is made on behalf of the Irish Global Health Network (IGHN) as the official organisational response to this consultation. IGHN was the organiser and co-host of the international conference IGHNxEU – Empowering Women for a Healthier Europe (Dublin, 14–15 November 2025), which brought together policymakers, health professionals, researchers and civil society to develop evidence-informed policy recommendations. Alongside this Submission Form, IGHN is providing the accompanying policy brief as official supporting material. This brief reflects the outcomes of the conference policy dialogues and represents a collective call for coordinated EU and national action to advance women’s health, gender equity and inclusive health systems across Europe. The additional information submitted sets out key policy asks, including the need to embed women’s health across the life-course in EU policy frameworks, strengthen gender-sensitive and inclusive governance, improve disaggregated data collection, and ensure sustained investment through the Multiannual Financial Framework. This summary is provided in line with the consultation requirements and should be read in conjunction with the full policy brief, which we respectfully submit as part of IGHN’s official contribution. The policy brief is available here for download and we encourage further discussion of its content: https://globalhealth.ie/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/IGHN-EIWH-Policy-Brief-FINAL_TOC-Dec-9.pdf

Human development as a critical part of the future Global Europe, should be the main priority of Ireland’s Presidency. Ireland has long been a champion for ODA and those who are furthest behind, and we are well positioned to clearly link sustainable development as a precursor to future global stability. The ‘dual objective’ of Global Europe is to foster partnerships that contribute “simultaneously to the sustainable development of partner countries and to the strategic interests of the Union”. Investing in Agenda2030 is in Europe’s strategic self-interest. It is an investment in a better and safer world, in developing new markets, in influence, and in relationships. ODA supports the development of prosperous economies and communities, and acts as an enabler to the structural shifts that are needed for countries to transform their economies in the way that Ireland has done. Ireland has the opportunity to reemphasise the founding principles of the European Consensus for Development in the European strategic external action The principles underpinning sustainable development – poverty reduction, civil society space, human rights, gender equality, climate action and peacebuilding – are all areas where Ireland already shows leadership on the world’s stage. These are the key areas where there is significant support from the Irish public, and where we have an existing, strong reputation as a voice that promotes the values and principles of a rules-based, multilateral system. This is where we can match our own expertise and values with European interests. Ireland can leverage its role as a bridge builder and demonstrate a different approach to peace and security – one that is built on a progressive policy of sustainable development, human rights and justice. The Presidency will present an important opportunity to look into future funding and long-term trajectory for development cooperation. Ireland should work to maintain focus on adequately financing development cooperation in the future, and the importance of inclusive, rights-based, sustainable financing that puts people & planet at its centre. In recognition to ensure that dialogue is undertaken to ensure the maintenance of a distinct focus on fragile and conflict affected states in considering future funding for development, with civil society as a key stakeholder in this process. Nutrition and Food Security are also strong pillars of Ireland’s overseas development policy, where we have demonstrable knowledge and expertise. The interconnectedness between climate, food security and hunger, and the importance of climate resilient and sustainable food systems for global prosperity, should be emphasised. The important role, and added value of civil society should be a cross-cutting theme in all of Ireland’s Presidency priorities. Ireland should actively demonstrate the key contribution and expertise civil society can bring to policy making, and implementation of Europe’s ambitions.

The Global Europe Instrument (Heading 3) in the upcoming MFF should be the main focus of work, and which will likely be most at risk of being cut to satisfy priorities and negotiations under other budget headings. Ireland should ensure that this is firmly on the Agenda of the Presidency, that the proposed budget is preserved and ensure 90% is devoted to ODA, reinstating minimum spending targets for fragile and conflict affected states and LDCs, counter proposals on aid conditionality and balance flexibility with predictability for partner countries. We should focus on ensuring an explicit reference to poverty reduction, and setting clear targets for human development, gender equality, climate and biodiversity and civil society. Policy coherence for sustainable development is critical. Ireland should specifically focus on the following: ● In regards to Climate action, the Irish Presidency should focus on: The post-2030 climate framework, ensuring that adaptation financing, gender action plan and just transition principles are embedded in EU law. Strengthening the EU’s Leadership by influencing Climate Finance Contributions - quality and quantity: Ireland is recognised by Least Developed Countries and Small Island Developing States as a trusted partner in climate finance negotiations and has built a strong reputation through its principled, grant-based climate finance support. To maintain influence within the climate negotiations and impact through climate action, Ireland could leverage its role in COP31 to influence the EUs approach to international climate finance contributions, while maintaining a focus on adaptation and loss and damage financing. Prioritise the external aspects of the European integrated framework for climate resilience, to support a just transition globally and highlight the inclusivity, intersectionality and interconnectedness of climate action. - With COP31 taking place during Ireland’s Presidency, work towards a substantive outcome to the SSJWA whose current 4 year mandate ends at COP31. An outcome which firstly recognises the imperative of addressing the agriculture climate finance gap and supports accessible grantbased actions for resilient and equitably transformative agriculture and food systems and secondly includes a formal decision for the continuance of work on climate action on agriculture and food security post COP31. Work closely with the Commission on the substantive implementation of the EU Civil Society Strategy in European member states, across EU institutions and in EU’s external action, including in the Global Gateway Strategy, which is critical to countering the shrinking of civil society space globally. The EU has the opportunity to respond positively to global trends by showcasing the value of a thriving, vibrant and well-resourced civic space. Ensuring the active participation of autonomous civil society in the design, implementation and monitoring of EU's strategy, including the Civil Society Platform and online knowledge hub, would set an important precedent in this regard. Prioritise Nutrition: A recent European Court of Auditor’s special report on the Commission’s support to fight hunger in Sub-Saharan Africa notes that the shift in focus from structural and persistent malnutrition to supporting value chains risks sidelining chronic nutrition crises, as nutrition is losing prominence on the EU agenda. This trend is reinforced by the Global Gateway initiative, which prioritises other sectors and does not directly address food insecurity or malnutrition. Ireland should use its presidency to put nutrition high on the EU’s political agenda. Integrating nutrition across relevant Council agendas would help reverse declining global attention and reaffirm nutrition as a foundation for sustainable development and stability. Existing EU frameworks, such as the Action Plan on Nutrition (2015–2025) and the Guidelines on Addressing Undernutrition in Emergencies, are now outdated and poorly aligned with newer EU priorities. Ireland can play a pivotal role by inviting the Commission to update its food security and nutrition policy frameworks. A renewed EU Nutrition Policy Framework is urgently needed, particularly in light of the recent reduction in U.S. foreign aid and limited willingness among other donors to fill the gap. Ireland and the EU’s N4G pledges should be amplified to support leadership on nutrition policy globally. Champion principled humanitarian aid and international humanitarian law through the COHAFA, CODEV and COHOM working party groupings: The European Commission (DG ECHO) is preparing a non-legislative Communication on humanitarian aid for Q2 2026 which is expected to focus on three areas: a Commission-wide integrated approach to fragility, international humanitarian law, and supply chains. Although much of the preparatory work on the Communication has occurred during the current Danish presidency and the Communication will be presented under the Cypriot presidency, any Council Conclusions (and potential European Parliament resolution) will fall under Ireland’s presidency. By including sufficient COHAFA agenda time for discussion and briefings from civil society organisations who engaged in the consultation processes for the Communication, Ireland can work to ensure well-informed Council Conclusions, which will be taken into account by the Commission for the implementation of the Communication on humanitarian aid.

The EU Presidency is an opportunity to highlight the importance of global citizenship, and counter mis and dis information regarding civil society in Europe. At a time of EU member states looking increasingly inward, closing space for civil society, and increased fragmentation of society within Europe, we must strongly champion the critical role of civil society and support efforts to foster global solidarity. Ireland’s principled position on ODA and humanitarian assistance provide an opportunity to show leadership through focusing on the values of peace, justice, human rights and solidarity in its agenda setting on foreign affairs matters in particular. These principles are key to security and stability, which are key elements of the EU’s strategic agenda for 2024 - 2029, and which are critical concerns to EU citizens.

EU citizens consistently support EU humanitarian aid and support EU engagement in partner countries. The Irish public in particular has been steadfast in its support and beliefs around ODA provision over the last six years, which emanates from a strong values base. Their understanding is founded in the belief that ODA provision must be based on human rights, humanitarianism, and shared humanity, demonstrating a clear public mandate for the Irish Government and Presidency to expand Ireland’s global engagement through aid, peacebuilding, and international cooperation. This is underscored by the fact the majority of the Irish public believes in Ireland's role on the international stage. 71% of the Irish public believes Ireland has a role to play in promoting peace and stability worldwide, further strengthening the call for an Irish Presidency promoting our soft power and founded in promoting humanitarianism, peacebuilding, and aid. Given the strong support for ODA in Ireland, we should emphasise the values and benefits that the EU provides globally, through its development and humanitarian funding. The Irish public, particularly young people, feel disconnected to the EU due to its lack of leadership in Gaza. This is an opportunity to show the positive work that the EU is supporting for communities affected by conflict, climate and hunger. Irish people want to see their values reflected in European policies and positions. Ireland’s strong Global Citizenship Education sector can be harnessed to communicate the values and benefits of the EU across regions, ages and demographics. In addition, Ireland can leverage the reach and influence of civil society organisations to showcase EU programmes that have had direct positive impact on Irish citizens, as well as those that have demonstrated Ireland’s and the EU’s values overseas. This will work towards further generating public awareness and empower civil society organisations to deliver this through their own networks and supporters. This would require financial support, capacity building opportunities and tangible inclusion in the formulation in the EU Presidency programme, essential to foster the required trust and goodwill needed to deliver joint communications and outreach.

In light of the shrinking space for civil society globally and the roll out of the EU’s Civil Society Strategy over the coming year, Ireland’s EU Presidency is an opportune moment to showcase the value of civil society in upholding fundamental freedoms, democracy and governance, as well as elevating policy making, towards supporting coherent and comprehensive EU and national policies. The effective inclusion of civil society in the EU Presidency spaces and processes would enhance debate and discussion and work towards ensuring that a diversity of voices and perspectives are reflected in EU Policy making. Throughout the Presidency, Ireland can demonstrate what meaningful engagement with civil society looks like. The following are some suggestions: Work with Dóchas, the Irish network for Development & Humanitarian Organisations, who are implementing a Presidency Programme with the EU Commission that is focused on global citizenship, civil society space, financing for sustainable development, climate and food security. Dóchas members include members of the Irish Emergency Alliance, and other INGO networks, can act as a link for the Irish Government to civil society organisations, and their partners in the Global South. Create opportunities for direct engagement between civil society and ministers in the margins of or during informal meetings of EU ministers being convened in Ireland. This could be through providing speaking opportunities, inclusion in social events, inviting civil society to co-design events, and/or providing for roundtable format events to allow for broader discussion on thematic areas and support engagement between political leaders and civil society representatives. As an example, the informal meeting of EU Ministers for Development (FAC-DEV), the informal meetings of the CODEV and COHAFA working parties, are key opportunities for our sector to shine a light on issues of common concern or raise specific themes outside the legislative agenda in a conversation with civil society representatives. These formats have benefited from civil society participation and resulted in enriching discussions. Consult with civil society organisations in the development of agendas for meetings and events Utilise informal meetings of working party groupings to shine a light on specific themes and provide civil society actors a platform to speak to lived experiences and perspectives, and bring in additional expertise from specific sectors to add value to the discussions. Apply the same level and depth of engagement with civil society, as we did during Ireland’s term at the UN Security Council. During this time, Ireland used its position to bring civil society voices - particularly those from the Global south - to the centre of dialogues and debates affecting them.

Digital Infrastructure

response_text: Trust and Innovation in Digital Infrastructure and Services: Reliable and innovative Digital Infrastructure underpins many of the objectives in the European Council’s Strategic Agenda 2024-2029, for a Europe that is secure, prosperous and competitive. Resilient and secure digital infrastructure ensures a level of trustworthiness, which enables consumers to choose and use electronic communications network (ECN) and services (ECS), and digital products/services with confidence. Resilience and security, along with regulatory certainty, can also foster investment and innovation, which will in turn ensure competitiveness and strengthen the Single Market. This proposed priority aligns with the European Council’s Strategic Agenda 2024-2029 (pillar two, a strong and secure Europe; and pillar three, a prosperous and competitive Europe). Connectivity is the backbone of the digital transformation, which means there is an increasing criticality and reliance on digital infrastructure. Communications, including ECN/ECS and cloud, are integral technologies to our daily lives. Access, resilience and cybersecurity are critical to ensuring the trust and confidence of consumers and businesses, a critical part of the efficient function of consumers’ work and social needs. Networks need to evolve to facilitate the proliferation of technologies (including AI and IoT) across all sectors – everything from energy, to transport, manufacturing, retail, health and agriculture. Ireland’s – indeed, Europe’s - future competitiveness depends on our capacity to respond to the pace and scale of technological change. This capacity in turn is contingent on resourcing; several pieces of EU digital legislation have led to significant increases in the remit of independent regulators. These digital regulators must be adequately equipped with additional resources, particularly at senior level, to ensure that Ireland and the EU remain a regulatory hub of choice for digital industries. A failure to deliver these resources is likely to result in significant negative consequences, including economic and reputational risks for the EU. Trust: Digital networks must be reliable, resilient and secure to foster trust among consumers/users - in particular vulnerable end-users - to choose and use digital products and services safely and with confidence. Additional consumer protection in the digital space is also a focus of the upcoming Digital Fairness Act (DFA). Regulatory certainty is also an important element for both consumers and businesses, to make decisions on expenditure and investment. Reliability and Resilience: As the response to disruption to telecommunications networks and services occasioned by extreme weather events such as storms indicates, network resilience is a prerequisite for businesses and end users. Furthermore, geopolitical challenges include assuring the security of Europe’s physical and digital communications assets in the face of malfeasance by state and non-state actors. Innovation: Competition is a key driver of both innovation and investment in high-speed digital networks. The provision of innovative solutions for the rapidly evolving digital ecosystem requires a regulatory environment that facilitates the development of effective competition and innovation to the benefit of users across Europe. Both the European Commission’s “Simpler and Faster Europe” initiative and the recently published Digital Omnibus proposal have the goal of lightening the administrative burden by making regulatory obligations easier to understand and faster to implement, without compromising consumer protection. The desired outcome is to stimulate competitiveness and innovation leading to increased economic growth. The Digital Omnibus proposes to streamline existing rules on AI, cybersecurity and data in Europe. However, and from a prosperity perspective, any simplification or other legislative measures should not lead to the lowering of users’ protection, including vulnerable end-users, or create a digital divide.

response_text: ComReg suggests that the best means to identify legislative proposals for the Irish Presidency is by reference to the three pillars and key priorities of the European Council’s Strategic Agenda 2024-2029. As Ireland’s Presidency occurs half-way through this period, it may be opportune to take stock of what has been achieved in the first two and a half years of this cycle and what remains to be done particularly with regards to digital infrastructure and services. The second pillar of this Agenda, ‘Strong & Secure’, lists among its various priorities: Strengthen resilience, preparedness, crisis prevention and response capacities Fight against organised crime (note - which includes cybercrime) The third pillar of this Agenda, ‘Prosperous & Competitive’, lists among its various priorities: A deeper single market, notably for energy, finance and telecommunications The green and digital transitions, including a genuine energy union and investment in game-changing digital technologies in Europe Digital Networks Act (DNA) Of particular interest to ComReg is the draft Digital Networks Act (DNA), due in January 2026. Europe’s future competitiveness depends on our capacity to respond to the pace and scale of technological change. This legislative proposal (due January 2026) will aim to reinforce competitiveness and drive a more integrated single market, while addressing challenges to the deployment of advanced networks, such as fibre, 5G/ 6G and cloud-based infrastructure. Ireland has been a key Member State in informing the European Commission’s thinking regarding many aspects of this upcoming legislation concerning digital networks/infrastructure. The DNA will also address how to tackle barriers for cross-border business operations, boost innovation and increase investment in the European electronic communications sector. These objectives will ultimately also benefit consumers/users of electronic communications networks and services, alongside the additional vertical consumer protections, and horizontal consumer protections that will be covered in another EU legislative proposal - the upcoming Digital Fairness Act (DFA). Digital Omnibus and Digital Omnibus on AI Regulation Proposal If implemented, the Digital Omnibus proposal would affect the regulatory obligations regarding AI (AI Act), cybersecurity (including for NIS2, CER, EU Digital Identity) and data (including Data Act). Clarity regarding these two simplification proposals will be crucial during the time of the Irish Presidency to provide regulatory certainty for both industry and for consumers /end users. Simplification should not be conflated with the concept of ‘reregulation’ and furthermore should not lead to the lowering of users’ protection, in particular vulnerable ones. For cybersecurity, simplifying reporting may ease the regulatory burden for industry but coordination will be required to ensure consistent and cohesive understanding across relevant regulatory bodies.

response_text: By ensuring that the Digital Networks Act (DNA) is brought to fruition in a way that facilitates trust and innovation in digital infrastructure while continuing to ensure adequate consumer protections, including people with disability, this will have a positive impact for people, businesses and communities across the EU who rely on secure and robust connectivity networks and products and services so enabled. We suggest that the Irish Presidency can make the most substantial positive impact by driving forward the three pillars of the Strategic Agenda 20/24/2029 which distil down to democracy, security, prosperity. It would be useful to distinguish between the following: New projects to commence during the Irish Presidency. Existing projects to advance during the Irish Presidency. As the Council, like any organisation, does not have unlimited resources and it is necessary to acknowledge this constraint it would help to identify actions that are realistically achievable and to set reasonable timeframe for achieving them.

response_text: A challenge for institutions like the European Council and the European Commission is that citizens may only engage with them when perceived issues or inadequacies arise or when something becomes politically contentious. The steady stream of technical improvements and regulatory refinements that quietly enhance daily life of our citizens may go unnoticed and unacknowledged. This may be because large public institutions are not always as effective at communicating their achievements or demonstrating their benefits to the wider public. This problem is often compounded by the fact that critics of those same institutions can be quite effective at getting their messages across, whether in traditional media or through social media and other channels. The Irish Presidency could address this communications gap by working to highlight the ways in which life has been made better by laws and regulations. A key challenge is to simplify complex issues and to develop and disseminate easy to understand and clear accessible messages that everyone can quickly digest and understand. Many people may reply on newspapers, television, and spend time on platforms like Facebook, Instagram, and LinkedIn to get information. These channels need to be utilised to achieve wider reach for engagement and awareness. End-users can be further engaged by highlighting ‘success stories’ of the EU to date (for example, Roam Like At Home, where you can use your mobile phone service across the EU just like you use it in your home country), and how future legislative proposals, such as the DNA, will build upon these benefits to citizens and consumers. The Irish ‘AI Summit’ scheduled to take place in October 2026 during the Presidency will be a great opportunity to showcase opportunities to be unlocked in Ireland and the EU regarding the future of AI. The Communicating Europe Initiative launched in 2025 could also be broadened. This initiative supports voluntary organisations, educational bodies, civil society groups and Local Authorities in raising awareness about the European Union and Ireland’s place within it (66 projects approved for funding to date).

response_text: The Irish Presidency should also capitalize on Ireland’s unique position as a bridge to the USA, and a close relationship with the UK, given all-island policies.

MFF negotiations: A Multiannual Financial Framework that strengthens democracies, including a focus on human rights and rule of law (both inside and outside the EU, through the Union’s multi-lateral and bilateral programmes). The renewal of the Action Plan for Democracy and Human Rights: Strong language on democracy as a guiding principle of EU foreign policy, consistent with the programming language in the next Global Europe instrument. Supporting initiatives that ensure Europe has pluralism in its political future, including advocating for safe participation in public life.

Trusted sources of information, including in media: Growing the capabilities and proliferation of trusted information sources (such as citizen’s information, public libraries and trusted, arm’s-length public institutions); Strengthen flexible operational support for public interest and fact-checking media, including in the European Neighbourhood, where such funding has been drastically reduced following the withdrawal of the United States. Disinformation online: It will be crucial to remove the financial incentives for the dissemination and circulation of disinformation and other forms of online manipulation. The Irish Presidency should focus on enforcing existing legislation to ensure transparency and governance in the monetisation strategies and practices of very large online platforms (VLOPSEs).
