Recommendation systems: Ensuring that algorithms such as recommendation systems do not undermine democratic debate. To this end, users must be given more control over these systems in line with the GDPR and the DSA. User control over recommender systems: Ensure that algorithm designs, such as recommendation systems, do not undermine democratic debate – in line with the GDPR and the DSA, greater user control over these systems must be granted. Greater transparency: Creation of a transparency framework for paid political influencers within the TTPA.

Doubling down on European values, ensuring that rights and freedoms of future generations are advanced. This includes broadening the dialogue on defence and security to encompass all dimensions of future security, including the role of peacebuilding, reconstruction and human rights protection/ advancement in conflict and post-conflict regions.

Ireland can showcase good practice in participative democracy, as well as demonstrate leadership that advances EU values, especially as these relate to rights and freedoms. As set out in Europe’s Democracy Sheild, there is a need to reach communities, especially those who are disengaged or are hard to reach. Ireland’s government (Programme for Government, January 2025) has already committed to supporting the European Democracy Sheild: the EU Council Presidency provides a platform to demonstrate that support, in Ireland and across Europe, through specific initiatives.
must provide a summary of the additional information under the ‘Any other comments’ question. This summary should also be limited to a maximum of 500 words.

Taking into account the current geopolitical and socioeconomic context in Europe, we recommend that Ireland prioritise Health Protection, Citizen Safety, and Resilient Societies as core themes of its 2026 Presidency. Serious allergies and anaphylaxis are rising across Europe and place a growing burden on individuals, schools, workplaces, and public services. Addressing them fits naturally within broader objectives to protect citizens’ wellbeing and reduce preventable health risks. A Resilient and Prepared Europe The EU must be equipped to respond to emergencies—whether acute health events, natural disasters, or public safety threats. This requires harmonised emergency response systems, stronger communitylevel preparedness, and cross-border cooperation. Ireland is one of the few Member States that has taken concrete steps to improve preparedness for serious allergic reactions, including allowing pharmacists to supply emergency medicines without a prescription during anaphylactic events. This national practice demonstrates effective emergency readiness and provides a model for EU-level policy coordination, which could inform upcoming initiatives under the European Health Union framework aimed at strengthening preparedness, prevention, and rapid response across Member States. A People-Centred Union that Protects Embedding people-centred principles into EU policymaking ensures that vulnerable populations and individuals at risk of medical emergencies are not left behind. The Presidency could advance reducing health inequalities across the EU, highlighting uneven access to diagnosis, specialist care, and emergency response protocols. Positioning timely care for serious allergies and anaphylaxis within this agenda demonstrates a commitment to practical, measurable improvements in patient safety and inclusion, while protecting citizens’ rights to safety in everyday environments such as schools, childcare centres, workplaces, and public venues. 3. A Future-Oriented Europe Built on Innovation and Collaboration Ireland’s strong reputation in digital innovation offers an opportunity to promote Digital Innovation for Health, leveraging the European Health Data Space and interoperable, patient-centred tools. For individuals at risk of serious allergic reactions, seamless access to medical information across borders can prevent emergencies and support the free movement of people. The Presidency can also prioritise harmonised awareness-raising, institutional readiness, and capacity building, ensuring schools, businesses, and public institutions are equipped and trained to respond effectively to life-threatening health incidents.

Ireland could use its Presidency to champion health resilience, citizen protection, and emergency preparedness, leveraging its national leadership in anaphylaxis response as a model for EU coordination. Key priorities include: Health Protection and Emergency Preparedness Serious allergies and anaphylaxis present a growing public-health challenge. The Presidency could: Promote timely access to emergency medicines, building on Ireland’s approach where pharmacists can supply life-saving treatment without prescription. Encourage harmonised school and public-venue preparedness, using Ireland as an example. Relevant upcoming EU initiative: Global health resilience initiative (non-legislative, Q2 2026) – to strengthen EU capacity for rapid response to health crises. Digital Innovation for Health Cross-border emergencies require seamless access to patient data: Promote the European Health Data Space for secure, interoperable sharing of health information, enabling faster response to anaphylactic events across borders. Support digital tools for citizen-centred care, enhancing emergency response and patient safety. 3. Reducing Health Inequalities and Strengthening Citizen Rights The Presidency could advance equitable access to emergency care and citizen-centred policy: Link preparedness to strengthening the Child Guarantee (non-legislative, Q2 2026) and Citizens omnibus (legislative, Q4 2026), ensuring children in schools, childcare centres, and communities are protected and have their rights effectively enforced. Promote intergenerational fairness through the Intergenerational fairness strategy (nonlegislative, Q1 2026), ensuring emergency preparedness and health access benefit current and future generations equally. Highlight Ireland’s model as a practical, replicable approach for other Member States. Objectives Establish a model for EU-level anaphylaxis and emergency response coordination, based on best practices of Ireland. Ensure equitable access to life-saving treatments across the EU. Promote digital innovation for preparedness, information sharing, and cross-border patient care. Strengthen citizen rights and intergenerational fairness, ensuring public health policies reflect social equity. Position health resilience as a pillar of EU citizen safety and social cohesion, demonstrating tangible improvements in public health readiness. By focusing on these targeted initiatives, Ireland can use its Presidency to deliver practical, measurable impacts on citizen safety, health equity, and cross-border emergency preparedness while reinforcing the EU’s social and legal frameworks.

The Irish Presidency has the potential to deliver significant, tangible impact for EU citizens by advancing health resilience and consumer safety. For individuals with serious allergies, policies that improve emergency response, access to medicines, and accurate allergen information can be life-saving. For people, expanded access to emergency treatment, including pharmacy-enabled emergency supply across the EU, enhances safety in daily life. Citizens with serious allergies would be better protected in schools, workplaces, sports facilities, cultural venues, and during cross-border travel. For businesses, harmonised allergen-labelling and staff-training expectations reduce regulatory uncertainty, simplify compliance, and improve consumer trust by fostering safer public environments. For communities and institutions, EU-supported readiness measures ,such as common school protocols, public-venue guidelines, and accessible training ,would significantly reduce preventable emergencies, supporting all three Alliance objectives. Replicating Ireland’s best practice on emergency medicine access would ensure that life-saving intervention is available regardless of where a reaction occurs, reducing inequalities across Member States.

Ireland has a strong opportunity to communicate the value of EU membership by focusing on everyday benefits and practical improvements that resonate directly with citizens. The 2026 Presidency can show how EU cooperation protects people, strengthens communities, and makes daily life safer—particularly in areas such as emergency preparedness for serious allergies and anaphylaxis. Highlight Practical Examples of EU Solidarity Citizens understand the EU best when they see clear, relatable outcomes. Ireland can communicate EU values by highlighting how cooperation improves safety and wellbeing, for example: Safer environments in schools, restaurants, transport and public venues. Shared health information that makes travel within the EU safer and more predictable. Harmonised allergen-labelling rules that protect consumers wherever they are. More consistent access to emergency support for serious allergic reactions. Ireland’s own approach—allowing pharmacists to supply emergency treatment during a serious allergic reaction—provides a concrete example of national leadership that improves citizen safety. Propose Council Recommendations on Emergency Readiness To strengthen public understanding of the EU’s benefits, Ireland could lead on a visible, citizen-centred initiative: Develop Council Recommendations on broader readiness and access to emergency treatment for serious allergy and anaphylaxis. This would help encourage Member States to: Improve preparedness in schools, public venues, workplaces, and transport hubs. Ensure trained responders are available across community settings. Reduce inequalities in access to time-sensitive, life-saving care. Such an initiative is easy for citizens to relate to, directly improves safety, and demonstrates EU cooperation in a human, practical way. A simple message: the EU protects people By showcasing initiatives that make everyday life safer, including better emergency preparedness for serious allergic reactions, the Irish Presidency can reinforce a clear message: EU cooperation delivers real, practical benefits for families, children, workers, and communities. This people-centred framing will strengthen public trust, build ownership, and demonstrate the concrete value of Ireland’s leadership at EU level.

In our view, Ireland’s Presidency should adopt a people--centred, future-oriented agenda that makes Europe a more attractive place to invest, build and scale the industrial and energy -transition. We would like to highlight three interlocking priorities: Moving from targets to tangible delivery should be at the heart of the Presidency. The EU has set ambitious goals on climate neutrality, circularity and strategic autonomy; the next phase must focus on making projects bankable, reducing uncertainty, and streamlining project development and permitting processes across Member States so capital can flow at the required scale and speed. Industrial decarbonisation should be explicitly linked to European security, competitiveness, and affordability. By accelerating low carbon industrial projects, resilient Critical Raw Materials (CRM) supply chains, and circular business models, the EU can simultaneously reduce dependence on external suppliers, mitigate energy price shocks and support high-quality employment across regions. The circular economy and CRM should be framed not only as environmental imperatives, but as core to Europe’s long-term industrial strategy. Harmonised and predictable rules for recycling, reuse and secondary raw materials can unlock large volumes of private investment and reduce strategic vulnerabilities in key value chains such as batteries, polymers, and fuels.

Given the limited duration of a Council Presidency, we suggest the Irish Presidency concentrate on a small number of enabling priorities where Council leadership can have an outsized impact on implementation: Permitting, zoning and project delivery for strategic industrial and decarbonisation assets Today, lengthy and fragmented permitting and zoning processes are one of the most significant deterrents to investment in industrial decarbonisation, CRM processing and circular infrastructure. We encourage the Irish Presidency to: Prioritise work in relevant Council configurations (notably TTE, ENVI, COMPET and ECOFIN) on mechanisms to streamline and harmonise permitting timelines and requirements for projects deemed of strategic European importance, including repurposing existing infrastructure to meet European climate priorities. Promote EU level benchmarks or indicative maximum timelines for permitting of qualifying projects, coupled with transparent monitoring and reporting by Member States. Explore instruments that link EU financial support and incentives to demonstrable progress on national level permitting reforms and administrative capacity. Consistent and timely implementation of existing EU legislation In areas such as biomethane, plastics recycling and broader circular economy legislation, the key challenge is not always a lack of EU-level ambition but uneven and delayed national implementation. This creates uncertainty for investors and can strand otherwise viable projects. The Presidency could support efforts to: Enhance monitoring and peer review of national transposition and implementation of key Green Deal and circular economy files Encourage the use of clear, enforceable minimum requirements and common methodologies where appropriate, to ensure that EU-wide legislation leads to predictable investment conditions rather than a patchwork of divergent national approaches. Provide political space in the Council for Member States to share best practices on effective implementation, particularly on topics such as waste-to-resource infrastructure, CRM recycling, and industrial decarbonisation support schemes. Industrial decarbonisation, CRMs and circular economy as core competitiveness priorities The Irish Presidency could use its role to ensure that industrial decarbonisation, CRM resilience and circularity are consistently treated as competitiveness and security issues, not niche environmental topics. Specific areas of focus could include: Facilitating progress on files and initiatives that support recycling and recovery of CRMs and other strategic materials. Encouraging policy coherence between energy, industrial, environmental and trade policies so that decarbonization projects are not undermined by conflicting signals. Highlighting and advancing measures that link circular economy solutions with lower lifecycle emissions and reduced import dependency.

Ireland’s Presidency can maximise positive impact by focusing on how EU-level decisions translate into tangible benefits: Linking decarbonisation to energy affordability and cost of living Communicating and delivering on the connection between industrial decarbonisation and lower, more stable energy costs will be critical for citizen support. By accelerating investment in efficient, flexible and local energy and industrial systems, the EU can: Reduce exposure to volatile fossil fuel imports; Improve energy efficiency and resource productivity; and Support lower operating costs for businesses, with benefits ultimately passed through to consumers. Supporting high-quality, regionally balanced jobs Many decarbonisation and circular economy projects are located in or near industrial regions that have faced structural economic challenges. By promoting enabling conditions for these projects, the Presidency can help support quality employment, skills development and regional regeneration, particularly in areas that might otherwise feel left behind by the transition. Providing a predictable and credible framework for investors and businesses Businesses of all sizes value predictability, speed and clarity. The Presidency can help by: Championing regulatory approaches that are proportionate, risk-based and coherent across sectors and Member States; Encouraging stable long-term frameworks over frequent, ad hoc changes; and Supporting platforms for constructive dialogue between EU institutions, Member States, investors, industry, and civil society.

To foster a sense of ownership over Ireland’s Presidency and EU membership more broadly, we suggest: Grounding communications in everyday impacts Messaging should clearly link EU-level decisions to outcomes that matter for citizens: good jobs, lower and more stable energy bills, improved local infrastructure, cleaner environments and strengthened security of supply. Case studies of concrete projects across Member States — including in Ireland — can bring this to life. Highlighting EU economic and trade benefits The Presidency has an opportunity to reaffirm how the single market, common standards and shared investment frameworks enable countries like Ireland to attract investment, grow exports and participate in resilient European value chains. This narrative can help counter perceptions that EU rules are only burdensome rather than enabling. Engaging local actors and investors in the conversation Involving local authorities, community organisations, businesses and investors in Presidencylinked dialogues and events can help citizens see that EU policy is something they can influence and benefit from, rather than something distant and abstract. In our experience, direct engagement between EU institutions and the investment community is less common in Europe than in some other jurisdictions; creating structured opportunities for such engagement during the Presidency would be highly valuable.

We recognise that the Council Presidency has a limited mandate and timeframe, and that its role is often more about agenda setting, convening and signalling than adopting entirely new legislation within six months. Precisely because of this, Ireland is well-placed to use its Presidency to: Elevate implementation, permitting reform and investment conditions as cross-cutting priorities across Council configurations; Encourage stronger, more systematic dialogue between EU institutions, Member States and investors on how to unlock capital for decarbonization, CRMs and the circular economy; and Showcase Ireland’s own experience as an open, investment-friendly economy and apply lessons learned to support a more competitive and cohesive European Union.

European competitiveness through investment in people Ireland's Presidency should position European competitiveness through investment in people as its central theme. In an era of rapid AI transformation and growing global competition for talent, Europe's greatest competitive advantage lies not in technology alone, but in ensuring its workforce can adapt, innovate, and thrive. AI is already changing how people work. Indeed's AI at Work Report reveals that 4 out of 5 jobs will be affected by AI in some way. For most workers, this means learning to work alongside and orchestrate AI rather than being replaced by it, as our most recent analysis reveals only a tiny fraction of skills (0.7%) are on track to total automation. The question is not whether AI will change employment, but whether European workers will be equipped to adapt and harness the opportunities these technologies create. Ireland should champion workforce adaptability as a key Presidency priority. Two legislative initiatives provide ideal vehicles for this agenda: the Quality Jobs Act and the Fair Labour Mobility Package. Together, these strengthen the current workforce whilst making the Single Market more attractive to talent. Quality Jobs Act The European Commission's Quality Jobs Roadmap presents a crucial opportunity to integrate workforce quality and adaptability into the heart of EU employment policy, with the Act poised to modernise existing rules on worker protection while fostering competitiveness. Ireland should use its Presidency to advance the Quality Jobs Act, ensuring it delivers on key areas identified in the Roadmap such as the Skills Portability Initiative and intergenerational fairness. Responsible use of algorithmic management Indeed supports the EU’s efforts to ensure the digital transition in the workplace upholds transparency, fairness, and worker protection. The Act’s focus on algorithmic management and AI at work should reflect these priorities while also avoiding regulatory overlap with issues already addressed by the AI Act, the GDPR, and existing labour law, as recognised by the Roadmap. The Quality Jobs Act should align with EU objectives for competitive, innovation-friendly labour markets that benefit both jobseekers. Job transitions and a skilled workforce Skills and quality jobs are key drivers of EU growth. According to the Indeed Hiring Lab’s 2025 AI at Work Report 2025, nearly half (46%) of the skills in a typical job posting fall into the categories of “hybrid transformation” or “full transformation. Under the report’s framework - the GenAI Skill Transformation Index (GSTI) “hybrid transformation” refers to skills where generative AI can perform the bulk of routine tasks, but human involvement remains essential for oversight, interpretation, handling exceptions, and ensuring ethical or legal compliance. In other words: hybrid transformation is not about full automation or replacement, but about reshaping how work gets done and integrating human judgment with AI-augmented efficiency. In that context, 46% of the ~2,900 commonly listed work-skills assessed by Hiring Lab are classified as being at risk of such hybrid transformation. Given this, “AI-driven hybrid transformation” should be understood as a shift toward AI-augmented workflows in which humans and AI collaborate: AI handles repetitive or automatable tasks, while humans continue to contribute the uniquely human skills, such as judgment, oversight, creativity, and interaction, to ensure quality, adaptability, and resilience. This distinction is important: rather than seeing AI as replacing workers, the GSTI shows AI as a partner - reshaping tasks and required skills, and creating demand for new combinations of human and AI-complementary capabilities which, if managed effectively, could foster a workforce rich in critical thinking, managerial competency and creativity. However, given these transformative changes, workers need targeted support in the context of a generally weaker labour market. The Ireland Presidency should advance the Skills Guarantee to help workers in restructuring sectors transition into strategic growth areas. For example, an increase in cybersecurity related and AI ethicist roles on our platform which demonstrates one pathway for workers facing transformation in perhaps tech or tech-adjacent vocations. The Quality Jobs Act should also provide incentives for employers adopting skills-based hiring that prioritises competencies over formal qualifications. Indeed believes that skills-based hiring can open up a much broader talent pool and foster a flexible labour market. Fair Labour Mobility package Labour mobility is a cornerstone of European competitiveness. Indeed's research reveals European workers are three times more internationally mobile than their American counterparts: 16.7% have foreign work experience, compared with 5.1% in the United States. Ireland stands out with 41.9% international mobility, second only to Switzerland at 50.9%. This positions Ireland uniquely to champion policies that strengthen this competitive advantage. Skills Portability Initiative The Single Market’s full potential will be unlocked by circulating skills. Cross-border work continues to rise, with 1.8 million people commuting or teleworking across borders in 2023, demonstrating the critical need for the Skills Portability Initiative to make it easier to recognise and accept skills and qualifications across the EU, independently of where they were acquired, and promote the use of interoperable digital credentials. Today, having skills and qualifications understood by employers in other EU Member States remains challenging, particularly as diplomas are often paper-based. When a worker in Cork can have qualifications recognised in France or Germany more easily, when an SME in Galway can recruit skilled workers from across Europe without administrative barriers, EU membership's value becomes immediately clear and personal. The initiative should build on existing tools for transparency of skills and qualifications, promote interoperable digital credentials, and make it easier for qualifications to be understood and accepted across the EU, independently of where they were acquired.
areas? Quality Jobs Act, Fair Labour Mobility Package, Skills Portability Initiative, Simplification

Ireland's Presidency presents a critical opportunity to position European competitiveness as central to the EU's future, anchored in investment in people. The Quality Jobs Act and Fair Labour Mobility Package address real challenges: the transformation of work driven by AI, regional economic disparities, and the need to ensure the Single Market remains an attractive destination for talent.

By advancing these initiatives, Ireland can communicate the values and benefits of EU membership in the most powerful way possible through tangible improvements in daily lives. When citizens see how EU membership enables them to access better jobs across the Single Market, develop AI-augmented skills recognised throughout the EU, build careers across borders without administrative friction, and work flexibly from regional areas, the value of EU membership becomes clear and personal.

respondent_type:
Family Carers Ireland is a national charity dedicated to supporting Ireland’s 500,000+ family carers.
[REDACTED UNDER GDPR]
geography: Family Carers Ireland operates on a national basis and is also a member of Eurocarers, the European network that brings together carers’ organisations as well as universities and research institutes across Europe. This submission is presented from the perspective of both Family Carers Ireland and Eurocarers.
response_text: Family Carers Ireland and Eurocarers urge the Irish Government to place family and informal carers at the centre of its presidency of the EU Council, prioritizing policies and legislation that will help achieve high-quality, affordable care services for people of all ages, that supports both care receivers and caregivers and promotes gender equality in care responsibilities. Approximately 80% of all long-term care in the EU is provided by informal carers with an economic value estimated to be €350bn per year (2.5% of EU GDP). The long-term care budget would have to double if this informal care had to be replaced by minimal formal care. Rationale: Demographic projections indicate a significant increase in demand for long-term care across the EU, with the number of people requiring care expected to rise from 30.8 million in 2019 to 38.1 million by 2050. This surge is driven by higher life expectancy and a growing share of the population aged 80 and over, creating challenges such as workforce shortages, rising costs, and the need for policy adjustments to ensure sustainable care systems. However, Europe is heavily reliant on informal care to meet the care needs of its citizens due to insufficient formal care services. This dependence on informal care carries substantial social and economic consequences for unpaid carers, including financial hardship, reduced employment opportunities, pension penalties and potential negative impacts on their physical health and wellbeing. There is an increasing recognition of the crucial role informal care plays in supporting both functional societies and the economy. This importance is highlighted by numerous reports from a range of EU institutions and international organizations, including DG EMPL, ECFIN, Santé, RTD, Connect, JUST, as well as the European Parliament, Committee of the Regions, European Economic and Social Committee, EIGE, Eurofound, WHO and OECD. These reports collectively emphasize that informal care (i) Reduces pressure on formal health and social care systems (ii) Contributes significantly to economic stability by enabling workforce participation (iii) Supports the social and emotional well-being of both care recipients and caregivers and (iv) Plays a critical role in upholding human dignity, particularly for older persons and people with disabilities. Central Proposal: In addition to the broad recommendations set out in this submission, Family Carers Ireland and Eurocarers propose, as a flagship event, hosting a two-day conference in Brussels as part of Ireland’s Presidency. The conference will explore informal care across Europe and include representatives from the Irish Government, member states, the European Parliament, and EU institutions. A draft programme for the two-day event is attached. Themes: Building a Caring Europe Together: Ensuring quality, affordable and accessible care services to improve the situation of informal carers and the people they care for, promoting person-centered care and championing the rights of the care workforce, Empowering Lives, Upholding Dignity: Advancing the rights of informal carers, children, people with disabilities, older people and all persons who need care across the EU. Aligned to: EU Council Strategic Agenda 2024 – 2029; European Pillar of Social Rights (Pillar2 2, 9, 12,15, 16, 17, 18); EU Care Strategy; UNCRPD.

respondent_type:
Family Carers Ireland is a national charity dedicated to supporting Ireland’s 500,000+ family carers.
[REDACTED UNDER GDPR]
geography: Family Carers Ireland operates on a national basis and is also a member of Eurocarers, the European network that brings together carers’ organisations as well as universities and research institutes across Europe. This submission is presented from the perspective of both Family Carers Ireland and Eurocarers.
response_text: In November 2017, the European Parliament, the Council, and the European Commission proclaimed the European Pillar of Social Rights, establishing 20 principles aimed at supporting well-functioning and fair labour markets and welfare systems. Several of these principles are particularly relevant to promoting the rights and well-being of informal carers, older people and persons with disabilities: Principle 18 – Long-Term Care: Affirms the right to affordable, high-quality long-term care services, particularly home care and community-based services. During Ireland’s Presidency the focus should be on: Support and recognition of informal carers through work–life balance measures, financial supports, respite, training, and counselling. Supporting Member States to move from institutional care to home and community-based alternatives. Expanding personal assistance, respite services, day centres, and community supports. EU quality guidelines for long-term care. Person-centred care planning that respects individual preferences independent living. Development of integrated care pathways. Fair and sustainable financing models that protect households and promote EU monitoring of affordability indicators. Improving working conditions, wages and contractual stability of care workers and develop EU standards for training, skills recognition, and continuous learning. Mobilisation EU funding programmes to invest in long-term care reforms. Principle 2 – Gender Equality: Promotes equality of treatment and opportunities between women and men in all areas. During Ireland’s Presidency the focus should be on: Advancing women’s rights through the integration of gender perspectives across all policies, and targeted measures for empowering women. Pay transparency to ensure equal pay for equal work, gender reporting and penalties for employers guilty of pay discrimination. Principle 9 – Work-Life Balance: Supports the right to balance professional and caring responsibilities. During Ireland’s Presidency the focus should be on: Work Life Balance Initiatives that promote a good balance between care, family and work commitments and equal opportunities for women and men in the workplace and at home. Implementation and promotion of the Work-life Balance Directive across members states. Develop measures to protect carers from discrimination and dismissal, encourage the gender-balanced use of leave, and supports the use of European funds to improve care services. Principle 10 – Health and Safety at Work: Emphasises workers’ rights to a high level of protection for health and safety. During Ireland’s Presidency the focus should be on: Ensuring fair pay and stable contracts for professional care workers. EU-level guidance on adequate minimum wages and wage structures that reflect the skill, responsibility, and emotional labour of care work. Reducing reliance on zero-hour, precarious contracts, ensuring predictable hours and income stability. Principle 17 – Inclusion of Persons with Disabilities: Recognises the right of people with disabilities to participate in the labour market and in society, including access to enabling services. During Ireland’s Presidency the focus should be on: Ensuring access to enabling services such as personal assistance, assistive technologies and mobility aids, housing, rehabilitation, OT and community-based services and respite. Enforcement of EU accessibility laws more consistently across Member States. Improve inclusive labour market policies. Strengthening social protection and income supports for disabled people and ensure disability benefits, allowances, and pensions do not penalise people for entering work. Advancement of independent living and deinstitutionalization across member states. These principles collectively provide a framework to ensure social protection, equality, and dignity for vulnerable groups, including older persons and people with disabilities, while fostering inclusive economic and social participation.

respondent_type:
Family Carers Ireland is a national charity dedicated to supporting Ireland’s 500,000+ family carers.
[REDACTED UNDER GDPR]
geography: Family Carers Ireland operates on a national basis and is also a member of Eurocarers, the European network that brings together carers’ organisations as well as universities and research institutes across Europe. This submission is presented from the perspective of both Family Carers Ireland and Eurocarers.
response_text: The Treaty on European Union affirms the core values that guide the EU: respect for human dignity, freedom, equality, the rule of law, and the protection of human rights, including the rights of minorities. These principles support a society rooted in solidarity, justice, non-discrimination, and equality between women and men—all of which are essential to how we design and deliver care. As Ireland assumes the Presidency of the EU Council, there is an important opportunity to place informal care and long-term care at the centre of the European agenda. By grounding policy-making in the Union’s values, the Presidency can help ensure that carers and those who rely on long-term support are treated with dignity, that their rights are protected, and that care systems across Europe reflect fairness, inclusion, and shared responsibility. Ireland’s ongoing practice of social dialogue and civic participation is an approach to good governance that we can promote at EU level. With the current negotiation on the Multi-Annual Financial Framework (MFF) 2028-2034, Ireland’s Presidency of the EU can play a key role in the finalisation of the MFF to preserve the financial sustainability of a social and democratic Europe. In addition to the recommendations set out in this submission, Family Carers Ireland and Eurocarers also propose hosting a two-day conference in Brussels as part of Ireland’s Presidency. The conference will explore informal care across Europe and include representatives from the Irish Government, member states, the European Parliament, and EU institutions. A draft programme for the two-day event is attached.

respondent_type:
Family Carers Ireland is a national charity dedicated to supporting Ireland’s 500,000+ family carers.
[REDACTED UNDER GDPR]
geography: Family Carers Ireland operates on a national basis and is also a member of Eurocarers, the European network that brings together carers’ organisations as well as universities and research institutes across Europe. This submission is presented from the perspective of both Family Carers Ireland and Eurocarers.
response_text: There are a number of practical, effective ways to communicate the values and benefits of EU membership and to foster a sense of shared ownership among citizens during Ireland’s Presidency of the Council of the EU: Connect EU Values to Everyday Life: People relate to concrete impacts, not abstract principles. Highlight how EU values - solidarity, equality, freedom, and human rights - translate into everyday benefits such as roaming-free mobile charges; consumer protections; workers’ rights including parental leave and anti-discrimination laws; improved healthcare cooperation, including cross-border care; greater investment in rural broadband, transport, and climate action funded by EU programmes. When citizens see that EU values improve daily life, they connect more strongly to membership. Make the Irish Presidency visible and participatory: Instead of presenting the Presidency as something happening “in Brussels,” bring it home to Ireland. Host local town-hall events, listening sessions, and thematic dialogues (e.g., disability and care, climate, rural development, digital skills); Create opportunities for citizens to suggest priorities or submit ideas; Involve youth councils, NGOs, carers’ organisations, disability groups, and local volunteer networks. The more people feel consulted, the more they feel ownership. Promote co-design with NGOs and civil society: Invite NGOs, carers’ organisations, youth groups, disability and older persons organisations to co-host events; participate in Presidency working groups; lead thematic campaigns (e.g., “Ireland and Europe in 2050”), thus embedding the Presidency in community life. Family Carers Ireland, along with partner agencies, are very happy to support and amplify any events relating to family carers. Proposed EU Event: Celebrating Informal Carers Across Europe: Family Carers Ireland and Eurocarers strongly encourage Ireland to host a European conference in Brussels to celebrate the invaluable contributions of informal carers and to plan for the future of long-term care provision across the EU. The event would bring together representatives from the Irish government, EU Member States, caring organisations, and EU institutions, providing a platform for dialogue, knowledge exchange, and collaboration. Under the theme “Building a Caring Europe Together”, the conference would highlight best practices, innovative solutions, and policy initiatives that support carers and ensure sustainable, high-quality long-term care throughout Europe. By showcasing Ireland’s leadership on this issue during its EU Presidency, the event would reinforce the Union’s shared values of solidarity, human dignity, and social inclusion, while fostering a sense of collective responsibility for the future of care in Europe. A draft programme for the two-day event is attached.

respondent_type:
Family Carers Ireland is a national charity dedicated to supporting Ireland’s 500,000+ family carers.
[REDACTED UNDER GDPR]
geography: Family Carers Ireland operates on a national basis and is also a member of Eurocarers, the European network that brings together carers’ organisations as well as universities and research institutes across Europe. This submission is presented from the perspective of both Family Carers Ireland and Eurocarers.
response_text: Long-Term Care in the European Union: Challenges and Priorities Long-term care systems across the EU vary in design and maturity, but they face several common challenges: Rising Demand: The number of people needing long-term care is projected to rise from 30.8 million in 2019 to 38.1 million by 2050. Demographic changes—fewer children, families living further apart, and more women in the labour market—threaten the sustainability of traditional LTC models that rely heavily on informal carers. Unmet Needs: Many people’s care needs remain unmet due to limited LTC services, insufficient social protection coverage, and variable quality of care. In 2019, only around a quarter of people with severe difficulties in personal care or household activities received home care. Workforce Challenges: Attracting and retaining formal care workers is difficult due to low wages and challenging working conditions. Labour shortages risk leaving the job creation potential of the care economy untapped, a problem expected to worsen in the coming years. Informal Carers: Informal carers face multiple challenges, including limited access to support measures and difficulties balancing care with paid employment. Social inequalities and territorial disparities often restrict access to quality care, particularly for those from disadvantaged or rural areas. Gender Dimension: Care responsibilities disproportionately affect women, who make up the majority of both formal and informal carers. Women are more likely to leave the labour market due to care obligations and are also more likely to need long-term care themselves, but with limited financial resources. Rising Costs: Long-term care is the fastest-growing social expenditure in the EU, projected to rise from 1.7% to 2.5% of GDP between 2019 and 2050, with significant variation across Member States. Underinvestment has contributed to structural weaknesses that must be urgently addressed. The provision of quality, affordable and accessible long-term care services is one of the most significant social challenges facing the European Union. We recommend that, during its Presidency, Ireland: Adopts the theme “Building a Caring Europe Together” and prioritises policies and legislation that strengthen long-term care provision and support both informal carers and the people they care for. Hosts a European Conference: Organise a two-day conference in Brussels on long-term care and informal care, bringing together Member States, EU institutions, carers’ organisations, and stakeholders to share best practices and build a collaborative vision for the future (draft Conference Programme attached). Family Carers Ireland and Eurocarers thank the Department of Foreign Affairs for the opportunity to submit our views on the priorities and policy programme to be pursued during Ireland’s Presidency of the Council of the European Union.

geography: National as well as EU wide
response_text: We, as young people across Ireland, identified six interconnected priorities that we believe should shape Ireland’s 2026 Presidency: Peace and Security, Climate Action, Education and Youth, Cost of Living, Equality, and Wellbeing and Care. These themes reflect our lived experiences and our strong commitment to future-oriented, people-centred policy. 1. Peace and Security We emphasised the need for a safer, more stable Europe. Our priorities include confronting disinformation, regulating AI, and improving digital security. We see misinformation, political polarisation, deepfakes, online hate, and far-right extremism as threats to democracy and peace. We want Ireland to champion an EU-wide approach to cybersecurity, digital literacy, and online protections, including transparent age-verification and stricter oversight of harmful content. We also called for stronger humanitarian responses to conflicts, especially in Gaza and Palestine, and for a more unified EU foreign policy. We also noted divided views on the question of arming Gardaí. 2. Climate Action and a Just Green Transition We stressed that climate action must focus on affordability, accessibility, and fairness. We experience gaps in rural transport, the high cost of sustainable energy and retrofitting, and the need for greater investment in renewable infrastructure. A just transition requires targeted grants, improved public transport, sustainable housing, and supportive incentives rather than punitive measures. We also want the EU to prioritise climate education, urban planning reform, and fair treatment of farming communities. Climate anxiety is widespread among us, and we want real, immediate action—not distant targets. 3. Education, Youth Rights, and Participation We believe Ireland should prioritise strengthening education systems across the EU. This includes mental health supports in schools, reforming guidance counselling, and providing more training for teachers working with neurodivergent students, along with meaningful civic and political education. We also see the need for clear AI regulation in education so that digital tools enhance, rather than replace, critical thinking. Beyond schools, we want stronger European commitments to youth participation, including improved structures for youth voice and expanded mobility opportunities such as Erasmus+. 4. Cost of Living and Social Inclusion The cost-of-living crisis creates barriers to independence, education, housing, transport, childcare, and even access to basic necessities like period products. We want Ireland to champion EU-level action on housing affordability, energy costs, quality public services, and social protections for young people, families, and students. 5. Equality, Inclusion and Human Rights We think Ireland should prioritise gender equality, anti-racism, LGBTQIA+ rights, cultural inclusion, and equitable access to education, healthcare, and public spaces. We experience barriers linked to religion, disability, race, and low income, and we are calling for better accessibility, cultural understanding, and mental health support. We want Ireland to use its Presidency to help build a more inclusive Europe that protects minority communities and expands equal opportunities. 6. Care, Safety and Wellbeing Finally, we highlighted concerns about substance misuse, youth homelessness, and the experiences of young people in the care system. We want EU-wide approaches that prioritise prevention, trauma-informed services, and supports that give every young person stability and dignity.

geography: National as well as EU wide
response_text: While we identified only one specific policy, we clearly articulated priority policy areas and the kinds of reforms we believe the Irish Presidency should advance. Our recommendations fall into five key domains. 1. AI Regulation, Cybersecurity and the Digital Sphere We strongly support robust implementation of the EU AI Act and further work to regulate deepfake technologies, data privacy risks, and harmful online behaviour. We recommend: A licensing system for access to high-risk AI (e.g., deepfakes). EU-wide standards for age-verification and platform safety. Stronger sanctions for cybercrime, hacking, and data breaches. Investment in media literacy and digital education. 2. Climate Action, Transport and a Just Transition We want the EU to prioritise affordable, accessible climate action. We recommend: Investment in rural public transport and cross-border rail. Grants for retrofitting, solar panels, and energy-efficient homes. Regulations to reduce unnecessary plastic packaging. Action on fast fashion, electronic waste, and greenwashing. Support for farmers through fair subsidies and sustainable agriculture. 3. Education, Skills, and Youth Rights We want the EU to strengthen education systems and protect young people's rights across Member States. We recommend: EU frameworks for mental health supports in schools. Teacher training for neurodivergence and inclusive education. Regulation ensuring AI supports rather than replaces learning. Expansion and promotion of Erasmus+ and youth mobility. Development of EU-wide civic and political education programmes. 4. Housing, Social Protection and the Cost of Living We highlighted urgent needs, including: EU cooperation on housing affordability and homelessness. Investment in public and student accommodation. Stronger worker protections and equal minimum wage for young people. Access to free period products and menstrual health supports. Childcare affordability and income supports for working families. 5. Equality, Anti-Discrimination, and Care Reform We want Ireland to prioritise: Gender equality and anti-racism measures. LGBTQIA+ protections. Equal access to healthcare, including mental health supports. EU-wide standards for young people in care, ensuring safety, cultural respect, and trauma-informed practice.

geography: National as well as EU wide
response_text: We emphasised that the most meaningful impact the Council can make under Ireland’s Presidency is to focus on people’s daily realities, affordability, safety, wellbeing, equality, and a sustainable future, while ensuring that all Member States and regions benefit fairly. Across all world café tables, we consistently highlighted that EU decisions have the greatest positive influence when they reduce inequality, strengthen community resilience, improve access to essential services, support young people’s transition to adulthood, and ensure that climate and digital transitions are both fair and affordable. A clear priority for us is action that reduces the cost of living and increases socio-economic security. We highlighted that housing insecurity, energy costs, the affordability of transport, and unequal access to education create barriers that limit our mobility, opportunities, and participation in society. Measures that improve access to affordable housing, expand public transport (especially in rural regions), reduce the cost of education, and ensure equal minimum wages for young workers were frequently identified as areas where the EU Presidency can deliver tangible benefits for communities. Improving access to grants, expanding maintenance supports, and ensuring fair pathways into employment, particularly for first-time workers, were viewed as high-impact actions at EU level. Climate action was also seen as an area where the Presidency can deliver significant community benefit, provided it is approached in a way that is fair, practical, and regionally balanced. We stressed that the impact of climate change is not equal across Europe and that infrastructure gaps, particularly in rural areas, make climate action harder for many communities. EU-level work that focuses on affordable green transport, renewable energy accessibility, positive incentives for households and farmers, and stronger regulation of major corporate polluters was viewed as essential. We believe these measures can reduce household costs, strengthen energy security, and protect communities from increasingly severe climate impacts. Digital safety and security emerged as a major cross-cutting concern. We linked misinformation, deepfakes, online harassment, and data exploitation to declining trust, polarisation, and fears about political interference. We see the Presidency as an opportunity for the EU to strengthen media literacy, accelerate implementation of the AI Act, improve age-verification and safety standards on digital platforms, and require greater transparency from large technology companies. We emphasised that citizens, businesses, and democratic institutions all benefit from a safer, more trustworthy digital environment. We also called for EU policies that strengthen social cohesion and inclusion. We highlighted the need for improved mental health supports, better access to youth facilities, stronger protections for marginalised communities, and meaningful mechanisms for young people to influence policymaking. We stressed that investing in the wellbeing of children and young people yields long-term social and economic benefits for communities and businesses.

geography: National as well as EU wide
response_text: We expressed that communication about the EU is most effective when it is clear, honest, relatable, and grounded in everyday experience. To create a sense of ownership over the Presidency, communication must be youth-inclusive, accessible across regions, and delivered through channels and formats that meet people where they are, including schools, youth spaces, and digital platforms. A recurring message from us was that EU communication should move beyond technical language and focus on practical impacts, demonstrating how EU decisions directly improve people’s lives. We highlighted the importance of education and civic literacy as foundational to building meaningful engagement with the EU. We strongly support the development of standardised, EU-wide civic and political education that teaches students about their rights, the functioning of EU institutions, and how they can influence policy. Many of us noted that current curricula do not equip young people to understand how EU decisions affect their lives or how to engage with EU consultations. We believe Ireland’s Presidency should be used to promote clear, accessible civic learning resources, teacher training, and digital tools that help young people understand and participate in European democracy. Communication must also address misinformation and disinformation, which we identified as one of the most significant threats to trust in the EU. We emphasised the need for large-scale public education on deepfakes, online manipulation, and AI-generated content. We recommended EU-backed campaigns that explain how to recognise misinformation, as well as stronger regulation and transparency requirements for social media platforms. We stressed that the Presidency should model responsible, factual communication and highlight the EU’s leadership in regulating AI and protecting citizens online. We also called for communication to reflect Europe’s diversity and to acknowledge the lived realities of different groups, including minorities, rural populations, migrants, LGBTQIA+ young people, and those experiencing poverty or discrimination. We expressed that citizens feel ownership when they see themselves represented and when policies respond to the issues they face- housing, mental health, transport, education, and climate action. Campaigns that showcase real stories of how EU initiatives make a difference in people’s everyday lives were seen as particularly effective. Importantly, we want communication to emphasise positive, hopeful narratives. Many of us described feeling overwhelmed by “doom messaging” around climate change, conflict, and the economy. We recommended framing the EU as a community capable of shared solutions, highlighting successful EU projects, cross-border cooperation, Erasmus+, environmental progress, and examples of social progress. Positive storytelling, combined with practical information on how citizens can participate, was viewed as essential to building a sense of collective European identity. Finally, we stressed that participation itself must be communicated as a benefit of EU membership. We advocated for opportunities to co-design policies through youth assemblies, digital platforms, local deliberation spaces, and youth-friendly consultations. We emphasised that when young people see their ideas reflected in policy outcomes, their sense of ownership and connection to the EU grows significantly.

geography: National as well as EU wide
response_text: 1. Mental Health as a Foundational Issue Mental health emerged repeatedly for us as a core concern across all discussions, affecting education outcomes, participation in sport, social inclusion, risk of homelessness, substance use, and personal wellbeing. We described long waiting lists, inconsistent support in schools, and a lack of youth-friendly spaces. We want Ireland to champion EU-level collaboration on mental health supports, best-practice sharing, and youth-centred services, recognising mental health as foundational to all other areas of life. We also noted the importance of access to sport, arts, and leisure essential parts of youth wellbeing but often underfunded. 2. The Importance of Youth Participation We emphasised that decisions about our lives must include our voices. We proposed that every EU Member State establish structures similar to Comhairle na nÓg to ensure young people can influence policy at both local and national levels. We also recommended that EU institutions increase youth representation and enhance political education so that all young people understand their rights and can engage confidently with democratic processes. 3. The Role of AI in Society Across all themes, we returned to the transformative and disruptive impact of AI not only on job security and education but also on peace, misinformation, and democracy. We voiced concern that rapid AI development risks outpacing regulation, creating inequalities and new forms of harm. We want the EU to take a leadership role in ensuring AI supports society without undermining safety, mental health, or social cohesion. 4. Rural Disadvantage and Unequal Access to Opportunities We highlighted deep disparities between rural and urban areas in transport, youth facilities, education support, healthcare access, and employment opportunities. We stressed that EU policy must recognise rural contexts and ensure no young person is left behind because of where they live. 5. Visibility, Culture and Identity We also raised issues related to culture, the Irish language, identity, and representation. We want the EU and Ireland to strengthen support for cultural diversity, languages, and inclusive spaces where every young person can “be themselves safely.” 6. Care Systems and Trauma-Informed Practice We highlighted serious concerns about housing, staff turnover, lack of cultural recognition, and the trauma many young people in care face. We want EU-level cooperation on standards of care, advocating for consistency, safety, and child-centred, trauma-informed practice. 7. Stability, Security and Humanitarian Concerns We expressed deep concern about rising instability within and beyond Europe. Many of us highlighted the humanitarian crisis in Palestine and urged stronger, more consistent EU engagement. We also discussed increasing far-right influence across Europe and its impact on minority communities and democratic norms. Our views on public safety were mixed: some of us supported expanded Garda armed units, while others cautioned that broader arming could erode community trust.

organisation: Centre for Finance and Security at the Royal United Services Institute
response_text: With Ibec and the Central Bank Governor calling for stronger security measures within Ireland’s economic agenda, and the recent drone incident during President Zelensky’s visit highlighting the reality of hybrid threats on Irish soil, Ireland should place economic security and sanctions at the centre of its 2026 Presidency agenda. Economic security will already feature prominently in the EU policy cycle and Ireland can drive stronger partnerships with industry on securing critical infrastructure and supply chains, strengthening foreign investment screening and improving information sharing on strategic dependencies. Within this, sanctions should remain a policy priority to align with the current mission of supporting Ukraine and countering Russian hybrid threats, as well as tackling other threats such as transnational organised crime and cyberattacks on EU critical infrastructure, businesses and individuals. The EU continues to work on enhancing its sanctions toolkit and Ireland will be well positioned to back its effective implementation and support the domestic architecture responsible for enforcement. Ireland has supported the adoption of 19 sanctions packages against Russia to date and, given the country’s own exposure to serious and organised crime threats posed by groups like the Kinahan and Hutch cartels, would be well positioned to support the refining of existing measures and to lead on the creation of a new regime. As a member state with a highly international economy, Ireland hosts a significant number of global firms whose exposure to restrictive EU measures is complex and fast evolving. Strengthening coordination between national competent authorities, improving resourcing for enforcement bodies and providing clearer guidance to the private sector on sanctions would help provide clarity and ensure more effective implementation. Using the Presidency to leverage these EU-level tools and drive improvements across the Union would also reduce compliance burdens for Irish businesses. Ireland should also frame maritime safety as a matter of national and European security. The expansion of Russia’s shadow fleet is reshaping shipping routes around Europe and growing scrutiny in the English Channel has pushed many of these ageing, poorly maintained and inadequately insured tankers westward toward Irish waters. This poses acute risks to Ireland’s maritime safety, marine ecosystems and coastal economies. Ireland should drive this issue at Council level to demonstrate leadership on a challenge that affects Ireland and the entire Union.

organisation: Centre for Finance and Security at the Royal United Services Institute
response_text: Following the steps of every Presidency since 2022, a first priority for the Irish Presidency should be to secure agreement on an Ireland sponsored sanctions package against Russia. The Presidency should support efforts identifying gaps across existing EU restrictive measures and resolve outstanding divergences between member states. Additionally, the Presidency should promote the efforts to develop an EU sanctions regime on transnational organised crime. This might require an initial phase to gather information from relevant stakeholders and input from Member States but the ultimate aim should be the development of a new sanctions regulation. Ireland should also champion the EU’s ongoing efforts to strengthen maritime domain awareness, including advancing work on legislative frameworks such as the Vessel Monitoring Directive. Coastal states in particular face growing pressures from high-risk vessels and the EU must keep pace with this evolving threat. A key gap concerns the reporting of insurance information by vessels that enter EU waters. Although the obligation exists in principle under the Mandatory Ship Reporting Systems, implementation remains inconsistent. Ireland can play a leading role in shaping an operational and enforceable model that ensures transparency, supports safety and reduces exposure to maritime security and environmental risks. The Irish Presidency would also be best placed to encourage closer alignment between EU and UK sanctions regimes. For a member state with unique economic connections to the UK, regulatory divergence creates disproportionate complexity and cost for Irish and EU businesses that operate across both jurisdictions. Ireland should facilitate structured dialogue and coordination to simplify compliance, support competitiveness and help maintain the integrity of EU sanctions.

organisation: Centre for Finance and Security at the Royal United Services Institute
response_text: A Presidency agenda that prioritises economic security, strengthens sanctions implementation and ultimately counters illicit finance would generate positive impacts for people, businesses and communities in Ireland and the rest of the Union. EU citizens would benefit from effective action against illicit finance to support the resilience of European democracy by limiting external interference, malign influence and criminal proceeds that undermine public institutions. The threats posed by Russia, transnational organised crime and Improved sanctions guidance and a more consistent regulatory landscape across the EU would reduce compliance burdens and uncertainty for EU businesses. Clearer rules allow firms to operate with confidence, allocate resources more efficiently and avoid costly regulatory inconsistencies. Enhanced enforcement coordination also creates a more level playing field across the EU, which benefits legitimate operators and strengthens the overall competitiveness of the EU economy. Communities across the EU, especially coastal and rural communities, would benefit from assertive action against the risks posed by the shadow fleet. An oil spill from an uninsured or inadequately insured tanker could devastate fisheries, tourism and local ecosystems, imposing long term economic and social costs. With these measures, Ireland would help protect livelihoods that depend directly on natural resources and coastal integrity. Thus, the Irish Presidency can demonstrate that sanctions and economic security policies have real world benefits that extend far beyond technical regulation.

organisation: Centre for Finance and Security at the Royal United Services Institute
response_text: To build a sense of ownership over Ireland’s Presidency of the Council of the EU, communications should focus on tangible, evidence-based outcomes aligned with citizens’ priorities for safety and stability. Focusing the presidential agenda on economic security, sanctions implementation and maritime safety, provides the perfect opportunity to demonstrate practical value. Linking these priorities to visible benefits, such as safer communities, more resilient supply chains, and a stable economic environment, can help citizens understand how EU-level decisions shape their lives in productive ways.

Defense in the context of neutrality and consenting cooperation. Energy prioritizing clean industry, and future research e.g. fusion. Privacy and digital rights, provide a robust framework to protect encryption, communication and speech from surveillance and state control.

Scrap the encryption backdoor aspect (states cannot demand access to encrypted data) and chat control surveillance elements (communication hosts should not be compelled to give states backdoor access) of the new digital safety regulations. These are unsafe and resemble the actions of tyannical states. They are not becoming of a free and democratic society and undermine the EU’s core values. Instead, safe encryption and state digital surveillance bans should be enshrined in legislation. Defense legislation should limit PESCO and other similar schemes to EU soil only. No power projection, no military role for the EU beyond its own borders and waters. The push for the bloc to act as a military alliance projecting power is an existential betrayal of the EU’s core goals, and Ireland’s role within it. The EU commission should also be barred from speaking on foreign policy matters. The commissioners are not figureheads or elected Presidents.

Pursue an agenda which focuses on freedom, democracy and justice for all Europeans. Do not fall into the trap of pursuing the degradation of privacy, mass surveillance, military posturing. This has been down the downfall of the United States. Europe must secure its external borders and control migration flows if it hopes to have a stable political future. We should remove tariffs on China and seek cooperation, as they will be the manufacturer of our needs in clean energy, electric vehicles and technology. The council should disavow Ursula Von Der Leyen’s commitments to lowering barriers to importing American agriproducts and vehicles. Neither of these are desirable for Europeans or of the standards required.

Do not talk about “misinformation” or “disinformation” as if you are a soviet politburo. Provide impartial, factual information and do not attempt to silence dissent. Nothing undermines the credibility of our institutions more than when they treat online commentary as an existential threat. Stop doing this and you’ll immediately be doing better on communication. People will say stupid wrong things, and you have to put up with it, end of story.

The European project has been lead to the point of crisis by the erosion of its core values. It has forgotten how to express itself as a peace project designed to bring prosperity to a continent and forge solidarity between its peoples. Europe is not a vehicle for the military agenda of NATO, or a lifeboat to every opportunistic migrant from the developing world. It must first and foremost put the needs of its own citizens first, avoid paternailsitic “safety” and “security” encroachment, stop treating free speech as a bogeyman. Trust must be rebuilt, and Ireland carries the hot potato.

organisation: Let’s Talk Prostate Cancer Expert Group (LTPC)
sector: Health Care – Specific focus on prostate Cancer and Men’s Health
geography:
LTPC’s geographical focus operates across three levels: 
National level: We advocate for timely screening and detection in several EU Member States, including Italy and Poland. 
EU level: Our work focuses on advancing legislation that enables Member States to implement timely screening initiatives. We also advocate for an EU-wide men’s health strategy with a dedicated emphasis on prostate cancer.
response_text: Ireland’s 2026 Presidency presents a timely and strategic opportunity to place citizens’ health, equity and screening at the centre of the European Union agenda. As Europe faces increasing pressure from demographic ageing, growing cancer incidence and persistent health system inequalities, a Presidency grounded in people-centred health improvements would resonate strongly across Member States. LTPC recommends three overarching thematic priorities that reflect Ireland’s unique strengths, particularly its pioneering work in men’s health, and that support the European Union’s wider objectives for a fairer and healthier society. The first priority should focus on creating a healthier and more equitable Europe. Significant disparities remain in screening, diagnosis and outcomes for major diseases, including prostate cancer. It is the most common and the second most deadly cancer among men in Europe. However, access to timely diagnosis, imaging and specialised care varies greatly across Member States. Ireland is the only country in the European Union with a dedicated Men’s Health Policy and Action Plan and operates a national Prostate Rapid Access Clinic network. Ireland also participates in the PRAISE U project. These national strengths provide Ireland with a strong foundation to lead a broader European discussion on gender specific health inequalities. Prostate cancer represents an effective entry point for such a discussion because it is highly prevalent, widely recognised and closely aligned with ongoing European initiatives such as Europe’s Beating Cancer Plan. The second priority should emphasise secondary prevention and timely diagnosis as key elements of future-proof and resilient healthcare systems. Across Europe, the value of prevention is well understood, but implementation remains uneven. Prostate cancer clearly demonstrates why delays in diagnosis matter. Late-stage diagnosis results in poorer clinical outcomes and a significant decline in quality of life, while placing far greater pressure on health systems. Treatment of advanced disease is approximately ten times more expensive than treatment of early-stage, potentially curable disease. Ireland has made considerable progress in streamlining diagnostic pathways, expanding Rapid Access Clinics and promoting awareness among men. This experience equips Ireland to guide a European-level conversation on how to improve screening pathways, strengthen population health literacy and expand diagnostic capacity. By drawing from its national achievements, Ireland can inspire practical and evidence-based actions that improve screening rates and reduce inequalities. The third priority should focus on building a Union empowered by data, innovation and evidence. The European Union is advancing several major initiatives, including the European Health Data Space, the EU Life Sciences Strategy and a range of innovation-focused legislative files. Ireland can play an important leadership role by ensuring that these frameworks translate into meaningful improvements for citizens. One concrete contribution would be to advance the development of an EU-level Men’s Health Indicator, beginning with prostate cancer. Such indicators could include time to diagnosis, stage at diagnosis, access to imaging and access to specialised care. Introducing these indicators would support Member States in identifying gaps, tracking progress and developing outcome-based policies.

organisation: Let’s Talk Prostate Cancer Expert Group (LTPC)
sector: Health Care – Specific focus on prostate Cancer and Men’s Health
geography:
LTPC’s geographical focus operates across three levels: 
National level: We advocate for timely screening and detection in several EU Member States, including Italy and Poland. 
EU level: Our work focuses on advancing legislation that enables Member States to implement timely screening initiatives. We also advocate for an EU-wide men’s health strategy with a dedicated emphasis on prostate cancer.
response_text: Ireland’s 2026 Presidency presents a strategic opportunity to advance policy areas where European cooperation can improve screening, timely diagnosis and outcomes for major diseases. Given Ireland’s recognised leadership in men’s health and its strong national record in prostate cancer awareness and care, the Presidency could play a decisive role in elevating prostate cancer and broader men’s health considerations within key European Union policy frameworks. This focus would support more equitable and resilient healthcare systems across the Union. A first area of focus should be the implementation of Europe’s Beating Cancer Plan, particularly the Council Recommendations on cancer screening. These Recommendations aim to expand screening programmes, yet implementation across Member States remains uneven. Prostate cancer illustrates this clearly. It is one of the most common and most deadly cancers among men in Europe, yet access to screening, diagnostic imaging and follow up care differs substantially between countries. Screening programmes are only effective if men participate, yet participation rates remain as low as twenty to thirty per cent in some Member States. Ireland is well placed to highlight these inconsistencies and encourage more coordinated action. By promoting public awareness, health literacy and communication strategies that motivate men to respond to screening invitations, Ireland can help ensure that screening programmes deliver impact. Ireland’s experience with streamlined diagnostic pathways, its national Prostate Rapid Access Clinic network and its participation in the PRAISE U project, including pilots led by Mr David Galvin exploring innovative PSA sampling, provide practical models for Member States. Ireland can promote risk based prostate cancer screening models and support improvements in participation rates, follow up diagnostics and specialist referrals. A second area that merits attention is the EU Life Sciences Strategy. This Strategy will shape European approaches to research, innovation and health literacy and offers a platform to support targeted and risk stratified prostate cancer screening pilots. Ireland’s National Men’s Health Policy and Action Plan provides a clear proof point of how gender specific health considerations can be embedded into policy through structured indicators, targeted awareness initiatives and coordinated care pathways. These elements demonstrate how national approaches can be replicated within the Life Sciences Strategy to ensure that innovation and health literacy initiatives respond to the needs of men. Ireland should advocate for the integration of such mechanisms to improve screening participation and reduce disparities in access to diagnostics. A third relevant policy area concerns the Innovation Act and the Biotech Act. These initiatives aim to expand Europe’s capacity to develop and deploy new health technologies. Ireland can encourage the inclusion of gender specific and disease specific health needs within innovation assessment frameworks, ensuring that diagnostic tools, imaging technologies and clinical investigations respond to diseases such as prostate cancer. A fourth opportunity lies in the European Health Data Space. High quality, sex disaggregated and disease specific data are essential for identifying inequalities and guiding policy. Ireland can promote comprehensive indicators, beginning with prostate cancer, to help Member States benchmark progress and identify gaps in screening and diagnostic pathways.

organisation: Let’s Talk Prostate Cancer Expert Group (LTPC)
sector: Health Care – Specific focus on prostate Cancer and Men’s Health
geography:
LTPC’s geographical focus operates across three levels: 
National level: We advocate for timely screening and detection in several EU Member States, including Italy and Poland. 
EU level: Our work focuses on advancing legislation that enables Member States to implement timely screening initiatives. We also advocate for an EU-wide men’s health strategy with a dedicated emphasis on prostate cancer.
response_text: Ireland’s 2026 Presidency has the potential to deliver a meaningful and visible impact for people, businesses and communities across the European Union by prioritising policies that strengthen screening, reduce inequities and support innovation. These areas directly influence the quality of life of European citizens and contribute to the resilience and efficiency of health systems. By drawing on its national experience in men’s health and its strong reputation for practical and people-centred policymaking, Ireland can guide Council work that delivers tangible improvements across Member States. A first way the Presidency can improve outcomes for people is by supporting earlier and more accurate diagnosis of major diseases through effective screening pathways. Prostate cancer provides a clear example. Without structured screening, most cases are diagnosed only once symptoms appear, often at an advanced stage when treatment options are limited and prognosis poorer. If Ireland encourages Member States to strengthen screening pathways and diagnostic capacity, citizens will benefit from shorter waiting times, improved access to imaging and more timely referrals to specialist services. These improvements are visible to the public and are perceived as indicators of a functioning and equitable healthcare system. A second area of impact concerns communities and local health systems. Many regions across Europe face shortages in diagnostic capacity, unequal access to specialist care and limited health literacy. Guided by Ireland’s experience with Rapid Access Clinics and targeted awareness campaigns, the Council can promote actions that help Member States share best practices, identify system gaps and invest effectively in screening and secondary prevention. Strengthening these elements reduces avoidable pressures on hospitals and helps ensure that communities receive sustainable and responsive healthcare. A third area of impact relates to the broader European economy and businesses in the health and life sciences sectors. When health systems articulate clear needs and when policies support innovation that responds to real population challenges, businesses can invest with confidence. The Presidency can contribute by advancing outcome-oriented frameworks under the Innovation Act and the Biotech Act. Integrating gender specific and disease-specific indicators, including those related to prostate cancer, will support the development of diagnostic tools, digital health solutions and clinical research aligned with the needs of European citizens.
