A fourth contribution relates to cohesion and solidarity within the European Union. Reducing inequalities in screening and treatment strengthens citizens’ expectations that they can access timely and high-quality care regardless of where they live. Council work focused on equity strengthens trust in public institutions and reinforces the principle that European cooperation delivers measurable and meaningful benefits. Through leadership in these areas, Ireland’s Presidency can improve daily life for citizens, support stronger communities, create clearer conditions for innovation and contribute to a more resilient and cohesive European Union.

organisation: Let’s Talk Prostate Cancer Expert Group (LTPC)
sector: Health Care – Specific focus on prostate Cancer and Men’s Health
geography:
LTPC’s geographical focus operates across three levels: 
National level: We advocate for timely screening and detection in several EU Member States, including Italy and Poland. 
EU level: Our work focuses on advancing legislation that enables Member States to implement timely screening initiatives. We also advocate for an EU-wide men’s health strategy with a dedicated emphasis on prostate cancer.
response_text: Ireland’s 2026 Presidency presents a significant opportunity to enhance citizens’ understanding of the value of European cooperation and to foster a sense of shared ownership over the Council’s work. Communication should focus on themes relevant to people’s daily lives, demonstrate clear and measurable benefits and reflect Ireland’s longstanding commitment to fairness, inclusion and public health. By grounding its communication in practical improvements to health and well-being, Ireland can help citizens across the Union see the Presidency as directly relevant to their own interests. A central element of this approach should be the use of health as a tangible and relatable example of European added value. Citizens consistently identify health as an area where cooperation across borders can make a real difference. By emphasising how improved screening pathways, more equitable diagnostic access and consistent standards of care can save lives, reduce anxiety and shorten waiting times, the Presidency can demonstrate how European-level action improves daily life. Prostate cancer provides a clear and relatable illustration, affecting families in every Member State and offering a compelling example of where cooperation can deliver visible improvements. A second way to strengthen citizen ownership is to highlight Ireland’s leadership in men’s health and its commitment to fairness and equity. As the only Member State with a national Men’s Health Policy and Action Plan, and with established Prostate Rapid Access Clinics and participation in PRAISE U pilots, Ireland can present its Presidency as grounded in experience and public health expertise. Sharing these best practices demonstrates how national strengths can benefit the wider Union. A third way to enhance public engagement is to involve civil society, patient organisations, clinicians and community groups in Presidency activities. Including these voices ensures that communication is participatory rather than top-down. Citizens are more likely to feel connected to the Presidency when they see individuals like themselves represented and when their concerns are acknowledged. This approach deepens trust and reinforces the principle that the European Union is shaped not only by its institutions but also by the communities it serves. A fourth communication opportunity lies in sharing positive and practical stories of cooperation. Highlighting examples of strengthened screening pathways, improved diagnostic infrastructure, or successful community-based prevention efforts helps citizens understand how European initiatives translate into local benefits. These stories should emphasise partnership, collective progress and the shared goal of improving public health. By focusing on relatable themes, showcasing national leadership, engaging diverse voices and presenting clear and evidence-based examples of impact, Ireland can help citizens feel more connected to the European project and take pride in the 2026 Presidency.

organisation: Let’s Talk Prostate Cancer Expert Group (LTPC)
sector: Health Care – Specific focus on prostate Cancer and Men’s Health
geography:
LTPC’s geographical focus operates across three levels: 
National level: We advocate for timely screening and detection in several EU Member States, including Italy and Poland. 
EU level: Our work focuses on advancing legislation that enables Member States to implement timely screening initiatives. We also advocate for an EU-wide men’s health strategy with a dedicated emphasis on prostate cancer.
response_text: LTPC welcomes the opportunity to contribute to the development of priorities for Ireland’s 2026 Presidency and appreciates the inclusive approach taken by the Government. As a multistakeholder and expert-led platform bringing together clinicians, patient advocates, researchers and public health organisations, LTPC is committed to supporting evidence-based policies that improve outcomes for men across Europe. Prostate cancer remains one of the most significant health challenges affecting European men. Its impact extends beyond mortality to quality of life, mental health and social wellbeing. Although this submission has focused on prostate cancer as an urgent entry point for broader European action on men’s health, LTPC emphasises that this should contribute to a more comprehensive understanding of gender specific health needs throughout the lifespan. Ireland’s national Men’s Health Policy and Action Plan, its Rapid Access Clinic network and its participation in the PRAISE U project demonstrate how structured interventions can improve awareness, support help-seeking behaviour and strengthen care pathways. Ireland’s Presidency also provides an opportunity to reinforce the country’s international leadership. Very few countries globally have developed a framework comparable to Ireland’s approach to men’s health. By embedding men’s health considerations within key European Union initiatives, Ireland can contribute to shaping global discussions on screening, health promotion and cancer control. Finally, LTPC would welcome continued engagement with Irish authorities during the preparation phase of the Presidency. Our expert group stands ready to provide evidence, insights and best practices that may support the development of proposals related to screening pathways and health equity. We would be pleased to contribute to future dialogue, consultations or expert roundtables.

geography: Dublin city, having worked with youth nationwide.
response_text: First and foremost, Ireland should use it’s unique position and perspective on recognising the rights of the Palestinian people to advance the case for a stronger position from the EU on Israel’s actions in Gaza, Palestine, and the wider Middle East. This aligns with the Council of Europe’s Work Plan for 2026, the European Council’s Strategic Agenda 2024-2029 (“Living up to our values at a global level”) and fostering a positive relationship between Irish and EU identities, which have been negatively impacted by the EU’s response to the crisis thus far. Another priority that is of vital importance is strengthening social cohesion and democratic culture through education, as aligned with the Strategic Agenda 2024-2029 (“Upholding European values within the Union”), the Council of Europe’s Work Plan for 2026 (“Supporting people and strengthening Europe’s social model” – specifically, “We must also ensure that young people are given the opportunities they need to thrive and that they are empowered to play a full part in our democracy”).

geography: Dublin city, having worked with youth nationwide.
response_text: While there is significant investment at European level in education and research in education for youth (Horizon Europe, Erasmus+) there remains a gap between young people’s attitudes towards the European Union, which are generally more positive than older generations (Damiani et al., 2024), and civic awareness or knowledge of the roles, responsibilities and functions of the EU amongst youth at second level, with approximately 25% of young people reporting low or no identification with Europe (Schnetzer et al., 2024). To best create a sense of ownership amongst citizens, in particular young people, there should be a coordinated education programme in both formal and non-formal education settings that both engages with the wider context of the EU and uses arts-based and creative methodologies to consult with youth on their visions of what they want for the future of Europe. These programmes could be structured using the Critical ChangeLab model (forthcoming EU Horizon project output, 2026) and would culminate in a Youth Assembly, exhibition, or presentation to key stakeholders on their visions of the future of Europe, and what steps need to be taken today. This could be coordinated with the Council of Europe’s education team and Irish educators who have already attended one trip to Brussels to engage with learning resources in both Irish and English.
Interconnected – innovative – independent

Energy Union: With the European Commission’s 10 December 2025 Grids Package, Ireland has a unique opportunity to shape the future of EU energy policy. Especially with regards to grids, the Irish presidency could find itself in a position to lead Europe by reaching an agreement on several legislative initiatives tabled to enable the “genuine Energy Union” that EU leaders have repeatedly called for, including at its 20 March 2025 Council meeting. Agreements on these pieces of regulation, would conclude a process initiated with the Member States’ call for a stronger European role in long-term electricity grid planning [Energy Council Conclusions of 20 May 2024] and supported by the need for an EU-wide electricity market to facilitate competitive energy prices, identified by the Draghi and Latta Reports. Ensuring low energy costs through electrification with clean energy and modern infrastructure is the main objectives of its Clean Industrial Deal and Action Plan for Affordable Energy from 26 February 2025. SupergridEurope proposes four main areas for the Irish Presidency to prioritise: Priority 1: Modernise and accelerate European electricity grids and Planning. Secure political agreement on the European Grids Package, including the proposed TEN-E Regulation (COM(2025) 1006) and the proposed Directive on accelerating of permit-granting procedures (COM(2025) 1007. Strengthened cross-border planning through improved governance as proposed by Article 11 in the Commission’s TEN-E Regulation (COM(2025) 1006) Lead a coalition to establish the first Important Project of Common European Interest (IPCEI) on electricity grid infrastructure (see below). Champion anticipatory grid investment and flexible connection rules Justification: Allow Ireland to demonstrate climate leadership, and drive overall EU competitiveness by bringing down electricity prices to benefit consumers while advancing practical implementation challenges at home. Priority 2: Accelerating Electrification Relevant files: Electrification Action Plan, including heating and cooling (Q1 2026), tariff guidance, flexible connection rules. Presidency actions: Support EU reforms enabling dynamic electricity pricing and cost-reflective network tariffs. Promote implementation of flexible connection policies across Member States. Advance integrated planning across electricity, hydrogen and gas systems Justification: Reaping the economic and system benefits of increased electrification, including through faster heat/transport electrification; Reduced fossil fuel imports; Increased sectoral competitiveness; improved energy system and cost efficiencies. Priority 3: Energy Security Relevant files: Strengthening energy security (Q1 2026 - legislative). Presidency Actions Updating the EU’s energy security framework, i.e. the rules and mechanisms that govern how EU ensures secure, resilient and reliable energy supplies across all Member States. Addressing emerging risks, incl. cybersecurity, physical threats Improve cross-border monitoring and coordination Align market functioning and infrastructure planning with security goals Justification: Ensuring a secure, resilient and reliable energy supplies across all Member States. Priority 4: Embedding Flexibility in the Energy System Relevant files: Electricity Market Design Reform (EMD), Flexibility Needs Assessments, Future Market Integration White Paper. Presidency actions: Prioritise early delivery of Ireland’s National Flexibility Needs Assessment Engage in Union wide FNA and Future Market Design Discussions. Justification: Flexibility is essential to a reliable, low-cost and decarbonised electricity system. As renewable generation grows and electrification intensifies, the ability of the system to respond dynamically to changes in supply and demand becomes increasingly critical. Without adequate flexibility, Member States face increased cost in the form of renewable curtailment, inefficient use of grid assets and price fluctuations. Other activities - Supporting events: SupergridEurope encourages the Irish Presidency to advance the four priorities listed above by organising energy policy-related events under the auspices of the EU Presidency. SupergridEurope are in discussions with partners in Brussels and Ireland to cooperate on: Q1 2026 event in Ireland to put focus on the energy initiatives expected from the upcoming Irish precedency. The intention is a broader discussion on Irish EU priorities to a wider stakeholder group to allign on EU energy priorities, agree why these are important in Ireland and abroad, idenfify messages and use participants to amplify – in Ireland and abroad, rallying support for Irish EU priorities. Q2: Informal event to communicate the priorities of the EU Presidency to Brussels stakeholders, including Permanent Representations, European Parliament, Commission, ACER, and the ENTSOs. H2 2026: SupergridEurope and Trifecta Ireland would be eager to contribute to activities during the informal Energy Council meeting in Ireland.

The Energy Union is incomplete and will remain so until we create the necessary energy infrastructure and market incentives, allowing families, businesses and the public sectors to benefit from Europe’s abundance in affordable, renewable energy resources, mainly in the forms of wind and solar. Accelerated electrification through grids, market reforms, flexibility and tariff reforms are the necessary enablers for establishing the free movement of electrons as a fifth European freedom, allowing us to achieve a real Energy Union, independent of imported fossil fuels at high, unpredictable prices. The Presidency is an opportunity to communicate how an energy independent, decarbonised Europe, will benefit and impact all people, businesses, communities and nations in Europe. It is an opportunity to gather European nations around a common objective that will impact all its citizens as we turn the first page of Europe as a modern, fossil free Electrostate, powered by indigenous renewable energy.

To foster public ownership and demonstrate the tangible benefits of EU membership, we suggest: Citizen-inclusive events alongside ministerial and Council meetings (public town halls, school & university outreach, regional ‘Energy & Climate Innovation Days’). Partnerships with trusted voices including influencers, community energy groups, researchers, and climate innovators. Visible storytelling showcasing Ireland’s leadership in renewables. The public in general don’t know about the success of onshore wind and rapid deployment of solar happening as well as the pipeline of projects and work being done to modernise the grid and streamline planning). Civil society participation in side-events to highlight social and regional benefits e.g. Job-creation, Community Benefit Fund, Local Rates to County Councils. As mentioned under Question 2, Trifecta/SupergridEurope suggest that the presidency organises a number of events at home and in Brussels to put focus on the (energy) initiatives expected from the upcoming Irish precedency This should be done before and during the Presidency. The intention is a broader discussion on Irish EU priorities to a wide group of stakeholders to achieve greater allignement among stakeholders abroad and at home, and discuss why they are important to each stakeholder. The broader stakeholder groups should idenfify shared messages and argumentation and can be used to greatly amplify amplify these in order to rally support for Irish EU priorities.

Energia supports high-level thematic priorities that build on those contained within the 2024-29 Strategic Agenda and the 2026 EU Commission Work Programme. Specifically, Energia supports a focus on EU security, competitiveness, and simplification. With regards to security, electrification powered by renewables and flexibility is the surest route to energy security. As a world-leader in building a renewables-led system, Ireland has an important role to play in promoting electrification and security of supply at the European level. This can be achieved through simplifying and accelerating the planning, permitting and connecting procedures for new generation, strengthening the EU Energy Union through our integrated electricity markets, and building a grid that is fit for an electrified Europe. In addition to energy security across Europe, energy security within Europe should also be an important theme of Ireland’s presidency. With regards to energy, each member state is bound by the reality of their own unique geographical location and the historic development of their market. As such, each member state must be responsible for ensuring the security of supply of its system and taking the necessary steps appropriate to their market. As a small-island system on the edge of Europe with strong links to non-EU countries, Ireland is well placed to represent this view through the Presidency. For example, while promoting interconnection generally across Europe is important for security of supply and competitiveness, each member state will have a level of interconnection linked to the size and physical characteristics of their market beyond which further interconnection can lead to increased dispatch down of renewable generation and challenges for national security of supply. EU policy should allow for these national characteristics to be accounted for as required. On competitiveness, strengthening and deepening Europe’s electricity market and promoting the increased participation of new technologies and demand response is the route to lowering prices and incentivising innovation. Ultimately, the largest gains for competitiveness and affordability will come from improved grid which promotes flexibility, gets more zero-cost-marginal renewables onto the system and lowers imperfections costs. On simplification, reducing the administrative burden on the delivery of new generation and grid and breaking down barriers to customer participation in the renewable transition can only be positive in delivering the EU’s energy transition and the attainment of the climate targets.

Energia is committed to powering the energy transition in a socially, environmentally, and ethically responsible manner. Through this, Energia supports a strengthened 2040 climate goal ambition that provides clarity and certainty to investors, communities, and customers alike. The Presidency should prioritise the underlying delivery mechanisms that contribute to the rollout of renewables, at appropriate scale and least cost. Aligned with Ireland’s national priorities, this includes streamlined permitting, increased simplification, improved market design, and greater support for storage and flexibility. A successful delivery of the 2040 climate targets will put us on course for climate neutrality by 2050, protect the EU’s competitiveness and strengthen our strategic autonomy. Furthermore, Energia supports the continued alignment of these 2040 goals with the EU Competitiveness Compass, Clean Industrial Deal, and Affordable Energy Action Plan. Energia believes that grid reinforcement, operational resilience, and system flexibility are primary enablers of further renewable growth. Through the rollout of the European Grids Package, Energia advocates for these priorities to be kept at its core. The focus should be on optimising and strengthening domestic grids, to accommodate for increasing renewable penetration. It will be essential to the energy transition to build a resilient, reliable, and future-proofed grid. Member State’s should have the freedom to assess and determine what would be the best approach for their own systems, and as such it will be important that the regulation surrounding this topic is non-prescriptive. A resilient and optimised grid is fundamental to delivering renewable energy at a lower cost, minimising imperfection costs, and ensuring reliable system performance as variable generation increases in the system. Key Presidency priorities related to this should include the acceleration of strategic grid reinforcement, enhanced operational flexibility, and reduced constraints and curtailment through improved planning and grid management. Energia also supports a focus on the Electrification Action Plan, which will support accessible and affordable electrification of heat, transport, and industry. Customer-centred electrification, supported by smart technology and tariffs, demand-side flexibility, and targeted assistance for vulnerable households, can materially reduce whole-system costs by shifting demand into periods of high-renewables on the system. Energia advocates for the implementation of this action plan to prioritise affordability, clarity, and investment certainty in order to deliver benefits for both domestic users and energy-intensive industrial sectors. Across all policy areas, Ireland in its Presidency should aim to push forward evidence-based, non-prescriptive regulation that gives room for the diversity of the Member States’ systemic nuances and complexities. By focusing on these policy areas through the lens of competitiveness, affordability, and security of supply, Energia believes that the Presidency can help to further the energy transition in a way that will help bolster Europe’s resilience and economic stability.

The Irish presidency can pursue a simplification of policy and non-prescriptive regulations to ensure the Council is promoting competitiveness, affordability while ensuring a cognisance of security of supply through the energy transition. See Q1 and Q2 for further detail.

The Presidency can best communicate the values and benefits of EU membership by clearly demonstrating how EU action delivers tangible improvements to daily lives, in areas such as energy affordability, increased reliability in energy supply, and economic stability through increased competitiveness and stability. Communication of the progress made throughout the Presidency should be transparent, accessible, and frequent. See Q1 and Q2 above for further detail.

Energia welcomes the opportunity to respond to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and this consultation on The Development of the Priorities and Policy Programme for Ireland’s Presidency of the Council of the European Union 2026. As a vertically integrated utility operating over 1.1GW renewable and flexible generation and supplying over 912,400 customer sites across the island of Ireland, Energia is committed to an Irish EU council presidency which drives a competitive and secure energy transition. While Ireland’s Presidency will encompass a broad range of priorities, this submission is focused on the areas identified as most relevant to Energia’s business. Energia recognise that there are clear intersections with wider aspects of the Presidency agenda, and as such the below recommendations are framed with these crossovers in mind. The Presidency provides a valuable opportunity to advance priorities that underpin Europe’s economic and energy resilience, the just energy transition, and the EU 2040 – 2050 climate ambitions. These include simplification of regulation, improved and clarified market design, and accelerated grid reinforcement to maximise indigenous renewables potential and reduce system constraints. A strong focus on electrification and flexibility will help lower whole-system costs, improve affordability, and bolster European competitiveness. Security of supply must remain central, with resilient domestic infrastructure and operational flexibility ensuring stability through the transition. Energia urges the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade to ensure Ireland uses its Council Presidency to promote a nuanced and holistic approach to electricity interconnection. The presidency can recognise that there are significant benefits to interconnection but is cognisant of the challenges and risks of a system that is over-reliant on interconnection such as excessive curtailment of indigenous renewables or the viability of domestic security of supply and system stability. In the context of competitiveness and security, Ireland has a valuable opportunity to prioritise and streamline simplified policies that accelerate the development of domestic grids to maximise the use of indigenous renewables. Energia is confident that Ireland’s insights from being a small-island system located on the edge of Europe with a high-level of renewable penetration will add enormous value to its term in the Presidency.

response_text: Ireland’s 2026 Presidency is an opportunity to highlight areas where the country has internationally recognised strengths and where cooperation can deliver meaningful societal and economic benefits across Europe. Ireland’s leadership in brain health, interdisciplinary research, public engagement and skills development positions it to champion themes that address major health and innovation challenges while emphasising collaboration, societal impact and economic value. These themes directly support the EU Strategic Agenda 2024–2029, advancing health resilience, digital transformation, research competitiveness, and sustainable economic growth. They align with the mission of the wider EU brain research community to promote cooperation between brain research organisations and other stakeholders, consistently promoting dialogue between scientists, industry and society. 1. Elevating Brain Health as a Central Societal and Economic Priority Brain health is fundamental to wellbeing, workforce participation and economic resilience. Neurological, neurodevelopmental and neuropsychiatric conditions impose growing social and financial burdens across Europe, with estimated annual costs exceeding €800 billion, underscoring the economic imperative for coordinated EU action. Ireland is particularly well placed to foreground this issue, with world-leading expertise in dementia, ageing, prevention, genomics, neuroscience, neuroimaging, digital health and precision medicine. Irish researchers have contributed to major breakthroughs through population-based studies, advanced genetic epidemiology and high-impact Phase 1 clinical trials. Ireland also hosts strong biomedical and neural-engineering programmes that support technological innovation. Highlighting brain health would allow Ireland to underscore the societal benefits of prevention and early intervention, alongside the economic importance of reducing the long-term burden of neurological disease. 2. Promoting Integrated Research Ecosystems that Deliver High Impact Ireland’s research landscape demonstrates how collaboration across universities, hospitals, industry and patient groups can accelerate discovery and deliver tangible societal and economic benefits. Irish-state supported research centres such as FutureNeuro, the Global Brain Health Institute, Trinity College Institute of Neuroscience, ADAPT, Insight, APC Microbiome, CÚRAM, Galway Neuroscience Centre, Centre for Pain Research, Ageing Research Centre and the Neuroimaging and Cognitive Genomics Research Centre illustrate the value of connecting basic science, engineering, clinical research and data-driven technologies. By emphasising integrated research ecosystems, Ireland can highlight how coordinated, cross-sectoral approaches generate high-impact science, foster innovation, and stimulate economic activity. 3. Strengthening Public and Patient Involvement to Enhance Societal Impact Ireland’s strong culture of public and patient involvement (PPI) is a distinctive national advantage. Advocacy organisations—particularly those within the Neurological Alliance of Ireland—work closely with researchers and clinician scientists to ensure studies reflect real-world needs and lived experience. This commitment to co-production enhances the societal relevance of research, builds public trust, and supports more effective translation of new findings into practice. Positioning PPI as a priority would allow Ireland to showcase the value of meaningful engagement for improving outcomes, strengthening public confidence and increasing the societal impact of research. 4. Investing in Skills and Talent for Long-Term Scientific and Economic Resilience Ireland’s growing talent base in genomics, data science, neuroscience, biomedical engineering, digital health and AI demonstrates the importance of sustained investment in people. Strong training pathways support innovation, attract international collaboration, and underpin long-term economic and scientific resilience. By highlighting skills and talent development, Ireland can underscore the importance of preparing the next generation to meet future health and technological challenges.

response_text: A first priority should be advancing implementation of the European Health Data Space (EHDS). The Irish Presidency should support coordinated implementation across Member States, promoting interoperability and ensuring that governance structures for the secondary use of health data are robust, trusted and research-friendly. Particular emphasis should be placed on facilitating responsible access for scientists, clinicians and innovators while maintaining strong safeguards for privacy and cybersecurity. The Presidency can also promote alignment between national digital health systems and the EHDS architecture to accelerate early benefits for patients and health systems. Ireland should also play a leading role in supporting implementation of the AI Act, helping to ensure that Europe’s AI ecosystem is both competitive and trustworthy. The Presidency is an opportunity to champion the implementation of the National Strategy for Accelerating Genetic and Genomic Medicine in Ireland, to optimise patient outcomes through precision medicine, attract clinical trials while leveraging the Irish research community to drive discovery and innovation. Ireland should also support work towards the development of a comprehensive EU Coordination Plan for Brain Health, recognising the growing burden of neurological, neurodegenerative and mental health conditions. In parallel, the Presidency could prioritise coordinated EU action on mental health by advancing implementation of the EU Mental Health Strategy, promoting integration of mental health indicators within the European Health Data Space, and strengthening support for prevention and early-intervention research, particularly in youth mental health. The Presidency can build on ongoing implementation of the ERA Policy Agenda 2025–2027, which aims to improve research careers, mobility and open science practices across Member States. The European Research Area Act offers a unique opportunity for the Presidency to advocate for measures that tackle longstanding challenges in Europe’s research ecosystem. There is also an opportunity for Ireland to further promote cross-border training and mobility programmes. There is a growing need to support clinician–scientist pathways that bridge clinical practice and research. Ireland can highlight this as both a workforce and innovation priority and could initiate a roadmap for strengthening clinician–scientist careers as part of Europe’s broader health workforce strategy.

response_text: Ireland has established world-class expertise in neuroscience, neuroimaging, genomics, digital health, and translational research, with centres and departments driving high-impact research in neurological, neurodegenerative, neuropsychiatric, neurodevelopmental, and acquired brain disorders. This concentrated expertise also strengthens industry partnerships, attracts global investment and talent, and supports the expansion of Ireland’s medtech clusters. Strong public and patient involvement underpin evidence-based research and prevention initiatives, providing a strong platform for leadership at the European level. Despite these strengths, gaps in infrastructure, fragmented data systems, limited neurorehabilitation services, workforce constraints, and the absence of a unified National Brain Health Plan present significant opportunities for development. A key priority lies in the creation of modern, integrated research infrastructure. Expanding digital health records and establishing a national Trusted Research Environment would allow researchers to securely link clinical, imaging, genomic, and outcomes data, accelerating discovery and enabling large-scale population studies. Increasing neuroimaging capacity outside Dublin and supporting the growth of national registries and biobanks within a robust ethical and governance framework would broaden participation in clinical research and enhance Ireland’s attractiveness for international collaboration. Sustained, long-term investment is essential to maintain and grow Ireland’s research excellence. Additional multi-year funding programmes would allow universities, hospitals, and community organisations to plan strategically, build stable research teams, and develop world-class facilities. Strengthening translational research infrastructure, from advanced preclinical laboratories to high-end clinical imaging, would facilitate the movement of discoveries from the laboratory to clinical application. Expanding structured PhD programmes, postdoctoral pathways, and early-career supports would reinforce the talent pipeline and ensure the next generation of researchers has clear and attractive career trajectories. Improving neurorehabilitation represents another major opportunity. Enhancing access to specialist services, developing consistent regional provision, and expanding pathways for both mild and moderate-to-severe traumatic brain injury would improve patient outcomes while generating valuable clinical research data. Embedding outcomes evaluation into rehabilitation programmes and providing structured supports for caregivers would strengthen service design and create evidence base capable of informing best practice across Europe. Developing talent, particularly clinician-scientists, is crucial to Ireland’s future competitiveness. Structured career pathways in neurology, psychiatry, rehabilitation, and related fields, combined with training in AI, data science, and translational neuroscience, would help retain highly skilled professionals and bridge the gap between scientific discovery and clinical care. Strengthening collaboration between clinical and academic institutions and recognising research as a core component of high-quality care would further integrate research into the health system. Finally, a unified National Brain Health Plan would consolidate existing strategies across neurology, psychiatry, neurodevelopment, rehabilitation, prevention, and research, reducing fragmentation and providing a clear framework for long-term implementation. Reinforcing collaboration across disciplines, institutions, and sectors, and linking researchers with clinicians, industry, and patient organisations, would amplify Ireland’s translational impact, scientific visibility, and competitiveness for international funding. By capitalising on these opportunities, Ireland can significantly strengthen its brain health ecosystem and position itself as a leader in European brain health research and innovation during its 2026 Presidency and beyond.

All decisions and actions of the EU must be in compliance with International Human Rights and Humanitarian Law. These decisions and actions must be applied consistently, if the EU is to have any moral or legal authority or to have the confidence of the citizens of the EU.

I have always supported the idea of the EU, but like many others, now recognise that it has lost all moral authority and credibility. This lack of morality will eventually affect all of us, regardless of where we live.

geography: This would reflect a holistic focus from the national level to the local scales.  SDSN Ireland is also formed under a global Secretariat, the SDSN Association, which is a global network of networks operating under the auspices of the UN Secretary General with regards to the 2030 Agenda and its SDGs, Paris Agreement and Pact for the Future.
response_text: Multilateral Renewal - EU Presidency should centre on rebuilding trust in multilateral cooperation to revitalise international governance and reaffirm collective problem-solving. A renewed EU commitment to cooperative security, climate diplomacy, humanitarian solidarity, and fair global financing signals that Europe will not retreat into geopolitical fragmentation or transactionalism. Ireland can convene member states, civil society, and global South partners to restore confidence in shared rules, evidence-based negotiation, and long-term commitments. Also prioritise mechanisms that strengthen transparency, accountability, and inclusive representation so multilateralism becomes more democratic, responsive, participatory, and resilient in the decades ahead. Intergenerational Equity - The principle of “leave no one behind” also requires policies attentive to the needs of future generations. Ireland should therefore elevate intergenerational fairness from rhetoric to operational principle: embedding youth participation in EU policy cycles, integrating future-impact assessments in climate, digital, and budget decisions. The Presidency should include formal youth advisory structures where delegates participate alongside official representatives that include long-term risk planning, protection of planetary boundaries, and the establishment of a Future’s Commissioner so today’s progress does not sacrifice the wellbeing of future generations. Accelerated SDG Delivery through Financing, Partnerships, and Monitoring - Ireland’s EU Presidency should champion an EU SDG Acceleration Declaration, pushing for innovative financing (e.g. blended finance, green bonds) and a regular EU-wide SDG review process. This should be supported by evidence-based, actionable approach to localising global goals and improving supporting data systems. Education/upskilling is also vital to success. The SDGs remain the indispensable global framework for sustainability and justice and is a living testament to Ireland’s leadership and soft power at the UN. Inclusive, Rights-Centred Digital Governance & AI Ethics - Ireland’s EU Presidency should advance digital commitments for universal internet access, safe and inclusive digital spaces to bridging the digital divide and advance human-rights focused AI governance structures especially focused on protection of young people. Ireland should lead an authentic EU Digital Trust & Inclusion initiative, focusing on digital literacy, equitable access, AI transparency, and data governance aligned with the rights of people and planet so that emerging technologies benefit all. A Just Transition of ‘Leaving No One Behind’ in Practice - Ireland’s EU Presidency should use EU social cohesion mechanisms and funds to target support for rural, island and disadvantaged communities; promote equitable recovery, job creation, and training especially in energy and digital sectors. There should be an overt commitment to equity, social inclusion, and support for vulnerable populations as we advance a critical green transition focused on a more secure and competitive Europe. Strengthening Science-Policy Integration, Research and Capacity-Building - Ireland’s EU Presidency should launch an EU Research & Sustainability Policy Lab that links scientific experts, academia, and EU institutions which aim to produce policy briefs, identify research needs, and pilot initiatives that bridge the gaps amongst researchers, policy makers and policy practitioners. Ireland should embed science, research and data-driven policy into the heart of EU decision-making especially with regards to supporting sustainable development, green competitiveness, technology governance, and human rights.

geography: This would reflect a holistic focus from the national level to the local scales.  SDSN Ireland is also formed under a global Secretariat, the SDSN Association, which is a global network of networks operating under the auspices of the UN Secretary General with regards to the 2030 Agenda and its SDGs, Paris Agreement and Pact for the Future.
response_text: Multilateral Renewal - Prioritise an EU roadmap to renew multilateral cooperation, with an emphasis on legitimacy, transparency, and fairness in EU governance. This includes strengthening EU coordination for a concrete roadmap for fossil fuel phaseout for COP31. The Presidency should also promote an EU position on information integrity, digital trust, and AI governance aligned with the forthcoming Global Digital Compact. By championing principled, rules-based cooperation and UN-EU alignment, Ireland can reinforce Europe’s role as a credible, stabilising, and future-oriented multilateral actor. Intergenerational Equity - Intergenerational fairness should be anchored as a cross-cutting lens, not just as an aspirational narrative. Ireland should champion future-impact assessments for EU legislation, that climate and biodiversity resilience, digital harms, fiscal sustainability, and social inclusion policies are evaluated for long-term consequences on today’s youths and future generations. The Presidency should establish a Future Generations Commissioner, ensure institutionalise youth participation in key Council dialogues, and champion sustainable financing models that do not externalise debt, climate instability, or digital risk to future citizens. Digital governance, trustworthy AI & information integrity - Finalise and operationalise the EU’s policy on AI, reinforce the Digital Services Act, and advance EU and multilateral positions on the UN Global Digital Compact for privacy, digital inclusion, disinformation, youth protection and societal wellbeing. Aim to produce Presidency-level guidance for AI transparency in public services, a European Council statement on platform accountability, and safeguards and digital literacy for schools and disadvantaged groups. SDG acceleration: finance, reporting and implementation - Ensuring that the SDG framework is utilised as a lens for EU legislative work to accelerate SDG implementation, e.g., the proposed Economic Impact Assessment should include long-term impacts to communities and the environment, and not only short-term financial gains. Also aim to secure political declaration for EU SDG Acceleration, establish blended-finance pipelines for nature-positive projects, especially through Irish Aid, thereby moving from rhetoric to measurable action. Just transition, regional cohesion and social inclusion - Resource and operationalise a Just Transition Fund that targets upskilling for green competitiveness and for expanding rural/island connectivity and digital inclusion. This could include an EU pilot for green/digital upskilling in remote regions in the spirit of “leave no one behind.” Science-policy integration & evidence for policy - Fast-track legislative/institutional links between EU research (Horizon) outputs and formalise expert rapid-response mechanisms for the climate and biodiversity crises and full SDG implementation for a fairer and more equitable Europe. Aim to create an EU Research & SDG Policy Lab to produce rapid evidence briefs and pilot policy tools that localise SDG targets. Climate and biodiversity resilience (marine and terrestrial) - Advance Nature Restoration Law roll-out, strengthen maritime biodiversity protection (MPAs) management and enforcement, nature-based coastal resilience measures, and integrate blue economy safeguards into EU maritime policies. Aim to commit member states to cross-boundary marine and coastal resilience and conservation programmes, fast-track nature restoration targets, and seed financing for blue-green local projects that integrate implementation of SDGs 13, 14 & 15 to regional resilience policies and practice.

response_text: Multilateral Renewal - The Irish Presidency should be commitment to principled multilateralism and cooperative global governance by supporting transparent financing for development, climate resilience, digital governance norms, and protection of global public goods. Broker EU consensus on reform of international financial institutions, enhancing joint climate–development diplomacy, and reinforce cooperation on information integrity and AI oversight. A strong and coherent EU voice, coordinated through Ireland’s Presidency, will help rebuild global trust and stabilise international partnerships in a fragmented geopolitical environment. Intergenerational Equity - Institutionalise meaningfully empowered youth participation, require future-impact assessments on major climate, digital, fiscal, and social proposals, and promote financing models that do not externalise ecological debt or economic precarity onto future citizens. This approach recognises that climate risk, biodiversity degradation, digital harms, and disinformation disproportionately impact the lives of youths and future Europeans. Embedding intergenerational responsibility will ensure that EU decisions protect not only present growth and competitiveness but long-term dignity, security, and planetary stability. Invest in Resilience and Inclusive Growth - Embed SDG-aligned thinking into EU legislation and budgetary decision-making. The Council can set the stage for long-term social and economic resilience. Encourage the adoption of an “EU SDG Acceleration Declaration” committing EU Member States to clear financing strategies, transparent progress reporting and partnership mechanisms. Capacity building for the labour force and SMEs on Education for Sustainable Development in public service (Education and Training) across the EU 27. Middle East and North Africa (MENA) cooperation on Migration and skill development and mobility. Promote blended-finance tools and de-risking instruments at EU level to mobilise sustainable investment — making green, social and infrastructure projects more accessible, especially for SMEs and communities. Secure a Trustworthy Digital Future – Support the UN Global Digital Compact and promote the need for fair, inclusive, and ethical digital governance. Advance AI regulation and digital services legislation that protect rights, privacy, wellbeing and inclusion, while enabling innovation. Promote digital literacy, access and inclusion initiatives so less-connected communities or disadvantaged groups are not left behind. Encourage regulatory clarity for digital SMEs and startups, ensuring smaller enterprises can operate under fair rules without stifling innovation. Support a Just Transition - A well-managed transition to a green, sustainable economy can bring new jobs, protect vulnerable regions, and preserve ecosystems while enabling long-term competitiveness. Embed principles of “just transition” into social and cohesion funding mechanisms co-created with workers, rural/island communities and disadvantaged groups. Drive cross-border cooperation on blue economy, rural regeneration, and nature-based projects to support both environmental goals and local livelihoods. Strengthen Science-Policy Integration - Drawing on SDSN Ireland’s vision for evidence-based sustainability, the Council can institutionalise rapid-response research-policy linkages. Establish an EU Research & SDG Policy Lab to channel academic and scientific expertise directly into Council decisions. Use research-driven SDG indicators to guide legislation and monitor outcomes thereby ensuring data-driven, transparent implementation. Stakeholder or Science engagement not just in consultation, but buddy or pairing schemes in EP and Council. Particularly for the March Multiannual Financial Framework.

response_text: Multilateral Renewal - Communicate EU membership as a practical insurance for stability, rights, culture, and collective problem-solving and that no nation can manage climate shocks, digital governance, migration, or security alone. By emphasising the EU’s role in fair digital rules, coordinated climate diplomacy, and crisis response, Ireland can show citizens that multilateralism is not distant bureaucracy, but it safeguards everyday wellbeing and democratic institutions. Intergenerational Equity - Framing EU cooperation as future-proofing can deepen citizen ownership. Own Europe’s commitment to climate action, biodiversity recovery, digital safety, and equitable opportunity. Ireland should communicate that EU policy reduces ecological debt, protects young people from disinformation and digital harm, and invests in education, upskilling, and green jobs. Communicating and Co-Creating EU Values - The core values embedded in the Pact for the Future, the SDGs, and the green-competitiveness priorities of the Danish Presidency offer a strong foundation for communicating what Ireland’s Presidency can deliver for its people, businesses, communities and the environment. To build public ownership, Ireland should adopt a transparent, participatory, and value-driven communication strategy that is meaningful to the individuals and those they love. A Shared Global-Local Pact - The EU isn’t just complex bureaucracy, but offers shared values of multilateral cooperation, human rights, sustainability, solidarity, and intergenerational equity. Citizens should hear that EU cooperation makes Ireland safer, more resilient, and more internationally responsible. Highlight how EU membership enables Ireland and its citizens to contribute and at times lead EU implementation of climate action, social inclusion, sustainable development, environmental protection, and global solidarity. Connect EU Action to Everyday Lives - Showcase success stories that are meaningful to the lives of individuals, families and communities including local initiatives in green infrastructure, digital inclusion, rural development, coastal resilience, healthcare, education, and EU funded projects. Celebrate our success but acknowledge shortcomings and areas to improve. Engage Citizens Directly - Launch an Irish Presidency Citizen Forum, facilitate online and local town-hall consultations, inviting citizens to propose priorities, comment on draft Presidency initiatives, and shape how EU-level decisions reflect local context. Include youth and future generations: create youth advisory panels for the Presidency, link with schools and third-level institutions to align with intergenerational equity goals. This could also be linked to the existing citizens assembly. A Platform for National Strength & Global Voice - Position EU membership as amplifying Ireland’s voice internationally: through climate diplomacy, global development, digital governance while reinforcing sovereignty by collaborating, not isolating. Convey solidarity - remind citizens that many challenges (climate change, pandemics, economic shocks, disinformation) are transnational and EU membership offers collective strength and shared burden. Tell the story on how the EU stood behind Ireland and the Good Friday Agreement during Brexit negotiations. Celebrate the Presidency - Brand the 2026 Presidency as a moment for Ireland to lead Europe and invite citizens to “own” it. Use storytelling, the arts, cultural events, public media campaigns, social media, community events, and civil society engagement to make it relatable.

geography: Main office is at the University of Limerick. Our membership comprises educators from 13 HEIs across the country. We are nationwide.
response_text: Priority: Promoting and supporting Global Citizenship Education (also referred to as Global Education in Europe) in all facets and levels of education. In line with the EU Strategic Agenda 2024–2029, the EU plays a vital role in emphasizing the upholding of core European values of freedom, democracy, equality, sustainability and human rights across societies. The EU presidency should ensure that relevant authorities and ministries appreciate the importance of education for justice, equality and sustainability as our most valuable tool to counter political extremism, radical right-winged ideologies, hate-motivated violence and manipulative propaganda that serves to instill fear and disquiet in people and societies. It is also crucial to understanding planetary interrelated crises of climate change, loss of habitat and biodiversity, and forced migration. The Council of the Europe must repeatedly reaffirmed the EU’s strong commitment to the SDGs, calling for accelerated implementation both within the Union and globally, mainstreaming the SDGs into policy sectors, and upholding the principles of no one left behind, social inclusion, environmental protection and economic stability.

geography: Main office is at the University of Limerick. Our membership comprises educators from 13 HEIs across the country. We are nationwide.
response_text: Strengthening the European Education Area (EEA) with a focus on citizenship and sustainability. The EU’s education policy already includes cooperation on quality, inclusion and green education as part of the European Education Area. This includes Council recommendations on education for environmental sustainability and competence frameworks such as GreenComp for sustainable development and climate education. The Irish Presidency could push for advancing these tools, promoting deeper integration of sustainability and global citizenship into national curricula and shared EU benchmarks. Ireland could encourage the adoption or updating of Council recommendations on: Education for democratic citizenship and human rights (building understanding of values, democracy and inclusion); Education for environmental sustainability and climate change; Global competence frameworks that help educators teach about global interdependence, social justice and interconnected challenges. These would provide policy clarity and incentives for member states to integrate global citizenship and sustainability systematically across education levels. Embed SDG 4.7 in EU Policy Coordination. SDG target 4.7 (education for sustainable development and global citizenship) could be emphasised more strongly in Council conclusions and in the Presidency’s agenda, encouraging monitoring, benchmarking and exchange of best practice across Member States for implementation. This aligns with broader EU goals on skills, lifelong learning and societal resilience Ireland could encourage aligning education policy with other EU priorities — such as Green Deal implementation, digital transition, and social cohesion — the Presidency can promote whole-of-society approaches where education for global citizenship becomes part of cross-sectoral policy coherence rather than a standalone initiative.

geography: Main office is at the University of Limerick. Our membership comprises educators from 13 HEIs across the country. We are nationwide.
response_text: By prioritising inclusive dialogue, knowledge exchange, and joint action frameworks, the Presidency can encourage cross-border cooperation on pressing crises such as climate change and migration, ensuring that policies are both locally grounded and coordinated at the EU level. Supporting joint funding mechanisms, green innovation programmes, and skills development can enable businesses and local actors to implement sustainable solutions, while harmonised migration policies and integration strategies can foster social cohesion and solidarity across borders. • By linking policy coherence, democratic participation, and practical collaboration, the Irish Presidency can help transform EU-wide commitments into tangible outcomes that unite people around solutions, rather than dividing them along national or sectoral lines, making progress on both climate action and humanitarian challenges visible and meaningful for all. As above, aligning education policy with other EU priorities — such as Green Deal implementation — solutions must be feasible and practical on the ground, and seek the voices of stakeholders particularly those who will be most impacted by change.

response_text: • Education has a crucial role to play in achieving this goal, and it must be addressed at all levels— from early years education, through primary and secondary schooling, examinations, and onward into Higher Education, Further Education, and Community Education. In Ireland, the Irish Development Education Association brings together relevant groups, while the Department of Foreign Affairs (Irish Aid) provides funding to support Global Citizenship Education, and the Department of Education and Youth drives this agenda through its national strategy on Education for Sustainable Development. This kind of cross-departmental collaboration is needed across Europe, and Ireland’s leadership in Global Citizenship Education offers a model that could inspire and inform initiatives throughout the EU.
