sector: National public health strategy, commercial determinants of health; planetary and public health.
response_text: The Most Exciting Ideas are Always in the most Boring Things: Public Procurement as Transformative Power Public institutions (schools and universities, government departments, the justice system, hospitals, libraries) spend €2.5 trillion on the provision of goods and services. At around 15% of all spending in EU, public institutions are one of the largest consumers in Europe (Public Procurement Database, Europe 2025). This is public procurement, and it is the catalyst through which Europe can drive population health, create a new meaning of competitiveness, and be the concrete manifestation of abstract values. Procurement is an excellent theme because cuts through all the themes of The EU Presidency; it gathers many different stakeholders – from farmers, to legal experts, to innovators, to health practitioner, to policymakers, to justice & equity stakeholders – in a forum that galvanises all of us in a common purpose; it has tangible goals and outcomes that can be felt by Europeans on the ground. Competitiveness: what incentives/disincentives are structurally within the procurement system that we want to enhance or replace? How can we change tax and subsidy levers to make sustainable/ecological/local options more affordable for public institutions? How can we use platforms and clearing houses to enable small and micro suppliers into the system? How can we easily verify sustainability claims? How can we ensure that compliance is the same amount of work for any supplier, large or small? What can we learn from other disciplines or areas of the economy that informs our perspective on competitiveness? Values: what types of values do we want to imbue in public procurement, and how do these differ regionally, and across goods? For example, food procurement might be envisioned as local, slow, less complex, and ecological. Medical procurement might be envisioned as scaled and speedy. What innovations are needed in supply chains to get the values we want? For example, how can we have less packaging in procurement, reward local producers, incentivise slow production techniques? How can we share goods and services with nearby institutions in frictionless and workable ways? Are there lessons from other economic domains on using supply chains to articulate values? How can the culture of public institutions change to become less materially intensive, or more frugal, and what are the hidden dangers in such culture shifts? What conflicts of interest exist between public and private exchanges of goods and services, and how can we improve this? Security: resilience is defined as ‘the ability of a system to recover from perturbation, the ability to repair itself’ (Meadows Thinking in Systems p.78). Its opposite is, surprisingly, stability (Meadows p. 77). Too much stability in a system makes it brittle and prone to systemic breakdown, but we desire stability as it drives productivity. Long, complex supply chains have huge stability benefits, and low resilience ones. What technology and metrics are available to measure ‘security’, and how can these be incorporated into decision dashboards? How much security is in our procurement is a balance of resilience and stability – have we got the right combination? For example, Ireland exports 90% of food it grows; it is one of the most nitrogen-intensive users in the world by size. This has resulted in stability (high productivity) but low resilience. (483 words)

organisation:
Trinity College Dublin 
Irish Doctors for the Environment
sector: National public health strategy, commercial determinants of health; planetary and public health.
response_text: The direct policy areas are in the directives on public procurement, especially the Public Sector Directive (Directive 2014/24) and the Utilities Directive (Directive 2014/25). However, changing this important legislation will have trickle-sideways effects to more recent directives, in particular the Waste Framework Directive (WFD), the Packaging and Packaging Waste Directive, Single-Use Plastics Directive (SUP), and Ecodesign for Sustainable Products Regulation (ESPR). The Presidency can achieve the realization that procurement is a way to talk about ecological crisis, cost-of-living, corruption/lobbying, and health in a new language that is practical, systemic, felt and positive. There would be five achievements: A greater ability of Europeans to walk around their public environments and ask the question “where does this stuff come from?” A crowd-sourced, rigorous legislative hackathon Europe-wide, that puts legal experts with all others involved in the provisioning of public procurement. A policy assembly (like a citizens’ assembly, but with policymakers) that vets the best legislative innovations Lobbying the EU to prototype the best legislative ‘products’, ringfencing them for a time-and place-bound experiment that can be researched. Hosting an interdisciplinary conference on Provisioning Systems, which brings together historians, literary theorists, economists, legislators, supply chain analysts, to discuss older versions of provision, the arcane bureaucracy that comes with it in the age of audit culture, as seen in art and novels as diverse as Kafka to David Foster Wallace, the efficiency paradoxes of stable provisioning systems, slow and fast supply chains, technological innovations, sharing economies, cultures of frugality and excess, and so on. Seeking a publisher to co-write a university textbook from the conference, and designing a module on Provisioning Systems that could be taught as a cross-disciplinary credit in European universities. (284 words)

organisation:
Trinity College Dublin 
Irish Doctors for the Environment
sector: National public health strategy, commercial determinants of health; planetary and public health.
response_text: The truly important thing about public procurement as a force for good is that it can achieve tangible and measurable changes in people’s everyday lives, on the ground, now. We have for the last 15 years been in an “envisioning era”, where every organisation and institution profusely produced missions about a glorious future and their ennobled purpose. We posit that the “structure of feeling” (Williams 1978) within Europe is that this logic and rhetoric is wearing thin, and we should grasp a mechanism such as procurement to embody and enact the vision, rather than articulate it in strategy documents, launches, websites and so on. The work of the Council could actually adopt a different tone-of-voice to that which everyone expects, and play with the idea of boring. Procurement is seen to be boring, but it is the secret spine that that stimulates: Innovation – legislative innovation on how to design policy and legislation to even the playing field, incorporate radical values, be hyper-local, massively micro, and so on. Instead of a tech hackathon, a legal and governance hackathon. The goal of this work would be to place the best proposals to into ‘legislative prototype’ – ring-fenced, time-bound real-world scenarios, and assess how they perform. So imagine if you could trial a clearing house for micro-farmers to supply food to hospitals in a region for a year, and see how the prototype worked; or if you could trial a sharing of a local school sharing the canteen of a university, and so on. (185 words)

organisation:
Trinity College Dublin 
Irish Doctors for the Environment
sector: National public health strategy, commercial determinants of health; planetary and public health.
response_text: Citizens on the ground come into contact with the EU not through vision statements and information campaigns, but the embodied experience of their public worlds – when play at school, get a medical test at a hospital, eat in a university canteen, and so on. We can make these public worlds “real utopias” (Wright, 2011) – spaces that articulate modest, sensible decisions about values, whether its labour rights, agro-ecological economy, local design, radical circularity, and so on. Procurement creates spaces, it shapes culture, it role models values. When you go into a public space that has made these decisions, you can feel this different world, and it can inspire you to require it in other spaces. This can have a lot of trickle-sideways effects. (122 words)

Housing must be a thematic priority for Ireland during the course of its Presidency of the Council in 2026. The housing crisis in Ireland remains the defining and most urgent issue in our society, and has been a dominant problem for the better part of the last 20 years. It is negatively impacted and shaped the lived experience of multiple generations and continues to cast a long shadow over our collective future. This issue is not just confined to Ireland. A recent research paper, “One roof, many realities: Europe’s complex housing crisis”, published by the Council of the European Union, clearly illustrated that this is a Union-wide problem. Affordability is one of the key issues when it comes to housing. Average housing prices have risen by 91.8% in Ireland between 2015 and 2025, and across Europe they have surged by 60.5%. As access to housing is increasingly constrained by unaffordable costs, the ensuing scarcity and precarity that people experience profoundly impacts them in vast number of ways. Essentially every social challenge that we must confront in both Ireland and the wider EU, from poverty and inequality to mental health, addiction, social cohesion and community development can be linked to a lack of access to housing. We must recognise this impact and reframe housing in a way that reflects its role at the heart of our society; as a fundamental human right and an essential social good. As the Council of the European Union’s recent research paper outlines, institutional investors such as private equity firms and real estate funds have been increasingly active in housing markets across the EU. For these entities, housing is primarily treated as a financial asset or investment vehicle. This is at odds with a recent statement made by President Ursula von der Leyen who said in September 2025 “Housing is about dignity. It is about fairness. And it is about Europe’s future. Eight years ago, the European Pillar of Social Rights made housing a social right in Europe. It’s time to turn this promise into reality”. It is impossible to reconcile this position with those who profit from the financialisation of housing and who are increasingly expanding their influence over housing markets. Since 2017, nearly half of all units in Ireland have been purchased by investment funds. In Sweden, institutional investors own 24% of private rental apartments. In the four largest Dutch cities, investors have bought a quarter of homes sold in recent years. The provision of social and affordable housing becomes even more challenging in the context of this landscape. Ireland should be using its Presidency of the Council to explore and examine how the EU can respond to this challenge. While there are significant variances across member states in their national housing problems, it is still the most profound and common issue that is shared among the citizens of the EU. It would be utterly irresponsible to dismiss these shared crises as a matter solely for national competence, and responding to them would be a way to show how meaningfully the EU’s actions can impact on the lives of Europeans.

Expanding EU supports for the development of public and social housing should be a core policy focus of work for the Irish Presidency. These supports should aim to increase state capacity for the provision of public and social housing, increase areas of innovation in the construction sectors to challenge the significant cost increases that the sector has faced over the last decade, and provide access to capital for states to embark on ambitious and radical housing policy. How housing is being viewed within the EU is shifting. The first ever European Affordable Housing Plan is set to be published next week. The Housing Advisory Board issued 15 recommendations to the European Parliament last week outlining the need for a “paradigm shift, so housing is seen as essential social as well as economic infrastructure and discourage the ‘financialisation’ of housing, where it is valued as a speculative asset rather than someone’s long term home”. The provision of social housing should be central to illustrating housing as an essential social good. The Board called for a reframing of affordability in the context of vibrancy and health of neighbourhoods and local communities, ending homelessness and taxing short term rentals as a means to fund these efforts. They suggested the promotion of cost rental models which, importantly, calculated rent based on actual costs of housing provisions rather than linked to market rents. Importantly in an Irish context, the Board recommended that there should be a focus on the efficient use of existing buildings and on urban regeneration, with a keen awareness to avoid displacement in these efforts. It is well documented that there are over 160,000 vacant homes in Ireland, and roughly 20,000 derelict properties. Tackling this should be a central policy focus during Ireland’s presidency. Another key recommendation that came from the Board was to insure minimum protection for tenants. They suggested that rental accommodation should “at a minimum, not pose a threat to the health and safety of tenants” and outlined how homelessness prevention should be made into a statutory obligation within national legal frameworks. The recommendations also included a call to amend State aid rules to help with housing provision. The EU has shown that it can provide significant resources to facilitate defence spending across member states, with the SAFE instrument providing €150 billion in loans for common procurement of defence equipment backed by the EU budget. EU Recovery funds that are due to cease in 2027 also showed how the Union was able to respond with huge resources to the challenges presented by the pandemic, with the largest stimulus package ever financed in Europe. The Board singled out existing financial instruments such as InvestEU to accelerate affordable housing supply. These instruments should also extend to the provision of social housing. The housing crises across member states are having immediate and profound impacts on the lives of millions of EU citizens right now. The intersection of these crises and the myriad of problems that are tearing the social fabric apart across the continent cannot be denied.

Any substantial positive impact for people is entirely contingent on delivery. Therefore, we need to address how delivery of a radical re-framing can be achieved. Something that is often communicated by the Irish Government is that the State does not have the capacity to finance wide-spread provision of public housing. Another key recommendation from the Housing Advisory Board was to fund better competence in assessing the financing and wider impacts of housing projects. They suggested that public authorities needed to strengthen financial literacy in housing project evaluation and public officials should be able to analyse housing project finances to be able to assess the real funding needs of projects and use subsidies more effectively. These types of measures are key to ensuring we can begin to build capacity within the State to effectively and efficiently deliver housing in a manner that can assess economic, social and environmental impacts simultaneously and find meaningful paths forward. Another issue that is raised is the State’s access to capital. Alongside the expansion of dedicated financial instruments designed for the provision of social and affordable housing, the Housing Advisory Board’s suggestion of the creation of a pan-European Affordable Housing Investment Fund could be a way to leverage the financial power of states collectively for the common good to create an EU-wide housing investment platform, investing equity and debt in different Member States into diversified forms of strictly regulated affordable housing and supporting infrastructure. Again, these mechanisms should also be explored for the provision of social housing. It is critical that we begin to develop state and EU led mechanisms that can shift away from our reliance on speculation by private investors for the provision of housing. This reliance will continue to have disastrous impacts on the lives of EU citizens and will continue to maintain a stranglehold on the provision of social housing and further exclude more and more proportions of society from the prospect of affordable home ownership. Local authorities still play an important role in the provision of social housing in Ireland, however they lack access to adequate resources to fulfil this function properly. As part of the introduction of any EU grants or financial instruments, local authorities should be able to directly access these funds and provided with the appropriate tools to utilise such monies. Construction costs have increased across the EU by 56% from 2010 to 2024. A significant substantial impact could come in tackling this barrier to affordable housing provision, for both public and private housing. The work of the Council should focus on sustainable, innovative methods in the construction sector to drive these costs down, such as Modern Methods of Construction and the requisite education and technical training that is required to implement such techniques.

EU citizens recognise the importance, value and benefit of EU membership when it has a positive impact in their everyday life. We already have clear examples of this when it comes to infrastructure in Ireland. Our road network is something that is widely recognised by Irish citizens as having been developed due to benefits accrued by our membership in the EU. Between 1994 and 1999, EU funding contributed to 61% of total expenditure on roads. When the resources of the EU are directed towards things that impact people’s lives is a positive and meaningful way, this will create a sense of ownership and pride amongst citizens. If the work of the Council can clearly contribute towards the provision of social and affordable housin, towards reframing housing as a social good and a fundamental human right, and if the actions of the EU can be seen to be challenging the interests of profit seeking speculators who seek to financialise housing markets and exclude more and more Europeans from the provision of social housing or the prospect of home ownership and housing security, then there won’t be much need to communicate the benefits and values of EU membership. It will simply become profoundly apparent in their lived experience.
Promoting a Culture of Peace for the People of Europe, Now and for the Future

International Relations/Foreign Affairs Friendly, co-operative international relations based in morality and justice; the pacific resolution of conflict through international arbitration or judicial determination, and adherence to international law. A Neutral Europe dedicated to co-operative and peaceful international relations across the globe; leaning on our ancient histories and cultures (going back, here in Ireland, for example, to Cáin Adomnán {Lex Innocentium} in the year 697 AD) to develop peaceful, non-violent ways to solve international conflicts and to ensure justice throughout the world. Establishment of the European Institute of Advanced Studies in Peace and Non-Violent Conflict Resolution, Dublin, modelled on Eamon De Valera’s Dublin Institute for Advanced Studies, 1940 (see additional information).

Keep us out of War. The Irish Presidency is of particular importance in these times of heightened international fear and mistrust. We are, and have long been, a neutral country. We have no war history. We have never attacked another country and we have no enemies. We have a long and proud history of voluntary services overseas, missionary work, famine relief and development projects. We also have a long, consistent and proud history of international peacekeeping with the United Nations. We enjoy excellent relations across the world. We have a cherished diaspora in every corner of the world. All the world becomes Irish on our national feast day, St. Patrick’s Day, and our Passport is welcome everywhere. We also have the experience of colonialism, the struggle for independence, and the Northern Ireland Peace Process. Who better, then, than an Irish Presidency to lead Europe out of these dark and unenlightened times? The Irish Government should have the confidence to do this. In another time of darkness (the Dark Ages), the Irish were known as the Island of Saints and Scholars. We established schools all over Europe, and people from all around Europe came to Ireland to study. Some historians say that the Irish Saved Civilization (e.g. Cahill, 1995). We might need to again! Will our government have the courage to try? For reassurance and conviction, they might look to Brigid, Colmcille, Adomnán, O’Connell, Louie Bennett, De Valera, Aiken, Casement, McBride, Childers – just for example!

Listen to the People. The European Union was originally established as a Peace Project after the devastation of Europe in the Second World War. Ireland is in a unique position to lead the European Union back to this wonderful vision and heritage. We believe that many of the current European Leaders are out of touch with their people and that the citizens of the European Union (in particular, the younger citizens) have become disillusioned by the policies of their governments in relation to militarism, international law and justice, and the protection of the natural environment – their planet. The EU must live up to its peace-project identity and aims by listening to the people, talking peace, not war; bringing an end to militarization, practising and modelling good international relations and statecraft and promoting diplomacy. Movement away from the militarization of the European Union will release resources back into social and environmental funds for the welfare of the citizens and people of the union. A move away from militarization with its vast expense will also release funds for the protection of the best of our patrimony – our land, water and air, and will enable the people of Europe to develop ways of protecting our continent from climate change and global warming.

In 1940, Taoiseach Eamon De Valera established the Dublin Institute for Advanced Studies as a statutory, independent research institute. Mr. De Valera was criticized for establishing the Dublin Institute in a time of war. However, he maintained that it is precisely during times of war that we must turn to education, learning and reason. De Valera’s Dublin Institute for Advanced Studies consisted of three schools – the School of Theoretical Physics, the School of Cosmic Physics and the School of Celtic Studies. Mr. De Valera was keen to develop knowledge of the sciences in Ireland. However, he had special reasons for including the School of Celtic Studies. While he wished to preserve our language and our manuscripts, one of Mr. De Valera’s principal aims was that the people of Ireland would become culturally confident and independent in thought and scholarship. Following in the wisdom and the footsteps of Mr. De Valera, at this time of heightened international aggression and mistrust, we believe that it is now time to establish the European Institute of Advanced Studies in Peace and Non-Violent Conflict Resolution, Dublin. We believe that the blueprint for this institute is set out in Article 29 of our Constitution: Devotion to the ideal of peace and friendly co-operation amongst nations founded on international justice and morality. Adherence to the principle of the pacific settlement of international disputes by international arbitration or judicial determination. Recognition and acceptance of the principles of international law. In keeping with Mr. De Valera’s aims – a culturally confident people, independent in thought and scholarship, with the principles set out for us in Article 29 of Bunreacht na hÉireann, and against the backdrop of a very real threat of WW III, we propose that we use the Irish EU Presidency as the launching pad for the European Institution for the Advanced Study of Peace and Non-Violent Conflict Resolution, Dublin.

organisation: European Academy of Dermatology and Venereology (EADV)
response_text: Prevention could serve as a highly impactful thematic priority for the Irish Presidency. In dermatology, Ireland has already demonstrated leadership by initiating a public consultation on banning sunbeds, one of the most harmful and avoidable risk factors for skin cancer. As Europe has the highest number of UVattributable cancer cases, representing 46% of all cases worldwide, we see this thematic priority as a key opportunity to reduce such burden. EADV welcomes the Institute of Public Health’s (IPH) report on suggesting a sunbed ban to reduce skin cancer in Ireland and seeks to transfer the scientific findings into actionable policies to safeguard the public. Public health campaigns in schools promoting sun protection and sun-safe behaviours have been wellreceived, and similar preventive initiatives could be highlighted and expanded during the Presidency. The theme of prevention could also extend to measures reducing children’s exposure to harmful content, including the promotion of unrealistic beauty ideals that may encourage unsafe practices like sunbed use. Stepping up the work in preventive health is also part of the Mission that Commission President Von der Leyen assigned to the Commissioner of Health and Food Safety. Any work on prevention should include skin cancer, a largely neglected disease that poses a huge burden on Europe’s healthcare systems and economy. Ireland’s Presidency of the Council comes at an ideal time to promote stronger sunbed regulation and skin-health initiatives. Ireland is already recognised as a leader in this area, and there is growing momentum across Europe for tighter controls on sunbed use. The European Code Against Cancer outlines 14 recommendations for preventing cancer through personal behaviours and broader public-health measures. The eighth recommendation warns against excessive sun exposure and explicitly advises to “never use sunbeds”, urging policymakers to harmonise and enforce policies and recommendations on protection from exposure to UV radiation – including from sunbeds - across the EU. Furthermore, the World Health Assembly adopted in May 2025 a Resolution classifying skin diseases as a global health priority, urging governments and the international community to prioritise these conditions in their health programmes. The Irish Presidency is therefore uniquely positioned to lead the EU on skin cancer prevention (particularly regulating the use of sunbeds) and will be able to draw on international examples to limit the existence of skin cancer through sunbed use. EADV would be happy to support the Council in its work and to provide our expertise in the subject area.

organisation: European Academy of Dermatology and Venereology (EADV)
response_text: The European Commission argues that the Low Voltage Directive (LVD) (2014/35/EU) in combination with the General Product Safety Regulation (Regulation (EU) 2023/988) are sufficient to protect individuals from the dangers of sunbed exposure. However, in reality, the LVD only governs the intensity of UV in sunbeds, but not the exposure duration, which is far more relevant according to the Scientific Committee on Health, Environmental, and Emerging Risks (SCHEER). The GPSR similarly cannot regulate exposure behaviour, despite the Commission arguing that the GPSR addresses all other health concerns outside of the LVD. In addition, under the LVD, the EU standard for sunbeds, EN 60335-2-27, allows a total erythemaeffective irradiance of <0.3 W/m² (made up of <0.15 W/m2 UVB and <0.15 W/m2 UVA), equivalent to an “extreme” UV index. At this intensity, unprotected skin can burn within minutes. Therefore, new legislation is necessary in the area of sunbed use in the EU to address one of the most preventable risk factors for skin cancer. It is key to note that individuals who use sunbeds have an 83% higher risk of developing skin cancer. Despite this evidence and the existence of legislation that bans sunbed use for children under 18 in Ireland, the UK, and over 20 EU Member States, many minors are still accessing sunbeds, increasing their chances of skin cancer. We would like to build on the excellence of the Irish Department of Health and continue its work on inhibiting preventable risk factors for skin cancer. In order to continue this work at the EU level and ensure that EU citizens, particularly children, are protected from skin cancer, we would advocate for the proposal of Council Conclusions on skin cancer prevention, echoing the need for a partial or full ban on sunbed use in the EU. This topic could be further addressed through a High-Level event under the patronage of the Irish Presidency, gathering representatives across the EU institutions and associations to amplify the need for a ban on sunbed use (at least for minors) across the EU. We would request additional attention towards the protection of children and young people from harmful content on social media, including material that promotes negative body image or unsafe behaviours like excessive tanning. We are pleased with the Council Conclusions for greater efforts to protect the mental health of children and teenagers in the digital era reached in June. It is essential to continue the work on protecting young people from material that promotes negative body image or unsafe behaviours such as excessive tanning. In a poll for European children from 2023, 68% felt the need to look beautiful on social media, with 51% of them feeling the need to change something about their bodies. We stand prepared to work with the Council on ensuring the protection of children and young people on social media.

organisation: European Academy of Dermatology and Venereology (EADV)
response_text: We believe that impactful work from the Council will be twofold. Firstly, the Council’s policy work will be chief in producing the most substantial positive impact for the people and businesses of the EU, namely through its work on achieving a potential ban on sunbed usage to reduce the prevalence of skin cancer. As noted in a 2020 study on the impact of policy-based interventions, it was found that a ban on commercial indoor tanning, in combination with a public information campaign on the use of sunbeds, would result in 204,000 melanomas and 2.4 million keratinocyte carcinomas in Europe, saving EUR 21.1 billion. This policy work from the Council is the first key step in bringing the most positive results to the people of the EU. Secondly, it will be paramount to engage with stakeholders to maximise the impact of the Presidency and ensure that policies are given sufficient support. As a professional society representing leading experts in dermatology, we are eager to support any relevant initiatives the Presidency chooses to champion. With a community of more than 12,000 members across all EU Member States, and a broad network of established communication channels, we are well-positioned to amplify the visibility, reach, and effectiveness of these efforts. Additionally, Ireland has been a trailblazer in the area of sunbed regulation, and through its continued advocacy and excellence in this area, the Irish Presidency can pave the way for a Europe better protected from skin cancer.

organisation: European Academy of Dermatology and Venereology (EADV)
response_text: As noted above, we believe that engagement with stakeholder organisations such as the EADV can significantly enhance the reach of Ireland’s Presidency. Leveraging established networks of relevant constituents will ensure that initiatives achieve maximum visibility and impact. By highlighting how EU membership and policies impact citizens’ daily lives, the Presidency can make the Union tangible and relevant. As the EU champions public health initiatives for all EU Member States, it is key to emphasise the work the Irish Council Presidency does during its term that makes a difference. We believe that due to the increasing prevalence of skin cancer diagnoses in the EU, skin cancer prevention efforts would generate an impactful outcome for those living with skin cancer and those susceptible to it. Disseminating the harmful impacts of sunbeds through digital platforms, traditional media, and public events could be combined to ensure that diverse audiences learn of the work of the Irish Presidency and feel that their concerns are represented in EU decisions. As above, we feel that engagement with stakeholder organisations such as the EADV will help to broaden the reach of Ireland’s Presidency and will allow existing networks of relevant constituents to be exploited for maximum impact.

geography: Limerick City & County: Our core activities are based in Limerick City and County, addressing local food security, community engagement, and sustainable food systems. While our primary impact is focused on the city & county, we actively collaborate with national networks and European partners, sharing best practices, sharing our partnership model and contributing to EU-wide initiatives on food sustainability and social inclusion. This multi-level approach ensures that local actions are informed by European standards and that Limerick serves as a model for integrated food partnership strategies. We are currently engaged in the following European Programmes. FEAST2030, CLEVERFOOD, FutureFoods
