response_text: Question 5 – Any other comments Respondents are welcome to submit additional information alongside Submission Form. However, in such cases, respondents must provide a summary of the additional information under the ‘Any other comments’ question. This summary should also be limited to a maximum of 500 words.

sector: Higher education, student mobility, and youth engagement, with a focus on EU education policy and the implementation of Erasmus+ Programmes.
geography: National and EU-wide. The submission reflects experiences across Irish Higher Education Institutions, including both urban and regional contexts, and is informed by Europe-wide student perspectives through the Erasmus Student Network.
response_text: Ireland's 2026 Presidency should take an approach that places young people, education and learning opportunities at the centre of EU policies, alongside a strong focus on inclusion, skills development, youth participation and practical implementation. In line with the EU Strategic Agenda 2024–2029, the Presidency should focus on priorities that strengthen social cohesion, support Europe’s long-term competitiveness and ensure that EU policies make a real difference in people’s lives, particularly for younger generations. Inclusion, Opportunity and Social Cohesion Ireland should prioritise policies that widen access to education, training and mobility opportunities and address barriers that limit participation in EU initiatives. Social, economic and regional inequalities continue to shape who is able to benefit from EU programmes in practice. Education, training and learning mobility play an important role in bringing people together, strengthening intercultural understanding and supporting democratic resilience, especially for young people and students from under-represented backgrounds. A stronger focus on inclusion helps ensure that EU education and youth policies remain fair and sustainable over time, and supports the agenda objective of strengthening democracy and social resilience. Skills, Education and EU Competitiveness The Presidency should underline the role of education, skills development and youth mobility as long-term investments in Europe’s future. Learning mobility under the Erasmus + Programme contributes to the Union of Skills by developing adaptable, multilingual and interculturally competent graduates, while also supporting their transition into the labour market and contributing to innovation and productivity across the Union. When education, employability and lifelong learning are better connected, regions are better placed to grow and benefit from the Single Market. Youth Participation and Practical Implementation Ireland should place strong emphasis on how EU policies affecting young people and learners are delivered in practice. At the same time, young people, students and civil society organisations should be actively involved in shaping and communicating EU priorities. This supports democratic participation and helps build a sense of shared ownership over EU decision-making. Consistent with the European Commission’s 2026 Work Programme focus on simplification, Ireland is well placed to champion a practical approach that improves how EU policies function on the ground. Youth-facing programmes are particularly sensitive to administrative complexity, delays and inconsistent implementation across Member States. Clearer processes, lower administrative burden and better coordination between institutions and authorities are essential if EU education and youth programmes are to work as intended. Combined, these priorities would support a Presidency that is inclusive, forward-looking and focused on practical outcomes, while helping Ireland guide the Council's work in a balanced and constructive way.

sector: Higher education, student mobility, and youth engagement, with a focus on EU education policy and the implementation of Erasmus+ Programmes.
geography: National and EU-wide. The submission reflects experiences across Irish Higher Education Institutions, including both urban and regional contexts, and is informed by Europe-wide student perspectives through the Erasmus Student Network.
response_text: ESN Ireland recommends that Ireland’s Presidency should focus on policy areas where progress can improve how EU policies are delivered in practice, particularly in the fields of education, youth, skills and mobility. These areas are central to the work of the Education, Youth, Culture and Sport Council and have clear links to employment and competitiveness objectives. A key priority should be the implementation of Erasmus+ and other EU education and youth programmes. While these programmes are widely recognised as successful, challenges remain in areas such as accessibility, inclusion and consistency across Member States. Europe-wide student evidence highlights challenges related to grant predictability, inclusion support, accommodation shortages and uneven recognition of learning outcomes. Addressing these issues does not require new legislative frameworks, but rather improved guidance, monitoring and coordination among institutions and national authorities, which the presidency should support. Secondly, the Presidency should support progress on recognition of learning and skills, building on existing Council Recommendations and Bologna tools. Automatic and timely recognition remains inconsistent across Member States and institutions, affecting academic progression and employability outcomes. Thirdly, Ireland’s Presidency could facilitate EU-level discussion on student accommodation and cost-of-living pressures, which increasingly affect access to education and mobility. Sharing experiences and good practice across Member States could help address common challenges. Lastly, Ireland should advance discussions on administrative simplification and digitalisation, in line with the Commission’s 2026 Work Programme. Complex and disconnected procedures can discourage participation and place unnecessary strain on institutions. The Presidency could encourage practical steps to streamline processes and improve coordination between national and institutional levels. Across these areas, the Presidency should aim to achieve practical improvements that make EU policies easier to access and more effective for those they are intended to support.

sector: Higher education, student mobility, and youth engagement, with a focus on EU education policy and the implementation of Erasmus+ Programmes.
geography: National and EU-wide. The submission reflects experiences across Irish Higher Education Institutions, including both urban and regional contexts, and is informed by Europe-wide student perspectives through the Erasmus Student Network.
response_text: Ireland’s Presidency can make a strong impact by focusing on how EU policies are experienced in practice and ensuring that Council work translates into real benefits for people and communities. This strategic challenge should focus on connecting policy to projects and institutionalising youth voice. First, the Presidency should prioritise effective delivery and implementation of existing EU initiatives, such as the Erasmus + Programme. Many EU programmes already have strong policy foundations, but their impact depends on how well they function in practice. By promoting this, the Council can help ensure that EU policies are accessible and workable for citizens, educational institutions and civil society organizations. The Irish Presidency can leverage the Erasmus+ Programme to make the most substantial impact in this area by championing the Vocational Education and Training (VET) dimension and focusing on real-world recognition of skills acquired through mobility programmes. This can be done by: Advocating for the prioritisation and increase in volume of Key Action 1 mobility for VET learners and apprentices. Standardising recognition and certification for hidden skills gained abroad such as resilience, adaptability, cultural competence and language skills through the use of the Youthpass certification for non-formal learning and the Europass mobility document for formal learning. However, the most immediate and substantial impact Ireland’s Presidency can have on young people is by making the Erasmus+ programme accessible to those considered to be with “fewer opportunities”, as defined by the Erasmus+ regulation, by lobbying the European Commission and other Member States to simplify funding access by focussing on small-scale partnerships under Key Action 2 and encouraging the use of the ‘Exceptional Costs’ category within Key Action 1 to remove financial barriers for persons with disabilities or with socio-economic needs. Additionally, Ireland’s Presidency could lobby for the maximum allowable pre-financing of these costs prior to mobility as this is vital in tackling the financial barriers/burden associated with mobility programmes like Erasmus+ for young people coming from disadvantaged backgrounds. By strategically focusing its efforts within the Council on the financial flexibility and skills recognition mechanisms of the Erasmus+ Inclusion and Diversity Strategy, the Irish Presidency can make the Programme an unparalleled tool for promoting social inclusion and economic opportunity for the most vulnerable young people across the EU.

sector: Higher education, student mobility, and youth engagement, with a focus on EU education policy and the implementation of Erasmus+ Programmes.
geography: National and EU-wide. The submission reflects experiences across Irish Higher Education Institutions, including both urban and regional contexts, and is informed by Europe-wide student perspectives through the Erasmus Student Network.
response_text: Ireland’s Presidency can best communicate the values and benefits of EU membership by: Shifting its focus on local impact by launching an initiative that brings the Presidency to the community by connecting every ministerial meeting’s outcome to a specific local youth project or community group such as an Erasmus+ project. Utilising digital forms of media such as social media platforms to engage national/EU youth-focused organisations to shed a light on Council decision-making, policy debates and outcomes. This provides valuable transparency and accountability by meeting young people precisely where they are and by presenting the information in an accessible yet digestible format. Embedding EU values in education by promoting the integration of EU values via non-formal and informal learning outlets, such as youth work (something Ireland has a strong track record in). Elevating EU youth dialogue by hosting the final EU Youth Conference of the current Youth Dialogue cycle as the Presidency’s flagship event. This would shift the youth consultation and presentation of policy recommendations by young people from being a nicety to a compulsory step in policy design, validating young people’s expertise and giving them agency over the Presidency’s agenda. A youth check on Presidency Priorities by establishing a Youth Advisory Panel diversely compose of young people and youth workers to vet the Priorities of the Irish Presidency and the accompanying Council Conclusions. This would give young EU citizens a visible, structured role in shaping the work of the Ireland Presidency as youth-proofed. Showcasing mobility as civic action by reframing the Erasmus+ Programme and the European Solidarity Corps projects as acts of European citizenship (volunteering, cross-border cooperation, diversification of youth engagement) as opposed to travel/study/work opportunities. Ireland’s existing strengths in youth work as managed by the National Youth Council of Ireland and its commitment to the EU Youth Strategy, position it perfectly for this Presidency to lead by example. A highly appropriate response to this would be to use the Presidency to institutionalise youth voice, turning policy consultation into genuine policy input and demonstrating that the Council’s work is directly influenced by its young citizens.

For its 2026 EU Presidency, Ireland should prioritise sustainable energy, rural resilience, and communitycentred governance. In particular, the rapid scaling of biomethane under REPowerEU highlights the urgent need for independent impact assessments, strict environmental safeguards, and oversight of public subsidies to prevent unsustainable industrial-scale biogas projects. Ireland can lead by embedding legally binding rules on feedstock use, digestate management, and spatial planning, ensuring local communities have a real voice in decision-making rather than bearing disproportionate social and environmental costs. By championing a model that balances climate, biodiversity, and rural development goals, Ireland can set a European benchmark for fair, sustainable energy transitions. Prioritising transparency, equitable benefitsharing, and preventative regulation will help avoid repeating mistakes seen elsewhere in Europe, reinforcing trust in decarbonisation policies. These thematic priorities will position Ireland as a leader in creating energy strategies that are both ambitious and socially responsible.

The European Commission’s REPowerEU action plan has set biomethane production on a course of massive upscale as part of efforts to increase EU energy independence, fixing a target of 35 billion cubic meters (bcm) per year by 2030 – up from 4,1 bcm in 2023. However, until this day, no Impact Assessment was carried out on the target. As biomethane production continues to grow rapidly both in Ireland and Europe (with a currently 21% year-over-year growth), so do concerns about its associated environmental and social risks as well as the irresponsible use of taxpayers money. While biogas production from sludge or collecting the gas that is produced in landfills is appropriate, there are particular concerns about the effects of large-scale biogas production on the use of limited agricultural land, the continuation of polluting industrial animal production, harm to local communities, and the effects of methane leaking from biogas facilities. Further concerns arise when looking closer at promoted use cases for biomethane such as heating or transport which are often inefficient, expensive, and lock Europe into existing fossil infrastructure. The Irish Presidency should therefore prioritize conducting an independent, interdisciplinary impact assessment to evaluate the feasibility and sustainability of this target, ensuring it aligns with climate, biodiversity, and rural community goals. Emphasis must be placed on implementing strict economic, environmental, and social safeguards for biogas and biomethane production. With reference to the Commission’s 2026 Work Programme as well as the wider EU Strategic Agenda that highlights the need to secure Europe’s energy independence, we therefore encourage the Irish Presidency to: Advocate for an independent impact assessment of the EU’s 35 bcm biomethane target, as a prerequisite to develop further any expansion of biomethane production as part of relevant policy files in 2026, such as the Circular Economy Act, Bioeconomy Strategy, Livestock Strategy, Energy Union Governance Upgrade, and Common Agricultural Policy. This includes prioritizing truly sustainable feedstocks, efficient use cases, and avoiding lock-ins of fossil infrastructure. Include the voices of local communities in the debate. In order to expand biomethane production rapidly, the 2025 REPowerEU roadmap foresees a “tripartite contract to better address the diverging needs in different areas of the EU and include national and local stakeholders”. However, a focus has been set on facilitating dialogue between the EU Commission, EU Member States’ governments as well as industrial stakeholders; and no commitment has been made to give a role to local communities themselves that are affected by such projects. In line with its “peoplecentred” approach, the Presidency should therefore intensify its efforts to give the Irish people and local communities across Europe a greater say in the development of fair and sustainable biomethane strategies. Scrutinise public subsidy schemes for unsustainable biomethane production. This is critical to prevent perverse incentives that undermine the EU’s climate, food security, and energy independence goals. Current subsidies often favour industrial-scale biogas projects reliant on unsustainable feedstocks - such as manure from factory farming or energy crops competing with food production - which lock in polluting practices as well as animal welfare violations, and divert resources from truly circular solutions. Without strict oversight, these subsidies risk distorting markets, inflating demand for unsustainable livestock farming, and sidelining local, communityled projects that deliver genuine environmental and social benefits.

Ireland’s presidency provides a unique opportunity to develop and promote a gold standard indigenous biogas industry that is sized and scaled to meet community needs. Learning from EU countries with an established biogas industry, Ireland can avoid the pitfalls of social acceptance that are consistently documented as barriers to bioenergy projects across the EU (Mancini & Raggi, 2022). Current regulatory gaps and weak planning assessments underestimate the cumulative impacts on rural infrastructure. Public health and safety questions about hazardous gas storage, particular emissions and emergency service access are heightened when regulatory oversight is perceived as reactive rather than preventative. Research has highlighted that digestate management and changes in feedstock mixes are critical risk vectors that demand much stronger regulation than is currently applied (Piadeh et. al, 2024). Ireland, through its presidency, can set the standard by developing industry-specific planning regulations that include community engagement at its core. The National Biomethane Strategy points directly to a highly industrialised model aimed at rapid development across rural Ireland. Within this model, revenue accrues to outside multi-national agriinvestors while costs are borne by host communities in terms of road damage, odour, environmental degradation, and reduced property values. Communities demand transparent environmental impact assessments, accessible monitoring data and enforceable operating limits. The development of industryspecific planning regulations aligned with benefit-sharing mechanisms has the potential to provide a blueprint for use across the EU, while maintaining community engagement and the highest environmental standards. Meaningful community engagement, spatial planning that respects local carrying capacity, strict feedstock limits, alongside legally binding digestate management plans, are safeguards that would increase local acceptance. Rapid roll-out risks polarising rural communities, undermining trust in decarbonisation policy, and producing environmental and social harms that outweigh local benefits. Ireland has an opportunity through its EU presidency to either lead and develop new industry standards or to repeat mistakes already impacting the rural communities and the environment across Europe.

Promoting Physical Activity as a European Policy Priority Regular physical activity is one of the most effective and accessible ways to improve public health, strengthen communities, and support social well-being. As Ireland prepares to assume the Presidency of the Council of the European Union in 2026, there is a significant opportunity to elevate physical activity as a strategic policy priority across EU institutions and Member States. Doing so would align with Ireland’s national strengths in sport, community engagement, and public health promotion, while contributing to EU-wide ambitions for healthier, more inclusive societies. As a policy priority, there are cross-sectional benefits to physical activity; Future proofing public health – promoting preventative healthcare, physical activity, physical literacy, and active living has both physical and mental health benefits. Strengthening communities – across Europe there are many communities that have insufficient access to physical activity facilities, amenities, active travel opportunities. Through its Presidency of the Council, Ireland can play a leading role in coordinating best practice in this area among member states to address this lack of opportunities and focus. Basis for inclusion as a policy priority: Despite decades of research and public campaigns, one-third of EU citizens do not meet recommended physical activity levels, and 45% report never engaging in sport or exercise. This widespread inactivity negatively impacts individual health, creates long-term pressure on healthcare systems, and undermines social cohesion. Inactivity is influenced by complex factors, including limited access to facilities, socioeconomic barriers, gender disparities, and health-related constraints. Addressing these challenges requires coordinated, cross-sectoral action across health, education, transport, urban planning, and social policy.

Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) 2028–2034 Ireland’s Presidency will occur during a pivotal phase in MFF negotiations. This presents a unique opportunity to prioritise sport and physical activity in future EU funding: Advocate for a dedicated EU budget line for local sport infrastructure. Promote recognition of sport and physical activity infrastructure as a core investment category under cohesion policy. Support the development of EU-wide minimum standards for local sport facilities, ensuring equitable access according to population needs and geography. Call for Erasmus+ Sport funding to be earmarked at a minimum of 5% to support grassroots participation. Strengthen sport and physical activity’s role in EU4Health, integrating sport into preventive healthcare strategies to combat chronic diseases and mental health challenges. Revision of the HEPA Recommendations The European Commission is expected to propose a revision of the Health-Enhancing Physical Activity (HEPA) recommendations in late 2026 or early 2027: Ireland can lead on consensus-building to modernise HEPA guidelines. The Presidency can promote stronger reporting mechanisms, data collection, cross-sectoral implementation, and an increased focus on physical literacy. New EU Strategy: "A Strategic Vision for Sport in Europe" (2026) The Commission will launch a long-term strategy in Q4 2026 on sport: The Presidency can ensure a strong focus on grassroots sport, community health, inclusion, and local implementation. • As part of this long-term strategy, Ireland should play a leading role in promoting a broader approach to sport and physical activity in line with the All-Island Physical Literacy Consensus Statement (2022). This statement provides opportunities for implementation at an individual, organisational, and systemic levels to promote effective advocacy and development of Physical Literacy in Ireland and Northern Ireland. A focus on this would promote consistent understanding, implementation, and advancement of Physical Literacy throughout the EU. 4. Active Cities and Local Sports Partnerships • Ireland can highlight best practice from the 29 Local Sports Partnerships and Limerick’s Global Active City Certification. This aligns with EU goals on sustainable urban development, active mobility, and community well-being. 6. Gender Equality in Sport EU Gender Equality Week (November 2026) provides a platform to: Highlight Ireland’s progress in promoting gender equality, but also to highlight the continuing inequities Promote safe, inclusive sporting environments Address gender‑based violence and stereotypes in sport

A Presidency focus on physical activity can deliver tangible benefits across public health and wellbeing, enhancing communities and social cohesion. For people: Improved physical and mental health Reduced chronic disease burden Increased social connection and community participation Healthier digital habits for children and young people For communities: Better local infrastructure and more inclusive and accessible public spaces More active and connected communities Enhanced cross-departmental collaboration For businesses: Reduced absenteeism, improved workforce well-being and productivity Opportunities for innovation in digital health, sport tech, and community design By embedding physical activity into EU policy frameworks, Ireland can help create long-term, sustainable improvements in public health and social cohesion.

Utilising physical activity as a policy priority can provide many tangible avenues for connecting EU citizens to EU institutions and promoting the benefits of EU membership directly through campaigns, events, and cultural exchange through sport. The key opportunities to achieve this are; European Week of Sport 2026 - Mobilise Local Authorities, LSPs, NGBs, and community groups to create a nationwide celebration of EU values through sport with a launch event in Dublin. Promoting Cultural Exchange through Sport and Physical Activity – Use the promotion of sport and physical activity as a platform for connecting EU citizens through the promotion of national games like Gaelic Games. EU-wide campaigns - Promote initiatives such as “Stroll More, Scroll Less” to connect EU policy with children’s well-being and online safety. High-level events - Special Olympics events and the TAFISA European Sport for All Games offer further opportunities to connect citizens to the Council Presidency.
All Island Physical Literacy Consensus Statement 2022 - Physical Literacy Statement.pdf

geography: West/North-West Region of Ireland (mixed urban & rural)
response_text: Developing sustainable and resilient environments, on land and at sea How Ireland and the EU may utilise its considerable research and innovation excellence to reduce health inequalities Utilising transformative data and artificial intelligence to boost economies and inward investment.

geography: West/North-West Region of Ireland (mixed urban & rural)
response_text: Accelerating green energy production on land and at sea. Reducing bureaucracy and cutting through “red tape” to create a more agile EU. Promoting access to and involvement in lifelong learning opportunities to upskill the workforce.

geography: West/North-West Region of Ireland (mixed urban & rural)
response_text: Increase investment in research and innovation to drive short- and long-term impactful benefits for societies, particularly to encourage working across different sectors (e.g., HEI, industry). Reducing burden of over-compliance and create a more agile/responsive and less risk-averse system.

geography: West/North-West Region of Ireland (mixed urban & rural)
response_text: Chose tractable targets that are meaningful to Irish and other EU citizens and have a laser sharp focus on delivering change in these areas. There is a widespread perception that the EU is ponderous and bureaucratic: making inroads into this area, even if small gains, would be powerful.

Ireland’s 2026 Presidency is an opportunity to help shape a competitive, sustainable and people-centred Europe at a pivotal time in the EU’s economic and regulatory agenda. Primark recommends the following high-level priorities that reflect the EU Strategic Agenda, Ireland’s consultation framing, and the needs of businesses and citizens across the Union. 1. A Competitive and Integrated Single Market Ireland should champion policies that enhance Europe’s competitiveness, reduce administrative complexity through harmonisation of interpretation and implementation of regulation across the EU, and support innovation and investment. A focus on regulatory coherence, simplification and digitalisation (objectives outlined in this consultation overview) will support Europe’s retail sector, improve productivity and preserve affordability for consumers. This aligns with Primark’s emphasis on a predictable, proportionate regulatory environment that enables physical retail and digital businesses to operate on a level playing field. 2. A Coherent, Practical and Ambitious Transition to a Circular Economy Ireland is uniquely positioned to lead discussions on the Circular Economy Act and the Environmental Omnibus Package. Primark supports an approach that balances ambition with feasibility, ensuring EU-wide harmonisation in areas such as eco-modulation, waste definitions and end-of-waste criteria. Specifically, we expect a deeper revision of the EPR in line with the Environmental Omnibus plans. In addition, the integration of the SCIP provisions into the Digital Product Passport requires sensible implementation. A harmonised framework will advance circularity while lowering administrative burden and supporting affordable access to more sustainable products. Strengthening EU-wide durability requirements is also critical, and Primark is committed to contributing to solutions that extend product lifespans while supporting a competitive and affordable single market. 3. A People-Centred Europe Supporting Affordability and Inclusion As an Irish-founded international retailer, Primark strongly supports an EU that protects and promotes jobs, recognising retail’s role as the largest private sector employer in the EU economy, strengthens community life across urban and rural areas, and maintains access to affordable, more sustainable products. This aligns with the consultation’s emphasis on an inclusive, future-oriented vision for the Union and should be a thematic focus of the Presidency.

Ireland’s Presidency will coincide with negotiations on key sustainability and competitiveness files. Primark recommends a consultative approach with industry and adequate timelines for any new requirements, with the Presidency prioritising the following: 1. Circular Economy Act (CEA) The CEA is central to Europe’s transition to circularity. Ireland should aim to secure: EU-wide harmonisation of EPR and PRO rules, including a digital one-stop-shop to simplify reporting and reduce duplication. Aligned eco-modulation criteria across ESPR, WFD and packaging rules to ensure consistency. EU-wide end-of-waste criteria and clarified waste-ownership rules, enabling cross-border reuse, recycling and innovation. Proportionate, phased transition timelines to support investment and maintain affordability. 2. Environmental Omnibus Package & ESPR Delegated Acts Ireland should promote coherence across interlinked legislation to avoid conflicting requirements and unnecessary administrative burdens. Key aims should include: Ensuring product durability, recyclability and recycled content requirements reflect technical feasibility, material availability and do not compromise affordability. Alignment between Digital Product Passport rules, SCIP provisions, textile labelling and related data requirements, preventing duplication. 3. A Stronger, Fairer Single Market for Retail and Consumers Ireland should support measures that ensure balanced competition between physical and digital retailers. As highlighted in Presidency planning, traditional retailers are often disproportionately affected by fragmented compliance obligations across a wide range of areas compared to some online entrants. Simplification and harmonisation are critical to maintaining a fair and competitive marketplace. 4. Investment in Circular Infrastructure The Presidency should promote EU and global investment in textile-to-textile recycling, sorting capacity and circular supply chain development, acknowledging that circularity is a global value chain requiring EU and non-EU cooperation. The Just Transition should be considered. 5. Coherence in Consumer Information and Environmental Claims Ireland should champion an EU-wide, harmonised approach to environmental claims to avoid fragmentation and multiple advertising regimes to comply with whilst strengthening consumer trust.

The Irish Presidency can deliver meaningful outcomes for citizens and businesses by ensuring that competitiveness, affordability and sustainability advance together. 1. Reduce administrative burden and support affordability Harmonised reporting systems, coherent definitions and aligned timelines will reduce compliance costs and help ensure that products remain affordable. The EU Commission has already stated that it has a goal of making business easier and faster in Europe. The Irish Presidency can deliver on that goal. 2. Support jobs, communities and shopping destinations Retail is the EU’s largest private sector employer, providing jobs for nearly 30 million people, and is a key contributor to community vitality. Primark’s footprint across Europe demonstrates the positive economic and social impact of physical retail. A balanced regulatory framework and level playing field will help safeguard employment and revitalise high street and shopping districts across the EU. 3. Enable citizens to participate in the circular economy Clear, consistent rules on product design, waste handling and sustainability information will make it easier for citizens to engage in reuse and recycling initiatives. Improved infrastructure, supported through EPR revenues and EU investment, will deliver visible, local benefits. 4. Provide regulatory predictability that drives innovation Businesses need stable, coherent rules to invest in new materials, recycling solutions and circular business models. A Presidency agenda that emphasises proportionality and synchronisation will unlock innovation across the Single Market. 5. Ensure the sustainability transition is inclusive The Presidency should continue emphasising that sustainability and affordability must move in parallel, so that all households can access more sustainable products. This principle is central to Primark’s business model and its sustainability strategy, Primark Cares.

To build trust, engagement and ownership, the Presidency should communicate EU benefits in ways that are accessible, tangible and people-centred. 1. Highlight everyday benefits of EU membership Ireland should communicate how EU legislation improves lives through strong consumer protection, environmental standards, workers’ rights and access to affordable products. These are all themes that, if communicated effectively, will be widely understood by citizens. 2. Showcase Irish leadership in sustainability and innovation The Government intends to highlight leading Irish businesses during the Presidency, including those contributing to Europe’s circular transition. Primark’s sustainability commitments and its progress against these, shown in its latest Sustainability & Ethics report and forthcoming EU Textile Transition Pathway pledges provide credible examples of Irish-led sustainability progress. 3. Connect sustainability with fairness and affordability Communications should reflect citizens’ concerns about cost-of-living pressures. A Presidency narrative that emphasises fairness, inclusivity and a just transition will resonate strongly across Europe. 4. Transparency and participation Open consultations, public-facing Presidency events and transparent communication on Presidency milestones will help citizens understand and feel part of Ireland’s EU leadership role. Clear explanations of how EU decisions influence everyday issues—such as consumer protections, product safety, environmental standards, digital rights and the affordability of essential goods—can make the Presidency’s work more relevant and accessible. Demonstrating these concrete benefits, alongside opportunities for direct engagement, will strengthen public confidence in EU policymaking and reinforce the value of Ireland’s contribution to shaping outcomes that impact people’s daily lives.

Primark welcomes the opportunity to contribute to Ireland’s preparations for its 2026 EU Presidency and supports the Government’s ambition to champion a competitive, more sustainable and people-centred Europe. We believe the Presidency can play a pivotal role in shaping a regulatory environment that supports innovation, strengthens the Single Market and makes the transition to a circular economy both practical and affordable for citizens. As the EU advances legislation to support the transition to a circular economy, Ireland is well placed to promote an approach centred on harmonisation, proportionality and coherence across the regulatory landscape. Primark strongly supports efforts to simplify compliance, align definitions and timelines, and promote digital tools that reduce administrative burden. Such measures are essential to ensuring that sustainability and environmental ambitions are delivered in a way that strengthens competitiveness, facilitates investment and protects consumer affordability. We also encourage the Presidency to highlight the importance of well-designed EPR systems and circular infrastructure that can operate effectively across borders. Harmonised reporting, clear end-of-waste criteria, and transparent governance structures will be critical enablers of a functioning circular economy. Investment in sorting, recycling and reuse capacity will help unlock real progress and give citizens meaningful ways to participate in circularity. Ireland’s Presidency offers a unique opportunity to showcase the contribution of Irish businesses to the European economy, including companies committed to advancing sustainability while maintaining affordability. Primark is proud of its Irish heritage and of its role supporting employment, shopping destinations and communities across the EU. We believe the Presidency can amplify positive examples of industry leadership that align with EU values and demonstrate how competitiveness, sustainability and inclusion can reinforce one another. In this context, Primark encourages the Government to champion a narrative that balances environmental ambition with economic resilience and social impact. A Presidency focus on practical, implementable regulation, on strengthening the Single Market, and on ensuring the green transition is fair and accessible will deliver benefits for people, businesses and communities across Europe. Primark stands ready to support the Government before and during the Presidency period, including by sharing insights from across the retail and textile sectors, participating in relevant stakeholder discussions and events, and contributing to initiatives that advance circularity and consumer awareness. In fact, we hope to be involved in at least one associated event around the Presidency and will be in contact with the relevant Government Department once there is greater clarity on event formation. We look forward to working collaboratively to help Ireland deliver a successful and impactful Presidency that reflects the values and interests of the Union and its citizens.

geography: Focused at improving the conditions of farm families and rural areas nationally and through cooperation EU Member State Organizations.
response_text: Given that agriculture is Ireland’s largest indigenous industry, exporting over €18.1 billion worth of goods in 2024 and supporting over 300,000 jobs directly and indirectly, it is imperative that a competitive agriculture sector is a central priority of the Irish Presidency of the EU in 2026. Given the timing of the Irish Presidency and the Council objective of concluding specific negotiations by the end of 2026. It is likely that Ireland will conclude negotiations on the Multiannual Financial Framework and Common Agricultural Policy which gives further importance to placing agriculture at the very center of the Presidency Priorities, and specifically an increased budget allocation for all genuine active farmers. A Profitable European Agriculture Sector: Agriculture across the EU faces significant challenges which have been further compounded following the COVID-19 crisis and the Russian invasion of Ukraine. Market volatility for both output and input prices have become commonplace which has made the sector more unstable. There is a sustained focus and necessity to attract young people into the farming sector and how to make farming more attractive in the EU. There is a lack of understanding on areas like the current costs of running a farming enterprise, the cost of compliance and how this has impacts on viability, attracting younger people into the sector and stabilizing incomes. If the EU Institutions are serious about the future of farming in Europe, making the sector attractive via fair and stable incomes should be central to this. Similarly, continually raiding CAP for environmental ambition will not promote greater economic nor social sustainability. New, independent money is needed. CAP should be for farmers and food production. Environmental action, including that of NRL obligations, should be funded elsewhere. A Fair Global Trading Environment: Global Trade has also become increasingly volatile in recent years stemming from significant geopolitical events which continue to shape and change how agricultural goods are traded. Ireland is a highly export oriented country especially in terms of meat and dairy. Our products are internationally recognized for their quality, traceability and commitments to high levels of animal welfare. The same standards do not apply globally and Irish and EU produce face increasing competition from produce that is not produced to the same EU phytosanitary and welfare standards. As stated in the Vision for Agriculture and Food – The EU must investigate further how it can prevent products which are not produced to the same standards from entering the EU Food Chain. This must encompass a central tenet to the success / progression of current and future EU trade agreements. True Simplification and Better Regulation: There is a significant push towards simplification in the current EU Commission spanning all sectors of the economy, yet farmers across the EU still contend with disproportionate levels of bureaucracy and incoherent legislation from the previous EU mandate that is not conducive to the effort to achieve a more competitive EU Agriculture Sector. There must be an absolute commitment to simplifying the implementation of EU laws for farmers directly on the ground. Equally the EU must move towards a more coherent system for proposing any new directives and regulations which are pragmatic and considerate of realities on the ground. There are too many examples of laws which have been proposed by the Commission which are eventually discovered to be unimplementable and not conducive to running a business competitively in the EU. Agriculture must be a centrally involved in the Communication on Better Regulation expected in 2026.

geography: Focused at improving the conditions of farm families and rural areas nationally and through cooperation EU Member State Organizations.
response_text: Common Agricultural Policy Regulation Post 2027 (Proposed) The announcement of the new structure, governance, and budget reduction of the CAP in July 2024 has brought significant concern over the most important policy to Irish farmers and has led to protests by farmers in Brussels. The new governance structure of the CAP represents a dilution of stakeholder input into the CAP and does not promote simplification. This proposal is hugely concerning for Irish farmers with up to 75% of family farm income in vulnerable sectors derived from Direct Payments in 2023/24. The proposal represents the potential loss of a ringfenced CAP fund and has completely eroded the Pillar 2 element focusing on infrastructure and Agri-environment schemes. This CAP proposal also has the potential to impose added liability to National Governments in terms of governance. The lack of ringfencing leaves the policy vulnerable to government change and thus the types of supports that farmers may receive. This offers little room for long term planning and has the potential to result in disjointed schemes and infrastructure commitments, neither of which are conducive to environmental improvement. It is imperative that under the Irish presidency, the government garners support for further ringfencing and significant increases in the commitments in the NRPPs surrounding agricultural productivity and food production for the benefit of all genuine active farmers. Amending EC Regulation 1/2005 on Live Animal Transport (Proposed) Ireland’s location as an island nation on the western fringes of the European Union must be considered when potentially revising the live Animal Transport regulation with key consideration given to the length of allowable journey times to ensure the continuity of trade between Ireland and EU member states and Ireland and third countries as well as the age of calves on when they can be first transported. An electrolyte feed as an alternative to milk replacers during transport must also be considered due to inconsistencies in the composition of different milk replacers and nutritional upsets in calves will increase if only protein-based feeds are used in transport. Ireland is a leader of best practice in terms of animal transport and has implemented both the current Regulation 1/2005 and additional measures beyond the current legislation to ensure good animal welfare during transport. Consideration of this must be given in any further revisions which could cause a disproportionate economic burden to Irish farmers. Full access and continuation of third country exports must also be assured given their economic importance to livestock producers and role as a competitive, fair and functioning market for Irish farmers. Ireland has demonstrated its commitment to safe third country exports via additional monitoring measures and reporting during transport, often being the only EU member state to do so. Unfair Trading Practices (Update of rules on unfair trading practices in the food chain (legislative, Article 43 TFEU, Q3 2026) A proposal on the revision of the UTP legislation is likely to be negotiated under the Irish Presidency. Under this revision, there should be greater powers given to the national competent authorities which enforce the UTPs. The EU should pay closer attention to the price returns occurring across food supply chains and aim for the greatest levels of transparency and fairness to be incorporated into agri-food supply chains particularly for those in the domestic retail market. Livestock strategy including elements on animal welfare (Q2 2026) Ireland is specifically well placed to contribute significantly to the future proposal of an EU Livestock Strategy. Irelands agriculture model is unique to the context of European Agriculture given that is predominantly grass based and livestock focused. Ireland is a leader in terms of progressive livestock farming with extensive research and extension services which could be a model to other member states in terms of livestock policy. The livestock strategy should promote animal farming and as stated in the vision recognise that ‘no one size fits all’ when it comes to livestock production in the EU.

geography: Focused at improving the conditions of farm families and rural areas nationally and through cooperation EU Member State Organizations.
response_text: Ireland has one of the highest shares of its population living rurally in Europe and this should be an important part of Ireland’s Presidency of the EU. It would be important that the benefits that come with hosting the presidency are not confined to purely to urban centers, but instead in locations where EU Legislation / proposals may have greatest impact (e.g. NRL and Western regions). This can serve as an example to other member states that rural communities should not be alienated by the EU and that it is listening and engaging with the issues that are affecting rural people across the EU. Other previous presidencies have shown the value of hosting presidency events outside of Capital cities, the Polish presidency utilized Gdansk and Poznan while the Belgian presidency regularly hosted events in Ghent. EU support is most visible in the Irish countryside with rural development projects in most communities and the impact of the CAP is visible in almost every farm yard in Ireland. The importance that this investment has had on Ireland cannot be underestimated and at a time when the CAP is coming under financial pressure from budget cuts, it should be displayed widely the impact that EU funding has had on modernizing the landscape of Irish Agriculture. Recognizing this rural demography, of which farming plays an important role in supporting, the Irish Presidency should place focus on policies which have significant socio-economic impacts for rural people, businesses, and communities. Ireland is distinctly unique in terms of its geographical location, climate, and agriculture model more broadly. An example of this being that more than 90% of Ireland’s agricultural area is covered by grasslands which is drastically more than the EU average. Equally Ireland has a distinctly high percentage of peatland soils which are important in the context of EU climate policy. The Government should take this opportunity to demonstrate Irelands unique characteristics to other EU delegations during the Presidency so they can understand Ireland better when it comes to future EU policy making. This will have benefits for rural people, businesses, and communities if other EU countries can understand Ireland more accurately moving forward. Farm visits should be incorporated into agriculture focused visits especially in July and September when weather is favorable.

geography: Focused at improving the conditions of farm families and rural areas nationally and through cooperation EU Member State Organizations.
response_text: In the months leading up to the Presidency, it is important that the Government communicates clearly what the significance of the Presidency is but equally how it functions in a simplified and digestible manner for those with more limited knowledge of how the EU functions. The EU legislative process and institutions themselves are complex and the government should try to increase general literacy of the European Union in the lead up to the Presidency. This can help people understand more what competencies the EU has and how it impacts them more directly, this can in turn help with creating a positive light around the presidency. In an agricultural context, communicating the development journey and transformation that Ireland has come on since joining the EU in 1973 would be valuable. While this has overwhelmingly been a positive journey and farmers appreciate the significant impact that EU has had on Ireland, there have also been challenging times for both Irish and EU agriculture including the BSE crisis and various CAP reforms. Highlighting this journey through events and agricultural media would be important.

respondent_type: Response on behalf of the European Cancer Organisation, a not-for-profit umbrella organisation.
response_text: ECO recommends that the Irish Presidency of the EU include in its high level thematic priorities: the preservation and enhancement of the European Health Union. In Ireland, 44,000 citizens are diagnosed with cancer every year, and 9,800 people die from the disease, making cancer the most common cause of death. This places a devastating burden on the Irish society and its healthcare system, with annual spending on cancer care reaching €1.14 billion and indirect costs amounting to €639 million. In recent years, the development and delivery of targeted policies have shown real impact in easing this burden. Notable examples include the EU Cancer Mission on cancer and Europe’s Beating Cancer Plan, yet also Ireland’s National Cancer Strategy for 2017–2026. These had a concrete impact on Ireland, through: With a rate of 7%, Ireland has the lowest rate of smoking among 15-year-olds in the EU, making it an example of how to implement the EU's Beating Cancer Plan, aiming to create a tobacco-free generation by 2040. Reaching out an 83% immunisation rate for HPV vaccination in 2022, close to the EU target of eliminating cervical cancer by 2040 through gender-neutral vaccination (WHO). Introducing a Central Bank (Amendment) Bill in February 2025 to prohibit financial service providers from discriminating against survivors of cancer from accessing financial services, paving the way for a stronger Right to be Forgotten. This underscores the strategic value of a coordinated approach, with EU and national initiatives reinforcing one another. Keeping health and cancer care high on the political agenda in Ireland and across the EU is therefore essential to sustaining momentum and addressing the enduring challenges at both levels. Without strengthened screening, prevention, and treatment pathways, Ireland risks facing an additional 15,000 new cancer cases every year by 2040, along with a continued increase in cancer deaths ; According to OECD, in 2022, more than half of adults in Ireland were either overweight or obese; Ireland’s breast-cancer screening programme has missed its targets for the past two years, with a target of 195,000 women in 2024, yet only 137,134 were screened. Despite this urge, the European Commission appears to be shifting health policy further into the frame of broader “competitiveness” priorities in the next Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) for 2028-2034. Under the proposed Commission architecture, the EU4Health Programme would be discontinued, eliminating the EU’s dedicated funding stream for health and cancer-specific initiatives. Instead, health is set to be incorporated into a wider Competitiveness Fund, under "health, biotech, agriculture and bioeconomy" heading. This merger risks diluting cancer-focused initiatives, as the overlap between these diverse policy areas may reduce their visibility and impact. In setting its high-level thematic priorities for its 2026 Presidency of the Council, Ireland should place cancer and health at the centre of its programming priorities. Building on its reputation as a cancer champion, Ireland is uniquely positioned to lead by example, setting high standards for other EU Member States. Strong and visible leadership is essential to ensure that health and cancer care remain prominent on the political agenda, both in overarching policy priorities and in the negotiations for the next Multiannual Financial Framework.

respondent_type: Response on behalf of the European Cancer Organisation, a not-for-profit umbrella organisation.
response_text: The Irish Presidency will take office at a moment when the European Union must decide whether to consolidate or dilute the gains made through Europe’s Beating Cancer Plan. The Presidency can play a pivotal role in the following areas: 1. Advancing Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) 2028–2034 negotiations With EU4Health no longer operating as a dedicated health instrument, cancer-related actions risk being absorbed into wide, catch-all funding envelopes in the next MFF 2028-2034. This makes it harder to guarantee that cancer priorities receive the targeted, ring-fenced investment needed to sustain progress. ECO calls on the Presidency to: Champion a €2 billion European Cancer Fund within the Competitiveness Fund to guarantee full implementation of Europe’s Beating Cancer Plan and ensure cancer is not marginalised within wider “Health, Biotech, Resilience and Bioeconomy” agendas. Strengthen the cancer relevance of National and Regional Partnership Plans (NRPPs) by raising the share for social objectives to 20%, enabling investment in national cancer screening, vaccination infrastructure, oncology workforce capacity and modern cancer-data systems. Secure the continuation of the Cancer Mission as a future Horizon Europe “moonshot” and support consideration of a European Cancer Institute to coordinate EU-wide cancer research and innovation. Calling for stronger and harmonised tobacco control policies Tobacco is a leading cause of preventable death in the EU, claiming over 700,000 lives annually and accounting for 27% of all cancer cases. The Presidency should push for the following measures: Advancing the revision of the Tobacco Taxation Directive and Tobacco Products Directive, ensuring higher and more consistent excise duties across all tobacco and nicotine products, including novel products that disproportionately attract young people; Facilitate agreement on New Own Resources, particularly the Tobacco Excise Duty Own Resource, generating sustainable revenue while reinforcing cancer and health prevention objectives. Showcasing Irish position on Alcohol policies Europe has the highest level of alcohol drinking globally. 7 of the top 10 countries with the highest alcohol consumption are in the EU, where approximately 240,000 people died because of alcohol in 2019. The Irish Government’s pioneering move to introduce legislation on alcohol labelling marked an important first step towards a healthier Europe. However, the subsequent announced delay to the measures being introduced cited, among other reasons, a need for European alignment on alcohol labelling. The Irish Presidency should therefore prioritise the following measures: Support greater consensus between EU member states on achieving health warnings on alcohol labelling across Europe – as was promised in Europe’s Beating Cancer Plan Within this, ensure consumers rights are upheld by mandating inclusion of a full list of all ingredients in all alcoholic beverages 3. Pushing for cancer to be integrated in the upcoming Gender Equality Strategy The forthcoming EU Gender Equality Strategy, expected for adoption in March 2026, will come before the Irish Presidency at first reading, giving Ireland a critical opportunity to reinforce the ambition and clarity of the text. The Strategy identifies health as a guiding principle; an approach ECO strongly welcomes. Yet to be truly effective, it must explicitly embed a holistic understanding of health, ensuring that gender-related disparities across cancer prevention, screening, diagnosis, treatment and survivorship are fully addressed. You may read more on ECO’s 5 Women Cancer Rights here: https://europeancancer.org/resources/news/press-release-introducing-five-basic-cancer-rights-for-women-at-the-european-parliament.html 4. Pushing for cancer to be integrated in other equality frameworks The Irish Presidency has an opportunity to make cancer a clearer priority across EU equality initiatives. By embedding cancer considerations within work on intergenerational fairness, anti-poverty measures and the emerging European Housing Strategy, the Presidency can help ensure that social and environmental determinants, such as age-relate vulnerability, income inequality and poor housing conditions, are addressed in a coherent way. This would strengthen the Union’s wider equality agenda while supporting more effective cancer prevention and protection for those most at risk.

respondent_type: Response on behalf of the European Cancer Organisation, a not-for-profit umbrella organisation.
response_text: The organisation of a High-Level event on Cancer, included directly in the Irish Presidency Programme, would provide a first means to achieve positive impact on the European cancer community. It could notably support elevating cancer as a strategic EU priority during the MFF 2028–2034 negotiations, ensuring it is addressed with dedicated focus rather than subsumed under broader competitiveness considerations. By providing the cancer community with a structured platform to contribute expertise, facilitating the exchange of best practices, and fostering multi-stakeholder collaboration, such an event would and drives actionable measures that improve outcomes for patients and communities across Europe. Such an event could also focus on areas where Ireland has demonstrated leadership, such as policies on alcohol and tobacco control, showcasing best-practice approaches that can be adopted across the EU. In parallel, an event hosted by the cancer community under the auspices of the Irish Presidency would offer a distinct but complementary space to elevate patient voices on distinct topics, highlight innovative initiatives and EU-funded projects for instance lead by Ireland, and foster collaboration across sectors. By demonstrating that the community is prepared to contribute expertise, this event can strengthen stakeholder engagement, bringing together healthcare professionals, researchers, patient organisations, and industry representatives in a more flexible, action-oriented setting. An example of a European Cancer Organisation led, national event focused on Ireland & Cancer policies can be found here : https://www.europeancancer.org/timetoaccelerate/impact/resource/together-against-cancer-ireland.html

respondent_type: Response on behalf of the European Cancer Organisation, a not-for-profit umbrella organisation.
response_text: In 2024, 76% if the Irish population declared being in favour of a common EU health policy and 4 out of 5 people in Ireland believe there should be more investment in cancer services. To demonstrate the value of EU membership and foster citizen ownership of Ireland’s Presidency, emphasis should be placed on concrete achievements. Europe’s Beating Cancer Plan illustrates how EU coordination enhances cancer prevention, treatment, and research, Ireland has for example benefited from increased investment in cancer prevention, treatment, and research, strengthening the healthcare system and improving outcomes for patients across the country. From 1973 up to 2018 Ireland was a net recipient of over €40 billion in EU funds; The European Health Data Space (EHDS) supports Ireland’s use of health and cancer data, with €3.6 million funding to establish a national Health Data Access Body for research and personalised care. The upcoming Irish Presidency, therefore, provides an opportunity to ensure that health and cancer care remain a central theme of the Irish Presidency, mirroring the Irish population’s key asks. The Irish Presidency could, for example, showcase how policy actions developed by Irish civil society, such as the National Cancer Information System (NCIS), which ensures that 16 of 26 chemotherapy-providing hospitals in Ireland can work together , the new radiation oncology centre in Galway, which has driven improvements in treatment and after-care for cancer patients, and the €95 million spent on anti-smoking initiatives since 2017, could contribute to the successful implementation of the EU's Beating Cancer Plan across Member States. By doing so, benefit will be provided not only to Irish cancer patients, healthcare professionals and researchers through increased investment in cancer care, but also to Irish society as a whole by addressing the indirect costs of cancer on Irish society.

geography:
CWI is a national organisation with members across the country working in rural and urban areas across the country.  Since its establishment, CWI has led the development of a wide range of strategic and action focused initiatives to reach its goals. The organisation has a membership of  The board or Central Group of CWI comprises a diverse group of people with significant experience and expertise in the field of community development including practitioners, academics and those with a long history of volunteering. Those that community work Ireland works with (target groups) are community workers, volunteers, community groups and marginalised communities who share its vision and values.  CWI has shown its ability to adapt quickly and respond to new issues and challenges. Needs are identified through consistent membership engagement, meetings, symposia, seminars, training, regional meetings & events, surveys & working group meetings. Key activities since 2020 include policy work – (briefs, position papers, submissions and representation), provision of training & supporting education for community workers, joint projects with other organisations on climate, mental health & tackling far right organising, production of resources webinars & toolkits, collaborative research, communications (e newsletters, website), joint organisation of the annual SIF, engaging with other organisations in the sector, supporting the Community Development Programme, provision of networking & sharing opportunities for members, establishment of networks and alliances on key issues (Ukraine, mental health, Covid 19).
CWI is associated with the International Association for Community Development
response_text: CWI and in consultation with members proposes a focus on the themes of: Protecting civil society and strengthening Democracy (including a focus on community development and collaborative governance) A strong vision for a social Europe Commitments to a Just Transition Human Rights and Social Inclusion There are many challenges facing communities across Europe including: Increasing levels of poverty, divisions, community tensions, the spread of disinformation l and conflict as a direct result of the activities of people seeking to spread hate and fear in communities, ongoing racism against and exclusion of the Traveller and Roma communities, lack of supports and resources for women experiencing domestic violence , a growing drugs crisis across urban and rural areas, a growing and serious mental health crisis especially within marginalised communities, the housing crisis and the climate crisis which will eventually affecting all communities across Europe but in particular those experiencing the highest levels of poverty. The Irish Presidency has potential to have an ambitious focus on building social cohesion and solidarity across Europe, strengthening commitments to end poverty, strengthen integration and tackle the spread of hate and fear, tackle the climate crisis and commit to the development of strong collaborative processes and partnerships with civil society based on core values of human rights, sustainability and social inclusion and which place the voices of those who are most marginalised in all their diversity at their centre.

Advancing human rights through stronger human rights and equality legislation across Europe Supporting autonomous community development work based on core values of collectivity, particpaiton, community empowerment, equality, Strengthening public participation through support for grass roots organisations working on human rights, equality and social inclusion. ‘A Life we Can all Afford’ – Setting ambitious antipoverty targets across Europe Building and strengthening the voice of those most marginalised in policy making through the creation of collaborative processes of decision making at EU level. Advancing implementation of the European Civil Society Strategy.

response_text: Strengthen grass roots community organisations Put in place measures to address the spread of hate and fear in our communities including through investment in strong and effective community development measures Engage marginalised communities in genuine dialogue and deep listening on the issues and challenges that they face and responses required Ensuring safe pathways for those seeking international protection Communicate the work of the Council in ways that are easily understandable and relatable to communities Hold inclusive events and opportunities for community involvement and engagement in the Presidency Make funding available to the community sector to engage in the Presidency Ensure a strong focus on anti-racism and social cohesion as a cross cutting theme Address the harms done to democracy and society by big tech firms - of recommender system; empower civil society organisations to take action to address and counter the spread of hate fear and disinformation online

response_text: Create value based narratives and illustrate clearly Ireland’s vision for an inclusive, socially cohesive, democratic and inclusive Europe committed to upholding human rights. Ensure strong commitments to addressing the challenges facing communities and society including, housing, cost of living, access to public services. Engage with civil society and community development organisations across the country through regional events and roundtables on Presidency priorities. Use creative methods and means of engaging people including young people in discussions, dialogue and debate on EU priorities. Use existing mechanisms such as the Annual Social Inclusion Forum and Civic Forum to communicate and dialogue on EU priorities.

response_text: Europe is at a cross roads and the Irish Presidency of the Council of Europe is a key moment and opportunity to show leadership in the direction that Europe will take into the future. It is essential that Ireland shows leadership in advancing an agenda of equality, human rights, social inclusion and defence of democracy. Supporting civil society nationally and across Europe and enhancing and resourcing grass roots community work at local and regional levels are key aspects of building community resilience and engagement. The Presidency should be used as an opportunity to show case excellent community work practice and government support for same, building on Irelands reputation as an international leader in the promotion and protection of human rights.

organisation: Irish Consortium on Gender Based Violence
response_text: Respect for Human Rights, including Gender Equality, the elimination of gender-based violence and the protection of civil society space

organisation: Irish Consortium on Gender Based Violence
response_text: To do all in its power to ensure the fulfilment of SDG5 on Gender Equality, paying particular attention to targets 5.2 End all violence and exploitation against women and girls and Target 5.3 Eliminate Forced Marriages and Genital Mutilation Ensure that sufficient resourcing is allocated to enable the fulfilment of Europe’s international human rights obligations before increasing any allocation to the European Defence Union.

organisation: Irish Consortium on Gender Based Violence
response_text: That Ireland advocate for a dedicated funding line for the prevention and mitigation of, and response to gender-based violence, within the Multi-annual Financial Framework or where such a budget line is not an option, to advocate at every opportunity for funding to go towards GBV, within the MFF, both in Overseas Development Assistance and within Europe.

geography: Belong To works with and on behalf of LGBTQ+ young people aged 10 to 23 in Ireland. The organisation is also a member of ILGA-Europe — the European Region of the International Lesbian,
response_text: A theme of inclusion and equality should form one of the high-level priorities for Ireland’s Presidency of the Council in 2026. The Commission Work Programme 2026 positions itself as “a pitch for unity, a programme for delivery and a plan for togetherness and an independent Europe”. In the face of fragmenting forces, Ireland’s role offers an opportunity to demonstrate the inseparability of inclusion and a stable, thriving Union. This choice directly supports the work programme’s priorities of: “Supporting people and strengthening Europe’s social model”; and “Upholding democracy, the rule of law and protecting our values.” It also supports the Strategic Agenda 2024–29 priorities of: “Upholding European values within the Union”; and “Living up to our values at global level.” Within this theme, LGBTQ+ inclusion must feature as a high-level priority. Recent findings from the European Union Agency for Fundamental Rights (FRA) indicate a significant rise in hate-motivated harassment across the EU. The European Commission Against Racism and Intolerance (ECRI) published its Sixth report on Ireland in 2025, which flagged a number of areas of concern related to LGBTQ+ communities, including mental health, hate speech, conversion practices, school inclusion, and nonconsensual medical interventions performed on intersex children. At the same time, rising authoritarian movements seek to undermine human rights, and weaponise LGBTQ+ communities in pursuit of this goal. As the EU LGBTIQ+ Equality Strategy 2026–30 notes: [A] recent OECD study refers to annual GDP losses in the EU associated with discrimination based on sexual orientation of up to EUR 89 million. The same study highlights that the impact of discrimination extends beyond the economy. It undermines social cohesion, weakens civic trust and erodes support for democratic values. Inclusive societies are more resilient, marked by greater solidarity, stronger institutions and higher levels of civic participation. (4) Responding in solidarity with those communities most affected demonstrates a commitment to the safety and full participation of all EU citizens, and reflects an active pursuit of social cohesion. Youth participation and inclusion must also feature prominently within this theme. The National Youth Council of Ireland’s recent Connecting EU with Youth report found that “young people's sense of belonging is tied to feeling safe, included, and empowered” (5), and that they are experiencing “a ‘loss of hope’ due to the perceived erosion of core EU values” (24). At the same time, they “find official EU language to be overcomplicated and express scepticism about the implementation of recommendations from consultation processes” (5). To sustain youth support for the EU now and into the future, Ireland’s Presidency of the Council must build in a significant theme of youth engagement and empowerment, including LGBTQ+ youth.

geography: Belong To works with and on behalf of LGBTQ+ young people aged 10 to 23 in Ireland. The organisation is also a member of ILGA-Europe — the European Region of the International Lesbian,
response_text: Implementation of the new EU LGBTIQ+ Equality Strategy 2026–30 Ireland’s Presidency will coincide with the early phases of implementation of the EU LGBTIQ+ Equality Strategy (2026–2030). Given civil society concerns that the new strategy falls behind the ambitions of its predecessor, its credibility must be demonstrated through decisive Council action and political commitment. Ending Conversion Practices The Presidency must support the Commission to enable Member states to end so-called “conversion practices”, or efforts to change or suppress an LGBTIQ+ person's identity. Aims: Drive forward commitments in the EU LGBTIQ+ Equality Strategy 2026–30, supporting engagement in structured dialogue and enabling Member states to combat conversion practices at a national level. EU LGBTIQ+ Equality Strategy 2026–30 commitments: Promote structured dialogue on the topic, in particular through the expert group on LGBTIQ+ equality, under the High-Level Group on non-discrimination, equality, and diversity. Based on the study’s findings, the Commission will take appropriate action to combat conversion practices, with a particular focus on supporting Member states, who play a critical role in this area. Harmonising hate offences across the EU The Union's response to hate offences is currently inconsistent. Ireland must focus on advancing initiatives to harmonise the definition of these crimes across the EU, specifically targeting discrimination based on sexual orientation and gender identity. Aims: Ensure support for and engagement with the Commission in implementing the EU LGBTIQ+ Equality Strategy 2026–30 commitments around tackling hate. Additionally, use harmonised definitions of hate crime to facilitate the stronger enforcement of the Digital Services Act (DSA) against anti-LGBTIQ+ hate speech and harassment online. EU LGBTIQ+ Equality Strategy 2026–30 commitments: • A legislative initiative based on the existing areas of crime covered by Article 83(1) of TFEU to harmonise the definition of hate offences committed online. 4. Implementing legal gender recognition across EU states Advocate General of the Court of Justice of the European Union (CJEU) delivered his Opinion in the Shipov case in September, stating that member states have an obligation to legally recognise the lived gender of their nationals. The Presidency should use the momentum provided by the CJEU to further enable member states to legally recognise the lived gender of their nationals under EU law. Aims: Ensure support for and engagement with the Commission in implementing the Equality Strategy commitments around tackling hate. EU LGBTIQ+ Equality Strategy 2026–30 commitments: Facilitate exchanges of best practices among member states to support the development of legal gender recognition procedures based on self-determination that are free from age restrictions.

geography: Belong To works with and on behalf of LGBTQ+ young people aged 10 to 23 in Ireland. The organisation is also a member of ILGA-Europe — the European Region of the International Lesbian,
response_text: Progress on equality protections has slowed in recent years, with many areas coming under sustained attack, including women’s rights, LGBTQ+ rights, and migrants’ rights. In the current political context, it is vital that institutions show leadership and demonstrate that progress continues to be a priority. According to a recent poll from the Irish Human Rights and Equality Commission, “80% of [people in Ireland] agreed that no matter who you are or where you come from, you should be treated equally”. Ireland has an opportunity to leverage its reputation as a progressive force to ensure that equality and inclusion remain prominent topics on the Council’s agenda in 2026. Driving forward legislation that enshrines equality and non-discrimination will create a substantial positive impact for people, businesses and communities across the EU.

geography: Belong To works with and on behalf of LGBTQ+ young people aged 10 to 23 in Ireland. The organisation is also a member of ILGA-Europe — the European Region of the International Lesbian,
response_text: Having just celebrated the 10-year anniversaries of both the Gender Recognition Act and the Thirtyfourth Amendment of the Constitution (Marriage Equality) Act, Ireland stands in a strong position to demonstrate the success of progressive legislation and to celebrate the positive impacts that these changes have had on the lives of EU citizens in Ireland. We recommend that a high-profile event is held to recognise and celebrate these milestones of progress. With reference to the NYCI research cited under Question 1, youth engagement is a key means of communicating the values and benefits of EU membership to its citizens. We recommend that Ireland commit to hosting a youth-led dialogue on core EU values in collaboration with civil society. This provides a tangible mechanism to empower young activists and allow them to feel ownership of their own part within the EU.

respondent_type: This submission is being made on behalf of Dublin Chamber’s 1,000+ member organisations, encompassing businesses of all sizes and sectors throughout the Greater Dublin Area (GDA).
response_text: Dublin Chamber welcomes the opportunity to contribute to the development of Ireland’s priorities and policy programme for its 2026 Presidency of the Council of the European Union. As the representative body for more than 1,000 businesses across the Greater Dublin Area, we engage daily with companies navigating both the opportunities and the pressures of operating within the EU Single Market. Ireland’s EU Presidency comes at a time of heightened geopolitical and economic uncertainty, and it presents a significant opportunity for this country to advance a more competitive, cohesive and resilient Europe, all while improving conditions for domestic enterprise.
