Informed by feedback from our members and the wider Chamber network, we believe that Ireland’s priorities for the Presidency should focus on enhancing competitiveness, strengthening the Single Market, creating a more efficient regulatory environment, and advancing key climate and energy objectives. Dublin’s business community emphasises the importance of consolidation over reinvention during this Presidency, and positioning Europe as an outward-looking, innovative and attractive destination to do business and invest. For Dublin businesses, strengthening and streamlining the EU Single Market should be the foremost priority for Ireland’s Presidency. Central to this is the creation of a more workable and coherent regulatory system. Members across all sizes and sectors continue to report that regulatory fragmentation coming from Brussels and rising administrative burdens are undermining competitiveness. Overly complex rules and excessive reporting obligations must be simplified and reduced if the Single Market is to remain competitive and become better integrated. The EU’s ambition to reduce administrative burdens by at least 25% for businesses and 35% for SMEs has been strongly welcomed by firms across the region. Ireland must act as a leader during its Presidency to drive progress towards these commitments and embed burden reduction across future legislative and reporting frameworks. With the EU having already commenced its rollout of the Competitiveness Compass and presented the Omnibus simplification packages, members urge the Government to drive the agenda forward during its Presidency. Ireland should champion the full implementation of the Draghi Report and ensure meaningful progress on forthcoming simplification measures. Energy security and decarbonisation are equally pressing priorities. Our members have noted several important forthcoming initiatives, including the European Grids Package, revisions to the TEN-E Regulation and the EU Action Plan on Affordable Energy, as critical to both climate delivery and economic resilience. For Ireland, advancing these files during its Presidency will be essential not only for meeting emissions targets but also for maintaining competitiveness. Modernising grid infrastructure, accelerating and simplifying permitting, and coordinating EU action on energy affordability should be central priorities for the next EU cycle. Ireland can also use its Presidency to demonstrate national leadership in effectively implementing the green transition, while supporting the adoption of the Environmental Omnibus to simplify environmental requirements for businesses. Maintaining a balanced and innovation-friendly approach to digitalisation is another key priority. Firms have highlighted that the cumulative impact of new EU legislation, from the Digital Services Act to the AI Act, has increased compliance complexity at a time when many organisations are still navigating the digital transition. Ireland’s Presidency should therefore prioritise coherent and practical implementation of these frameworks, promote innovation-enabling tools such as regulatory sandboxes, and position itself as a leader in AI skills development. The proposed Digital Omnibus simplification package also offers a timely opportunity to streamline and better align existing rules. Ensuring its swift adoption, including amendments across the General Data Protection Regulation, Data Act, cybersecurity rules, and parts of the AI Act during trilogue under the Irish Presidency, should be a priority of the Irish Presidency.

respondent_type: This submission is being made on behalf of Dublin Chamber’s 1,000+ member organisations, encompassing businesses of all sizes and sectors throughout the Greater Dublin Area (GDA).
response_text: Given the length of the Presidency, members emphasise the importance of clear prioritisation and realism about what can be achieved. With several major EU files set to reach decisive stages next year, including in taxation, digital regulation, climate and energy policy, and competitiveness reforms, Ireland’s Presidency will play a pivotal role in shaping their final direction. The focus should be on advancing well-developed, strategically important proposals rather than launching new initiatives that may ultimately be reshaped by subsequent Presidencies. One such strategic area of focus should be access to finance and capital. Members have identified Europe’s underdeveloped investment landscape, particularly in relation to savings mobilisation, SME finance and fragmented cross-border capital markets, as a structural drag on competitiveness. The need to diversify funding opportunities for businesses and ensure free movement of capital across the EU is reflected strongly across our members’ priorities. Progress on the EU’s three unions - the Savings and Investments Union, the Banking Union and the Capital Markets Union - is therefore urgent. Ireland will be well placed during its Presidency to advance the Banking Union and Capital Markets Union, all while coordinating Member States to mobilise private investments toward a European Savings and Investments Union. Ensuring a coherent approach to taxation policy is another area of critical importance for firms. They have highlighted the forthcoming revision of the Anti-Tax Avoidance Directive and the Directive on Administrative Cooperation in 2026, noting that both files are technically demanding and politically sensitive. Given the requirement for unanimity, Ireland should seek to ensure adequate Council time for meaningful negotiation while also promoting stability, certainty, and simplicity in corporate taxation, elements essential to the predictability of the Irish business environment. Beyond simplifying regulation, inconsistent implementation and gold-plating of EU directives remain key drivers of fragmentation - an issue of particular concern for Irish businesses. EU Directives drafted for civil-law systems often contain broad or subjective terminology that creates challenges when transposed into Ireland’s commonlaw system. Our members cited Ireland’s experience with Environmental Impact Assessments, where ambiguous terms such as “appropriate” have contributed to extensive documentation requirements, heightened litigation risk, and delays to critical infrastructure. Ireland’s Presidency presents an opportunity to advocate for more precise EU legislative drafting, better adapted to diverse legal systems, and for transposition practices that enhance legal certainty and reduce unnecessary litigation.

respondent_type: This submission is being made on behalf of Dublin Chamber’s 1,000+ member organisations, encompassing businesses of all sizes and sectors throughout the Greater Dublin Area (GDA).
response_text: Ireland can make a meaningful contribution by ensuring high-quality negotiation processes throughout the Presidency. This includes allowing sufficient time for complex fiscal and technical files, facilitating constructive dialogue among Member States, and ensuring that decisions are grounded in robust evidence and policy analysis. Strengthening cooperation between national regulators will also help improve regulatory coherence and reduce fragmentation. Ireland should also ensure that the perspective of SMEs remains at the forefront of Council negotiations. SMEs make up the vast majority of Ireland and Europe’s business landscape and can too often be disproportionately affected by complex or fragmented regulation. Applying clear SME-impact assessments across legislative files will help ensure that proposals do not create unnecessary burdens and remain practical for businesses both large and small. By embedding this approach throughout the Presidency’s work, Ireland can support more effective, proportionate policymaking that strengthens competitiveness and delivers meaningful benefits for businesses of all sizes across the EU.

respondent_type: This submission is being made on behalf of Dublin Chamber’s 1,000+ member organisations, encompassing businesses of all sizes and sectors throughout the Greater Dublin Area (GDA).
response_text: Members have highlighted the importance of a clear, open and confident communications strategy accompanying the Presidency. In a period of geopolitical volatility, coinciding with elections next year in the US, citizens and businesses will need stable and positive messaging about the EU’s role in supporting prosperity, security and opportunity. Ireland should use its Presidency to highlight its identity as a constructive, outward-looking and multicultural Member State. This includes showcasing leadership in digital innovation, SME support and youth engagement, and communicating the tangible benefits of EU membership, such as mobility, trade access, investment and regulatory stability. Stakeholder engagement must remain central. Targeted outreach to SMEs, young people and sectoral groups will help maintain transparency and ensure that businesses can engage with developments throughout Ireland’s Presidency.

respondent_type: This submission is being made on behalf of Dublin Chamber’s 1,000+ member organisations, encompassing businesses of all sizes and sectors throughout the Greater Dublin Area (GDA).
response_text: To ensure meaningful progress for businesses, citizens and the wider European community, Dublin Chamber recommends that Government prioritise the following in its Presidency. 1. Advance the EU’s simplification agenda • Reduce regulatory fragmentation and administrative burdens where possible through supporting the full implementation of the Draghi Report and upcoming simplification packages. 2. Improve Regulatory Quality and Coherence • Promote clearer, more precise EU legislation suitable for both civil- and common-law systems and improve consistency in national transposition. 3. Enhance Competitiveness Through Capital and Tax Reform To improve access to finance and capital, advance the Banking and Capital Markets Unions and coordinate Member States to mobilise private investments toward a European Savings and Investment Union. Ensure balanced, evidence-based negotiation of the forthcoming Anti-Tax Avoidance Directive and the Directive on Administrative Cooperation revisions to maintain tax clarity and stability. 4. Accelerate Energy Security and the Green Transition • Prioritise the delivery of the European Grids Package, TEN-E revisions and the Action Plan on Affordable Energy. Support faster permitting and grid modernisation and highlight Ireland’s leadership in decarbonisation. 5. Support an Innovation-Friendly Digital Framework Promote coherent and practical implementation of digital regulation and advance the Digital Omnibus and innovation-enabling tools such as regulatory sandboxes. Position Ireland as a leader in AI skills development. 6. Put SMEs at the Centre • SME-proof new legislation and ensure manageable compliance requirements. Improve SME access to finance and cross-border markets. 7. Deliver a Clear and Confident EU Communications Strategy • Highlight the benefits of EU membership and Ireland’s role within it and provide transparent updates, engaging with SMEs, young people and regional stakeholders. Ireland’s 2026 Presidency offers a pivotal opportunity to help shape Europe’s trajectory towards greater competitiveness and cohesion. The priorities identified by Dublin Chamber members reflect both the opportunities and the challenges facing businesses operating in a rapidly evolving Single Market. By prioritising regulatory simplification, strengthening competitiveness, improving regulatory coherence and supporting the energy and digital transitions, Ireland can make a meaningful contribution to the EU at a critical moment. Dublin Chamber stands ready to support Government throughout the Presidency and to ensure that the business community continues to inform and strengthen Ireland’s leadership at EU level.

sector: Environment/climate, campaigning to end fossil fuel exploration and the development of new fossil fuel infrastructure in Ireland
response_text: This submission is made on behalf of Not Here Not Anywhere (NHNA), a nationwide, grassroots, non-partisan group campaigning to end fossil fuel exploration and the development of new fossil fuel infrastructure in Ireland. Climate change must be the top priority for Ireland’s Presidency of the Council. The climate crisis is not a distant challenge, it is our current, shared reality. 2024 was the warmest year on record worldwide with an average global surface temperature of 1.55°C above pre-industrial levels (World Meteorological Organisation, 2025). Closely interlinked with the global biodiversity crisis, human-driven climate change has severe social, ecological, and economic implications. These impacts are far-reaching and disproportionate, having the largest impacts on the communities that have contributed the least to this crisis. To address this complex crisis, we have nationally enshrined legislation (such as Climate Action and Low Carbon Development (Amendment) Act 2021) and internationally agreed obligations established through the processes of the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change. Whilst some action has been taken, we are still significantly off-track in terms of reducing global emissions and reducing anthropocentric impacts on the environment in Ireland, Europe, and internationally. The UN Emissions Gap Report 2024 stated that ‘we would need global mobilization on a scale and pace never seen before’, without which the critical Paris Agreement goal of limiting global warming to 1.5°C above pre-industrial levels ‘will be dead within a few years and 2°C will take its place in the intensive care unit’ (UN, 2024: XI). We are at a critical point in history and we must take immediate and radical action to reduce the biggest contributor to global greenhouse gas (GHG) emission - fossil fuels. Therefore, it is vital that Ireland uses its Presidency to place the climate crisis high up on the EU’s agenda to achieve urgently needed climate action.

sector: Environment/climate, campaigning to end fossil fuel exploration and the development of new fossil fuel infrastructure in Ireland
response_text: LNG One focus of work for the Irish Presidency of the Council should be to immediately reduce dependence on fossil fuels, the number one cause of climate change. Some European governments and the fossil fuel industry are pushing to build Liquefied Natural Gas (LNG) terminals which will lock us into decades of polluting gas consumption, increase reliance on imported energy, and obstruct investment in clean local energy, delaying the urgent transition towards a zero carbon future. . Increasingly, leaders on global climate policy are calling for a rapid move away from all fossil fuels, including natural gas. There is currently excess LNG in the EU supply chain, with TotalEnergies’ terminal in Le Havre being demobilised due to lack of demand (TotalEnergies.com, 2025). Yet, there has been a recent proliferation of LNG in Europe, with several proposed projects in Ireland. With an even greater greenhouse gas footprint than conventional gas, and 20% higher lifecycle emissions than coal (Howarth, 2024), ending the use of LNG should be a global priority. LNG as an interim energy source requires massive infrastructure expenditures, for ships and liquefaction plants and the pipelines that supply them. Instead, redoubling efforts to ramp up the green economy as fast as possible can yield energy security, along with more jobs than fossil fuel investments (World Economic Forum, 2021). In July 2020, then Vice President of the European Investment Bank stated that ‘investing in new fossil fuel infrastructure like LNG terminals is increasingly an economically unsound decision’ (Reuters, 2020a). On a project-by-project basis, clean energy portfolios - optimised combinations of demand-side management and wind, solar, and storage technologies - are cheaper than 90% of proposed gas-fired power units (Teplin et al. 2019). There is precedent for LNG opposition in Europe: LNG projects have faced opposition and delays as governments recognised that they are incompatible with climate targets. In 2019, the Swedish government withdrew support for a proposed LNG Terminal and removed it from the EU’s Projects of Common Interest list (350.org, 2019). The French government stopped a deal between energy firm Engie and a US LNG company, citing climate and environmental impacts (Reuters, 2020b). Data centres The rapidly growing energy usage of data centres is further contributing to devastating climate change and undermining already slow progress in renewables production. A report by Beyond Fossil Fuels says that Europe’s electricity demand from data centres could rise by up to 160 per cent by 2030, reaching 287 TWh/year, more than Spain's total electricity consumption in 2022 (Euronews, 2025a). Prioritising this policy area is vital for the Irish Presidency of the Council because of the unequal consumption of energy by data centres per country, with Ireland’s energy consumption well above the European average (Power Magazine, 2025). Data centres are also heavy water users, often wasting drinking water (Mytton, 2021). Each data centre has a water demand equivalent to a large Irish town. With increasing global heating and water stress, this is another resource challenge that will be exacerbated by proliferation of data centres.

sector: Environment/climate, campaigning to end fossil fuel exploration and the development of new fossil fuel infrastructure in Ireland
response_text: The most substantial positive impact for people, businesses and communities across the EU would be to ensure they survive the climate crisis. People across Europe are experiencing the effects of climate change. Europe is the fastest warming continent and 2024 was the warmest year on record in Europe, with ‘heatwaves, droughts and floods affecting a quarter of all EU regions’ last summer (Euronews.com, 2025b). Prior to this, in June, ‘a growing share of Europeans (38%)...report feeling personally exposed to environmental and climate-related risks’ (europa.eu, 2025). ‘Climate change caused 16,469 deaths in European cities this summer, new research estimates’ (Gardner, 2025). The climate crisis is upon us. The EU Strategic Agenda 2024-2029, states: In particular, the European Union will pursue efforts to promote global peace, justice and stability, as well as democracy, universal human rights and the achievement of the Sustainable Development Goals in all international fora The target of maintaining temperatures below 1.5°C has already been missed (UNEP, 2025). We must therefore invest heavily in developing renewable energy and immediately phase out fossil fuels if we are to keep global temperature rise ‘well below 2°C’, a key sustainable development goal coming out of the Paris Agreement which the Strategic Agenda pledges to uphold. Supporting any new major oil and gas infrastructure would lock us into fossil fuel energy for 30-40 years and jeopardise our ability to fulfil our current and future climate action commitments and meet critical global warming limits. It is crucial that the EU does not further lock in its dependence on fossil fuels if we are to meet our climate targets under the Paris Agreement. Solutions to power disruption, and to our wider energy security, lie not in large centralised fossil fuel projects but localised distributed renewables, retrofits, and energy storage, and demand management which prioritises households and essential services over large commercial energy users like data centres. These measures are what Ireland should put on the agenda and promote during its presidency. Legislative proposals on data centres should include: Setting an overall cap on the level of data centre energy demand; required transparency from data about the sectors they are providing services to, and the types of services provided, and allowing bans on some types of services (e.g. some forms of cryptocurrency mining) completely; required flexibility from data centres at times when wind and solar energy on the grid is low relative to demand - and not allowing data centres to use fossil fuel generation as the means of providing this flexibility. New data centres must be powered entirely by, and existing centres should be required to transition rapidly to: On site direct renewable power source generation combined with energy storage, or Off site renewable power source and energy storage with dedicated grid connection (avoiding Renewable Energy Certificates) Any renewable energy infrastructure must comply with best practice public participation 4. New data centres should have infrastructure in place to enable heat generated from them to be utilised for district heating systems

sector: Environment/climate, campaigning to end fossil fuel exploration and the development of new fossil fuel infrastructure in Ireland
response_text: Again, ‘Climate change [is estimated to have] caused 16,469 deaths in European cities this summer’ (Gardner, 2025). Public participation is vital as part of a just transition. However, if Ireland and the EU continue their current trajectory of counterproductive and insufficient energy and climate policy, endeavouring to convince citizens of the benefits of its policies is convincing them of policies that are currently leading to their demise. Instead, NHNA urges the Government to lead the EU towards its climate commitments to protect all citizens from the effects of the climate crisis caused by fossil fuels, a key objective of the strategic agenda: The European Union will strengthen its resilience, preparedness, crisis prevention and response capacities, in an all-hazards and whole-of-society approach, to protect our citizens and societies against different crises, including natural disasters and health emergencies. (Strategic Agenda, 2024) While communication strategy is not our primary area of expertise as a grassroots climate group, NHNA recommends that in order to ‘create a sense of ownership amongst citizens’, Ireland must lead the EU in creating actual ownership among citizens, starting with their energy. Rather than profit-driven corporations continuing to lead fossil fuel expansion, energy democracy would ensure citizens control energy production. Energy democracy means that energy is produced by the people, for the people. Renewable energy is produced and controlled at local level by communities and the state, not for-profit private companies. Energy democracy gives rise to green, local employment and allows small and medium-sized social enterprises to develop. This means that energy is cheaper, more accessible, and energy demand is managed more efficiently (Not Here Not Anywhere, 2025). Ireland must seize the opportunity to protect citizens from the climate crisis by leading the EU’s divestment in fossil fuels.

Ireland’s Presidency of the Council of the European Union in presents a unique opportunity to champion a policy agenda that reinforces the EU's role as a global leader in life sciences. BioPharmaChem Ireland (BPCI) proposes three high-level thematic priorities, centred on securing Europe’s long-term health and economic resilience: 1. A Pro-competitiveness, pro-innovation agenda: Ireland must leverage its Presidency to foster a pro-innovation and pro-competitiveness stance across the EU. This requires a policy focus that stimulates investment, protects Intellectual Property and addresses highly specialised skills shortages in R&D, regulatory science, health and safety, green chemistry and digitalisation. This priority addresses the pressing challenge of underinvestment in innovation identified in The Draghi report on EU competitiveness, which notes that the EU's private sector spends drastically less on pharma R&D compared to the US and China. Draghi identifies this as a key contributing factor to the erosion of the EU pharma sector’s global competitiveness. The report also highlights the lack of specialised skills and talent as a major hindrance to EU competitiveness, particularly within STEM fields. Amidst a new era of geopolitical and economic uncertainty, the Presidency of the Council of the EU offers a critical window to promote policies designed to substantially stimulate investment. Ireland possesses core competitive strengths, such as a highly educated workforce and strong manufacturing infrastructure, that provide the essential capacity to absorb this investment effectively and rapidly translate it into scalable production, thereby driving comprehensive economic growth. Regulatory excellence in the EU: The second priority must be to champion a new era of regulatory excellence. The EU’s life sciences competitiveness is being undermined by a slow, complex and fragmented regulatory system, causing companies and investors to prioritise non-EU markets. Regulatory excellence includes targeted policy intervention aimed at closing the gap with competitors who offer significantly shorter, simpler, predictable and agile approvals. This is a necessary prerequisite for driving investment into the EU and ensuring faster access to innovative medicines for patients. A balanced, innovation-led green transition: The third priority is ensuring the transition to a green economy is strategic and balanced, not self-defeating. Environmental policy must consider the operational needs of the sector to ensure that decarbonisation neither inhibits Europe’s competitiveness nor its ability to produce essential medicines. This priority must also include an active focus on policies that promote access to affordable, renewable energy for industrial users. One of the Irish biopharmachem sector’s greatest barriers to achieving both growth and full carbon neutrality is the inadequate access to renewable energy. If this critical energy deficit is not addressed, production facilities will be forced to relocate outside of Europe, thereby compromising the EU’s crucial manufacturing resilience and strategic autonomy.

Advocate for measures in the forthcoming EU Biotech Act that will: incentivise innovation, such as leveraging the Single Market Strategy, creating life sciences index funds and de-risking investment in life sciences and, reduce regulatory complexity. Please see BPCI’s submission to the EU Commission’s consultation on the Biotech Act, attached as an appendix, for additional detail. Guarantee significant progress on the national Life Sciences Strategy prior to the Presidency. Equip Ireland with a strategy and a clear set of priorities that can then be promoted at the EU level. This effort must also include the establishment of a dedicated and well-resourced national Office of Life Sciences to serve as the crucial national connection to the EU Life Sciences Strategy. Such an institutional link is essential for ensuring that Ireland can proactively connect with industry domestically while communicating priorities to the EU. Support a competitive regulatory data protection length at least equal to the competitor’s RDP baseline under the General Pharmaceutical Legislation to ensure the EU pharmaceutical sector to remains competitive globally. Promote a proportional and targeted lens for the Critical Medicines Act, ensuring measures such as the mandatory stock requirements are proportional to the actual risk of shortage and patient impact. Similarly, ensure that collaborative procurement options are only used in specific circumstances where they demonstrably accelerate patient access, rather than systematically replacing existing national pricing and reimbursement pathways. Support the re-examination of the Urban Wastewater Treatment Directive to ensure a fair and just sciencebased system that reflects the polluter pays principle and does not place a disproportionate burden on the pharmaceutical sector. To prevent widespread supply chain disruptions and safeguard patient access to medicine, the EU must adopt a targeted, risk-based approach, not a blanket ban, to the proposed restriction on Per- and Polyfluoroalkyl Substances (PFAS) under the EU's REACH Regulation. Essential-use derogations and realistic transition periods are imperative, given that PFAS are critical for the pharmaceutical sector’s ability to produce medicines, as well as for the continuous operation of key European industries like renewable energy, semiconductors, water treatment and medical devices. Create opportunities for thorough stakeholder engagement from the pharmaceutical sector, so all parties have a clear understanding of the complexities of PFAS use and the implications of a ban. Complement environmental policy with innovation policy for an economically viable green transition. EU-level research funding to accelerate the development and validation of viable PFAS alternatives to ensure a robust future supply of medicines. This should be complemented by dedicated R&D support for industrial energy efficiency and green process innovation. Drive policies that ensure access to affordable, secure renewable energy for industrial users. High energy costs affect manufacturing as well as chemical storage, formulation, distribution and recovery facilities. Affordable and predictable renewable energy is essential to retain critical capacity in Europe. Aim to close the gap with jurisdictions who offer shorter, simpler regulatory approvals by ensuring regulatory bodies are appropriately resourced. This funding is essential to conduct early science-led dialogue, manage flexible regulatory sandboxes, streamline regulatory approval pathways and enable the rapid, safe adoption of new technologies. The EU must also offer digitalisation of compliance tools to ease the regulatory burden on SMEs, ensure better alignment between EU agencies, and provide timely decision-making for regulatory policy such as the REACH Regulation.

Member States’ healthcare systems must transform their approach to bio-pharmaceutical innovation, by moving beyond cost containment to viewing healthcare spending as a strategic investment in societal and economic growth. The Draghi report on EU competitiveness notes that the EU's private sector drastically underinvests in pharmaceutical R&D spending relative to the US and China. This deficiency is compounded by the fragmentation and duplication of public R&D efforts across member states, creating inefficiencies and undermining scale. Draghi also points to the EU’s structural barriers to scale-up, specifically a widening venture capital gap that prevents the translation of innovation into commercial success, as key hinderance to growth. The EU’s R&D competitiveness is already in decline. IQVIA 2024 data indicates European companies started only 21% of new global clinical trials while the US increased its share to 35%. The EU is now squeezed between a rapidly expanding, self-sufficient R&D ecosystem in China and aggressive US financial policies actively pulling investment away. Ultimately, this is a critical patient access issue, as the region that leads R&D delivers new treatments to its citizens first. Failure to compete directly undermines the EU's goal of 'Strategic Autonomy' in health, forcing its patients to wait longer for the next generation of medicines. To reverse this decline in pharma R&D competitiveness, Draghi points to strong IP protections as a catalyst to medical innovation. The report also calls for stability in investment incentives and the leveraging of fiscal policy to finance higher-risk innovation. The EU Biotech Act will aim to accelerate the translation of biotech innovation into improved industrial processes and products that can be brought to market. This a unique opportunity to address inefficiencies and promote investment for the sector. Adding to the investment challenge is a slow, complex, and fragmented regulatory system that compels innovators to navigate dual EU and divergent national laws. Industry prioritises markets offering the clearest and fastest path to approval. Consequently, the EU is now routinely the second or third market for innovative treatments. This regulatory burden is further compounded by a fundamental shift in the global innovation landscape. The R&D pipeline has evolved into a complex spectrum of "deep tech" medicines, such as AI-designed drugs and patientspecific cell therapies. These advanced treatments demand agile and adaptable regulatory frameworks that enable the EMA to co-develop regulations in real-time with technologic advancement, rather than waiting years for policy to catch up. If Europe fails to adapt its systems, by implementing tools such as regulatory sandboxes, sector competitiveness will suffer. Finally, the biopharmachem sector strongly supports Ireland’s sustainability commitments and actively champions the green transition. However, environmental policy requires careful calibration. While industry seeks to drive decarbonisation, policy must not inhibit its critical ability to produce life-changing medicines. The Draghi Report directly addresses this dichotomy, calling for a more joined-up approach to policy coordination to mitigate the risk that "decarbonisation could run contrary to competitiveness and growth." This principle applies directly to complex regulations like the REACH Regulation and the proposed PFAS restrictions, which must be coordinated with the operational needs of the strategic life sciences supply chain.

To best communicate the value of EU membership and foster citizen ownership, Ireland’s Presidency should emphasise the link between support for the biopharmachem sector and the tangible economic and health benefits a strong domestic sector directly delivers to citizens. Messaging should explain that regulatory reforms, such as streamlining approvals, are not bureaucratic exercises but essential steps to accelerate access to breakthrough medicines for families across the EU. The Presidency’s work can assist Europe in accessing new treatments faster. Communication should clearly link the competitiveness agenda to local economic stability. Highlighting efforts to attract global R&D and manufacturing investment secures high-value, sustainable jobs in local communities. The Presidency’s focus on affordable and secure energy can be framed as directly protecting EU manufacturing, which safeguards local economies from global price volatility and outsourcing. The Presidency’s approach to environmental policy must be communicated as achieving a smart green future. This highlights that Ireland and industry is committed to the green transition while also being responsible to patients by ensuring that critical manufacturing supply chains remain intact. This balanced approach demonstrates that EU policy can be both ambitious and pragmatic, providing a credible path for the sustainable transition that citizens can support.

This submission outlines the core strategic priorities of BioPharmaChem Ireland (BPCI) ahead of Ireland's Presidency of the Council of the EU in 2026. These priorities are evidence-based, drawing on key findings from BPCI's reports and meticulously informed by direct input from our members to ensure we accurately represent the most critical issues facing the Irish biopharmaceutical, pharmaceutical, and chemical sectors. The BioPharmaChem Ireland (BPCI)’s Manufacturing in Ireland Report highlights the core risks undermining the sector’s future competitiveness. The majority of manufacturers anticipate cost increases in key areas such as materials and energy, with only one in seven projecting an increase in profitability over the next six months. Concurrently, the sector faces major operational challenges, including the regulatory environment, attracting and retaining a quality workforce and persistently rising costs. Critically, trade uncertainty has become the single most pressing issue for the industry. These findings underscore the urgent need for the EU to focus on promoting procompetitiveness measures that will rapidly restore confidence in European business and stimulate crucial long-term investment. BPCI’s Sustainable Strategy and Responsible Care Report 2025, highlights the industry's significant progress toward sustainability goals while simultaneously revealing a critical operational vulnerability. Tracking emission data between 2022 and 2024, the report notes that despite increasing activity, the Irish biopharmachem industry achieved a 26% reduction in carbon emissions and sourced nearly three-quarters of its total electricity consumption from renewable sources. However, this strong sustainability performance is overshadowed by severe energy capacity concerns: 9% of manufacturing sites are currently operating beyond their Maximum Import Capacity (MIC), with a further 12% exceeding 90% of their limit. This creates a serious potential for operational disruptions in the manufacturing of essential medicines, a risk reflected by the fact that approximately three-quarters of the industry is either concerned or very concerned about capacity issues. BPCI's upcoming Indigenous Biopharmachem Strategy report reveals an ecosystem of unexpected scale and diversity, identifying over 130 homegrown companies operating across the full value chain, from pre-clinical discovery to manufacturing and logistics. However, this growth potential is currently constrained by critical structural barriers, specifically regarding infrastructure gaps and the availability of lifecycle capital. The strategy indicates that indigenous companies lack necessary continuous and robust funding support from proof-of-concept to commercialisation, while the fiscal environment requires targeted enhancement to expand entrepreneur reliefs and streamline R&D and EIIS frameworks BPCI’s submission to the EU Commission’s public consultation on the EU Biotech Act, attached as an appendix, provides significant detail regarding opportunities enhance the competitiveness environment for the sector. BPCI welcomes the opportunity to provide further details on the above-mentioned reports and/or policy priorities. We are committed to supporting Ireland’s EU Council Presidency by using our key platforms, such as the BioPharmaChem Impact Conference 2026, to showcase and advance the Presidency’s strategic work to the industry. This collaborative work is designed to ensure that Industry and Government approach the Presidency as unified, strategic partners, thereby maximising its collective impact on the EU agenda.

organisation: Society of St Vincent de Paul
response_text: The Society of St Vincent de Paul recommends that Ireland use its EU Presidency to revitalise Social Europe, delivering social cohesion and equality across Ireland and the EU. This recommendation is founded in SVP’s experience supporting those impacted by poverty. Poverty is not abstract: our members regularly work with people in cold, dark homes, who are sacrificing food or heat to afford basics for themselves and their loved ones. For some we support, their inability to make ends meet is new, brought on by personal crisis or rising energy prices and the cost of living; for others, this experience pre-dates Covid-19, and may be intergenerational. Theme 1: Delivering Social Justice in a Social Europe The European Pillar of Social Rights’ Action Plan set the goal of reducing the number of people at risk of poverty or social exclusion by 15 million by 2030, 5 million of which should be children. This would require a reduction below 76 million people, and children to under 18 million: in 2024, there were 93.3 million people in the EU at risk of poverty or social exclusion, roughly 19.5million of which were children. Concerted, countrylevel and EU-wide action is required on poverty. SVP believes the aim should be an eradication, not alleviation of poverty, though we understand reduction as a step in the right direction. For either eradication or reduction, the EU must seriously address the structural drivers of poverty—this is not possible without the inclusion of the voices and perspectives of those living in poverty. Though we advocate for a focus on poverty, we emphasise that this focus must be cross-cutting if it is to deliver meaningful change. Theme 2: Revitalising the Just Transition Though the ‘green transition’ has recently been prioritised by Denmark’s 2025 EU Presidency, it is important that principles of equality and social justice be embedded in the energy transition as a ‘just transition’. The just transition must be prioritised within the EU Presidency agenda to ensure that vulnerable groups and communities are able to enjoy the benefits of the energy transition and are not disproportionately impacted by its costs. This includes attention to existing systemic inequalities that may be exacerbated by the energy transition and therefore require additional investment. As a leader in renewable energy, Ireland is well-placed to lead conversations on equality within the transition at the EU level. It is important that as the EU scales up its energy transition, it continues to invest in and implement policies to bridge short-term implications for energy poverty and ensure the just transition achieves equality and dignity for all EU households.

organisation: Society of St Vincent de Paul
response_text: The EU Anti-Poverty Strategy The EU Anti-Poverty Strategy is currently in development, and Ireland must use its presidency of the EU to ensure that Strategy address the structural causes of poverty and is well implemented. Any Strategy must be cross-cutting and must target those groups most at risk of poverty, such as children, minority ethnic groups such as Travellers and Roma, lone-parents, disabled people, migrants, and older people. The Strategy must include clear, time-bound targets. Child poverty requires additional focus within the strategy. Beyond the Strategy, Ireland may further support reduction in child poverty through monitoring of members states’ implementation of the European Child Guarantee. Adequate Minimum Income and Adequate Minimum Wages As part of the implementation of the Pillar of Social Rights Action Plan, the Council Recommendation acknowledges the important role of Minimum Income Schemes in social protection schemes. However, the Recommendation is non-binding and lacks concrete measures to target groups such as Travellers and Roma. Many Minimum Income Schemes, including Ireland’s, continue to be inadequate to meet actual needs for those relying on social protection. We recommend that Ireland develop the Council Recommendation into a binding EU Directive on Minimum Income Schemes. Any such Directive must work in tandem with the 2022 Directive on Adequate Minimum Wages. The Multiannual Financial Framework 2028-2034 The new Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) is currently in development and will amount to nearly €2 trillion. Within this, a key measure in the MFF is the European Social Fund Plus, which is specifically targeted at addressing material deprivation, promoting social inclusion, and fighting poverty and homelessness. The Irish 2026 EU Presidency is an opportunity to direct negotiations on the MFF toward social investment on issues such as poverty and housing. SVP recommends that attention to social justice not be limited to the Social Fund Plus: poverty is a cross-cutting issue and must be invested in accordingly. Affordable Housing Plan 2026 Given Ireland’s own housing and homelessness crisis, Ireland must use its EU Presidency to lead joint EU action to prioritise affordable housing and homelessness prevention. The European Commission has committed to putting forward an Affordable Housing Plan in 2026—Ireland should play an active role in the development of this Plan in association with key stakeholders in housing and homelessness. The Plan must include targeted actions on accessibility for disabled homes and solutions to address housing for ethnic minority groups such as Travellers and Roma. Action on housing during the EU Presidency should include the introduction of a Council Recommendation on ending homelessness that contains. Action on housing in Ireland’s 2026 Presidency should be accompanied by investment. We further recommend that the housing crisis form a major theme in events planned as part of the Presidency and that these events centre stakeholders.

organisation: Society of St Vincent de Paul
response_text: Ireland’s experience of inequality underscores the need for a focus on economic growth and energy security to be accompanied by an equal focus on social justice. Our most recent SILC figures show a rise in consistent poverty, a rise even greater for children, 8.5% of whom are now in consistent poverty. Deprivation figures suggest that roughly 807,800 people in Ireland are going without basics: 7.4% of people went without heating at some point last year. As of November 2025, there are 16,766 people in emergency accommodation – 5,274 of whom are children. This is an increase of 1800 people in the 12 months to November 2025 and does not include those in ‘hidden’ homelessness. Our housing crisis has additional impacts on social cohesion: over 5,300 people in IPAS accommodation have received status to remain yet are stuck in direct provision because they lack suitable housing options. Low-income households continue to be most negatively affected by housing insecurity, which directly impacts on their long-term wellbeing and participation in society. These challenges are not unique to Ireland: in 2024, 21.0% of the population of the EU were at risk of poverty or social exclusion. This risk is higher for women and young adults, as well as households with children. Rising housing costs and shortage are increasingly faced across the EU, with 17% of Europeans living in overcrowded homes. We emphasise these challenges because they offer a roadmap for where policy-making in Ireland and the EU must go in the coming years. In 2026, Ireland has a unique opportunity to focus attention on these shared challenges through its EU Presidency.

organisation: Society of St Vincent de Paul
response_text: Throughout Ireland’s EU Presidency, we recommend marginalized voices and the voices of young people are included in events and policy discussions. Though we have specific recommendations for young people, for example, it is important that their needs are considered beyond these areas also. Pro-active and meaningful engagement with civil society must be embedded throughout Ireland’s EU Presidency, highlighting the importance of civil society to democratic processes and ensuring much-needed viewpoints are fed into policy.

organisation: Society of St Vincent de Paul
response_text: We have included our full submission alongside this form. In our full submission, we outline the challenges facing households in Ireland and the EU and argue that these challenges are where Ireland must look for its priorities in its 2026 EU Presidency. The values and benefits of EU membership will only be felt and experienced by EU citizens when and where EU actions address inequality and social cohesion in their lives.

Ireland’s Presidency should prioritise a coherent, forward-looking approach to animal welfare, reflecting the EU’s recognition of animal sentience (Article 13 TFEU) and the growing public demand for transparency, ethical standards and sustainability. A central thematic priority should be modernising EU animal welfare legislation to ensure consistent, enforceable standards across Member States in farming, transport, wildlife management, companion animals and scientific research. This strengthens the internal market, reinforces the EU’s One Health approach, and supports public health. Ireland should champion transparent food labelling, enabling consumers to make informed choices. Labelling should clearly indicate production methods, housing systems, transport conditions and whether painful practices were used (e.g., tail docking, beak trimming, or other procedures performed without anaesthesia). Transparency empowers consumers, supports higher-welfare producers and aligns with EU objectives on consumer protection. Conversely, legislative attention devoted to restricting the use of “meaty terms” on plant-based products diverts resources from more pressing welfare concerns. Consumers are not confused by plant-based labelling; instead, they deserve honest, welfare-relevant information about animal-derived foods. Ireland and the EU should also lead on ethical import standards, including progressing EU-wide action to end the fur farming trade in all EU Member States and the sale and import of fur products and to prevent the import of low-welfare animal products produced under conditions that would be unlawful within the EU. In addition, Ireland’s Presidency provides a critical opportunity to ensure meaningful progress toward ending the use, production, and trade of foie gras, veal from restrictive systems, and caged-rabbit meat. Another priority is wildlife protection, including addressing practices such as hare coursing and fox hunting. The Irish hare, listed under Annex V of the Habitats Directive, requires conservation measures inconsistent with coursing and capture. Ireland can help facilitate a broader EU dialogue on aligning wildlife management with sentience obligations. Finally, the Presidency should advance responsible scientific innovation, promote scientific innovation through accelerating the transition toward validated alternatives to animal testing. Positioning animal welfare as a central thematic priority delivers ethical, environmental, economic and public health benefits for all EU citizens.

Key policy areas Ireland should advance during its Presidency include: 1. Transparent EU food labelling Ireland should advocate for mandatory welfare-related labelling, ensuring consumers know how animals were kept, transported and treated. This includes disclosure of painful practices. 2. Ethical import standards The EU should not import or sell products derived from fur farming, a practice already banned in many Member States, nor low-welfare animal products produced under conditions prohibited within the EU. Ireland should progress Council discussions on trade rules that uphold welfare, traceability and consumer trust. 3. Stronger dog breeding and traceability rules Ireland faces significant welfare issues and reputational damage linked to intensive dog breeding. An EU-level approach to traceability, breeder regulation and cross-border sale of dogs is essential to protect consumers and animals. 4. Equine traceability Improvements to equine traceability and enforcement of the laws should be prioritised to support biosecurity, food safety and welfare. 5. Live animal transport reform Ireland should work towards stronger limits on journey times, stricter conditions, and long-term transition toward meat-only or carcass-only trade, reducing welfare risks. 6. Phase-out of cages & review of intensive animal farming The Presidency can facilitate progress on the long-awaited legislative proposal to end caged housing systems, aligning regulation with scientific evidence and public demand. Intensive farming, including pig farming, poultry farming, and fish farming also require review due to their impacts on animal welfare, habitat degradation, pollution, antimicrobial and zoonotic disease risk. Ireland and the EU should support a shift toward more sustainable models, including greater supports for arable farming to reduce pressure on landscapes and improve environmental and welfare outcomes. In addition, Ireland’s Presidency provides a critical opportunity to ensure meaningful progress toward ending the use, production, and trade of foie gras, veal from restrictive systems, and caged-rabbit meat. 7. Wildlife protection and ending inhumane practices The Irish hare, protected under the Habitats Directive (Annex V), is still used in hare coursing. Ireland can highlight the need for consistent EU-wide protection for vulnerable wildlife and encourage dialogue on ending practices such as hare coursing and fox hunting, which raise significant welfare, biodiversity and enforcement concerns. 8. Animal testing Ireland and the EU should push for investment in non-animal scientific methods and regulatory acceptance of validated alternatives, progressing the EU’s commitment to eventual phase-out. 9. Marine protection and effective Marine Protected Areas (MPAs) Strengthening MPAs under the EU Biodiversity Strategy 2030 would protect vulnerable marine specie, including cetaceans, seals and seabirds, from bycatch, noise disturbance and habitat degradation. Ireland can advance clearer EU standards for MPA management, improved bycatch mitigation and better monitoring. This supports biodiversity, coastal communities and the welfare of sentient marine animals. 10. Environmental protection, pollution, habitat loss. Ireland should also prioritise EU action on environmental protection and habitat loss, including tackling habitat loss and reducing pollution from farming and associated industries. Strengthening these areas supports biodiversity, protects water quality and directly improves welfare outcomes for wildlife and farmed animals alike.

A Presidency that advances animal welfare and transparency will deliver significant benefits for citizens, businesses and communities across the EU. Transparent welfare-related food labelling empowers consumers and strengthens trust in the food chain. It also supports farmers who invest in higher-welfare systems by allowing them to differentiate their products. Improving standards, such as phasing out cages, reducing long-distance transport and improving enforcement of dog and equine traceability, creates a level competitive playing field and reduces illegal activity that harms rural communities. Progress on restricting low-welfare imports and fur products protects EU producers from unfair competition and aligns the market with consumer expectations. Strengthening biodiversity protections, including addressing hare coursing and fox hunting, reinforces the Habitats Directive and protects vulnerable species such as the Irish hare. Advancing alternatives to animal testing supports innovation, sustainable growth and ethical science. Collectively, these measures improve public health, reduce antimicrobial use, strengthen environmental protection and elevate the EU’s global leadership in welfare standards.

Animal welfare, transparent food labelling and ethical trade are areas where EU action is tangible and meaningful to citizens. Ireland can highlight how EU membership ensures higher standards, protects consumers and safeguards biodiversity, including species protected under EU law, such as the Irish hare. Communicating progress on updated welfare legislation, import restrictions on low-welfare products, and improved enforcement will demonstrate the EU’s responsiveness to public priorities. Emphasising consumer benefits, accurate welfare labelling, safer food, reduced disease risks and ethical trade, helps citizens feel directly connected to EU decision-making. Positive stories, ethical farms, innovative alternatives to testing, biodiversity protection, can build trust and strengthen the sense of shared European responsibility. Ireland could also use targeted social media campaigns, short explainer videos and accessible infographics to help citizens understand the issues being discussed at Council level. Paid ads or boosted posts during key Presidency milestones would ensure broad reach, particularly for younger audiences. Clear, plain-language updates, preferably in video format, shared through Instagram, TikTok, X, Facebook and LinkedIn, would make EU processes feel more visible, engaging and relevant to everyday life. The Council of the EU often uses engaging visuals, even featuring dogs in some of its social media posts. Ireland could adopt a similar, approachable style to communicate Presidency priorities clearly to the public.

Ireland has an opportunity to deliver a Presidency that meaningfully advances the EU’s approach to animal welfare, transparency and ethical standards. Citizens deserve higher welfare, stronger enforcement, sustainable food systems and clear and transparent food labelling that reflects real conditions, so they can make informed decisions. Addressing issues such as dog breeding, inconsistent equine traceability, long-distance transport, painful and unethical farming practices, and the sale of fur products will strengthen the internal market and improve welfare outcomes. Furthermore, current national practices, such as hare coursing and fox hunting, sit uneasily alongside Article 13 TFEU, the Habitats Directive, and UN Convention on the Rights of the Child (Art. 19 right not to witness violence, see also General Comment 26). Ireland can lead an honest discussion on aligning Member State practices with modern welfare expectations and EU law. Transparent food labelling, ethical import policy, and investment in alternatives to animal testing all contribute to a more sustainable, trusted and forward-looking European Union. Ireland can help deliver this vision.

Screen Producers Ireland (SPI) represents over 250 independent production companies on the island of Ireland. SPI also hold the chair of the European Producers Association – CEPI. CEPI represents 2,600 production companies across 19 countries. According to the Digital Creative Industries Roadmap published by the Department of Communications, Culture and Sport in January 2024, the creative industries cover almost 9% of all jobs in Ireland. This is slightly more than the agri-food production sector (8.5%) and not far short of the largest employment sector in Ireland which is tourism (10%). The European Council Strategic agenda 2024-2029 sets out that: “We will promote our cultural diversity and heritage.” The EU Commission work progamme for 2026 states: “Update of rules on audiovisual media services” Taking into account the two policy objectives as set out above the EU Presidency creates the potential for the creative industries In Ireland and the EU to be seen as a cultural, social and economic opportunity. At European level, 2026 is a key year for the development of audiovisual policy across Europe with consultations taking place on the new AgoraEU programme, Copyright Directive, the revisions of the AVMSD 2018 and potential changes to the definition of the definition of European Works. This is alongside the ongoing work of AI regulation to ensure the growth of this technology does not impinge on creativity of European creatives. All of these policy interventions create the opportunity for potential of Taking both of these policy actions into account SPI proposes the following: the review of the AVMS Directive, to be delivered in November/December (quotas and the definition of "European Works"), (ii) the review of the Copyright Directive (already under way with the text and data mining AI scraping exception); and (iii) making sure that independent producers are put back at the centre of the AgoraEU Programme, which is replacing the Creative Europe Media Programme. Use of AI in the creative industries and the implementation of the AI Act.

The cultural priorities of the Council presidency can have a very positive impact on the Irish Presidency. Events throughout the 6 months that drive home the importance of our stories and how we tell them to ourselves brings home the message of the priorities we have identified above. While those priorities are high level and effect policy positions, the end results of the actions impact how Irish, and European, stories are conceived and conveyed beyond the policy platform. Producers are creative entrepreneurs who produce celebrated film, animation, and TV, creating high-value all-island and regionally spread employment, fostering Europe’s media production eco-system along with promoting Ireland’s artistic culture and heritage The Independent production sector is an integral element in the delivery of public service media to audiences across Ireland and Europe. The audiovisual production sector industry is central to the creative industries in Ireland. It drives innovation, creativity, and economic growth, while fostering cultural diversity and supporting skilled employment across the creative industries, with over 15K FTE roles per year currently in the audiovisual sector. However, it is important that targeted measures are taken to support the audiovisual sector, and wider creative industries in Ireland. While the creative industries in Ireland accounts for 3.73% of Ireland’s gross value added, this unfortunately falls below the EU average of 5.54% of GVA. Alongside this, there are significant threats to the current public service media sphere, a recent statement which was signed by industry representative bodies globally stated that: “We are witnessing increasingly aggressive attempts by powerful political and corporate actors to dismantle the regulatory protections that ensure the diversity and accessibility of cultural expression.” Considering this context, Ireland must continue to safeguard its burgeoning screen industry, which over the past number of years has gained a reputation as an excellent filming location for both indigenous and incoming productions.

Through strategic communication and engagement with the wider industry, SPI would support the Presidency to build out the following: Delivery of events across the country which would communicate the positive effects of European funding and policy decisions on Irish and European story telling; Delivery of positive examples of European and Irish co-productions, via special screenings, events, and media releases; Delivery of strategic campaign with Creative Europe, demonstrating its success in Ireland. These events would be coordinated with European producer and more wider AV sector stakeholders through our positive relationships.

geography: Island of Ireland with a focus on all regions
response_text: Sustainable Regional Development Sustainable tourism contributes to sustainable regionally balanced economic development that delivers employment and prosperity for communities across member states. The European Strategy on sustainable tourism is due to be launched in Q2 2026. This is just before the term of the Irish presidency of the EU council. Ireland has been relatively successful in avoiding strong overtourism sentiment, with 9/10 people saying tourism is ‘good for their community’ in a study in 2024 by Fáilte Ireland, and this is influenced by tourism supporting local SMEs, across regions. As many member states struggle with concentration and overtourism it is a good opportunity to share more sustainable approaches – which include promoting experience brands like the Wild Atlantic Way, or Ireland’s Hidden Heartlands, and year round tourism, for example, leveraging sporting events and festivals like St Patrick’s day in March, or our newer ‘Ireland, Home of Halloween’ activations in October. Home of Halloween highlights the origins of Halloween 2000 years ago in Celtic culture, and attracted 50M Euros worth of incremental trip bookings this Autumn, to attend modern day festivals island wide. Intra-European Connectivity At a time of global uncertainty, there are benefits to developing Intra-European tourism. Tourism Ireland recently completed a Mainland European Appraisal, to look at growing spend from European visitors to Ireland from 2B Euros per year in 2024 to 2.75B Euros per year by 2030, with investment. For all member states, proximity of European markets is beneficial from the point of view of sustainable travel, from close by, accessible markets. As an EU agenda point, building travel connections between the member states and in particular developing new tourist markets in less explored regions of member states can deliver employment and prosperity within the EU. Tourism strengthens cultural and social connections between member states and can aid our broader European sense of identity and appreciation. Reconciliation and Collaboration across borders This is the 3rd Irish Presidency of the EU Council since the Good Friday Agreement, all going well, it is due to be only the second that the Northern Ireland executive has been in operation (the institutions were suspended for the 2004 Irish presidency, but in operation for the 2013 Irish presidency). EU member states and the EU institutions showed enormous solidarity with Ireland during the Brexit period of negotiations. The upcoming Irish presidency is against a backdrop of polarisation and conflict across the globe. Therefore, the Irish Presidency of the Council is a timely opportunity to showcase the success of the Good Friday Agreement as well as EU investment in Northern Ireland and the border regions.

geography: Island of Ireland with a focus on all regions
response_text: The European Strategy on sustainable tourism, a non-legislative element of the EU Commission’s work programme for Europe’s sustainable prosperity and competitiveness is due to be launched in Q2 2026. This is just before the term of the Irish presidency of the EU council. The term of the presidency is an excellent opportunity to explore this strategy among Member States as well as to review progress on the European Agenda for Tourism 2030 which was launched in December 2022. Ireland has been successful in shifting its tourism model to a more sustainable and regionally balanced offering. As many Member States struggle with concentration and overtourism it is a good opportunity to share more sustainable approaches. It is also an opportunity to align regulatory approaches as recommended by the European Travel Commission in their September 2025 report “Futureproofing European Tourism Through Scenario Planning and Strategic Foresight” https://etc-corporate.org/uploads/2025/09/Futureproofing-European-Tourism_2025.pdf In 2024 78% (581m) of Europe’s international tourist arrivals were Intra-European whereas 22% (167m) were non-European. Global uncertainty and climate change threatens the economic value to the Member states of Transatlantic and long-haul tourism. So, the focus should be to further develop Intra-European tourism and maximising the value per carbon footprint of non-European tourism. Building travel connection points between the Member states and in particular developing new tourist markets in less explored regions of Member states can deliver employment and prosperity within the EU while strengthening cultural and social connections between Member State citizens. In line with the priorities of recent Council presidencies, the development of the tourism economy strengthens SMEs and provides employment opportunities to sections of the populations often locked out of employment.

geography: Island of Ireland with a focus on all regions
response_text: The July to December 2026 period of the Irish Presidency covers Ireland’s busiest tourism season from July to September and the months where Ireland is trying to develop further tourism; October (Ireland, Home of Halloween), November and December, showcasing Winter in Dublin and other key cities. Showcasing Irish tourism in these shoulder seasons, and/or bringing EU visitors outside of Dublin to showcase both the product and economic benefits of tourism for regional towns and communities could be of benefit, and could resonate with other member states’ interests also.

geography: Island of Ireland with a focus on all regions
response_text: As noted in answer to question 1, the Irish Presidency of the Council is a timely opportunity to showcase the success of the Good Friday Agreement as well as EU investment in Northern Ireland and the border regions. Tourism is a primary showcase of collaboration, and is one of our largest shared indigenous industries across this island, supporting 1 in 10 jobs island-wide. Visitors coming to the island do not plan their trips based on where the border lies, but rather what there is to see and do across this island. Businesses north and south of the border work together, knowing that the proposition is stronger when we bring all the island offers together overseas. Overseas tourism spend to both Ireland and Northern Ireland grew by >100%, or doubled, between 2010 and 2024 from over 3B Euros per annum coming in from overseas visitors, to over 6B Euros. Intent to visit NI has increased 10X since 2002, showing there’s truth to the phrase ‘peace brings tourism and tourism brings peace’. Shared Island initiatives continue to strengthen collaboration, and Tourism Ireland is proud to market the island overseas as part of our North South remit. We never take any of this for granted – continued EU appreciation of the journey to peace, and support for the necessary structures that facilitate collaboration, would be meaningful.

Ireland’s Presidency should adopt a unifying thematic priority focused on strengthening integrity, credibility and transparency across all aspects of Europe’s climate transition. Public confidence in EU climate and energy policy depends on the reliability of sustainability claims attached to all decarbonisation pathways — renewable fuels, renewable electricity, hydrogen, RFNBOs, synthetic fuels and emerging low-carbon technologies. Today, that confidence is undermined by structural weaknesses in the Union’s systems for certification, auditing, data quality, and traceability. A Presidency theme such as “Credibility in the Climate Transition” would directly support the Strategic Agenda 2024–2029, which highlights the Union’s need to become climate-neutral while strengthening competitiveness, resilience and public trust. It would also reflect the Programme for Government commitment to improve traceability in HVO procurement to ensure the product is from sustainable sources. Because certification of feedstocks is an EU competenceunder the Renewable Energy Directive, national implementation cannot succeed without EU-level reform. Focusing the Presidency on credibility would help reconcile environmental ambition, industrial competitiveness and fairness for citizens. It would demonstrate Ireland’s ability to act as a neutral, constructive broker across all Council configurations by: Promoting transparency and traceability across all energy vectors, not just individual technologies or fuels. Supporting the development of consistent, reliable and enforceable verification systems. Encouraging effective implementation of EU law to avoid market fragmentation and loss of trust. This cross-cutting integrity agenda is one that only an EU Presidency can meaningfully advance, and one that would strengthen the foundation of Europe’s climate transition for the decade ahead.

In line with the EU Strategic Agenda’s focus on competitiveness, resilience and climate neutrality, Ireland should prioritise reforms to strengthen sustainability certification, traceability and enforcement across all renewable and low-carbon energy pathways under the Renewable Energy Directive (RED II/III). Although renewable fuels provide a clear and immediate example, the underlying governance challenge is broader. A credible climate transition requires technology-neutral systems that apply consistent verification standards to renewable electricity, hydrogen, RFNBOs, synthetic fuels, biofuels and emerging technologies alike. Four Presidency priorities are recommended: Deliver a fully operational, independently verified and mandatory Union Database (UDB) Including uniform auditing standards, real-time integrity checks and open interoperability. This is essential to providing reliable chain-of-custody data for all energy pathways counted towards EU climate targets. Harmonise sustainability checks across all Member States With standardised verification of feedstock provenance, emissions calculations and traceability requirements — to reduce market distortion, strengthen competitiveness and ensure equal treatment of all technologies. Strengthen EU-level enforcement mechanisms Including clear escalation procedures where national oversight is insufficient. Weak enforcement creates unfair competition, undermines climate targets, and increases costs for compliant businesses and consumers. Introduce proportionate enhanced scrutiny for high-risk inputs and pathways Including, but not limited to, certain waste oils, residues and other categories where documented risks of fraud are highest. Ireland should aim for Presidency Conclusions or a Progress Report that: Embeds technology-neutral, credibility-focused governance as a core principle of RED implementation. Commits Member States to strengthening traceability and verification across all renewable and low-carbon pathways. Accelerates technical and governance reforms to the UDB. Reinforces consistent enforcement and better implementation across the Union. Such outcomes would demonstrate EU leadership while addressing a well-recognised systemic weakness that affects all 27 Member States.

A more credible, transparent and consistently enforced sustainability framework will benefit people, businesses and communities in several essential ways. For consumers and communities: A trustworthy certification and traceability system ensures that climate-related costs borne by households and businesses translate into real emissions reductions. Weak certification ultimately increases consumer costs by allowing distortions, rewarding non-compliance, and undermining confidence in climate measures. Strengthening governance supports fairness, transparency and public buy-in. For businesses and European industry: Consistent EU-wide enforcement protects compliant operators from being undercut by non-compliant competitors. This reinforces competitiveness, supports high-quality employment and encourages investment in genuinely sustainable technologies. For environmental integrity: Robust verification ensures that emissions reductions reported under RED III are real, measurable and credible — a prerequisite for progress towards 2030 and 2050 climate goals. For Member States and public administrations: Stronger EU systems reduce duplication, improve implementation, and support the uniform application of EU rules. This helps smaller Member States — including Ireland — overcome the structural limits of unilateral national oversight in globalised supply chains. A Presidency focus on credibility therefore supports a people-centred, competitive and trustworthy climate transition across the Union.

Ireland can use its Presidency to highlight how the EU delivers tangible, people-centred benefits, especially in areas where coordinated EU action is more effective than fragmented national approaches. A focus on transparency and credibility in the climate transition provides a practical narrative demonstrating: Fairness and consumer protection — ensuring that products marketed as “renewable” or “sustainable” genuinely deliver environmental benefits. Environmental integrity — showing that EU climate action is evidence-based, effective and globally leading. A competitive, fair Single Market — where businesses operate under common, consistently enforced rules. Trust in EU governance — by improving the reliability of systems on which citizens, businesses and policymakers rely. Clear communication of these benefits — supported by real improvements in EU systems — will help build public understanding of Ireland’s role and foster a sense of collective ownership of the Presidency.

Ireland’s experience as a small, open energy market underscores the limits of unilateral action in addressing sustainability risks in global fuel and energy supply chains. Effective traceability and verification are only achievable at EU level. The Irish Presidency therefore presents a unique opportunity to act on national commitments, advance the EU Strategic Agenda, and address system-wide gaps that are now widely recognised by governments, industry and civil society. Fuels for Ireland urges the Government to use the Presidency to: Prioritise the credibility and consistency of EU-wide sustainability systems; Reinforce technology neutrality and evidence-based climate governance; Ensure that traceability and verification requirements are universally applied and enforced; and Deliver improvements that benefit consumers, support legitimate businesses and strengthen the environmental integrity of the Union’s climate architecture.

Ireland’s Presidency of the Council of the EU in 2026 presents a pivotal opportunity to address one of Europe’s most pressing yet under-recognised health challenges: chronic kidney disease (CKD). CKD sits at the intersection of metabolic health, most often evolving alongside cardiovascular diseases (CVDs), diabetes and other metabolic disorders. While we welcome the EU’s renewed attention to noncommunicable diseases (NCDs) and cardiovascular diseases (CVDs) in particular, we regret the persistent low level of policy attention and investment directed toward kidney disease. Prioritizing CVDs and diabetes while neglecting kidney disease is neither scientifically sound nor cost-effective for healthcare systems, and it has serious, sometimes tragic, consequences for patients. Ireland, supported by a strong stakeholder community such as the Irish Kidney Association and the Irish Nephrology Society, and building on its long-standing commitment to improving public health, has a significant window to address this gap during its upcoming EU presidency. EKHA recommends three high-level thematic priorities: Renew and update the EU’s commitment to kidney health CKD affects 1 in 8 Europeans and is projected to become the third leading cause of death in Western Europe by 2050 - a 95% increase since 2000. Despite its scale and societal cost, kidney disease remains largely absent from major EU health initiatives and lacks robust political recognition compared to other non-communicable diseases (NCDs) such as diabetes and cardiovascular disease. Ireland’s Presidency can play an instrumental role in ensuring kidney health is fully integrated into the EU’s NCD strategy and related policy processes, aligning with the WHO Resolution on Kidney Health adopted in May 2025. Improve prevention, screening, and early treatment The potential to prevent kidney disease or slow its progression remains vastly underutilised, even though screening is cost-effective, clinically impactful and can be integrated within other diseases ‘early detection programmes. Albuminuria screening for example, has proven its value as a scalable and actionable clinical biomarker to assess risk and progress of both kidney disease and CVD. The EU should support Member States in harmonising approaches to early detection through a new Council Recommendation on joint CVD/CKD/Diabetes screening. Ireland’s recent decision to integrate kidney disease among the diseases to be screened alongside CVDs and diabetes within the National Chronic Disease Management Programme, provides an inspiring model that could be replicated across EU Member States. 3. Achieve equitable access to high-quality treatments for kidney failure Transplantation is the optimal treatment for kidney failure, delivering the best outcomes at the lowest economic and ecological cost. It is also the only life-saving option for organ failure of the heart, liver and lungs. Yet access to transplantation remains unequal across Europe, and dialysis, while lifesaving for endstage kidney failure, remains highly burdensome for patients and carries significant financial and environmental strain.
