Ireland’s Presidency should prioritise updating the EU Action Plan on Organ Donation and Transplantation (mandated by Council Conclusions in 2024) as a way to strengthen mutual learning across countries and sectors, expand donation after circulatory determination of death (DCDD), enhance living donation framework, and improve education and training, among other urgent priorities needed to address the growing shortage of organs in the EU.

Renew EU Commitment to Kidney Health Despite its prevalence and staggering cost, kidney disease receives little attention from EU policymakers and agencies compared with other NCDs. An official, high-level ministerial event during the EU Irish Presidency focusing on kidney disease would represent a major step forward in breaking the silence. This event would mark the first EU forum to kick-start in-depth discussions and decisive actions aimed at tackling the escalating threat of kidney disease. Building on the landmark 2025 WHO resolution on kidney disease, the event could highlight the need for prevention, early detection and management of kidney disease and associated metabolic disorders (Hypertension, CVDs, diabetes, obesity) and access to affordable and high-quality care. Lead the development of an EU Council Recommendation on CKD, CVD and Diabetes’ Screening There are substantial gaps in kidney disease diagnosis. Building on the success of the Council Recommendation on cancer screening and the European Cardiovascular Health Plan’s recommendations on CVD’s health checks, there is a timely opportunity for Ireland to extend this progress by leading the development of a Council Recommendation on joint screening for kidney disease, CVD and diabetes – three conditions that share similar risk factors and frequently develop together. 3. Work alongside the European Commission to update the EU Action Plan on Organ Donation and Transplantation Transplantation stands as one of the most cost-effective approaches for treating advanced NCDs that impact the kidney, heart, liver and lungs. The added value of EU collaboration in this field has widely been demonstrated by the success of the EU legislative framework on organ donation and transplantation, and the associated action plan, which ended in 2015. Last year, the Council Conclusions on transplantation formally invited the European Commission to update its action plan. It is now crucial to maintain political momentum and reaffirm Member States’ consensus on this issue, for example through follow-up conclusions and/or a Council resolution, to ensure that these recommendations have a meaningful impact on patients.

Ireland’s EU Presidency can deliver transformative benefits by prioritising kidney health as a model for chronic disease prevention and management. CKD affects 1 in 8 Europeans and is extremely costly for Member States. For example, in Ireland, provision of treatment of end-stage kidney failure is costing the Irish payer almost EUR 1 million per day, or EUR 125,000 every year. Without intervention, this burden will escalate, straining health systems and economies. Already in Ireland, the current rate of increase is such that every year, the equivalents of two new dialysis units are needed. By embedding kidney health into EU policy, Ireland can create measurable improvements in health outcomes, economic resilience, and social equity, while ensuring long-term health cost saving. For People: Early detection and prevention strategies will significantly improve life expectancy and quality of life for millions. CKD often progresses silently until advanced stages, yet screening and timely intervention can halt or slow progression. Integrating kidney health into NCD frameworks ensures patients receive comprehensive care alongside cardiovascular and diabetes screening and management. Expanding access to transplantation (the gold standard treatment) reduces mortality, costs and enhances quality. For Businesses: CKD-related productivity losses and healthcare costs undermine economic stability. By reducing disease progression through prevention and early treatment, Ireland’s Presidency can help lower absenteeism and improve workforce participation. Given the growing burden of kidney disease, there is clear and growing interest from the industry in developing treatments that will help address this challenge. Recognizing kidney disease as a policy priority with unmet needs would further stimulate innovation across medical technologies, pharmaceuticals and digital health, while creating new market opportunities and supporting Europe’s competitiveness in health innovation. For Communities: Health inequalities remain stark across Member States, with vulnerable populations (including the elderly, children, and displaced persons) facing barriers to care. Ireland can champion equity indicators and targeted funding mechanisms to close these gaps. Cross-border collaboration on organ donation and transplantation fosters solidarity and ensures that lifesaving treatments are accessible regardless of geography.

Ireland’s Presidency can leverage kidney health policy as a powerful narrative to demonstrate the benefits of collective EU action on health. Health is a universal concern, and initiatives that improve prevention, equity, and access can resonate strongly with citizens. Public Awareness Campaigns Ireland should launch a Europe-wide campaign highlighting the Presidency’s commitment to improving health outcomes through collaborative EU action. Messaging can emphasize the cross-border nature of health threats and showcase how EU-level action on screening and organ donation and transplantation can directly benefit citizens. Linking kidney health to broader NCD prevention, as well as highlighting its cost-saving nature, can reinforce the EU’s role in addressing health issues. Showcase Success Stories Communicating real-world examples of EU solidarity, such as cross-border organ sharing and transplantation programs, will make the benefits of EU action on kidney health tangible. These stories should illustrate how cooperation saves lives and reduces inequalities, fostering trust and pride in EU institutions. Digital Engagement and Citizen Participation Interactive platforms can create a sense of ownership. Ireland could promote patient-led initiatives, such as peer support networks and digital health literacy programs, to empower citizens and demonstrate how EU policies enable innovation and inclusivity. Virtual town halls and social media campaigns can invite public input on health priorities, reinforcing transparency and engagement. Connect to Sustainability and Innovation Highlighting how innovative care models reduce environmental impact and align with EU climate goals can broaden appeal beyond health. Framing kidney health initiatives as part of a sustainable, futureoriented EU agenda strengthens the narrative of shared responsibility and progress.

EKHA strongly supports Ireland’s leadership in aligning EU health policy with global commitments under the WHO Resolution on Kidney Health adopted in May 2025. This Presidency is a pivotal moment to transform political recognition into concrete action. Some key opportunities include: Prioritize kidney health and embed it into EU strategies for NCDs Foster joint early detection programs for kidney disease, CVDs and diabetes Sustain EU political momentum on transplantation to improve patient outcomes Ensuring equitable access to high-quality treatments across Member States, addressing disparities that undermine EU solidarity. CKD data specific to Ireland: 1 in 7 people over 50 have CKD in Ireland, and 98% don't even know it. Patients requiring treatment via dialysis or transplantation increased by 2.7% from 2023 to 2024.

geography: Urban in the main with the majority of higher education service delivery in Dublin; provision of Early Childhood Education interventions nationwide in areas of socio economic deprivation including rural
response_text: Ireland’s 2026 Presidency should prioritise themes that advance the EU Strategic Agenda 2024–2029, address long-term structural challenges, and reflect Ireland’s strengths in education, digital innovation, and social inclusion. National College of Ireland (NCI) recommends the following high-level priorities: 1. A Skilled, Inclusive, and Future-Ready Europe The EU’s competitiveness depends on a labour force equipped for digital, green, and AI-driven transitions. Ireland should champion an agenda focused on strengthening skills pathways, widening participation in education, and enhancing mobility and recognition of prior learning (RPL). This includes promoting lifelong learning, tackling NEET rates, and supporting disadvantaged learners—aligning with Ireland’s strong record in skills innovation and social partnership. 2. Europe’s Digital and AI Transformation Building on Europe’s Digital Decade targets, Ireland should emphasise responsible AI, cybersecurity resilience, digital public services, and SME digitalisation. As a global technology hub, Ireland is well positioned to lead practical Council discussions on AI governance, ethical innovation, and interoperable digital infrastructures. 3. A Competitive and Entrepreneurial Single Market Reinforcing the Single Market—particularly for services, digital products, and emerging technologies—should be a core priority. Ireland can support reforms that unlock entrepreneurship, strengthen research and innovation ecosystems, and enhance the scaling capacity of European SMEs and startups. 4. Social Inclusion, Youth Empowerment, and Community Resilience Ireland should foreground policies that promote equity, cohesion, and community development, emphasising support for marginalised groups, urban regeneration, and social innovation. This aligns strongly with Ireland’s national priorities and its partner network across education, community development, and youth services. 5. A Sustainable, Green, and Secure Europe Ireland should reinforce climate action aligned with the 2040 climate-neutrality trajectory, while prioritising energy security, just transition, and biodiversity. As an island nation, Ireland is well placed to elevate policy solutions on renewables, nature restoration, the blue economy, and climate adaptation.

geography: Urban in the main with the majority of higher education service delivery in Dublin; provision of Early Childhood Education interventions nationwide in areas of socio economic deprivation including rural
response_text: Ireland’s Presidency should advance legislative proposals that align with the EU Strategic Agenda, the Commission Work Programme 2026, and Ireland’s national strengths. NCI recommends prioritising the following: 1. Skills, Education, and Labour Mobility Legislation Key initiatives include: Strengthening the European Education Area Advancing the European Skills Agenda, including micro-credentials and lifelong learning frameworks Enhancing recognition of prior learning (RPL) across Member States Supporting reforms to vocational training, apprenticeships, and work-based learning Ireland should aim to reach Council positions that accelerate implementation and reduce fragmentation between national systems. 2. AI, Digital, and Cybersecurity Measures Priority could include: Implementation and follow-up measures to the EU AI Act Further development of the European Cybersecurity Framework New proposals on data access, digital identity, and interoperability Ireland should aim to promote innovation-friendly regulation and strengthen Europe’s digital sovereignty. 3. Single Market Reform Initiatives Ireland can advance proposals supporting: SME competitiveness Reduced administrative burden Innovation funding and R&I collaboration Deepening the Digital Single Market The objective should be to accelerate Europe’s competitiveness globally. 4. Green Transition and Energy Security Legislation Climate adaptation and resilience Nature restoration and biodiversity Renewable energy frameworks Ireland should seek balanced outcomes that support economic resilience and social fairness. 5. Youth, Social Inclusion, and Regional Cohesion Policies Ireland should prioritise legislation and Council conclusions on: NEET engagement and youth skills programmes Urban regeneration Social inclusion and equality measures The Presidency should aim to ensure that EU policies support all regions and all communities—not only high-growth urban centres.

geography: Urban in the main with the majority of higher education service delivery in Dublin; provision of Early Childhood Education interventions nationwide in areas of socio economic deprivation including rural
response_text: Ireland’s Presidency can maximise its impact through the following approaches: 1. A Presidency Focused on Skills and Social Mobility By prioritising skills ecosystems—including access, inclusion, and lifelong learning—Ireland can help ensure people across the EU have the tools to succeed in a changing labour market. This includes work-based learning, apprenticeships, and digital upskilling. 2. Practical Outcomes for SMEs and Startups Concrete progress on reducing regulatory burdens, improving access to finance, and simplifying Single Market rules will drive growth and innovation, especially for SMEs and entrepreneurs. 3. Accelerating Digital and AI Readiness Across Society The Presidency should promote policies that make AI and digital transformation accessible, safe, and beneficial for citizens, public services, communities, and businesses—ensuring no region is left behind. 4. Delivering a Fair and Just Green Transition Through balanced Council negotiations, Ireland can ensure climate action supports workers, vulnerable communities, and regional resilience, promoting a transition that is equitable as well as ambitious. 5. Strengthening Community Resilience and Social Inclusion Ireland can showcase models of community-based education, regeneration, and partnership—areas where Ireland has deep expertise—to support cohesion and shared prosperity across the EU.

geography: Urban in the main with the majority of higher education service delivery in Dublin; provision of Early Childhood Education interventions nationwide in areas of socio economic deprivation including rural
response_text: 1. Citizen-Centred Communication and Storytelling Ireland should prioritise accessible communication that connects EU policies to real-life outcomes: jobs, education, rights, community development, and digital services. Storytelling—through videos, local events, and case studies—can highlight how EU decisions improve everyday life. 2. Youth Engagement and Co-Creation Given the centrality of young people in Europe’s future, Ireland should involve youth organisations, students, and apprentices directly in Presidency activities. Initiatives may include youth assemblies, policy labs, and school/university engagement programmes. 3. Regional and Community Outreach Events should be held not only in Dublin but across all regions, including rural and urban disadvantaged areas. This strengthens a sense of shared ownership and demonstrates the EU’s commitment to all communities. 4. Partnerships with Education and Civil Society Ireland can collaborate with colleges, schools, community groups, and NGOs to deliver inclusive engagement campaigns. NCI and similar institutions can play a central role in hosting dialogues, workshops, and public events. 5. Emphasising Core European Values All communication should reinforce values of solidarity, equality, inclusion, democracy, sustainability, and respect for human rights—articulated in an accessible, engaging way.

geography: Urban in the main with the majority of higher education service delivery in Dublin; provision of Early Childhood Education interventions nationwide in areas of socio economic deprivation including rural
response_text: National College of Ireland (NCI) wishes to highlight the central importance of tertiary education, skills development, and social inclusion as cross-cutting enablers of the EU’s Strategic Agenda 2024–2029. As Europe undergoes rapid technological, demographic, and economic transformation, the role of higher education institutions—particularly those with strong community, access, and industry networks—will be essential to ensuring a resilient, competitive, and cohesive Union. Ireland’s Presidency offers an opportunity to strengthen Europe’s capacity to support learners at all stages of life, particularly those from disadvantaged or underrepresented backgrounds. NCI recommends that the Presidency promote a joined-up European approach to widening participation across tertiary education and vocational pathways, with a focus on learners experiencing socio-economic disadvantage, early school leavers, newly arrived migrants, and NEET youth. Ensuring that every individual can access high-quality, flexible pathways into skills, work, and further learning will be vital to Europe’s competitiveness and social cohesion. NCI also encourages Ireland to promote more ambitious frameworks for work-based learning, apprenticeships, and pre-apprenticeship pathways as part of the European Skills Agenda. Many Member States lack a coordinated early-stage and bridging skills ecosystem. Ireland can lead by sharing successful models that integrate industry partnerships, digital skills training, wraparound supports, and community engagement—elements that have proven effective in improving outcomes for underserved communities and supporting progression into tertiary study or employment. Ireland should also amplify the importance of micro-credentials and flexible, stackable learning. These tools can support transitions into and within tertiary education, help mid-career workers adapt to changes driven by AI and automation, and foster greater mobility within the Single Market. NCI would welcome an Irish Presidency that seeks to standardise micro-credential recognition across the EU, enabling individuals to build skills gradually and transparently, regardless of geography. Given Ireland’s strengths in digital innovation, there is a unique opportunity to champion equitable access to AI education and digital literacy. The Presidency could emphasise initiatives ensuring that schools, colleges, tertiary institutions, SMEs, and communities can harness AI technologies safely and effectively. Embedding ethical AI principles into EU education and training frameworks would help establish Europe as a global leader in responsible innovation. Finally, NCI encourages the Presidency to maintain a strong focus on social inclusion, community resilience, early childhood education interventions and access to tertiary education. Policy development should consider the needs of urban and rural disadvantaged areas, supporting investments in education, childcare, community services, and lifelong learning. A fair transition—digital, green, and economic—must ensure that every community benefits from Europe’s progress. Ireland’s Presidency can make a distinct contribution by placing people, skills, tertiary access, and equity at the heart of Europe’s future. NCI stands ready to collaborate with Government and EU partners to advance these aims.

organisation: European Federation of Pharmaceutical Industries and Associations (EFPIA)
respondent_type:
Trade and business association
EFPIA represents the biopharmaceutical industry operating in Europe. Through its direct membership of 36 national associations, 40 leading pharmaceutical companies and a growing number of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), EFPIA’s mission is to create a collaborative environment that enables our members to innovate, discover, develop and deliver new therapies and vaccines for people across Europe, as well as contribute to the European economy.
response_text: We suggest that Ireland should emphasise Europe’s competitiveness as a key Presidency and Trio theme. Over a year ago, Mario Draghi issued a wake-up call to Europe: the rapidly shifting global environment is posing an existential challenge to the foundations of the European economy. While Draghi’s diagnosis was sobering, his prescription was equally clear. The EU must close the innovation gap with the United States and China and place competitiveness at the heart of its policymaking. Today, restoring Europe’s competitiveness has become a geopolitical necessity. As the world order recalibrates, strengthening the EU’s innovation leadership and adopting smarter, more resilient trade policies, are the best vehicles to safeguarding Europe’s international standing, while improving citizens’ wellbeing. Nowhere is this more evident than in the field of health. At the end of the 20th century, Europe was the pharmacy of the world, responsible for developing half of all the innovative medicines globally. Today, that share has fallen to 1/5. In the last 20 years, Europe has lost a quarter of its global share of R&D investment. This decline affects European citizens directly: the EU has lost 60,000 clinical trials places in the last decade, and patients in Europe must now wait significantly longer to access newly approved medicines than those in the United States. To reverse this course, Ireland should use its Presidency of the Council of the EU to sustain and strengthen the momentum behind Europe’s competitiveness agenda, fully aligned with the EU Strategic Agenda 2024-2029, the Commission’s Competitiveness Compass, and the recommendations set out in the Draghi Report. In practice, this requires action across three key priorities. We believe the Irish Presidency should: First, work to ensure that the EU’s legislation strengthens Europe’s ability to research, develop and manufacture products in a competitive global environment. Across health, industry, research, single market, finance, environment and chemicals policy, substantial work is needed to reduce regulatory burdens, streamline bureaucratic overload, and create the conditions and incentives that enable companies to scale up in Europe. Second, ensure that EU trade policy supports Europe’s competitiveness. This requires safeguarding and deepening the transatlantic partnership, ensuring that the EU’s diversification strategy and free trade negotiations deliver real opportunities for innovative industries, and championing a multilateral agenda that advances open trade at a time when protectionist pressures are rising. Third, lead a strategic conversation on Europe’s choice to remain a global leader in the research, development, and production of new medicines. Closing the competitiveness gap with the US and China will require a clear, collective decision to invest more on innovation. The Presidency should lead these efforts by establishing a European Pharmaceutical Taskforce bringing together key stakeholders to comprehensively address the barriers to the sector’s competitiveness. Ireland’s recent history demonstrates how a strong focus on competitiveness can drive remarkable social and economic progress. By championing competitiveness and delivering on these three key priorities, the Irish Presidency can help steer the EU toward a future in which innovation delivers fairer outcomes for all.

respondent_type:

EFPIA represents the biopharmaceutical industry operating in Europe. Through its direct membership of 36 national associations, 40 leading pharmaceutical companies and a growing number of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), EFPIA’s mission is to create a collaborative environment that enables our members to innovate, discover, develop and deliver new therapies and vaccines for people across Europe, as well as contribute to the European economy.
response_text: Internal Competitiveness EPSCO If the Critical Medicines Act is not concluded under the Cypriot Presidency, Ireland should continue negotiations to ensure the proposal keeps a tight focus on genuine critical medicines, uses joint procurement selectively and with strong safeguards, and avoids protectionist measures – such as local-production requirements – that risk fragmenting supply chains and undermining competitiveness. On the Biotech Act I, the Presidency should ensure the legislation strengthens Europe’s IP framework, simplifies and harmonises clinical trials, establishes end-to-end regulatory oversight, creates a coherent framework for advanced manufacturing, expands access to funding and investment opportunities, and harnesses digitalisation and AI. Ireland should implement the EU Cardiovascular Health Plan by adopting the Council Recommendation on health checks and preparing a Recommendation on vaccination against respiratory infections. The Presidency should prioritise cancer through a renewed Pact to Act and sustained focus on the EBCP, the EU Cancer Mission, and the national cancer control plans implementation. COMPET Regarding the Public Procurement Act, Ireland should prioritise clinical value, quality, and secure supply over price-only or winner-takes-all models. Any EU preference and localisation criteria should be applied carefully to avoid market distortions and remain consistent with international commitments. On the European Innovation Act, the Presidency should simplify and clarify legislation, strengthening IP and market incentives to secure investments, supporting dare-to-try approaches, and enabling access to capital and markets for all companies. Ireland should work towards a General Approach on the European Research Act and drive early engagement with industry on any provisions that may affect its research activities, including AI, partnerships, clinical research, and IP management. GAC Ireland should pursue an ambitious and earmarked budget for health within the MFF, including but not limited to the Competitiveness Fund and Horizon Europe. The latter should include a significant budget for collaborative research (Pillar II - Health) with a focus on public-private partnerships and rules that reflect industrial realities and enable novel agile collaborations. ENVI Ireland should advance the revision of REACH and conclude the Environmental Omnibus, supporting innovation for the manufacturing of pharmaceuticals and ensuring simplification of EU acts by reducing duplications of requirements and administrative burden. In preparation of the Circular Economy Act, the Presidency should prioritise sustainable manufacturing, support to innovation, and responsible resource use, recognising the highly regulated nature and global supply chains of medicines. Ireland should schedule discussions on the universal PFAS restriction proposal to bring clarity on impact on medicines and their manufacturing. External Competitiveness FAC/TRADE The Presidency should safeguard and deepen the transatlantic partnership by seeking exemptions and/or a grace period for potential tariffs on innovative pharmaceutical products, ensuring medicines are excluded from any potential retaliatory measures, and promoting a positive transatlantic agenda. Ireland should also drive the EU’s diversification strategy by requiring strong IP protection in all EU FTAs, advancing harmonisation of regulatory requirements, and ensuring fair, transparent, and non-discriminatory market access. Multilaterally, the Presidency should defend the WTO rules-based trading system, resist protectionist pressures, and ensure international agreements do not create legal uncertainties or impose unworkable obligations on companies.

organisation: European Federation of Pharmaceutical Industries and Associations (EFPIA)
respondent_type:
Trade and business association
EFPIA represents the biopharmaceutical industry operating in Europe. Through its direct membership of 36 national associations, 40 leading pharmaceutical companies and a growing number of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), EFPIA’s mission is to create a collaborative environment that enables our members to innovate, discover, develop and deliver new therapies and vaccines for people across Europe, as well as contribute to the European economy.
response_text: We suggest that Ireland should lead the creation of a European Pharmaceutical Taskforce to secure the future of the sector in the EU. Besides advancing the EU’s legislative agenda, the Irish Presidency has a major opportunity to shape the high-level strategic discussions needed to future-proof the European economy. In line with Draghi’s recommendations, one of the central debates must focus on closing the EU’s widening innovation gap with the United States and China. The research-based pharmaceutical sector is essential to this effort. It delivers the strongest contribution to the EU’s trade balance, reinvests a higher share of its revenue into research and development than any other sector, and serves as a catalyst for breakthrough technologies such as biotechnology, AI, and digital health. Across the Union, the innovative pharmaceutical industry directly employs more than 950,000 people and supports over 2.6 million additional jobs. EU leaders have repeatedly acknowledged the sector’s strategic value. Pharma and healthcare feature among the ten strategic sectors identified in the Draghi report. In October 2025, the European Council reaffirmed the need for a strong pharmaceutical sector in Europe, echoing the European Commission’s ambition to make the EU the world’s most attractive destination for life sciences by 2030. Yet the environment for pharmaceutical investment, innovation, and access in Europe is deteriorating, and the situation is exacerbated by the United States government increasing pressure through tariffs and its MFN pricing policy. As one of Europe’s largest exporters of medicines, Ireland is uniquely positioned to help drive the creation of a European Pharmaceutical Taskforce, composed of the European Commission (Trade, Industry, and Health Commissioners), Member States, and industry partners. This Taskforce should pursue two core objectives. First, it should pave the way for a strong, unified political statement in support of Europe’s research-based pharmaceutical sector, delivered as a high-level Declaration during the Irish Presidency. This Declaration should reaffirm the sector’s strategic importance and articulate the EU’s clear choice to invest in its future to avoid becoming dependent on innovation happening elsewhere. Second, the Taskforce should translate this commitment into practical change. By addressing both domestic and external challenges to competitiveness, the second key output of the Taskforce should be a selection of five key benchmarking ‘innovation’ indicators that enable progress to be tracked at both national and EU level in the years ahead. By helping to address the competitiveness challenges facing the innovative pharmaceutical sector in a comprehensive and forward-looking way, the Irish Presidency can deliver a lasting positive impact for people, businesses, and communities across the EU. Making the right strategic choices now will help Europe close the innovation gap, improve health outcomes for patients, and generate sustainable economic growth and security for the decades ahead.

EFPIA represents the biopharmaceutical industry operating in Europe. Through its direct membership of 36 national associations, 40 leading pharmaceutical companies and a growing number of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), EFPIA’s mission is to create a collaborative environment that enables our members to innovate, discover, develop and deliver new therapies and vaccines for people across Europe, as well as contribute to the European economy.
response_text: Ever since Ireland joined the EU more than 50 years ago, citizens across the island have benefitted from unprecedented economic, social and scientific progress, much of which would not have been possible without the EU framework. Ireland’s upcoming Presidency of the Council of the EU offers a unique opportunity to highlight these achievements and create a strong sense of national ownership. A defining factor in this success has been the EU’s principle of solidarity, which ensures that prosperity, security, and opportunity are shared across Member States. This collective spirit has supported Ireland’s economic transformation, strengthened resilience during economic crises and public health emergencies, and enabled sustained investment and innovation. One of the EU’s most visible success stories is the Single Market. By providing unhindered access to a market of over 447 million consumers, EU membership has enabled Irish companies to grow, export, and compete globally. For the innovative pharmaceutical sector, the Single Market has been transformative. Ireland now hosts the largest pharmaceutical production footprint in Europe, with output valued at €67 billion in 2023, and supporting around 50,000 high-quality, direct jobs across the island. The European Medicines Agency (EMA) has also delivered enormous benefits for Irish patients. Since its creation in 1995, the EMA has ensured that all EU citizens – whether in Cork or Copenhagen – benefit from a single, centralised approval system for medicines grounded in world-class scientific expertise. Looking ahead, the implementation of joint Health Technology Assessment has the potential to further improve consistency, transparency, and efficiency in evaluating clinical evidence across Member States. These mechanisms give EU patients faster, safer, and more equitable access to medical innovation. The EU’s coordinated response to the COVID-19 pandemic showcased the power of acting together in times of crisis. Thanks to common action, scientific cooperation and regulatory efficiency, Irish citizens gained fast and equitable access to COVID-19 vaccines. The European Commission secured up to 4.2 billion doses for Member States, and by August 2023, 84.8% of the EU adult population had received at least one dose. Ireland embodied the principle of solidarity by achieving one of the highest vaccine uptake rates in Europe, helping protect communities nationwide and accelerating Ireland’s recovery. Finally, EU membership has strengthened Ireland’s research and innovation ecosystem through collaborative partnerships like the Innovative Medicines Initiative and the Innovative Health Initiative. These programmes, bringing together industry, academia, SMEs, and patient organisations, have provided major funding opportunities and supported Ireland’s universities and research centres in contributing to cutting-edge medical breakthroughs. A strong example is the IMI SOPHIA project, in which University College Cork and University College Dublin, together with other EU partners, have recently advanced the understanding of obesity and improved the ability to predict obesity-related complications. By communicating these concrete benefits on prosperity, health, safety, and scientific leadership, the Irish Presidency can help citizens understand that EU membership is not an abstract political project, but a shared endeavour that improves daily lives. Crucially, the Presidency contribute to ensure that these successes continue to be delivered in the future.
