Éagsúlacht Theangeolaíoch agus Chultúrtha mar Bhunchloch don Aontas Eorpach: Ba cheart d’Éirinn ardán a chruthú agus ceannaireacht a thabhairt i dtaobh teangacha agus cultúir mionlaigh, ag aithint go bhfuil ár n-éagsúlacht teangeolaíoch ríthábhachtach don fhéiniúlacht Eorpach. Tá dualgas ar an AE a cuid teangacha oifigiúla agus oibre a chur chun cinn, lena n-áirítear an Ghaeilge, agus a chinntiú go bhfuil rochtain chothrom ag saoránaigh ar sheirbhísí agus ar dhoiciméid ina dteanga dhúchais féin. Tá deis ag Éire í féin a chur chun cinn mar cheannaire sa réimse taighde praitic-bhunaithe i dtaobh na hearnála seo. Nuálaíocht Dhigiteach agus Teicneolaíocht AI do Theangacha ar Íseal Acmhainn: Tá deis ollmhór ag an Uachtaránacht ceannródaíocht a thabhairt i dtaobh forbairt uirlisí AI do theangacha mionlaigh agus neamh-fhorleathana. Tá infheistíocht straitéiseach de dhíth i dtaighde agus i bhforbairt teicneolaíochtaí cainte go téacs, teicneolaíochtaí cainte go cainte, agus aistriúchán meaisín do theangacha mar an Ghaeilge, Gaeilge na hAlban, Breatnais, Bascais, agus eile. Cinnteoidh sé seo nach bhfágfar teangacha beaga ar gcúl san aois dhigiteach. Forbairt Réigiúnach Inbhuanaithe agus Comhdhéanamh Sóisialta: Tá riachtanas i dtaobh beartais Eorpacha láidir a thacaíonn le pobail thuaithe agus le ceantair iargúlta, go háirithe iad siúd atá bunaithe ar theangacha agus cultúir mionlaigh. Ba cheart go mbeadh infheistíocht dhírithe ann i mbonneagar, i bhfiontraíocht áitiúil, i gcomhshaoil chruthaitheacha, agus i dtimpeallacht shaibhir theangeolaíoch. Ní mór freisin go mbeadh comhtháthú níos fearr idir beartais réigiúnacha, teanga, oideachais, agus forbartha eacnamaíoch. Athléimneacht Aeráide agus an tAistriú Glas Tuaithe: Is gá an tAistriú Glas a threisiú i bpobail tuaithe agus i gceantair chósta, ag tabhairt aitheantas do ról ríthábhachtach na bpobal seo i gcothú na bithéagsúlachta agus timpeallachtaí inbhuanaithe. Ba cheart go mbeadh infheistíochtaí spriocdhírithe ann i saoráidí fuinnimh in-athnuaite, líonraí siúil agus rothaíochta, agus i straitéisí cósta-chosanta atá dírithe ar phobail iargúlta.

Ba cheart go ndéanfadh Uachtaránacht na hÉireann dul chun cinn sna réimsí beartais seo a leanas: An Acht um Sheirbhísí Digiteacha agus Ceart Teanga Dhigiteach: Ag leathnú raoin fheidhme an Achta um Sheirbhísí Digiteacha chun cumhdach cuimsitheach ilteangach a chinntiú ar ardáin mhóra dhigiteacha. Ba cheart d’Éire an cás a neartú i dtaobh rialacháin láidre i dtaobh cuideachtaí mhóra teicneolaíochta (Google, Meta, Apple, Microsoft agus srl) ag cinntiú tacaíocht chuimsitheach theanga a chur ar fáil do theangacha oifigiúla an AE go léir, lena n-áirítear teangacha mionlaigh. Áirítear leis seo rochtain ar uirlisí aistriúcháin, rochtain ar aithint cainte, agus ar chomhéadain úsáideora. Straitéis Eorpach um Fhorbairt Réigiúnach agus Limistéir Thuaithe: Feabhas a chur ar Chiste Forbartha Réigiúnaí na hEorpa agus ar an gClár um Fhorbairt Tuaithe chun éagsúlacht theangeolaíoch agus chultúrtha a neartú mar chuid de chritéir mheastóireachta. Ba cheart tosaíocht a thabhairt do thionscadail a chuireann cultúr agus teanga chun cinn mar acmhainní eacnamaíocha i gcomhthéacsanna tuaithe, lena n-áirítear tionscadail turasóireachta cultúr-bhunaithe, ionaid chruthaitheacha agus líonraí gnó áitiúla. Tionscnamh Eorpach um Theicneolaíocht Teanga: Bunú clár infheistíochta straitéiseach faoi Horizon Europe atá dírithe go sonrach ar theicneolaíochtaí teanga do theangacha acmhainní ísle. Ba cheart é seo a bheith bunaithe ar shamhail mhaoinithe atá cosúil le CLAIRE (Confederation of Laboratories for Artificial Intelligence Research in Europe), ag tabhairt le chéile institiúidí taighde, rialtais náisiúnta, agus an earnáil phríobháideach chun bonneagar sonraí agus samhlacha teanga ardchaighdeáin a fhorbairt. Athbhreithniú ar an gCreat Eorpach um Chosaint Teangacha Mionlaigh: Neartú a dhéanamh ar an gCairt Eorpach do Theangacha Réigiúnacha nó Mionlaigh agus a chinntiú go bhfuil naisc shoiléir inti maidir le hoideachas, le seirbhísí poiblí, le meáin, agus le húsáid na dteangacha mionlaigh i bpróisis rialtais.

Is féidir le hUachtaránacht na hÉireann tionchar shuntasach dearfach a imirt trí: • Infheistíocht Dhíreach i mBonneagar Teanga: Trí tacú le tionscnaimh ar nós an European Language Equality (ELE) agus European Language Grid, cuirfear tacair shonraí, samhlacha meaisínfhoghlama, agus uirlisí teicneolaíochta teanga ar fáil saor in aisce do phobail teanga neamh-fhorleathana. Cabhróidh sé seo le gnólachtaí beaga agus meánmhéide in earnálacha teanga-bhunaithe/teanga-lárnach (mar shampla na meáin, turasóireacht, oideachas, cruthú ábhair) a gcuid táirgí agus seirbhísí a dhaingniú agus a leathnú go margaí ilteangacha. Cruthú Post agus Deiseanna i gCeantair Tuaithe agus Imeallacha: Is féidir poist inmharthana agus deiseanna gnó a chruthú i gceantair ina raibh sin dúshlánach san am ata caite, trí beartas láidir AE maidir le forbairt thuaithe agus tacaíocht do gheilleagair chruthaitheacha bunaithe ar chultúr agus teanga. Cuirfidh sé seo freisin le deiseanna don aos óg fanacht ina bpobail dhúchais agus a gcultúr agus a dteanga a chur chun cinn. Nasc idir Shláinte Theanga agus Sláinte Pobail: Aithint go bhfuil baint dhíreach idir folláine theangeolaíoch agus folláine sóisialta, cultúrtha agus eacnamaíoch. Léirítear i dtaighde go bhfuil pobail theanga bríomhar mar bhunús le comhshaoil chultúrtha, sláinte mheabhrach níos fearr, agus féiniúlacht áitiúil láidir. Trí infheistíocht i dteangacha, déantar infheistíocht i bpobail.

Molann muid na bearta cumarsáide seo leanas: Imeachtaí Ilteangacha ar fud na hEorpa: Eagrú sraith de cheardlanna, ceolchoirmeacha, agus imeachtaí cultúir ina gcuirfear éagsúlacht theangeolaíoch na hEorpa in iúl. D'fhéadfaí 'Seachtain na dTeangacha Mionlaigh' a reáchtáil, áit a dtaispeánfar ceol, litríocht, scannáin, agus teicneolaíocht as pobail teanga neamhfhorleathana/mionlaigh. Ardán Digiteach Idirghníomhach: A chinntiú go bhfuil tacaíocht ilteangach iomlán (teangacha oifigiúla go léir an AE) ar fáil ar láithreáin agus aipeanna cuí, a chuirfidh eolas faoi Uachtaránacht na hÉireann ar fáil, lena n-áirítear físeáin idirnáisiúnta faoi thosaíochtaí, rannpháirtíocht dhíreach ó shaoránaigh (comhairliúcháin, suirbhéanna), agus nuashonruithe ó chruinnithe agus ó chinn scríbe móra. Comhpháirtíocht le Pobail Áitiúla: Dul i gcomhpháirtíocht le heagraíochtaí pobail, le heagraíochtaí teanga, le scoileanna, agus le grúpaí óige chun imeachtaí áitiúla agus tionscadail oideachais a reáchtáil a léiríonn cén chaoi mar a oibríonn an tAontas Eorpach agus cén tionchar atá aige ar an saol laethúil. Ba chóir go bhféadfaí na himeachtaí seo a sholáthar go hiomlán trí Ghaeilge, chun freastal ar phobail Gaeltachta agus ar phobail labhartha Gaeilge taobh amuigh den Ghaeltacht. Ardán do Chur Chuige Údarás na Gaeltachta: Úsáid Uachtaránacht 2026 mar ardán chun taithí agus cur chuigí uathúil Údarás na Gaeltachta i dtaobh pleanáil teanga, forbairt pobail agus forbairt eacnamaíochta tuaithe, a roinnt le ballstáit eile AE atá ag streachailt le pobail mionteanga a chothú agus a neartú. Tabharfar léargas ar shamhlacha éifeachtacha pleanála teanga agus forbartha pobail, chomh maith le léargas ar an gcaoi a bhfuil teicneolaíocht agus nuálaíocht curtha i bhfeidhm chun teangacha mionlaigh a thabhairt isteach san aois dhigiteach.

Tugann Uachtaránacht na hÉireann 2026 deis uathúil don tír ceannródaíocht a dhéanamh i réimse atá fíorriachtanach don todhchaí: cosaint agus cur chun cinn na héagsúlachta teangeolaíochta agus cultúrtha mar shócmhainn luachmhar d'Aontas Eorpach. Mar ghníomhaireacht stáit atá dírithe ar fhorbairt eacnamaíoch, shóisialta, theangeolaíoch agus chultúrtha réigiún Gaeltachta na hÉireann, tuigeann Údarás na Gaeltachta go bhfuil cúram faoi leith ar an Uachtaránacht seo dúshlán na dteangacha mionlaigh agus neamhfhorleathana san aois dhigiteach a shainaithint agus a aghaidh a thabhairt air. Tá ról lárnach ag an Uachtaránacht i gcinntiú go mbeidh teangacha amhail an Ghaeilge, Gaeilge na hAlban, Breatnais, Ceirnis, Bascais, Catalóinis, agus teangacha mionlaigh eile in ann teacht slán sa todhchaí - ní hamháin ar mhaithe le cúrsaí oidhreachta agus cultúir, ach mar theangacha bríomhara atá in ann freastal ar riachtanais na sochaí comhaimseartha. Tá an infheistíocht i dteicneolaíocht teanga, i mbonneagar digiteach, agus i samhlacha AI do theangacha ar íseal-acmhainn níos tábhachtaí anois ná riamh. Gan an infheistíocht seo, beidh teangacha beaga fágtha ar gcúl ag earnáil a thugann fócas ar theangacha móra amháin. Tá dualgas ar an Aontas Eorpach a chinntiú go mbeidh rochtain chothrom ag saoránaigh i dteangacha beaga ar na hacmhainní céanna digiteacha - aistriúchán, aithint cainte, uirlisí scríbhneoireachta, agus ardáin chumarsáide - atá ar fáil do chainteoirí teangacha móra. Tá taithí agus eolas uathúil ag Údarás na Gaeltachta i réimse pleanála teanga pobalbhunaithe, forbartha eacnamaíoch réigiúnaí, agus comhtháthú teicneolaíochta nua-aimseartha i gcomhthéacsanna mionteanga. Ba mhaith linn oibriú go dlúth leis an gComhairle agus le hinstitiúidí eile an AE le linn na hUachtaránachta chun an taithí seo a roinnt agus chun tacú le Ballstáit eile a bhfuil dúshláin chosúla acu le pobail mionteanga.

I believe the Irish presidency should focus on a ‘A Europe that delivers for all’ agenda. Considering Ireland’s unique island and land border situation, and the fact that the two other countries making up the trio are Lithuania and Greece, I believe Defence & Secure External Borders should be a key area of focus. This will provide continuity on a similar theme of the current trio of presidencies, hopefully leading to some long lasting achievements. However, the focus must remain on the EU and it’s capabilities, and should not include NATO. A second area of focus has to be Affordability. This particularly applies to housing, an area that every European country is struggling to address. The widespread nature of this issue means that if the Irish presidency can help move the needle on it, it would be everlasting. Tackling this issue requires bold ideas beyond just making apartments smaller or limiting short term lets. Thirdly, Digital Competitiveness & Security. Ireland is home to many major tech players, which has benefited the Irish state greatly, but has, I believe, had a negative impact on the EU as a whole. In this era of AI and Quantum, it is time for Europe to become competitive. The building blocks are there, we need to create the environment in which they can thrive. In particular, developing AI that actually improves the lives of European citizens, rather than just lining the pockets of industry leaders will require strong commitment across the EU as a whole. Strong government leadership will be required to prevent the watering down of AI and Privacy regulation and I think Ireland is in a strong position to take such a role. This theme is also intertwined with the theme of Defence & Secure External Borders as cyber security is becoming an increasingly critical area for the EU to address, as evidenced by, for example, the relatively recent ransomware attack on Irish healthcare institutions.

Ensuring alignment and agreement across the multiple pieces of legislation related to Digital Competitiveness & Security, primarily the Cloud and AI Development Act, the Chips Act, the AI Act, the Quantum Act, and the recently announced digital omnibus to simplify and streamline rules, will be crucial to their success. Ireland, as the primary host of multinational tech companies in the Union, has the skills, knowledge, and position to promote this alignment. It is also an opportunity for Ireland to show it is committed to the growth and success of the European tech ecosystem, regardless of any impact that may have on the American tech companies it hosts. Regarding Affordability, although the Commission’s work programme for 2026 in this area is unambitious in my opinion, the ‘initiative on short term rentals’ and any initiatives resulting from the ‘anti-poverty strategy’ must be prioritised. The lack of affordable housing EU wide is one of, if not the biggest, issue facing citizens of the Union. It has to be addressed through determination and ambition, putting regular people at the centre. Defence has long been a controversial subject in Ireland given our neutrality, but I don’t believe this neutrality means we shouldn’t be able to adequately defend ourselves, especially when we consider the criticality of the undersea cables within our territorial waters. Under the Defence & Secure External Borders theme, the initiatives for ‘Strengthening Frontex’ and ‘Simplifying defence and sensitive security procurement’ should receive focus. Ireland also needs to improve it’s national defence and security situation so an increased focus on knowledge and capabilities sharing from other EU member states is encouraged.

People need to understand what is being done for them to be able to feel they are part of it. Often, the work at the EU level is too abstract for average citizens to relate to so I believe simplifying the messaging is important. It is also important to relate the work of the Council during Ireland’s presidency to what matters most to the Irish people, and other EU citizens, such as affordable housing and border security. The messaging should also be spread across different media, allowing as many people as possible to access it. The messaging needs to be results oriented. People don’t care about what the Council or other institutions are trying to do if there aren’t any tangible results at the end. When it comes to politics, “Do or do not. There is no try”.

The 2026 Presidency occurs at a critical juncture for the European Union. The life sciences sector, a cornerstone of Europe’s economy and societal well-being, faces profound challenges to its global competitiveness. Over the last two decades, Europe’s share of global R&D investment has fallen by a quarter, with investment flowing to more competitive destinations like the United States and China. This trend directly impacts European patients, who face longer waits for innovative medicines and have fewer opportunities to participate in clinical trials. To address this, Ireland has an opportunity to champion a compelling and cohesive vision. We recommend that Ireland adopt the following overarching theme for its Presidency: "Better Health, Stronger Europe: Investing in Resilience and Innovation" This theme directly connects the EU’s long-term economic prosperity and strategic autonomy with the health and well-being of its citizens. It provides a strong narrative for why a thriving life sciences ecosystem is not just an industrial goal but a societal necessity. This vision can be built upon three strategic pillars: Driving Competitiveness for Better Health Outcomes: Enhancing Europe’s life sciences ecosystem is a prerequisite for delivering faster, more equitable access to innovative medicines and for expanding opportunities for citizens to participate in cutting-edge clinical trials. The Presidency should champion the view that healthcare spending is a strategic investment in societal resilience and economic productivity, not simply a cost to be contained. Strengthening Strategic Resilience: True resilience is the capacity of the EU’s health systems and supply chains to anticipate and absorb shocks. This means ensuring the security of medicine supply, leveraging digital infrastructure to monitor public health threats, and diversifying manufacturing to prepare for future challenges without resorting to protectionist measures. Accelerating Patient-Centred Innovation: The Presidency must place the patient at the heart of its agenda. This involves translating scientific breakthroughs into tangible benefits by improving regulatory pathways, embracing the potential of digital health and the European Health Data Space, and decisively tackling unmet medical needs in areas such as cancer, cardiovascular disease, rare diseases, and neurological conditions. By framing its priorities around this central theme, the Irish Presidency can champion a positive, forward-looking agenda that aligns the EU’s industrial, health, and research policies toward a common, citizen-focused goal.

The legislative agenda for the Irish Presidency will be substantially shaped by inherited files from the outgoing Trio presidencies. Within this context, Ireland has a crucial opportunity to provide leadership and steer key proposals toward outcomes that foster innovation, competitiveness, and patient access. The Presidency should focus on two primary legislative priorities. Future-Proofing the EU's Life Sciences Ecosystem EU Biotech Act: This Act should be a flagship priority for the Irish Presidency, championed as a critical simplification instrument. Ireland’s goal should be to ensure the legislation strengthens the EU’s intellectual property (IP) framework, simplifies and harmonises clinical trial authorisations through measures like a single portal for core document submission and a harmonised approach to ethical reviews, and creates seamless end-to-end regulatory oversight. A well-designed Biotech Act will make the EU a more attractive and predictable destination for high-value investment in research and advanced manufacturing. Revision of the Pharmaceutical Legislation: This represents a once-in-a-generation opportunity to modernise the EU’s regulatory environment. The Irish Presidency should work to ensure the implementation of the legislation. Targeted Revision of the Medical Devices & IVD Regulations: While pharmaceutical reform is vital, the Irish Presidency must also address the critical bottlenecks in the diagnostics sector. We recommend that Ireland prioritize the targeted revision of the IVDR and MDR to streamline certification processes. A functioning diagnostics market is the foundation of the entire health ecosystem; without tests, there are no diagnoses, and without diagnoses, there is no treatment. Multiannual Financial Framework: The EU’s budget plays an important role in realizing the competitiveness agenda and health and life science policy priorities. In this context, the multiannual financial framework (MFF) is particularly important, with regard to the negotiations for the forthcoming MFF 2028-2034. Ensuring Timely and Equitable Patient Access Ireland should leverage its significant manufacturing credibility to guide legislation toward its intended purpose: genuine supply resilience. The Presidency should champion key elements such as real-time shortage alerts, diversified manufacturing, and risk-based assessments of vulnerabilities. It is critical to avoid protectionist measures like local-production requirements, which risk fragmenting global supply chains and undermining competitiveness. Implementation of the Health Technology Assessment (HTA) Regulation: With joint clinical assessments now underway since January 2025, the Irish Presidency should promote the swift and effective implementation of the HTA Regulation. The aim must be to ensure a consistent, high-quality, and timely process for evaluating clinical evidence. This will reduce duplicative processes across Member States, minimise delays, and accelerate patient access to proven innovations. By successfully advancing these legislative files, the Irish Presidency can deliver a lasting legacy that strengthens Europe’s health security, boosts its industrial competitiveness, and, most importantly, improves health outcomes for millions of citizens.

The ultimate success of the Irish Presidency will be measured by its ability to demonstrate how high-level EU strategy delivers concrete benefits for citizens’ health, economic security, and community well-being. Beyond advancing specific legislative files, Ireland can make a substantial impact by spearheading a high-level strategic initiative. We recommend that Ireland champion the creation of a European Pharmaceutical Taskforce as a key priority for the Irish Presidency, bringing together the European Commission, Member States, and industry partners. This Taskforce should pursue two core objectives. First, it should deliver a bold, high-level Political Declaration during the Irish Presidency that reaffirms the strategic importance of Europe's research-based pharmaceutical sector and the EU's collective commitment to invest in its future. Second, it must translate this political commitment into tangible action by developing a selection of five key benchmarking ‘innovation’ indicators that enable progress to be tracked at both national and EU level in the years ahead, ensuring accountability long after the Presidency concludes. This initiative would anchor the Presidency's work in delivering tangible benefits across several key areas: Faster Access to Innovation: By working to streamline regulatory and reimbursement pathways, the Presidency can directly reduce the time patients must wait for life-changing treatments. This is particularly critical for those living with cancer, rare diseases, and other serious conditions where time is of the essence. Turning the Tide on Cancer through Early Detection: Treatment is only half the battle. The Presidency should drive the full implementation of the EU Council Recommendations on Cancer Screening. By championing the rollout of lung, prostate, and gastric cancer screening programs across Member States, Ireland can help shift European healthcare systems from a model of "sick care" to true "preventative health," saving lives and reducing long-term costs. Driving Regional Prosperity: A competitive and thriving life sciences sector supports high-quality, sustainable jobs and investment in communities across Europe, well beyond major urban centres. Ireland’s own distributed ecosystem is a prime example of this positive regional impact, which the Presidency can showcase as a model for Europe. Empowering Patients through Digital Health: Championing the effective and interoperable implementation of the European Health Data Space (EHDS) will empower patients with greater control over their own health data, improve care coordination between providers, and create unprecedented opportunities to accelerate research and discovery. Operationalize the EU Cardiovascular Health Plan As Chair of the Council, Ireland is uniquely positioned to steer Member State discussions toward the concrete implementation of the EU Cardiovascular Health Plan. We encourage the Presidency to guide the Council toward a consensus on prioritizing secondary prevention, specifically by facilitating agreement on EU-wide early detection standards and "Heart Health Checks." By leading these critical discussions, Ireland can drive a coordinated EU response to reduce preventable mortality and healthcare costs. By focusing on these practical outcomes, the Presidency can build a powerful narrative that connects its work in Brussels and Luxembourg to the daily lives of people, businesses, and communities across the Union.

Effective communication requires moving beyond technical policy discussions to build a clear, compelling, and relatable narrative that connects the Presidency's work with the daily lives and concerns of European citizens. This requires a people-centric message and tangible examples of the EU's positive impact. To achieve this, we recommend adopting a clear and simple narrative for the Presidency, such as: "Our Health, Our Future: Delivering for Europe’s Citizens" This framing directly links the benefits of EU cooperation—a cornerstone of Ireland’s own modern history—with visible, positive outcomes in healthcare, economic security, and innovation that resonate with citizens. It transforms the abstract concept of EU policy into a shared goal of improved well-being for all. To build a sense of public ownership, this narrative should be supported by concrete communication strategies: Showcase Tangible Benefits: Use digital storytelling and media engagement to highlight practical examples of EU action. Feature stories on earlier cancer diagnoses made possible by EU research, secure medicine supplies during a crisis, or improved access to vaccines for families and communities. This makes the benefits of EU membership personal and relatable. Facilitate Patient-Centred Dialogue: Organise a series of patient roundtables and citizen dialogues to highlight the lived experiences of those directly affected by health policy. Ensuring the voices of patients are heard and integrated into the Presidency's work will make the process more inclusive and demonstrate a genuine commitment to public engagement. By adopting this approach, Ireland can communicate the value of the EU in a way that is authentic, impactful, and builds a strong sense of national and European pride in the Presidency’s mission.

cases, respondents must provide a summary of the additional information under the ‘Any other comments’ question. This summary should also be limited to a maximum of 500 words. For Ireland to lead the European life sciences agenda with credibility, it must first articulate its own clear national vision. Therefore, our single most critical recommendation is that Ireland seize a unique and time-sensitive opportunity to reinforce its leadership credentials ahead of its Presidency. The Case for a National Life Sciences Strategy We strongly recommend that the Irish Government publish an ambitious National Life Sciences Strategy before the Presidency begins in the second half of 2026. Taking this proactive step is essential. It will provide Ireland with the strategic clarity, policy framework, and international credibility required to shape EU priorities. By publishing its own strategy, Ireland can move beyond its formal role as a neutral and honest broker to become an informed and exemplary broker, leading the EU by example. An Irish strategy aligned with the EU's own ambitions will serve as a powerful blueprint for other Member States. Based on our extensive engagement and analysis, we believe this national strategy should be built upon three strategic pillars: Fostering Enterprise: A focus on growing indigenous companies, sustaining high-value Foreign Direct Investment (FDI), and protecting Ireland's world-class advanced manufacturing base to ensure a resilient and innovative industrial ecosystem. Innovation Uptake: A commitment to accelerate patient access to new medicines and diagnostics, reform procurement to focus on value, and expand the clinical trial ecosystem to establish Ireland as an "Early Launch Market" for cutting-edge therapies. Research, Data & Digital: A vision to position Ireland as a global hub for life sciences research and a leader in the adoption of the European Health Data Space (EHDS) and other digital health innovations that can transform care delivery and R&D. By launching a National Life Sciences Strategy, Ireland can champion its Presidency theme of "Better Health, Stronger Europe" with unmatched authority and authenticity. It will send an unmistakable signal that Ireland is not just chairing the EU agenda, but is actively leading by example. Roche is fully committed to partnering with the Irish government to help deliver a successful Presidency that yields lasting benefits for patients and reinforces the vital connection between Better Health and a Stronger Europe.

organisation: Secretariat of the Steering Group on Prevention of Respiratory Infections
geography: EU wide, with relevance at national level across EU-27 Member States
response_text: Ireland should choose EU resilience and preparedness as high-level thematic priorities for its Presidency of the Council in 2026. The COVID-19 pandemic, alongside other challenges such as geopolitical tensions, energy-supply disruptions, and extreme weather events like floods, wildfires, and droughts, has underscored the importance of building a resilient Union. By strengthening its ability to anticipate, respond to, and recover from a wide range of shocks, the EU can better safeguard its citizens, economies, and essential services. In this context, investing in public health prevention is a key element of preparedness and resilience. In a world of rising health threats and mounting pressure on health systems, the EU has a clear opportunity and responsibility to lead on preparedness by reinforcing investment in public health prevention. One aspect of this is the prevention and mitigation of respiratory infections. This is not only a public health priority but also a vital component of EU resilience, safeguarding citizens, economies, and essential services from the destabilising effects of large-scale outbreaks. Investing in prevention is a critical part of promoting global health security preparedness, as infectious diseases know no borders. As other global actors reduce their long-term public health investments, the EU can step forward to fill the gap and champion a model of long-term resilience. To match the scale of today’s challenges and address the reality of respiratory infections, some with pandemic potential, EU action is needed. These infections can not only overwhelm healthcare systems, but also disrupt essential services, and undermine workforce capacity and economic stability. Indeed, respiratory infections (influenza, COVID-19, Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV)), and pneumococcal disease) are among the most serious public health threats facing Europe. Across the EU, respiratory infections are the leading cause of comorbidities, hospitalisation, and death. These infections can overwhelm healthcare systems, disrupt essential services, and undermine workforce capacity and economic stability. Immunisation against respiratory infections is a proven, cost-effective tool that strengthens strategic autonomy, reducing economic losses and reliance on emergency measures and external supplies during crises. Safe and effective immunisation tools are available, and the prevention of severe outcomes is both feasible and cost effective. A comprehensive EU approach will save lives, protect economic productivity, and maintain public trust while ensuring that the EU is prepared for future cross-border health threats. Now is the time for the EU to take responsibility and act decisively to protect the health and security of its citizens.

organisation: Secretariat of the Steering Group on Prevention of Respiratory Infections
geography: EU wide, with relevance at national level across EU-27 Member States
response_text: During its Presidency, Ireland should prioritise the prevention of respiratory infections (such as seasonal influenza, COVID-19, pneumococcal diseases, and RSV) as a key European health challenge within the larger framework of respiratory health prevention. Ireland is uniquely positioned to drive this agenda among Member States, leading by example with its own national experience. Ireland’s preventive respiratory health leadership is long established. In 2004, it became the first country in the world to ban indoor smoking in workplaces, paving the way for similar policies across Europe and marking a major milestone in respiratory health policy. This pioneering move set a global precedent, significantly improved indoor air quality, and lowering rates of smoking-related respiratory illness. Ireland is also a leader in influenza vaccination and public confidence in vaccination, demonstrating its experience, success and credibility in public health prevention and respiratory health. Respiratory infections remain among the most serious public health threats facing Europe and improved uptake of existing vaccines could substantially reduce the burdens associated with these infections in Europe. However, despite the availability of effective immunisation methods, immunisation coverage remains below target in many EU countries and existing EU frameworks are no longer fit for purpose. The 2009 Council Recommendation on Seasonal Influenza Vaccination represents an important step but is now insufficient to address the scale and complexity of today’s respiratory health challenges, which urgently require a broader (beyond influenza) and more ambitious approach. Given the clear cross-border implications of respiratory infections, EU-level action is essential. In this context, the Steering Group welcomes the intention of the European Commission to develop new Council Recommendation on vaccination against respiratory infections as a preventive measure for cardiovascular disease as a flagship initiative within its forthcoming Cardiovascular Health Plan. We believe that the Irish Presidency is well-placed to lead the way in generating political momentum ahead of such Recommendations, drawing on the successes of its own national experience, to elevate respiratory health within the EU health political agenda. This focus would also align with other Irish health priorities, including the revision of the EU’s tobacco legislation, under the broader umbrella of promoting respiratory health, and more broadly with EU priorities, such as strengthening EU resilience, improving access to critical medicines, and completing the European Health Union. By championing comprehensive respiratory and immunisation policy, Ireland could host a high-level conference during its Presidency, engaging stakeholders from across the EU to reinforce the importance of action. Achieving this would be a meaningful accomplishment of the Irish Presidency and leave an important legacy in public health.

organisation: Secretariat of the Steering Group on Prevention of Respiratory Infections
geography: EU wide, with relevance at national level across EU-27 Member States
response_text: Respiratory infections are among the most common infectious diseases in Europe, and many of their most serious consequences are preventable. Infections such as RSV, pneumococcal disease, COVID-19 and influenza pose a significant and evolving threat to public health in Europe, affecting a range of at-risk groups including older adults, young children, pregnant people and those with underlying health conditions such as chronic respiratory, cardiovascular, metabolic or kidney diseases. Their cumulative burden, combined with rising health threats and mounting pressure on health systems, underlines the urgent need for stronger prevention and preparedness. The benefits of immunisation extend beyond merely reducing disease severity. Immunisation also plays an important preventive role in lowering the risk of exacerbation and initiation of non-communicable diseases, including cardiovascular disease and chronic respiratory diseases. For example, immunisation against respiratory infections has been shown to lower the risk of heart attack, stroke, and heart failure. Meanwhile, at least 70% of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) exacerbations are infectious in origin, with respiratory infections identified in approximately 30% of cases. Immunisation also plays a critical role in addressing the growing threat of antimicrobial resistance by helping to prevent the emergence and transmission of drug-resistant and drug-sensitive infections and lower antibiotic use. However, significant disparities in healthy life expectancy and vaccine uptake remain across Europe, correlating with socioeconomic factors and varying levels of healthcare access, with persisting barriers in Central and Eastern Europe. 15 years after the publication of the Council Recommendation on Seasonal Influenza Vaccination, the EU is still lagging behind in immunisation against respiratory infections. In 2023-2024, the median vaccination rate for influenza among older adults in the EU was only 45.7%, compared to the target of 75%. Meanwhile, in 2023-24 just 12% of adults aged 60 and above received a COVID-19 vaccine. For older adults aged 60-69, most reporting countries fell below 35%. By prioritising prevention of respiratory infections among its health priorities, the Irish Presidency can help promote healthier lives and better outcomes for citizens and communities across the EU. It can also contribute to European economic competitiveness and resilience by reducing healthcare costs, preventing productivity losses, helping workforces remain healthy and efficient, supporting economic growth and limiting absenteeism. By keeping populations healthy, immunisation also reduces pressure on healthcare systems and reinforces economic security across Europe. Adult immunisation programmes can return up to 19 times their initial investment and in the case of pneumococcal immunisation – 33 times. Annual seasonal influenza immunisation can save up to €332 million in healthcare costs in Europe by preventing hospitalisations and visits to general practitioners. Together, prioritising prevention of respiratory infections can help ensure equitable access to preventive measures across all Member States, particularly for vulnerable populations, and send a strong signal of renewed EU commitment to disease prevention, health system resilience, and preparedness.

organisation: Secretariat of the Steering Group on Prevention of Respiratory Infections
geography: EU wide, with relevance at national level across EU-27 Member States
response_text: The EU has both the opportunity and responsibility to lead by investing in long-term preparedness and resilience. Immunisation is a proven, cost-effective tool to protect citizens, safeguard economies and build capacity in responding to emergencies. Despite overwhelming evidence that immunisation saves lives, prevents hospitalisations, increases preparedness and reduces healthcare costs, inconsistent immunisation coverage across Member States continues to leave millions unprotected. Highlighting successes in this area and addressing vaccine hesitancy can make the benefits of EU-level action tangible and relatable for EU citizens. To foster a sense of citizen ownership over Ireland’s EU Presidency, communication should emphasise how EU initiatives—like a proposed Council Recommendation on immunisation against respiratory infections—directly benefit people’s lives. Ireland can engage EU citizens by showcasing its national experience as a model for EU-wide action, demonstrating how policies developed at the EU level can be adapted to diverse health systems. Ireland is one of Europe’s leaders in immunisation and should lead as an example during its EU Presidency. This leadership position has been established through a combination of high vaccine uptake, evidence-driven decision-making, and early adoption of new preventive measures. As mentioned previously, Ireland has historically been a champion in prevention in respiratory health, including through consistently meeting the World Health Organization’s 75% target for flu vaccine uptake among older adults. This strong track record positions Ireland to lead EU efforts on respiratory infection prevention. Ireland is well positioned to lead the effort to promote prevention across Europe, which aligns closely with its national priorities through work at Council working party level. The Department of Health’s Statement of Strategy 2023–2025 identifies pandemic preparedness and public health promotion - particularly through strengthened screening and immunisation - as a top strategic priority. Similarly, Objective 5 of the HSE Health Protection Strategy 2022–2027 focuses on immunisation, including enhancing prevention and control of vaccine-preventable diseases across population groups. Ireland is also pioneering in this area through its recently expanded RSV immunisation programme for infants - one of the first of its kind in Europe. Its example could be highly impactful for other EU countries, demonstrating how preventive strategies can be scaled and adapted across different health systems. With a Council Recommendation on the value of immunisation against respiratory infections, the EU could provide support to Member States, including Ireland, towards improved prevention measures. This could include support by the European Commission and the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control in building capacity and infrastructure for improved disease surveillance and vaccination coverage reporting. Together, this can promote enhanced health resilience, stronger health systems, and improved health outcomes for all EU citizens. Building trust in the EU, and vaccines, relies on making the case for how they improve their everyday lives and providing clear and accessible information about how not only how they function, but add value to our societies – including by supporting resilience and preparedness. By acting on this pressing public health issue, Ireland can help advance the wellbeing and safety of citizens across the EU during its Presidency.

organisation: Secretariat of the Steering Group on Prevention of Respiratory Infections
geography: EU wide, with relevance at national level across EU-27 Member States
response_text: Please find attached: the Steering Group’s manifesto, which outlines in further detail our core policy ask of a new Council Recommendation on the value of immunisation against respiratory infections. The manifesto includes scientific evidence regarding the burden of respiratory infections across Europe and explains the key policy levers to promote improved prevention through immunisation. a memo explaining how this call for action aligns with Irish policy priorities and how the upcoming EU Presidency can provide an opportunity for Ireland to lead by example in promoting respiratory infection prevention, and respiratory heath more broadly. About the Steering Group: The Steering Group on the Prevention of Respiratory Infections is an EU-level coalition active since 2017. The Steering Group brings together 12 organisations representing healthcare professionals, scientists, academics, civic society organisations and industry. [REDACTED UNDER GDPR] unites health stakeholders to advocate for broader immunisation efforts on influenza, COVID-19, respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) and pneumococcal diseases, toward stronger EU health policy and increased awareness. Members of the Steering Group include: Active Citizenship Network (ACN), Adult Immunization Board (AIB), Coalition for Life Course Immunization (CLCI), Dutch Immunisation Foundation (De Nederlandse Immunisatie Stichting), European Federation of Allergy and Airways Diseases Patient’s Associations (EFA), European Specialist Nurses Organisation (ESNO), European Scientific Working Group on Influenza (ESWI), International Longevity Centre UK (ILC UK), Vaccine Confidence Project, Vaccines Europe [sponsoring member], World Association for Infectious Diseases and Immunological Disorders (WAidid), and World Medical Association (WMA).

geography: The geographical focus of this submission is EU wide as it is important that the priorities which Ireland sets out are wide reaching.
response_text: The issue of security, defence and common peace across our shared continent must be a high-level priority for Ireland given the current geopolitical threats the EU is facing. It is imperative that the European Union is enabled to protect its infrastructure and prepare for imminent crises that could and will severely damage our Member States. We must place our fundamental values at the core of the Presidency and commit to upholding them across the EU and Ireland must strive to build on citizen engagement across all Member States and let us lead by example in fostering further cohesion amongst European citizens in the deeper integration of the European project. It is essential that we eradicate the spread of false Europhobic and Eurosceptic messaging and instead emphasis the need for democratic resilience. Likewise, the EU must act as a global leader in championing our values at a global level to enhance international principles and promote global peace and justice and this is something Ireland can focus on as chair.

geography: The geographical focus of this submission is EU wide as it is important that the priorities which Ireland sets out are wide reaching.
response_text: It is imperative that the EU re-calibrates its approach to counteracting climate change and increased environmental sustainability. A tightened approach towards large CO2 emitters must be established and they must be held accountable for not meeting European climate and environmental targets. With regards to the individual, DG Environment and other supporting stakeholders must continue to carry out outreach work to ensure the message of the positive impact European citizens can make to our journey of collective action in order to create a greener and more sustainable future for Europe. Similarly, the development of sustainable tourism is important across the continent. In the case of Ireland, the institutions must continue to engage with key stakeholders to formulate greener transport options given that we are an island member state with limited rail connectivity.

geography: The geographical focus of this submission is EU wide as it is important that the priorities which Ireland sets out are wide reaching.
response_text: Ireland can drive forward EU legislation on climate action, renewable energy, and digital innovation ensuring that all sectors benefit from initiatives. By steering negotiations on the next Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) and Common Fisheries Policy (CFP), the Presidency can ensure food security, fair incomes, and rural development across the Union. These are areas important to many of the 27 bloc. Likewise, it is essential that Ireland takes the lead on Mercosur.

geography: The geographical focus of this submission is EU wide as it is important that the priorities which Ireland sets out are wide reaching.
response_text: We know that the most effective way to best inform citizens of existing and potential benefits owning to EU membership is through education, informative campaigns and on the ground work and this should be best situated in the context of the commitment to a united and independent European. In my area of study specific to Europe I continue to witness the disconnection between the Irish people and the core values and the principles of EU citizenship. This also directly applies to all European nationalities and is not case specific. We must highlight the importance of skills, vocational training and education to EU citizens and the need for shared talent and experience across Member States. There are numerous opportunities for mobility within the EU, yet they are often under subscribed. Ireland’s upcoming Presidency is a valuable opportunity to carry out an extensive outreach to renew the European surface which exists parallel to national identity and advance the social dimension to our EU project.
