response_text: N/A

Ireland has long held a recognised leading, trailblazer role in tobacco control, both nationally and within the EU. This leadership is reflected in Ireland’s ambitious public health policies and its strong alignment with the EU Beating Cancer Plan. As Ireland prepares for the 2026 Presidency, continuing—and strengthening—this pioneering role offers a unique opportunity to distinguish itself and contribute to delivering a healthier, more resilient Europe. Priority 1: Advancing a Future-Oriented EU Public Health Agenda Ireland’s Presidency should champion a forward-looking public health agenda that supports the EU Strategic Agenda 2024–2029 and accelerates progress on the Beating Cancer Plan. To achieve Europe’s 2040 cancer objectives, the EU must make measurable progress on tobacco and nicotine regulation, including reforms under the Tobacco Products Directive (TPD) and the Tobacco Tax Directive (TTD). Although it remains uncertain whether both directives will be fully tabled during Ireland’s Presidency, this moment provides an important political window. Ireland can use its Presidency to push for progress, set clear political direction, and ensure strong Council alignment on the importance of updated, evidence-based regulation. Updated tobacco and nicotine legislation—covering product standards, flavours, marketing, taxation, and monitoring—will be critical to protecting public health. Priority 2: Ending the Tobacco Epidemic and Addressing the Rapidly Growing Nicotine Market Ireland can position the EU at the forefront of tobacco endgame strategies—aimed at driving smoking prevalence to near-zero levels. Such an approach aligns strongly with the Beating Cancer Plan and with Ireland’s own longstanding leadership. Simultaneously, the EU faces an accelerating vaping and nicotine epidemic, with new products, flavours, and disposable devices expanding at a pace that outstrips current legislation. The nicotine industry is innovating rapidly and targeting young people aggressively. Ireland’s Presidency can elevate the urgency of modernising EU rules to address emerging nicotine products, reduce youth exposure, and strengthen cross-border enforcement. Priority 3: Protecting Children and Young People Across the EU A people-centred, future-oriented Presidency should focus on safeguarding children and young people from addictive substances and commercial determinants of health. Ireland can highlight the need for stronger measures on advertising, digital marketing, packaging, and availability—in alignment with the FCTC's MPOWER framework. Reducing early nicotine exposure is essential for Europe’s health and equity goals. Priority 4: A Fair, Health-Protective and Resilient Single Market Strong tobacco and nicotine regulation supports a competitive and fair Single Market, reduces health inequalities, and strengthens economic resilience. Updated TPD and TTD frameworks will provide clarity, protect consumers, and ensure coherent market rules across Member States. Conclusion By reinforcing its pioneering role and championing progress on the TPD and TTD, Ireland can make a measurable and lasting contribution during its 2026 Presidency. This aligns with the EU’s long-term vision while advancing the Beating Cancer Plan.

The Irish Presidency has a unique opportunity to drive progress on key policy areas critical to public health, youth protection, and the EU’s long-term ambitions under the Beating Cancer Plan. Ireland’s leadership in tobacco and nicotine control positions it to advance legislative files that will determine whether the EU can meet its 2040 cancer and health equity targets. Tobacco and Nicotine Regulation: Tobacco Products Directive (TPD) Revision The TPD revision should be a central focus of the Irish Presidency. Even if the TPD formally falls outside its remit, this period provides a strategic opportunity to push for progress, accelerate discussions, and set strong political direction. The rapid evolution of the nicotine market—including vaping products, nicotine pouches, flavour innovations, and disposable devices—requires a modernised framework that keeps pace with industry tactics targeting young people. The Irish Presidency should aim to: Support ambitious Council positions on product standards, flavour bans, packaging rules, and digital marketing restrictions. Strengthen provisions on nicotine and emerging products, including phased restrictions or bans targeting youth. Advance cross-border enforcement to ensure consistent implementation across Member States. Uphold Article 5.3 of the WHO FCTC to prevent tobacco industry interference and safeguard evidence-based policy. Tobacco Tax Directive (TTD): Closing Gaps and Preventing Youth Uptake Modernising the TTD is essential to reduce affordability, a key driver of youth tobacco and nicotine use. The Irish Presidency can: Advocate taxation frameworks covering all nicotine products, including emerging ones. Support minimum tax levels to reduce price gaps between traditional tobacco and alternatives. Strengthen links between fiscal measures and cancer prevention objectives. A robust TTD also promotes a fairer and more coherent Single Market. Protecting Children and Young People Youth protection should remain a priority across all Council configurations. Ireland can champion stronger measures on advertising, online promotion, packaging, retailer licensing, and school-based prevention — including holding digital platforms such as Snapchat accountable for the promotion and visibility of nicotine products. Strengthening Europe’s Public Health Architecture Ireland can reinforce Europe’s chronic disease prevention capacity through improved data collection, monitoring industry tactics, and addressing commercial determinants of health. These measures support both the Beating Cancer Plan and EU resilience goals. International Coordination and COP12 Ireland’s Presidency, in coordination with its Trio partners Lithuania and Greece, will align its priorities with international developments, including COP12 outcomes. Relevant policy and legislative objectives will be reflected in both national and Trio programmes. The evolution of the Council’s legislative agenda through the Danish and Cypriot Presidencies will further shape Ireland’s engagement with COP12 priorities, ensuring the EU can respond effectively in areas where coordinated action is needed. Conclusion By prioritising ambitious action on the TPD and TTD, strengthening youth protection, enforcing Article 5.3, and supporting a modern public health architecture, Ireland can play a decisive role in shaping a healthier, future-oriented European Union during its 2026 Presidency.

The Irish Presidency can make a substantial positive impact across the EU by focusing on policies that protect people’s health, strengthen communities, and create fair economic conditions. Ireland’s track record in public health and tobacco control demonstrates how ambitious leadership can set standards that later become the norm across the EU. Healthier People and Communities By promoting prevention and health protection, the Presidency can reduce disease, improve wellbeing, and empower citizens to make healthier choices. Prioritising youth protection and chronic disease prevention ensures long-term benefits for families and communities while reducing pressure on health systems. Supporting businesses and fair markets Clear and harmonised EU policies provide certainty for businesses and encourage responsible innovation. Consistent standards on product safety, marketing, and taxation enable businesses—especially small and medium-sized enterprises—to operate on a level playing field while contributing to healthier societies. Reducing inequalities Policies targeting health disparities and protecting young people from harmful products strengthen social cohesion and community resilience. Integrating health, education, and social initiatives ensures benefits are widely and equitably shared across populations. Setting New Norms Across the EU The Irish Presidency can introduce ambitious, forward-looking policies that set new standards, which later become EU and global norms—an approach long proven in tobacco control. By showcasing what works and encouraging adoption across Member States, Ireland can leave a lasting legacy that benefits people, communities, and economies. Conclusion Through leadership that combines health protection, fairness, and equity, the Irish Presidency can deliver tangible improvements across the EU.

Communicating the benefits of EU membership during Ireland’s Presidency can be most effective by highlighting tangible achievements that citizens can relate to, showcasing Ireland’s leadership in Europe. Tobacco and nicotine control provides a clear example of national pride, where Ireland has consistently protected public health, especially for young people. Showcase Leadership and Results Ireland can highlight its role as a trailblazer in tobacco and nicotine control by sharing measurable results, such as reductions in youth smoking, strong smoke-free policies, and innovative measures addressing emerging nicotine products. Demonstrating these successes shows citizens how EU membership allows Ireland to influence policy across Europe. Link Policies to Everyday Benefits Communications should make clear how Ireland’s leadership in tobacco and nicotine control directly benefits citizens: healthier communities, reduced healthcare costs, and protection of young people. Showing concrete outcomes makes the EU’s impact visible and relevant. Engage Young People and Foster Ownership Youth-focused campaigns—through social media, storytelling, and participatory initiatives—can connect young people to the Presidency and show that EU-level decisions directly affect their wellbeing. Highlighting Ireland’s protective measures for youth builds civic engagement and pride. Strengthen Ireland’s International Profile By presenting its successes in tobacco and nicotine control as best practice, Ireland can position itself as a public health leader in Europe, boosting national pride and demonstrating how ambitious policies create tangible international recognition. Conclusion Focusing on Ireland’s achievements in tobacco and nicotine control, showing real benefits for citizens, and engaging young people will create a sense of ownership over the Presidency and illustrate how EU membership empowers Ireland to make a meaningful difference at home and across Europe.

We welcome the opportunity for collaboration and exchange of ideas during Ireland’s Presidency. In line with Article 5.3 on tobacco industry interference, the Presidency can set an example by ensuring that discussions and policy development remain independent of commercial interests, while providing space for civil society and expert voices to contribute evidence-based insights. Ireland’s leadership in tobacco and nicotine control provides a strong foundation to take the first steps toward ambitious, implementable policies. By encouraging exchange among Member States, civil society, and technical experts, the Presidency can accelerate progress, strengthen cooperation, and build consensus on measures that protect public health and young people. In summary, the Presidency is an opportunity to advance policy while safeguarding independence, champion collaboration, and take concrete steps toward meaningful change that benefits people, communities, and the EU as a whole.

organisation: National Society for Prevention of Cruelty to Animals (NSPCA)
response_text: This is a key opportunity for Ireland to champion high standards of animal welfare across the EU, particularly in areas such as live animal transport and on-farm welfare, while promoting evidence-based, science-led policies that reflect the One Health, One Welfare approach. Ireland should also advance sustainable agri-food systems that protect and promote biodiversity, enhance animal welfare, and contribute to reducing the country’s climate emissions. Ireland has embedded the One Health One Welfare approach across key policies, providing a strong foundation for its EU Council Presidency. The Animal Welfare Strategy 2021–2025 and 2026–2030 consultation materials, national Animal Health Surveillance and Biosecurity strategies, iNAP plans, and agri-food strategies like Food Vision all reflect this holistic approach, recognising the interdependence of human wellbeing, animal welfare, and environmental health. Through further expansion of the One Health One Welfare concept, Ireland has the opportunity to provide leadership in policy areas where citizens expect ambitious action by promoting coherent, humane and sustainable policy across animal welfare, public health, environmental protection, and food-system resilience. General Principles Ireland’s Presidency should prioritise animal welfare as a core element of sustainable and ethical EU agriculture. All animals deserve a life worth living, not merely freedom from suffering. Policy should aim to enable animals to express natural behaviours, enjoy social interactions, and experience physical and mental well-being. Legislation and initiatives should be science-based, transparent, and enforceable. The strategy should adopt a One Health, One Welfare approach, recognising interconnections between animal welfare, public health, and environmental sustainability. Transforming food and agriculture systems to meet climate and biodiversity targets. A resilient, sustainable and competitive Europe.

organisation: National Society for Prevention of Cruelty to Animals (NSPCA)
response_text: Advance the Revision of the EU Animal Transport Regulation The NSPCA supports ambitious EU-wide reforms to minimise suffering of animals during live transport. The revision of the Animal Transport Regulation remains a major pending legislative file which Ireland’s Presidency should prioritise progress on. Key Recommendations Support science-based limits on journey times, tailored to species-specific tolerance thresholds. Include time spent on sea transport and roll-on/roll-off vessel crossings within total journey times, recognising the well-documented welfare risks inherent to these types of journeys Limit journey durations for vulnerable animals (pigs, poultry and pregnant animals). Phase out the live transport of unweaned calves, as evidence shows that welfare risks for this vulnerable group cannot be effectively mitigated even with regulation. As an immediate transitional step, the minimum transport age should be raised, with a longer-term goal of ending their export entirely. Phase out the live export of farm animals to non-EU countries lacking enforceable welfare standards. Evidence shows such transport causes severe stress, injury, disease, and death. The focus should shift to more humane and sustainable trade, such as exporting meat or genetic material instead of live animals. Prioritise transport of meat and carcasses over the long-distance movement of live animals. Ensure enforceable welfare requirements during transit to include sufficient space, ventilation, food, water, rest, and ability to express natural behaviours. Prohibit the transport of animals in extreme temperatures, or require mandatory heating and cooling systems that go beyond simple ventilation, ensuring stable internal conditions compatible with animals’ thermal needs Stronger regulations to assess fitness for transport to ensure that animals unfit to travel are not transported. Veterinary oversight and strict enforcement are essential. Promote digital traceability, harmonised enforcement, and real-time journey monitoring across all Member States. Include GPS tracking, and inspection at departure, during transit, and on arrival. Require Member States to report transport statistics, inspections, and penalties for non-compliance. Strengthen competency requirements for transporters and official veterinarians. Provide financial and logistical assistance to implement higher standards without economic disadvantage. Progress the Revision of On-Farm Animal Welfare Legislation The European Commission has committed to revising multiple pieces of on-farm legislation (laying hens, broilers, pigs, dairy cattle, rabbits, fish and others). This supports the EC’s long-term ambition for sustainable food systems, climate resilience, and higher animal welfare as recognised under One Health, One Welfare. Ireland’s Presidency should support the revision of on-farm welfare rules to ensure animals are kept in conditions that promote their health and well-being. Key Recommendations Support a phased EU-wide transition away from cages for all farmed species including sow stalls, farrowing crates and barren cages. Strengthen species-specific welfare requirements for all farmed animals including aquatic animals, including space allowances, enrichment, no mutilations and outdoor access to enable animals to move freely and express natural behaviours. Regulate for mandatory welfare audits, veterinary inspections, and farm-specific welfare plans. Improve traceability and record-keeping through digital records integrated across EU databases linking welfare, health, and transport data. Incentives for higher welfare through EU funding for improved systems and welfare-friendly labelling schemes. Ensure welfare assessments are embedded within CAP strategic planning and environmental/climate funding instruments. Re-instate the mandate for EFSA animal welfare opinions on farmed aquatic animals and invertebrates. Promote sustainable aquaculture development including by applying the precautionary principle and attaching animal welfare criteria to the disbursement of EU funding for aquaculture and promoting low trophic species and practices.

organisation: National Society for Prevention of Cruelty to Animals (NSPCA)
response_text: Integrating Animal Welfare into Sustainable Agriculture & Climate Policy Ireland should ensure that animal welfare is treated as a core pillar of sustainable agriculture. Fully aligned with the Strategic Agenda’s emphasis on climate resilience, farm viability, and evidence-led transformation. Key Recommendations Promote CAP strategic planning that rewards higher-welfare, lower-emission farming systems. Advance EU-level metrics linking welfare, emissions, and antimicrobial reduction. Encourage Council discussions on transition pathways for farmers adopting high-welfare systems. Highlight animal welfare’s contribution to resilient food systems, biodiversity, and public trust in agriculture.

organisation: National Society for Prevention of Cruelty to Animals (NSPCA)
response_text: One practical approach is to showcase initiatives that connect EU policymaking to issues that resonate widely with the public. A flagship example would be hosting a Joint DAFM / NSPCA / Eurogroup for Animals EU Presidency Conference on Animal Welfare. Co-organised with key stakeholders, including Member States, scientists, NGOs, and industry representatives, this conference would place Ireland at the centre of EU policy discussions while highlighting the concrete ways EU membership supports societal values, environmental sustainability, and public health. The conference could focus on themes that link policy to citizens’ everyday concerns, including: Evidence-led One Health, One Welfare policymaking, showing how integrated approaches benefit both humans and animals Transitioning to high-welfare, sustainable production systems, demonstrating how EU standards support ethical, sustainable and environmentally responsible farming Welfare, climate resilience, biodiversity, and the future of EU farming, connecting EU policies to long-term sustainability Organised crime and illegal animal trade, highlighting the costs of inaction and the solutions achievable through coordinated EU action By actively involving the public, civil society, and media in these discussions, Ireland can illustrate the practical value of EU membership, show how decisions at the EU level affect national life, and foster a sense of shared ownership over its Presidency. Citizens gain insight into how Ireland’s leadership can shape EU-wide outcomes that improve wellbeing, uphold ethical standards, and protect the environment, reinforcing the tangible benefits of participation in the EU.

organisation: National Society for Prevention of Cruelty to Animals (NSPCA)
response_text: Summary Any Other Comments (please see accompanying doc for additional information) Summary of Any Other Comments - for its 2026 EU Presidency, Ireland should prioritise policy areas and legislative proposals that strengthen animal welfare and sustainable farming. Key focuses should include: Slaughter Regulation: Phasing out CO₂ stunning for pigs, promoting non-aversive alternatives, ensuring veterinary oversight, CCTV, and harmonised staff training. Illegal Trade: Implementing robust dog and cat traceability, fostering cross-border cooperation, and extending solutions to other species. EU-Mercosur Agreement: Opposing ratification of the EU-Mercosur trade deals, which would increase imports of animal products produced under lower welfare standards, undermining EU farmers and sustainability goals. Member States should withhold consent until EU welfare standards apply to imports and full democratic scrutiny is ensured. Through these actions, the Presidency can achieve tangible progress in humane, science-based, and sustainable EU policies that benefit animals, farmers, and society.

geography:
Only 7% of Irish SMEs export to the EU and Irish SME engagement in EU projects and opportunities is low, vis a vis our comparable geographies. This is something that can be addressed via the presidency (and in particular now that other export markets are proving tricky)
Let’s lean in to our EU membership and make competitiveness everybody’s priority.
response_text: Suggested Priority Theme: Competitiveness from the Ground Up – Building Europe’s Economic Strength Through SMEs Ireland’s Presidency should focus on renewing Europe’s competitiveness by deepening inclusion across the Single Market. The EU Strategic Agenda 2024–2029 emphasises a more competitive and resilient Europe and an economy that works for people and businesses of all sizes. Building on this, Ireland can champion an approach that strengthens competitiveness from the ground up, prioritising policies that help small and medium enterprises (SMEs) innovate, trade and grow. This aligns with the European Commission’s 2026 Work Programme priorities on implementing the SME Relief Package and Late Payment Regulation, embedding SME-friendly measures within the Green Deal Industrial Plan, and supporting digital transformation through the AI Act and Digital Europe Programme. SMEs represent over 99% of businesses and 66% of jobs across the EU. A competitiveness strategy that empowers SMEs supports cohesion, innovation diffusion, and public trust – building competitiveness from the ground up. This also supports community and regional initiatives – building economic viability across every part of the bloc.

geography:
Only 7% of Irish SMEs export to the EU and Irish SME engagement in EU projects and opportunities is low, vis a vis our comparable geographies. This is something that can be addressed via the presidency (and in particular now that other export markets are proving tricky)
Let’s lean in to our EU membership and make competitiveness everybody’s priority.
response_text: Ireland could prioritise progress in the following areas under relevant Council configurations: 1. Competitiveness Council (COMPET): - Implement the SME Relief Package and Late Payment Directive reform to improve liquidity and fairness in the Single Market. - Advance SME access provisions within the AI Act and related AI innovation ecosystem initiatives. - Promote measures under the Single Market Programme (2021–2027) that simplify EU funding access for smaller firms. 2. Economic and Financial Affairs Council (ECOFIN): - Support the Capital Markets Union agenda with an SME focus, including simplified cross-border finance. 3. Employment, Social Policy, Health and Consumer Affairs Council (EPSCO): - Advance Green Skills and Digital Skills Compacts, ensuring SMEs benefit from upskilling investments under ESF+ and Erasmus+. 4. Environment and Energy Councils (ENVI / TTE): - Implement the Net-Zero Industry Act and Critical Raw Materials Act inclusively, ensuring SMEs participate in green supply chains.

geography:
Only 7% of Irish SMEs export to the EU and Irish SME engagement in EU projects and opportunities is low, vis a vis our comparable geographies. This is something that can be addressed via the presidency (and in particular now that other export markets are proving tricky)
Let’s lean in to our EU membership and make competitiveness everybody’s priority.
response_text: Ireland can deliver visible impact by promoting practical inclusion in Europe’s competitiveness agenda, ensuring that the tools, standards, and investments developed in Brussels reach small businesses in every Member State. One deliverable could be a Presidency initiative called 'Think Blue: Bringing Europe Home to SMEs' – a partnership-driven awareness and access campaign that would: - Make EU programmes and Single Market opportunities accessible to small firms. (these are currently extremely complex and beyond the reach of the average SME) - Provide a unified digital gateway linking to EU supports and funding streams - Twin Irish and European regions to exchange skills and business practices. For Irish SMEs, this initiative would help them find partners, funding, and customers in Europe. For the EU, it would demonstrate that the Council Presidency can translate policy ambition into citizen-level benefit.

geography:
Only 7% of Irish SMEs export to the EU and Irish SME engagement in EU projects and opportunities is low, vis a vis our comparable geographies. This is something that can be addressed via the presidency (and in particular now that other export markets are proving tricky)
Let’s lean in to our EU membership and make competitiveness everybody’s priority.
response_text: Ireland can use its Presidency to connect citizens and small enterprises directly with Europe’s opportunities by: -Ireland’s missionaries were our first exporters. Why don’t we draw on that heritage and bring knowledge and understanding of the EU to smaller businesses? (not just the rules – the benefits) Organising local 'Europe Weeks' across all counties, co-hosted with Local Enterprise Offices and Chambers. - Promoting a 'Made in Europe, Made in Ireland' label to highlight joint EU–Irish projects. - Sharing success stories of SMEs benefiting from EU programmes. - Providing plain-language guides and online pathways to help small firms access EU supports. This will make the Presidency more visible and relatable, showcasing the tangible benefits of EU membership.

geography:
Only 7% of Irish SMEs export to the EU and Irish SME engagement in EU projects and opportunities is low, vis a vis our comparable geographies. This is something that can be addressed via the presidency (and in particular now that other export markets are proving tricky)
Let’s lean in to our EU membership and make competitiveness everybody’s priority.
response_text: Competitiveness from the Ground Up positions Ireland’s Presidency as a bridge between EU-level strategy and local economic reality. This can go some way to addressing a sense of imbalance and unfairness – complexity built into policy is tough to navigate. By focusing on SMEs, and simplification, Ireland can help the EU deliver on its goals of prosperity, fairness, and green transition. This approach aligns with the EU Strategic Agenda 2024–2029 and supports legislative priorities under COMPET, ECOFIN, and EPSCO configurations. Official Ireland also has to take a leaf from that book and make a commitment to reducing red tape and complexity from EU-originated regulation. It also leaves a tangible legacy: higher SME engagement with EU markets and programmes, showing that competitiveness can be built from the ground up.

Priority 1: Advance the Implementation of the EU Directive on Combating Violence Against Women Priority 2: Promote Cross-Border Protection and Recognition of Protection Orders Priority 3: Ensure Sustainable EU Funding for Domestic Abuse Services Priority 4: Strengthen EU Child Protection Measures in DSGBV Contexts Priority 5: Lead EU Action on Digital and Technology-Facilitated Abuse Priority 6: Promote Integration of DSGBV into Broader EU Agendas Domestic abuse must be recognised as a barrier to gender equality, workforce participation, health and wellbeing, social cohesion, and economic stability. Ireland’s Presidency should embed DSGBV considerations into EU policies including health, migration, justice, digital affairs, and economic planning.

Priority 1: Advance the Implementation of the EU Directive on Combating Violence Against Women - Full implementation of the Directive across all Member States. - Strong monitoring mechanisms to ensure compliance, especially in areas of minimum standards for support services, emergency barring orders, and survivor-centred justice. - Stable long‑term funding for DSGBV services to meet EU standards. Priority 2: Promote Cross-Border Protection and Recognition of Protection Orders - Strengthen recognition and enforcement of protection, safety, and barring orders in all Member States. - Create a fast‑track mechanism ensuring that survivors fleeing abuse can access safety, income, child protection supports, and legal remedies without delay. - Improve data‑sharing protocols between Member States while safeguarding privacy. Priority 3: Ensure Sustainable EU Funding for Domestic Abuse Services - Increased EU‑level funding streams dedicated to refuge services, outreach programmes, child support, and perpetrator interventions. - Funding models that recognise children as rights‑holders and victims in their own right. - Simplified funding access for small- and medium‑sized NGOs. Priority 4: Strengthen EU Child Protection Measures in DSGBV Contexts - EU‑wide minimum standards for specialist child support within refuge and community services. - Embedding trauma‑informed, child‑centred approaches across child protection systems. - Improved cooperation between domestic abuse services, schools, health systems, and social services. Priority 5: Lead EU Action on Digital and Technology-Facilitated Abuse - EU standards for response, investigation, and prosecution of digital coercive control, stalking, image‑based abuse, and GPS/IoT‑enabled tracking. - Regulation of emerging technologies that can be misused for harassment, control, or surveillance. - Support for frontline services in digital safety training. Priority 6: Promote Integration of DSGBV into Broader EU Agendas Domestic abuse must be recognised as a barrier to gender equality, workforce participation, health and wellbeing, social cohesion, and economic stability. Ireland’s Presidency should embed DSGBV considerations into EU policies including health, migration, justice, digital affairs, and economic planning.

Domestic abuse is not isolated—it affects families, communities, and economies. As a frontline service, Amber witnesses daily the escalation in severity of abuse, the rise in coercive control, increasing complexity of survivors’ needs, pressure on refuge capacity, and the need for coordinated multi‑agency responses. Ireland’s EU Council Presidency offers a critical opportunity to strengthen protection for survivors across Member States, drive EU‑wide consistency in DSGBV responses, embed child safeguarding at the centre of DSGBV policy, and advance equality and human rights. Amber Women’s Refuge CLG strongly encourages Ireland to place domestic, sexual, and gender‑based violence at the heart of its EU priorities and stands ready to support further consultation and dialogue.

organisation:
European Pain Federation EFIC

*Please note that although this submission is formally submitted via EFIC, it reflects a consultation process carried out jointly with the Irish Pain Society (IPS), Pain Alliance Europe (PAE), the Societal Impact of Pain (SIP) Platform, Chronic Pain Ireland (CPI), SIP Ireland, and several clinical and research pain centres and Universities across Ireland.
response_text: Ireland’s Presidency of the Council in 2026 offers an important opportunity to articulate a people-centred and future-oriented vision for the European Union. A phrase such as “A Healthier, Fairer, and More Resilient Europe” would align with the Strategic Agenda 2024–2029 and reflect Ireland’s commitment to equity, wellbeing, and innovation. Three broad thematic priorities could guide the Presidency’s policy focus. 1. Prevention and Improved Management of Chronic Health Conditions Promoting prevention and early intervention is essential to reducing avoidable disability, maintaining quality of life, supporting independent living, and mitigating long-term pressures on health and social systems. Chronic conditions such as chronic pain affect 1 in 5 adults in Europe – 1 in 3 people in Ireland (35% of all adults) – and is strongly associated with reduced quality of life, poorer mental health, and social isolation. In addition, the cost of chronic pain in Ireland is over €5 billion per year, almost 3% of GDP. A focus on primary prevention (avoiding preventable pain and injury) and secondary prevention (timely diagnosis, treatment, and rehabilitation) would support EU efforts on cancer, musculoskeletal conditions, workplace health and mental health. For Ireland, this aligns with national priorities to improve access, reduce waiting lists, and promote community-based care. Improving the management of chronic pain—through earlier diagnosis, multidisciplinary care, and evidence-based treatment pathways—can further reduce disability, and long-term economic impact on health and social systems. 2. Enhancing Europe’s Research and Innovation Capacity to Address High-Burden Societal Challenges Scientific research and innovation are central to the EU’s competitiveness and preparedness for future health and social needs. Strategic investment in health research helps address areas that impose a high burden on European citizens and economies. Health research also functions as a public good, delivering long-term societal value by improving prevention, treatment and system resilience. This aim is also very compatible with Ireland’s strong reputation in education and a knowledge-driven economy. Despite affecting more than 100 million Europeans, chronic pain remains under-researched compared with other major health challenges. The Pain Research Strategy (PRiSE) offers a coordinated roadmap for strengthening pain research across Europe, supporting innovation, informing clinical practice, and improving rehabilitation and treatment pathways. PRiSE illustrates how investment in under-researched areas generates advances across neuroscience, rehabilitation, mental health, digital health, and health-services research, delivering meaningful societal and economic returns. 3. Supporting Employment, Economic Participation, and Healthy Working Lives Across Europe Ensuring that individuals can participate in economic and social life is fundamental for the EU’s resilience. Chronic conditions like chronic pain – one of the leading contributors to absenteeism and reduced productivity—affect people’s ability to remain in or return to work. In Ireland, chronic pain has a substantial economic impact, with 12% of affected individuals unable to work or needing to reduce their working hours. Further, people with chronic pain are three times more likely to be unemployed. A Presidency theme centred on economic participation and healthy working lives would enhace inclusive employment policies, rehabilitation pathways, workplace wellbeing initiatives, while supporting social fairness, competitiveness, and digital transformation.

organisation:
European Pain Federation EFIC

*Please note that although this submission is formally submitted via EFIC, it reflects a consultation process carried out jointly with the Irish Pain Society (IPS), Pain Alliance Europe (PAE), the Societal Impact of Pain (SIP) Platform, Chronic Pain Ireland (CPI), SIP Ireland, and several clinical and research pain centres and Universities across Ireland.
response_text: 1. Prevention and Improved Management of Chronic Health Conditions Strengthening prevention and early intervention is essential to improving quality of life and reducing long-term pressures on health and social systems. Chronic conditions such as chronic pain—which affects 1 in 5 adults in Europe and 35% of all adults in Ireland—demonstrate the importance of both primary prevention (avoiding preventable pain and injury) and secondary prevention (timely diagnosis, adequate treatment, and rehabilitation). Improved management of chronic pain—through multidisciplinary care, accessible treatment pathways, and better integration of pain services into national health strategies—would reduce disability, enhance patient outcomes, and alleviate the burden on health and social systems across the EU. What Ireland could aim to achieve: Adoption of Council Conclusions on Primary and Secondary Prevention, promoting coordinated EU action on early diagnosis, rehabilitation, and chronic disease management. A Health Council Policy Debate on integrating prevention approaches into national health strategies, highlighting the wide social and economic impact of chronic conditions. These steps would reinforce existing EU priorities while advancing a coherent prevention agenda across Member States. 2. Strengthening EU Research and Innovation – Including a Coordinated Agenda for Pain Research The next Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF 2028–2034) will determine Europe’s research priorities for the coming decade. Ireland’s Presidency is well placed to contribute to early debates, especially regarding the alignment of research investments with high-burden societal challenges. Chronic pain remains one of the most prevalent health issues in Europe, yet historically has been significantly underfunded in EU programmes. Strengthening EU investment in health research is essential not only for advancing innovation but for addressing major challenges—such as non-communicable diseases and mental health—where research acts as a public good that provides long-term value for all Member States. What Ireland could aim to achieve: A Council Debate on Research Priorities for the Next MFF, emphasising the need to direct funding toward high-burden areas that have traditionally received limited investment—such as chronic pain. Approaches like PRiSE provide clear, evidence-based guidance on how coordinated EU action can close research gaps in prevention, diagnosis, rehabilitation, and innovative treatment pathways. Advancement of implementation discussions on the European Health Data Space, particularly regarding the adoption of internationally harmonised classification and coding systems—such as ICD-11—to improve the consistency, comparability, and clinical utility of health data. 3. Employment, Economic Participation, and Healthy Working Lives Promoting participation in the labour market is central to Europe’s economic and social sustainability. Chronic conditions—such as chronic pain, a leading contributor to absenteeism and reduced productivity—create barriers to employment. In Ireland, the PRIME Study shows that chronic pain substantially increases the likelihood of work disruption and depression – as high as 15% in the latter – highlighting the importance of rehabilitation and workplace supports. What Ireland could aim to achieve: Adoption of Council Conclusions on Healthy Working Lives, focusing on rehabilitation, return-to-work pathways, workplace wellbeing, and inclusive employment policies. A Joint EPSCO–Health Council Debate on the socioeconomic impact of chronic conditions and their relevance for labour-market participation.

organisation:
European Pain Federation EFIC

*Please note that although this submission is formally submitted via EFIC, it reflects a consultation process carried out jointly with the Irish Pain Society (IPS), Pain Alliance Europe (PAE), the Societal Impact of Pain (SIP) Platform, Chronic Pain Ireland (CPI), SIP Ireland, and several clinical and research pain centres and Universities across Ireland.
response_text: The work of the Council during the Irish Presidency can make a substantial positive impact across the EU by promoting a vision of Europe that prioritises wellbeing, resilience, and full participation in society. By encouraging cooperation on policies that help people stay healthy, active, and engaged—including strengthening prevention, rehabilitation, and early intervention—the Presidency can support individuals in maintaining quality of life and independence while reducing pressures on health and social systems. Facilitating progress on research and innovation, particularly in areas of high societal burden, will help generate new knowledge, technologies, and care pathways that benefit both communities and businesses by driving competitiveness and improving access to effective treatment and support. Advancing work on the European Health Data Space, including efforts toward harmonised classification and coding systems such as ICD-11, will improve the reliability and comparability of health information, enabling better clinical decisions, more efficient public planning, and stronger European research output. Finally, by supporting initiatives that help people remain in or return to employment—such as those addressing the challenges posed by chronic conditions, disability, and long-term health problems—the Presidency can contribute to fairer labour markets, stronger local economies, and more inclusive communities. Together, these efforts would help build a Europe where individuals, businesses, and societies can thrive, and where the benefits of progress are shared widely and sustainably across the Union.

organisation:
European Pain Federation EFIC

*Please note that although this submission is formally submitted via EFIC, it reflects a consultation process carried out jointly with the Irish Pain Society (IPS), Pain Alliance Europe (PAE), the Societal Impact of Pain (SIP) Platform, Chronic Pain Ireland (CPI), SIP Ireland, and several clinical and research pain centres and Universities across Ireland.
response_text: Communicating the values and benefits of EU membership is most effective when citizens can clearly see how European cooperation improves their everyday lives—particularly in areas that matter deeply to people’s wellbeing, security, and ability to participate fully in society. Highlighting EU initiatives that address real-life challenges, such as access to quality healthcare, research into under-prioritised conditions like chronic pain, support for people living with long-term illness or disability, workplace wellbeing, and protections for vulnerable groups, can make the EU’s role tangible and relatable. Ireland’s Presidency can foster a sense of ownership by showing how the EU helps ensure that no community faces these challenges alone: through shared investment in research, cross-border health cooperation, coordinated disease prevention, and policies that help individuals stay active in work and social life despite chronic conditions. Communicating honestly about the Presidency’s goals and progress, using clear language and real stories from patients, carers, healthcare professionals, and families, can build trust and strengthen citizens’ connection with the EU. Engaging civil-society organisations, patient groups, community networks, and those affected by chronic conditions provides citizens who often feel unheard with a meaningful role in shaping Ireland’s contribution to the Union’s agenda. By bringing these voices into the conversation—and by showing how EU membership enables practical improvements in health, wellbeing, inclusion, and economic participation—Ireland can create a Presidency that not only reflects European values but is recognised by citizens as directly relevant to their daily lives and future prospects.

organisation:
European Pain Federation EFIC

*Please note that although this submission is formally submitted via EFIC, it reflects a consultation process carried out jointly with the Irish Pain Society (IPS), Pain Alliance Europe (PAE), the Societal Impact of Pain (SIP) Platform, Chronic Pain Ireland (CPI), SIP Ireland, and several clinical and research pain centres and Universities across Ireland.
response_text: As supporting material to this submission, several documents are provided which may be of relevance to the Irish Presidency’s reflections on EU health, research, and prevention priorities. These documents illustrate areas where coordinated European action can generate substantial public-health and socioeconomic benefits. The SIP Book of Evidence on the Burden of Pain was created for individuals from a non-scientific background to gain an insight into what pain is, understand the different definitions used, and the debilitating effects pain has on patients and societies. he EFIC Pain Research Strategy (PRiSE) provides an evidence-based roadmap for strengthening pain research in Europe. It identifies major gaps in current funding, sets priority areas for investment, and recommends mechanisms to align research efforts with societal burden and clinical need. PRiSE highlights the importance of multidisciplinary work, better integration of basic and clinical science, and improved data infrastructure to support prevention, diagnosis, rehabilitation, and treatment. It also underscores that chronic pain—affecting 1 in 5 Europeans—remains significantly under-researched despite its wide impact on wellbeing, employment, and public expenditure. The SIP Position Paper on Preventive Healthcare for Chronic Pain sets out policy recommendations for strengthening both primary and secondary prevention. It highlights the need for early intervention, better access to rehabilitation, and integrated care pathways to reduce the transition from acute to chronic pain and support quality of life. The paper also places pain prevention within wider EU priorities—healthy ageing, mental health, musculoskeletal health, and workplace wellbeing—showing how coordinated prevention strategies can improve outcomes and reduce pressure on health and social systems. The SIP Position Paper on ICD-11 underscores the importance of adopting the WHO’s latest international classification system across EU Member States. It explains how ICD-11 enables clearer and more clinically relevant coding for chronic pain and other long-term conditions, supporting accurate data collection, improved health-system planning, cross-border comparability, and stronger research foundations. This is especially relevant to the European Health Data Space, which foresees harmonised international coding systems to enhance data quality and interoperability across the Union. These documents are offered as technical background to support the Irish Presidency’s reflections on its upcoming policy priorities. Sources: Access to treatment (2024) European Pain Federation. From Grundfos’ perspective as a global leader in advanced water and pump technologies, Ireland’s 2026 Presidency should frame Europe’s future through three interconnected themes: water resilience, industrial competitiveness, and resource efficiency. These respond directly to the EU Strategic Agenda 2024–2029 and reflect urgent challenges shared across Member States. A Water-Resilient, Climate-Adapted Europe Water scarcity, extreme weather, ageing infrastructure and rising industrial demand increasingly constrain Europe’s economic development. Ireland is well placed—reputable, practical and experiencing its own water-capacity pressures—to elevate water resilience as a core pillar of the EU agenda. Priorities should include delivering the Water Resilience Strategy, accelerating digitalisation of water systems, and promoting circular water use across municipalities and industry. This is foundational for climate adaptation, competitiveness and public health. Competitiveness Through Industrial Energy and Water Efficiency Europe cannot compete globally without reducing its structural input costs. Energy efficiency remains Europe’s “first fuel”, and industrial pumping systems alone account for a significant share of electricity use. Water systems are also major energy consumers for municipalities. Ireland can champion a Presidency theme centred on resource efficiency as an industrial strategy, encouraging deployment of high-efficiency technologies, digital monitoring systems, process optimisation and circular water models. This theme sits naturally between COMPET, ENVI and ECOFIN priorities. Modern, Digital Infrastructure for Europe’s Future Growth Europe faces pronounced under-investment in water infrastructure, with an estimated €23bn/year financing gap. Ireland’s own national agenda—housing expansion, industrial investment and infrastructure upgrades—mirrors this EU-wide challenge. A Presidency focus on modernisation and digitalisation of water and wastewater systems would enable improved resilience, lower operating costs, stronger environmental performance, and enhanced service reliability for citizens. Taken together, these themes frame Ireland’s Presidency as forward-looking, citizen-focused and competitiveness-driven, while fully aligned with the Union’s broader priorities. The Presidency can present water and energy efficiency not as environmental add-ons, but as strategic levers for Europe’s economic strength and climate resilience.

Implementation of the Water Resilience Strategy (WRS) Ireland should prioritise Council work that converts the WRS into clear, measurable, Union-wide actions. This includes: A detailed implementation roadmap with milestones. Embedding “Water Efficiency First” across relevant industrial, energy and digital policy files. Strengthening incentives for industrial water reuse, cascading water systems and digital water monitoring. Advancing common indicators for leakage reduction, digitalisation, reuse and operational performance in water utilities. Industrial Energy and Water Efficiency (COMPET/ENVI) To boost competitiveness, Ireland can advance measures that accelerate uptake of proven, highefficiency technologies: Progressing Ecodesign & Energy Labelling implementing acts affecting industrial equipment such as pumps and drives. Promoting work to be undertaken to mainstream industrial water reuse as part of the industrial competitiveness agenda Encouraging Member States—via EED implementation—to prioritise industrial system-level retrofits for energy savings. • Supporting GBER enhancements to unlock state aid for industrial water and energy efficiency, particularly for SMEs. Digital Water Infrastructure (TTE/ENVI) Ireland can promote harmonised EU approaches that modernise water systems through innovation and digital tools. Key objectives: Standards for data interoperability across water networks. Support for digital twins, smart pumps, and AI-driven process optimisation. Cross-border demonstration projects that showcase efficiency and resilience gains. Financing Water and Energy Resilience (ECOFIN) Ireland can help shift EU funding toward outcome-based models that reward measurable efficiency and resilience improvements. This includes: Better alignment of Cohesion Funds, Horizon instruments and the Strategic Technologies platforms with water-resilience needs Simplifying and scaling access to EU funding for municipalities pursuing digital and efficiency upgrades. Infrastructure for Housing and Industrial Growth (GAC/ENVI) Ireland can facilitate discussions on integrating resource-efficient water and energy planning into industrial permitting, territorial development and urban planning frameworks.

Reducing Costs for Households and Industry Energy and water efficiency directly lower bills for citizens and operational costs for businesses. Highefficiency pump systems, digital monitoring and leak reduction deliver 20–50% energy savings in many applications. These are fast, tangible results that strengthen household finances and Europe’s competitiveness. Strengthening Climate Adaptation and Public Protection Smart water infrastructure reduces leakage, improves stormwater management and enhances preparedness for floods and droughts. This protects homes, agriculture, and essential public services— delivering societal security as climate risks increase. Enabling Industrial Growth and Job Creation Water availability and energy efficiency are now decisive factors for investment in sectors such as pharma, semiconductors, data centres and manufacturing. By promoting resilient infrastructure and efficient processes, the Council can help Member States attract high-value investment, supporting longterm employment and regional development. Enhancing Trust in Public Infrastructure Digitalisation improves transparency, reporting and asset management in water utilities. Citizens experience fewer service disruptions, while municipalities gain tools to prioritise investments based on real-time performance. Stronger public trust is an important outcome of modern infrastructure aligned with EU objectives. In short, by focusing on resilience and efficiency, Ireland can lead Council work that delivers visible, everyday benefits while building Europe’s long-term economic foundations.

geography: National and, as a part of Euronext, EU wide (with the operation of 8 securities markets across Europe).
response_text: Enhancing the competitiveness of EU markets – The Presidency should continue the current work of the Council to reinforce and drive forward measures to enhance EU competitiveness, e.g. accelerating the implementation of the EU legislative simplification agenda to enhance the attractiveness and accessibility of EU markets, and the integration of EU capital markets for the benefit of EU companies and investors. Accelerating the integration of EU capital markets – The Presidency should accelerate progress on legislative measures under the Savings and Investment Union with a view to making EU capital markets work better for EU businesses, EU citizens, delivering economic growth and enhancing the competitiveness of the EU.

geography: National and, as a part of Euronext, EU wide (with the operation of 8 securities markets across Europe).
response_text: Savings and Investment Union The Savings and Investment Union and related legislative proposals should be a key priority for the Irish Presidency of the Council in 2026. Its stated aim is to create better financial opportunities for EU citizens, while enhancing our financial system’s capability to connect savings with productive investments. This will lead to more choice for citizens who wish to grow their household wealth and allow businesses across Europe to grow and scale in Europe, while at the same time enhancing European competitiveness. There are a number of important proposals that the Irish Presidency should progress including: Market Integration Package – Fragmented capital markets, regulatory divergence, and limited crossborder scale continue to act as barriers to growth. The result is a persistent gap between Europe’s economic potential and its actual performance. We believe that a more integrated, transparent, and efficient capital market is imperative and therefore work to progress this Market Integration Package is essential, with the potential ambition of reaching Council General Approach or further progressing the relevant files depending on level of progress made in negotiations during the first half of 2026. Securitisation Framework – The European Commission’s proposal to revise the securitisation framework should also be finalised (if still on the table). This aims to balance the need to foster issuance, investment and growth, with maintaining financial stability and could help revitalise the European securitisation market in order to enhance the resilience and competitiveness of the EU financial system.

geography: National and, as a part of Euronext, EU wide (with the operation of 8 securities markets across Europe).
response_text: By making meaningful progress on SIU legislative proposals, the work of the Council can drive forward an agenda of making EU capital markets better deliver for EU companies, capital markets participants and EU citizens / households, thereby enhancing economic development and cooperation in the EU and leading to enhanced EU competitiveness. People, businesses and communities need to see tangible progress being made on initiatives that will help create a better future for themselves and generations to follow. As part of this, the Presidency should continue the current work of the Council and focus on the simplification agenda and the need for more streamlined EU legislation that achieves its regulatory outcomes in a less cumbersome and costly way for market participants.

geography: National and, as a part of Euronext, EU wide (with the operation of 8 securities markets across Europe).
response_text: Promote via an advertising campaign the benefits that EU membership has delivered and continues to deliver for Ireland. Outline how the SIU can lead to better integrated EU capital markets to better support EU companies, EU citizens and European economic growth and competitiveness. Webcast certain EU Presidency events so that citizens have the opportunity to engage with activity connected to the Presidency. Articulate and promote a clear plan of priority areas and deliverables for the Irish Presidency, update on progress and develop a sense of pride in achieving major milestones, i.e. showcase what Europe can deliver for its citizens and that at the end of 2026 Europe is in a better place and its future looks brighter as a result of the progress made during the Irish Presidency.

geography: National and, as a part of Euronext, EU wide (with the operation of 8 securities markets across Europe).

response_text: Artificial Intelligence There are 3 key reasons why AI should be one of the high-level thematic priorities for Ireland’s EU presidency. To maintain the EU’s economic competitiveness AI has become a core technology in driving productivity, innovation and creativity in high-value industries. Ireland should insure it is at the heart of this development. Cement Ireland’s position as a key digital and tech hub With 16 of the top 20 global technology companies having bases in Ireland, we have both the strategic and technological knowledge to hand to enable significant movement on AI which would send a strong message to the global digital and technology companies about Ireland as a location of choice. Position Ireland as a Global Leader in “trusted AI” Establish opportunities or the provision of a structured, real-world testing environment for AI Platforms to train models using properly licensed content while demonstrating legal compliance in a transparent and auditable way. Given the strong regulatory framework and structures which exist in Ireland and considering the industries that are based here including pharma and technology, the opportunity to position Ireland as the trusted AI leader to guide the EU through the next phase of responsible, human-centered AI development and ultimately implementation is one that should be grasped. This would also be helpful to examine how to ensure that AI does not interfere with the democratic process in terms of elections and pre-election campaigning Culture As part of the Danish Presidency of the EU, culture and media were chosen as key focus with a specific view of protection democracies from disinformation and interference. Ireland should build on the work started by Denmark in continuing to strengthen and develop cultural importance in Europe. With such a strong culture Ireland is well placed to shine a spotlight on culture during its Presidency. Specifically focusing on music as this is IMRO’s area of expertise, Ireland has a unique position in the international music scene with many Irish artists performing worldwide. Music and culture are under threat with many challenges facing performers and artists including funding, AI, infrastructure to name but a few. The Irish Presidency offers an opportunity to shine a spotlight on culture, increase public interest and engagement in cultural activities and ensure the next generation has the exposure to all aspects of our culture and the prospect of becoming more culturally involved.

The Irish Presidency of the Council in 2026 should prioritise several key policy areas and legislative proposals, drawing on Ireland’s strengths and the current challenges facing the EU: Trusted Artificial Intelligence (AI): Legislative proposals should support the introduction of AI Sandbox to allow for real-world testing environments for AI platforms to ensure AI models are trained with properly licensed content and in full compliance with legal and regulatory standards. The introduction of a Sandbox would allow for the building of trusted infrastructure for training AI on licensed and traceable content. It would ensure that rights holders across specific industries retain control, receive attribution and are compensated when their work is used in AI systems. It would also position Ireland as a market leader in the development of open-source AI systems while allowing partnerships to enable transparent and verifiable rights management as open source allows public verification of software code, without exposing privet or licensed data. Ireland should ensure the inclusion of several important principles into actionable measures including the creation of a functioning music licensing market for AI, the application of EU copyright laws to all GenAI providers operating in the EU and transparency across the AI value chain. Embedding Copyright Protection in a competitive and secure Europe Continuing the Danish Presidency’s theme of competitiveness, the Irish Presidency should emphasise that a strong copyright framework is a vital enabler of the Single Market for creative content, cultural assets and digital services. It should underscore that protecting creators’ rights is not a regulatory burden but an investment in Europe’s creative economy, cultural diversity and global competitiveness. Council Conclusions Stakeholder dialogues between Member States’ Ministries, the Commission, creative sectors especially those based in Ireland, academics and technology platforms should be arranged. The focus of these dialogues should be the importance of the three-step test, transparency obligations for AI platforms handling creative works; and a roadmap for how the creative industries will engage in forthcoming AI‐and‐copyright policy processes. With a view to achieving a position by the end of the Presidency, the ultimate aim should be the creation of a functional licensing market in which the European innovation and creative sector can grow hand in hand. Culture and Media Development CDSM Review The conclusions of the review and evaluation being carried out on the Copyright in the Digital Single Market (CDSM) directive will be concluding as the Irish Presidency term is beginning. The results of this review will determine whether the CDSM Directive is achieving its aim of balancing creators rights with user access, whether the rules of online content are sufficient and whether fair remuneration for authors is being achieved. Ireland was one of the first countries to implement the Directive adapting our copyright laws to align with the directive. The Irish Presidency should continue to be leaders in this area and actively address recommendations from the Review. Buy-outs Online audiovisual services are increasingly using buy-outs whereby a one-off payment is given to music creators in exchange for their rights for music used in television programmes and film. With the continued growth of platforms such as Netflix, Disney and Amazon this practise will only increase with the bargaining power of creators diminishing as the power of the platforms grows. The “Principle of appropriate and proportionate remuneration” as set out in Article 18 of the CDSM Directive offers an opportunity to address this issue to the benefit of creators for the exploitation of their works. This principle should be made a mandatory rule applying to all copyright contracts, whether they are national, European or international. Such a move would eliminate a reliance on the laws of a third country to impose contractual provisions that deprive creators from claiming or using already existing mechanism to ensure fair remuneration of the use of their works. The impact of this change would be immediately felt by music creators in all corners of Europe and would be a lasting legacy of the Irish Presidency. Music Streaming Media regulation is an accepted and necessary part of our daily lives, whether devised and implemented at EU or national level it ensures fairness, impartiality and balance in the media we consume. Streaming services are the outlier as there are no regulations pertaining to their activities. With the review of the Audio-Visual Media Services Directive (AVMSD) there is an opportunity to conduct a root and branch examination of music streaming services – the algorithms, the use and presentation of AI generated works, the prominence given to EU or national artists. Regulation in this area would serve EU citizens well as it would introduce fairness and transparency to music streaming which is the number one method by which Europeans access music. Free access to cultural events throughout the country through the circulation of Culture Cards or Ireland EU Presidency Cards sent to every house in the country would not only create awareness of Ireland’s EU presidency but also focus the nation’s attention on the cultural activities in their area. It would encourage people to attend events reducing technostress through offline engagement and creating tech-free times on a regular basis over the 6 months of the Presidency. This in turn could create an offline habit which would live on long after the Presidency has moved to other countries.

People, businesses and communities throughout Ireland are reflective of their counterparts throughout Europe. While we might be living in different countries and speaking different languages we are all experiencing the same problems, the same issues and the same difficulties. Ireland could make the most of its Presidency through a focus on areas which impact the lives of people, business and communities in Ireland and throughout the wider European region. Media, culture and music are central to the lives of every European regardless of age, interest, language or country. There isn’t one person who is not using or exposed to some form or culture or music on a daily basis. Roundtable discussions, dialogues and conferences involving key stakeholders, community leaders, business owners and operators to allow for a sharing of problems and exploration of solutions would present opportunities to propose better operations for the culture and music uses of EU citizens. This would also have the knock-on effect of creating networks and relationships which will live longer and provide deeper benefits to EU citizens than the term of the Irish Presidency

Ensure maximum exposure for Irish culture throughout the tenure of the Irish presidency. The Presidency provides an opportunity for Ireland to showcase itself to our European neighbours during the 6 months of the presidency. This is not solely related to the politicians travelling but also includes media, visiting dignitaries, industry groups and representative organisations. With numerous events, meetings, gatherings, conferences, dinners etc being organised, the Irish Presidency should grasp the opportunity to share the very best of Irish music, song and dance by including performances from Irish artists at every available opportunity. This could provide a springboard for many artists to bring their performances to other countries and gain exposure for their craft. It would also ensure that the events organised by the Irish Presidency would be very strongly linked with Ireland, very unique, engaging and special. There is no other country in the world who’s music, song and dance is as universally enjoyed and as sought out as Ireland’s and when we have an opportunity to showcase it, we should!

IMRO is excited at the prospect of Ireland’s Presidency of the EU and the potential for the sustained sharing of Irish music creativity and performing talent to a wide EU audience. We are more than happy to get involved in the planning and execution of the Presidency and would welcome the opportunity to make this Presidency a successful, wide reaching and beneficial term to Irish and European citizens IMRO is an active member of GESAC, the European umbrella for Collective Management Organisations with IMRO CEO Victor Finn currently holding the position of GESAC Vice-President. GESAC is very involved in all of the EU Presidencies to ensure that copyright and cultural issues are to the fore and that there is positive progression with each term. Their input, knowledge and expertise is also available to the Irish Presidency. Separately, there are both Copyright and Cultural conferences organised as a staple of the EU Presidencies and IMRO and by extension GESAC are well placed and more than willing to get involved in the organisation of any aspect of these conferences. This could be in the form of topics, speakers, logistics or other

1 in 2 people will get cancer in their lifetime. 44,000 people get a cancer diagnosis in Ireland each year. By 2045, twice as many people will have a cancer diagnosis compared to 2015. Cancer is the leading cause of death in Ireland with 10,000 deaths registered in 2024. That said, 2 in 3 people survive their cancer diagnosis and 220,000+ people are living beyond cancer in Ireland, each one deserving to live well after cancer. Ireland’s National Cancer Strategy is due to expire in 2026, and preparations should soon be made to develop a new strategic plan. The Irish Cancer Society recommends that a key high-level thematic priority of Ireland’s Presidency would be the European Health Union, with a focus on cancer care. It is imperative that health retains the strategic focus of the European Union into the future with dedicated funding instruments (e.g. EU4Health). In particular, cancer has been a cross-cutting theme of the EU4Health programme and it is imperative that there is an opportunity for cancer and other health/healthcare matters to be prioritised by the European Union. In the upcoming Multiannual Financial Framework from 2028-2034, we are concerned that positioning health alongside other competing areas runs the risk that there will be inadequate funding for vital programmes, collaborations and cross-cutting themes like cancer. Under the thematic priority of a European Health Union, Ireland can highlight its progress in enhancing cancer outcomes in recent decades, the long-term results of strategic initiatives (e.g. smoking ban) and Ireland can also speak to how we will build on progress in the coming years. Ireland can take this opportunity to showcase our commitment to cancer care and share lessons with our EU counterparts including on: the upcoming legislation on the Right to be Forgotten after Cancer (via the Central Bank Amendment Bill 2025), for people seeking access to financial products and services. the 2024 law to protect maternity leave for new mothers while they are in treatment for serious illness like cancer (Leave our Leave legislation). Furthermore, Ireland has an opportunity to further advance outcomes along the cancer care pathway and demonstrate leadership in the following areas amongst its EU peers, including (inter alia): prevention initiatives such as: o implementing a HPV vaccination catch-up programme for young people aged 24 and younger. finalising (future-proofed) legislation on the regulation of novel nicotine inhaling products. banning sunbed use expanding existing screening and introducing new screening in line with EU Council recommendations. securing fast access to medicines for people who need them progressing the digital transformation in healthcare, which would support health data and personal access to one’s own electronic health records.

The European Union must bring specific focus back to health, and with cross-cutting focus on cancer. The Irish Presidency presents such an opportunity by adopting a European Health Union as a thematic priority. Ireland’s Presidency is an opportunity to: dedicate a Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) 2028–2034 programme for Health harmonise strong tobacco control policies (e.g. via the revision of the Tobacco Taxation Directive and Tobacco Products Directive) make the case for alcohol policies as a cancer control measure (e.g. health warnings on labels across Europe, ingredients list on alcohol beverages) drawing upon Ireland’s experience with the Public Health (Alcohol) Act 2018 and its plans for its full implementation. include cancer in the EU Gender Equality Strategy and other frameworks.

During the tenure of the Irish EU Council Presidency, the Government must include a High-Level event on Cancer in the Presidency Programme. Such an activity would give prominence to: the lived experience of being diagnosed with cancer. the impact of dedicated EU funding streams focusing on health, and on cancer. Ireland’s efforts to improve cancer prevention, testing, treatment and outcomes. Ireland’s ambition for further enhancing cancer outcomes in the next Irish National Cancer Strategy. The need to support people live well with and after cancer.

It is important for people to not only know that EU funding has been granted for projects, but to understand in real terms what it means for them and their loved ones. As such, the Government should highlight key initiatives of the European Union such as Europe’s Beating Cancer Plan, EU4Health and what this means for public policy and the residents of Ireland with regard to their health. Ireland can also highlight and provide examples of how EU funding has been used to further our health and cancer care interests. For instance, we have benefitted from €3.6 million in EU funding for investment in digital health infrastructure (relevant to the European Health Data Space). Communicating in real terms what was achieved with this funding can support residents of Ireland to understand the work that the Government will continue to do to progress our digital health infrastructure.

Climate Action and Sustainable Development – Given the European Commission’s recent moves to dismantle environmental and human rights standards, Ireland’s focus on climate change and sustainable development can serve as a counterweight, to recentre the priorities of the Union back towards its targets both under the Paris Agreement and the Sustainable Development Goals. This is particularly pertinent given Irelands key role in the original negotiation of the SDGs and the importance of accelerated action nationally, at EU level and internationally as we enter the final years towards the 2030 target of these goals. Peacebuilding – As 2024 has been the most violent year on record since the end of the Cold War, Ireland must utilize our unique perspective and experience in the work of peace from our own peace process, and our experience in the disarmament space such as the Convention on Cluster Munitions and the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty. Ireland should share our experience and expertise in these areas with our European colleagues and lead an active policy platform on peacebuilding. International Development – ODA has seen a drop of up 17% of its funding in 2025, following a 9% drop in 2024, with large funders such as the USA and UK dramatically slashing contributions to ODA. In this time, Ireland has increased its ODA spending and has continued to focus on the positive outcomes and contributions we can make to global safety and prosperity through ODA. Ireland should take its continued commitment to ODA into its policy agenda for the EU Presidency and refocus the conversation on the overwhelming public good achieved by ODA on every level on a global scale. Multilateralism and the Protection of International Law – As a multilateral organisation, the European Union has shown the value of cooperation amongst states in achieving social, economic and political goals through cooperation across states. The upholding of international law and the rules of how we engage with one another is central to what allows states to work together effectively for common good. As multilateralism is under threat and we have seen a consistent undermining on international law, it is now vital for us to uphold and protect the validity of international law and global system.

Social Cohesion Funding – The EU’s various social cohesion funding streams such as the Just Transition Fund and Regional Development Fund, which have supported the work of peace and cooperation in local communities across the Union. Especially given moves under the SAFE regulation, a component of ReArm Europe, which seeks to divert funding away from social cohesion, towards the development of military infrastructure and arms manufacturing capacity. This goes against the founding statement of the Union, where in Schuman Declaration it states, "The pooling of coal and steel production... will change the destinies of those regions which have long been devoted to the manufacture of munitions of war, of which they have been the most constant victims”. These moves are at odds with the founding vision of the union and can only lead to increased conflict. The European Green Deal – Ireland must prioritise the EU’s commitments under the European Green Deal and cut emissions by at least 50% by 2030 and net zero by 2050. These targets are becoming increasingly unlikely to be met by both Ireland individually and the Union as a whole, and this is simply not good enough. The looming climate catastrophe is the responsibility of us all, and we must continue to press forward with radical proposals which will allow us to reach these targets and create a safer, more sustainable and prosperous Europe. Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive and the Corporate Sustainability Due-Diligence Directive – The recent rollbacks on these vital regulatory directives have placed the European Union at a crossroads, of what exactly will be the priorities for the Union with regards to how it expects corporations to engage with both climate policies and human rights and ethical standards in business practice. Ireland must shift the narrative back to supporting these hard-won pieces of vital legislation which hold large corporations to account for their actions and their effects on the climate as well as the people and communities contributing to each part of the supply chain.

Over the years citizens and communities have contributed to, and benefited from, the development of higher standards in many areas’ of policy such as the environment, equality, and employment standards. It is vital that this aspect of the EU is emphasized, with people and communities being placed at the centre of the work of the council. There is a perception that the priorities of business has overtaken the priorities of people and communities.
