The rollback in rights and regulations which communities and citizens have engaged with as corporate lobbying is centre stage, is bad for public confidence in and engagement with the EU. Having a strong focus on issues like sustainable development and climate which matter to citizens and communities as well as universal rights and international law will give the public a greater confidence in the direction of the Union. Proactive engagement by all Departments with the new bodies such as the new EU Scrutiny Committee on how EU directives are being transposed would send a positive message to the public on Irelands commitment to accountability and engagement within the EU. Ireland showing genuine leadership in human rights international law and the issue of Palestine would be positive for Ireland as well as public confidence in the role Ireland is playing at a European level.

It is an imperative that the Council allow for constructive engagement by citizens with decision making, promoting positive public engagement and having different thoughts and perspectives on the direction Europe might take. There must be room for nuanced discussion and debate and not a narrative focus purely on business or security but communicating effectively the role Europe can play in raising rights and standards not just in Europe but globally.

organisation: Food Allergy Centre Padua University Hospital  Padua Italy
response_text: Taking into account the current geopolitical and socioeconomic context in Europe, we recommend that Ireland prioritise Health Protection, Citizen Safety, and Resilient Societies as core themes of its 2026 Presidency. Serious allergies and anaphylaxis are rising across Europe and place a growing burden on individuals, schools, workplaces, and public services. Addressing them fits naturally within broader objectives to protect citizens’ wellbeing and reduce preventable health risks. . A R e s i l i e n t an d P r e p a r e d E u r o p e The EU must be equipped to respond to emergencies—whether acute health events, natural disasters, or public safety threats. This requires harmonised emergency response systems, stronger community level preparedness, and cross-border cooperation. Ireland is one of the few Member States that has taken concrete steps to improve preparedness for serious allergic reactions, including allowing pharmacists to supply emergency medicines without a prescription during anaphylactic events. This national practice demonstrates effective emergency readiness and provides a model for EU-level policy coordination, which could inform upcoming initiatives under the European Health Union framework aimed at strengthening preparedness, prevention, and rapid response across Member States. . A P e o p l e -C e n t r e d U n i o n t h a t P r o t e c t s Embedding people-centred principles into EU policymaking ensures that vulnerable populations and individuals at risk of medical emergencies are not left behind. The Presidency could advance reducing health inequalities across the EU, highlighting uneven access to diagnosis, specialist care, and emergency response protocols. Positioning timely care for serious allergies and anaphylaxis within this agenda demonstrates a commitment to practical, measurable improvements in patient safety and inclusion, while protecting citizens’ rights to safety in everyday environments such as schools, childcare centres, workplaces, and public venues. 3 . A F u t u r e -O r i e n t e d E u r o p e B u i l t o n I n n o v a t i o n a n d C o l l a b o r a t i o n Ireland’s strong reputation in digital innovation offers an opportunity to promote Digital Innovation for Health, leveraging the European Health Data Space and interoperable, patient-centred tools. For individuals at risk of serious allergic reactions, seamless access to medical information across borders can prevent emergencies and support the free movement of people. The Presidency can also prioritise harmonised awareness-raising, institutional readiness, and capacity building, ensuring schools, businesses, and public institutions are equipped and trained to respond effectively to lifethreatening health incidents.

organisation: Food Allergy Centre Padua University Hospital  Padua Italy
response_text: Ireland could use its Presidency to champion health resilience, citizen protection, and emergency preparedness, leveraging its national leadership in anaphylaxis response as a model for EU coordination. Key priorities include: Health Protection and Emergency Preparedness Serious allergies and anaphylaxis present a growing public-health challenge. The Presidency could: •Promote timely access to emergency medicines, building on Ireland’s approach where pharmacists can supply life-saving treatment without prescription. •Encourage harmonised school and public-venue preparedness, using Ireland as an example. Relevant upcoming EU initiative: •Global health resilience initiative (non-legislative, Q2 2026) – to strengthen EU capacity for rapid response to health crises. Digital Innovation for Health Cross-border emergencies require seamless access to patient data: Promote the European Health Data Space for secure, interoperable sharing of health information, enabling faster response to anaphylactic events across borders. Support digital tools for citizen-centred care, enhancing emergency response and patient safety. 3. Reducing Health Inequalities and Strengthening Citizen Rights The Presidency could advance equitable access to emergency care and citizen-centred policy: Link preparedness to strengthening the Child Guarantee (non-legislative, Q2 2026) and Citizens omnibus (legislative, Q4 2026), ensuring children in schools, childcare centres, and communities are protected and have their rights effectively enforced. Promote intergenerational fairness through the Intergenerational fairness strategy (non legislative, Q1 2026), ensuring emergency preparedness and health access benefit current and future generations equally. Highlight Ireland’s model as a practical, replicable approach for other Member States. Objectives Establish a model for EU-level anaphylaxis and emergency response coordination, based on best practices of Ireland. Ensure equitable access to life-saving treatments across the EU. Promote digital innovation for preparedness, information sharing, and cross-border patient care. Strengthen citizen rights and intergenerational fairness, ensuring public health policies reflect social equity. Position health resilience as a pillar of EU citizen safety and social cohesion, demonstrating tangible improvements in public health readiness. By focusing on these targeted initiatives, Ireland can use its Presidency to deliver practical, measurable impacts on citizen safety, health equity, and cross-border emergency preparedness while reinforcing the EU’s social and legal frameworks.

organisation: Food Allergy Centre Padua University Hospital  Padua Italy
response_text: The Irish Presidency has the potential to deliver significant, tangible impact for EU citizens by advancing health resilience and consumer safety. For individuals with serious allergies, policies that improve emergency response, access to medicines, and accurate allergen information can be lifesaving. For people, expanded access to emergency treatment, including pharmacy-enabled emergency supply across the EU, enhances safety in daily life. Citizens with serious allergies would be better protected in schools, workplaces, sports facilities, cultural venues, and during cross-border travel. For businesses, harmonised allergen-labelling and staff-training expectations reduce regulatory uncertainty, simplify compliance, and improve consumer trust by fostering safer public environments. For communities and institutions, EU-supported readiness measures ,such as common school protocols, public-venue guidelines, and accessible training ,would significantly reduce preventable emergencies, supporting all three Alliance objectives. Replicating Ireland’s best practice on emergency medicine access would ensure that life-saving intervention is available regardless of where a reaction occurs, reducing inequalities across Member States.

organisation: Food Allergy Centre Padua University Hospital  Padua Italy
response_text: Ireland has a strong opportunity to communicate the value of EU membership by focusing on everyday benefits and practical improvements that resonate directly with citizens. The 2026 Presidency can show how EU cooperation protects people, strengthens communities, and makes daily life safer—particularly in areas such as emergency preparedness for serious allergies and anaphylaxis. Highlight Practical Examples of EU Solidarity Citizens understand the EU best when they see clear, relatable outcomes. Ireland can communicate EU values by highlighting how cooperation improves safety and wellbeing, for example: Safer environments in schools, restaurants, transport and public venues. Shared health information that makes travel within the EU safer and more predictable. • Harmonised allergen-labelling rules that protect consumers wherever they are. • More consistent access to emergency support for serious allergic reactions. Ireland’s own approach—allowing pharmacists to supply emergency treatment during a serious allergic reaction—provides a concrete example of national leadership that improves citizen safety. Propose Council Recommendations on Emergency Readiness To strengthen public understanding of the EU’s benefits, Ireland could lead on a visible, citizencentred initiative: Develop Council Recommendations on broader readiness and access to emergency treatment for serious allergy and anaphylaxis. This would help encourage Member States to: Improve preparedness in schools, public venues, workplaces, and transport hubs. • Ensure trained responders are available across community settings. Reduce inequalities in access to time-sensitive, life-saving care. Such an initiative is easy for citizens to relate to, directly improves safety, and demonstrates EU cooperation delivers real, practical benefits for families, children, workers, and communities. This people-centred framing will strengthen public trust, build ownership, and demonstrate the concrete value of Ireland’s leadership at EU level.

geography: I was born and raised in a rural farming community but currently live and work in an urban area.
response_text: Empowering Citizens, Restoring Nature, Strengthening Europe: Ireland’s Presidency Priorities for 2026 Ireland’s 2026 Presidency presents a strategic opportunity to advance a European Union that delivers meaningful social, environmental, and democratic benefits for all citizens. Ireland should prioritise a coherent set of themes centred on social justice, environmental stewardship, intergenerational responsibility, and strategic autonomy. A primary priority should be the eradication of poverty and homelessness across the Union. Ireland should work to strengthen the implementation of the European Pillar of Social Rights by advancing measures on adequate minimum income, fair working conditions, and stronger protections for those in precarious or low-paid employment. Particular emphasis should be placed on elevating housing as a core social right and ensuring that EU funding instruments—especially cohesion policy and the Social Climate Fund—target vulnerable communities and support a just transition to a sustainable economy. Ireland should also promote a more citizen-centred Union, ensuring that EU policymaking is transparent, accountable, and oriented towards the well-being of ordinary people rather than narrow corporate or institutional interests. Priority areas include enhancing consumer and digital rights, strengthening EU frameworks for civic participation, and improving access to high-quality public services such as healthcare, education, and public transport. The Presidency should support Member States in exploring free or low-cost public transport as an equitable climate and mobility measure. A dedicated priority should focus on long-term, intergenerational policymaking. Ireland should seek to embed an EU-wide requirement for “Future Generations Impact Assessments” for major legislative proposals and funding decisions. These assessments would examine implications for climate stability, biodiversity, resource use, social equality, and fiscal sustainability, ensuring that today’s decisions do not compromise the rights and opportunities of future Europeans. Environmental protection and restoration should form another core theme. Ireland is well placed to lead on biodiversity recovery, rewilding, and the expansion of protected areas, including both terrestrial and marine national parks. The Presidency should support the implementation of the Nature Restoration Law, promote EU-wide rewilding frameworks, and encourage nature-positive land-use transitions, with appropriate support for farmers and coastal communities. These measures should be linked to broader climate resilience, clean energy, and circular-economy objectives. Finally, Ireland should advance a vision of European strategic autonomy grounded in peace, diplomacy, and civilian resilience. Consistent with Ireland’s long-standing policy of military neutrality, the Presidency should prioritise strengthening the EU’s independent capabilities in areas such as cyber-security, humanitarian response, supply-chain security, and civilian crisis management. This approach supports a more self-reliant and stable Europe while maintaining a strong commitment to international cooperation and conflict prevention. Together, these priorities outline a balanced and forward-looking programme that aligns with Ireland’s values and supports a fair, sustainable, and citizen-focused European Union.

geography: I was born and raised in a rural farming community but currently live and work in an urban area.
response_text: Strengthening Social Protection, Housing Rights, and Anti-Poverty Frameworks Ireland should prioritise legislative files that reinforce the European Pillar of Social Rights and directly contribute to the eradication of poverty and homelessness. Key proposals include: Securing ambitious Council conclusions on the Adequate Minimum Income Directive, with binding standards that effectively raise living conditions across all Member States. Advancing legislative measures that protect workers in precarious employment, including platform workers, seasonal employees, and gig-economy labour. Supporting EU-level action to recognise housing as a fundamental social right, including frameworks to prevent homelessness, regulate speculative practices, and promote public and social housing investment. Ireland should aim to embed stronger social-impact obligations across all EU funding programmes to ensure that the benefits of the green and digital transitions accrue first to vulnerable communities. Nature Restoration, Rewilding, and Sustainable Land and Marine Management The Presidency should place particular emphasis on the implementation of the Nature Restoration Law and associated financing mechanisms. Priority actions include: Developing EU-wide rewilding frameworks, including ecological corridors, large-scale habitat restoration, and the expansion of terrestrial and marine national parks. Supporting legislative and policy measures to end grazing on Europe’s most ecologically fragile uplands, enabling large-scale rewilding, carbon recovery, and biodiversity restoration. Advancing reforms to the Common Agricultural Policy to reward nature-positive practices and support rural communities transitioning away from environmentally damaging land use. Ireland should aim to secure Council progress on long-term restoration funding within the Multiannual Financial Framework. Fair, Accessible and Sustainable Public Services and Mobility Ireland should advance proposals that support Member States in developing equitable and sustainable public services, including: EU-supported initiatives for free or low-cost public transport, supported by cohesion and climate funds. Accelerated progress on the TEN-T revision and initiatives promoting low-emission mobility. Strengthened cross-border cooperation in health and education to deliver high-quality, accessible services. Digital Rights, Consumer Protection, and Democratic Accountability Ireland should prioritise legislative work that strengthens the EU’s citizen-first digital and consumer regulatory frameworks, including: Enforcement of the Digital Services Act and Digital Markets Act. AI transparency, ethical governance, and data-protection measures that protect citizens rather than corporate interests. Enhanced consumer-protection legislation covering predatory digital practices and essential-service affordability. Strategic Autonomy, Civilian Security, and Peacebuilding Reflecting Ireland’s commitment to peace and neutrality, the Presidency should promote a model of EU security grounded in diplomacy, resilience, and independence. Priority areas include: Legislative progress on cybersecurity, civilian crisis management, supply-chain resilience, and strategic-industrial capacity. Strengthening the EU’s humanitarian and disaster-response systems. The overarching aim should be a Europe that is self-reliant, peaceful, environmentally restored, and firmly oriented towards the well-being of current and future generations.

geography: I was born and raised in a rural farming community but currently live and work in an urban area.
response_text: Ireland’s Presidency offers an important opportunity to demonstrate that the work of the Council can deliver direct, measurable benefits for citizens, communities, and enterprises across the Union. By prioritising a socially just transition, long-term sustainability, renewed democratic accountability, and strengthened European resilience, the Presidency can ensure that the EU operates in the interests of its people and future generations. Advancing a Social Europe That Reduces Poverty and Strengthens Community Well-Being Delivering tangible social progress is essential to improving quality of life across the Union. The Presidency can make a substantial positive impact by securing progress on the Adequate Minimum Income Directive, improving protections for precarious workers, and elevating housing as a fundamental social right. These initiatives would reduce poverty, enhance income security, and strengthen the social fabric of communities. Coordinating better use of EU funding instruments—particularly cohesion policy, the Social Climate Fund, and ESF+—would ensure that vulnerable groups receive targeted support during the green and digital transitions. Delivering Environmental Restoration and Long-Term Community Resilience Communities benefit most from healthy ecosystems, resilient landscapes, and restored natural capital. Through prioritising the implementation of the Nature Restoration Law, expanding protected marine and terrestrial areas, and progressing EU-wide rewilding frameworks, the Presidency can deliver significant ecological, social, and economic gains. Ending grazing on Europe’s most fragile uplands and promoting rewilding will restore biodiversity, enhance carbon sequestration, and create new opportunities for nature-based tourism, rural regeneration, and sustainable enterprise. These actions directly support communities while preserving natural assets for future generations. Supporting Accessible Public Services and Sustainable Mobility Free or low-cost public transport, improved cross-border healthcare cooperation, and strengthened educational mobility can significantly improve the everyday lives of citizens. The Presidency can advance these goals by promoting EU-level funding and legislative frameworks that enable Member States to expand accessible public services. Sustainable mobility initiatives—especially through TEN-T reforms—will strengthen regional economies, reduce transport costs for households, and promote climate-friendly economic development. Enhancing Digital Rights, Consumer Protections, and Business Fairness Businesses, particularly SMEs, benefit from predictable regulation, fair competition, and consumer trust. By reinforcing the Digital Services Act and Digital Markets Act, advancing AI transparency, and strengthening protections against unfair digital and commercial practices, the Presidency can support a competitive, innovative, and responsible economic environment. Strong digital rights and consumer protections also reinforce public trust in the digital economy, which is essential for long-term growth. Building a More Resilient, Peaceful, and Self-Sufficient Union A Europe that is strategically autonomous, civilian-resilient, and committed to peace brings stability to communities and security to businesses. The Presidency can deliver impact by advancing legislation on cyber resilience, protecting critical infrastructure, ensuring supply-chain security, and strengthening humanitarian and disaster-response mechanisms. These measures reduce reliance on external powers, enhance crisis preparedness, and support a Europe capable of acting independently for the well-being of its people.

geography: I was born and raised in a rural farming community but currently live and work in an urban area.
response_text: Effective communication of the values and benefits of EU membership requires approaches that are accessible, transparent, participatory, and grounded in the lived experiences of citizens and communities. Ireland’s Presidency should aim to strengthen public understanding of the EU as a union that delivers social progress, environmental protection, economic fairness, and long-term security for present and future generations. Equally, it should ensure that citizens feel directly engaged in, and represented by, the work carried out during the Presidency. Demonstrating Tangible, People-Centred Outcomes Communication is most effective when it is practical and relevant to everyday life. The Presidency should highlight EU achievements that improve living standards—such as measures reducing poverty, enhancing workers’ rights, supporting affordable housing, protecting consumers, and strengthening public services. Communicating these benefits in clear, accessible language will reinforce the idea of a Union that operates for the wellbeing of its people rather than for institutional or corporate interests. Real-world examples, case studies, and community-level data should be used to show how EU initiatives translate into better opportunities, greater security, and improved quality of life. Engaging Communities Through Inclusive and Participatory Processes Creating a sense of ownership requires citizens to see themselves as active participants rather than passive observers. Ireland should organise extensive community-level dialogues, regional forums, and targeted consultations involving young people, civil society, trade unions, small businesses, farmers, and environmental organisations. These forums should allow citizens to articulate their priorities on issues such as social rights, rewilding and biodiversity, public transport, digital fairness, and long-term sustainability. Incorporating these perspectives into public reporting on the Presidency will reinforce the idea that citizen voices directly inform Ireland’s approach at EU level. Prioritising Youth Engagement and Intergenerational Responsibility Young people are among the most directly affected by EU policy on climate, digital rights, public services, and long-term sustainability. The Presidency should promote youth assemblies, model council debates, and educational partnerships that explain how EU decisions impact future generations. Communicating Ireland’s commitment to Future Generations Impact Assessments will further demonstrate the EU’s long-term responsibility, helping young people see the Union as an instrument for safeguarding their future. Clear, Consistent, and Transparent Messaging The Presidency should adopt a unified communication strategy centred on the values of fairness, sustainability, democracy, and peace. Communication should emphasise Ireland’s leadership in areas such as nature restoration, rewilding, social rights, and strategic autonomy. Transparency—including regular public briefings, accessible summaries of Council outcomes, and clear explanations of legislative progress—will strengthen trust and counter misinformation. Cultural, Creative, and Community-Based Communication Ireland should leverage its strong cultural sector to communicate EU values in an engaging and inclusive manner. Artistic projects, local exhibitions, digital storytelling, and national events celebrating Ireland’s Presidency can help broaden engagement beyond traditional political audiences. These initiatives should emphasise shared European identity, cultural diversity, and the collective commitment to protecting people, communities, and the natural world.

geography: I was born and raised in a rural farming community but currently live and work in an urban area.
response_text: Ireland’s 2026 Presidency represents a unique opportunity to demonstrate that the European Union can be a Union of citizens, rather than institutions or elites. While Ireland has made progress in social and environmental policy, significant challenges remain, including persistent poverty and homelessness, gaps in healthcare provision, underinvestment in public infrastructure, and ongoing pressures on biodiversity, rewilding, and climate action. Holding the EU Presidency offers Ireland a platform to confront these challenges with ambition, leadership, and concrete action. By leveraging the Presidency to advance ambitious EU-wide initiatives in social protection, housing, healthcare, sustainability, and ecological restoration, Ireland can demonstrate a practical commitment to tackling these longstanding domestic issues while setting a bold example for other Member States. The Presidency should embed intergenerational responsibility and long-term sustainability into all Council deliberations, ensuring that decisions contribute to a fairer, greener, and more resilient Europe. Initiatives such as ending grazing on Europe’s most fragile uplands, expanding terrestrial and marine national parks, and prioritising social and climate-focused investment would allow Ireland to translate domestic imperatives into European leadership. By pairing radical ambition with citizen-centred communication, Ireland can strengthen public trust in the EU, foster engagement and ownership among citizens, and show that the Union can deliver tangible improvements in people’s lives. In doing so, the Irish Presidency can leave a lasting positive legacy, demonstrating that Europe’s environmental, social, and economic challenges can be addressed with courage, vision, and practical action.

Ireland’s Presidency of the Council of the European Union in 2026 offers an important opportunity to champion themes that reinforce the competitiveness of the European Union, uphold the integrity of the Single Market and protect the economic foundations upon which diverse industries depend. From the standpoint of Sazerac, these priorities matter profoundly because regulatory coherence, market stability, and investment confidence underpin our long term ability to supply consumers, support employment, and maintain strong relationships with agricultural and rural partners. The Commission Work Programme for 2026 foregrounds competitiveness and innovation, and Ireland is well positioned to build on these priorities through its Presidency. The proposed European Innovation Act, which aims to strengthen European industrial renewal and support research-led growth, is a clear example of the type of enabling environment that multinational producers rely upon. Ireland should also focus on ensuring that the Single Market remains functional, predictable, and free from unnecessary barriers. The Twenty Eighth Regime for Innovative Companies, which seeks to simplify cross border business conditions, reflects the kind of structural reform that can reinforce Europe’s appeal for global investment. These benefit sectors such as spirits production that must navigate complex regulatory requirements across Member States. Policies that reduce fragmentation and encourage proportional and science-led regulation help preserve consumer choice, avoid duplication of compliance burdens and support the continued availability of a diverse range of products across the European Union. Sustainability and supply chain resilience should form another key theme. The Work Programme recognises the strategic importance of Europe’s agri food sector. The introduction of policy to strengthen competitiveness and resilience in farming is particularly relevant given our reliance on grain producers, maltsters and rural services. A Presidency that emphasises balanced agricultural policy can help ensure that environmental objectives are aligned with economic sustainability for primary producers and processors. A further priority should be workforce development. The Quality Jobs Act, which aims to support modern employment conditions, and the Fair Labour Mobility Package, which proposes new tools such as a European Social Security Pass, are important for maintaining an adaptable and skilled workforce. Global firms depend on clear and consistent labour frameworks to invest confidently in people and future capacity. Finally, Ireland can use its Presidency to highlight the value of partnership between government and industry. The Work Programme’s emphasis on better regulation and simplification, particularly through its forthcoming Communication on Better Regulation, provides an opportunity to showcase the benefits of reducing administrative burdens for businesses while maintaining high standards of consumer and environmental protection. Together these themes form a coherent and pragmatic Presidency agenda that supports competitiveness, sustainability, and long term prosperity for European communities.

Ireland’s Presidency should concentrate on policy areas that encourage competitiveness, strengthen supply chain resilience and ensure that the Single Market remains predictable and coherent for producers, suppliers and consumers. Ireland’s perspective as a nation with economic strengths presents a unique opportunity to advance policies that balance regulatory objectives with economic sustainability for Sazerac. One priority area is the improvement of regulatory proportionality and simplification. The forthcoming Communication on Better Regulation, which aims to streamline legislative processes and reduce unnecessary burdens, is essential for sectors such as spirits manufacturing. A clarified and predictable regulatory environment enables companies to plan investment cycles with confidence, retain product diversity and maintain relationships with suppliers. In addition, the planned omnibus initiative on simplifying food and feed safety legislation provides a practical opportunity to remove duplicative requirements and promote a more harmonised approach to compliance across the Union. Ireland should also prioritise competitiveness through modernisation of the Single Market framework. The European Product Act reforms, which aim to update rules on product compliance, standardisation, and market surveillance, are particularly relevant for companies distributing across the Single Market. Ensuring that these reforms do not create new complexities or fragmentation will be important for preserving consumer choice and avoiding supply disruptions. Ireland can use the Presidency to advocate for proportionate implementation and for impact assessments that reflect the realities of cross border manufacturing and distribution. Agricultural and rural resilience should also receive focused attention. The proposed update of unfair trading practices rules in the food chain reflects the European Union's recognition that farmers must be supported through improved market transparency and fairer trading conditions. These initiatives complement Ireland’s interest in sustaining rural economies and align with Sazerac’s reliance on stable agricultural inputs. A Presidency that advances these files can help ensure that regulatory changes take account of the interconnected nature of the agri food supply chain. Skills development and labour mobility represent another crucial policy domain. The Fair Labour Mobility Package, including its proposals for a European Social Security Pass and measures to strengthen the European Labour Authority, will support the movement of talent across borders and improve the functioning of labour markets. This is particularly relevant for global companies that depend on specialised skills and predictable workforce planning. Together these policy priorities can help Ireland deliver a Presidency that supports a competitive Single Market, improves regulatory certainty, strengthens rural communities and ensures that European businesses remain resilient in a changing global environment.

Ireland’s Presidency can achieve substantial positive outcomes for people, businesses and communities by prioritising practical reforms that support competitiveness, ensure regulatory predictability, and reinforce the resilience of European supply chains. The Commission Work Programme identifies several initiatives that align directly with these goals and offer Ireland a strong basis for shaping discussions within the Council. A key area where the Presidency can make a meaningful difference is in simplifying regulatory requirements. The Communication on Better Regulation aims to improve legislative coherence, reduce administrative burdens and promote clearer implementation across Member States. We would like to see single-market coherence on stances related to labelling for the alcohol industry, rather than having to abide by individual, complex and ambiguous rules and varying member states. When applied effectively, such simplification makes it easier for companies to invest, scale production and maintain employment. For communities whose livelihoods depend on manufacturing, agriculture or logistics, the benefits of reduced administrative complexity are significant. The planned simplification of food and feed safety legislation provides another concrete opportunity to remove duplication and align national practices. The Presidency can also support rural communities by advancing agricultural policies that strengthen competitiveness and fairness within the supply chain. The planned update to unfair trading practices rules seeks to increase transparency, promote cooperation among enforcement authorities and ensure that farmers are not compelled to sell below production cost. These measures are essential for maintaining the viability of primary producers who supply industries such as spirits manufacturing. A Presidency that progresses initiatives like these will deliver benefits that extend far beyond the agricultural sector into the wider rural economy. Consumer welfare can also be strengthened through a focus on regulatory coherence within the Single Market. The European Product Act reforms, which aim to update rules governing product compliance and standardisation, have the potential to improve product safety and clarity while maintaining choice. Ireland can promote balanced implementation that avoids unnecessary costs for producers while ensuring that consumers benefit from consistent product information and reliable availability. Workforce development is another area where the Presidency can have a positive impact. The Fair Labour Mobility Package introduces proposals that aim to improve the portability of social security rights and strengthen labour market governance. These reforms support workers in accessing opportunities across the Union and help businesses attract talent more efficiently. When combined with the Quality Jobs Act, which aims to modernise working conditions, these initiatives can contribute to more resilient and dynamic labour markets. Together these measures support communities by sustaining jobs, strengthening rural economies, increasing consumer choice and improving the conditions for enterprise growth. Ireland can therefore deliver a Presidency that creates practical and lasting benefits for citizens across Europe.

Ireland can communicate the values and benefits of European Union membership effectively by grounding its Presidency narrative in the themes that impact citizens in everyday life, particularly those linked to competitiveness, consumer protection, rural resilience, and employment. There are several examples of upcoming policies which Ireland can draw upon to illustrate how the European Union delivers practical change for households and businesses. A clear narrative on the importance of simpler and more predictable regulation will resonate strongly with both consumers and enterprises. The Communication on Better Regulation, which aims to make laws clearer and reduce administrative burdens, Ireland can demonstrate how the European Union seeks to remove unnecessary complexity from people’s lives. When rules are easier to understand and apply, businesses can operate more effectively, workers can spend less time navigating bureaucracy and consumers experience more consistent access to goods and services. Agricultural and rural policy provides another compelling storytelling opportunity. Citizens in rural communities are acutely aware of the pressures facing farmers and agri-food producers. By highlighting initiatives such as the update to unfair trading practices rules, Ireland can show how the European Union is working to strengthen fairness in the food supply chain and support rural economic resilience. These policies provide tangible benefits for rural communities linked to Sazerac’s own supply chain, including grain producers and transport providers. Consumer facing initiatives also offer accessible examples to communicate the role and value of the Single Market. The European Product Act reforms, which aim to modernise compliance rules and improve standards, can help demonstrate how the European Union works to protect consumers while supporting the availability of diverse and affordable products. Ireland can position itself as a leader in promoting balanced implementation that benefits both producers and consumers. Workforce policy is an area that speaks directly to the interests of families and young people. The Fair Labour Mobility Package, which aims to improve the portability of social security rights and strengthen cooperation between Member States, provides a concrete example of how European Union action helps workers access employment opportunities more easily. These measures support a more dynamic and inclusive labour market and help citizens understand how European policies affect their personal and professional lives. By combining practical policy examples, inclusive public engagement and clear messaging, Ireland can help citizens recognise the value of the European Union in their daily lives and foster a sense of shared ownership over the Presidency and its achievements.

Sazerac welcomes the opportunity to contribute to Ireland’s preparations for its 2026 Council Presidency. Several initiatives proposed for 2026 provide important opportunities to support competitiveness, supply chain stability and rural livelihoods, all of which are directly relevant to Sazerac’s operations and the communities we serve. Sazerac values the constructive engagement it has experienced with Irish authorities and believes that Ireland’s Presidency offers an opportunity to highlight how international companies contribute to economic growth, employment and rural development. As the Presidency agenda advances, Sazerac remains ready to provide further insights into the economic and social contributions of the spirits sector, as well as the potential impacts of regulatory decisions on investment and supply chain resilience. We believe that a Presidency focused on competitiveness, rural sustainability, workforce mobility and better regulation will support a strong and vibrant European economy that is capable of responding to emerging global challenges while protecting the interests of citizens and communities.

organisation: Atlantic Technological University (ATU) Friends of Palestine
response_text: As a neutral country with a long and proud historical dedication to peace and diplomacy, it is vital that Ireland demonstrate a clear commitment to diplomacy over hyper-militarization. Irish has previously acted as a leader in this area through the work of former minister for external affairs Frank Aiken, who was one of the leading figures in the nuclear disarmament movement. Active Irish neutrality as exemplified in the legacy of Aiken is cherished by the Irish people and positions us uniquely as a leader in peacebuilding in a European context that is increasingly hawkish. Our history as a former colony affords us a unique perspective on the horrors of imperialism, a complete rejection of imperialism (corporate and state) should be central to our presidency. As such, Ireland must make meaningful sanctions against Israel central to the objectives of this presidency. Israel has been permitted and supported to commit a genocide against the people of Palestine. Europe must immediately cease any cultural, educational or economic collaboration with Israel. Europe must call for an invocation of UN powers under Chapter 7 of the UN Charter to facilitate the safe delivery of humanitarian aid into Gaza. Europe must support an end to the illegal occupation of Palestine, the removal of all illegal settlements, a full recognition of the equal rights of Palestinians including a right to self-determination, the provision of reparations for the untold suffering endured by people of Palestine at the hands of Israel and its allies, a right of return for all Palestinians and a demand that Israel be held accountable for its crimes.

organisation: Atlantic Technological University (ATU) Friends of Palestine
response_text: The presidency should be focused on the area of Foreign Affairs. Through this pursuit we must be unequivocal in our vision for a Europe that is committed to diplomacy over hyper-militarization, with a dedication to peace as a unifying and unshakeable principle. Together with this in our approach to Foreign Affairs we must assert ourselves as fundamentally opposed to imperialism and colonialism in all its forms. These principles must take practical effect through the development of policy guided by the actions outlined in Question 5 above.

organisation: Atlantic Technological University (ATU) Friends of Palestine
response_text: The most substantial positive impact for the people, businesses and communities across the EU can be achieved through an unwavering commitment to peace, diplomacy and anti-imperialism as outlined in Question 5 above.

organisation: Atlantic Technological University (ATU) Friends of Palestine
response_text: Demonstrating a clear, unequivocal commitment to diplomacy and the pursuit of peace, through actions and words, will communicate to the people of Europe that their lives and wellbeing are central to the values of the EU. The people of Europe have shown by taking to the streets in their millions, through lobbying, protesting, boycotting Israeli products, services and events, through their humanitarian donations and support for Palestine, that they are steadfastly opposed to the illegal occupation of Palestine, to Israeli apartheid and genocide. By showing dedicated support for Palestine through the measures outlined in Question 5 above, the EU can demonstrate that its citizens have been heard and that their representatives will honor the will of the people. There is no clearer way to create a sense of ownership among the citizens of Europe than through actions that are of and for the people.

respondent_type: [REDACTED UNDER GDPR] Food Allergy Italia APS, a patient organisation that represents patients and consumers with food allergy and anaphylaxis. Through social initiatives, Food Allergy Italia aims to improve the quality of life for patients and their families, raise awareness of these conditions, and promote full inclusion of food-allergic patients within the community.
sector: Advocacy, Citizens’ Safety, Food allergy, Food allergen labelling, Patients’ rights
response_text: Taking into account the current geopolitical and socioeconomic context in Europe, we recommend that Ireland prioritise Health Protection, Citizen Safety, and Resilient Societies as core themes of its 2026 Presidency. Serious food allergies and anaphylaxis are rising across Europe and place a growing burden on individuals, schools, workplaces, and public services. Addressing them fits naturally within broader objectives to protect citizens’ wellbeing and reduce preventable health risks. 1. A Resilient and Prepared Europe The EU must be equipped to respond to emergencies—whether acute health events, natural disasters, or public safety threats. This requires harmonised emergency response systems, stronger community-level preparedness, and cross-border cooperation. Ireland is one of the few Member States that has taken concrete steps to improve preparedness for serious allergic reactions, including allowing pharmacists to supply emergency medicines without a prescription during anaphylactic events. This national practice demonstrates effective emergency readiness and provides a model for EU-level policy coordination, which could inform upcoming initiatives under the European Health Union framework aimed at strengthening preparedness, prevention, and rapid response across Member States. 2. A People-Centred Union that Protects Embedding people-centred principles into EU policymaking ensures that vulnerable populations and individuals at risk of medical emergencies are not left behind. The Presidency could advance reducing health inequalities across the EU, highlighting uneven access to diagnosis, specialist care, treatments, and emergency response protocols. Positioning timely care for serious allergies and anaphylaxis within this agenda demonstrates a commitment to practical, measurable improvements in patient safety and inclusion, while protecting citizens’ rights to safety in everyday environments such as schools, childcare centres, workplaces, and public venues. 3. A Future-Oriented Europe Built on Innovation and Collaboration Ireland’s strong reputation in digital innovation offers an opportunity to promote Digital Innovation for Health, leveraging the European Health Data Space and interoperable, patient-centred tools. For individuals at risk of serious allergic reactions, seamless access to medical information across borders can prevent emergencies and support the free movement of people. The Presidency can also prioritise harmonised awareness-raising, institutional readiness, and capacity building, ensuring schools, businesses, and public institutions are equipped and trained to respond effectively to life-threatening health incidents.

respondent_type: [REDACTED UNDER GDPR] Food Allergy Italia APS, a patient organisation that represents patients and consumers with food allergy and anaphylaxis. Through social initiatives, Food Allergy Italia aims to improve the quality of life for patients and their families, raise awareness of these conditions, and promote full inclusion of food-allergic patients within the community.
sector: Advocacy, Citizens’ Safety, Food allergy, Food allergen labelling, Patients’ rights
response_text: Ireland could use its Presidency to champion health resilience, citizen protection, and emergency preparedness, leveraging its national leadership in anaphylaxis response as a model for EU coordination. Key priorities include: 1. Health Protection and Emergency Preparedness Serious allergies and anaphylaxis present a growing public-health challenge. The Presidency could: Promote timely access to emergency medicines, to ensure treatment for all patients at risk Encourage harmonised school and public-venue preparedness, using Ireland as an example. Relevant upcoming EU initiative: Global health resilience initiative (non-legislative, Q2 2026) – to strengthen EU capacity for rapid response to health crises. 2. Digital Innovation for Health Cross-border emergencies require seamless access to patient data: Promote the European Health Data Space for secure, interoperable sharing of health information, enabling faster response to anaphylactic events across borders. Support digital tools for citizen-centred care, enhancing emergency response and patient safety. 3. Reducing Health Inequalities and Strengthening Citizen Rights The Presidency could advance equitable access to emergency care and citizen-centred policy: Link preparedness to strengthening the Child Guarantee (non-legislative, Q2 2026) and Citizens omnibus (legislative, Q4 2026), ensuring children in schools, childcare centres, and communities are protected and have their rights effectively enforced. Promote intergenerational fairness through the Intergenerational fairness strategy (non-legislative, Q1 2026), ensuring emergency preparedness and health access benefit current and future generations equally. Highlight Ireland’s model as a practical, replicable approach for other Member States. Objectives Establish a model for EU-level anaphylaxis and emergency response coordination, based on best practices of Ireland. Ensure equitable access to life-saving treatments across the EU. Promote digital innovation for preparedness, information sharing, and cross-border patient care. Strengthen citizen rights and intergenerational fairness, ensuring public health policies reflect social equity. Position health resilience as a pillar of EU citizen safety and social cohesion, demonstrating tangible improvements in public health readiness. By focusing on these targeted initiatives, Ireland can use its Presidency to deliver practical, measurable impacts on citizen safety, health equity, and cross-border emergency preparedness while reinforcing the EU’s social and legal frameworks.

Through social initiatives, Food Allergy Italia aims to improve the quality of life for patients and their families, raise awareness of these conditions, and promote full inclusion of food-allergic patients within the community.
sector: Advocacy, Citizens’ Safety, Food allergy, Food allergen labelling, Patients’ rights
response_text: The Irish Presidency has the potential to deliver significant, tangible impact for EU citizens by advancing health resilience and consumer safety. For individuals with serious food allergies, policies that improve emergency response, access to medicines, and accurate allergen information can be life-saving. For people, expanded access to emergency treatment, including pharmacy-enabled emergency supply across the EU, enhances safety in daily life. Citizens with serious food allergies would be better protected in schools, workplaces, sports facilities, cultural venues, and during cross-border travel. For businesses, harmonised food allergen-labelling and staff-training expectations reduce regulatory uncertainty, simplify compliance, and improve consumer trust by fostering safer public environments. For communities and institutions, EU-supported readiness measures, such as common school protocols, public-venue guidelines, and accessible training, would significantly reduce preventable emergencies. Replicating Ireland’s best practice on emergency medicine access would ensure that life-saving intervention is available regardless of where a reaction occurs, reducing inequalities across Member States.

Through social initiatives, Food Allergy Italia aims to improve the quality of life for patients and their families, raise awareness of these conditions, and promote full inclusion of food-allergic patients within the community.
