response_text: Ireland has a strong opportunity to communicate the value of EU membership by focusing on everyday benefits and practical improvements that resonate directly with citizens. The 2026 Presidency can show how EU cooperation protects people, strengthens communities, and makes daily life safer—particularly in areas such as emergency preparedness for serious allergies and anaphylaxis. 1. Highlight Practical Examples of EU Solidarity Citizens understand the EU best when they see clear, relatable outcomes. Ireland can communicate EU values by highlighting how cooperation improves safety and wellbeing, for example: Safer environments in schools, restaurants, transport and public venues. Shared health information that makes travel within the EU safer and more predictable. Harmonised food allergen-labelling rules that protect consumers wherever they are. More consistent access to emergency support for serious allergic reactions. 2. Propose Council Recommendations on Emergency Readiness To strengthen public understanding of the EU’s benefits, Ireland could lead on a visible, citizen-centred initiative: Develop Council Recommendations on broader readiness and access to emergency treatment for serious allergy and anaphylaxis. This would help encourage Member States to: Improve preparedness in schools, public venues, workplaces, and transport hubs. Ensure trained responders are available across community settings. Reduce inequalities in access to time-sensitive, life-saving care. Such an initiative is easy for citizens to relate to, directly improves safety, and demonstrates EU cooperation in a human, practical way. 3. A simple message: the EU protects people By showcasing initiatives that make everyday life safer, including better emergency preparedness for serious allergic reactions, the Irish Presidency can reinforce a clear message: EU cooperation delivers real, practical benefits for families, children, workers, and communities. This people-centred framing will strengthen public trust, build ownership, and demonstrate the concrete value of Ireland’s leadership at EU level.

The Fine Gael delegation welcomes the opportunity to respond to the Government’s consultation on Ireland’s forthcoming Presidency on of the EU Council. Ireland will assume the Presidency at a particularly critical time for the EU as MEPs in Parliament and Member States in Council work to finalise the next Multiannual Financial Framework and implement a range of policy actions, all in the context of an increasingly volatile global environment and rapidly evolving international relationships. We are now almost 18 months into the 2024-2029 European Parliament term and approaching the oneyear anniversary of the current European Commission taking office, and throughout this time there has been a single, overarching priority that has set the tone for all policy actions taken at European level: competitiveness. When Ireland assumes the Presidency, we will pass the two-year anniversary of the Mario Draghi report on the Future of European Competitiveness. The Fine Gael delegation believes that this should be the main high-level priority for the Presidency in 2026. At a high level, Ireland’s Presidency should aim to progress the types of initiatives that would result in the delivery of the objectives set out in Mr. Draghi’s report, for example lowering energy costs, simplification and removal of red-tape and overregulation, removing barriers to the roll-out of critical infrastructure, and better enabling access to capital for European SMEs and start-ups. this is only partly true, and often the challenge is about the need for clearer rules that are easier to navigate. Nevertheless, it is a fact that in recent years over 100 separate pieces of digital legislation have been proposed at EU level. Companies must spend a huge amount of time on their compliance with EU regulatory obligations. The companies that people largely choose to share their data with remain the large US multinationals, while European competition struggles to grow. Despite past efforts, the EU remains too slow where speed is needed and too fragmented where unity is vital. Child safety online The Irish Presidency should put the safety of children and young people at the centre of the EU’s digital agenda. Across Europe, parents are increasingly worried about the risks young people face as they grow up in a rapidly evolving online environment marked by harmful content, manipulative design, and unsafe interactions. The Presidency should drive coordinated Council engagement on wider online-safety debates, such as the harmonisation of age-verification systems, the promotion of digital literacy, and programmes to empower parents and guardians in supporting young people’s online lives. Irish leadership in this regard will bring real, tangible benefits to citizens across the country, and across Europe. Tackling online fraud Over 3 in 4 Irish people have encountered some form of suspicious activities online, while 45% of people state that they have experienced more suspicious activity compared to this time last year. Such incidents are hard to track and almost impossible to reverse after they happen. The Digital Services Act (DSA) obliges platforms to take down illegal content once it has been reported; however, it creates few proactive obligations prior to publication or even reporting by individuals. It is all too easy to post fake advertisements, purporting to be from regulated institutions, and for unsuspecting citizens to be scammed out of their own money before the advert disappears again. Some platforms are currently making 10% of their advertising revenue from such fake advertisements, thereby profiting from people’s misery. Delivering more homes, faster and at lower cost Across the EU, housing supply is held back by complex processes, fragmented standards, and limited access to affordable finance for both public and private developers. Ireland can use its Presidency to advance measures that streamline approvals, encourage common standards for modern construction methods, and promote the wider use of digital planning tools that reduce delays while maintaining high safety and quality. By focusing on practical steps that remove unnecessary bottlenecks ad bring down building costs, the EU can help ensure that more homes are built where they are needed and built at a pace that meets the scale of Europe’s housing challenge. Delivering for Farmers Ireland has a great opportunity during its Presidency to help deliver a fair income for farmers in the face of rising input costs, market volatility, and environmental obligations. This is critical for the viability of our farming sector and for our rural towns and villages. Ireland can use its Presidency to facilitate progress on practical tools to improve farmers’ bargaining power, reduce administrative burdens, and ensure a level playing field across the Single Market. These would all have significant positive impact on a sector that has been continuously under pressure in recent years. Generational renewal remains one of the most acute challenges within the agriculture sector. By delivering a positive outcome on CAP, the Irish Presidency can help deliver advance targeted schemes and EU-level incentives that make farming a viable and attractive career path for young men and women, including support for training, access to finance, and rural development programmes as contained within the Commission’s Generational Renewal Strategy. More broadly, the Presidency should ensure that rural development remains at the heart of EU policymaking in 2026 - protecting the funding streams that communities rely on, championing programmes like LEADER, and ensuring that policy choices made in Brussels translate into real benefits for families, businesses, and communities across rural Europe.

To effectively communicate the values and benefits of EU membership, we need to meet citizens where they are and showing clearly how EU-level decisions improve daily life. A nationwide programme of events, directly linking EU actions to tangible outcomes for households, communities and businesses would help make the Presidency visible and more relevant for citizens. Additionally, specific engagement across schools and universities would help to build students’ interest and understanding of how the EU works, the role of the Council and Parliament, and how EU policies benefit them. Schools and universities could also be involved through national competitions and debates on Ireland's role in the EU, helping younger generations build a sense of connection and ownership over the Presidency. Highlighting the benefits of EU programmes such as Erasmus+, PEACEPLUS and LEADER through local events would help reinforce how EU membership delivers for rural Ireland, job creation and regional development. Housing is a top priority for the Government, for citizens and for the European Commission, and should feature prominently in citizen-focused engagement. A high-profile Housing Summit during the Presidency would demonstrate how EU cooperation can help lower construction costs, accelerate delivery, share best practices and support the new Affordable Housing Plan for Europe. This should align clearly with Ireland’s broader Presidency agenda and help link policy priorities to real outcomes. The Presidency should also include initiatives that help businesses and communities to make the most of EU opportunities. A targeted campaign to support cross-border trade, especially for SMEs and start-ups, would sit naturally alongside an emphasis on competitiveness, reducing red tape, and improving access to finance. The EU Week of Sport in September 2026 is an important opportunity to highlight the EU’s support for grassroots sport and celebrating Irish traditional sports, such as the GAA, being played across Europe. The Irish Presidency should combine the official launch of sport week in Dublin with support for local sports clubs, school, and community groups to host local events around the country. Likewise, the EU Gender Equality Week in November 2026 provides a valuable opportunity to showcase Ireland’s leadership on Women, Peace and Security and to highlight national and EU-level efforts to combat gender-based violence and strengthen women’s economic security.

sector: Our organization is dedicated to addressing the challenges within climate change mitigation, biodiversity conservation, awareness, human rights advocacy and humanitarian awareness.
geography: The geographical focus for the Mary Robinson Climate and Nature conference is a generalized one of all of Ireland and the EU.
response_text: Inspired by the MRCANC 2026 theme “Fite Fuaite / Interwoven,” Ireland’s Presidency should champion an integrated, justice-centred approach. The overarching vision should be: “An Interwoven Europe: Justice, Resilience, and Partnership for People and Planet.” The three priority themes should be: Climate and Nature Justice as the Core of EU Policy: Ensuring the green transition is fair, leaves no one behind, and recognises the disproportionate burden on vulnerable communities and regions. Empowering Communities and Intergenerational Leadership: Placing grassroots action, youth voices, and local knowledge at the heart of EU decision-making, particularly in biodiversity, energy, and rural resilience. Global Solidarity through Coherent Policies: Aligning EU trade, agriculture, and development policies to support global climate goals, biodiversity protection, and human rights, honouring our international commitments. These themes directly reflect the values of the Mary Robinson Centre and align with the EU Strategic Agenda's pillars on sustainability, resilience, and democracy.

sector: Our organization is dedicated to addressing the challenges within climate change mitigation, biodiversity conservation, awareness, human rights advocacy and humanitarian awareness.
geography: The geographical focus for the Mary Robinson Climate and Nature conference is a generalized one of all of Ireland and the EU.
response_text: Ireland should use its neutral chair role to weave justice and community impact into key legislative files: ENVI Council (Environment): Priority: Secure a Council agreement on the EU 2040 Climate Target that legally embeds just transition principles and adequate support for regions like the West of Ireland. Priority: Drive forward the implementation of the Nature Restoration Law, ensuring it actively supports community-led biodiversity projects and sustainable land use. Furthermore, to tangibly demonstrate Ireland's commitment to a people-centred Presidency, the Mary Robinson Centre, as the home of the annual Mary Robinson Climate & Nature Conference, hereby expresses its formal intention to apply to host an Informal Meeting of EU Environment Ministers or a High-Level Presidency Conference on Climate Justice during the 2026 Presidency. Hosting such a meeting in Ballina, County Mayo, would powerfully symbolise the EU's commitment to connecting its high-level policy work with grassroots innovation, community leadership, and the principles of just transition. It would place the lived experience of communities in the West of Ireland at the very heart of the European dialogue. AGRIFISH Council (Agriculture and Fisheries): Achievement: Advance the CAP Strategic Plans review to better reward farmers for biodiversity, carbon sequestration, and water quality improvements, linking it to community resilience. EPSCO Council (Employment, Social Policy, Health): Achievement: Integrate strong social and employment safeguards into all climate-related legislation, ensuring the Green Deal creates quality jobs and manages labour market transitions fairly. Cross-cutting & External Relations: Achievement: Champion EU policies that halt imported deforestation (enforcement of EUDR) and ensure trade agreements uphold environmental and human rights standards. Achievement: Build a unified EU position to increase climate finance and deliver on loss and damage funding at international negotiations, demonstrating leadership on global justice.

sector: Our organization is dedicated to addressing the challenges within climate change mitigation, biodiversity conservation, awareness, human rights advocacy and humanitarian awareness.
geography: The geographical focus for the Mary Robinson Climate and Nature conference is a generalized one of all of Ireland and the EU.
response_text: Impact is measured by tangible benefits in communities and strengthened solidarity: For People & Communities: By ensuring EU funds and policies directly support local climate action – like community energy projects, biodiversity gardens, and peatland restoration – making the EU relevant in towns like Ballina. Policies must reduce energy poverty and support sustainable local food systems. For Intergenerational Equity: By formally incorporating youth climate councils and intergenerational dialogues into policy feedback loops, ensuring the voices shaping the future are heard in the Council’s preparatory bodies. For Business & Social Economy: By creating clear, supportive frameworks for community-led renewable energy cooperatives and green social enterprises, ensuring the economic benefits of the transition are shared locally.

sector: Our organization is dedicated to addressing the challenges within climate change mitigation, biodiversity conservation, awareness, human rights advocacy and humanitarian awareness.
geography: The geographical focus for the Mary Robinson Climate and Nature conference is a generalized one of all of Ireland and the EU.
response_text: Ireland’s Presidency should adopt the MRCANC model of immersive, local storytelling: “The Presidency in Your Place” Tour: Host Council informal meetings or citizen dialogues not in capital cities, but in communities on the frontlines of transition (e.g., the Midlands, coastal areas). Pair them with visits to local projects like the Oweninny Wind Farm. Interwoven Stories Campaign: Use digital media to tell human-centred stories that weave together an EU policy (e.g., the Nature Restoration Law) with a local community project (e.g., a Mayo wetland restoration), showing the direct connection. Youth Climate Delegation: Appoint a youth advisory group from across the EU to shadow the Presidency, providing formal input at key moments and reporting directly to the public via social media. Lead with Ethical Narrative: Consistently use the language of justice, fairness, and intergenerational responsibility in all Presidency communications, framing technical negotiations as moral imperatives.

sector: Our organization is dedicated to addressing the challenges within climate change mitigation, biodiversity conservation, awareness, human rights advocacy and humanitarian awareness.
geography: The geographical focus for the Mary Robinson Climate and Nature conference is a generalized one of all of Ireland and the EU.
response_text: The MRCANC model demonstrates that effective climate action is interwoven, inclusive, and community-grounded. We urge the Irish Presidency to embody this ethos institutionally by: Establishing a Presidency Advisory Group on Climate Justice and Community Resilience, comprising civil society, youth, and front-line community representatives. Applying an “Interwoven Impact Assessment” to major Presidency files, evaluating them not just economically, but for their impacts on social cohesion, biodiversity, and intergenerational equity. Ensuring all Presidency-hosted events follow best-practice accessibility and sustainability guidelines (plant-based catering, sensory-friendly spaces), leading by example. Ireland’s unique credibility as a champion of justice and multilateralism positions it to chair not just with efficiency, but with moral authority. The success of the 2026 Presidency should be judged by whether it made the EU’s work more just, more connected to its citizens, and more effective for the planet.

Ireland has successfully positioned itself as a digital capital of the EU. Its upcoming Presidency of the Council of the EU presents a timely opportunity to champion accelerating the adoption of technologies like Artificial Intelligence (AI), to strengthen Irish and EU competitiveness as well as the productivity of enterprises and the public sector across the region. Identifying ways in which the EU can support and boost the adoption of digital and AI technologies across Europe should be a central pillar of the Irish Presidency. This priority is already embedded in both EU and Irish national policy, yet 2025 data shows the EU remains far from reaching its 2030 Digital Decade targets for technology uptake. Recent initiatives such as the EU Apply AI Strategy, which introduces an “AI-first” approach across organisations and public administrations, are important steps. The Irish Presidency can play a pivotal role in sustaining this momentum. Salesforce provided recommendations for boosting AI adoption in Europe in its response to the EU Public Consultation on this initiative. Benefits of Prioritising AI Policy Salesforce supports the EU’s goal to lead in responsible and trusted AI innovation and accelerate AI adoption. Across key industries, from manufacturing to pharmaceuticals, latest innovations such as AI agents are enabling optimisation of production and productivity gains, making European enterprises more innovative and competitive. The societal benefits are equally significant. AI is enhancing customer service, making public services more responsive and strengthening cybersecurity. Ireland’s national commitment to delivering more efficient and user-friendly digital public services already positions AI as a key driver of more accessible and citizen-centric services. AI is also leveling the playing field for SMEs, the backbone of the Irish and European economy. Our latest global research showed that a key strategy for SMEs to level the playing field against larger competitors and drive their growth is ramping up their tech investments. 75% of SMEs are already investing in AI and experiencing tangible returns, including increased productivity, improved customer experiences, and revenue growth. Yet many SMEs remain overwhelmed by the pace of technological change and face barriers such as data quality, skills gaps, and security concerns. The Irish Presidency can create a strong EU-focus on enabling secure, trustworthy AI adoption to ensure SMEs can fully benefit. It can approach this in a number of ways for example: set up an SME Taskforce to identify barriers and potential measures to encourage the safe and responsible adoption across the sector. It could also run a short, targeted campaign that outlines the benefits for SMEs, which then builds confidence across the sector. Given Ireland is a major European technology hub, it is uniquely positioned to lead this agenda. It should continue to champion the EU’s work toward global alignment with partners, including the establishment of globally interoperable AI governance frameworks, by actively supporting EU engagement in the G7, the OECD, and other international fora. For these reasons, we recommend that Accelerating AI and digital technology adoption to strengthen EU competitiveness, productivity, and public-sector effectiveness be selected as a core thematic priority for Ireland’s 2026 Presidency of the Council.

We believe the Irish Presidency should prioritise the following policy areas and legislative files during its term: Accelerating AI and broader technology adoption As outlined in our response to Question 1, accelerating AI deployment across the EU economy and public sector should be a core focus of the Irish Presidency. Ireland’s position as a leading European technology hub gives it a unique role in steering Council discussions toward practical measures that enhance adoption, foster innovation, and ensure the benefits of AI are accessible across sectors and Member States. Advancing the EU’s agenda on simplifying digital rules The EU’s ambition to be a global digital leader is hindered by an increasingly fragmented and overlapping regulatory landscape. Ireland’s recent policy paper ‘Ireland’s Priorities for Digital Simplification’ sets out proposals to reduce regulatory complexity, improve coherence across digital legislation and support innovation and competitiveness in the Single Market. These policies can be advanced by Ireland, through its presidency. Despite strong research and innovation capacity, Europe has faced challenges translating these strengths into global competitiveness, particularly in advanced technologies such as AI. To unlock the full potential of the Digital Single Market, the EU must move toward a simpler, more coherent, and more predictable digital regulatory framework. In this context, Salesforce welcomes the European Union’s focus on simplification and its commitment to building a more coherent and consistent legislative framework for digital policy, including through the recently presented Digital Omnibus proposals. These initiatives offer a concrete opportunity to streamline rules, reduce legal uncertainty, and facilitate responsible technology deployment across the EU. We encourage the Irish Presidency to prioritise progress on these files within the Council to support timely adoption and ensure businesses can benefit from a clearer and more enabling regulatory environment. Salesforce provided concrete suggestions and recommendations ahead of the presentation of the Digital Omnibus and remains committed to continuing engaging with policymakers throughout the legislative process. We also encourage Ireland to support and actively contribute to the Digital Fitness Check the European Commission is expected to conduct in 2026. This will be an essential mechanism to evaluate the cumulative impact of digital legislation, assess interoperability between regulatory instruments, and ensure Europe’s digital rules effectively contribute to competitiveness and innovation. 3. Strengthening international collaboration In line with the EU’s 2025 International Digital Strategy, Salesforce supports the EU’s commitment to working closely with global partners to strengthen Europe’s competitiveness. We believe the Irish Presidency has a key role to play in fostering relationships with third countries. In this context, we welcome the remarks made by the Minister of State for Trade Promotion, AI and Digital Transformation, Niamh Smyth, during the signing ceremony of the Declaration for European Digital Sovereignty, where she reiterated the importance of pursuing digital sovereignty in an open and collaborative manner. We urge the Presidency to continue advancing this approach, which, as Minister Smyth noted, “makes the EU stronger in the long run.”

across the EU? The Irish Presidency has an opportunity to deliver substantial, tangible benefits for people, businesses and communities across the EU by placing a strong focus on digital transformation and regulatory simplification—two areas that directly affect citizens’ daily lives and the competitiveness of European enterprises. Supporting the digitalisation of organisations, including the public sector Building on the themes outlined in our previous answers, advancing the digital transformation of Europe’s economy and public administrations would have immediate and widespread impact across the 27 Member States. Encouraging the adoption of trustworthy and innovative technologies, particularly AI, can increase productivity for businesses of all sizes, support job creation, and help workers focus on higher-value, more meaningful tasks. In the public sector, accelerating the deployment of modern digital tools can significantly improve the quality, speed, and accessibility of public services. One such example of these opportunities is healthcare, as seen here in Ireland with the ongoing rollout of a national electronic health record (EHR) aimed to deliver faster diagnostics, better-coordinated care, and more seamless patient experiences. Technologies such as agentic AI can help public administrations reduce backlogs, simplify administrative processes, and respond more effectively to the needs of citizens. For communities, this translates into quicker access to essential services, more personalised interactions with public bodies, and a more efficient use of public resources. Advancing the EU agenda on simplifying digital rules A clearer, more coherent digital regulatory framework would directly benefit EU citizens and organisations by reducing administrative burdens, improving legal certainty, and enabling faster innovation. Simplification supports SMEs in particular - helping them adopt new technologies more easily and compete more effectively - while also empowering consumers by ensuring that rules governing digital services are understandable, consistent, and future-proof. By prioritising progress on initiatives such as the Digital Omnibus proposals and actively contributing to the 2026 Digital Fitness Check, the Irish Presidency can help create a regulatory environment that better supports economic growth, innovation, and consumer trust.

We recognise the importance of this question and the broader benefits of EU membership. In this context, we believe that one effective way to communicate the value of EU membership - and to foster a greater sense of citizen ownership over Ireland’s Presidency - is to ground the Presidency’s programme in initiatives that deliver clear, tangible benefits for Irish citizens and enterprises. This includes focusing on initiatives that can boost the adoption of trusted, innovative technologies that improve daily life, enhance public services, and strengthen the competitiveness of Irish businesses. Demonstrating how EU-level cooperation directly enables such positive outcomes can help make the work of the Presidency more visible, relevant, and meaningful to EU citizens.

As the European home to the world’s leading technology companies, Ireland is its operational heartbeat within the EU. This proximity between policymakers, regulators, and industry provides Ireland with a distinct comparative advantage. Ireland should leverage this feedback loop to champion pragmatic policymaking that balances robust regulation with the imperative for European competitiveness.

sector: Promotion of fair, balanced, transparent and efficient civil justice laws
geography: EJF is a Belgium-registered, European organization that engages in an open and constructive dialogue with opinion leaders in EU Institutions, national Governments and other relevant stakeholders. EJF develops position papers and other outreach materials, organizes expert debates and participates in thought-leadership events.
response_text: Europe must be able to protect and defend its industries, consumers, enterprises, SMEs and innovative startups. The 2026 Commission Work Programme (Point 2: Sustainable Prosperity and Competitiveness) maintains its emphasis on unlocking the full potential of the Single Market by 2028 and on strengthening support mechanisms for SMEs, innovative companies, enterprises and startups. Reducing regulatory fragmentation among Member States in the area of Third-Party Litigation Funding (TPLF) would significantly enhance the EU’s competitiveness and economic security. Most importantly, harmonizing the EU’s TPLF regulatory framework would safeguard industry, consumers, enterprises, and startups from the financial and reputational harm of profit-driven mass litigation including unfounded claims and from the use of TPLF by non-EU organisations to obtain unfair competitive advantages. If civil litigation remains funded by unregulated private third parties, EJF expects a significant growth in profit-driven litigation in the EU, which would undermine public confidence in the European justice systems at a time when maintaining faith in our democratic institutions is so critical.

sector: Promotion of fair, balanced, transparent and efficient civil justice laws
geography: EJF is a Belgium-registered, European organization that engages in an open and constructive dialogue with opinion leaders in EU Institutions, national Governments and other relevant stakeholders. EJF develops position papers and other outreach materials, organizes expert debates and participates in thought-leadership events.
response_text: Regulation of Third-Party Litigation Funding (TPLF) should build on the European Parliament’s resolution adopted in September 2022, the Commission’s mapping study in which 58% of respondents were in favour of TPLF regulation, and the Commissioner for Justice’s stated commitment to act. Divergent and opaque national rules on TPLF - further fragmented through the implementation of the Representative Actions Directive - create legal uncertainty and distort competition, undermine effective enforcement and trigger forum shopping. Ireland can steer Council discussions toward a Minimum Harmonisation Directive and Recommendation focused on transparency, independence of litigation conduct, conflict-of-interest safeguards and proportionate financial soundness rules. It should also promote evidence-generation tools—including annual reporting and an EU-level register—and explore proportionate oversight options leveraging existing EU networks. By anchoring TPLF in fairness, transparency and consumer protection, the Irish Presidency can enhance the effective delivery of justice and strengthen the EU’s economic competitiveness. Third-party litigation funders currently operate in the EU in a regulatory vacuum and without any transparency requirements. This lack of oversight is in stark contrast with other related sectors, such as legal and financial services that are highly regulated. Due to its clear position that prohibits TPLF under its own laws, Ireland is uniquely placed to explain the benefits for consumers and for businesses of regulating TPLF and of preventing the spread of privatized enforcement through profit-driven mass litigation and to put forward the regulation of TPLF at EU level.

sector: Promotion of fair, balanced, transparent and efficient civil justice laws
geography: EJF is a Belgium-registered, European organization that engages in an open and constructive dialogue with opinion leaders in EU Institutions, national Governments and other relevant stakeholders. EJF develops position papers and other outreach materials, organizes expert debates and participates in thought-leadership events.
response_text: A central contribution the Council can make under the Irish Presidency is reducing fragmentation among Member States in areas that directly influence legal certainty, cross-border cooperation, and business confidence. The overarching objective must be to promote civil justice systems that are fair, balanced, and effective—ensuring that consumers with legitimate grievances are compensated, while also recognizing that access to justice can depend on financial resources. The EU Directive on Representative Actions (RAD) introduces the role of funders in disputes, however still provides incomplete regulation on litigation funding from our perspective, that means not across all mass claim measures and without adequate safeguards. The ECIPE Paper – ‘The Impact of Increased Mass Litigation in Europe’ 03/2025 well summarizes that while minimum standards have been implemented into the RAD, it allowed nonharmonized rules to persist. The different implementations of the RAD indeed led to an increased patchwork across the Members States, beside other mass claim measures still exist in parallel. The potential for forum shopping therefore expands, as some EU countries adopt a more permissive approach to mass litigation. Our experience from other jurisdictions demonstrates that without adequate safeguards, incl. supervision, private funders’ commercial interests may diverge from, or even conflict with, those of claimants. This misalignment can compromise fairness, inflate costs, and incentivize unmeritorious claims. This misalignment can compromise fairness, inflate costs, and incentivise unmeritorious claims. The introduction of a purely profit-motivated third party, often non-EU based, into the traditional lawyer-client relationship, raises serious ethical concerns and presents an economic security threat for Europe. Given that litigation funding is rapidly becoming part of mainstream litigation culture in Europe, harmonising TPLF frameworks at the EU level has become increasingly necessary. Doing so would help prevent abusive practices, protect consumers and enterprises from undue risks, and ensure that TPLF serves its intended purpose: facilitating legitimate access to justice rather than promoting profitdriven and unethical litigation strategies.

sector: Promotion of fair, balanced, transparent and efficient civil justice laws
geography: EJF is a Belgium-registered, European organization that engages in an open and constructive dialogue with opinion leaders in EU Institutions, national Governments and other relevant stakeholders. EJF develops position papers and other outreach materials, organizes expert debates and participates in thought-leadership events.
response_text: A meaningful communication strategy for Ireland’s Presidency of the Council of the EU must focus on demonstrating, in concrete and relatable ways, how EU membership delivers tangible benefits to citizens, businesses, and communities. To create a genuine sense of ownership among citizens, communication should be transparent, accessible, and centred on real outcomes that improve daily life. It is essential to highlight how EU membership strengthens economic opportunity, protects consumers, and supports the competitiveness of Irish and European enterprises, SMEs, and innovative startups. Demonstrating progress on issues such as reducing administrative burdens, improving cross-border cooperation, and building fair and effective civil justice systems including by regulation of TPLF would help citizens understand how EU-level action directly contributes to a more secure, prosperous, and predictable legal environment and reinforce the rule of law in the EU.

Delivering on the twin transition for European competitiveness Ireland’s EU Presidency is an opportunity to position the delivery of the twin green and digital transition as a central strategic priority for the European Union. Progress on delivery is essential not only for climate objectives, but for energy security, economic competitiveness, and the resilience of Europe’s industrial base. Fostering sustainable innovation will be key to delivering on this priority, accelerating the deployment of renewable energy sources, electrification of transport and heating, and the adoption of smart technologies that optimise energy use and reduce waste. By promoting digital solutions such as smart grids, IoT-enabled infrastructure, and data-driven energy management, the EU can deliver cleaner, more affordable energy while enhancing resilience. Building a resilient, secure competitive future The EU’s economy depends increasingly on the resilience of its foundational infrastructure, notably energy systems, housing, water services, transport and digital networks and AI. These underpin industrial competitiveness, social wellbeing and economic security. Ireland’s EU Presidency should advance a European agenda that strengthens infrastructure and renewal to support secure, affordable and sustainable growth. It should emphasise modern, interconnected and resilient energy infrastructure, including electricity grids and storage, as a foundation for clean industrial growth, system stability and consumer protection. Improving energy efficiency and resource productivity across buildings and public infrastructure will also be central to strengthening Europe’s long-term competitiveness and economic security. By prioritising affordability and sustainability, these measures will reduce costs for households and enterprises while safeguarding supply security. The message: a Europe built to last, where infrastructure underpins prosperity and resilience for all communities. Putting European citizens at the heart of our competitiveness Europe’s long-term competitiveness and economic security depend on its people. As the EU delivers the green and digital transitions, ensuring that citizens are equipped to participate in and benefit from economic transformation will be central to sustaining growth, social cohesion and democratic resilience. Ireland’s EU Presidency has a crucial role to play ensuring a Just Transition - advancing a European agenda that strengthens skills, workforce adaptation and access to opportunity across all regions. Priority could be given to education, reskilling and lifelong learning aligned with clean energy, digital technologies and the circular economy, alongside measures that support workforce mobility and regional innovation. By placing citizens at the centre of Europe’s competitiveness strategy, the transition becomes a foundation for inclusive growth, social stability and shared prosperity. A competitive Europe must also be a Europe that works for its people.

Electrification and energy efficiency Electrification is the cornerstone of Europe’s strategy to exit the energy trilemma of affordability, security, and decarbonisation. Ireland’s EU Presidency presents a vital moment to deliver on the aims of the EU Commission’s work programme, which commits to ensuring a genuine Energy Union by upgrading grids, removing bottlenecks, cutting red tape for cross-border energy projects, and boosting electrification and the resilience of the electricity system. The forthcoming reviews of the Energy Efficiency Directive (EED) and the Renewable Energy Directive (RED) represent a pivotal opportunity to accelerate delivery. The Irish Presidency will play a central role in launching and shaping these negotiations and setting the direction for the next phase of EU electrification. Key policy priorities should include Ensuring a level-playing field for electricity: reform energy taxation, deploy tripartite contracts for electrification and energy efficiency, expand PPAs, CfDs, and state guarantees to secure affordable, clean electricity. Support electrification in key sectors: Buildings: Ensure, under existing frameworks, heat pump deployment and digital building management. Retrofit programmes should integrate smart controls and demand-response capabilities - directly supporting the goals of EU’s Affordable Housing Action Plan Transport: Driving effective implementation of Alternative Fuels Infrastructure and electricity market legislation Industry: Promote and incentivise direct electrification of heat and motion Taken together, these measures could deliver on the Affordable Energy Action Plan and the EU’s Green Deal objectives, ensuring competitiveness while reducing fossil fuel dependency by up to one-third by 2030 and structurally lowering energy prices through efficiency, flexibility, and digital control. Grid modernisation and infrastructure planning The European Grids Package is pivotal to unlocking electrification at scale. Ireland should prioritise accelerated permitting for transmission and distribution upgrades, anticipatory investments, and regional coordination through ENTSO-E. Beyond physical expansion, non-wire alternative could be prioritised. As negotiations on the next Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) and the European Competitiveness Fund (ECF) are expected to reach a decisive phase during the Irish Presidency, Ireland is well positioned to ensure that funding for smart grids, digital water systems, and building automation is earmarked. Embedding efficiency tests and digitalisation requirements would ensure value for money Ireland can bring its bold approach to infrastructure reform at home to Europe, addressing the persistent bottlenecks in planning and permitting undermine Europe’s competitiveness. Digital infrastructure and AI sustainability Without intervention, European data centre power demand could result in grid bottlenecks and a slowdown of electrification as well as increased emissions. The Irish Presidency could lead on maximising sustainability vis-à-vis AI Act implementation and data centre permitting rules. EU-UK relations The Irish Presidency is uniquely well placed to lead constructive dialogue on EU–UK cooperation as a strategic enabler of Europe’s green transition, competitiveness, and resilience, particularly if a UK–EU leaders summit falls within the Presidency period. This builds on the European Commission Work Plan, which seeks to harness partnerships to deliver on energy. Ireland could Advance Council conclusions on energy cooperation, facilitate trade and industrial collaboration and enable workforce mobility and skills for infrastructure through targeted mobility schemes.

Lowering energy costs and enhancing security Efficiency-first policies are central to Europe’s energy transition because they reduce consumption while maintaining performance. The European Commission estimates that without past efficiency gains, EU energy use in 2022 would have been 27% higher, equivalent to the combined annual energy consumption of France, the Netherlands, Austria, and Finland. Improving efficiency cuts fossil fuel imports by €33 billion annually by 2030 and delivers up to 40% of required CO₂ reductions. The Council Presidency is a key opportunity to prioritise accelerating implementation of the Affordable Energy Action Plan and the Clean Industrial Deal through: Fast-tracking grid and flexibility legislation under the European Grids Package to enable dynamic load management and reduce peak demand, lowering costs for households and SMEs. Making electricity competitive by guiding the revision of the Energy Taxation Directive (ETD) Driving reforms to electricity market design to decouple retail prices from volatile gas costs and promote long-term contracts for renewables, ensuring predictable and affordable energy. Ensuring adequate incentives are available for industries and SMEs, including dynamic pricing and flexible connection agreements. Strengthening energy security by coordinating gas storage rules and diversification measures, building on Council agreements to safeguard winter supply and phase out Russian imports. These steps will help shield citizens from energy poverty (affecting over 46 million Europeans) and restore competitiveness by reducing industrial electricity costs, which remain 2-3 times higher than in the US and China. Creating jobs and industrial renewal The twin transition is an engine of job creation. The Clean Industrial Deal mobilises over €100 billion to support EU-made clean manufacturing and electrification, with sustainability criteria in public procurement to boost demand for European technologies. Priority actions include: Scaling heat pump, rooftop PV, and building management system deployment, which studies show could generate up to 1 million installation and maintenance jobs across the EU - roles that cannot be offshored. Embedding sustainability in procurement frameworks, as recommended by Mario Draghi’s competitiveness report, to stimulate local supply chains and SMEs. Supporting workforce reskilling for green and digital transitions, leveraging Council conclusions on industrial policy and tax incentives for clean technologies. This approach aligns with the EU’s industrial strategy to strengthen resilience, reduce dependencies, and create high-quality jobs in sectors critical for the green transition. Boosting competitiveness European industries face structural disadvantages due to high energy costs and global competition. The Irish Presidency can help embed competitiveness into EU legislation by: Advancing the Electrification Act and Clean Industrial Deal measures Promoting digitalisation and AI-driven optimisation in industrial processes Driving investment frameworks under InvestEU and the proposed Industrial Decarbonisation Bank to de-risk clean energy projects and accelerate innovation. By embedding these principles in Council conclusions and legislative negotiations, Ireland can help position Europe as a global leader in clean, competitive manufacturing.

Citizen-centric narrative The starting point is a clear, relatable message. Ireland’s Presidency should use its overarching slogan and priority themes to translate EU policies into tangible benefits for everyday life: lower energy bills, cleaner air, and digital opportunities for all. Rather than abstract references to treaties or governance, communication should focus on how EU initiatives - such as the Electrification Action Plan and European Grids Package - enable practical improvements: affordable energy, modern infrastructure, and green jobs. Storytelling should highlight real examples, like families saving on heating costs through retrofits or communities benefiting from local renewable projects. This approach frames EU membership as a driver of prosperity and sustainability, reinforcing trust and relevance. Engage through local platforms Ownership grows when citizens see themselves in the process. Regional forums, town halls, and pop-up “EU in Your Community” events can showcase success stories such as community solar schemes, smart homes, and EV charging hubs. These events should be interactive, e.g., using live demonstrations of energy-saving technologies and digital tools, to make the EU’s climate and digital ambitions tangible. Collaboration with Member States, local authorities and civil society will ensure inclusivity, reaching rural areas and underrepresented groups. Digital town halls can complement physical events, enabling broad participation and dialogue. Partnerships with education and industry Schools and universities are critical multipliers for EU values. Educational programmes can link Presidency themes to curricula, offering workshops on sustainability, energy, AI, and digital careers. Competitions for students, such as designing “smart cities of the future”, can spark creativity and ownership. Similarly, partnerships with SMEs and industry associations can showcase pathways to green jobs and digital innovation, reinforcing the message that EU membership drives competitiveness and opportunity. These collaborations should be highlighted through case studies and media campaigns, demonstrating how EU policies translate into local economic growth. Inclusive and transparent communication Transparency is key. Regular progress reports, accessible summaries of Council decisions, and clear timelines for Presidency initiatives should be published in plain language. By combining local engagement, digital innovation, and educational outreach, Ireland can transform its Presidency into a shared European project - one where citizens feel informed, involved, and empowered.

sector: Global health, women’s rights and empowerment
response_text: In the current geopolitical context, it will be very important that Ireland’s Presidency set an example and position gender equity and inclusion as a central thematic priority. It should focus on inequalities in health and healthcare leadership affecting women and minority groups, especially also migrant women. Ireland should emphasize the right to the highest attainable standard of health as a fundamental human right for all, building on its tradition of human rights leadership and global health action. This will also help Ireland in its ambition to be elected into the UN Human Rights Council and its role in promoting inclusive, rights-based EU policies.

sector: Global health, women’s rights and empowerment
response_text: The Irish Presidency should prioritise proposals that strengthen gender equality in health systems and support diversity in healthcare leadership and governance. This means also to focus on universal, inclusive and affordable access to healthcare for all, especially women, migrants and other underserved groups. The Irish Presidency should aim to reduce health disparities of women and marginalized communities, among them women with migration background. Ireland should stress implementation and measurable progress across Member States in order to ensure some lasting impact. This requires political alignment and legislative action that ensure gender equality and diversity in health care governance.

sector: Global health, women’s rights and empowerment
response_text: It is important that Ireland considered its role and impact it can have on the MFF negotiations and advocate for gender equity and social inclusion of marginalized communities as core principles of EU funding. It also means to ensure that rights-based investment in health, social protection and community resilience are made. The protection and advancement of human rights are hugely important in the currently so rapidly changing global context. Therefore, health cannot act in a silo but need to be linked to equitable policies that ensure economic stability, climate justice and human rights.

sector: Global health, women’s rights and empowerment
response_text: Women in Global Health Switzerland is very concerned about the current rollback in women’s health and rights. Therefore, it is important that Ireland shows leadership on gender equity and inclusion. It should promote the systematic involved of civil society in the policy making processes during its Presidency, in particular by reaching out to women’s rights organizations, migrant communities and networks, LBTIQ+ groups, and patient groups. Enabling a co-creation process, regular consultations and ongoing monitoring will be essential in order to communicate the values and benefits of the EU membership to its citizens but also to create ownership among them. Inclusive participation is built on trust and democratic engagement and dialogue with civil society.

sector: Global health, women’s rights and empowerment
response_text: As participant of the Conference organized by the Irish Global Health Network IGHNxEU – Empowering Women for a Healthier Europe, I would like to submit the following document to which I have contributed in support to my submission: https://globalhealth.ie/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/IGHNEIWH-Policy-Brief-FINAL_TOC-Dec-9.pdf Thank you for considering and good luck in all the preparations, looking forward to further engagement.

sector: Human rights, social cohesion, youth engagement, anti-racism, agri-food systems, global governance, Africa-Europe relations
response_text: In the year and a half since the adoption of the The 2024–2029 EU Strategic Agenda, the global political landscape has evolved rapidly, marked by rising instability and emerging challenges. Throughout its Presidency’s term, Ireland will guide the work of the Member States in strengthening the EU’s capacity to act in this increasingly complex environment. While a wide range of priorities could be pursued, we highlight the following three high-level thematic areas for Ireland’s Council Presidency term, as they have enduring relevance and could benefit from focused dialogue and consideration among Member States. Shaping Europe Through the Essential Role of Youth Europe is a rapidly aging continent. Beyond the demographic implications of this challenge, having youth as meaningful protagonists of their social environments will require their participation in processes and spaces through which consequential decisions are made, particularly those that shape policy. The Irish Presidency should place youth policies at the heart of its agenda. Fostering a culture in which youth feel their voices are heard and opinions valued will need to go beyond establishing formal mechanisms for youth participation. It will require cultivating a structure that embraces openness and humility toward the creative and sometimes challenging insights young people bring to policy discussions. If youth are given such creative space, they will not only contribute to existing policy processes, but can bring fresh ideas to help rethink and reshape current social structures. In this respect, young people should not be regarded merely as inheritors of existing social systems. Overcoming Racism and Advancing Social Cohesion Considering Ireland’s longstanding role in advancing equality and social cohesion, the Council could prioritize anti-racism and social cohesion during its presidency. Without recognizing that humanity is indivisible, arbitrary divisions—of “us” versus “them”—will continue to fragment European society. Efforts to eradicate racism must be transformative, fostering an understanding that there is only an “us.” A European Union that truly values “unity in diversity” is not about mere coexistence or asking certain groups to fit an existing framework. Instead, it fosters joint conversations among populations from different backgrounds, harnessing their contributions to co-create something new. The presidency should host dialogues that foster this understanding and initiate legislative action that is binding and consequential for all member states. Promoting Just, Sustainable, and Secure Food Systems Considering Ireland’s strong connection to agriculture, we believe it is imperative to uphold a just, sustainable and resilient food system that supports the needs and well-being of all. In this context, the Presidency should ensure that any legislation relating to agricultural trade enables trade to be conducted fairly and to the benefit of all, without causing any country or region, within or beyond the EU, to become overly dependent on another, or exploited for the advantage of the other. Furthermore, the Presidency’s priorities should allow for every country—not only those privileged in the existing economic order—to work towards food sovereignty, strengthen resilience to ecological, economic, and other pressures, and maintain the ability to make independent decisions.

sector: Human rights, social cohesion, youth engagement, anti-racism, agri-food systems, global governance, Africa-Europe relations
response_text: In relation to the above high-level strategic priorities we suggest work on the following policy areas: Shaping Europe Through the Essential Role of Youth The Education, Youth, Culture and Sport Council (EYCS) could place greater emphasis on the pivotal role of young people as drivers of social progress by promoting sustained deliberations on expanding their participation in decision-making processes and harnessing their capacity to reimagine and shape society. In line with the forthcoming EU Youth Strategy, the Irish Presidency could help advance conversations on a bold, comprehensive, and binding framework for youth engagement across all member states. This could include a white paper on youth, outlining measures to implement coordinated approaches across member states, regions, and cities, ensuring that young people at the local level are actively involved in addressing societal challenges and contributing to policy development. Furthermore, realizing the potential of young people as agents of change requires access to empowering educational experiences. Within the context of the European Education Area, the Irish Presidency could promote a vision of education that extends beyond preparing youth for the labor market. Education should be recognized as a tool to inspire young people to develop their talents and capabilities for personal growth and societal progress, fostering critical thinking, social awareness, and moral and civic responsibility. Overcoming Racism and Advancing Social Cohesion The Irish Presidency could, through the deliberations of the Employment, Social Policy, Health, and Consumer Affairs Council (EPSCO), reinvigorate progress on the Equal Treatment Directive, fostering consensus for binding legislation aimed at combating discrimination across all EU member states. Beyond addressing discrimination, the Directive could be strengthened to encompass measures that promote social cohesion and inclusion at every level of society, ensuring that equality is not only a legal principle but also a practical reality. By encouraging coordinated policies and sharing best practices, the Presidency can help create a more inclusive European Union, where diversity is respected, equal opportunities are guaranteed, and social solidarity is reinforced across communities. Promoting Just, Sustainable, and Secure Food Systems The Agriculture and Fisheries Council (AGRIFISH) will consider how to implement the post-2027 CAP Strategic Plans, alongside priorities such as farm income, competitiveness, climate adaptation, simplification, and food security.The Irish Presidency could ensure that post-CAP plans reflect that no region should be exploited for another’s advantage, adopting new practices and economic models for production, consumption, distribution, and trade. Food systems should uphold justice and reflect humanity’s interconnection, with agricultural trade conducted fairly and without creating excessive dependency. EU policies should enable all countries to pursue food sovereignty, strengthen resilience to ecological, economic, or other pressures, and maintain independent decision-making. Given the central role of farming in Irish society, the Presidency could also explore how the CAP supports educational initiatives for young people. Encouraging youth to engage sustainably in agriculture is essential to foster a new generation of farmers who can apply their skills to develop context-appropriate technologies, support communities, and enhance food security in an economically viable and environmentally just way.

sector: Human rights, social cohesion, youth engagement, anti-racism, agri-food systems, global governance, Africa-Europe relations
response_text: The Irish Presidency could maximize its impact by embedding consultative frameworks across all strategic priorities, fostering meaningful engagement between social actors at multiple levels, particularly at the grassroots during the period of the Presidency. By expanding and sustaining these spaces for dialogue—bringing together local communities, municipalities, and EU staff working on relevant dossiers—the Presidency can ensure that regional and EU-level policies are informed by the lived realities of citizens. This approach not only enhances the relevance and effectiveness of policies but also strengthens the process of reading of the social reality and increases trust and cohesion between institutions and the people they serve. More fundamentally, reorienting relationships between institutions and grassroots actors toward a mutually supportive model can unlock the vast reservoir of creativity, expertise, and constructive capacity that exists across individuals and communities throughout Europe.

sector: Human rights, social cohesion, youth engagement, anti-racism, agri-food systems, global governance, Africa-Europe relations
response_text: The Irish Presidency has the opportunity to show that EU membership is not merely a political or economic arrangement, but a framework enabling Europe to act collectively on shared challenges, both within the continent and globally. Framing EU action as a way to promote not only European prosperity but also the wellbeing of all of humanity makes Europe’s purpose tangible and meaningful, especially at a time when citizens are increasingly aware of and concerned about the suffering and challenges faced by people all around the world. By strengthening consultative frameworks that bring together local communities, municipalities, civil society, and EU institutions, the Presidency can ensure that EU policies respond to the lived realities of people on the ground. Grassroots engagement—through public consultations, town halls, digital plaqorms, and participatory initiatives—can foster a sense of shared responsibility, demonstrating how citizens’ voices shape Europe’s agenda. Communicating the Presidency’s work in this way underscores the principle that Europe’s strength, security, and prosperity are inseparable from the wellbeing of the wider world. Citizens are not only informed about the benefits of EU membership but are empowered to feel personally connected to, and invested in, the Presidency’s work—recognizing that Europe’s mission is inseparable from humanity’s collective future.

sector: Human rights, social cohesion, youth engagement, anti-racism, agri-food systems, global governance, Africa-Europe relations
response_text: N/A

sector: Multiple sectors/industries across the public, private and community sectors.
response_text: SIPTU believes that Quality Jobs must be a central and explicit thematic priority for Ireland’s EU Presidency. For workers across Ireland and Europe, delivering decent pay, secure work, strong collective bargaining, and fair conditions is essential to building a competitive and sustainable European economy. Our recommendation is strongly supported by existing EU commitments: The Strategic Agenda 2024–2029, endorsed by the Taoiseach and EU leaders, commits the European Union to creating good jobs. President von der Leyen’s Political Priorities for the 2024–2029 Commission included a Quality Jobs Roadmap to support fair wages, good working conditions, training, fair transitions, and -crucially- increased collective bargaining coverage. Published in early December 2025, the Quality Jobs Roadmap contains a strong commitment to improving job quality and creating high-quality and future-proof jobs in Europe. The forthcoming Quality Jobs Act should ensure workers’ rights while keeping the EU up with technological, climatic and societal changes. The Joint Declaration on the EU Legislative Priorities for 2025 emphasises that promoting quality jobs is essential to Europe’s sustainable prosperity and competitiveness. The Danish Presidency Programme commits to active engagement with the Commission’s Quality Jobs Roadmap. The (draft) Cypriot Presidency Programme also commits to advancing policies that promote quality employment. In addition, all European social partners—ETUC, BusinessEurope, SMEUnited—together with the institutions, have recognised in the Val Duchesse Tripartite Declaration (31 January 2024) that Europe’s long-term competitiveness must go hand in hand with quality jobs. SIPTU, as part of the ICTU and the ETUC, fully supports this shared position. Prioritising Quality Jobs during Ireland’s Presidency would help drive progress on initiatives that are of direct value to all Member States and build on the ongoing work of the Council. It would also align with the Commission’s forthcoming legislation: with the Quality Jobs Act expected in late 2026 during the Irish Presidency. Ireland can and should play a lead role in this initiative. Quality jobs will also form a key component of several dossiers that will be active during the Irish Presidency, including: the new Action Plan for the European Pillar of Social Rights, the EU Anti-Poverty Strategy, the Gender Equality Strategy 2026–2030 the Fair Labour Mobility Package Finally, the Government has already signalled its support. In his address to Eurofound’s Foundation Forum on 20 November 2025, the Taoiseach welcomed the Commission’s Quality Jobs Roadmap and described it as setting “an ambitious employment agenda for the EU to remain competitive, innovative and fair, and create a level playing field that prioritises high standards for quality jobs.” Roxana Mînzatu, Executive Vice-President for Social Rights and Skills, Quality Jobs and Preparedness also addressed the event in Dublin. Given this clear national and European alignment, SIPTU believes it is both logical and necessary for Ireland to make Quality Jobs a flagship priority of its Presidency in 2026 thereby delivering tangible improvements for workers in Ireland and across Europe.

sector: Multiple sectors/industries across the public, private and community sectors.
response_text: The Irish Presidency could best communicate the values and benefits of EU membership and create a sense of ownership over Ireland’s Presidency by strengthening and developing the EU’s framework on social dialogue and collective bargaining, for workers in Ireland and across Europe, as recommended above. We recognise that the Irish Presidency will face an extremely busy agenda and a very heavy workload across a wide range of policy areas during its term. But we cannot over-emphasise the importance of the Irish Presidency addressing and being seen to address the main day-to-day cost of living challenges facing workers and their families, especially low pay, insecure work, exorbitant housing costs, rising energy prices, which were identified as the most important issues in Member States (including in Ireland), according to the most recent Eurobarometer survey (Standard Eurobarometer 103) carried out in Spring 2025. The European Council’s Strategic Agenda 2024-2029 committed to address the aspirations of citizens. The most effective way of Ireland doing this as far as workers are concerned would be by strengthening and developing the EU’s framework on social dialogue and collective bargaining and advancing the next steps recommended in the Quality Jobs Roadmap agenda during its Council Presidency.

response_text: As I write this, there is a large, organized attack online against the EU, focused on the idea of “Abolish the EU.” Our Union is starting to matter as a real and powerful economic block, let’s keep going. I would ask that we prepare specifically for the 1st high-level EU Housing Summit - October 20-21st 2026, it is just 312 days away, at the Convention Centre Dublin. A flagship part of our Presidency – Dan Jørgensen – the EU Commissioner for Energy and Housing has publicly asked for solutions on a better utilisation of Europe’s existing housing stock, it will be on stage there. At 67% under occupancy in Ireland compared to the EU average of 33% we really cannot afford not to be leading on this? Do we want an Irish example in Dublin?

geography: Our predominant focus is on the national context of disability rights policy; however, we have a community team who engage with the disability sector at regional level. Finally, we also follow all relevant updates at the EU level on this policy area in light of our membership of the EDF and EASPD.
response_text: Ireland’s Presidency of the EU presents a unique opportunity to demonstrate leadership on equality, inclusion, and human rights at a European level in line with the EU Strategic Agenda 2024-2029. Highlighting the value of a social and inclusive Europe. It will coincide domestically with the implementation of the National Human Rights Strategy for Disabled People (2025), offering a timely platform to show Ireland’s commitment to the UN CRPD in action. At a European level, initiatives and policy developments of significant during the Irish presidency, include the second phase of the European Disability Rights Strategy; implementation of the European Accessibility Act and policy focus on affordable housing, poverty reduction and climate change, offer an opportunity to strengthen disability mainstreaming. The EU must deliver on its commitments under the EU Pillar of Social Rights e.g. r Principle 17, with a new Action Plan to be adopted by the end of 2025, and ongoing commitments to the UN Sustainable Development Goals. Against this backdrop of human rights commitments seeking to leave no one behind, Ireland has the opportunity to support the EU’s progress towards becoming a true Union of Equality. However, this cannot be achieved without ensuring the rights of marginalised groups are respected and advanced. Considering the current political climate and advancing climate crisis, upholding human rights standards is more important than ever. Ireland can support the realignment of the EU with its core values outlined in its Strategic Agenda, notably: “respect for human rights (including the rights of persons belonging to minorities – which remain a cornerstone of our Union)”. We propose the following thematic priorities: The Advancement of Disability Rights – In light of Ireland’s recent publication of its Human Rights Strategy for Disabled People and the EU’s soon to be updated Disability Rights Strategy, ‘the advancement of disability rights across the Union’ should be prioritised. The Taoiseach has identified disability as a key government priority – and thus should be reflected in the Irish presidency. One in four adults in the EU live with a disability. Ireland can raise the visibility of the EU’s largest minority group, a group anyone can join at any point in their life. The Commission will update the EU Disability Rights Strategy 2021–2030 in the second quarter of 2026, making such a focus timely. Moreover, the EU Parliament Disability Rights Week, International Day of Persons with Disabilities, International Day of Sign Languages, and Human Rights Day fall within the Irish Presidency. In a world where respect for human dignity and rights is increasingly under attack, the EU is a vital guarantor to progress the full and equal participation of disabled people. Reinforce a Social Europe through inclusive growth that combats poverty and invests in society. DFI highly values being part of the EU project and supports its vision for a Social Europe. This involves advancing the 2030 Agenda that seeks to leave no one behind. Ireland should prioritise working to re-align the EU’s actions with its commitments under the UN SDGs, particularly on combatting poverty. The concept of leaving no one behind relates to the context in which we find ourselves – political unrest, war, climate crisis, and threat to democratic values. Ireland’s Presidency term will be timely, considering the lack of movement as planned during the Danish Presidency on key areas like the EU Equal Treatment Directive, Anti-Poverty Strategy, the Affordable Housing Plan, and the EU Pillar of Social Rights Action Plan. It is essential that the EU combats disability poverty - 28.7% of persons with disabilities are at risk of poverty and social exclusion in the EU, compared to 17.9% for persons without disabilities. Equally 11% of persons with disabilities in the EU report being overburdened by the cost of their housing, and only 28.9% consider their dwelling meets their needs.

geography: Our predominant focus is on the national context of disability rights policy; however, we have a community team who engage with the disability sector at regional level. Finally, we also follow all relevant updates at the EU level on this policy area in light of our membership of the EDF and EASPD.
response_text: EU Disability Rights Strategy: During Ireland’s Presidency, the new flagship initiatives under the Strategy should be adopted (planned for Q2 2026). Ambitious initiatives and concrete actions in line with EU Parliament recommendations, and the recent concluding observations of the UN CRPD Committee are necessary. Ireland can ensure that the flagships also align with the detailed recommendations of the European Disability Forum. A focus on addressing employment of disabled people can help to redeem Ireland’s poor reputation, with one of the worst disability employment gaps (38.2%). EU Equal Treatment Directive: Denmark, during its Presidency, aims to reach Council unanimity on the EU Equal Treatment Directive, however it is unlikely that this will be achieved. It is crucial that the EU adopts this Directive, which has been blocked for 17 years by some Member States. Given the current environment, this Directive should be prioritised – to reach Council unanimity, or if this has been achieved, to prioritise implementation. De-prioritisation would represent a backslide on equality and caving to anti-democratic actors. This Directive would prohibit both indirect and direct discrimination based on disability and would apply the principle of “equal treatment” on grounds including disability - across a wide range of areas. EU Pillar of Social Rights and new Action Plan: The implementation of the EPSR Action Plan should be prioritised, including targeted measures for people with disabilities; for instance, implementing the Adequate Minimum Wage Directive, Platform Work Directive and a new 'quality job target' to promote decent work (EESC Opinion). The EESC urges the establishment of ambitious EU-wide standards to combat in-work poverty. These actions would complement measures included in the EU Anti-Poverty Strategy and align with commitments to combat poverty under the SDGs. Upcoming EU Anti-Poverty Strategy: Considering the upcoming publication (Q2 2026) of the EU’s Anti-Poverty Strategy, and our emphasis on defending a Social Europe, Ireland can pay a positive role in arguing for an ambitious approach to eradicating poverty. Socio-economic issues need to be addressed to cut across the divisions which are being exploited by far-right forces across the EU. Ireland can be a unifier in this area and support careful targeting of those groups with higher levels of poverty (including disabled people). EU Affordable Housing Plan: The first EU-level housing strategy will be adopted in Q2 2026, meaning implementation will begin as Ireland takes up the Presidency. Ireland should work to ensure the Plan has a specific focus on increasing the stock of housing accessible to disabled people. We can also work to change the narrative on housing - to recognise affordable and accessible homes as a fundamental right. Ireland is well-positioned given that one of its former TDs, Eamon Ryan, is Chair of the EU’s independent Housing Advisory Board. EU Accessibility Act: The CRPD Committee’s recent concluding observations to the EU, raised concerns about the limited scope and delays transposing the European Accessibility Act (EAA). The EU is obliged under UN CRPD Article 9 on Accessibility, to ensure disabled people have access, on an equal basis with others, to the physical environment, transport, information and communication, and digital services. Without full and effective implementation of the EAA, these rights remain unrealised, leaving disabled people unable to participate equally in European society.

geography: Our predominant focus is on the national context of disability rights policy; however, we have a community team who engage with the disability sector at regional level. Finally, we also follow all relevant updates at the EU level on this policy area in light of our membership of the EDF and EASPD.
response_text: Take a rights-based and intersectional approach: The Presidency is an opportunity for Ireland to ensure the protection of fundamental rights is firmly on the EU agenda. To do so Ireland should lead by example, keeping the EU core values and principles central to every action and decision it takes during its Presidency term. This approach recognises and treats each individual as a rights-holder with autonomy and dignity. Moreover, it recognises each person’s layers of identities e.g. age, gender, sexual orientation, disability, language, ethnicity, amongst others, which inform their diverse lived experiences. Taking a rights-based approach will have a positive impact not only on disabled people across the EU, but in fact on all communities. Emphasise a Social Europe: Europe and the world are undergoing turbulent times, with ongoing crises and social cohesion under threat. While in many countries (including Ireland) economic growth is continuing, significant swathes of the population constantly live with low incomes, in deprivation and feel marginalised. An unbalanced focus only on economic growth will not deliver social progress or support social cohesion, and risks gains being accrued by only a subset of the population. Moreover, the negative impact of austerity are still being felt by individuals and many community and voluntary organisations whose core funding has still not returned to pre-austerity levels, despite significant economic growth. Ireland can support the EU to re-focus its attention and agenda on societal, as well as economic needs. This can emphasise a return to economic progress to feed society, social development and support those who are more economically vulnerable in our society at EU level. Mainstream Disability Rights in the Multiannual Financial Framework (2028-2034): Ireland’s Presidency will take place during formative negotiations on the next Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF). This presents an opportunity for Ireland to treat disability rights as an essential requirement across EU investment. Ireland should prioritise embedding accessibility, reasonable accommodation, universal design, and UN CRPD compliance as core funding conditions within the next MFF. The UN CPRD Committee, in its March 2025 Concluding Observations to the EU, emphasised this. Equally, EU funds have been a key tool to support the employment of persons with disabilities in the open labour market across the EU. But despite the use of EU funds for this objective, the gap in employment rates between persons with and without disabilities stands at 24 percentage points and has not improved over the past decade.

geography: Our predominant focus is on the national context of disability rights policy; however, we have a community team who engage with the disability sector at regional level. Finally, we also follow all relevant updates at the EU level on this policy area in light of our membership of the EDF and EASPD.
