response_text: Via a Disability Accessible Presidency – considering (i) the EU is the only regional entity to have ratified the CRPD, (ii) commitments therefore under Article 9 on accessibility, and (ii) with ongoing Member State’s implementation of the EU Accessibility Act, Ireland’s presidency should aim to be fully accessible to disabled people. Moreover, Article 29 of the CRPD, obliges State Parties to ensure that disabled people can effectively and fully participate in political and public life on an equal basis with others. Not only will mainstreaming accessibility measures ensuring disabled people can follow the Irish presidency, but also that they can actively participate in and engage with it on an equal basis with others. Ireland has the opportunity to champion accessibility throughout the course of its presidency. This would involve ensuring all information and communication is provided in ISL (as one of Ireland’s 3 national languages), plain English and easy-to-read formats e.g. on the Irish Presidency webpage. Moreover, the webpage should be screen reader compatible. This will create a sense of ownership of Ireland’s Presidency by its disabled citizens. Any events held by the Irish Presidency should ensure physical accessibility, International Sign interpretation, and live captioning is provided given the international audience. EU supporting progress on equality in Ireland: The EU has been a positive force for social development, equality and human rights in Europe and internationally. Many of the positive developments in Ireland’s equality approach and legal frameworks etc. have their origin in the EU. The values of equality, diversity, and equity are central to the EU’s foundation in post-war Europe and have been integral to Ireland’s journey as member of the EU. Emphasising this when communicating the EU Presidency can help to re-affirm social values and a social agenda and orientation for the EU.

geography: Our predominant focus is on the national context of disability rights policy; however, we have a community team who engage with the disability sector at regional level. Finally, we also follow all relevant updates at the EU level on this policy area in light of our membership of the EDF and EASPD.
response_text: It is very challenging to summarise key concerns in 500 words, and so we would welcome the opportunity to discuss any of the issues raised above with relevant personnel working on Ireland’s EU programme. One important consideration is adequate funding for disability and other civil society organisations to increase awareness and engagement in Irish Presidency. Organisation operate with limited and restricted funds. As a result, to plan and run any events, or develop policy papers/inputs relevant to the presidency, without financial support is a major challenge and obstacle to greater engagement. The following resources may be of relevance while considering the points we have raised in our submission: Better Europe joint submission to the EU Semester Process (DFI were part of) Pages 6-7 (which analyses the European Commission’s 2025 EU Semester Report on Ireland) of DFI’s Pre Budget Submission to the Department of Social Protection. The UN CPRD Committee’s Concluding Observations to the EU (March 2025) The European Parliament’s recently adopted position on the second half of the EU Strategy on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (25th November): The report clearly calls on the EU Commission to urgently develop new actions and flagship initiatives. Among other things, it urges the Commission to pay particular attention to the extra cost of living of persons with disabilities, the situation of women and girls with disabilities, mental health among persons with disabilities, and to people with invisible disabilities. Some of the proposed actions for inclusion in the second half of the Strategy include: An EU-funded Employment and Skills Guarantee for persons with disabilities. Continued efforts to improve the freedom of movement of persons with disabilities throughout the EU. Strengthening the European accessibility centre AccessibleEU, through the creation of a dedicated permanent regulatory agency. An EU directive regulating the use of artificial intelligence algorithms for managing, monitoring and recruiting workers. It would address the risks of discrimination that candidates and employees with disabilities often face from AI algorithms. An ambitious agreement on Regulation (EC) No 261/2004 on air passenger rights. Revising Regulation (EU) No 1300/2014 on the accessibility of rail infrastructure for persons with disabilities in order to address and prevent the persistent challenges and discrimination faced by persons with disabilities Necessary legislative initiatives to ensure the equal right to vote and to stand for election of persons with disabilities An EU strategy on the transition from institutions to community-based care Making all plenary debates in Parliament available with International Sign interpretation.

geography: Our focus is on EU-wide areas of policy and legislation as they affect oral health.
response_text: Support the update of the Professional Qualifications Directive (PQD 2005/36) for the clarification and strengthening of clinical training requirements and the encouragement of free movement of professionals. Support working conditions and the retention of dental practitioners in public and community healthcare settings: including through the development of a EU Health Workforce Strategy. Ensure that EU digital health policies, including the European Health Data Space, take into account the financial and administrative impacts on dental professionals of all practice sizes, with particular attention to small and micro enterprises. Ensure that, the upcoming update of the MDR (2017/745), provides a clear, risk-based pathway allowing provenly safe and low-risk medical devices to remain on the market without unnecessary regulatory or administrative burden The simplification and burden reduction efforts of the next Irish Presidency should not come at the expense of patient safety, workforce planning, sustainable healthcare practices, or the protection of patient data. Within the upcoming Omnibus packages, it is crucial that the Irish Presidency ensures that the foreseen simplification and modernisation of digital legislation and data protection do not in any way jeopardise electronic health information exchange and the privileged relationship between healthcare professionals and patients. Fully encompass oral health under current EU health initiatives such as the EU Cardiovascular Health Plan, the European Beating Cancer Plan and other legislative action around health prevention and addressing risk factors common to both oral conditions and NCDs. Call for the revision of the EU Tobacco Legislation beyond the Tobacco Taxation Directive, and particularly the Tobacco Advertising Directive and the Tobacco Products Directive. Promote the continued safe use of fluoride use for the prevention of dental disease.

Ireland should use its 2026 Presidency to insist that the Union remembers why it exists: for peace, human dignity and social justice, not for an arms race. Three linked themes follow. A Peaceful and Principled Europe Ireland should explicitly frame its Presidency around human security, diplomacy and respect for international law. That means resisting the drift toward an EU military union and promoting conflict prevention, arms control, peacebuilding and non-violent resolution of disputes. Ireland, with its tradition of UN peacekeeping and constitutional commitment to neutrality, is uniquely placed to lead this conversation. A Europe that Ends Complicity in War and Occupation The EU’s credibility in the Global South is being destroyed by visible double standards. During Ireland’s Presidency, the Union should commit to applying international humanitarian and human rights law consistently, including in Palestine. That means: ending exports of weapons and dual-use goods to states committing grave breaches of international law, demanding an immediate and lasting ceasefire in Gaza, and supporting genuine political solutions based on equality and self-determination. A Just, Sustainable and Caring Europe The EU Strategic Agenda 2024-2029 is framed around a “strong and secure Europe” and competitiveness. Ireland should rebalance this by putting social protection, public health, decent work and climate justice at the centre of “security”. A Europe that pours hundreds of billions into armaments while people cannot afford housing, energy or care is not secure. Cross-cutting all three themes should be: protection of civil liberties and shrinking civic space; support for trade unions, social dialogue and workers’ rights; climate action that does not push new extractive frontiers onto vulnerable communities at home or abroad. In short, Ireland should choose a Presidency vision that says clearly: security is not tanks and drones, but peace, rights, strong public services and a consistent commitment to international law, from Ukraine to Palestine.

From a neutrality and human-rights perspective, Ireland should concentrate its Presidency efforts on areas where Council decisions can quickly reduce human suffering and restrain militarisation. Arms exports and EU defence funding Champion a review and tightening of the EU Common Position on Arms Exports, so that no weapons or components are exported to states credibly accused of war crimes, including in Gaza, Yemen and elsewhere. Use negotiations on EU budget and defence instruments (including new defence loan and Readiness-type schemes) to redirect funds from weapons procurement toward civil resilience: health, housing, climate adaptation and energy poverty measures. Push for full transparency on arms licences, end-use monitoring and public reporting. International law and Palestine Seek Council conclusions that commit the EU to: supporting investigations by the International Criminal Court and other accountability mechanisms; defending the jurisdiction of international courts; and applying human-rights clauses in all association and trade agreements consistently, including with Israel. Promote practical measures such as: banning settlement products, suspending cooperation that directly or indirectly sustains illegal occupation, and significantly increasing civilian and UN-led humanitarian support. Migration, asylum and externalisation Use the Presidency to slow and, where possible, reverse the trend toward Fortress Europe and outsourcing border control to authoritarian regimes. Prioritise safe and legal routes, fair responsibility-sharing, protection at sea, and an end to practices that expose people on the move to torture, pushbacks and detention in inhuman conditions. Civil liberties, digital rights and the AI Act implementation Focus Council work on protecting civic space, safeguarding journalists, whistle-blowers and human rights defenders, and preventing surveillance technologies from being used against peaceful dissent. Ensure implementation of the AI Act and other digital legislation is anchored in fundamental rights, not security rhetoric. Climate, energy and social protection In negotiations on the Clean Industrial Deal, energy and climate files, Ireland should argue that every euro redirected from social and climate spending into armaments weakens real security. Prioritise measures that reduce energy poverty, support community-owned renewables, and create decent green jobs rather than subsidising fossil-fuel lock-in or extractive mega-projects. The overarching Presidency aim should be clear: to re-orient EU decision-making away from militarisation and toward human security, solidarity and respect for international law.

Council work under Ireland’s Presidency can improve daily life across the Union if it is guided by three tests: Does this decision reduce human suffering? Does it strengthen democracy? Does it shift resources from war to welfare? Deliver visible social gains Ireland should prioritise progress on files that ease the cost-of-living crisis: measures on energy affordability, tenants’ rights, fair wages, and platform workers; stronger protections for public health; and support for quality public services. When people see hospitals, schools and housing improved, Europe feels real. Advance peace and de-escalation The Presidency should use every diplomatic tool to press for ceasefires, prisoner exchanges and political solutions in conflicts affecting Europe, while insisting on accountability for all serious violations of international law. That includes ending EU complicity in the devastation of Gaza and supporting a just peace in Palestine, alongside continued support for Ukraine grounded in international law and diplomacy. Peace work has direct benefits: fewer refugees fleeing war, less pressure on public budgets for weapons, and more resources for community needs. Protect small businesses and workers, not just multinationals Council negotiations on competition, trade and industrial policy should favour SMEs, co-operatives and local economies, ensuring fair taxation of large corporations and digital giants. This can include pushing for stronger EU-level action against tax avoidance and profit-shifting, so that public revenues are available for social and climate priorities. Strengthen democracy from the bottom up Ireland can make the Presidency a model of participatory democracy by embedding structured dialogue with trade unions, NGOs, migrant groups, youth movements and faith communities in the Council’s work. If minority voices, including Palestinian, migrant and traveller communities, are heard in Presidency-linked forums, decisions will reflect Europe as it actually is. Reframe “security” as human security Instead of allowing “security and defence” to mean ever-growing military budgets, Ireland should push the Council toward a human-security paradigm: food, energy and housing security, climate stability, and freedom from fear of war, racist violence or state repression. A Presidency that brings concrete improvements to social protection, peace efforts and democratic participation will leave a legacy that citizens, communities and ethical businesses can genuinely feel and own.

Communication around the Presidency should not be glossy advertising. It should be honest, participatory and rooted in lived experience. Be candid about both benefits and failures People will trust the Presidency more if it acknowledges shortcomings: from austerity policies to the EU’s role in militarisation and migration tragedies. Explain clearly where Ireland intends to do things differently - for example, on peace, Palestine, asylum, and social justice - and report publicly on what was or was not achieved. Bring the Presidency to communities, not just Brussels and Dublin Hold local “EU and Our Community” assemblies in towns, rural areas and estates, in partnership with schools, trade unions, NGOs and parish groups. Use these to listen first, then explain concretely how Council decisions affect housing, work, farms, hospitals and climate. Ensure formats that work for migrants, people with disabilities, young people and those with limited English. Centre stories of solidarity, not slogans Show, through human stories, how EU decisions can protect rights, support workers, and stand with oppressed peoples. Palestinians, Ukrainians, refugees, frontline health staff and care workers should all be visible in Presidency communications as partners, not props. Use independent voices and critical allies Rather than only official spokespeople, involve trade unionists, academics, community organisers, faith leaders and youth activists as commentators and co-hosts of Presidency events. Let them criticise as well as praise. This shared, sometimes uncomfortable, conversation creates real ownership. Invest in civic education, especially for young people Support schools and youth groups to run critical, participatory programmes on how the EU works, what the Council does, and how decisions on war, climate and migration are made. Link these to Presidency events, but keep control in the hands of teachers, students and youth workers rather than turning them into PR exercises. If Ireland communicates its Presidency as a joint project with citizens - including those most affected by war, poverty and exclusion - then EU membership will feel less like something done to people and more like something done with them.

If a fuller submission were attached, it would expand on three points summarised here: Constitutional neutrality and EU militarisation An annex would set out how Ireland’s tradition of military neutrality, UN peacekeeping and constitutional safeguards can guide a distinctive Presidency agenda. It would analyse the legal and political risks of deeper EU militarisation, including joint debt for arms, pressure to reach very high defence-spending targets, and the merging of civilian and military research. It would argue that Ireland’s Presidency should instead promote demilitarisation, arms control and investment in civil resilience. EU complicity in Israel’s violations of international law A second section would document how EU trade, research and arms flows link to Israel’s occupation and the destruction in Gaza, drawing on UN reports and human rights organisations. It would outline concrete levers available to the Council and Member States: arms embargoes, suspension or restriction of agreements that enable serious violations, and support for accountability processes. The argument would be simple: the EU cannot claim to stand for a “rules-based international order” while enabling collective punishment and permanent occupation. A human-security budget for the Union A third section would examine ongoing debates on the EU’s long-term budget and new defence instruments, highlighting how funds could instead be redirected toward housing, healthcare, climate adaptation, just transition and global solidarity. It would propose criteria for assessing every new initiative: does this spending reduce structural violence, inequality and climate risk, or does it fuel them? Overall, the attached material would reinforce the central claim of this submission: that Ireland’s 2026 Presidency should be remembered not for how efficiently it armed Europe, but for how bravely it used a small country’s voice to defend peace, neutrality, Palestine and the basic idea that human lives matter more than weapons or GDP.

organisation: Irish National Organisation of the Unemployed
response_text: We recommend three overarching areas of focus in the Ireland’s Presidency of the EU in 2026: Strengthening the vision of a social Europe, with increased emphasis on the realisation of social rights for everyone. This should include an effective anti-poverty strategy that addresses its root causes, ensuring income adequacy and access to social infrastructure and public services. Enhancing civil society participation and deepening our democracy. Renewed emphasis on a Just Transition as we decarbonise our economy. Ireland has a long positive history of progressing a social agenda in the European Union. In its Presidency in 2026, Ireland can shape and drive an agenda focused on a renewal of social cohesion and societal wellbeing; seeking to ensure that all citizens can participate fully in economic, social and cultural life. There are significant risks for the EU and its member states in overly focusing on economic growth over social development – including reduced trust among individuals, institutions and the state, greater fragmentation, and erosion of the social contract. Indeed, while imperfect, Ireland’s increased focus on wellbeing is an approach we can promote at EU level. Likewise, Ireland’s ongoing practice of social dialogue and civic participation is an approach to good governance that we should deepen and promote at EU level. With the current negotiation on the Multi-annual Financial Framework (MFF) 2028-2034, Ireland’s Presidency of the EU can play a key role in the finalisation of the MFF to preserve the financial sustainability of a social and democratic Europe.

organisation: Irish National Organisation of the Unemployed
response_text: MFF The negotiations for the 2028-2034 Multi-annual Financial Framework marks a key moment for Ireland’s Presidency to ensure further protections are placed upon funding that strengthens the European Union’s democracy and its social infrastructure. Ringfenced funding under the “cohesion” areas of investment are crucial to maintain momentum in this area and make inroads in facing challenges many Member States face. Anti-Poverty Strategy The publication of the EU Anti-Poverty Strategy marks a key opportunity to address the erosion of incomes and falling wealth equality across member states. Recognising Ireland’s long history of robust social protection structures and our own anti-poverty targets, we should ensure targeted measures are matched with ambitious investment to ensure poverty is no longer a major risk for so many people living in the EU today. European Pillar of Social Rights The renewal of this Pillar is an essential policy tool to drive policy coherence in social measures and to address social inequalities. Of importance is the inclusion of the “working poor” as a vulnerable group that requires support, as well as the need to strengthen minimum incomes across member states. Severe housing shortages should also be of focus as a major driver of precarity and social exclusion. There is an opportunity to ensure the objectives within the Pillar are made enforceable via integration with MFF processes, keeping the vision of a “social Europe” to the fore in this period.

organisation: Irish National Organisation of the Unemployed
response_text: The “social clause” or article 9 of the Treaty of the Functioning of the European Union, should be promoted meaningful within policy developments of Ireland’s Presidency. The clause states that “In defining and implementing its policies and activities, the Union shall take into account requirements linked to the promotion of a high level of employment, the guarantee of adequate social protection, the fight against social exclusion, and a high level of education, training and protection of human health.” Embedding this social clause is necessary to create a positive impact for all member states and their citizens. Greater coherence of European economic, environmental and social policy in support of a social Europe can be done by acting on the von der Leyen Commission’s decision to integrate the UN Sustainable Development Goals and the European Pillar of Social Rights into the economic processes of the European Semester. Further actions to develop this include: Making the European Pillar of Social Rights enforceable through legislative initiatives, including the Multiannual Financial Framework and turning it into a strategic tool to influence EU macroeconomic governance. Taking greater account of social impacts when making Country-specific Recommendations, especially those requiring fiscal consolidation measures, and ensure no return of austerity policy. Making Country-specific Recommendations that seek to achieve reductions in poverty, where rates are high or rising.

organisation: Irish National Organisation of the Unemployed
response_text: As many high-level meetings are to take place across Ireland, the visibility of the Presidency is needed to both raise awareness and to promote opportunities to get involved in the events during Ireland’s term. There is a key opportunity for the State to partner with other national and regional organisations with members across the country, as they have the best connections and insight into how to effectively promote the Presidency within their jurisdiction. Partnership participation with community organisations can be an effective strategy to run engaging events and ensure people can be empowered to participate in activities and gain further insights of the benefits of EU membership and decision making structures. A key determinant of the success of this approach is to ensure adequate funding is provided to ensure organisations can fully participate and develop strategic initiatives that will serve their members effectively.

organisation: Irish National Organisation of the Unemployed
response_text: A strengthened focus on a “Social Europe” comes at a pivotal time as the EU faces rapid changes that risk further fragmentation and division within and across the EU. The Treaty of the European Union states “The Union is founded on the values of respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights, including the rights of persons belonging to minorities. These values are common to the Member States in a society in which pluralism, non-discrimination, tolerance, justice, solidarity and equality between women and men prevail.” The Irish Presidency of the EU provides the opportunity to put those values at the centre of European policymaking.

As the Irish Presidency in 2026, the Council should promote water prioritization primarily through its international agenda — building on the momentum generated by the 2023 UN Water Conference and preparing for the 2026 follow-up. The EU’s international dimension under the European Water Resilience Strategy aims to “reinforce the EU’s role in promoting water resilience worldwide through international partnerships and cooperation.” The Presidency should champion: Implementation of the global Water Action Agenda commitments, ensuring the EU delivers on access to safe drinking water and sanitation, ecosystem restoration, and transboundary-water cooperation. Strengthened diplomacy for water, embedding water security into the EU’s foreign policy, humanitarian aid, and climate diplomacy — consistent with the Council’s prior calls for water as a tool for peace, security, development and human dignity. Mobilization of international finance and partnerships (development banks, multilateral organisations, private sector) to support water and sanitation infrastructure globally, nature-based water restoration, and integrated water-resource management. This mirrors the Strategy’s emphasis on cooperation, research, innovation, and financing. What the Irish Presidency should aim to achieve: A clear EU roadmap for delivering on the Water Action Agenda by 2030 — with measurable contributions to SDG 6 globally (safe water, sanitation, ecosystem restoration). Institutionalisation of water diplomacy across EU external action, including enhanced transboundary water-management cooperation with partner countries, especially in regions exposed to water stress. Strategic alignment of EU external financing — via development cooperation and multilateral banks — to water resilience, with focus on water infrastructure, ecosystem restoration, sanitation, and sustainable water-resource management globally. By doing so, the Irish Presidency would strengthen the EU’s global role on water, uphold its international commitments, and help shape a more resilient, equitable water future worldwide — ahead of and beyond the 2026 UN Water Conference.

organisation: People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals Foundation (PETA)
response_text: Ireland’s Presidency will begin at a time when the European Union is navigating rapid economic, scientific and societal change. Citizens and businesses increasingly expect the Union to deliver clarity, transparency, innovation and strong protection standards, while the EU Strategic Agenda 2024–2029 emphasises competitiveness, resilience and democratic renewal as central priorities for the coming years. These overarching objectives offer a clear orientation for Ireland as it opens the next Council cycle. PETA recommends that Ireland structure its Presidency around two broad, forward-looking themes that reflect the Union’s strategic direction and the urgent need to accelerate Europe’s transition away from animal testing toward modern, humane, and scientifically advanced approaches. By placing replacement technologies at the heart of its Presidency, Ireland can reinforce both Europe’s scientific and economic foundations and its democratic values. Theme 1 – A Competitive, Innovative and High-Standards Europe for People, Animals and the Environment This theme aligns closely with the Strategic Agenda’s ambition to foster “a prosperous and competitive Europe.” Strengthening long-term competitiveness requires a regulatory environment that is coherent, predictable and grounded in excellent science. A Presidency anchored in this theme would lend strong support to innovation, the functioning of the Single Market and the development of modern, efficient governance structures. Ireland is well positioned to highlight the importance of research excellence, regulatory consistency and high protection standards as core components of a resilient and future-ready European economy. Emphasising the value of clear, transparent and science-led decision-making and championing non- animal replacement technologies would help create the conditions for high-quality jobs, sustainable growth and Europe’s leadership in the green and digital transitions. Theme 2 – A Cohesive and Values-Driven Union This theme reflects the Strategic Agenda’s priority of building “a free and democratic Europe,” grounded in the principles of dignity, equality, human rights and the rule of law. As societal and technological transitions accelerate, strengthening public trust and ensuring transparent, accountable decision-making are essential for maintaining confidence in the European project. Ireland has a long-standing reputation for promoting inclusive, evidence-based and participatory governance. A Presidency shaped around this theme would reinforce democratic legitimacy by supporting clarity in policymaking, meaningful citizen engagement and value-driven approaches across the Council’s work. Central to this is recognising citizens’ growing demand for ethical science and stronger protections for animals. By advancing policies that replace animal testing with humane, humanrelevant technologies, Ireland can help deepen citizens’ sense of connection to the Union, strengthen democratic resilience, and demonstrate that European values extend to how we conduct science itself.

organisation: People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals Foundation (PETA)
response_text: Ireland’s Presidency will coincide with a pivotal moment for modernising the EU’s regulatory frameworks for chemicals, product safety and research. Building on the Strategic Agenda 2024–2029 commitments to competitiveness, innovation and strong protection standards, the Presidency can make meaningful progress on several major initiatives that require coordinated Council stewardship. 1. Modernising REACH: Spare Animals, Cut Costs, and Lead in Innovation The revision of REACH will be central to strengthening the Single Market, improving scientific quality and increasing regulatory efficiency. Ireland can advance Council discussions by supporting: A stepwise, science-led framework making non-animal approaches the default and allowing animal tests only when non-animal options are demonstrably exhausted and scientifically justified; Future-proof, performance-based, information requirements, updated as science evolves; An independent expert committee to accelerate acceptance of non-animal approaches; Greater transparency and data reuse, including reporting on animal and non-animal use and expanding data-sharing provisions; Alignment of REACH with the Cosmetics Regulation, using existing cosmetics non-animal safety data to meet REACH requirements. Evaluation of the Cosmetics Products Regulation (CPR) Ireland can reinforce consumer confidence and EU values by: Supporting a CPR revision that fully protects and enforces the bans on animal testing and marketing of animal-tested cosmetics and ingredients; Preserving the ethical and scientific integrity of the CPR while enhancing transparency and enforcement. Evaluating the Biocidal Products Regulation (BPR) The Presidency could promote modernisation by: Systematic reporting on non-animal and animal-test use; Non-animal approaches as the default, enforced through tiered testing and weight-of-evidence approaches; Future-proof, science-driven information requirements and regular training to build regulatory confidence in innovative approaches; Stronger data sharing and legal interoperability to prevent redundant testing and improve efficiency. Implementing the EU Roadmap to Phase Out Animal Testing for Chemical Safety Following the European Citizens’ Initiative “Save Cruelty-Free Cosmetics”, the Commission committed to a cross-sector Roadmap. We encourage the Irish Presidency to: Support coordinated implementation of the roadmap across environment, health, research and industry portfolios. Promote structured monitoring and transparent reporting on progress. Encourage cooperation between Member States, EU agencies and relevant stakeholders, to advance acceptance of non-animal approaches. Ensure that Roadmap objectives are reflected in chemicals policy discussions, including REACH implementation. Advancing the ERA Action on Non-Animal Methods in Biomedical Research and Testing Ireland can ensure coherence with the European Research Area (ERA) Policy Agenda 2025–2027, which prioritises accelerating non-animal methods in biomedical research and testing by: Supporting cooperation between Health, Environment and Research ministries; Promoting transparency and stakeholder engagement; Encouraging legislative coherence so that sectoral laws do not hinder deployment of validated non-animal approaches.

organisation: People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals Foundation (PETA)
response_text: These reforms would improve predictability for businesses, reduce unnecessary regulatory burden, and reflect the expectations of more than 1.2 million European citizens who supported the European Citizens’ Initiative “Save Cruelty-Free Cosmetics – Commit to a Europe Without Animal Testing”. Building on this clear societal and economic mandate, the Irish Presidency can make a substantial positive impact by advancing coherent, future-ready regulatory systems that serve people, businesses and communities across the Union. The Irish Presidency has an opportunity to strengthen the EU’s capacity to deliver clear, science-based and efficient regulatory outcomes. Many of the challenges faced by stakeholders, such as complexity, inconsistent implementation and limited transparency, stem from fragmentation across existing frameworks. Addressing these issues through practical, consensus-driven Council work would contribute directly to the Strategic Agenda’s goals of competitiveness, resilience and democratic renewal. Increasing regulatory coherence and predictability for businesses, especially SMEs Businesses benefit from regulatory systems that are clear, proportionate and consistent across sectors. Progress on modernising REACH, the CPR and the BPR would improve clarity, reduce duplication and facilitate compliance, particularly for SMEs. Enhanced data-sharing, better coordination between Member States and aligned assessment principles would support innovation while reducing unnecessary burdens. Improving scientific quality and strengthening protection for citizens Accelerating the uptake of modern, human-relevant scientific approaches would improve the reliability of safety assessments, better protect human health and the environment, and ensure that EU decisions reflect state-of-the-art science. This contributes to safer products, healthier communities and a more resilient environment. Enhancing transparency to support public trust Citizens increasingly expect openness in regulatory processes. Advancing transparency in data use, assessment pathways and progress under the EU Roadmap towards phasing out animal testing would reinforce trust in EU institutions and demonstrate commitment to accountable, evidence-based policymaking. Supporting innovation and Europe’s scientific leadership Promoting cross-sector coordination and investment in advanced non-animal appraoches will help maintain Europe’s leadership in science and innovation. This not only enhances the EU’s competitiveness but also ensures more efficient use of public and private research funding. By promoting regulatory coherence, scientific excellence and transparent governance, Ireland’s Presidency can help deliver a modern, responsive and values-driven regulatory environment that benefits citizens, businesses and communities across the European Union.

organisation: People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals Foundation (PETA)
response_text: Communicating the values and benefits of EU membership during Ireland’s Presidency will require an approach grounded in transparency, accessibility and meaningful public engagement. A central aspect of reinforcing public trust is showing that EU institutions not only inform citizens, but also listen to them. The strong public mobilisation behind the European Citizens’ Initiative “Save Cruelty-Free Cosmetics – Commit to a Europe Without Animal Testing,” illustrates the value citizens place on ethical, scientifically robust and future-oriented policymaking. Communicating clearly how the EU follows up on such initiatives—and how citizen participation contributes to shaping the policy agenda, would demonstrate that democratic mechanisms function and that public input carries weight. Ireland’s Presidency could enhance visibility and public understanding by: providing clear, accessible explanations of Council deliberations and legislative progress; highlighting concrete examples of how EU cooperation improves daily life, including through safer products, stronger environmental protection and support for scientific innovation; supporting youth engagement, civil society dialogue and partnerships with educational and research institutions; using digital tools and multilingual communication to make complex policy areas more understandable and relatable to non-specialist audiences. Public-facing events, Presidency-branded communication campaigns and collaboration with the European Parliament and European Commission would help deepen citizens’ understanding of the Presidency’s role and the value of EU cooperation. Emphasising openness, accountability and responsiveness, including through visible follow-up to citizen-led initiatives, can further strengthen public confidence. By placing people at the centre of its communication efforts, Ireland can reinforce the EU’s founding values and foster a stronger sense of shared ownership and trust in the European project.

organisation: People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals Foundation (PETA)
response_text: As Ireland develops its Presidency programme, we would welcome consideration of opportunities to facilitate structured dialogue on the modernisation of the EU’s regulatory frameworks for chemicals, product safety and research. Several priority initiatives, particularly the revision of REACH and the forthcoming EU Roadmap towards phasing out animal testing for chemical safety assessments, would benefit from focused, cross-sector exchanges that support evidence-based Council deliberations. The Presidency could add significant value by convening, endorsing or participating in thematic events that gather Member States, EU agencies, scientific experts, industry, and civil society. PETA would be pleased to contribute to or help organise such discussions. Our organisation works extensively on EU chemicals policy and the transition towards non-animal approaches for chemical safety assessments. We regularly engage with EU institutions, EU agencies and Member State experts, providing scientific and policy expertise to support modern, efficient and future-proof regulatory outcomes that protect human health and the environment while contributing to the EU’s commitment to phase out animal testing. We would therefore welcome the opportunity to engage with the Irish Presidency—either through participation as speakers in Presidency-organised events or through collaboration on the planning and delivery of a new multistakeholder discussion as part of the Presidency’s programme. We remain at your disposal for any further information.

At Astellas, we are committed to transforming innovative science into value for patients. We support the development of healthcare solutions through a deep understanding of patients' experiences and medical needs. We are driving the evolution of transformative therapies, focusing on new targets with cutting-edge modalities, and we are committed to tackling disease with high unmet medical needs. Considering the global environment pharmaceutical companies face and the linked challenges on health, single market, and trade, we believe that EU’s competitiveness is necessary to reignite productivity and sustain growth while defending access to the highest quality of care & healthcare resilience. We welcome a strong health and industrial agenda, focusing on faster access to medicines and fairer access to innovation. We believe that access to innovation & patient-centered innovation pathways requires political actions to facilitate regulatory and reimbursement pathways for ATMPs, oncological therapies, biomarkers, diagnostics, and ATMPs: Precision oncology diagnostic: Access to biomarker testing remains fragmented and inequitable, limiting the real-world impact of precision oncology. Today, testing availability, reimbursement, laboratory capacity, quality assurance, and turnaround times vary dramatically between Member States. Patients in Northern and Western Europe are far more likely to receive timely, high-quality testing than those in Central, Eastern and Southern Europe. Misaligned approval and reimbursement pathways for companion diagnostics, inconsistent quality standards, and lack of sustainable funding continue to restrict patient access to precision therapies. Access to combination therapies: Combination therapies are recognized as the most innovative treatment options in oncology (and beyond). Although these therapies can significantly improve patient outcomes, there are considerable challenges related to pricing models and competition laws. While pricing decisions fall under national competences, Articles 3 and 101-109 TFEU rule on common competition and the approximation of laws. Advanced Therapies (ATMPs): Incentives to support the translation of research into commercialization (from clinical trials to reimbursement) are required to scale innovation in Europe. Discoveries deliver impact when they reach patients, and a strong political commitment to innovation, reducing barriers in the single market, and harmonization of the EU system is required to reduce unpredictability across 27 national systems. Furthermore, it is the right political moment to champion for Women’s Health and Menopause, the up-coming EU equal strategy and recognizing menopause as a structural issue across the EU – it is an equality, labor, economic, and fiscal issue. Ireland has already taken leadership steps in this area, guided by the Women’s Health Action Plan 2025 and the Civil Service menopause in the workplace policy framework. This is an opportunity to take these learnings forward and champion an EU-wide approach that recognizes menopause as a key life stage requiring innovation and workplace inclusion to improve health outcomes. The workplace impacts of menopause are clear – Astellas’ Menopause Experience and Attitudes Survey found that 59% believe menopause is a taboo topic that people are uncomfortable discussing, and that 36% of women have experienced some kind of negative impact in the workplace, whether it be reduced productivity or outright discrimination.

Trade: The Presidency should ensure that EU trade policy supports Europe’s competitiveness through close transatlantic partnerships, free trade negotiations, and strategic conversations to address internal and external barriers for innovative industries with a strong presence across the Region. MFN risk mitigation policy, solid industrial policy, and EU Member States' cooperation to avoid price spillovers will be fundamental for EU economies. Competitiveness: The Presidency should pursue an ambitious and earmarked budget for health within the MFF, including but not limited to the Competitiveness Fund and Horizon Europe, and strengthen publicprivate partnerships. Furthermore, the Presidency should ensure that the EU Critical Medicines Act proposal achieves the availability of innovative and critical medicines on the markets, strengthening manufacturing capacities in Europe, and enhancing external cooperation to reduce risks of a fragmented supply chain, which will undermine competitiveness. On the Biotech Act, the Presidency should ensure the legislation strengthens Europe’s IP framework, simplifies and harmonizes clinical trials, establishes end-to-end regulatory oversight, creates a coherent framework for advanced manufacturing, expands access to funding and investment opportunities, and harnesses digitalization and AI. Access: Ireland has been a highly influential Member States in shaping the EU HTA framework, and its 2026 Council Presidency represents a pivotal moment for implementation. It is essential that Ireland ensures the regulation delivers on its intended objectives - minimizing duplication, accelerating assessments, and enabling faster, more equitable access to innovative therapies across all Member States. Oncology: The Presidency should keep cancer (and rare cancers) high on the political agenda and therefore ensure that the Europe Beating Cancer Plan, the EU Cancer Mission receive adequate funds and political attention, as well as the EU Council’s recommendations on cancer screening are fully implemented across Europe and therefore reflected in the national cancer control plans. ATMPs: The Presidency should work on building a Europe’s biotechnology ecosystem that remains fragmented, particularly in the transition from discovery to development. Cell and gene therapies are revolutionizing the treatment of life-threatening conditions, offering durable or potentially curative outcomes for patients. This disease area is critical to drive Europe’s health and global competitiveness. Still, policy actions are required to ensure that ATMPs are invented, developed, manufactured, and delivered to patients across EU. Women’s health: The Presidency should encourage more systematic coverage of menopause within Council discussions on health cooperation, healthy ageing, equality, and economic participation. It can help create a more coherent EU approach and further investments in the next EU budget 2028 -2034 negotiations. This would strengthen outcomes for women, support businesses through improved retention and productivity, and contribute to healthier, more inclusive European communities. The period is timely, as the WHO has recently incorporated perimenopause and menopause into its life-course SRHR framework, signaling an important shift in global health attention.

Astellas believes that the following policy solutions and actions can support relevant achievements in the therapeutic areas highlighted: Precision oncology diagnostic: There are several concrete solutions (already available or emerging) that can accelerate equitable access to precision medicine - delivering benefits for patients, national cancer strategies and healthcare systems, such as: Align EU regulatory and reimbursement pathways so that companion diagnostics and precision therapies are evaluated, approved and funded in parallel, avoiding current delays and inconsistencies. Establish EU-wide standards for biomarker test quality, accreditation and data infrastructure Support dedicated EU funds for biomarker testing, including investment in next-generation sequencing (NGS) capacity and national laboratory networks. Create structured platforms for Member State collaboration, enabling shared learning on coding, reimbursement models, procurement, turnaround time optimization, and data collection. Close Europe’s diagnostic access gap by embedding precision medicine as a standard component of high-quality cancer care. European Framework for Combination Therapies: Close the access gap by ensuring that patients across Europe benefit from the most effective combination of regimen, and providing a win-win-win for patients, healthcare systems, and the innovative pharma industry, such as: Work with Member States and extend Belgian-style competition (and UK) law guidance across Europe to give companies the legal certainty required for collaborative access solutions Issue clear, EU-wide safe-harbour provisions enabling good-faith, transparent and regulator-reviewed multi-company negotiations. Ensure competition policy is aligned with public health goals, recognizing that overly restrictive interpretations can delay or deny access to life-extending cancer care. Accelerate national policy adoption by encouraging Ministries of Health and reimbursement authorities to integrate emerging methods into HTA practice. European Framework for ATMPs: Europe’s access and reimbursement frameworks have not kept pace with its industrial innovation, and the Council should ensure a more coherent policy ecosystem will improve predictability for innovators. Policy actions could include: Ensure EU funds used to develop an upskill the regulatory network to be familiar with ATMP development, clinical trials, and manufacturing. Support Member States in applying cross-border healthcare provisions to ATMPs. Promote a dialogue between the European Commission, regulators, HTA bodies, payers, and industry to enable earlier dialogue and shared expectations on value and evidence requirements. Women’s Health & Menopause: the EU/WHO cooperation in Women’s Health and Menopause aligns with the EU Strategic Agenda 2024-2029 and Draghi’s report. Policy actions could include: Encourage progress on more consistent, evidence-based menopause care across the EU, ensuring that every woman can assess a minimum-level of appropriate support regardless of where she lives, as well as great attention to menopause within discussions on EU workforce participation and productivity. Extend the Irish Women’s Health Action Plan as best practice across the EU Member States. Accelerate the evolution of a comprehensive Women’s Health/Equity strategy, with a minimum service level of menopause treatment and understanding consistent across Europe. This includes access to care, choice of treatments, and menopause education of primary care health professionals and specialists to diagnose and treat menopause symptoms, for example, hot flushes and night sweats, considered the cardinal symptoms of menopause.

We believe that the EU’s values can be transmitted through clear communication and direct public engagement, when possible. It is therefore important that the Presidency will communicate to the EU citizens how the Council (and therefore all 27 Member States) is committed to guaranteeing Health, strengthening the national health care systems, supporting the economy through competition & industrial policy, as well as ensuring equality on the labor market. An effective Presidency will require cross-area cooperation, which connects trade, competitiveness, health, R&D, and beyond at EU level. This should also be translated to Member States level too. Furthermore, stakeholders’ engagement is vital for a democratic Europe, as well as including their solid expertise in specific issues. In this regard, roundtable discussions, country visits, and digital engagement could ensure that a patientcentered/industry dialogue is effective. Astellas Pharma remains available to further cooperate with the Irish Presidency, as well as our colleagues in the Irish affiliate & across the EU.

Please find below a few publications & data which highlight the needed actions mentioned above: Combination Therapies: A Framework for Value-aligned Pricing of Combination Therapies Why We Need a New Outcomes-Based Value Attribution Framework for Combination Regimens in Oncology ATMPs: Securing Europe’s Future in Advanced Therapies Menopause: Global cross-sectional survey of women with vasomotor symptoms associated with menopause: prevalence and quality of life burden Distribution of feelings on whether there is a stigma around talking about the menopause at work in the United Kingdom, Germany, Spain, and Italy as of 2021 Feelings of whether more menopause support in the workplace would have had a positive impact in the United Kingdom, Germany, Spain, and Italy as of 2021 The Future of Work Podcast

Ireland’s Presidency should focus on three linked themes that strengthen democracy, protect rights, and support social cohesion across the Union. These themes align with Ireland’s foreign policy, the National LGBTI+ Inclusion Strategy, and Ireland’s campaign for a seat on the UN Human Rights Council. Protect rights, democracy, and the rule of law The Presidency should reaffirm that fundamental rights, including LGBTIQ+ equality, are core to the EU’s constitutional order. Attacks on LGBTIQ+ people form part of broader democratic backsliding in several Member States. The Council should place rights protection at the centre of its work, strengthen scrutiny of rule-of-law concerns, and ensure civil society participation across formations. This requires visible political leadership and clear messaging that rights are non-negotiable. Build a safer and more inclusive social Europe The Presidency should address inequality, hate crime, and violence through coordinated action. LGBTIQ+ people experience higher rates of poverty, homelessness, and mental health distress. These realities link directly to wider EU priorities in housing, youth, health, and employment. The Presidency should support measures that strengthen community safety, improve data collection, and promote inclusive access to services. A coherent social agenda reduces polarisation and strengthens cohesion. Position the EU as a values-based global actor In the period leading to Ireland’s UN Human Rights Council campaign, the Presidency should demonstrate that internal and external human rights commitments are aligned. This includes supporting human rights defenders, strengthening the EU’s global work on equality, and ensuring consistent positions in UN fora. Ireland is well placed to lead this work due to its international reputation on equality and its long-standing engagement with civil society. The Presidency should also advance the new EU LGBTIQ Equality Strategy 2026–2030. This strategy is essential for coordinating equality work across institutions, promoting best practice, and ensuring accountability. Progress on this file would show that the EU remains committed to strengthening rights at a time of increasing political pressure. Ireland should use its own National LGBTI+ Inclusion Strategy as a reference point. This demonstrates national leadership and helps ground Presidency priorities in lived experience. These three LGBTQ+ themes give the Presidency coherence and clarity. They respond to real community needs across Europe and highlight Ireland’s strengths as a country that values equality, inclusion, and democratic stability. Ireland’s role in hosting major European equality events in this period further strengthens the case for a Presidency anchored in rights and democratic values.

The Presidency should prioritise a focused set of policy areas where progress is achievable and where outcomes will improve the lives of people across the Union. EU LGBTIQ Equality Strategy 2026–2030 The Presidency should secure meaningful progress on the next EU strategy. This includes stronger cross-Council coordination, structured engagement with civil society, and improved monitoring of Member State commitments. A clear Council mandate is essential to protect consistency and avoid fragmentation across formations. Free movement and family recognition The Presidency should prioritise the Regulation on parenthood recognition and press for alignment with established CJEU case law. Families must retain their legal status when moving across borders. Ensuring mutual recognition is critical for mobility, worker rights, and children’s wellbeing. Hate crime, hate speech, and digital safety The Presidency should advance work on the Eurocrimes extension and ensure coordinated action against online hate and targeted disinformation. Rising anti-LGBTIQ hate threatens safety and undermines trust in democratic institutions. The Presidency should promote better national data systems and stronger cooperation between law enforcement bodies. Ending conversion practices The Presidency should support EU-level work that helps Member States introduce bans covering sexual orientation, gender identity, gender expression, and sex characteristics. Any EU approach should include safeguards that protect access to gender-affirming healthcare and mental health supports. Clarity on this point is essential to avoid harm. Asylum and migration The Presidency should ensure that the implementation of the Pact on Migration and Asylum includes safeguards for vulnerable groups, including LGBTIQ refugees. This requires attention to reception conditions, privacy, fair procedures, and independent monitoring. Cooperation with the EU Agency for Fundamental Rights and civil society should be standard practice. 6. External action and Ireland’s UN campaign The Presidency should promote Council conclusions reaffirming LGBTIQ rights in the EU’s external work. This includes support for human rights defenders, strategic engagement with partner countries, and consistent positions at the UN. Ireland’s leadership in this area would strengthen its credibility during the Human Rights Council campaign. These areas offer clear pathways for progress and demonstrate that the EU delivers for people in concrete ways. They also align with Ireland’s domestic commitments and the needs identified by LGBTIQ organisations across Europe.

A Presidency centred on equality, safety, and social cohesion will deliver practical benefits for households, workplaces, and communities across Europe. Housing, community safety, and protection from discrimination are deeply connected, and progress in these areas will support a more stable and confident Union. Housing, homelessness, and social cohesion The housing crisis across Europe is one of the main pressures shaping public sentiment. Insecure housing, overcrowding, and rising homelessness are driving social frustration, weakening trust in institutions, and creating conditions that allow extremist and far-right narratives to take hold. These dynamics directly affect LGBTIQ people, who already face higher risks of homelessness due to family rejection, discrimination, and economic inequality. The Presidency should frame housing as a core element of community stability. Investment in affordable housing, protections for vulnerable groups, and better coordination across Member States will strengthen social cohesion. Communities with secure housing are more resilient, less isolated, and less susceptible to polarising messaging. Addressing housing is essential to building safer communities and reducing the conditions in which hate thrives. Safer communities Clearer protections against hate crime and hate speech remain vital. Anti-LGBTIQ hate, anti-migrant sentiment, and online harassment are rising across Europe. These trends undermine community safety and weaken public trust. Stronger enforcement (online and offline), better data, and coordinated action between Member States will help protect people and stabilise communities. Fairer workplaces and easier mobility Consistent recognition of families across the Union supports mobility and strengthens workforce participation. People can relocate for work with confidence when their family rights are secure. Clear non-discrimination rules help businesses create safer workplaces, support talent retention, and reduce conflict. When workers feel protected, they invest more in their roles and contribute to stronger local economies. Stronger integration for refugees and migrants LGBTIQ refugees face higher risk of violence, exploitation, and social isolation. Fair procedures, safe reception systems, and independent oversight help people rebuild their lives and participate in their communities. These measures improve outcomes for individuals and promote cohesion within host communities. Practical actions for the Presidency Connect work on equality with EU-level efforts to address housing and homelessness. Support coordinated action on hate crime, online safety, and data collection. Promote mutual recognition of families to strengthen worker mobility. Highlight best practice on reception, integration, and community safety. Encourage joint engagement between civil society, local authorities, and Member States. A Presidency focused on these areas will support safer communities, stronger participation, and a more cohesive society, conditions that are essential for democratic stability across the Union.

The Presidency should show that EU values are lived, shared, and shaped by people across Ireland and Europe. This requires clear communication, engagement in trusted spaces, and a focus on lived experience. Show real stories People understand EU values when they see their impact. The Presidency should highlight stories of families recognised across borders, young people moving for education, workers protected by equality law, and LGBTIQ refugees who find safety. These stories make European cooperation concrete and connect policy to everyday life. Engage communities directly The Presidency should meet people where they are. Events should take place in community centres, youth services, arts spaces, migrant organisations, LGBTIQ centres, and local libraries. These settings create trust, draw in people who are rarely reached by EU institutions, and support open conversation. Make communication simple and accessible Clear information strengthens ownership. The Presidency should produce short explainers and visual guides on free movement, family rights, digital protections, and community safety. Translations and plain English should be standard. Materials should be designed for use in schools, workplaces, and community settings. Create space for dialogue Ownership grows when people feel heard. The Presidency should hold town-hall meetings, roundtables, community discussions, and online Q&A sessions. These formats enable people to question decision-makers directly and provide feedback grounded in their lived experiences. Build trust to counter disinformation Disinformation targets groups already at risk. The Presidency should work with educators, civil society partners, and local leaders to provide accurate information about EU decisions. Trusted messengers are essential. This approach builds confidence and reduces the influence of polarising narratives. Use major equality events to strengthen engagement Ireland has a unique opportunity in October 2026, when Outhouse LGBTQ+ Centre together with LGBT Ireland will host the ILGA-Europe Annual Meeting in Dublin. This gathering, supported by Government partners, will bring more than 400 activists and experts from 52 countries across Europe and Central Asia. The Presidency should integrate this event into its communications and engagement work. It is a rare moment to show Ireland’s leadership, support dialogue between Member States and civil society, and reinforce the EU’s commitment to dignity and inclusion. Practical actions for the Presidency Launch a “Europe in Communities” outreach programme through civic and cultural spaces. Develop short, accessible guides on key rights and protections. Establish an at-risk populations advisory panel for Presidency communications. Create a digital hub with real stories, practical tools, and participation opportunities. Use the ILGA-Europe Annual Meeting as a platform for Presidency dialogues on rights and community safety for LGBTQ+ people. These actions will make the Presidency visible, relatable, and genuinely participatory. They will help people see the EU as something they shape, not something distant.

Outhouse LGBTQ+ Centre welcomes this consultation and supports a Presidency that strengthens rights, democracy, and social cohesion across the Union. Our recommendations are based on daily engagement with people whose lives are shaped by EU policy and who depend on strong protections in areas such as mobility, safety, asylum, and access to services. We see the impact of EU decisions first-hand. Rules on family recognition affect whether people can live and work across borders. Digital policy influences the safety of LGBTIQ people online. Asylum procedures shape the experiences of refugees who rely on fair treatment and safe reception. These issues are not abstract. They define the lived reality of many people who pass through our doors each week. The Presidency should close gaps between high-level commitments and people’s day-to-day experience. This includes stronger monitoring of Member State implementation in equality, asylum, digital safety, and justice. It also requires consistent involvement of civil society, especially groups that work with people most affected by discrimination, violence, and social exclusion. Ireland has a strong international profile in human rights and equality. The Presidency should reinforce this by aligning domestic commitments with EU and UN priorities. The National LGBTI+ Inclusion Strategy offers a clear national direction that corresponds closely with European policy needs. Linking these frameworks will strengthen coherence and credibility. The Presidency should also consider how Ireland’s convening role can support progress at EU level. In October 2026, Outhouse LGBTQ+ Centre with LGBT Ireland will host the ILGA-Europe Annual Meeting in Dublin. This event, supported by Government partners, will bring together more than 400 activists, experts, and human-rights defenders from 52 countries across Europe and Central Asia. Its timing during the Presidency offers a major opportunity to deepen engagement between EU institutions, Member States, and civil society. It also reinforces Ireland’s position as a trusted leader within the European equality movement. We encourage the Government to draw on this moment. The Annual Meeting can support dialogue on rights, democracy, and community safety during the Presidency. It can also highlight Ireland’s leadership in Europe and strengthen connections that support Ireland’s campaign for a seat on the UN Human Rights Council. Outhouse is ready to assist with Presidency outreach and community engagement. We host thousands of people each year and can help ensure that those least heard are part of the conversation. We thank the Department for the opportunity to contribute and remain available to support this work.

sector: National Organisation for LGBTQI+ people across Ireland
geography: LGBT Ireland is the national organisation for LGBTQI+ people across Ireland, with both a national and regional focus. The organisation is also a member of ILGA-Europe, the European Region of the International Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Trans & Intersex Association, which works for equality and human rights for LGBTI+ people at the European level.
response_text: LGBTQI+ communities face many of the same concerns and intersecting crises as everyone, including climate, housing, cost of living, conflict, and threats to democracy. This submission outlines priorities from a LGBTQI+ perspective, but our proposals for Ireland’s Presidency also contribute more broadly to delivering a stronger Social Europe, advancing commitments to build a Union of Equality, and support the priorities and strategic orientations in the EU Strategic Agenda. 1. People and Fundamental Values at the Heart of Europe By focusing on people and values, Ireland can advance the shared vision of a fair, cohesive EU, grounded in equality and human rights. It should ensure the EU’s fundamental values – respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law, and human rights – are central to the Council’s work. The Strategic Agenda identifies these values as the Union’s primary strength, its compass both within the EU and globally, and the foundation for a stronger, more prosperous and more democratic union for citizens. Ireland should seek to ensure legislative and policy processes across Council configurations reflect the obligations in the Treaties and the Charter of Fundamental Rights, including commitments to eliminate inequalities and combat discrimination on all grounds. This requires mainstreaming equality across the Council’s agenda and reinforcing a rights-based approach in all legislation and policy. A people-centred Presidency should emphasise measures that support inclusive social standards, equal access to rights, and protections for all, including those whose rights remain unevenly protected across the EU, such as LGBTQI+ persons. The aim should be to facilitate progress on existing legislative files, support evidence-based discussions, and strengthen implementation of EU law so everyone in Europe, regardless of sexual orientation, gender identity or expression, or sex characteristics, can live safe, authentic, and dignified lives. 2. Protecting and Strengthening Europe’s Democratic Union Ireland’s Presidency will take place at a moment of heightened threats to democracy, civic space, and fundamental rights across Europe. The Strategic Agenda emphasises the need to defend democracy, safeguard the rule of law, and counter extremism. A second high-level priority should therefore focus on defending democracy and combating hate online and offline. Across Europe, LGBTQI+ communities and other marginalised groups face rising hate, violence, disinformation, and scapegoating, fuelled by extremist rhetoric and polarisation. These attacks are frequently used to undermine democratic institutions, weaken the rule of law, and restrict civil society. Protecting our communities is inseparable from protecting the integrity of Europe’s democratic systems. Ireland’s Presidency should work to strengthen legal and policy responses to hate, reinforce fundamental rights, and support resilient democratic institutions. This includes facilitating Council discussions on countering hate and discrimination, supporting digital policy to tackle online hate, and helping advance rule of law mechanisms and instruments that safeguard rights. With its strong equality and human rights record and reputation, Ireland can guide efforts to ensure the EU remains steadfast in defending democratic values and resisting the instrumentalisation of vulnerable communities. A Presidency grounded in protecting democracy and fundamental rights will contribute significantly to a resilient, credible, and unified EU.

sector: National Organisation for LGBTQI+ people across Ireland
geography: LGBT Ireland is the national organisation for LGBTQI+ people across Ireland, with both a national and regional focus. The organisation is also a member of ILGA-Europe, the European Region of the International Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Trans & Intersex Association, which works for equality and human rights for LGBTI+ people at the European level.
response_text: Ireland’s Presidency should support progress on policy areas and legislative proposals essential to delivering LGBTQI+ equality, including: Implementation of EU LGBTIQ+ Equality Strategy: provide strong leadership to ensure the Council fulfils its responsibilities under the EU LGBTIQ+ Equality Strategy, including through cooperation with other EU institutions, to ensure full and effective implementation; Mainstreaming Equality: champion systematic LGBTQI+ equality mainstreaming across all Council configurations, ensuring equality considerations are embedded in all policy areas and legislative proposals. The following focus areas will help close gaps in legal protections, and support the EU Strategic Agenda, Commission workplan, and more broadly a Union of Equality and Social Europe. Strengthening Anti-Discrimination Frameworks: prioritise closing long-standing gaps in the EU’s antidiscrimination legal framework. Current protections are uneven, limited largely to employment, and do not fully protect trans, intersex, and non-binary people, leaving significant gaps. Ireland should: o prioritise renewed efforts in Council to achieve the unanimity required to adopt the Horizontal Equal Treatment Directive (Pending Proposal 102, Ref: COM(2008)426 final 2008/0140 (CNS) 2.07.2008); o ensure concrete plans for comprehensive protection to include not only sexual orientation, but also gender identity, gender expression, and sex characteristics, taking into account EU case law, secondary legislation (Victims’ Rights Direct, Recast Qualification Directive, and the inclusion of these grounds in the 2024 Equality Bodies Directive (2022/0400). Tackling Hate: Rising hate speech and hate crime across Europe demand a coordinated EU response. Ireland should: o prioritise work to unblock progress on adding hate crime and hate speech to the list of Eurocrimes under Article 83(1) TFEU (Pending Proposal 100, Ref: COM(2021)777 final 9.12.2021); o facilitate Council discussions on approaches to tackling online hate including AI-facilitated discrimination and online harms, and addressing intersectional discrimination, to strengthen the EU’s capability to address emerging threats; o ensure the revised Victims’ Rights Directive reflects the specific needs of LGBTQI+ victims and marginalised groups in its implementation. Ensuring Freedom of Movement: facilitate Council work to ensure full and effective freedom of movement for all LGBTQI+ people and families. This fundamental right may be violated due to disparities between states in legal recognition of rainbow families, or the absence of or barriers to accessing legal gender recognition. Ireland should help progress legislation and guidance ensuring equal recognition across borders within the EU of family relationships, marriages, partnerships, parenthood, children’s rights, and legal gender recognition, to ensure fundamental rights and freedoms are upheld. Key priorities include: advance negotiations on the draft Regulation on mutual recognition of parenthood; o support incorporation of relevant CJEU rulings on cross-border family and gender recognition in legislation; encourage Member States to address barriers faced by rainbow families and trans and nonbinary people in cross-border situations. Migration and Asylum: We support and endorse the submission of the Coalition on the EU Migration Pact, of which we are a member. We particularly emphasise the need to protect the rights of LGBTQI+ migrants, refugees and asylum seekers in all relevant EU policy and legislation.

sector: National Organisation for LGBTQI+ people across Ireland
geography: LGBT Ireland is the national organisation for LGBTQI+ people across Ireland, with both a national and regional focus. The organisation is also a member of ILGA-Europe, the European Region of the International Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Trans & Intersex Association, which works for equality and human rights for LGBTI+ people at the European level.
response_text: Ireland’s Presidency can deliver the greatest positive impact by strengthening the fairness, effectiveness and inclusiveness of the Council’s work, ensuring EU policies deliver real and measurable benefits for people, businesses and communities across the Union. A Presidency grounded in fundamental rights, equality, democratic values and evidence-based policymaking will not only improve outcomes for marginalised communities, including LGBTQI+ people, but will also enhance social cohesion, economic participation, and trust in the European project more broadly. Ensure meaningful and structured engagement with civil society and affected communities: A strong and vibrant civil society is essential for a democratic, resilient and socially cohesive EU. Ireland should champion the establishment of a more formalised and inclusive mechanism for structured dialogue between civil society and the Council. It will be essential that this includes the meaningful participation of LGBTQI+ organisations in systematic engagement with the EU Council, including Council-led discussions, events, conferences, expert groups, and informal ministerial meetings. Civil society organisations, particularly those representing marginalised groups, bring essential evidence and realworld insight on barriers to rights, access to services, and implementation gaps. Ensuring sustained EU and national funding for these organisations will also safeguard their long-term contribution to EU policy development, strengthen democratic participation, and protect civic space at a time of increasing pressure. Promote people-centred, rights-based policymaking that strengthens social and economic inclusion: Policies that safeguard equality, combat discrimination and protect fundamental rights directly support stronger labour markets, healthier communities and more resilient economies. Ireland’s Presidency should help shape Council deliberations so legislative files and policy processes consistently consider the real-life impacts on those most affected, including LGBTQI+ communities. This principled approach will ensure new measures, whether in employment, digital policy, health, education, or internal market governance, lead to fairer participation, reduced inequalities, and improved outcomes for people, businesses and communities across Europe. Facilitate more effective rights protection and cross-border cooperation: A major challenge in the EU remains the uneven protection of rights and freedoms across Member States. The Presidency can add value by strengthening and coordinating the Council’s work to address and close gaps. Ireland can also promote better cross-border cooperation in areas where people and businesses encounter significant barriers, such as free movement, family recognition, access to services, digital identity systems, and tackling hate crime and violence. Improving legal certainty and reducing administrative burdens benefits not only LGBTQI+ communities but also employers, service providers and national administrations. Reinforce democratic resilience and trust in EU institutions: In a period of growing polarisation and disinformation, an inclusive Presidency that visibly centres EU values can help restore public trust. By supporting policy coherence between equality, rule of law, digital safety, and fundamental rights, the Presidency can demonstrate that protecting marginalised and minoritised groups also strengthens democracy, social stability and sustainable economic development.

sector: National Organisation for LGBTQI+ people across Ireland
geography: LGBT Ireland is the national organisation for LGBTQI+ people across Ireland, with both a national and regional focus. The organisation is also a member of ILGA-Europe, the European Region of the International Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Trans & Intersex Association, which works for equality and human rights for LGBTI+ people at the European level.
response_text: Ireland’s Presidency provides a unique opportunity to re-energise public understanding of the EU as a project rooted in peace, prosperity, equality and shared European values.
