To foster a sense of shared ownership and highlight the value of EU membership, the Irish Presidency should prioritize clear, inclusive communication strategies. Key actions include: Sharing real-life stories of patients: Sharing real-life stories of patients who benefit from faster diagnosis and equitable access will help illustrate the value of European action. Public communication should explain why tailored approval routes are necessary for rare disease medicines and highlight the risk-sharing mechanisms that ensure responsible innovation. Explaining the European impact of policy initiatives: Clearly communicate how EU-level actions—such as harmonized approval routes, risk-sharing mechanisms, and collaborative research—benefit citizens in all member states, not just Ireland. Engaging citizens through regional events: Ireland has a unique opportunity to demonstrate the regional impact of the life sciences sector, showcasing how EU policy supports jobs, training and research capacity in communities beyond major cities. Regional site visits to pharmaceutical and life-science facilities in Ireland, particularly in rural and regional areas during the Presidency can highlight how EU membership supports investment, employment and innovation across the country. Promoting inclusivity and transparency: Ensure that communication materials are accessible in multiple languages and tailored to diverse audiences, reinforcing the idea that the EU Presidency is a collective endeavour. Highlighting the role of EU membership in driving progress: Emphasize how working together as a Union enables member states to address complex health challenges more effectively than acting alone, and how every citizen benefits from shared solutions. By adopting these approaches, the Irish Presidency can help citizens across Europe feel connected to, and invested in, the work of the Council—strengthening both the sense of European identity and the tangible benefits of EU membership.

As stated, the Presidency should adopt “Competitiveness for Equity” as its guiding theme, ensuring innovation translates into faster and fairer patient outcomes. We believe publishing a National Life Sciences Strategy ahead of the Presidency will assist Ireland to lead on major EU initiatives such as the Critical Medicines Act and Biotech Act, shaping policies on supply resilience, regulatory simplification, and investment conditions. Integrating early access and separate evaluation routes for rare disease medicines should be a key element of a National Life Sciences Strategy. The strategy should include clear indicators to track progress, such as timeliness of access, use of real-world evidence, and clinical trial initiation. By positioning the health system as research-active and innovation-ready, and making rare diseases a central focus, Ireland can demonstrate leadership and drive practical improvements in diagnostics, data, and access for rare disease patients. By prioritizing rare diseases at the European level, the Presidency can drive practical improvements in patient outcomes, support investment in research, and reinforce the EU’s leadership in health innovation. Summary: Ireland’s EU Presidency should make rare diseases a central priority, implementing new policies and communication strategies to ensure faster, fairer access to innovative treatments. By adopting a collaborative, European approach, the Irish Presidency can help ensure that progress in rare disease care benefits all citizens, strengthens the sense of European identity, and demonstrates the tangible value of EU membership.

sector: Financial Services – Asset Management & Investment Funds
geography: EU Wide: Ireland is the second largest location for regulated investment funds in the EU and the third largest globally. The funds and asset management industry directly employs over 19,500 professionals across Ireland, with over 37,468 of a total employment impact right across the country and provide services to almost 8,900 Irish regulated investment funds with assets of just under EUR 5 trillion. Given our role as one of the EU’s major financial services centres, we have a responsibility to play a leading role in the development of policy that impacts citizens, businesses, investors, and the wider economy.
response_text: The upcoming Irish Presidency of the Council of the EU in H2 2026 will provide a significant opportunity to showcase Ireland’s leadership, commitment, and importance for the European Union. The remarks delivered by Tánaiste Simon Harris in February on our Union of Values and the emphasis on reviving European competitiveness and innovation; deepening European security; and protecting European values and democracy establish a positive tone for the Irish Presidency. As one of Europe’s major financial services centres, our country will play a crucial role in the debate and delivery of a successful Savings and Investments Union (SIU) and on efforts around simplification and burden reduction for Europe’s economic activity. The SIU is a key objective of the European Commission (multiple legislative proposals in 2025 and more planned in their 2026 Work Programme) and Council (March 2024 Eurogroup statement on the future of Capital Markets Union). With this in mind, we propose the following two suggestions to be considered as part of the Presidency’s High-Level Thematic Priorities: Building on the Promise of the Savings and Investments Union for EU Citizens and the Real Economy Delivering Simplification to Enhance our Global Competitiveness These themes support a prosperous, resilient, and globally competitive EU economy, while directly addressing citizens’ long-term financial wellbeing, including challenges related to aging populations and pensions. They also reflect the EU Strategic Agenda 2024–2029, which aims to improve citizens’ economic and social wellbeing and accelerate financial integration.

sector: Financial Services – Asset Management & Investment Funds
geography: EU Wide: Ireland is the second largest location for regulated investment funds in the EU and the third largest globally. The funds and asset management industry directly employs over 19,500 professionals across Ireland, with over 37,468 of a total employment impact right across the country and provide services to almost 8,900 Irish regulated investment funds with assets of just under EUR 5 trillion. Given our role as one of the EU’s major financial services centres, we have a responsibility to play a leading role in the development of policy that impacts citizens, businesses, investors, and the wider economy.
response_text: As noted in our response to Question 1, achieving substantial progress towards delivering a successful EU Savings and Investments Union (SIU) is critical to the EU’s long-term success. As the March 2024 Eurogroup statement explains, “Open, well-functioning, and integrated European capital markets are crucial to promote the single market and to attract the necessary investments, and thereby to boost the EU’s global competitiveness, innovation, sustainable growth, and job creation. It will provide better funding possibilities for growing companies, including small and medium-sized companies, and give EU citizens the opportunity to invest their savings more productively in Europe.” The Presidency should look to progress negotiations, ensuring thorough analysis of legislative proposals, on files related to the SIU programme as established in the European Commission’s SIU Communication (March 2025). These include: Market Integration and Supervision Package: This is a comprehensive legislative package that proposes amendments across the entire regulatory framework impacting investing (asset management, trading, post-trading, innovation, and supervisory structures). The Commission argues that its proposals will address EU capital market fragmentation, remove barriers to investment, and drive supervisory convergence. It is critical that we do not negatively impact those things that are working well, and here we would insist on the protection of the global UCITS brand – one of the biggest EU success stories. The Irish Presidency should facilitate rigorous debate of the Commission’s proposals and ensure there is ample time for detailed analysis of the wide-ranging proposals. Given the scale of the package, we would not expect the Irish Presidency to have reached a Council General Approach before the end of its Presidency but that it will have advanced the debate in Council. EU Securitization Framework Review: There is broad agreement on the need to revitalize Europe’s Securitization market. If successful, this could channel additional funding to EU businesses and spur innovation in Europe’s economy. The Irish Presidency should aim to reach a final agreement in trilogue by the end of 2026. Pensions Package: On 20 November 2025, the European Commission published a legislative package that proposes amendments to the Pan-European Personal Pension Product (PEPP) Regulation and the Directive on Institutions for Occupational Retirement Provision (IORP II). Given the importance of delivering a better pensions environment for EU citizens and ensuring their long-term financial wellbeing is protected, the Irish Presidency should seek to advance negotiations in Council on both of these legislative proposals, potentially reaching Council General Approaches for each. SFDR 2.0: Recognizing continued challenges around the EU’s Sustainable Finance Framework, the European Commission issued a proposal for a legislative review of the Sustainable Finance Disclosure Regulation (SFDR) on 20 November 2025. We believe that the Irish Presidency should aim to begin trilogue negotiations during its Presidency on the SFDR review.

Given our role as one of the EU’s major financial services centres, we have a responsibility to play a leading role in the development of policy that impacts citizens, businesses, investors, and the wider economy.
response_text: This is a very broad question, and we will limit our comments to the areas where our expertise offers value. Advancing reforms that deepen capital markets; establishing an environment where EU businesses are more investible; driving regulatory simplification and burden reduction; while protecting trusted investment vehicles (UCITS) will help unlock funding for companies and improve the long-term financial well-being of citizens. The Presidency can also maximise real-world benefits by clearly communicating how these initiatives support people and communities. By promoting financial literacy, highlighting practical gains such as better access to investment products, and showcasing how EU cooperation fuels business growth and financial security, Ireland can deepen public trust and engagement. This combination of targeted policy action and transparent communication will ensure the Council’s work delivers tangible improvements across the EU.

response_text: This question falls somewhat outside our area of expertise. We would suggest that by communicating specific examples of EU policy that demonstrate tangible benefits, that citizens will feel a stronger connection and sense of ownership over Ireland’s EU Presidency. Using the Savings and Investments Union workstream as a practical example, the Presidency can show how EU initiatives directly support citizens’ financial wellbeing, create new investment opportunities, and provide funding for the real economy.

For its 2026 EU Presidency, Ireland should prioritise sustainable energy, rural resilience, and communitycentred governance. In particular, the rapid scaling of biomethane under REPowerEU highlights the urgent need for independent impact assessments, strict environmental safeguards, and oversight of public subsidies to prevent unsustainable industrial-scale biogas projects. Ireland can lead by embedding legally binding rules on feedstock use, digestate management, and spatial planning, ensuring local communities have a real voice in decision-making rather than bearing disproportionate social and environmental costs. By championing a model that balances climate, biodiversity, and rural development goals, Ireland can set a European benchmark for fair, sustainable energy transitions. Prioritising transparency, equitable benefitsharing, and preventative regulation will help avoid repeating mistakes seen elsewhere in Europe, reinforcing trust in decarbonisation policies. These thematic priorities will position Ireland as a leader in creating energy strategies that are both ambitious and socially responsible.

The European Commission’s REPowerEU action plan has set biomethane production on a course of massive upscale as part of efforts to increase EU energy independence, fixing a target of 35 billion cubic meters (bcm) per year by 2030 – up from 4,1 bcm in 2023. However, until this day, no Impact Assessment was carried out on the target. As biomethane production continues to grow rapidly both in Ireland and Europe (with a currently 21% year-over-year growth), so do concerns about its associated environmental and social risks as well as the irresponsible use of taxpayers money. While biogas production from sludge or collecting the gas that is produced in landfills is appropriate, there are particular concerns about the effects of large-scale biogas production on the use of limited agricultural land, the continuation of polluting industrial animal production, harm to local communities, and the effects of methane leaking from biogas facilities. Further concerns arise when looking closer at promoted use cases for biomethane such as heating or transport which are often inefficient, expensive, and lock Europe into existing fossil infrastructure. The Irish Presidency should therefore prioritize conducting an independent, interdisciplinary impact assessment to evaluate the feasibility and sustainability of this target, ensuring it aligns with climate, biodiversity, and rural community goals. Emphasis must be placed on implementing strict economic, environmental, and social safeguards for biogas and biomethane production. With reference to the Commission’s 2026 Work Programme as well as the wider EU Strategic Agenda that highlights the need to secure Europe’s energy independence, we therefore encourage the Irish Presidency to: Advocate for an independent impact assessment of the EU’s 35 bcm biomethane target, as a prerequisite to develop further any expansion of biomethane production as part of relevant policy files in 2026, such as the Circular Economy Act, Bioeconomy Strategy, Livestock Strategy, Energy Union Governance Upgrade, and Common Agricultural Policy. This includes prioritizing truly sustainable feedstocks, efficient use cases, and avoiding lock-ins of fossil infrastructure. Include the voices of local communities in the debate. In order to expand biomethane production rapidly, the 2025 REPowerEU roadmap foresees a “tripartite contract to better address the diverging needs in different areas of the EU and include national and local stakeholders”. However, a focus has been set on facilitating dialogue between the EU Commission, EU Member States’ governments as well as industrial stakeholders; and no commitment has been made to give a role to local communities themselves that are affected by such projects. In line with its “peoplecentred” approach, the Presidency should therefore intensify its efforts to give the Irish people and local communities across Europe a greater say in the development of fair and sustainable biomethane strategies. Scrutinise public subsidy schemes for unsustainable biomethane production. This is critical to prevent perverse incentives that undermine the EU’s climate, food security, and energy independence goals. Current subsidies often favour industrial-scale biogas projects reliant on unsustainable feedstocks - such as manure from factory farming or energy crops competing with food production - which lock in polluting practices as well as animal welfare violations, and divert resources from truly circular solutions. Without strict oversight, these subsidies risk distorting markets, inflating demand for unsustainable livestock farming, and sidelining local, communityled projects that deliver genuine environmental and social benefits.

Ireland’s presidency provides a unique opportunity to develop and promote a gold standard indigenous biogas industry that is sized and scaled to meet community needs. Learning from EU countries with an established biogas industry, Ireland can avoid the pitfalls of social acceptance that are consistently documented as barriers to bioenergy projects across the EU (Mancini & Raggi, 2022). Current regulatory gaps and weak planning assessments underestimate the cumulative impacts on rural infrastructure. Public health and safety questions about hazardous gas storage, particular emissions and emergency service access are heightened when regulatory oversight is perceived as reactive rather than preventative. Research has highlighted that digestate management and changes in feedstock mixes are critical risk vectors that demand much stronger regulation than is currently applied (Piadeh et. al, 2024). Ireland, through its presidency, can set the standard by developing industry-specific planning regulations that include community engagement at its core. The National Biomethane Strategy points directly to a highly industrialised model aimed at rapid development across rural Ireland. Within this model, revenue accrues to outside multi-national agriinvestors while costs are borne by host communities in terms of road damage, odour, environmental degradation, and reduced property values. Communities demand transparent environmental impact assessments, accessible monitoring data and enforceable operating limits. The development of industryspecific planning regulations aligned with benefit-sharing mechanisms has the potential to provide a blueprint for use across the EU, while maintaining community engagement and the highest environmental standards. Meaningful community engagement, spatial planning that respects local carrying capacity, strict feedstock limits, alongside legally binding digestate management plans, are safeguards that would increase local acceptance. Rapid roll-out risks polarising rural communities, undermining trust in decarbonisation policy, and producing environmental and social harms that outweigh local benefits. Ireland has an opportunity through its EU presidency to either lead and develop new industry standards or to repeat mistakes already impacting the rural communities and the environment across Europe.

sector: Community Development Approach to Drugs Policy
geography: National network, also longstanding member of EU Civil Society Forum on Drugs
response_text: Supporting Civil Society and Community Engagement in EU and Irish Drugs Strategies 2026 will be a significant and important year in relation to the future direction of drugs policy for both the EU and Ireland, as both will be launching new Drugs Strategies during the year. For many years now, EU and Irish Drug Strategies have been underpinned by a common commitment to a whole-of-society approach, strengthening sectoral and partner co-operation and actively engaging civil society. This strong commitment to the crucial importance of having Civil Society and Community engagement at the heart of our response to drugs is reflected in both EU and Irish drug policy to date. Since it was formally established in 2008, the EU Civil Society Forum on Drugs (EU CSF) has played a crucial role in bringing the knowledge and experience of civil society from across the EU into its policymaking process and, in Ireland, community involvement has been central to all of our policymaking structures in relation to drugs for the last 30 years, through the engagement of Community Reps in our National Oversight Structures and Local & Regional Drug & Alcohol Task Forces. Citywide Drugs Crisis Campaign has been an active member of the EU CSF since 2012, the Ana Liffey Drug Project and Merchant’s Quay have also been involved as Irish member organisations. During this time Citywide has continued to highlight the innovative and inclusive model of a Community Development Approach to Drugs that has developed in Ireland and which is now deeply rooted in our NDS, reflecting a commitment to addressing not just drug-related harms but also the underlying causes that give rise to these harms. Taoiseach Micheál Martin, in his address to Citywide’s recent event to mark its 30th anniversary, restated the commitment of the Irish government to this approach “Challenges with drugs and substance abuse are experienced in every town, every city across Ireland, but the drivers and catalysts for these problems can vary substantially from community to community. That’s why the community development approach is so vital as it focuses on listening to the community members themselves – supporting them to identify their own unique challenges and working to address them.” A similar commitment to addressing underlying causes is reflected in the new EU Drugs Strategy, which sets out the need for a strong alignment between the Drugs Strategy and the forthcoming EU Anti-Poverty Strategy, which, in turn, sets out to address the multiple dimensions and structural causes of exclusion. Consultation on our next NDS will be ongoing during the first half of 2026 between the Dept of Health and the Oireachtas Committee on Drugs, with the Committee due to present its Final Report to government in June 2026. This presents an ideal opportunity to launch Ireland’s next National Drugs Strategy during the second half of 2026 at an event in Dublin to be hosted by the Taoiseach as part of the EU Presidency, and with EU Drug Ministers and our partners from EU Civil Society invited to attend.

organisation: The Music Publishers Association of Ireland (MPAI)
response_text: As representatives of an industry which is simultaneously local, national and international, as well as one built on commercial strength, outstanding creativity and leading technological innovation, we strongly recommend that Ireland’s Presidency of the Council in 2026 focuses on leading on clear implementation of what will have been two years of extensive EU policy making - particularly in the digital sphere. We encourage Ireland to lead on ‘simplification’ meaning implementation, not erosion or reduction in Single Market standards. Working towards a European Union of Member States driving Commerce, Collaboration and Culture.

organisation: The Music Publishers Association of Ireland (MPAI)
response_text: Aimi to achieve full Implementation of The EU Artificial Intelligence Act including the timely set up of the compliance provisions and framework. Delivery on the EU Digital Services Act and support for the new infrastructure e.g. DSC network throughout MS level and at EU level. Strong support for EU cultural policy including Music Moves Europe. Trade policy – ensuring Europe focusses on exporting its regulatory high standards to 3rd countries via FTAs and trade compliance talks.

organisation: The Music Publishers Association of Ireland (MPAI)
response_text: In order to give confidence to people, businesses and communities the Council and its Member States should focus on strong respect for recently concluded EU legislative packages, principally those highlighted in Q2 above. MPAI and our European/global level trade body is ready at any point to support the Presidency with detailed and sophisticated support for its work e.g. a presentation to COREPER I or II, ANTICI, MEHRTENS or similar support with presentations or events across the co-legislators in Parliament and Council. ICMP has done so successfully with the previous Irish Presidency.

organisation: The Music Publishers Association of Ireland (MPAI)
response_text: Among Ireland’s greatest political strengths are those which are evidenced at EU level also – respected diplomatic profile, robust economic planning and the frequently proven ability to bring together disparate European governments to common positions. Ireland, as a net financial contributor to the EU budget, also has a great story to tell re: return on investment in EU cooperation and policies. The music industry – so central to the Irish economy and whose profile is respected worldwide – is an industry of communication. We are ready to help work with the Presidency team to communicate how European cultural, digital, trade, IP and other policies have been hugely beneficial to every last European citizen and company.

organisation: The Music Publishers Association of Ireland (MPAI)
response_text: MPAI is national association ready to support your work. We would also emphasise that our international (European and global) trade body ICMP (www.icmpmusic.com) which represents the majors, indies and 80 national groups worldwide, with an office in Brussels and good relationship with the PermRep(s) is ready to help in supporting the Presidency to successful outcomes. Inclusion, equality, rights, and safety for all
Democracy, transparency, accountability, fairness, rule of law, and social justice
The EU started as a dream of equality and social justice – in these turbulent times we need to be reminded of that dream
Remind the world what it means to be an EU citizen and the rights and protections as well the social responsibilities that come with that membership and legacy

We are calling on the Irish government to champion trans and LGBTQIA+ rights during their presidency. Ireland led the world in 2015 by being the first country to include marriage equality our Constitution – we have the opportunity now to build on that legacy and reputation. We ask that you address the following issues: Implementation of the new EU LGBTIQ+ Equality Strategy 2026–30 Conversion Practices Hate crime and hate speech Implementing legal gender recognition across EU states Tackle anti-LGBTQ+ hate speech and harassment online We ask also that you address the rising violence against women – all women and especially our sisters in marginalized groups and groups who are especially vulnerable – which is part of the rising violence and oppression against the LGBTIQ+ community across Europe.

Competitiveness: Both Ireland and the EU as a whole have entered a period of increased uncertainty in recent times, with geopolitical developments giving rise to challenges in many Member States. In this context, an ongoing focus on maintaining and enhancing competitiveness to support continued economic growth must be a key priority for Ireland’s Presidency. Cork Chamber members emphasise the importance of a horizontal approach to competitiveness, strengthening factors within domestic and European control to mitigate the impact of external developments. Regulatory Simplification: In line with the recommendations made in the Draghi Report and other policy documents, progressing the simplification of EU regulation and legislative burdens will be critical in 2026. The simplification of overarching legislative and regulatory frameworks must be accompanied by enhanced supports for and investments in key policy areas that serve as a foundation for European businesses and communities to grow and thrive, such as innovation and research, and sustainability. The Single Market and Trade: Charting a course for a thriving Single Market and an environment in which European business can scale and grow is imperative, but must be accompanied by a recognition of the importance of balanced, regional economic development. In an era of geopolitical uncertainties, supporting market diversification and enhanced trade links with third countries is critical to the success of European business, as is managing EU relations with key partners such as the US. Supports for SMEs: Supporting SMEs to remain competitive is critical, and ensuring that regulatory frameworks are not overly burdensome for smaller enterprises must be a priority. This is particularly important as regulatory requirements in areas like sustainability continue to evolve, resulting in increased administrative and financial pressures on smaller organisations. Green and Digital Transitions: Key to Europe’s economic and population growth is a continued emphasis on both the green and digital transitions. Prioritisation of sustainability at all levels and a just transition for businesses and communities should be a core focus of Ireland’s Presidency. Ensuring that sustainability and climate goals are embedded in policymaking and practical actions at all levels is critical. Supporting businesses with clear, proportionate sustainability requirements is vital to ensure the continued competitiveness of Europe’s economy. This must be accompanied by bold action to accelerate the decarbonisation of Europe’s energy system, supporting a future of energy security and independence based on renewable sources. Deeper interconnection and collaboration in the European energy market is critical, alongside progress towards institutional decarbonisation, leveraging initiatives like the EU Climate-Neutral and Smart Cities Mission of which both Cork and Dublin are participants. Harnessing the progress already made in the digital transition to support increased digitalisation across sectors should be prioritised. New and innovative technologies have the potential to support areas like sustainability reporting, for example, and this potential should be explored and leveraged where appropriate. Ensuring that businesses, particularly SMEs, can access digital tools and digitalise their operations is also critical. In parallel, support for innovation must continue, enabling the European tech sector to grow and develop.

Advancing the EU’s ongoing competitiveness drive through appropriate regulatory simplification measures and Omnibus proposals should be a key focus of work for the Irish Presidency. In areas like sustainability reporting, simplification efforts must continue apace to reduce disproportionate administrative burdens affecting SMEs in particular. Progress on simplification, standardisation and the streamlining of regulatory requirements across policy areas will play an important role in enhancing competitiveness across Europe. The Irish Presidency should also seek to progress key national aims in this regard, such as the simplification of public procurement guidelines in line with the recommendations made by the recent Accelerating Infrastructure Taskforce Report, in order to enable more efficient infrastructure and housing delivery at a national level. Plans for Omnibus proposals in areas like taxation should also be progressed, supporting the national measures to simplify taxation policy announced in Budget 2026. In addition, proposals to deepen Single Market integration, as well as proposals regarding particular sectors, should continue to be a key focus of legislative progress, building on the recommendations of the Letta Report and advancements already made to improve market access and trade potential. Proposals to develop strategies for certain key sectors such as tourism are also important in the context of strengthening Europe’s domestic economy and should be a key focus. Policy areas like research and innovation, supporting research capacity, skills development and talent mobility should be another core focus area for Ireland’s Presidency term. Strengthening EU support for these critical policy areas will also contribute to Europe’s ongoing competitiveness. Proposals in the area of gender equality, fair labour, talent mobility and digitalisation are also crucial in this regard and should be progressed. Continued progress on key legislative files in the area of climate and sustainability should also be maintained. Areas like energy security and independence, as well as energy market integration and infrastructural improvements, are already the subject of a number of legislative proposals. Maintaining momentum in these areas is key to the future of the green transition. With a revision of climate targets planned for the coming months, it is vital that the journey to climate neutrality is accelerated where possible, with due regard for the potential impacts on citizens. In parallel, continued progress on legislation that will support businesses and communities in their sustainability and decarbonisation journeys is crucial. Ensuring that legislative requirements are fair and proportionate will be critical in this regard.

Ensuring engagement with Europe’s regions is vital to the success of any Presidency term. As an island nation on the outermost edge of Europe, Ireland’s regional development serves as an important success story when it comes to economic growth and regional investment; surveys indicating continued high support for Ireland’s EU membership are testament to this. Ireland’s Presidency presents an important opportunity to showcase Ireland’s regions on the European stage, demonstrating the transformative impact of EU membership. Hosting both high-level and citizen engagement events in regions across Ireland during the Presidency term should be prioritised, promoting continued engagement with regions and ensuring that the benefits of EU membership and possibilities for engagement with EU legislative developments are better understood. As Ireland’s second city and the key economic driver of the southern region, Cork should be considered as a potential location for events during the Presidency, both high-level and citizen-focused. Similarly, the Presidency presents an opportunity to encourage engagement with the Single Market. Supporting Irish businesses in accessing the Single Market and cross-border trade opportunities should be prioritised, as well as the promotion of Irish business in other Member States. Showcasing opportunities for talent mobility, cross-border research and innovation initiatives, and other collaborative programmes should form part of planned activities to accompany the Presidency term. Clear communications and guidelines regarding EU funding and programmes would support greater uptake, particularly among SMEs and smaller organisations who may not otherwise have the resources required to participate in EU-funded programmes.

Each quarter, Cork Chamber conducts an Economic Trends survey among members, assessing business confidence and economic outlook. In Q4 2025, members were also asked about potential policy priorities for Ireland’s Presidency, as well as their views on the benefits of EU membership and their awareness of plans for the upcoming Presidency term. While the majority of those surveyed were aware that Ireland would take on the Presidency of the Council of the EU in the second half of 2026, most were not aware of related events and activities. Ensuring that there is a higher level of awareness among both businesses and the wider population of European activities and initiatives during the Presidency term should therefore be a key focus of planning for the Presidency. Engaging with local and regional organisations to support regional events and citizen engagement initiatives, particularly youth engagement, should be explored in this regard. Alongside the high-level goals of the Presidency with regard to legislative developments and progress, there should be a focus on promoting social inclusion insofar as possible, through effective communication campaigns targeted regional, rural and disadvantaged communities who may typically feel excluded from European initiatives. The promotion of EU-funded programmes and initiatives to organisations should also be explored, ensuring that effective communications and guidelines are supplied to those who may be interested in participating. Equipping smaller organisations and SMEs with the necessary tools to avail of EU initiatives is crucial to encourage participation and demonstrate the tangible benefits of EU membership for organisations of all sizes, in all regions.

The Enterprise Europe Network (EEN) and REEValue are examples of European Commission-funded projects that deliver tangible value to businesses across the EU. Hosted within Cork Chamber, these projects ensure that local businesses can directly benefit from European expertise. The EEN is the world’s largest business support network for SMEs, operating in over 50 countries. Through EEN, Cork Chamber members can gain access to international trade and partnering opportunities, innovation supports and expert advice on EU regulations, funding and market entry. This is particularly valuable for companies seeking to expand internationally. EEN helps de-risk growth by providing expert advice, one-to-one support and access to a vast European business ecosystem. REEValue complements this by focusing on enhancing energy efficiency and promoting renewable energy investments for businesses in the food, drink & transport value chains. Through REEValue, Cork Chamber members are supported in reducing costs and improving environmental performance. For Cork Chamber members, the benefit lies in having direct access to European-funded expertise through a trusted local organisation. These projects enhance competitiveness, support sustainable growth and open international doors. Enhancing awareness and uptake of such initiatives, many of which are already available in Ireland, should also form part of planned Presidency activities.

Law Reform Commission: The Commission also recommends retaining the main elements of the current gross negligence manslaughter test, namely that the negligence which caused the death of the victim was of a very high degree and involved a high degree of risk or likelihood of substantial personal injury to others. But the Commission adds that a person should only be liable if he or she was mentally and physically capable of averting to, and avoiding the risk of death at the time of the fatality. The Legal Test (Ireland) Gross Negligence Manslaughter Duty of Care: The defendant must have owed a legal duty of care to the deceased (e.g., landlord to tenant, doctor to patient). Breach of Duty: The defendant breached this duty through an act or omission. Causation: The breach must have directly caused the death. Gross Negligence: This is the key element, judged by the jury: The negligence must be of a very high degree, significantly more than ordinary carelessness or the standard for civil liability. It must involve a serious and obvious risk of death, not just injury, to others. The conduct must be so bad in all circumstances that it amounts to a criminal act or omission, showing a reckless disregard for life 48 lives lost due to 31 bye-law breaches, can only constitute a very high degree of negligence – no sign of prosecution and/or justice Justice for 48 Stardust victims who were unlawfully killed – when someone has been unlawfully killed then someone has unlawfully killed them Nightclub fires in Europe: Club Cinq Sept France The Club Cinq-Sept fire was a major blaze at a nightclub just outside Saint-Laurent-du-Pont, Isère, France, on Sunday, 1 November 1970. Criminal charges were brought against a number of people; some received suspended jail sentences. Volendam Café Fire The owner was convicted to a conditional prison sentence and community service. As a result of the inquiry Mayor of Edam-Volendam Frank IJsselmuiden and alderman Wim Visscher resigned their positions. Colectiv Nightclub fire Bucharest On 2 November, prosecutors charged the club's owners—Alin Anastasescu, Paul Gancea, and Costin Mincu—with negligent homicide and negligent bodily harm, The Alcalá 20 nightclub fire occurred on 17 December 1983 at 4:45 a.m. at Alcalá 20. The four club owners were arrested and the trial, which took place 10 years later, found them guilty. Teatre and Fonda Nightclub fire Spain On 1 October 2023, a fire broke out in a building hosting at least three nightclubs in Murcia, Spain, killing at least 13 people and injuring 24. A SPANISH COURT has opened a manslaughter probe into a deadly fire that killed 13 people inside a nightclub which had ignored an earlier closure order. Stardust Nightclub fire Dublin 48 people unlawfully killed. 31 bye-law breaches to include locked, blocked and chained exit doors. Steel plates welded to windows, carpet tiles on walls, no staff fire training and more. No arrest, no charge, no prosecution, no punishment, nothing. Justice for 48 Stardust victims who were unlawfully killed – when someone has been unlawfully killed then someone has unlawfully killed them

Ireland provides an example of a successful peace process, and the Good Friday Agreement is rightly praised everywhere. Given the troubling state of the world, we can use our Presidency to promote the ingredients that make for successful, sustainable and peaceful societies. These include fundamental values, obligations and principles that are intrinsic to the EU and international legal orders. For example, on equality and human rights. Leadership next year therefore should be demonstrated by returning the EU to its foundational values in a world of conflict, war and growing disrespect for a rules-based order and its associated institutions. Too many states now operate with impunity and mock the values we claim to cherish. Ireland has managed a peaceful transition based on fundamental values and principles. Our island is facing into another transition in the years ahead – as the choice envisaged in the Good Friday Agreement will be exercised. These realities - for our shared island, for Europe and the world - should shape the approach that Ireland takes next year.

In April 2017 the European Council made clear that Northern Ireland will automatically return to the EU, if there is a vote for constitutional change. This remains a hugely significant development in the circumstances of Brexit. An EU promise to all the people of Northern Ireland. Moves towards constitutional change will happen within an EU member state. And because of this, Ireland has a responsibility to commence discussions with its European partners – and associated institutions – on the implications. There are multiple ways this can be achieved, publicly and privately, but in particular it would be of assistance to expand existing research efforts to embrace the European implications. That could include expert seminars, roundtables and events that explore constitutional transitions across Europe and internationally. Preparations for constitutional change in Ireland must therefore also include EU member states and institutions. Linked to this, the Presidency should ensure that Northern Ireland is fully included before, during and after. For example, proposals for observer status in the European Parliament should be advanced and connected to ongoing work to address the serious ongoing risk of deep and destabilising divergence on the island of Ireland.

At this moment of crisis for the world, with the rise of repressive authoritarianism and disregard for the rules of the international legal system, we must play our part in reminding everyone in the EU that our foundational values are hardwired into what makes for successful and sustainable societies that people want to live in. This is not the moment for the EU to abandon the progressive values it professes in its legal order. Human rights, equality and respect for international law make a genuine difference to the lives of people here and anywhere. Ireland must ensure that during the Presidency the shared values of principled leadership are maintained and defended.

Inclusion is central to achieving this objective. Ensuring that civic space actors are centrally involved at all stages. As indicated above, this is also about guaranteeing that the EU holds to its own fundamental values that secure protections for everyone: that will send a robust signal to the world. If the EU is serious about its own foundations, much more should be done to raise awareness of the role of the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights, the work of the EU Fundamental Rights Agency, and the necessity of respect for international law. This will include delivering an unequivocal message to those states that operate with impunity and continue to demonstrate contempt for international law. We need to remind ourselves, time and again, about the values that we are defending and why they matter. When the EU fails to live up to these values, we must say so. In Ireland this also means that the Irish Government should be open to the transition facing this island. The choice envisaged in the Good Friday Agreement is on the horizon. It will bring all the opportunities and benefits of EU membership for the people of Northern Ireland once again. A new and united Ireland within the EU is a realisable objective. We are constitutionally committed to this outcome. It is a choice promised to the people of Ireland. Communicating openly about the nature of our peace process - and what it means for Ireland’s future - is part of ensuring that Ireland can be trusted as a good faith actor in these conversations. In particular, work on the implications for the EU, the role the EU will play, and lesson learning from comparative experience in Europe should be part of this agenda. Many across Europe already know and understand this and are awaiting principled leadership from the Irish Government.
Simplification, Competitiveness and Reduction of Regulatory Burden

Prioritise implementation of the EU Simplification Omnibus Regulation amending Regulation 1107/2009 Prioritise the agreement of Sanitary and Phytosanitary (SPS) agreement with UK. There is also a requirement for Veterinary Medicine alignment of packaging. In the past, packaging could be shared across UK and ROI. This is becoming increasingly difficult as regulations diverge, and the timing of changes between UK and EU is not synchronised. Alignment will preserve the availability of Veterinary Medicines in ROI market.
By express delivery of regulation, in the context of the requirements outlined in Question 1 above.

Through effective communication of what it means to be a European citizen – Freedom of choice, Freedom of movement, Freedom to choose our Government through democratic election. Only 8% of the World’s population live in ‘true democracy’ and we are the lucky ones – let us not lose what the EU stands for.

sector: Youth information and mental health support
geography: spunout is an online service supporting young people across 26 counties.
response_text: Ireland’s high-level thematic priorities for its Presidency should include a specific focus on the crucial issue of amplifying youth voice, high-quality youth information and most importantly, youth mental health. This is an area of critical and growing concern for Ireland and the European Union. Ireland can lead the way in demonstrating a high-level commitment to tackling this issue from all member states.

sector: Youth information and mental health support
geography: spunout is an online service supporting young people across 26 counties.
response_text: The Irish presidency has a chance, through both the Employment, Social Policy, Health and Consumer Affairs Council and the Education, Youth, Culture and Sport Council to highlight the need for sustained and targeted investment in youth mental health across all member states. According to the WHO, mental health conditions are one of the leading causes of illness among young people, with more than half of these conditions emerging before the age of 14. Anxiety, depression and behavioural disorders are three leading causes of morbidity among adolescents. Young people face unique and distinct challenges and require a distinct focus on their mental health needs, with tailored, adequate support based on their specific challenges and life experiences. Untreated mental health issues in adolescence and young adulthood significantly contribute to a range of negative health outcomes across a person’s entire lifespan. The WHO Regional Office for Europe has found that one in seven children and adolescents aged 0-19 lives with a mental health condition, and that this number is increasing as time goes on. At the same time, the WHO has determined that one in five countries lack policies to support the mental health of children and young people. These issues are connected with the growing crisis of loneliness among young people in Europe, to which Irish young people are particularly at risk. Research by the European Commission has shown that Ireland has the highest reported rates of loneliness in Europe (20% self-reporting as lonely vs 13% of all Europeans). This problem is particularly and increasingly acute for young people and has a strong connection with the growing mental health crisis in our country and our continent.

sector: Youth information and mental health support
geography: spunout is an online service supporting young people across 26 counties.
response_text: In order to deliver a positive impact for people and communities across the EU during Ireland’s presidency, the Council should demonstrate a shared commitment from member states and European institutions to tackling the worsening challenges facing young people in the areas of mental health, social isolation and loneliness. The Council’s work will rightly and necessarily involve a great deal of consideration of ‘high-level’ geopolitical concerns facing the European Union; however, in order for the idea of the EU to mean something to young people across the continent, it is critical that they see the Council taking a serious and sustained interest in solving the most critical issues facing them in their own lives; of which mental health challenges and lack of appropriate services are among the most pressing, in addition to challenges facing young people relating to accessing high-quality youth information. For substantial positive impact, we recommend engaging young people in this work.

sector: Youth information and mental health support
geography: spunout is an online service supporting young people across 26 counties.
response_text: The best, indeed the only way to communicate the values and benefits of EU membership to young citizens is to ensure that the institutions of the European Union are responsive to their own needs, values and life experiences. Ireland’s Presidency of the Council should therefore lead the way in bringing young people into the deliberative and policy-forming process, inviting genuine and sustained youth participation as much as possible throughout the course of the Presidency. As they face increasing challenges of isolation, social atomisation, and mental health crisis, young people increasingly feel a sense of hopelessness and despair in relation to their democratic institutions. All European member states are dealing, in some way, with the fraying of the social contract as young people increasingly feel the promise of a better life for each subsequent generation has been abandoned. Young people will only feel true ownership of the European Union if and when they feel directly consulted, engaged and responded to by its institutions. spunout intends to run a Young Citizens’ Assembly in 2026, bringing together young people from all parts of the country to express their views on the crucial policy issues most important to them. We would be eager to discuss any ways in which this Young Citizens’ Assembly could work with the Government to ensure a greater youth connection with and ownership of Ireland’s Presidency of the Council of the EU.

sector: Youth information and mental health support
geography: spunout is an online service supporting young people across 26 counties.
response_text: In November 2025, spunout published a research report on the growing crisis of loneliness among young people in Ireland and the resultant impact on their mental health. We attach a copy of this research with our submission and are available to further discuss its findings at any time. About spunout: spunout is Ireland’s youth information and support platform, working towards an Ireland where all young people are supported and empowered to thrive. We offer a range of free and accessible services: we provide factual, youth-friendly information on mental health and wellbeing; immediate and anonymous text-based support; opportunities for young people to share their stories and experiences; and clear signposting to trusted services and resources nationwide. Our work is focused on measurably improving the quality of life for young people, increasing access to potentially lifesaving services. In 2025, spunout has facilitated 6,245 high-risk conversations, 5,553 involving self-harm and 692 involving suicidal ideation, and has supported 5,925 actively at-risk individuals to safety plan. Through our Navigator service, spunout has also connected more than 28,731 young people with information and signposting on vital mental health resources.

As representative of the 45,000 people living with epilepsy in Ireland, Epilepsy Ireland believe that delivering the World Health Organisation’s Intersectoral Global Action Plan on Epilepsy and Neurological (WHO IGAP) conditions should be a high-level thematic priority for Ireland’s presidency of the European council. This would not only benefit people with epilepsy, but also the entire neurological community in Ireland; with 800,000 people living with a Neurological condition in Ireland. The WHO IGAP was adopted by all EU members states in 2022, and called on all countries to: To raise the prioritisation of, and strengthen governance for, epilepsy and other neurological disorders. To provide effective, timely and responsive diagnosis, treatment, and care for all patients. To implement strategies for promotion and prevention of epilepsy and other neurological disorders. To foster research and innovation into, and strengthen information systems, for epilepsy and other neurological disorders. To strengthen the public health approach to epilepsy. Given the successes that Ireland has achieved by enabling a national focus on epilepsy and by resourcing (in part at least) the implementation of a national programme, the IGAP now provides us with an opportunity to collaboratively develop and implement the next level of critical transformation that is required here. For example, we still have one of the lowest ratios of consultant neurologists per head of population in Europe; we need to better integrate clinical genetics into epilepsy diagnosis and treatment; expand our epilepsy surgery programme; embed new e-health technologies into clinical practice; and there is an urgent need to tackle preventable epilepsy deaths including those from Sudden Unexpected Death in Epilepsy (SUDEP). Ireland has a proud recent history in leading the way on the international and European stage. For example, we created a global domino effect being the first country to introduce a smoking ban in 2004; and in 2015, we were the first country in the world to legalise same-sex marriage by popular vote. Our presidency of the EU in 2026 offers another opportunity to lead the way, by committing to the goals and targets of the IGAP on epilepsy and other neurological disorders – something that will have a national and European impact.

Under IGAP, national governments are required to take concrete steps to ensure that the targets set out in the plan are achieved by 2031 via several policy/legislative initiatives. These include ensuring that every country has at least one functioning awareness campaign or advocacy programme for neurological disorders, doubling global research output on neurological conditions, increasing service coverage for epilepsy by 50% from the 2021 baseline, and ensuring that 80% of countries have developed or updated legislation to promote and protect the human rights of people with epilepsy. Establishing an action plan to meet these targets under the auspices of Ireland’s EU Presidency would not only set a strong European example but also inspire global action, encouraging member states to follow suit. Ireland could seek Council support for the implementation of these key objectives and promote coordinated measures to address the shortage of specialist services, while highlighting positive developments at home, such as the publication of the Model of Care for epilepsy. In the area of research and innovation, our Presidency could advocate for the Horizon programme to prioritize epilepsy and neurological research, showcasing Ireland’s leadership through initiatives like FutureNeuro—Research Ireland’s world-class epilepsy and neurology research centre at the Royal College of Surgeons. This approach would strengthen EU research collaborations and accelerate progress in understanding and treating neurological conditions, delivering benefits for patients, science, and society.

Epilepsy is a neurological disorder characterized by a tendency to experience recurring seizures. In Ireland, over 45,000 people live with epilepsy, including 10,000–15,000 individuals who endure uncontrolled seizures. For this group in particular, the consequences can be profound and long-lasting, affecting education, employment, social participation, self-esteem, and independent living. Beyond these challenges, people with epilepsy must cope with the physical impact of seizures, the side effects of medication, and, for many, the social stigma and economic burden that often accompany the condition. Its deeply individual impact means epilepsy is frequently regarded as a hidden disability. Prioritising the implementation of IGAP during our presidency would send a powerful message to people living with epilepsy and other neurological conditions: that they are seen and valued. Through IGAP, we can address many of the obstacles they face, ensuring earlier diagnosis, access to appropriate medicines, surgical assessment where indicated, and coordinated community supports. For the wider European community, EU-led or supported awareness campaigns can play a vital role in reducing stigma and fostering a more inclusive and understanding society across Europe. The benefits of implementing IGAP extend beyond healthcare. A strong research and data agenda will accelerate innovation in therapeutics, diagnostics, and digital tools—creating opportunities for SMEs and industry while addressing unmet medical needs. This approach not only improves lives but also strengthens Europe’s position as a leader in brain health and neurological research.

For a small nation, Ireland has made an immeasurable impact on the global stage, and this is a source of pride for all our citizens. In our view, the true value of EU membership lies in its ability to foster a community that is collaborative, understanding, and supportive of every individual. We believe that prioritising the implementation of the IGAP and thereby focusing on a section of society that often feels underrepresented, undervalued, and misunderstood, is a powerful way to demonstrate the benefits of EU membership. Introducing a clear action plan to improve the lives of those affected will not only deliver tangible change but also showcase the EU’s commitment to inclusivity and care. Communicating these efforts will, in itself, help advance some of IGAP’s key objectives by raising awareness and increasing understanding of epilepsy and other neurological conditions. With limited progress made so far on IGAP implementation, Ireland has a unique opportunity to use the platform of our presidency to drive meaningful action. By doing so, we can spark a ripple effect across Europe, encouraging broader adoption and progress. Such leadership would be recognised by our citizens as a clear example of Irish initiative and ownership, reinforcing our reputation as a nation that leads with purpose and compassion.

Epilepsy affects over 50 million people worldwide, including more than 45,000 in Ireland. The WHO IGAP sets ambitious targets for 2031, aiming to drive universal awareness, double global research output, significantly expand service coverage, and strengthen human rights protections. Ireland is well-positioned to lead on this agenda, with a strong foundation that includes advanced clinical programmes, a growing specialist workforce, an epilepsy-specific electronic patient record, and FutureNeuro—a world-class epilepsy and neurolgy research centre. By showcasing these achievements while acknowledging the challenges and realities faced by people living with epilepsy, Ireland can spark an EU-wide conversation during our presidency that transforms IGAP commitments into measurable progress. We propose that Ireland uses its Presidency to secure Council Conclusions endorsing IGAP implementation across the EU, convene a High-Level Meeting on Brain Health with concrete deliverables on workforce development, digital health, and outcomes data, and launch an EU-wide awareness partnership to combat stigma while informing citizens about rights, safety—including SUDEP risk reduction—and access pathways. Epilepsy Ireland stands ready to support the Department of Foreign Affairs and the Department of Health in preparing content, engaging stakeholders and shaping communications to ensure that Ireland’s 2026 Presidency leaves a lasting legacy for people living with epilepsy and other neurological conditions across the European Union.

organisation: Shine: Support, Advocacy and Education for Mental Illness
geography: National, with EU-wide relevance through anti-stigma, rights-based and social-policy agendas
response_text: Ireland’s Presidency offers a real opportunity to embed mental health, as part of social resilience, equality, and human rights, within the EU’s strategic direction. Across the Union, mental illness is now a major public-health and socio-economic issue. The European Commission’s 2023 Communication “A Comprehensive Approach to Mental Health” and the European Parliament’s 2024 resolution on mental health both recognise this. The 2024–2029 EU Strategic Agenda commits the Union to strengthening resilience, protecting democracy, and promoting social cohesion. Mental health, and the structural factors shaping it, cut directly across these priorities. From Shine’s perspective, Ireland should champion three Presidency themes: 1. A People-Centred and Inclusive Europe: This would signal the importance of social protection, wellbeing, equality, and inclusion for all citizens, including those living with mental illness. It aligns with EPSCO Council work on mental-health integration across health, employment, and social-policy frameworks. 2. A Resilient and Healthy Europe: This theme should explicitly include mental health as a core pillar of public-health resilience, alongside preparedness for digital transformation, economic uncertainty, and demographic change. 3. A Rights-Based and Participatory Europe: Shine strongly supports an EU that centres lived experience and participation, reflecting UNCRPD principles and ongoing EU work on equality, anti-discrimination, and social inclusion. Together, these themes would help position Ireland’s Presidency as future-facing, socially grounded, and consistent with the 2024–2029 Strategic Agenda.

organisation: Shine: Support, Advocacy and Education for Mental Illness
geography: National, with EU-wide relevance through anti-stigma, rights-based and social-policy agendas
response_text: Several EU policy areas in 2026 intersect directly with mental health, human rights, and social wellbeing. Shine recommends prioritising the following: 1. Implementation of the EU’s Comprehensive Approach to Mental Health While the Communication is not legislation, Council configurations (EPSCO; Education, Youth, Culture and Sport) will be dealing with its rollout. Ireland can guide progress on: embedding mental-health targets within existing EU social-policy frameworks; promoting early intervention and community-based supports; strengthening cross-border access to mental-health information and services (building on the European Health Data Space Regulation). 2. Strengthening Social Inclusion and Anti-Discrimination Law This includes work expected under the Commission’s 2026 Work Programme on: improving the implementation of the EU Equality Directives; progressing long-delayed measures on non-discrimination outside employment; enhancing rights protections for people with psychosocial disabilities. 3. Digital Policy and AI Governance Mental-health impacts of digital transformation, including social-media harms, misinformation, and risks created by generative AI, should receive explicit focus. Ireland can lead discussions on: ensuring the EU AI Act is implemented with strong protections for vulnerable groups; promoting safe digital environments for young people; supporting research on digital determinants of mental health. 4. Employment, Poverty and Social-Protection Measures The EU Strategic Agenda identifies economic resilience and fair transitions as core priorities. The Presidency can help advance: renewed measures to reduce poverty and social exclusion; employment initiatives that remove barriers faced by people living with mental illness; stronger employer obligations around workplace mental health under the EU’s occupational-safety framework. What Ireland should aim to achieve Ireland should aim for: formal Council conclusions that strengthen the EU’s commitment to mental health across all policies; progress on files that enhance equality, participation, and social protection; greater visibility of lived-experience leadership in EU policy; practical, implementable outcomes rather than high-level statements.

organisation: Shine: Support, Advocacy and Education for Mental Illness
geography: National, with EU-wide relevance through anti-stigma, rights-based and social-policy agendas
response_text: Three approaches would maximise impact across the Union: 1. Mainstream mental health across all Council configurations Mental illness affects employment, education, social inclusion, poverty, digital safety and public health. Ireland can help ensure each formation- EPSCO, ENVI, EYCS, COMPET, TTE-reflects the mental-health dimension of its work. 2. Strengthen the rights and participation of people with lived experience A Presidency that embeds lived experience sets a standard for participatory policymaking. Ireland is well positioned to showcase models of NGO-government partnership and co-production. 3. Prioritise concrete, actionable outcomes Citizens will only experience “substantial positive impact” if 2026 produces measurable improvements. This includes: better access to mental-health supports; reduced stigma and discrimination; improvements in digital safety; stronger social-protection measures; commitment to inclusive labour markets. By focusing on outcomes rather than symbolism, Ireland can deliver meaningful improvements that are felt across communities, including those marginalised by mental illness.

organisation: Shine: Support, Advocacy and Education for Mental Illness
geography: National, with EU-wide relevance through anti-stigma, rights-based and social-policy agendas
response_text: Shine recommends a Presidency communication approach that emphasises: 1. Real, people-centred stories Citizens respond to lived experience, not institutional language. Sharing concrete stories—of improved services, rights protections, or digital safety—helps people see the EU’s relevance in their daily lives. 2. Visibility of community and NGO voices Including NGOs, lived-experience advocates, young people, and local organisations in the Presidency narrative will help build ownership. Ireland has a strong civil-society sector that can communicate EU benefits credibly. 3. Engagement outside traditional political spaces To reach people who feel disconnected from EU institutions, Ireland should prioritise: community-based events; regional town-hall sessions; targeted digital campaigns aimed at younger audiences and marginalised communities. 4. Transparency and clarity Citizens need a clear explanation of what a Presidency does and what it cannot do. Making the process accessible, concise and visible will strengthen trust and democratic engagement.

organisation: Shine: Support, Advocacy and Education for Mental Illness
geography: National, with EU-wide relevance through anti-stigma, rights-based and social-policy agendas
response_text: Shine encourages Ireland to use its Presidency to demonstrate leadership on mental health across the EU. Member States face rising levels of psychological distress, increased suicide risk in marginalised groups, and structural inequalities that compound poor mental health outcomes. The Union has already recognised mental health as a cross-cutting policy issue, but implementation remains uneven. Ireland has significant expertise, from community-based models to lived-experience governance, that can enrich EU-level discussions. By championing a people-centred and rights-based approach, Ireland can help ensure that mental health is not treated as a niche health topic but as an essential part of the EU’s social and economic resilience. If helpful, Shine can provide more detailed information on: lived-experience governance and policy development/implementation models; national anti-stigma initiatives; community-based recovery supports; lessons from Ireland’s suicide-prevention work; approaches to digital safety and mental health.

Honestly the only policy decisions I see European countries make look like they are designed to Deliberately inflicting on the group conditions of life calculated to bring about its physical destruction, in whole or in part Imposing measures intended to prevent births within the group Indigenous European people want to have kids but increasingly can’t afford to because they are being punitively taxed to pay for global majority people to move to their country. Indigenous Europeans are dying out as a group because of your policies. Global majority immigrants are very, very expensive (see data from Sweden, Denmark, Holland etc.). Indigenous Europeans are a minority group. Please just focus on not genociding them. Its very, very easy.

As Ireland prepares for its Council Presidency in 2026, it has the opportunity to champion forward-looking priorities that strengthen the EU’s competitiveness, democratic values, and cultural identity. One of the key themes should be supporting and empowering Europe’s Cultural and Creative Sectors and Industries (CCSIs) in the digital age. The Irish Presidency should continue the work of the current Danish Presidency and make AI and copyright a cornerstone of its agenda, express a clear intention to embed digital and cultural policy in Europe’s competitiveness and security agenda. The European CCSIs, including the media sector, are central to the EU’s economic and cultural strength. They provide around 17 million jobs and contribute roughly 7% of EU GDP. Beyond their economic impact, these sectors express the heart of Europe’s identity, diversity, and democratic principles. Europe’s longstanding leadership in art, media, and culture has shaped its global influence. Yet this position is increasingly under pressure due to rapid technological change, especially the rise of AI and other frontier technologies, without said change being accompanied by fit-for-purpose legal protections allowing rightsholders to exercise and enforce their copyright and related rights. EU policy must evolve toward a digital environment that is both innovative and fair, one that protects and promotes European creativity. The unauthorised use of large quantities of creative works for AI training and other copyright-relevant AI-related purposes poses real risks for the sector’s sustainability and for the livelihoods of authors, artists, publishers, and other rightsholders. In many cases, creative content has been copied, processed, and monetised without permission or payment, undermining the exclusive rights guaranteed by EU copyright law. This disrespect of EU rules not only threatens the economic foundations of creative professions but also weakens public trust in technology. Ireland could prioritise a theme: “Culture, Creativity, and Fair Innovation in the Digital Era” Under this banner, the Presidency could work to strengthen the protection of authors, artists, publishers, and rightsholders by promoting robust implementation and enforceability of the EU copyright acquis; ensuring full, actionable transparency in AI purposes; promoting licensing; and exploring fair remuneration models when creative works are used by generative AI models and systems. Given Ireland’s strong history and experience of regulation, the wide number of technology companies based in Ireland and strength of the sectors where AI is having a significant impact, such as music and pharma, together with the breadth and reputation of Irish literary work, we are perhaps uniquely positions towards a responsible, ethical and rights-respecting AI environment.

A key priority for the Irish Presidency in 2026 should be strengthening the EU copyright framework to ensure effective protection of authors, publishers, rightsholders and their creative works in the AI era. As generative AI technologies increasingly rely on large-scale ingestion and reproduction of creative content, the EU must reinforce rules that safeguard creators, preserve cultural diversity and support sustainable media and cultural ecosystems. All of this work should be guided by the long-standing principles of international and EU copyright law. At the core is the three-step test, set out in the Berne Convention and embedded throughout the EU copyright system. Under this test, any exception to copyright must be limited to specific cases, must not interfere with the normal use of a work, and must not unfairly harm the legitimate interests of rightsholders. This remains the key standard for assessing any proposal to broaden exceptions or limitations. The Irish Presidency should make clear that this principle continues to apply to all EU policy developments, including those involving AI, text and data mining, and the digital use of protected content. In addition, the Presidency could assess and further examine the European Parliament’s proposal to establish an irrebuttable presumption that, for any general-purpose AI model or system placed on the Union market, copyright-protected works and other protected subject matter have been used for training whenever the applicable transparency obligations have not been fully met.

First and foremost, the Presidency should prioritise open dialogues and inclusiveness with the directly impacted stakeholders (authors, artists, publishers, rightsholders in general and collective management organisations). Building on the work of previous Presidencies (the Danish and, before this, the Polish and Hungarian ones), Ireland could organize structured consultations, expert conferences, and targeted questionnaires to collect evidence and perspectives from across Member States and sectors to assess the impact of AI and digital technologies on Europe’s creative and information ecosystems. Ensuring that all voices (large and small businesses, CCSIs, civil society, and academia) are represented will strengthen the democratic legitimacy of EU policymaking and help achieve balanced and future-proof outcomes. Inclusive dialogue would also facilitate a more coherent implementation of existing EU frameworks. While much attention has been given to audiovisual and music industries, the text, image and publishing sectors, including journalism, literature, visual arts and translation, have faced some of the earliest and most profound disruptions. Generative AI is trained and subsequently built upon vast volumes of protected written and visual material, including press content, literary and visual works, often without authorisation, credit, or remuneration. This not only undermines the rights of authors and publishers but also distorts the market by enabling AI-generated content that is often misleading, unverified, and hallucinatory, competing unfairly with authentic, human-created work.

Social media is now a primary source of information for a majority of EU citizens. The Irish Presidency could take the lead by running an EU-wide awareness campaign that uses visuals, short videos, infographics, and personal stories to clearly explain what the EU has achieved and how its policies make everyday life better. People are more likely to feel connected to their European identity when they understand what it means and why it matters. Sharing regular, easy-to-follow updates on the Presidency’s priorities, decisions, and results, through the accessible channels mentioned above, can help make the Council’s work feel less distant or complicated. Showing how Ireland’s leadership is shaping EU policy on real-life issues like protecting culture and the creative workers would strengthen its image as a positive and influential voice in Europe. Iti is also important for the Presidency to resist any simplification agenda which would erode fundamental rights of creators or undermine the legal certainty provided by the EU copyright framework.

sector: Supporting approved housing bodies (AHBs) to increase delivery of social and affordable housing.
response_text: Housing access and affordability has become a Europe-wide issue in recent years with the numbers of households at the most acute end of this issue growing. FEANTSA, the European Federation of National Organisations Working with the Homeless estimate that 1.2m people in Europe are either sleeping rough or accessing emergency accommodation. Ursula von der Leyen, in her State of the Union address recently said that what Europe is experiencing is “more than a housing crisis, it is a social crisis” and promised that the forthcoming Affordable Housing Plan will be “a European effort anchored in local realities”. While housing will remain a national competency, the European Commission providing high-level leadership on this issue in delivering an Affordable Housing Plan is a recognition of the vital role housing plays in social cohesion. The forthcoming EU Anti-Poverty Strategy, expected in Spring 2026, will focus on addressing structural inequality including how this manifests in housing terms through homelessness. Both the Affordable Housing Plan and the Anti-Poverty Strategy are outlined in the 2026 Commission Work Programme therefore a high-level thematic priority that focuses on housing and homelessness would be very much in keeping with policies that will begin their implementation during the Irish Presidency as well as resonating locally where housing remains one of the most pressing social issues. Ireland has recently launched a new housing plan, “Delivering Homes, Building Communities”, which aims to deliver 300,000 additional homes by 2030. This plan builds on plans launched in 2016 and 2020. The AHB sector was and is central to delivering the social and affordable housing commitments in these plans. As a sector we believe there is an opportunity to highlight some of challenges and successes with a housing summit hosted by Ireland during the Presidency. There is already a successful model which the sector is happy to work with other key stakeholders to replicate. The International Social Housing Festival which was hosted by the ICSH in June 2025 in Dublin.
