Ireland’s Presidency priorities will focus on addressing shared challenges across EU member states and housing is also central to several other of these common issues such as competitiveness, EU budgets including a Multiannual Framework Budget and adapting and preparing for climate change. Ireland’s EU presidency comes at a key time when State Aid rules are being revised to help Member States with the delivery of social and affordable housing and the EU initiates the use of the Social Climate Fund to deliver member states’ Social Climate Plans to ensure a Just Transition for “vulnerable” households. Measures such as increasing the energy efficiency of buildings, the renovation of buildings, the decarbonisation of heating and cooling in buildings set out in these plans are aligned with housing as a central-theme.

sector: Supporting approved housing bodies (AHBs) to increase delivery of social and affordable housing.
response_text: The Lisbon Declaration, signed in June 2021, was a commitment by EU Member States at the highest political level to end homelessness by 2030. Since then, progress on working towards this aim has been inconsistent across Member States. The European Platform on Combatting Homelessness (EPOCH), in which the DHLGH is involved, has delivered important outcomes in the areas of mutual learning, monitoring and promotion of good practices. However, there is no clear roadmap at EU level on how the aim of ending homelessness by 2030 will be achieved. As homelessness is such an acute and unfortunately growing issue within Europe, we would hope to see a Council of Ministers meeting on this issue during the Irish Presidency to include a recommendation on ending homelessness. This would reaffirm the principles and objectives of the Lisbon Declaration and, taken in tandem with the roll-out of the Affordable Housing Plan and Anti-Poverty Strategy, would deliver the strongest possible guidance to Member States on the need for progress on ending homelessness. When it comes to housing more generally, the EU has identified priority areas to support Member States to address structural drivers and unlock public and private investment for affordable and sustainable housing, as follows: Establish a pan-European investment platform for affordable and sustainable housing Inject liquidity into the housing market and double the planned cohesion policy investments in affordable housing Revise state aid rules to make it easier for member states to support affordable housing Develop a European Strategy for Housing Construction to support housing supply Tackle systemic issues with short-term accommodation rentals and analyse the impact of housing speculation Bring down energy bills and reduce energy poverty to make homes affordable, decent, and sustainable Through the Affordable Housing Dialogue we will identify further areas where there could be European added value We expect the EU Affordable Housing Plan due for release in December 2025 to set out the role of the European Commission in addressing these cross-cutting policy and legislative areas, that could be further developed and actioned through Ireland hosting the EU Housing Summit during the term of its EU presidency. The Public Procurement Act and the delivery of housing should also be tied in to the Green Deal and the climate change agenda.

sector: Supporting approved housing bodies (AHBs) to increase delivery of social and affordable housing.
response_text: In September 2025, Ursula von der Lyon stated that “Housing is about dignity. It is about fairness. And it is about Europe's future. Eight years ago, the European Pillar of Social Rights made housing a social right in Europe. It's time to turn this promise into reality.” Housing access and affordability is a challenge across the European Union and is having a negative impact on people, business and communities. There is a unique opportunity to work together across these three strands to share and promote workable and replicable solutions to the housing crisis. In December 2025, the EU will publish its first ever EU Affordable Housing Plan, and Ireland through its EU presidency will be in a position to influence the transition of this plan from words into action in the early days of its implementation, which will impact on the lives of all EU residents. Ireland is in a unique position to show leadership in this regard in terms of the levels of government support it is currently providing for the delivery of the housing (being one of the highest capital spenders in Europe on a per capita basis), and having demonstrated the capacity to (i) scale up the delivery of social housing over the last decade at an unprecedented pace through non-profit providers in partnership with private sector builders, developers and local authorities, and (ii) successfully create a new tenure of cost rental housing to address affordability challenges for “the squeezed middle” who earn too much to qualify for social housing and which is currently being scaled up in delivery through social housing providers, local authorities and a publicly owned “state developer” in the form of the Land Development Authority.

sector: Supporting approved housing bodies (AHBs) to increase delivery of social and affordable housing.
response_text: While the policy programme of the Irish Presidency cannot exclusively focus on national policy priorities, the inclusion as a high-level theme of an issue that is both in keeping with the Commission’s Work Programme and that resonates with citizens in Ireland and across Europe would be an important instrument in building buy-in and ownership among citizens. Spotlighting the work that Europe is doing on housing and homelessness, as well as the scale up of retrofit programmes, especially those targeted at the inclusion of vulnerable groups such as tenants of social housing, and re-affirming it through a Council of Ministers recommendation could underline the benefits of EU membership and make its work more tangible for all.

sector: Supporting approved housing bodies (AHBs) to increase delivery of social and affordable housing.
response_text: The ICSH represents over 270 housing associations, large and small, that deliver homes for families across Ireland and are a presence in every community. The new national housing plan, Delivering Homes, Building Communities, along with the forthcoming EU Affordable Housing Plan provides us with a unique platform to host a housing summit. There is an appetite to share information and solutions across Europe as evidenced by the number of attendees at the International Social Housing Festival (ISHF) hosted by the ICSH in Dublin last June. The ICSH facilitated many site visits to exemplary social and affordable housing schemes across Dublin as part of the ISHF and we would be very willing to showcase what the approved housing body sector has achieved as part of any forthcoming housing related events. European funding has contributed to the development of many social and affordable housing projects in Dublin and across Ireland. European Investment Bank and Council of Europe Development Bank funding has been crucial for many schemes. In addition, European funding through Interreg, Horizon Europe, Erasmus, Erasmus+ and the Leonard da Vinci programmes have contributed to the climate innovation, retrofitting and education and training development of the approved housing body sector. Ireland’s record in social and affordable housing delivery, and especially in recent years, the development of cost rental housing, has been something that other European member states have been keen to examine and learn from. Approved housing bodies have led the way in the development of cost rental housing as a mechanism to increase affordable housing options for middle income groups. The sector has delivered over 2,000 cost rental homes since the scheme’s inception with a strong pipeline of many thousands more to be delivered. In the ICSH, we have a very strong track record of facilitating knowledge exchanges between practitioners across Europe and would be very willing to be part of any such work during Ireland’s presidency.

From the perspective of the Irish Deaf Society, Ireland’s Presidency should place people and communities firmly at the centre of EU decision-making. Values such as respect, diversity, inclusion and accessibility should guide the Presidency’s high-level priorities. A first theme should be Accessibility and Inclusion. These are essential to ensuring that everyone can live, work, travel and participate fully in European society. Ireland should champion accessibility as a shared European value, in line with our obligations under the UNCRPD. A second theme should be A People-Focused Digital Future. As digital systems increasingly shape our lives, the EU must ensure digital developments are trustworthy, safe and accessible from the start. This means embedding sign language access, captioning and universal design into AI systems, online platforms and public digital services. A third theme should be Strengthening Democracy and Community Participation. Ireland is well placed to highlight how accessible information, inclusive public dialogue and community engagement build trust in European institutions. Ensuring that Deaf and disabled people can engage with EU processes is vital to democracy. These priorities would reflect Ireland’s reputation for fairness and leadership in equality, while providing a positive and forward-looking vision for the EU.

areas? Ireland’s Presidency offers a valuable opportunity to shape practical progress on rights, accessibility and equality across the EU. For the Irish Deaf Society, several policy areas deserve particular focus. First, the Presidency should prioritise strong and consistent implementation of the European Accessibility Act. As key provisions take effect from 2025 onwards, Ireland can support Member States navigate challenges, share good practice and ensure that accessibility obligations, such as accessible digital content, consumer goods and communication standards deliver meaningful improvements for citizens. Second, Ireland should continue advancing the EU Disability Rights Strategy 2021-2030, ensuring that UNCRPD principles underpin Council discussions across all areas. This includes progress on the European Disability Card, accessible transport, inclusive employment and access to justice. Third, digital policy requires particular care. As the EU rolls out the AI Act and develops further digital measures, Ireland should champion accessibility by design. Digital products and services must include sign languages, captioning and usability standards from the outset, not as an afterthought. Finally, Ireland could play a constructive role in highlighting the EU’s rich linguistic diversity, including national sign languages. Promoting accessible public information, emergency communication and recognition of sign language rights will contribute to a more cohesive European community.

The EU delivers its greatest value when decisions translate into tangible improvements in people’s everyday lives. Ireland’s Presidency can help ensure that Council work has real and lasting impact across communities, businesses and public services. A central way to achieve this is by mainstreaming accessibility across all policy discussions. Accessible legislation, communications, transport and digital services benefit everyone. They reduce barriers and support people to participate more fully in work, education and public life. Ireland can also ensure that civil society and DPOs are meaningfully included throughout the Presidency. When people with lived experience help shape policy, the outcomes are stronger, more practical and more widely supported. This reflects the UNCRPD principle of “nothing about us without us”. Another important contribution lies in building public trust. Inclusive communication, including sign language interpretation, captions and accessible formats, will help ensure that people across the EU understand and feel connected to the work being done in their name. Finally, Ireland can champion initiatives that remove cross-border barriers, whether in travel, digital public services,or consumer rights. When people can move freely, access services easily and trust that their rights apply wherever they go, the EU becomes more relevant and beneficial to everyday life. By promoting inclusion, fairness and practical solutions, Ireland can help shape an EU that people genuinely feel a part of.

Ireland has always approached Europe with a sense of partnership, community and possibility. To foster a strong sense of ownership over the Presidency, communication must be open, accessible and community-focused. A first step is ensuring that all Presidency information is fully accessible, including Irish Sign Language interpretation, captioning, Plain English materials and clear multilingual communication. When people can access the information, they can engage. Ireland should also work closely with DPOs, community organisations, youth groups and schools. People connect best with Europe when they can see the relevance in their own daily lives, whether that’s through accessible public services, travel rights, digital protections or cultural exchange. Sharing real stories of how EU membership supports people, businesses, students and communities across Ireland can help make the benefits concrete and relatable. Short videos in ISL, local media features and community events would resonate strongly. The Presidency also offers an opportunity to highlight Ireland’s own linguistic and cultural diversity, including Irish Sign Language. Visibility of ISL at public events sends a powerful message about inclusion and equality, both Irish values and European ones. Finally, we can build a sense of collective ownership by giving people opportunities to participate, whether through consultations, online forums, town-hall events or accessible digital platforms. By focusing on openness, accessibility and community connection, Ireland can help citizens feel both informed about and included in the work of the EU.

The Irish Deaf Society welcomes this opportunity to contribute to the development of Ireland’s Presidency Programme. As Ireland’s national Deaf-led DPO, we emphasise that full implementation of the UNCRPD must guide all aspects of the Presidency. Ireland has the chance to show real leadership by ensuring that accessibility, equality and participation are reflected not just in policy content, but in the design and delivery of the Presidency itself. IDS would be pleased to work with Government departments to support accessible communication, event planning, and inclusion of DPOs throughout the process. These actions would strengthen Ireland’s standing in Europe and demonstrate our commitment to fairness, respect, and the rights of all citizens.

organisation: Association for the Study of Obesity on the Island of Ireland (ASOI), Irish Coalition for People Living with Obesity (ICPO), and the European Association for the Study of Obesity (EASO)
response_text: We believe that the upcoming Irish Presidency should continue with the overarching theme of working to improve the health and well-being of EU citizens, with a particular focus on obesity. For several years, the European institutions have maintained a focus on addressing non-communicable diseases (NCDs) and implementing prevention measures. The EU launched its Healthier Together – NCDs initiative in December 2021 which aimed to reduce the burden of major NCDs and improve citizens’ health and well-being. This included 5 strands: health determinants, cardiovascular diseases (CVDs), diabetes, chronic respiratory diseases, and mental health. In June 2024, under the Belgian Presidency, the Council adopted a set of conclusions on the Future of the European Health Union, which call for further actions to prevent non-communicable diseases and for addressing priority needs in healthcare. At the same time, the European Commission has worked on Europe’s Beating Cancer Plan that was published in 2021, accompanied by a Council recommendation for a new approach on cancer screening in 2022 under Czechia’s Presidency. Following a set of Council conclusions on the improvement of cardiovascular health in the European Union in December 2024 led by the Hungarian Presidency, the Commission is now expected to adopt a strategy for an EU Cardiovascular Health Plan on 16 December 2025. The EU Cardiovascular Health Plan is likely to be an important topic of discussion in the upcoming Cypriot Presidency in the first half of 2026, as also requested by Commissioner Olivér Várhelyi in the latest EPSCO meeting. One important aspect that is missing from all these initiatives is appropriate action to address obesity. EU level action on obesity is critical as obesity is now the fourth leading risk factor for mortality globally, followed by high blood pressure, dietary risks, and tobacco use. More specifically, in Europe, between 10-13% of all deaths are linked to obesity, making it a leading contributor to preventable mortality. Importantly, it is a chronic, relapsing disease that also acts as a gateway for other non-communicable diseases as it increases the risk for over 230 other conditions and NCDs. Despite its growing prevalence, and the significant health implications for people living with obesity, obesity has still not received the same attention at the EU-level as other NCDs. For example, even though the upcoming EU Cardiovascular Health Plan is expected to address obesity and diabetes, these diseases have been limited as simply risk factors for the development of CVDs within the Call for Evidence. In reality, obesity is a direct causal factor for several CVDs and managing obesity can reduce the prevalence of CVDs and other NCDs. It is clear that the Council has been very influential previously in progressing action on NCDs, specifically cancer and CVDs. We would like to see the Irish Presidency continue this important work, building on the discussions held by the Cypriot Presidency on cardiovascular health, by driving forward discussions on EU-level action on obesity.

organisation: Association for the Study of Obesity on the Island of Ireland (ASOI), Irish Coalition for People Living with Obesity (ICPO), and the European Association for the Study of Obesity (EASO)
response_text: Following the work of the Council in the development of Council conclusions on the improvement of cardiovascular health in Europe and the upcoming publication of the EU Cardiovascular Health Plan in December 2025, the Irish Presidency should continue building on this work on NCDs by focusing specifically on obesity. While obesity is not specifically related to a specific legislative proposal, obesity is one of the most pressing health and societal challenges faced by Europe. Because it is a chronic, relapsing disease that also acts as a gateway to the development of several other NCDs, a coherent and comprehensive approach to addressing obesity is essential to reducing its impact on individuals, health systems and economies. As part of this focus on obesity, the Irish Presidency could aim to publish a set of Council Conclusions related to obesity that outlines the Council’s overall position on obesity and encourages the European Commission to take action through the development of a concrete EU Action Plan on Obesity, drawing on the Europe’s Beating Cancer Plan and the EU Cardiovascular Health Plan. It may also be beneficial to host an event in parallel with an EPSCO Council meeting to continue these discussions and bring additional stakeholders to the table to discuss the need for EU level action on obesity. As representatives of people living with obesity, researchers and practitioners working on obesity, we believe that the Irish Presidency is well-placed to drive forward the discussions that will lead to the development of an ambitious, patient-centred EU Action Plan on Obesity that encompasses preventive health measures and health promotion, improved screening and diagnosis, and comprehensive treatment and management. Some of the key aspects that should be considered by the Council include: • Adopting obesity as a health and societal priority, similar to other NCDs. The need to develop and implement comprehensive, multi-sectoral approaches to address obesity through comprehensive national plans and the establishment of multidisciplinary treatment pathways in line with other chronic diseases. Considering the need to work together with other NCDs, for example, by implementing joint obesity, diabetes and CVD health checks to reduce burden on healthcare systems and patients. Calling for research and funding opportunities, for example by launching an EU-funded project on health literacy in obesity or for advancing the research agenda. Implementing comprehensive obesity education in medical, nursing, and health professional curricula. The Irish Presidency can take a leadership role in driving forward these discussions by building on the work the Irish government has already undertaken on obesity through its Irish Obesity Policy and Action Plan for 2016-2025, which is currently being revised for 2026 onwards.

organisation: Association for the Study of Obesity on the Island of Ireland (ASOI), Irish Coalition for People Living with Obesity (ICPO), and the European Association for the Study of Obesity (EASO)
response_text: From our perspective, the Irish Presidency can make the most substantial impact by addressing the key issues that people and communities across the EU are living with. One of the most pressing of these is the rising prevalence of obesity, particularly as it is a gateway to other NCDs and significantly affects the quality of life of people living with the disease. In Ireland alone, the prevalence of obesity has doubled in the last 3 decades and 21% of Irish adults were living with BMI-defined obesity in 2024. There is a strong socio-economic gradient to obesity prevalence, and large inequalities in health status exist according to socio-economic status in Ireland. More broadly in the EU, 23% of adults were estimated to have BMI-defined obesity. Living with overweight or obesity affects far more than health – it can shape people’s daily lives and opportunities. These conditions also create a substantial strain on healthcare systems and national economies. The impact extends into workplaces and communities, where stigma, reduced opportunities and health complications can contribute to absences and lower productivity. In 2019, the economic impact of overweight and obesity in the EU was estimated at approximately €141 billion in direct healthcare costs and €323 billion in wider societal costs such as lost productivity. The OECD has also estimated that the impact of obesity and its related conditions will reduce GDP by 3.3% due to these factors of absences and decreased productivity. Ireland is already a leader in action on obesity, both at the policy level through evidence-based approaches such as the Model of Care for the Management of Overweight and Obesity in Ireland as well as at the practice level through a set of published Clinical Practice Guidelines for the Management of Obesity in Adults in Ireland and national education and training initiatives for health professionals. The CPGs align with existing evidence-based principles of chronic disease management and shift the goals of management from weight change alone to patient-centred health and functional outcomes that improve the overall health, social and economic wellbeing of people living with obesity and their communities. In 2025, Ireland was identified as a world leader in its innovative approaches to integrated obesity care and hosted the World Health Organization Demonstration Platform for Obesity – showcasing our national collaborative approach across HSE, ASOI, ICPO and the Department of Health. Therefore, we believe that the Irish Presidency can make a significant impact by placing obesity high on the Council’s agenda. Addressing obesity requires a coordinated approach and integrated policy action across several areas including health, the environment, education and industry. By sharing the effective practices and policies that have already been adopted and implemented in Ireland and promoting similar action across the EU, the Irish Presidency can make a significant impact that improves the health and well being of EU citizens and communities.

organisation: Association for the Study of Obesity on the Island of Ireland (ASOI), Irish Coalition for People Living with Obesity (ICPO), and the European Association for the Study of Obesity (EASO)
response_text: One of the greatest benefits of EU membership is the ability to share knowledge and best practices between all 27 Member States. The Irish Presidency has an ideal opportunity to showcase how Ireland has taken a leading role in addressing obesity through concrete policy and practical actions and highlighting how Ireland can influence policy action at the EU level. Taking a leading role in addressing one of the most pressing public health and societal challenges facing both Ireland and the EU as a whole is something that citizens should be proud of. In the field of obesity, the Irish Government has already made big strides in addressing obesity through the Irish Obesity Policy and Action Plan for 2016-2025. This plan includes a comprehensive, crosssectoral approach to obesity prevention through Healthy Ireland Implementation Plans and Slaintecare Healthy Communities initiatives. It also included the establishment of a National Clinical Programme for Obesity (NCPO) and the publication of the Model of Care for the Management of Overweight and Obesity in Ireland. In addition to action at policy level, ASOI, ICPO, and the HSE NCPO worked with 70 specialists from across Ireland, to adapt the Canadian Clinical Practice Guidelines, and published Clinical Practice Guidelines for the Management of Obesity in Adults in Ireland in 2022. The Model of Care and the Irish CPGs recognise that weight bias and stigma have a profound effect on how care is delivered and experienced, and multiple studies have demonstrated the negative impact of weight bias on physical and mental health. In addition, a key principle of the NCPO is that weight-based stigma and discrimination will not be tolerated in the Irish healthcare system. Efforts to train health professional in obesity management have been facilitated through Irish participation in European training and masterclass events through EASO, clinical exchanges of staff between clinical centres of excellence across Europe (EASO COMs) and hosting the 2020 International and European Obesity Congress and the 2023 European Obesity Congress in Dublin. Training of health professional to manage child and adolescent obesity has improved with mandatory training added to two undergraduate medical curricula and online training completed by over 3000 health professionals across Ireland. Productive and effective networks have been established in Ireland over the last 10 years, across government, clinical, academic, and lived experience partners, demonstrating what can be achieved by working together. This is work that is now extending beyond Ireland as members of ICPO have been instrumental in working with the WHO on the Acceleration Plan to Stop Obesity and have spoken at several events focused on obesity and other NCDs in the European Parliament. By including obesity as a priority in its programme, the Irish Presidency can showcase the impressive work that has already been done in Ireland to address obesity and improve the lives of people living with obesity. Highlighting Ireland’s role as a leader in this area and sharing best practices with other EU countries can give a sense of ownership to and provide value to Irish citizens, ultimately showing the importance of leading the Presidency of the Council.

organisation: Association for the Study of Obesity on the Island of Ireland (ASOI), Irish Coalition for People Living with Obesity (ICPO), and the European Association for the Study of Obesity (EASO)
response_text: Thank you for the opportunity to submit and highlight this important health priority

The Irish Presidency has a unique opportunity to reinforce Europe’s global leadership in life sciences by focusing on two interlinked policy pillars, inter alia, via the Biotech Act Parts 1 & 2: a world-class intellectual property (IP) system and a future-proof clinical trials framework. Both are essential to attract investment, accelerate innovation, and ensure timely patient access to transformative therapies. 1. Enhancing the European Intellectual Property System Intellectual property is the cornerstone of biopharmaceutical innovation, underpinning the high-risk, long-term investments required to bring new therapies to market. The EU’s IP framework, while robust, faces challenges from ongoing legislative reforms and global competition, notably from the US and Asia. The Irish Presidency should prioritise: Strengthening Regulatory Data Protection (RDP): The current RDP term is insufficient for therapies with limited patent protection or long development cycles, especially biologics. The EU should extend the baseline RDP term by two years and consider even longer protection for complex biologics, aligning with or surpassing the US standard. This will incentivise investment in breakthrough medicines and address unmet patient needs. Robust Patent Enforcement and Early Dispute Resolution: The EU would benefit from introducing mechanisms for early resolution of patent disputes, including a single public patent registry and requirements for generic/biosimilar manufacturers to assert their position on listed patents during marketing authorisation. This will provide legal clarity, reduce “launches at risk,” and balance timely market entry for generics with strong protection for innovators. 2. Modernising the Clinical Trials Ecosystem Clinical trials are the engine of evidence generation and patient access. However, regulatory fragmentation and operational inefficiencies undermine Europe’s competitiveness. The Irish Presidency should champion: A Harmonised, Product-Based Regulatory Model: Move towards a Core Dossier system, enabling sponsors to maintain a centralised product dossier referenced across multiple trials. This will reduce duplication, streamline approvals, and foster continuity of scientific knowledge. Centralised Ethics and Authorisation Processes: Establish a Single European Ethics Committee for clinical trials and empower the EMA to coordinate Clinical Trial Authorisation reviews. This will eliminate duplicative national requirements, accelerate trial start-up, and ensure uniform standards for patient safety and data protection. Digitalisation and Interoperability: Upgrade the Clinical Trials Information System (CTIS) with cloud-based architecture, real-time updates, and seamless integration with the European Health Data Space. Promote EU-wide recognition of electronic consent (e-consent) and interoperability of digital platforms to support innovative trial designs and cross-border research. Streamlined Timelines and Simplified Legislation: Shorten validation, assessment, and decision phases for trial approvals. Align overlapping regulations (GDPR, CTR, MDR/IVDR, AI Act) to reduce compliance complexity and operational delays. By focusing on the above policy areas, the Irish Presidency can help create a best-in-class environment for life sciences innovation, ensuring Europe remains competitive, resilient, and able to deliver cutting-edge therapies to patients. The Presidency should aim to deliver legislative progress on IP and clinical trials, foster regulatory harmonisation, and champion digital transformation across the sector. Finally, the presidency should work on providing clear and timely guidance on the use of AI in the life cycle of medicine as well as mobilizing private R&D investment in the EU and bolster the supporting environ

By focusing efforts on securing Europe’s global leadership in life sciences, the Council can help improve patients’ access to innovation with associated and interlinked benefits in health, wellbeing, productivity and growth. One specific area where we urge attention is brain health. Despite extraordinary scientific progress in cancer, cardiovascular disease, etc, brain health remains one of the most under-prioritized global health challenges of our time — a quiet crisis that threatens not only individual wellbeing but societal progress. The Irish Presidency could help deliver this attention and the bold, coordinated action required. With this direction the Council could integrate brain health into national health strategies and global policy frameworks, improve health care systems, and ensure timely access to innovation. Starting a process that unlocks the promise for transformational science for brain health would be a powerful legacy.

Europe’s ATMP Opportunity (Summary) Europe is at a critical juncture in the race to lead next-generation medical innovation, particularly advanced therapy medicinal products (ATMPs) like cell and gene therapies. These breakthroughs have transformed cancer care and may promise solutions for severe autoimmune diseases. Yet, regulatory fragmentation, and limited investment risk leaving Europe behind the US and Asia. Ireland’s Presidency offers a unique chance to position Europe as a leader in ATMPs. With world-class universities, clinical research centres, and a thriving biotech sector, Ireland can leverage its strengths in biomanufacturing and regulatory excellence to accelerate EU-wide adoption and scale of these transformative therapies. The Draghi report, commissioned to guide Europe’s competitiveness strategy, places special emphasis on ATMPs as a strategic priority. It states: “The pharmaceutical sector is recognised together with 9 other sectors as a strategic pillar where Europe needs to do more. … Europe is losing ground to other regions of the world, mostly China and the US, particularly in the areas of orphan drugs and advanced medicinal products.” The report further highlights: “The EU biotechnology and biomanufacturing sector has been recognised as one out of ten strategic technology sectors for Europe’s competitiveness, economic security, and sustainability; … the sector still faces regulatory and financial obstacles and an incomplete internal market; … the Commission is expected to present an EU Biotech Act.” It calls for: “Maximising the impact of the EU Health Data Space, streamlining the set-up and management of multi-country trials in the EU, expediting access to markets, and rapid and full implementation of the EU HTA Regulation.” The Draghi report also recommends: “Establishing an EU HTA agency in the long-term, improving business predictability through a continuous evidence-based dialogue with stakeholders, and increasing and focusing public R&D investment in the EU, through innovation hubs in life sciences.” The Irish Presidency should work on the following key topics to advance and unleash the ambition / potential of ATMPs 1. Value Recognition & Sustainable Reimbursement: ATMPs are often one-time treatments with curative potential, requiring payers to recognize their full value upfront. Europe’s HTA processes must adapt to reflect the long-term savings and societal benefits these therapies offer. As recommended under the Draghi report, a dedicated agency should coordinate joint clinical assessments and scientific consultations, ensuring high-quality outputs and appropriate involvement of all stakeholders. 2. Building the ATMP Ecosystem: Europe should promote high-quality, standardized production with EU accreditation for manufacturing. Large-scale, GMP-compliant production is essential for accessibility, while academic innovation should be supported for niche indications. Integrating robust Chemistry, Manufacturing, and Controls (CMC) standards will ensure safety and efficacy at scale. 3. Regulatory Agility: Europe must adopt product-centric regulatory models, enable platform technology master files (PTMFs), and strengthen coordination between EMA, HTA bodies, and payers for joint evidence generation. A single European ethics review process for clinical trials and a “third pathway” for non-profit developers will reduce delays and fragmentation. 4. Public-Private Collaboration: Establish shared EU databases and annual “Advanced Therapy Horizon Forums” to align priorities and avoid duplication. Support innovation hubs that combine manufacturing, regulatory, and digital expertise. 5. Investment in Skills, Infrastructure, and Data: Create EU-wide certification for ATMP manufacturing personnel, invest in data interoperability, and integrate genomic and real-world evidence registries to support continuous learning and post-market monitoring. Conclusion: The Draghi report’s emphasis on ATMPs should guide the Irish Presidency to make advanced therapies a flagship priority. By embracing collaboration, investing boldly in innovation, and adapting regulatory frameworks, Europe can define the next decade of medical innovation and deliver life-changing treatments to patients across the continent.

For its 2026 EU Presidency, Ireland should prioritise sustainable energy, rural resilience, and community-centred governance. In particular, the rapid scaling of biomethane under REPowerEU highlights the urgent need for independent impact assessments, strict environmental safeguards, and oversight of public subsidies to prevent unsustainable industrial-scale biogas projects. Ireland can lead by embedding legally binding rules on feedstock use, digestate management, and spatial planning, ensuring local communities have a real voice in decision-making rather than bearing disproportionate social and environmental costs. By championing a model that balances climate, biodiversity, and rural development goals, Ireland can set a European benchmark for fair, sustainable energy transitions. Prioritising transparency, equitable benefit-sharing, and preventative regulation will help avoid repeating mistakes seen elsewhere in Europe, reinforcing trust in decarbonisation policies. These thematic priorities will position Ireland as a leader in creating energy strategies that are both ambitious and socially responsible.

The European Commission’s REPowerEU action plan has set biomethane production on a course of massive upscale as part of efforts to increase EU energy independence, fixing a target of 35 billion cubic meters (bcm) per year by 2030 – up from 4,1 bcm in 2023. However, until this day, no Impact Assessment was carried out on the target. As biomethane production continues to grow rapidly both in Ireland and Europe (with a currently 21% year-over-year growth), so do concerns about its associated environmental and social risks as well as the irresponsible use of taxpayers money. While biogas production from sludge or collecting the gas that is produced in landfills is appropriate, there are particular concerns about the effects of large-scale biogas production on the use of limited agricultural land, the continuation of polluting industrial animal production, harm to local communities, and the effects of methane leaking from biogas facilities. Further concerns arise when looking closer at promoted use cases for biomethane such as heating or transport which are often inefficient, expensive, and lock Europe into existing fossil infrastructure. The Irish Presidency should therefore prioritize conducting an independent, interdisciplinary impact assessment to evaluate the feasibility and sustainability of this target, ensuring it aligns with climate, biodiversity, and rural community goals. Emphasis must be placed on implementing strict economic, environmental, and social safeguards for biogas and biomethane production. With reference to the Commission’s 2026 Work Programme as well as the wider EU Strategic Agenda that highlights the need to secure Europe’s energy independence, we therefore encourage the Irish Presidency to: Advocate for an independent impact assessment of the EU’s 35 bcm biomethane target, as a prerequisite to develop further any expansion of biomethane production as part of relevant policy files in 2026, such as the Circular Economy Act, Bioeconomy Strategy, Livestock Strategy, Energy Union Governance Upgrade, and Common Agricultural Policy. This includes prioritizing truly sustainable feedstocks, efficient use cases, and avoiding lock-ins of fossil infrastructure. Include the voices of local communities in the debate. In order to expand biomethane production rapidly, the 2025 REPowerEU roadmap foresees a “tripartite contract to better address the diverging needs in different areas of the EU and include national and local stakeholders”. However, a focus has been set on facilitating dialogue between the EU Commission, EU Member States’ governments as well as industrial stakeholders; and no commitment has been made to give a role to local communities themselves that are affected by such projects. In line with its “people-centred” approach, the Presidency should therefore intensify its efforts to give the Irish people and local communities across Europe a greater say in the development of fair and sustainable biomethane strategies. Scrutinise public subsidy schemes for unsustainable biomethane production. This is critical to prevent perverse incentives that undermine the EU’s climate, food security, and energy independence goals. Current subsidies often favour industrial-scale biogas projects reliant on unsustainable feedstocks - such as manure from factory farming or energy crops competing with food production - which lock in polluting practices as well as animal welfare violations, and divert resources from truly circular solutions. Without strict oversight, these subsidies risk distorting markets, inflating demand for unsustainable livestock farming, and sidelining local, community-led projects that deliver genuine environmental and social benefits.

Ireland’s presidency provides a unique opportunity to develop and promote a gold standard indigenous biogas industry that is sized and scaled to meet community needs. Learning from EU countries with an established biogas industry, Ireland can avoid the pitfalls of social acceptance that are consistently documented as barriers to bioenergy projects across the EU (Mancini & Raggi, 2022). Current regulatory gaps and weak planning assessments underestimate the cumulative impacts on rural infrastructure. Public health and safety questions about hazardous gas storage, particular emissions and emergency service access are heightened when regulatory oversight is perceived as reactive rather than preventative. Research has highlighted that digestate management and changes in feedstock mixes are critical risk vectors that demand much stronger regulation than is currently applied (Piadeh et. al, 2024). Ireland, through its presidency, can set the standard by developing industry-specific planning regulations that include community engagement at its core. The National Biomethane Strategy points directly to a highly industrialised model aimed at rapid development across rural Ireland. Within this model, revenue accrues to outside multi-national agri-investors while costs are borne by host communities in terms of road damage, odour, environmental degradation, and reduced property values. Communities demand transparent environmental impact assessments, accessible monitoring data and enforceable operating limits. The development of industry-specific planning regulations aligned with benefit-sharing mechanisms has the potential to provide a blueprint for use across the EU, while maintaining community engagement and the highest environmental standards. Meaningful community engagement, spatial planning that respects local carrying capacity, strict feedstock limits, alongside legally binding digestate management plans, are safeguards that would increase local acceptance. Rapid roll-out risks polarising rural communities, undermining trust in decarbonisation policy, and producing environmental and social harms that outweigh local benefits. Ireland has an opportunity through its EU presidency to either lead and develop new industry standards or to repeat mistakes already impacting the rural communities and the environment across Europe.

geography: EU-wide, with engagement in national CVH implementation strategies across multiple Member States, including Ireland.
response_text: Cardiovascular disease remains the leading cause of mortality and disability across the EU, and with the EU Cardiovascular Health Plan scheduled for publication in December 2025, the Irish Presidency has a unique opportunity to champion its early implementation. In this context, the EU SHD Coalition recommends that Ireland adopt “Boosting Cardiovascular Health in Europe: Delivering the EU Cardiovascular Health Plan” as the high-level thematic focus of its 2026 Presidency. This would align closely with the EU Strategic Agenda 2024–2029 and demonstrate visible benefits of EU cooperation for citizens. Ireland can play a central role in promoting a shift towards earlier prevention and detection of cardiovascular diseases across the Union, especially of Structural Heart Disease (SHD). Structural Heart Disease refers to a range of abnormalities of the heart’s valves and chambers, including aortic stenosis and mitral regurgitation. It disproportionately affects older adults and often remains silent until advanced stages. Across Europe, SHD affects an estimated 14 million people, yet more than half of cases go undiagnosed, contributing significantly to avoidable hospitalisations, disability, and premature mortality. By advancing implementation of the EU flagship initiative “EU Cares for Your Heart,” the Presidency could support Member States in developing national CVH strategies by 2027 and help accelerate the rollout of the EU Protocol on Health Checks for Cardiovascular Diseases. This Protocol, including routine cardiac auscultation and tailored screening approaches based on age, gender, and geographical needs, will be essential for improving timely diagnosis of hypertension, diabetes, obesity, and structural heart disease. It will also be instrumental in achieving the EU-level target of reducing cardiovascular mortality by 20% by 2035. Ireland should also highlight the importance of strengthening cardiovascular treatment, including for SHD, and care pathways. The creation of the European Network of Cardiovascular Health Centres foreseen in the CVH Plan represents a major opportunity to reduce inequalities in access to high-quality diagnosis, intervention, rehabilitation, and long-term management. The Presidency can support early discussions on how to establish and operationalise this network so that expertise is shared efficiently and patients benefit from consistently high standards of care regardless of where they live. Finally, the Presidency can reinforce the EU’s commitment to innovation, digital health and workforce capacity. Strengthening primary care skills, including clinical auscultation and the use of digital diagnostic aids, will be crucial for early detection. Nevertheless, to ensure meaningful progress, the Presidency should above all emphasise the need for sufficient EU and national budget allocations dedicated to implementing the CVH Plan’s flagship initiatives, following the example of the EU’s Beating Cancer plan. By emphasising prevention, equitable access, treatment excellence, innovation, and workforce capability, the Irish Presidency can deliver a future-oriented vision that directly improves the health and wellbeing of EU citizens.

geography: EU-wide, with engagement in national CVH implementation strategies across multiple Member States, including Ireland.
response_text: The EU SHD Coalition recommends that the Irish Presidency prioritise the early implementation of the EU Cardiovascular Health Plan, with particular focus on the 2026 proposal for the EU Protocol on Health Checks for Cardiovascular Diseases. This Protocol will provide a shared, evidence-based framework for Member States to deliver high-quality, accessible cardiovascular health checks. Ireland can play a vital role by facilitating early Council discussions and encouraging agreement on key components such as routine cardiac auscultation, age- and gender-tailored screening approaches, incentives to improve participation, and mechanisms to support mobile outreach programmes. These elements will be crucial for improving detection of structural heart disease, hypertension, diabetes and obesity, thereby reducing long-term health burdens and inequalities. The Presidency should also give prominence to the establishment of the European Network of Cardiovascular Health Centres. This new network will help ensure that advanced diagnostic and treatment capabilities are available across the EU, supporting more equal access to care and enabling patients to benefit from shared expertise. Ireland can support discussions on criteria, governance, accreditation, and pathways for integration with national health systems, ensuring clinical excellence and consistent standards of care. This will be essential for translating the CVH Plan into real improvements in diagnosis, treatment, rehabilitation, and long-term disease management. Ireland will additionally have an important role in supporting innovation and digital transformation in cardiovascular health. As the Commission prepares to introduce a breakthrough regulatory pathway for cardiovascular medical devices within the MDR revision, the Presidency can facilitate constructive dialogue among Member States to ensure timely and effective adoption of innovative technologies. The Presidency can further encourage progress on the deployment of AI tools in clinical settings, the development of a blueprint for cardiovascular AI, and the increased use of real-world evidence to support clinical and policy decision-making. Ensuring interoperability and the alignment of cardiovascular indicators with the European Health Data Space will also be crucial for monitoring progress and supporting Member States. Finally, Ireland can guide discussions on how Member States will develop national cardiovascular health strategies by 2027, with sufficient dedicated budget allocations. These strategies will form the backbone of CVH Plan implementation and will need to incorporate prevention, screening, early diagnosis, referral pathways, treatment access, rehabilitation, and the reduction of health inequalities. The development of a cardiovascular health inequalities dashboard, foreseen in the CVH Plan, will be essential for monitoring progress. By supporting Member States in these areas, the Presidency can help ensure that the EU Cardiovascular Health Plan moves rapidly from vision to practical action and could also highlight how progress in implementing the EU CVH Plan will reinforce national health objectives, strengthening links between EU-level action and domestic outcomes.

geography: EU-wide, with engagement in national CVH implementation strategies across multiple Member States, including Ireland.
response_text: Placing the implementation of the EU Cardiovascular Health Plan at the centre of the Irish Presidency would generate significant and direct benefits for citizens, communities, health systems, and European competitiveness. Improved prevention and early detection of cardiovascular disease, including structural heart disease, will reduce avoidable mortality and disability and help ensure that people live longer, healthier and more active lives. Earlier diagnosis through routine health checks, including cardiac auscultation, will lead to timely treatment, fewer complications, and better long-term outcomes. These improvements are especially relevant for older people and women, who are disproportionately affected by underdiagnosed cardiovascular conditions. Health systems across the EU would also benefit substantially. It has been proven that earlier detection and treatment reduce the burden on hospitals, emergency services, and long-term care by decreasing the need for complex interventions and advanced-stage treatments. This contributes to greater system resilience, efficiency and sustainability. The Commission’s proposals for mobile screening outreach and the creation of the European Network of Cardiovascular Health Centres will support more equitable access to care and reduce regional disparities, ensuring that rural, remote, or underserved populations benefit from the same high standards as those in major urban centres. Given that Ireland itself faces similar demographic challenges, improvements in early detection and referral pathways under the EU CVH Plan would support better outcomes nationally while reducing pressures on Irish hospitals. Moreover, communities stand to gain through improved healthy ageing and reduced social and economic pressures associated with chronic cardiovascular disease. Healthier citizens participate more fully in society, are able to remain active for longer, and have greater opportunities for employment and community involvement. By reducing inequalities linked to age, gender, socio-economic status or geography, the Irish Presidency can help strengthen social cohesion and improve overall quality of life across the EU. The Presidency’s support for innovation and digital transformation would also positively impact European businesses and the wider economy. Establishing a breakthrough regulatory pathway for cardiovascular medical devices will boost EU competitiveness and stimulate investment in research, development and manufacturing. Promoting the integration of AI tools, real-world evidence and digital diagnostics into clinical practice will support Europe’s position as a global leader in health innovation and technology. These processes will strengthen collaboration between the public and private sectors and drive economic growth in high-value industries. Through the implementation of the EU Cardiovascular Health Plan, the Irish Presidency can deliver visible, meaningful progress at a scale that citizens and communities will feel directly. This would become one of the most impactful legacies of its term.

geography: EU-wide, with engagement in national CVH implementation strategies across multiple Member States, including Ireland.
response_text: Cardiovascular health provides a powerful and accessible way to communicate the benefits of EU membership, as it touches nearly every household in Europe. The Irish Presidency can highlight how EU cooperation leads to tangible improvements in people’s daily lives by demonstrating progress on initiatives within the EU Cardiovascular Health Plan. Public campaigns linked to “EU Cares for Your Heart” can showcase how the Union supports healthier lifestyles, early risk detection and the prevention of serious illness. By emphasising consistent standards across Member States, such as those in the forthcoming EU Protocol on Health Checks, citizens can clearly see how EU action leads to earlier diagnosis and better access to care. The Presidency can also underline how these developments will directly improve cardiovascular outcomes in Ireland, contributing to national efforts to address heart disease and reduce health inequalities. Communicating the creation of the European Network of Cardiovascular Health Centres offers another strong pathway. Citizens, and especially patients, will be able to appreciate how EU collaboration ensures the availability of high-quality, specialist cardiovascular services regardless of where they live. This demonstrates the practical value of EU solidarity and the benefits of shared expertise. Highlighting success stories from clinicians, patients and researchers can further reinforce public trust and engagement, showing real-life examples of the lifesaving impact of early detection, guideline-consistent care pathways, rehabilitation and innovative technologies. Ensuring clear and accessible communication through public events, digital campaigns and collaboration with civil society and patient organisations will help strengthen citizens’ understanding of the EU’s positive influence on their health, wellbeing and futures.

geography: EU-wide, with engagement in national CVH implementation strategies across multiple Member States, including Ireland.
response_text: The EU SHD Coalition welcomes Ireland’s inclusive consultation process and commends its proactive approach in shaping a Presidency programme that addresses some of Europe’s most pressing health challenges. The launch of the EU Cardiovascular Health Plan presents a unique opportunity for Europe to significantly reduce the burden of cardiovascular disease and improve health outcomes for millions of citizens. With its strong record in public health and cardiovascular care, Ireland is well positioned to lead early implementation and foster genuine progress. Stronger budgetary commitments, following the example of the EU’s Beating Cancer plan, at both EU and national levels, will be essential to ensure the successful rollout of the Health Check Protocol, the cardiovascular centres of excellence and the broader CVH Plan initiatives. Structural heart disease is explicitly recognised within the 2024 Council Conclusions on Cardiovascular Health and is expected to be present also in the EU CVH Plan, reflecting growing awareness of the need for earlier detection and more consistent access to treatment. Routine cardiac auscultation within the EU Protocol on Health Checks will be essential in identifying undiagnosed SHD and other cardiovascular disorders, which cannot be prevented through a healthy lifestyle, at an early stage. Ireland, by advancing these initiatives during its Presidency, can also strengthen its own national cardiovascular strategy, improving SHD and CVH outcomes for Irish citizens. The Irish Presidency has an exceptional opportunity to transform the ambitions of the EU Cardiovascular Health Plan into concrete improvements in prevention, detection, treatment and long-term management. By supporting Member States and advancing key EU-level initiatives, Ireland can deliver a lasting health legacy for citizens across the Union.

I believe that during Ireland’s Presidency of the Council in 2026 should focus on the issue of climate change, Ireland needs to advocate for a sustainable society, renewable energy, and reducing reliance on fossil fuels. Ireland could work to strengthen EU and global partnerships that share research, technology, and best practices for clean energy. Ireland should advocate for public awareness campaigns across the EU about sustainable living and climate resilience. With persistent efforts we can achieve cleaner air, job creation in green sectors, and reduced vulnerability to energy price shocks. Ireland should also prioritize promoting peace throughout the world, especially in the conflicts going on in Palestine and Ukraine, along with the many conflicts and genocides going on in African countries such as Sudan. Ireland should review foreign aid to protect countries that need aid in developing, and especially those countries that will suffer from climate related issues. Ireland’s aid should reflect compassion and a sense of shared global responsibility. Ireland has a strong reputation for overseas aid and can continue to lead by example within the EU.

In relation to climate change, Ireland should push legislation for more investments in renewable energy, and energy efficiency for the EU to meet its climate goals, extra investments and improvements are needed especially in the sectors of aviation and transport. Investing in more public transport routes, higher energy efficient transport such as electric busses, and improving punctuality and convenience to incentivize the use of public transport, many people need to travel to work, school, or personal reasons, so improvements in public transport would take many cars off the road. Investment in energy sources such as wind or solar energy will improve energy prices and lower emissions, along with the investments in energy we also need to invest in grid infrastructure and storage. To promote peace and provide aid to countries in conflict Ireland, leading the Council should commit to a long-term reconstruction plans to rebuild and fund schools, hospitals, and housing. The EU needs to prioritize international law in the response to the genocide in Gaza to maintain moral credibility, continual aid to Gaza to alleviate pressure on Gazans, and a plan needs to be made for when the violence ends, while pushing for an end to any occupation in Gaza.

In 2026, Ireland takes charge of the EU Council - a rare shot, yet doable - to push Europe toward fairer policies and greener power routes, since tighter ties help. By betting on long-term fixes instead of divisions, plus standing strong together, Dublin might change how Brussels operates in ways people feel - giving real wins to citizens, businesses, even local communities across the area. Even though weather changes remain a serious issue now, they also open real opportunities. Should Ireland step up, it might speed up Europe’s shift to clean energy - driving funding into offshore turbines, solar setups, or new tech that creates jobs, lowers power costs, while ditching fossil fuels. Folks teaming up tends to kickstart new thinking; when we look after the environment, everyone gains - big companies included, yet local communities and small businesses also get a lift, nudging progress forward little by little. Breathing cleaner air along with having clean water improves well-being, creates steady work, all while giving Europe better footing ahead. Irelands got a rep for backing folks when times get rough, yet pitching in to keep things peaceful. Because it’s done this before, some countries might open up more - perhaps even joining forces on hot issues such as Ukraine or Palestine. Supporting aid missions, urging dialogue over conflict, yet standing firm on liberty and justice - this strengthens the EU’s goal of global peace. These actions help people facing tough situations; at the same time, they create more stable surroundings in Europe, lowering threats for nearby areas. Fostering global connection as nations progress side by side - while ensuring shifts unfold gradually Ireland might play a role in helping Europe voice things more evenly worldwide. Nations struggling from climate changes count on strong partnerships to influence future outcomes. Because of help with steady growth - linked to good schools, improved health centers, or swifter aid during crises - the EU might speed up change in these countries while quietly supporting global stability. Viewed this way - not out of duty, yet because it benefits everyone - it reveals what Europe truly means: creating shared understanding so we can tackle major issues together. Ireland steering the Council isn't just about choices - it's watching closely, stirring cooperation across countries, maybe even building global ties. Ireland might nudge Europe’s path in actual ways - say by changing how homes tap into energy, stopping disputes from flaring up, or forging global links - if it zeroes in on slashing emissions, calming clashes, or connecting countries. If we clock hours at work bringing people together around shared goals, Ireland might help shape a quieter, greener Europe - brighter and full of hope - where humans matter most while compassion shapes worldwide choices.

Ireland needs to communicate issues in a way that is simple, down to earth, and with a focus on the issues that affect people's everyday lives, such as affordability, transport, family life, services etc... A lot of people, when they think of the EU, or even their national governments, they think of men in suits who make decisions for themselves and their buddies, and that these decisions have no impact on their lives, they float around, taking whatever comes to them, and only getting involved every 4/5 years when it’s time to tick a box. This is not a healthy state of society; it is not healthy to have a society where people do not involve themselves in the running of the country, this leaves all the decisions to a privileged few, which is not truly democratic. But if we look at our own local governments, we see a lot more involvement in events and campaigns involving local councilors because they know how to reach their local community, local councilors know what the people care about, and centres their campaigning messaging around that. If we were able to replicate this at an EU level, to a much larger audience than the local council. We can send out our policy message in a way that will get EU citizens to actually listen, and get on board with an EU vision under the Irish presidency which prioritizes everyone, and not just a few.
No comments

High-Level Thematic Priorities for Ireland’s 2026 EU Presidency Air Connectivity, Single European Sky & Liberalisation Complete and implement the Single European Sky initiative to modernise EU airspace management, reduce fragmentation, and minimise delays. Maintain a liberalised EU aviation market, resisting protectionist measures and supporting open skies within Europe. Advance external air transport agreements with global partners to boost trade, tourism, and investment. Address air traffic control disruptions by promoting contingency planning and minimum service requirements during strikes. Highlight aviation’s economic contribution and progress a new, dedicated EU Aviation Strategy. Sustainable Aviation Fuels (SAF) & Climate Action Scale up deployment of SAF through EU-wide incentives, funding, and infrastructure. Implement a SAF credit system to encourage broader industry participation in decarbonisation. Align with ReFuelEU Aviation and strengthen emissions trading measures. Promote climate innovation, including research into electric and hydrogen propulsion and operational efficiencies. Noise Management & Regulatory Consistency Ensure consistent EU-wide application of the Balanced Approach to aircraft noise management (Regulation 598/2014). Prevent ad-hoc or politically motivated noise restrictions by promoting evidence-based, proportionate policies. Facilitate dialogue and share best practices among Member States to standardise noise mitigation. Aviation Security & Resilience Strengthen EU coordination on aviation cybersecurity and anti-drone measures. Promote harmonised response protocols and joint preparedness exercises for aviation crisis management. Support cross-border emergency preparedness and prioritise protection of critical infrastructure. Ensure regulatory agencies like EASA are fully resourced to maintain high safety standards. Transport Infrastructure & Regional Connectivity Fast-track integration and expansion of the Trans-European Transport Network (TEN-T), especially corridors significant for Ireland. Secure EU funding for strategic transport projects, including cross-border rail, port enhancements, and sustainable transport modes. Promote sustainable, climate-resilient infrastructure aligned with the EU Green Deal. Coordinate efforts to resolve bottlenecks in major infrastructure projects and enhance regional accessibility. Summary Statement: Ireland should focus its Presidency on strengthening connectivity, driving sustainability, and promoting inclusive growth. By championing these priorities, Ireland can help build a more competitive, cohesive, and climate-resilient Europe, advancing both national and EU-wide interests.

Priority Policy Areas & Legislative Proposals Single European Sky (SES) Reform Aim: Complete and implement SES reforms to modernise EU airspace management, reduce fragmentation, and cut delays. Actions: Advance legislative proposals to finalise SES; promote integrated, efficient airspace management; support measures to mitigate air traffic control disruptions. Sustainable Aviation Fuels (SAF) & Climate Action Aim: Accelerate the deployment and uptake of SAF across the EU to meet climate targets. Actions: Drive implementation of the ReFuelEU Aviation Regulation; advocate for robust EU incentives, blending mandates, and funding for SAF production; support reforms to the EU Emissions Trading Scheme (ETS) to align carbon pricing with SAF incentives. Balanced Approach to Aircraft Noise (Regulation 598/2014) Aim: Ensure consistent, evidence-based application of noise management rules across Member States. Actions: Promote EU-wide guidance and monitoring of Regulation 598/2014; discourage ad-hoc or politically motivated restrictions; encourage use of objective data and community consultation. External Air Transport Agreements Aim: Liberalise and expand EU air transport agreements with key global partners. Actions: Progress negotiations for new or expanded open skies agreements, especially with Middle Eastern, Asian, and Indian markets; enhance connectivity for trade, tourism, and investment. Airport Slot Regulation Aim: Revise the Airport Slot Regulation to ensure rules governing access to airport capacity reflect current and future aviation market dynamics. Actions: Promote connectivity and competition between airlines by updating slot allocation rules to support growth, innovation, and fair access. Aviation Security & Resilience Aim: Strengthen EU coordination on aviation cybersecurity, anti-drone measures, and crisis management. Actions: Develop unified EU protocols for drone detection and cyber defence; conduct joint preparedness exercises; ensure regulatory agencies like EASA are adequately resourced. Trans-European Transport Network (TEN-T) Integration Aim: Fast-track integration and expansion of the TEN-T core network to improve regional connectivity. Actions: Prioritise legislative and funding support for strategic transport projects, including cross-border rail, ports, and sustainable infrastructure; streamline permitting and investment processes. EU Aviation Strategy Aim: Develop a new, comprehensive EU Aviation Strategy to address emerging challenges and opportunities. Actions: Initiate work on a long-term vision for European aviation, covering competitiveness, sustainability, digitalisation, and resilience. What the Irish Presidency Should Achieve Deliver tangible progress on SES reform and SAF deployment, positioning the EU as a leader in sustainable, efficient aviation. Secure agreement on consistent noise management practices, balancing community needs with operational efficiency. Expand EU’s global connectivity through new air transport agreements. Enhance the security and resilience of European aviation infrastructure. Accelerate delivery of key transport infrastructure projects, especially those supporting regional and cross-border connectivity. Lay the groundwork for a renewed EU Aviation Strategy that reflects the sector’s transformation and future needs. In summary: Ireland’s Presidency should focus on advancing legislative proposals and policy initiatives that modernise aviation, drive sustainability, improve connectivity, and strengthen resilience—delivering benefits for Ireland and the wider EU.

Maximising Positive Impact During Ireland’s 2026 EU Presidency Enhancing Connectivity and Mobility Modernise EU airspace management by advancing the Single European Sky reforms, reducing delays and making travel more efficient for passengers and businesses. Expand open skies agreements and improve regional transport links, ensuring all EU regions—including peripheral and island communities—are better connected to opportunities, markets, and each other. Driving Sustainability and Climate Action Accelerate the adoption of Sustainable Aviation Fuels (SAF) and support climate innovation, helping the EU meet its climate targets while safeguarding affordable, accessible travel. Promote investment in green, resilient transport infrastructure—such as electrified rail, green ports, and climate-proofed airports—benefiting communities and future generations. Supporting Economic Growth and Job Creation Secure EU funding for strategic infrastructure projects, stimulating local economies and creating jobs across Member States. Strengthen the competitiveness of the EU’s aviation and transport sectors, supporting trade, tourism, and investment that benefit businesses large and small. Improving Quality of Life and Community Wellbeing Ensure consistent, evidence-based noise management to protect communities living near airports, balancing environmental concerns with economic needs. Foster dialogue and share best practices on noise mitigation, community engagement, and regional development. Boosting Security and Resilience Enhance EU-wide coordination on aviation security, cybersecurity, and anti-drone measures, making travel safer for everyone. Promote joint preparedness and crisis management, ensuring the EU can respond effectively to disruptions and emergencies. Championing Inclusivity and Cohesion Prioritise projects and policies that reduce regional disparities, ensuring no community is left behind in the EU’s connectivity and growth. Use the Presidency to bring together stakeholders from across Europe, building consensus and unity around shared challenges and opportunities. Summary Statement: By focusing on these areas, the Irish Presidency can deliver real, tangible benefits—making travel safer, greener, and more accessible; supporting jobs and economic growth; and improving quality of life for people and communities across the EU. This approach will help build a more competitive, cohesive, and climate-resilient Europe, true to the spirit of “Ní neart go cur le chéile”—there is no strength without unity.

1. Use Clear, Relatable Messaging Highlight Tangible Benefits: Focus on real-world examples—such as improved travel, job opportunities, funding for local projects, and environmental protections—that directly impact people’s lives. Tell Human Stories: Share stories of individuals, businesses, and communities who have benefited from EU membership, making the EU’s impact personal and relatable. 2. Foster Two-Way Engagement Encourage Dialogue: Create opportunities for citizens to ask questions, share concerns, and contribute ideas—through town halls, online forums, and social media campaigns. Consult Widely: Involve a broad range of stakeholders, including youth, community groups, and businesses, in shaping the Presidency’s agenda and communicating its progress. 3. Make the Presidency Visible and Accessible Brand the Presidency: Use a distinct visual identity (logo, tagline, consistent design) for all Presidency communications, events, and materials to build recognition and pride. Showcase Irish Leadership: Highlight Ireland’s role in chairing EU meetings, leading negotiations, and representing the EU on the world stage. 4. Leverage Multiple Communication Channels Digital Platforms: Use social media, dedicated websites, and video content to reach a wide audience, especially younger citizens. Traditional Media: Engage with TV, radio, and print to ensure broad coverage, including in rural and older populations. On-the-Ground Events: Organise public events, school visits, and community workshops to bring the EU and the Presidency closer to citizens. 5. Promote Transparency and Accountability Share Progress and Outcomes: Regularly update citizens on what the Presidency is achieving, using plain language and clear visuals. Celebrate Successes: Publicise milestones, agreements, and positive impacts resulting from Ireland’s leadership in the Council. 6. Empower Internal and Community Champions Engage Staff and Stakeholders: Equip public servants, community leaders, and business representatives with toolkits and training to act as ambassadors for the EU and the Presidency. Encourage Local Initiatives: Support grassroots projects and campaigns that communicate EU values and benefits at the community level. Summary Statement: By combining clear messaging, active engagement, strong branding, and transparent reporting, Ireland can help citizens see the EU as a force for good in their daily lives and take pride in Ireland’s leadership role during the Presidency.

Summary of Additional Information daa’s submission provides a strategic vision for Ireland’s 2026 EU Presidency, focusing on aviation, communications, and infrastructure. It highlights the importance of connecting Ireland to the world through safe, sustainable, and competitive infrastructure, with Dublin and Cork airports playing a central role in national and regional development. The document outlines key thematic priorities such as: Completing the Single European Sky initiative to modernise EU airspace management. Scaling up Sustainable Aviation Fuels (SAF) and supporting climate action. Ensuring consistent, evidence-based noise management across the EU. Liberalising air transport agreements to enhance global connectivity. Strengthening aviation security, resilience, and regulatory capacity. Fast-tracking Trans-European Transport Network (TEN-T) projects to improve regional access and economic cohesion. It provides detailed rationale and proposed actions for each priority area, emphasising the need for: EU-wide coordination and harmonisation. Investment in sustainable and resilient infrastructure. Policies that balance economic growth with environmental protection and community wellbeing. The submission also stresses the importance of effective communication and engagement, recommending that Ireland use its Presidency to: Highlight the benefits of EU membership. Foster a sense of ownership and unity among citizens. Promote transparency, inclusivity, and dialogue at all levels. daa stands ready to support the Government in delivering a Presidency programme that enhances connectivity, drives sustainability, and promotes inclusive growth, in line with both national interests and the EU’s long-term prosperity.

The Work Programme of the European Commission for 2026 commits to developing the first EU Antipoverty strategy which “…will address structural causes of exclusion and strengthen support services.” One of the Irish government’s key priorities should therefore ensure that the strategy will be developed and backed across the EU, as promised, by a strengthened Child Guarantee that will include investments and reforms to tackle child poverty. Leadership on this theme, as an ‘Irish Presidency for Children’ would be fitting, and the government could work collaboratively with partners, experts, civil society and children and young people to make a real and lasting difference in Ireland and other Member States.

Measures which will achieve the alleviation of child poverty and exclusion in the European Union by an agreed date and any necessary proposals to support these are critical. The Irish government could use the Presidency to develop an agreed multi-annual, shared roadmap. Given the variation in the rates of poverty and exclusion across Member States, what is working or has worked to address and solve poverty and exclusion in some countries, can be shared and adapted for local contexts where necessary. There is a wealth of evidence and expertise available in Ireland and beyond to develop impactful proposals. It is important that a holistic approach is taken which looks at all aspects of children’s lives, as well as at specific groups of children who are more vulnerable to poverty and exclusion, across the EU.
