To secure Council conclusions reinforcing child poverty eradication as a cross-cutting EU priority and accelerating legislative progress on social rights, the Irish Presidency should ensure that: The Employment, Social Policy, Health and Consumer Affairs Council (EPSCO) prioritises the implementation of the European Child Guarantee, ensuring Member States deliver concrete measures for children in poverty. The Education, Youth, Culture and Sport Council (EYCS): support initiatives for equitable access to Early Years provision. The Environment Council (ENVI): embeds child-focused impact assessments in climate legislation.

In 2024, 24.2% of children and young people (aged under 18 years) in the EU were at risk of poverty or social exclusion. The impact on those young lives is well documented, but child poverty is also expensive for communities and societies, while being avoidable, if sustainable solutions are implemented. Achieving an EU-led and shared plan to end child poverty during the Irish Presidency will achieve a longterm impact for individuals, communities and businesses in every Member State. For Children and Families: Reduce poverty rates through targeted EU funding and social protection measures. For Communities: Strengthen resilience by investing in child-centered services and inclusive education. For Businesses: Promote family-friendly policies and inclusive skills development for future generations. These actions would be enhanced by integrating child poverty and well-being impact assessments into any economic and social policy frameworks which are developed or progressed during the Presidency.

Leading and facilitating a meaningful public dialogue with those affected by poverty, maximizing the voices of children and young people would be valuable, and would support the development of strong proposals to feed into a coherent anti-poverty plan. Branding the Irish Presidency as a ‘Presidency for Children’ would underpin this. As a theme, it could cross the work on the new anti-poverty strategy as well as underpin other themes that the government selects for the six-month period.

Ireland should champion child poverty eradication as a flagship Presidency theme. The government could ensure that climate, digital, education, and economic policies consider child well-being. Finally, it will be important to advocate for long-term investment in children, acknowledging this as a human right and as being essential for sustainable growth and social cohesion in the future across the European Union.

organisation: The Institute of International & European Affairs
response_text: This submission proposes that the Irish Presidency could make a significant impact by prioritising a new Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) that is fit for the clean transition, and which would aim to marry decarbonisation and competitiveness through a modernised European industrial and energy strategy. In this context, it is suggested that Ireland could act as a bridge-builder among Member States, industry and the citizenry by focusing on three mutually reinforcing priorities: (1) a clean industrial strategy centered on strategic net-zero technologies, (2) electrification and grid modernisation as core infrastructure, and (3) a socially just and regionally fair transition. The Irish Presidency will coincide with important negotiations on the EU’s next MFF budget (2028–2034), which will determine how Europe funds the Clean Industrial Deal, how it strengthens competitiveness and how it invests in critical energy infrastructure. The Commission’s Clean Industrial Deal, proposed in February 2025, would earmark over €100 billion to support industrial decarbonisation and competitiveness, while the newly proposed €400 billion European Competitiveness Fund aims to modernise grids, scale clean technologies and link these investments to cohesion policy. We believe that Ireland’s Presidency could be central to shaping how these instruments are embedded within the next MFF and how they interact with national and regional investment plans. Below are four high level themes which we suggest for consideration during the Presidency preparations: Electrification and grids: The Irish Presidency could frame regulatory reform and investment of electrification as a cross-cutting priority. Using the full MFF Toolbox & National and Regional Partnership Plans: This could be embedded across the European Competitiveness Fund, Connecting Europe Facility and Horizon Europe. In doing so the Irish Presidency could help address the EU-wide bottleneck of grid infrastructure. This issue is linked to the development of EU wide manufacturing, the emergence of advanced technologies, and new data capabilities, all of which will drive up electricity consumption. Shared Infrastructure Challenges: This agenda could also create opportunities for coalition-building among both larger and smaller Member States, for whom these issues are a common concern. An efficiency-first approach to public finance should guide resource allocation. It should prioritise guarantees and competitive mechanisms over direct subsidies for deploying mature technologies. Unlocking Energy Investment: Public funding could be directed towards emerging technologies such as heat pumps, long-term energy storage, and batteries. These emerging technologies require capital support, while solar, wind, and electric vehicles are already attracting private investment. The main aim of this policy approach is to balance limited fiscal resources while maximising private sector investment and engagement within the market. However, social safeguards and just transition measures must also be put in place. These should be reflected across the MFF architecture. The Irish Presidency could therefore champion stronger social protections for workers and vulnerable households, which would align with existing transition-fund frameworks and help address legitimate concerns about distributional impacts.

organisation: The Institute of International & European Affairs
response_text: The Irish Presidency comes at a key juncture in the MFF negotiations. We suggest that the Presidency could consider focusing work on four key interconnected legislative and policy domains which cut across the MFF negotiations. Each of these is set out below, with an indication of what success in this area could look like: The European Competitiveness Fund Governance: The Presidency could work towards the adoption of merit-based allocation procedures, in which strategic technologies (such as those based within the Net Zero Industry Act) are identified on an objective criteria, rather than allowing geographical distribution to take precedence. To achieve this, an early priority could be the design of a transparent methodology that prevents incumbent industries from capturing funding decisions. A neutral, evidence-based methodology would also support the advancement of the “Made in EU” criteria, ensuring that funding genuinely builds EU technological and industrial capacity rather than reinforcing legacy actors. Delivering on these criteria will require sustained investment in an EU-wide technology culture, the development of stronger value-added manufacturing capabilities, and procurement rules that maintain market discipline while incentivising innovation. Grid Infrastructure and Renewables Integration: The Irish Presidency could also work to operationalise and increase the Connecting Europe Facility’s Energy Programme through national and regional partnership plans. In implementing this, it would need to support reform of renewable-energy legislation, with measures that can be transposed into Member State plans. This could be aligned with post-COVID recovery precedents. The Irish Presidency could work to build partnerships to help the EU achieve agreement on standardised grid integration requirements across all Member States. Climate Mainstreaming and Horizon Europe Protection: The Presidency could work towards protecting the 35% climate mainstreaming target within the MFF and across different financial instruments, in response to possible downward pressure from other parties during MFF negotiations. In conjunction with this, it could aim to safeguard Horizon Europe’s proposed €175 billion research budget from competing emerging priorities. The presidency could frame research investment as essential to develop the necessary infrastructure to compete against competitors such as China, the USA and South Korea. Balancing Cohesion with Competitiveness: The presidency could aim to broker compromises between Member States with the aim of balancing geographic distribution with an exploration of how merit-based allocation could work at a regional level. Possible solutions could include allocating a percentage of national partnership planned funding through a competitive led-market mechanism, while also offering a mechanism that supports regional/national funding for clearly defined, interconnected initiatives. There is an opportunity to establish strong governance and coordination mechanisms to ensure the new European Competitiveness Fund works strategically with the Connecting Europe Facility and with Member States’ national investment plans. The aim of this would be to prevent any form of policy or strategic fragmentation.

organisation: The Institute of International & European Affairs
response_text: In order to achieve this, and in the context of the proposals submitted here, the work of the Council during the Irish Presidency could focus on the principles of efficiency-first, appropriate prioritisation and rapid deployment. These principles are explored below and presented within the context of the relationship between citizens, communities, and EU-based business. Each point unpacks options or mechanisms that could be made available and brought into play Communities and EU Citizens: Electrification and grid modernisation will directly improve citizens' energy security and help reduce costs to citizens on the demand side of deployment mechanisms. The goal must be to ensure that funding can reach households to improve their ability to achieve energy efficiency, such as through heat pumps and renewable heating delivered via accessible instruments that could include guarantees for retail banking partnerships. When this is widened to small communities, it could also be supported by improving grid infrastructure and expanding local renewable generation. By embedding just transition measures into such projects, the Presidency agenda has the opportunity to support those who work in carbon-intensive sectors through retraining, social supports, and economic diversification programmes. Small and Medium Enterprises (SMEs): Returning to efficiency-first financial principles could support and prioritise SMEs over larger corporations, especially in light of the ongoing private capital investment shortages in the EU. The Presidency could link this to the Competitiveness Fund and Member State partnership plans to include a dedicated SME window with more streamlined processes. The large-scale deployment of renewables and energy efficiency can create commercial opportunities across the supply chain. However, initiatives like this depend on grid modernization within the bloc. EU Industry: The Presidency could work on an evidence-based technological priority list which could provide strategic clarity for EU wide industrial investment strategy and planning. This could link with the “Made in EU” criteria and aim to protect EU manufacturing from underpriced imports, while at the same time creating and developing lead markets for emerging sectors. This would require coherent signals across research (Horizon Europe), development (Competitiveness Fund), and deployment (Infrastructure) to reduce market uncertainty and enable the private investment needed for the scaling of these markets. Implementation Mechanisms: Where feasible and appropriate, civil society actors and other stakeholders could have greater and more systematic involvement in high-level meetings, such as the informal Energy Councils, in order to ensure that a diversity of views are represented. Furthermore, the Presidency could publish a ‘pipeline’ of priority projects, including grid upgrades, renewables, and building renovation. The purpose of this pipeline would be to ensure that MFF funding is used steadily throughout its financial cycle, rather than being disbursed in the final months of its cycle through emergency procedures.

organisation: The Institute of International & European Affairs
response_text: In the context of the proposals contained in this submission, the Irish Presidency could employ a narrative in which the immediate and accessible material benefits and long-term resilience for citizens and the Union are emphasised. As such, the Presidency could frame the MFF priorities around clear outcomes such as cheaper and cleaner energy through grid modernisation and electrification; job creation in renewable energy, manufacturing and retrofitting; and a clear vision for energy independence in the EU. Such investments could also help to address the current cost-of-living pressures facing EU citizens and communities. Thus, this headline theme for the Irish Presidency could be framed as developing pragmatic solutions to serve both business and households in the EU. The Irish Presidency could furthermore promote itself as a bridge-builder among member states and between the citizenry, private and public institutions, to reflect Ireland’s consensus building approach and its reputation as an ‘honest broker’. This would complement an approach that recognises that realising our climate ambitions does not need to come at the expense of European competitiveness, nor at the expense of other policy areas which have, as a result of geopolitical tensions, come to be seen as higher priority in recent times.

organisation: The Institute of International & European Affairs
response_text: This submission was prepared by and on behalf of the IIEA. It follows discussions with expert members of its Climate and Energy Working Group, as well as European partners and colleagues, including: the Strategic Perspectives; the Jacques Delors Centre; Environmental Justice Network Ireland; Climate Strategy & Partners; E3G; CONCITO; and Transport & Environment.

Position gender equity and inclusion as a central thematic priority Focus on inequalities in health and healthcare leadership affecting women and minority groups Emphasise the right to health as a fundamental human right Build on Ireland’s tradition of human rights leadership and global health action Link this priority to Ireland’s international commitments and UN Human Rights Council ambitions Highlight Ireland’s role in promoting inclusive, rights-based EU policies

Refer to the Issues at Stake - EU Tools listed in the table on page 16 of the policy brief Prioritise proposals that strengthen gender equality in health systems Support diversity in healthcare leadership and governance Focus on universal, inclusive and affordable access to healthcare Aim to reduce health disparities for women and marginalised communities Emphasise practical implementation and measurable progress across Member States Call for accelerated legislative progress and political alignment

Advocate for gender equity and social inclusion as core principles of EU funding Emphasise rights-based investment in health, social protection and community resilience Stress the importance of protecting and advancing human rights in a changing global context Link equitable policies to economic stability and business sustainability Reference key themes from the main policy recommendations in the brief

Frame public health as essential to social justice, economic resilience and democratic stability Emphasise that universal access to quality healthcare reflects core EU values Highlight concerns about rollbacks in women’s health and rights Stress the importance of visible EU leadership on equity and inclusion ● Promote systematic involvement of civil society in policymaking ● Include participation of: ○ Women’s rights and women’s health organisations ○ Gender equality organisations ○ Migrant and Roma communities ○ LGBTIQ+ groups ○ Disability and carers’ organisations Emphasise co-creation, consultation and ongoing monitoring Highlight that inclusive participation builds trust, ownership and democratic engagement

I participated in the two-day international conference IGHNxEU – Empowering Women for a Healthier Europe, held in Dublin on 14–15 November 2025. As a contributor to the policy discussions, I helped inform the development of the below linked policy brief. I wish to submit this policy brief as supporting evidence for my submission: https://globalhealth.ie/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/IGHN-EIWH-Policy-Brief-FINAL_TOC-Dec-9.pdf

organisation: Food Allergy Centre Padua University Hospital  Padua Italy
response_text: Taking into account the current geopolitical and socioeconomic context in Europe, we recommend that Ireland prioritise Health Protection, Citizen Safety, and Resilient Societies as core themes of its 2026 Presidency. Serious allergies and anaphylaxis are rising across Europe and place a growing burden on individuals, schools, workplaces, and public services. Addressing them fits naturally within broader objectives to protect citizens’ wellbeing and reduce preventable health risks. . A R e s i l i e n t an d P r e p a r e d E u r o p e The EU must be equipped to respond to emergencies—whether acute health events, natural disasters, or public safety threats. This requires harmonised emergency response systems, stronger community level preparedness, and cross-border cooperation. Ireland is one of the few Member States that has taken concrete steps to improve preparedness for serious allergic reactions, including allowing pharmacists to supply emergency medicines without a prescription during anaphylactic events. This national practice demonstrates effective emergency readiness and provides a model for EU-level policy coordination, which could inform upcoming initiatives under the European Health Union framework aimed at strengthening preparedness, prevention, and rapid response across Member States. . A P e o p l e -C e n t r e d U n i o n t h a t P r o t e c t s Embedding people-centred principles into EU policymaking ensures that vulnerable populations and individuals at risk of medical emergencies are not left behind. The Presidency could advance reducing health inequalities across the EU, highlighting uneven access to diagnosis, specialist care, and emergency response protocols. Positioning timely care for serious allergies and anaphylaxis within this agenda demonstrates a commitment to practical, measurable improvements in patient safety and inclusion, while protecting citizens’ rights to safety in everyday environments such as schools, childcare centres, workplaces, and public venues. 3 . A F u t u r e -O r i e n t e d E u r o p e B u i l t o n I n n o v a t i o n a n d C o l l a b o r a t i o n Ireland’s strong reputation in digital innovation offers an opportunity to promote Digital Innovation for Health, leveraging the European Health Data Space and interoperable, patient-centred tools. For individuals at risk of serious allergic reactions, seamless access to medical information across borders can prevent emergencies and support the free movement of people. The Presidency can also prioritise harmonised awareness-raising, institutional readiness, and capacity building, ensuring schools, businesses, and public institutions are equipped and trained to respond effectively to lifethreatening health incidents.

organisation: Food Allergy Centre Padua University Hospital  Padua Italy
response_text: Ireland could use its Presidency to champion health resilience, citizen protection, and emergency preparedness, leveraging its national leadership in anaphylaxis response as a model for EU coordination. Key priorities include: Health Protection and Emergency Preparedness Serious allergies and anaphylaxis present a growing public-health challenge. The Presidency could: •Promote timely access to emergency medicines, building on Ireland’s approach where pharmacists can supply life-saving treatment without prescription. •Encourage harmonised school and public-venue preparedness, using Ireland as an example. Relevant upcoming EU initiative: •Global health resilience initiative (non-legislative, Q2 2026) – to strengthen EU capacity for rapid response to health crises. Digital Innovation for Health Cross-border emergencies require seamless access to patient data: Promote the European Health Data Space for secure, interoperable sharing of health information, enabling faster response to anaphylactic events across borders. Support digital tools for citizen-centred care, enhancing emergency response and patient safety. 3. Reducing Health Inequalities and Strengthening Citizen Rights The Presidency could advance equitable access to emergency care and citizen-centred policy: Link preparedness to strengthening the Child Guarantee (non-legislative, Q2 2026) and Citizens omnibus (legislative, Q4 2026), ensuring children in schools, childcare centres, and communities are protected and have their rights effectively enforced. Promote intergenerational fairness through the Intergenerational fairness strategy (non legislative, Q1 2026), ensuring emergency preparedness and health access benefit current and future generations equally. Highlight Ireland’s model as a practical, replicable approach for other Member States. Objectives Establish a model for EU-level anaphylaxis and emergency response coordination, based on best practices of Ireland. Ensure equitable access to life-saving treatments across the EU. Promote digital innovation for preparedness, information sharing, and cross-border patient care. Strengthen citizen rights and intergenerational fairness, ensuring public health policies reflect social equity. Position health resilience as a pillar of EU citizen safety and social cohesion, demonstrating tangible improvements in public health readiness. By focusing on these targeted initiatives, Ireland can use its Presidency to deliver practical, measurable impacts on citizen safety, health equity, and cross-border emergency preparedness while reinforcing the EU’s social and legal frameworks.

organisation: Food Allergy Centre Padua University Hospital  Padua Italy
response_text: The Irish Presidency has the potential to deliver significant, tangible impact for EU citizens by advancing health resilience and consumer safety. For individuals with serious allergies, policies that improve emergency response, access to medicines, and accurate allergen information can be lifesaving. For people, expanded access to emergency treatment, including pharmacy-enabled emergency supply across the EU, enhances safety in daily life. Citizens with serious allergies would be better protected in schools, workplaces, sports facilities, cultural venues, and during cross-border travel. For businesses, harmonised allergen-labelling and staff-training expectations reduce regulatory uncertainty, simplify compliance, and improve consumer trust by fostering safer public environments. For communities and institutions, EU-supported readiness measures ,such as common school protocols, public-venue guidelines, and accessible training ,would significantly reduce preventable emergencies, supporting all three Alliance objectives. Replicating Ireland’s best practice on emergency medicine access would ensure that life-saving intervention is available regardless of where a reaction occurs, reducing inequalities across Member States.

organisation: Food Allergy Centre Padua University Hospital  Padua Italy
response_text: Ireland has a strong opportunity to communicate the value of EU membership by focusing on everyday benefits and practical improvements that resonate directly with citizens. The 2026 Presidency can show how EU cooperation protects people, strengthens communities, and makes daily life safer—particularly in areas such as emergency preparedness for serious allergies and anaphylaxis. Highlight Practical Examples of EU Solidarity Citizens understand the EU best when they see clear, relatable outcomes. Ireland can communicate EU values by highlighting how cooperation improves safety and wellbeing, for example: Safer environments in schools, restaurants, transport and public venues. Shared health information that makes travel within the EU safer and more predictable. • Harmonised allergen-labelling rules that protect consumers wherever they are. • More consistent access to emergency support for serious allergic reactions. Ireland’s own approach—allowing pharmacists to supply emergency treatment during a serious allergic reaction—provides a concrete example of national leadership that improves citizen safety. Propose Council Recommendations on Emergency Readiness To strengthen public understanding of the EU’s benefits, Ireland could lead on a visible, citizencentred initiative: Develop Council Recommendations on broader readiness and access to emergency treatment for serious allergy and anaphylaxis. This would help encourage Member States to: Improve preparedness in schools, public venues, workplaces, and transport hubs. • Ensure trained responders are available across community settings. Reduce inequalities in access to time-sensitive, life-saving care. Such an initiative is easy for citizens to relate to, directly improves safety, and demonstrates EU cooperation delivers real, practical benefits for families, children, workers, and communities. This people-centred framing will strengthen public trust, build ownership, and demonstrate the concrete value of Ireland’s leadership at EU level.

The Competition and Consumer Protection Commission (CCPC) considers that strengthening the Single Market, competition and consumer protection should be a key thematic priority for Ireland’s Presidency of the Council. Both the Draghi and Letta reports highlighted the need for the EU to strengthen its global competitiveness and the internal market. In addressing these challenges, policymakers must recognise that robust and vibrant levels of competition between businesses are essential to ensuring competitiveness. However, recent debates on competitiveness have included calls for competition policy to be used to support the creation of “European champions”. The argument suggests that if the EU is to compete with the US or China, certain European firms should be allowed to build the scale and resources to do so, irrespective of the impact on competitive dynamics in markets. Yet if companies cannot compete effectively to achieve scale in their home markets, how they can hope to succeed globally? Firms aiming compete internationally, must first successfully compete at home, including within the European market. In December 2025, the CCPC published its State of Competition in Ireland report on the non-financial services sector. The report found that market concentration has been increasing in the Irish services sector, resulting in certain industries in which businesses hold increased market power. In examining conditions for competition in the services sector, the CCPC found that businesses reported a number of barriers to expansion in their existing market or into new ones. These barriers included the inability to source skilled staff, difficulties in securing financing, and the global economic environment. The completion of the Single Market will be essential in strengthening the competitiveness of the EU economy. There are many policy and legislative initiatives under the Single Market Strategy, the Savings and Investment Union, and the Competitiveness Compass which will contribute to deepening the single market. These measures aim to provide more opportunities for businesses to grow, improving access to financing for investment and growth, and driving simplification to make it easier to do business across the Union, while also ensuring a high standard of consumer protection. Ireland’s Presidency will play a vital role in driving forward the implementation of many of those initiatives.

Consumer Agenda 2025-2030 The CCPC considers the 2030 Consumer Agenda to be a significant opportunity for Ireland’s Presidency. The 2030 Consumer Agenda, adopted in November 2025, sets out measures in 4 keys areas: Enabling consumers to leverage the benefits of the Single Market. Ensuring digital fairness and protecting consumers, particularly children, online. Enabling sustainable consumption and protecting consumers from greenwashing, and Effective enforcement and redress to protect consumers and shield compliant businesses from unfair competition, Two major proposals in this area, the Digital Fairness Act (DFA) and the revised Consumer Protection Cooperation Regulation are expected in Q4 2026. The CCPC considers that stronger consumer protection online and strengthened enforcement are key priorities for the Single Market and Ireland. The CCPC supports the DFA’s aim to tackle harmful practices such as dark patterns, addictive design, unfair personalised pricing, and subscription traps. A central principle we have advocated is “easy in, easy out” for digital contracts: consumers should be able to cancel subscriptions or withdraw from contracts as easily as they sign up. This is critical to restoring trust in digital markets and empowering consumers to make informed choices. The Presidency should champion this principle and ensure robust, practical measures to support consumer decision-making online, alongside clear obligations for traders and effective enforcement mechanisms. Ireland should also take proactive positions on related reviews, including the Digital Fitness Check, proposed amendments to Regulation 1/2003, and the review of the Digital Markets Act (DMA), all scheduled to progress during Ireland’s term. These initiatives will help maintain competitive markets and safeguard consumer interests in an evolving digital economy. Better Regulation The Irish presidency should prioritise progressing plans for major simplification of regulation in 2026. Simplification must not mean deregulation. The Irish Presidency should ensure that, while advancing the simplification agenda, the interests of EU citizens and businesses are protected alongside competitiveness. Key priorities include the 28th regime which will set harmonised rules for innovative companies throughout the EU, with a legislative proposal expected in Q1 2026. Furthermore, the Commission’s 2026 work programme commits to cutting administrative burdens for Small and Medium Enterprises (SMEs) by 35% without lowering standards. These initiatives will enhance competitiveness, support start-ups and scale-ups, and align with Ireland’s growth priorities. The CCPC considers that the Irish presidency should support the advancement of these measures and other related proposals. Additionally, in the area of digital, the Digital Omnibus Regulation, proposed by the European Commission in November 2025, seeks to simplify existing rules on Artificial Intelligence, cybersecurity, and data. With Ireland hosting leading companies in these sectors, the Presidency should prioritise advancing this proposal to achieve the right balance between competitiveness and robust protections for citizens. Public Procurement Finally, the Presidency should prioritise advancing revisions to the EU public procurement Directives. Public procurement is central to the Single Market, promoting competitive markets and safeguarding the public interest. However, recent studies have raised concerns about competitiveness in procurement across the EU. The Commission’s 2024–2029 political guidelines announced a revision of the Directives, and its 2026 Work Programme includes a Public Procurement Act proposal planned for Q2 2026. At national level, a new Public Procurement Strategy for Ireland is being developed to update policy areas and address added complexity in procurement practices.

The OCO is proposing that the Irish Presidency chooses “Children’s Rights at the Heart of Europe” as a thematic area. New challenges are emerging which pose a threat to children’s rights: rising poverty and housing instability the impact of climate change on children; online safety and AI; changes to migration laws and policies that impact children on the move; mental health; and the impact of armed conflicts on children. It is critical that children’s rights become part of the highest political agenda of the EU and are made integral to the Irish Presidency with the participation of children and young people at its centre. The start of the Irish Presidency will culminate with the 20th anniversary of the EU Commission’s Communication Towards an EU strategy on the rights of the child. At the time, the ambition was for the Union to be a “beacon to the rest of the world” when it came to children’s rights. This proposal led to the launch of the Strategy on Children’s Rights and the European Child Guarantee in 2021. Both initiatives were guided and took fully into account the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child (the UNCRC). The EU Strategy explicitly provides that the UNCRC, which all EU Member States (MS) have ratified, continues to guide the EU’s action in the field of children’s rights. It recognises that more than 30 years after its entry into force, significant progress has been made and children are increasingly recognised as having their own set of rights. However, further action is needed to advance the full implementation of the UNCRC at EU level. The Irish Presidency should emphasise the importance of upholding the UNCRC in all EU actions internal and external, and consider initiating a conversation in Ireland about the full and direct incorporation of the Convention into domestic law. This thematic area cuts across the EU’s priorities for 2024-2029: A strong Europe that safeguards the rights of the most vulnerable: the EU Pact on Migration and Asylum (the EU Pact) will start being implemented during the Irish Presidency with significant impacts on the rights of children on the move. The Irish Presidency’s focus and contribution in the area of migration should be to ensure that the respect for human rights guide and inform the implementation of the EU Pact. The European Commission (EC) recognises that migrant and refugee children are in a state of particular vulnerability and require specific and appropriate protection and this should be a key focus. A Europe that upholds human rights and the rule of law: in an era of power politics and uncertainty, there is growing evidence that international law and the international order are under attack. The Irish Presidency has the opportunity and the responsibility to ensure that Europe leads by example in upholding international law, especially international human rights law, including the UNCRC, the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR) and the EU’s own Charter of Fundamental Rights (CFREU) in its policies and actions, both internally and externally. A responsible Europe that assesses the impact of artificial Intelligence (AI) and provides robust regulation: The OCO has put a spotlight on the children’s rights implications of AI, which should be taken under advisement by the Irish Presidency in the forthcoming EU initiatives on AI. The new EU AI Act refers to children’s rights, and the EU Digital Services Act sets out obligations for online service providers, including high privacy, safety and security standards for children. However, a discussion is needed on how we can implement more robust regulation, and stronger enforcement within a children’s rights framework.

The OCO proposes that the Irish Presidency focuses on the following policy areas identified in the Work Programme of the European Commission for 2026: Implementation of the EU Pact on Migration and Asylum Respect of safeguards and rights - one of the building blocks to implement the core obligations of the EU Pact – should be an area of focus of the Irish Presidency in the implementation of the EU Pact. It is a cross-cutting dimension of all legislative acts and an aspect which will need to be operationalised in each of the other building blocks. The EC is very clear: “There can be no picking and choosing. All building blocks need to be implemented and are interdependent.” The EU Pact sets out important safeguards and rights for applicants for international protection and people with specific needs, particularly children and families with children. The implementation of these fundamental rights and safeguards serves to protect human dignity and ensure a genuine and effective right to asylum, including for the most vulnerable, as well as the access to effective remedies in line with the EU Charter, the ECHR and the UNCRC. The Irish Presidency must ensure that the implementation of the EU Pact complies with human rights standards as required by the Pact and international human rights law. Strategy for the Rights of Persons with Disabilities The Irish Presidency must ensure that the review of the Strategy for the Rights of Persons with Disabilities will include provisions and measures that guarantee children with disabilities are seen, heard and counted. Children with disabilities must be an integral part of the updated Strategy, they must be actively involved in the consultation process and the Strategy should require that data on their experiences is collected and disaggregated by disability. Children with disabilities are subjects of rights under both the UNCRC and UNCRPD, and the Irish Presidency should ensure that this is reflected in the new strategy. Anti-poverty strategy The Irish Presidency must ensure that the EU's first Anti-Poverty Strategy will tackle child poverty as a priority and will be informed by the voices of those with lived experience of poverty. The European Child Guarantee should be strengthened and integrated in the Strategy. Special attention should be dedicated to particularly vulnerable groups of children, including migrant children, Roma children, children with disabilities, LGBTQIA+ children, children in alternative care, and homeless children who are disproportionately affected by poverty, in addition to the intersection with other forms of human rights violations and discrimination. Online safety and artificial intelligence (AI) An OCO Survey on Extremism, Discrimination and Gender Roles revealed that there is a clear link between the online world and the prevalence of extremist views particularly for boys and young men. This is also a reality in other MS of the EU. With the growth of the AI landscape, the EU must ensure that regulators hold social media companies to account and include a special focus on children in its work on AI to ensure that children are protected from harm. Up until now the focus on children and children’s rights in relation to AI has been marginal at best. This must be addressed to ensure children are safe online and that they are not being targeted through harmful algorithms. The Irish Presidency must ensure that children’s rights have a special focus in regulatory work around AI.

The work of the Council during the term of the Irish Presidency would make the most substantial positive impact for children if it was to ensure that a children’s rights perspective is mainstreamed in all relevant policies, legislation and funding programmes. Children’s rights are an integral part of EU values as provided in Article 24 CFREU. The EU Strategy on the Rights of the Child commits to strengthen the mainstreaming of children’s rights across all relevant EU actions with the specific needs of certain groups of children, including those in situations of multiple vulnerabilities and facing intersecting forms of discrimination, being duly taken into account. For this to happen, the Council must take children’s rights seriously in its work and ensure that child rights impact assessments (CRIAs) are part and parcel of EU policy/legislation making in areas such as migration, poverty, disability, online safety and AI. The Council should also consider a review of the current EU Strategy on the Rights of the Child 2021-2024 and ensure that a mainstreaming checklist on the rights of the child, promised by the EC in 2021 but never delivered, is developed with the involvement of civil society and children.

The best way for the Irish Presidency to communicate the values and benefits of EU membership to its citizens: To lead by example in a world where human rights and the rule of law are under attack. The EU is built on fundamental rights, democracy and the rule of law. Article 2 of the Treaty on European Union provides that “The Union is founded on the values of respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights, including the rights of persons belonging to minorities.” The EU Charter of fundamental rights applies in conjunction with national and international fundamental rights protection systems, including the European Convention on Human Rights. The scope of application of the Charter reflects the scope of EU law itself: “the Charter is the ‘shadow’ of EU law. This means, in essence, that there can be no situation that is governed by EU law in which the Charter does not apply.” The Irish Presidency must ensure that EU actions abide by the Charter and international human rights law at all times and in all areas, especially at a time when a total disregard for human rights is being openly displayed by major players. The best way for the Irish Presidency to create a sense of ownership: To foster participation of its citizens, including children in EU policy making. There is no better way of creating a sense of ownership than involving people in decision making processes. The EU Strategy on the Rights of the Child commits to child participation and creates an EU Children Participation Platform, however, participation must be understood as going beyond consultation. For participation to be meaningful and produce a sense of ownership, children’s views must be taken seriously and given due weight, which means they must be able to influence an outcome, or a decision. The Irish Presidency should implement child participation in EU policy making in line with the guidance from the UN Committee on the Rights of the Child as required by Article 24 of the CFREU.

Supporting Informal/Family Carers and Disabled people through an Equality Lens Often key to the well-being of large numbers of disabled people, and representing a hidden workforce, Ireland’s estimated 600,000 family carers1 deserve a better deal to be less isolated and experience a better quality of life. Nearly half (45%) of the EU population provides unpaid care. Unpaid carers provide in excess of 80% of care across the EU. In many EU countries, family carers face even greater challenges in securing recognition and supports than some of their Irish counterparts. The 2022 European Care Strategy is a key document, and this Presidency has the opportunity to move it forward. Historically, and continuing today, Irish MEP’s have been key supports for, and drivers in, developing a formal EU Agenda for Care (including Frances Fitzgerald, Marian Harkin and Luke Ming Flanagan). We understand that the EU Commission is also intending to come forward with a ‘Care Deal’. This is also an opportunity at a carer focused event to showcase good examples of comprehensive Irish state funded support for family carers – in the area of income supports (Carers Allowance, Carers Benefit, Carer Support Grant, Pensions for Carers); direct face-to-face carer supports (e.g. Citizens Information, Family Carers Ireland, Dementia Advisors) and online carer support interventions (delivered by our own organisation, Care Alliance Ireland).

Focus on Resilience & Work-Life Balance The core challenge for informal/family carers of working age is balancing their care duties with paid work, which impacts their financial security, mental health, and the overall labour market. Goal: Advance the effective implementation and monitoring of the Work-Life Balance Directive across all Member States, specifically concerning carer’s leave and flexible working arrangements. Specifically: o Prioritise work by Eurofound and the Commission to establish and monitor EU-wide qualitative and quantitative data on the living conditions and needs of informal/family carers. This data is critical for evidence-based policymaking, addressing the "invisibility" of the role and it complements the EU Monitoring Framework on the Council Recommendation on the access to affordable high-quality long-term care. o Drive discussions in the EPSCO on ways to ensure that informal carers are identified across the EU and that periods of registered, intensive informal care contribute to the carer's social security and pension entitlements, mitigating the long-term risk of poverty and the gender pension gap. Invest in Quality Care & Professionalisation A major theme of the European Care Strategy is improving the formal care sector to reduce the forced reliance on informal/family care. Goal: Facilitate agreement and commitments on sustainable funding for professional long-term care, making informal care a choice, not a necessity. Specifically: o Focus Council discussions on Member State National Action Plans to ensure guaranteed access to high-quality, affordable respite care (day care, temporary residential care, inhome support). Push for a shared best-practice framework for respite services. o Promote policies that ensure professional care staff are trained to cooperate with and support informal/family carers, formally recognising informal/family carers as "cocreators" of care who require support, counselling, and training themselves. o Promote the mental health and well-being of professional carers and informal/family carers. 3. Leverage Digitalisation in Care (linked to the competitiveness/single market) Digital solutions have the potential to significantly improve the efficiency and quality of care, linking to the goal of a robust Digital Single Market. Goal: Promote the adoption of accessible, interoperable digital solutions to support informal care. Specifically: o Promote the existing EC/WHO online training for carers which includes country factsheets outlining the rights, support services (e.g., respite care), and financial benefits available to family carers in their specific country. o Fund initiatives across the EU that drive the adoption of online family carer peer-to-peer support interventions (using such interventions as delivered by Care Alliance Ireland as a possible template)

The core objective must be to transform the role of the informal/family carer from an invisible necessity that drives poverty and gender inequality into a recognised, valued, and supported choice. Address Carers’ Economic Security and Competitiveness By linking the care agenda to the Presidency’s anticipated focus on Competitiveness and a robust Single Market, the work of the Council can directly support businesses and individual livelihoods. The Presidency should prioritise the effective monitoring and enforcement of the Work-Life Balance (WLB) Directive, particularly the provisions for Carer’s Leave, and encourage Member States and stakeholders to go beyond the legal requirements of the WLB Directive - for example by providing paid Carer Leave. The Council should advance discussions on how periods of registered intensive caregiving can be integrated into social security and pension systems at the EU level. This directly mitigates the risk of poverty, a substantial concern for both Care Alliance Ireland and for Eurocarers and its members, and helps women in particular remain economically active, thereby improving overall labour market participation. Enhance Data and Recognition of the Carer Role to Unlock Support The Presidency can champion a common framework, building on the Work-Life Balance Directive and the Care Strategy, for the early identification and assessment of carers’ needs across all member states. This requires political endorsement in the Council of the EU for a refined harmonised data collection methodology on informal care, complementing the EU monitoring Framework on the Council Recommendation on access to affordable high-quality long-term care. This evidence is crucial to inform policy, ensure support reaches those who need it, and make the 'invisible workforce' visible to policymakers. 3. Prioritise Implementation and Investment in Quality Care The most significant impact will come from ensuring that the Council Recommendation on Long-Term Care is not merely adopted, but actively implemented and triggers a change of approach to informal carer in policy making and societal representations. The Presidency must drive the translation of the Council Recommendation into concrete national action plans with dedicated funding under the European Semester process, and the next EU funding period. This includes facilitating ministerial agreement in the EPSCO to set common, ambitious quantitative targets for the provision of affordable, high-quality care – both formal and informal. By focusing on these three implementation-oriented areas, the Irish Presidency can make a profound and lasting positive impact on the health, financial stability, and societal inclusion of millions of EU citizens.

The Irish Presidency can best communicate the values and benefits of EU membership and foster a sense of citizen ownership, particularly among informal/family carers, by placing the European Care Strategy at the heart of its public engagement. The strategy must be to make EU action directly relevant to the most profound challenges in people's daily lives. Focus on Tangible, Personal Impact Instead of abstract policy discussions, the Presidency should frame its work through the lens of intergenerational solidarity and gender equality, which are core EU values visible in care policy. Highlight how the EU, through the Work-Life Balance Directive and the European Care Strategy, provides tangible rights such as Carer’s Leave and financial protections that prevent poverty and contribute to pension entitlements for carers. Use real-life testimonials from carers across Ireland and Europe (e.g., in short videos or web articles) to demonstrate how these EU measures have allowed them to stay in the workforce or access essential respite services. This connects the EU Presidency’s agenda to personal empowerment. Involve Carers as Partners, Not Just Beneficiaries The Presidency should consider a means by which citizens can co-shape policy by hosting targeted "Citizens’ Care Dialogues" or high-profile public events that specifically invite Eurocarers and national carer organisations to share their expertise. Enable a clear communication stream that explains policy developments in simple terms and also enables citizens the chance to be heard. This should be framed so that citizens perceive themselves as co-producers of care and partners in policy implementation. This would demonstrate that Ireland’s role as the Presidency is about listening to and incorporating the lived experiences of vulnerable groups into EU policy. 3. Translate EU Policy into Local Benefit The communication must show the 'EU-to-Local' pathway, connecting Presidency decisions in Brussels to services in local communities. Launch a clear information campaign explaining how member states are investing in local, high-quality formal and informal care and digital support services. Utilise local media and community networks to host events showcasing EU-funded projects that improve care, demonstrating that the Presidency is focused on delivering a Europe that provides support and dignity for those who care, thereby strengthening the public perception of EU membership benefits.

We understand that our colleagues in Family Carers Ireland and Eurocarers are already liaising with the Irish government and the EU commission with respect to a possible event on care/long-term care and family members as a central role in this. We are supportive of such proposals.

The Fair Labour Mobility Package Quality Jobs Roadmap In relation to the Val Duchesse Tripartite Declaration initiative, it is important to note that the employer representatives who participated in that initiative accepted that the aspiration for long-term competitiveness within the EU needs to go hand in hand with quality jobs. It is vitally important that these unequivocal public statements are supported on the ground by the members of these representative bodies, and one way to ensure this is for the Irish government during its presidency to adopt as one of its high-level thematic priorities that the EU embodies and tangibly supports the principle of decent work.

Millions of EU workers are experiencing a cost-of-living crisis and discovering that work does not provide sufficient income for them and their dependents to maintain a basic standard of living. They are enduring a lack of proper housing and health care along with rising prices due to outof-control food and energy inflation. One effective way to equip workers to deal with these harsh realities is to ensure that they are afforded statutory collective bargaining rights to allow them and their chosen trade union to negotiate with their employer a fair and just reward for their labour. That is why addressing the issues raised in our responses to questions one and two above is so important. When it comes to housing, it is essential to carefully consider the European Affordable Housing Plan review scheduled for publication on December 16, 2025. This was commissioned by the EU to examine State aid rules for services of general economic interest, and it is hoped the findings will aid efforts to improve support and access to affordable housing.

In simple terms the best way of promoting the benefits of EU membership is through the delivery of meaningful and timely actions which lead to tangible improvements in the lives of citizens across all 27 States. The achievement of this goal is especially important now, as an increasing number of individuals and groups are critically challenging established democratic norms and values. This trend has contributed to the emergence of more extreme viewpoints that clearly lack an emphasis on the common good or collective solidarity. Most citizens’ needs are relatively simple: they require access to an adequate income that provides a home, heat, food, and clothing. As a minimum, these benchmarks should be used by the EU to assess whether it is effectively serving the interests of its citizens. If these goals aren't met, it's hard to foster value or ownership in people who believe their basic needs are being ignored. If the ultimate objective is to create a people-centered theme which promotes a future-oriented vision for the EU, citizens must believe that such a future is preferable to their current existence.

geography: We are a National Trade Association with over 155 members from Ireland’s industrial engineering sectors
response_text: Executive Summary As global markets shift, energy systems transform, and technological innovation accelerates, engineering industries are at the heart of shaping a competitive, resilient, and sustainable future. The Irish Presidency offers a unique opportunity to lead on policies that strengthen Europe’s industrial base, secure strategic autonomy, and deliver prosperity for businesses and citizens alike. This document sets out Engineering Industries Ireland’s ambition for Ireland’s EU Presidency to strengthen Europe’s industrial base, enhance competitiveness, and secure strategic autonomy. It focuses on five priority areas: Global Trade Competitiveness: Reduce barriers to international trade, address rising compliance costs from new Machinery Regulation, CBAM and new directives, and counter unfair competition from statesubsidised imports. Affordable Energy Future: Lower energy costs and ensure supply security through accelerated investment in cross-border interconnectors, LNG storage, and renewable energy infrastructure. Streamline permitting and foster innovation partnerships to deliver a resilient, decarbonized energy system. Dual-Use Strategies: Embed dual-use innovation across Europe’s industrial base to leverage commercial technologies for defence and security applications. Align EU and national frameworks to unlock funding and accelerate R&D. Skills and Talent Development: Address Europe’s skills gap by supporting the Union of Skills agenda, expanding apprenticeships, and promoting lifelong learning. Boost digital and STEM capabilities to ensure the green and digital transitions create high-quality jobs. Fostering Diversity and Inclusion: gender equality and inclusion in engineering and technology sectors. Remove structural barriers, improve childcare infrastructure, and advance women’s participation in technology, engineering and mathematics and leadership roles to build a competitive and equitable Europe. By championing these measures, Ireland will help position Europe as a global leader in industrial engineering excellence future-proofing industry, creating high quality jobs, and reinforcing the foundations of a strong, sustainable Europe.

geography: We are a National Trade Association with over 155 members from Ireland’s industrial engineering sectors
response_text: Policy Priorities for the Irish Presidency of the Council in 2026: Advancing Global Trade Competitiveness The Irish Presidency should prioritize policies that strengthen European industry’s ability to compete globally while ensuring sustainability and resilience. Key focus areas include: Trade Defence and Fair Competition European manufacturers face mounting pressure from state-subsidized imports, particularly from China, which distort markets and threaten industrial viability. The Presidency should advance reforms to EU trade defence instruments, ensuring faster investigations, stronger anti-dumping measures, and effective enforcement of level-playing-field rules. This will safeguard Europe’s industrial base and prevent erosion of competitiveness. Regulatory Balance and Competitiveness Compliance costs linked to CBAM, the revised Machinery Directive, Ecodesign Regulation, and cybersecurity frameworks (NIS 2, Cyber Resilience Act) risk overburdening SMEs. The Presidency should champion a Competitiveness Check for all new legislation, ensuring sustainability and safety objectives are met without disproportionate cost impacts. Streamlined implementation guidelines and harmonized standards will reduce complexity and support innovation. Export Support and Market Diversification To enable firms to compete globally, Ireland should push for an EU-wide State-backed export credit insurance scheme, providing risk mitigation and financing for international expansion. Deepening the Single Market by removing barriers and enforcing existing rules will further enhance competitiveness. The Presidency should also prioritize WTO reform, strategic bilateral trade agreements, and frameworks for digital trade and data flows, embedding trade diversification and supply chain resilience into the EU’s Economic Security Strategy. Energy Affordability and Infrastructure High energy costs undermine industrial competitiveness. The Presidency should accelerate the Energy Highways initiative, cross-border interconnectors, and LNG storage investments to secure supply and stabilize prices. Streamlined permitting for renewables and hydrogen networks will advance decarbonization while reducing costs. A balanced approach—combining infrastructure investment with innovation partnerships—will strengthen Europe’s energy autonomy. Dual-Use Innovation Embedding dual-use strategies across the industrial base will unlock synergies between commercial and defence technologies, reducing R&D costs and accelerating innovation. The Presidency should align EU and national frameworks to facilitate funding and certification for dual-use applications in AI, robotics, sensors, and autonomous systems, reinforcing resilience and competitiveness. 6. Skills, Talent, and Inclusion Addressing the skills crisis is critical. Ireland should lead on the Union of Skills agenda, promoting consistent funding for apprenticeships, lifelong learning, and digital upskilling. Expanding visa programs for engineering talent will support green and digital transitions. Additionally, advancing gender equality through childcare infrastructure, tax reforms, and targeted STEM initiatives will foster diversity, address labour shortages, and ensure inclusive growth

geography: We are a National Trade Association with over 155 members from Ireland’s industrial engineering sectors
response_text: Maximizing Positive Impact During the Irish Presidency: Global Trade Competitiveness The Irish Presidency of the Council in 2026 can deliver substantial benefits for people, businesses, and communities by championing policies that strengthen competitiveness, foster resilience, and ensure inclusive growth. The following priorities will have the most significant impact: Reducing Regulatory Burden While Supporting Sustainability European businesses face rising compliance costs from CBAM, Ecodesign, and cybersecurity regulations. While these measures are essential for climate and security objectives, their implementation must avoid disproportionate impacts on SMEs. The Presidency should lead efforts to introduce a Competitiveness Check for all new legislation, harmonize standards, and provide clear guidance to reduce complexity. This will protect jobs, encourage innovation, and ensure businesses remain globally competitive without compromising sustainability goals. Strengthening Trade Defence and Fair Competition State-subsidized imports, particularly from China, distort markets and threaten EU manufacturing. The Presidency should prioritize modernizing trade defence instruments, accelerating anti-dumping investigations, and enforcing level-playing-field rules. These measures will safeguard Europe’s industrial base, secure employment, and maintain community prosperity. Expanding Market Access and Diversification To help businesses thrive globally, Ireland should advocate for: State-backed export credit insurance schemes to reduce risk for SMEs. Deepening the Single Market by removing barriers and enforcing existing rules. Advancing WTO reform, strategic bilateral trade agreements, and frameworks for digital trade and data flows. Embedding trade diversification and supply chain resilience into EU Economic Security Strategies will protect communities from external shocks and ensure long-term stability. Delivering Affordable and Secure Energy High energy costs undermine competitiveness and household budgets. The Presidency should accelerate the Energy Highways initiative, cross-border interconnectors, and LNG storage investments to stabilize prices and secure supply. Streamlined permitting for renewables and hydrogen networks will reduce reliance on fossil fuels, cut costs, and create green jobs benefiting both businesses and communities. Investing in Skills and Inclusion Addressing the skills crisis is vital for competitiveness and social cohesion. The Presidency should: Promote the Union of Skills agenda for lifelong learning and digital upskilling. Support consistent funding for apprenticeships and expand visa programs for engineering talent. Advance gender equality through childcare infrastructure, tax reforms, and targeted STEM initiatives. These measures will ensure the twin transition of green and digital and create opportunities rather than displacement, fostering inclusive growth across Europe. Outcome By focusing on competitiveness, fair trade, energy affordability, skills, and inclusion, the Irish Presidency can deliver tangible benefits: stronger businesses, secure jobs, and resilient communities. This agenda will position Europe as a global leader in sustainable industry while ensuring prosperity for its citizens.

geography: We are a National Trade Association with over 155 members from Ireland’s industrial engineering sectors
response_text: The Irish Presidency of the Council in 2026 offers a unique opportunity to demonstrate the tangible benefits of EU membership and foster a sense of shared ownership among citizens. By linking the Presidency’s priorities to real-world outcomes for people, businesses, and communities, Ireland can make the EU’s role visible, relevant, and inspiring. 1. Showcasing Economic Opportunity and Competitiveness Citizens often perceive EU policy as distant or overly technical. The Presidency should communicate how EU initiatives directly support jobs, innovation, and prosperity. For example: Global Trade Competitiveness: Explain how strengthening trade defence mechanisms protects European industries from unfair competition and secures employment in sectors like engineering and manufacturing. Market Access: Highlight efforts to secure new trade agreements and diversify supply chains, ensuring businesses can grow internationally and communities benefit from stable, affordable goods. Messaging should emphasize that these actions safeguard Europe’s industrial base and create opportunities for SMEs the backbone of local economies. Linking Energy Policy to Everyday Benefits Energy affordability and security resonate strongly with citizens. The Presidency should frame its leadership on the Energy Highways initiative, cross-border interconnectors, and renewable infrastructure as measures that: Lower household energy bills. Reduce reliance on imported fossil fuels. Create green jobs in emerging sectors like offshore wind and hydrogen. Clear, relatable narratives such as “EU cooperation means cheaper, cleaner energy for Irish homes” will make EU action tangible. Human-Centered Communication on Skills and Inclusion The Union of Skills agenda and gender equality initiatives should be presented as investments in people: Explain how EU-backed apprenticeships and lifelong learning programs equip workers for highquality jobs in the green and digital economy. Showcase efforts to remove barriers for women in STEM and improve childcare infrastructure as steps toward a fairer, more inclusive Europe. Stories of individuals benefiting from these programs can personalize the message and build emotional connection. Use Accessible Language and Multiple Channels To create ownership, communication must move beyond technical jargon. Strategies include: Digital storytelling: Short videos and infographics showing how EU trade agreements open markets for Irish businesses or how energy projects cut costs. Community engagement: Town halls, school programs, and partnerships with local media to explain EU initiatives in practical terms. • Social media campaigns: Highlighting success stories under themes like “Ireland at the Heart of Europe’s Future.” 5. Emphasize Shared Values Finally, link policies to core EU values solidarity, sustainability, and security. Position Ireland’s Presidency as a driver of a competitive, inclusive, and resilient Europe that protects citizens’ interests globally. Outcome By connecting EU policies to everyday benefits, jobs, affordable energy, skills, and fairness, the Irish Presidency can transform abstract concepts into tangible value, fostering pride in EU membership and a sense of collective ownership.

geography: We are a National Trade Association with over 155 members from Ireland’s industrial engineering sectors
response_text: About Engineering Industries Ireland As Ireland’s engineering business representative group and one of Ibec’s newest Trade Association launched in November 2021, Engineering Industries Ireland represents over 155 industrial engineering manufacturing and services companies in Ireland. We represent the engineering sectors of 11,906 enterprises, employing 62,068 people with a net turnover of €28.9 billion and an output value of €22.5 billion. Our members are involved in a wide range of sectors, including agricultural and marine machinery, automotive and aerospace, building services and HVAC engineering, engineering services, energy and environment, electronics and embedded systems, industrial automation, materials handling, metal fabrication and processing, packaging, paper and print, and precision engineering. We represent engineering businesses, both homegrown and multinationals, big and small, to advocate for a supportive business environment, as well as provide expert employer relations, industry insight and incomparable networking opportunities for our members. In terms of broad policy positions, Engineering Industries Ireland and Ibec are aligned when it comes to Ireland’s presidency of the EU and support the broad Ibec campaign for Ireland’s EU Presidency. Making a Resilient, Competitive EU a Reality: The Business Ambition for Ireland’s EU Presidency

respondent_type: Irish chapter of a global movement to advance gender equity in health
response_text: Ireland should choose to advance gender equity and inclusion as a central theme to their Presidency of the Council. As part of this area, a focus should be given to inequalities in health and healthcare leadership affecting women and minorities. Health is a fundamental human right and yet women and girls, and those from minority or traditionally underserved groups, have worse health outcomes, find it more difficult to access care and are under-represented in leadership and decision making. A key part of A Better World is advancing gender equality and health is a key part of this. Research by Women in Global Health shows that despite 70% of health workers worldwide being female, only 25% of those in leadership positions in health are women. Research also shows that women have poorer health outcomes, particularly those from minority backgrounds. We are also seeing a roll back of women’s rights and comprehensive SRHR world wide and within the EU bloc. All three pillars of the Council’s strategic agenda could be advanced by improving equity and inclusion in health. A healthy Europe is a strong and secure Europe. As we have seen with the Covid-19 pandemic, pandemics respect no borders. The reduction in funding for global health efforts globally are shortsighted, health security and equity is a front line defence. A free and democratic Europe cannot be achieved if there are inequities in sectors or within countries. The strategy highlights that values such as human dignity and the respect for human rights is the EU’s strength. Access to health for women and underserved communities is key to dignity and human rights. Prioritising this will build a strong, inclusive Europe. A key part of a prosperous and competitive Europe is health cooperation. Ireland should drive gender equity within health cooperation for a fair, equitable Europe. Europe’s technological and industry should be underpinned by increased research and investment in issues that impact women’s health, which has traditionally been underfunded. Creating good jobs and ensuring representation at leadership that goes beyond gender quotas but also sees representation from communities who are traditionally underrepresented is key to maximizing Europe’s prosperity. Ireland has long been a champion of the furthest behind at a global stage and are a respected voice at a European level. Ireland should champion gender equity in health as part of their Presidency, with a focus on the right to health which would position the government well for advancing their bid for a seat on the UN Human Right’s Council.

respondent_type: Irish chapter of a global movement to advance gender equity in health
response_text: Ireland should focus on universal, inclusive and affordable healthcare for all and support diversity in healthcare leadership and governance. This can be achieved through legislative proposals not only in the health sphere such as ensuring equity and targeted actions are embedded in the EU4Health programme but also through ensuring diversity in health leadership is prioritised in the European Pillar of Social Rights and that the Roadmap for Women’s Rights includes women from underserved and marginalized communities such as migrant women, women with disabilities, Roma and traveller women and LGBTQI+. Ireland should propose a mechanism for monitoring gender equity and inclusion through all the programmes run by the EU but also legislating that EU Member States report on gender equity and inclusion annually with a chapter to include equity and inclusion in healthcare. Ireland should implement meaningful consultation mechanisms for all EU policies being renewed going forward. Women in all their diversity should be at the table when decisions are being made.

respondent_type: Irish chapter of a global movement to advance gender equity in health
response_text: Ireland’s Presidency comes at a pivotal time in the EU. The new Multi-Annual Financial Framework is being developed and this brings with it opportunity to ember Ireland’s views of equity, inclusion and leaving no one behind in the negotiations. This will have substantial impact on people, businesses and communities across the EU. By advocating for gender equity and social inclusion as a core principle of EU funding, Ireland can ensure that advances across the EU are available to everyone. Without embedding inclusion and equity in funding from the outset, there is a risk that any advances made do not include those who are traditionally marginalized. Ireland should emphasise a rights-based investment in health, social protection and community resilience. When people’s human rights are being upheld, they are able to participate more in society driving economic stability and sustainability for business. For there to be a substantive positive impact on people, businesses and communities across the EU, these stakeholders need to be meaningfully consulted. Too often business voices are the loudest in these fora and there is a need to balance what is best for business with what is best for the population as a whole. Ireland should systematically involve civil society, with a particular focus on communities that are traditionally underrepresented such as ethnic and gender minorities, disability and carers organisations, in public policies to co-create, implement and monitor EU and national gender-equal policies and actions.

respondent_type: Irish chapter of a global movement to advance gender equity in health
response_text: Public health is essential to social justice, economic resilience, democratic stability and Europe’s security. This needs to be communicated more openly particularly at a time where we see funds being diverted from overseas development assistance to defence. No one is safe until everyone is safe as we saw with the COVID pandemic. By using this framing, citizens of the EU will see their role within the EU and globally as key to safe, health, democratic societies. Ireland has long benefited from public support for the EU and the public has seen it’s self as part of a global community. This should be emphasized and can be fostered through showing how Ireland’s values of gender equity and rights can be advanced as part of the EU and how the bloc can complement the work being done at a national level. As outlined in Q3, meaningful consultation of communities is key. Where people can see their role in co-creating policies that impact them, there will be a sense of ownership and pride fostered. When people feel that policies reflect their lived reality, that they have had input into and are actionable they will see the benefit of EU membership/

respondent_type: Irish chapter of a global movement to advance gender equity in health
response_text: An EU Ombusman for Gender Equity and Inclusion with health as part of their remit would serve as an accountability mechanism and show to EU citizens and the world that the EU is committed to a more equitable world and that the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the EU are still core to the bloc’s beliefs.

Ireland’s Presidency of the Council of the European Union occurs at a time of significant geopolitical and sociopolitical instability, marked by a rise in authoritarianism, the weakening of long-standing democratic norms and values, a curtailment of fundamental rights and freedoms, and an increasingly disempowered citizenry. While it can be tempting to respond to the challenges we confront in a reactive manner, we mustn’t abandon the principles and values on which our Union was founded, and which we strive to protect and promote on the international stage, in doing so. It is essential that we defend the erosion of the hard-fought freedoms and democratic rights that many of us have come to take for granted. At the very foundation of the European Union lies a robust commitment to democracy, in which European citizens are active and engaged participants. Civil society’s importance in the realisation of the values that underpin the foundations of the Union, as enshrined in Article 2 of the Treaty on European Union (TEU), are recognised in Article 11 of the TEU, which states that the EU “shall maintain open, transparent and regular dialogue” with civil society, and separately Article 15 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU), which states that civil society participation shall be ensured through the operational transparency of the Union. This participation strengthens social cohesion, improves the quality and legitimacy of public decision-making, and builds a shared commitment to the principles of equality, inclusion, and accountability. At a time when polarisation, disinformation, declining institutional trust, and shrinking civic space threaten the resilience of our democracy, empowering people to engage meaningfully in public life is more important than ever, and will help to restore and reinforce its foundations. While the work of civil society becomes more essential, it has also become increasingly difficult, with civic space under assault in a growing number of countries - according to the 2025 CIVICUS Monitor, more than 70% of the world’s population live in severely constrained civic space, where freedom of association, expression and peaceful assembly are under threat. Ireland has historically had a strong tradition of civic engagement, community organising and human rights advocacy, but the role of the civic, community and voluntary sector has become underappreciated and contested, and. in some cases, undermined entirely, as observed in the exclusion of key civil society voices in the oversight processes informing the development of Ireland’s forthcoming National Drugs Strategy. Our proud tradition of civic engagement has made an indispensable contribution to a vibrant democracy in Ireland, but this positive legacy risks being undone if we do not preserve the space afforded to civil society, especially when expressing dissent informed by a significant depth of expertise. While we had the luxury of being somewhat protected from the erosion of civic and democratic participation observed in other jurisdictions, that is sadly no longer the reality. Ireland is now experiencing a contraction of civic space, from within and without, fueled by rising inequality, strategic disempowerment of our citizens, the curtailment of expression through intimidation, algorithmic misinformation and manipulation, and interference by mal-actors.
