This trend is mirrored across the EU, where civil society organisations (CSOs) have been significantly restricted in their ability to operate and organise in certain member states in recent years, as documented by Civil Society Europe. CSOs across the continent are finding it increasingly challenging to access stable public funding streams, whilst obstacles to fundraising through donations, cross-border philanthropy, or crowdfunding persist. This is an acute issue in Ireland, where concrete action is yet to be taken to address long-standing legal obstacles to funding for CSOs under our Electoral Acts. By including civil society engagement and democratic participation within the thematic priorities of Ireland’s Presidency of the Council of the EU, an opportunity is presented to reinforce Europe’s democratic values, respond proactively to shrinking civic space across our continent, strengthen the EU’s institutional dialogue with citizens and citizens’ organisations, and enhance democratic resilience in the face of significant sociopolitical and geopolitical challenges. Driving this agenda would leave a positive, lasting legacy in support of a more inclusive, participatory, and resilient Union, at a time when these values are coming under increasing pressure.

A vibrant, protected, and well-supported civil society represents one of the EU’s strongest assets for sustaining a healthy democracy and countering the forces that weaken it and erode confidence in democratic institutions and processes. This was recognised in Ursula Von der Leyen’s candidacy for Commission Presidency, which called for citizens to be placed at the heart of European democracy, for participation to be embedded across the Union, for civil society to be better protected in its work, and for engagement between the Union and civil society to be “stepped up”. This commitment has been reflected in the EU’s Strategic Agenda 2024-2029, which aims to strengthen democratic resilience by protecting a “free and pluralistic” civil society in Europe. While it is one thing to recognise the central role played by civil society in a healthy democracy, there needs to be an acknowledgement that the dynamic between civil society and government is not purely collaborative, and at times must be robust and confrontational. Civil society’s independence is therefore critical, and the need for CSOs to be able to advocate, organise and campaign freely and without interference is absolute, even when dissenting from government policy. This tension is a fundamental ingredient of a healthy democracy. In 2024, Michael McGrath was appointed EU Commissioner for Democracy, Justice, the Rule of Law and Consumer Protection - a hugely important brief at a critical juncture. As Commissioner, Mr McGrath is tasked with upholding and strengthening the values and principles that underpin the EU. Within this, he is charged with specific responsibility for implementing the EU’s new Democracy Package, made up of the European Democracy Shield and the EU’s first ever Strategy for Civil Society. Against this backdrop, Ireland’s Presidency offers a unique and timely opportunity to champion a renewed European commitment to civic participation and democratic resilience. Prioritising the protection of civic space and democratic participation as a high-level thematic focus would allow Ireland to: • reinforce and enhance the EU’s foundational democratic values; • prioritise a rights based approach to policy & legislative developement • respond proactively to the documented shrinking of civic space across Europe; • strengthen structured dialogue between EU institutions and citizens’ organisations; • support policy reforms that enable a more enabling environment for CSOs, including improved funding mechanisms and reduced regulatory burdens; • shape the operationalisation of the EU’s proposed Civil Society Platform; • promote healthy environments for civic action at national and EU levels; • encourage a more participatory, inclusive, and trusted Union. At a time of increasing geopolitical pressure, disinformation, algorithmic manipulation, democratic backsliding, and fragmentation, Ireland can play a leading role in ensuring that EU policies and legislation better support citizens’ active and meaningful democratic participation for generations to come - in close alignment with the EU’s own policy priorities for the duration of this mandate.

During its term, the Council can make a substantial positive impact across the EU by championing a model of policymaking grounded in co-design and co-creation, positively transforming how European institutions deliver for the communities they serve. Traditional consultation processes often fail to reach the communities they need to hear from the most, and as a result communities feel sidelined, or excluded from participating entirely. When participation is tokenistic or selective, policy development misses vital insights about lived and living experience that can positively impact all-of-society. Civil society can help to bridge the gap and articulate the perspectives of a broad diversity of communities, especially those that are most marginalised and disempowered. But, increasingly, civil society across our continent lacks the independence and stability to be able to organise and advocate effectively. There is also the issue of self-censorship due to fears that criticism of governing institutions can jeopardise access to funding, which creates a significant chilling effect. These issues undermine robust public dialogue and civil society’s ability to shape public policy, and erode the principles of freedom of expression and association. When people from diverse backgrounds can participate and engage openly and without fear or restraint, and when organisations representing their interests are resourced and empowered to speak freely, the quality of policymaking improves markedly. Co-design can help to instigate this shift, by bringing policymakers, service providers, CSOs, businesses and communities into the same problem-solving space from the outset. The Irish Presidency has an opportunity to demonstrate that when we embrace co-design, where stakeholders are meaningfully involved, outcomes improve across the board. Supporting civil society’s independence and capacity helps to amplify the voices of traditionally marginalised groups, disempowered communities, and those furthest from political processes. When these perspectives are embraced, policies become more inclusive and are therefore more responsive to lived experience. A thriving civic landscape can provide a robust evidence base to inform policy decisions, help to build social consensus for reform, and promote greater institutional trust, but it must be empowered and resourced effectively to do so. Strengthening our participatory democracy is therefore an investment in our shared prosperity, social cohesion, and policymaking that positively impacts individuals, communities and industry. If meaningful engagement and co-creation are embedded into the heart of EU policymaking during the Irish Presidency, the Council will demonstrate that the EU is serious about listening and adapting. Openness to dialogue, even where dissent is expressed, helps to foster trust at a time when democratic institutions face growing scepticism. It also ensures that policymaking is informed not only by governments, but by the lived and living experience of our citizens, leaving individuals, communities and industry better served, more empowered and more resilient.

Communicating the values and benefits of EU membership, and fostering a real sense of ownership over Ireland’s Presidency of the Council of the EU, requires an approach rooted in participation, co-creation and trust. Recent research published by European Movement Ireland has indicated that, whilst support for membership of the EU remains strong in Ireland, 43% of people do not feel that their views are represented at the EU level, and, concerningly, trust in governing institutions has declined sharply. People are more likely to value and defend democratic institutions when they can see themselves in the policymaking process, when they feel their experiences shape decisions, and when engagement is meaningful rather than symbolic. The task, therefore, is less about communicating the value of the EU to its citizens, and more about demonstrating it, and opening the Presidency and the broader EU project to greater public involvement. Co-design and co-creation offer a powerful way to achieve this. Diverse and engaging creative and cultural programming, community-led events and dialogues, participatory workshops and sectoral roundtables can create structured spaces for people to discuss the work of the Council. When citizens believe that their perspectives inform Ireland’s positions and priorities, the Presidency becomes something they feel they are shaping rather than observing. Engaging a diversity of voices in these processes is essential, especially those who are furthest away from political processes. These communities can contribute nuanced perspectives that enrich decision-making and increase legitimacy. The Irish Presidency can demonstrate leadership in this respect by actively reaching out to under-represented groups and providing accessible, well-supported pathways for them to participate. Ultimately, a sense of ownership will grow when people feel the EU reflects their concerns, protects their rights, and embraces their perspectives and ideas. By embedding participation into the heart of the Presidency, Ireland can help to build a stronger relationship between Europe and its citizens.

Ireland’s Presidency coincides with an important year in relation to the future direction of drugs policy for both the EU and Ireland, as both launch updated Drugs Strategies, and there is an opportunity for this to be recognised. For many years now, the EU and Irish Drug Strategies have been underpinned by a shared commitment to a whole-of-society approach, strengthening sectoral and partner co-operation and actively engaging civil society. This strong commitment to embracing civil society and community engagement at the heart of our response to drugs and drug-related harms has been reflected in both EU and Irish drug policy to date, and it is essential that this constructive collaboration continues to underpin future strategies. With the EU’s Democracy Shield falling under the purview of Commissioner McGrath, the Irish Presidency should also take the opportunity to interrogate the role of manipulative interference by largely unregulated technological services and recommender systems in the lives of European citizens, and the negative impact that this has had on our democracy. The Democracy Shield focuses primarily on the interference of external mal-actors and neglects the subtly harmful role of technologies that have become integrated in our everyday lives. The Democracy Shield should expand its focus, and consider the harms caused and exacerbated by these technologies, including recommender algorithms. While technology contributes a certain value to our society, it also poses risks of significant harm. Europe has played a leading role in regulating technological services in recent years, striking a better balance between the protection of our fundamental rights, dignity and privacy, and stimulating innovation. Given the potentially transformative role of emerging technologies, like artificial intelligence, in our society, it is imperative that the EU approaches the regulation of emerging technologies, including artificial intelligence, with an equivalent level of skepticism, and care for citizens’ fundamental rights.

Environment and Human Rights Water Resilience – Ireland’s waters are in a poor state, with nitrate pollution + flooding damaging the environment and threatening communities and the economy. Every country in Europe is struggling with water pollution, and needs to increase water efficiency + reuse. Water scarcity + flooding also wreak havoc in many parts of Europe, with water scarcity increasing in almost every part of the EU. Ireland needs to defend the existing EU water legislation from it being opened up and rewritten during the EU omnibus and ensure its proper implementation – which it has consistently failed to do. It should also push for countries to implement nature-based solutions, sponge cities, tackle pollution at the source, and increase water reuse wherever possible. Nature restoration should also be a priority – the relationship between ecosystem degradation and climate change is cyclical, with one accelerating the other. Peace keeping + civil rights should also be a priority – the EU has failed on international issues like Palestine, and we have seen civil rights relating to protest and freedom of speech regarding Palestine and criticism of Israel be severely curtailed across the EU, particularly in Germany. Ireland must stand up for human and civil rights, and the fundamental rights of everyone in the EU to freedom of speech, freedom of assembly, due process under the law, and freedom from policy violence.
Protect the Water Framework Directive from being watered down and gutted. Water is a strategic as well as environmental priority. Implement the EU’s water resilience strategy.

geography: National, EU and global – we provide pharmaceutical and non-prescription health products, throughout the country, but are an EU headquartered company (Germany) with a large global footprint. This also includes our significant crop science division, as one of the largest seed producers in the world, alongside our portfolio of vital crop protection products.
response_text: As a large multinational life sciences company headquartered in the EU’s largest member state, Bayer believes it is becoming increasingly important that Ireland continues some of the themes from recent presidencies and the current Commission agenda for simplification, while fostering greater EU competitiveness and boosting European innovation. The EU is at a crossroad, with Europe’s choice as to the direction it takes crucial to its future international relevance. This is now Ireland’s choice, and the Irish presidency has an opportunity to draw a line under some complex and contentious policy areas, bring a fresh focus and perspective on the current geopolitical turmoil and place it in a more positive context for European businesses and citizens, initiating actions that can lead to greater European economic resilience and a more prosperous future for everyone who lives and works in the EU. The Irish presidency must choose the path of prosperity for future EU presidencies to follow. Through both the Letta and Draghi reports the imperative for the EU to focus its attention on how to boost competitiveness and close the growing innovation gap with China and the US is clear, with the pharmaceutical sector highlighted as one of the key industries to achieve this. However, so far, the EU’s actions have not fully matched this recognised imperative. There are a number of current and planned legislative files (see response to question 2) that are very significant for the pharmaceutical sector and we therefore believe that the high-level thematic priorities must provide ample scope for the Irish presidency to close or significantly progress these legislative files. Alongside our European and Irish industry associations, EFPIA and IPHA, we believe the theme should encompass both the need for greater strategic resilience for the pharmaceutical sector, alongside the need for greater economic competitiveness that leads to improved equality – specifically patient outcomes – for European citizens. The thematic priorities must also take account of how this can best be achieved. The regulatory burden on European businesses must be reduced alongside targeted measures to incentivise innovation. A renewed focus on the Single Market, particularly where this can release capital and funding across the whole value-chain and incentivise companies to scale up, is needed. With Europe falling further behind in global research and development, the Irish presidency’s thematic priorities should include leading the discussion on how investment in innovation can be realised and harnessed to deliver for European patients. Lastly, given Ireland’s leading role in promoting and enhancing women’s health, we hope this is an area the Irish presidency will consider in its thematic priorities, to see the same priority given to women’s health across Europe. This includes using the presidency to encourage self-care in health promotion and disease prevention. Specifically, Ireland is leading in how to support women through menopause, a significant un-met need across the EU, and we believe Ireland should use its presidency to highlight and coordinate a fresh EU-wide approach, potentially including in work on the upcoming gender equality strategy.

geography: National, EU and global – we provide pharmaceutical and non-prescription health products, throughout the country, but are an EU headquartered company (Germany) with a large global footprint. This also includes our significant crop science division, as one of the largest seed producers in the world, alongside our portfolio of vital crop protection products.
response_text: Given the pharmaceutical sector’s footprint in Ireland and the Irish Government’s understanding of the strategic importance of the sector to the EU, it is vital that the Irish Presidency allocates sufficient time and resources to progress significantly or conclude as many of these files as possible. The pharmaceutical sector is uniquely positioned to simultaneously drive two key pillars of our future: better health and economic stability and growth. However, the US administration’s Most Favoured Nation (MFN) drug pricing policy is a direct and immediate challenge to the European health and welfare models. Without an immediate, decisive and coordinated European policy response, it will accelerate the erosion of Europe’s competitiveness and could delay the launch of innovative medicines in Europe. By taking immediate action in delivering faster, more comprehensive access to medicines for patients consistently across member states, by accelerating turning scientific excellence into healthcare solutions and by attracting talent, R&D and manufacturing investment, Europe can once again, become a global leader in life-sciences. We therefore believe the Biotech Act should be a flagship legislative priority for the Irish presidency, delivering greater IP protections, simplifying and harmonising the clinic trials structure, while enhancing greater access to funding and investment opportunities across the value-chain. The Biotech Act is also vital to agricultural innovation for EU farmers and must deliver meaningful change and simplify the system to boost competitiveness for the EU agrifood sector. Depending on progress made by the Cypriot presidency, Ireland should focus progress on the Critical Medicines Act on delivering genuine supply resilience, utilising its own manufacturing experience to advocate against protectionist measures that would fragment supply chains. The end goal should be on delivering better patient outcomes first, being selective about joint procurement and ensuring appropriate safeguards. The European Innovation Act is also an important file to progress, under both the simplification and competitiveness agendas. The aim for the Irish presidency should be capitalising on the potential of this Act to simplify and clarify legislation, boost investment and market incentives, while enabling access to capital and markets for companies across the value-chain. Given the scope of the “omnibus” legislative packages, it follows that these should be given suitable priority by the Irish presidency. Specifically, concluding the Environmental Omnibus and advancing the Food and Feed Safety Omnibus would be a significant step in simplifying legislation around the manufacturing of pharmaceuticals and supporting agricultural innovation for EU farmers. We also hope that Ireland will take the lead in shaping the Council's position on the upcoming REACH simplification, with the aim of avoiding double-regulation with the existing profound sectoral legislations. Cognisant of the current geopolitical and trade landscape, we hope the Presidency will prioritise implementation of the EU Economic Security strategy, aiming for balance across the three pillars of ‘Promote, Protect, Partner’. This policy must reflect the new geopolitical reality, which means it should encompass a broader range of policy tools and objectives, including EU industrial and internal market policies. Finally, Ireland must seek to resolve the issue of unitary Supplementary Protection Certificates, which may still undermine IP protections and thus future investment across the life sciences.

geography: National, EU and global – we provide pharmaceutical and non-prescription health products, throughout the country, but are an EU headquartered company (Germany) with a large global footprint. This also includes our significant crop science division, as one of the largest seed producers in the world, alongside our portfolio of vital crop protection products.
response_text: The US MFN policy is not merely a US domestic issue nor an unrealistic scenario; it is a direct and immediate challenge to the European health and welfare models. The E and its Member States must respond with a unified, ambitious, and evidence-based strategy. The time for deliberation is over. As a matter of urgency, policy solutions to protect patient access, safeguard European innovation, and ensure that Europe maintains its strategic autonomy and resilience in the life sciences must be adopted and implemented. As a large European headquartered company, we recognise the significant positive impact EU-level decisions can have on citizens, businesses and communities in every Member State. While Ireland enjoys strong support for the EU, this is not the case across the EU and we would encourage Ireland’s presidency to focus the presidency’s activity on what will deliver tangible outcomes for everyone living and working in the EU. Bayer’s President of global Pharmaceuticals, Stefan Oelrich, as president of our European industry association, EFPIA, has the same focus on delivering tangible benefits to patients across Europe. It is why we would like to see legislative consideration for measures that will free up capital for investment in companies of all sizes across the pharmaceutical value-chain, to turn financial investment into tangible products that will lead to life changing and life saving outcomes for EU patients. It is why the competitiveness and strategic resilience agendas for the EU are so vital to get right for our sector. As a country with a strong manufacturing footprint and understanding of the value of innovative medicines, we strongly hope Ireland’s presidency will support our industry and realise the value of cooperation across the EU. To this effect, we hope the Irish Presidency will advocate for and deliver a high-level declaration of support by the European Council for Europe’s research-based pharmaceutical sector, reaffirming our sector’s strategic importance to the EU and a commitment to invest in the sector’s future, for the greater benefit of European patients. Currently, access to innovative medicines for EU citizens is not equal. Greater support for actions that reduce time-to-treatment gaps is needed. The fact that there is not uniform adherence to the implementation of the Transparency Directive and 180-day decision requirement is a significant obstacle to equal access to innovative medicines. Obstacles such as this are why we would like to see the Irish Presidency also work towards the creation of a European Pharmaceutical Taskforce, composed of the European Commission, Member States, and industry partners. It is only by having a forum such as this, involving all necessary stakeholders, that we believe the EU will be able to tackle the challenge of boosting competitiveness for our sector, protect the strategic resilience for the future and ultimately deliver better health outcomes for European citizens.

geography: National, EU and global – we provide pharmaceutical and non-prescription health products, throughout the country, but are an EU headquartered company (Germany) with a large global footprint. This also includes our significant crop science division, as one of the largest seed producers in the world, alongside our portfolio of vital crop protection products.
response_text: Following on from our response to Question 3, we believe Ireland’s communications regarding the value and benefits of EU membership should focus on understanding the tangible benefits and real outcomes to individual citizens from the European Union’s cooperation across Member States. Much of Ireland’s presidency work will inevitably be of a technical nature, including work involving our own sectors. We would therefore strongly encourage the Irish Presidency to work with IPHA and EFPIA, as our pharmaceutical representative associations, on an event that places the sector at the heart of discussions around strategic resilience for the EU, in tandem with the public declaration of support mentioned previously. The pharmaceutical sector necessitates strong cooperation across the EU to maximise the potential of innovative medicines for patients – including the single approval system of the European Medicines Agency, the increasing efficiency of joint Health Technology Assessments, supply-chain impact of the Single Market, and the research benefits of scientific collaboration across the EU. But there is a lot more that needs to be done to truly realise the potential of the EU for European patients and we would therefore welcome greater patient involvement and understanding. The event proposed by IPHA is one such opportunity. We also support the suggestion of regional engagement during Ireland’s presidency, including high-profile site visits to pharmaceutical and life-science facilities in Ireland and across EU Member States. As an industry, we are working to raise awareness of individual patient stories, to both raise awareness, but also to provide some positivity and understanding across the many therapeutic areas. We would welcome the Irish Presidency taking a similar approach, to highlight the impact EU-level policy decision have in citizens’ everyday lives, as well as supporting European businesses, employment and scientific research. Any communication initiatives that demonstrate the interconnectedness of the European health infrastructure would be very welcome.

geography: National, EU and global – we provide pharmaceutical and non-prescription health products, throughout the country, but are an EU headquartered company (Germany) with a large global footprint. This also includes our significant crop science division, as one of the largest seed producers in the world, alongside our portfolio of vital crop protection products.
response_text: We would like to highlight that Bayer’s global President of Pharmaceuticals, Stefan Oelrich, holds the 2-year rotating presidency of EFPIA, our European industry association. Stefan and Bayer are looking forward to working with the Irish Government in their work to support the innovative pharmaceutical industry in Europe. Stefan will be speaking at IPHA’s annual conference on 4th March, specifically addressing Ireland’s EU Presidency and the competitiveness and strategic resilience imperatives for the industry in Europe, and hope to use the opportunity for high-level bilateral engagement with Irish ministers and officials ahead of Ireland’s presidency. Stefan and his team both at Bayer and EFPIA will be very happy to make themselves available for further engagement ahead of and during Ireland’s presidency, to address and work together to tackle the many issues affecting our industry and European patients.

sector: Gender Equality – Working across issues including Climate Justice, Health, Violence Against Women, Care, Leadership, and Economic Equality in an all-island context
geography: All-island perspective, including ROI and NI
response_text: A central theme should be the integration of gender budgeting and intersectional equality lenses across EU governance. This directly supports the Strategic Agenda’s emphasis on “equality”, “democratic resilience”, and “reducing disparities”. Ireland can build continuity with the Cypriot Presidency by embedding gender-responsive budgeting as a core dimension of EU policy, regulation, and investment frameworks. A second priority should be accelerating progress in women’s health, with a focus on endometriosis, reproductive care, and gender-sensitive care. This responds to the Strategic Agenda commitment to “further strengthen health cooperation at European and international level and improve access to medicines across the Union.” Ireland can champion women’s health as both a social imperative and an economic one, reducing productivity loss and enhancing labour-market participation. With Ireland’s investment and success with the Women’s Health Action Plans, this focus would position Ireland as a leader in women’s health policy. Third, Ireland should elevate the care economy as a pillar of Europe’s competitiveness. A public model of high-quality childcare is essential infrastructure for economic growth, gender equality, and meeting demographic challenges. The Presidency can frame childcare investment as a competitiveness priority aligned with the Agenda’s vision for “increased participation in the labour market. Fourthly, Ireland is uniquely placed to highlight all-island cooperation within EU frameworks – showcasing cross-border models of peace, health cooperation, DSGBV response and innovation as aligned with the Agenda’s priorities on cohesion, resilience, neighbourhood stability, and territorial development. Fifth, Ireland’s establishment of Cuan – the national agency with statutory responsibility for DSGBV –positions the State as a leader in coordinated, whole-of-government responses. This experience can inform EU work on governance models that improve citizen safety, participation and equality. Lastly, Ireland should bring a gendered-dimension to the green and digital transitions. As Europe moves along the path of climate neutrality by 2050, we must ensure that women and marginalised communities are central to “a just and fair climate transition.” Together, these priorities position Ireland’s Presidency as one focused on equality-driven competitiveness, strengthened democratic resilience, and delivering visible benefits for citizens.

sector: Gender Equality – Working across issues including Climate Justice, Health, Violence Against Women, Care, Leadership, and Economic Equality in an all-island context
geography: All-island perspective, including ROI and NI
response_text: Ireland should focus its Presidency on advancing policy areas that deliver long-term equality, competitiveness, and societal health and well-being. Central to this is embedding gender budgeting within EU fiscal governance, particularly in the context of the next Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF). Ireland should progress EU-wide methodologies for gender and equality-impact assessments, improved data systems, and expenditure tracking. This directly supports the Strategic Agenda’s commitments to “ensuring that the EU budget is fit for the future.” Ireland should advance the European Care Strategy by positioning childcare as essential economic infrastructure. Priorities should include EU-wide indicators for accessibility and affordability, guidance on sustainable public childcare models, and greater alignment between care policies and economic governance processes such as the European Semester. Ireland should also prioritise women’s participation in democratic life, focusing on gender quotas, combating disinformation, and protections from online harassment targeting women in public roles. This complements the Strategic Agenda’s vision for protecting “democratic discourse” and “free and pluralistic media and civil society.” Finally, Ireland should promote all-island and regional cooperation within cohesion policy, research, health data infrastructure, and DSGBV responses.

sector: Gender Equality – Working across issues including Climate Justice, Health, Violence Against Women, Care, Leadership, and Economic Equality in an all-island context
geography: All-island perspective, including ROI and NI
response_text: Ireland’s Presidency can have substantial EU-wide impact by demonstrating how equality, care, and democratic resilience are essential drivers of economic and social strength. First, embedding gender budgeting and intersectional equality tools across EU institutions will improve resource allocation, increase policy effectiveness, and enhance transparency. Clear equality metrics and budgeting standards will deliver lasting value for citizens, especially women, young people, and marginalised groups. Second, prioritising childcare and the care economy will expand labour-market participation, promote youth and female employment, and enhance competitiveness. By positioning care infrastructure as essential to economic strategy, Ireland can recognise the fundamental role of state-led care infrastructure in our EU economy. This approach benefits businesses by supporting workforce stability and benefits families by improving access to public, affordable, and high-quality care. Third, advancing women’s health, particularly in areas of high unmet need such as endometriosis, will reduce the economic burden of chronic conditions and improve social well-being. Better health outcomes have direct benefits for productivity, job retention, and equality. Lastly, promoting women’s equal participation in political and public life strengthens democracy, broadens representation, and enhances decision-making quality.

sector: Gender Equality – Working across issues including Climate Justice, Health, Violence Against Women, Care, Leadership, and Economic Equality in an all-island context
geography: All-island perspective, including ROI and NI
response_text: Ireland can communicate the values and benefits of EU membership by making the Presidency person-centred, accessible, and grounded in lived experience. A strategic communication approach should highlight tangible, everyday impacts of EU action. Stories illustrating improved childcare access, advances in women’s health, protections against DSGBV, and opportunities for young people can make EU policy visible and relevant. Communication strategies should also embed meaningful ways of reaching marginalised groups, including Traveller and Roma women, migrant women, victims-survivors of DSGBV, disabled women, and LGBTQ+ individuals. Ireland should promote the Presidency as an example of inclusive, participatory democracy. This includes structured engagement with civil society, youth groups, community organisations, and marginalised communities. Citizens’ dialogues, regional forums, and sector-specific consultations can create a sense of involvement and ownership. Digital engagement should be modern, interactive, and accessible. Ireland can leverage creative formats – e.g. short video explainers and social media storytelling – to highlight progress and showcase the collaborative nature of EU decision-making. Ireland is uniquely positioned to highlight all-island cooperation as a story of the EU’s positive and stabilising influence. Showcasing cross-border health initiatives, research collaboration, infrastructure projects, all-island DSGBV initiatives, and peacebuilding partnerships provides a compelling narrative of EU membership as a foundation for stability and shared prosperity. The Presidency should also emphasise that the EU’s core values – including equality and democracy –align strongly with Ireland’s own social commitment. By highlighting Ireland’s leadership on equality, women’s health, democratic participation, and DSGBV, the Presidency can show citizens that Ireland shapes Europe in ways that reflect national priorities and values. This fosters pride, ownership, and a sense of shared purpose in Ireland’s role within the EU.

sector: Gender Equality – Working across issues including Climate Justice, Health, Violence Against Women, Care, Leadership, and Economic Equality in an all-island context
geography: All-island perspective, including ROI and NI
response_text: N/A
SWAN supports the Environmental Pillar’s proposal of ‘Resilience’ as outlined in their submission. Resilience also ties in well with the Commission’s Water Resilience Strategy launched in 2025.

Ireland’s Presidency should prioritise policy areas that secure the health and resilience of Europe’s waters and aquatic ecosystems, which are foundations of public health, biodiversity, and climate adaptation. Ireland is well placed to encourage the effective implementation of existing EU water environment legislation, including the Water Framework Directive (WFD), Marine Strategy Framework Directive (MSFD), Urban Wastewater Treatment Directive, Maritime Spatial Planning Directive (MSPD), the Nature Restoration Regulation (NRR), Habitats Directive and other related instruments. Ireland’s Presidency can help drive a renewed EU effort to translate these policies into tangible, positive conservation outcomes. We propose these actions focussed on relevant policy and legislative areas, and outcomes: Water Environment Drive coherent implementation of the revised Urban Wastewater Treatment Directive, ensuring strong provisions on nutrient removal, stormwater management, and micro-pollutant control. Support mainstreaming of nature-based solutions for water management, flood prevention, and climate adaptation across EU funding and policy instruments. Promote ambitious national implementation of the WFD and uphold the “no deterioration” principle, resisting any moves to weaken its environmental objectives or timelines. Ensure momentum for restoration targets for wetlands, rivers, and marine habitats in the Nature Restoration Law. Support stronger mechanisms for compliance with environmental legislation across Member States. Reinforce the principles of the Aarhus Convention, improving transparency, access to justice, and public engagement in environmental decision-making. Marine Protected Areas The delivery of the EU-wide commitment to establish a coherent network of Marine Protected Areas (MPAs) across 30% of European waters by 2030. Although this target has already been agreed, many Member States, including Ireland, are falling behind. Ireland’s upcoming national MPA legislation, currently being drafted to meet these obligations, provides a timely opportunity to align national ambition with EU-level leadership during the Presidency. Simplification must not mean deregulation The Commission is currently on a drive to “simplify” EU regulation, including very recently adopted measures that form part of the European Green Deal. While seeking to ensure regulation achieves its objectives efficiently is theoretically uncontroversial, in practice the process so far has been accompanied by a strong deregulation push that clearly risks undermining standards and outcomes for EU citizens and the environment. Some companies, industry alliances and their well-paid lobbyists (especially fossil fuel companies, big tech and chemical companies) are using this political pivot from the Commission to seek wholescale deregulation (in a “shock doctrine” style manipulation of current geopolitical and geo-economic turbulence), However, many experts, institutions and agencies, including the ECB for example, are warning that this not in fact good for business as a whole, who benefit from regulatory certainty, and is essentially punishing those businesses that have invested in transition, is rewarding laggards and undermines the EU’s transition to long-term sustainability and prosperity. One example for water is the alarming review and weakening of the Water Framework Directive. Freshwater ecosystems are already in critical condition, and further damage will worsen health risks while reducing their ability to shield us from climate disasters. The Irish Presidency has a duty and an opportunity to uphold the future-oriented standard setting that has epitomized EU innovation and protects citizens, our environment and our common future. The new Multilateral Financial Framework must ensure adequate and dedicated funding for: nature restoration, to deliver the Nature Restoration Law in partnership with farmers, communities and environmentalists economically, socially and environmentally sustainable agriculture, including “fully funded Pillar Two of CAP, including LEADER” as Minister Byrne put it to us recently. civil society and active citizenship, including continuing LIFE funding

Getting Our House in Order: Strengthening Ireland’s Water and Marine Leadership Before the 2026 EU Council Presidency The Government has an important opportunity and responsibility to demonstrate environmental leadership. Water quality, marine health, and the sustainable management of our aquatic ecosystems sit at the intersection of climate, biodiversity, energy, and food policies, areas that will be central to European debate during the Presidency. To speak credibly on these priorities at EU level, Ireland must first ensure it is meeting its own obligations under key directives and strategies. Ireland’s record on water quality remains a persistent concern. The most recent EPA Water Quality in Ireland report shows that nearly half of monitored rivers and lakes are in less-than-good ecological status and the number of these is growing, while nitrate and phosphate pollution pressures are rising in many catchments. As a Presidency, Ireland will be expected to coordinate and advance negotiations on various water environment related files. However, ongoing EU infringement proceedings against Ireland under the WFD, the Habitats Directive, Drinking Water Directive and the Urban Waste Water Treatment Directive risk undermining our credibility in convening discussions on Europe’s water future. Before taking the helm, the Government should take demonstrable steps to show progress in tackling agricultural pollution, upgrading wastewater infrastructure, and preventing physical damage to our waters. The recent ruling by the ECJ that Ireland is in breach of its obligations under the EU Water Framework Directive (WFD) is a case in point. Two significant steps Ireland could take in addressing this breach are: The exemption threshold for abstraction is way too high and should be dropped to at least 10m3 Review the Arterial Drainage Act as promised in the Water Action Plan so as to reduce the physical damage to our waterways in Ireland, such as dredging, draining and damage to habitats. Furthermore, Ireland must transition farmers off the nitrate’s derogation over the next three years. The science shows that Ireland’s water quality is declining and there are no evidence-based measures in Ireland’s Nitrates Action Programme that will improve water quality in three years to ensure Ireland gets the derogation again. This is unfair to farmers who will be once again brought to a cliff-edge economically. Ireland cannot hold credibility if it continues to plan to seek derogation while its lakes and rivers are dying, such as Lady’s Island’s lake, whose green polluted waters can be seen from space. Ireland’s marine environment also requires urgent attention. The Marine Strategy Framework Directive (MSFD) commits member states to achieving “Good Environmental Status” in their marine waters, yet Ireland’s most recent marine assessment highlights serious gaps in data, monitoring, and implementation. Pressures, such as aquaculture, pollution and overfishing, continue to compound challenges for marine biodiversity. The designation and effective management of Marine Protected Areas, targeted to cover 30% of Ireland’s maritime area by 2030, must be accelerated. Delivering this commitment is essential both to meeting EU Biodiversity Strategy targets and to positioning Ireland as a credible advocate for marine ambition during its Presidency. Setting a high bar domestically would not only bolster Ireland’s standing in Brussels but also deliver tangible benefits to rural communities, coastal economies, and ecosystems at home. Action on freshwater and marine protection should be framed not merely as regulatory compliance but as a central investment in Ireland’s environmental resilience, public health, and sustainable economic future. Ireland can only lead on Europe’s environmental agenda if it first restores ambition and credibility at home.

Ireland’s core focus during the presidency should be values driven and reflect its long-standing foreignpolicy strengths and commitment to respond to today’s most urgent global challenges. The Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) should underpin all ‘three priority themes’. With the 2030 deadline approaching, Ireland should use its Presidency to re-energise EUMS/EU efforts to deliver on the SDGs, particularly for those furthest behind: promoting policy coherence for development across all Council formations, supporting equitable and sustainable partnerships, and advocating for scaled-up development and climate finance. One of the priority three themes should focus on the EU’s external action, by aiming to reinforce principled humanitarian and development policies, and demonstrate leadership grounded in solidarity and human rights. Under this thematic priority, Ireland should focus on five specific inter-related issues: Promote robust EU policy and financing for fragile and conflict-affected contexts. As negotiations on the next Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) advance, Ireland should ensure that sufficient political attention is dedicated to the humanitarian aid, resilience and human development components of the proposed Global Europe Instrument. Support the re-prioritisation of food security and nutrition as foundational pillars for sustainable growth and prosperity. Ireland’s sustained leadership at global forums, including Nutrition for Growth (N4G) and the UN Food Systems Summits, positions it well to drive ambitious EU engagement on ending hunger and malnutrition. As the EU moves to implement its own N4G commitments, Ireland can encourage clearer targets, longer-term investment, and stronger accountability. Using its convening power, Ireland can promote support for resilient and inclusive nutrition sensitive food systems and ensure that EU policies prioritise vulnerable and crisis-affected communities. Champion access to quality education in emergencies, especially for girls, as a core element of Ireland’s development policy and Presidency priorities. Advocate for full implementation of DG ECHO’s commitment to allocate at least 10% of EU humanitarian aid to Education in Emergencies through 2027 and into the next MFF and Global Europe negotiations, including ensuring clear implementation pathways, robust accountability and coherence across EU funding instruments. Ireland’s Programme for Government commitment to Afghanistan’s women and girls should translate into specific actions to highlight and identify initiatives at EU level that will improve their lives. Advocate for a clear EU position that climate finance must not deepen debt burdens and ensure that grant-based support becomes central to the EU’s contribution to the New Collective Quantified Goal. As Council President, Ireland will lead the EU delegation at COP and can ensure EU discussions give due consideration for prioritising grants over loans, emphasising the importance of fairness, debt sustainability, and accessibility for least developed countries (LDCs) and small island developing states (SIDS). Elevate Sudan as a core Presidency cross-cutting priority and leverage any diplomatic influence to address what is now the world’s largest humanitarian crisis. Ireland should use its diplomatic influence to elevate Sudan on the Council agenda, press for a cessation of hostilities and a negotiated political solution, and mobilise stronger EU action. This must include championing a coherent regional approach to provide adequate humanitarian assistance to civilians in neighbouring countries, supporting coordinated cross-border assistance, reinforcing protection for refugees. Given Ireland’s appreciation of the importance of and leadership on conflict-induced hunger, Ireland has a credible role to play in highlighting the links between conflict and hunger, including the EU’s role in condemning the use of starvation as a weapon of war.

In connection with the above five proposed issues there are specific policy areas and supporting processes that Ireland should focus on, these are as follows: Considering the 2026 Communication on humanitarian aid which is likely to be published under the Cypriot Presidency of the Council, Ireland can work to ensure well-informed Council Conclusions, which will be considered by the Commission for the implementation of the Communication on humanitarian aid. Throughout 2026, Ireland should influence the COHAFA agenda, to ensure sufficient time is allocated for discussion and briefings from civil society organisations who engaged in the consultation processes for the 2026 Communication on humanitarian aid – particularly on the issues highlighted in Q1. Evidence and perspectives from those most deeply affected by crises and those trying to address the impacts of crises, strengthen decision-making and understanding and is irreplaceable. The High Representative of the European Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy & Vice-President of the European Commission was tasked in her mission letter to lead on developing a renewed EU approach to the Sahel, and progress has been made, including the validation of the principles of a renewed approach at the November 2025 Foreign Affairs Council. While the renewed EU approach to the Sahel is likely to be finalised before Ireland takes up the presidency, the challenges in terms of EU engagement in the Sahel will continue into Ireland’s presidency, and Ireland should include Sahel in the COAFR agenda and allow sufficient time for discussions to focus on how the EU can continue to support human development and humanitarian diplomacy in this fragile region. The EU recent N4G pledge signified there is continued financial and political commitment, however existing EU frameworks, such as the Action Plan on Nutrition (2015–2025) and the Guidelines on Addressing Undernutrition in Emergencies, are now outdated and poorly aligned with newer EU priorities. Ireland can play a pivotal role by inviting the Commission to update the EU Nutrition Policy Framework, which is urgently needed, particularly in light of the recent ODA cuts. For this, Ireland can leverage a recent European Court of Auditor’s special report on the Commission’s support to fight hunger in Sub-Saharan Africa which notes that the shift in focus from addressing malnutrition to supporting value chains risks sidelining chronic nutrition crises, and as such nutrition is losing prominence on the EU agenda. This trend is reinforced by the Global Gateway initiative, which prioritises other sectors and does not directly address food insecurity or malnutrition. Ireland should use its presidency to put nutrition high on the EU’s political agenda. Integrating nutrition across relevant Council agendas would help reverse declining global attention and reaffirm nutrition as a foundation for sustainable development and stability. Ireland should place Sudan at the heart of the Foreign Affairs Council agenda and leverage its political leadership – including by convening a high-level Ministerial Roundtable on Sudan - to help mobilize the attention, action and resources required to address one of the world’s most severe and underfunded humanitarian emergencies. Fragile and neglected contexts like Afghanistan should also be considered. Ireland should use the presidency to challenge EUMS and UNMS on the scourge, normalisation and political apathy related to conflict-induced hunger. Ireland can play a pivotal role in mobilizing collective EU action against conflict-induced food insecurity, advocating for the EU to continue to condemn the use of starvation as a weapon of war—in line with UN Security Council Resolution 2417 - and to prioritize immediate, coordinated responses to address the devastating levels of conflictdriven hunger Ireland’s focus on and engagement in the development of Gender Action Plan IV will be essential, as a progressive country which promotes and protects all forms of equality. Regardless of challenges, GAP IV should not only sustain but strengthen the momentum built under GAP III. GAP IV presents a crucial opportunity for the EU to reaffirm and strengthen its commitment to gender equality as a core value and strategic priority in its external action. To do so, it should focus even more on implementation, deepen partnerships with organisations working to promote and sustain gender equality, develop mechanisms to correctly track investments in gender to ensure an accurate analysis of meaningful financial and political support, and allocate adequate resources and capacity to deliver and implement GAP IV.

In an increasingly fragmented EU, Ireland’s Presidency offers an opportunity to turn principles in action - not only through policy but through storytelling and communities coming together in ways that inspire unity and empathy. Using Ireland’s arts and cultural heritage, the presidency should spotlight how solidarity, human rights, and peace shaped Ireland’s transformation - a much-needed story right now. This narrative reinforces the importance of education as an investment throughout life - not just formal schooling but lifelong learning and global citizenship education that equips people to participate fully in society, foster social cohesion and adapt to a changing economy. It also highlights the role of the arts in telling stories of perseverance and the need to keep communities at the heart of progress. Irelands place in the world is informed by and influenced by Irish people who support the development agenda, the reputation of Ireland on the global stage. Emphasizing the value of Ireland’s global standing, and the important role the commitment to ODA play in that is important. Ireland has benefited significantly from investment, evident in the prosperity and development in the country, and there is a strong willingness to use our solidarity, empathy and wealth to continue to promote the SDGs, the importance of humanitarian aid, and the values of equality at a global level. The EU DEAR programme is an important element of bringing communities together, to share the vision of the EU and educate and inform citizens about the value of the EU being values driven and working collectively to improve the lives of EU citizens, in a safer, more equal and prosperous world. The prosperity of people, businesses and communities across the EU is dependent on global stability – Ireland’s own journey from poverty and conflict to peace and growth is proof of this. During its Presidency, Ireland can help the Council ensure discussions reflect the values Strategic Agenda for the Union for 202429: “… continuing to be the strongest supporter of the international legal order, steadfastly upholding the United Nations and the principles enshrined in the UN Charter. In particular, the European Union will pursue efforts to promote global peace, justice and stability, as well as democracy, universal human rights and the achievement of the Sustainable Development Goals in all international fora. We will strive for a reformed multilateral system, making it more inclusive and more effective”. At this moment of instability and division, the EU needs this vision more than ever, to protect its values, strengthen its economy, and ensure that every community feels connected to Europe’s future.

To foster genuine sense of ownership amongst all citizens, communication must go beyond slogans and social media campaigns. The communications strategy should be rooted in Global Citizenship Education (GCE) as a guiding approach – helping people understand how EU membership connects to their daily lives and communities. This strategy should consider the following: Prioritise meaningful engagement over digital noise. While social media has a role, over-reliance on digital messaging will not create impact or ownership. People need space to meet, discuss, and question – community forums and partnerships with local organisations should be central. Elected representatives and civil servants must be well-briefed on the approach and equipped to communicate why Ireland as an EU MS matters, why multilateralism matters and how Ireland’s Presidency is of importance to all. Ownership only comes when people feel included. Bringing citizens together through schools, cultural/arts events and local dialogues, will reinforce that the EU is not a distant political concept, but a part of their everyday lives. National and local media should be engaged to tell stories that resonate to their audiences in a way that enables them to develop informed opinions about the influence EU decisions have on their lives and the lives of others around the globe. Taking inspiration from Ireland’s recent Presidential election, for the EU presidency, the government and the Department of Foreign Affairs should invest in a strong, positive and comprehensive communications strategy that prioritizes authentic, empathic, face-to-face engagement with people in Ireland. This strategy should have a clear objective to foster connections and community across the globe, and build support, understanding and appreciation of what it means to be a proud EU and Irish citizen.

organisation: UN Special Rapporteur on human rights defenders
respondent_type: Individual human rights expert appointed by the UN Human Rights Council
response_text: The international framework to protect, promote and uphold human rights is under strain. The UN charter has been routinely undermined in recent years while attacks on the International Criminal Court damage a key accountability pillar in the international system. The trend of democratic backsliding over the past decade has narrowed the space in which human rights defenders have to work while the risks they face remain severe. According to the UN High Commissioner on Human Rights, at least 625 human rights defenders and media workers were killed or disappeared in 2024, the highest number ever recorded. Simultaneously, human rights defenders around the world have become increasingly vocal in questioning the adherence of traditionally supportive states to the values contained in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. Against this backdrop and in keeping with the European Council’s Strategic Agenda 2024-2029, which includes as a priority “upholding the UN Charter” and “protecting free and pluralistic media and civil society" within the “Free and Democratic Europe” pillar, the UN Special Rapporteur on human rights defenders believes the Irish Presidency should re-emphasize the EU’s commitment to its foundational principles of democracy, rule of law and respect for human rights. It should make clear the EU’s respect for international human rights law and the institutions designed to deliver it. As highlighted in the Strategic Agenda 2024-2029, values emphasising respect for human rights are “EU’s primary strength, as well as its compass both within the EU and globally”. Within this broader policy area, the Special Rapporteur encourages a specific focus on human rights defenders who hold EU citizenship and who have been imprisoned for, or sentenced to terms of, ten years or more outside of EU borders. These individuals serving lengthy prison sentences as a result of promoting values championed by the EU serve as both a stark reminder of the impunity which exist for human rights violations globally and the inability of the EU thus far to have secured their release. Focsusing on their cases during the Irish Presidency would send a powerful signal that the EU, at least under the Irish Presidency, follows through on the principles it promotes and does not abandon its own citizens who are imprisoned for peaceful human rights activism. In my capacity as UN Special Rapporteur on human rights defenders, I am aware of three such cases: Abdulhadi Alkhawaja, joint Danish - Bahraini citizenship, serving life imprisonment for his peaceful activities in the 2011 pro-democracy protests; Dawit Isaak, joint Swedish - Eritrean citizenship, imprisoned since 2001 for his reporting and writing on calls for democracy; Abdoul Aziz Goma, joint Irish - Togolese citizenship, serving 10 years in prison for his provision of shelter to a group of young protesters calling for political reform.

organisation: UN Special Rapporteur on human rights defenders
respondent_type: Individual human rights expert appointed by the UN Human Rights Council
response_text: The issue and cases above could be platformed through a variety of means during the six months of the Irish Presidency, including by: Pressing for the inclusion of the cases on the agendas of PSC, COHOM and the Council regional groups (COMOG/COAFR) and other relevant Council groups, ensuring time is dedicated to discussing these cases and a roadmap for collective EU action is devised at the beginning of Ireland’s term; Encouraging the High Representative and EU Special Representatives (where relevant) to prioritise these cases in bilateral meetings and demarches, using the Council presidency to keep them on the agenda and to request regular reporting back to Council; Encouraging systematic raising of these cases in EU positions at the UN (GA, HRC, treaty bodies) and regional organisations; Pressing the EU Foreign Affairs Council to table dedicated debates, inviting affected member states to brief colleagues and seek agreement on strong Council conclusions condemning arbitrary detention of human rights defenders and calling for releases in general term

Proposed Theme: "Securing Europe’s Sustainable Energy and Competitiveness". Security of Europe's energy supply Ireland should ensure it has operationalised the Hydrogen & Decarbonised Gas Market Package on time transposing Directive (EU) 2024/1788 by mid‑2026. As Council Presidency in H2 2026, use its agenda‑setting role to accelerate EU‑level practicalities (ENNOH, integrated hydrogen, gas, electricity planning, and timely secondary measures), moving the framework from paper to practice. Scaling up sustainability of data centres and Large Energy Users EU data‑centre electricity use is rising towards ~115 TWh by 2030, with grid connection lead times and local adequacy emerging as key constraints. Ireland should broker a common framework that: Sets minimum efficiency metrics (e.g., PUE/SPUE) and requires participation in flexibility markets (demand response, behind‑the‑meter storage/RES, ancillary services). Enables non‑firm/phased connections and strategic siting near renewable and hydrogen infrastructure, and reuses waste heat into district networks where viable. Recognises hydrogen technologies (fuel cells/turbines) for low‑emission back‑up and peak support where necessary, ensuring digital growth strengthens energy security and climate goals. Agreement the EU's long-term budget To convert targets into projects, the Presidency should prioritise agreement on the Multiannual Financial Framework and related instruments that channel funding to grids, flexibility, hydrogen infrastructure and projects (including IPCEIs and the Hydrogen Bank), while simplifying permitting and access to capital. This aligns with the Commission’s 2026 work programme which foresees an Energy Security Package and Electrification Strategy and with the inter‑institutional priority to build a genuine Energy Union before 2030. A budget settlement that couples simplification with targeted investment will lower system costs for citizens and businesses, enhance competitiveness and accelerate security‑enhancing clean fuels across the Union.

1. RFNBO certainty with pragmatic compliance. To unblock investment in renewable hydrogen and e‑fuels. Presidency asks: Ireland proposes that the Commission, as part of the Energy Security Package and in parallel with the European Hydrogen Bank, table a targeted amendment to Delegated Regulation (EU) 2023/1184 and supporting guidance. Europe must accelerate investments in energy infrastructure and for that it needs to create the right conditions through simplification of the highly complex regulatory environment for companies, especially the energy-intensive industry. Also, as rightly pointed out by the Draghi report, access to affordable energy and feedstock, including renewable and low carbon hydrogen, is essential to ensure European industry remains competitive. For example, the temporal correlation is hindering projects: strict requirements, like hourly temporal correlation, raise the cost of renewable hydrogen by 25% to 35% (this can easily represent 1.5-2eur/kg of hydrogen). The additionality principle makes electricity more expensive and, in most cases, unavailable in the short term; especially in times when other electricity-hungry players like datacenters are quickly developing across Europe. The geographical correlation restricts the pool of renewable energy assets hydrogen producers can rely on when producing RFNBO-compliant energy. That is why we would like to recommend a targeted revision of the RFNBOs Delegated Acts, focusing on feasible and more flexible implementation. One way of adopting the rules without having to engage in a lengthy process could be by extending the transitional period both for additionality and temporal correlation.

Energy affordability, stability and security Cut bills through flexibility‑first delivery Ireland can steer Council conclusions that require Member States to quantify flexibility needs and rapidly deploy demand‑side response, storage (including h2 storage) and sector‑coupling within the electricity‑market‑design framework. Flexibility lowers peak prices, reduces redispatch/curtailment and improves reliability, directly benefiting households and SMEs; ENTSO‑E projects pan‑EU flexibility needs will roughly double by 2030, underlining the urgency Turn hydrogen rules into investable projects The Council should move from legislation to implementation of the Hydrogen & Decarbonised Gas Market Package, integrating hydrogen into Ten‑Year Network Development Plans and enabling cost‑effective repurposing of suitable gas assets. That creates predictable network access and market rules, stabilising investor expectations and enabling long‑term contracts for industry. Scale renewable hydrogen supply and offtake Under Ireland’s chairing, the Council can back the European Hydrogen Bank auctions (including “Auctions‑as‑a‑Service”) to bring RFNBO projects to final investment decision with 10‑year fixed terms and invite the Commission to align auction timetables with infrastructure/industrial demand hubs. This accelerates clean‑fuel availability for hard‑to‑electrify sectors (such as the HGV fleet across Europe) and diversifies energy sources away from volatile fossil imports. Provide RFNBO certainty and lower delivery risk To ensure molecules are genuinely renewable yet financeable, the Council can request targeted guidance and an amending Delegated Act under (EU) 2023/1184 that preserves integrity while streamlining compliance (e.g., pragmatic temporal/geographic correlation where electrolysers deliver system benefits). This reduces transaction costs, supports long‑term PPAs and speeds project delivery. Make digital growth strengthen, not strain, energy systems Council conclusions on sustainable, flexible data centres minimum efficiency metrics (PUE/SPUE), participation in flexibility markets, non‑firm/phased connections, strategic siting and waste‑heat recovery and ensure AI‑driven demand does not undermine security or affordability, and can even provide local flexibility where hydrogen or storage can be co‑located. Finance delivery at scale A political agreement on the Multiannual Financial Framework linked to the Commission’s 2026 Energy Security Package should prioritise grids, storage, hydrogen infrastructure/IPCEIs and the Hydrogen Bank, with simplified access and permitting. This lowers the cost of capital, speeds projects and anchors the Energy Union’s credibility.

From 1975 to 2026: continuing the journey: Ireland’s first Presidency in 1975 helped to define the role of the European Council which met formally for the first time in Dublin (10–11 March 1975) and coincided with milestones such as the launch of the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF), a vehicle that has since financed tangible local improvements across the Union. We should explicitly link the 2026 Presidency to that founding moment we worked to develop the EU in 1975; let’s continue the journey together in 2026. Interactive "Action" Events: Instead of abstract policy meetings, the Presidency should host a major "Accelerating Permitting" conference involving civil society to discuss how renewable projects deliver local benefits. o Hydrogen Ireland will be organising key hydrogen events in Dublin in the 2nd half of 2026 and would be keen to include Government Department representation. We will also continue our engagement at a EU level with the Clean Hydrogen Partnership and Hydrogen Europe. In 2026 we will also join the EU Hydrogen Council. Local Benefits Focus: Communication should highlight how EU directives support Community Benefit Funds and how renewable projects contribute local rates to County Councils, directly funding community services. Showcasing Irish Success: Showcasing Irish success (innovation + culture): Use the Presidency to host “Energy Innovation Days” to showcase Irish projects, SMEs, researchers and communities delivering the transition (including hydrogen where relevant). To reach audiences who don’t engage with policy, pair the technical programme with focused cultural engagement, such as an energy-themed art competition or exhibition (visual art, photography, short film) that illustrates Ireland’s energy story and the EU’s contribution to the transition through accessible images and narratives. This broadens participation, increases public visibility, and supports genuine citizen ownership. Ireland’s Presidency works across the island of Ireland reflecting the all island nature of the energy networks: Ireland should showcase the success of relationships with third countries such as GB/NI through successes in The Shared Island Fund. Emissions and energy challenge is cross border issue. Benefit for Ireland: Increased public engagement fosters "social licence" for essential infrastructure. By clearly linking EU policy to local economic wins (jobs, community funds), we can reduce local opposition to the grid and renewable projects required for Ireland’s future.

Ireland’s Presidency of the Council of the European Union in 2026 presents a unique opportunity to demonstrate leadership in the emerging clean energy economy, particularly in areas where Ireland has a natural comparative advantage. Hydrogen Ireland would suggest three additional proposals for consideration, aligned with EU strategic priorities on climate neutrality, energy security, data security, industrial competitiveness, and regional cohesion. High Level Hydrogen Summit: ‘From Green Electrons to Green Molecules – Europe’s Island Advantage’ Ireland could host a High Level Hydrogen Summit during the Presidency transition period, convening EU energy ministers, senior Commission representatives, industry leaders, research institutions, and island and peripheral region stakeholders. The purpose of the summit would be to position Ireland as a convenor of European dialogue on the role of clean hydrogen in enabling resilient, decentralised, and integrated energy systems. The theme. ‘From Green Electrons to Green Molecules – Europe’s Island Advantage,’ reflects the strategic opportunity for Ireland and other island or peripheral regions to lead in renewable hydrogen production, system coupling, and innovation in maritime, aviation, and heavy transport decarbonisation. The summit would also highlight Ireland’s offshore renewable energy potential, its emerging hydrogen valleys, and the role of cross border cooperation with partners such as Cyprus, the North Sea region, and the Atlantic seaboard. This event would serve as a blueprint for how Europe can leverage geographically diverse renewable resources to strengthen energy security, accelerate industrial transformation, and support the EU’s wider climate and competitiveness agenda. Council Conclusion on Hydrogen for Strategic Autonomy Ireland could propose a Council Conclusion on Hydrogen for Strategic Autonomy, developed in partnership with other geographically peripheral and island EU Member States, including Cyprus. Such a conclusion would recognise the essential role of renewable hydrogen in achieving the EU’s objectives for energy resilience, transport decarbonisation, and industrial competitiveness. The proposal would emphasise: The importance of hydrogen in balancing variable offshore renewable energy and enabling system flexibility. The need for targeted support for island and peripheral regions with high renewable potential but limited interconnection capacity. The role of hydrogen in decarbonising hard to electrify sectors such as maritime transport, aviation, heavy industry, and long distance mobility. Opportunities for Europe to lead globally in hydrogen innovation, standards, and certification. The value of coordinated EU action to accelerate infrastructure development, skills, and investment certainty. A Council Conclusion of this nature would reinforce Ireland’s leadership in shaping Europe’s clean energy future while ensuring that the specific needs and opportunities of island regions are fully reflected in EU policy frameworks. 3. EU Framework for Sustainable, Grid Integrated Data Centres Ireland could propose an EU level initiative to develop a coherent framework for sustainable, grid integrated data centres that supports Europe’s digital sovereignty while ensuring energy/system resilience. As a country with one of the highest concentrations of data centres in Europe, Ireland has deep practical experience in managing the intersection of digital infrastructure, grid capacity, renewable integration, and community impact. This proposal would encourage the EU to adopt a systems based approach to data centre development, focusing on: • Grid aware planning that aligns new data centre capacity with renewable generation zones, offshore wind development, and future hydrogen enabled flexibility. Demand side flexibility through on site electrolysers, thermal storage, and smart load management to reduce peak demand and support system balancing. Circular water and heat systems, including advanced water reuse technologies and district heating integration, to reduce environmental impact and support local communities. Hydrogen ready backup and resilience systems to replace diesel generation and accelerate the transition to zero carbon digital infrastructure. EU wide standards for energy efficiency, water stewardship, and carbon transparency to ensure competitiveness and consistency across Member States. A Presidency led initiative in this area would position Ireland as a thought leader in the future of sustainable digital infrastructure, while supporting the EU’s broader goals on climate neutrality, strategic autonomy, and digital leadership.

As a significant employer in Ireland and as a global leader in enterprise cloud applications for finance and human resources, Workday proposes that Ireland’s 2026 EU Presidency focuses on pragmatic implementation rather than new regulation. We believe Ireland is uniquely positioned to bridge the gap between high-level EU ambition and on-the-ground operational reality. We suggest three thematic priorities: Accelerating Technology Adoption for Economic Growth. With many new digital laws adopted, the Irish Presidency must ensure EU Member States focus on delivering technology adoption to build growth. Europe currently trails global competitors in converting technological capacity and innovation into economic gain. Ireland should lead an agenda that incentivizes the practical uptake of digital tools, including AI and cloud, across the public sector, SMEs and large enterprises. By positioning the EU not just as a regulator, but as a super-adopter, Ireland can demonstrate how responsible deployment drives the growth required to sustain the European model. The "Skills-First" Labour Market. Europe faces a dual challenge: a shrinking working-age population and a rapid evolution in job requirements, underpinned by the AI revolution. Ireland should champion a shift from traditional degree-based credentials to a flexible "Skills-First" economy. The Presidency should prioritise policies that support skills-based hiring and mobility, ensuring the workforce is agile enough to prosper alongside digital and AI transformation. This approach aligns with Ireland’s status as a global talent hub and transforms technological disruption into a catalyst for growth. Delivering the Single Market and Keeping Markets Open. The focus of the Irish Presidency - and EU as a whole - must shift from legislative creation to the seamless implementation and operation of a true Single Market. The Presidency should champion policies which enable businesses to easily scale and grow across the EU - such as a meaningful 28th Regime - and adopt an open, risk- and evidence-based approach to digital sovereignty, which reinforces open markets and facilitates access to trusted best-in-class technology. European enterprises need confidence that they can leverage the most advanced global technology innovations securely - including cloud and AI, without facing fragmentation or protectionist barriers that stifle competitiveness.

The Irish Presidency should secure Council positions and conclude trilogues on digital regulations proposed in late 2025 or expected in H1 2026. The Presidency must steer EU Member States towards regulations which drive real simplification, foster competition and maintain openness to trusted global partners. These include: Digital Omnibus and AI Omnibus The Irish Presidency must urgently work to adopt the Digital Omnibus and AI Omnibus proposals, if not finalized during the Cypriot Presidency, to deliver immediate relief to businesses in Europe. The Council must be ambitious to reduce administrative burden by removing overlapping and contradictory compliance obligations and ensure a risk-based approach to policymaking that prioritises tangible impact over box-ticking. A successful outcome in the Council would be a harmonized rulebook that delivers legal certainty, lowers the cost of compliance and accelerates the adoption of AI technologies by European businesses, thereby driving competitiveness rather than layering on red tape. Cybersecurity Act (Review) In reviewing the Cybersecurity Act, the Presidency must focus on strengthening Europe’s cyber resilience without fragmenting the Single Market or excluding global leaders.
