A central priority should be delivering a coordinated European approach to housing, based on the commitment by all 27 Member States to work towards ending homelessness by 2030 as part of the Lisbon Declaration, and aligned with the forthcoming European Affordable Housing and anti-poverty plans. This starts with the recognition that housing is first and foremost a home and a basic human right, not a financial asset. This has also expressed by our colleagues in the *Irish Homeless Policy Group (IHPG*), of which we are members. *The IHPG is a coalition of organisations working on the frontline of Ireland’s housing and homelessness crisis. Members include groups that provide direct housing support, advocacy, policy research, and legal interventions for those experiencing or at risk of homelessness, committed to ending homelessness. Effective implementation of the new EU Anti-Poverty Strategy currently being developed, should also be a key priority. Guaranteeing access to essential services like housing, healthcare, and education, to all, particularly the most marginalised, including ethnic minorities and addressing the intersectional dimensions of poverty, those related to gender, age, disability, and discrimination is crucial. This should be done from a community development approach, in conjunction with those with lived and diverse experiences of poverty and social exclusion.

sector: Service provision: homelessness, domestic abuse services and senior services
geography: Local (Galway) with reference to relevant national and regional (EU) structures, law and policy impacting upon our service delivery.
response_text: The Irish Presidency presents a clear opportunity to prioritise joint EU action on housing and homelessness. COPE Galway supports and would like to reiterate the Simon Communities of Ireland’s call for the Irish Presidency to table a draft Council Recommendation on ending homelessness, for adoption under the Presidency in 2026. We agree that there is clear institutional momentum in the EU and an appetite for a Council Recommendation on ending homelessness. As per the Sinon Communities of Ireland’s submission, which we fully support: In February 2024, the Belgian Presidency held a Ministerial Conference on the European Platform on Combatting Homelessness (EPOCH). The event was an opportunity to discuss efforts to eradicate homelessness in the EU by 2030, a commitment all 27 EU countries agreed to work towards with the signing of the Lisbon Declaration in 2021. A report from the event noted a growing will among member states for a Council Recommendation on eradicating homelessness, recognising the urgency of coordinated EU-level action and the value of the Housing First. In March 2025, the European Parliament welcomed intentions for a Council Recommendation on homelessness as part of a resolution on the European Semester for Economic Policy Coordination: Employment and Social Priorities for 2025 (§16). The Council Conclusions on the future European Affordable Housing Plan, published in November 2025, proposes “stronger cooperation at EU level on homelessness, building on the work of and further strengthening the European Platform on Combating Homelessness and housing-led policies such as the Housing First Principle. The Housing Advisory Board, chaired by Eammon Ryan, recently published its recommendations to the European Commission, which included that the Commission propose, and Council adopt by 2026, a “Recommendation on Homelessness that transforms the Lisbon Declaration into a governance framework at national level and a plan for European-level action to support an monitor progress” (pg. 14). Reiterating Ireland’s commitment to ending homelessness by 2030 in the Delivering Homes, Building Communities housing plan. In addition, the Presidency presents an ideal occasion to make strides towards gender equality, Europe’s unfinished promise. Gender inequality is the cause of all violence against women and ccultural/societal violence, in turn, is a social mechanism that helps keeps women in a subordinate position to men and societal change requires reaching people’s hearts and minds with new understandings of justice and fairness. Ireland should encourage the wider use of gender mainstreaming methods and tools across EU structures and departments such as gender budgeting and gender impact assessments in line with the principles and best practices in our own recently published ‘National Strategy for Women and Girls 2025–2030.’ The EU’s Work-Life Balance Directive (2019/1158), for example, is designed to promote gender equality by legislating the equal sharing of caring responsibilities. This marks a milestone in European policymaking by creating new regulations to promote gender equality. Ireland can further the human right of gender equality during the Presidency by promoting adherence to this Directive, and leading on its implementation, and that of other related EU directives, such as that on pay transparency. Other key actions that should be concentrated on include championing efforts to end gender-based violence and fostering international cooperation to ensure strong gender equality policies across Europe. Ireland should also champion effective response to the scourge of digital violence, effecting women and girls across Europe. November 2025 data from an EU-wide Council of European Municipalities and Regions survey stated that around 32% of women political representatives in Europe report experiencing violence. Nearly one in three of these facing cyberviolence, including threats, harassment and abuse on digital platforms. Ireland has a clear record in support of gender equality initiatives, such as during its tenure on the UN Security Council and its consistent support for the Women, Peace and Security agenda. This should be continued during the Irish EU Presidency.

sector: Service provision: homelessness, domestic abuse services and senior services
geography: Local (Galway) with reference to relevant national and regional (EU) structures, law and policy impacting upon our service delivery.
response_text: We agree with our colleagues in the IHPG and the Simon Communities of Ireland, that prioritising coordinated EU action to end homelessness is not only the morally right thing to do and a reflection of the core European values of dignity, equality, and human rights, but it is also fiscally beneficial for Member States. The cost of providing emergency accommodation, crisis supports, and health services for persons experiencing homelessness is substantial. Investing in prevention and permanent solutions is far more sustainable and cost-effective. Experiencing homelessness can have multiple negative impacts, including adverse effects on physical health, mental health, and overall wellbeing. For children, experiencing homelessness can negatively affect development, cognitive functioning, participation in education, and opportunities later in life. By investing in early intervention, family support, and housing-led responses, these long-term harms, can be prevented and community wellbeing strengthened. This applies equally to older people renting and at risk of homelessness

sector: Service provision: homelessness, domestic abuse services and senior services
geography: Local (Galway) with reference to relevant national and regional (EU) structures, law and policy impacting upon our service delivery.
response_text: Ireland should highlight how EU actions and policies directly impact and support affordable housing, ending and preventing homelessness and should ensure that those with lived experiences of homelessness, poverty and exclusion should be able to meaningfully contribute to discussions and debates around those issues. Inclusion leads to more effective policymaking as the wants and needs of those impacted is taken into consideration. We agree with our colleague in the Irish Homeless Policy Group, that Ireland should adopt an accessible communication strategy, that should be designed and co-created in partnership with Disabled Persons’ Organisations, civil society groups, ethic and other minorities and representative community organisations to ensure they reflect lived realities and meet all accessibility needs. Outreach efforts must be deliberately targeted toward those that have historically been underrepresented in EU-level conversations, ensuring that the benefits of the Presidency are shared widely and that the Presidency itself reflects the diversity of the people it serves.

organisation: School of Languages, Literatures and Cultural Studies, Trinity College Dublin
response_text: Multilingual education should be a high-level thematic priority for the Presidency of the Council in 2026. The establishment of this priority can be directly linked to Ireland’s pioneering role in modern-language education, the celebration of whose founding moment coincides with Ireland’s Presidency of the Council In 1776, Chairs of Modern Languages in French, German, Italian and Spanish were officially established in Trinity College Dublin. These were the first such Chairs in these islands (the first Chair of Romance Languages in Oxford University would not be created until 1909, and the Drapers Professorship of French in Cambridge University was launched in 1919) and in the case of the Chairs of French and German, are the oldest continuous Chairs in these languages in the world. If it was highly unusual for a British university to provide modern language instruction before the middle of the nineteenth century, for Ireland’s university sector it became the general rule. By 1850 all Irish universities officially offered modern languages. The Presidency of the Council presents a unique opportunity to leverage Ireland’s ground-breaking initiatives in modern language education in the Anglophone world to promote multilingual education both internally on the island of Ireland and throughout the European Union. Three main motivating factors justify the adoption of multilingual education as a thematic priority, these are political, social and psychological. Politicially, the Anglophone Order that dominated Western Europe for much of second half of the twentieth century has gradually begun to unravel in the new century. The advent of Brexit, the rise of American populism and the emergence of a multipolar world mean that the future is inescapbly multilingual. When Anglophone spaces become increasingly unstable or unwelcoming, then any informed policy, whether in foreign affairs, trade or research, must look to other language spaces both with a view to forming potential partnerships and with an eye to doing things differently. Learning a modern language fundamentally alters an individual’s regime of attention but one could equally argue that this utopian promise extends to a whole society. Regimes of attention are hopelessly compromised by a failure to engage more fully with foreign languages. The solutions, the perspectives, the insights to contend with major social problems available in other languages are, as a result, often ignored. A healthy pluralism in the public sphere is vitally dependent on expanding the range of policy and societal options that learning foreign languages can offer. Socially, as societies across the European become more multi-ethnic and mulitilingual, the question of social cohesion becomes more pressing. Linguistic foreignness, difference or alterity are no longer elements without or external to European societies but an intrinsic part of them. If respectful communication is central to social cohesion, there can be no long lasting or meaningful form of cohesion if all the forms of communication in European societies are not taken into consideration. Psychologically, learning languages is a public health issue with decisive consequences for individual wellbeing in the context of Europe’s ageing population. Research carried out by the School of Psychology in Trinity College Dublin has conclusively shown that speaking multiple languages can slow the biological processes of aging and protect against age-related decline.

organisation: School of Languages, Literatures and Cultural Studies, Trinity College Dublin
response_text: The European Union has made a substantial commitment to multilingualism in its founding documents and in the provision of translation and interpreting services where speaking a particular national language is not an obstacle to democratic participation in the deliberations of the EU. An embrace of multilingual education as a priority by the Irish Presidency would turn the foundational multilingualism of the EU into an active force for political, economic, and social good in European societies. Actively engaging with Europe’s language diversity would have positive impacts in a number of different areas: Businesses: In a world of growing economic uncertainty, where traditional markets are increasingly subject to the vagaries of ideological choices, a resilient business base requires the capacity to increase access to previously underexplored or underdeveloped markets. These markets are overwhelmingly situated outside the Anglophone world. Any successful or sustainable penetration of markets entails speaking the language of the customer, whether within Europe or beyond. The broader the range of language knowledge, the greater the reach of business opportunity. Poor language skills and lacklustre cultural adaptability are distinct liabilities in a foreign trade dependent economic bloc. If Ireland’s knowledge of English has often acted as a disincentive for learning foreign languages, the problem for many EU member states is that an excessive reliance on English as a second language leaves them equally exposed on the languages front. Emphasis on the importance of foreign languages as a life-skill, as a promoter of cultural awareness, and as a means of enhancing the value of other skills—be they intellectual or vocational—can only have positive outcomes in terms of the diversification of trade outlets and the maximization of economic opportunity. Communities: In an uncertain global context, and in the resurgence of divisive populisms that excessively privilege narrow interests, the acquisition of foreign languages becomes a way to substitute curiosity for condemnation and partnership for paranoia. As Jacques Delors once observed, you cannot fall in love with a market. Creating a sustained sense of shared European identity cannot be based solely on transactional self interest, there must be a feeling of deeper engagement with one’s fellow Europeans. Languages become a privileged form of access to the history, society, and art forms of different European societies and open up a wealth of experiences that give substance and permanence to the civic experiences of Europeanness. Learning modern languages is a critical factor in binding communities together at both national and supra-national level. People: A general aim of the Euorpean Union is to promote the well-being of its citizens. Dr Augustín Ibáñez, Professor of Global Brain Health in Trinity College Dublin, in an extensive cross-sectional and longtitudinal study carried out across 27 European countries found that multilingualism was a key factor in preventing accelerated aging. The study found that individuals from countries where people commonly speak at least one additional language were 2.17 times less likely to experience accelerated aging, while monolinguals were over twice as likely to show early aging patterns. These effects remained significant even after adjusting for linguistic, social, physical, and sociopolitical factors. The protective impact of multilingualism was consistent across both cross-sectional analyses, reflecting current differences in aging, and longitudinal analyses, showing that multilingualism predicts a lower risk of accelerated aging over time. The long-term health impacts of modern language learning would be demonstrably beneficial for Europe’s population.

organisation: School of Languages, Literatures and Cultural Studies, Trinity College Dublin
response_text: The experience of learning the language of another member state is the most immediate, but also the most enduring, experience of belonging to a wider political entity predicated on democratic access and cultural inclusiveness. The ability to develop human contact, acquire historical knowledge, appreciate cultural practices (music, food, performance arts) and engage in resilient forms of educational and economic relationships (research, business) is greatly enhanced by the knowledge of another’s language. The notion of hospitality is crucial here. Learning the language(s) of citizens of other Member States is a way of welcoming the cultures and languages of others into one’s society. This form of recognition not only leads to an enrichment of the lives of European citizens but it creates a sense of reciprocal obligation (I recognise you because you have recognized me) which not only binds citizens closer together but makes them feel that European identities are concrete, communicative realities rather than distant, institutional abstractions. The sense of ownership of the European project can only be intensified by the regular engagement with and the practice of the language(s) of other Europeans, a concrete enactment of the EU motto, ‘Unity in Diversity.’ A largely unexplored resource in terms of public representations of the European ideal is the extraordinary range of languages (twenty-four in all) that have official, working status in the EU. Each of these languages carries an incalculably rich body of story, song, insight and expression that, in many instances, is largely unknown to citizens from the different EU Member States. By making this overlooked treasure, a key thematic priority of te Irish Presidency of the Council, the Irish Presidency would highlight the immense possibilities and boundless interest of intense language engagement across the Members States of the Union. Ireland’s historical commitment to modern language learning, the bilingual nature of the State and the strength of Ireland’s international reputation in the area of literary expression makes Ireland a credible advocate of multlingualism as a thematic priority of the EU Presidency with clear, tangible outcomes for citizens, communities and businesses in the Union. The Trinity Long Room Hub working in conjunction with the School of Languages, Literatures and Cultural Studies and the Trinity Centre for Literary and Cultural Translation can provide the expertise and tools that would give expression and substance to an active campaign centred around European multlingualism. For the College, there would be no more fitting way to honour 250 years of involvement in modern language education in Europe than to become an active partner with the State in promoting multilingualism as an active, life-long dimension to the lives of European citizens. The mental health benefits of multilingualism are a further element in making intelligible the real world impact of a renewed commitment in public policy to the foundational multilingualism of European institutions.

As Ireland prepares to assume the Presidency of the Council of the European Union in 2026, it faces a pivotal opportunity to shape the EU’s policy agenda at a time of geopolitical turbulence and intense legislative activity, including for financial services. Global instability and declining economic competitiveness, as highlighted by Mario Draghi, underscore the need for the EU to harness the full power of the Single Market to drive growth, attract investment, and strengthen its global role. Ireland’s Presidency should therefore be defined by a future-oriented vision for the EU, underpinned by three overarching themes aimed at fostering economic competitiveness: simplification of the regulatory framework, driving forward and completing the Savings and Investment Union (SIU), and strengthening and harmonising the EU’s financial architecture. Driving Forward and Completing the Savings and Investment Union (SIU) The EU faces a significant investment gap—estimated at €800bn annually—to meet its objectives for decarbonisation, digitalisation, and defence. Despite high savings rates, much capital remains underutilised, and the EU lags behind other regions in innovation and capital market development. Advancing the SIU is essential to closing this gap and restoring the EU’s global competitiveness. Ireland should use its Presidency to drive forward the SIU strategy, developing deeper and more liquid capital markets, breaking down internal barriers, and boosting retail investor participation. Key actions include harmonising supervisory outcomes, removing barriers to cross-border investment, revitalising the securitisation market, and promoting financial literacy across Member States Simplification of the Regulatory Framework. The EU’s financial services sector is constrained by a complex and fragmented regulatory environment that hinders global competitiveness. Ireland’s Presidency presents a critical opportunity to champion a legislative agenda focused on proportionality and simplicity. Regulations should be tailored to the size, complexity, and systemic risk of financial institutions, reducing unnecessary administrative burdens and unlocking capital for productive investment. By advocating for a smarter, simpler, and more agile regulatory environment, Ireland can help lead the EU toward a more competitive and integrated financial market. This includes revising and simplifying the macroprudential framework, reviewing the methodology for identifying systemically important institutions, and advancing a dedicated regime for investment firms. 3. Strengthening and Harmonising Financial Architecture. To realise the full potential of the Single Market, the EU must strengthen and harmonise its financial architecture. This includes further supervisory convergence to tackle internal barriers, harmonising insolvency law, and advancing a common EU-wide legal framework for capital markets. Enhanced EU-level supervision of systemic market infrastructures should streamline existing processes and ensure consistent regulatory outcomes. Ireland’s expertise as a global financial services hub positions it to lead efforts in building a more resilient, integrated, and innovative financial system for the EU By focusing on these three themes, Ireland can help drive a Presidency programme that is ambitious, balanced, and responsive to the evolving needs of the EU and its citizens, while directly addressing the competitiveness challenge at the heart of Europe’s future.

Key Policy Areas and Legislative Proposals for the Irish Presidency of the Council in 2026 Building on the overarching themes of competitiveness, simplification, and integration of the EU financial architecture, the Irish Presidency should prioritise the following financial services policy areas and legislative proposals: Advancing the Savings and Investment Union (SIU). Ireland should champion the development of deeper and more liquid capital markets to close the EU’s €800bn annual investment gap and restore global competitiveness. Focus areas should relate to: Removing barriers to cross-border investment: Launch a review of national barriers and push for the replacement of Directives with Regulations where appropriate, especially in listing, trading, and posttrade frameworks as outlined in the EU MIP. Harmonise insolvency law: Progress a common EU-wide legal framework to enable true capital markets via the EU 28th regime. Revitalise securitisation markets: Prioritise finding agreement with the European Parliament on a revised securitisation framework. From an industry perspective, the ambition of policymakers on securitisation is being viewed as a litmus test for the wider SIU agenda. As such, we believe it is crucial that the final agreement is ambitious, more risk-sensitive and proportionate from a capital/risk weight floor perspective, and that there is alignment in terms haircuts with covered bonds. Boost retail investor participation: without simplifying the investor journey and creating the correct tax incentives, retail investors will remain uninvested in EU markets. We therefore firmly believe the Irish Government needs to prioritise SIAs both domestically and at EU level. At the same time, policymakers must simplify disclosure requirements and harmonise investor protection rules via the RIS. Promote financial literacy: Accelerate the EU’s Financial Literacy Strategy and coordinate progress on Savings and Investment Accounts. Simplification and Proportionality in Regulation. The Irish Presidency should drive a smarter, simpler, and more agile regulatory environment, focussing on: Revising the macroprudential framework for banks: This should focus on eliminating unnecessary or duplicative capital buffers while addressing double counting of risks. Review O-SII methodology calculation: Ensure O-SII designations reflect actual systemic importance and do not disproportionately impact smaller member states as currently the case. Focus on O-SII designation should form a key part of any discussions on revising the macroprudential framework. Establish a dedicated investment firm regime: EU capital market development hinges on having deep and liquid markets both primary and secondary. Having active market makers is therefore essential. Given many of the largest EU market makers are located in Ireland, we believe the Irish Government should focus on reviewing the Investment Firms Regime to ensure it is proportionate and risk-based – removing inappropriate bank-focused rules like arbitrary balance sheet thresholds and the application of BRRD. Embed competitiveness mandates within the ESAs: Integrate competitiveness and sustainable growth into the mandates of EU supervisory authorities. Simplify CRR/CRD reporting: Streamline requirements and ensure future revisions do not add complexity, especially for smaller institutions. Strengthening and Harmonising Financial Architecture. Ireland should lead efforts to create a more resilient, integrated, and innovative financial system. Enhance supervisory convergence: Through the EU MIP package, Ireland should look to tackle internal barriers and ensure consistent regulatory outcomes across Member States. The overarching principle should be that supervisory outcomes across the EU are consistent, rather than necessarily on centralised supervision. Improve trading and post-trade market structure: Foster competition among infrastructure providers and standardise post-trade processes. Additionally, the Irish Government should focus on structural issues that give way to unlevel playing field issues, like the use of single market maker models operating in some EU jurisdictions. Sustainable Finance and Digital Innovation. Harmonise sustainability rules: Better alignment of frameworks such as CRR/CRD, MiFID, SFDR, CSRD, and the EU Taxonomy to reduce duplication and regulatory fragmentation is needed above and beyond the EU Omnibus package. Advance digital finance: There is a real need to simplify the digital/cyber regulatory framework, remove overlaps between DORA and the Cyber Resilience Act, and support a market-driven approach to the digital euro and open finance. Consumer Protection and Housing Develop a harmonised EU consumer protection framework: Advocate for a harmonised, outcomesfocused, and principle-based consumer protection framework. This will strengthen trust in the financial system, support cross-border financial services, and underpin the Savings and Investment Union. Support effective delivery of housing: Progress the EU Affordable Housing Plan and advocate for more flexible State aid rules to enable Member States to support viable housing projects. Driving Reform of Third Party Litigation Funding (TPLF): Ireland should champion EU-wide reform of third party litigation funding and collective redress frameworks. Experience in the UK has shown that the current opt-out regime can result in low consumer redress rates, high litigation costs, and disproportionate benefits for funders and lawyers rather than claimants. Without reform, there is a risk of speculative claims, economic inefficiency, and adverse impacts on innovation and market capitalisation. The Irish Presidency should lead efforts to introduce enhanced scrutiny at the certification stage, establish a formal regulatory framework for litigation funders, and ensure independent oversight of the distribution phase. These reforms would help deliver fairer, more effective redress for consumers, reduce uncertainty for businesses, and safeguard the integrity of the EU’s collective actions regime.

Ireland’s upcoming EU Council Presidency presents an opportunity to deliver tangible, far-reaching benefits for people, businesses and communities across the European Union. Assuming leadership amid geopolitical turbulence and significant legislative activity in financial services, Ireland is well placed to champion an agenda that strengthens Europe’s resilience, competitiveness and capacity to drive positive change throughout the Single Market. Above all, having a laser focus on simplifying the regulatory framework and rebuilding economic competitiveness is of paramount importance. That is why we strongly believe that the Irish Presidency should prioritise resources on the EU’s biggest and most pressing issues, like the SIU, the Markets Integration Package, the EU budget and simplification. All of these “big ticket” items can have a real impact on EU citizens either through enhancing economic activity, how companies raise money, consumers invest for retirement or through large scale infrastructure projects that provide a public good. To deliver the greatest impact, the Council must address the root causes of Europe’s competitiveness challenge. The most substantial progress can be made by advancing the EU’s Savings and Investment Union (SIU). The SIU is not just a financial sector initiative – it is a strategic lever for unlocking the EU’s economic potential. By developing deeper and more liquid capital markets, the EU can mobilise household savings for productive investment, close the innovation gap, and diversify funding sources for key priorities such as decarbonisation and digitalisation. However, this will require tough political decisions and a willingness to break down entrenched barriers, including harmonising insolvency law, revitalising the securitisation market, and removing obstacles to cross-border investment. The Irish Presidency can play a pivotal role as a bridge builder, fostering compromise and driving forward the SIU agenda to ensure that capital flows efficiently across the Union. Equally, a simplified and proportionate regulatory environment is fundamental to enabling the financial sector to act as a true catalyst for growth and resilience. The current regulatory landscape is characterised by complexity and fragmentation, which imposes unnecessary administrative burdens and stifles innovation – especially for smaller institutions. By championing “simplification rather than deregulation”, the Irish Presidency can help ensure that regulations are fit for purpose, proportionate to risk, and do not create undue barriers compared to global peers. The need for simplification is particularly acute in the digital and cyber domain. The EU’s ambitious digital agenda has resulted in a patchwork of overlapping rules, making compliance challenging and potentially undermining Europe’s global competitiveness. The Irish Presidency should take a pragmatic approach to ongoing negotiations, prioritising the digital omnibus package and ensuring that frameworks like DORA and the Cyber Resilience Act are aligned and proportionate. By advancing a future-proof regulatory framework for digital finance, the Council can foster responsible innovation, support cross-border data sharing, and strengthen both business growth and consumer protection. In summary, by concentrating resources on the SIU and regulatory simplification, Ireland’s Presidency can help shape a pragmatic, competitive, and innovation-driven EU financial framework – one that delivers real benefits for citizens and businesses, and positions the EU as a global leader in economic resilience and growth.

Effectively communicating the values and benefits of EU membership to citizens and fostering a genuine sense of ownership over Ireland’s Presidency of the Council of the EU, demands a strategic, multi-layered approach that resonates at both local and national levels. To make the benefits of EU membership truly relatable, communication should centre on tangible outcomes. This means highlighting how EU membership has spurred economic growth, created jobs, harmonised consumer protections, and enabled infrastructural improvements throughout Ireland. Organising events and awareness campaigns further strengthens this strategy. Collaborative projects with schools, local authorities, and various stakeholders can ensure these initiatives are inclusive and relevant, reaching people from all walks of life. These efforts help bridge the gap between citizens and policymakers, encouraging active participation, and a sense of shared purpose. Ireland’s presidency should not concentrate events solely in Dublin but extend them across the country to reflect the national character and economic diversity. The Ireland for Finance strategy has shown that regional promotion delivers tangible benefits: today, one in four international financial services jobs are outside Dublin. By hosting presidency events beyond Dublin, Ireland would not only showcase its vibrant regional economies but also reinforce the message that prosperity and innovation are shared across the island. This approach aligns directly with the government’s own findings that regionalisation strengthens both industry and local labour markets, ensuring that Ireland’s international reputation is built on inclusivity and balance. To further strengthen this approach, the Irish Presidency should focus on delivering and communicating progress on “big ticket” policy items that have a visible and positive impact on people’s lives and the wider economy. When citizens see real movement on issues such as economic competitiveness, simplification of rules, and the removal of barriers to business and opportunity, it becomes clear that the EU is focused on outcomes that matter. This not only demonstrates that the EU delivers but also helps counter the perception that the Union is overly complex or burdensome. A key part of this communication strategy should be to simplify the language used in all Presidency messaging. EU policy is often seen as technical and inaccessible; therefore, the Irish Presidency should set a new standard by focusing on the “purpose” and “impact” of each proposal. Every communication should answer: “Why does this matter?” and “How will it improve people’s lives?” By translating complex policy into clear, relatable language, the Presidency can make the EU’s work more accessible and meaningful. It is also important to reframe the narrative around the Single Market. While it is one of the EU’s greatest achievements, its benefits often go unnoticed. The Presidency should highlight concrete examples of how the Single Market enables Irish businesses to grow, supports jobs, and gives consumers more choice and better prices. By making these benefits visible, citizens can better appreciate the value of EU membership. Finally, by prioritising simplification and the removal of unnecessary barriers, the Irish Presidency can show that policymakers are serious about improving economic performance and reducing complexity. This not only benefits businesses but also reassures citizens that the EU is evolving to meet their needs.
must provide a summary of the additional information under the ‘Any other comments’ question. This summary should also be limited to a maximum of 500 words.

Aviation is a cornerstone of the global economy. It drives trade, supports jobs, and connects people and cultures in ways no other industry can. Aviation plays a critical role in both the EU and Irish economies and crucially is a key social and economic connector to regions across the globe. Europe maintains a key competitive advantage in aircraft leasing, anchored by Ireland, as the world’s leading aircraft leasing hub employing 8,500 people directly and indirectly with total assets of €268bn. Policies to enhance and strengthen aviation should be prioritised by the Irish Presidency and could fall under the theme Ireland 2025: Sustaining human connection, promoting economic growth. Draft an EU Aviation Strategy As a sector undergoing profound transformation, a dedicated EU Aviation Strategy is warranted. The EU’s aviation sector exports €55bn annually, demonstrating its global competitive advantage that must be retained and expanded. An EU Aviation Strategy aligns with the pressing need at home to develop a longterm horizon for aviation in Ireland through a revised National Aviation Policy (NAP). Decarbonisation of aviation The decarbonisation of European transport is a massive undertaking which requires policy certainty, technological neutrality and private sector buy-in. The lack of supply of Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) across Europe, as well as a lack of incentives for the production of SAF, is frustrating decarbonisation efforts as EU mandates only grow in scope. The recently published Sustainable Transport Investment Plan (STIP), a strategic framework to boost investment in renewable and low-carbon aviation and maritime fuels must be prioritised and further developed / enhanced, as it can provide the policy certainty needed to kickstart the market and deliver on Europe's decarbonisation ambitions for aviation. Regulatory resources for aviation The aerospace supply chain is experiencing significant challenges, including the capacity of EU Aviation Safety Agency (EASA) to carry out its core duties in a timely fashion, such as certification duties. The global aviation industry is set to double over the next two decades presenting a strong opportunity for Europe to capitalize on its competitive advantage in this high-technology, export-oriented industry, EASA must be adequately funded and resourced to enable European business to continue to be competitive globally. Trade & U.S. investment policy The European economy requires stability and predictability with the U.S., our largest trading partner. The inclusion of zero tariffs for aircraft and aircraft parts should be retained indefinitely to help support the continued success of European aerospace, aircraft leasing and aviation sectors. Taxation policy Safeguard Ireland’s ability to attract and retain aircraft leasing companies by ensuring a competitive, consistent, and transparent EU tax regime. In the absence of this, we fear that rising administration and compliance costs could threaten Ireland’s aircraft leasing sector’s long-term competitiveness. In addition, maintain the current VAT regime for aviation, i.e. zero-rating with the right to deduct input VAT, which reflects international practice (International Civil Aviation Organisation Doc. 8632) in exempting international air transport from VAT. • Sanctions policy Continued dialogue with industry should be a cornerstone for sanctions evolution. On the assumption that sanctions against Russia are maintained throughout Ireland’s Presidency careful consideration needs to be given in relation to the potential inclusion of additional products, such as critical raw materials (such as titanium) which may result in unintended consequences for the European aerospace industry by creating dependencies on supply from outside the EU, which is not aligned with the EU’s drive for strategic autonomy.

Policy areas in aviation that should be a focus of work for the Irish Presidency of the Council in 2026: Implementation of the Sustainable Transport Investment Plan ALI and Ibec have long called for increased investment in sustainable fuels for transport to boost production to compete with incentives offered in other regions. The recently published STIP will provide financing and investment frameworks while aiming to de-risk private investments in renewable and low-carbon fuels for the maritime and aviation industry. Ireland has a rich aviation heritage and strong reputation in this competitive market. As the first EU country to launch a SAF Policy Roadmap, Ireland should prioritise implementation of STIP measures to ensure rapid scale-up of SAF production and associated alternative fuel infrastructure (AFI), explore EU-level incentives (e.g. dedicated funding, offtake guarantees) to boost viability while developing an indigenous SAF sector. In addition, while the Commission is assessing its feasibility, we must expedite a Book-and-Claim to enable global access to SAF and avoid costly, piecemeal infrastructure projects. Innovative technologies for zeroemission aviation must be considered including battery propulsion air mobility and the hydrogen supply chain. Increase EASA Funding Despite setting safety standards for 41 states, EASA operates on a budget (~€250–300 million) and staff (~800) dramatically lower than the U.S. FAA (40,000 staff, ~$20 billion budget). EASA must scale up to ensure Europe maintains its competitive advantage and to ensure the efficient certification of existing and emerging technologies as well as SAF, drones, etc to maintain pace with technological innovations, meet the EU’s commitment to decreasing transport greenhouse gas emissions and develop and produce SAF in Europe. Increased funding would empower EASA to: ➢ Align budgets and workforce with its global counterparts, Expand digital, environmental, and cybersecurity capabilities, Maintain Europe’s top-tier safety record, Create additional high value and essential jobs in Europe across the aviation ecosystem, including pilots, engineers, etc. Support emerging technologies and sustainable aviation, ➢ Ensure fair, proportional oversight, and ➢ Strengthen stakeholder collaboration. • Draft an EU Aviation Strategy Given that the current Aviation Strategy for Europe dates back to 2015, a comprehensive update is now necessary. We urge the prioritisation of a renewed strategic framework that simultaneously safeguards the sector’s global competitive edge and accelerates the delivery of the EU’s ambitious decarbonisation mandates. An EU aviation strategy is vital to: Support the economic and societal benefits and connectivity of aviation, Support the 15 million jobs and $1.2 trillion in European economic activity, Uphold safety, security, and regulatory clarity and fairness, ➢ Support innovation, technological innovations and net-zero goals. Build strategic resilience and autonomy.

Aviation in the EU Aviation is a key enabler of the EU Single Market, ensuring free movement of people and goods. The European aviation network connects over 450 million citizens and links Europe globally. Around 2.9 million people work in the EU aviation sector (airlines, airports, manufacturers, air navigation, etc.) and supports over 15 million jobs when including indirect. Economic Contribution $1.2 trillion GDP. Europe is home to major aerospace manufacturers (Airbus and Safran), which are global leaders in innovation, R&D, and exports. The sector drives technological advancement, including sustainability, e.g., hydrogen aircraft, Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF), electric aviation. With ~ 60% of the global market share of leased aircraft operating across 95+ countries, Europe maintains a key competitive advantage in aircraft leasing, anchored by Ireland as the world’s leading aircraft leasing hub. Aviation in Ireland About 30% of Irish exports by value (especially high-tech and pharma goods) are transported by air. Aviation connectivity supports Ireland’s role as a base for global tech and pharmaceutical firms (e.g. Apple, Pfizer, Google). Over 140,000 jobs are supported directly, indirectly, or induced by aviation and aerospace in Ireland. Aviation contributes around €8–10 billion annually to Ireland’s GDP when including direct, indirect, and induced impacts. Ireland is the world’s leading hub for aircraft leasing, with over 60% of the market share. It is unmatched when it comes to talent, skills, innovation, expertise, research and development, and the representation of the major global leasing firms. Ireland acts as a transatlantic hub, connecting Europe and North America. Over 80% of international visitors arrive by air. Aviation underpins a tourism sector worth over €5 billion annually and supports hundreds of thousands of jobs across hospitality and retail.
Retail participation in EU capital Markets- SIU
Savings & Investment Union Cross-Border Simplification Financial Literacy EU Digital Finance Agenda

1. Accelerating Delivery of the Savings and Investment Union (SIU) The Irish Presidency should prioritise progress on the legislative files essential to completing the Savings and Investment Union. The Presidency should aim to advance negotiations and secure meaningful progress on legislative files underpinning the SIU, laying the foundation for long-term EU competitiveness and financial resilience. Positioning Ireland as the SIU “Implementation Model” Ireland’s financial services sector is well-placed to serve as a practical reference point for Member States in the development of the SIU. Domestic reforms—such as simplification efforts, product innovation, and proportionate regulation, will serve as practical leadership. The Presidency should facilitate knowledgesharing to drive consensus on fit-for-purpose, consumer-friendly investment products. Promoting Cross-Border Simplification and Eliminating Duplication A priority for the Presidency should be advancing EU-level initiatives that streamline cross-border distribution and reduce unnecessary regulatory duplication, supporting the Capital Markets Union and efficient European capital markets. This is not a call for deregulation, but rather for coherent and aligned regulation that supports competitiveness. The Commission has committed to addressing overlaps across legislative files—for example, between DORA and the Cyber Resilience Act, and within ESG-related reporting frameworks. It will be important for the Irish Presidency to monitor progress closely and ensure that the Commission delivers on its commitment to eliminate these inefficiencies. Strengthening European Financial Culture and Consumer Protection Ireland should champion the implementation of the Commission’s Financial Literacy Strategy across all Member States. A more financially informed population is critical to consumer protection, retail investor participation and financing Europe’s green and digital transitions, as well as increased participation in European capital markets. Embedding a shared European financial culture will support the long-term objectives of the SIU, ensuring savers are both protected and empowered to engage confidently with financial products. Advancing the EU’s Digital Finance Agenda, Including the Digital Euro. The Presidency should aim to initiate negotiations on the Digital Euro legislative file. This is a key component of the EU’s digital finance agenda, and early progress will help provide clarity to industry, consumers, and public authorities on the future direction of digital payments infrastructure in Europe.
As above, SIU is about empowering citizens to participate in our capital markets and have an impact on European infrastructure, defence, innovation and sustainability.
