I believe that the Irish government, of all the EU government, is best placed to add a policy of peace to our presidency. We are neutral, we have no war baggage, we have a long history of international aid and we have a long and proud history of international peacekeeping.

As the European Peacebuilding Liaison Office, we believe Ireland has the opportunity in 2026 to anchor its Presidency of the Council in a coherent set of priorities that strengthen conflict prevention, mediation and sustainable peace across the European Union and beyond. Ireland’s long-standing commitment to peacebuilding, multilateralism and principled diplomacy positions it well to champion a forward-looking peace agenda at a moment when global insecurity continues to grow. Ireland should place comprehensive engagement across the full conflict cycle at the centre of its Presidency programme. Addressing insecurity calls for political leadership inside the Council to ensure that emerging tensions, active crises and post conflict recovery all receive rapid and coordinated attention. Ireland can promote systematic conflict analysis across all external action files, encourage the use of flexible funding that supports diplomacy, mediation and peacebuilding at every stage, and champion stronger links between EU delegations, civil society and local peacebuilders who provide essential context and continuity. A Presidency that prioritises the entire conflict cycle would help shift the EU from reactive responses to coherent, long-term peacebuilding. Ireland should also integrate a concise but firm set of priorities that address current global challenges to peace. The EU must reinforce humanitarian disarmament by strengthening the Ottawa Convention and advancing humanitarian mine action. Recent attempts by some states to dilute commitments or withdraw from the Convention highlight the need for renewed diplomatic engagement, better compliance support and expanded assistance for communities living with the daily threat of explosive ordnance. Ireland is well placed to mobilise member states behind a unified EU position that protects the integrity of this vital treaty. At the same time, Ireland should reaffirm the Women, Peace and Security agenda as a core pillar of EU external action. A growing gender backlash is undermining women’s participation in peace processes and limiting funding for women peacebuilders. Ireland can counter this trend by promoting stronger accountability for WPS commitments in all Council working groups, protecting hard won gains and signalling that gender equality remains essential for durable peace. Together, these priorities would allow Ireland to help the European Union act as a more effective and principled force for peace at a moment when international norms and multilateral cooperation face significant pressure.

As EPLO, we recommend that the Irish Presidency of the Council in 2026 prioritises policy areas and legislative files that can strengthen the EU’s integrated approach to fragility and reinforce its role as a global peace actor. Ireland’s track record in humanitarian diplomacy, conflict prevention and multilateralism positions it well to steer the Council toward constructive and coherent outcomes. A central focus should be the EU’s external action framework, particularly policies that bridge humanitarian, development and peace efforts. Following the publication of the Communication on Humanitarian Aid in Q2 of 2026, the Irish Presidency should lead the adoption of Council conclusions that reinforce conflict prevention and peace within the EU’s approach to fragility. These conclusions should underline the need for conflict sensitive planning across all EU financial instruments, stronger coordination between humanitarian, development and peace actors and sustained political attention to promoting dialogue and reducing violence in fragile contexts. By reinforcing the peace element of the HDP nexus, the EU will be better equipped to address complex crises where humanitarian need is rooted in protracted conflict. Ireland should also prioritise updated Council conclusions on conflict prevention and peacebuilding. The last comprehensive conclusions in this field are dated, given the outbreak of war on the European continent and active conflict reaching the highest levels worldwide since WWII. Updated conclusions should reaffirm prevention as a strategic EU priority, call for systematic conflict analysis across all external policies, support inclusive mediation efforts and strengthen partnerships with civil society and local peacebuilders. The Presidency should aim for clear operational commitments that can guide Council working groups and EU delegations in fragile and conflict affected environments. The Irish Presidency should address the planned reduction in the EU’s diplomatic footprint, involving centralising staff in regional hubs and downsizing delegation presence on the ground. This trend undermines diplomacy as a primary tool for conflict prevention and resolution, as local engagement and contextual understanding are essential for early action. Ireland should encourage a renewed commitment to field-based diplomacy, backed by adequate staffing, political access and resources. In its upcoming Presidency of the Council, Ireland should promote greater transparency and oversight of the EU’s expanding defence capability and production initiatives, including initiatives under ReArm Europe. Increased defence investments and new instruments supporting arms production require clear safeguards to ensure coherence with the EU’s commitments to conflict prevention, humanitarian principles and responsible export controls. Ireland can encourage systematic impact assessments, improved public reporting and stronger parliamentary scrutiny across relevant initiatives. Such measures would help ensure that defence related policies reinforce, rather than undermine, the EU’s wider goals of sustainable peace, human security and international stability.

From EPLO’s standpoint, the Council can make the greatest positive impact for people, businesses and communities by placing peace and stability at the heart of its work during the Irish Presidency. Lasting prosperity depends on reducing the risks and costs associated with conflict, both within the EU and in its neighbourhood. By strengthening conflict prevention, supporting inclusive dialogue, reinforcing the EU’s integrated approach to fragility and promoting social peace, the Presidency can help create safer environments for citizens, more predictable conditions for businesses and more resilient communities. A Council agenda grounded in peace will deliver long term security, economic stability and social cohesion across the Union.

Ireland should express three mutually reinforcing high‑level priorities for its 2026 Council Presidency. 1) Talent and Open Knowledge. The Presidency should champion policies that attract, develop, and retain world‑class researchers across all disciplines while embedding open research as the default. In practice, this means promoting predictable, excellence‑based programmes from PhD to principal investigator, revitalising research infrastructure so that Europe remains globally competitive, and advancing FAIR data and open access to maximise the impact and reusability of publicly funded knowledge. These actions mirror our domestic commitments to annual investigator‑led calls, an expanded PhD pipeline, well-equipped facilities, and a system‑wide shift to open research and research assessment reform. 2) Innovation and Competitiveness. The Presidency should emphasise translation of excellent science into productivity, quality jobs, and strategic autonomy. We propose prioritising large‑scale public–private partnerships and mission‑oriented instruments that de‑risk private R&D, support SMEs to collaborate across borders, and accelerate the creation and scaling of spin‑outs. This includes facilitating simpler co‑funding models, clearer IP and data‑sharing norms, and better brokerage so that high‑potential firms and regions can connect to European value chains. 3) Societal Impact and Cohesion. The Presidency should place interdisciplinary and transdisciplinary research at the centre of European problem‑solving in areas citizens care about most: climate resilience and energy transition, trustworthy and inclusive digital transformation (including AI), health and ageing, and housing and the built environment. Engaged research where communities and end‑users co‑design and co‑implement research should be promoted so that policy and public services are informed by evidence and earn public trust. These priorities reflect Ireland’s strengths as a small, open, and agile economy that brokers collaboration and builds consensus. They align naturally with an international government strategy that deepens links in the ERA while diversifying global partnerships so that European researchers, companies, and regions can access broader talent pools, infrastructures, and markets. Taken together, the three priorities provide a clear and people‑centred vision for a Presidency that accelerates researcher mobility and openness, strengthens Europe’s innovation capacity, and delivers tangible societal benefit.

Research Ireland recommends several policy areas and associated goals for the Irish Presidency in 2026. 1) Open Research and Research Assessment Reform. The Presidency should seek Council conclusions that consolidate Europe’s transition to FAIR data and open access, embedding transparent data‑management planning, robust repositories, and interoperable metadata across Member States. Reform of research assessment should recognise a broader range of outputs—such as data sets, software, interdisciplinary collaboration, engagement with policy and society, and talent development—alongside publications and citations. This combination will increase reproducibility and accelerate knowledge diffusion while preserving research and knowledge security. 2) Research Careers, Mobility, and Visas. Building on Europe’s excellence programmes, Ireland should promote a Council roadmap for modern research careers that provides predictable, excellence‑based opportunities at all stages, improves intersectoral mobility, and reduces administrative friction for visas and secondments. This includes better alignment with the EU Framework Programme’s Marie Skłodowska Curie Actions, increased portability of grants and pensions where feasible, and interoperable recognition of skills and qualifications. 3) Public–Private Partnerships and European Innovation Capacity. To convert knowledge into competitiveness, the Presidency should advance simplified frameworks for large‑scale partnerships, Research Centre‑style collaborations, and Important Projects of Common European Interest (IPCEIs). Clearer co‑funding models, proportionate reporting, and streamlined state‑aid guidance will help SMEs and FDI‑intensive sectors to engage at scale. Guidance on data‑sharing, IP, and standard‑setting can further speed translation and embed high‑value activity in Europe. 4) Mission‑Driven, Interdisciplinary Research for Societal Challenges. The Presidency should facilitate cross‑domain, cross‑border initiatives that tackle climate resilience, energy, digital trust and AI governance, health innovation, and housing. Programmes should require meaningful engagement with end‑users and public administrations, with explicit pathways to policy adoption and service delivery, so that results are implemented and felt by citizens. 5) Internationalisation within the ERA. The Presidency should reinforce diversified, values‑based international cooperation that strengthens European capacity while safeguarding research security. Practical steps include enhanced National Contact Point networks, structured support for consortia formation, and measures that raise participation and success rates across Member States—particularly for smaller research systems. Indicative Presidency deliverables include: (a) Council conclusions on open research and engaged research; (b) a Council roadmap on researcher mobility and careers; and (c) practical guidance for scaling public–private partnerships, including clear participation pathways for SMEs and smaller Member States in IPCEIs and co‑funded partnerships.

The work of the Council under Ireland’s Presidency can deliver substantial, visible value for people, businesses, and communities as follows: Elevate talent as the primary driver of impact. Predictable and excellence‑based programmes across all disciplines, coupled with modern infrastructures, will expand the researcher pipeline that sustains innovation in SMEs and FDI companies, strengthens the competitiveness of higher education, and equips the public sector with the analytical capacity for evidence‑informed policy. Convert research into innovation capacity at company and ecosystem level. Scaling public–private centres, co‑funded partnerships, and spin‑out pathways will de‑risk private R&D, improve productivity, and create high‑quality jobs in every region. Simplified rules for cross‑border collaboration and brokerage will allow SMEs to participate more easily in European value chains. Deliver mission‑driven outcomes that citizens can feel. Interdisciplinary programmes should address climate resilience and energy affordability, trustworthy AI and digital inclusion, health and ageing, and housing and the built environment. Using engaged research methods that are co‑designed with communities and public services translate scientific advances into better local services, healthier environments, and stronger social cohesion. Strengthen international connectivity to lift performance system‑wide. Facilitating mobility, secondments, and diversified partnerships will help retain and attract talent, give researchers access to world‑class facilities, and improve success in European programmes. Embed an evidence‑informed public sector. The Presidency can promote EU guidance and communities of practice on research‑policy interfaces, meta‑research and benchmarking, and the use of data analytics to target investments where they make the greatest difference. These levers enable Ireland to be a strategic leader, partner, connector, and advocate to ensure that excellent research reliably becomes widely shared prosperity and quality of life.

Ireland can communicate the values and benefits of EU membership—and foster a sense of citizen ownership of the Presidency—through a citizen‑first ‘research‑in‑everyday‑life’ approach. We propose, first, telling human stories of impact. Communications should consistently link EU‑funded and nationally funded research to tangible outcomes such as new medicines, cleaner and cheaper energy, safer and more trustworthy digital services, and cultural wellbeing. Case studies should follow a ‘from lab to life’ arc that explains the journey from discovery to everyday benefit. Co‑create with citizens through engaged research. Presidency‑branded living labs, open town halls with researchers and policymakers, and community‑based participatory research can invite citizens to shape priorities and monitor progress. These formats not only improve relevance and uptake but also build trust by making research transparent and collaborative. Be open by default. FAIR/open practices should extend to communication: open data showcases, code and data reproducibility demonstrations, and simple, transparent impact dashboards that visualise collaboration networks, funding flows, and local benefits during the Presidency term. Local to European. A distributed campaign delivered with universities, Technological Universities, Research Centres and regional hubs should connect local priorities to EU missions. Diaspora‑enabled research networks and diplomatic missions can amplify these stories internationally, positioning Ireland as a welcoming, outward‑looking science nation. One Team Ireland narrative. Messages should be aligned across Research Ireland, DFHERIS, the HEA, Enterprise Ireland, IDA Ireland and diplomatic missions so the Presidency is seen as a national endeavour that advances European progress.

Women for Election would like to see the Irish Presidency building out high level thematic principles that address current threats to democracy across Europe. This would mirror initiatives in the EU’s strategic agenda 2024-2029, and in particular, the priorities set out under the heading A free and democratic Europe. We believe that a resilient democracy is one where diverse women can safely participate, lead and be heard. Themes to support this vision would include: Towards gender-balanced and inclusive democracy - Putting women’s voices at the heart of decision making enhances and strengthens democracy. Actions would include support for gender-balanced local government, national parliaments and cabinets, candidate-support measures, quotas and pipeline programmes for women, Traveller and Roma women, women with a migrant background and other underrepresented groups, as well as practical measures to make politics safer and more family-friendly e.g. harassment policies, parental leave, flexible working. A safe, open and accountable digital public sphere - Use the Presidency to prioritise full implementation and enforcement of the Digital Services Act and the proposed “democracy shield” to effectively tackle online harassment, disinformation and foreign interference, with special attention being paid to the safety of candidates, elected representatives, journalists and activists—especially women and minorities, and to promote and ensure electoral integrity and transparency. Protection of civic space and human rights defenders - Champion EU-wide standards to protect NGOs, community groups, libraries, schools and media outlets from intimidation, SLAPPs and reputational attacks, and to ensure they can promote equality, inclusion and democratic participation without fear. Equality, anti-racism and social cohesion as democracy goals - Frame gender equality, anti-racism and anti-discrimination as core democratic infrastructure, including action on hate crime/hate speech, support for inclusive local democracy, and targeted initiatives to increase the participation of women from minority and migrant backgrounds. Youth and civic education for democratic participation - Prioritise EU programmes that equip young people—especially girls and under-represented groups—with the skills, confidence and opportunities to engage in politics.

Women for Election suggests that the following policy areas and legislative proposals should be a focus of work for the Irish Presidency. Digital democracy and platform accountability The Irish Presidency could focus on enforcement of the Digital Services Act, the new European Democracy Shield and the Centre for Democratic Resilience. The aim would be to drive strict, electionfocused enforcement of the DSA (with a particular focus on disinformation, deepfakes and targeted political ads), embed robust gender and anti-racism safeguards in the Democracy Shield, and secure Council conclusions on protecting candidates—particularly women and minorities—from online abuse and manipulation. Combating online and offline violence against women (including women in politics) The Irish Presidency could focus on the Directive on combating violence against women and domestic violence (EU 2024/1385) making sure that the Directive is implemented ambitiously in all member states, with specific standards and guidance on tackling abuse directed at women in public life, including candidates, councillors, members of parliament, journalists, and activists. Media freedom, pluralism and safety of journalists and public figures The Irish Presidency could focus on the implementation of the European Media Freedom Act (Regulation 2024/1083), including rules on media independence, ownership transparency and protection from political interference with an emphasis on securing strong, independence-protecting interpretations of EMFA, and underlining the safeguarding of local and public-interest media and the prevention of smear campaigns and coordinated harassment targeting women and minority voices. Protecting civic space and those who participate in public debate (anti-SLAPP) The Irish Presidency could focus on the transposition and strengthening of the Anti-SLAPP (Strategic Lawsuits against Public Participation) Directive on protecting people engaged in public participation (EU 2024/1069) to ensure the Directive becomes a real shield - early dismissal of abusive cases, cost protection, and effective compensation - explicitly highlighting protection for NGOs, community leaders and politically active women who may be sued to intimidate them out of public life. Gender-balanced representation and safe conditions for political participation The Irish Presidency could focus on follow-up to the EU Gender Equality Strategy; implementation of equality and anti-discrimination law; and continued use of funding programmes like CERV and Erasmus+ to support women’s political leadership. The aim would be to secure Council conclusions committing to concrete targets for women’s representation at all levels (local, national, EU), minimum standards on candidate safety and anti-harassment measures within parties and institutions, and ring-fenced EU funding for women’s leadership, training and candidate-support schemes.

Women for Election believes that Ireland can make significant impact during its Presidency by strengthening and protecting the foundations of Europe’s democracies. An inclusive and healthy democracy delivers stability, prosperity and fairness, all of which are essential for people, businesses and communities to thrive. By championing robust implementation of the Digital Services Act, the European Democracy Shield and other measures, Ireland can help ensure that citizens can participate in civic society without fear of online abuse, intimidation or manipulation. A safer public sphere supports healthier debate, better decisionmaking and increased trust in political institutions. Democracies are stronger, more effective and more economically resilient when diverse women are represented at every level. Ireland can use its Presidency to encourage progress toward gender-balanced parliaments and cabinets, improved candidate-support measures, and practical reforms that make politics more accessible and family-friendly. A political system that fully utilises women’s leadership results in better policies for social cohesion, economic competitiveness, and community wellbeing. Ireland also has an opportunity to prioritise EU programmes that equip young people — especially girls and under-represented groups — with the skills and confidence to engage in civic and political life. Strengthening youth participation will help build Europe’s future leaders, support social stability, and ensure that communities across the EU have a strong pipeline of informed, engaged citizens. A focus on democratic resilience, inclusion and meaningful participation would enable Ireland’s Presidency to deliver long-lasting benefits for people, businesses and communities across the EU thereby ensuring that Europe remains strong, united and responsive to the needs of all who live and work within it.

respondent_type: Representative body for Credit Unions in Ireland
response_text: It is our view, that a second half calendar Presidency limits the amount that can be achieved and thus a strategic narrow focus should be taken. It is quite clear that the Competitiveness agenda, the Multiannual Financial Framework, defence issues, Savings and Investment Union and the Digital Euro will be among the key ticket items expected of Ireland to deliver. A focus on achieving rather than sloganeering should be taken and a relentless focus on achieving a few, large priority issues should be advanced.

respondent_type: Representative body for Credit Unions in Ireland
response_text: For financial services, the Irish Presidency should focus on achieving full agreements on files rather than progress reports. Achieving agreement on some of the following would be a major success in line with the Competitiveness agenda, 1) the Retail Investment Regulation and Directive if not already agreed at trilogue stage; 2) the single currency package of a Regulation on the establishment of the digital euro and the Regulation on the legal tender of euro banknotes and coins; 3) proposals emanating from the Savings and Investment Union and 4) the securitisation package.

respondent_type: Representative body for Credit Unions in Ireland
response_text: Realistically the Council Presidency is an opportunity for Irish officials to reestablish credibility and show that Irish officials can achieve compromises and consensus in a rapidly changing geopolitical landscape.

respondent_type: Representative body for Credit Unions in Ireland
response_text: The Presidency could be a good opportunity to highlight to Irish citizens the value of a career in the EU given the lack of Irish staff in the EU institutions.

respondent_type: Representative body for Credit Unions in Ireland
response_text: The Irish League of Credit Unions welcomes the opportunity to help in any way we can during the Irish Presidency and as a key component of the European Network of Credit Unions we look forward to leveraging our contacts throughout Europe during the Presidency.

respondent_type: NGO on behalf of 22 pan-European Umbrella Organisations, representing 500+ national organisations
sector: EU Policy, Advocacy, and Education for patients and families affected by neurological conditions both common conditions such as Alzheimer’s disease, Epilepsy, Parkinson’s disease, Multiple Sclerosis, Migraine etc and also rare disease such as Ataxia, Dystonia, ALS, Motor Neuron Disease, Huntington’s disease, myasthenia gravis etc
geography: EU Wide representing 1 in 3 people across Europe
response_text: 1) “Brain health & resilient health systems” (Health Union that works in real life). Ireland can lead with a unifying theme: brain health across the life course—prevention, early diagnosis, timely treatment, rehabilitation, and long-term support. This reflects the lived reality that neurological conditions affect 1 in 3 people and are often lifelong, fluctuating, and “invisible.” EFNA’s survey ( n=4,800 responses of people living with neurological conditions in the EU) shows the scale of unmet need: fatigue (85%), pain (74%), sleep issues (74%), and stigma (84%). A presidency priority should explicitly connect clinical outcomes with quality of life, participation, and dignity—because neurological conditions are not only “health” issues; they affect work, education, relationships, and income. 2) “Digital, data, and trust—people-powered innovation.” Make Europe’s digital health agenda tangible by prioritising trusted health data use for better care and research, while protecting rights. EFNA data underscores why: 85% report clinicians did not believe symptom severity; 67% were initially misdiagnosed; 56% struggled to describe symptoms. Better data pathways, patient-reported outcomes, and interoperability can reduce diagnostic delay and disbelief—if implemented with transparency, safeguards, and meaningful patient involvement. 3) “Fairness & inclusion: participation in society despite chronic illness and disability.” A thematic priority should tackle the social impact of neurological conditions: EFNA reports 71% adjusted their job role or schedule, yet only 35% found employers accommodating; 74% face higher living costs; 72% report negative income impact; and 37% of those applying for mortgages/insurance were denied due to their condition. A presidency priority on inclusion aligns with EU values and improves economic participation. 4) “Competitiveness with purpose: life sciences, access, and affordability.” Ireland can credibly convene a “competitiveness that delivers” agenda: encourage biomedical innovation (including biotech) while ensuring equitable access to medicines and technologies across Member States—especially for neurology where unmet need remains substantial. 5) “Future preparedness: workforce, prevention, and long-term care.” Neurology depends on specialist teams and continuity of care. A forward-looking priority should include health workforce planning, community-based services, and prevention/risk reduction across the lifespan. Key EFNA message for the programme: Europe cannot claim resilience or competitiveness if millions remain unheard, misdiagnosed, and excluded from work and community life associated with significant losses to national and EU funds ( ~798 billion annually- data from the European Brain Council https://www.braincouncil.eu/wp-content/uploads/2021/01/Open-Access-Government-October-2019.pdf).

respondent_type: NGO on behalf of 22 pan-European Umbrella Organisations, representing 500+ national organisations
sector: EU Policy, Advocacy, and Education for patients and families affected by neurological conditions both common conditions such as Alzheimer’s disease, Epilepsy, Parkinson’s disease, Multiple Sclerosis, Migraine etc and also rare disease such as Ataxia, Dystonia, ALS, Motor Neuron Disease, Huntington’s disease, myasthenia gravis etc
geography: EU Wide representing 1 in 3 people across Europe
response_text: 1) “European Health Data Space (EHDS): shift from “law passed” to “benefits delivered.” Ireland should drive Council work on implementation readiness: interoperable electronic health records, cross-border continuity of care, and governance that earns trust. Aim to embed meaningful patient access, easy-to-use consent/permissions where relevant, and systematic use of patient-reported outcomes to capture “invisible” symptoms (fatigue, pain, sleep, cognition). EFNA’s findings on disbelief, misdiagnosis, and difficulty describing symptoms show why EHDS must improve the clinical encounter, not just infrastructure. 2) EU Health Technology Assessment (HTA) Joint Clinical Assessments (JCA): make patient relevance non-negotiable. Since JCAs began in January 2025 for oncology medicines and ATMPs, apply to orphan medicine from 2028 and all medicines from 2030, Ireland should prioritise smooth implementation and quality—ensuring endpoints reflect outcomes that matter to neurology patients (function, fatigue, cognition, ability to work, caregiver burden). Aim: strengthen guidance and practice for patient input so that decisions reflect real-world benefit and reduce inequities in access. 3) EU pharmaceutical reform (“pharma package”): access, supply, and innovation balance. Ireland should steer remaining steps so reform improves availability and affordability while sustaining R&D. Aim: champion provisions that reduce shortages and speed access, and ensure incentives align with unmet need (including neurological and rare neurological conditions). 4) EU Biotech Act: accelerate responsibly, with patient benefit and security. Ireland should support an innovation-friendly framework that also addresses ethical, safety, and dual-use/biosecurity concerns. Aim: improve translation for advanced therapies relevant to neurology while maintaining robust oversight and public trust. 5) European Reference Networks (ERNs) and cross-border care: strengthen the “expertise without borders” model. Ireland should promote deeper integration of ERNs into national pathways (referral, reimbursement, digital consults), especially for rare and complex neurological conditions. Aim: make ERNs easier to access, reduce geographic inequity, and support shared clinical guidelines and registries. 6) Brain health research partnership & a European Neurological Health Strategy: from advocacy to action. With the European Partnership for Brain Health planned to start in January 2026, Ireland’s presidency is perfectly timed to align Council discussions on research, implementation science, and health system uptake. Aim: secure cross-DG and cross-Council momentum for an EU-level brain/neurological health strategy that links prevention, care pathways, workforce, and research.

respondent_type: NGO on behalf of 22 pan-European Umbrella Organisations, representing 500+ national organisations
sector: EU Policy, Advocacy, and Education for patients and families affected by neurological conditions both common conditions such as Alzheimer’s disease, Epilepsy, Parkinson’s disease, Multiple Sclerosis, Migraine etc and also rare disease such as Ataxia, Dystonia, ALS, Motor Neuron Disease, Huntington’s disease, myasthenia gravis etc
geography: EU Wide representing 1 in 3 people across Europe
response_text: Make “impact” measurable in daily life. The Council can focus on decisions that change what people experience: earlier diagnosis, fewer crises, better functioning, and real inclusion in work and community. 1) Reduce misdiagnosis and disbelief—systematically. EFNA survey data is stark: 85% say clinicians did not believe symptom severity; 83% did not receive adequate treatment because they were not taken seriously; 67% were initially misdiagnosed; 56% struggled to describe symptoms. Council work can push Member States to embed health literacy and communication training, standardised symptom assessment, and patient-reported outcomes into care pathways—supported by EHDS implementation. 2) Turn EHDS into better care and faster research (with trust). Prioritise practical cross-border use cases: medication lists, diagnostic summaries, imaging, and emergency data—plus federated research access that accelerates neurology studies while protecting privacy. The impact for business is clear too: predictable rules and interoperability reduce duplication and lower innovation costs for SMEs and medtech. 3) Improve access and affordability through HTA coordination. Robust JCAs can reduce duplication, speed national decisions, and support more equitable access—especially when assessments consider outcomes that matter in neurological conditions (fatigue, cognition, function, participation). Faster access reduces long-term disability costs and supports productivity. 4) Strengthen ERNs and rare neurology pathways. For rare/complex neurological diseases, expertise is scarce. Better ERN integration reduces “postcode lotteries,” supports earlier correct diagnosis, and enables shared standards. Communities benefit when people can stay active locally while accessing specialist expertise digitally. 5) Keep people in work and education. EFNA shows 71% adjusted work; only 35% had employer accommodation; 72% saw negative income impact; 74% faced higher living costs. Council conclusions and coordinated initiatives can promote disability inclusion, flexible work supports, anti-discrimination practice in insurance/finance, and caregiver recognition—lifting participation and reducing poverty risk. 6) Invest in prevention and long-term care capacity. Council momentum can align EU4Health, Horizon Europe, and national reforms toward prevention, rehabilitation, and community services. This is where citizens see “EU added value”: less fragmentation, more continuity, and healthier ageing.

respondent_type: NGO on behalf of 22 pan-European Umbrella Organisations, representing 500+ national organisations
sector: EU Policy, Advocacy, and Education for patients and families affected by neurological conditions both common conditions such as Alzheimer’s disease, Epilepsy, Parkinson’s disease, Multiple Sclerosis, Migraine etc and also rare disease such as Ataxia, Dystonia, ALS, Motor Neuron Disease, Huntington’s disease, myasthenia gravis etc
geography: EU Wide representing 1 in 3 people across Europe
response_text: 1) Lead with “EU helps in my everyday life” stories—backed by data. Use a simple narrative: EU cooperation improves care, access, and fairness. Pair personal stories (patients, carers, clinicians) with EFNA survey facts (n,4800 pan EU): stigma 84%, fatigue 85%, misdiagnosis 67%, work disruption 71%, higher living costs 74%. The combination is powerful: emotional truth + credible evidence. 2) Make the Presidency participatory, not performative. Create visible channels for citizen input: regional dialogues (including rural communities), disability-accessible formats, youth and older-person panels, and targeted sessions with patient organisations and caregivers. Publish “you said / we did” summaries monthly to show impact and accountability. 3) Communicate through trusted messengers. Citizens trust local clinicians, community organisations, and patient groups more than institutions. Partner with civil society (including EFNA members), universities, libraries, employers, and local media to explain what dossiers (EHDS, HTA, pharma reform) mean in practice: fewer forms, safer cross-border care, quicker access to medicines, better research. 4) Show transparency on trade-offs. Explain openly how Europe balances privacy with research, affordability with innovation, and national competence with EU coordination. Trust grows when uncertainty and limits are acknowledged. 5) Create simple “Presidency dashboards” focused on outcomes. Instead of listing meetings, track citizen-relevant indicators: steps completed on EHDS implementation guidance, JCA stakeholder involvement quality, ERN accessibility actions, and concrete commitments on brain health research partnership alignment. 6) Celebrate EU membership as shared problem-solving. Frame Ireland’s Presidency as a service to Europeans: convening, brokering, and improving daily life—especially for those whose needs are often invisible. When citizens see their experience reflected (fatigue, pain, stigma, work barriers), they are more likely to feel ownership and pride.
