We think that the following areas should be considered thematic priorities for the Presidency of the Council in 2026: Competitiveness, internal market and economic prosperity Defence and security Trade and economic security Enlargement Fundamental rights, justice and the rule of law (Article 7 TEU procedure) Data protection and digital innovation Green transition and energy security Relationship with the UK

Several policy areas and corresponding legislative proposals should be prioritized, namely: Competitiveness, Internal Market and Economic Prosperity Ireland’s Council Presidency should focus on implementing the agenda of the Letta and Draghi reports, completing the EU internal market and promoting EU economic competitiveness, with the aim of achieving an economy that works for people. Among current legislative initiatives, the EU should develop the 28th regime for European companies, particularly for SMEs. It will help remove internal barriers in the single market, advance the digitalisation of corporate operations and reduce the fragmented nature of corporate regulation – enhancing the productivity of European businesses. Ireland’s Council Presidency should also focus on deepening, consolidating and modernising the Single Market in the areas of telecoms, energy, defence industry and services. Furthermore, the EU should eventually achieve financial integration by creating a Savings and Investment Union (SIU). Ireland, as a key financial hub, could have a significant role in moving forward among others the ‘Market integration package’ for a single market for financial services. Ireland’s Council Presidency should also promote the simplification of the regulatory agenda, but without resulting in de-regulation. It shall develop funding mechanisms to support European public goods. It will be noted that the next EU budget, the 2028-2035 Multi-annual Financial Framework (MFF), is due to be concluded during the Irish Council Presidency, so special attention will need to be devoted to fiscal and budgetary issues, including the introduction of new own resources and future EU debt issuance. Defence and Security Given changes in transatlantic relations, Ireland’s Council Presidency should devote attention to the development of a European defence and technological industrial base. Moreover, given uncertainties about the future role of NATO, and respecting the neutrality of non-aligned EU member states, efforts should be sustained to develop autonomous military capabilities, as well as improve its existing defence governance structures, by strengthening the EU military committee and military planning and conduct capability (MPCC). Ireland’s Council Presidency will need to maintain a strong focus on security and defence in light of Russia’s illegal war of aggression against Ukraine. This includes strengthening the Union’s capacity to provide long-term security guarantees to Ukraine and addressing the implications of Article 42(7) TEU, the mutual defence clause, particularly in the context of closer political and security alignment with partner countries. Trade and Economic Security Ireland’s Council Presidency should promote the conclusion of new trade agreements and the ratification of deals that the EU has already reached, e.g. with Mercosur. Moreover, it should champion free trade drawing on New Zealand’s example (see FIT Partnership, ACCTS, cooperation with CPTPP) in the interest of EU’s competitiveness. At the same time, Ireland’s Council Presidency should combine openness towards trade with a focus on economic security, e.g. by fully implementing the Foreign Direct Investment (FDI) Screening Regulation, the Anti-Coercion Instrument and the other mechanisms in the EU toolbox. Enlargement Ireland’s Council Presidency should prioritise EU enlargement as a strategic policy area, based on a merit-based and differentiated approach. Particular focus could be placed on Montenegro and Albania, while negotiations with Ukraine, Moldova and other Western Balkan candidates continue, alongside work on gradual integration, EU absorption capacity including necessary EU reforms and strict rule-of-law conditionality. Fundamental Rights, Justice and the Rule of Law Ireland’s Council Presidency should seek to advance the Art. 7 TEU procedure on rule of law backsliding in Member States, including with a move to a vote on Art. 7 (2) TEU in the Council, as this allows the EU to show that it is capable of acting in light of rule of law threats from within. Deepening of the relationship with the Council of Europe should also be explored. Data protection and digital innovation Ireland’s Council Presidency should preserve its data protection framework and enforcement laws, despite foreign pressures, and start a conversation on the regulation of data centres in the EU, from a cybersecurity, energy, environmental, and technological sovereignty perspective. Securing data centres’ capacity in the EU has a strategic value, and contributes to the objectives of the digital and green transition. Green transition and energy security Ireland’s Council Presidency should continue the fight against climate change while phasing out of Russian fossil fuels. Ireland’s natural endowments place it in a strong position to lead the development of offshore wind energy, thereby enhancing EU energy security and supporting low-carbon economic growth. Ireland should actively promote the expansion of this sector, advancing offshore wind and other low-carbon technologies, building resilient supply chains with non-EU partners. Ireland is well placed to foster these relationships, supported by its longstanding ties with many developing countries. Relationship with the UK Given its role as the closest neighbour to the UK (now a former EU Member State after Brexit) Ireland should use the Council Presidency as an opportunity to deepen EU-UK relations, e.g. by concluding the SPS agreement, and other sectoral accords envisaged in the May 2025 EU-UK reset.

The Irish Council Presidency would make the most substantial positive impact by focusing on the following areas: For businesses, benefiting the EU’s economy and society, therefore its people and communities: By pushing for the full implementation of the Letta and Draghi reports, including setting up a 28th regime for innovative companies, Ireland would position itself as a start-up hub in Europe. A prominent competitiveness theme will contribute to keeping the EU economy buoyant, creating or preserving employment, lowering costs, raising living standards, and preserving the global position of the EU. For people, businesses and communities’ rights protection: Ireland can have a decisive influence on the lives of Europeans if it seeks to advance the accession of the European Union to the European Convention on Human Rights. This can be achieved both through policy prioritisation within the Council, as well as through Ireland’s membership of the Council of Europe. For people, businesses and communities’ understanding of the post-COVID-19 Recovery funding: As the Irish Council Presidency will coincide with the end of the implementation of the Recovery and Resilience Facility (RRF), it would be the ideal moment to showcase to the public the achievements across all EU Member States and in Ireland (projects, reforms and investments), illustrating them concretely throughout the six policy pillars supported with EU funding. Such an endeavour would support effectiveness of EU policies and accountability.

We have several proposals to ensure communication on the values and benefits of EU membership to the broader public, namely: Establish an EU Council Presidency Strategic Engagement Fund which would allow Ireland to partner with research centres and appropriate think tanks in order to deliver events in person, online or in hybrid form on specific policy priorities which draw upon the expertise of the relevant partner organisation during the term of the Irish Council Presidency, in partnership with, or on behalf of the Irish Government. Ensure campaigns, events and social media presence, in partnership with academic and research communities and civil society actors, e.g. weekly seminars, debates and forums (for example, in cooperation with the Brexit Institute / Dublin European Law Institute). Illustrate the practical benefits of EU membership for Ireland through a video series (focus on one story per county, of something that would not be possible without EU membership). Produce a video series on the Resilience and Recovery Facility final phase with tangible projects financed in Ireland and across the EU. Appoint and liaise with student ambassadors in each university and school to help communicate the benefits of EU membership to younger generations.

The Brexit Institute/Dublin European Law Institute, as a leading research centre & think tank for European law and policy in Dublin, remains open to support the Irish Government during its Council Presidency and to cooperate, e.g. by hosting events with the Government and relevant partners, before and during the Irish Council Presidency. Contact point for this submission [REDACTED UNDER GDPR]

Employment, Social Policy, Health and Consumer Affairs (EPSCO) Reason: Figures released in for July 2025 show official unemployment rates as low as 2.6% in Malta and as high as 10% in Spain and Finland with an overall historic low of 5.9% for the EU.

Unemployment Policy. There are many reasons for the level of unemployment such as Frictional, Seasonal, Cyclical and structural. However, the common economic explanation is that up to 5% unemployment is considered as full employment in an economy. We are leaving behind a portion of society by accepting that 5% are not capable of economic activity. However, this number doesn’t include people who are counted under other initiatives such as Community Employment, TUS or other schemes which are short term activities in terms of the participants. Supports for EU Citizens who are unemployed or under-employed are needed. However, with the numbers involved consistently at low percentages of the workforce, I think we need to redefine these terms. Paying a small benefit to people does not take care of many aspects of human need such as self-worth, mental health and personal well-being as well as gaining new skills. EU Employment policy should aim to place people in suitable settings so that these human factors are also supported. For example people placed on Community Employment and TUS Schemes are doing valuable work for a small top up from basic unemployment payments. These jobs need to be done and as participants accept the payment levels it is my opinion that these people are not as such unemployed. Ireland’s Presidency should push our EU partners to rethink how individuals are supported by offering job placement (usually through local companies either Leader Companies or local companies run by volunteers) as distinct from just a payment. Individuals can transition between this type of supported employment to commercial employment if they wish and opportunities arise. This approach can work alongside other employment initiatives.

It would be a great success if Ireland’s term of the Presidency could put structures in place to redefine employment which will support as many EU Citizens as possible to be recognized for their contribution to society and the option to move between community employment roles and the commercial job market.

EU Membership is seen as being beneficial to citizens in that there are many regulation related issues that would not have come about with the initiative being made at EU level. Unemployment is an area where in my opinion there can be more alignment on policies to support citizens to be valuable in their communities as well as supporting their well-being and mental health. Every EU Citizens has a value and supporting them to reach this and feel a sense of belonging is important.

In January 2025, the EU was estimated to have 450m inhabitants. These are mostly consisting of Household family units with varying numbers. Family Structures have a significant impact on the members. Families where consistent or even generational unemployment is an issue can be left behind. Support for the Individuals within families through gainful activities such as Community Employment where payment for a work placement is where possible given instead of a payment should be a priority. With the EU experiencing historically low unemployment level, this is the time to rethink the approach to supporting the 5% of the EU working age community.

Ireland should prioritise Global Citizenship Education (GCE) as one high-level thematic focus of its 2026 EU Presidency. Within higher education in particular, GCE is a critical and scalable tool for equipping future European citizens, researchers, and professionals with the knowledge, values, and competencies needed to respond to the EU’s most urgent challenges and to advance its long-term strategic goals. GCE aligns directly with two major commitments outlined in the EU Strategic Agenda 2024–2029: to “become the first climate-neutral continent” and to “take the lead in addressing global challenges”. Higher education institutions are uniquely positioned to contribute to these ambitions by cultivating critical thinking, systems understanding, and informed civic engagement across all disciplines. Embedding GCE into teaching, research, and campus life enables students to engage with the root causes of global challenges and to participate meaningfully in shaping sustainable, just, and democratic futures. Positioning GCE as a Presidency priority also strengthens delivery of the “Free and Democratic Europe” pillar. HEIs are central arenas for democratic debate, media literacy, and civic participation; GCE supports these functions by nurturing the ability to: safeguard the rule of law; strengthen democratic resilience and pluralistic debate; uphold academic freedom and civil society space; promote responsible digital engagement and challenge disinformation; foster a culture of global peace, justice, and solidarity. At a time of rising populism, disinformation, xenophobia, polarisation, and armed conflicts GCE can enhance these contributions by grounding education in shared humanity, critical inquiry, respect for diversity, and a deeper understanding of global interdependencies. Given Ireland’s long-standing leadership in GCE, global solidarity, human rights, and human development, the 2026 Presidency is a key opportunity to reassert these priorities at EU level. Ireland should therefore champion the integration of GCE into the negotiations for the 2028–2034 Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF). Allowing GCE to slip from the political agenda would be inconsistent with recent EU Council Conclusions and Recommendations, including on: the transformative role of education for sustainable development and global citizenship; education and training for European values and democratic citizenship; learning for the green transition and sustainable development. Prioritising GCE would also align with the Dublin Declaration on Global Education to 2050, endorsed by 25 Member States at the Dublin Congress co-hosted by Ireland and Luxembourg in 2022.

The policy area of Global Citizenship Education, as set at Council level via the EU Council Conclusions, and at European Commission level within DG-INTPA via the Development Education and Awareness Raising (DEAR) Programme and within DG-EAC, should be a priority for Ireland in the lead up to, during and beyond its Presidency of the Council. In particular, Ireland should ensure that GCE features within the priorities of the new MFF being currently negotiated. GCE must play a core and expanded role as part of this. In the face of an increasingly challenging climate crisis, rising inequality, war, disinformation, and political extremism it is paramount that EU citizens are informed and engaged to address those challenges. GCE fosters the necessary critical thinking, empathy and understanding of issues. Investment in GCE can contribute to ensuring that future of the European Union is not shaped by fear and division, but by inclusion and equality and justice. The new MFF must therefore ensure robust support for civil society organisations and higher education to deliver inclusive, high-quality GCE initiatives. This includes safeguarding funding for working on human rights, gender equality, peace, and accountability, even in contexts facing local political pressures. transparency, sustainability, and predictability in the financial support of Global Citizenship Education programmes, such as DEAR, Erasmus+, and AgoraEU. DEAR remaining a separate funding stream and not be sidelined or absorbed into broader funding envelopes. Improved cohesion and coherence between funding instruments and programmes that support GCE to help strengthen the impact of regional initiatives and foster a consistent EU-wide message in citizenship education. Strengthening these resources is essential for fostering informed, active, and globally responsible EU citizens. Ireland should also prioritise the SDGs and lead the Council in engaging the process for the post-Agenda 2030 framework for sustainable development.

By reaffirming and amplifying its policy and funding support for Global Citizenship Education, given its role in fostering solidarity, critical understanding and global connections and the multiplier effect GCE investment can have. The direct beneficiaries are the millions of learners and citizens reached by quality GCE, bringing democratic values into their communities and engaging throughout their lives to protect these values.
By amplifying the examples of EU values in action, e.g. amplifying and enabling the work of GCE practitioners across all 27 EU Member States.

STAND is a member of IDEA, the Irish Development Education Association, and also one of nine Strategic Partners to Irish Aid for their implementation of the Global Citizenship Education Strategy. Together with the other 8 strategic partners we have contributed to the overall submission from IDEA. This submission is to be seen in this context and in support of the IDEA submission – highlighting the importance of GCE in particular for the higher education sector.

We only propose one, on which we have expertise: Foster a transition towards sustainable, healthy, resilient and fair food and farming systems As Europe faces escalating environmental pressures, strengthening the Union’s capacity to absorb shocks, adapt to change and transition fairly has never been more urgent. Ireland’s Presidency in 2026 presents a unique opportunity to steer the EU towards a more resilient future—one that safeguards our environment, supports vulnerable communities and ensures long-term prosperity across Member States. By placing environmental resilience at the heart of its Presidency priorities, Ireland can help the Union align its policies with the realities of a rapidly changing climate, degraded ecosystems and increasingly fragile resource systems, including those underpinning our food production. Environmental resilience must begin with preparing the EU for the intensifying impacts of climate change. From rising temperatures and severe droughts to floods and biodiversity collapse, Europe’s ecosystems and economies are already feeling the strain. A Presidency focus on accelerating climate adaptation, advancing nature restoration and ensuring climate-proof investment across sectors would help deliver long-term stability. This includes strengthening the EU’s capacity to prevent and manage climate-related risks, improving water resilience strategies, and ensuring that all relevant sectoral policies—from agriculture to transport—contribute to reducing Europe’s vulnerability to environmental disruption. A central pillar of building environmental resilience is delivering a just transition. The shift towards sustainability will only be successful if it is equitable and socially grounded. Many regions and sectors, particularly rural areas, farmers, fishers and low-income communities, are most exposed to both environmental pressures and structural changes. The Presidency can help advance EU-level frameworks that ensure support, training, and fair economic opportunities accompany the transition to more sustainable practices. This involves creating space for social dialogue, supporting diversification in rural regions and ensuring that environmental ambition goes hand in hand with socioeconomic fairness. A resilient Europe must notably rely on robust, sustainable and secure food systems. Environmental degradation, water scarcity and climate extremes increasingly threaten Europe’s capacity to produce food. At the same time, our current production systems, mostly based on intensive farming practices, often exacerbate these pressures. Strengthening food system resilience therefore requires a long-term shift towards models that work with nature, reduce dependency on vulnerable inputs like imported feed and fertilizers and prioritise efficient resource use in the EU. A Presidency committed to enhancing food system resilience could encourage progress on sustainable farm practices, improved animal welfare standards, reduced waste and a more circular use of resources. These measures benefit ecosystems while supporting farmers in maintaining viable livelihoods in the face of environmental and economic volatility. An overarching Presidency priority focused on Strengthening the EU’s Environmental Resilience through a Just Transition would create coherence across Council formations—linking climate, environment, agriculture, energy and social affairs—while providing the strategic clarity the Union needs.

The Irish Presidency of the Council in 2026 will take place at a strategically significant moment for several major EU agriculture policy files. We highlight three priority areas where Ireland can make a decisive contribution in the field of sustainable food systems and animal welfare. 1. Delivering on the long-overdue revision of the EU animal welfare legislation The European Commission is expected to present the long-awaited revision of the EU’s animal welfare legislation during the Irish Presidency. This will be the first substantial update in more than 20 years, including proposals on phasing out cages as per the European Citizens Initiative “End the Cage Age”. Given the broad support among Irish and European citizens and many Member States for more coherent and science-based standards, Ireland will be uniquely placed to shape the early political framing of this legislative process. The Presidency should ensure the Council begins structured, early discussions on the upcoming proposal, dedicating time to exploring key themes with Member States and engaging proactively with stakeholders to clarify expectations, concerns and opportunities. In parallel, the Presidency will be tasked to facilitate progress, and potentially reach an agreement, on the proposal on animal transport. Ireland should help bridge differing Member State positions, promoting science-based standards that improve conditions for animals during transport, especially vulnerable animals such as unweaned calves. Finally, the Irish Presidency should encourage the Member states to achieve better and more uniform enforcement of the EU’s legislative acquis on animal welfare. This would not only enhance animal welfare but address the market distortions that arise from the differing standards of enforcement in member states. 2. Advancing negotiations on the post-2027 Common Agricultural Policy Negotiations on the next CAP will still be ongoing in 2026 and will be entering a crucial phase. A key task for the Presidency will be to facilitate genuine progress towards a CAP that works for farmed animal welfare, Europeans health and farmers income while ensuring the policy remains aligned with the Union’s climate, nature and food security objectives. This requires fostering constructive engagement between Member States on sensitive issues such as farm income support, the greening of the sector and the transition of the livestock systems towards more sustainability and higher animal welfare. 3. Paving the way for more sustainable Livestock and Protein production in Europe The European Commission is also expected to publish a new EU Protein Plan and a Livestock Strategy shortly before the start of the Irish Presidency. These offer important opportunities to accelerate Europe’s shift towards a more extensive and sustainable livestock sector with higher animal welfare outcomes and a more balanced and resilient protein system, one less dependent on imports and more aligned with environmental, health and strategic autonomy objectives. Ireland should prioritize early Council work on these files and consider adopting council conclusions on these matters. On the Livestock Strategy it will be key to transition towards a more extensive and higher animal welfare livestock sector in the EU. It is key that under extensification also species like chickens and pigs are counted and it does not only focus on grazing for cows. For the protein plan we believe it is key that there is a focus on food and feed needs in the EU. We should not just produce more feed in the EU to build of our feed dependency but also support alternative proteins that can prove crucial for our food security.

The Irish Presidency has an opportunity to demonstrate that EU decision-making can deliver concrete, widely shared benefits for citizens, businesses and rural communities. For people, the Presidency can deliver progress on a strongly felt societal demand. Improving animal welfare is one of the rare issues on which Europeans express near-universal agreement (as Eurobarometer surveys consistently show). Public expectations have steadily grown, and citizens want the EU to act decisively to ensure higher, more consistent standards across Member States. By helping prepare and advance the upcoming animal-welfare legislation revision, the Irish Presidency can show that the Council responds to citizens’ priorities and aligns EU action with societal values. This sends a strong signal about an EU that listens and delivers on its promises. As 1,4 million people supported the End The Cage Age European Citizen Initiative and the EU Commission backed by many member states have committed to follow with legislation on this, we believe it crucial strong proposals banning the use of cages for all EU animals will be presented soon. This is crucial not to erode the citizens trust in the EU’s democratic tools. For businesses and farmers, harmonised standards provide long-term strategic advantages. Clear EU-wide rules provide certainty for investment, create a level playing field and enable innovation in higher-welfare production models. EU citizens expect the same animal welfare standards to apply for all products on the EU market, regardless of where they were produced. It is therefore crucial that import requirements are adopted and get enforced in order to prevent animal-based products produced with weaker animal welfare standards to be placed on the EU single market. For rural communities, the Presidency can support an agricultural transition that brings renewed opportunities. More extensive, agroecological and higher-welfare forms of farming offer significant potential to revitalise rural areas. These systems tend to require more skilled labor and due to their lower use of pesticides pose less threats to farmer and rural health outcomes. They also contribute to biodiversity recovery and nature restoration which can reinforce tourism in rural regions. By promoting policy frameworks that incentivise these models, including through CAP negotiations and work on related initiatives such as the Protein Plan and the livestock strategy, the Irish Presidency can lay groundwork for rural areas where farming is both economically viable and socially attractive, helping to address depopulation and generational renewal.

The Irish Presidency can also strengthen public ownership of its Presidency by demonstrating that citizens’ concerns genuinely shape the Union’s agenda. A clear example is the widespread support for stronger animal welfare rules. Championing progress on animal welfare would illustrate the added value of EU membership. Issues such as the treatment of farm animals enjoy strong public support across Europe, yet require coordinated action to deliver meaningful change. As a member state, Ireland can help transform this public demand into concrete, Union-wide policies capable of improving the lives of billions of animals. In Ireland alone, 14,646 citizens signed the End the Cage Age initiative, calling for an end to the caging of farmed animals. By fostering constructive dialogue on the long-awaited revision of EU animal welfare legislation, the Presidency can show these citizens that their voices matter, that Ireland takes their concerns seriously, and that the democratic tools of the European Union truly work. By visibly advancing files that resonate with citizens, the Irish Presidency can show that the EU is not a distant institution but a democratic project in which people’s priorities can be heard, supported, and turned into real outcomes.

In addition to the priorities outlined above, we encourage the Irish Presidency to foster constructive and forward-looking discussions on the future of Europe’s oceans, fisheries and aquaculture. Two major initiatives are expected during or shortly after the term of the Presidency: the Commission’s Vision 2040 for Fisheries and Aquaculture (Q3 2026) and the forthcoming Ocean Act (Q4 2026). Both will shape the long-term direction of EU marine governance and provide important opportunities for coherence across environmental, economic and animal-welfare objectives. The Vision 2040 initiative will set the strategic trajectory for fisheries and aquaculture over the next decade and beyond. We encourage the Presidency to support early, inclusive dialogue on how these sectors can remain competitive while transitioning towards genuinely sustainable and resilient practices. This should include consideration of stock restoration, the transition to low trophic and non-carnivorous aquacultural practices, and fair global supply chains. Crucially, as scientific understanding advances, discussions should also take into account growing evidence on fish welfare, ensuring that future policies reflect both societal expectations and the biological needs of aquatic animals. It is crucial to develop specie specific regulations for the different farmed fish species. Similarly, the Ocean Act will be central to shaping Europe’s broader ocean governance framework. The Presidency can play a valuable role by encouraging Member States to exchange on ambitious approaches to protecting marine ecosystems, strengthening resilience to climate impacts and improving the long-term health of European seas. The Ocean Act must empower Europe to develop a maritime sector anchored in sustainability and strategic autonomy.

Ireland’s upcoming European Presidency provides a significant opportunity to shape the EU’s emerging housing agenda at a time of acute crisis across member states. With the appointment of the first EU Housing Commissioner and a growing consensus on housing affordability and homelessness as crossborder challenges, Ireland is well positioned to lead a Presidency defined by social ambition, practical cooperation and the legislative and policy reform required for meaningful change. Combined, the Affordable Housing Plan and the Anti-Poverty Strategy provide a powerful mandate for the Irish Government to focus on ending homelessness and enhancing the supply of public housing across Europe. Some elements the government should focus on are: 1. Make Housing Affordability a Core EU Social Priority The New Housing Commissioner has signalled a clear focus on affordability, recognising that soaring rents, insufficient public housing and instability in private markets are shared and growing European issues. Ireland should champion a Council agenda that frames housing as vital social infrastructure and a high-functioning housing system as the cornerstone of Europe’s social fabric and economic progression. The Presidency should advocate for a coordinated EU approach to expanding affordable and social housing, building on current momentum. Eight years ago, the EU made housing a social right, it is time to activate this pledge. Ensure that public housing is accessible to people experiencing homelessness From the Irish experience, we know that additional social and affordable housing does not automatically reduce homelessness. During Housing for All, more than 130,000 public homes were procured. In the same period, homelessness increased to unprecedented levels. Public housing, in and of itself, does not reduce homelessness. Housing supply must reflect the needs of homeless households. For example, in Ireland we need one-bed units for single adults and four/five bed houses for large families, cohorts that spend the longest time in emergency accommodation. During its tenure, Ireland must work towards gearing public housing for households who are homeless, in terms of property type and in terms of ringfencing housing allocations. EU agreement on this principle and the development of pan-European strategies to link public housing to homeless households will reduce overall homeless figures. Lead on Ending Homelessness Through an EU-wide Implementation Framework The Lisbon Declaration (2021), which Ireland signed, committed Member States to ending homelessness by 2030. Currently, with rising homeless figures in Ireland and across the EU, this seems out of reach. But homelessness is solvable. Ireland can use the Presidency to transform the declaration from aspiration to reality by leading the development of a practical implementation and monitoring framework. This should include: Common indicators on homelessness and housing exclusion. Targeted approaches to preventing homelessness and reoccurring homelessness: universal prevention, upstream prevention, crisis-stage prevention, emergency-stage prevention and repeat prevention. A shared European data platform to support evidence-based policymaking.

Housing and homelessness are intrinsically linked, with the current housing crisis creating rising levels of homelessness. In the last decade, house prices across Europe have increased by 24%, while rents in major cities have almost doubled during the same period. While bound together, solving homelessness requires targeted measures beyond housing relating to health, social inclusion, and life skills. Some policy areas the Irish presidency should focus on include: Create an EU-level Housing First Framework Housing First works in Ireland, in Europe and across North America. It has universally high success rates in supporting tenants to maintain housing. Households traditionally considered difficult to house continue to live independently in Housing First tenancies. Much of this is due to the integrated approach from statutory and voluntary organisations across housing, health and social inclusion. The European Commission already prioritise evidence, mutual learning and finance for homelessness; the Irish Council Presidency can convert learning and momentum into solid Council recommendations and encourage national strategies aligned to Housing First. Ireland should aim to develop Council recommendation endorsing Housing First as a priority approach to ending homelessness, strengthening the European Platform on Combatting Homelessness (EPOCH). Develop a common definition of homelessness and data gathering The Irish presidency should commit to developing a common EU definition of homelessness, a common data-gathering framework for homelessness (indicators, methodology, profile etc.) and a roadmap to end rough sleeping across Europe. This will help us to understand why people rough sleep (capacity, exclusions, vulnerabilities etc.) and enable Europe to finance targeted and evidence-based responses to ending homelessness. Reduce bottlenecks that block supply Cumbersome planning rules raise costs and elongate delivery times for housing delivery. The Presidency can convene Member States to agree common best practice and encourage faster (and greener) planning rules. Under Ireland’s presidency the EU Council should commence a process to streamline social and affordable housing permissions, with mutual recognition of planning best practices and guidance on balancing speed, transparency and environmental protection. Promote an EU approach to short-term rental lettings and platforms Holiday and short-term letting across Europe, particularly large European cities, reduces the supply and increases the cost of long-term rentals. In Ireland, during the Covid pandemic, there was a significant decline in family homelessness (particularly in Dublin), as short-term letting ground to a halt, with landlords subsequently providing transitional tenancies to the DRHE for families experiencing homelessness. The Council, working with other EU structures, should focus on a common approach to reporting and capping levels of short-term letting across Europe, to create a sustainable and accessible rental market for the citizens of larger European cities. Building on the EU Short-Term Rental Regulations, Ireland can prioritise implementation and monitoring. In brief, Ireland should: Secure a Council recommendation on Housing First targets and implementation Create a common definition of and data gathering strategies of homelessness Streamline affordable and social planning rules across the EU Promote and EU approach to short-term rental and letting platforms

A functioning housing system is essential for a thriving EU, work-force mobility, prosperity and social fairness. Extensive and growing rates of homelessness undermine the social fabric of member states and deprive citizens of their social and human rights. By using Ireland’s EU presidency to reduce homelessness and accelerate the supply of public housing, we will create social solidarity, inclusion and a thriving economy across Europe. The Irish Presidency in 2026 can secure substantial and tangible benefits for Europeans by steering the Council towards actions that directly improve housing affordability and reduce homelessness. While the Lisbon Treaty places primary responsibility for housing with Member States, the EU can play a crucial enabling role through funding, coordination, and evidence-based policy. The Presidency can maximise impact through some core priorities. 1. Ending homelessness through a common EU framework and common data-gathering Rough sleeping and hidden homelessness remain growing challenges in multiple Member States. Building on Ireland’s national Housing First expertise, the Presidency can secure a Council recommendation endorsing Housing First as the preferred approach, supported by preventative measures and integrated health and social services. Establishing an EU-wide statistical framework on homelessness—common definitions, indicators and reporting cycles—would allow the Council and the Commission to track progress, direct funding more effectively, and strengthen accountability. Better data, combined with shared best practice, can materially improve outcomes for vulnerable communities. 2. Supporting communities and local economies by improving rental market fairness Short-term rental growth has reduced long-term rental supply in many European cities, affecting workers, local businesses and neighbourhood cohesion. The Irish Presidency can lead Council discussions on platform transparency, registration systems and tax cooperation—non-binding but practical steps that help Member States manage local housing pressures while supporting sustainable tourism and digital-platform innovation.

Explain the Everyday Benefits of EU Membership Translate EU policies into relatable impacts: consumer rights, travel freedoms, housing investment, green transition, youth opportunities. Use Storytelling and Real Examples Highlight EU-supported housing projects, community initiatives, and lived experiences that demonstrate the value of EU membership. Engage Young People Use creative campaigns, schools' outreach, competitions and social media to connect young people to EU themes. Ensure Transparency and Participation Publish clear Presidency progress updates and invite input during policy discussions.

NOVAS welcomes the opportunity to contribute to Ireland’s Presidency programme. The rise in housing insecurity and homelessness is a European-wide issue that requires a European response. Ireland’s Presidency of the EU Council can help to build on work already begun by the Commission and support member states to address the issue with common, evidence-based strategies and mutually agreed frameworks. NOVAS will support the Government in its efforts to prioritise this issue through frontline, lived and living experience, data and policy recommendations. Ireland has the experience and credibility to lead an ambitious Presidency that strengthens social cohesion, economic competitiveness and wellbeing across the EU.

Friends of the Irish Environment (FIE) recommends Resilience as the overarching theme for Ireland’s 2026 Presidency, expressed through a slogan such as “Resilient Together.” This theme reflects growing environmental, social and economic volatility across Europe and highlights the need to strengthen the natural, social, territorial and democratic systems that sustain wellbeing. Across the EU, citizens are already experiencing the consequences of climate change, biodiversity collapse, pollution and unstable supply chains. Communities affected by storms, flooding and environmental degradation continue to demonstrate solidarity, adaptability and creativity. These experiences show that resilience emerges from strong ecosystems, empowered communities and effective public institutions working together. Ireland’s Presidency can therefore provide leadership by advancing a positive, future-oriented programme grounded in three mutually reinforcing priorities. 1. Environmental and Ecological Resilience Healthy ecosystems underpin climate stability, food security, water quality and economic prosperity. Strengthening environmental resilience should therefore be a core priority of the Presidency. Ireland should champion full implementation of the European Green Deal, including nature restoration, clean water, zero-pollution objectives, climate adaptation and biodiversity protection. A resilient Europe requires robust environmental law, grounded in scientific evidence and applied consistently across Member States. As political pressure grows to weaken EU environmental rules, Ireland can lead by ensuring that regulatory “simplification” enhances clarity and enforceability rather than reducing environmental safeguards. A Presidency focused on ecological resilience also provides an opportunity to embed nature-based solutions, sustainable land-use planning, climate-proofed infrastructure and long-term adaptation across all sectors. This reflects the growing recognition that environmental protection is central to societal and economic security. 2. Democratic, Community and Territorial Resilience Environmental resilience depends on strong democracies, engaged citizens and transparent decisionmaking. Communities must be supported to participate meaningfully in shaping the transitions affecting them. Ireland should use its Presidency to strengthen public access to environmental information, participation and justice, in line with the Aarhus Convention. Protecting civic space, supporting environmental defenders and ensuring open governance across the EU are essential for building trust and enabling fair, science-based decision-making. A community-centred approach also requires recognising the crucial role of local and regional authorities in delivering climate action, nature protection, spatial planning, sustainable mobility and place-based development. Strengthening multi-level governance and territorial cohesion will improve environmental outcomes, support healthy placemaking and reinforce democratic legitimacy. 3. Economic and Just Transition Resilience A resilient Europe requires a fair, well-funded and legally certain transition to a sustainable economy. The Presidency should support adequate EU funding for climate action, biodiversity restoration, rural development, innovation, skills and community-led transition. Rather than deregulation, Europe’s businesses and communities need predictable, science-based rules that support innovation, competitiveness and long-term planning. Ireland can play a leadership role in ensuring the next Multiannual Financial Framework and EU packages—such as the Circular Economy Act and the 2040 climate framework—maintain environmental integrity while delivering visible benefits for people. A Just Transition focused on fairness, participation, regional opportunity and community wellbeing will strengthen Europe’s social fabric and economic stability.

FIE propose a particular focus on the following policy and legislative areas and outcomes: Simplification must reinforce, not weaken, EU standards The Commission’s current focus on simplifying EU regulation presents a genuine opportunity to improve clarity, accessibility and administrative efficiency. As recognised in EU Treaties and recent jurisprudence, however, simplification must remain entirely consistent with the Union’s obligations under Articles 3(3) TEU, 11 and 191 TFEU, and Article 37 of the Charter to ensure a high level of environmental protection and continuous improvement. Any reform must therefore maintain or strengthen environmental integrity and legal certainty. Regulatory certainty supports innovation and competitiveness Clear, evidence-based standards benefit responsible businesses, investors and citizens. While some actors use the political moment to advocate broad deregulation, EU institutions and experts continue to underline that weakening standards increases uncertainty, rewards laggards and penalises those already investing in the transition. Judicial findings across Europe also show that vague or diluted criteria lead to inconsistent and often unlawful decision-making. Simplification should therefore enhance the clarity, enforceability and scientific grounding of rules rather than dilute them. A leadership opportunity for the Irish Presidency The Irish Presidency has both a responsibility and an opportunity to uphold the EU’s tradition of forwardlooking, high-quality standard-setting. By supporting simplification that improves usability while preserving environmental integrity, Ireland can help safeguard public trust, provide regulatory certainty for businesses, and reinforce the EU’s long-term sustainability and competitiveness. A future-proof Multiannual Financial Framework The next MFF must ensure adequate, dedicated funding to meet existing legal obligations and societal needs. This includes: Nature restoration, delivered in partnership with farmers, communities and environmental stakeholders; Economically, socially and environmentally sustainable agriculture, including fully funded rural development programmes; Active citizenship and civil society, including continued support for LIFE, recognising the value of public participation affirmed in recent ECtHR jurisprudence These investments enhance resilience, compliance and community-led transition. Circular Economy Act: Practical benefits for people and business A well-designed Circular Economy Act can deliver visible gains: reducing built-in obsolescence, strengthening the right to repair, enhancing supply chain security, and supporting more sustainable resource use. Clear, measurable, science-based criteria—aligned with existing EU law—will help ensure the Act drives innovation and consumer confidence. 2040 Climate Package: Continuity, clarity and fairness The 2040 climate framework will shape Europe’s pathway to climate neutrality. Consistent with recent rulings such as Klimaseniorinnen, EU climate governance must rely on quantified pathways, timely action and structured engagement with scientific evidence. The package should therefore preserve the integrity of the existing regime, avoid creating new loopholes, and deliver a fair, transparent transition that addresses citizens’ material concerns—both legally and socially essential.

The most substantial positive impact the Irish Presidency can make is to ensure that EU decision-making is grounded in the lived realities of Europe’s people, regions, and local communities. This requires embedding the principles of subsidiarity, territorial cohesion, environmental resilience, and democratic participation across the Council’s work. When local and regional actors are involved early and meaningfully, EU policy becomes more effective, better implemented, and more trusted. A first priority should be strengthening multi-level governance. Local and regional authorities are central to delivering the EU’s climate, biodiversity, spatial planning, mobility, water, housing, and public service objectives. The Presidency can champion their systematic involvement in shaping national and EU positions, ensuring that territorial expertise informs negotiations. This would help produce legislation that is practical, proportionate, implementable and responsive to different regional starting points. Supporting structured dialogue with civil society, social partners, community organisations and business networks will further embed democratic legitimacy and improve policy outcomes. The Presidency also has an opportunity to reinforce environmental and ecological resilience as foundations of long-term wellbeing and economic stability. Council processes should uphold the EU’s high environmental standards and avoid any dilution that would undermine public health, biodiversity, climate mitigation or adaptation. Clear, science-based and enforceable rules provide regulatory certainty—benefiting responsible businesses, investors and communities—and support a fair and competitive internal market. Embedding environmental integrity across all Council work will help safeguard water resources, restore nature, improve air quality and strengthen Europe’s ability to withstand growing climate risks. A third area of impact is advancing a fair, well-funded and legally predictable transition. The Presidency should work to secure an ambitious Multiannual Financial Framework that provides sufficient resources for climate action, nature restoration, sustainable agriculture, regional development, innovation, skills and community-led transition. Adequate, targeted funding enhances resilience, supports competitiveness, and ensures that no region or community is left behind as Europe accelerates towards climate neutrality. The Presidency can also add value by promoting coherence across EU initiatives—particularly the Circular Economy Act and the 2040 climate framework—to ensure they reinforce rather than undermine one another. This means championing policies that reduce waste, strengthen the right to repair, enhance supply chain resilience, and deliver climate action in a way that is fair, transparent and attentive to people’s material concerns. Finally, the work of the Council can make a major difference by reinforcing open governance, transparency and access to information. Ensuring strong public rights to participation and justice strengthens trust, supports evidence-based decisions, and empowers communities to play an active role in shaping Europe’s future. By combining territorial expertise, strong environmental governance, subsidiarity, and a fair transition, the Irish Presidency can help deliver EU policies that produce meaningful, lasting benefits for people, businesses and communities across all regions.

The most effective way to communicate the values and benefits of EU membership is to demonstrate how EU law and policy have already tangibly improved life in Ireland and other countries. The upcoming Presidency should highlight concrete, relatable examples that show the EU as a practical force for cleaner environments, stronger rights, and healthier communities. Environmental protection offers some of the clearest examples. EU nature legislation has transformed how Ireland safeguards its bogs, woodlands and coastlines, protecting landscapes that are central to national identity. The Birds and Habitats Directives have created binding duties to protect important species and habitats, resulting in stronger oversight, clearer standards, and greater accountability when environmental rules are not followed. The new Nature Restoration Law goes further by requiring the active repair of damaged ecosystems, offering long-term benefits for biodiversity, climate resilience, and community well-being. Another significant achievement is the improvement of water quality. EU water and marine laws have raised expectations for Ireland’s rivers, lakes and coastal waters, driving investment in wastewater treatment and requiring action on pollution sources. These directives have helped revive rivers, make beaches safer, and protect drinking water, ensuring that environmental quality is not a luxury but a legal right. EU planning rules have also empowered people and communities. Requirements for Environmental Impact Assessments (EIA) and Strategic Environmental Assessments (SEA) ensure that major projects are properly evaluated before they proceed. These rules embed sustainability into infrastructure and landuse decisions and guarantee public participation, with courts reinforcing that communities must be meaningfully heard. This helps citizens understand that the EU is not distant—it is shaping decisions that affect towns, housing, transport and local environments directly. Equally important is the EU’s role in promoting transparency. The Access to Information on the Environment Directive enables anyone to request environmental information from public bodies. This right has strengthened accountability, supported investigative journalism, and empowered communities to identify environmental issues, challenge poor decision-making, and demand better outcomes. It exemplifies the EU’s commitment to openness and democratic participation. The EU has also driven major improvements in waste management. Past shortcomings in Ireland’s waste and landfill practices were addressed only after EU intervention, resulting in stricter regulations, safer waste handling and cleaner communities. This demonstrates that EU enforcement can turn local concerns into national progress, making visible improvements in environmental quality and public health. Communicating these successes should rely on accessible storytelling, not technical language. Using real locations, communities, and stories will show that EU action has shaped Ireland’s natural environment, public services and democratic rights. Citizen ownership can be deepened through regional events, workshops, school and university engagements, cultural initiatives, and public dialogues that invite people to participate in shaping Ireland’s Presidency priorities. Ultimately, the message should be simple: EU membership has delivered cleaner water, protected nature, strengthened public rights, improved planning, and supported transparency. Ireland’s Presidency is an opportunity to highlight these achievements and involve citizens directly in shaping the next chapter of Ireland’s place in Europe.

As Ireland prepares to assume the Presidency of the Council of the European Union in 2026, we must strengthen domestic compliance and governance with EU environmental law. Ireland is currently subject to a significant number of infringement proceedings for failures to fully transpose, implement, or enforce EU directives. These include active referrals to the Court of Justice concerning wastewater treatment obligations, delays in revising river basin and flood risk management plans, and insufficient protection of priority habitats. Additional proceedings remain ongoing in areas such as renewable energy permitting, environmental assessment, nature conservation, and water pollution control. The scale and persistence of these actions highlight structural shortcomings that require urgent and coordinated attention. A Member State entrusted with chairing the Council’s legislative work must demonstrate adherence to the Union’s legal framework. Effective stewardship depends on credibility: a Presidency that guides negotiations on climate, nature restoration, pollution prevention, and circular-economy measures must be seen as upholding these same standards at home. Continued non-compliance risks undermining Ireland’s influence, eroding trust in environmental governance, and exposing the State to financial penalties and reputational harm. Strengthening compliance should therefore be considered an integral component of Ireland’s Presidency preparation. Key actions include adequate resourcing, especially of areas subject to long term underinvestment such as sewage treatment and nature protection; reinforcing administrative capacity within departments and regulatory bodies; improving coordination with local authorities responsible for implementation; ensuring transposition processes are timely, complete and scientifically robust; and embedding transparency, public participation and access to justice, consistent with the Aarhus Convention. Many of Ireland’s current infringements reflect delays, inconsistent application of standards, or gaps in monitoring and enforcement—issues that can be effectively addressed through clearer governance structures, proactive planning and adequate resourcing. Enhanced compliance will also produce tangible benefits for communities, businesses and the environment. Full and consistent implementation of EU environmental law supports cleaner water, healthier ecosystems, climate resilience, and a predictable and fair regulatory environment. It reduces long-term public expenditure by preventing environmental degradation, protecting health, and avoiding litigation. Moreover, a coherent compliance framework underpins a just transition by ensuring that environmental rules apply equally and transparently across sectors and regions. As Ireland enters a period of heightened responsibility within the EU, demonstrating leadership through strong domestic governance is both necessary and advantageous. By resolving long-standing infringements, improving enforcement systems, and ensuring that environmental decisions are grounded in clear evidence and meaningful public participation, Ireland can show its commitment to the Union’s values and reinforce the legitimacy of its Presidency. The 2026 Presidency will offer Ireland a critical platform to highlight the benefits of ambitious, enforceable environmental standards and to advance resilient, science-based policymaking across the Union. To use that platform effectively, Ireland must ensure its implementation framework fully aligns with EU law and meets a high standard of environmental protection. Strengthening domestic compliance is therefore essential to the credibility, authority, and success of the Irish Presidency.

Ending Discrimination Against Cancer Survivors (EDACS) welcomes this crucial opportunity to contribute to the development of the Priorities and Policy Programme for Ireland’s Presidency of the Council of the European Union in 2026. I commend Ireland’s proactive stance in developing its own legislation on the Right to Be Forgotten (RTBF) through the Central Bank (Amendment) Bill 2025, as already implemented in France, Belgium, the Netherlands, Portugal, Romania, Spain, Cyprus, Italy, Slovenia, as well as Monaco. Building upon this timely domestic development, which uniquely positions Ireland to lead the effort to ensure that all cancer survivors are no longer penalised for their medical history, I urge the Irish Presidency to focus on Cancer Survivorship and the Quality of Life of Cancer Survivors. Thanks to the tremendous progress of medicine in the last decades, cancer is no longer a death sentence, and more citizens are able to enjoy a good quality of life. The proportions of cancer survivors are increasing of 3% on a yearly basis and in 2020 more than 20 million cancer survivors have been estimated in Europe. However, despite these significant medical advancements, these individuals frequently face systemic and often invisible discrimination. The latter manifest in critical areas such as access to financial services (e.g., life insurance, mortgages, credit), employment opportunities, and even social integration. Such barriers undermine their ability to fully reintegrate into society, contribute to the economy, and live lives free from the punitive consequences of a past illness. A major provision to improve the quality of life of cancer survivors is the Right To Be Forgotten. The latter allows cancer survivors to no longer be penalised for their medical history. It mandates that banks and insurers disregard oncological medical history five years after the end of treatment, provided there is no relapse. This ensures that financial assessments are based on current health status, enabling survivors to regain equitable access to financial services essential for social reintegration. During its Presidency, I encourage Ireland to place Cancer Survivorship as a high-level thematic priority, to directly address a critical societal challenge impacting millions of EU citizens. This priority aligns with fundamental European values of social justice, equality, and health equity, but also touches upon economic participation, consumer protection, and the functioning of the single market by removing discriminatory barriers.

The Right to Be Forgotten has gained increasing recognition at the EU level as a key instrument to combat financial discrimination against cancer survivors. Although progress has been made, notably through, the recognition of the RTBF in the Beating Cancer Plan, and the inclusion of the latter in the Consumer Credit Directive, much remains to be done to harmonise and ensure legislation in all Member States and beyond. Addressing Cancer Survivorship and the Right To Be Forgotten, aligns perfectly with the broader European commitment outlined in Europe's Beating Cancer Plan (EBCP). Launched with the objective to tackle the entire cancer pathway, the EBCP explicitly recognises the need to improve the quality of life for cancer survivors and directly calls for action on the Right to Be Forgotten under its sixth flagship 'Improving the quality of life of cancer patients and survivors'. The Irish Presidency should continue to capitalise on the strategic framework and political impetus of the European Cancer Beating Plan (EBCP), ensuring its robust and continued implementation at the EU level. This includes driving the harmonisation of the end of financial discrimination against cancer survivors, especially considering the initiative laid out in the Plan, namely a Code of Conduct, has failed. As of December 2025, nine EU Member States (France, Belgium, the Netherlands, Portugal, Romania, Spain, Cyprus, Italy, Slovenia) have adopted binding legal measures around the 'Right to Be Forgotten' (RTBF). In addition to Ireland and Luxembourg’s ongoing legislative efforts for the Right to Be Forgotten, three more Member States (Denmark, Greece, and Czech Republic) have introduced non-legislative measures such as codes of conduct. Beyond the EBCP, we encourage the Irish Presidency to support the effective implementation of the Consumer Credit Directive and to advocate for a reconsideration of the revision of the Mortgage Credit Directive in order to include the RTBF with a five-year limit applicable to all cancer survivors without relapse. More broadly, the Irish Presidency should advocate for the inclusion of anti-discrimination safeguards for cancer survivors across all EU initiatives that address financial exclusion, barriers to adoption, and obstacles to workforce reintegration. Most importantly, besides European frameworks, the Irish Presidency, building upon the legitimacy stemming from its domestic legislative development for the Right To Be Forgotten, should push its counterpart Member States for the adoption of national legislation guaranteeing a single, reasonable timeframe of five years after the completion of treatment, free from cancer-related discrimination. This legislation should be based on proven best practices, such as the French and Belgian models, and should include exception frameworks (with shorter timeframes) for certain types of cancer, adapted to local realities and reflecting ongoing medical progress.

The Irish Presidency holds an important opportunity to advance policies impacting and improving the lives of over 20 million cancer survivors across Europe. Indeed, while cancer is no longer a life sentence, recovery often entails lifelong discrimination due to medical history records. Difficulties securing employment, accessing vital financial services such as life insurance, travel insurance, loans, and mortgages, create an unjust double sentence. Such discriminations jeopardise the European values of equality, non-discrimination, and social inclusion, and undermine key objectives of fostering an inclusive Single Market, combating poverty, upholding consumer rights, ensuring fair working conditions and social protection. The recognition of RTBF is therefore not a matter of empathy; it is a matter of justice and human rights for European citizens.

organisation: Food Allergy Centre Padua University Hospital
sector: Health Sector : I am an allergist and a pediatrician
response_text: Taking into account the current geopolitical and socioeconomic context in Europe, we recommend that Ireland prioritise Health Protection, Citizen Safety, and Resilient Societies as core themes of its 2026 Presidency. Serious allergies and anaphylaxis are rising across Europe and place a growing burden on individuals, schools, workplaces, and public services. Addressing them fits naturally within broader objectives to protect citizens’ wellbeing and reduce preventable health risks. A Re s i l i ent and P r ep ar ed Eur op e The EU must be equipped to respond to emergencies—whether acute health events, natural disasters, or public safety threats. This requires harmonised emergency response systems, stronger community- level preparedness, and cross-border cooperation. Ireland is one of the few Member States that has taken concrete steps to improve preparedness for serious allergic reactions, including allowing pharmacists to supply emergency medicines without a prescription during anaphylactic events. This national practice demonstrates effective emergency readiness and provides a model for EU-level policy coordination, which could inform upcoming initiatives under the European Health Union framework aimed at strengthening preparedness, prevention, and rapid response across Member States. A P e opl e - C entr ed Uni on th at Pro tec t s Embedding people-centred principles into EU policymaking ensures that vulnerable populations and individuals at risk of medical emergencies are not left behind. The Presidency could advance reducing health inequalities across the EU, highlighting uneven access to diagnosis, specialist care, and emergency response protocols. Positioning timely care for serious allergies and anaphylaxis within this agenda demonstrates a commitment to practical, measurable improvements in patient safety and inclusion, while protecting citizens’ rights to safety in everyday environments such as schools, childcare centres, workplaces, and public venues. 3 . A Fut ur e - Ori ente d E urop e Built o n In no v ation an d Coll abor a t i on Ireland’s strong reputation in digital innovation offers an opportunity to promote Digital Innovation for Health, leveraging the European Health Data Space and interoperable, patient-centred tools. For individuals at risk of serious allergic reactions, seamless access to medical information across borders can prevent emergencies and support the free movement of people. The Presidency can also prioritise harmonised awareness-raising, institutional readiness, and capacity building, ensuring schools, businesses, and public institutions are equipped and trained to respond effectively to life-threatening health incidents.

organisation: Food Allergy Centre Padua University Hospital
sector: Health Sector : I am an allergist and a pediatrician
response_text: Ireland could use its Presidency to champion health resilience, citizen protection, and emergency preparedness, leveraging its national leadership in anaphylaxis response as a model for EU coordination. Key priorities include: Health Protection and Emergency Preparedness Serious allergies and anaphylaxis present a growing public-health challenge. The Presidency could: Promote timely access to emergency medicines, building on Ireland’s approach where pharmacists If adequately trained can supply life-saving treatment without prescription. Encourage harmonised school and public-venue preparedness, using Ireland as an example. Relevant upcoming EU initiative: Global health resilience initiative (non-legislative, Q2 2026) – to strengthen EU capacity for rapid response to health crises. Digital Innovation for Health Cross-border emergencies require seamless access to patient data: Promote the European Health Data Space for secure, interoperable sharing of health information, enabling faster response to anaphylactic events across borders. Support digital tools for citizen-centred care, enhancing emergency response and patient safety. 3. Reducing Health Inequalities and Strengthening Citizen Rights The Presidency could advance equitable access to emergency care and citizen-centred policy: Link preparedness to strengthening the Child Guarantee (non-legislative, Q2 2026) and Citizens omnibus (legislative, Q4 2026), ensuring children in schools, childcare centres, and communities are protected and have their rights effectively enforced. Promote intergenerational fairness through the Intergenerational fairness strategy (non- legislative, Q1 2026), ensuring emergency preparedness and health access benefit current and future generations equally. Highlight Ireland’s model as a practical, replicable approach for other Member States. Objectives Establish a model for EU-level anaphylaxis and emergency response coordination, based on best practices of Ireland. Ensure equitable access to life-saving treatments across the EU. Promote digital innovation for preparedness, information sharing, and cross-border patient care. Strengthen citizen rights and intergenerational fairness, ensuring public health policies reflect social equity. Position health resilience as a pillar of EU citizen safety and social cohesion, demonstrating tangible improvements in public health readiness. By focusing on these targeted initiatives, Ireland can use its Presidency to deliver practical, measurable impacts on citizen safety, health equity, and cross-border emergency preparedness while reinforcing the EU’s social and legal frameworks.

organisation: Food Allergy Centre Padua University Hospital
sector: Health Sector : I am an allergist and a pediatrician
response_text: The Irish Presidency has the potential to deliver significant, tangible impact for EU citizens by advancing health resilience and consumer safety. For individuals with serious allergies, policies that improve emergency response, access to medicines, and accurate allergen information can be life-saving. For people, expanded access to emergency treatment, including pharmacy-enabled emergency supply across the EU, enhances safety in daily life. Citizens with serious allergies would be better protected in schools, workplaces, sports facilities, cultural venues, and during cross-border travel. For businesses, harmonised allergen-labelling and staff-training expectations reduce regulatory uncertainty, simplify compliance, and improve consumer trust by fostering safer public environments. For communities and institutions, EU-supported readiness measures ,such as common school protocols, public-venue guidelines, and accessible training ,would significantly reduce preventable emergencies, supporting all three Alliance objectives. Replicating Ireland’s best practice on emergency medicine access would ensure that life-saving intervention is available regardless of where a reaction occurs, reducing inequalities across Member States.

organisation: Food Allergy Centre Padua University Hospital
sector: Health Sector : I am an allergist and a pediatrician
response_text: Ireland has a strong opportunity to communicate the value of EU membership by focusing on everyday benefits and practical improvements that resonate directly with citizens. The 2026 Presidency can show how EU cooperation protects people, strengthens communities, and makes daily life safer—particularly in areas such as emergency preparedness for serious allergies and anaphylaxis. Highlight Practical Examples of EU Solidarity Citizens understand the EU best when they see clear, relatable outcomes. Ireland can communicate EU values by highlighting how cooperation improves safety and wellbeing, for example: Safer environments in schools, restaurants, transport and public venues. Shared health information that makes travel within the EU safer and more predictable. Harmonised allergen-labelling rules that protect consumers wherever they are. More consistent access to emergency support for serious allergic reactions. Ireland’s own approach—allowing pharmacists to supply emergency treatment during a serious allergic reaction—provides a concrete example of national leadership that improves citizen safety. Propose Council Recommendations on Emergency Readiness To strengthen public understanding of the EU’s benefits, Ireland could lead on a visible, citizen-centred initiative: Develop Council Recommendations on broader readiness and access to emergency treatment for serious allergy and anaphylaxis. This would help encourage Member States to: Improve preparedness in schools, public venues, workplaces, and transport hubs. Ensure trained responders are available across community settings. Reduce inequalities in access to time-sensitive, life-saving care. Such an initiative is easy for citizens to relate to, directly improves safety, and demonstrates EU cooperation in a human, practical way. A simple message: the EU protects people By showcasing initiatives that make everyday life safer, including better emergency preparedness for serious allergic reactions, the Irish Presidency can reinforce a clear message: EU cooperation delivers real, practical benefits for families, children, workers, and communities. This people-centred framing will strengthen public trust, build ownership, and demonstrate the concrete value of Ireland’s leadership at EU level.

As a Tourism Innova5on Programme Manager with responsibility for delivering the EU Commission 2024 European Capital of Smart Tourism Award I fully understand and appreciate the benefits of being Irish. It is because of my experience that I firmly believe that Ireland should play to its EU strengths and Global sov power and focus on the theme of Tourism before, during and aver its Government takes the honour of being fully responsible for the EU Presidency. By including and ini5a5ng a Tourism theme during the first of the try-country presidency it presents a unique opportunity for all three countries and its elected officials to prosper. They reflect the Irish spirit—forward-looking, community-minded, and globally engaged—and ensure that Europe’s tourism sector is truly FUTURE READY TOURISM: UNITE, ELEVATE, INNOVATE, and ACCELERATE toward a resilient, sustainable European tourism model.

Tourism policy.
