Communicating the values and benefits of EU membership to citizens—and ensuring they feel genuine ownership of Ireland’s upcoming 2026 Presidency—requires an approach that is grounded in Irish identity, community engagement, and clear storytelling about the EU’s relevance to daily life. The EU’s Strategic Agenda 2024–2029 emphasises resilience, competitiveness, sustainability and skills; these themes deeply resonate with the concerns of Irish people, from rural communities to vibrant urban centres. To connect citizens meaningfully with Ireland’s Presidency, communication must make these priorities tangible, relatable, and locally rooted. Tell Ireland’s EU story in an Irish voice People respond to narratives that feel authentic and familiar. Ireland’s EU journey—from peace building to economic transformation, from workers’ rights to regional development—should be retold through voices that citizens trust: community leaders, small business owners, tourism workers, artists, farmers, students. Communicating the Presidency can draw from the Irish tradition of storytelling, making complex EU policy accessible through personal experience, local case studies, and cultural expression. Show—not just tell—the benefits of EU membership Citizens engage most when they see real-world impact. Ireland can highlight local successes linked to EU cooperation: sustainable tourism initiatives, skills and training supports, environmental protection, research partnerships, heritage preservation, and rural development. Pop-up exhibitions, travelling “EU in Your Community” roadshows, and partnerships with libraries, GAA clubs, and festivals can bring the EU into everyday public spaces. Create participatory, citizen-led Presidency initiatives A sense of ownership grows when people are active participants rather than observers. Ireland can host allisland citizens’ dialogues, youth assemblies, and community innovation challenges linked to Presidency themes such as sustainability, tourism, and digital transition. Schools and universities could engage through EU Presidency learning modules, student ambassador programmes, and project competitions tied to real EU policy questions. This supports the EU Strategic Agenda’s priority on skills and civic engagement. Celebrate Ireland’s role in shaping Europe’s future Citizens should see Ireland not just as a beneficiary of the EU, but as a contributor. Communicating flagship Presidency initiatives—such as the Dublin Declaration on Future Ready Tourism, the European Tourism Innovation Research & Development Hub, and the EU Tourism Training & Skills Portal—can demonstrate Ireland’s leadership in areas that matter to communities, businesses, and workers. These projects align with Council configurations on Competitiveness and Education, making EU policymaking more visible and relatable to Irish audiences. Use culture as a bridge to Europe Culture is often the most powerful connector. Irish artists, creators, venues, and festivals can be mobilised to express the themes of the Presidency—welcome, sustainability, innovation, community—through music, literature, film and public art. Cultural exchange with Lithuania and Greece, our Trio partners, can showcase shared European values in a way that policy statements alone cannot. Keep communication simple, human, and hopeful Above all, messages should focus on what the EU enables: opportunity, mobility, peace, environmental protection, cultural richness, and economic security. Ireland’s Presidency should be framed as a national moment—a chance for citizens to help steer Europe at a time when our collective future is being shaped.

FUTURE READY TOURISM - UNITE, ELEVATE, INNOVATE and ACCELERATE Submission to Ireland’s Presidency of the Council of the European Union, July–December 2026 by Nollaig Fahy, Tourism Innovation Programme Manager. As an Irish and European citizen with decades of experience across national, EU and global tourism, I welcome the opportunity to contribute to Ireland’s preparations for the 2026 EU Council Presidency. Tourism is one of Europe’s most culturally meaningful and economically vital sectors, and Ireland—with our instinct for welcome and our growing reputation in innovation—can play a pivotal role in shaping Europe’s future under the EU Strategic Agenda 2024–2029, which prioritises competitiveness, resilience, sustainability, and skills. Guided by these priorities, and aligned with the Council’s legislative programme and the Commission’s 2026 Work Programme—particularly its strands on sustainability, digital transition, European competitiveness, and skills development—I propose the following three legacy projects for the Ireland– Lithuania–Greece Trio Presidency. These projects also support the work of the Competitiveness Council (Tourism policy and the single market) and the Education, Youth, Culture and Sport Council (skills and training). Legacy Project 1 — The Dublin Declaration on FUTURE READY TOURISM - UNITE, ELEVATE, INNOVATE, and ACCELERATE In line with the EU Strategic Agenda’s call for improved governance and long-term strategic coordination, the Dublin Declaration would establish a modernised EU tourism governance framework. It would: Strengthen cross-directorate coordination within the European Commission; Introduce a Tourism Mainstreaming Protocol to align with the Commission’s 2026 legislative priorities; • Establish a long-term Tourism Governance Council, operating within the Competitiveness Council’s remit; Deliver a 2036 EU Tourism Roadmap aligned with green and digital transition goals. Legacy Impact: A durable governance structure for tourism, giving the EU the coordination capacity it needs to deliver the 2024–2029 Strategic Agenda and future legislative cycles. Legacy Project 2 — European Tourism Innovation Research & Development Hub Aligned with the Strategic Agenda’s emphasis on innovation and competitiveness, —headquartered digitally in Dublin—would be Europe’s first permanent tourism research and innovation online hub. It would: Integrate tourism into the EU’s research fabric, supporting the Commission’s 2026 R&I priorities; Advance innovation in digital heritage, AI, and climate-neutral mobility; Offer applied research fellowships; Operate a Trio Knowledge Lab connecting Ireland, Lithuania, and Greece. Legacy Impact: A world-leading EU tourism research ecosystem supporting the Competitiveness Council’s mandate and strengthening Europe’s innovation capacity. Legacy Project 3 — EU Tourism Prosperity Training & Skills Hub Reflecting the Strategic Agenda’s commitment to a skilled workforce and resilient communities, this online Hub—developed through the Education & Youth Council’s skills mandate—would: • Provide training in sustainable tourism, mobility innovation, cultural stewardship, and digital

Ireland’s 2026 EU Presidency provides an opportunity to set a forward-looking agenda that prioritises long-term resilience and prosperity. Driving a future that delivers for coming generations at the heart of its thematic priorities would signal the EU’s commitment to purposeful, people-centred action. Health is central to this vision it enables citizens to learn, work, and participate fully in society, reinforcing social stability, economic vitality, and the foundations of a strong, sustainable Europe for decades to come. Health has been largely absent for high-level thematical frameworks, with Belgium’s Presidency a notable exception in explicitly prioritising the health agenda. This gap is striking given that non-communicable diseases (NCDs), particularly cardiovascular disease (CVD), remain the leading cause of mortality in Europe, driving long-term disability, caregiver burden, avoidable hospital pressure, and sustained economic loss through premature death and preventable illness. Ireland has an opportunity to position health, not as a technical sector issue, but as a strategic pillar essential to Europe’s resilience. Prevention specifically reduces long-term healthcare costs that strain national budgets, and addresses health inequalities strengthening social cohesion. The ongoing development of the EU Cardiovascular Health Plan presents a unique opportunity for Ireland to demonstrate leadership in key prevention areas such as obesity and nicotine addiction, but also in delivering EU-wide improvements to acute care systems, rehabilitation and community services promoting health and wellbeing for CVD patients. Ireland has a well-established domestic track record in prevention, population-level health advocacy, and public health awareness. Our cardiovascular care community is also highly respected throughout Europe for its expertise and innovation. This gives us unique credibility in elevating both prevention and care focused discussions at European level. The Presidency term therefore represents an important agenda-setting moment to: Prioritise cardiovascular disease, which is Europe’s biggest killer disease, across the full spectrum of prevention, emergency care, rehabilitation and support in the community. Seek greater protection for children from detrimental commercial drivers of disease, including through the audiovisual and digital marketing environment. Develop programmes to improve the lives of tens of millions of people living with the effects of CVD, including by upholding their rights under the UN Convention on the Rights of People with Disabilities. Emphasise environmental policy as a direct contributor to long-term cardiovascular health, community participation and economic productivity. A Presidency that prioritises health does not simply improve outcomes for patients, it strengthens the EU’s broader policy objectives preventing avoidable mortality, reducing inequalities, protecting future generations, and supporting citizens to live, learn, and work well for longer. Embedding a Presidency focus on future generations, with health as a key thematic pillar, would show how EU policy can complement national efforts, protect health across all policy areas, and advance a stronger Health Union. This approach recognises longevity and wellbeing as core European assets and underscores that Europe’s future strength depends not just on treating illness, but on preventing it effectively, equitably, and sustainably at scale.

CVD requires particular priority given significant deficits in services and supports throughout the EU despite being by far its biggest cause of mortality, accounting for one third of all deaths. Failure to do more to address the needs of an estimated 62 million people living with a cardiovascular condition is also driving high levels of long-term disability, caregiver burden, avoidable hospital pressure, and sustained economic loss through premature death and preventable illness. In Ireland it’s estimated that around 10,000 people die of cardiovascular disease each year, with 600,000 people living with CV conditions. The Irish Government is demonstrating strong commitment to better cardiovascular health outcomes through key actions: implementing the National Review of Specialist Cardiac Services and National Stroke Strategy, delivering a new National Cardiovascular Health Policy, signing the Stroke Action Plan for Europe, and playing a prominent role in securing the EU Cardiovascular Health Plan - all of which will make a real difference to citizens' lives. This provides a strong foundation for the Irish Presidency to play a leadership role in shaping a healthier future for EU citizens. Below we outline areas of highest policy importance and what constructive progress could represent for citizens and communities should these files land on the Council agenda in 2026. Cardiovascular Prevention The EU burden of heart disease and stroke demonstrates the importance of comprehensive prevention policy that links modifiable risk factors to long-term health outcomes. Specific EU actions to support efforts by member Governments to tackle Europe’s obesity crisis and to reduce persistently high rates of smoking and nicotine addiction include: Measures to reduce consumption of ultraprocessed foods, including designing EU-wide levies on unhealthy products and subsidies for healthy food. The introduction of mandatory front of pack labelling providing clear information to consumers on the nutritional value of food products and beverages. A full review of the Audiovisual Media Services Directive to provide greater protection from unhealthy food marketing, which is driving Europe's childhood obesity crisis through traditional advertising and the growing influence of content creators and influencers. Accelerating the revision of the Tobacco Products Directive and its extension to protect children from nicotine addiction through use of e-cigarettes and other novel products Improved treatment, care and support The EU can play an important role in reducing high levels of preventable death and disability from CVD that persist in every EU State through: The development of an EU-wide programme to support all Member States in developing or upgrading national cardiovascular health strategies. This should include implementation of the EU Cardiovascular Health Plan and the Stroke Action Plan for Europe. Programmes to reduce inequalities in women’s cardiovascular health. Research to assess and mitigate the financial impact of CVD on patients and their families, long-term psychological impacts and to develop cost effective pathways of community services and supports.

Ireland’s Presidency term can make the strongest social and economic impact by emphasising: Prevention at scale, protection of children, inclusive public policy, and healthier environments, recognising these areas as structural drivers of EU credibility and resilience. Addressing the needs of the 62 million people living with a cardiovascular condition and their families. Council discussions that visibly connect obesity, hypertension, tobacco use, nicotine dependence, air quality, and physical inactivity to cardiovascular mortality would underscore the EU's role in preventing the Union's largest cause of premature death. Ireland should reinforce the importance of protecting children and future adult cardiovascular health from commercial drivers of disease. Advancing implementation of the files mentioned above would ensure people living with heart disease, stroke, and related disabilities are centred in prevention and rehabilitation policy design. Progressing the EU CVH plan would also play a signficant role in prevention as well as the treatment and care of heart disease, stroke and blood vessel diseases. The provisions focusing on living with the effects of CVD provide an opportunity to improve the health, wellbeing and quality of life of a large group of vulnerable citizens who, in broad terms, have not been well served by health and social care systems in member States to date.

Making EU Membership Tangible Citizens value EU membership when they can trace a direct line between EU action and improvements in their communities. For patients and families affected by CVD, Ireland’s leading cause of death, the EU’s role is largely invisible. Making connections explicit offers a strong communication opportunity. Communicate through concrete protections The EU’s strength lies in addressing challenges that cross borders and overpower individual member states particularly where commercial interests operate across jurisdictions. Cardiovascular prevention and health protection show that EU level coordination could make tobacco advertising restrictions, controls on junk food marketing to children across digital platforms, and air quality standards that reduce cardiovascular mortality far more effective. This would prevent industry from exploiting regulatory gaps and ensure greater benefits for citizens. However, most Irish people do not recognise existing and potential daily protections as stemming from EU legislation, which represents both a communication failure and an opportunity. Build ownership through recognisable priorities Citizens develop ownership when they see their concerns genuinely reflected in what the government champions at EU level. An effective Presidency strategy would choose visible priorities that resonate with lived experience, issues including non-communicable disease prevention or disability rights implementation affect millions daily but rarely dominate political discourse. Moving beyond tick boxing exercises to meaningful involvement of patient groups, health NGOs, and civil society transform citizens from audience to participants. Championing legislative files that deliver better outcomes for current and future generations shows citizens their government is actively protecting their interests at EU level. The approach Communication should emphasise tangible results in accessible language and showcase how coordinated standards can contributed to the reduction of disease burden. Local engagement with patient groups and accessible summaries would ground the Presidency in communities’ daily concerns rather than distant institutional proceedings. Ireland’s Presidency offers a moment to demonstrate that EU membership isn’t abstract cooperation but practical protection of citizens’ health and wellbeing. Citizens develop ownership of both the Presidency and the broader EU project when they see their government championing protections that directly improve their lives.

Ireland's Presidency coincides with a unique opportunity with the development and early implementation of the EU Cardiovascular Health Plan. As cardiovascular disease remains the leading cause of death across the Union, Ireland can demonstrate transformative leadership by championing this Plan whilst modelling a more participatory approach to EU policymaking, one that embeds civil society, community voices whilst maintaining clear boundaries between public health advocacy and commercial interests. Building the CVD Plan with community and patient voices The EU Cardiovascular Health Plan offers a concrete framework for Ireland's Presidency to advance prevention at scale. Championing this Plan means ensuring civil society, patient organisations, and health NGOs are central to shaping its implementation. Ireland should establish structured engagement mechanisms that bring these voices into Council preparatory discussions on cardiovascular health, prevention policy, and related file, ensuring public health perspectives are heard as prominently as commercial stakeholders. This means inviting patient organisations to contribute expertise during the development of Council positions; hosting roundtables that connect lived experiences of heart disease and stroke directly with Member State delegations; and ensuring people living with cardiovascular conditions and related disabilities have visible representation in Presidency events. Their lived experience reveals how policies translate into daily realities, where gaps exist, and what truly constitutes meaningful protection. Protecting policy space from commercial interests On files involving tobacco, vaping, food marketing, and product regulation, all critical to cardiovascular disease prevention, it is essential that Ireland's Presidency maintains clear separation between public health policy development and industry lobbying. Commercial actors have well-documented records of undermining health protections through regulatory delay, weakened standards, and false equivalence between public health evidence and industry-funded research. Transparency Ireland's Presidency could enhance policy integrity by being transparent about which stakeholders are consulted during Council negotiations, identifying industry representatives clearly, and prioritising independent scientific evidence over commercially motivated positions. This builds public trust and demonstrates that Council decisions serve citizen interests.

The United Nations has designated next year International Year of the Volunteer for Sustainable Development, or International Volunteer Year (IVY 2026) for short. The fact that this first of its kind global celebration of volunteering coincides with Ireland’s Presidency of the EU presents a unique opportunity to shine a light on our incredible record of volunteering and cement Ireland as a leader in volunteering. Ireland has a strong culture of volunteering with over 1 million people volunteering each year. Ireland is seen as a global leader in volunteering across Europe because we have relatively high levels of volunteering, a national volunteer development organisation in Volunteer Ireland, a network of local county-based Volunteer Centres, and a Government commitment to volunteering through a National Volunteering Strategy. Volunteer Ireland has been named national lead on IVY 2026 by the United Nations. We are also members, and sit on the board, of the Centre for European Volunteering (CEV), the European network of over 60 organisations dedicated to the promotion of, and support to, volunteers and volunteering in Europe at European, national and regional level. Specifically, Ireland should focus on the following: 1. Strengthening Social Cohesion and Community Resilience Volunteering enhances solidarity, inclusion, and supports core EU values. Volunteering is a recognised driver of social cohesion (European Commission, 2023; OECD, 2020). Ireland should prioritise policy measures that invest in community infrastructure, volunteer-involving organisations, local volunteer organisations, and promote cross-border civic cooperation will reinforce Europe’s capacity to respond to social, environmental, and economic challenges. Reinforcing Democracy and Civic Participation Volunteering fosters civic skills, habits of participation, and trust in institutions (Putnam, 2000; European Parliament Research Service, 2022). Ireland should prioritise initiatives that build democratic resilience through civic engagement and community participation. With challenges such as disinformation, polarisation, and declining trust in institutions, Europe must elevate civic engagement. Volunteering provides meaningful pathways for citizens to participate in public life. Ireland should champion a European agenda that strengthens democratic resilience through greater support for civic education, community organising, and volunteer-based democratic initiatives. Promoting Inclusion and Equality Through Civic Engagement Volunteering is a proven mechanism for integrating marginalised communities, including migrants, people with disabilities, older adults, and young people. (UN Volunteers, 2018; European Economic and Social Committee, 2019). Ireland should position inclusive volunteering as a key driver of equality and social participation within the EU’s wider inclusion strategies. Building a Resilient Europe Through Preparedness and Community Response Volunteers play a central role during emergencies, from COVID-19 to natural disasters (European Commission Civil Protection Mechanism Report, 2022). Ireland should prioritise EU-wide frameworks that support the mobilisation, protection, training, and recognition of volunteers in preparedness and emergency response systems. Supporting the Future of Europe’s Civil Society A strong, independent, and well-resourced civil society sector is essential to the functioning of European democracies. (Council of Europe, 2019). The Presidency should champion strategic investment, regulatory clarity, and enabling environments for non-profit and volunteer-involving organisations and community organisations.

The Irish Presidency of the EU Council in 2026 offers a timely opportunity to recognise, support and promote the role of volunteering within the European policy landscape and to align EU initiatives with Ireland’s tradition of community engagement and volunteer-led solidarity. Ireland can use its Presidency to champion a policy vision in which volunteering is recognised as a mechanism for civic participation, democracy, resilience, population preparedness and social cohesion across the European Union. Ireland is well-positioned to advocate for sustained investment in volunteering infrastructure, both at national and European levels given its leading example in having a National Volunteering Strategy that has the provision of volunteering infrastructure at its core. Population preparedness and resilience-building should form a priority area. In Ireland and other member states, the contributions of volunteers in emergencies have clearly demonstrated the importance of a whole-of-society approach. During its Presidency, Ireland should push for stronger integration of volunteer-involving organisations within EU preparedness strategies and structures, particularly under the Union Civil Protection Mechanism. This includes enhanced capacity-building for Irish and European organisations that engage volunteers in crisis response, ensuring they have the tools, training, and coordination platforms needed to operate safely and efficiently. Embedding volunteer expertise in advisory and management structures would reinforce public trust and expand the collective capacity to respond to future challenges. The Irish Presidency should advocate for volunteering and solidarity to remain at the core of the Erasmus+ programme with a clear legal and budgetary framework that recognises volunteering as a unique contribution to European unity, resilience, preparedness and democracy. The Irish Presidency should also support an increased European Solidarity Corps budget to improve the quality of experiences and better enable the inclusion of people with fewer opportunities who may require additional resources. The Irish Presidency should work on ensuring that the newly proposed AgoraEU programme explicitly recognises and addresses volunteering, to give continuity to what has been achieved through Regulation 2021/692 (establishing the CERV programme), in alignment with Article 11 TEU on participatory democracy, and as a recognition of volunteering as a key mechanism for democratic engagement, solidarity, and active participation. For Ireland, which has deeply embedded traditions of community volunteering, this is an opportunity to ensure that the EU’s new democratic engagement frameworks reflect the role of volunteers as facilitators of dialogue, social cohesion, and active citizenship. The same applies to the European Democracy Shield, where volunteer-driven engagement should be acknowledged as a key element of societal resilience against democratic threats. The role of volunteers in providing the required civic education, media literacy and critical thinking skills will be essential to its success. Ireland should also promote EU-level recognition and validation of skills gained through volunteering. Integrating volunteering into the intergenerational fairness agenda would further align European policy with Ireland’s community values. Ensuring stable, long-term funding for volunteering infrastructure will be essential to enabling safe, meaningful, and accessible participation for people of all ages across Ireland and the EU.

To deliver the most meaningful benefits to people, communities, and businesses, the Irish Presidency should prioritise initiatives that strengthen Europe’s social infrastructure—especially its volunteer-driven and community-based systems. Specifically: Putting People and Communities at the Centre of Policy Design Policies are most effective when rooted in lived experience. Public trust increases when citizens contribute to policymaking (OECD Trust Framework, 2021). Ireland can lead by embedding participatory processes including citizen panels, youth assemblies, and civil society led consultations into Council work. This enhances trust and ensures policies reflect community realities and deliver tangible benefits. Investing in Community Resilience Evidence shows volunteer networks strengthen resilience and local capacity to respond to crises (UNDRR, 2020). Supporting volunteer training and safety while ensuring volunteers, volunteer involving organisations and volunteer infrastructure bodies are included in emergency planning and frameworks is critical. Improving Wellbeing and Social Cohesion Volunteering improves mental health, reduces loneliness, and increases social ties and participation (WHO, 2021; Johns Hopkins Center for Civil Society Studies, 2017). By promoting policies that support inclusive volunteering, the Presidency can ensure that the benefits of EU membership are felt at community level. Supporting Skills and the Social Economy Volunteering develops soft and transferable skills essential to labour markets (EU Skills Agenda Report, 2022). The Presidency can advance recognition frameworks linking volunteering to education, training, and employability. Strengthening Cross-Border Mobility and Cooperation A stronger system of cross-border volunteering, crisis response, youth exchanges, and civil society cooperation will create a more connected and resilient Europe. Cross-border volunteering creates solidarity and shared European identity (Eurobarometer 2021). Strengthened mobility frameworks will benefit both communities and businesses through increased cooperation, trust and shared learning. By foregrounding volunteering and community engagement, Ireland can ensure its Presidency has a visible, people-centred impact that aligns with the EU’s founding values and long-term priorities. 6. Communicating the Value and Impact of Volunteering Volunteering is not only critical to Irish society but to communities in every Member State. The Irish Presidency provides us with a unique platform to ensure the value of volunteering is recognised and understood across the EU. Given the Irish Presidency falls during IVY 2026 it is imperative that volunteering is recognised within the EU Council as a driver of social cohesion, humanitarian effort and emergency response. It’s impact should be reflected in communications and policies throughout the Irish Presidency.

Ireland’s Presidency presents an opportunity to deepen public understanding of the EU and foster a shared sense of ownership. Volunteer Ireland recommends: Use Volunteering as a Visible Expression of EU Values Volunteering exemplifies solidarity, democracy, and participation, core EU values listed in Article 2 of the Treaty on European Union (TEU). Showcasing community projects supported by EU funding, or aligned with EU priorities, helps citizens see the practical impact of EU membership in everyday life. Volunteerdriven events, local dialogues, and community action days can make EU values more visible. Highlight Community Impact Stories Research shows storytelling increases public understanding of EU action (European Commission, 2021). Sharing examples of volunteer-led community projects supported by EU programmes will resonate strongly with citizens. Positive narratives particularly those highlighting volunteers helping during crises, supporting vulnerable people, or contributing to environmental sustainability are powerful tools for demonstrating European solidarity. Engage Youth and Civil Society Youth participation and civil society involvement increase trust in EU institutions (Eurofound, 2019). Cocreating Presidency events with volunteers, volunteering infrastructure bodies, and civil society organisations ensures key stakeholders are directly involved in Presidency related events. This builds a sense of ownership over Ireland’s role in the EU and strengthens civic participation. Ensure Accessible, Inclusive Communication Clear language, multi-language materials, and community-based communication channels boost understanding and participation (FRA, 2020). Use clear, jargon-free messaging, multiple languages, and community-based communication channels to ensure that information reaches diverse audiences, including migrants, rural communities, and disadvantaged groups. Emphasise Opportunities, Not Institutions Citizens respond more positively to opportunities such as Erasmus+, European Solidarity Corps, and community funding than to institutional explanations (Eurobarometer, 2022). Focusing on tangible benefits will strengthen connection with the EU. Citizens connect more strongly with opportunities that affect them personally. Communicating about EU-funded volunteering programmes, Erasmus+ youth mobility, and community-resilience initiatives provides a relatable entry point to understanding the EU.

More information on International Volunteer Year (IVY 2026): Through Resolution 78/127, the United Nations General Assembly has proclaimed 2026 as the International Year of Volunteers for Sustainable Development (IVY2026), thereby promoting and recognising volunteerism as a significant force for sustainable development. The General Assembly calls on Member States, United Nations system organisations, and other relevant stakeholders, including civil society, the private sector and academia, to observe the International Year at national and regional levels. Every day, millions of people around the world take action – big and small – to make life better for others and for their communities. Whether it’s mentoring youth, supporting local health efforts, or responding to emergencies, volunteers drive meaningful change in communities. Through their actions, volunteers become a force for achieving the Sustainable Development Goals - connecting people, strengthening resilience, and creating lasting impact. The International Volunteer Year 2026 invites us to celebrate and recognise the incredible contributions of volunteers everywhere. It’s a moment to raise awareness, spark conversations, and inspire even more people to get involved.

We recommend inclusion (of all people, including persons with disabilities), accessibility (to all benefits, programmes, services and opportunities for all people, including persons with disabilities), universal design, which benefits everyone, including persons with disabilities, and equality should be at the core of Ireland’s Presidency of the European Council in 2026. These issues should inform how Ireland’s Presidency is organised and how all stakeholders are engaged to ensure a disability accessible Presidency. Full participation of people with disabilities as equal stakeholders should be planned for and provided. Further, Ireland should utilise its presidency to choose ‘access’ as its high-level thematic priority, which informs all aspects of policy discussion. As an international NGO, we recommend that consultation with the people most impacted by crises, e.g., poverty, humanitarian, conflict, and climate crisis, should be a key feature of Ireland’s leadership as it holds the EU Presidency, with a focus on access and disability inclusion in Europe’s Global Gateway. As part of the EU Presidency, CBM Ireland recommends that Ireland should convene an EU high-level event focused on disability-inclusive climate action at COP31. CBM Ireland, which is part of a global federation and is present in Australia, is having a parallel conversation with the Australian government, which will lead the negotiations leading up to COP31 in Türkiye. Access to affordable housing and energy is the twin crisis experienced across the European public, which exacerbates the lives and livelihoods of people with disabilities. Ireland should use its domestic experience and expertise of the Just Transition Commission to address the key issues of the housing and energy crises, align them with the broader issues of the climate crisis, and promote affordable, accessible housing and energy, with renewables as the core principle.

Union of equality: Strategy for the rights of persons with disabilities 2021-2030: Remove barriers to fully implement the UNCRPD across EU rules and policies, which UNCRPD Committee recommended in its recent review (https://docs.un.org/en/CRPD/C/EU/CO/2-3) Article 32 of the UNCRPD: Ireland should demonstrate its firm leadership by preserving the ODA budget, preventing cuts, mergers, etc and increasing investment in disability inclusion in line with GDS 2025 commitments and the Berlin-Amman Declaration, and work to clear a pathway across the EU to ringfence at least 15% Official Development Assistance to be specifically disability inclusive. Inclusive climate action – enhance policies and budgets in light of disability-inclusive paths taken by the COP30 decisions, e.g., Global Mutirao, Gender Action Plan, Just Transition Programme and Global Goal on Adaptation. As a party to the Paris Agreement and the UNCRPD, Ireland and the EU share the role of promoting disability-inclusive approaches to current and future climate action.

CBM Ireland suggests that Ireland’s leadership at the European Council should emphasise walking the talk, by putting disability inclusion at the center of its Presidency: Promoting inclusive, pro-people, civil-society-engaged development, humanitarian, and climate action. Strengthening implementation of the EU’s obligations under the UNCRPD, including implementation of the recent review of the CRPD Committee, and implementing its Presidency in full alignment with obligations under the CRPD. For CBM Ireland, there is a particular desire to see UNCRPD Article 32 on international development fully implemented across Europe through commitments to disability-inclusive external action, at a minimum, commitments made at the 2025 Global Disability Summit and the Berlin-Amman Declaration. Ensuring disability-inclusive and disability-mainstreaming approaches across all Council conclusions adopted and events organised during the Irish Presidency, including, among others, the use, support and promotion of Sign Language, accessible venues and all necessary disability inclusion supports.

Use Irish public support for ODA as the role model, champion it across the EU by tackling the rise of anti-ODA sentiment. Promote people-to-people dialogue within Europe and beyond with the people affected and benefited by EU policies and programmes and growth, especially, people in the Global South. People with disabilities are disproportionately affected by climate change. EU member states have a role to play in tackling it to ensure their ODA makes a steady/sustainable impact on the people and promotes global justice. Ireland’s leadership should consider communicating this vital message to the internal and external audiences and utilise relationships already in place in its Programme Countries and with partners such as CBM Ireland to bring voices of people with disabilities to Ireland to inform the Irish and European public of the reality of the impact of Climate change. It is a fact that Ireland is only slightly affected by climate change, while the real, devastating effects are being felt in the Global South. This results in climate apathy amongst the public, and Ireland should use the opportunity of its European Presidency to present, clearly and starkly, the impact on others, using real, human stories.

CBM Ireland, in collaboration with Dóchas – the Irish Development NGO Network, and the Disability Focal Point of Irish Aid, is currently in the process of proposing a Disability Strategy for Ireland’s ODA programme. We believe that, as a party to the UNCRPD, Ireland should lead by example during its EU Presidency in the area of disability rights and make firm public commitments to disability inclusion both domestically and in its external action.

sector: Fórsa is the largest public sector union in Ireland representing over 90,000 workers across the public and civil service including health, education, and local authorities, as well as staff in the commercial state sector, state agencies, private companies and the community and voluntary sector.
response_text: Fórsa strongly believes the fundamental challenges of housing, healthcare, and cost of living facing workers and society today must form the backbone of the development of the priorities and policy programme for Ireland’s Presidency of the Council of the European Union 2026.

sector: Fórsa is the largest public sector union in Ireland representing over 90,000 workers across the public and civil service including health, education, and local authorities, as well as staff in the commercial state sector, state agencies, private companies and the community and voluntary sector.
response_text: Many national governments consider the interlinked issues of housing, healthcare and cost of living as priority crises requiring coordinated EU action, providing an opportunity for the Irish Presidency to achieve much needed reform in these thematic areas. Our submission highlights the significant challenges facing Europe’s labour market and social cohesion, along with specific recommendations for Ireland’s Presidency and policy programme for 2026 on each of the priority themes. This Presidency and policy programme will be a befitting opportunity for the Irish Presidency to adopt a proactive and progressive economic strategy that will deliver a better quality of life for workers and their families and build stronger communities across Europe.

sector: Fórsa is the largest public sector union in Ireland representing over 90,000 workers across the public and civil service including health, education, and local authorities, as well as staff in the commercial state sector, state agencies, private companies and the community and voluntary sector.
response_text: The EU and its institutions play an incredibly influential role in people’s lives but the work that is carried out in Brussels, Strasbourg, and Luxembourg is often far removed from people’s daily lives. The Irish Presidency is a real opportunity to bring the work of Europe closer to its citizens by focusing on policies and issues that matter to them most. It is our view that anything less than an ambitious proactive approach to tackle the interconnected issues of housing, healthcare and cost of living represents a significant missed opportunity for the Presidency. Interventionist policies specifically targeting these issues must be prioritised to tackle today’s most prominent issues in people’s everyday lives.

sector: Fórsa is the largest public sector union in Ireland representing over 90,000 workers across the public and civil service including health, education, and local authorities, as well as staff in the commercial state sector, state agencies, private companies and the community and voluntary sector.
response_text: Fórsa is the largest public sector union in Ireland representing over 90,000 workers across the public and civil service including health, education, and local authorities, as well as staff in the commercial state sector, state agencies, private companies and the community and voluntary sector. As such, our union is uniquely placed to provide an informed perspective into the experiences and issues facing Irish workers and wider society. Forsa’s 2025 membership survey revealed that workers across Ireland share the same frustrations. These are centred around housing, healthcare and the rising cost of living. When compared to broader European data, it is evident that workers in Ireland and across the European Union, share the same problems and struggles. For this reason, we have proposed three thematic priority areas for Ireland’s Presidency of the Council of the European Union in the submission accompanying this form. Please refer to Fórsa’s accompanying submission which highlights the shared problems of Irish and European workers and represent some of the most pressing issues facing Ireland’s Presidency at this moment in time.

sector:
ActionAid Ireland is an international NGO focused on women’s rights working in the area of human rights, development and humanitarian response. 
We adopt a human rights approach to development and working towards sustainable, long-term change to address the root causes of poverty and injustice more effectively.
geography: Global - our submission will focus predominately on the EU’s external action with a focus on its role in the Global South.
response_text: Ireland’s Presidency comes at a time when the commitments of EU Member States is weaker in relation to human rights, international law and sustainable development. The Council’s work will be shaped by overlapping pressures — geopolitical instability, deepening humanitarian crises, fragmentation of the multilateral system, and debates about competitiveness. Against that backdrop, three priorities would allow Ireland to contribute constructively and credibly to the EU’s strategic agenda. Rebalancing the EU’s external action towards poverty reduction and human rights The redesign of the EU’s external financing instruments risks diluting the European Union’s long-standing commitment to poverty eradication, gender equality and sustainable development. A Presidency priority centred on poverty reduction, rights, and development cooperation would help ensure that the EU’s external policies remain aligned with European values. It would also signal that the shift towards a more “economic foreign policy” should not come at the expense of the Union’s obligations under Article 208 TFEU and the 2030 Agenda. Strengthening accountability and international law in EU foreign policy At a time when grave breaches of international humanitarian law are unfolding — like in the occupied Palestinian territory and in Sudan — the EU’s credibility depends on its willingness to uphold accountability and justice. A Presidency priority centered on accountability, protection of civilians, and respect for international law would show a commitment to the EU’s core values. This focus would reflect the expectations of European citizens, who consistently express strong support for EU foreign policy that prioritizes human rights. Ireland is well-placed to facilitate constructive Council discussions on how the EU applies existing legal obligations consistently across different contexts where international law has been breached. One area where this principle is urgently needed is the EU’s response to Israel’s genocide in Gaza and the wider illegal occupation. Ireland’s Presidency should support steps towards accountability, including the use of Article 2 of the EU–Israel Association Agreement, which is triggered when the essential human-rights clause is breached. Ensuring economic competitiveness aligns with social, environmental and human-rights standards Debates on competitiveness are shaping a growing share of the EU’s legislative agenda, including discussions on the Omnibus package and the future of environmental protection and wider due diligence. A Presidency focused on “competitiveness with integrity” would recognise the need for economic resilience while acknowledging that deregulation cannot come at the expense of human rights and environmental protections. When setting out its priorities, we would encourage Ireland to avoid replicating the Danish Presidency’s framing of competitiveness, which focused heavily on supply-chain security and regulatory simplification but gave little space to human rights or responsible business conduct. Along with the need to protect human rights, it’s important to also note that while proponents of deregulation claim it will unleash growth by removing “burdens” – this claim is not supported by evidence. Hundreds of economists across Europe have made clear that sustainability regulations related to due diligence do not undermine competitiveness—and that the real challenges for growth are elsewhere such as energy shocks, under-investment, weak industrial policy and skills gaps.

sector:
ActionAid Ireland is an international NGO focused on women’s rights working in the area of human rights, development and humanitarian response. 
We adopt a human rights approach to development and working towards sustainable, long-term change to address the root causes of poverty and injustice more effectively.
geography: Global - our submission will focus predominately on the EU’s external action with a focus on its role in the Global South.
response_text: Ireland’s Presidency will coincide with several major legislative files and policy debates. In line with the above three priorities, three areas stand out as requiring attention and principled stewardship. 1. Multi Annual Financial Framework (MFF) 2028–2034 and the Global Europe Instrument Negotiations on the Global Europe Instrument (GEI) under the next MFF will define the direction of EU external action. The current proposals risk undermining the EU’s focus on poverty eradication, shifting ODA towards geopolitical and commercial objectives, and weakening commitments to gender equality. Ireland’s Presidency should work to: Anchor the GEI in poverty reduction and human rights, explicitly grounding negotiations in Article 208 TFEU and the EU’s stated values on human rights and development cooperation. Protect ODA integrity, including by resisting negative migration conditionality and ensuring that development assistance is not diverted into security or commercial export priorities. Strengthen gender equality obligations, including dedicated, measurable commitments for funding women’s rights organisations, whose share of ODA remains extremely low. Ensure climate and environmental commitments remain robust, encouraging greater ambition in the EU’s climate finance towards adaptation, mitigation, loss and damage, and a just transition. 2. Accountability and international humanitarian law: EU–Israel Association Agreement & FAC workstream The scale and gravity of violations in the occupied Palestinian territory underline the urgency of restoring credibility to the EU’s human-rights conditionality. Article 2 of the EU–Israel Association Agreement establishes that respect for human rights and democratic principles constitutes an “essential element” of the agreement. Given the findings of UN experts, the ICJ advisory opinion and multiple organisations, the Presidency should support the Council initiating the formal process to suspend the EU–Israel Association Agreement until Israel complies with its obligations under international law. More broadly the Irish Presidency should work within the Foreign Affairs Council to ensure a consistent application of EU human-rights conditionality across all third countries, including in cases of grave breaches of humanitarian law, attacks on civilians and obstruction of humanitarian access. 3. Competitiveness, due diligence and the deregulatory agenda The Omnibus proposals and related discussions on “competitiveness” have major implications for human rights, environmental standards and the EU’s global footprint. Despite evidence that shows that the implementation cost of human rights and environmental due diligence for large companies is 0.009% of revenues, EU member states are continuing to pursue a deregulatory agenda. Ireland’s Presidency should aim to: Protect the core integrity of the Corporate Sustainability Due Diligence Directive (CSDDD), including obligations beyond first-tier suppliers, meaningful transition plans, strong civil liability provisions and the role of affected communities. Ensure the financial sector is brought within the scope of due-diligence and reporting frameworks, given its large global footprint and the impact of unregulated capital flows on the world’s climate. Promote an evidence-based, balanced discussion on competitiveness that focuses on economic resilience while staying committed to the EU’s stated values related to human rights.

sector:
ActionAid Ireland is an international NGO focused on women’s rights working in the area of human rights, development and humanitarian response. 
We adopt a human rights approach to development and working towards sustainable, long-term change to address the root causes of poverty and injustice more effectively.
geography: Global - our submission will focus predominately on the EU’s external action with a focus on its role in the Global South.
response_text: One of the clearest ways Ireland can make a meaningful impact during its Presidency is by placing women’s rights at the centre of the Council’s work and promoting the work of women’s rights organisations. The global context highlights why a focus on women’s rights is crucial right now. Across every region, we are witnessing a rapid erosion of rights: coordinated “anti-gender” movements, democratic backsliding, escalating conflicts, and unprecedented cuts to ODA. These forces are converging to undermine decades of progress for women and girls. Women’s rights organisations have always been underfunded — now they are being pushed beyond breaking point. According to AWID, women’s rights organisations receive only 0.13% of the total Official Development Assistance (ODA) and only 0.4% of all gender related aid. The gutting of ODA is now amplifying this. UN Women’s latest survey of more than 400 women’s rights organisations across humanitarian settings puts this in stark terms: nine in ten have already lost funding, nearly three-quarters have had to cut staff, and almost half expect to close imminently if cuts continue. The first programmes to go when ODA is cut are those most essential to women’s rights — GBV services, sexual and reproductive health, and protection. Despite some progress worldwide on gender equality and women’s and girls’ empowerment, none of the indicators and sub-indicators of Sustainable Development Goal 5—the goal for gender equality—has been met. At current rates, gender parity in parliaments remains a distant dream, potentially not achievable until 2063. Overall, 24.3 million more females live in extreme poverty compared to males. By 2030, a projected 8.1 per cent of females (compared to 7.6 per cent of males) will linger in extreme poverty, missing the SDG target. Ending extreme poverty for women and girls will take an additional 137 years if this trend continues. And about 1 in 4 girls continue to be married as children. Discriminatory legal frameworks prevail in many parts of the world. In 18% of countries, women do not have equal rights to confer citizenship to their spouses and their children. By 2050, climate change may push up to 158 million more women and girls into extreme poverty ($2.15 per day), 16 million more than men and boys. This is precisely why an Irish Presidency centred on women’s rights would have the most transformational impact. When women’s rights organisations are supported, the effects cascade across communities and countries. Their work reduces violence, strengthens community resilience, expands civic space, and drives legal and policy reforms that benefit entire societies. Research consistently shows that feminist movements have been the strongest driver of laws to end violence against women — more influential than political parties, economic growth or international interventions. Being steadfast in support for women’s rights is one of the surest ways to strengthen democracy, prevent conflict, and build resilience to impacts of humanitarian crises. It is also consistent with what Ireland has already signalled in its campaign for the UN Human Rights Council seat for 2027–2029.

sector:
ActionAid Ireland is an international NGO focused on women’s rights working in the area of human rights, development and humanitarian response. 
We adopt a human rights approach to development and working towards sustainable, long-term change to address the root causes of poverty and injustice more effectively.
geography: Global - our submission will focus predominately on the EU’s external action with a focus on its role in the Global South.
response_text: Irish people remain among the most optimistic in Europe about the EU’s future, but that trust cannot be taken for granted. The EU Agency for Fundamental Rights (FRA) 2025 report highlights a worrying drift in parts of the EU away from the values it is built on. If the EU steps back from its commitments to human rights, non-discrimination and the rule of law, it is not only the EU that is weakened — it will become harder for Ireland to explain why these institutions matter. Recent shifts in migration policy is a clear example. The Council’s position on the Return Regulation shaped in part by the rise of the far-right across Europe, is out of step with the views of Irish. ESRI research shows broad public support in Ireland for migrants and refugees and a strong preference for humane and principled policies. When EU decisions move away from that, it creates a disconnect between EU values and the values Irish people hold. By defending the values the founding principles of the EU, principles and values that Irish people hold, this will increase ownership and alignment around shared and principled values. The public are supportive of Ireland standing up for human rights, for global justice, and for development cooperation that reaches the people who need it most. Civil society can play a critical role here, not only in helping the Presidency tell these stories but in supporting Ireland to develop positions through meaningful engagement before and during the Presidency. Structured dialogue with civil society in Ireland, alongside engagement through Ireland’s embassy networks, would help ensure EU priorities are shaped by real experiences, reinforce public trust, and demonstrate that the Presidency is something citizens can see themselves reflected in.

sector:
ActionAid Ireland is an international NGO focused on women’s rights working in the area of human rights, development and humanitarian response. 
We adopt a human rights approach to development and working towards sustainable, long-term change to address the root causes of poverty and injustice more effectively.
geography: Global - our submission will focus predominately on the EU’s external action with a focus on its role in the Global South.
response_text: Ireland’s Presidency will take place in a time of rising conflict, including the illegal Russian invasion of Ukraine, which has created direct security threats in Europe. At a moment like this, Ireland’s history of peacebuilding and neutrality gives us a credible role to push for a stronger focus on peacebuilding, diplomacy and conflict prevention. In March of 2025 Ursula von der Leyen introduced a new €800 billion package to increase military spending within the EU—an effort comparable to the €806 billion allocated for post-COVID recovery. Within this focus, not enough attention is paid to an EU long-term peace and development strategy that prioritise conflict resolution, prevention, mediation and peacebuilding. States have an obligation to protect their citizens, and the reality is Europe is facing new threats. However, higher military budgets have not proven to be the best approach to ensuring lasting peace. Instead, they risk escalating tensions, prompting other nations to increase their own military spending. This can lead to an arms race and a greater likelihood of military interventions, potentially worsening conflicts rather than preventing them. The projected levels of investment (EU 2%) bring us back to the 1990s level of spending. Investing in conflict prevention on the other hand saves lives, with potential savings between US$698 million and $1.5 billion per year. There is little evidence available to suggest that building military-security capabilities leads to reform, and improved peace, justice and development outcomes. Take the example of Afghanistan, evidence shows how military spending did not lead to security in the region. Despite 16 states supplying the country with weapons and equipment for nearly two decades and the US spending 83 billion USD on training and arming Afghanistan National Defense and Security Forces (ANDSF), chaos and fear engulfed Afghanistan as the Taliban swiftly defeated the ANDSF in the wake of the US withdrawal in 2021. This example illustrates how little military spending and militarisation of a society have to do with peace, safety, and stability, and how, in fact, military spending undermines these. Military expenditure has a huge impact on and plays a role in the climate crises, which constitute a major threat to peace and security In 2019, it was reported that the US military, the world’s largest industrial military, was the single biggest polluter in the world. Militarization can facilitate GBV and sexual violence in conflict, destabilize communities, exacerbate power imbalances, and reinforce already existing patriarchal structures. Excessive prioritization of defense spending diverts resources from education, healthcare, economic development, climate action, and ODA, all of which are fundamental to long-term peace and stability. These sectors are already underfunded globally, and in Europe, climate finance commitments remain insufficient given the scale of the crisis. Given our history of conflict and our commitment to neutrality, Ireland is perfectly placed to use its Presidency to champion Article 26 of the Charter of the United Nations. Which recognizes disarmament as a precondition for durable peace, security and development.

sector: International development, humanitarian action, human rights and equality
response_text: A Union of Values At a time of heightened geopolitical competition and conflict at Europe’s borders and around the world, rising inequality, accelerating climate change and growing forced displacement, Ireland’s Presidency of the Council of the European Union represents a timely opportunity to reassert the EU’s founding values: human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights - and to show that these values matter in practice. Ireland can seek to reaffirm those values connected to the lived reality of European and global citizens today. It can elevate the values and test all agreements, legislative proposals and agreed EU positions against their adherence to the founding mission of the European Union. It can institute a new reporting mechanism for accountability related to the founding values. Oxfam proposes the following areas as thematic priorities sitting underneath the values umbrella. A: Europe and its role in the world Recent shifts to an EU more focused on self-interest and geoeconomic goals endanger development gains in the global south and risk increasing the debt burden of partner countries. We propose a rebalancing of this agenda back in favour of achieving the Sustainable Development Goals and restoring the true spirit of international development cooperation. Oxfam proposes the Irish Presidency focuses on: Ensuring the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) is a clear expression of EU values and creating a new complementary strategy to the Global Gateway that prioritises political support and funding towards poverty reduction, fragile states and reaching the furthest behind first. Continuing to lead the EU to take a stronger position to protect the people of Palestine Play a central role in ensuring sufficient humanitarian assistance for those in conflict e.g. in Sudan, Gaza, Ukraine and holding those who perpetrate human rights abuses to account. Focus on Africa Ireland could place particular emphasis on Africa and EU–African Union relations, along the lines of the Spanish Presidency’s focus on Latin America in 2023. With 11 of Ireland’s 14 aid partner countries located in Africa, and given the continent’s disproportionate exposure to conflict, poverty, inequality and climate change, Ireland is well placed to help the EU build a genuine partnership grounded in equality, trust and African leadership. B: A more equal Europe “Inequality has become one of the main concerns for EU citizens” DG Employment, Social Affairs and Inclusion (DG-EMPL). We propose a focus on: EU-wide advances for more progressive taxation to fund public services for all Prioritise the lived experience of European citizens including on affordable housing and decent work, especially for vulnerable groups Prioritise rights and resist deregulation C: A green and digital future A future-proofed, decarbonised economy can be the foundation for a more sustainable future, but only with fairness and human rights at their core. We propose a focus on: Ensuring the EU embeds a just transition in all climate action, including in COP31 so that meeting 2040 climate targets does not disproportionately fall on those who can least afford it. Recognising digital rights as the fulcrum for democracy and regulating the tech industry to protect citizens across Europe and globally.

sector: International development, humanitarian action, human rights and equality
response_text: A Union of Values Undertake a renewed Living Our Values process that embeds transparency and accountability into EU decision-making. This should systematically assess the real-world impact of legislative proposals and agreed EU positions on affected communities, including through: Mandatory poverty and inequality impact assessments Systematic climate justice analysis Assessment of extraterritorial human rights impacts Europe and its role in the world Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) Ireland should lead agreement on an MFF that strengthens the EU’s global role in advancing justice and sustainability, including: A complementary strategy to Global Gateway that rebalances political attention and funding towards poverty reduction, fragile states and those furthest behind Full compliance of NDICI – Global Europe with Article 208 TFEU, restoring poverty eradication as its primary objective and alignment with the OECD definition of ODA At least €200 billion (0.2% of EU collective GNI) for external action Separate financial instruments for development cooperation, humanitarian assistance and pre-accession assistance Ringfenced funding to tackle gender-based violence in partner countries Migration Official development assistance must focus on communities most in need and not be instrumentalised for border control. Ireland should challenge the externalisation of EU border management, oppose opaque migration deals with third countries, and insist that all such agreements and monitoring reports are published and subject to democratic scrutiny. Migration instruments should prioritise safer, cheaper mobility by expanding safe and legal pathways to the EU, reducing reliance on smugglers and traffickers. The EU Pact for the Mediterranean and plans to strengthen Frontex must reflect collective EU responsibility to ensure the Mediterranean is a safe route, not a deadly barrier. A more equal Europe Encourage a stronger Commission role in advancing tax justice, including proposals for EU-level capital gains and wealth taxes, an EU assets registry, and a ban on harmful regimes for individuals such as “golden passports”. Build cross-EU support for a UN Framework Convention on International Tax Cooperation to ensure developing countries can participate equally in global tax reform. Ensure the Quality Jobs Act delivers improved working conditions, addresses gender inequality, and guarantees living wages across global supply chains and within the EU. The green transition must create decent, secure jobs, particularly for workers currently in precarious employment or in sectors most affected by decarbonisation. A green and digital future Climate justice Use upcoming reforms of the Circular Economy framework, Energy Union, Climate Action architecture and Climate Resilience framework to position the EU as a global leader at COP31, including by: Targeting emissions linked to excessive consumption Applying polluter-pays and windfall taxes on fossil fuel companies Strengthening corporate sustainability regulation Digital rights Adopt a strong, enforceable Digital Fairness Act that centres people’s rights and safeguards the integrity of the EU’s digital rulebook. Simplification Prioritise the quality of protections over the quantity of laws. Any simplification process must respect human rights and climate commitments, ensure transparency, and meaningfully include civil society, affected communities, workers and public-interest actors in EU law-making.

sector: International development, humanitarian action, human rights and equality
response_text: It can show citizens that it is clearly on the side of the citizen and not the side of the already monied and powerful. The EU Council can open up EU law-making processes more, especially to those who do not have ready access to Brussels-based policymakers. This opening up should allow impacted communities to engage and influence policy and law in a way that is meangingful and respectful. It can help Europeans understand how they fit into a just future that protects the planet. It can regulate digital platforms to curb the negative impact of social media and mis/disinformation to help build trust in digital media. It can examine ways to restore the citizen to the place of owner of their own data and the content they create. Specifically it can: Design a decarbonised sustainable economy Commit to an economic model focused on equality, wellbeing and planetary health. Recognise a more equal economy is a stronger one Advance gender equality and social inclusion as economic strengths. Deliver a just green transition that works for communities and business Support a just transition with community investment and community benefit from the use of resources in their area. Ensuring the cost of climate and energy measures are placed on the polluters and those with the greatest ability to afford it. Provide policy certainty for businesses through clear, ambitious climate pathways and a regulation process that levels the playing field between large and small businesses. Shape a digital future based on rights and innovation Implement digital rules in ways that protect privacy, freedom of expression and civic space, thereby building public trust in digital services. Set out a pathway for the democratisation of digital information so that people and communities can own and use their own digital information, not just large monopolistic platforms. Ensuring digital infrastructure growth aligns with environmental sustainability and community consent. Address the crisis in trust Ireland can lead Council work that responds to declining trust - especially among younger people - by: Advancing the European Democracy Shield in ways that protect independent media, civil society and human rights defenders. Investing in media literacy, participation and transparency, helping people see how EU decisions affect their lives. Keeping the Council’s work open and participatory, reinforcing the EU’s values of democracy and the rule of law. Show the EU acts when international law is being broken Show that the EU has clear accountability measures for those actors, either in Europe or without, who perpetrate serious human rights abuses, continue illegal occupations, commit war crimes or crimes against humanity. Stand up for the Charters we have signed up for and the Courts we are party to. Implement their rulings and refuse complicity in the face of genocide and man-made famine.

sector: International development, humanitarian action, human rights and equality
response_text: Security is everyday Show how security is an everyday thing – secure jobs, secure and affordable energy, secure and affordable housing, clean air, safe water, safe online spaces, freedom from abuse and violence. Values must be experienced to be real Be explicit that the founding values are expressed through action, not only rhetoric. How does the commitment to democracy and human dignity make my life better? How am I more free because of the EU. Be straightforward and honest Acknowledge challenges, both internal and external, rather than glossing over them. The rise of populism shows a form of political communication where people are rejecting technocratic explanations in favour of “straight talking”. This, of course, has its dark side but it shows that exclusive language without real-life application can be hollow for citizens. What is the story of the EU? The greatest peace project of our time - how does this resonate in the 21st century? How are we stronger when we come together? How is the EU forging the future that we need? How is the EU leading the world, not simply responding to the actions of other major powers? Possible outreach methodologies Presidency youth delegates from every county / local authority Consultation with communities throughout Ireland where their priorities are influential and are acted upon by the Irish presidency Trips to Brussels for Irish community groups – youth, retired, migrant, traveller… - but again where their input is meaningful and influential Social media influencers influence the Presidency Irish public representatives speak to schools etc about the upcoming Presidency, what it means and how citizens can get involved and get closer to the centre of Europe Open up the processes, not simply to explain or to extol them, but to involve Bring sectors together to engage with each other as well as with policymakers i.e. business civil society, youth, farmers, sport, art, academia. Include children in policy formation Note: Oxfam Ireland is undertaking a “The Europe that we want” process with young people from across the 4 provinces of Ireland to ascertain their values, their priorities and help design a young people’s Manifesto for Europe.

sector: International development, humanitarian action, human rights and equality
response_text: Competitiveness and security are the watchwords of the European Union right now and this is entirely understandable. We suggest that security is not simply about military defence and preparedness. Indeed, real security is a few steps back. It is in dealing with the root causes of conflict, the inequality that allows extremism to thrive, the climate change that endangers whole regions and causes resource wars. Long term security is in human development and a more equal future for all. Aware throughout all of this process that Ireland is one of 27 members, we submit that seeking to or going some way to redirecting the EU towards an contemporary expression of its founding values is one that will benefit Ireland, the EU and the rest of the world.

sector: Clinical Psychology, Health Psychology, School Psychology, Food Allergy and Anaphylaxis
response_text: Taking into account the current geopolitical and socioeconomic context in Europe, we recommend that Ireland prioritise Health Protection, Citizen Safety, and Resilient Societies as core themes of its 2026 Presidency. Serious allergies and anaphylaxis are rising across Europe and place a growing burden on individuals, schools, workplaces, and public services. Addressing them fits naturally within broader objectives to protect citizens’ wellbeing and reduce preventable health risks. 1 . A R e s i l i e n t an d P r e p a r e d E u r o p e The EU must be equipped to respond to emergencies—whether acute health events, natural disasters, or public safety threats. This requires harmonised emergency response systems, stronger community level preparedness, and cross-border cooperation. Ireland is one of the few Member States that has taken concrete steps to improve preparedness for serious allergic reactions, including allowing pharmacists to supply emergency medicines without a prescription during anaphylactic events. This national practice demonstrates effective emergency readiness and provides a model for EU-level policy coordination, which could inform upcoming initiatives under the European Health Union framework aimed at strengthening preparedness, prevention, and rapid response across Member States. 2 . A P e o p l e -C e n t r e d U n i o n t h a t P r o t e c t s Embedding people-centred principles into EU policymaking ensures that vulnerable populations and individuals at risk of medical emergencies are not left behind. The Presidency could advance reducing health inequalities across the EU, highlighting uneven access to diagnosis, specialist care, and emergency response protocols. Positioning timely care for serious allergies and anaphylaxis within this agenda demonstrates a commitment to practical, measurable improvements in patient safety and inclusion, while protecting citizens’ rights to safety in everyday environments such as schools, childcare centres, workplaces, and public venues. 3 . A F u t u r e -O r i e n t e d E u r o p e B u i l t o n I n n o v a t i o n a n d C o l l a b o r a t i o n Ireland’s strong reputation in digital innovation offers an opportunity to promote Digital Innovation for Health, leveraging the European Health Data Space and interoperable, patient-centred tools. For individuals at risk of serious allergic reactions, seamless access to medical information across borders can prevent emergencies and support the free movement of people. The Presidency can also prioritise harmonised awareness-raising, institutional readiness, and capacity building, ensuring schools, businesses, and public institutions are equipped and trained to respond effectively to life-threatening health incidents.

sector: Clinical Psychology, Health Psychology, School Psychology, Food Allergy and Anaphylaxis
response_text: Ireland could use its Presidency to champion health resilience, citizen protection, and emergency preparedness, leveraging its national leadership in anaphylaxis response as a model for EU coordination. Key priorities include: 1. Health Protection and Emergency Preparedness Serious allergies and anaphylaxis present a growing public-health challenge. The Presidency could: Promote timely access to emergency medicines, building on Ireland’s approach where pharmacists can supply life-saving treatment without prescription. Encourage harmonised school and public-venue preparedness, using Ireland as an example. Relevant upcoming EU initiative: Global health resilience initiative (non-legislative, Q2 2026) – to strengthen EU capacity for rapid response to health crises. 2. Digital Innovation for Health Cross-border emergencies require seamless access to patient data: • Promote the European Health Data Space for secure, interoperable sharing of health information, enabling faster response to anaphylactic events across borders. • Support digital tools for citizen-centred care, enhancing emergency response and patient safety. 3. Reducing Health Inequalities and Strengthening Citizen Rights The Presidency could advance equitable access to emergency care and citizen-centred policy: • Link preparedness to strengthening the Child Guarantee (non-legislative, Q2 2026) and Citizens omnibus (legislative, Q4 2026), ensuring children in schools, childcare centres, and communities are protected and have their rights effectively enforced. • Promote intergenerational fairness through the Intergenerational fairness strategy (non legislative, Q1 2026), ensuring emergency preparedness and health access benefit current and future generations equally. • Highlight Ireland’s model as a practical, replicable approach for other Member States. Objectives • Establish a model for EU-level anaphylaxis and emergency response coordination, based on best practices of Ireland. • Ensure equitable access to life-saving treatments across the EU. • Promote digital innovation for preparedness, information sharing, and cross-border patient care. • Strengthen citizen rights and intergenerational fairness, ensuring public health policies reflect social equity. • Position health resilience as a pillar of EU citizen safety and social cohesion, demonstrating tangible improvements in public health readiness.
