By focusing on these targeted initiatives, Ireland can use its Presidency to deliver practical, measurable impacts on citizen safety, health equity, and cross-border emergency preparedness while reinforcing the EU’s social and legal frameworks.

sector: Clinical Psychology, Health Psychology, School Psychology, Food Allergy and Anaphylaxis
response_text: The Irish Presidency has the potential to deliver significant, tangible impact for EU citizens by advancing health resilience and consumer safety. For individuals with serious allergies, policies that improve emergency response, access to medicines, and accurate allergen information can be life-saving. For people, expanded access to emergency treatment, including pharmacy-enabled emergency supply across the EU, enhances safety in daily life. Citizens with serious allergies would be better protected in schools, workplaces, sports facilities, cultural venues, and during cross-border travel. For businesses, harmonised allergen-labelling and staff-training expectations reduce regulatory uncertainty, simplify compliance, and improve consumer trust by fostering safer public environments. For communities and institutions, EU-supported readiness measures ,such as common school protocols, public-venue guidelines, and accessible training ,would significantly reduce preventable emergencies, supporting all three Alliance objectives. Replicating Ireland’s best practice on emergency medicine access would ensure that life-saving intervention is available regardless of where a reaction occurs, reducing inequalities across Member States.

sector: Clinical Psychology, Health Psychology, School Psychology, Food Allergy and Anaphylaxis
response_text: Ireland has a strong opportunity to communicate the value of EU membership by focusing on everyday benefits and practical improvements that resonate directly with citizens. The 2026 Presidency can show how EU cooperation protects people, strengthens communities, and makes daily life safer—particularly in areas such as emergency preparedness for serious allergies and anaphylaxis. Highlight Practical Examples of EU Solidarity Citizens understand the EU best when they see clear, relatable outcomes. Ireland can communicate EU values by highlighting how cooperation improves safety and wellbeing, for example: • Safer environments in schools, restaurants, transport and public venues. • Shared health information that makes travel within the EU safer and more predictable. • Harmonised allergen-labelling rules that protect consumers wherever they are. • More consistent access to emergency support for serious allergic reactions. Ireland’s own approach—allowing pharmacists to supply emergency treatment during a serious allergic reaction—provides a concrete example of national leadership that improves citizen safety. Propose Council Recommendations on Emergency Readiness To strengthen public understanding of the EU’s benefits, Ireland could lead on a visible, citizen-centred initiative: Develop Council Recommendations on broader readiness and access to emergency treatment for serious allergy and anaphylaxis. This would help encourage Member States to: • Improve preparedness in schools, public venues, workplaces, and transport hubs. • Ensure trained responders are available across community settings. • Reduce inequalities in access to time-sensitive, life-saving care. Such an initiative is easy for citizens to relate to, directly improves safety, and demonstrates EU cooperation in a human, practical way. 3. A simple message: the EU protects people By showcasing initiatives that make everyday life safer, including better emergency preparedness for serious allergic reactions, the Irish Presidency can reinforce a clear message: EU cooperation delivers real, practical benefits for families, children, workers, and communities. This people-centred framing will strengthen public trust, build ownership, and demonstrate the concrete value of Ireland’s leadership at EU level.

Ireland’s presidency of the Council of the European Union offers a valuable opportunity to shape the presidency’s agenda so that it reflects the priorities and challenges of the European Union as a whole, while also considering Ireland’s perspectives. The Shannon Airport Group welcomes the opportunity to provide input to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade as it prepares Ireland’s Presidency priorities and policy programme and believe one high level priority should focus on Transport. Transport Strong international transport links have long sustained Ireland’s economy, and this emphasis must guide our Presidency agenda. Transport is not only a national priority for Ireland but a strategic pillar of the European Union’s competitiveness, cohesion, and climate transition. As highlighted in the Draghi Report, “well‑functioning transport networks and services and a prosperous transport industry are crucial to the competitiveness of the entire EU economy”. Efficient transport systems not only ensure access to goods, services, and innovation, but also drive territorial balance and social inclusion across member states. For Ireland, as an island nation reliant on aviation and maritime, the resilience and sustainability of transport infrastructure is inseparable from our competitiveness and our ability to contribute to Europe’s collective prosperity. At EU level, transport is recognised as a service of general interest and a priority sector for the transition to a net‑zero economy. With demand for passenger and freight mobility projected to grow sharply by 2050, and with emissions from transport still higher than in 1990, Ireland’s presidency of the Council of the EU in 2026 offers a critical opportunity to champion investment in resilient, sustainable transport that strengthens both Ireland’s connectivity and the EU’s collective prosperity. As an island nation, Ireland’s presidency of the EU council should strongly advocate for transport investment in island nations and those at Europe’s periphery. Transport policy at a European level must explicitly recognise the catalytic role of airports and ports in island and peripheral economies. Uniform EU-wide frameworks risk overlooking structural asymmetries, such as geographic isolation, that constrain the capacity of peripheral member states to benefit equally from transport integration. Addressing these imbalances requires differentiated policy design and funding criteria that account for national geography, spatial location within the Union. Funding Investment in Transport Ireland’s 2026 Presidency is strategically timed to influence the next EU budget (MFF 2028–2034). By chairing negotiations, hosting summits, and representing the Council, Ireland will play a pivotal role in shaping Europe’s financial priorities for the next decade. The Connecting Europe Facility (CEF) 2028– 2034 prioritises transport and energy pillars alongside military mobility, with its financial envelope proposed to increase to €81.4 billion from €33.72 billion in the 2021–2027 period. The oversubscription of CEF calls in 2021–2027, with projects averaging three to four times the available budget, underscores the scale of demand for investment. Ireland should stand firmly behind the ambition to expand the CEF and resist any downward revision to funding during interinstitutional negotiations. Moreover, consideration should be given to how EU funds can better serve Island and peripheral regions of Europe.

Aviation Policy should be a key focus for Ireland Recognising aviation’s strategic importance as a driver of Europe’s economic growth and connectivity, the Irish Presidency should lend its full support to the European Commission’s forthcoming Industrial Aviation Strategy. This strategy has the potential to be a cornerstone of Europe’s aviation future, setting the direction of EU research and innovation funding while advancing the twin imperatives of decarbonisation and digitalisation, alongside safeguarding competitiveness. Industry stakeholders have called for a significant increase in EU funding for civil aviation research in the next long-term budget to ensure Europe remains at the forefront of global aviation innovation. From an Irish perspective, expanded funding offers opportunities to expand research funding for universities and aviation firms, to leverage Ireland’s renewable energy strengths, to scale digital air traffic management innovations already pioneered by the Irish Aviation Authority and to advance cybersecurity investment under NIS2. By championing these priorities, the Irish Presidency can help ensure that Ireland not only contributes to Europe’s aviation transformation but secure Ireland’s position as a global leader in the sector. The decarbonisation of the aviation sector remains a key challenge. Currently, limited availability of Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) across Europe, coupled with insufficient incentives for its production and adoption, is hindering progress on decarbonisation even as EU requirements continue to expand. In an Irish context, the Shannon Estuary has been identified as Ireland’s leading site for Atlantic offshore wind, creating a major opportunity to produce green hydrogen and SAF. Producing SAF within the estuary creates an opportunity to decarbonise the aviation sector here, which will be vital to Ireland as an island nation critically reliant upon air connectivity. The production of SAF also provides a mechanism to sustainably store excess green hydrogen from the estuary and opens the opportunity for Ireland to become a net energy exporter. The Irish Presidency of the EU Council provides an opportunity to further support the development of SAF both at a European and National level and position Ireland as a hub for SAF research and deployment. Ten T The Draghi Report highlights, the potential of the EU’s transport sector has not yet been fully leveraged, noting that completion of TEN‑T is projected to bring an annual GDP increase of €467 billion by 2050, requiring an estimated €845 billion in investment by 2040, including €210 billion for cross‑border links. The completion of the core network by 2030 and the extended core by 2040 will deliver an interconnected, interoperable, smart, safe, sustainable, resilient, and multimodal European transport system, strengthening competitiveness and cohesion across the Union. Strengthening the integration of peripheral regions into the core Trans-European Transport Network (TEN-T) is not only a matter of national interest but also a broader European imperative for competitiveness, cohesion, and resilience. Supporting the timely completion of the Trans‑European Transport Network (TEN‑T) must be a central priority during Ireland’s Presidency of the Council of the EU in 2026.

As the European Union reaffirms its leadership in the global race for technological innovation, it must do so without compromising the values that define it: democracy, freedom of expression, respect for human fundamental rights and the richness and diversity of European cultures. Today, one of the greatest threats to European values is the rapid development of Artificial Intelligence, which places significant pressure on the Cultural and Creative Sectors (CCSs). The Irish Presidency has the unique opportunity to demonstrate that the CCSs lie at the heart of the digital era and AI development, as an EU that neglects culture is an EU that compromises its fundamental values. By promoting a digital environment that is fair and supportive of European creativity, the Presidency can ensure that rightsholders are protected and that the EU copyright framework is fully respected and enforced, safeguarding the very foundation of Europe’s cultural and innovative strength. The overarching priority should be to use the power of culture and creativity to drive both innovation and the preservation of Europe’s core values.

The Irish Presidency should actively support the European Commission in safeguarding authors’ rights by ensuring the proper implementation of the AI Act and DSM Directive. In the course of the assessment of the DSM Directive, clarification is needed with regard to the applicability of Art. 3 and 4 to AI training. While the Juri report from the European Parliament emphasises that the rules on Text and Data Mining (TDM) were never meant to cover AI training, it became obvious that such interpretation would seriously be in conflict with the EU Copyright Framework. It must be made clear that neither Art. 3 nor Art. 4 cover the (entire) process of AI training and that any use of protected works for AI training would need a license from the authors. Further, Art. 4 DSM Directive is the first ever limitation for commercial purposes and bears a very high risk of being in conflict with the three-step test. It is therefore necessary to specify that TDM following Art. 4 DSM directive may not be used for commercial AI uses. Beyond the AI Act and its implementing Code of Practice, further legislation is needed to ensure fair remuneration of authors in the fast-evolving technical environment. Technical solutions have not solved the problems of digital mass uses of works – but bear the high risk of being outdated before they can be implemented. The European legislators should rather rely on the abstract principles of copyright which proved fit to adapt to the immense technical changes of the last 100 years. Clearing rights for the use of a very high number of works can be achieved with CMOs, offering simple licenses to mass users. Yet, European rightsholders would also need the support of the national and pan European institutions to defend their rights. For example, anti-trust remedies might be taken into consideration in cases where a user tries to evade licenses offered to him or in cases where unlicensed use of works results in content which is re-commercialised in Europe. These legislations have the potential to significantly impact the lives of European visual artists, making it essential to consider their effects while large technological companies continue to generate massive profits at the expense of creators. The Irish Presidency should also engage closely with stakeholders, paying careful attention to the needs and challenges of the CCSs. By doing so, it can demonstrate that European institutions are capable of driving positive change, contributing to a thriving society, and promoting innovation while consistently upholding the values of cultural diversity and democracy.

We have seen in previous Presidencies of the Council that the most effective way to make a positive impact is to engage directly with people. To achieve this, it is crucial to involve stakeholders through questionnaires, consultations, roundtables, and thematic conferences—not as one-sided monologues, but as opportunities for policymakers and stakeholders to exchange views and improve the whole society. Understanding what happens in people’s lives is the first step toward a European Union that is truly closer to its citizens.

As noted above, it is essential that European citizens feel connected to and engaged with the work of the EU. Social media offer the most immediate way to reach people, and the messages shared through these channels should highlight practical examples of the Presidency’s work and impact. In addition, public events in Brussels and across Ireland can spark curiosity and interest, helping citizens understand and appreciate the positive effects of the Council Presidency’s work.

must provide a summary of the additional information under the ‘Any other comments’ question. This summary should also be limited to a maximum of 500 words. Ensuring a decent livelihood for artists is vital to fostering a flourishing cultural sector. This is also recognised by Commissioner for Intergenerational Fairness, Youth, Culture and Sport Glenn Micallef, who, through the “Culture Compass” initiative, has put forward an EU Artists’ Charter aimed at empowering artists and cultural professionals. Authors can create only if they receive a fair remuneration, and every source of income plays a critical role. It is therefore crucial to preserve and reinforce remuneration rights (such as Public Lending Right, private copy, resale right, reprography and so on) especially as these are increasingly challenged by counter-lobbying efforts that do not consider how essential these rights are to artists’ livelihoods. Where such remuneration is due for uses made for cultural and educational purposes, the beneficiaries must be sustainably funded and be able to pay fair and adequate remuneration to the authors. For these reasons, it is also important that limitations and exceptions to copyright are not further expanded, including in the digital environment, as this would also undermine authors’ income opportunities, whereas the existing framework already cover essential areas such as education.

NetApp would encourage Ireland to focus on 3 broad areas, all of which relate to the core themes of boosting Europe’s competitiveness and resilience: Securing the ICT Supply Chain – Data is one of Europe’s most prized strategic assets when it comes to competitiveness. Like 5G infrastructure and submarine cables, data infrastructure intersects with matters of national economic security, particularly as it pertains to critical or sensitive sectors such as many public services, financial services, healthcare, revenue collection, law enforcement and education. However, we have observed an inconsistent approach from Member State to Member State in ensuring that Europe’s data is stored in secure locations with secure and trustworthy providers. To that end, we would encourage the Irish Presidency to work towards a common position on the use of ‘trusted vendor’ criteria to ensure that both public and private sector organisations are partnering with reliable ICT and data infrastructure partners. Ensuring Procurement Supports EU Objectives – Procuring authorities have, far too often, been focused on price, selecting the lowest bid regardless of the track record of the supplier in question, or the potential risks they pose, ultimately undermining the resilience and security of key sectors of the economy. Broadly, we recommend the Irish Presidency encourage further discussion on how public authorities move away from using price as the sole criteria for procurement, towards a position where quality, consisting of factors like price, safety, sustainability, and resilience, become the norm. Building Europe’s Data Infrastructure – Scaling Europe’s capabilities in cloud and artificial intelligence will be a core goal of the upcoming CAIDA. The ability to scale these industries will be key to Europe’s global competitiveness and attractiveness in the coming decades. We would, therefore, encourage the Irish Presidency to promote discussion on how Europe’s data infrastructure can be developed in a secure and sustainable manner, whilst ensuring access to best-in-class technologies.

areas? Securing the ICT Supply Chain Both the publication of the ICT Supply Chain Toolbox, and the revision of the EU Cybersecurity Act (‘CSA’) will be excellent opportunities for Member States to reinforce trust and security in the ICT Supply Chain. The Irish Presidency can deliver a pragmatic agenda when it comes to cybersecurity, focusing on: Prioritizing supply chain security in data infrastructure – foster dialogue on a consistent approach to the implementation of the ICT Supply Chain Toolbox at national level, protecting valuable data from backdoor vulnerabilities and cyberattacks whilst ensuring continued access to leading technologies. Delivering a workable approach to cyber certification – in the context of the CSA, work towards a European Cybersecurity Certification Framework (ECCF) that facilitates the rapid adoption of certification schemes that deliver functional outcomes for cybersecurity assurance and minimize the risk of political stalemate. Ensuring Procurement Supports EU Objectives A proposal to revise the Public Procurement Directives is expected Q2 2026, while initiatives like the Cloud and AI Development Act (‘CAIDA’) and Review of the CSA, may also impact the way cloud and data storage solutions are procured. In that regard, we urge the Irish Presidency to prioritize the discussion of several issues: Advancing functional, quality-driven procurement practices – ensure procuring authorities focus on the best possible quality supply when it comes to procurement, considering a wide range of factors including price, safety, sustainability, and resilience. Developing a harmonized approach to ‘trusted vendor’ – work with Member States, in the context of these initiatives, to form a consistent view on what constitutes a ‘trusted vendor’, reflecting organizations’ governance, risk management and transparency practices. This definition should then be applied horizontally across relevant initiatives to ensure consistency in procurement practices between Member State authorities. Indeed, we consider that the horizontal application of ‘trusted vendor’ criteria will be fundamental to reinforcing the trust dimension of Europe’s approach to sovereignty and European preference, central to the current technology policy agenda. Developing the concept of ‘European preference’ – advance the discussion on how the definition of ‘European preference’ can be operationalized to deliver on the objectives of strategic autonomy and competitiveness, while providing European businesses with the best chance to succeed globally by ensuring access to cutting-edge technology. Building Europe’s Data Infrastructure CAIDA should ensure that Europe remains an attractive place for investment in data infrastructure, and that it is open to trustworthy international partners to contribute. We would urge the Irish Presidency to prioritize: Developing a workable definition of ‘sovereign cloud’ – developing such a definition should be a high priority so providers can augment their existing partnerships as soon as possible to deliver compliant solutions to the market. • Continuing to attract third-country investment – foster a discussion on the creation of frameworks that allow non-EU firms to continue to participate in the European cloud and AI markets when they meet ‘sovereignty-aligned’ criteria (e.g., data residency, transparency, etc.).

As public and private sector organizations digitalize, their data must be stored in an environment that is safe and allows for the maximization of its value to drive better decision-making. Choosing a ‘trusted vendor’ is key to achieving both. It ensures that organizations can take full advantage of their data, benefit fully from new technologies like AI, advance their competitiveness, and navigate an ever-expanding cyber risk landscape. The security, sustainability and flexibility of data infrastructure is fundamental as the EU looks to move ahead with the digital transition, protect its security interests and boost its competitiveness in key industrial ecosystems. Thus, Europe needs to ensure that it has access to cutting-edge technologies from trusted providers and does not leave its data vulnerable to backdoor attacks or cyberthreats from hostile actors. An agenda that prioritizes these issues benefits both business and citizens to the extent that it takes steps towards ensuring their data is protected and secure. More broadly, Europe’s competitiveness will be strengthened by taking a pragmatic approach that balances security and sovereignty with openness and cooperation, encouraging inward investment and local skills development. It is this approach that has allowed Ireland to attract so many technology companies to establish their regional and international bases of operations.

Whilst this question is an important one, it is not one on which NetApp has a strong view or expertise. Therefore, we would confine our response to the issues on which we have concrete experience and knowledge.

We have included a position paper that summarizes our answers to Questions 1 – 3. We would welcome further engagement with the Irish Presidency and look forward to collaborating on an agenda that benefits businesses and citizens alike.

Renewing Social Europe: Embed fairness, social cohesion, and wellbeing at the heart of EU policymaking. Youth Empowerment & Inclusion: Make youth unemployment and participation central themes; defend dedicated youth funding. Just Transition & Sustainability: Champion climate action and SDGs under a Presidency theme such as “Delivering the SDGs: A Sustainable Europe for Future Generations.” Democratic Participation: Strengthen civic space and counter disinformation to protect EU values. Addressing Youth Unemployment as a Strategic Objective for Social Europe As Ireland prepares to assume the EU Presidency, tackling youth unemployment must stand as a central pillar of our broader theme on Social Europe. CSO figures reveal a troubling rise in youth unemployment. Particularly alarming is the surge among 15–19-year-olds, signalling growing vulnerability among those with limited educational attainment and minimal labour market experience. Across Europe, young people face increasingly complex transitions from education to employment, exacerbated by technological disruption, automation, and precarious work. Without decisive action, these dynamics risk deepening intergenerational inequality. The revitalisation of the Youth Guarantee, focussing on the European Youth Forum’s Position Paper on Youth Guarantee: How to support young people finding a pathway, must be a cornerstone of EU social policy. Youth work has a critical role to play in this strategy. Operating in informal, out-of-school settings, youth work services engage directly with those furthest from the labour market, including NEETs. By providing outreach, mentoring, and bridging programmes focused on skill development and job readiness, youth work complements formal education and activation measures. Its capacity to build confidence, foster resilience, and develop transferable skills makes it an indispensable resource for employability. To maximise impact, we must uphold quality standards in youth work, ensuring consistency, accountability, and measurable outcomes across Member States. Investing in professional development and evidence-based practice will strengthen youth. Tackling mis and disinformation False information is eroding trust in institutions, fuelling hate speech, and disproportionately impacting young people, who are increasingly exposed to misleading narratives across social media and AI-generated content. Focus groups and studies show that misinformation not only overwhelms and fatigues youth, but also disengages them from civic life, while extremist networks exploit disinformation to recruit and radicalise. Addressing this challenge at the EU level is essential to safeguard democratic processes, protect vulnerable communities, and build resilience among citizens against the evolving threats of false information. Investing in Youth Work, Intercultural and Global Citizenship Educators to help address this issue will be important in tackling mis and disinformation at personal, local, national, and European levels and in turn, should work to reduce negative narratives against people of colour in Europe and across the world.

Youth Employment & Education: Revitalise the Youth Guarantee with tailored pathways and adequate funding. Retain the Erasmus+ Youth Chapter with earmarked funding (minimum 15%). Safeguard the European Solidarity Corps as a distinct volunteering programme. Social Rights & Anti-Poverty: Advance a framework directive on adequate minimum income and enforceable social rights. Push for legislative initiatives to make the European Pillar of Social Rights binding. Enhanced focus on poverty reduction for global south countries. Just Transition & Climate: Protect Green Deal instruments and EU budget lines for climate and biodiversity. Ensure education is at the core, supporting people – individuals, farmers, communities, policy makers, business, and leaders to understand why this focus is important and how they can make changes for a better future. Digital & AI Governance: Develop EU-wide strategies for digital upskilling and mitigating automation risks. Youth focussed legislative Priorities for Ireland’s EU Presidency (2026) 1. Housing and Cost of Living Ireland should lead on EU-level measures to address housing affordability and social cohesion. Housing insecurity is a major barrier to youth wellbeing, as highlighted in the Youth Forum’s Youth Progress Index. The Presidency should work to remove EU regulatory obstacles that limit investment in social and affordable housing and advance initiatives such as the Affordable Housing Plan and a Council Recommendation on Ending Homelessness. The aim is to ensure adequate housing supply, protect vulnerable groups, and embed housing within the European Pillar of Social Rights. 2. Reform of the EU Electoral Act The Presidency should prioritise provisions that can achieve consensus, particularly standardising the voting age for European elections at 16 (Article 23 of the 2022 proposed text). Ireland should advocate a targeted approach—advancing select articles rather than the entire package—to strengthen youth participation and address persistently low voter turnout among young people. 3. Erasmus+ and Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) Ireland should secure a strong, well-funded youth chapter in Erasmus+, with earmarked structural and project-based funding for youth organisations. This is essential to safeguard civic space and democratic participation. The Presidency should also promote measures to support youth information services, linked to digital regulation and combating misinformation, deepfakes, and AI-driven threats. It should also support greater cooperation between European member states and countries in the Global South including EU-AU partnerships. Objectives include sustainable funding, stronger social media accountability, and access to regulatory mechanisms to protect young people and civil society. 4. Climate and SDGs Ireland should place education at the core of its approach to climate action and the Sustainable Development Goals, with a strong focus on Global Citizenship Education and Education for Sustainable Development. Ireland should champion the SDGs as a central theme, ensuring they guide policy and practice. Ireland must also provide strong leadership within the EU at COP31, advancing ambitious and inclusive climate commitments. A fair and compassionate approach to debt is also essential, recognising the disproportionate burdens faced by many countries. Finally, Ireland should work to establish tax equity between the Global South and Global North. For peace to take root, compromises must be made, and the interdependence of North and South, as well as rural and urban communities, must be acknowledged and respected.

People: Reduce youth unemployment through inclusive apprenticeships, digital skills programmes, and strong social safety nets. Businesses: Promote investment in job-intensive sectors (renewable energy, health, education) and fair labour standards. Communities: Strengthen social infrastructure, housing, childcare, and support social economy initiatives. The Irish Presidency can make the most substantial positive impact by making the work and role of the Council more visible and understandable to citizens, thereby strengthening trust in EU institutions. A key opportunity lies in addressing some of the more challenging recommendations from the Conference on the Future of Europe, including those linked to youth participation such as the 25% Project. Demonstrating progress on these proposals would show a genuine commitment to democratic renewal. Ireland’s strong track record in deliberative and participatory democracy, for example through citizens’assemblies, positions it to lead by example. The Presidency should integrate these principles into its approach, ensuring inclusive dialogue and transparency in decision-making. This could include referencing youth-driven recommendations from the EU Youth Dialogue consultations and embedding them in Council priorities.

To communicate the values and benefits of EU membership and create a sense of ownership over Ireland’s Presidency, we should build on proven engagement models such as those used during the European Year of Youth. Micro-grant schemes that empower local youth-led initiatives and ambitious, inclusive events can make EU values tangible. For example, the ‘All Abroad’ train event with Léargas demonstrated how creative experiences can connect young people to Europe in a meaningful way. Similarly, initiatives like Oíche na hÓige (Youth Night), where youth clubs and services across Ireland opened their doors to the community, showcased the impact of youth work and fostered dialogue between young people and the wider public. Replicating and scaling such events during the Presidency would highlight EU principles of diversity, equality, and inclusion while making them visible at local level. These efforts should be complemented by strong communication campaigns, social media engagement, and partnerships with schools and community organisations to ensure that citizens not only understand the benefits of EU membership but feel actively involved in shaping Ireland’s role in Europe.

Part 1: Synopsis of EU Youth Dialogue Consultation on Irish EU Presidency Priorities (Oct 2025) During the Young Voices consultation in Dublin, over 40 young people (ages 15–25) outlined their vision for Ireland’s upcoming EU Presidency. Their recommendations emphasise empowering youth as active European citizens through education, participation, and representation. Education for Active Citizenship Young people want the EU Presidency to champion reforms in education systems across member states. They call for curricula that address emerging challenges such as AI, misinformation, and propaganda, while fostering critical thinking and civic engagement. Education should be adaptive, thought-provoking, and equip youth with skills to navigate digital realities and participate meaningfully in democratic life. Inclusive Participation and Representation Participants stressed the need for accessible, meaningful spaces for youth engagement at local, national, and EU levels. They advocate for youth representation in decision-making structures and partnerships with elected representatives, ensuring diverse voices, urban and rural, are heard and valued. Support and Capacity Building The Presidency should promote initiatives that strengthen youth capacities and networks, such as Erasmus+ and Youth, Peace and Security consultations. These programmes enable cross-border learning, skill development, and active involvement in European affairs. Part 2: Synopsis of Community and Voluntary Pillar Proposals for Ireland Presidency of the EU The Community and Voluntary (CV) Pillar, of which NYCI is a member, urges Ireland to use its EU Presidency to renew the vision of a Social Europe, placing equality, solidarity, and human rights at the heart of EU policymaking. Against a backdrop of geopolitical instability, climate challenges, and rising inequality, the CV Pillar emphasises that economic growth must not overshadow social development. Three Core Themes for the Presidency: Strengthening Social Europe Make the European Pillar of Social Rights enforceable and integrate social objectives into EU economic governance. Advance an EU Anti-Poverty Strategy, including measures for child poverty, NEETs, housing, and homelessness. Promote an EU framework directive on adequate minimum income and ensure access to childcare, education, and healthcare. Safeguard cohesion funding in the Multiannual Financial Framework (2028–2034) and prioritise social investment. Enhancing Democracy & Civil Society Protect civic space and adopt Council Conclusions on civil society engagement. Secure sustainable EU funding for CSOs and promote inclusive governance. Counter disinformation and support initiatives like the EU Civil Society Strategy and Democracy Shield. Just Transition & Sustainability Champion the SDGs as a Presidency theme Protect Green Deal instruments and expand EU budget lines for climate action and biodiversity. Part 3: Synopsis of the Irish Development Education Association Proposals for Ireland Presidency of the EU Ireland should advocate for: A real global perspective in the Multi-Financial Framework proposal. In the current proposal, citizenship education is narrowly framed around EU values, overlooking global challenges like climate change, inequality, peace, and human rights. Reintegrating a global dimension is essential to equip young people with the skills, solidarity, and critical perspective needed to be responsible and active citizens. Development Education and Awareness Raising (DEAR) to remain a separate funding stream. It is in the EU's best interests that citizen engagement and global solidarity remain at the heart of the EU's global partnerships. Transparency, sustainability, and predictability in the financial support of Global Citizenship Education programmes, such as DEAR, Erasmus+, and AgoraEU.

Protecting democratic values and partnership with civil society Presidency of the EU provides an opportunity for Ireland to assert vital democratic values that are being eroded across several member States and globally. This includes human rights protections, the rule of law, free and fair elections, as well as protection of civic space for dialogue and defense of NGOs. When the rule of law and democracy are under attack from internal and external threats, civil society organisations act as watchdogs, promoting transparency and good governance, while also enabling people, including from disadvantaged groups, to participate in decision-making at local, national, and EU level. These organisations are indispensable to a healthy democratic ecosystem and must be recognised as such by public authorities. The general need for a high level of partnership and dialogue between Government and civil society organisations in a healthy democracy should be highlighted during the Presidency. Strengthening the connection of Irish citizens to the EU could be achieved through the organisation of events during the Presidency taking place all across Ireland. Renewed vision of a social Europe Ireland has a long and positive history of progressing a social agenda in the EU, and the Presidency provides an opportunity to shape and drive an agenda focused on a renewal of social cohesion and societal wellbeing. There are significant risks for the EU and its Member States in overly focusing on economic growth over social development, including reduced trust among individuals, institutions and the state, greater fragmentation, and erosion of the social contract. We recommend an increased focus on wellbeing measurement at EU level, as well as social dialogue and civic participation. Ireland should seek to play a key role in the finalisation of the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) to preserve the financial sustainability of a social and democratic Europe, as well as a renewed focus on the implementation of the Social Economy Action Plan. 3. Renewed emphasis on a just transition Ireland’s Presidency offers a unique opportunity to press for the protection and expansion of EU budget lines dedicated to the Just Transition, climate action and biodiversity, to champion the SDGs as an overarching framework for European policymaking. It is also vital that Ireland seek to counter the European Commission’s current ‘omnibus simplification’ process and deregulatory agenda, which poses risks to flagship Green Deal instruments, including the LIFE programme and environmental and social elements of the CAP.

Create a safe and enabling environment for civil society Promote Council Conclusions on protecting civil society and safeguarding democratic participation in EU policymaking. Promote initiatives that protect civil society such as the EU Civil Society Strategy, Democracy Shield and Civil Society Platform Support joint work by civil society and parliamentarians to counter disinformation campaigns targeting the social justice agenda, climate action, and biodiversity renewal. Particular attention should be paid to promoting the Democracy Shield which is under development by Commissioner McGrath. Model good practice through inclusive stakeholder engagement, drawing on domestic models of dialogue and collaborative governance with the community and voluntary sector (Civic Forum, Health Dialogue Forum etc.) Call for inclusion of a chapter on civic space in the annual Rule of Law report to track democratic dialogue. Counter the European Commission’s current ‘omnibus simplification’ process and deregulatory agenda Press for the protection and expansion of EU budget lines dedicated to the Just Transition, climate action and biodiversity, protecting flagship Green Deal instruments, including the LIFE programme and environmental and social elements of the CAP. Build alliances with like-minded member states to prevent cuts that would disproportionately harm rural communities, civil society and future generations. Ensure greater coherence of European economic, environmental and social policy in support of a social Europe Make the European Pillar of Social Rights enforceable through legislative initiatives, including the Multiannual Financial Framework, turning it into a strategic tool to influence EU macroeconomic governance. Take greater account of social impacts when making Country-Specific Recommendations, especially those requiring fiscal consolidation measures, and ensure no return of austerity policy. Strengthen implementation of the new Pillar of Social Rights Action Plan Prioritise a Council Recommendation on ending homelessness, behind which there is significant momentum. Advance proposals for an EU framework directive on adequate minimum income to build on the Directive of Adequate Minimum Wages and the 2023 recommendation. Include access to child care, education (including lifelong) and healthcare across member states. Progress implementation of the EU Anti-Poverty Strategy Monitor and address poverty amongst sub-groups such as children, young people, minority ethnic groups including Travellers and Roma, lone-parents, disabled people, vulnerable migrants, older people, communities facing socio-economic disadvantage and the working poor. Support developments in the social economy Reintroduce the EU Equality Directive 2008 which proposed to establish a minimum level of protection against discrimination. Implement the Social Economy Action Plan, working in partnership with social economy stakeholders. EU funding The Irish Presidency will come at a critical time in the negotiations on the MFF. The Irish Government should promote an approach to the MMF which ensures that critical cohesion funding for social initiatives and investment is retained or increased in the next round of EU funding. Streamline EU funding to make it accessible to civil society and social economy organisations who play a vital role in the delivery of EU policy priorities.

Europe for all Trust in EU institutions is in serious crisis, with misinformation dominating the narrative. The presidency provides an opportunity for Ireland to communicate the democratic values of the European project to its citizens as well as promoting Irish examples of these values across Europe. However, trust goes both ways and the high-level priorities chosen by the Irish government should reflect the needs and priorities of citizens and demonstrate the relevance of EU policy in people’s lives. The actions of the EU on the international stage and in major global conflicts also has a significant impact on trust and perception in its institutions. The Presidency provides an opportunity to set the tone in Europe and to speak out on issues that really matter, as well as working to influence policy and legislation that will have a tangible effect at national level across Europe. At an event gathering together more than 100 of The Wheel’s members, we heard from a broad range of organisations about their priorities and hopes. These included issues such as housing, progressing rights for people seeking international protection, the European Council’s recommendation on homelessness, promotion of social enterprise, reversing the deregulation of climate protections and improving interactions between civil society organisations and the EU more generally. Active citizenship Ireland ranks low in citizen engagement with EU policy and institutions, and civil society uptake of European funding is also low. We recommend that government develop a programme of active citizenship and engagement around the Presidency. This should include meangingful opportunities for a broad cross-section of society, especially young people and communities with the least access to power. Moreover, it will be crucial for events to be organisation all across Ireland, in both rural and urban areas, to engage all citizens and ensure that the Presidency can benefit everyone.

Civil society and EU values Government has already acknowledged the central role that civil society can play in communicating EU values to citizens across Ireland. These organisations are embedded in every community in Ireland, and represent those who are furthest from political institutions. EU policy, in particular, can seem remote and irrelevant to many. In order to improve engagement around the presidency, Government should promote an accessible Europe that can be experienced at local level in both rural and urban areas. It is vital that Government engage with key stakeholders to ensure that groups at risk of poverty and social exclusion, and unemployed people, can influence policy direction and implementation, and that their experiences become part of the dialogue with European institutions to try and repair social cohesion and political legitimacy. It is essential, therefore, that the high-level priorities chosen by Government are meaningful to people across society and do not relate solely to economic growth. Funding for civil society In order to achieve this, civil society needs support and funding. We recommend that: CERV, under the new AgoraEU programme, should be protected and expanded in the next MFF to respond to rising threats to our sector, including the rise of populism, hate, attacks on civic freedoms and the unprecedented rise of misinformation, which disproportionately affects our sector. The Presidency provides an opportunity for Ireland to recommend the establishment of a match funding facility at member-state level to support civil society participation in EU funding programmes with low cofinancing rates such as the Interregs. This would support the Quadruple Helix model of the academic, private, public and civil society sectors all working together to solve problems. Without meaningful support for civil society groups to participate, this model cannot work. Stronger controls are needed for EU funding managed at national level to ensure that a reasonable portion of funding is ringfenced for civil society. Consultation and co-design processes of nationally-managed EU funding programmes should be meaningful and not just tokenistic or an afterthought. Applications and reporting requirements should be streamlined, so that smaller social economy and civil society organisations have a fair chance to access funding. Funding should be adjusted to acknowledge rising costs across the EU in the next Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF). In countries with higher costs of living, EU funding is becoming increasingly unsustainable.

Reducing Europe’s import dependency on soya and strengthening resilience of our food system Europe’s current protein supply is highly vulnerable due to its strong dependence on imported soya, with approximately 92% of soya used in the EU is imported. This dependence poses significant risks for food security, market stability and sustainability, particularly in the context of increasing global trade disruptions, geopolitical instability, and environmental challenges in major exporting regions. A resilient and secure European food system requires a holistic protein strategy that reduces reliance on imports while strengthening domestic and regional production capacities. Enhancing European soya production Ireland’s Presidency should prioritise policies and initiatives aimed at boosting sustainable European soya cultivation. Increasing production within the continent not only enhances protein self-sufficiency but also supports farmers in diversifying crop rotations, improving soil health, and contributing to climate and biodiversity objectives. Integrating Ukraine as a key player in the European protein system Ukraine is by far the largest soya-producing country in Europe and therefore essential for a truly integrated European protein market. The Presidency should promote closer market integration between EU and Ukrainian soya sectors, facilitating trade, investment, and sustainability alignment. This would strengthen the resilience of Europe’s feed and food supply chains, support Ukraine’s economic recovery, and advance the EU’s geopolitical and sustainability goals simultaneously.

Developing a coherent European protein strategy Ireland could use its Presidency to drive forward a protein strategy that takes a holistic approach across feed, food, and industrial uses, included a dedicated budget to drive change. Such a strategy should: Encourage investment in European legume cultivation Support research and innovation on plant breeding, agronomy, and climate adaptation Improve the market framework for sustainable European protein crops Foster cooperation between EU Member States and neighbouring producers Livestock Strategy Ireland should use its mandate to reach a common position with the Commission and the Council ensuring that the livestock strategy also covers the topic of European and regional animal feed. The livestock strategy is directly linked to the broader European protein strategy. Strengthening European feed production – particularly of sustainable soya and other protein crops – will increase resilience, reduce import dependency and improve the environmental performance of livestock farming. When the topic of livestock is approached holistically, the EU can support food security, sustainability and competitiveness in the livestock sector. EU Plant-Based Action Plan Building on successful examples such as Denmark’s Plant-Based Action Plan, the EU should adopt a Plant-Based Strategy that complements the Protein Strategy and supports dietary transition, innovation, and market development. The Irish Presidency should aim to advance legislative and policy work on promoting plant-based protein value chains within Europe, linking food and feed objectives.

By promoting a Europe-wide shift toward sustainable, home-grown soya and other protein crops, the Council’s work can strengthen both economic resilience and environmental integrity for the benefit of people, businesses, and communities across the EU: - Strengthening Europe’s food system resilience through supporting European protein production creates benefits for farmers, feed and food companies and consumers alike. - Strengthening short, transparent supply chains adds value in rural regions and keeps economic benefits within local communities.

Donau Soja’s Protein Strategy for Europe can serve as a model for an EU protein strategy. It provides a holistic framework for a “Protein Transition” based on five interconnected pillars that address both the supply and demand sides of Europe’s protein challenge: Sustainable and responsible imports: Imports to Europe should be on a level playing field with EU production to ensure high environmental and social standards contributing to global sustainability and deforestation-free supply chains while supporting competitiveness of EU farmers. Increased production of legumes in Europe: Expanding the cultivation of legumes such as soya, peas, and faba beans would reduce the protein deficit, improve soil health, enhance biodiversity, and strengthen rural economies. Improved use of existing and new protein resources: Better utilisation of by-products (e.g. rapeseed and sunflower meal), forage crops (e.g. alfalfa, clover), and novel sources like algae can diversify and strengthen Europe’s protein base. Increased efficiency of protein use: Matching livestock diets more precisely to their nutritional needs can reduce nitrogen losses, lower feed costs, and cut pollution. Healthier and more sustainable diets: Encouraging a shift towards more plant-based diets and moderate consumption of meat and dairy can reduce environmental impacts, improve public health, and support the overall protein transition Find the complete strategy here: DS_Protein-Strategy-for-Europe-26072018-2.pdf And the Donau Soja Position Paper on expectations for a European protein strategy arising from the EU’s Vision for Agriculture and Food: DS_Position-Paper_03.11.25.pdf

sector: Physiotherapy and Education for Sustainable Development
response_text: Education for sustainable Development should be a high level thematic priority. As a nation Ireland has always been a leader in education, current data on our progress achieving SDGs corroborates this with SGD 4 (quality education) being our strongest area. As a nation we can lead in this EU priority area by highlighting our successes and driving progress to ensure no one is left behind. One example where particular impact could be made is encouraging all nations to embed sustainable education into all higher education courses, as we are currently striving to do with great support from the HEA. We can also further drive the impact of this through lobbying professional accreditation bodies to include emphasis on sustainability in education for their respective fields (some Irish bodies currently do this such as nursing and education).

sector: Physiotherapy and Education for Sustainable Development
response_text: Education policy should be a focus. It is where we can lead and show impact. We should aim to get agreement from our EU partners that all higher level institution commit to embedding education for sustainable development into curricula. We should aim to get agreement from our EU partners that all professional regulatory bodies connected to higher level institutions should encourage the inclusion of education for sustainable development relevant to their areas.

sector: Physiotherapy and Education for Sustainable Development
response_text: We can make most impact through demonstrating our success in this area – we are currently embedding Education for sustainable development in our education systems and our professional competencies. This will drive change going forward in many businesses and have effects downstream on people and communities across the EU.

sector: Physiotherapy and Education for Sustainable Development
response_text: We can best communicate the values and benefits of EU membership to citizens through them being able to relate to our mandate – everyone can relate to education. Education is something our citizens are proud of and value. That pride can be leveraged to support our presidency and enable our citizens to see Ireland as a strong contributor and guiding force in the EU on the areas we are achieving well in.

sector: Physiotherapy and Education for Sustainable Development
response_text: While this document concentrated on higher education there is ample work going on in secondary and primary education in this field too. There are a multitude of resources we can lean on to support this theme. All EU members are currently engaged in this process but we are excelling and evidently are still the nation of scholars. We cannot let education for sustainable development be a “nice to have” but rather need to see it as the powerful agent of change for all of society that it is. The strength in the approach outlined in this submission is that to do that we must now only rely on our educational institutions but also our professional regulatory institutions and employers etc as well. We are all players in this field!

geography: As highlighted earlier, AsIAm is a national organisation which supports Autistic people and families across Ireland. We also advocate for policy change at a European level through our membership of Autism Europe.
response_text: From AsIAm’s perspective, Ireland’s Presidency of the Council (EU) presents a real opportunity to promote European values by prioritising a people-centred, rights-based approach which advances Autistic people's inclusion, equality and the community’s full and active participation across the EU, as well as Disabled people. We believe that one of the Presidency’s core thematic priorities should focus on advancing the EU’s rights agenda, particularly with regard to growing concerns around the restrictions of democratic values across the Union, with a particular focus on ensuring Autistic people across the European Union have equal access to services and community life. The EU’s commitment to United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (UNCRPD) and the implementation of the European Disability Strategy, and towards the successor Disability Strategy over the coming years are important mechanisms to achieving this. Ireland must use this presidency as an opportunity to advance and safeguard the rights of Autistic people, by ensuring a pan-European approach to support Autistic people within our respective societies. This aligns with Ireland’s recent progress on disability rights, such as the Autism Innovation Strategy, and reflects the EU Strategic Agenda’s vision for a fair, social and inclusive Europe, and promoting democratic values across the Union. As part of this theme and considering the UNCRPD’s central role within the EU’s Social agenda, the Irish Presidency could highlight the need for coordinated European action on supporting Autistic people and families through the development of a European Autism Strategy, building on the work of the Autism Innovation Strategy in Ireland and the National Human Rights Strategy for Disabled People, in recognising the specific structural barriers Autistic people face across Member States, and the work that several EU Members have undertaken in developing their own autism strategies. Placing the economic, social and cultural rights of Autistic people at the centre of Ireland’s Presidency strengthens our commitment to advancing these rights, and aligns with the EU’s broader priorities, such as promoting social rights, enhancing workforce participation, strengthening access to education, improving public services, and supporting digital and green transitions, which Ireland plays a vital role in advancing rights and protecting democratic freedoms and the rule of law. Autistic people come from all walks of life and live in every community and village across Ireland and the EU. (Disabled people – who comprise 20% of the EU population and 22% of Ireland’s population, (at least 1 in 27 of which are Autistic)

geography: As highlighted earlier, AsIAm is a national organisation which supports Autistic people and families across Ireland. We also advocate for policy change at a European level through our membership of Autism Europe.
response_text: AsIAm recommends that as part of the the Irish Presidency in the second half of 2026, the Government highlight and advance the following policy areas: Implementation of the European Disability Strategy (EDRS) 2021–2030, and successor Disability Strategy Ireland should prioritise Council discussions that advance tangible progress on key initiatives within the European Disability Strategy, including: The Disability Card and Parking Card Regulation; The framework for disability-inclusive social protection and employment, including harmonising access to social protection and disability supports across the EU so that Disabled people have the same freedom of movement as all EU citizens; The Disability Employment Package; Enlargement of accessibility standards across digital and built environments. Mainstreaming disability policy on key issues, including housing, wellbeing and social inclusion, and access to social and cultural rights. The Presidency should focus on reaching Council milestones that strengthen monitoring, enforcement, and mainstreaming of disability rights across all policy areas, recognising the influence EU social policy has on promoting wellbeing and living standards for Disabled people in Ireland, including Autistic people. Development of a European Autism Strategy There is currently no EU-level coordinated approach to supporting the unique barriers Autistic people experience in our community, despite the visibility of Autistic people increasing from 1-65 to 1 in 22 in Irish society. Many members of the Autistic community experience unique inequalities in accessing key supports and services. These include access to the following; diagnosis and assessment, appropriate educational placements, employment opportunities, access to health and disability services, social inclusion, community life, and independent living, particularly on the issue of deinstitutionalisation, where aspects of EU Social Funds are used within some Member States to keep Autistic people, and people with intellectual disabilities in these institutions. Such approaches are not conducive to advancing the rights of Autistic people in society. The development of a pan-European Autism Strategy would support Autistic people across Europe in accessing support, community life and having the same opportunities as neurotypical people within their respective societies. The Irish Autism Innovation Strategy which is 16 months in operation has made several positive inroads in advancing the position of Autistic people within Irish society. These include specific research studies on Autistic life in Ireland, adaptation of Universal Design Principles, the creation of Community Hub One Stop Shops, greater engagement with policymakers in the design and creation of policy guidance documents, which have a direct impact on the Autistic community. A pan-European approach to supporting Autistic people would assist in the breaking down of the systemic barriers Autistic people experience within our society. Advocating for a European Autism Strategy is an opportunity for Ireland to show leadership in advancing the importance of addressing the unique barriers Autistic people experience across our European societies. A European Autism Strategy would enable: Harmonised standards for early supports, education, and employment for Autistic people; Better data collection and comparability across Member States on Autistic people’s participation in society; Recognition of autism within EU research and funding programmes; Greater knowledge sharing and collaboration among professionals in advancing studies specific to the Autistic community’s needs. Greater protection of Autistic people’s rights, autonomy, and equal participation across the European Union; A shift to neurodiversity-affirming, rights-based policies across the Union, aligning with our UNCRPD obligations and shifting attitudes to supporting Autistic people across the EU. Standardised language on Autism that has a rights-based focus on it. The Irish Presidency could advocate for Council Conclusions mandating the European Commission to explore and outline such a strategy. Strengthening accessibility in digital and public service transformation As the EU implements major digital reforms including the European Accessibility Act and the Digital Services Act, accessibility must be its foundation. Ireland could steer work on ensuring that AI deployment, social media, public digital services, and online platforms are fully accessible and safe for Autistic users.

geography: As highlighted earlier, AsIAm is a national organisation which supports Autistic people and families across Ireland. We also advocate for policy change at a European level through our membership of Autism Europe.
response_text: Ireland can make a meaningful contribution by: Ensuring disability inclusion is mainstreamed across every Council configuration - from EPSCO to TTE, ENVI, COMPET, and EYCS. Centering and amplifying the voices and lived experiences of Autistic people through structured civil-society engagement alongside EU policy discussions and involving community voices in the center of these conversations. Championing implementation of the European Pillar of Social Rights, including its provisions on supporting Autistic people in key areas of employment, social protection, education, and healthcare. Supporting initiatives that promote independent living, deinstitutionalisation, and community-based supports across the EU. Encouraging Member States to adopt rights-based approaches to disability that uphold dignity, autonomy, equality, and full and equal participation in all aspects of society and community life. This work would have lasting impact across the Union by making real progress on reducing inequalities, increasing labour-market participation, and supporting inclusive communities—outcomes that benefit economies and societies across all EU Member States.

geography: As highlighted earlier, AsIAm is a national organisation which supports Autistic people and families across Ireland. We also advocate for policy change at a European level through our membership of Autism Europe.
response_text: Ireland’s Presidency offers an opportunity for Ireland to demonstrate the EU’s positive influence on the everyday lives of its citizens, including Autistic citizens. This can be achieved by: Showcasing the EU’s leadership on equality, social inclusion, disability rights, and promoting economic, social and cultural rights. Partnering with Disabled People’s Organisations (DPOs) to communicate how EU policies influence education, travel, employment, consumer rights, and accessibility. Developing public campaigns that highlight personal stories - how EU funding, regulation, and rights frameworks support individuals and communities to be inclusive. Ensuring Presidency events are fully accessible and inclusive, demonstrating EU values in practice. Using clear communication, plain language, and outreach to involve citizens who are often excluded from political discourse, including Autistic people.

geography: As highlighted earlier, AsIAm is a national organisation which supports Autistic people and families across Ireland. We also advocate for policy change at a European level through our membership of Autism Europe.
response_text: AsIAm welcomes Ireland’s commitment to a people-centered Presidency. We strongly encourage Ireland to use its platform to advance a coordinated European response to the needs and rights of autistic people, consistent with the CRPD and the European Disability Rights Strategy. A European Autism Strategy would represent a transformative step toward equality, mainstreaming neurodiversity across EU policy, strengthening cross-border collaboration, and giving Autistic people the same opportunities for education, employment, community participation and independent living as their non-disabled peers. As Ireland makes progress on the Autism Innovation Strategy, this Presidency provides a unique moment for Ireland to play a leadership role in advancing social policy across the EU share best practice, shape positive EU-wide change, and ensure Autistic voices and experiences guide policy development at every level.

organisation: School of Law and Government, Dublin City University
response_text: In the drive for greater security and combatting serious, organised crime, we must ensure that fundamental rights and democratic values are upheld by investigative and law enforcement operatives. Police need to be well trained to conduct effective, human-rights compliant investigative interviews, which lead to the gathering of valuable intelligence and reliable evidence which can be used in criminal proceedings. While the EU previously issued a series of Procedural Rights Directives, more could be done to ensure effective investigations take place across Europe, which uphold human rights and the rule of law. This issue ought to be central to the EU’s current policy and planning, as effective policing and respect for the rule of law underpin many of the Union’s goals.

organisation: School of Law and Government, Dublin City University
response_text: Articulating the importance of effective, human-rights compliant investigative interviewing (in line with the so-called Méndez Principles – the Principles on Effective Interviewing for Investigations and Information-Gathering 2021 – which have been referenced with approval by the UN General Assembly) in the context of increased securitisation and the fight against serious and organised crime would be an admirable achievement for the Irish Presidency. It would highlight the importance of respecting the rule of law, even in times of crisis and high stakes investigations, and would reinvigorate the Procedural Rights Directives, which overlap to a certain extent with the 13 legal and procedural safeguards set out in the Méndez Principles.

organisation: School of Law and Government, Dublin City University
response_text: A sense of stability is sorely needed across each of those constituencies. Focusing on quality policing, with expertise in effective interviewing and enhancing suspect rights could contribute to this in a very concrete manner. The EU should formally support the Méndez Principles and seek to have each state party become compliant with their terms. The Irish Presidency could at least put this on the agenda. Many EU states, for example, do not routinely audio record police interviews – a basic expectation in that context could be required under EU law. That is just one example of how Ireland could lead on this important issue. Even rights which seem well-established are coming under pressure these days and the EU needs to lead on upholding the rule of law, insisting on minimum protections for citizens, and ensuring effective criminal justice processes for all (suspects, victims, witnesses, the wider public, and indeed the police who work within the system).

organisation: School of Law and Government, Dublin City University
response_text: The 2026 Commission Work Programme speaks about Europe’s Independence Moment. There are many issues on which the EU can, should and must show global leadership at a time of instability and fear. My suggestion is that a focus on the rule of law, protection of human rights, and effective police investigations could be an important part of such global leadership. The science behind the Méndez Principles is now clear that coercion, abuse and denial of legal rights in police interviews does not lead to reliable information. The EU could and should do more in leading the call for better and more consistent police training, particularly in relation to investigative interviewing, and redoubling efforts to ensure protections for suspects, victims, and witnesses who are interviewed by the police.

Europe is at an important juncture with its competitiveness agenda. The EU is clear that it wants “simpler rules, stronger delivery” and “a prosperous and competitive Europe”. There has been substantial discussion of reforms, but so far only a limited number of policy changes have actually been implemented. Ireland has a unique opportunity to drive the competitiveness agenda by focusing on the European built environment during its presidency. (The term built environment refers to the physical buildings and infrastructure which underpin economic growth.) A potential slogan for the presidency could be “A Europe that can build – for people, for climate, for competitiveness.” Focusing on this is good for competitiveness because the built environment is a key input to economic growth. Workers need homes. Businesses need factories and premises. Trade requires infrastructure like roads and bridges. Travel requires public transit infrastructure. And electricity users need generators like wind and solar to be built, along with transmission systems to move the electricity to homes and businesses. The construction of these inputs will boost economic growth across the continent. Removing barriers to their construction is essential for competitiveness and the EU’s wider prosperity. Simplification of rules is already at the top of the European agenda, and this theme would help drive that agenda to completion. A strong and competitive EU growth rate is key to any other future goals that the EU has, from enlargement to security to climate.

The EU Commission’s 2026 work plan already includes a focus on the built environment. A Construction Services Act is slated for late 2026, and is aimed at easing barriers to the construction of housing and infrastructure. Reforms to permitting, emanating from the Directorate-General for Environment, are also expected in 2026. In addition, housing is a key focus area for the EU in 2026, with proposals expected to be published. The built environment is the key underlying theme here. The Irish government should aim to prioritise these built environment agenda items, making them central to the presidency. They can have an outsized impact on EU growth rates and cohesion. In its public research, Progress Ireland has proposed how environmental directives (Environmental Impact Assessment, Birds and Habitats, and the Aarhus Convention) can be reformed to allow more building without compromising on environmental goals.

One of the biggest challenges across the EU is the increase in the cost of living experienced by millions of Europeans, across all income brackets and regions. This is undermining political confidence in the benefits of integration and the EU project as a whole. The most impactful thing that the EU could do is to address this cost of living increase directly by tackling the built environment. High housing costs form a significant part of the cost of living increase across Europe. Addressing these costs through reforms will also deliver growth, boosting the legitimacy of the European project among ordinary voters.

sector: Research, Higher Education, and Social Science Research Infrastructure Development. I work within the European social science research ecosystem, contributing to the design, coordination, and strategic advancement of a large-scale research infrastructure, Growing Up in Digital Europe (GUIDE). As [REDACTED UNDER GDPR] of GUIDE, my work spans research management, scientific direction, and engagement with national and EU-level stakeholders, including those involved in ESFRI, the European Commission, and child wellbeing policy frameworks.
geography: EU wide with an emphasis on Ireland’s leadership role
response_text: Priority 1: A Europe that Invests in Children and Young People to Strengthen Social Cohesion Investing in children and youth is central to Europe’s long-term stability, prosperity, and democratic resilience. This priority advances the European Council’s commitment to “supporting young people, reducing inequalities, and renewing Europe’s social contract,” while aligning closely with the European Commission’s 2026 Work Programme, including tackling child poverty and the cost-of-living crisis, strengthening the Child Guarantee, and promoting intergenerational fairness. A Presidency that foregrounds children and youth would signal Europe’s commitment to building societies where every young person has the opportunity to thrive. Ireland is in a uniquely strong position to lead this agenda. As host of Growing Up in Digital Europe (GUIDE), Europe’s first pan-European, comparative, longitudinal cohort study of children’s wellbeing, Ireland can showcase how high-quality research infrastructures underpin transformative policymaking. GUIDE, coordinated by University College Dublin, holds ESFRI Roadmap status and is advancing toward establishment as a European Research Infrastructure, with Ireland as the legal seat. The GUIDE consortium currently involves 21 Member States and 5 non-EU countries (UK, Norway, Iceland, Ukraine, and Australia). It will generate data that will inform evidence-based policymaking on areas such as children’s wellbeing, family circumstances, education, digital experiences, and health, for decades. This evidence base is urgently needed. Member States face shared challenges: persistent child poverty, widening inequalities, pressures on health and education systems, and rapid technological change shaping young people’s lives. GUIDE will allow the EU to monitor these dynamics over time, evaluate national and EU-level initiatives, and understand how early-life inequalities compound into adulthood. It will support the implementation and monitoring of the EU Child Guarantee, the EU Strategy on the Rights of the Child, and forthcoming initiatives on digital safety, mental health, and social inclusion. Highlighting GUIDE during the Irish Presidency positions Ireland as a European leader shaping the knowledge base for a more just and cohesive future. Priority 2: A Strong, Sustainable and Connected European Research and Innovation System Europe’s ability to thrive in a changing world depends on a research and innovation system that is connected, high-performing, and strategically autonomous. The European Council Strategic Agenda and the Commission’s Work Programme call for reinforcing Europe’s competitiveness and deepening cooperation in research and innovation. Ireland’s Presidency provides a timely opportunity to champion this vision, drawing on its leadership of GUIDE. As an emerging European Research Infrastructure, GUIDE exemplifies the value of coordinated, cross-border research investments that mobilise expertise from universities, national statistical systems, NGOs, policymakers, and international partners. Its development demonstrates how shared methodologies, interoperable data infrastructures, and collaborative governance can advance both scientific excellence and policy impact. GUIDE’s European Commission-funded collaborative work with other social science research infrastructures (SHARE, The Generations and Gender Programme, and the European Social Survey) is in areas such as the green transition, open science and data governance, and innovative pathways for translating research into policy. Strengthening Europe’s knowledge systems underpins competitiveness, digital sovereignty, wellbeing, and Europe’s ability to respond collectively to social, economic, and environmental challenges.

sector: Research, Higher Education, and Social Science Research Infrastructure Development. I work within the European social science research ecosystem, contributing to the design, coordination, and strategic advancement of a large-scale research infrastructure, Growing Up in Digital Europe (GUIDE). As [REDACTED UNDER GDPR] of GUIDE, my work spans research management, scientific direction, and engagement with national and EU-level stakeholders, including those involved in ESFRI, the European Commission, and child wellbeing policy frameworks.
geography: EU wide with an emphasis on Ireland’s leadership role
response_text: Policy area: Child wellbeing.
