The 2026 Commission Work Programme places renewed emphasis on combating child poverty, improving access to essential services, strengthening the European Child Guarantee and supporting intergenerational fairness. These priorities reflect the EU’s longstanding commitment to ensuring every child has the opportunity to thrive, regardless of background, by guaranteeing access to healthcare, education, childcare, nutrition and housing for children in need. Progress in these areas would have a direct and positive impact on families and communities across the EU. The Irish Presidency should aim to achieve the following: Steer Council discussions to advance files relating to the strengthened Child Guarantee, mental health, education and social inclusion. The Child Guarantee remains a central pillar of EU social policy, aiming to address cycles of disadvantage and social exclusion by ensuring children in need can access essential services. The Presidency can play a key role in bringing Member States closer to political agreement on any Commission proposals or regulatory guidance connected to national action plans, monitoring frameworks and the EU Anti-Poverty Strategy that is developing around the Guarantee. Facilitate evidence-informed debate, reflecting the EU’s long-term need for high-quality, comparable data to monitor childhood inequality and wellbeing. Past Presidencies have shown that events such as informal ministerial meetings and technical roundtables are effective platforms for building consensus, exchanging best practice and elevating evidence-based policymaking. For example, Presidencies have convened expert events alongside formal Council meetings to examine implementation challenges and policy coherence across member states. This approach can help ensure that ongoing efforts to reduce child poverty and improve wellbeing are grounded in robust evidence and systematically monitored, even as data infrastructures continue to develop. Showcase Ireland’s hosting of Growing Up in Digital Europe (GUIDE) as an example of an emerging European Research Infrastructure that will, once operational, support future EU policy evaluation. The Irish Presidency can draw attention to the significant preparatory progress being made on GUIDE, which to date has been funded through successive European Commission grants. This work exemplifies Europe’s investment in building the knowledge needed to inform public policy over the long term. By presenting GUIDE in conferences, workshops and Presidency-branded events on child wellbeing and social policy, Ireland can highlight how collaborative research infrastructures contribute to Europe’s capacity to understand and address complex challenges such as inequality, education trajectories and digital engagement among young people.

sector: Research, Higher Education, and Social Science Research Infrastructure Development. I work within the European social science research ecosystem, contributing to the design, coordination, and strategic advancement of a large-scale research infrastructure, Growing Up in Digital Europe (GUIDE). As [REDACTED UNDER GDPR] of GUIDE, my work spans research management, scientific direction, and engagement with national and EU-level stakeholders, including those involved in ESFRI, the European Commission, and child wellbeing policy frameworks.
geography: EU wide with an emphasis on Ireland’s leadership role
response_text: The Irish Presidency can make a substantial positive impact by advancing Council work in areas where coordinated EU action delivers clear and tangible benefits for citizens, businesses and local communities. Recent Presidencies have shown that meaningful impact comes from progressing legislative files that improve daily life, such as Belgium’s focus on fair working conditions, France’s delivery of the Digital Services Act, Spain’s prioritisation of mental health and youth inclusion, and Portugal’s emphasis on social rights. Building on these precedents, Ireland can help deliver outcomes that matter across the Union. First, the Presidency can advance key initiatives aimed at improving child wellbeing, tackling poverty and strengthening access to essential services. These areas are central to the 2026 Commission Work Programme, and progress here would directly support families and reinforce social cohesion. By facilitating constructive, evidence-informed discussions on the strengthened Child Guarantee, mental health and social inclusion, Ireland can contribute to long-term improvements in living standards and opportunities for young people. Second, the Presidency can strengthen Europe’s competitiveness by supporting progress on research, innovation and the European Research Area. Past Presidencies, such as Germany’s leadership on Horizon Europe and Slovenia’s focus on research infrastructures, have shown the value of advancing knowledge, innovation and technology policy. Ireland can contribute by promoting open science, secure and FAIR data governance, and sustainable European research infrastructures. The development of the Growing Up in Digital Europe (GUIDE) research infrastructure, hosted in Ireland, can be highlighted as an example of how Member States contribute to Europe’s long-term scientific capabilities.

sector: Research, Higher Education, and Social Science Research Infrastructure Development. I work within the European social science research ecosystem, contributing to the design, coordination, and strategic advancement of a large-scale research infrastructure, Growing Up in Digital Europe (GUIDE). As [REDACTED UNDER GDPR] of GUIDE, my work spans research management, scientific direction, and engagement with national and EU-level stakeholders, including those involved in ESFRI, the European Commission, and child wellbeing policy frameworks.
geography: EU wide with an emphasis on Ireland’s leadership role
response_text: Other Presidencies have used public dialogues, school programmes, cultural events, digital campaigns, regional outreach, youth participation and transparency initiatives to build citizen ownership. Ireland can adopt similar approaches, tailored to themes like child wellbeing, digital fairness, and research excellence, showcasing initiatives such as GUIDE as examples of Ireland’s positive contribution to Europe’s future. Ireland could host events across the country, including outside of Dublin, to highlight EU investment in research, social initiatives, infrastructure and innovation, making the EU tangible and accessible. Recent Presidencies have demonstrated the value of consistent, accessible communication, including public briefings and livestreamed events. Ireland could build on this by offering regular public updates, using clear language, and creating digital channels where citizens can follow progress in real time. Recent Presidencies have successfully integrated schools and youth organisations into their programmes through outreach, debates and youth parliaments. Ireland can build ownership among young people by involving schools, universities, and youth groups in Presidency dialogues, particularly on themes such as digital safety, mental health, skills and child wellbeing, which matter directly to younger generations. This approach aligns strongly with the ethos of GUIDE, which has embedded youth participation and child-centred principles since its earliest design stages. Highlighting this during the Presidency would reinforce Ireland’s commitment to meaningful youth engagement, reflecting values central to the EU’s strategic agenda and helping to strengthen trust and deepen citizens’ sense of connection to the EU.

sector: Research, Higher Education, and Social Science Research Infrastructure Development. I work within the European social science research ecosystem, contributing to the design, coordination, and strategic advancement of a large-scale research infrastructure, Growing Up in Digital Europe (GUIDE). As [REDACTED UNDER GDPR] of GUIDE, my work spans research management, scientific direction, and engagement with national and EU-level stakeholders, including those involved in ESFRI, the European Commission, and child wellbeing policy frameworks.
geography: EU wide with an emphasis on Ireland’s leadership role
response_text: See: https://www.guidecohort.eu/ GUIDE Preparatory phase project (2022-2026): https://cordis.europa.eu/project/id/101078945 GUIDE’s entry on the ESFRI Roadmap: https://ri-portfolio.esfri.eu/ri-portfolio/portfolio-editions/2024-first-edition/catalogue/guide/ Other GUIDE development projects: https://cordis.europa.eu/project/id/101008589 https://cordis.europa.eu/project/id/777449 https://cordis.europa.eu/project/id/613368/ GUIDE is also involved in a cross-research infrastructure project on Social Aspects of the Green Transition (SoGreen): https://sogreen-project.eu/ GUIDE has been in development since 2014, originally under UK leadership, and the transition of the Central Hub to University College Dublin in 2020 marked a decisive strengthening of Ireland’s role in shaping this major European initiative. This builds on Ireland’s long-standing experience in running Growing Up in Ireland, our national longitudinal study, which has demonstrated the sustained value of child-centred, high-quality evidence for policymaking. Over the past five years, the project has gained considerable momentum across Europe: GUIDE has now been added to several national research infrastructure roadmaps (including Iceland, Poland, Slovakia and Slovenia), with further applications under active review. The consortium has also secured funding for pilot studies in a growing number of countries, including the UK, Norway, Denmark, Italy and Slovenia, alongside the European Commission-funded pilots conducted in 2023 in Ireland, France, Croatia and Finland. Ireland’s Trio partners, Lithuania and Greece, are also members of the GUIDE consortium, which provides a helpful continuity of understanding and engagement across the 18-month Trio Presidency period. GUIDE is now entering a critical phase as we move toward establishing the study as a European Research Infrastructure Consortium (ERIC). Achieving this outcome requires visible, sustained commitment from participating Member States. Ireland’s engagement as the host country and legal seat is therefore essential to maintaining the strong European momentum already in place. The timing of Ireland’s Presidency of the Council of the European Union in the second half of 2026 provides a unique opportunity to demonstrate this leadership. Presidency periods traditionally showcase national contributions that align with wider EU priorities, and GUIDE offers a clear example of Ireland supporting Europe’s long-term capacity for evidence-informed policymaking on children and young people. Visible political support during this period would signal Ireland’s commitment as host, strengthen confidence among Member States considering participation, and help consolidate the foundation needed to advance GUIDE toward ERIC status. We would be pleased to provide further information or brief officials as needed to support the development of the Presidency programme or to clarify the role of GUIDE within the wider European Research Infrastructure landscape.

In line the political guidelines for the European Commission 2024-2029, I suggest Ireland chooses the following as high-level thematic priorities: Preparing our Union for the future Supporting people, strengthening our societies and our social model 3. Sustainable prosperity and competitiveness

Tourism is Europe’s most visible expression of its shared values – mobility, culture, creativity and quality of life. As global tourism transforms in scale and complexity, Ireland’s Presidency provides a unique opportunity to lead EU tourism with a coherent, sustainable, innovation-driven approach. With the world’s population increasing and transport connectivity improving, more people will be on the move whether to study, to work or to visit. Thus tourism, the ‘activity’ of people taking a trip to a destination outside their usual residence, for less than a year, will become an even more pronounced feature of the European economy in the years ahead. Currently the sector represents 10% of EU GDP and sustains over 22 million jobs. The key choice facing the EU, from a tourism perspective, is whether it will offer innovative leadership and support to Member States for the benefit of its citizens, or continue to respond in an ad hoc, fragmented manner to challenges as they arise. The PwC ‘Stock-taking study of the co-implementation of Transition pathway for Tourism and EU Agenda 2030’ (Oct ’25), highlights the entrenched barriers that impact tourism actors across EU-27 as follows: Governance fragmentation, including low political prioritisation of tourism Access to funding Data limitations Skills shortages The upcoming Ireland-Lithuania-Greece Presidency Trio provides a political opportunity to champion a transformative approach to the implementation of the new EU Sustainable Tourism Strategy due Q2, 2026. The European Agenda for Tourism 2030, negotiations on the MFF 2028-2034, and the adoption by the United Nations of a resolution (26/2/24) to declare 2027 as the ‘International Year of Sustainable and Resilient Tourism’ create a compelling backdrop to support such action. The Commission’s Work Programme 2026 identifies Tourism in Annex 1: New Initiatives1, No 10. A sustainable and resilient EU tourism sector will support all the key aims of this work programme. The EU Commissioner for Sustainable Transport and Tourism has correctly identified the following challenges facing the sector: boosting competitiveness, enhancing climate resilience, ensuring balances tourism, embracing digital innovation and securing a skilled workforce. However, more fundamental tourism challenges remain to be addressed including tourism governance, tourism innovation and tourism financing. In addition to hosting the 25th European Tourism Forum, the Irish Presidency should aim to achieve the following with regard to tourism: Governance Reform - Elevate and prioritise tourism in the work of the Competitiveness Council. Establish a tourism policy coordination mechanism across the European Commission Innovation & Research Inclusion – Integrate tourism into the EU’s research, innovation and digital transformation architecture Dedicated EU Funding line – A distinct budget for tourism under the MFF 2028-2034 would – facilitate the development of incubators and accelerators to support tourism start-ups deliver new innovative products & services improve collaboration across the tourism value chain build research and development capability provide an evidence-based to aid decision-making accelerate decarbonisation reduce seasonality viii. deliver employment growth ensure profitabIe SME’s and enable communities to become sustainable and resilient

Ireland and its citizens have a proud record of introducing key initiatives, through tourism, which impact people, businesses and communities at European and global level. In 1951, the world’s first duty-free shop opened at Shannon Airport and Ireland exported this innovation across the globe. In 1985, an Irish Commissioner, Peter Sutherland, began work on airline de-regulation which transformed travel across the EU. Today, Dublin is home to the EU’s largest carrier, Ryanair, and Ireland is the leading centre for aircraft leasing globally. While individuals such as Gerald Lawless and Willie Walsh have made a huge impact on the international hospitality and tourism stage, others such as Padraic Gilligan and Patrick Delaney are equally recognized among their peers as global leaders in the business, incentive and conference travel sector. The setting of an agreed 18-month programme on tourism between the ‘trio’ countries would be a catalyst for transformation, not just for the sector, but for people, businesses and communities across the EU. It would support resolutions on tourism adopted by the European Parliament in 2011, 2015 and 2021 and address shortcomings identified by the European Court of Auditors in its report on ‘EU Support for Tourism’, 2021. ‘Trio’ level outcomes could include 1. Governance Actions: Elevate tourism as a priority area of focus for the EU’s Competitiveness Council Establish a European Tourism Coordination Mechanism (ETCM) across various DG’s within the Commission whose activities impact tourism Strengthen the Tourism Unit within DG Move Benefits: Provide leadership and coherence in European Union tourism policy development and implementation Increase tourism’s contribution to EU’s political objectives Encourage greater co-ordination on tourism by Member States and by regional and local authorities • Re-position tourism as a strategic priority for the EU, alongside the agri-food, fishing, construction, pharma and ICT sectors. 2. A world-leading tourism research and innovation ecosystem Actions: Integrate tourism explicitly into Horizon Europe successor programmes and into the work programmes of the expanded European Research Council and the European Innovation Council Create an EU Tourism Knowledge & Innovation Platform Support tourism SME start-ups, innovation, sustainability and productivity projects. Benefits: Create key infrastructure to support a tourism research and innovation agenda across the EU Foster innovation and lead process change with a particular focus on SME’s in line with EU strategy Identify where resources should be allocated to support a competitive and sustainable tourism industry Co-ordinate EU funding opportunities for tourism research and innovation Improve the return on investment of public funds in EU tourism Provide local authorities with data to guide development and planning. 3. Establish a dedicated tourism budget line within the MFF 2028–2034. Actions: Introduce a policy-based funding structure for tourism under the new MFF Create an EU Tourism Investment Facility for infrastructure and innovation projects Simplify SME access through a one-stop EU funding portal. Benefits: Facilitate long-term strategic planning for tourism development Provide targeted investment by ensuring funds are specifically earmarked for tourism development, marketing, infrastructure, and support services Enable better tracking of spending and outcomes, improving transparency and accountability Instil stakeholder confidence by signalling commitment to tourism to investors, businesses, and international partners and encourages private sector collaboration and co-investment.

Ireland’s Presidency in 2026 should reflect the realities of demographic change, evolving public health pressures, and the need for a fair, resilient and inclusive Europe. The themes chosen should support Member States to build systems that are equitable, person-centred and prepared for the future, particularly in the context of an ageing population, increasing chronic conditions, and widening health and social inequalities. Dementia is one of the defining public health and societal challenges of our time, affecting millions across the EU and placing increasing pressure on health systems, families, and communities. In May 2025, Member States at the 78th World Health Assembly agreed to extend the Global Action Plan on the Public Health Response to Dementia by six years in response to the growing challenge of dementia across the world. There are almost eight million people living with dementia in the European Union and prevalence rates are rising sharply with this number expected to double to 14.3 million by 2050. It is estimated that when a person is diagnosed with dementia, three people in their lives are significantly impacted. In Ireland, an estimated 64,000 people live with dementia, supported by over 180,000 family carers. These figures highlight the urgency of embedding dementia within European health and social policy initiatives. As Ireland prepares for its Presidency of the Council of Europe, there is a unique opportunity to frame dementia as both a public health and human rights priority, aligning with the Council’s broader mission of democracy, rule of law, and social inclusion. The EU Presidency framework traditionally emphasises high-level priorities such as strengthening democracy, protecting human rights, and addressing equality. Dementia can be advanced indirectly through public health, equity, inclusion and rights-based approaches ensuring that people living with dementia are recognised as equal citizens entitled to dignity, protection, and inclusion. Healthy Ageing and Protecting Health Systems: Ireland should champion an EU focus on promoting health across the life course, with emphasis on prevention, population health equity, and supporting sustainability and preparedness of health systems. Human Rights, Inclusion and Participation: Ireland should prioritise a Europe where people of all ages, backgrounds and abilities can live with dignity, independence and autonomy, in line with the UNCRPD. Research, Innovation, Data and Ethics: As the pace of health research, digital tools, assistive technologies and therapeutic interventions accelerate, the EU Presidency should adopt evidence-based, ethical and person-centred approaches to these matters. Community, Care and Social Solidarity: Ireland has a vibrant community-culture and should highlight the role and value of strong communities, inclusive services, and cross-sector collaboration in supporting wellbeing across the lifespan. Although the Council of Europe Presidency does not define dementia-specific priorities, advocacy groups and policy frameworks across Europe, under the umbrella of Alzheimer Europe, have already identified dementia as a pressing issue. Key priorities include raising awareness of dementia as a societal challenge, improving care, supporting carers and families with social and financial measures, promoting research and ensuring human rights protections for people living with dementia.

Implementation of the European Care Strategy: Ireland should use its Presidency to strengthen momentum behind applying the European Care Strategy and its associated Council Recommendation across Member States. There remains significant variation in access, quality, and rights-based implementation of long-term care. The Presidency should aim to: Promote meaningful indicators and shared monitoring mechanisms for community-based care, quality standards, carer supports, and equitable access. Facilitate peer learning and structured exchange on workforce development, integrated care models, and sustainable funding. Promote rights-based, person-centred care that supports autonomy and dignity Advancing the EU Disability Rights Strategy and Related Legal Reform: Ensuring full implementation of the UNCRPD requires further concrete policy progress at EU level. The Presidency should aim to: Strengthen accessibility requirements across digital services, built environments and public information. Support ongoing work on legal capacity, supported decision-making, and non-discrimination frameworks. • Promote legislative and policy action that ensures equal participation for people with age-related or cognitive disabilities, and protection from exclusion, stigma, or rights violations. Strengthening Prevention and Population Health Approaches to Ageing: Ireland should support EU cooperation on prevention, healthy ageing and public awareness, aligned with ongoing noncommunicable disease frameworks. The Presidency should aim to: Progress a European Initiative on brain health building on existing work with non-communicable diseases (e.g. Stroke Action Plan for Europe) to support equitable and high-quality standards, promote risk reduction and life course approaches and improve quality of care. Encourage Member States to integrate ageing and brain health into public health campaigns and planning, in addition to promoting EU-wide campaigns. Support coordinated EU action on health inequalities, ensuring access regardless of geography, socioeconomic status, disability, or age. Supporting Fair and Ethical Use of Digital Health and New Innovations: As new digital tools, diagnostics, and treatment options emerge, it is important that all Member States can benefit from them in an ethical, equitable and coordinated way. The Presidency should aim to: Support the roll-out of the European Health Data Space (EHDS). Strengthen cooperation under the Health Technology Assessment (HTA) Regulation so that decisions on new technologies and treatments are transparent, consistent and fair across the EU. Promote EU support for health system readiness, including staff training, shared guidance and investment in infrastructure, so new tools and innovations can be introduced safely, ethically and effectively. Community, Care and Social Solidarity: Ireland’s Presidency can highlight the role of the communitybased supports, inclusive public services and multi-sector collaboration in supporting people to live well, participate in society and maintain independence for as long as possible. The Presidency should aim to: Support the implementation of the European Care Strategy by promoting high-quality, accessible and community-based care options that reflect people’s rights, autonomy, and preferences. Encourage Member States to invest in age-friendly, dementia-inclusive and disability-inclusive environments, ensuring public spaces, transport, housing, and digital services are accessible to all. Promote greater recognition and support for informal and family carers, including access to information, respite, flexible work arrangements and social protection. Facilitate shared learning on integrated and person-centred models of care.

The Irish Presidency has a real opportunity to create meaningful impact by helping ensure that existing EU strategies and commitments translate into tangible improvements in people’s day-to-day lives. To do this well, the focus needs to shift from policy ambition to practical delivery with an emphasis on implementation, equity, and collaboration across Member States and sectors. Driving implementation and delivery There is already strong policy direction at EU level, particularly in areas such as disability rights, long-term care, digital transformation, healthy ageing and public health. The challenge now is not a lack of strategy but implementation. The Presidency can make a significant difference by supporting shared monitoring and reporting systems, enabling bidirectional learning between Member States, and encouraging the targeted use of EU funding to scale what works, rather than reinventing new approaches. Promoting Inclusion, Participation and Brain Health A healthier and more equitable Europe must prioritise inclusion and equitable access to services and opportunities. Central to this is supporting wellbeing across the lifespan including brain health as part of prevention and healthy ageing. We know more than ever before about how brain health can be protected, how risks can be reduced, and how people can be supported to live well for longer. There is momentum, evidence and public interest and now is a unique moment to act on it. Priorities should include advancing a European initiative on brain health, progressing age-friendly, disabilityinclusive and dementia-inclusive approaches, and tackling the digital, geographic and socio-economic barriers that continue to shape access to care, information and innovation. Strengthening Workforce and Community Capacity Europe’s changing demographics mean we must plan and invest now in the future workforce and care systems. The Presidency can support this by highlighting the importance of recruitment, training and retention across health and social care, while recognising and better supporting informal and family carers who form the backbone of support systems across the EU. Equally, community-based, integrated models of care must continue to be prioritised, as they promote independence, dignity and social connection. Building Dementia-Inclusive Communities Ireland has a unique opportunity to make a lasting impact on the lives of people living with dementia and their family carers, an impact that will resonate not only within Ireland but across Europe. A dementia-inclusive community can be described as a city, town, or village where people with dementia are understood, respected, and supported, and where they feel confident in contributing to community life. In such communities, awareness and understanding of dementia are widespread, and those living with the condition have choice and control over their daily lives. Ireland is already taking important steps toward this vision. The ASI is rolling out its Friends of ASI initiative nationwide, encouraging individuals, businesses, and services to create welcoming and supportive environments. This initiative works in tandem with the HSE’s Dementia: Understand Together campaign, a national partnership involving ASI, Age Friendly Ireland, Age & Opportunity, the Dementia Services Information and Development Centre, and Healthy Ireland.

To build understanding, connection, and a sense of shared ownership, communication around Ireland’s Presidency should be relatable, accessible and rooted in the everyday realities of people across the EU. Rather than focusing solely on high-level policy language or institutional processes, the emphasis should be on what EU cooperation means in practice. Storytelling is one of the most powerful ways to connect policy with lived experience. When we speak about the benefits of EU membership for people with dementia and their carers, abstract concepts become meaningful through real-life stories. For example, cross-border healthcare initiatives allow families to access specialist services beyond their own country, while EU-funded respite programmes provide carers with much-needed support. These experiences highlight how European solidarity translates into everyday improvements in quality of life. The values of EU membership are made tangible through these lived realities. Solidarity is expressed when countries work together so carers never feel isolated. Human rights are upheld by ensuring the dignity and autonomy of people living with dementia. Equality is reinforced by guaranteeing fair treatment regardless of where someone resides in Europe. Community is fostered through EU projects that bring carers together to share ideas and mutual support. Innovation is advanced through EU research funding, which drives new treatments and care models that directly benefit families. During the Presidency, communication channels play a vital role in making these values visible and accessible. Community workshops – such as dementia cafés, carer support groups, and local health centres – can host EUthemed sessions that connect policy to everyday life. Accessible media, including short radio spots, subtitled videos, and illustrated brochures, ensures that information reaches diverse audiences. Carer networks, in partnership with dementia-friendly organisations, provide trusted platforms to co-deliver messages. Symbolic events, such as lighting dementia-friendly landmarks with the EU flag, reinforce the sense of belonging to a wider European community. The beneficial impact of these efforts is profound. People with dementia feel included and valued as European citizens. Carers gain practical awareness of the supports and rights available to them through EU membership. Communities, in turn, strengthen their sense of solidarity, recognising that they are part of a collective European effort to uphold dignity, equality, and innovation in dementia care.

The Alzheimer Society of Ireland is proud to be the leading dementia-specific service provider in Ireland, working at the heart of local communities across the country. Every day, we provide services and supports designed to meet the needs of people living with dementia and their families, while also advocating for their rights. Our vision is simple but powerful: an Ireland where people on the dementia journey are valued, can realise their rights, make their own choices, and live well in the place they call home. As a national non-profit organisation, the ASI is committed to empowering and championing the voices of people with dementia and their carers. One of the ways we do this is through the Alzheimer National Helpline, which offers information and support to anyone affected by dementia. Beyond the Helpline, the ASI provides a wide range of services including Day Care, Day Care at Home, Home Care, Family Carer Training, Dementia Advisers, Alzheimer Cafés, and Social Clubs. The ASI is especially excited to announce that Ireland will host the prestigious 36th Alzheimer Europe Conference from October 27th-29th 2026, at the Convention Centre Dublin. The theme of the conference, “Sláinte: Building momentum in dementia through policy, research and partnership”, reflects our shared commitment to progress. More than 1,500 delegates from across Europe are expected to attend. This will be listed as an Official event of Ireland’s Presidency programme. This conference comes at a crucial time. Dementia is becoming more prevalent in Ireland, placing increasing pressure on families, communities, and the healthcare system. With Ireland set to hold the Presidency of the Council of the European Union, the conference offers a unique opportunity to put dementia firmly on both national and European policy agendas. The event will bring together people living with dementia, family carers, researchers, clinicians, and policymakers to share knowledge, shape policy, and inspire innovation in care and treatment. Importantly, advocates living with dementia and family carers will play a central role, ensuring their voices are heard in discussions about research and advocacy. Hosting this event marks a significant milestone in Ireland’s ongoing commitment to improving the lives of people affected by dementia. In addition to this, there is a strong foundation for leadership in the dementia space in Ireland, with the National Dementia Strategy, launched in 2014 and reviewed in 2018, placing a focus on awareness, timely diagnosis, integrated services, training, research, and leadership. The landmark Model of Care for Dementia in Ireland (2023) builds on the National Dementia Strategy setting specific targets and practice recommendations underpinned by the principles of citizenship, a person-centred approach, integration, personal outcome focused support and timeliness. Dementia must be recognised as a European public health and human rights priority. During its Presidency, Ireland can advance dementia policy through collaboration with Alzheimer Europe, national strategies, and broader Council of Europe frameworks on rights and social inclusion. By doing so, Ireland would not only strengthen its domestic response but also set a precedent for embedding dementia into pan-European rights-based legislation.

respondent_type: Academic; Research Institute in Trinity College Dublin
geography: National, with hopefully EU-wide application and benefits
response_text: The central question explored in this document is how Ireland’s eighth presidency will offer something distinctive, engaging our own people young and old, and showcasing to our European partners the very best of what we can contribute in terms of leadership and vision. The crucial answers here are for Q.4 and Q.5. This is Ireland’s eighth presidency and the previous seven have all been great successes. This is something we do very well and the hard-work and planning over many years pays off. The suggestions here are attempts to show how we can better communicate our vision to our own internal audiences, creating a sense of shared ownership, and offering a model that will be studied and imitated by others. Using a catchy, inclusive, over-arching slogan to show what this presidency is about, for example something like ‘Our Europe: Secure, Trusted, and Ready for the Future’, I believe the priorities should follow the EU Strategic Agenda for 2024-29 while including dimensions that shows a distinct Irish influence and direction. Whatever priorities are chosen they should reflect Ireland’s distinctive strengths and our ability respond to Europe’s evolving challenges. These could be: 1. Strengthening European Security and Technological Resilience This presidency is an opportunity to show that Ireland is not a weak link in the chain of European security, but a country that can make a significant contribution to our common defence and shared security. One area is in the realm of cybersecurity and emerging technologies. Ireland has genuine world-class expertise here and can show that while we may not have the biggest military capabilities, we do have the technological skills and expertise to help defend against hybrid threats, cyberattacks, and misinformation. Our Institute has collaborated on different projects with ADAPT, the national research centre with leading expertise in the area of AI and cybersecurity, which will become part of DANÚ, the new Research Ireland National Centre for AI in late 2026. Together we have the expertise and the framework for communicating that expertise. We can ensure that Ireland can contribute meaningfully to advancing a Union that protects all its citizens while remaining open, democratic, and rights-respecting. 2. Renewing Democratic Trust, Civic Participation and Public Engagement in Open Debates. Democratic trust is under strain across Europe. Part of the problem is that we have become intolerant of other points of view, entrenched in our own positions, susceptible to external influence and manipulation, and unwilling to embrace complexity. In Ireland we have one of the best educational ecosystems in the world, so let’s demonstrate how that power can be mobilised for the greater good. By drawing on our own traditions of deliberative democracy, civic dialogue and open debate we can lead efforts to strengthen democratic resilience. This is an area where the Arts and Humanities (and Social Sciences) can have a pivotal role to play. 3. Securing a Sustainable, and Competitive Future for All Ireland should lead on how the EU can implement the green and digital transitions in a way that protects competitiveness, supports SMEs, and ensures no region is left behind. Ireland can show how it is possible to develop policies that enhance well-being, sustainability, and economic opportunity.

respondent_type: Academic; Research Institute in Trinity College Dublin
geography: National, with hopefully EU-wide application and benefits
response_text: Greater work to implement the AI Act and initiatives related to critical infrastructure protection. Enhance the European Democracy Shield and EU Strategy for Civil Society Develop policies supporting digital transformation.

respondent_type: Academic; Research Institute in Trinity College Dublin
geography: National, with hopefully EU-wide application and benefits
response_text: The substantial positive impacts are included above, but the main benefits that can be shared and felt across Europe are: Making Europe safer for citizens and businesses. Showing how we can present a new vision, and new leadership of supporting democratic confidence and social cohesion. Showing how we can advance a fair, affordable green and digital transition. Channelling the very best of our research we can show how we can ensure the EU is better able to address AI-related risks, cybersecurity vulnerabilities, and technological dependencies, and that we can develop co-ordinated approaches to hybrid threats, including disinformation, deepfakes, and electoral interference. The presidency is an opportunity to show how democracy itself can be reenergised by nurturing a more engaged and informed citizenry. Engaging with researchers across all our institutions and encouraging them to engage with schools across the country to reach the next generation of thinkers, we can explore how to tackle these challenges, encouraging open debate and a respect for divergent points of view. This will also help provide people with the tools for countering disinformation. Developing and scaling civic participation mechanisms and digital literacy programmes could provide a model of transparent citizen-engagement that could be shared across Member States. This would help the EU in upholding its values globally and internally. We can show how we can provide better practical supports for business competitiveness, simplifying regulation, allowing better access to EU funding, and showing how SMEs can innovate efficiently and securely.

respondent_type: Academic; Research Institute in Trinity College Dublin
geography: National, with hopefully EU-wide application and benefits
response_text: For me, this is the crucial question. Ireland has a great European story, stretching back across many centuries, and taking on a new focus and direction after 1973. However it is a story that is not really fully appreciated or understood. What does it mean to be Irish and European? What has Europe done for Ireland and how has Ireland helped make Europe the great community of nations and the force it is today? To create a sense of ownership among our citizens about our forthcoming Presidency we need to frame all communications around real-life impacts: security, opportunity, trust, fairness, and a genuine European community. Avoiding jargon and acronyms, we should show how our membership protects rights, strengthens our country, expands our economic prospects, offers the greatest collective security in an increasingly unstable world, and helps create a better future for all of us across Europe. In practice this could mean hosting regional dialogues, community workshops and town-halls, partnering with universities and local authorities and various groups in civil society. The universities and technological universities provide a perfect place to help host and direct some of these engagements, and could reach out to schools across the country so that a younger generation is part of these conversations. This is about storytelling. Statistics are impressive when you know the context, but otherwise they can feel impersonal and meaningless. We need case studies of what Europe really means, in terms of families, entrepreneurs, students, farmers, researchers, artists, and activists. We can show the lived benefits of EU membership, what it meant for us in the 1970s and what it continues to mean. And we should trust our people with the truth. We have difficult decisions to make around defense and security; we need to play our part and we need to be seen to be playing our part. Let’s have these conversations, perhaps hosted by our universities and research institutes exploring everything from cybersecurity to drone attacks to other threats to our very existence. We can show our European partners that we are facing our challenges head on, and we can show our citizens that we trust them with the most complex of issues. In effect, these could be informal citizens’ assemblies, involving a greater range of people, and across the entire country. We should seek to foster a sense of ownership and pride and engagement around our forthcoming presidency. Instead of telling people why Europe matters or what this presidency is about, let’s show people, and let’s make our communities a part of it. For example, we could send a short pack to schools over the summer and have a competition, with different categories of awards and prizes for different age groups. These entries could then be shared and published online. As explore below we can find ways to include all schools and educational institutions across the country.

respondent_type: Academic; Research Institute in Trinity College Dublin
geography: National, with hopefully EU-wide application and benefits
response_text: Ireland has 7 universities and 5 technological universities, for a total of 12 in total, which is a number with a special EU resonance and symbolism. We have about 750 post-primary, second-level schools in the country. We have over 3000 primary schools. We have 26 other member states. Let’s try and involve them all in this European story. Storytelling is what Ireland is famous for, it is part of our international reputation, and it is what we do best. So let’s craft and tell a great European story. There are opportunities and potential here for collaborations and projects across our member states. Let’s have our students in primary schools find our about Europe, in ways that are meaningful and understandable, from simple packs where they can colour the flag and learn about European capitals and landmarks, to finding our about roaming, and cheaper travel, and the euro, and even how Ireland and Europe has changed so much over the past 50 years. A more advanced package for post-primary students could de developed. Could we twin each school with a school in one of the 26 other member states? What better way could they learn about other students and other cultures and what we have in common. Thanks to the most accessible of technology we can video conference with schools and young people around Europe. And through our 12 universities and technological universities we can link with the other 26 member states and do a series of events and collaborations that can explore, debate, and exchange ideas. We have Irish students and researchers in every member state. We have students and researchers from every member state in our universities. Even showing this on a map of Europe, with threads connecting each country and point of contact, is a way of showing how interconnected we are. Collectively those threads will show the strongest of fabrics, because they will reveal how numerous and extensive they are. Erasmus + was a great achievement of our 2013 presidency,. Let’s try and bring together, through online collaborations, some of the people who have benefitted from Erasmus+ from across member states, old and new. How they benefitted, where they went, what it meant. The European story in action. Working together. Sharing stories.

organisation: Global Allergy and Asthma Excellence Network GA2LEN
response_text: Taking into account the current geopolitical and socioeconomic context in Europe, we recommend that Ireland prioritise Health Protection, Citizen Safety, and Resilient Societies as core themes of its 2026 Presidency. Serious allergies and anaphylaxis are rising across Europe and place a growing burden on individuals, schools, workplaces, and public services. Addressing them fits naturally within broader objectives to protect citizens’ wellbeing and reduce preventable health risks. A Resilient and Prepared Europe The EU must be equipped to respond to emergencies—whether acute health events, natural disasters, or public safety threats. This requires harmonised emergency response systems, stronger communitylevel preparedness, and cross-border cooperation. Ireland is one of the few Member States that has taken concrete steps to improve preparedness for serious allergic reactions, including allowing pharmacists to supply emergency medicines without a prescription during anaphylactic events. This national practice demonstrates effective emergency readiness and provides a model for EU-level policy coordination, which could inform upcoming initiatives under the European Health Union framework aimed at strengthening preparedness, prevention, and rapid response across Member States. A People-Centred Union that Protects Embedding people-centred principles into EU policymaking ensures that vulnerable populations and individuals at risk of medical emergencies are not left behind. The Presidency could advance reducing health inequalities across the EU, highlighting uneven access to diagnosis, specialist care, and emergency response protocols. Positioning timely care for serious allergies and anaphylaxis within this agenda demonstrates a commitment to practical, measurable improvements in patient safety and inclusion, while protecting citizens’ rights to safety in everyday environments such as schools, childcare centres, workplaces, and public venues. 3. A Future-Oriented Europe Built on Innovation and Collaboration Ireland’s strong reputation in digital innovation offers an opportunity to promote Digital Innovation for Health, leveraging the European Health Data Space and interoperable, patient-centred tools. For individuals at risk of serious allergic reactions, seamless access to medical information across borders can prevent emergencies and support the free movement of people. The Presidency can also prioritise harmonised awareness-raising, institutional readiness, and capacity building, ensuring schools, businesses, and public institutions are equipped and trained to respond effectively to life-threatening health incidents.

organisation: Global Allergy and Asthma Excellence Network GA2LEN
response_text: Ireland could use its Presidency to champion health resilience, citizen protection, and emergency preparedness, leveraging its national leadership in anaphylaxis response as a model for EU coordination. Key priorities include: Health Protection and Emergency Preparedness Serious allergies and anaphylaxis present a growing public-health challenge. The Presidency could: Promote timely access to emergency medicines, building on Ireland’s approach where pharmacists can supply life-saving treatment without prescription. Encourage harmonised school and public-venue preparedness, using Ireland as an example. Relevant upcoming EU initiative: Global health resilience initiative (non-legislative, Q2 2026) – to strengthen EU capacity for rapid response to health crises. Digital Innovation for Health Cross-border emergencies require seamless access to patient data: Promote the European Health Data Space for secure, interoperable sharing of health information, enabling faster response to anaphylactic events across borders. Support digital tools for citizen-centred care, enhancing emergency response and patient safety. 3. Reducing Health Inequalities and Strengthening Citizen Rights The Presidency could advance equitable access to emergency care and citizen-centred policy: Link preparedness to strengthening the Child Guarantee (non-legislative, Q2 2026) and Citizens omnibus (legislative, Q4 2026), ensuring children in schools, childcare centres, and communities are protected and have their rights effectively enforced. Promote intergenerational fairness through the Intergenerational fairness strategy (nonlegislative, Q1 2026), ensuring emergency preparedness and health access benefit current and future generations equally. Highlight Ireland’s model as a practical, replicable approach for other Member States. Objectives Establish a model for EU-level anaphylaxis and emergency response coordination, based on best practices of Ireland. Ensure equitable access to life-saving treatments across the EU. Promote digital innovation for preparedness, information sharing, and cross-border patient care. Strengthen citizen rights and intergenerational fairness, ensuring public health policies reflect social equity. Position health resilience as a pillar of EU citizen safety and social cohesion, demonstrating tangible improvements in public health readiness. By focusing on these targeted initiatives, Ireland can use its Presidency to deliver practical, measurable impacts on citizen safety, health equity, and cross-border emergency preparedness while reinforcing the EU’s social and legal frameworks.

organisation: Global Allergy and Asthma Excellence Network GA2LEN
response_text: The Irish Presidency has the potential to deliver significant, tangible impact for EU citizens by advancing health resilience and consumer safety. For individuals with serious allergies, policies that improve emergency response, access to medicines, and accurate allergen information can be life-saving. For people, expanded access to emergency treatment, including pharmacy-enabled emergency supply across the EU, enhances safety in daily life. Citizens with serious allergies would be better protected in schools, workplaces, sports facilities, cultural venues, and during cross-border travel. For businesses, harmonised allergen-labelling and staff-training expectations reduce regulatory uncertainty, simplify compliance, and improve consumer trust by fostering safer public environments. For communities and institutions, EU-supported readiness measures ,such as common school protocols, public-venue guidelines, and accessible training ,would significantly reduce preventable emergencies, supporting all three Alliance objectives. Replicating Ireland’s best practice on emergency medicine access would ensure that life-saving intervention is available regardless of where a reaction occurs, reducing inequalities across Member States.

organisation: Global Allergy and Asthma Excellence Network GA2LEN
response_text: Ireland has a strong opportunity to communicate the value of EU membership by focusing on everyday benefits and practical improvements that resonate directly with citizens. The 2026 Presidency can show how EU cooperation protects people, strengthens communities, and makes daily life safer—particularly in areas such as emergency preparedness for serious allergies and anaphylaxis. Highlight Practical Examples of EU Solidarity Citizens understand the EU best when they see clear, relatable outcomes. Ireland can communicate EU values by highlighting how cooperation improves safety and wellbeing, for example: Safer environments in schools, restaurants, transport and public venues. Shared health information that makes travel within the EU safer and more predictable. Harmonised allergen-labelling rules that protect consumers wherever they are. More consistent access to emergency support for serious allergic reactions. Ireland’s own approach—allowing pharmacists to supply emergency treatment during a serious allergic reaction—provides a concrete example of national leadership that improves citizen safety. Propose Council Recommendations on Emergency Readiness To strengthen public understanding of the EU’s benefits, Ireland could lead on a visible, citizen-centred initiative: Develop Council Recommendations on broader readiness and access to emergency treatment for serious allergy and anaphylaxis. This would help encourage Member States to: Improve preparedness in schools, public venues, workplaces, and transport hubs. Ensure trained responders are available across community settings. Reduce inequalities in access to time-sensitive, life-saving care. Such an initiative is easy for citizens to relate to, directly improves safety, and demonstrates EU cooperation in a human, practical way. A simple message: the EU protects people By showcasing initiatives that make everyday life safer, including better emergency preparedness for serious allergic reactions, the Irish Presidency can reinforce a clear message: EU cooperation delivers real, practical benefits for families, children, workers, and communities. This people-centred framing will strengthen public trust, build ownership, and demonstrate the concrete value of Ireland’s leadership at EU level.

organisation: European Network of People who Use Drugs (EuroNPUD)
response_text: Ireland’s 2026 Presidency should align closely with the EU Strategic Agenda 2024–2029, which emphasises protecting citizens, strengthening the social fabric of the Union, and ensuring a resilient, values-driven Europe. Within that framework, Ireland can deliver unique added value by prioritising a human rights–based, public-health–centred approach to drug policy, grounded in the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights. Upholding dignity (Article 1), life (Article 2), non-discrimination (Article 21) and healthcare (Article 35) should be central to the Presidency’s thematic vision. A key priority should be strengthening Europe’s response to an increasingly toxic and unstable drug landscape, in line with both the Strategic Agenda and the European Commission’s 2026 Work Programme, which highlights health protection, crisis preparedness, and social resilience. Ensuring universal access to life-saving interventions—naloxone without prescription, OAMT, stimulant agonist treatment, drug checking, and community-led safe consumption spaces—should be championed as essential to the protection of health and life across the Union. The Presidency should also help the EU realign its approach with modern international guidance. UN High Commissioner for Human Rights Volker Türk recently called for “a transformative approach… that prioritises health, dignity, and inclusion.” His statements reinforce the need for policies that are “gender-sensitive and evidence-based,” support “inclusive access to voluntary medical care,” and highlight that harmful criminalisation must be replaced by humane, public-health approaches. His clear call for decriminalisation, combined with support for responsible regulation—especially at a time when seven European states already operate cannabis regulation models—supports another key thematic priority: fostering structured EU dialogue on legal regulation and emerging global reforms. Finally, Ireland should elevate the meaningful participation of people who use drugs in EU policymaking as a Presidency priority. This aligns with the Strategic Agenda’s emphasis on strengthening democracy and inclusion, ensures policy relevance, and enhances the EU’s capacity to respond to evolving drug market realities. Through these thematic priorities, Ireland can help operationalise the values embedded in Europe’s 2024–2029 strategy, set the tone for the Joint Declaration on Legislative Priorities for 2026, and position the EU as a global leader in rights-based, life-saving drug policy.

organisation: European Network of People who Use Drugs (EuroNPUD)
response_text: Ireland’s 2026 Presidency should ensure that Council work reflects the European Commission Work Programme for 2026, the EU’s Strategic Agenda 2024–2029, and the forthcoming Joint Declaration on Legislative Priorities for 2026. Within these overarching frameworks, several concrete policy areas deserve focused attention. Embedding Human Rights in EU Drug Policy Legislation The Presidency should work to anchor all drug-related legislative files within the Charter of Fundamental Rights. This includes integrating the International Guidelines on Human Rights and Drug Policy, echoed in Volker Türk’s call for policies that “prioritise health, dignity, and inclusion.” Legislative discussions should also reflect his statement that “decriminalisation is another crucial step” and that EU policy must “treat the person, not punish the drug use disorder.” Harmonising EU Access to Harm Reduction Services Ireland should promote legislative progress on universal access to naloxone (including non-prescription models), OAMT, stimulant agonist therapies, drug checking, and safe consumption spaces. Türk’s reminder that “harm reduction measures… are essential” supports elevating these interventions within EU health and social policy files. EU Overdose Prevention Strategy & Naloxone Standards Legislation or Council conclusions should support harmonised naloxone provision across Member States, including peer distribution and integration into emergency, prison, and community services. This aligns directly with EU priorities on public health and resilience identified in the 2026 Work Programme. EU Recognition of Drug Checking Services Ireland should advance legal or regulatory recognition of drug checking as a public health service. Enabling Member States to implement mobile, nightlife, and community-based drug checking supports early warning capacities prioritised in the Strategic Agenda. Modernising EU Early Warning and Monitoring Systems The Presidency should promote reforms that incorporate community-generated data and peer worker expertise into EU drug market monitoring. This policy area supports EU objectives around preparedness, resilience, and data-driven governance. EU Dialogue on Decriminalisation and Responsible Regulation Ireland should convene structured EU-level dialogue—consistent with Türk’s call for collaboration—on decriminalisation and emerging regulatory models. With seven European states already implementing cannabis regulation, the EU must begin taking stock of lessons learned, alongside longstanding and innovative developments in heroin-assisted treatment, ketamine therapy, and psilocybin reform. Ensuring Participation of People Who Use Drugs in Law-Shaping Processes Ireland should ensure legislative processes reflect democracy and inclusion by involving experiential experts and peer-led organisations in Council dialogues and preparatory work. Aligning these policy priorities with EU strategic documents will help advance coherent, rights-based reforms across the Union.

organisation: European Network of People who Use Drugs (EuroNPUD)
response_text: By aligning its work with the EU Strategic Agenda 2024–2029, the 2026 Commission Work Programme, and forthcoming Joint Legislative Priorities, Ireland can lead the Council in delivering major social and public health gains. Scaling up harm reduction—naloxone, OAMT, drug checking, and safe consumption spaces—will immediately reduce preventable deaths, hospital pressures, and community harm. These outcomes advance the Strategic Agenda’s objectives on public health resilience and improving living standards. Embedding human rights into EU drug policy will strengthen social cohesion, reduce inequalities, and enhance trust in institutions. As Volker Türk emphasises, replacing punitive measures with “inclusive access to voluntary medical care and other social services” improves the health and wellbeing of individuals, families, and communities. Improving early warning systems and responding to supply toxicity will enhance community safety and reduce poisonings. This directly supports the Strategic Agenda’s focus on crisis preparedness and citizen protection. Additionally, structured dialogue on decriminalisation and responsible regulation—now increasingly relevant as seven European states regulate cannabis—can reduce criminal market harms, support social reintegration, and lower the costs of enforcement. Türk’s call for regulation that “eliminates profits from illegal trafficking, criminality and violence” underscores the broader societal benefits. Businesses and communities will also benefit from stabilised nightlife environments, reduced emergency callouts, and stronger public trust in local and EU institutions. Involving peer-led organisations strengthens democratic inclusion—a central goal of the Strategic Agenda—and ensures policies are informed by those with lived experience, increasing both effectiveness and public legitimacy.

organisation: European Network of People who Use Drugs (EuroNPUD)
response_text: Ireland can help citizens feel genuine ownership of the 2026 Presidency by showing how EU cooperation delivers concrete benefits in line with the EU Strategic Agenda 2024–2029, particularly its focus on health, safety, inclusion, and shared European values. Communication should highlight real, measurable outcomes: fewer overdose deaths, safer communities, better access to healthcare, and reduced harms from toxic drug supplies. Linking these outcomes to EU cooperation will demonstrate the practical advantages of membership. Using language consistent with respected international human rights leadership can enhance trust—especially Volker Türk’s call for policies that “prioritise health, dignity, and inclusion.” This reinforces the EU’s own Charter commitments and counters misinformation or punitive narratives. Citizen engagement should include participatory events, dialogues with civil society, and visibility for peer-led organisations. This aligns with the Strategic Agenda’s focus on strengthening democracy and fosters a sense that citizens—not institutions alone—shape the EU. Highlighting Ireland's leadership role, including its hosting of EuroNPUD, reinforces how local civil society contributes to EU direction-setting. Transparent reporting and accessible storytelling about the Presidency’s achievements will further build connection and ownership.

organisation: European Network of People who Use Drugs (EuroNPUD)
response_text: EuroNPUD—the European Network of People Who Use Drugs—is the EU’s sole regional peer-led drug user advocacy network and is proudly registered in Ireland. Its expertise rooted in lived experience provides the EU with essential knowledge for shaping modern, rights-based drug policy, directly supporting goals in the EU Strategic Agenda 2024–2029. As the Presidency approaches, Ireland has an opportunity to highlight the importance of peer-led participation, in line with Volker Türk’s call for “collaboration” and “inclusive access” in developing humane, effective drug policy. Ensuring that EuroNPUD and similar organisations can meaningfully engage in all relevant Presidency processes will strengthen EU democracy, improve public health outcomes, and reinforce the Union’s commitment to dignity and equality. EuroNPUD stands ready to support Ireland in contributing to a transformative, evidence-based, and rights-centred EU agenda in 2026.

THE CIRCULAR ECONOMY Repair, circularity and appropriate management of waste from electrical and electronic equipment (WEEE) are essential to the EU’s transition to a circular economy. The programme of the Danish EU Presidency for 2025 contains one mention of circularity, and positions of Cyprus (and later Lithuania) remain unclear on this matter. Ireland’s Presidency offers a crucial opportunity to truly prioritise the circular economy as a core aspect of the EU’s competitiveness and resilience. Ireland and Europe both have important targets set for 2030 relating to the circular economy. Ireland’s draft Whole of Government Circular Economy Strategy contains a ‘vision is for Ireland to become a recognised leader in circularity by 2030’ while the EU’s Competitiveness Compass aims to make the EU the world leader in the circular economy by 2030. The EU’s Clean Industrial Deal also contains an ambition to double Europe’s circular economy rate by 2030 from 12 to 24%. These targets must be approached with pragmatism and realism. With just over four years until 2030, all opportunities must be leveraged to take stock of where we are currently and to identify risks and compliance gaps. Ireland has the platform to ensure harmonisation and a level playing field at a key moment for the European Union. The EU Strategic Agenda 2024-2029 emphasises the importance of ‘making a success of the green and digital transitions,’ aiming toward a ‘more circular and resource-efficient economy.’ The Commission Work Programme for 2026 also contains many files relating to the circular economy, creating an opportunity for Ireland to demonstrate its leadership. SIMPLIFICATION AND COMPETITIVENESS Over the past five years, several major EU laws such as the Ecodesign for Sustainable Products Regulation (ESP-R) and Right to Repair Directive have been adopted, with secondary legislation to follow many of these packages in the coming years. Ireland’s Presidency offers a strong opportunity to take stock of the existing ‘compliance maze’ acting as a barrier to achieving a true circular economy. This means addressing regulatory fragmentation and removing barriers to legislative harmonisation.

areas? ENVIRONMENTAL OMNIBUS (Q4 2025 ) This Omnibus is a package of six legislative proposals. Further debate will be needed on details of this proposal. Some early industry considerations are: We welcome the proposal of the Commission to discontinue the Substances of Concern in Products (SCIP) Database. The database has proven to be a costly failure, imposing substantial administrative and financial burdens on manufacturers without achieving its intended purpose or improving recycling outcomes*. There is some concern regarding the proposal of the Commission to suspend the application of the rules on the appointment of authorised representatives (AR) for extended producer responsibility (EPR) for waste, waste electrical and electronic equipment and single use plastic waste until 1 January 2035. The European Commission stipulates this obligation will be suspended for European producers while further streamlining of the EPR schemes under the Circular Economy Act is pending. The AR system is a key mechanism of Extended Producer Responsibility (EPR), ensuring compliance with WEEE collection, treatment, and financing obligations. Further discussion and debate will be required on this matter*. CARBON BORDER ADJUSTMENT MECHANISM (Q4 2025) In addition to introducing further anti-circumvention measures and export compensation, the CBAM proposal will expand the scope to include downstream products. At present, only raw materials such as aluminium, steel, and cement are covered by CBAM, while finished goods made from these materials (e.g., washing machines, dishwashers) are not. This gap exposes the mechanism to carbon leakage and places EU manufacturers at a competitive disadvantage, since equivalent carbon costs are not applied to imported finished products. THE OMNIBUS TO SIMPLIFY ENERGY PRODUCT LEGISLATION (Q2 2026) This presents a valuable opportunity to resolve overlaps and duplication between the Ecodesign for Sustainable Products Regulation (ESPR) and other harmonised legislation, such as chemicals, packaging, and waste rules. THE EUROPEAN PRODUCT ACT (EPA) (Q3 2026) This will include updates to rules on market surveillance and the compliance of products. It is an Act that will drive crucial enforcement measures enabling existing legislation to realise its intended ambition. The EPA will also address standardisation measures, updating the New Legislative Framework (NLF) on product rules. The revision of the existing framework under the EPA should also tackle the issue of non-compliant products on online marketplaces by placing more possibilities on trades and platforms. THE CIRCULAR ECONOMY ACT (Q3 2026) Ireland must take stock of the effectiveness of the existing WEEE Directive. It is an important opportunity to highlight priority issues such as harmonised EPR frameworks, realistic collection targets, and measures to incentivise CRM recovery. Government has already recognised that methodology for EEE ‘does not take account of the varying lifecycles of certain electrical and electronic equipment’ such as washing machines and refrigerators5.’ Any updated methodology or targets should consider the lifespan of an electronic product through repair and reuse. It will also be important to address the significant distortion of collection targets caused by the inclusion of new product streams with exceptionally long lifespans. Specifically, products such as heat pumps and photovoltaic (PV) panels have operational lives of 15 years or more. Their inclusion in current "Put on Market" (POM) figures artificially inflates short-term collection targets to a level that is fundamentally unachievable, as these items will not enter the waste stream for a significant period of time. The current WEEE system is disproportionately focused on collection quantity (weight), often to the detriment of recovery quality. This emphasis can conflict with our shared core environmental and sustainability objectives.

The European Commission has estimated that the current circular material use rate in the EU is 11.8%6. In just over four years, the EU is aiming to double this. In the meantime, we are struggling as a Member State and as an EU bloc to accurately gauge both our WEEE collection rates and our critical raw materials recovery. The adage that you ‘cannot manage what you cannot measure’, rings true even more when discussing matters relating to the circular economy. Creating a stable market for secondary raw materials can be achieved by introducing economic incentives and investing in recycling infrastructure and R&D. Ensuring the quality of recycled materials is appropriately advocated for will be essential to ensure and promote a balanced market and to promote consumer trust. This will benefit people, business and communities. We support ambitions at the EU level to significantly strengthen enforcement mechanisms, consistently applying them across all Member States to combat non-compliance, such as illegal exports and "free riding" by online sellers. A level playing field means addressing compliance gaps and market barriers, ensuring loopholes in existing legislation are addressed in a timely and proportionate manner. An “all actors” approach must be taken to ensure accountability across the entire value chain. In certain instances, a level playing field may entail an interpretation of compliance that transcends a mere ‘letter of the law’ approach, particularly regarding WEEE takeback. These measures, if promoted through the Irish Presidency, will enable us to achieve a truly harmonised Single Market for Waste. Additionally, circularity and economic growth must be seen as symbiotic. A circular economy is a thriving economy.
N/A

The WGA is actively engaged in many circular economy matters at the national and European level, including the Right to Repair Directive, Ecodesign for Sustainable Products Regulation (ESP-R) and effective implementation of the WEEE Directive. We are an active member of APPLiA, the voice of the home appliance industry in Europe representing one of Europe’s largest manufacturing sectors for turnover and employment. The WGA also have a strong working relationship with WEEE Ireland and the ERP. The Irish Government has already recognised the importance of circularity enablers such as access to raw materials, circular products and the digital transformation. The White Goods Association (WGA) acknowledge ambitions in the Programme for Government (PfG) to promote a circular economy and have recently submitted a response to the consultation on the draft Whole of Government Circular Economy Strategy 2026-2028. To achieve our national ambitions for a truly circular economy that fosters innovation, competitiveness and economic growth and to be European leaders in this field, effectively prioritising files of importance will be paramount during the Irish Presidency. Ireland is uniquely well placed to spearhead the way on these files. The WGA welcomes the opportunity provided by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (“The Department”) to provide industry views on how Ireland can best fulfil its Presidency role. Ireland’s approach to circular economy and related product files must be pragmatic and evidence-based, leveraging existing and robust reports and research to ensure targets, goals and objectives are well aligned and set up for success. Industry is a committed partner in this endeavor and would welcome the opportunity to discuss our position further. *a few short lines of additional context on specific files are included in a separately attached proposal. The longer document outlines the following: - Environment Omnibus On the database: The information is difficult for recyclers to access and use, and there is no evidence that it has improved recycling outcomes. Furthermore, this system is redundant because substances of very high concern (SVHCs) are already subject to mandatory reporting under the REACH Regulation (Article 33). On the Commission’s proposal on AR’s - Currently this is a mandatory requirement. It has helped address the significant problem of "free-riders"—producers who sell EEE remotely but fail to register or finance WEEE management in the destination country. The AR must fulfil the producer's WEEE obligations, such as registration, reporting, and compliance enforcement, in that local market

The policy priorities of the Irish Presidency should be fully aligned with the Council’s Strategic Agenda 2024-2029. The themes “a free and democratic Europe” and “a prosperous and competitive Europe” are of particular importance: The Law Society submits that the Irish Presidency of the Council should support broader EU objectives on the protection of democracy, rule of law, and improving access to justice. Improving the EU’s overall competitiveness, and particularly via implementing the Letta and Draghi Reports, should be a significant policy focus for an Irish Presidency. This includes prioritising legislation and measures such as the 28th Company Law Regime, the Digital Omnibus Bill and the EU Innovation Act when introduced at Council level. Ireland should utilise the opportunity provided by the Presidency to improve overall representation and diversity in the EU in order to improve the legitimacy of EU institutions. This will help establish an ongoing legacy for the Irish Presidency.

An Irish Council Presidency must aim (a) to prioritise the harmonisation of EU laws and regulations across the EU in order to enhance the single market and (b) strengthen democratic resilience, access to justice, and rule of law across the EU. Some examples of this include: Assisting with the negotiations around the 28th Regime of Company Law, Expediting the overall recommendations of the Letta and Draghi Reports, including the prioritisation of digital innovation, Prioritising the topic of access to justice at a high level in the Council in order to cement the issue on the agenda of the Commission, Organising a Presidency Conference and high-level discussions around the topic of improving representation and diversity in EU hiring, Assisting the implementation of the Democracy Shield initiative generally, expediting legislation that aims to both protect democratic resilience, strengthen media freedoms, and combat disand-misinformation.

As noted earlier, the Irish Presidency of the Council should prioritise improving the competitiveness of the EU in line with the Letta and Draghi Reports. This includes an agenda aimed at the overall harmonisation and simplification of EU laws in order to remove confusion for businesses and citizens. Rule of law and access to justice should be a crucial focus of an Irish Council Presidency. We also note the prioritisation of competitiveness via the 28th Regime and the promotion of the recommendations of the Letta and Draghi Reports: delivering prosperity to EU citizens via the simplification of barriers to doing business will greatly help the overall reputation of the EU particularly given the current difficult economic and political tailwinds. It is important that an Irish Council Presidency establishes a legacy that lasts beyond its Presidency. To this end, the Irish Presidency should encourage engagement and discourse around improved representation in the EU. There is also an opportunity to assist the Commission in supporting and Member States’ approach to the effective and timely transposition of EU legislation.

The Law Society notes that continued EU membership is very popular among Irish citizens. However, there are opportunities for the Irish Presidency (and its successors) to do more to seek to communicate the impact, relevance and benefits of EU membership to citizens across all Member States.

Please see attached Submission which expands upon the Law Society’s perspective on many of the issues raised in this questionnaire.
