A summary of the Submission is set out below under three main policy priority headings: Democracy, Justice and the Rule of Law, which includes: o A focus on strengthening democratic resilience in the EU by supporting the EU Democracy Shield, o Supporting Europe’s response to migration pressures, and o Prioritising the enhancement of access to justice across the EU. Competitiveness, which includes: o Supporting the continued implementation of the Letta and Draghi Reports, and o Improving ease of doing business by shaping and supporting the proposed 28th Company Law Regime and by facilitating continued digitalisation across the EU (including via AI). Promoting diversity of representation in the EU, which includes: o Encouraging improved representation throughout the EU. Advocate for the improved representation of certain EU nationalities within the EU institutions with a view to highlighting the current trends in representation or underrepresentation among EU Member States. o Assisting the Commission in supporting and Member States’ approach to the effective and timely transposition of EU legislation.

geography: Scale Ireland is an Irish representative body but maintains active international links, especially within the EU.
response_text: As Ireland’s largest representative body for start-up and scaling companies in the technology sector, Scale Ireland believes that Ireland has a unique opportunity when it comes to choosing high-level thematic priorities. We believe that Ireland’s Presidency should adopt the high-level theme of "Competitiveness through Innovation: A Scale-up First Europe." Reflecting the EU Strategic Agenda 2024-2029 regarding a "prosperous and competitive Europe", Ireland is uniquely positioned to champion the indigenous tech sector. To this end, we propose three themes: 1. Accelerating the Single Market for Capital: Addressing the funding gap is the single greatest challenge for European scale-ups. Ireland should prioritise the completion of the Capital Markets Union (CMU) and the Savings and Investment Union. It is Scale Ireland’s belief that we need to use this opportunity to drive both economic growth as well as sectoral resilience. A functional CMU is essential to mobilise private capital, ensuring Irish and European start-ups can scale globally without relocating to the US or Asia to access growth finance. 2. Digital Leadership & AI Sovereignty: Building on Ireland’s reputation as a digital hub, the Presidency should focus on securing Europe’s AI, digital and cyber talent pipeline. The priority must be to elevate Ireland’s leadership in enhancing Europe's digital capabilities, moving beyond regulation to active adoption and innovation. Alongside other members of the Department of Enterprise’s Digital Advisory Forum, we believe we should work to secure the "AI, digital and cyber talent pipeline" by hosting an ambitious AI Summit to showcase European capability. 3. Regulatory Simplicity ("Think Small First"): The Presidency should champion a competitive and simplified digital rulebook. The priority should be reducing the administrative burden on high-growth companies. We advocate for a "28th Regime" approach - an optional standardised legal framework for companies to trade across the EU without navigating 27 different legal systems, making the Single Market a tangible reality for start-ups.

geography: Scale Ireland is an Irish representative body but maintains active international links, especially within the EU.
response_text: The Irish Presidency should focus on legislative proposals of the European Commission’s 2026 Work Programme. 1. Capital Markets Union (CMU), Savings and Investments Union & Listing Act: The Presidency must advance the Savings and Investment Union. Specifically, we urge a focus on accessing savings for investments in European innovative businesses, harmonising insolvency proceedings and simplifying listing rules for SMEs on public markets. This is critical to creating viable exit strategies for founders and investors within Europe. 2. Implementation of the AI Act & Digital Rulebook: As the AI Act moves into full implementation, the Presidency must ensure that the compliance burden does not stifle early-stage innovation. Work should focus on the European AI Office to ensure an SME focus and that "regulatory sandboxes" are accessible and effective for start-ups, not just incumbents. We strongly believe that we need to champion and deliver a competitive and simplified digital rulebook, ensuring interoperability and open markets are preserved. 3. Talent & Employee Ownership (ESOPs): To secure the talent pipeline, the Presidency should advance the EU Talent Pool initiative and push for the mutual recognition of qualifications in deep-tech sectors. Crucially, Ireland should lead discussions on the harmonisation of Stock Option (ESOP) treatment across Member States. Promoting a unified, attractive framework for employee ownership is vital for start-ups to attract top-tier talent against global competitors. This would leave taxation issues to member states. 4. Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF): Ireland should ensure the ringfencing of the MFF budget for digital entrepreneurship, research, innovation and adoption. This includes defending and expanding the budget for the European Innovation Council (EIC) to support deep-tech scale-ups.

geography: Scale Ireland is an Irish representative body but maintains active international links, especially within the EU.
response_text: The Council can maximise impact by shifting focus from regulation to implementation and simplification. For Businesses (Startups & Scale-ups): The substantial impact will come from removing friction. By advancing the Single Market enforcement and the 28th Regime, the Council can allow an Irish software company to sell to German or French customers as easily as they do locally. This reduces the "cost of doing business," which Scale Ireland’s State of Startups Survey consistently identifies as a major barrier. For People (Talent & Workers): By prioritising the up-skilling and re-skilling agenda, the Council can ensure the workforce is prepared for the AI and digital transition. Promoting digital adoption in traditional SMEs will democratise productivity gains, protecting jobs and creating high-value employment in regional communities, not just capital cities. For Communities: Access to regional funding and equity is important. The Presidency can impact communities by ensuring that EU R&D funding (Horizon Europe/EIC) is accessible to start-ups in all regions, not just major hubs. Promoting "Smart Villages" and digital connectivity ensures that the benefits of the digital transition - such as remote working and remote founding - are felt in rural Ireland and across Europe.

geography: Scale Ireland is an Irish representative body but maintains active international links, especially within the EU.
response_text: To create ownership, the Presidency must make the EU visible and relevant to the next generation of innovators and entrepreneurs. 1. "The European Start-up Capital": Ireland should utilise the Presidency to host a flagship European AI & Innovation Summit in Dublin. Unlike traditional diplomatic summits, this should be open to students, founders, and researchers and investors.. Showcasing "home-grown" European unicorns and scaling companies promotes visibility, proving that the EU is a launchpad for global ambition. 2. Regional Roadshows: Scale Ireland’s Regional Summits have proven that innovation is nationwide. The Presidency should sponsor a "Digital Europe Roadshow" visiting universities and hubs in Cork, Galway, Limerick, and beyond, explaining how EU policy (like the AI Act or EIC funding) directly support local jobs and research. 3. Engaging the Ecosystem: Utilise digital platforms to run "Policy workshops" where citizens and founders can contribute ideas to simplify EU rules. This moves communication from "broadcasting" to "co-creating," giving the tech community a direct stake in the Presidency’s success.

geography: Scale Ireland is an Irish representative body but maintains active international links, especially within the EU.
response_text: Scale Ireland submits these comments as an active member of the Enterprise Digital Advisory Forum (EDAF) In addition to the points raised above, Scale Ireland highlights the following critical technical considerations for the Presidency: • R&D Tax Credit Harmonisation: While tax remains a national competence, the Presidency should encourage best-practice sharing on R&D incentives. The current disparity in R&D definitions creates friction for cross-border collaboration. • Definition of "Startup": We would like the Council to distinguish between "SMEs" (traditional small businesses) and "Start-ups" (high-growth, innovation-driven enterprises) in legislative texts. One-size-fits-all SME policies often fail to address the specific equity-finance and rapid-scaling needs of start-ups. • State Aid & GBER: We advocate for a continued review of the General Block Exemption Regulation (GBER) to ensure it is fit for purpose for deep-tech investment, allowing Member States to agilely support innovation without bureaucratic delays. We believe that by focusing on Capital, Talent, and Simplification, Ireland’s 2026 Presidency can be the turning point that establishes Europe as a global leader in deep-tech scaling.

Through leadership in innovation, Ireland can help establish a robust policy framework that builds investor confidence and lays the foundation for decarbonising shipping and aviation. In addition to supporting the ramp up of e-fuels as the best means to decarbonise long haul flights and deep sea shipping, zero carbon emissions innovation in flights and shipping should be central to the wider decarbonisation conversation. The policies mentioned earlier not only advance climate objectives but also strengthen Europe’s strategic energy sovereignty by reducing dependence on imported fossil fuels, fostering domestic renewable energy and renewable fuel industries, and creating a resilient, innovation-driven energy ecosystem. By prioritising climate and innovation, Ireland can ensure Europe’s policies achieve environmental targets while reinforcing technological leadership, industrial competitiveness, and long-term energy sovereignty. The SASHA Coalition (Skies and Seas Hydrogen-fuels Accelerator) has recently welcomed new members from Ireland who are driving innovation in climate and clean technologies for aviation and shipping. These members are at the forefront of sustainable fuel solutions such as green hydrogen and direct air capture, crucial for decarbonising these sectors. We would welcome the opportunity to collaborate on Presidency events to showcase Irish leadership in innovation, highlighting the country’s role in advancing Europe’s transition to low-carbon transport and its leadership in climate and industrial innovation.

RFEUA and FEUM: The Commission has announced it plans to reopen RFEUA with the clear intention to leave the mandates under Annex I outside of the scope of the reopening. These mandates are crucial in ensuring regulatory certainty for e-kerosene producers, but also aviation fuel suppliers who are responsible for reaching the targets, and airlines who will be using the e-kerosene. As tools are deployed the create more financial certainty and de-risk investments in e-fuel production (through the double sided auction system announced in the Sustainable Transport Investment Plan for instance), it is of utmost importance that the mandates stay where they are. We therefore recommend the Irish Presidency to follow the Commission’s lead on keeping the changes to minimal adaptations on the anti-tankering rules, should the Commission in fact make such a legislative proposal, and ensure no amendments are tabled outside of this scope. On FEUM, the Commission has indicated it sought to review the regulation along with the EU ETS, which is planned in Q3 2026. The Regulation clearly states it should be reviewed if and when a global fuels standard is adopted. As the next vote for the International Maritime Organization’s (IMO) Net Zero Framework (NZF) is only expected in October 2026, there is a timing mismatch. We would like to urge to Irish Presidency to ensure any legislative proposal for an amendment of FEUM by the Commission is only looked into once the IMO NZF is approved. Revision of the Energy Taxation Directive: The aviation industry continues to benefit from a privileged fiscal regime across the EU, which directly affects the ability of less emitting sectors to compete on a level playing field. This preferential tax treatments currently afforded to fossil-fuel-powered flights and ships. artificially strengthens the competitive position of high-emitting aircraft and fuels. . This fiscal regime stems from the Energy Tax Directive (ETD), a Directive adopted more than 20 years ago and which must now be revised to reflect the EU’s current strategic priorities. We recommend addressing this in the revision by clearly and unequivocally authorising the taxation of aviation fuels both for intra-EU and international flights through a revision of the ETD, as initially proposed by the Commission in 2021. Revenues generated from fossil fuel taxation via the revision of Energy Taxation Directive (ETD), or other aviation-related revenue streams must be reinvested into the development of sustainable alternative fuels, clean technologies, and renewable low-carbon industrial base. This is critical not only from an equity perspective, but also for ensuring that emerging clean technologies can compete on a genuinely level playing field.

During its term, the Irish EU Council Presidency can make a substantial positive impact for people, businesses, and communities across the Union by placing climate, energy sovereignty, and leadership in innovation at the heart of its agenda. Europe faces an urgent need to decarbonise its economy in line with its 2040 climate targets, and the Presidency offers a pivotal opportunity to provide the political leadership necessary to translate ambition into concrete action. The EU Council plays a central role in this process. By bringing together the governments of all member states, it coordinates legislative priorities, ensures alignment across national policies, and facilitates consensus on key climate and energy dossiers. During the Irish Presidency, the Council can accelerate negotiations on critical files such as the EU Emissions Trading System (EU ETS), RFEUA/FEUM, and the Energy Taxation Directive (ETD), enabling timely adoption and effective implementation of measures that drive decarbonisation and innovation across the Union. Policies such as the EU ETS, RFEUA, and the ETD are essential instruments in this effort. The EU ETS provides cost-effective mechanisms to reduce emissions while sending clear market signals that stimulate investment in zero-carbon technologies. RFEUA/FEUM and the ETD accelerate the adoption of sustainable fuels, improve energy efficiency, and ensure taxation aligns with climate objectives. By coordinating these policies effectively, the Irish Presidency can create a predictable regulatory environment that encourages businesses to invest in innovation, helping European companies lead the global transition to clean energy and low-emission transport. The Presidency can also reinforce Europe’s strategic energy sovereignty. By reducing reliance on imported fossil fuels and promoting domestic renewable energy and sustainable fuel production, the EU strengthens its resilience to energy price volatility and geopolitical pressures. This benefits communities across Europe by safeguarding energy security, supporting local industrial growth, and generating employment in emerging sectors such as green aviation and clean technology. For citizens, these policies translate into tangible improvements in air quality, public health, and long-term economic resilience. For businesses, they provide certainty for planning and investing in zero-carbon technologies innovation, ensuring European industries remain globally competitive. By prioritising climate, energy sovereignty, and leadership in innovation, Ireland can use its Presidency to ensure that Europe’s policies not only meet environmental objectives but also deliver equitable economic benefits, strengthen industrial competitiveness, and secure a resilient, zero carbon future for all EU citizens.

Ireland’s Presidency of the Council of the EU offers a unique opportunity to communicate the tangible benefits of EU membership to citizens by highlighting how European policies deliver real-world improvements for people, communities, and businesses. Climate and innovation provide a compelling entry point for this narrative, demonstrating how EU action directly contributes to a sustainable, resilient, and prosperous future. The benefits from EU membership, and the climate action we feel the Presidency will focus on, we ensure Ireland general budget for climate action will benefit. For example if the EU ETS had included international aviation bbetween 2012-2023 the EU would have raised an additional €26bn in revenues for climate action for member states. This revenues could fund energy-efficient retrofits for more than 12,800 homes, saving households €20.7m in energy bills annually. These are tangible benefits from Irish government and EU action that will improve people’s lives that can be easily communicated. EU climate policies, such as the EU Emissions Trading System (EU ETS), ReFuelEU Aviation and Maritime, and the Energy Taxation Directive (ETD), are concrete examples of Europe’s leadership in decarbonisation. These initiatives drive the transition to technologies, support the growth of industries, and reduce dependence on imported fossil fuels. By framing these policies in terms of their direct impact cleaner air, lower energy vulnerability, innovation-driven job creation, and economic competitiveness citizens can see the value of EU membership in improving daily life, protecting communities, and safeguarding the planet for future generations.

organisation: Trinity College Dublin, the University of Dublin
response_text: As the birthplace of democracy, the EU must fiercely defend European values and create a future where both humanity and the planet can flourish. Ireland’s Presidency should therefore focus on: European values: The values of equality, fairness, inclusion, justice, freedom and human rights are under threat around the world. During the Presidency, Ireland must stand up for Europe’s foundational values to defend democracy, empower critical thinking, counter the spread of mis- and dis-information, and strengthen democratic institutions and European cohesion. Accountability and transparency should be viewed as competitive advantages that attract investment and safeguard democracy. Ireland will begin the next Trio cycle and should set the tone with a re-affirmation of the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights ahead of the charter’s twentieth anniversary in 2027. In addition, and as the deadline for the UN SDGs draws closer (2030), Ireland should draw on its experience as Co-Chair of the UN SDG development to accelerate existing shared EU and UN SDG aims. Competitiveness: Ireland’s Presidency should drive Europe’s competitiveness agenda, particularly in research and innovation. New technologies, including AI, bring huge opportunities; Europe must be at the forefront of the responsible development and ethical application of these technologies. Education and research are central to Europe’s future prosperity. The Presidency will coincide with high-level negotiations on FP10 and the next Erasmus programme; Ireland should advocate for continued investment in research and education and the Union of Skills (including life-long learning) to ensure the EU can deliver the objectives of its competitiveness compass. To be competitive, however, Europe must also be resilient. Sustainability in its widest sense (economic, social and environmental) should be a core tenet of the Presidency. Europe will only be resilient to climate or political-induced shocks to economic systems, supply chains, export markets, labour markets, financial markets if we have resilient natural systems, and resilient communities and populations. A wide range of mitigation and adaptation strategies are necessary to address the climate crisis and these must be aligned to European values. Holistic policy making and long-term generational planning, informed by transdisciplinary research, will have genuine positive impact on citizens’ lives: healthier people, better livelihoods, fairer and more competitive economies, all underpinned by healthy, resilient natural systems and stronger health systems. Security: Competitiveness and security are interconnected. Ireland's comparative advantage lies in convening diverse stakeholders to translate policy into practice. The Presidency should leverage this capacity to advance the competitiveness-values-security nexus through transparency mechanisms, facilitating knowledge sharing between member states and demonstrating how smaller states achieve impact through strategic partnership-building. Contributors to actionable strategies should include regulators, law enforcement, civil society, business, and academia.

organisation: Trinity College Dublin, the University of Dublin
response_text: Holistic legislation: A collaborative approach must be taken, using inclusive processes and evidence-based, research-informed decision-making. Universities, communities and business organisations should engage in open discussion to find solutions that deliver a fairer, more secure Europe that aligns with European values. The twin transition: Legislation linked to the green and digital transitions should be prioritised. This includes Fit for 55 Package, the Circular Economy Act, the energy union package, digital fairness, and the education Package (particularly around digital education and skills). Citizen inclusion, talent development, security, and fairness: the Fair Labour Mobility Package, anti-fraud and anti-corruption legislation, the European Product Act, the ERA act and the European integrated framework for climate resilience can all inform a human-centred approach to building a fair society equipped to meet the economic and societal challenges of the climate crisis, the uncertain geopolitical landscape, and increased digitisation. The EC Strategic Agenda 2024-2029: the Irish Presidency should focus on ‘respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights, including the rights of persons belonging to minorities.’ It should counter racism, hate speech and hate crime in our local, national and European community. With migration reform a focus of the EU and Council, Ireland must ensure that the EU is an open, safe and welcoming union to all and that migration reform does not feed anti-immigration sentiment. The EC Strategic Agenda also commits to strengthening ‘democratic resilience, including by deepening citizen engagement, protecting free and pluralistic media and civil society, tackling foreign interference and countering attempts at destabilisation, including through disinformation and hate speech.’ Ireland must strive for European cohesion and counter division driven by populist misinformation campaigns, particularly on digital platforms. International Criminal Court: Ireland should advocate for strengthening EU support for the ICC, and ensuring EU foreign policy upholds international humanitarian law in contemporary conflicts. Multi-Annual Financial Framework and European Research Area Act: Ireland should enable the passage of these and, if the European Innovation Act is passed during the Presidency, Ireland must ensure that the impact on universities and their role in the proposals are well identified and understood. EU Asset Recovery Directive: The Presidency should advance Ireland's opt-in to the EU Asset Recovery Directive and enhanced participation in Europol's Project A.S.S.E.T. Equality, diversity, and inclusion: The forthcoming EU Action Plan on Anti-Racism, the EU LGBTIQ Equality Strategy and the 2026-2030 EU Gender Equality Strategy should be prioritised during the Presidency, in addition to the ongoing commitments of the EU Strategy for the Rights of Persons with Disabilities 2021 to 2030. Responsible AI frameworks: Ireland can lead on responsible AI frameworks for financial compliance and fraud detection and should also promote legislation enabling cross-border access to public procurement data to detect bid-rigging. The Presidency should also consider how the AI Act will be interpreted within educational settings and how educational policies, practices, and infrastructures should ensure the benefits of AI can be harnessed responsible to accelerate learning opportunities and enhance student and citizen learning while mitigating potential risks. Work of previous Presidency: Progress made during the previous Presidency, such as the Gender Equality Strategy 2026-2030 and intergenerational fairness, should be reflected in Ireland’s Presidency.

organisation: Trinity College Dublin, the University of Dublin
response_text: Expert input: consult subject matter experts to understand potential impacts and demonstrate the value of research and education on everyday life. Public consultation: engage with citizens through town halls, business fora, surveys, and online platforms. The Presidency should be perceived as a participatory democratic exercise with ongoing, meaningful public engagement with all communities. Representation: include diverse voices: different socioeconomic groups, regions, genders, and minority communities.

organisation: Trinity College Dublin, the University of Dublin
response_text: A sense of ownership comes with being heard and included: Engage with citizens, communities and businesses to create a multi-way dialogue to inform the work of the Presidency and communicate this work (and its impact) in real-life situations through a comprehensive communications strategy. Demonstrate the collaborative nature of the EU: Proactively counter dis-information about EU laws and regulations being ‘imposed’ by explaining the collaborative process among member states and the role of citizens in their development. Education: The work of the EU and its instruments of governance are not well understood at Member State level. Bridging information gaps through good communication, targeted educational programmes, and policy alignment can strengthen cohesion and enhance the collective European identity. Given the strength of the tech sector in Ireland and the importance of addressing information manipulation and disinformation Ireland should lead on the implementation of the Democracy Shield and the EU Strategy for Civil Society as they align with national interests and the brief of the EU Commissioner for Justice, whose brief includes key freedoms (elections, people, media, democratic institutions). HEIs are well positioned to support this work through expertise, teaching, research and civic engagement.

organisation: Trinity College Dublin, the University of Dublin
response_text: Contributors (in alphabetical order) [REDACTED UNDER GDPR]

Ireland’s 2026 Presidency offers an opportunity to promote a people-centred and resilient European Union. Two high-level themes are proposed: 1. Reducing Poverty and Inequality A focus on economic inclusion and social fairness aligns closely with the EU Strategic Agenda 2024–2029. Ireland could highlight policies that protect vulnerable households, support equitable growth, and strengthen the EU’s commitment to tackling poverty both within Europe and globally. Addressing the main drivers of poverty in partner countries is a central part of this effort, especially where lack of access to essential health services directly contributes to lost income, disability, and long-term vulnerability. 2. Strengthening Health Systems and Crisis Preparedness Resilient health systems underpin economic stability, wellbeing and effective crisis response. Ireland could champion measures that address health inequalities, improve access to essential services, and reinforce Europe’s capacity to prepare for and manage future shocks. As part of this, the Presidency could draw attention to significant global health gaps—such as limited access to essential surgical and anaesthetic care—which are closely linked to maternal mortality, avoidable disability, and economic instability in low-resource settings. Highlighting this issue would support EU goals on resilience, poverty reduction and global responsibility. These two priorities offer a clear, people-centred vision for the Presidency, reflecting Ireland’s strengths and aligning with the EU’s long-term strategic objectives while remaining focused and achievable.

A clear and high-impact policy area that Ireland could prioritise during its 2026 Presidency is addressing the funding gap for essential surgical and anaesthetic care within EU external action. This issue sits directly at the intersection of poverty reduction, health-system strengthening, gender equality and economic resilience. Lack of access to basic surgical care is a major, but often overlooked, driver of poverty in low-resource settings. Preventable disability, maternal and neonatal mortality, and loss of income frequently result from conditions that require straightforward surgical intervention. Families often face catastrophic health expenditure when services are unavailable or unaffordable. Despite this, essential surgery remains one of the least funded areas within EU development, humanitarian and research programmes. Ireland could use the Presidency to encourage the Council to: Recognise essential surgical and anaesthetic care as part of the EU’s approach to poverty reduction and health-system resilience. Explore dedicated funding opportunities for surgical capacity-building within Global Europe (NDICI), humanitarian assistance and related EU external instruments. Promote the use of standardised indicators, such as the Lancet Commission’s core surgical metrics, to track progress and ensure accountability in EU-supported health programmes. Addressing this funding gap would support the EU’s Strategic Agenda commitment to a more resilient and globally responsible Europe. It would also build on Ireland’s strengths in global health partnerships, demonstrating leadership in an area where relatively modest investment can deliver substantial and long-lasting social and economic benefits.

A significant area that deserves attention within the wider framework of poverty reduction and health-system strengthening is the global gap in access to essential surgical and anaesthetic care. Around five billion people cannot obtain safe, timely and affordable surgery when needed. This gap contributes directly to avoidable disability, maternal mortality, loss of income and long-term economic vulnerability for households and communities. For many low-resource settings, the inability to access basic surgical care is a major but often overlooked driver of poverty. Despite the clear evidence of impact and cost-effectiveness, essential surgery receives limited attention within current EU development, humanitarian and research funding mechanisms. This funding gap restricts progress in workforce training, emergency preparedness, infrastructure and universal access to essential services. Ireland is well placed to highlight this issue during its Presidency, given its strong record in global health cooperation and its experience with practical, long-term partnerships. The RCSI–COSECSA collaboration, for example, has supported surgical training and capacity-building across East, Central and Southern Africa, demonstrating how sustained support can strengthen health systems and deliver measurable results. Addressing the global surgery funding gap would reinforce EU priorities on fairness, resilience and poverty reduction. It would also reflect Ireland’s commitment to people-centred development and its capacity to provide leadership in areas where targeted action can make a substantial difference.

Ireland’s Presidency of the Council of the European Union in 2026 offers a significant opportunity to renew the EU’s commitment to human rights defender (HRD) protection worldwide. Given that Ireland played a critical role in securing the EU Guidelines on Human Rights Defenders in 2004, it is uniquely positioned to lead a Presidency that prioritises their practical and operational implementation. This focus is urgently needed. Front Line Defenders global work shows that HRDs now face increasingly sophisticated and multilayered forms of repression, including digital surveillance, deregistration of their organisations, withdrawal of funding, restrictions on financial transfers, asset freezes, politically motivated sanctioning measures, and the misuse of counter-terrorism frameworks to criminalise and silence peaceful human rights work. In many regions, these criminalisation processes are rooted in business interest and linked to their operations. Across regions, restrictive NGO laws, smear campaigns, digital surveillance, online harassment, and the misuse of cybersecurity and disinformation frameworks have restricted space in which human rights defenders operate. A particular concern documented across multiple regions is the long-term imprisonment of HRDs often following unfair trials. Many defenders are serving sentences of a decade or more, including individuals with EU nationality or strong EU links. These long-term detentions are used strategically: they remove influential voices from public life, intimidate broader communities of defenders and reshape civic space environments in ways that undermine the very values the EU seeks to advance. A high-level theme centered on “Strengthening EU Support to Human Rights Defenders” would allow Ireland to consolidate existing EU tools while elevating the urgent need for sustained, coordinated EU engagement on long term imprisonment cases. As Front Line Defenders experience shows, consistent diplomatic pressure, concrete support to HRDs and visible international engagement can meaningfully shift outcomes whereas inconsistent attention allows repression to deepen. This thematic focus would also allow Ireland to highlight the indispensable contributions of HRDs in documenting violations and working on issues including but not limited to defending environmental rights and land, exposing businesses malpractices, corruption, advancing women’s rights, LGBTI+ rights and preventing conflict, work that directly reinforces EU foreign policy objectives. By placing HRD protection and protecting civic space online and offline, including sustained action on long term imprisonment at the heart of its thematic agenda, Ireland can deliver a Presidency that is principled and operational building directly on Ireland’s legacy in shaping the EU’s HRD protection architecture.

To advance a Presidency theme on strengthening EU support to human rights defenders, Ireland can adopt an ambitious, action oriented approach that enhances the EU’s work in this area without requiring a formal review or legislative change. Ireland could launch a Presidency HRD Protection Initiative. This could include but is not limited to: A targeted focus on HRD protection in selected contexts, focusing on environments where defenders are increasingly targeted through a combination of offline and online repression. Drawing on delegation and embassy practice, EEAS expertise and input from HRDs, this exercise could examine cases involving deregistration, funding withdrawal, asset freezes, misuse of counter-terrorism and sanction frameworks, as well as digital surveillance, online smear campaigns and disinformation attacks. Given global patterns documented by Front Line Defenders, the deep dive should also specifically include environmental and land rights defenders, who remain among the most targeted groups due to their exposure of environmental damage, land grabs, corruption and abuses linked to extractive projects. The objective would be to identify a set of very concrete, actionable measures that the EU, including delegations and Member States embassies, can implement immediately to meaningfully address these trends and strengthen HRD protection. As the next EU Action Plan on Human Rights and Democracy will be negotiated during the Irish Presidency, the findings of this targeted exercise could also directly inform the Action Plan’s HRD operational actions. Ireland would be well placed to ensure that strong existing language on HRDs is preserved and reinforced in the new Action Plan and that it translates into clear, operational expectations for delegations and Member States embassies. Ireland should also use its Presidency to drive a more structured and sustained EU response to the long-term imprisonment of human rights defenders. By leading COHOM in adopting a short list of emblematic cases, including dual EU nationals such as Abdulhadi Al-Khawaja and Dawit Isaak, Ireland could launch a six-month programe of intensified and coordinated EU diplomacy. This could include joint demarches at key moments in each case, regular trial and prison-condition monitoring, strategic capital to capital outreach and consistent, aligned messaging in political dialogues and relevant multilateral fora. Such an approach would help move the EU to a persistent, case based diplomatic strategy, increasing pressure for progress in emblematic cases and signaling to governments worldwide that the long-term detention of HRDs will remain a priority concern throughout the Irish Presidency Ireland should also ensure HRDs are directly heard within the Council of the EU system by encouraging COHOM and relevant Council of the EU working parties, including but not limited to COTER,COJUR, COEST, COMAG, COLAT, COAFR, Mashreq/Maghreb and COJUR, to systematically invite HRDs to brief delegations. Their insights would help ensure that HRD protection concerns are incorporated into policy debates and legislative proposals coming before the Council, including those related to counter-terrorism cooperation, digital regulation, sanctions regimes, AML frameworks, environmental protection and other areas directly affecting defenders. The Irish Presidency should play a role in bridging the EU’s climate and environmental agendas with its human rights and HRD protection commitments, by bringing together the Council formations and working parties that shape these policies. As the EU accelerates its energy transition, Ireland can foster an approach that recognises environmental and land rights defenders as essential partners in ensuring that climate action is both effective and rights-respecting. This could include convening joint discussions between environment, energy, and human rights officials; promoting discussions on a rights-based energy transition; and integrating human rights impacts and HRD protection into renewable-energy and critical-raw-materials projects.

An Irish Presidency that strengthens the EU’s capacity to protect HRDs delivers broad benefits for people, communities and businesses across Europe. HRDs are often the first to identify patterns of corruption, environmental destruction, illicit financial flows, organised crime, abuses linked to extractive industries and big tech, and early warning signs of instability. By enhancing the EU’s ability to act on these insights the Irish Presidency would help reinforce human rights and the rule of law which in turn positively affects European citizens and economies.

Ireland can best communicate the values and benefits of EU membership by highlighting how the EU’s actions directly support people who defend human rights in some of the most difficult environments worldwide. Sharing concrete stories of human rights defenders, environmental HRDs protecting land and water, and resisting corporate malpractices, women HRDs defending equality, journalists HRDs uncovering corruption helps illustrate the tangible impact of EU diplomacy and why EU membership matters. These examples resonate with Irish citizens’ deeply held values of fairness, solidarity and standing up for those at risk. It its crucial that the Irish Presidency challenges the persistent narrative that HRDs are obstacles to progress or that protecting them undermines economic competitiveness. In reality, safeguarding HRDs, and enforcing human rights and environmental obligations for companies are not burdensome constraints but essential foundations for sustainable development, ethical investment, and public trust. Corporate accountability prevents abuses that ultimately carry high economic, social, and reputational costs, while HRDs often serve as early-warning actors who help identify risks, prevent conflict, and ensure that development benefits the the wider people rather than only a few. Communicating these positive, tangible contributions, showing that strong human rights protections support innovation, stability, and long-term prosperity, can help citizens see EU values not as abstract ideals but as practical tools that strengthens economy and society as a whole. The Presidency also gives Ireland an opportunity to demonstrate how a small Member State can meaningfully shape the EU’s global human-rights agenda. Ireland’s leadership in securing the EU Guidelines on Human Rights Defenders show citizens that Ireland can influence significant EU policy outcomes grounded in principle and credibility. Clear, accessible communication can make these issues visible and relatable. Organising exchanges and initiatives with HRDs in Ireland during the Presidency to share first hand experience could deepen public understanding of both the risks they face and the ways the EU can help protect them.

Building on the response to Question 3 above, the Irish Presidency should also make it a priority to challenge the prevalent ‘security-first’ rhetoric that provides cover for human rights violations of human rights and the targeting of HRDs in the name of national security. Ireland should ensure it is understood across all EU institutions and member states that respect for human rights must be at the centre of any current and future counter terrorism measures. In particular, ensure that any measures stemming from the new EU Internal Security Strategy (https://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/TXT/HTML/?uri=CELEX:52025DC0148 ) and the forthcoming new EU Counter Terrorism Agenda are fully compliant with obligations to respect international human rights law, international refugee law and international humanitarian law and that human rights experts (including HRDs) are meaningfully consulted in their preparation. The Irish Presidency should also take measures to combat the spreading misuse of Counter Terrorism laws across the world, including in Europe, to restrict or criminalise the legitimate activities of HRDs and others expressing rights to free expression, assembly and association. It should leads discussions to stop the use by the EU of overly broad definitions of terrorism and terrorist activities that often leads to or facilitates this misuse and ensure that the EU does not use or advocate for overly broad definitions of terrorism and terrorist activities in its international cooperation, including multilateral activities and bilateral dialogues with third countries. The Irish Presidency should fully implement the recommendations made to all regional organisations by the UN Special Rapporteur on Promotion and Protection of Human Rights while Countering Terrorism, in his August 2024 report to the General Assembly (https://docs.un.org/en/A/79/324 ) and his March 2025 report to the Human Rights Council (https://docs.un.org/en/A/HRC/58/47 ) and organise a dedicated Council discussion with a view to carrying out a full assessment of EU implementation of these recommendations. Looking ahead to the European Commission’s 2026 work programme, it is important to also ensure that emerging digital and industrial initiatives, such as the Cloud and AI Development Act, as well as the recently environmental omnibus and digital omnibus, are developed with strong human-rights safeguards, including protections for environmental and land-rights defenders impacted by data-centre expansion and resource use. Likewise, as the EU launches a Critical Raw Materials Centre and revises rules on digital legislation, the Presidency can promote an approach that embeds human-rights due diligence, and HRD protection across these strategic sectors. Front Line Defenders stands ready to elaborate further and to work with Ireland in advancing these recommendations throughout the Presidency.

We propose that Ireland should champion collective coordinated action to reduce health inequities and inequalities across Europe as a high-level thematic priority for its Presidency of the Council. We propose a Dublin/Irish Declaration on Addressing Health Inequalities and Improving Health Equity in Europe, and establishment of EU Mission on Health Equity based in Ireland. Huge progress has been made in Public Health in Europe since Ireland last held this role . Spurred on by the experience of the COVID-19 pandemic, we have seen great improvements made in emergency planning and response, disease surveillance, genomics, vaccine development and therapeutics. But these benefits have not been shared equally: we have seen widening gaps in experience of morbidity and mortality among people in Europe. People in the EU now live an average of 81.4 years. Yet, a child born in Spain—the country with the highest life expectancy (84 years)—can expect to live more than eight years longer than a child born in Bulgaria, where life expectancy is 75.8 years. Healthy Life Years (HLY) showed an even wider gap, ranging from about 52 to 69 years across the EU—17-years—highlighting that living longer does not necessarily mean living healthier. HLY are decreasing in many countries, with more people becoming ill earlier than in the past. There are also stark differences within countries. The European Social Survey (ESS) shows that people in lower socioeconomic groups are twice as likely to report poor health as those in higher groups. The higher someone’s social position, the more likely they are to live a long and healthy life, a pattern known as the “social gradient in health”. Countries exhibiting higher levels of income inequality tend to have poorer population health outcomes. Such health inequities reflect not only unequal access to healthcare, prevention, screening and vaccine programmes, but also to wider determinants of health, including income distribution, education, employment, housing, air quality, food security, safe spaces and other assets which promote and protect health. The social gradient in health is not fixed. Health improvements vary across socioeconomic groups, with disparities evident by gender, race/ethnicity, and disability highlighting that health inequalities are both avoidable and unjust. Vulnerable and marginalised groups, including some ethnic minorities and migrant populations experience even poorer health These inequalities undermine our shared European values, weaken economic competitiveness, and reduce resilience in the face of geopolitical and environmental crises. To reduce inequalities across the EU, we must address the social gradient in health, improving health for everyone, but at a scale and intensity proportionate to the degree of need. A Presidency anchored in equity would support Member States facing demographic ageing, workforce pressures, and regionally unbalanced development—areas where Ireland can offer recognised leadership. By prioritising health equity Ireland can shape a Presidency that aligns with EU values, enhances quality of life, and strengthens resilience. This would support more inclusive, sustainable development across Europe and ensure that progress in public health benefits everyone.

Ireland should focus its Presidency on driving a whole-of-government, health in all policies, cross-sectoral EU approach to improving health equity and reducing inequities and inequalities. This means that multiple policy sectors, including health and social services, education, housing, employment, and economic policy, must collaborate. While Member States retain primary responsibility for healthcare, education, and social policy, the EU plays a unique decisive role in shaping the structural conditions that influence health, including setting standards on employment protections, consumer and environmental regulation, and market governance. Equality is one of the themes of the Strategic Agenda. A focus on health equity would build on the European Pillar of Social Rights, the European Child Guarantee and the planned Anti-Poverty Strategy, and the themes of recent presidencies (Poland: health security, mental health in children and health promotion and disease prevention; and Denmark: gender equality). It would also contribute to a range of EU supported projects and joint actions targeting cancer, cardiovascular disease, infectious diseases and digital health. Multiple sectors share the need for priority actions on housing, clima The WHO report on the Social Determinants of Health (2008) increased global awareness of health equity. It led to the of the European Commission Communication on Solidarity in Health (2009), followed by Council Conclusions and a reference in the EU 2020 strategy (2010–2020) on ‘‘the need to combat poverty and social exclusion and reduce health inequalities to ensure that everybody can benefit from growth.’’ A focus on health equity would enable the intersecting actions proposed in the 2025 WHO report on Social Determinants of Health Equity: - Addressing economic inequality and investing in social infrastructure and universal public services - Overcoming structural discrimination - Managing the challenges and opportunities posed by the mega-trends of climate change and the digital transformation in a way that systematically promotes health equity. - Putting in place governance arrangements that will maximize the coherence and impact of action. Key areas in which Ireland could lead include: 1. Strengthening EU social and employment protections Legislation relating to working hours, minimum wages, job security, and occupational health and safety has direct impacts on health equity. Ireland can advance initiatives that support fairer labour conditions and reduce socioeconomic vulnerability. 2. Regulating commercial determinants of health EU-level regulations on tobacco, alcohol, and unhealthy food are essential to reducing chronic disease and narrowing health gaps. Ireland’s proven leadership in public health legislation, from pioneering smoke-free workplaces to implementing Tobacco 21, puts it in a strong position to drive more ambitious EU-level action 3. Supporting Member State action through EU frameworks Enhanced cooperation on child wellbeing, early learning, housing quality, and environmental justice can help Member States tackle upstream determinants of health equity. By focusing on these areas, Ireland’s Presidency can help deliver lasting improvements in health outcomes and reduce inequities across Europe.

Health inequalities impose substantial economic and social costs across the EU. The European Parliament estimates that these disparities reduce GDP by approximately 1.4%, nearly the equivalent of the EU’s annual defence spending. For Ireland, leadership on health equity would align us with EU economic resilience goals—strengthening labour market participation, productivity, and long-term fiscal sustainability. Tackling health inequalities is not merely a moral imperative but an essential component of economic strategy. Economic losses arise from decreased productivity, lower tax revenues, and increased spending on healthcare and welfare. Current actions, often siloed, are insufficient to counter the deep structural forces that determine social conditions and health outcomes. Consequently, achieving health equity is seen as a vital strategy for strengthening societal resilience, improving competitiveness, and ensuring long-term sustainability. Childhood is a critical period of development, during which the effects of policy can have long-lasting and intergenerational impacts. Several EU states have rising levels of child poverty. A Dublin/Irish Declaration on Addressing Health Inequities and Inequalities in Europe, and establishment of EU Mission on Health Equities based in Ireland as part of the Presidency can support the Council in delivering high-impact initiatives by prioritising equity, prevention, and cross-sector collaboration. A decisive shift towards prevention is critical: prevention is recognised as the first principle of sustainable healthcare and carries a demonstrated return on investment of up to 14:1, making it one of the most effective levers for long-term system sustainability, and reducing the need for healthcare services. This shift aligns with the EU’s transition toward value-based, sustainable healthcare systems—a stated priority for several Member States and the European Commission. Current efforts remain overly focused on treatment, while over 80% of health outcomes are shaped by socioeconomic and environmental factors. Health inequalities persist even in countries that have maintained universal, free healthcare for decades, demonstrating that complementary action in other sectors is always required to ensure equity. Coordinated EU-level action across housing, education, employment, transport, climate, and social protection, anchored in strong preventive and equity focused policies, will generate significant benefits. In 2021, around 75 million people in the EU were living in poverty or at risk of poverty, disproportionately affecting migrants, children, women, and people with lower educational attainment. Income insecurity is identified as one of the main factors accounting for the lack of health equity. There is growing evidence of increasing ill health in working age people from preventable causes, that can cause poverty and social disadvantage. Improving the health of the population is an economic imperative. Improving health equity enhances workforce participation, strengthens competitiveness, builds social cohesion, and increases resilience to future shocks. Actions that reduce inequities benefit businesses through a healthier and more productive labour force, and support communities by creating environments where people can thrive. By focusing on health equity, Ireland’s Presidency can deliver tangible improvements that citizens can feel in their daily lives.

Effective communication of the benefits of EU membership requires clear, people-centred messaging. Ireland could also convene community partnership conversations/dialogues—co-hosted with local authorities and civil society—feeding directly into Council working groups, providing our populations with a visible route into EU policymaking. Ireland could lead on a “Dublin (or other Irish City) Declaration on Health Equity and Addressing Health Inequalities in Europe”, endorsed by all Member States, signalling collective commitment to tackling the social, economic, environmental, and educational conditions that shape the health of the people of Europe. This will support action at Member State level but also across the EU, working with communities and the people we serve, to improve the healthy life expectancy of all our citizens, enabling us to realise the benefits of a healthy population, making Europe a great place to live for everyone, and providing global leadership on tackling health inequities. This Declaration would highlight shared European values, fairness, solidarity, equity, and wellbeing, and communicate that the EU is acting directly on issues that matter to citizens: health, quality of life, access to opportunity, and community resilience. It would also help foster public ownership of the Presidency by demonstrating how EU collaboration produces concrete, visible benefits. EU membership connects directly to people’s lives – awareness of this can be improved through visible signposting of EU support, multimedia participatory formats, and active inclusion of communities and targeted population groups by addressing practical and digital barriers will also address health and wider inequalities. Health is a fundamental human right. Health inequalities affect everyone. Poor health, can lead to a lack of trust, damaging social participation and cohesion and reduce democratic engagement and social stability. Improving health for all makes society stronger, more inclusive, productive, and innovative. Reducing health inequalities is key to Europe’s prosperity, competitiveness, security, and resilience as described in the EU Strategic Agenda. A focus on health equity during the Presidency and the establishment of a mission in Ireland would support to ongoing commitment to improve everyday living conditions, reduce poverty and economic insecurity, address structural discrimination and exclusion, and enhance place-based, community led actions. In Ireland it would build the on the Child Poverty and Wellbeing programme work across sectors - income and joblessness, early learning, cost of education, and family homelessness. Institutions need more dialogue with citizens about their concerns – health inequalities affect everyone and can be framed around rights, solidarity, security and sustainability.

Health inequalities are differences in health that arise from social disadvantage. They stem from obstacles such as poverty, discrimination, unequal power, and limited access to the resources that help people stay healthy, fair work, safe environments, quality education, good housing, healthcare, and social support. These drivers are known collectively as the social determinants of health. The links below provide an overview of the key issues, challenges, risks, and evidence-based interventions to address health inequities across Europe, drawing on the HSE Position Paper on Health Inequalities, Ireland’s new Public Health Strategy, and EuroHealthNet’s report on social inequalities in health in the EU. The latter report especially uses recent comparable data from across Europe to describe the scale of health inequalities and the social and economic forces driving them. Data also show an increase in mortality rates observed in the lower socioeconomic groups for specific causes of death. This pattern implies that the conditions of deprivation are actively generating premature death, an outcome known as social pathogenesis, rather than simply failing to prevent it. Researchers found rising mortality rates from several conditions, including lung cancer, breast cancer, respiratory disease, gastrointestinal disease, and injuries among men and/or women in lower socioeconomic groups in multiple countries, including Finland, Norway, and Denmark. For women, mortality from lung cancer has increased across all surveyed countries, with the strongest increases concentrated among women with low levels of education. The social gradient is not fixed. Health outcomes vary by socioeconomic status, gender, ethnicity, and disability, demonstrating that health inequalities are avoidable and unjust. They also undermine EU values, weaken competitiveness, and reduce social resilience. Around 75 million people in the EU lived in or at risk of poverty in 2021, disproportionately affecting migrants, children, women, and people with lower levels of education. Income insecurity is one of the five main barriers to health equity, and countries with higher income inequality tend to have poorer population health overall. The COVID-19 pandemic exposed and exacerbated existing inequalities. Mortality impacts were lowest in Nordic countries and highest in Central and Eastern Europe, reflecting pre-existing disadvantage. Long COVID was more prevalent among people with lower education and pre-existing conditions such as obesity, while higher education was protective, offering resources such as health literacy, job control, and the ability to navigate protective measures like vaccination. Structural disadvantage, including discrimination and low institutional trust, also reduced vaccine uptake. Addressing these inequalities is essential for Europe’s competitiveness, security, and resilience—and requires systemic, cross-sector leadership and coordinated action. Ireland’s Presidency can help chart a path toward a more equitable and healthier Europe. Links: Healthy Ireland Framework HSE position paper on health inequalities HSE National Public Health Strategy Social inequalities in health in the EU | EuroHealthNet WHO Report on Social Determinants of Health Equity 2025

Ireland’s Presidency of the Council in 2026 offers a unique opportunity to shape the European Union’s agenda at a time of profound environmental, economic, and geopolitical change. Our priorities should reflect both the European Union’s long-term strategic objectives and the practical needs of citizens and businesses. Three themes stand out as critical: strengthening strategic autonomy, climate action, and simplification. Strategic Autonomy and Resilience Ireland should prioritise strengthening the EU’s strategic autonomy to ensure resilience in an increasingly uncertain global environment. Energy independence must be accelerated through diversification of sources and improved grid interconnections, reducing reliance on external suppliers. Digital sovereignty is equally critical, requiring investment in EU cloud infrastructure and robust cybersecurity standards. Securing supply chains for critical raw materials such as lithium and rare earths will underpin Europe’s industrial competitiveness, while risk mapping and contingency planning will bolster resilience across key sectors. Ireland should also advocate for balanced trade agreements that protect EU interests, while positioning the Union as a global leader in ethical AI and data governance. Finally, strengthening the euro’s international role and reducing dependence on external payment systems will reinforce financial autonomy and economic stability. Climate Action Ireland should champion an ambitious climate agenda during its Presidency, positioning the EU as a global leader in decarbonisation and sustainability. Accelerating the implementation of the Green Deal must be a central priority, with a strong push for timely delivery of Fit for 55 measures and net-zero targets. Harmonising carbon pricing across sectors through a strengthened EU Emissions Trading System will be key to driving emissions reductions efficiently. While Europe already provides subsidies for renewable energy and some tax credits, expanding these measures, alongside introducing effective domestic tax incentives monitored by a robust peer review mechanism, will be key to further mobilising private capital for clean technologies. Our experience advising businesses on transformational decarbonisation projects has shown us that there are challenges associated with accessing the Innovation Fund and Horizon Europe. Further education and experience shares by successful applicants would support more successful outcomes and access to this capital. A robust Just Transition framework is essential to support regions and sectors most affected by decarbonisation, ensuring fairness and social cohesion. Ireland should also advance circular economy legislation, including mandatory recycling targets and eco-design standards, while promoting innovation partnerships in areas such as hydrogen, energy storage, and carbon capture. Finally, climate diplomacy should remain a cornerstone, reinforcing the EU’s leadership in COP negotiations and climate finance. Simplification Simplification, as highlighted in the Draghi report, should focus on reducing regulatory complexity and making EU rules more practical and proportionate. Ireland can lead by promoting a digital-first approach, ensuring that funding applications and compliance processes are fully digitised and user-friendly. At the same time, the Common Agricultural Policy and cohesion funds should be streamlined with fewer, clearer rules to ease the administrative burden on farmers and SMEs. Future legislation must also reflect SME-friendly principles, applying proportionality so that smaller businesses are not overburdened by requirements designed for larger enterprises. By embedding Draghi’s vision of simpler, smarter regulation, Ireland can help create a framework that supports competitiveness, innovation, and trust in EU institutions. EU Commission President Ursula Von Der Leyen has stated her aim to cut red tape for MNEs by 25% across the EU. This would certainly make it easier and less costly to do business in the EU, strengthening economic growth which will positively impact our citizens' lives. By focusing on climate action, simplification, and strategic autonomy, Ireland can help the EU deliver on its most pressing challenges while laying the foundations for sustainable growth and resilience. These priorities will not only advance European objectives but also reflect Ireland’s commitment to a fair, innovative, and forward-looking European Union.

Ireland’s Presidency of the Council in 2026 should prioritise legislative and policy areas that strengthen Europe’s competitiveness, sustainability, and regulatory clarity. This is a moment to move beyond broad commitments and deliver tangible progress on industrial transformation, tax simplification, and smarter regulation. By focusing on the Clean Industrial Deal, tax and regulatory simplification, and Draghi-inspired measures, Ireland can help the EU achieve its strategic objectives while reducing complexity for businesses and citizens. Tax and Interest Simplification On taxation, Ireland will need to push forward on the simplification of the Anti-Tax Avoidance Directive (ATAD), particularly with respect to Controlled Foreign Companies (CFC) and Interest Limitation Rules (ILR), which remain overly complex for SMEs and cross-border groups. In parallel, advancing work on the Directive on Administrative Co-operation (DAC), including improvements to data exchange and reporting standards, will strengthen transparency and enforcement. These steps will not only improve the functioning of the single market but also demonstrate Ireland’s commitment to practical, business-friendly solutions. Clean Industrial Deal and Sustainability A key priority should be advancing the implementation of the Net-Zero Industry Act to accelerate the deployment of clean technology manufacturing capacity across Europe, particularly in batteries, hydrogen, and solar. Ireland should also ensure the smooth rollout of the Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism (CBAM), addressing compliance challenges for SMEs and preparing for its expansion to additional sectors, while promoting consistency of data requirements across regulations—for example, aligning emissions data for CBAM with sustainability reporting and similar needs under the EUDR (EU Deforestation Regulation). Following up on the Critical Raw Materials Act will be essential to secure supply chains, with measures such as ambitious recycling targets and strategic stockpiling. In addition, a priority should be to promote activation of the Clean Industrial Deal (CID) tax incentives, such as targeted credits and accelerated depreciation for clean-tech investments. Depending on progress under the Cypriot Presidency, the Government will need to consider whether efforts will be required to get Council agreement on the Energy Taxation Directive to drive industrial decarbonisation and competitiveness across the Union. Finally, revising the Industrial Emissions Directive to tighten standards for heavy industry, while coupling this with innovation funding, will help balance environmental ambition with competitiveness. Better Regulation and Digital-by-Default Ireland should also champion Draghi’s call for a new approach to regulation. Updating the Better Regulation agenda by making administrative burden assessments mandatory for all new legislative proposals, including those under the EU Digital Act and the VAT in the Digital Age (VIDA) initiative, will ensure that rules are proportionate and workable. These measures will help create a regulatory environment that fosters innovation, competitiveness, and trust in EU governance. By focusing on industrial decarbonisation, tax simplification, and smarter regulation, Ireland’s Presidency can deliver concrete outcomes that strengthen Europe’s resilience and competitiveness. These priorities reflect Ireland’s commitment to a forward-looking, practical, and sustainable European Union.

Ireland’s Presidency of the Council in 2026 can make a substantial positive impact by focusing on outcomes that citizens and businesses can see and feel. This means delivering policies that strengthen Europe’s global leadership, simplifying everyday interactions with EU systems, and securing long-term competitiveness and resilience. By aligning with the current trio’s priorities while advancing Ireland’s own agenda, the Presidency can help shape a Union that is greener, fairer, and more secure. Positioning the EU as a Global Climate Leader Climate leadership must be at the heart of Ireland’s Presidency. Accelerating decarbonisation policies will not only reduce emissions but also reinforce the EU’s credibility in international climate diplomacy. Ireland should use its term to strengthen the European Union’s influence in global negotiations, encouraging major players such as the US and China to strengthen their commitments. This is about more than targets; it is about demonstrating that Europe can lead by example, combining ambition with practical delivery. By embedding climate considerations into trade, industrial policy, and finance, Ireland can help the EU project a unified voice on sustainability and climate finance, benefiting communities worldwide while creating opportunities for European businesses. Delivering Tangible Benefits for People and Businesses For citizens and SMEs, the most visible impact will come from simplification and accessibility. Ireland should champion measures inspired by Draghi’s recommendations to reduce regulatory burdens and make compliance digital-by-default. The Presidency will also give Ireland the opportunity to champion dialogue between small and medium enterprises (SMEs) and the EU institutions, given that goal of the current Commission mandate is to slash red tape by 35% (compared to 25% for MNEs). Streamlined processes for funding applications and reporting will save time and resources, while clearer rules will give businesses confidence to invest and grow. Improving access to EU programmes, particularly for smaller enterprises and local communities, will ensure that the benefits of EU initiatives are widely enjoyed. These changes will not only enhance trust in EU institutions but also demonstrate that Europe can deliver practical solutions to everyday challenges. Advancing the Capital Markets through Savings and Investments Union to secure the EU’s digital future Ireland’s Presidency should also drive progress on advancing the Savings and Investments Union (SIU) given that incentivising venture capital and repurposing household savings into strategic EU business activities is a key EU Commission objective. A 2024 report indicates that the total EU spend on R&D activities amounts to only c.50% of the tech investment by US companies. This is partly attributable to accessing venture capital. Without private investment into EU businesses, it will not be possible for the EU to achieve the broader digital transformation required to keep pace with EU and Chinese equivalent progress in this growth area. By providing a simpler, and tax-efficient route for ordinary citizens to invest in EU businesses, this can deliver tangible benefits for a wide range of EU citizens, whilst also delivering on our technology and AI objectives. By combining climate leadership, regulatory simplification, and accessibility of capital markets, Ireland’s Presidency can deliver real benefits for people, businesses, and communities. This approach will not only align with the Trio’s priorities but also reflect Ireland’s commitment to a competitive, sustainable, and inclusive Europe.

Communicating the values and benefits of EU membership during Ireland’s Presidency is about making the role tangible and relatable. Citizens need to understand what the Presidency means, why it matters, and how it connects to their daily lives. By combining clear explanations, real-life examples, and accessible engagement, Ireland can create a sense of ownership and pride in this national achievement. Explain the Presidency in Simple Terms The first step is clarity. Many people do not know what the Presidency involves, so Ireland should explain it in straightforward language: for six months, Ireland will chair meetings of EU ministers, set agendas, and help broker agreements that shape laws for 450 million people. This is not a ceremonial role—it is a leadership position within one of the world’s largest trading blocs, influencing decisions on climate, trade, security, and more. Framing the Presidency as Ireland’s chance to lead and shape Europe’s future will make its significance clear. Connect EU Benefits to Everyday Life To create a sense of ownership, communication must link EU membership to tangible benefits. Examples such as CAP support for farmers, consumer protections, the abolition of roaming charges, and EU funding for roads, schools, and research show how EU decisions impact daily life. Storytelling is key: share real stories of businesses growing through Single Market access, communities revitalised by cohesion funds, and students thriving through Erasmus+. These narratives make EU membership personal and positive, moving it beyond abstract policy. Ireland is ideally suited to telling this story, given our national economic transformation since joining the EEC in 1973. Show the Presidency as a National Achievement Ireland should emphasise that this is a moment of leadership. As the first in the Trio (with Lithuania and Greece to follow), Ireland sets the tone for 18 months of EU priorities. This is an opportunity to showcase Irish values, fairness, openness, responsibility and innovation, on a European stage. Framing the Presidency as a source of national pride will help citizens see it as their achievement, not just a government role. Engage Through Accessible Channels Communication must be interactive and inclusive. Social media campaigns, local events, and tools like “What the EU does for me” can make information accessible. Short videos, infographics, and community dialogues will help reach diverse audiences. The message should frame Ireland’s EU membership as empowerment, not bureaucracy: Ireland helps shape rules, not just follow them. Linking EU action to global challenges, such as climate leadership and influencing major powers, will underline the relevance of Ireland’s role in a changing world. By explaining the Presidency clearly, connecting EU benefits to everyday life, and engaging citizens through storytelling and accessible platforms, Ireland can foster pride and ownership. This approach will not only strengthen understanding of EU membership but also highlight Ireland’s leadership in shaping Europe’s future.
N/a

organisation: Pavee Point Traveller and Roma Centre
sector: Pavee Point is a national non-governmental organisation committed to the attainment of human rights for Irish Travellers and Roma
geography: Pavee Point works at local, regional, national and international levels and will discuss the issues across all relevant contexts.
response_text: Pavee Point would urge the State to use the Irish EU Presidency as an opportunity to be a voice for inclusion and equality. We have unfortunately seen a rise in far right, racist and exclusionary rhetoric, policy and practice across Europe and this is deeply concerning. Ireland has an opportunity to showcase the true, founding values of the EU – respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights, including the rights of persons belonging to minorities. This could be captured in the overarching phrase or slogan decided on by Ireland, using the language of human rights and social justice such as “Equality at the Heart of Europe’s Future”. This is in line with the actions under the first priority within the Strategic Agenda for the Union 2024-29 - a free and democratic Europe. Ireland’s Presidency should prioritise the theme Supporting people, strengthening our societies and our social model from the 2026 Workplan of the Commission. This recognises that in recent years many Europeans, particularly those most marginalised have been impacted by the rising cost of living, the accommodation crisis, energy poverty, and divisions and inequalities in our society. The key priority must be focusing on a Europe that works for all, with equal opportunities and outcomes. Across European member states, we have witnessed a rise in tensions and divisions in communities, creating the conditions for extremists to play on people’s fears. The rights of all minority groups (including Travellers and Roma) in Europe must be at the centre of any policy plans. Currently at the EU level, there are a number of positive policy developments in progress. It is important that Ireland plays a key role in progressing key policy areas focused on human rights and social justice. For example: The new Action Plan on the Implementation of the European Pillar of Social Rights. The first EU Anti-Poverty Strategy The first European Affordable Housing Plan The next iteration of the EU Anti Racism Strategy Commitment to Strengthen and Invest in the Child Guarantee The consultation processes for these strategies took place in 2025 and are due for publication in 2026. Some may coincide with the Irish EU Presidency. These policies are timely and provide an opportunity to focus on the issues many families across Europe are facing every day, including poverty, homelessness, and social exclusion, with a clear impetus to address structural causes of exclusion and strengthen responses. Within this work, it is important to consider the families and communities that are most at risk of experiencing poverty, racism and barriers to realising their social rights and work to ensure that no-one is left behind. Travellers, Roma, and other minority ethnic or marginalised groups must be named within these responses, with targeted actions and resources.

organisation: Pavee Point Traveller and Roma Centre
sector: Pavee Point is a national non-governmental organisation committed to the attainment of human rights for Irish Travellers and Roma
geography: Pavee Point works at local, regional, national and international levels and will discuss the issues across all relevant contexts.
response_text: Connections must be made between mainstream EU strategies and commitments already made in the EU and national Roma Frameworks – ensuring a targeted and mainstream approach that acknowledges the impacts of racism. The annual EU Roma Platform will be hosted by Ireland during the EU Presidency, this is an important event that focuses on the rights of Travellers and Roma across Europe.
