Considering the deteriorating situation for many Roma in the EU, Ireland can play a key role in calling for decisive EU action. This could build on the Commission’s 8 September 2025 acknowledgment of Roma security and protection from racist targeting as a priority concern. We are conscious that there has been recent diminishing of the Equality Portfolio at the EU level. With the publication of the next EU Anti Racism Strategy in 2026, the strategy needs adequate resources and a clear political commitment, with equality and anti-racism named and prioritised across EU and EU Commission agendas. The EU must address structural racism within institutions, criminal justice systems and public services, rather than centring focus only on individualised issues such as addressing incidents of hate speech and hate crimes. Within the 2026 Workplan, there is a Proposal for a Council Directive on implementing the principle of equal treatment between persons irrespective of religion or belief, disability, age or sexual orientation. This directive, first introduced in 2008, aims to extend anti-discrimination laws beyond employment to areas like housing, goods, and services and is seen as a crucial step toward closing a long-standing protection gap in EU anti-discrimination law. As a Traveller and Roma organisation, we know that people can face discrimination on multiple and intersecting grounds in all areas of life and progressing this Directive would deliver on the EU’s promises of equality and fundamental rights. Another named Directive under the theme ‘A more inclusive and protective Europe’ is extending the list of EU crimes to hate speech and hate crime. ‘EU Crimes’ are a list of serious crimes with a cross-border dimension that the European Parliament and the Council may establish minimum rules concerning the definition of criminal offences and sanctions. With a documented increase in hate speech and hate crimes, we would urge the Irish Government to consider how this can be progressed in 2026 to create greater protections for victims across the EU, including Ireland. We also join with our colleagues from the Irish Homeless Policy Group in calling for the Irish Presidency to table a draft Council Recommendation on ending homelessness, for adoption under the presidency in 2026. There is clear institutional momentum in the EU for a Council Recommendation on ending homelessness.

organisation: Pavee Point Traveller and Roma Centre
sector: Pavee Point is a national non-governmental organisation committed to the attainment of human rights for Irish Travellers and Roma
geography: Pavee Point works at local, regional, national and international levels and will discuss the issues across all relevant contexts.
response_text: The Irish EU Presidency can make a substantial positive impact by choosing to use Ireland’s unique voice and position to shift the focus to peace, inclusion and equality, at a time where division and exclusion is becoming more prominent in member states across the EU. This can be mainstreamed across the workplan and all key events, ensuring all voices (especially those most marginalised are included). The Commission’s 2026 Workplan describes a “system-wide shift to managing migration”. It is imperative that migration is not treated in isolation with anti-racism efforts. The language in relation to migration is concerning, with a stronger focus on tighter controls rather than meaningful integration and inclusion, feeding into some of the current far right rhetoric. The application of the Migration Pact and associated legislation is in danger of embedding racism in EU systems, with border militarisation, severe immigration controls, and countering EU commitments to human rights and equality. This all leads to the systematic exclusion of racialised communities, migrants, and minorities. EU level oversight is needed to monitor the racialised impacts of these extreme migration policies and this work and discussions should be prioritised during the Presidency.

organisation: Pavee Point Traveller and Roma Centre
sector: Pavee Point is a national non-governmental organisation committed to the attainment of human rights for Irish Travellers and Roma
geography: Pavee Point works at local, regional, national and international levels and will discuss the issues across all relevant contexts.
response_text: As mentioned above, a focus on the founding values of the EU should serve as a guide for the Irish EU Presidency - respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights, including the rights of persons belonging to minorities. This requires communicating positive messages of an inclusive Europe for all citizens, ensuring visibility of marginalised and minority groups in the workplan, events, and communication materials. It is also important to work in collaboration with civil society and community organisations (including Traveller and Roma organisations) to ensure that these messages reach all communities and opportunities for participation are created.

sector: We support pathways to equitable employability for individuals who are experiencing barriers and advice business on how to implement and embed inclusion.
response_text: Ireland’s 2026 Presidency offers a unique opportunity to place inclusive employment, equity and corporate social justice at the heart of the EU agenda. As highlighted in ODI’s work, Europe cannot meet its equality or economic objectives without addressing the persistent exclusion of people with disabilities from the labour market. Ireland has the largest disability employment gap in the EU, despite more than one-fifth of its population living with a disability. Closing this gap must become a central Presidency ambition. The Presidency should prioritise building a labour market where every person, including people with disabilities and those from a migrant background, can access, retain and progress in meaningful employment. ODI’s enterprise-driven model of inclusion, Social Corporate Justice, demonstrates that inclusion strengthens innovation, talent pipelines and organisational performance. Inclusive employment is not only a social imperative but an economic strategy. ODI’s Corporate Social Justice approach emphasises the responsibility of governments and employers to remove systemic barriers and embed equity into policy design. People with disabilities, migrants, and other underrepresented groups face structural challenges despite having the skills to participate fully in work and society. Ireland’s Presidency should champion EU-wide approaches that tackle discrimination, promotes reasonable accommodations and support equitable access to education, training, and employment supports. ODI partners consistently highlight the power of collaboration and partnership across public, private and civil society. Inclusive employment efforts such as placements, supported employment pathways and equitable entrepreneurship programmes demonstrate the impact of coordinated, multi-stakeholder approaches. Ireland should therefore prioritise European cohesion policies that reduce inequality between and within regions and that promote equal rights and opportunities for all citizens.

sector: We support pathways to equitable employability for individuals who are experiencing barriers and advice business on how to implement and embed inclusion.
response_text: Ireland’s Presidency should focus on EU-level reforms that address the structural barriers preventing people with disabilities and other margionalised communities from entering and remaining in the labour market. ODI’s engagement with employers and research highlight several priority areas. Disability Employment and Inclusive Labour Market Reform: Ireland should champion an EU framework that supports member states to reduce disability employment gaps through coordinated action. At EU level, Ireland can lead by proposing enhanced implementation mechanisms under Article 27 of the UNCRPD to promote inclusive employment, retention and progression. Inclusive SME Supports: ODI has developed a number of practical toolkits for inclusive recruitment, accessible job specifications and other supports for SMEs. Ireland should advocate for a coordinated SME Inclusion Support Programme to provide training, resources and advisory services Research, Data and Lived Experience Informed Policy: ODI emphasises the need for research into enterprise-level barriers to inclusive employment. Ireland should lead an EU initiative on: Standardised disability employment data collection Research on employer barriers and supports Evidence-led EU labour market inclusion strategies Cost of Disability Supports: The cost of disability is a major barrier to employment and ODI calls for a non-means-tested Cost of Disability Payment. Ireland has the opportunity to lead an EU discussion on common principles for recognising and offsetting disability-related costs. As well as how EU funding can better support people transitioning into work.

sector: We support pathways to equitable employability for individuals who are experiencing barriers and advice business on how to implement and embed inclusion.
response_text: The Irish Presidency has the opportunity deliver significant positive impact by prioritising inclusion and equity informed and championed by business. ODI’s work shows that disabled people, migrants and individuals experencing barriers to employment often have strong skills but lack accessible pathways into work. By championing incusive employment it not only improves social mobility and economic independence for marginalised groups, it also has a positive impact on business. ODI partners repeatedly demonstrate that inclusive workplaces deliver better business performance. Disability-inclusive companies outperform peers, drive innovation and improve retention and organisational culture, Council initiatives that strengthen employer supports, such as inclusion toolkits, training and accessibility standards can enable SMEs and large employers to attract untapped talent while improving productivity and retention. When institutions deliver tangible improvements in people’s daily lives, such as accessible work, training and inclusive employer practices, public trust in the EU grows. Ensuring that the Council’s work improves quality of life, especially for under-represented groups, will reinforce EU values of equality, dignity and opportunity. Refugees and displaced people around the world remain in urgent need of support: the number of people worldwide who have been forcibly displaced is currently at an all-time high. Community Sponsorship provides a community led solution and constitutes a legal admission pathway and protection for refugees. Community Sponsorship places the responsibility of providing integration supports to refugees in the hands of local members of the community within the resettlement country. Community sponsorship creates lasting bonds between new members of the community and their neighbours. In doing so, it strengthens communities and builds awareness of broader refugee-related issues Irish communities are very well disposed to utilising this model and supporting displaced people here. This needs more Government support and increased capacity to allow more people to engage with this model and ensure better integration and engagement for people arriving in Ireland through no fault of their own. We would ask that this exemplary work be highlighted throughout the Presidency, especially as only two countries, Ireland and Brazil, are hosting small numbers of Afghans at present, despite the ongoing gender violations and violence being experienced.

sector: We support pathways to equitable employability for individuals who are experiencing barriers and advice business on how to implement and embed inclusion.
response_text: A successful Presidency must meaningfully engage citizens and communicate the EU’s relevance in their daily lives. ODI’s experience shows the importance of storytelling, participation and visibility in building trust and inclusion. We know personal stories, from participants, mentors, and employers, are one of the most powerful ways to communicate impact. Case studies from refugees, disabled people and others who might experience barriers entering employment show the EU’s values of equality, opportunity, and solidarity in action. Communication informed by lived experience is hugely impactful. Ireland should therefore centre its communications on real stories of people whose lives have improved due to EU supports as well as employers transforming workplaces with inclusive practices. To build “ownership” of the Presidency, citizens must feel involved. Ireland can mirror ODI’s collaborative, partnership-driven approach by engaging youth, disability organisations and migrant communities. Reaching out to those who tend to be harder to reach or marginalised. Partnering with civil society networks to co-design Presidency themes while ensuring events are fully accessible, inclusive and diverse

Ireland should have urban food systems as a high-level thematic priority. In 2024 the High-Level Panels of Experts of the Committee on World Food Security (CFS) report focused on “strengthening urban and peri-urban food systems” as a critical area for action as epicentres of multiple health and sustainability challenges. This focus would align with broader sustainability ambitions within the EU, specifically links between food systems, climate change, urban development and environment (European Green Deal). While rural agriculture is included in the strategic agenda (2024-2029), a thematic priority on UPU food systems could reflect a timely and forward-looking agenda for urbanisation trends and sustainability challenges. In addition to supporting the Urban Agenda for the EU Food Partnership.Which recognizes the important role urban areas play in EU sustainable and resilient futures. Food system transformation demands action beyond the dominant commercial models (Jackson et al., 2021), to include niche activities that adopt sustainability drivers, diverse business models and alternative organisational forms, such as food sharing initiatives (FSIs). FSIs support collective actions around food and food related items, operating across the food system. Food sharing involves collective actions around food between friends, families, neighbours, communities and even between strangers across the food system, from growing, to cooking and eating, surplus food redistribution and community composting. FSIs are organisations that help to facilitate diverse forms of food sharing, including sharing food itself, but also seeds, plants, food products and meals, as well as sharing spaces for growing or cooking and eating, and sharing skills and knowledge. FSIs may adopt different organisational forms, including co- operatives and social enterprises, charities and for-profits, and they can be led by grassroots, community, private sector or state actors as exemplified by seed libraries, community gardens, community supported agriculture, community kitchens, and surplus food redistribution organisations. Preliminary research has established the sustainability practices and potential of contemporary UPU FSIs (Davies, 2019) but identified challenges for FSIs related to: a lack of awareness of FSI landscapes; limited knowledge about the investments needed for, and impacts of, FSIs; policy contexts which have evolved with commercial imperatives not sustainability as key drivers; unclear pathways to expanding citizen engagement in food sharing; and a lack of collective voice for FSIs in food systems transformations. CULTIVATE (HEU innovation action grant agreement number 101083377) is addressing these challenges through the Food Sharing Compass, a compilation of new tools: the Food Sharing Map (identify, map, track and monitor FSI landscapes) , the Food Sharing Calculator (cost benefit analysis and sustainability impact assessments), the Menu of Good Governance, the Library of Citizen Engagement and the Food Sharing Community of Practice.

FSIs play a role in food systems and the transition towards more sustainable forms. As a result, FSIs need to be considered when reshaping governance dynamics and developing food-related policies and programs. Policymakers will benefit from the greater understanding of the FSI landscapes, their location, and their evolution through the Food Sharing Map (2026). A comparative analysis policy brief has been produced. This has implications for a variety of policy sectors within UPU areas from parks and gardens policies to food waste reduction targets. The sustainability impacts of FSIs (see also a report on Food Sharing in Dublin) will help inform policy developments to optimise and support sustainable food sharing. CULTIVATE has also produced a policy brief which summarizes key governance barriers that currently limit the sustainability potential of FSIs and distils a suite of high-level policy recommendations to rectify this, outlined below (Herrero & Moragues-Faus, 2024): Acknowledge food sharing initiatives’ sustainability potential as enablers of healthy and sustainable food environments in official documents such the Framework for a Sustainable Food System (FSFS). Integrate regulatory policies and voluntary agreements to allow the development of wider sustainable food sharing strategies. Promote food sharing collaborations and agreements between a wide range of stakeholders including national and local governments, businesses, charities, NGOs and communities, farmers, food entrepreneurs and activists. Create synergies between different levels of food sharing governance. Empower vulnerable citizen groups (e.g., the elderly, poorer households, long-term unemployed, migrants) to participate in food sharing initiatives through job creation as well as cultural inclusion measures. Grant financial independence and budget for collaborative governance on food sharing. Consider food sharing as one of the strategic responses to health, socio-economic or climate crises and allocate resilience funds to increase their capacity to act in case of disruptive events.

The Irish Presidency could work towards positive outcomes by embedding justice orientated food system transformation across the EU. Systematically mapping our food systems and food sharing landscapes is a prerequisite for establishing distributional justice around food offerings. Once the landscape is known the estimates for sustainability impact can be established and taken into consideration in planning and resource allocation decisions leading to greater recognition justice through acknowledgement of the existence and impact of, and from, food sharing initiatives. Combined, distributional and recognition justice enhance procedural justice by ensuring the voices of FSIs and those they support can be included in decision making. Such inclusion can enhance social cohesion, food security, resilience and support local economies and communities. These steps in just transitions are described in the linked papers, Geoforum and People, place and policy. By mapping food systems, enabling evidence-based support for FSIs and institutionalising participatory governance, the EU Council can help build food systems that are sustainable, equitable, resilient, locally rooted and socially inclusive. In turn delivering real, tangible benefits to people, businesses and communities across the EU.

Break out of the echo chamber: actively include marginalised voices by engaging with networks that connect across different demographic groups. If people aren’t involved in planning and creation, they’re much less likely to feel ownership of the outcomes. That’s why we need co-design, co-creation, consultation, and collaboration. Food sharing initiatives illustrate this well, they leverage existing local networks to transcend social barriers and bring together people from all kinds of backgrounds. We should combine bottom-up and top-down approaches and reduce fragmented efforts by ensuring strong coordination and clear communication across stakeholders. The Library of Citizen Engagement is a CULTIVATE tool developed by Wageningen University and Research, that offers practical engagement mechanisms for enabling citizen engagement in the food system.

The Cultivate data repository community holds supporting documentation for food sharing, just transitions and food system resilience building. The abstracts of some key publications are outlined below: Food sharing governance in European cities: insights from a scoping review: Food sharing initiatives (FSI) are rapidly growing in urban areas and present new opportunities to shape more sustainable urban food systems through collaborative efforts. These initiatives operate within a governance landscape that supports, influences, guides, and regulates their activities. This scoping review aims to explore the current knowledge of food sharing governance in Europe and reveal some of the governance elements that play a role in promoting or hindering the expansion of food sharing initiatives. Our research first offers a quantitative analysis of the literature, pinpointing areas for further investigation. Additionally, we provide a qualitative understanding of the benefits food sharing initiatives entail and the barriers and enablers they encounter. This comprehensive insight has led to developing a new framework to classify internal and external food sharing governance elements consisting of eight categories: structural factors, regulation, resources, discourses, relations between social actors (including power relations), participation, knowledge, and internal organisation. While avoiding idealisations and assessing these initiatives within their specific contexts is crucial, it is worth granting them visibility and support as they possess the potential to transform the food system. Evolving foodscapes: Tracing trajectories of urban and peri-urban food sharing initiatives for just food transitions: Urban and peri-urban (UPU) area food systems need reconfiguration to support just transitions towards sustainability. Collaborative acts around food – food sharing for brevity – have been mooted as a potentially productive arena for enacting such a transition, with research exploring the location, goals, and activities of individual food sharing initiatives (FSIs) internationally. Situated conceptually at the intersection of diverse economies approaches and critical mapping, with an overarching concern for achieving just transitions to sustainable food systems, this paper advances understanding of FSIs by adopting a novel longitudinal lens and focusing on the UPU scale. Implementing a co-designed and collaboratively translated system for identifying and categorizing FSIs that have a digital presence in two European cities: Milan and Barcelona, we contextualize and compare the results uncovered, contrasting these with findings from earlier research to establish evolutionary trajectories for urban FSI landscapes. The expanded mapping process offers significant empirical insights tracing the often invisible but dynamically evolving location, form, and function of UPU FSI landscapes. These methodological and empirical insights are interrogated to identify what contribution critical mapping of FSIs at the UPU scale makes to allied efforts for just and sustainable food systems. In conclusion, while the approach outlined has limitations in terms of resource intensity and explanatory power, we see the approach as one vital component in furthering comprehensive understanding of UPU food systems, providing opportunities to: document diverse food geographies; create new spatial imaginaries; support efforts for greater food democracy, and advocate for more equitable distribution of sustainable food sharing initiatives.

We recommend that a major priority be placed on the vital role a healthy, trustworthy and sustainable media ecosystem can play in strengthening inclusive and resilient democracies. This priority is especially timely given the Danish Presidency of the Council of the EU (July–December 2025), placed strong, independent, and trustworthy media at the centre of its democratic, security, competitiveness and cultural agenda. The Danish Presidency’s focus on leveraging media, culture, and European content to counter disinformation and foreign interference aligns closely with Ireland’s own strengths and ambitions in this area. Ireland enters this conversation from a position of democratic credibility. We consistently rank among the top countries in the World Press Freedom Index, reflecting a long-standing commitment to protecting independent journalism and media plurality Moreover, international monitoring shows that press freedom is not just a pillar of democracy, it is a measure of its vitality. A recent Reuters Digital News Reports show that Ireland enjoys some of the highest levels of trust in news across Europe. These strengths demonstrate that when independent journalism is protected and media systems are transparent and diverse, public trust naturally follows. Ireland’s experience can therefore serve as a practical model in shaping EU-level measures to strengthen the wider information ecosystem. The case for prioritising this area is further strengthened by compelling audience insights. According to research from Kantar Media, 80% of Irish people read a print or digital news brand every week - an exceptional level of mass reach by any international standard. This demonstrates both the vibrancy of Ireland’s news ecosystem and the extent to which reliable news remains central to public life. Among younger audiences, trust is equally strong. A recent study by NewsBrands and ColourText focusing on 16–30-year-olds found that Irish news brands are the most trusted source of information and the go-to destination for verifying stories. Notably, 78% of respondents said they are concerned about fake news on social media, and a majority (57%) reported that they would turn first to established Irish news brands to verify something they saw on those platforms. These insights highlight a critical opportunity: young people value trustworthy journalism, but they need better protection and support to navigate increasingly complex digital information environments. At the core of this priority is the protection and promotion of independent, high-quality journalism as a cornerstone of democratic life. Trusted journalism ensures citizens can access accurate information, participate meaningfully in public debate, and hold public and private power to account. In an era where mis- and disinformation proliferate through digital platforms, algorithmic feeds, and AI-generated content, safeguarding the visibility and viability of reliable news and trusted sources of information is essential. Democracies cannot function without a shared factual foundation. We also recommend prioritising the digital resilience of citizens, particularly children and young people, who increasingly encounter news online, where false or manipulated content can erode trust in institutions and cause serious harm. Strengthening platform accountability, improving safety standards, and ensuring comprehensive media literacy education will help young people recognise misinformation, understand how algorithms and AI shape what they see, and appreciate the role of trusted, editorially responsible journalism. To support this broader goal, the EU must adopt legislative measures that foster a diverse, independent, and financially sustainable media sector. Ireland’s own mix of public service broadcasting, national and regional journalism, and independent digital outlets demonstrates the value of pluralism. Modern regulation should ensure fair value exchange between platforms, AI systems, and publishers, recognising the significant public value produced by journalism. Fair compensation, whether for linking, aggregation, or AI training, is essential to sustaining quality reporting and newsroom jobs. Taken together, this thematic priority supports a resilient, well-informed European public, protects young people, sustains diverse media, and reinforces democratic confidence. Ireland is uniquely positioned to lead this effort.

The Irish Presidency should prioritise strengthening democratic resilience by supporting a strong, independent, and pluralistic media sector. The current Programme for Government commits to “a strong, independent media sector that provides essential public service broadcasting, supports local journalism, and upholds press freedom,” noting that “a well-resourced, transparent, and accountable media landscape is fundamental to an informed society and democracy” and pledging to “support efforts to ensure that national and local media are paid properly for their news content when it is used by online platforms.” These commitments provide a clear mandate for Ireland to champion media-related policies at the EU level and to bring an Irish perspective to EU discussions on democratic resilience and information integrity. As An Taoiseach highlighted on World Press Freedom Day 2025, Ireland has a “long tradition of trusted reporting, a cornerstone of our democracy that has helped shape society and protect our values. But today that trust is under extraordinary strain across the world. Misinformation, deepfakes, and mistruths make it hard to know what’s real and what’s designed to deceive. Around the world we see the destruction of truth weaponised for political ends, with grave results.” This statement underscores the urgency of ensuring that independent journalism remains financially and editorially sustainable in the face of evolving technological and economic pressures. The Strategic Agenda for the Union 2024–2029 reinforces this approach, highlighting the importance of strengthening democratic resilience, protecting free and pluralistic media, and supporting civil society. Ireland, together with thirty other countries, recently signed a declaration that “culture, cultural heritage and media policies must be a vital part of the European collaboration and European security in order to protect our democracies.” The declaration recognizes the need to guarantee citizens’ access to trustworthy news media and equip them with the digital skills needed to navigate a digitized information landscape. Measures such as the European Democracy Shield should be leveraged to strengthen resilience including promoting media literacy, reinforcing a robust framework for free and trusted media, and ensuring major technology platforms fulfil their responsibilities. These actions are critical not only for countering misinformation but also for protecting children, young people, and the wider public online. The Presidency should prioritise fair and transparent conditions for independent, pluralistic, and editorially accountable media. EU regulatory frameworks, including the Audiovisual Media Services Directive and the Copyright Directive, must be updated to reflect the realities of today’s digital and AI-driven media environment. Copyright law must evolve to maintain clear rules and a fair, efficient market that encourages innovation while protecting publishers’ investment in journalism. While Artificial Intelligence offers opportunities for creative content generation, it also poses existential risks. Uncompensated use of copyrighted content by platforms to train AI threatens the viability of trusted journalism, undermining the foundation that supports quality reporting and democratic values. The EU needs to use AI wisely. The increasing global reliance on a few AI products and services affect our cultural diversity and linguistic, press freedom and media plurality. This can marginalise local voices, languages, and perspectives. As Teresa Ribera, Executive Vice-President for Clean, Just and Competitive Transition, said when the European Commission announced the opening of a formal antitrust investigation to assess whether Google has breached EU Competition rules by using the content of web publishers for AI purposes: “a free and democratic society depends on diverse media, open access to information, and a vibrant creative landscape. These values are central to who we are as Europeans. AI is bringing remarkable innovation and many benefits for people and businesses across Europe, but this progress cannot come at the expense of the principles at the heart of our societies. This is why we are investigating whether Google may have imposed unfair terms and conditions on publishers and content creators, while placing rival AI models developers at a disadvantage, in breach of EU competition rules. “ The Irish Presidency should lead EU discussions to ensure that AI supports, rather than erodes, independent media and democratic information systems. By reinforcing press freedom, media pluralism, sustainable funding, digital literacy, and effective regulation, Ireland can safeguard democratic institutions, protect citizens from misinformation, and ensure that trusted journalism continues to underpin an informed and resilient European public.

During the Irish Presidency, the Council can help to support democracy and a strong and sustainable media ecosystem by: Advancing the robust implementation of the European Media Freedom Act Promoting EU-wide minimum standards for the protection of journalists, digital safety and measures against SLAPPs and abusive litigation Expanding independent funding mechanisms for local, regional and investigative journalism Supporting media pluralism to prevent the growth of news deserts and ensure access to diverse and trustworthy information right across all member states Promoting fair competition rules that prevent large digital platforms, including AI companies, from: Undermining media revenue models Prioritising disinformation over quality journalism Or extracting content without fair compensation. Encouraging progress on platform transparency, including algorithmic auditing and clear rules for recommendation systems that impact access to news Using the Council’s agenda to improve: Coordination between Member States on counter-disinformation early-warning systems and funding for media literacy programmes, especially for young people and digitally vulnerable communities Encouraging AI and digital policy that: protects journalists from harmful uses of AI (deepfakes, automated harassment, surveillance) and enables newsrooms to ethically adopt AI tools without compromising integrity or copyright. The Council’s work should engage stakeholders at the national and EU level while consistently anchoring discussions in a broader EU perspective and long-term European vision - ensuring that citizens, businesses, communities, and a free, diverse media sector are part of an open and transparent dialogue. Ireland can use its Presidency as an opportunity to showcase the best of Irish practice and innovation to partners across the EU including: 1. Citizens • Civil society groups, youth councils, NGOs, educators, local communities • Use public dialogues, consultations, outreach campaigns 2. Businesses • Industry associations such as NewsBrands Ireland and EU, SMEs, startups, chambers of commerce • Involve them through policy roundtables, innovation forums and sector-specific consultations 3. Public Sector & Authorities • Regional and municipal governments, public agencies, social partners • Engage via coordinated policy workshops and implementation networks 4. Experts & Academia • Think tanks, universities, research institutes • Use evidence-based input for shaping priorities 5. EU Institutions & Member States • European Commission, Parliament, Council working parties, national ministries • Collaborate on agenda-setting and legislative negotiations

Ireland’s Presidency of the Council of the EU should prioritise participation, creativity, and trusted information. We believe it is particularly important to direct communications at young people, who are most vulnerable to disinformation, misinformation and algorithmic and AI distortion. One of the most effective ways to build this sense of engagement is to involve young people directly in telling the story of what the EU means to them. We recommend a nationwide second level schools campaign inviting students to express their understanding of Europe through a medium of their choice - journalistic articles, videos or podcasts. Framing the EU through personal creativity helps students connect European values to issues that matter in their own lives: climate action, education opportunities, housing, diversity, security and defence, and digital safety. As part of this initiative, NewsBrands Ireland will run a dedicated journalism competition on the theme of EU citizenship, complementing its long-running Young Journalist news literacy and student journalism programme. This programme already engages approximately 10,000 secondary school students every year, equipping them with the skills to analyse media, understand credible sources, and practise responsible journalism. Integrating an EU-focused competition into this existing national framework ensures wide reach, strong participation, and high educational value. Through this process, students will be encouraged to research and report on how the EU shapes their local communities, families, and future prospects. Whether exploring EU-funded projects in their area, opportunities such as Erasmus+, or the wider benefits of membership, students will gain a deeper appreciation of the EU’s tangible impact. They will also have the opportunity to write features, interviews, or opinion pieces about the EU, using the news literacy tools embedded in the programme to fact-check sources, verify claims, and reflect on how trustworthy information supports healthy democracy. A campaign of this kind not only strengthens media literacy but also reinforces the values of citizenship, participation, and democratic engagement - core principles of the EU itself. By empowering students to become storytellers and critical thinkers, Ireland can spark broader conversations in families, schools, and communities about the importance of EU membership. Beyond schools, the content created - articles, videos, podcasts, and artwork - can be showcased during Ireland’s Presidency at national events, online platforms, regional exhibitions, and through news media outlets. Highlighting young people’s perspectives will help create a shared narrative of ownership: the Presidency is not just a governmental milestone, but a national moment in which every citizen has a role.

Ireland has the opportunity to set a positive and forward-looking agenda in a challenging time, demonstrating leadership, resilience, and innovation at the heart of Europe. By engaging stakeholders at the national level with a clear EU perspective and long-term vision, Ireland can ensure citizens, businesses, communities, and a free, diverse media sector are part of an open, transparent, and inclusive dialogue. The H 2 2026 EU Presidency allows Ireland to showcase best national practices, strengthen partnerships across the Union, and reinforce its brand as a proactive, visionary, and collaborative EU leader.

sector: I have worked in business, industry, research (science and engineering) and administration.
geography: One item is of national interest with EU implications, but other policy and legislative areas are intended to be EU wide.
response_text: Ireland’s priorities should be “A Reunified Ireland in A Social Europe” “Reunification and Re-admission” Preparation for Irish reunification within the European Union, the potential rapid re-accession of an independent Scotland and/or Wales into the EU, and the likely access of Iceland to the EU over a timeframe 2029-2032. This is analogous to the prioritisation by the Irish Presidency, in January 1990 – June 1990 under Taoiseach Haughey, of the reunification of Germany. “Advancing Europe’s Social Democracy” should be one of the two key themes. We should re-ignite the social defence of Europe, in the spirit of Jacques Delors’ famed “social chapter”, as a counterpoint from a neutral member state (which will be welcomed by EU citizens across Europe) to the emphasis by some other member states on military defence. Within that, Ireland should initiate a strategic goal for Europe to create a socio-political reserve within the European treaty framework, to be called the European Social Space (the German equivalent “Europäische Sozialbereich” would be a more accurate descriptor – why not use this?). All European national governments should be free to declare essentials for society as economically reserved into the European Social Space, and the European Union as a whole may also make such directives. It is envisaged that sectors such as housing, healthcare provisions, transport, food provision and so on will be reserved into the European Social Space. Such reserved sectors within the European Social Space will be in a safe harbour of protection from free market forces. Democratically elected centre-left or left governments in EU countries will be empowered to implement their programmes within the European Social Space, without the current interferences of free-market oriented rules. The parts of the economy that belong in the marketplace, outside the European Social Space, will be subject to free market rules, but the parts of the economy that are the essentials of living, what is “zuhaus”, “at home”, to use another German expression, will be governed by economic rules giving priority to society and people over the demands of capitalism. The principle will be to go back to the basic economics of why markets arose, and what they are for – surpluses to the essentials of human subsistence. As one of the other priorities in unpacking the European Social Space, the EU needs to initiate a dirigiste programme, using the Airbus Industrie model as a successful template, to create European scale alternatives to the major data, commercial and banking hyperscale companies to counter US dominance, to assert European sovereignty as a means to the end of defending Europe socially.

sector: I have worked in business, industry, research (science and engineering) and administration.
geography: One item is of national interest with EU implications, but other policy and legislative areas are intended to be EU wide.
response_text: Policy Areas Preparation for Ireland’s Reunification and the reincorporation of the North of Ireland into the EU. There should be a specific focus on designing a federal Ireland with modern regional governments (not 2, but 12-14) in the model of other EU member states such as Austria. Initiation of a new flagship report: “Europe’s Social Space: defending and expanding Europe’s social democracy” to be commissioned from a recognised and experienced left of centre figure on the EU level (examples in answer to question 3). Initiation of a global EU political strategy to educate electorates in non-EU countries, especially in the USA, of the advantages and benefits of social democracy, with a view to effecting a decisive redirection of US politics to a position on the economic left of Franklin Roosevelt’s New Deal policies, and advancing and supporting the emergence of strong social democratic regimes throughout the Americas. Revive the seminal idea of a European Economic Community as a template for concerted action by Europe to develop strategic hyperscale goods and services conglomerates to challenge US and Chinese hyperscale domination in social media, semiconductors, financial services and other sectors in which Europe does not lead. Initiation of a series of dirigiste “grand European Economic Community projects”, using the successful Airbus Industrie as the template for integrating the EU’s distinctive model of small, specialist, deep knowledge and craft manufacturers to deliver hyperscaled goods and services to deliver viable EU offerings to rival US and Chinese products as a level one ambition and goal; to achieve EU sovereignty in key strategic sectors as a level two ambition and goal, and EU dominance as a level three ambition and goal. The mandating of at least one retail banking entity in each EU member state to be operated on the banking model of the German “Sparkasse” model or the Spanish “Caja Laboral” model, to provide a social democratic full service banking model to offer citizens a choice to bank on a social democratic model with local investment. Legislative Proposals The Irish Presidency must lead on initiating EU legislation to establish the framework for a European Social Space within the Union, a socio-economic safe harbour for key strategic essential sectors of European or national social necessity within which the EU or national governments may place essential sectors (housing, basic income, social need, health, education, public transport, climate defence measures) such that they are protected from neo-conservative concepts of “free enterprise”. The Irish Presidency must lead on initiating EU legislation to mandate the establishment of a social democratic retail bank within each member state. The Irish Presidency must lead on the necessary EU legislation to give effect to the co-ordination of European supply chains to deliver hyperscale goods and services suppliers.

sector: I have worked in business, industry, research (science and engineering) and administration.
geography: One item is of national interest with EU implications, but other policy and legislative areas are intended to be EU wide.
response_text: The Council must, under the Irish Presidency, change tack, in sailing parlance. It must tack left in economic terms, and start to lead Europe back to the basics of the social contract and the economic aspects of social democracy that have been watered down over the past fifty or so years. It is time to decisively reject the corrosive effects of neo-conservative economics on the EU and its peoples. The continued drift from social democracy and social protection, and the allied lack of sufficient investment in social essentials over recent decades are the root causes of what is alienating ordinary people of limited means from the European project and is driving them into the hands of the far right. The European project is a social democratic project, and can never be any other. The EU is increasingly seen as having hard-wired free enterprise into its treaties, and is, rightly or wrongly, seen as frustrating the implementation of social democratic policies (often by national governments unwilling to implement declared social democratic policies by hiding behind over-zealous interpretations of EU law). Current treaties such as CETA and Mercosur with their subversive investor-state courts further erode European democracy and sovereignty, rendering elected social democratic governments impotent, and leading to electoral alienation. Not just the perception of that must change, but also must the realities. The “bridges too far”, both at national and European level, must be revisited and reversed. A national example of a “bridge too far” is the German “Hartz IV” measure, and similar provisions in other countries. Likewise, flat single rate non-progressive income tax has no place in a social democratic EU. Neither have EU level measures, such as, for example, the infamous Bolkestein directive allowing multinational enterprises to take advantage of the lowest social protection national regime of labour laws. The selective citation of the Draghi report to support “less government”, “less regulation” ideologies of the right needs to be countered by a Presidency steering Draghi onto its true course of a call to action by Europe, which will actually need to be more dirigiste in nature, to marshal the diverse and predominantly small enterprises of Europe to create hyper-scale organised competition to the over-dominant US and Chinese hyperscale companies in many sectors. Draghi must be tempered also by a greater invocation of the Letta Report, which takes also a social viewpoint. Even Letta’s report is weak in this respect. The Irish Presidency needs to commission a major figure of the European centre-left (any of Frans Timmermans who has a recent Commission and national experience, or Andrea Nahles, author of “Frau, gläubig, links – Was mir wichtig ist”, or Peer Steinbruck, author of “Das Elend der Sozialdemokratie”, or Martine Aubry, Mayor of Lille would be good candidates) and give that person a brief to honestly report on the alienation of the European citizen from the social-democratic perspective and to draft a similarly seminal report with a great call to action to re-centre the EU to its natural left of centre position.

sector: I have worked in business, industry, research (science and engineering) and administration.
geography: One item is of national interest with EU implications, but other policy and legislative areas are intended to be EU wide.
response_text: Ireland’s Presidency of the Council of the EU must agitate to expand social democracy. It should start a social democratic crusade and openly challenge the US Trump regime. The EU also needs to actively work to spread European social democratic values inside the US electorate to counter what Trump is doing in Europe. Ireland’s Presidency needs to work in harmony with the clearly expressed political directions of the large majority of its citizens, perhaps as most recently expressed at the ballot box in the sense of Irish reunification, progressive socio-economic democracy, and a Europe which needs to urgently redirect its external policies to be a consistently moral beacon of international human rights and order. I emphasise “in harmony”. The Irish Presidency cannot be used to advance positions (openly or by nuance) which fly in the face of the large majority of its own citizens. The people of Ireland expect a Presidency which will lead in the political direction set out above. So do many tens of millions of EU citizens in all of the 26 other EU Member States, some of whom may despair of the directions of their own governments and who would look to Ireland to advance what they believe in accord with the majority in Ireland. A Presidency which tries to actively advance EU positions against a large majority of its own citizens, expressed at the ballot box, for example with respect to weakening Irish neutrality, or EU social democracy, or GDPR, or agriculture protections, or advocating positions against these, would be fatally flawed and alienate citizens. There is a second choice: a do-nothing, say-nothing, propose-nothing, initiate-nothing, don’t-speak-out-of-turn, don’t-rock-the-boat, indecisive, dithering, lacklustre and mediocre presidency, which would be a failure of leadership. That would be a wasted opportunity. There is only one option for success, which is the third choice: an Irish Presidency which leads in new directions in harmony with the people of Ireland and where we (and vast numbers of EU citizens, often who are disengaged today) want to see the EU go. For example, an Irish Presidency which set in train a “Timmermans Report” or a “Nahles Report”, a new Social Chapter, and the European Social Space would make an impact that would last a decade and would reshape the EU for the better. Never mind that the fruits would come in successive presidencies, Ireland would have led. Only in the context of such a presidency will Irish citizens engage, be enthused and energised, and own a democratic Irish Presidency which is “by them, of them and for them”. Ireland’s Presidency of the Council of the EU cannot become the plaything of an elite, perceived or otherwise, which wants to push a solely EPP oriented direction, this direction having been so decisively rejected at the ballot box recently. The use of Ireland’s Presidency of the Council of the EU for promotion and planning for Irish reunification would be an excellent way to create a sense of ownership, amongst citizens, over Ireland’s Presidency.

From IP2Innovate’s perspective, the Irish Presidency’s priorities should focus on a prosperous and competitive Europe, in line with the 2024-2029 Strategic Agenda. The modernisation of EU patent rules, especially the patent enforcement framework, would directly support key objectives of the Strategic Agenda in the following ways: Competitiveness and innovation: The modernisation of patent rules would contribute to making business easier and faster in Europe and ensure companies here can perform well and compete on a level playing field. Boosting productivity through digital technology diffusion: Under the current patent enforcement framework, companies hesitate to adopt AI systems, IoT solutions, or advanced semiconductors when a single patent dispute could halt operations. Completing the Single Market: Fragmented national approaches to enforcement of patents enable forum shopping and undermine the Single Market. EU-level modernisation of the patent enforcement framework would ensure consistency across Member States. Cutting red tape and simplifying business: The current unpredictable patent enforcement framework forces companies to expend enormous resources navigating legal risks rather than innovating. Put in place more than two decades ago, it is not fit for the digital age. Its modernisation is needed to create predictable outcomes, reduce the administrative burden of defensive patent strategies, and ultimately support investment in productive R&D rather than litigation and excessive settlements. Supporting SMEs and midcaps: Small innovative companies are most vulnerable to abusive litigation. They need a system that does not allow patent assertion entities to extract disproportionate settlements through the threat of business-ending injunctions. Economic security and strategic autonomy: Critical technology sectors - semiconductors, AI, quantum - are at the highest risk of abusive patent litigation because of their complexity. A balanced patent system would ensure Europe can lead in these strategic technologies that underpin its resilience and sovereignty.

The current EU legal framework for the enforcement of IP rights (IPRED) was not designed for AI systems, IoT technologies, semiconductors, smart phones, or connected cars. It allows for products – even complex products with thousands of components – to be removed from the market in their entirety when even a single component-related patent is infringed. While the IPRED does call for proportionate remedies, it needs to be modernised to make clear when an alternative to outright product removal would be the most appropriate remedy for infringement. Because of this lack of clarity about how proportionality should be applied, injunctions resulting in product removals have been granted almost automatically in all patent cases since the IPRED was adopted in 2004. This situation has been compounded by the fact that the IPRED has not been given proper effect in most Member States. This harmful dynamic could be resolved by modernising the IPRED to specify when courts should be required to consider alternative remedies to removing product lines from the market in patent suits. IP2Innovate’s members own 484,000 patents and published applications worldwide. Modernising the IPRED is not about weakening intellectual property rights or undermining IP valorisation – it is about ensuring patent enforcement works properly in the digital age so that remedies reflect the real harm caused and do not unintentionally block innovation or investment. A more balanced and predictable patent enforcement framework will help Europe compete globally, attract investment, support its industrial base, and ensure that those who genuinely innovate can thrive. As part of improving proportionality, the EU should also consider measures to increase transparency around the publication of judicial rulings and decisions, as well as the role of patent assertion entities and litigation financing and control. We support greater transparency in patent disputes - in national courts and the UPC - as well as more broadly, and hope that ongoing EU level examination of disclosure and accountability in litigation funding will result in clearer and more balanced litigation practices overall.

The European Commission has commissioned a study on how the Intellectual Property Rights Enforcement Directive (IPRED) is being applied. The Irish Presidency could take steps to advance this important discussion with key stakeholders, including the European Parliament, and encourage the European Commission to take actions to ensure Europe’s patent ecosystem is more supportive for innovation and innovative companies including SMEs. Examples of activities that could help achieve these objectives include: Organising a high-level conference on the European patent enforcement framework in Europe and its importance for innovation. Include the modernisation of the European patent framework in the priorities of the Competitiveness Council with a view to adopt Council conclusions on the European patent enforcement framework.
