N/A

In Ireland, culture and creativity are hardwired into our DNA. Ireland is known for its musicians, composers, filmmakers and writers. This rich heritage has been protected and nurtured by progressive laws which emanated from the EU, alongside strong legal enforcement. At the same time, Ireland exemplifies a forward-looking approach to innovation, and an openness to creating conditions for technological growth. This allows Ireland to play a unique role in being a true advocate for the growth of a competitive EU internal market where innovation and respect for the protection of intellectual property rights thrive together. It is essential for the creative industries that the EU’s legal and policy framework remains robust and fit for purpose and continues to protect and nurture human artistry. Creative industries, and particularly the recorded music industry, have embraced digital innovation and technological change and recognise that the responsible use of technology and AI have a crucial role in fostering the development of smart knowledge-based economies. Technological development should evolve with, and not at the expense of, the cultural and creative sectors. IRMA hopes that the Irish Presidency will foster the responsible use of the output of the creative industries. A strong copyright framework that protects creators’ rights is not a regulatory burden but an investment in Europe’s economy and competitiveness. We hope that the Presidency will: Promote a legal and commercial landscape in the EU that fully respects the principles of freedom of contract, freedom to conduct business, respect for intellectual property and fair competition. Ensure that the existing EU rules are fully implemented and enforced in a meaningful manner.

IRMA hopes that the Irish Presidency will prioritise the effective implementation of the current digital acquis and ensure that any future evaluations are grounded in a thorough and balanced assessment, including stakeholder input and in particular: Competitiveness – Copyright policy The Irish Presidency will commence around the time that the Commission’s evaluation process of Directive 2019/790 on copyright and related rights in the Digital Single Market (DSM Directive) is due to end. The Presidency could facilitate a technical and in-depth exchange of views among Member States in the Council, based on economic data and stakeholder consultations on the various topics under review. It would be beneficial to provide opportunities for policymakers and stakeholders to express their positions in dedicated fora, for instance, during Presidency conferences. From IRMA’s viewpoint it is hoped that freedom of contract and the protection of exclusive rights will remain intact. Artificial Intelligence On the subject of AI and copyright, the Irish Presidency could continue requesting that the European Commission, in particular its AI Board and the AI Office, provide regular feedback on the application of the AI implementation package, namely the GPAI Code of Practice and Transparency Template. This is to allow Member States to follow the process closely and ensure that the intention of the co-legislators regarding the transparency and copyright compliance provisions is fully met. Telecommunications With respect to the Digital Omnibus package, it is hoped that Ireland will ensure that the simplification of EU digital rules does not modify the core provisions of the AI Act and other core EU acts, such as the GDPR. Where there are divergences among Member States, Ireland is in a strong position to balance these pressures, given the concentration of technology platforms residing here side by side with a prolific cultural sector. We suggest that there should be a focus on the meaningful application of existing rules rather than pushing for new legislation prematurely.

In order make a substantial and positive impact for people, communities and businesses, it is important that citizens see their core personal, social and cultural issues given priority alongside broader economic planning. In practical terms for the cultural sector, this means: The implementation of the existing EU legislative framework, including in the areas of Artificial Intelligence and Intellectual Property. Evidence-based policy making, based on robust economic data, in full consultation with all relevant stakeholders. A fair and competitive market based on legal certainly fosters an environment that encourages investments in both the creative sector and in new technologies. This ultimately benefits end users and consumers. Encouraging discussion on how to harness the existing tools to continue combating infringements of intellectual property rights. This must also include new challenges such as streaming fraud, which are not only detrimental to artists and the entire music ecosystem but can also engender mistrust in new technologies among audiences. It is to be hoped that in weighing its priorities, the Presidency maintains a human-centred focus during discussions on technology and innovation. Technological advancement is something to be embraced, and in doing so, legislative advancement will hopefully enhance protections for the cultural and creative sectors. The most effective means to achieve this is to maintain provisions that are currently functioning well, such as freedom of contract. It vital to the Irish recorded music industry that the Irish Presidency ensures that the EU’s institutions implement the AI Act’s copyright rules in a meaningful way, and resists moves to dilute these as part of the Digital Omnibus package. The Irish Recorded Music Association is keen to be a constructive and positive partner in this process, and we are more than willing to provide our perspective and insights during any consultations and events which take place during the Presidency.

In a world where citizens feel increasingly disempowered, the EU stands out as a place where innovation exists alongside high regulatory standards and the protection of the cultural and creative sectors. The Irish Presidency is well placed to draw on this legacy and demonstrate the EU’s track record of improving citizens’ quality of life. This goes far beyond economic advancement to include the protection of democracy and civil rights, and the advancement of the cultural realm. The Irish Presidency can communicate that the EU is a safe haven for sensible regulation that protects citizens’ rights. We see this in existing initiatives such as the European Democracy Shield, an effort to empower, protect, and promote strong and resilient democracies. The EU should also remain a safe haven for the protection of cultural output from piracy and unfair use. We have seen recent incidents where deepfake videos were used in an effort to disrupt the Irish Presidential election, and the potential for this to have a detrimental impact on democratic participation and trust in media. This is a challenge already faced by creators and rightsholders, as underregulated technological developments threaten to undermine their copyrighted creative works. The existing threats to cultural output provide a harbinger for political risk across our institutions. At a more prosaic level, the European Union has an opportunity to revitalise music education as a means to sustain cohesive societies and creative economies. Initiatives such as Erasmus+ offer platforms to increase and improve cultural exchange to further enhance our mutual understanding. In addition, we suggest that, throughout the Presidency, the Irish government could encourage civil society participation wherever possible, in order to create a sense of ownership amongst citizens. Again, this is an area where the Irish Recorded Music Association is keen to be a constructive and active participant in civil society initiatives organised during the Presidency.

The recorded music industry has a proven track record of innovation and successful collaborations with technology platforms. It is in the best interests of both the creative industry and tech platforms to have a coherent licensing system and a legislative framework that provides appropriate regulatory guardrails to a well-functioning market.

geography: National and EU Wide, and International
response_text: The upcoming Irish Presidency of the European Union marks an unprecedented opportunity for Ireland to assert its interests and priorities onto the EU’s priorities. It is an opportunity to promote Irish interests abroad, and to attract investment. The opportunity must not be wasted. The Presidency takes place as a referendum on Irish Unity approaches and ten years after the Brexit vote which dragged the north of our country out of the EU despite the people there voting strongly to remain. The Presidency will also happen at a time of much global uncertainty and as the EU strays ever further from the vision of peaceful cooperation it likes to project. The Irish Presidency must not be used as a hiding place from the big issues of the day, it should not be passive Presidency focussed on creating a distraction from its own mess at home and deflecting all criticism under the pretence of protecting the country’s image in front of the world’s cameras. Instead, Sinn Féin is calling for an active ambitious and assertive EU Presidency where the country leaves a positive mark on the EU and its priorities. Some of the key thematic issues Ireland should prioritise Irish Unity, welcoming back the island of Ireland into the EU Promotion of Peace The cost-of-living crisis and energy costs for workers and families Protecting Workers’ Rights and the Environment in a time of change Overseas Development Fair play for Farmers and the Fishing Industry Irish Unity, welcoming back the island of Ireland into the EU The Irish Presidency comes at a critical time for the future of our country. It will be ten years since the North voted to remain in the European Union with the rest of Ireland and rejected Brexit. Yet the British government chose to ignore the clear democratic will of the people and without consent forcibly removed the North from the EU in January 2020. Years of tortured negotiations needed up a with Special Status for the north and a 2017 EU Council confirmation that if and when the people of Ireland, North and South, vote for reunification – as provided for in the Good Friday Agreement – the North will automatically rejoin the European Union as part of a United Ireland. The preparation for this referendum must start in earnest during the Irish Presidency. The reunification of our country must be woven into the logic and actions of the entire Presidency. A majority of people believe their long-term future would be best served by rejoining the European Union. There exists a democratic deficit as a result of Brexit and there is an onus on the Irish Government to help rectify this. Irish citizens in the North are also EU citizens by law, and the government and the EU must give voice to them. Irish MEPs in a recent letter to the President of the European Parliament called for observer status in the European Parliament for our locally elected political representatives - a policy Sinn Féin has been advocating since 2017. An Amárach Research poll for the European Movement Ireland, published in May 2035 found that a majority of people in both parts of Ireland – 67% in the North and 62% in the South – now support a United Ireland within the EU.It confirms that people want change, and they want a future back in the European Union. These figures reflect a growing understanding that the cost of Brexit – economically, politically, and socially – has been detrimental for the North of Ireland. The same poll shows that 60% of people in the North do not believe that our relationship has improved since Brexit with the EU. Only 29% think otherwise. This is a stark indictment of a process that was imposed upon our people against their democratic consent. The European Council’s 2017 statement in the context of Brexit stated that in the event of a united Ireland the state will automatically be within the EU. The Harvey-Bassett report assesses that reunification would be viewed as a territorial extension of an existing EU Member State (Ireland), and No Article 49 EU accession process is needed. A smooth and legitimate process will require coordinated planning across jurisdictions, deep civic engagement, and active EU support. It is essential that the groundwork begins now to avoid uncertainty and ensure a peaceful, democratic transition to a united Ireland within the European Union. The North of Ireland has been held back for too long by partition. The Irish Government must now take up its responsibilities under the Good Friday Agreement, step forward, and begin the necessary planning. That means convening a Citizens’ Assembly and preparing for constitutional change in a way that is inclusive, respectful and forward-looking. Promotion of Peace The EU has lost immense credibility among the Irish people and more broadly across the EU for its political support of the genocidal Israeli regime’s actions during its war on the people of Gaza. It has proven a dark chapter for the EU. Despite the ceasefire agreement, people are still being killed in their hundreds, and the ongoing pursuit of settlements undermines the potential for a two-state solution. Similarly, the EU has failed to adequately pressure the UAE for its role in fuelling conflict in Sudan. The Irish government must take initiatives that attempt to reposition the EU and restore its credibility and promote a role for the EU as a supporter of peace and democracy, in Palestine, in Sudan, in Ukraine, and other conflicts across the world. The cost of living crisis and energy costs for workers and families It is crucial that the energy market and the nature of it is restructured. Since 2018, residential electricity prices have more than double. Irish households should not have to pay the highest prices in Europe indefinitely. Energy prices have fallen much more slowly here than other EU countries. And the gap between retail and wholesale prices is the highest in the world. This situation in Ireland and indeed across many other member states needs to be taken seriously and get this issue under control. Protecting Workers’ Rights and the Environment in a time of change The EU has shifted into an agenda that is anti-workers’ rights and has proposed measures that will impact negatively on the environment all in the name of competition or deregulation. The Irish Presidency should draw a line in the sand on such proposals and instead refocus on tackling the cost of living in a real way while protecting workers and the environment. It must act as a rallying call for a social Europe and push for a 180 degree turn on workers’ rights and the deregulation agenda. Overseas Development The worrying reality is that millions of people in the developing world have seen life saving projects defunded due to cuts in overseas development aid in the US as well as various European countries. Ireland should show leadership in ensuring this tide is turned around, but also in exploring other mechanisms, including examination of Debt restructuring Fair play for Farmers and the Fishing Industry We must ensure that farmers and fishers have an adequate income and food security. We must promote these industries and encourage our young people to pursue careers in these areas. These must be a viable and practical way to earn a living in Ireland. It is crucial that our farms remain family run and that our fishing industries remain family run also. That these sectors continue to be centered around the family farm and the family business.

geography: National and EU Wide, and International
response_text: There should be a renewed approach to the Multiannual Financial Framework which will be a large part of the discussion and needs to consider the cost-of-living crisis affecting workers in Ireland and across Europe. The Global Europe regulation statement that was discussed at the Foreign Affairs committee on 25th November 2025, was extremely general and lacked any great detail. In effect it purports to be an instrument of foreign policy of the EU. We in Sinn Féin believe that it is very important that Ireland and every member state retains its own independent foreign policy. The Global Europe regulation must also reflect on how the crisis in ODA can be addressed. We need to see further detail on this, and we need to have clear guidelines on what is the timescale for the further development of this and what this will mean in practical terms. There is much commentary on investment in European security and respect for neutrality. This implies that this measure could involve military expenditure of some shape or form. From Sinn Féin's point of view, we are very clear that there is a need for investment in our Defence Forces but that should be a decision taken by an Irish Government independently and according to our own needs and priorities. We would have a watchful eye on any regulations that have military dimensions in terms of expenditure. With regards Irish Unity, we propose calling a High-Level EU Summit to advance preparations for re-unification and laying out the practicalities agreement at Council level as to how many extra MEPs, votes at Council level a United Ireland would be entitled to and other legal issues that unity would bring ensuring full a participation of the Assembly and Executive in the Presidency’s activities including meetings across the Six Counties. including Six County representation and input in all cultural events linked to the Presidency With regards Peace, in Palestine, in Sudan, and Ukraine, we propose proposing an EU initiative to recognise the State of Palestine during the Presidency pushing for EU payments to the Palestinian Authority to be advanced in light of the dire economic situation in the West Bank and for the Palestinian tax revenues being held by Israel to be released proposing an EU-wide ban on settlement goods and services, mirroring Ireland’s own Occupied Territories Bill working to deliver a full suite of sanctions on the Israeli state, mirroring those rightfully imposed on Russia working to deliver a full suspension of the EU-Israel Association Agreement working to deliver an EU-wide arms embargo on Israel working to ensure that Israel are excluded from Horizon Europe and its successor programmes and that no Israeli companies can benefit financially from the European Defence Fund more effective pressure on the UAE and other states and parties who fuel the conflict in Sudan by continuing to flood it with large scale and sophisticated weapons continued pressure by political, diplomatic and economic means on Russia to halt its illegal occupation of Ukraine a meeting of the UN Secretary General and top EU officials in Ireland marking the importance of the United Nations in peace building and conflict resolution a major domestic event showcasing Irish neutrality and the achievements of Ireland’s peacekeepers through the decades an event marking Ireland’s role in the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty and the ongoing importance of adherence to the Treaty On workers rights and the Environment host a conference of social actors like Trade Unions, Women’s Rights groups and Human Rights Organisations to set out a new social course for the EU insist on a social and environmental check on all legislation being discussed during the Presidency to ensure it does not allow backwards movement on workers’ rights or environment standards champion workers’ rights legislation that was promised by the Commission (right to disconnect/implementing the European Pillar of Social Rights) finalisation of a new PeacePlus programme focussed on removing the traumas and economic and social imbalances caused by partition

geography: National and EU Wide, and International
response_text: Plainly the main issue facing people, businesses and communities are housing, cost of living, domestic energy expenses. It is not apparent that these at the main priorities of either the European Commission or the European Council. It is crucial that they tackle these crises in terms of accessibility and affordability. It is crucial that the energy market and the nature of it is restructured. Since 2018, residential electricity prices have more than double. Irish households should not have to pay the highest prices in Europe indefinitely. Energy prices have fallen much more slowly here than other EU countries. And the gap between retail and wholesale prices is the highest in the world. This situation in Ireland and indeed across many other member states needs to be taken seriously and get this issue under control.

geography: National and EU Wide, and International
response_text: Across Europe many people feel distant and detached from these institutions. There is a feeling that these institutions do not respect the real need for subsidiarity, national legislatures and that they do not respect the need for decisions to be taken at a local level. This is an opportunity for Ireland to play a leading role in these European institutions in reasserting its respect for the individual sovereignty of member states and for decisions to be made at a local and domestic level. This should be a presidency that communicates to the people of Europe that there is respect for all countries, for their domestic legislatures and their sovereignty, and that mutual cooperation works best when members states can feel confident in their own independence as national states Sinn Féin believe in being strong on neutrality and strong on defense. We anticipate and appreciate that there will likely be discussion around military expenditure and Defence spending, and we are clear that each member state should have the right to decide themselves what their priorities should be in relation to Defence spending. It is crucial that each member state retains and has control over their sovereignty, independence and subsidiarity. While we respect the rights of sovereign states to take such decisions, to spend on defence and enter into military alliances - indeed we ourselves believe considerable investment is needed in our Defence Forces, that this is necessary. However, the EU was not imagined as a military alliance and it should not double as one - In recent times, the lines between NATO meetings and EU meetings have become blurred. Ireland’s Presidency must put clear waters between the two and no NATO discussion or side meetings should happen in our country. It is important that there is respect for Irish neutrality and the neutrality of other members states in relation to this.

geography: National and EU Wide, and International
response_text: This is a great opportunity for Ireland. However, concerns have been raised in recent weeks among Irish and European military leaders in relation to Ireland’s ability to resource security operations during the upcoming EU Presidency. This is completely and utterly down to this Government and its predecessors and how they have completely neglected our Defence Forces. They have allowed the Defence Forces to become depleted. It is a cause of great concern and regret that the Government has left us in this vulnerable position and that events around the EU Presidency could be exposed due to a lack of capability, particularly in relation to tackling drones but also our ability to monitor and police our own waters. This should hopefully be a lesson to our Government and should encourage them to finally take our Defence Forces seriously. Sinn Féin are very concerned by the significant crisis that is being caused by the huge cut in USAID. Whether anyone can fill the gap is a question. One of the proposals being explored by development organisations is the issue of debt held by Third World countries and the restructuring of that debt. This needs to be discussed at an EU level and it should be an element of the discussion that Ireland will be looking at as part of its Presidency. We believe also that there must be a discussion around the EU and a reevaluation of this. Recent comments from senior EU leaders would make it appear that the EU is imagined now as a military organization. This is not the case and indeed ca never be the case. This rhetoric needs to be challenged and Ireland as a sovereign and neutral country that promotes peace building should play its role in that. The EU should not be requiring particular actions of member states that would compromise neutrality. It must respect the sovereignty and national independence of each member state. Gaeilge The Presidency must be proudly bi-lingual and not slip into being a monolinguistic Presidency i.e. English only. The Presidency must also mark the end once and for all of the technical derogation on Irish interpretation, currently in place, as this limits the rights of Irish speakers in the EU for Irish at EU level. EU Budget While there be a multitude of legislative files to be dealt with the sign-off on the MFF (EU Budget) will be most important. The government must ensure that a fair Budget that protects farmers, workers and the environment is achieved. NATO ban In recent times, the lines between NATO meetings and EU meetings have become blurred. Ireland’s Presidency must put clear waters between the two and no NATO discussion or side meetings should happen in our country. Corporate sponsors The Presidency should avoid corporate sponsorship. If the government insists it is necessary, all sponsors must be ethically cleared meaning no fossil fuel companies or companies implicated in the occupation of Palestinian territory for example. An Anti-Partitionist Presidency An anti-partitionist image in all cultural and political events. Token inclusion of six county people or politicians in events or cultural exhibitions is not sufficient. From day one the Council Presidency must be visibly and unambiguously anti-partitionist in its presentation and content. Conclusion: A “do-nothing, say nothing” EU Presidency suits only the pollical establishment at home and in Brussels. Simply being competent chairpersons is not what the Irish people want or deserve. Failing to champion Irish Unity during the six months Ireland holds the Presidency would be an abdication of leadership in our efforts to unify our country. Those who say they support Irish Unity must act to do so during the six months. We fully respect the workload Irish civil servants and others will come under during this period as literally hundreds of meetings fall under Ireland’s role as chair. The technical and administrative role as well as policing and other costs cannot be neglected and must be fully resourced. Sinn Féin has engaged with and will continue to respond to Ministers as they seek input on priorities in specific areas of policy. The nitty-gritty of the Presidency is in files and negotiation rooms but that is not all the Presidency is or should be. This must be a political Presidency- one that is distinctively and proudly Irish and pro-Irish interests, an active and assertive period of Irish leadership for the European Union.

Ireland’s 2026 Presidency is an opportunity to place housing, homelessness, and anti-poverty action at the forefront of the EU’s social agenda. With rising housing costs and growing rates of homelessness and persistent poverty across the EU, Ireland is well positioned to champion a Presidency grounded in the EU values of dignity, equality, and human rights. A central thematic priority should be delivering a coordinated European approach to housing, grounded in the commitment by all 27 Member States to work towards ending homelessness by 2030 as part of the Lisbon Declaration, and aligned with the forthcoming European Affordable Housing Plan. This must include a clear recognition that housing is first and foremost a home - as opposed to a financial asset - and that secure, affordable homes are the foundation of wellbeing and thriving communities. Addressing poverty more broadly must also form a key pillar of the Presidency, the Irish Presidency should identify, progress, and monitor measures to ensure the effective implementation of the new EU Anti-Poverty Strategy currently being developed. This should be done through effective collaboration with organisations representing the diversity of experience of poverty and social exclusion, and co-creation with those with lived experience. Simon Communities of Ireland are members of Irish Homeless Policy Group (IHPG), the Irish Coalition to End Youth Homelessness (ICEYH), the Wheel, the Community Platform (and Community and Voluntary Pillar) and the Children’s Rights Alliance. Therefore, we support submissions by our peers in these collaborative working spaces.

The Irish Presidency presents a timely opportunity to prioritise joint EU action on housing and homelessness. In particular, the Simon Communities of Ireland are calling for the Irish Presidency to table a draft Council Recommendation on ending homelessness, for adoption under the presidency in 2026. There is clear institutional momentum in the EU for a Council Recommendation on ending homelessness. In February 2024, the Belgian Presidency held a Ministerial Conference on the European Platform on Combatting Homelessness (EPOCH). The event was an opportunity to discuss efforts to eradicate homelessness in the EU by 2030, a commitment all 27 EU countries agreed to work towards with the signing of the Lisbon Declaration in 2021. A report from the event noted a growing will among member states for a Council Recommendation on eradicating homelessness, recognising the urgency of coordinated EU-level action and the value of the Housing First. In an official Opinion, the European Economic and Social Committee (EESC) explicitly called in 2024 for an EU homeless strategy, “underpinned by a Council Recommendation on homelessness. The EESC therefore calls on the Belgian Presidency of the EU to start work on a Recommendation” (§ 1.3). In March 2025, the European Parliament welcomed intentions for a Council Recommendation on homelessness as part of a resolution on the European Semester for Economic Policy Coordination: Employment and Social Priorities for 2025 (§16). The Council Conclusions on the future European Affordable Housing Plan, published in November 2025, proposes “stronger cooperation at EU level on homelessness, building on the work of and further strengthening the European Platform on Combating Homelessness and housing-led policies such as the Housing First Principle; and consider whether a proposal for a new Council Recommendation on ending homelessness in Europe could contribute to this end” (paragraph 37). The Committee of the Regions, in a recent Opinion on an EU Anti-Poverty Strategy, also recently called on the Council to “follow-up on the Belgian Presidency’s initiative to prepare a Council Recommendation on ending homelessness” (§ 104). The Housing Advisory Board, chaired by Eammon Ryan, recently published its recommendations to the European Commission, which included that the Commission propose, and Council adopt by 2026, a “Recommendation on Homelessness that transforms the Lisbon Declaration into a governance framework at national level and a plan for European-level action to support an monitor progress” (pg 14). Coupled with Government reiterating Ireland’s commitment to ending homelessness by 2030 in the Delivering Homes, Building Communities housing plan, Ireland is well-positioned to lead on this agenda during the presidency.

Prioritising coordinated EU action to end homelessness is not only the morally right thing to do and a reflection the core European values of dignity, equality, and human rights, but it is also fiscally beneficial for Member States. The cost of providing emergency accommodation, crisis supports, and health services for persons experiencing homelessness is substantial for Member States. Investing in prevention and permanent solutions is far more sustainable and cost-effective. Experiencing homelessness can have multiple negative impacts, including adverse effects on physical health, mental health, and overall wellbeing. For children, experiencing homelessness can negatively affect development, cognitive functioning, participation in education, and opportunities later in life. By investing in early intervention, family support, and housing-led responses, Member States can prevent these long-term harms, strengthen community wellbeing, and significantly reduce public expenditure associated with emergency responses and downstream health and social services. More broadly, addressing Europe’s housing crisis would strengthen economic competitiveness, labour market functioning, and community resilience across the EU. Across many Member States, workers – especially younger people, essential workers, and those on low to moderate incomes – are increasingly priced out of renting or buying near employment hubs, undermining businesses’ ability to attract and retain staff. This reduces productivity, increases commuting pressures, and weakens social cohesion as people are pushed away from communities where they work, study, or have family ties. By supporting the implementation of the European Affordable Housing Plan and promoting accessible and affordable housing, Ireland’s Presidency can help ensure European cities and towns remain vibrant, dynamic, and economically competitive. Improving housing affordability is therefore not just a moral obligation – it is also cornerstone of a thriving economy, a stable workforce, and strong local communities. Through ambitious action on homelessness and housing, the Irish Presidency is an opportunity to deliver a tangible positive impact for people, businesses, and communities across the EU.

Exit polls found that housing and homelessness was the most important issue for voters in the 2024 general election – nominated as a top issue by 28% of voters – followed by cost of living at 19%. A 2025 poll by Statica also found that 64% of respondents viewed housing as one of the top two issues facing Ireland. Before and during the Presidency, Ireland should highlight how EU actions and policies directly impact and support affordable housing, and ending and preventing homelessness. By showing how European cooperation contributes to increased investment in sustainable and affordable homes and strengthening social rights both in Ireland and abroad, the Presidency can make the EU feel more relevant, accessible, and impactful. Central to this approach should be centring the voices of lived experience and creating meaningful platforms for to contribute to Presidency events and policy discussions – particularly for persons experiencing homelessness, migrant communities, Travellers and Roma, young persons, and disabled persons. Ensuring these groups are visible and active participants in Presidency events will both ensure effective policymaking and foster a stronger sense of ownership among communities who are often underrepresented in the decisionmaking process. Ireland should also adopt an accessible communication strategy. All Presidency communications, including digital content, publications, public events, and outreach materials, should be available in easy-to-read formats, accessible layouts, and multiple languages, including Irish Sign Language and other formats where appropriate. Communications should be designed and co-created in partnership with Disabled Persons’ Organisations, civil society groups, and representative community organisations to ensure they reflect lived realities and meet diverse accessibility needs. Finally, outreach efforts must be deliberately targeted toward communities that have historically been underrepresented in EU-level conversations, ensuring that the benefits of the Presidency are shared widely and that the Presidency itself reflects the diversity of the people it serves.

respondent_type:
NGO
The Irish Council for International Students (ICOS) is a national NGO and membership organisation representing 27 higher education institutions across the Republic of Ireland. Our membership includes universities, colleges, and Aontas na Mac Léinn in Éirinn (AMLÉ), the national student union. ICOS also convenes a Student Advisory Group to provide structured, lived-experience input into our advocacy and policy work.
sector:
International student advocacy; international education; higher education mobility; student-facing immigration, accommodation, and welfare systems.
ICOS supports the rights and welfare of international students in Ireland. We work across a network of 27 institutional members and focus on ethical mobility, learner voice, and accessible information and support systems for international learners in higher education.
This includes managing the Ireland Fellows Programme on behalf of Irish Aid.
geography: Our work is national in scope within Ireland, but our focus intersects directly with EU-level mobility and migration systems. This includes infrastructure and policy debates relevant to the Justice and Home Affairs (JHA) and Education, Youth, Culture and Sport (EYCS) Council configurations in the context of the 2026 Presidency.
response_text: ICOS welcomes the opportunity to contribute to this consultation. As a national NGO advocating for international students, we work at the intersection of education, mobility, immigration, and inclusion. These lived experiences offer concrete insights into how EU systems perform, and how they can be strengthened to deliver greater fairness, resilience, and public value. Based on this expertise, ICOS proposes the following three areas as strong, people-centred thematic priorities that Ireland’s Presidency could credibly lead on and contribute to broader EU objectives. 1. Inclusive Mobility for a Future-Ready Europe Learner mobility is a long-standing expression of European cooperation. When mobility systems are clear, fair, and rights-based, they deliver public value: talent development, social cohesion, and global connection. International students and researchers engage daily with EU-regulated systems, including visas, immigration registration, housing markets, and qualification recognition. Their experiences are a real-world measure of how the EU delivers. Ireland’s Presidency can: Champion transparent, timely visa and work pathways (JHA configuration) Promote fair qualification recognition and academic transitions (EYCS) Support multilingual, accessible public information on rights and redress mechanisms Mobility should not be reduced to a transactional market. It is a public good that supports inclusion, human development, and democratic participation, reflecting core EU values and aligned with the EU Strategic Agenda 2024-2029 and the European Education Area. 2. International Education as Strategic Public Infrastructure Ethical international education supports not only individuals, but EU-wide strategic goals: Research and innovation Climate adaptation and global cooperation Gender equality and inclusive economic development International students contribute to Europe’s demographic sustainability and are integral to its future skills ecosystem. The Presidency can: Position study and research exchange as key components of the EU’s competitiveness and talent strategy Reinforce long-term alumni networks as soft-power assets Champion education as a durable, rights-based investment in the Union’s internal strength and external partnerships (SDGs 4 and 17) 3. Safer Digital Living for Mobile Citizens International learners rely on digital platforms for accommodation, services, and community life, often across language barriers and legal systems. Yet they remain vulnerable to scams, exploitative practices, and information gaps. Ireland’s Presidency should: Promote platform accountability and digital consumer protections Advance a rights-based approach to digital services in cross-border settings Ensure that mobile learners’ lived experiences inform the broader EU digital transformation agenda These themes reflect Ireland’s capacity to convene practical, people-centred solutions across Council configurations. Learner mobility is a human measure of how EU systems work. When they reduce friction, prevent harm, and enable belonging, they also enhance Europe’s competitiveness and social resilience. This delivers benefits for individuals, institutions, and communities alike. These themes also reflect the role of civil society in strengthening EU systems and delivering public value, bridging institutions and communities at national and international levels.

NGO
The Irish Council for International Students (ICOS) is a national NGO and membership organisation representing 27 higher education institutions across the Republic of Ireland. Our membership includes universities, colleges, and Aontas na Mac Léinn in Éirinn (AMLÉ), the national student union. ICOS also convenes a Student Advisory Group to provide structured, lived-experience input into our advocacy and policy work.
sector:
International student advocacy; international education; higher education mobility; student-facing immigration, accommodation, and welfare systems.
ICOS supports the rights and welfare of international students in Ireland. We work across a network of 27 institutional members and focus on ethical mobility, learner voice, and accessible information and support systems for international learners in higher education.
This includes managing the Ireland Fellows Programme on behalf of Irish Aid.
geography: Our work is national in scope within Ireland, but our focus intersects directly with EU-level mobility and migration systems. This includes infrastructure and policy debates relevant to the Justice and Home Affairs (JHA) and Education, Youth, Culture and Sport (EYCS) Council configurations in the context of the 2026 Presidency.
response_text: Ethical, well-governed learner mobility contributes to Europe’s social cohesion and global competitiveness while advancing the EU’s role in international cooperation, particularly through SDG 4 (inclusive, equitable quality education) and SDG 17 (global partnerships). This includes international students, researchers, and mobile learners across all stages of education and training. Ireland’s Presidency provides an opportunity to make progress on the systems international learners and education providers depend on, including immigration, accommodation, consumer protection, and qualification recognition. These issues cut across Council configurations, including Education, Youth, Culture and Sport, Justice and Home Affairs, and Employment, Social Policy, Health and Consumer Affairs. ICOS recommends a cross-cutting focus on the following, framed around values-driven governance and practical outcomes: A coherent, inclusive approach to international education EU legislation and policy should uphold the rights and welfare of all international students, across Erasmus+, national scholarships, and self-funded pathways. This includes transparent approaches to residence permits, post-study options, access to public services, and protection from discrimination. The 2026 European Commission Work Programme should prioritise inclusive mobility as a core element of EU education policy and advance practical proposals to enhance student safety and wellbeing. Fair, learner-centred migration and visa systems ICOS urges the Presidency to prioritise work within the JHA configuration to improve mobility pathways for third-country nationals, including students and researchers. Fair, efficient, and transparent visa and residency processes are central to Europe’s credibility and attractiveness as a destination for study, research, innovation, and skills development, and should be positioned as shared EU infrastructure. Such systems also underpin broader resilience and security by ensuring well-managed and rights-based migration. Protection from discrimination and exploitation Across EU Member States, international students are often vulnerable to racism, housing discrimination, precarious work, and exploitative recruitment. The Presidency should support stronger safeguards and clear redress mechanisms, ensuring that learners are treated as rights-holders, not solely as economic contributors. This includes tackling hate crime, discrimination, and extreme hate speech, in line with the EU Anti-Racism Action Plan and the Digital Services Act, aligning with EPSCO priorities around equality, social protection, and fair working conditions. Strengthening cross border education through EYCS ICOS recommends that the Presidency use the EYCS configuration to support progress on: Ethical, transparent cross-border student recruitment Qualification recognition and fair transitions between education and work High-quality learner supports and wellbeing systems These priorities reinforce the strategic goals of the European Education Area and the EU’s position as a global leader in inclusive, ethical and values-driven international education. International education and research support broader EU goals: climate adaptation, global solidarity, innovation, and gender equality. Strong alumni networks enhance long-term EU influence and partnership-building, strengthening both internal cohesion and external engagement. They align with the EU’s external action objectives under the Global Gateway strategy and NDICI–Global Europe, both of which emphasise education, gender equality, climate action, and inclusive international partnerships. Ireland’s Presidency can help embed these priorities across EU agendas, ensuring that mobility, education, and inclusion are recognised not only as sectoral issues, but as strategic enablers of the Union’s future success.

NGO
The Irish Council for International Students (ICOS) is a national NGO and membership organisation representing 27 higher education institutions across the Republic of Ireland. Our membership includes universities, colleges, and Aontas na Mac Léinn in Éirinn (AMLÉ), the national student union. ICOS also convenes a Student Advisory Group to provide structured, lived-experience input into our advocacy and policy work.
sector:
International student advocacy; international education; higher education mobility; student-facing immigration, accommodation, and welfare systems.
ICOS supports the rights and welfare of international students in Ireland. We work across a network of 27 institutional members and focus on ethical mobility, learner voice, and accessible information and support systems for international learners in higher education.
This includes managing the Ireland Fellows Programme on behalf of Irish Aid.
geography: Our work is national in scope within Ireland, but our focus intersects directly with EU-level mobility and migration systems. This includes infrastructure and policy debates relevant to the Justice and Home Affairs (JHA) and Education, Youth, Culture and Sport (EYCS) Council configurations in the context of the 2026 Presidency.
response_text: The most substantial impact will come from improving the clarity, fairness, and accessibility of systems that people engage with in their daily lives, particularly those navigating education, migration, housing, and work across borders. From ICOS’ perspective, the Irish Presidency can make a lasting difference by championing joined-up, people-centred governance, especially in areas where EU institutions directly shape the lived experiences of mobile learners, international students, and their host communities. Strengthen trust in cross-border systems People feel the value of the EU when systems work, when immigration processes are predictable, housing is fair, rights are respected, and information is accessible. International students and researchers – who move for study, training, and research – are an important case in point. Their journeys rely on multiple EU-regulated systems across Member States. The Presidency can: Prioritise efficiency and transparency in visa and residency systems Promote consistency in qualification recognition and access to work Encourage consumer protections for mobile citizens, especially in digital markets Efficient, rights-based systems reduce stress, build social and economic resilience, and contribute to security by reducing uncertainty and vulnerability. For students and institutions, clearer pathways reduce stress, unlock opportunity, and support businesses and institutions in planning, recruiting, and retaining talent. Deliver fairness and protection through inclusive policy design Discrimination, exploitation, and exclusion – including hate crime and online hate speech – undermine EU values and erode social cohesion. International students, including those from third countries, are often vulnerable to racism, housing scams, precarious work, and unclear redress systems. Ireland’s Presidency can support: Rights-based policymaking across Council configurations Stronger accountability for actors profiting from mobility (e.g. recruitment, accommodation platforms) Investment in accessible, multilingual public information Protecting learners’ dignity and safety contributes to community stability and reflects the EU’s commitment to equality, non-discrimination, and fundamental rights. This benefits individuals and the communities, institutions, and businesses that depend on safe, ethical systems. Frame education mobility as a shared public good International education contributes not only to individual opportunity, but to broader public value across the Union. When properly supported, it strengthens: Local economies (housing, services, innovation hubs) Business ecosystems (talent development, alumni networks) Social cohesion (intercultural understanding, civic engagement) Well-managed mobility enhances competitiveness, skills development, and long-term innovation across Member States. By promoting ethical, inclusive international education, as part of the European Education Area and broader talent strategies, Ireland can help make the EU more globally attractive, economically competitive, and socially resilient. Lead by example in civic participation and inclusion Ireland’s Presidency can model inclusive civic engagement by creating space for youth, international students, and underrepresented communities to participate in EU discussions. These groups are often directly affected by EU policy but excluded from formal processes. Empowering their voices enhances transparency, trust, and legitimacy. The Council’s work can have lasting, people-centred impact by strengthening systems, protecting rights, and enabling participation. By championing EU values in practice – fairness, openness, solidarity, and opportunity – Ireland’s Presidency can help shape a future-ready Europe grounded in inclusion, sustainability, competitiveness, and collective security.
