NGO
The Irish Council for International Students (ICOS) is a national NGO and membership organisation representing 27 higher education institutions across the Republic of Ireland. Our membership includes universities, colleges, and Aontas na Mac Léinn in Éirinn (AMLÉ), the national student union. ICOS also convenes a Student Advisory Group to provide structured, lived-experience input into our advocacy and policy work.
sector:
International student advocacy; international education; higher education mobility; student-facing immigration, accommodation, and welfare systems.
ICOS supports the rights and welfare of international students in Ireland. We work across a network of 27 institutional members and focus on ethical mobility, learner voice, and accessible information and support systems for international learners in higher education.
This includes managing the Ireland Fellows Programme on behalf of Irish Aid.
geography: Our work is national in scope within Ireland, but our focus intersects directly with EU-level mobility and migration systems. This includes infrastructure and policy debates relevant to the Justice and Home Affairs (JHA) and Education, Youth, Culture and Sport (EYCS) Council configurations in the context of the 2026 Presidency.
response_text: As the national NGO supporting the rights and wellbeing of international students in Ireland, ICOS believes that education mobility provides one of the most visible and relatable demonstrations of EU cooperation in everyday life. Students, whether participating in Erasmus+, on (inter)national or institutional scholarships, or self-funded, experience the EU not as an abstract project, but through tangible freedoms: to move, to study, to connect, to belong. Their journeys offer a powerful lens through which to communicate not only what the EU stands for, but also what it makes possible. ICOS proposes the following approaches to communicate EU values and build broader public ownership of Ireland’s 2026 Presidency: Amplify diverse student, researcher, and alumni voices International students and researchers speak directly to core EU values – freedom, dignity, and opportunity – through their lived experience. Sharing their stories, challenges, and contributions demonstrates how European cooperation delivers real public value. These narratives resonate across borders, generations, and sectors, while reflecting the EU’s competitiveness in education, research, and inclusive partnerships. Promote inclusion, belonging, and civic participation Student mobility is not a one-way process. International learners actively contribute to their host communities through volunteering, peer support, cultural exchange, and civic life. Tackling hate crime, discrimination, and hate speech is essential to ensuring these contributions are visible, safe, and valued. Highlighting these contributions shows how inclusion strengthens Europe, fosters innovation, and builds lasting, people-to-people partnerships. Use inclusive, accessible, multilingual channels To reach and engage diverse audiences, Presidency communications should reflect Europe’s linguistic and cultural diversity. Multilingual and youth-friendly content, shared via social media, education settings, and community organisations, can extend the Presidency’s reach, especially among newcomers, mobile citizens, and underrepresented groups. Make mobility visible, and rights clear Showcase how EU membership enables study, research, training, and cross-border exchange. This includes demystifying practical systems, such as visa renewals or digital residence permits, through user-centred, rights-based information. Strong, transparent systems not only build public trust; they also reinforce collective security by reducing discrimination, misinformation, and risk. When people see the EU improving access, transparency, and fairness, public trust grows. Create civic participation spaces for students and youth Civil society and student-led initiatives can act as trusted intermediaries, helping to make EU policy more tangible and relevant to citizens. Ireland’s Presidency can lead by embedding student voices into Presidency activities and legacy. Youth assemblies, student-led dialogues, and consultations aligned with the EU Youth Strategy and the EYCS Council configuration can support authentic engagement and long-term impact. This also strengthens the democratic foundations of the Union and builds ownership among future leaders. Ireland’s credibility in international education, rooted in people, partnerships, and shared values, offers a powerful platform to deliver these messages. The Presidency can help communicate not only what Europe is, but what it is becoming: open, fair, connected, and future-focused.

Proposed overarching slogan: A competitive, agile Europe in a fractious world. Why? An Taoiseach, Micheál Martin TD, recently said “We want to major on competitiveness in the six months of the Irish Presidency”. Europe’s citizens, consumers and businesses want Europe, once again, to be a leader on enterprise, innovation and technological development. Ireland, as a pro-market, business-friendly Member State, is perfectly placed to chair discussions and drive forward the competitiveness agenda. In his seminal report, Mario Draghi described competitiveness and productivity as an existential challenge for Europe. One year on, he says the issues are even more acute and Europe’s citizens are disappointed by how slowly the EU moves. The Council of the EU must take on this challenge and set the tone and pace of the competitiveness agenda. Chancellor Merz has gathered signatories by 19 other heads of state, including Ireland, calling for a systematic review of all EU regulations to identify rules that are superfluous, excessive, or unbalanced, as well as a thorough examination of the entire acquis of EU rules to determine whether regulations are still fit for purpose to meet the European Competitiveness goals. The Council of the EU should pursue this agenda in earnest. Digital policy must be at the centre of the competitiveness agenda - not simply viewed as one aspect of it. The Draghi report found that the EU is weak in emerging technologies, such as AI, that will drive future growth and that the productivity gap between the EU and the US is largely explained by the tech sector. Drawing on Draghi’s words, “Europe has long styled itself as a regulatory power—it must now prove it can adapt to a fast-changing technological landscape.” The simplification agenda behind the Digital Omnibus and the Digital Fitness Check represents a crucial moment to address the existing shortcomings and should not fall short of the big ambitions needed to ensure a more prosperous future of Europe. This moment requires a complete overhaul of Europe’s digital rulebook - a thorough revision of the entire digital acquis to determine which laws are still fit for purpose and truly support the European competitiveness ambitions. Moreover, a pause on implementation of the pipeline of digital laws is needed to allow for the regulatory revision to take place. Ireland is the third largest exporter of digitally delivered services in the world (WTO, 2023) - a recognised digital hub - and should adopt a leadership position in shaping Europe’s digital agenda. Europe needs to be open-minded and agile to benefit from and shape the economic developments of the coming decades. Ireland has benefitted hugely from US multinational investment and this is now very much a two-way street, with 200,000 people employed by Irish companies across all 50 US States. The broader EU-US economic relationship should be prioritised during Ireland’s Presidency, particularly in fast-moving areas like AI. Ireland has a unique relationship with the US and should ensure this is brought to the fore during its Presidency term to strengthen EU-US ties.

The Digital Omnibus The Commission’s Omnibus proposal takes some steps toward simplification, yet it falls significantly short. The Council should go much further. The AI Act European leaders such as Christine Lagarde and Mario Draghi are actively questioning Europe’s approach to this once-in-a-generation moment to handle AI. A bolder pause and rethink of the AI Act is essential. While the delay of the High Risk framework was necessary, the way it is drafted is confusing and does not bring the necessary legal certainty. The proposal doesn’t address the General Purpose AI Model regime’s approach, which is redundant due to its duplicative attempt to regulate both upstream and downstream activities. The AI Act still lacks a clear mandate for regulators at both EU and national levels to promote innovation. The privacy framework (GDPR and ePrivacy Directive) While taking steps to modernise the privacy framework is positive, this is a missed opportunity to introduce the fundamental innovation principle that would set the foundations for a future-proof privacy regime. DPAs should be tasked with promoting a balanced approach that supports both data protection and economic growth, and should be held accountable for ensuring proportionality in their decisions. Digital Fitness Check Drawing on the call from 20 Heads of State, including Ireland, the Council should ensure that the EU's digital rules are effective, proportionate and fit for the future. Digital Fairness Act The Commission should withdraw the DFA. It contradicts the EU’s efforts to simplify digital regulations, introducing new rules for companies in areas already addressed by existing (and recent) EU laws. The October letter from 20 Heads of State called for “self-restraint when it comes to new legislation” and this is an example of over-regulation. Protecting Minors Online Meta believes that there is one area of the digital regulatory framework where an additional piece of targeted regulation is required. Ireland’s recent call that more urgent action is required at EU level on the question of online age verification is very welcome. Ireland should support an EU-wide digital majority age that would restrict access to certain online platforms, including social media, for younger teens unless they have parental approval. This approach mirrors the offline world, where parents set boundaries for their children’s activities. The most effective and efficient way to implement a solution is at the operating system (OS) or App store level. The OS or App store would serve as the first line of defense across the ecosystem, since this is where users initially engage and where age information is already collected. The OS or App store could share this signal with services such as Meta’s. EU Batteries Regulation The EU Batteries Regulation is an example of over-regulation which we know is of deep concern to Member States. Article 11 should be delayed for at least 3 years. Even if the Commission manages to carefully review all the applications for partial derogations, industry will be given only 1 year to comply (by February 2027) with a provision that deeply affects complex production processes. AI Summit Ireland should deliver an ambitious summit that critically evaluates Europe’s approach to AI. Ensure a good mix of contributors to the summit, including politicians, policymakers, industry, civil society and citizens. Reflect the breadth of debate in this area across the globe. It is particularly important that the voice of European industry is heard and understood during this event. CEOs from Siemens, Bosch, Ericsson and others have gone public, urging bold reform and a “Stop the Clock” on the AI Act to keep Europe competitive.

For people and communities The Council can ensure that the interests of people and communities are placed at the heart of the EU agenda. The European Commission, in particular, is often perceived as far removed from the views of people and communities and the Council is well placed to address this. In the last few years, many U.S. tech companies have been forced to hold back updates or put a pause on product plans due to the European regulatory environment, particularly related to privacy, data protection, and competition laws. The problems include overlapping regulations, inconsistent guidance and regulatory interpretations that go well beyond the laws enacted by EU policymakers, where economic considerations and competitiveness are not balanced as they should be against other rights, including privacy rights. This means that single-issue regulators, more often data protection authorities, do not ensure a fair balancing of rights. Moreover, regulatory enforcement is often fragmented and delayed across the EU as the GDPR’s “one-stop-shop” solution has been undermined. The Council can ensure that a better balance is struck, where EU consumers are protected and gain access to the best products and services available globally. Many EU citizens associate the EU with improving their rights and choices as consumers. That notion is now under threat. For businesses As Mario Draghi has pointed out, over-regulation stifles innovation. The people and communities mentioned above are not producing enough entrepreneurs and startups. Europe's share of global tech market capitalisation has collapsed from ~20% in 2000 to a mere ~4% today. None of the world's top 10 companies or most valuable unicorns calls Europe home. While the US and China race ahead, Europe is left further behind in the global AI race. This term of the Irish Presidency can put a spotlight on the factors that are preventing this generation of Europeans from producing the top companies of the future. We stand at a critical crossroads, especially in regard to AI. In Christine Lagarde’s words (November), “there are reasons to believe AI could spread faster, and deliver tangible economic gains sooner, than previous technology waves. If that is the path we are on – and I believe it may be – Europe needs to position itself accordingly. We need to remove all the obstacles that stop us from embracing this transformation. Otherwise we risk letting the wave of AI adoption pass us by and jeopardise Europe’s future…..And this time, the consequences extend beyond losing the race in AI models. We would eventually face a further loss of competitiveness for many of our sectors and industries.”

“Europe’s citizens and companies value the diagnosis, the clear priorities and the action plans. But they also express growing frustration. They are disappointed by how slowly the EU moves. They see us failing to match the speed of change elsewhere. They are ready to act—but fear governments have not grasped the gravity of the moment.” (Mario Draghi, September 2025) It has been reported that only 11% of Mario Draghi’s recommendations have been implemented, one year on. Repeated implementation gaps lead to cynicism and apathy among citizens about the political system that represents them. In early December, the Irish Government published Accelerating Infrastructure - a Report and Action Plan to help drive the efficient delivery of infrastructure across Ireland. There is a collective drive and momentum to implement this new Report and Action Plan, across government as a whole, and its agencies. The same commitment to delivery should be brought to the implementation of the Draghi Report, across the entire European Commission. The Irish Presidency can make a virtue of its implementation – carry out a full-scale review, two years on, and – in the words of Minister Jack Chambers, demand “urgency, collaboration, and accountability at every level”. Citizens would see the values and benefits of EU membership if they could see the delivery of actions long-promised by political leaders - i.e. the EU doing what it said it would do. If the Irish Presidency could make this happen, citizens would see the public service and political system taking assertive action on their behalf, restoring trust and a sense of agency over the problems society has identified.

Summary: Ireland’s Presidency should pursue a number of initiatives to help European citizens benefit from digital advancement. It is an opportunity to promote tech startups and unicorns, digital adoption among European SMEs and enhance the Digital Single Market. Ireland’s Presidency should promote initiatives to enhance the digital intensity of EU businesses, the up-skilling and re-skilling of the workforce and the digitalisation of public services, drawing on the targets set out in the forthcoming National Digital and AI Plan. Additionally, the Presidency should: Ensure all Directorate Generals reflect the ambition of a competitive digitalised single market in their initiatives, enable coherence in policy development and delivery. Remove bottlenecks and regulatory barriers in the Single Market which impact the rollout of digital products and services. Enable businesses to scale to become pan-European and global players, by addressing fragmented implementation and interpretation of digital rules to allow agility and enhance certainty for businesses and consumers. Deliver a Capital Markets/Savings and Investment Union. Enhance access to funding for digital entrepreneurs and innovation. Develop complementary sources of finance to bank lending. Diversifying the financing landscape will unlock additional funds necessary to finance the twin green and digital transitions (up to €500 billion a year until 2030). Unlock the potential of savings, pension funds and private wealth funds. Also encourage more venture capital support of start-ups from banks and venture capital companies from EU. At its April 2024 meeting in Dublin, the D9+ Ministers called for Europe to do more to create the conditions for EU unicorns. These commitments should be re-prioritised and debated as part of a dedicated D9+ meeting during Ireland’s Presidency. The Dublin Declaration said: “We, the D9+ Ministers: Will support efforts at national and EU level to address barriers hindering innovation and growth and fragmenting the digital single market, be they legal, administrative, or regulatory in nature; Support increased efforts to improve the investment environment for startups and scaleups to boost the EU’s competitiveness and innovation. We aim to work at national and EU level to mobilise private capital such as retail investor savings, pension funds and private wealth funds, for investment in innovative firms that have the potential to grow and achieve scale in the EU; Support exchange and implementation of best practice policies for incubation and ecosystem development for startups and scaleups, in order to boost Europe’s competitiveness and innovation potential, through organisations such as the European Startup Nations Alliance.”

organisation: Sexual Exploitation Research and Policy Institute
response_text: Ireland’s priorities should focus on achieving - • A Safe and Equal Europe - free from Domestic, Sexual and Gender Based Violence (DSGBV) online and offline; and where adults and children can partake in a safe online world, protected from violent and abusive content and technologies. Europe is facing an epidemic of violence against women and girls (VAWG). This is manifesting both offline and online. trade is responsible for essentially grooming some children to perpetrate or submit to sexual Around 50 million women aged 18-74 in the EU or 31% have experienced physical (including threats) or sexual violence in adulthood. 35% of women in the youngest age group (aged 18 to 29) reported experiencing gender-based violence. 1 in 8 women have experienced sexual violence, including rape, by a non-partner 30% of women across the EU fear that fake intimate images of them may be shared without their consent. Online misogyny and abuse is on the rise and women and girls speak of the chilling effect this has on their participation in both online and offline spaces. A significant driver of this violence is the proliferation of violent, misogynistic, and degrading pornographic content online. Online pornography is normalising violence against women and girls, grooming men and boys to perpetrate sexual violence, and contributing to child-on-child sexual abuse. The average age a child in the EU accesses pornography is 13. According to SERP’s Facing Reality: Addressing the role of pornography in the pandemic of violence against women and girls report, ‘the pornography violence.’ Pornography has saturated our culture and laid the foundations for cyber violence against women and girls, including image-based sexual abuse (IBSA), ‘deepfake’ pornography and the growing threat of AI to women and children’s safety, particularly ‘nudification’ apps and ‘AI Girlfriends’. An online survey of 18-year-olds in four European countries found that: One in three had someone share sexually explicit images or video of them without their permission. Nearly one in three experienced a peer either sharing sexually explicit content with them or trying to talk to them about sexual topics online. Children’s unfettered access to online pornography is having a detrimental effect on their mental, emotional, physical and neurological wellbeing. Pornography is also a form of commercial sexual exploitation, with vulnerable and marginalised women and girls routinely trafficked and coerced into the pornography industry. Technology, including social media and messaging platforms, is utilised by human traffickers at all stages of exploitation, including the recruitment of women into this harmful industry. Pornography undermines our European values of ‘respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights, including the rights of persons belonging to minorities.’ The Commission’s proposed Gender Equality Strategy aims to ‘reinforce equality, inclusion and participation in all areas of society.’ This cannot be realised until we have stopped the free and unfettered access to violent pornography by both adults and children and actively held to account the pornography profiteers of sexual exploitation and human trafficking. Ireland is a leader in addressing DSGBV, as well as human trafficking and sexual exploitation. The launch of Cuan was a pivotal moment in our history. Ireland should harness this leadership now as we take on the EU Presidency.

organisation: Sexual Exploitation Research and Policy Institute
response_text: Ireland should build on the work of the Danish Presidency and continue to focus on Gender Equality under the remit of the Employment, Social Policy, Health and Consumer Affairs Council. The Commission’s Programme of Work underscores the need for further action in this area. The planned Gender Equality Strategy 2026-2030 is a vital opportunity that can be harnessed in this regard. This Strategy must consider the impact of online pornography on violence against women and girls, both inside and outside of the pornography industry. The Strategy must reflect the lived experiences of women and girls who are affected by the harms of pornography, and the impact this has on their inclusion in offline and online spaces. It must also consider the role of pornography in domestic and intimate partner abuse and in driving rates of sexual assault and rape. This Strategy must also include addressing the impact of pornography on men and boys and how this shapes their sexual scripts and grooms them to perpetrate sexual violence. Ireland must also continue the work of the Danish Presidency in ensuring full implementation of the Directive on combating violence against women and domestic violence across all Member States. This Directive is key in outlining the obligations of Member States in relation to violence against women and domestic violence. Ireland should use its Presidency to work with Member States to ensure they are meeting these obligations and prioritising the safety of women and girls both online and offline. The Programme of Work also commits to making the online environment safe, fair and empowering so that people can make the most of technology. Currently the online environment is one infiltrated by misogyny, VAWG and unregulated AI experiments on women’s safety. Ireland must use its Presidency to ensure that the Digital Services Act is fit for purpose and that Member States have the power and capabilities to implement age verification for pornography at a national level. Again, following the Danish Presidency, Ireland should continue to work towards the realisation of The Jutland Declaration: Shaping a Safe Online World for Minors, of which Ireland is a signatory. Ireland should utilise the Digital Fairness Act to work towards implementing the European Parliament’s Resolution on the impact of harmful technologies and online content to minors, including calls for: A minimum age of 16 for access to social-media platforms, video-sharing platforms and AI companions. Possible bans on addictive product features such as infinite scrolling, autoplay, loot boxes and engagement-based recommendations. Strict age-verification enforcement including personal liability for senior managers where platforms fail to comply, and Regulation of AI tools including deepfakes and chatbots. While we understand that delaying children’s access to social media is a contested issue, especially concerning children’s rights to access the online world, the evidence is clear that the harms of social media are too acute to ignore. Unfettered access to harmful content online, including pornography is having a detrimental effect on young people. The tech and pornography industries should be held accountable for the harmful content on their sites as a matter of urgency. Until then the best option available is to delay children’s access to social media. Ireland should build on the new rules planned for tackling organised crime including human trafficking, as outlined in the Political Guidelines. This is an opportunity to work with Member States on identifying and addressing the role of human trafficking and exploitation within the pornography industry and wider commercial sexual exploitation.

organisation: Sexual Exploitation Research and Policy Institute
response_text: According to the Political Guidelines for the Next European Commission 2024-2029, ‘the most basic of rights is the right to feel safe – wherever we are and whatever time of day it is’. This is not a feeling enjoyed by most women and girls across the EU. Research shows that women and girls do not feel safe online or offline. They live in fear of abuse, harassment and sexual assault in both online and offline spheres. They police themselves online, scared to post photos and videos, in case they are digitally altered, they restrict their own speech for fear of abuse and ridicule, they employ tech safety mechanisms to protect themselves from harassment. In the offline world, they do not run after dark, avoid taking taxi’s alone and shrink in work environments not designed for them. Women and girls do not enjoy the right to feel safe. The work of the Council during the term of the Irish Presidency can start to address this. A Gender Equality Strategy that: addresses the drivers of violence against women and girls including violent and misogynistic pornography; that truly places the experiences of women and girls at its center; and takes seriously the role of men and boys, could make a real difference to women and girls in EU Member States. Provided it is robustly implemented. Ireland has shown leadership at a national level in addressing DSGBV, it can now show leadership at the EU level. Equally if Ireland leads the Council’s work in addressing online harms by ensuring age verification for pornography can be implemented at a national level, this will have a very real impact. Age verification for pornography in the United Kingdom has resulted in a decrease in traffic to mainstream pornography websites. The regulator Ofcom has reported that overall, visitor numbers to the 10 most-visited pornography services in the UK have now settled at a “lower level” than before age verification was introduced in July this year. It is estimated that this decrease in traffic is a result of minors no longer being able to access pornography sites, as well as some adults who have chosen not to undertake the age verification process. Should EU Member States follow suit and implement national age verification with the support of the Council, they too could see a real and tangible impact in protecting children from online pornography. This in turn, would begin to help to reduce the impact of pornography on sexual violence amongst young people. The Presidency is a critical moment for Ireland. Women and girls in particular have lost faith in institutions and systems to protect them. A brave and bold agenda that puts women and girls’ safety at the heart of this Presidency can begin to turn that around, both in Ireland and across the EU.

organisation: Sexual Exploitation Research and Policy Institute
response_text: Nothing to add.

organisation: Sexual Exploitation Research and Policy Institute

sector: All sectors and all areas of work
response_text: ICTU sees Quality Jobs as an obvious and essential high-level thematic priority for Ireland’s Presidency. In line with the request above regarding the framing of feedback (p.2), we would justify our recommendation by referencing: The Strategic Agenda 2024-2029, adopted by EU leaders including the Taoiseach, which commits to ‘creat[ing] good jobs’ (p.6); President von der Leyen’s Political Priorities for the 2024-2020 European Commission, which commit to putting forward a ‘Quality Jobs Roadmap, developed with the social partners [that] will support fair wages, good working conditions, training and fair job transitions for workers and self-employed people, notably by increasing collective bargaining coverage’ (p.18); The Joint Declaration on the EU legislative priorities for 2025 (March 2025), which commits to promote quality jobs in order to ‘boost Europe’s sustainable prosperity and competitiveness’ (p.3); The Danish Presidency’s policy programme, which commits to engaging with the European Commission’s Quality Jobs Roadmap (p.28); And the incoming Cypriot Presidency’s (draft) programme, which commits to ‘advance policies that promote quality employment’ (p.25). It would also reflect the views of the Council, the Commission and the European social partners (including BusinessEurope on behalf of IBEC, SMEUnited on behalf of ISME and the ETUC on behalf of ICTU) outlined in the Val Duchesse Tripartite Declaration of 31 January 2024, that the ‘EU’s future long-term competitiveness needs to go hand in hand with quality jobs’ (p.4). Taking account of the views set out in the consultation document above, it would contribute to making progress on policy areas and initiatives that are ‘likely to be of most value and relevance for the Union – and all of its 27 Member States’, ‘build on the work done by its predecessor in progressing the Council’s legislative and policy agenda’ and reflect the ‘programme of legislation’ planned by the European Commission - with the Commission’s 2026 work programme committing to follow-up its Quality Jobs Roadmap, issued on 3 December 2025 (tbc), with a legislative proposal for a Quality Jobs Act in Q4 2026. Quality jobs will also be a core element of other initiatives that will be on the Council’s agenda during the Irish Presidency, including the new action plan to implement the European Pillar of Social Rights, the anti-poverty strategy, the gender equality strategy 2026-30, the fair labour mobility package, amongst others (see response to Question 2 below). Since the Taoiseach stated in his 20 November 2025 speech at Eurofound’s Foundation Forum: Europe’s social model – the key to competitive growth that the Government was looking forward to the Commission’s Quality Jobs Roadmap, which he said would set an ‘an ambitious employment agenda for the EU to remain competitive, innovative and fair, and create a level playing field that prioritises high standards for quality jobs’, it would be logical for this key initiative for workers in Ireland and all across Europe to be made a thematic priority of Ireland’s Presidency next year. (474 words)

sector: All sectors and all areas of work
response_text: Following on from our response to Question 1, the Quality Jobs Roadmap and the legislative proposal for a Quality Jobs Act should be a focus of work for the Irish Presidency. ICTU would also identify a number of other specific policy areas and legislative proposals that should also be a focus of work for the Irish Presidency: First, key pending legislative proposals of relevance to workers that may not be adopted by the end of the Cypriot Presidency. We would highlight proposals such as the draft traineeships directive; the draft regulation on support to workers affected by imminent job displacement in enterprises undergoing restructuring (i.e. amending the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund); the draft regulation on the coordination of social security systems, and the sixth revision of the carcinogens, mutagens and reprotoxic substances directive (CMRD), amongst others. If these have not been adopted by June 2026, the Irish Presidency should aim to do so during its term. Second, previously announced Commission commitments for new initiatives of relevance to workers that are expected over the coming weeks: to a new action plan to implement the European Pillar of Social Rights (announced for Q4 2025) and the EU housing package (consisting of the European Affordable Housing Plan, the review of state aid rules on services of general economic interest in order to better facilitate support for affordable housing, the housing construction strategy, etc. and now announced for 16 December 2025). We would also highlight specific commitments in the Commission’s 2026 work programme, particularly the legislative proposal on a public procurement act (expected in Q2 2026); the legislative and non-legislative initiatives on short-term rentals (Q2 2026); the fair labour mobility package, consisting of legislative proposals for a European Social Security Pass, to strengthen the European Labour Authority, and on skills portability (Q3 2026); the ‘fairness package’, consisting of an ‘inter-generational fairness strategy’ (Q1 2026), an anti-poverty strategy (Q2 2026), and strengthening the European child guarantee (Q2 2026); and the gender equality strategy 2026-2030 (Q1 2026), amongst others. The Irish Presidency should also focus on ensuring the effectiveness of the European Fair Transition Observatory, which should become operational in early 2026, and the Commission’s report on the implementation of the EU occupational safety and health (OSH) Framework Directive and related directives, expected by mid-2026. On all of these, it should commit to legislation and measures that improves living and working conditions in accordance with Ireland’s treaty obligations (TFEU, Article 151) and oppose legislation and measures that run counter to this obligation, such as ‘simplification’ initiatives that, as the European Union Agency for Fundamental Rights’ 2025 report warns (pages 8-9), are presented as a means to alleviate as a means to alleviate regulatory burdens on businesses, a number of these changes – if adopted – risk weakening human rights’, especially for workers and consumers. Equally, it should not support proposal for a 28th Company Regime (expected Q1 2026) that encompasses labour law, as this would enable companies to circumvent national labour laws and collective agreements.

sector: All sectors and all areas of work
response_text: This could and would be done by promoting the adoption of legislation and strategies that strengthen and develop the EU framework on social dialogue including collective bargaining across a range of initiatives that will be on the Council’s agenda during the Irish Presidency. This should take account of the Court of Justice of the European Union’s 11th November 2025 ruling in Denmark’s legal challenge to the adequate minimum wages directive, which unequivocally upheld all of the Directive’s provisions promoting collective bargaining as fully compatible with the EU treaties. Again, we would justify this recommendation by referencing: The statement by EU leaders (including the Taoiseach) at the Porto Social Summit in May 2021, which stressed that Europe’s ‘social dimension, social dialogue and the active involvement of social partners are at the core of a highly competitive social market economy’; The Council Recommendation of 12 June 2023 on strengthening social dialogue, which acknowledges that ‘Member States with robust frameworks for social dialogue and a wide coverage of collective bargaining tend to have more competitive and resilient economies’; The European Council’s Strategic Agenda 2024-2029, which commits the EU and its Member States to ‘the aim of further strengthening social dialogue’. The Council’s guidelines for the employment policies of the Member States (December 2024), which consider social dialogue and collective bargaining as key to ensuring both economic competitiveness and social fairness. And the Commission’s recent consultation document for its first stage consultation of the European social partners on the Quality Jobs Act which states that, ‘Strong social dialogue and collective bargaining help improve working conditions, health and safety at work and mitigate labour shortages, contributing to a competitive, resilient and inclusive social market economy (p.14)’. Furthermore, the Letta Report emphasised that if Europe is to be effective in supporting businesses and quality jobs, there needs to be increased coordination and negotiation mechanisms between employers and it specifically identified social dialogue and collective bargaining as ‘unique tools for governments and social partners to find tailored and fair solutions (p.105), while the Draghi report stressed that competitiveness today is ‘less about relative labour costs and more about knowledge and skills embodied in the labour force’, explicitly warned against seeking to promote competitiveness by using wage repression to lower relative costs’ (p.13), and emphasized the importance of involving trade unions, ‘who have the ability to build the trust necessary to shape pathways of technology and skills upgrades that can truly benefit both companies and workers’ (p.274). The Irish Presidency should therefore promote measures that strengthens and develops the EU framework on social dialogue including collective bargaining, in particular through the new action plan to implement the European Pillar of Social Rights, the Quality Jobs Roadmap and the legislative proposal for a Quality Jobs Act and the legislative proposal for a public procurement act, and other relevant initiatives that will be on the Council’s agenda during Ireland’s presidency.

sector: All sectors and all areas of work
response_text: The Irish Presidency during its six-month term could best communicate the values and benefits of EU membership and create a sense of ownership over Ireland’s Presidency by strengthening and developing the EU’s framework on social dialogue and collective bargaining, for workers in Ireland and across Europe, as recommended above. We recognise and appreciate that the Irish Presidency will face an extremely busy agenda and a very heavy work load across a wide range of areas during its term. But we cannot under-emphasise the importance of the Irish Presidency addressing and being seen to address the main day-to-day challenges facing workers and their families, especially rising prices, inflation and the cost of living, which were identified as the most important issues at national level in 18 Member States and the second most important issue in seven Member States (including Ireland), according to the most recent Eurobarometer survey (Standard Eurobarometer 103) conducted in Spring 2025. Since the European Council’s Strategic Agenda 2024-2029 committed to address the ‘aspirations of our citizens’, the most effective way of Ireland doing this as far as workers are concerned would be by strengthening and developing the EU’s framework on social dialogue and collective bargaining during its Council Presidency. As the Council’s 2023 Recommendation on strengthening social dialogue points out, countries with ‘robust frameworks for social dialogue and a wide coverage of collective bargaining tend to have more competitive and resilient economies’.

sector: All sectors and all areas of work
response_text: ICTU would welcome the opportunity to have further and a regular engagement over the first half of 2026 with the Government on the development of its programme for Ireland’s Presidency, particularly after the publication over the coming weeks of the Cypriot Presidency programme, and later of the Joint Declaration on Legislative Priorities for 2026 of the European Parliament, the Council of the EU and the European Commission (the 2025 Joint Declaration was published in March 2025) as both of these will provide greater clarity as to what will be on the EU’s agenda in the second half of 2026 than is the case in December 2025. Such engagement would enable us to contribute effectively to the development of Ireland’s programme and to ensure that the Government is more aware of the key concerns and expectations of workers before it presents its programme just before the start of the Irish Presidency on 1 July 2026.

geography: Our feedback relates to local communities which we believe is applicable EU-wide.
response_text: Sustainable Skerries welcomes the invitation from the Government to contribute ideas to shape Ireland’s Presidency of the Council of the European Union in 2026. This process provides a vital opportunity for communities such as ours to help shape the Presidency’s priorities, by highlighting our perspectives and experiences as active citizens. We support making “Resilience” the main theme of the Presidency. Europe is dealing with major challenges such as climate change, environmental pressures, political uncertainty and rising social and economic stresses. In this context, resilience is essential. This suggestion aligns with the EU’s strategic agenda for a strong and secure Europe. For us, resilience is far more than preparing for crises or rebuilding after them. It is about cultivating the skills, networks and solidarity mechanisms that allow societies to transform, innovate and thrive. True resilience enables communities and countries not merely to withstand shocks, but to regenerate, adapt and shape a better future. Ireland’s Presidency offers an important opportunity to promote a broad, community-centred understanding of resilience. Through this consultation, communities like ours can help shape priorities in ways that reflect lived local experience and the realities of active citizens across Ireland. Our close cooperation with our local authority, Fingal County Council, has helped us achieve a lot. Together we have developed pollinator corridors, planted urban orchards, improved local infrastructure, run planning consultations, promoted active travel and delivered climate education. Support from Government and local grants has allowed us to grow our work and bring real benefits to our town. It is this partnership and collaborative spirit that is an essential ingredient of societal resilience. In our experience, resilience is both deeply local and inherently systemic. It depends on more than infrastructure or emergency response plans. It grows from everyday practices: shortening supply lines for food and energy, reducing waste, living in harmony with nature and strengthening the relationships and skills that bind communities together. Resilience relies fundamentally on social capital - trust, solidarity, shared knowledge and collective responsibility. To build resilience, communities and countries need inviting public spaces, places to meet and learn, access to practical skills, opportunities for young and old to learn together, reliable and accessible information and analysis, inclusive policy processes, and well-organised local support mechanisms. Investments in these areas help communities feel confident, informed and ready for whatever comes next. We encourage the Government to make community-led resilience a central part of Ireland’s Presidency agenda. This means integrating citizen and local group perspectives into policy agendas, supporting volunteer-led initiatives through grants and expert collaboration with local authorities, and prioritising long-term resilience over short-term crisis response. Key areas include responsive and inclusive local democratic processes, climate-adaptive infrastructure, decentralised renewable energy, sustainable and accessible transport, and financial mechanisms such as home retrofitting supports, incentives for local food production, and sustainability measures for businesses.

geography: Our feedback relates to local communities which we believe is applicable EU-wide.
response_text: At a broader level, Ireland should champion wellbeing economics, ensuring policy success is measured not only through GDP, but through the health, cohesion and sustainability of communities. We would like to see the Irish Presidency of the Council in 2026 focus on policy areas and legislative proposals that support local communities in becoming more resilient. Ireland already has inspiring examples of resilience in action. The Cloughjordan Ecovillage shows how a community can live sustainably. The Sustainable Energy Communities network brings local groups together to reduce energy use and increase efficiency. Community gardens and allotments across the country are helping people grow food, protect biodiversity, meet neighbours and strengthen local food security. In the economy, credit unions support local businesses and community projects, Local Enterprise Offices help small businesses become more sustainable, and Community Wealth Building projects aim to keep economic value within local communities. In housing, cost rental homes offer long-term affordable rents, and community-led housing groups provide secure homes that strengthen local connections. Retrofitting schemes help households cut energy costs and become more resilient to rising fuel prices. In health and wellbeing, community-based care is expanding, and social prescribing connects people with local activities and support mechanisms that improve health and reduce isolation. These examples show that resilience is already being built across Ireland in practical, community-driven ways that support people, nature and local economies. Resilience means giving communities the tools, confidence and support they need to adapt and flourish in a changing world. Ireland’s 2026 EU Presidency is a chance to highlight the role of communities as central actors in this effort. The more EU policy and legislation can support this, the better the outcomes for all EU citizens.

geography: Our feedback relates to local communities which we believe is applicable EU-wide.
response_text: See responses to Questions 1 and 2 above.

geography: Our feedback relates to local communities which we believe is applicable EU-wide.
response_text: There is an opportunity to create a sense of ownership amongst citizens over Ireland’s Presidency of the Council of the EU by linking the values and benefits of EU membership, and the theme and legislative priorities of the Presidency, to tangible actions and benefits for local communities. Sustainable Skerries is ready to contribute evidence, experience and practical insights to help ensure diverse local voices shape Ireland’s vision for 2026. We hope the final Presidency programme will reflect the resilience already growing in towns like ours and will help communities across Ireland and the EU continue to thrive.

geography: Rural and Urban, EU wide (and Global)
response_text: I think the three biggest threats at the moment are global instability from war, environmental degradation and destruction, and the disruption of family and community lives (including through homelessness, unemployment, addictions, or ill health) leading to loss of meaning, loss of community, and loss of health and happiness for individuals (which in turn leads to social unrest). Therefore, I think Ireland’s top three priorities should be: 1. to promote peace, do all it can to stop war (particularly in Gaza, but also in Ukraine, Sudan, and other parts of the world), including passing the Occupied Territories Bill; 2. do all it can to stop further degradation to the environment, by passing laws banning forever chemicals, and severely limiting plastics, pesticides, nitrates and other poisons, as well as limiting the use of fossil fuels. Instead it should support technologies that provide environmentally sustainable and healthful alternatives; 3. Promote people’s wellbeing, the building of small communities and social supports, and the development of small businesses and social enterprises by limiting the power of corporates. Themes – peace and justice; environmental repair not despair; people’s needs rather than business’s (focus on community and small local businesses instead – fostering ‘all for one and one for all’ attitudes).

geography: Rural and Urban, EU wide (and Global)
response_text: A global Europe and the rule of law: I think European defence is a priority, but this can only be achieved if there is equity and the EU stands up for the sovereignty of the law both in the EU and internationally. The EU must stand up for Gaza as well as for Ukraine. The authority of the International and European courts must recognized and adhered to. Israel cannot be trusted (nor the US). Since 1948 Israel has been stealing land belonging to Palestinians, with the intent of eventually getting rid of all the Palestinian people, which it is doing now. A global Europe should embrace respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms for all, and Ireland, as a neutral country, should put peace and justice at the top of its presidential agenda, using all lawful means in its power to achieve it. Furthermore, buying/selling ‘defence’ systems from/to Israel and the US gives them information and power to dictate national/European and international policy – this cannot continue. EU security information should not go outside of Europe, therefore, Ireland should prioritise the development of the capacities needed to house and process its data in Europe (e.g. European High Performance Computing Joint Undertaking, sufficient clean energy, water for cooling, and environmentally fair processes for decontaminating that water.). Supporting people and strengthening Europe’s social model: Rather than making it harder for migrants and asylum seekers seeking shelter in Europe, Ireland should focus on all the positives that they bring with them and how much they add to the European economy. They are very often hard-working, innovative, and entrepreneurial and can contribute to their new host country. Supporting people, strengthening our societies and our social model: Ireland should focus on establishing the framework for achieving climate neutrality, and on supporting children and young people to grow in healthy, safe, and clean environments. Therefore, Ireland should work on the proposed regulation to ensure that limits are set for all toxic materials and ‘forever’ chemicals are banned. Sustaining our quality of life: food security, water and nature: Ireland is well placed to lead on the Vision for Agriculture and Food, but it should not accept the nitrates derogation it has recently been given. Instead Ireland should withstand commercial interests and push them to find alternative solutions, such as using multi-species planting to capture nitrogen in the soil safely (using legumes for example). Therefore, Ireland should lead policy development on identifying, planning, implementing, and incentivizing uptake of better crop farming practices, and evaluating the outcomes. Millions of small farming projects should be encouraged across all regions to develop sustainable local farming practices in every EU country. The livestock and fishing industries also need to be more sustainable. Ireland should lead out on restricting fishing vessels from fishing close to the coast where fish reproduce, ban bottom trawling (which destroys the ecosystems on the seabed), and introduce at-sea monitoring (live cctv) of commercial fishing vessels to ensure compliance, to allow fish stocks to recover.

geography: Rural and Urban, EU wide (and Global)
response_text: The Council can empower people to make the choices that are best for themselves, their families, their communities, countries, Europe, and, ultimately, the world by guiding national policy to create and support environments, structures, and processes that make the best choices the easiest to make. The main goal of the Commission is to make Europe economically competitive and a good place for business. There is nothing wrong with that, until business objectives compete with social objectives. The Council can work to make sure that the needs and values of the member states and their peoples are not neglected when such conflicts arise, particularly when businesses can impact people’s health and wellbeing (with unhealthy commodities such as tobacco, alcohol, drugs, gambling, sugar-sweetened drinks, and ultra-processed foods, or by-products that poison the water/land/rivers/sea/air). Better regulation is not regulation that is easier for industry actors to comply with, it is regulation that safeguards the people first, and then secondly makes it easier for industry to comply. The Council must defend people’s right to a healthy environment and prevent industry from taking that away. Please keep this in mind every time industry actors promote the benefit of their product or their industry on the economy, and ask who benefits here? If it adversely impacts the environment, people’s health, happiness, work, relationships, or freedoms, is the opportunity worth the cost? If the people benefitting are not the ones bearing the cost and the impacts, is it fair?

geography: Rural and Urban, EU wide (and Global)
response_text: Have a party! Seriously, the benefit of being a member of the EU is the freedom we have, unity yet diversity. This needs to be celebrated. Ireland could start its presidency with a celebration of some sort. Unfortunately, by July there will probably be another heatwave across Europe, with more fires (and possibly floods too), otherwise I would suggest a European street party. Perhaps you could plan supports for people affected by these disasters next summer, maybe bring some of them over to Ireland for respite. I think asking people’s opinions over the next six months regarding what Ireland should do during its presidency is a good way to get people involved (not in forms like this, but in interviews on TV, social media, on the streets) and talking about it. Then see where those conversations take you/us. And pass the Occupied Territories Bill as an act of solidarity and people power to fight genocide.

sector: ICT – Cloud and software based business services

response_text: A pro-growth, pro-innovation Presidency building on the strengths of the single market and including industry engagement

sector: ICT – Cloud and software based business services
geography: EU wide and significant investor in Ireland
response_text: These comments are strictly within the digital arena. We would priorities the Omnibus bills to simplify, harmonize and embed existing regulations. In particular AI, Data Act, cybersecurity and environmental regulations should all be addressed. Given the number of extant regulations and directives awaiting implementation and enforcement this should be combined with regulatory restraint. A particular focus should be on clear demarcation of B2B and B2C in terms of simplifying and implementing existing regulations. This should be alongside a focus on ensuring regulations are updated and any new proposals are brought back into alignment with single market regulatory approaches and truly work to create a single market. There should also be a process for EU industry input and member state alignment on OECD global minimum tax and other regulatory affairs that ensures a level playing field for EU companies. Given the scope and potential of AI on EU productivity we strongly recommend significant industry involvement on the AI summit and look forward to engaging with the Irish Government on this key and timely event.

geography: We are a EU organizations/initiative, which is mainly conentrated on two objectives: First: the deficit of democracy within the architecture of EU institutions, Second: A European security architectur, which includes Russia and would establish long lasting peace with the Russian Federation.
response_text: Europe must find it´s way back to it´s core values and interests: Peace and international understanding by diplomacy, balance of interest as a non-aligned neutral “peace power”. First: The promise, that European integration would establish a long lasting peace order on the European continent, which would establish Europe mainly as a postimperial diplomatic power - instead of a military power - on the world stage. Second: That the institutions of the EU are build in a way, that they enable a democratic process, with a division of power as well as the representation of peoples interests in the decision process. Europe has to return to a political process, which is once again open and can be influenced by public debate, activism and elections.

organisation:

geography: We are a EU organizations/initiative, which is mainly conentrated on two objectives: First: the deficit of democracy within the architecture of EU institutions, Second: A European security architectur, which includes Russia and would establish long lasting peace with the Russian Federation.
response_text: We think as a neutral country and one of the co-initiators of the nuclear ban treaty Ireland can play a crucial role to bring Europe, our beautiful continent back to reason, and prevent it to be torn apart by power politics and destroyed by war and neo imperialism. Hopefully the Irish Presidency can help to avoid a new Cold War style division of the world in two competing camps. Europe needs a foreign policy which creates a balance between the United States in the West and the rising countries of the BRICS alliance. Such a balance would enable Europe to regain the sovereignty, which was lost due to the one-sided transatlantic orientation of recent decades. A future Europe should be decentralised, subsidiary, regional, social, neutral, post-colonial and post-imperial, committed to a global peace order of a multipolar world and a bridge and mediator between east and west.

response_text: In showing by example how neutrality and disarmament instead of re-armament is the way to earn trust and security. Ultimately, it is about trust – the bond between states, cultures and people that determines war and peace. It is about finding this trust even in the face of all conflicts and restoring the bond with the help of new concepts.
