European Peace Project, 
European Transcontinental Initiative
geography: We are a EU organizations/initiative, which is mainly conentrated on two objectives: First: the deficit of democracy within the architecture of EU institutions, Second: A European security architectur, which includes Russia and would establish long lasting peace with the Russian Federation.
response_text: For European integration to be successful and supported by the entire population of this continent, it needs a positive vision of peace, participation, equality, freedom and social justice as well as the unification of individual and social human rights. Europe once promised freedom from war, freedom from poverty, freedom of expression, freedom of religion... The EU now stands mainly for the free movement of goods, capital and services, for bureaucracy instead of democracy, for tech feudalism instead of equality and social security, and, fatally, more recently, for war. The attempt to enlarge or unite Europe under the banner of war and against Russia will be its downfall, as this is the exact opposite of Europe's original promise of peace. Unification can never be achieved against something, especially not against Russia, which is an integral part of Europe. It is crucial to find a way for open discussion with citizens and in societies across borders about the crucial questions which determine the future: How can we shape a new multipolar world peacefully? How can a diverse world work together and live in peace without getting lost in rivalries? How can we achieve understanding in diversity instead of division (“us” versus “them”)? How can we emancipate Europe from NATO, GAFA, and the dollar/US financial system so that we are free and autonomous in terms of economics and information and not bound in our international politics? How can we prevent a ‘national regression’ in the face of the multiple crises in Europe and strives for a fundamental rethinking of Europe's political structures, both internally and externally. How can we find a peaceful European integration with all countries on this continent and become a neutral, non-aligned mediator in international conflict? How can we rediscover and revive our fundamental European values and interests, because if we do so, we will find out what unites us as Europeans? The European Peace Project, together with the European Transcontinental Initiative, is a platform where reflection on these questions can take place.

organisation:
European Peace Project, 
European Transcontinental Initiative
geography: We are a EU organizations/initiative, which is mainly conentrated on two objectives: First: the deficit of democracy within the architecture of EU institutions, Second: A European security architectur, which includes Russia and would establish long lasting peace with the Russian Federation.
response_text: Please read our attached memorandum, which we wrote 20 years after the failure of the European Constitutional Treaty. Europe stands at a critical historical juncture and must fundamentally rethink its political project in order to survive as a meaningful global actor. The EU, conceived largely as a contractual and technocratic arrangement, lacks a living political identity and democratic foundation. To prevent its disintegration, Europe needs an emancipatory transformation equivalent to a core institutional renovation: it must free itself from unilateral transatlantic dependence, reconnect with its citizens, and pursue balanced cooperation with all global powers. Above all, Europe must rediscover its own intellectual, political, social, and economic traditions to help shape a just and peaceful 21st century. The continent risks being torn between defenders of a distant, technocratic EU and advocates of a return to the nation state. This polarization threatens to turn long-standing debates about reforming Europe into a rejection of Europe altogether. Conventional reforms are no longer sufficient to resolve the structural crisis of European democracy. Instead, Europe must renew its original post-war ambition as a peace project that transcended national conflicts and sought to establish a democratic, social, and decentralized political entity. Sadly there is broad decay in Europe’s political, economic, strategic, social, and cultural spheres. While EU institutions still exist, Europe’s intellectual foundations—rooted in Enlightenment, humanism, and universalism—are eroding. Postcolonial guilt narratives, postmodern individualism, and monopolistic capitalism have displaced Europe’s universal political spirit and its promises of democracy and peace. A pivotal missed opportunity followed the peaceful revolutions of 1989. The fall of the Berlin Wall offered the chance to build a sovereign, federal Europe reconciled with Russia and freed from Cold War divisions. This vision culminated in the draft European Constitution of 2004, which failed after referendums in France and the Netherlands. Without a constitution, the EU could not establish democratic legitimacy, civic unity, or sovereignty. As a result, Europe became unable to protect its citizens or its culture from globalization and subordinated the common good to powerful economic interests. Two foundational mistakes underpin this crisis. First, Europe assumed it could achieve emancipation alongside the United States, underestimating that a sovereign Europe contradicts US strategic interests. Second, Europe aligned culturally with American postmodernism rather than grounding unity in its own diverse cultural traditions. These errors contributed to renewed geopolitical conflict, including the war in Ukraine, and the abandonment of Europe’s peace narrative. Let us think beyond the current EU: democratic, sovereign, and culturally rooted. This vision centers on equal political rights for all European citizens—moving beyond “market citizenship”—while preserving decentralization and subsidiarity. Europe could become a republic in which legal equality coexists with cultural diversity, providing collective protection in a multipolar world. F Europe’s shared cultural heritage is crucial for it´s identity and unity —its revolutions, social movements, arts, philosophy, and humanist critique of technology—as the basis for renewed legitimacy and trust. A post-Atlantic Europe, committed to peace, open to dialogue with the Global South, and guided by a new humanism, is not a utopia but as a rediscovery of Europe’s enduring essence, waiting to be given political form.

Talamh Beo proposes the following overarching framing and three Presidency themes: Overarching phrase / slogan “A Living Europe: Fair Livelihoods, Living Land, Shared Future.” Theme 1 – Fair Livelihoods for Farmers and Rural Communities Across the EU, farmers face income insecurity, market volatility and rapid structural change. The Presidency should place decent livelihoods for small- and medium-scale farmers, farm workers and rural communities at the heart of the EU agenda. This means prioritising fair prices, strong social protections, and policies that enable people to remain on the land and in rural areas. A Presidency focus on fair livelihoods would align Ireland with the growing European movement for a redistributive CAP and stronger market regulation. Theme 2 – A Just Green Transition through Agroecology The European Green Deal and the Strategic Agenda 2024–2029 require a farming model that can deliver simultaneously on climate, biodiversity, water and food security. The Presidency should highlight agroecology as a central pathway for the CAP post-2027 and for wider EU policies on soil health, nature restoration, climate adaptation and resilience. This includes supporting diversified farming systems, reduced dependence on synthetic inputs, and a transition away from extractive, export-oriented models. Theme 3 – Food Sovereignty, Democracy and Local Food Systems Citizens are increasingly concerned about food affordability, quality, and origin. The Presidency should foreground Food Sovereignty as a democratic framework for food systems – strengthening local and regional food economies, short supply chains, and public participation in decision-making. This links directly to the EU’s cohesion, health, social inclusion and security agendas, and can be reflected in the work of multiple Council formations (AGRIFISH, ENVI, EPSCO, GAC). Food Sovereignty is the democratic foundation for a fair and sustainable food system, linking farmers’ rights, seed autonomy, and community-led food distribution Together these themes would allow Ireland to act as an honest broker while still offering a positive, future-oriented vision: an EU where land, livelihoods and democracy are central to the green transition, and where rural communities are recognised as key partners in delivering Union-wide objectives.

From Talamh Beo’s perspective, the Irish Presidency should focus on the following priority areas within the Council’s 2026 work: 1. CAP Post-2027 Orientation (AGRIFISH / ENVI / ECOFIN) Lead early Council debates on fundamental CAP reform, including a move away from uncoupled, hectare-based payments toward “public money for public goods”, targeted to environmental and social outcomes Promote mandatory capping and degressivity of direct payments, prioritising small- and medium-scale family farms and active farmers. Ensure that the Council conclusions on CAP post-2027 explicitly reference agroecology and diversified farming systems as key instruments for delivering Green Deal and biodiversity objectives. 2. Market Regulation and Fair Prices (AGRIFISH / COMPET) Strengthen the Common Market Organisation (CMO): explore tools for production management, crisis reserves and strategic stocks to stabilise prices and ensure cost-covering farm incomes. Without strong market regulation tools, farmers are structurally exposed to price volatility and corporate abuses. Strengthening the CMO is essential for restoring farmers’ bargaining power. Advance Council work on implementation and possible revision of the Unfair Trading Practices Directive, with stronger enforcement, transparency and penalties. 3. Food Sovereignty and Local Food Systems (AGRIFISH / ENVI / EPSCO / GAC) Highlight best practice on local food policy frameworks that recognise local food producers, short supply chains, and local processing infrastructure. Support legislative and policy initiatives that increase EU production of fruit, vegetables and protein crops, reducing import dependence and enhancing food autonomy, including specific income supports for Local Food Producers. Prioritise generational renewal and land access in rural development and cohesion discussions, including land observatories, support for new entrants and tools to address land concentration, such as and EU Directive on Land to address speculation, concentration and artificialisation, and to guarantee young and new farmers access to land and credit. 4. Trade and Global Solidarity (FAC / TRADE / AGRIFISH) Use the Presidency to steer Council discussions towards coherent trade policies that do not undermine EU climate, biodiversity and social goals. Create space for a political discussion on trade deals such as MERCOSUR, and on reforms to prevent agricultural dumping and to support food sovereignty in partner countries. Trade agreements such as MERCOSUR undermine small farms, depress prices, and accelerate environmental destruction, contradicting EU objectives for equality and climate action.

The work of the Council during Ireland’s Presidency can deliver substantial positive impact if it pursues an integrated approach that connects farm incomes, environmental sustainability and community resilience. For people and communities, prioritising agroecology and local food systems can: Improve access to healthy, affordable food, particularly in low-income and peripheral regions. Create meaningful, place-based employment in farming, processing, distribution, tourism and care for the land. Enhance public health by supporting diets rich in fresh, minimally processed food. Strengthen social cohesion, as citizens reconnect with local farmers, landscapes and cultures. For businesses, especially SMEs and family farms, a rebalanced policy agenda can: Provide more predictable prices and income stability through improved market regulation. Support diversification and innovation (e.g. horticulture, mixed farming, value-added processing, community-supported agriculture). Reduce exposure to volatile global commodity chains and input markets by supporting soil health, on-farm biodiversity and circular use of nutrients and energy. For the EU as a whole, these priorities would: Contribute directly to climate mitigation and adaptation, biodiversity protection, water quality and soil health. Increase food system resilience to shocks (climate events, conflicts, pandemics). Help address citizens’ concerns about fairness, concentration of power and democratic control over essential resources such as land, water and seeds. Analysis shows that small and medium farms are the backbone of rural employment, biodiversity and cultural identity. Policies that protect these farms offer the greatest return in terms of resilience, social cohesion and climate mitigation. An Irish Presidency that deliberately links fair livelihoods, living landscapes and strong communities can help rebuild trust in the European project, particularly in rural regions where citizens often feel left behind by globalisation and past policy choices.

Ireland’s Presidency offers a strong opportunity to connect EU institutions with everyday life, especially in rural areas. Talamh Beo suggests: People-centred storytelling Highlight real stories of farmers, food workers, communities and youth from across the EU who are building resilient local food systems, restoring ecosystems and sustaining rural life Showcase the alternative systems already put in place by communities across Europe to produce and distribute food in short supply chains, and the accompanying research which demonstrates their many benefits Local and regional dialogues Organise Presidency-branded public forums and town-hall conversations in rural towns and urban neighbourhoods, co-hosted with local authorities, farmers’ groups, youth and community organisations, to engage discussions on Food Sovereignty Integrate these dialogues into formal Presidency events (e.g. informal AGRIFISH, ENVI or GAC meetings) so that Ministers hear directly from citizen Visible, participatory events in Ireland Host accessible Presidency events on food, farming and rural futures that are open to the public as well as decision-makers, not just closed diplomatic meetings Incorporate culture, arts and heritage – for example, food festivals, farm visits, storytelling, and local markets – to show the EU as part of daily life Support organisations already active in Ireland on Food Sovereignty and Agroecology during the presidency Youth and schools engagement Develop Presidency education packs for schools focusing on EU decision-making and food systems, including visits, debates and exchanges between schools in different Member States. Digital engagement and transparency Provide clear, plain-language updates on Presidency negotiations and outcomes, explaining why they matter for households, farmers, workers and small businesses By making food, land and community central to its communications, Ireland can show citizens that the EU is not an abstract bureaucracy but a shared project shaping the future of their local places.

Talamh Beo is a farmer- and citizen-led organisation working for Food Sovereignty and an agroecological transition in Ireland and Europe. We are the Irish member of the international peasant movement La Via Campesina, representing small-scale farmers, land-based workers and rural communities. Alongside this form you can find our Local Food Policy Framework, which proposes institutional recognition and supports for local food producers and short supply chains; We recognise that the Presidency must act as an impartial chair and honest broker. Our intention is not to promote narrow national interests but to offer a coherent, people-centred vision that responds to shared challenges across the Union: climate breakdown, biodiversity collapse, rural decline, food insecurity, and growing mistrust in institutions. We believe Ireland is uniquely well placed – culturally, historically and politically – to lead a European conversation on how fair livelihoods, living land and democratic participation can underpin the EU’s Strategic Agenda 2024–2029. We would welcome opportunities to contribute further, including to Presidency events that bring farmers and citizens into dialogue with EU decision-makers.

Focus on holding Israel accountable for committing an ongoing genocide. Europe must boycott, sanction and divest from this apartheid state, via trade (including services), educational and institutional links, research and development, culture and sports Ramp down militarism and spending on the military industrial complex. Only the warmongers, who profit obscenely, want war. The people do not. Stop allowing migrants and refugees to die in The Mediterranean. Stop criminalising people who help those migrants. Improve migrant processing centres across Europe, with a focus on dignity and humanity.

End the EU-Israel Association Agreement. Trade benefits for a supremacist genocidal state must not continue. In fact, there should be no trade. Europe should not pass CETA. The approval of it this week in the Dáil is an absolute betrayal of the Irish people. It will be detrimental to all of Europe’s citizens to put the profits of corporations ahead of people’s rights and well-being.

The Council, and the Irish government could actually listen to the people and fulfil our demands. However, never has it been clearer that this government operates independently of the wishes of the people. The most positive impact would be to stop spending on war and start spending on health, education and housing . This must be extended to all inhabitants of Europe, no matter what their current legal status.

If this government and the EU policies actually reflected the will of the people, we would automatically have that sense of ownership. Currently, the EU’s values seem to be gaslighting a genocide, putting corporations’ profits ahead of people’s standard of living, and warmongering. The EU would need Israeli levels of hasbara funding to attempt to communicate that these “values” are positive. Reflect the will of the people, particularly in relation to Israel, and the people will find that sense of ownership. Economy and profit isn’t everything. Put humanity first.

Ireland’s Presidency in 2026 should foreground Community Stewardship for a Resilient Europe—a theme that reflects the EU’s ambitions on climate, biodiversity, food security, cohesion and democratic engagement. This aligns directly with the lived experience of place-based organisations such as the Burrenbeo Trust and it’s pan European Farming for Nature (FFN) initiative, which demonstrate that the most enduring climate and nature solutions come from empowered, informed communities. Three overarching thematic priorities are proposed: A nature positive Europe through community stewardship Place-based, community led models (such as Burrenbeo’s Heritage Keepers and Hare’s Corner programmes) demonstrate how citizens can become active custodians of their environment. These participatory approaches deliver measurable biodiversity gains, stronger local economies, and more resilient rural development. The Presidency should champion EU support for local stewardship initiatives, especially within AGRIFISH and ENVI Council configurations. A fair and future proof agricultural system led by farmers The Farming for Nature programme offers a proven European model for positive farmer recognition, peer to peer learning, and practical biodiversity action. The multi-country network (Ireland, Austria, Lithuania) shows the scalability of this constructive, non polarising approach. Elevating farmer led innovation aligns with the Strategic Agenda’s call for resilient agriculture, balanced land management, and strengthened rural cohesion. A participatory, people centred Europe To address disconnection from EU institutions, the Presidency should highlight models that activate citizen engagement, particularly in rural and peripheral regions. Burrenbeo’s community festivals, placebased learning, and youth programmes demonstrate how cultural heritage and environmental care can rebuild trust, identity and social inclusion. These priorities would allow Ireland to lead with integrity, drawing from successful home grown European facing models while serving the needs of all Member States.

Based on the EU Strategic Agenda and the Commission’s 2026 Work Programme, Ireland’s Presidency could make meaningful progress in the following areas: Implementation of the Nature Restoration Law (NRL) Ireland is well placed to guide Member States in developing locally grounded, socially supported restoration pathways. Burrenbeo’s work shows how community engagement accelerates restoration and reduces conflict. Ireland could champion EU guidance that integrates community led monitoring, local education, and farmer involvement. Strengthening agri-environment schemes through farmer networks The FFN model (now operational across Ireland, Austria and Lithuania) demonstrates how positive recognition, ambassador networks, and farm walks drive adoption of biodiversity actions. Legislative work under AGRIFISH could integrate “farmer-to-farmer knowledge exchange” as a recognised pillar within CAP strategic plans. Rural development and social cohesion The Presidency could foreground landscape level partnerships, such as Burrenbeo’s community stewardship programmes, as models for the EU’s Long Term Vision for Rural Areas. Support for bottomup governance structures would strengthen community resilience and accelerate rural participation in climate and biodiversity transitions. Youth and Education for Sustainability Through the EYCS configuration, Ireland could progress initiatives supporting place-based learning, heritage education, citizen science and youth leadership, areas where Burrenbeo has decades of practical expertise. Embedding environmental literacy into EU programmes would foster long-term civic ownership of EU goals.

Ireland can ensure the Presidency is genuinely people centred by promoting models that empower citizens and farmers as co-creators of EU solutions. The Burrenbeo and FFN experiences show that when individuals feel ownership over their landscape, change becomes lasting, cost-effective and socially supported. Ireland could maximise impact in the following ways: Elevate real examples of community and farmer leadership across Europe Through Presidency events and Council discussions, Ireland can highlight practical case studies such as FFN ambassador farm walks, Austrian biodiversity outreach, Lithuanian farm plans, and Ireland’s learnercentred community stewardship programmes to demonstrate what success looks like on the ground. Strengthen EU support for participatory governance Council work could promote mechanisms that empower local actors: stewardship-based schemes, community monitoring, farmer mentor networks, and landscape partnerships. These ensure EU policies deliver tangible results for people and businesses. Foster cross-border rural innovation networks The existing FFN tri-country partnership is a working blueprint for how rural actors can share knowledge, co-create solutions and build European solidarity. The Irish Presidency could support similar networks in other Member States, creating durable peer-learning structures with low cost and high impact. Make climate and biodiversity policies socially inclusive The Presidency can champion approaches that are not punitive or divisive but motivational and solutions oriented. FFN’s ambassador model, where farmers lead by example, build trust and communicate results, shows how policy goals can align with farmer pride and community cohesion. The networks and sense of collective action developed through programmes such as the Hare’s Corner and Heritage Keepers further speak to the social role of environmental and climate actions.

Ireland has a unique opportunity to demonstrate the EU’s relevance through stories of local communities succeeding with EU support. The following approaches are suggested: 1. Showcase citizen and farmer-led European success stories Use Presidency events, digital communication, and local engagement to highlight examples like: FFN ambassadors improving biodiversity while building thriving farm enterprises; Burrenbeo led community festivals and learning programmes that foster pride of place; Austrian and Lithuanian partners developing films, farm plans, kitchen-table discussions, and outreach activities. These stories make the EU tangible, human, and relatable. Bring Presidency conversations into communities Ireland could: host Presidency linked farm walks and community events, use local media, schools, and NGOs to share “EU in my Place” stories, involve youth groups, volunteers, and local heritage organisations. Promote a positive narrative of Europe as a partner in resilience By emphasising community stewardship, sustainable food systems, and rural futures, Ireland can communicate the EU as a supportive, collaborative space that strengthens local identity rather than diluting it. Engage mainstream and social media using ambassador voices Ireland can model innovative solutions, using ambassadors, digital storytelling, local festivals, and cocreated content that showcases the EU as relevant to daily life.

Ireland is in a powerful position to provide European leadership rooted in its own success stories. Organisations like Burrenbeo Trust and it’s Farming for Nature network have pioneered forms of community participation and farmer-led environmental action that have already gained traction across Europe. A European expansion is underway, with: Austria: ambassador films, public outreach, farm walks, awards events with public participation, and a growing nomination process; Lithuania: farm biodiversity plans, farm walks, online discussions, farmer engagement materials, and long-term LIFE funding proposals; • Ireland: 120+ ambassadors, extensive peer-to-peer mentorship, a major annual national festival, and farmer-led biodiversity action. These initiatives demonstrate a practical, scalable pathway for delivering the EU’s climate, food system, and rural development goals in a way that strengthens community resilience and democratic engagement. Ireland’s Presidency can use these working models to champion a shift from policy for communities to policy with and by communities—a principle that can underpin a more innovative, cohesive and futureorientated European Union.

Cardiovascular health will be a major policy theme in the field of healthcare policy during the Irish Presidency. The European Commission is expected to present its EU Cardiovascular Health Plan on 16 December 2025. Consequently, the Irish Presidency will lead efforts in the Council resulting from the Cardiovascular Health Plan. Blood and Beyond would like to see the Irish Presidency help in bringing attention to the relationship between poor health, caused by anaemia, iron deficiency, blood loss, and coagulopathy, and cardiovascular diseases. Anaemia, for example, is the leading cause of poor blood health worldwide. Only in Europe, more than 28 million people are estimated to suffer anaemia. In the context of cardiovascular diseases, anaemia is a neglected but major cardiovascular risk amplifier that worsens cardiovascular disease outcomes and increases mortality. There is clear evidence linking untreated anaemia to heart failure, ischemic events, and perioperative complications. As Blood and Beyond, we believe that blood health optimization (including anaemia prevention and treatment) should be included among modifiable determinants to be looked at in the “EU Cares for Your Heart” Flagship initiative. We advocate for stronger actions on early diagnosis and screening, as early diagnosis of anaemia reduces hospitalisations and improves cardiovascular outcomes. We support the inclusion of haemoglobin and iron status as health check indicators in the upcoming 2026 Council Recommendation on health checks. As regards care pathways, the current state of play is characterized by fragmented care pathways and lack of standardization. Against this backdrop, an effective, standardized vehicle to improve blood health is Patient Blood Management (PBM). PBM is an evidence-based, patient-centred standard of care endorsed by the World Health Organization. EU work to implement the objectives of the upcoming EU Cardiovascular Health Plan should consider the implementation of PBM programmes to improve quality of care, reduce transfusion-related complications arising from postoperative recovery, and lower healthcare costs. Another important element to consider in the implementation of the EU Cardiovascular Health Plan is ensuring health equity. The EU is working to reduce inequalities in health. Against this backdrop, it is worth emphasizing that anaemia prevalence is much higher among women of reproductive age, the elderly, low-income populations, and chronic disease patients. Therefore, optimising the population’s blood health should be a goal in the implementation of cardiovascular health actions at the EU and national levels. Apart from addressing Blood Health in the context of the policy work on Cardiovascular Health, we would like the Irish Presidency to also give greater attention to the topic of Blood Health in the broader framework of non-communicable diseases and as a standalone issue to tackle. All in all, the Irish Presidency has a strategic opportunity to elevate the blood health in the EU policy agenda, starting from the upcoming EU work on cardiovascular diseases.

Strengthening a Social Europe should be one of the high-level thematic priorities of Ireland’s Presidency. This covers many areas in which Ireland can be a leader and role model. Our submission will focus on education as a key aspect of a Social Europe, and specifically on adult literacy education. Access to education, training and lifelong learning is a right enshrined in the European Pillar of Social Rights, and Article 9 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union says the Union will promote a “high level” of education and training for all EU citizens. Education, training and lifelong learning also enable a host of other rights to be realised. In Ireland today, 21% of adults have literacy needs, 25% have numeracy needs (both figures are from the OECD Survey of Adult Skills 2023), and 27% have digital literacy needs (Digital Economy and Society Index 2023). This means that these adults don’t have the level of reading, maths or digital skills considered necessary to fully participate and reach their potential in today’s society. Across EU countries, the level of literacy need ranges from 12% in Sweden to 42% in Portugal. The level of numeracy need ranges from 12% in Finland and Sweden to 40% in Portugal (OECD Survey of Adult Skills 2023). And the average level of digital literacy need in the EU is 44%, ranging from 17% in the Netherlands to 72% in Romania (Digital Economy and Society Index 2023). Literacy and numeracy needs are associated with poor health, low life satisfaction, unemployment, low incomes and low social trust. A person with literacy or numeracy needs is less likely to believe that they have a say in what the government does (OECD Survey of Adult Skills 2023). These facts have obvious implications for the wellbeing of millions of Europeans, as well as the EU’s ambitions to be a democratic, secure and competitive Europe (EU Strategic Agenda 2024-2029). The EU’s Strategic Agenda 2024-2029 commits to “leaving no one behind” (p2). In terms of education and skills, this means putting policy attention on adults who have had very poor educational experiences and now need support to develop their basic literacy, numeracy or digital skills. The Strategic Agenda 2024-2029 specifically states that “we will invest in people’s skills, training and education throughout their lives” (p9). Ironically, adults with low levels of educational attainment are currently the least likely to engage in lifelong learning (OECD Trends in Adult Learning 2025, and SOLAS Lifelong Learning Amongst Adults in Ireland 2025). Their rights are not being realised; and they need to be targeted if Member States are going to meet the target of 60% of adults to be in training by 2030 (European Pillar of Social Rights Action Plan). To conclude, we would like to see a strong commitment to a Social Europe in Ireland’s Presidency, with a focus on the furthest behind in education. Ireland is known for its highly educated population, and it was one of only two countries (with Estonia) to increase its level of adult learning between the OECD Surveys of Adult Skills in 2012 and 2023 (OECD Trends in Adult Learning 2025). The land of saints and scholars should continue to lead and to strive for truly equal educational opportunities.

In the context that we have set out above, the following should be a focus of work for the Irish Presidency: Finishing, launching and beginning implementation of the 2030 Roadmap on the Future of Digital Education and Skills, which we understand is expected in the second half of 2026. The Roadmap should include lifelong learning of digital skills. We also recommend that the latest version of the European Digital Competence Framework (DigComp 3.0) is integrated into the roadmap and associated guidance/promotions. Advancing existing EU initiatives for inclusive lifelong learning, such as the New European Agenda for Adult Learning (NEAAL) 2021-2030, the Union of Skills and the associated Action Plan on Basic Skills (both 2025). The Irish Presidency should aim to raise awareness of the need for these programmes (with reference to the literacy and lifelong learning statistics discussed under Question 1) and to encourage Member States to embed these programmes in their education/skills policy. European Democracy Shield (2025) – As President, Ireland can promote literacy, numeracy, digital literacy and media literacy of citizens as essential defences against misinformation/disinformation. This could tie in with the Adult Literacy for Life media literacy campaign. Making sure the European Social Fund after 2027 is sufficient, transparent and accessible in practice by civil society organisations. Skills and Lifelong Learning is currently one of the five priority areas of Ireland’s European Social Fund programme, EIST (Employment, Inclusion, Skills and Training) – this should be maintained.

To have the most substantial positive impact, the Council must clearly communicate the work it is doing for people, businesses and communities across the EU. We note that simplification is a central aim of the Commission Work Programme 2026. We propose that simplification is not just about the systems that have to be navigated, but it’s also about the language that is used within them. Ireland could lead by example and put the Commission’s guidance on plain language into practice as President of the Council of the European Union. A “Plain language Presidency” would mean Applying plain language principles to all internal and external communications around the Presidency (policy documents, meeting notes, correspondence, press releases, and so on) Highlighting that Ireland is doing this, and why Challenging other Member States to do the same Connecting with international networks such as the Plain Language Association International Network (PLAIN) or the International Plain Language Federation Sharing learnings from the experience with EU institutions, with other departments in Ireland’s civil service, and so on Keeping good practice going beyond the end of 2026 The benefits of Ireland leading a plain language Presidency include, but aren’t limited to: Better public understanding of Ireland’s Presidency and the workings of the EU as a whole Less risk of misinformation/disinformation spreading about the Presidency Inclusion of marginalised citizens (such as people with literacy needs or whose first language is not English) Smoother, more efficient administration of the Presidency Easier translation into other EU languages

As set out in our answer to Question 3, a plain language Presidency would have a very positive impact on • Communicating the values and benefits of EU membership • Creating a sense of ownership of Ireland’s Presidency Non-written forms of communication should also be used. For example, we have found that local radio is very effective for engaging adults with literacy needs. It is also important to share personal stories – what does the EU, or Ireland’s Presidency of the EU, mean to real individuals?

We understand that Ireland will host a programme of events as part of its Presidency. We have been in touch with colleagues in the European Basic Skills Network (EBSN) about the possibility of holding their annual conference in Dublin during the Presidency. They are open to this and we would be happy to progress it further if the idea is welcomed by the Department of Foreign Affairs and/or Department of Further and Higher Education, Research, Innovation and Science. EBSN is an association of stakeholders in basic skills policy for adults, which advocates at EU level. Its “vision is to make sure that all inhabitants of Europe have the level of basic skills and competencies they need for lifelong learning, social and professional inclusion and active citizenship” (EBSN Charter, p2). By hosting the EBSN annual conference in 2026, Ireland would be showing its commitment to key EU goals, policies and values. We are happy to be contacted in relation to any aspect of this submission.

For its 2026 EU Presidency, Ireland should prioritise sustainable energy, rural resilience, and communitycentred governance. In particular, the rapid scaling of biomethane under REPowerEU highlights the urgent need for independent impact assessments, strict environmental safeguards, and oversight of public subsidies to prevent unsustainable industrial-scale biogas projects. Ireland can lead by embedding legally binding rules on feedstock use, digestate management, and spatial planning, ensuring local communities have a real voice in decision-making rather than bearing disproportionate social and environmental costs. By championing a model that balances climate, biodiversity, and rural development goals, Ireland can set a European benchmark for fair, sustainable energy transitions. Prioritising transparency, equitable benefitsharing, and preventative regulation will help avoid repeating mistakes seen elsewhere in Europe, reinforcing trust in decarbonisation policies. These thematic priorities will position Ireland as a leader in creating energy strategies that are both ambitious and socially responsible.

The European Commission’s REPowerEU action plan has set biomethane production on a course of massive upscale as part of efforts to increase EU energy independence, fixing a target of 35 billion cubic meters (bcm) per year by 2030 – up from 4,1 bcm in 2023. However, until this day, no Impact Assessment was carried out on the target. As biomethane production continues to grow rapidly both in Ireland and Europe (with a currently 21% year-over-year growth), so do concerns about its associated environmental and social risks as well as the irresponsible use of taxpayers money. While biogas production from sludge or collecting the gas that is produced in landfills is appropriate, there are particular concerns about the effects of large-scale biogas production on the use of limited agricultural land, the continuation of polluting industrial animal production, harm to local communities, and the effects of methane leaking from biogas facilities. Further concerns arise when looking closer at promoted use cases for biomethane such as heating or transport which are often inefficient, expensive, and lock Europe into existing fossil infrastructure. The Irish Presidency should therefore prioritize conducting an independent, interdisciplinary impact assessment to evaluate the feasibility and sustainability of this target, ensuring it aligns with climate, biodiversity, and rural community goals. Emphasis must be placed on implementing strict economic, environmental, and social safeguards for biogas and biomethane production. With reference to the Commission’s 2026 Work Programme as well as the wider EU Strategic Agenda that highlights the need to secure Europe’s energy independence, we therefore encourage the Irish Presidency to: Advocate for an independent impact assessment of the EU’s 35 bcm biomethane target, as a prerequisite to develop further any expansion of biomethane production as part of relevant policy files in 2026, such as the Circular Economy Act, Bioeconomy Strategy, Livestock Strategy, Energy Union Governance Upgrade, and Common Agricultural Policy. This includes prioritizing truly sustainable feedstocks, efficient use cases, and avoiding lock-ins of fossil infrastructure. Include the voices of local communities in the debate. In order to expand biomethane production rapidly, the 2025 REPowerEU roadmap foresees a “tripartite contract to better address the diverging needs in different areas of the EU and include national and local stakeholders”. However, a focus has been set on facilitating dialogue between the EU Commission, EU Member States’ governments as well as industrial stakeholders; and no commitment has been made to give a role to local communities themselves that are affected by such projects. In line with its “peoplecentred” approach, the Presidency should therefore intensify its efforts to give the Irish people and local communities across Europe a greater say in the development of fair and sustainable biomethane strategies. Scrutinise public subsidy schemes for unsustainable biomethane production. This is critical to prevent perverse incentives that undermine the EU’s climate, food security, and energy independence goals. Current subsidies often favour industrial-scale biogas projects reliant on unsustainable feedstocks - such as manure from factory farming or energy crops competing with food production - which lock in polluting practices as well as animal welfare violations, and divert resources from truly circular solutions. Without strict oversight, these subsidies risk distorting markets, inflating demand for unsustainable livestock farming, and sidelining local, communityled projects that deliver genuine environmental and social benefits.

Ireland’s presidency provides a unique opportunity to develop and promote a gold standard indigenous biogas industry that is sized and scaled to meet community needs. Learning from EU countries with an established biogas industry, Ireland can avoid the pitfalls of social acceptance that are consistently documented as barriers to bioenergy projects across the EU (Mancini & Raggi, 2022). Current regulatory gaps and weak planning assessments underestimate the cumulative impacts on rural infrastructure. Public health and safety questions about hazardous gas storage, particular emissions and emergency service access are heightened when regulatory oversight is perceived as reactive rather than preventative. Research has highlighted that digestate management and changes in feedstock mixes are critical risk vectors that demand much stronger regulation than is currently applied (Piadeh et. al, 2024). Ireland, through its presidency, can set the standard by developing industry-specific planning regulations that include community engagement at its core. The National Biomethane Strategy points directly to a highly industrialised model aimed at rapid development across rural Ireland. Within this model, revenue accrues to outside multi-national agriinvestors while costs are borne by host communities in terms of road damage, odour, environmental degradation, and reduced property values. Communities demand transparent environmental impact assessments, accessible monitoring data and enforceable operating limits. The development of industryspecific planning regulations aligned with benefit-sharing mechanisms has the potential to provide a blueprint for use across the EU, while maintaining community engagement and the highest environmental standards. Meaningful community engagement, spatial planning that respects local carrying capacity, strict feedstock limits, alongside legally binding digestate management plans, are safeguards that would increase local acceptance. Rapid roll-out risks polarising rural communities, undermining trust in decarbonisation policy, and producing environmental and social harms that outweigh local benefits. Ireland has an opportunity through its EU presidency to either lead and develop new industry standards or to repeat mistakes already impacting the rural communities and the environment across Europe.

Ireland’s 2026 Presidency should champion a vision of Europe where people living with rare diseases experience timely diagnosis, coordinated care and equitable access to innovation regardless of geography. Grounded in patient partnership, Ireland should promote three mutually reinforcing thematic priorities: (1) Research-active health systems as a pillar of care for rare diseases. Ireland is well placed to lead a European shift toward integrating research, innovation and clinical trials directly into the care pathway. For rare diseases, research is not optional; it is the mechanism by which new diagnostics, therapies and models of care become possible. Ireland should elevate this as a central European principle: that people with rare diseases must have seamless access to research opportunities as part of routine care, and that healthcare systems more generally embrace research and promote innovation for the benefit of all European citizens and the wider European ecosystem and industrial base. (2) A European framework for timely, equitable access to diagnosis, specialised services and therapies. People living with rare diseases experience systemic inequities driven by fragmented care pathways and inconsistent access across Member States. Ireland should prioritise addressing the diagnostic odyssey, strengthening cross-border networks, ensuring sustainable access to orphan medicines, and advancing a coordinated European Action Plan for Rare Diseases. This framework should commit Europe to reducing unacceptable delays in diagnosis, scaling specialist expertise, improving access to transformative therapies and driving research & development of new innovations across the fields of cell & gene therapies, medical devices, diagnostic tools and data/AI enabled care pathways. (3) Data, networks and workforce capability as foundational enablers. The Presidency should emphasise interoperable registries, real-world evidence, genomic data infrastructures and the long-term sustainability of European Reference Networks (ERNs). Equally, it should promote the need for a highly trained, mobile workforce capable of providing specialist rare-disease care across Member States. These are prerequisites for equitable access, high-quality research and resilient health systems. These priorities reflect Ireland’s strengths in patient partnership, translational science and life sciences leadership. They also align with Europe’s emerging consensus that supporting people with rare diseases is both a moral imperative and a strategic opportunity for European health, innovation and competitiveness.

From a rare-disease and patient-centred perspective, Ireland should focus its Presidency on targeted initiatives that can deliver meaningful, lasting impact: (1) A time-bound European Action Plan for Rare Diseases. Ireland should seek political agreement to commence and structure an EU Action Plan addressing diagnosis, care coordination, access to therapies, research integration and long-term data strategy. This Action Plan would help reduce current fragmentation and provide a coherent, multi-sector framework for accelerating progress across Member States. (2) Embedding rare-disease priorities within the EU Life Sciences Strategy and regulatory agenda. Ireland should ensure that reforms to clinical trials, regulatory pathways and incentives explicitly serve people living with rare disease. Work should focus on reducing barriers to paediatric and rare/ultra-rare trials, encouraging multi-country clinical trials, adaptive pathways and improving predictability for innovators without compromising equity and safety. driving collaboration and adoption of screening and diagnostic tools to shorten the diagnostic journey for people living with rare diseases, and in particular adopting a standardised approach to newborn screening assessment and recommendation. (3) Strengthening ERNs, workforce mobility and specialist centres. Ireland should pursue Council conclusions promoting the sustainability of ERNs, improving cross-border referral mechanisms and supporting workforce development through training, accreditation and mobility frameworks. (4) Alignment of access and reimbursement mechanisms. Ireland should encourage progress on joint clinical assessments, coordinated HTA processes, joint negotiation and procurement and structured dialogue between industry, regulators, payers and patient groups to shorten delays to treatment access. (5) Delivering interoperable rare-disease data systems and trusted research environments. The Presidency should support deliverables that enable secure, cross-border use of rare-disease registries, genomic data and real-world evidence. This includes defining minimum standards, FAIR principles and conditions for safe data reuse for research and regulatory decision-making. The overarching objective must be to translate political commitments into measurable, near-term actions that advance equity, accelerate innovation and materially improve outcomes for people living with rare diseases.

Ireland can maximise impact by grounding its Presidency in the lived reality of people with rare diseases and by promoting cross-sector collaboration that delivers tangible change. First, anchor Council work in deliverables that improve patient outcomes. Measurable objectives—reducing diagnostic delay, increasing research participation, strengthening ERN utilisation—will provide clarity to Member States and industry while focusing EU cooperation on what matters most to patients. Second, champion a whole-of-government and whole-of-ecosystem approach. Rare diseases sit at the intersection of health, research, education, enterprise and social policy. Ireland should model integrated governance by convening ministers and stakeholders across these domains, thereby creating an enabling environment for research and innovation and driving improvements in outcomes for people living with rare diseases. Third, launch practical demonstrator initiatives. Ireland can lead EU-level pilots that provide immediate value to patients while generating evidence for wider EU implementation. Such demonstrators attract investment, reduce regulatory uncertainty and build confidence among innovators. Fourth, mobilise investment and regulatory alignment. By linking regulatory reforms with funding streams across Horizon Europe successors, EU4Health and national programmes, Ireland can help accelerate development of diagnostics, digital tools and therapeutic options. Alignment of HTA processes and cross-border access pathways will reduce fragmentation and support both industry and health systems. Leveraging public/private and public/patient organisation investment opportunities will drive better patient-led innovation and productisation. Finally, embed patient partnership as a cornerstone of policy development. Involving patient organisations throughout the Presidency—policy design, consultations, events and implementation—ensures legitimacy, strengthens outcomes and fosters solutions aligned with real needs. This integrated, patient-centred approach will produce benefits that extend beyond the rare-disease community, improving system resilience, boosting innovation and enhancing Europe’s competitiveness in life sciences.

Ireland should communicate its Presidency in a way that reflects the values of solidarity, equity and partnership that underpin rare-disease advocacy. (1) Lead with lived experience and human impact. Stories from people with rare diseases demonstrate the concrete value of European cooperation—from cross-border specialist networks to coordinated research and improved access to therapies. These narratives make EU policy relevant to citizens. (2) Use patient partnership as a model for wider citizen engagement. Co-designed events, public dialogues and digital consultations—involving patient groups, families and clinical experts—illustrate how inclusive processes strengthen European policymaking and foster a sense of shared purpose. (3) Bring the Presidency to communities. Regional events in hospitals, universities, patient organisations and research centres can highlight Ireland’s leadership while showing how EU action supports local ecosystems: better services, stronger research capacity and new opportunities for young people. (4) Communicate clear, accessible benefits. Messages should focus on what EU cooperation delivers: earlier diagnosis, access to rare disease expertise unavailable in small Member States, the ability to participate in clinical research, and investment that strengthens local health services and industry. (5) Provide transparency through clear reporting. A public Presidency tracker—showing commitments, milestones and progress—will promote trust and demonstrate the tangible value of joint European action. This communication approach, grounded in partnership and lived experience, will strengthen public understanding of the EU’s relevance and foster a deep sense of ownership of Ireland’s Presidency.

Rare Diseases Ireland is seeking a Rare Diseases Conference on the theme of “embedding research and innovation as standard in rare disease care” as an official event of the Irish EU Presidency. There are a number of examples of patient-led research and innovation, conducted in partnership with healthcare professionals, researchers, and industry, within the Irish healthcare system and the wider ecosystem that are driving improved outcomes for people living with rare diseases (PLWRD). We would propose to showcase some of this work as examples of embedding research and driving innovation for the benefit of people living with rare diseases, the healthcare system, including healthcare professionals, researchers and industry, and society as a whole. Demonstrate Ireland’s positive action across the thematic priorities Research-active health systems as a pillar of care for rare diseases A European framework for timely, equitable access to diagnosis, specialised services and therapies Data, networks and workforce capability as foundational enablers Highlight areas of EU policy and legislation that can deliver better health outcomes Call for A time-bound European Action Plan for Rare Diseases Embedding rare-disease priorities within the EU Life Sciences Strategy and regulatory agenda. Alignment of access and reimbursement mechanisms. Strengthening ERNs, workforce mobility and specialist centres. Delivering interoperable rare-disease data systems and trusted research environments. Showcase the positive impact for people, businesses and communities across the EU anchor Council work in deliverables that improve patient outcomes. demonstrate the benefits of a whole-of-government and whole-of-ecosystem approach. highlight practical demonstrator initiatives. mobilise investment and regulatory alignment. embed rare disease patient partnership as a cornerstone of future development. Create a sense of ownership, amongst people living with rare diseases, their families and care givers over Ireland’s EU Presidency lead with lived experience and human impact use patient partnership as a model for wider citizen engagement bring the rare disease community into the heart of the presidency communicate clear, accessible benefits for all of EU membership Our Letter to the Minister for Health & colleagues across government is included with this submission.

If left unchallenged, this trend risks normalising exclusionary and anti-democratic policies that weaken social cohesion, silence civil society and erode protections for the most vulnerable. We urgently need a counterweight, a vision rooted in hope, dignity and shared responsibility. Ireland is uniquely placed to provide that counterweight. As a country with a strong human rights reputation, a commitment to peace and neutrality, and lived experience of colonialism and conflict, Ireland can speak with authenticity and authority on what a values-led Europe should look like. The Irish Presidency of the EU in 2026 represents a strategic opportunity to project a vision of Europe that leans into core values: peace, sustainability, equality, social inclusion, freedom of expression, minority rights, a strong civil society, and accountable democracy, particularly in the digital sphere. The Presidency should focus on high-level priorities that reflect a forward-looking, progressive agenda: Defending and Deepening Democracy - reinforcing democratic institutions, promoting civic participation, and protecting the integrity of elections and digital spaces. Advancing Social Inclusion and Equality - tackling exclusion, racism, and discrimination, and investing in the empowerment of marginalised communities. Protecting Human Rights and Freedoms - safeguarding freedom of expression, minority rights, civil society space, and the rule of law. This moment demands ambition. Ireland has the opportunity to set a “High Water Mark” for the kind of Europe we want to build: one that not only preserves democratic gains but actively strengthens the social, environmental, and civic foundations of the Union. By projecting a vision that combines courage, hope, and practical solutions, the Irish Presidency can inspire a Europe that is resilient, inclusive, and people-centred.

Europe’s democratic institutions face growing pressure from disinformation, polarisation, and digital manipulation. Ireland should prioritise: Digital OmniBus, Digital Services Act and Digital Markets Act implementation – turn off recommender system by default. Ensure platforms are held to account for harmful content. Protect the use of personal data for sale and targeting of ads. Electoral integrity and transparency – promote coordinated EU standards for secure, fair, and inclusive elections, including online political campaigning and protection against foreign interference. Protection from external interference: strengthen the EU’s ability to detect, prevent and respond to influence operations by outside states seeking to undermine trust in institutions, destabilise elections or amplify division within member states. Champion diversity in politics - Diversity in political representation is essential for a democracy. Set minimum standards and targets and encourage member states to adopt measures that increase representation of women, minorities, migrants, people with disabilities, and young people in elected offices and decision-making bodies. 2. Advancing Social Inclusion and Equality Inequality, social exclusion, affordability and cost of living, along with discrimination erode social cohesion and increase vulnerability to hate narratives, ideas and extremism. Ireland should lead on EU Anti-Racism Strategy 2026–2030 - centering the strategy as part of the EU Presidency Civil society funding and empowerment – ensuring the Multiannual Financial Framework supports grassroots organisations working with marginalised communities, promoting political participation and advancing legal and advocacy strategies that uphold equality and human rights Minority participation – fostering policies that support migrants, refugees, and minority groups to participate fully in social, economic, and civic life. 4. Protecting Human Rights and Freedoms The integrity of Europe depends on safeguarding fundamental rights, freedoms and civic space. Ireland should prioritise: Freedom of expression and minority rights – defending free speech while ensuring protection against hate speech and harassment, particularly online. Civil society space – ensuring NGOs, community groups, and advocacy organisations can operate freely, safely, and effectively across the EU. Promote public participation - support capacity building and leadership development, for underrepresented groups to strengthen leadership and representation. Overall Impact By focusing on these interconnected areas, Ireland can deliver a Presidency that strengthens democratic resilience, advances equality, fosters sustainable transformation, and protects human rights. This approach positions the EU as a forward-looking, people-centred, and values-led project at a time when progressive leadership is urgently needed.

To deliver meaningful impact, the Irish Presidency must start from the lived experience of communities. Across Ireland we see that people want fairness, security, and a sense of belonging - things that Europe can help strengthen when it acts with intention. Strengthen Community Resilience Local communities are on the front line of disinformation, hate, and polarisation. Ireland can drive a European approach that: Supports community-based organisations Builds local infrastructure for dialogue and inclusion Provides early-warning and rapid-response systems for harmful narratives Address Affordability and Cost of Living Cost-of-living pressures, insecure housing, and unstable work erode trust in democratic institutions and give space for disinformation and hate to grow. The Presidency should prioritise: Measures that support affordable, sustainable housing Better protections for workers Supports for families facing energy and living costs Tackle the Big Tech Harms The EU must address the growing impact of Big Tech on democracy, public discourse, and social cohesion. Effective action requires transparency, accountability, and citizen empowerment to safeguard rights online. Make recommendation to turn of recommender system by default Support civil society to report and take cases under the Digital Services Act Prepare communities to recognise and counter harmful online content Protect Rights and Promote Inclusion A strong Europe is one where everyone feels safe and valued. Priorities should include: Anti-racism Protection of minority communities ● Investment in cohesion and belonging 5. Bring people Into the Process A people-centred Presidency listens and engages. Ireland should prioritise: Genuine public participation Clear communication around decisions Empowering civil society to help shape policy debates

Communicating Europe effectively means grounding it in people’s lived experiences. From our work, we see that trust grows when people feel seen, heard, and included. 1. Shape the Narrative on the EU The EU presidency needs to say what it is for and articulate its shared values. EU communication should be: Develop a range of value lead statements focusing the role of values of rights under attack - minority rights, civil society, digital rights. Center people’s voices -workers, families, young people, communities. 2. Bring the EU to communities Ireland should facilitate: Local forums / town halls where people can speak directly into EU priorities. Community-led conversations supported by civil society. Engagements that reach groups typically excluded from national-level dialogue. Engage Young People Creatively Young people are shaping Europe’s future now, but they are also being targeted and their trust in democratic institutions being eroded. The Presidency should: Partner with youth organisations, schools, and digital creators Use storytelling and creative tools Provide meaningful routes for youth participation in policy discussions Trust is the foundation of resilience against disinformation. Celebrate Ireland’s Place in Europe Community events, culture, and the arts can help people see Ireland’s Presidency as something shared -not distant. Invest in the arts and culture.

Ireland’s Presidency comes at a defining moment. Communities across Europe are experiencing rising hate, targeted disinformation, and deepening uncertainty. The issues we see at community level - fear, exclusion, and a sense of being left behind -are shaping the political landscape across the continent. Hope and Courage Collective, urges Ireland to adopt a Presidency approach that puts minority rights, values civil society, promotes democracy and participation and holds big tech to account, while prioritising social cohesion at the heart of its agenda. We recommend a focus on; Defending Europe from outside interference in our sovereignty and running of our democracy Strengthening civic space and protecting the role of progressive civil societyI Investing in tools to prevent and respond to harmful narratives ● Ensuring that minority communities are central to policy design ● Using the Presidency to champion a ‘High Water Mark’ of rights. Ireland has a unique credibility grounded in our own peacebuilding and community development traditions. We can lead Europe in building a future where cohesion, fairness, and democracy are not slogans but lived realities.

As Ireland begins a Trio Presidency with Lithuania and Greece, three Member States on the EU’s geographic periphery, the Presidency has an opportunity to champion a competitiveness-driven EU agenda with aviation as a central enabler of mobility, cohesion and economic opportunity. The Trio has a strong shared interest in: the competitiveness of EU air transport, reliable and affordable connectivity, a deliverable and balanced sustainability pathway, and strong EU regulatory capacity to support growing air travel A clear overarching theme could therefore be: “A Competitive, Connected and Sustainable Europe.” Three highlevel priorities should underpin this: Competitiveness through connectivity and mobility: Aviation is essential to the free movement of people and goods, regional development, Europe’s Single Market, and global trade. Ireland’s Presidency should emphasise aviation’s role in maintaining the EU’s global competitiveness, particularly as other world regions scale connectivity, capacity and innovation. An energy transition that creates opportunities for Europe - The energy transition can create new jobs, energy security and support aviation’s license to grow but support is needed to ensure this is delivered in a way that maintains a globally competitive European aviation sector. The Presidency should emphasise the need for: An ETS revision that ensures decarbonisation is delivered without undermining EU competitiveness, regional cohesion or periphery connectivity. Strengthening investment signals and incentives for EU SAF production by: Accelerating work on an EU Revenue Certainty Mechanism for SAF producers (similar to the UK) with the financial support provided by the EU ETS revenues Overcoming investment inertia in SAF. Supporting the execution of pathfinder projects, that seek to bring a handful of projects to FID, through the focused use of existing policy and industry levers, Particularly, supporting new technologies such as advanced biofuel production could benefit rural livelihoods Accelerating work on the design and implementation of an EU SAF Book and Claim system. Ensure the next MFF and its programmes reflect the critical role of aviation to EU competitiveness and support delivery of these objectives. Ensuring availability of cost competitive SAF – supporting a technology agnostic approach that seeks to scale available SAF technologies today as a priority, mature those that show medium term potential and de-risk longer term technologies Preparing for the ReFuel EU revision in 2027 by understanding the evolving availability and sustainability of affordable biogenic and non-biogenic feedstocks, including their ability to support rural livelihoods., Promoting SAF as a source of energy security, untilising instruments like PESCO Military Mobility and the Connecting Europe Facility to accelerate the production of SAF as dual use infrastructure. 3. Future-Proofing Skills, Safety and Regulatory Capacity: With air traffic growth recovering and surpassing pre-covid levels, the EU must invest in the skills, training and regulatory capability needed to ensure the competitiveness of EU aviation. Ireland can elevate the need for EU-level action on skills pipelines, and the strengthening of EASA’s capacity to manage rising certification, oversight, safety and sustainability demands.

1. Legislation: ETS revision for aviation: Ireland will likely hold the Presidency during the Commission’s ETS update (Q3 2026). In keeping with the thematic priorities, Ireland, as an island nation and connectivity-dependent economy, is ideally placed to lead on shaping the ETS revision, so that decarbonisation is delivered without undermining EU competitiveness, regional cohesion or periphery connectivity. Ireland can shape the scope and ambition for aviation: Balance ambition with competitiveness by keeping the scope of the ETS limited to intra-EU flights and therefore ensuring a better ETS-CORSIA alignment consistent with international agreements Transitional flexibilities for essential routes Reinforce the SAF Allowances for the uptake of SAF, by extending them beyond 2030 and providing the demand side a formal framework to couple their long term SAF purchase agreements Ensure ETS costs don’t undermine EU regional and island connectivity 2. Policy: Ireland should focus on progressing policy files that reinforce Europe’s leadership in sustainable, competitive aviation. Ireland should steer Council discussions on ensuring a fair, stable and globally competitive framework for SAF scale-up. This includes: strengthening investment signals and incentives, accelerating work on a revenue certainty mechanism for SAF producers progressing work on the design and implementation of an EU SAF Book and Claim system. Supporting a technology agnostic approach that seeks to scale SAF technologies over the near, medium and long term, Examines the potential for greater SAF feedstock diversity to enhance EU energy and economic security. Using PESCO Military Mobility and Connecting Europe Facility funds to advance SAF production as critical dualuse infrastructure. Ensure there are no trade barriers to the import of SAF that comply with the sustainability requirements of the Renewable Energy Directive III. Earmark the revenues of the ETS for the decarbonisation of the aviation industry, including advanced biofuels in the pool of projects benefiting from the Innovation Fund.

Aviation is a horizontal enabler of economic opportunity across regions and sectors. By strengthening EU aviation competitiveness and ensuring a fair, deliverable green transition for the sector, the Council can help deliver benefits such as: Lower-carbon, reliable and affordable mobility for EU citizens. Stronger regional cohesion, especially for peripheral and island regions such as Ireland. High-quality employment, supported by improved training, apprenticeships and EU mobility frameworks. Business competitiveness, enhanced through global connectivity, investment in innovation, and secure supply chains.

Ireland can leverage its Presidency to tell a compelling, people focused story, on the importance of aviation for EU economic and social integration. The presidency could highlight how EU cooperation enables safer, greener and more affordable travel for EU citizens. That aviation is essential for cohesion and integration of peripheral EU communities. That Ireland is a global leader in aviation and an EU champion for its continued growth and competitiveness.

General observations: 2026 will mark an important moment for this Government and for Ireland. For the first time since 2013, Ireland will assume the Presidency of the Council of the European Union – a rare opportunity to project national leadership, shape Europe’s agenda and showcase Ireland’s important contribution to the European project. As an island nation and global aviation hub, Ireland has a uniquely deep stake in the future of aviation. Irish based lessors command over 50% of the aircraft leasing market, the country is home to Europe’s largest airline - Ryanair and ranks first among developed nations in flights per capita terms. It is our view that the Council Presidency is an opportunity to reaffirm this global leadership position and champion the critical role aviation plays in Europe’s competitiveness and cohesion.

geography: Located in Dublin with deep collaboration and networks within the EU and internationally in education, research and innovation
response_text: High-level thematic priorities could include: Strengthening Europe’s competitiveness through strategic investments in education, research and innovation to improve the economic and social wellbeing of citizens. This can include boosting the research and innovation capacity of Europe in emerging and enabling technologies and key sectors, including quantum technologies, space, artificial intelligence, health and life sciences, net-zero technologies and advanced materials. Advancing Europe’s capability and capacity to enable green and digital transitions supporting the creation of enterprises, new markets and future jobs. Strategic investments in water, energy and transport infrastructure and those to enable Europe’s circular and resource-efficient economy to drive improved standards for all EU citizens. Support investment in digital technologies and infrastructure, enabling their application in all areas of the economy. Identify collaborative mechanisms that can speed up Europe’s response to a rapidly evolving digital landscape and ensure responsible use of AI. Support development of sustainable and viable food systems as part of a sustainable agricultural sector strengthening Europe’s food supply chain. Protect nature, biodiversity and our oceans.

geography: Located in Dublin with deep collaboration and networks within the EU and internationally in education, research and innovation
response_text: Future Research and Innovation Framework Programme, FP10 Support the Commission’s proposed near doubling of Horizon Europe’s budget to €175 billion in the MFF to ensure a strengthened and standalone FP10 programme is established to support the EU’s ambitions on competitiveness, prosperity and sovereignty. This programme will enhance Ireland’s research capacity and industry collaboration supporting new innovations, talent development and economic growth. Scaleup Europe Fund Support the Commission’s proposed new Scaleup Europe Fund which will help mobilise private investors to develop fast-growing deep tech companies in areas such as quantum, artificial intelligence, and biotech. This funding will help support companies to scale in Ireland, including those emanating from commercialisation activities at universities and will also support enterprises from across Europe that wish to locate in Ireland to scale. Connection of New European Competitiveness Fund to the Future Research and Innovation Programme/FP10 Support a connection between the future FP10 and the new ECF underpinned by autonomous legislations, put at equal level, to accelerate advanced technologies in areas including sustainable energy, climate solutions, advanced digital and computing, and health and life sciences. By designing two strong, self-standing and complementary programmes and connecting them prudently, Europe can turn excellent research into world-leading technologies, enhancing competitiveness and prosperity. Erasmus+ and European Education Cooperation Support increased and sustained investment in Erasmus+ within the next MFF to ensure the long-term viability of student and staff mobility, including activities under the European University Alliances. Mobility numbers continue to grow while budgets remain static, forcing institutions to restrict participation and duration of exchanges. Also simplifying administrative processes, particularly for Blended Intensive Programmes (BIPs), would strengthen impact and accessibility. Sustained investment in Erasmus+ underpins the EU’s broader social and democratic objectives by promoting intercultural understanding, inclusion, and collaboration - key values at a time when European solidarity is needed.

geography: Located in Dublin with deep collaboration and networks within the EU and internationally in education, research and innovation
response_text: Partnerships with Civic Actors including Universities There is an opportunity to optimise collaboration between the Irish government and partner organisations including universities to support the dissemination of the values and benefits of EU membership to citizens. Through ‘bottom-up’ initiatives led by civic actors including universities as well as other stakeholders, a large and diverse range of citizens can be engaged with during the course of the Irish Presidency of the Council of the EU. The Irish government could provide partners with a range of supports including relevant collateral, logos and messaging for the Irish Presidency of the Council of the EU. There is also the opportunity for promotion/ advertisement of initiatives led by partner organisations to become designated side events of Ireland’s Presidency of the Council of the EU to citizens. Showcasing Impacts of Ireland’s Participation in EU Programmes UCD is strongly committed to excellence in education, research and innovation and engaging with partners to deliver impact locally, nationally and globally as set out in the UCD Strategy to 2030, Breaking Boundaries. European research and innovation programmes, including Horizon Europe as well as education initiatives including ERASMUS + and the European Universities Initiative have been vital for UCD to enhance our international research networks, support talent development and mobility and provide innovation partnerships between companies and third sector stakeholders in Ireland and across Europe and beyond. UCD is currently in the top 20 among all European higher education institutions in terms of Horizon Europe performance and 1st nationally. Through a range of official presidency events, side events and initiatives UCD hopes to utilise the opportunity to showcase our participation in EU R&I innovation programmes as well as education initiatives e.g. ERASMUS + and the European Universities Initiative. Key stakeholders including education, industry and third sector stakeholders as well as the UCD community of students and alumni will participate in our initiatives and help communicate relevant EU policy that address societal challenges. Areas of focus for UCD initiatives will include AI, sustainability, the circular economy, agri-food and agtech, start-up and scale up ecosystem and One Health. Advancing Ireland’s International Partnerships through the EU Presidency UCD has strong partnerships with education, research and innovation partners internationally, including the UK and Northern Ireland.
