There is an opportunity through conferences and other associated Presidency events to involve relevant speakers and attendees from these jurisdictions as trusted partners of Ireland. UCD can leverage support for Ireland’s Presidency initiatives through the university’s participation in major EU and international education and R&I networks including UNICA, CESAER, Una Europa, EARMA to amplify Ireland’s research, education, and innovation cooperation, promoting shared European values and European competitiveness. There is an opportunity for Ireland to strengthen the EU’s partnerships with African countries through initiatives including Global Europe and the Global Gateway under the Presidency. UCD has extensive education and research partnerships in Africa and can utilise its networks and relationships together with Irish Government and EU Commission stakeholders to advance and strengthen the EU–Africa partnership, particularly in research, higher education, climate action and food security.

Ireland’s EU presidency should use “Engineering Strategic Autonomy and Sustainable innovation” as a central theme. Engineering is the backbone of Europe’s economy and innovation, powering sectors from advanced research in ESA, CERN, and fusion energy to everyday manufacturing and high-value industrial systems. For several years the EU and many of its member states have identified engineering as a critical skill with persistent shortages that constrain Europe’s ability to meet its climate, energy, and digital ambitions. A core priority should include targeted efforts to increase female participation in engineering, ensuring gender diversity in the talent pipeline and addressing long-term skills shortages. This engineering theme ensures Europe strengthens its technological sovereignty, reduces dependency on external suppliers, and accelerates the green and digital transitions. A critical element of this theme is sustainable sovereignty, ensuring Europe can meet its climate and energy goals without dependency on external suppliers. By focusing on expanding the EU’s engineering capacity the EU can mitigate geopolitical risks, secure essential technology supply chains (including solar, battery, grid, and digital systems), and deliver resilient infrastructure. Strengthening engineering aligns directly with the EU Green Deal, Net Zero targets, digital competitiveness initiatives, and Industry 4.0 ambitions by ensuring the workforce and industrial base needed to deliver large-scale transformation. Engineering should also be positioned as a driver of innovation in the Agri food sector, ensuring Europe can secure sustainable, climate-resilient food and feed supply chains. This includes enabling advanced processing technologies, energy-efficient production systems, and improved supply-chain resilience. By placing engineering at the centre of its Presidency, Ireland can highlight the link between strategic autonomy, sustainability, and future competitiveness. This focus will reinforce Europe’s leadership in advanced science, industrial capability, and sustainable economic development. Overall, this thematic priority will enable Europe to strengthen its technological independence, support regional economic growth, and ensure that the benefits of innovation and resilience reach all citizens.

The Irish Presidency should place a clear emphasis on educational development, industrial policy, and security resilience. The EU’s long-term economic resilience and global competitiveness depend on a strong and sustained pipeline of engineers. As the world faces increasingly complex challenges ranging from climate change and digital transformation to housing and energy security the demand for highly skilled STEM professionals will continue to grow. The EU is well-positioned to meet this demand, but only if it invests in engineering education. Targeted initiatives should encourage female participation in engineering at all levels, including mentorship programmes, scholarships, and awareness campaigns. EU-wide engineering education and skills frameworks with mobility programmes (developing models similar to Erasmus+), will create a unified talent pool for critical sectors. Structured secondment models can enhance knowledge exchange across borders. One identified barrier to the engineering pipeline is lack of understanding of engineering for teachers, the EU must support targeted teacher training to improve STEM and engineering education at all levels and support public awareness campaign to enhance engineering’s appeal and visibility. On the industrial front, legislative proposals must incentivise EU-based production of strategic technologies such as semiconductors, renewable energy systems, and advanced infrastructure to reduce dependency on external suppliers, particularly China and the USA. High-quality infrastructure is essential to both providing a high quality of life for those living in the EU and supporting the growth of the EU economy. There are noticeable delays to infrastructure due to complex regulatory and planning processes. To address this, targeted exemptions from the planning process should be considered for essential public infrastructure that directly support developments identified for the public good. Embedding engineering capability into critical infrastructure and agri-food innovation policies will strengthen Europe’s autonomy, improve security, and resilience against global shocks. The Irish Presidency should aim to deliver a comprehensive roadmap for technological and energy independence, fully aligned with the advocacy work of organisations like Engineers Ireland and Engineers Europe in topics such as innovation, sustainability, and the highest professional standards.

Engineering-led policies will create high-value jobs and future-proof careers, offering citizens opportunities in sectors that drive Europe’s competitiveness. Businesses will benefit from secure supply chains and reduced vulnerability to global shocks, while communities will see tangible improvements through clean energy systems, safer transport, and digital connectivity. While larger countries like Spain, France, Germany, and Italy play pivotal roles in research and development and have benefited from substantial investments. Smaller nations such as Ireland, Denmark and others have had limited opportunities, but possess high levels of capability in STEM. To optimise the skills available across Europe, all member states should be supported to develop capacity and institutions with the goal to foster local innovation hubs in manufacturing capacity including strategic technologies such as Agri-food and solar panels the Irish Presidency can strengthen regional economies and ensure that prosperity is shared across all member states. Crucially, the council should emphasise the high international value of European research programmes and institutions within Europe such as CERN, Fusion for Energy (F4E), and ESA. These initiatives represent Europe’s leadership in advanced science and engineering, from particle physics to fusion energy and space technology. Supporting and expanding participation in these projects will not only drive innovation but also create collaborative opportunities for EU engineers working in English, reinforcing Europe’s technological sovereignty and global standing. This also offers pathways for women and underrepresented groups in STEM, broadening the talent pool and future-proofing Europe’s workforce.

Public engagement initiatives such as school outreach, STEM exhibitions, and media campaigns can showcase how EU policies deliver tangible benefits, such as clean energy, technological sovereignty, and economic resilience. Collaborations with universities, industry, and civil society will reinforce the message that EU membership delivers prosperity, security, and opportunity. Highlighting flagship projects like CERN, ESA, and other innovations can demonstrate Europe’s leadership in research and innovation. This can create a sense of pride and ownership among citizens while promoting the EU as a community of shared values and ambitions.

The EU Presidency is a strategic opportunity to shape Europe’s future. By prioritising engineering sovereignty, sustainability, and research excellence, the EU can secure its technological independence, drive competitiveness, strengthen cyber security, and ensure resilience for generations to come. Encouraging female participation in engineering and driving innovation ensures Europe benefits from a diverse workforce while securing sustainable future. Positioning engineering as a cornerstone of EU policy benefits all member states and positions Europe as a global leader in innovation and sustainable development.

sector: International aid and development, global justice, human rights
response_text: Thematic priorities 1. Climate justice Climate change remains the single biggest threat facing humanity. Despite the real and pressing impact on the lives of every EU citizen, it is still not prioritised and treated with the urgency required at EU level. Greenhouse gas emissions across the continent have reduced, driven by reductions in energy, but progress in other sectors such as agriculture and industry has been more limited. Several EU Member States, including Ireland, remain far off track to meet legally-binding climate targets, and analysis from the European Environment Agency shows that even if all current and planned policies and measures were implemented in full across the EU, this would still fall slightly short of the 2030 target of 55% reductions. The recent inclusion of international credits and review clauses in the agreed 2040 target is deeply concerning. Ireland should use its EU Presidency to ensure that climate action is restored as a priority at EU level. We should emphasise urgently closing the emissions gap, delivering on long overdue commitments on climate finance, and taking a strong collective position at the COP31 summit, in line with the core principle of climate justice outlined in the Paris Agreement. (2) Economic Justice Despite record levels of wealth, global poverty persists. Extreme inequality between rich and poor is a defining feature of the modern global economy, in which a handful of powerful companies and individuals possess more economic might than many governments. It is essential that EU policy seeks to tackle, not exacerbate, these asymmetries. Ireland should prioritise coordinated EU action on issues of corporate power and deregulation, sovereign debt, fair taxation and anti-avoidance measures, and reducing inequality. In particular, Ireland should seek to correct the narrative that has sought to justify sweeping deregulation and reductions in environmental and human rights standards across the EU under a guide of “competitiveness” and “simplification”. The Omnibus I process saw the interests of a small number of the world’s largest and most powerful companies prioritised over basic protections for workers, human rights defenders and local communities impacted by abuses in global supply chains. This regressive approach undermines the EU’s credibility and the core values it claims to uphold. The Irish Presidency must work to ensure that EU’s strategic agenda commitment to “respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights, including the rights of persons belonging to minorities” is maintained. (3) Equitable international development and peacebuilding Ireland should emphasise core principles underpinning sustainable development – poverty reduction, civil society space, human rights, gender equality, climate action peacebuilding. This is especially important at a time where the erosion of international law, human rights norms and safeguards is rising. Ireland’s EU Presidency is an opportunity to defend the rules-based, multilateral system and seek to ensure consistency in the EU’s external positions, be that in relation to Ukraine, Palestine, South Sudan or other parts of the world beset by conflict and poverty. It should seek to emphasise the long, hard and essential work of diplomacy, peacebuilding and disarmament and resist a rising tide of militarisation. It should seek to invest in effective, human-rights based humanitarian aid and development work.

sector: International aid and development, global justice, human rights
response_text: 1. Defending the EU Green Deal and climate commitments Ireland should prioritise the completion and effective implementation of key EU Green Deal files, particularly those that remain vulnerable to political dilution or delay. This includes defending climate, biodiversity and environmental legislation that continues to face pressure from a short-sighted, self-harming deregulatory agenda. It should seek to drive progress and maintain a focus on human rights, development and global justice in upcoming Commission legislative files, including (but not limited to) those regarding electrification, heating and cooling; governance of the Energy Union and Climate Action; the phasing out of fossil fuel subsidies; investment in energy efficiency and renewable energy; the review of trading practices in food supply systems; the climate package for the decade ahead; the deforestation regulation; and the role of green investment in the upcoming EU budget. 2. A fairer European and global economy Ireland should prioritise EU legislative efforts that have the potential to address inequality, corporate power and asymmetries in the European and global economy, and in particular push back against a short-sighted and harmful deregulatory agenda at EU level. This includes, but is not limited to, mooted ‘Omnibus’ legislation on taxation and antitrust laws; regulation of venture capital funds; shareholder rights and previous work on issues such as beneficial ownership and transparency registers; anti-fraud architecture; and new strategies on anti-poverty and anti-corruption. The EU must take a position in support of a strong UN Binding Treaty on Business and Human Rights, championing the priorities of Global South civil society groups to ensure enforceable corporate accountability, effective remedies for affected communities, and the inclusion of human rights considerations in all corporate-related EU legislation. 3. Global Gateway and external action: Ireland should ensure that the Global Gateway strategy and EU external action more broadly uphold human rights, environmental standards, and democratic values. Civil society in Europe and the Global South has so far had minimal participation, undermining transparency and accountability. The Presidency can lead efforts to embed meaningful stakeholder engagement, public scrutiny, and impact monitoring, ensuring that decision-making is guided by both European and, crucially, Global South civil society. In particular Ireland should seek to draw on its own experiences during the development of a new Middle East Strategy, and seek to ensure that the EU delivers on the obligations outlined in the ICJ Advisory Opinion of July 2024, including a full ban on all trade with illegal Israeli settlements. It should seek to advocate for and defend effective funding for international development and humanitarian aid in negotiations on the next multi-annual financial framework (MFF).

sector: International aid and development, global justice, human rights
response_text: In recent years there has been a concerning disconnect between policies pursued at EU level and the demand from European citizens for a fair, sustainable and prosperous continent. There is a real risk that the EU responds to rising international tensions by pursuing a path of increased militarisation, as well as a race to the bottom in areas of trade, economic standards and corporate accountability. We urge the Irish Government to use its Presidency of the European Council to re-emphasise core values of peace, diplomacy, equitable development and global justice, ensuring that the EU uses its power and influence to improve the lives of people not just on the continent of Europe, but around the world.

sector: International aid and development, global justice, human rights
response_text: Along with our colleagues in the Dóchas Network, we support efforts to increase global citizenship education and ensuring that core principles of justice, equality, fairness and equitable development are widely understood. Ultimately, however, the values and benefits of EU membership are not something to be communicated – the EU will be judged on its actions and on the results it delivers. The public remain interested in and attentive to the progress made, or indeed setbacks in, key areas including climate change, equality, international peace and development, and the promotion of human rights and global justice. Communication is important, but it is the substance, delivery and results in these areas that will ultimately matter.

Taking into account the current geopolitical and socioeconomic context in Europe, we recommend that Ireland prioritise Health Protection, Citizen Safety, and Resilient Societies as core themes of its 2026 Presidency. Serious allergies and anaphylaxis are rising across Europe and place a growing burden on individuals, schools, workplaces, and public services. Addressing them fits naturally within broader objectives to protect citizens’ wellbeing and reduce preventable health risks. A Resilient and Prepared Europe The EU must be equipped to respond to emergencies—whether acute health events, natural disasters, or public safety threats. This requires harmonised emergency response systems, stronger communitylevel preparedness, and cross-border cooperation. Ireland is one of the few Member States that has taken concrete steps to improve preparedness for serious allergic reactions, including allowing pharmacists to supply emergency medicines without a prescription during anaphylactic events. This national practice demonstrates effective emergency readiness and provides a model for EU-level policy coordination, which could inform upcoming initiatives under the European Health Union framework aimed at strengthening preparedness, prevention, and rapid response across Member States. A People-Centred Union that Protects Embedding people-centred principles into EU policymaking ensures that vulnerable populations and individuals at risk of medical emergencies are not left behind. The Presidency could advance reducing health inequalities across the EU, highlighting uneven access to diagnosis, specialist care, and emergency response protocols. Positioning timely care for serious allergies and anaphylaxis within this agenda demonstrates a commitment to practical, measurable improvements in patient safety and inclusion, while protecting citizens’ rights to safety in everyday environments such as schools, childcare centres, workplaces, and public venues. 3. A Future-Oriented Europe Built on Innovation and Collaboration Ireland’s strong reputation in digital innovation offers an opportunity to promote Digital Innovation for Health, leveraging the European Health Data Space and interoperable, patient-centred tools. For individuals at risk of serious allergic reactions, seamless access to medical information across borders can prevent emergencies and support the free movement of people. The Presidency can also prioritise harmonised awareness-raising, institutional readiness, and capacity building, ensuring schools, businesses, and public institutions are equipped and trained to respond effectively to life-threatening health incidents.

Ireland could use its Presidency to champion health resilience, citizen protection, and emergency preparedness, leveraging its national leadership in anaphylaxis response as a model for EU coordination. Key priorities include: Health Protection and Emergency Preparedness Serious allergies and anaphylaxis present a growing public-health challenge. The Presidency could: Promote timely access to emergency medicines, building on Ireland’s approach where pharmacists can supply life-saving treatment without prescription. Encourage harmonised school and public-venue preparedness, using Ireland as an example. Relevant upcoming EU initiative: Global health resilience initiative (non-legislative, Q2 2026) – to strengthen EU capacity for rapid response to health crises. Digital Innovation for Health Cross-border emergencies require seamless access to patient data: Promote the European Health Data Space for secure, interoperable sharing of health information, enabling faster response to anaphylactic events across borders. Support digital tools for citizen-centred care, enhancing emergency response and patient safety. 3. Reducing Health Inequalities and Strengthening Citizen Rights The Presidency could advance equitable access to emergency care and citizen-centred policy: Link preparedness to strengthening the Child Guarantee (non-legislative, Q2 2026) and Citizens omnibus (legislative, Q4 2026), ensuring children in schools, childcare centres, and communities are protected and have their rights effectively enforced. Promote intergenerational fairness through the Intergenerational fairness strategy (nonlegislative, Q1 2026), ensuring emergency preparedness and health access benefit current and future generations equally. Highlight Ireland’s model as a practical, replicable approach for other Member States. Objectives Establish a model for EU-level anaphylaxis and emergency response coordination, based on best practices of Ireland. Ensure equitable access to life-saving treatments across the EU. Promote digital innovation for preparedness, information sharing, and cross-border patient care. Strengthen citizen rights and intergenerational fairness, ensuring public health policies reflect social equity. Position health resilience as a pillar of EU citizen safety and social cohesion, demonstrating tangible improvements in public health readiness. By focusing on these targeted initiatives, Ireland can use its Presidency to deliver practical, measurable impacts on citizen safety, health equity, and cross-border emergency preparedness while reinforcing the EU’s social and legal frameworks.

The Irish Presidency has the potential to deliver significant, tangible impact for EU citizens by advancing health resilience and consumer safety. For individuals with serious allergies, policies that improve emergency response, access to medicines, and accurate allergen information can be life-saving. For people, expanded access to emergency treatment, including pharmacy-enabled emergency supply across the EU, enhances safety in daily life. Citizens with serious allergies would be better protected in schools, workplaces, sports facilities, cultural venues, and during cross-border travel. For businesses, harmonised allergen-labelling and staff-training expectations reduce regulatory uncertainty, simplify compliance, and improve consumer trust by fostering safer public environments. For communities and institutions, EU-supported readiness measures ,such as common school protocols, public-venue guidelines, and accessible training ,would significantly reduce preventable emergencies, supporting all three Alliance objectives. Replicating Ireland’s best practice on emergency medicine access would ensure that life-saving intervention is available regardless of where a reaction occurs, reducing inequalities across Member States.

Ireland has a strong opportunity to communicate the value of EU membership by focusing on everyday benefits and practical improvements that resonate directly with citizens. The 2026 Presidency can show how EU cooperation protects people, strengthens communities, and makes daily life safer—particularly in areas such as emergency preparedness for serious allergies and anaphylaxis. Highlight Practical Examples of EU Solidarity Citizens understand the EU best when they see clear, relatable outcomes. Ireland can communicate EU values by highlighting how cooperation improves safety and wellbeing, for example: Safer environments in schools, restaurants, transport and public venues. Shared health information that makes travel within the EU safer and more predictable. Harmonised allergen-labelling rules that protect consumers wherever they are. More consistent access to emergency support for serious allergic reactions. Ireland’s own approach—allowing pharmacists to supply emergency treatment during a serious allergic reaction—provides a concrete example of national leadership that improves citizen safety. Propose Council Recommendations on Emergency Readiness To strengthen public understanding of the EU’s benefits, Ireland could lead on a visible, citizen-centred initiative: Develop Council Recommendations on broader readiness and access to emergency treatment for serious allergy and anaphylaxis. This would help encourage Member States to: Improve preparedness in schools, public venues, workplaces, and transport hubs. Ensure trained responders are available across community settings. Reduce inequalities in access to time-sensitive, life-saving care. Such an initiative is easy for citizens to relate to, directly improves safety, and demonstrates EU cooperation in a human, practical way. A simple message: the EU protects people By showcasing initiatives that make everyday life safer, including better emergency preparedness for serious allergic reactions, the Irish Presidency can reinforce a clear message: EU cooperation delivers real, practical benefits for families, children, workers, and communities. This people-centred framing will strengthen public trust, build ownership, and demonstrate the concrete value of Ireland’s leadership at EU level.

A focus on highlighting the vested interests that are driving the push towards militarisation in Europe. Working towards sanctions on Israel. We in the West are complicit in the genocide. Ireland, we help finance the genocide through facilitating the sale of Israeli sovereign bonds, and logistically, through allowing weaponry to flow through Shannon Airport.

By keeping the Triple Lock we will show our commitment to our proud history of neutrality and our commitment to the principles and goals of the United Nations. Ending the use of Shannon Airport by all foreign military, and not allowing any foreign military fly though Ireland’s airspace These measures would set a great example to other countries in the EU.

End the drive towards militarism and cease trading with Israel. These measures would be supported by the people across the EU. We need to silence the pro militarisation propaganda that is so widespread. Arms manufacturers are making billions through the warmongering of NATO, and the scaremongering that is accompanying it.
Should how our Neutrality can be a powerful force. That it can make countries more, not less powerful

Those who still believe in internationalism need to stand up and speak truth to power. As our governments are increasingly moving toward military alliances, it is left to the citizens to unite in solidarity and say no to our governments, we don’t want to sacrifice spending on the welfare of the people, for spending that will only enrich corporations and also threaten our safety.

International Humanitarian Law (IHL) Given the current geopolitical context, with over 130 armed conflicts globally and rising casualties amongst civilians, humanitarian workers and other protected persons, respect and ensuring respect for International Humanitarian Law is more critical than ever. As the EU places greater emphasis on preparedness and defence, Ireland should draw on its strong tradition of championing IHL at the international and regional level. It can ensure that members states place IHL at the centre of their preparedness and defence planning so strategies center on protection of people as provided for by IHL. Prioritising Access to Affordable and Inclusive Housing The current housing market is increasingly out of reach for many people supported by the Red Cross in Ireland and across the EU. This group includes low-income families, single parents, migrants, people with disabilities, and young people. For migrants in particular, limited access to stable housing heightens the risk of homelessness and social exclusion. Addressing these challenges requires sustained and sufficient EU funding to complement national and regional housing investment. In parallel, EU state aid rules should enable greater public investment and prioritisation of social and affordable housing, allowing Member States and local authorities to respond more effectively to housing needs. As the EU will be launching its new Housing plan and releasing an Anti-poverty strategy in 2026, the priority would be timely. Humane Implementation of the Pact on Migration and Asylum Commencement of the Irish Presidency aligns with the implementation of the EU Pact on Asylum and Migration. Within the framework of the Pact, reception should be utilised as an enabler for integration. When reception systems are well resourced and inclusive, people seeking asylum can access the services they are entitled to and begin rebuilding their lives with dignity. Community Preparedness In a time of economic pressure, climate instability, and geopolitical uncertainty, community preparedness is vital for a people centred and future oriented Europe. Strengthening community volunteer organisations ensures that citizens are not passive recipients of aid but active participants in their own safety and resilience. Building local preparedness capacities reduces trauma and loss when disaster strikes, enabling citizens and communities to recover faster and with greater confidence — forging a stronger, more secure Europe when it is needed most. Community-Based Mental Health During periods of economic strain and geopolitical uncertainty, the social and psychological resilience of communities becomes as vital as physical safety. Strengthening community based mental health systems, particularly those supported by volunteer networks, helps prevent trauma and promotes recovery after crises. This approach aligns with the EU’s recent emphasis on mental health, including the Commission’s 2023 Communication and successive Council Conclusions calling for accessible, peoplecentred support. By promoting mental health and psychosocial support (MHPSS) as a core element of preparedness, the Irish Presidency can reinforce Europe’s people-centred and future-oriented vision. Mental resilience is social resilience — and it is fundamental to a stronger, more cohesive Europe when collective stress is at its peak.

International Humanitarian Law Ireland has championed the protection of civilians in armed conflict through various initiatives, including through its leading role on the Political Declaration on Explosive Weapons in Populated Areas. As the EU strengthens its preparedness for future armed conflicts, it should ensure policies are in place for the highest level of civilian protection, and that member states implement IHL in times of peace. In EU’s external action, Ireland can play a role in reinforcing EU support for IHL globally. During Ireland’s presidency, the conclusion of the Global Initiative to Galvanize Political Will on IHL will take place. Ireland can encourage member states to support this initiative. Amid rising defence spending and withdrawals from disarmament treaties, Ireland can help ensure that new policies uphold IHL obligations to protect civilians. A people-centered MFF The Irish Presidency should help steer the discussions towards a people-centred Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) for 2028–2034, ensuring solidarity with the most marginalised, fostering meaningful civil-society partnerships, and equipping the EU to act predictably and flexibly amid global and regional challenges. A dedicated forum on the future of cohesion funds could help ensure that forthcoming National and Regional Plans maintain strong social commitments. An inclusive transition out of TPD Since the outbreak of the conflict in Ukraine, Ireland has welcomed many people under the Temporary Protection Directive (TPD). As Member States prepare to implement the Council’s recommendation on transitioning away from TPD, they should address the needs of the most vulnerable - those with no viable pathway to alternative legal status who cannot return to Ukraine due to specific vulnerabilities. This group should be granted access to stable status to safeguard their rights. The Presidency could initiate structured follow-up on implementation of the Council recommendation, including a platform for exchange between Member States and stakeholders. Aligning the EU’s Facilitation Directive with international standards Trilogues around the Facilitation Directive in 2026 will offer an opportunity to prevent undue criminalisation of migrants and humanitarian actors, and reaffirm EU’s commitment to human dignity and solidarity. A mandatory, unambiguous humanitarian exemption should be included to protect humanitarian actors, migrants and their families, and those acting in solidarity. Community Preparedness and Mental Health The Presidency should promote operationalisation of the EU Preparedness Union Strategy by advancing policies that strengthen local voluntary capacities. Streamlined EU funding under the Union Civil Protection Mechanism should be accessible to community and volunteer organisations supporting public awareness, early warning, and civil protection preparedness. Ireland can also encourage integration of community-based actors into cross-border preparedness and response planning. The Presidency could strengthen EU’s work on mental health by promoting the integration of mental health and psychosocial support into EU disaster preparedness and response policies. Building on EU policies, Ireland can encourage EPSCO to prioritise community-based and volunteer-led approaches as essential for early mental health intervention and post-crisis psychosocial recovery. The presidency can support closer coordination between health, social policy, and civil protection frameworks to ensure that mental wellbeing is considered across preparedness planning.

International Humanitarian Law The Council can make a substantial positive impact by strengthening EU-wide implementation of IHL, including through the Preparedness Union Strategy. Strengthening compliance with IHL is also essential to safeguarding humanitarian access, ensuring that aid reaches civilians when they need it most. By bringing organisations with operational IHL expertise into relevant working parties (COHAFA, COJUR, PROCIV, etc.), the Council can ensure policies are grounded in operational realities and deliver meaningful protection for people and communities. Housing and Social Inclusion The Council can make a substantial positive impact by improving housing accessibility, including addressing barriers that prevent migrants from entering the private rental market. Strengthening funding for social work and counselling as part of social housing programmes, alongside efforts to combat discrimination, would support inclusion and stability for people and communities across the EU. Reception and Temporary Protection The Council can take a firm stand for a humane implementation of the EU Pact on Migration and Asylum, ensuring that people are at the centre of the reception system, and that systems are in place to provide safe and supportive environments. Additionally, accommodation must be tailored to individual needs and additional support should be provided to people exiting from reception facilities. In the transition away from the Temporary Protection Directive, alternative legal statuses are considered for the needs of the most vulnerable who may be unable to return to Ukraine. The needs and rights of those who remain must be safeguarded. This work should be advanced across relevant Council bodies, including the Justice and Home Affairs Council and working parties such as the Asylum Working Party, IMEX and SCIFA, to ensure coherent and humane implementation across Member States. Community Engagement The Presidency should prioritise meaningful involvement of community-based actors, people with lived experience, and organisations representing those facing heightened vulnerabilities across all relevant dialogue and consultation fora during the Presidency. Ensuring that these perspectives feed into EU policy debates will help ground EU priorities in lived realities and operational experience. Community Preparedness Directing funding towards volunteer led organisations that specialise in community preparedness produces measurable local benefit. These groups have the trust, reach, and flexibility to engage residents, raise hazard awareness, and mobilise early action. By channelling EU resources through such community networks, preparedness initiatives become more inclusive and effective, especially for vulnerable groups. Sustainable financial support for volunteer driven programmes ensures that preparedness remains embedded at the community level rather than dependent on emergency cycles or institutional capacity alone. Community-Based Mental Health Volunteer led organisations deliver mental health and psychosocial support where it matters most — locally and without barriers. Targeted EU funding for community-based mental health initiatives allows volunteers to reach vulnerable people early, build supportive networks, and reduce isolation during and after crises. Sustained support for these volunteer systems enhances social cohesion, reduces trauma, and directly contributes to recovery, long after formal interventions have concluded. EU investment in these capacities ensures mental wellbeing remains a pillar of preparedness and resilience.

International Humanitarian Law In recent years, particularly with armed conflict in Ukraine, Gaza and elsewhere capturing the attention of the European public, there has been growing calls for European Members States to ensure respect for IHL. Grassroots efforts calling for peace and IHL compliance, alongside the welcoming of millions of people fleeing armed conflict to the EU, reflects a strong and ongoing desire from European citizens for the EU to uphold values of peace and respect for the rule of law. Persistent non-compliance with IHL undermines confidence in it as a cornerstone of the rules-based international order. Irelands’ values and beliefs must be reflected in the EU, especially as the current geopolitical climate and shifting attitudes towards defence and security risk distancing the EU from these values and from the expectations of the Irish public. Migration The values and benefits of the European Union are reflected in how people seeking protection, or simply a better life in the EU and Ireland, are treated. We need a different narrative on migration, one that moves beyond fear, security, and division, and instead emphasises the added value of intercultural communities across the EU. Community Preparedness Community preparedness communicates empowerment, agency, and shared responsibility — core values of the European Union. It is about communities understanding risks, taking responsibility, and acting together to reduce harm. Public campaigns that highlight volunteer-led preparedness exemplify solidarity in practice, showing citizens that preparedness is not only the role of institutions but a collective European that strengthens both confidence and unity. Community-Based Mental Health Community based mental health fosters empowerment, dignity, and agency. It shows that solidarity is not abstract but experienced person-to-person when volunteers help their neighbours cope, recover, and rebuild. These initiatives demonstrate that preparedness is more than preventing harm — it is about enabling people and communities to take responsibility for their wellbeing and future. Promoting such stories under the Irish Presidency communicates the Union’s human face: compassionate, proactive, and united in care.
The protection and development of tourism as a key indigenous industry and key regional employer in Ireland and Europe.

The upcoming Greening Corporate Fleets legislative proposal from the Commission may include an accelerated purchase mandate on commercial fleets that would lead to fleets across Europe being obliged to purchase a rising number of EVs annually up to 2030 and beyond. We ask the Irish Presidency to support the exclusion of any premature EV fleet mandate for the car rental sector. Our members recognise that the car rental industry shares a responsibility in contributing towards Ireland’s climate action targets. While the industry currently only accounts for 2% of total inbound tourism emissions (ATU ‘Longitudinal study of Tourism Emissions’), we are committed to working with Government and the broader transport and tourism sector to ensure these emissions are reduced, without unintended consequences. To achieve the electrification of the rental fleet in Ireland, it is important that the following enabling conditions are considered: Demand: Overseas visitors currently prefer to rent internal combustion engine (ICE) cars. This is due to a combination of unfamiliarity, charging anxiety, cost, and the already challenging experience of driving an unfamiliar right-hand drive. CRCI members’ data shows that utilisation rates for EVs, i.e. the percentage of time a vehicle is actively rented out, were as low as 24% last year, compared with the 80% required for vehicles to break even. This challenge is being encountered in car rental markets right across Europe, even in trailblazing Norway. Costs: In 2024, the average EV rental cost 33% more than its petrol or diesel equivalent due to higher purchase prices, faster and deeper depreciation, higher maintenance, repair and insurance costs and lower utilisation rates. All these factors increased the TCO (Total Cost of Ownership) for car rental companies and hence the cost of rental to consumers. Second Hand EV Demand: Currently, there is a 24% oversupply to the Irish second-hand EV market. This forces additional depreciation on rental EVs, making them even more expensive and less financially viable. It is likely that consumers will have to be incentivised to purchase second-hand EVs, to establish a functioning market for car rental companies to sell their cars into. Charging infrastructure: This remains a major barrier to our EV rollout, with limited coverage in remote regions and tourism destinations, and constrained grid capacity at Dublin Airport, where 83% of Irish tourism car rentals originate. Based on Dublin Airport Authority plans, comprehensive infrastructure suitable for processing large numbers of tourist rentals will not be in place until well beyond 2030. All these challenges can and will be overcome, but the electrification of car rental fleets will only be successful once these enabling conditions are addressed. We call on the Irish Presidency to create an environment where visitors can confidently rent, drive and charge electric vehicles. Imposing mandatory EV purchases on the car rental sector before these enabling conditions are in place would trigger lower fleet purchases and mean that ICE cars are held for longer, ultimately leading to a smaller, older fleet, financial stress on rental companies and the reduction of current visitor levels in rural areas.
A pragmatic approach to the development of sustainable tourism would be of enormous benefit to Ireland and the EU economically, socially and environmentally.

Show that the Irish Presidency is fully focused on the pragmatic implementation of climate action measures in a way that gets results without damaging otherwise sustainable industries those measures address.

The Car Rental Council of Ireland and our members are committed to working with the Irish Presidency and Irish Government to create the enabling conditions and policies that support a flourishing, sustainable, and regionally balanced tourism sector. We would welcome the opportunity to meet with you soon to discuss further how this can be achieved.

organisation: European Respiratory Society and The School for Moral Ambition
response_text: As an Irish citizen working in public health and EU regulatory policy, I believe Ireland’s Presidency in 2026 should build on the qualities that have defined Irelands contribution to Europe for two decades: fairness, practical leadership, respect for evidence and a deep instinct to protect the next generation. These values have shaped Ireland’s approach to public health, digital safety, food standards and innovation policy, and they can offer the Union a unifying direction at a moment of significant social, technological and economic change. Protecting Europe’s Youngest Citizens Ireland has repeatedly demonstrated that strong public-interest policy can coexist with economic success. From world-leading workplace smoking bans to plain packaging and road-safety reforms, Ireland’s instinct has been to protect young people first and build long-term consensus around that goal. Today, Europe faces a similar generational test: adolescents have unprecedented access to high-potency nicotine products, targeted online advertising and emerging addictive designs. The Presidency can place youth protection at the centre of its narrative; a framework broad enough to guide decisions across taxation, consumer safety, digital regulation, food systems and environmental health. Tobacco control remains one of the clearest examples of how Ireland’s experience can support the Union. Ireland has learned that strong prevention measures, coherent taxation and firm implementation of WHO FCTC obligations; including Article 5.3 on protection from industry interference, are critical to reducing addiction and restoring trust in policymaking. This perspective is directly relevant to files such as the Tobacco Taxation Directive and the upcoming revision of the Tobacco Products Directive, where the EU must balance youth protection, Single Market stability and public-health ambition. Strengthening Evidence Integrity Across multiple policy areas, Ireland has developed a reputation for grounding difficult decisions in independent, verifiable evidence. Whether addressing illicit trade in harmful products, regulating digital pladorms, responding to public-health challenges or building financial resilience, Ireland has shown that transparency and evidence integrity are prerequisites for good governance. A Presidency priority on evidence integrity would not single out any dossier; rather, it would help the Council navigate contested files, from health to food to green and digital transitions, with greater confidence and unity. Innovation That Serves Society Ireland’s economic success has long been tied to innovation, but also to an understanding that innovation must strengthen, not weaken, the social contract. As Europe enters a decade shaped by AI, biotechnology and major shifs in food systems, Ireland can help champion a “trusted innovation” approach. This means ensuring AI regulation is enforceable yet innovation-compatible; supporting biotechnology that improves health and food security; and future-proofing agriculture through diversification while protecting farmers’ livelihoods. These priorities align with Ireland’s experience as a consensus-builder and a bridge between technological opportunity and societal protection. Together, these three themes; youth protection, evidence integrity and innovation that strengthens society, reflect Ireland’s identity and offer a compelling, unifying direction for the 2026 Presidency.

organisation: European Respiratory Society and The School for Moral Ambition
response_text: Ireland’s Presidency should focus on policy areas where it can combine its national strengths with the Union’s strategic needs. Two files stand out as requiring clear, steady leadership: the Tobacco Taxation Directive (TTD) and the next Tobacco Products Directive (TPD). Both carry major implications for youth protection, health systems, enforcement capacity and the Single Market. 1. Tobacco Taxation Directive (TTD) Regardless of the stage the file reaches by mid-2026, Ireland should aim to ensure the Direc1ve delivers coherent minimum rates, full product coverage and genuine youth-protec1on value. Ireland is uniquely posi1oned to help the Council: facilitate agreement if trilogues are ongoing consolidate a Council mandate if nego1a1ons are s1ll open or support finalisa1on and implementa1on steps if the file is close to conclusion. Ireland’s long experience with high excise, strong enforcement and stable revenues gives it credibility to guide Member States through remaining technical and poli1cal challenges, while ensuring robust Ar1cle 5.3-compliant processes. The file is too strategically important for Europe’s fiscal, health and Single Market goals to drif further; Ireland can provide the clarity and momentum needed. 2. Tobacco Products Directive (TPD) revision The upcoming TPD revision will define Europe’s response to rapidly evolving nicotine markets and rising youth uptake. The Presidency should treat this as a priority orientation file if the formal proposal is published before or during Ireland’s term. Ireland can: help the Council frame the core questions around flavours, product design, nicotine limits, marketing, novel products and environmental impacts support consistency with the TTD to prevent regulatory loopholes highlight the evidence base required for proportionate but effective measures. Ireland’s reputation for youth protection and evidence integrity gives it a natural role in shaping an early, balanced Council position. Strengthening 5.3 implementation within tobacco policymaking Within the tobacco context, Ireland can encourage practical steps that reinforce transparency and protect policymaking from commercial interference. This strengthens trust in the evidence base, supports Member States, and improves negotiability of both TTD and TPD. Innovation that protects public wellbeing Beyond tobacco, Ireland should champion trusted innovation across AI, biotech and food systems. Priorities include innovation-compatible AI implementation, safe and future-proof biotechnology pathways, and reducing political barriers to sustainable food innovation while supporting farmers.

organisation: European Respiratory Society and The School for Moral Ambition
response_text: The Council can have the greatest positive impact by focusing on areas where clear, evidence-led EU action improves people’s lives, reduces long-term costs and strengthens Europe’s competitiveness. Ireland’s Presidency is well positioned to advance three types of impact: protecting health, strengthening trust in policymaking and enabling innovation that serves communities. Delivering strong, coherent public-health measures that reduce long-term harm Substantial impact comes from prevention. Completing or advancing the Tobacco Taxation Directive (TTD) and supporting progress on the next Tobacco Products Directive (TPD) would reduce youth addiction, prevent avoidable disease and ease future pressure on healthcare systems. Clear minimum rates, coherent rules for emerging nicotine products, and processes that uphold WHO FCTC Article 5.3 can deliver benefits felt for decades. This protects families, reduces inequali1es, supports workforce par1cipa1on and helps Member States safeguard public finances. Few files offer such a direct, measurable return. Reinforcing evidence integrity across Council work Ci1zens and businesses benefit when EU decisions are based on independent, transparent evidence rather than compe1ng narra1ves or vested interests. Ireland can embed prac1cal steps that strengthen evidence integrity within the Council’s handling of sensi1ve files. This increases regulatory predictability for businesses, improves trust among communi1es and enhances the Union’s ability to respond to contested issues — from tobacco to food standards, environmental policy and digital regula1on. A Council that communicates and prac1ces evidence-based decision-making has a mul1plier effect on legi1macy and stability. Enabling trusted innovation that creates opportunity in all regions When innova1on is well-regulated and socially grounded, communi1es benefit from new industries, farmers benefit from diversified markets, and SMEs gain clearer pathways to compete. Ireland can use the Presidency to: support smooth, innova1on-compa1ble implementa1on of the AI Act encourage coherent EU approaches to biotechnology that protect health and the environment reduce poli1cal barriers to sustainable food innova1on while ensuring farmers are supported in the transi1on. This combina1on helps Europe stay compe11ve while ensuring that technological change strengthens rather than erodes social cohesion. 4. Deepening the Single Market and free movement Businesses and ci1zens feel the benefits of Europe most clearly when barriers come down: easier mobility, consistent rules and smoother trade. Priori1sing free movement and reducing market fragmenta1on would directly improve opportuni1es across regions. Together, these ac1ons would allow the Irish Presidency to deliver concrete improvements to people’s wellbeing, to business certainty and to community resilience across the EU.

organisation: European Respiratory Society and The School for Moral Ambition
response_text: Ireland’s Presidency is a chance to show people that the European Union is not something distant, but a project that improves daily life in practical, tangible ways. To build a sense of ownership, Ireland should communicate Europe through real stories, not abstract institutions; and highlight where EU action directly protects people, supports communities and creates future opportunities. Show how Europe protects young people The clearest way to make EU membership meaningful is to show how it safeguards the next generation. Whether through safer food, cleaner air, fair digital rules, or reducing youth addiction to harmful products, citizens respond to policies that visibly protect children. Ireland can foreground the Presidency as an opportunity to shape a Europe where young people face fewer risks and more possibilities. This connects directly to key files such as the TTD and TPD, but also to digital safety, environmental standards and consumer protection. Highlight evidence, fairness and trust as European values Citizens are more likely to feel ownership when they believe decisions are made openly and on the basis of reliable evidence. Ireland has a strong history of transparent, consensus-led policymaking. The Presidency can communicate that Europe works when decisions are grounded in fairness and when policy is protected from vested interests; a principle clearly illustrated in tobacco regulation but relevant across all sectors. Tell the innovation story in human terms People want to understand how Europe prepares them for the future. Ireland can communicate Europe as a place where innovation serves society: AI that is trustworthy, biotechnology that protects health, and food systems that support farmers while creating new sustainable opportunities. When people see that EU rules make their lives safer and their work more secure, they feel part of the project. Connect EU membership to Ireland’s national strengths Finally, citizens should feel that Ireland’s Presidency reflects Irish values: fairness, protection of the vulnerable, respect for evidence, and ambition for future generations. Communicating this alignment can turn the Presidency from a technical exercise into something people see as authentically “ours”.

organisation: European Respiratory Society and The School for Moral Ambition
response_text: Ireland’s Presidency comes at a time when citizens expect Europe to provide clarity, fairness and protection in areas that directly shape daily life; health, food, digital environments and economic resilience. Across these domains, a unifying thread is emerging: the need for public decisions that are transparent, evidence-based and insulated from undue influence. Strengthening this principle would not only improve outcomes in individual files such as the TTD and TPD, but also reinforce trust in the European project more broadly. Ireland is well placed to champion this approach. Ireland’s national experience shows that difficult reforms; whether in public health, digital safety or food standards, succeed when they are grounded in evidence, communicated honestly, and designed with the next generation in mind. As the EU enters a decade defined by rapid technological change, evolving health risks and rising geopolitical pressure, Member States will benefit from a Presidency that can bridge innovation with societal protection and help the Council navigate complex choices with confidence. Finally, the Presidency would be well served by keeping a clear focus on implementation. Citizens experience the EU not through announcements but through the real-world impact of policies. Whether finalising tobacco legislation, strengthening food-system resilience, improving AI governance or reinforcing the Single Market, Ireland can highlight the practical benefits of European cooperation and show how evidence-led policymaking delivers tangible improvements in people’s lives.

(1) Simplification (2) Competitiveness (3) Resilience. Simplification is key – every sector stands to benefit from a streamlining of applicable regulatory frameworks through a reduction in unnecessary complexity and improved efficiency. Ireland’s Presidency of the Council should focus on initiatives that strengthen the EU’s economic resilience and competitiveness, and simplifying the regulatory burden across the EU will be central to meeting those priorities. Fragmented and overly complex rules increase costs for businesses and deter cross-border investment and trade. The IMF describes the frictional cost of doing cross-border business in Europe as if they amounted to internal tariffs. The numbers are striking. Remaining barriers within the single market are equivalent to a 45% tariff on trade in goods. In services, the cost of doing business cross-border in the EU is even higher: the equivalent of a 110% tariff. Innovation and growth should be central themes for the Presidency. Ensuring Europe remains attractive for investment and capable of fostering new technologies and financial solutions is critical. Importantly, these objectives should not come at the expense of financial stability or investor protection. Instead, the challenge - and indeed the opportunity - lies in combining these principles so that regulation supports innovation and growth, while safeguarding market integrity.

Within the remit of financial services, the Presidency should focus on advancing the Savings and Investments Union (SIU) agenda, which aims to deepen EU capital markets and mobilise household savings into productive investments. Four key policy areas stand out: Retail Investor Participation and Advice Framework: Retail investors remain underrepresented in European capital markets, with only 34% of adults investing compared to 58% in the US. The Central Bank of Ireland recently found that just 36% of the Irish population hold any kind of investment product; 5% of the population report they invest in investment funds, yet 10% invest in crypto. 53% of the population reported that they have no exposure to capital markets at all. The Presidency should champion initiatives to grow retail investor participation in capital markets, by simplifying the investor journey under MiFID, notably through the introduction of a simplified advice regime, reducing the perception that investment is just for the wealthy. This initiative would bridge the gap between execution-only services and fully personalised advice, enabling scalable, affordable financial planning for mass-market investors. Simplified advice could help millions of savers become investors, improving financial inclusion and long-term wealth creation. Simplification and Digitalisation of the Investor Journey: Current disclosure frameworks are outdated and paper based. The Presidency should accelerate reforms to PRIIPs and UCITS documentation, making electronic delivery the default and enabling layered, intuitive digital tools. Simplifying disclosures will enhance transparency and investor confidence. These changes will reduce friction and cost, encouraging broader participation. Attractive Individual Investment Accounts and Pension Reform: The Presidency should use its platform to advocate for the rollout of tax-advantaged individual investment accounts across Member States – and should deliver this domestically too. Tax advantages can come in different forms and Member States should not neglect of the attractiveness of tax simplification as an incentive for investors. Designed for ease of use, flexibility, and regular contributions, evidence suggests these accounts could unlock €1.5–€4.8 trillion of EU household savings over 10 years. From an Irish perspective, that estimate is €47-€148 billion over 10 years.6 In parallel, following through on proposed reforms to the Pan-European Personal Pension Product (PEPP) to make it fit for purpose through life-cycling strategies, simplified onboarding, and better tax treatment, will strengthen longterm savings and deepen the European investor base. The Irish experience of auto-enrolment can serve as a case study for ensuring pension systems provide better outcomes for all citizens. Reduction of Fragmentation in EU Capital Markets Structure: By focusing on transparency (e.g., consolidated tapes), post-trade efficiency, and harmonised trading rules, the Presidency could play its part in reducing fragmentation and enhancing liquidity. This would make EU markets more competitive globally, lower borrowing costs, and drive economic resilience. These measures will create a structurally deep and diverse investor base, a cornerstone for vibrant EU capital markets and household financial resilience. The ongoing EU securitisation market reforms represent a strategic opportunity for the Presidency to demonstrate leadership in strengthening capital markets and supporting financing for the real economy.

The Irish Presidency has a unique opportunity to deliver lasting benefits by advancing policies that foster more integrated, efficient, and resilient European capital markets. These reforms are far from abstract, they have the potential to translate directly into improved financial wellbeing for citizens, greater competitiveness for businesses, and stronger foundations for communities across the Union. By committing to progressing to the SIU project, citizens, businesses and communities stand to benefit: Building Financial Security and Wealth for Citizens: European households save more than their US counterparts, yet their wealth has grown at only one-third the US rate since 2009. This disparity stems largely from the fact that a significant share of European savings remains in low-yield bank deposits rather than invested in productive assets. The Irish Presidency can help to reverse this trend by accelerating the Savings and Investments Union (SIU) agenda, which aims to make investing simpler, safer, and more accessible. These measures can help empower citizens to invest confidently, strengthen retirement readiness, and narrow Europe’s wealth gap. Unlocking Capital for European Companies: Integrated capital markets reduce the cost of capital and expand funding options for companies. Today, many European corporates are net savers, limiting investment in growth and innovation. In addition to the workstreams underway to increase the supply of capital, the Presidency should ensure that Member States equally champion measures that stimulate demand for capital, ensuring that new savings flow into productive opportunities. Removing remaining frictions in cross-border trade and services will allow firms to scale across the EU’s 450million-person market. Promoting strategic investment in digitalisation, AI adoption, and the energy transition will create pathways for businesses to grow and compete globally. Enhancing private market access – for retail and institutional investors alike - through frameworks like ELTIFs and reforms to Solvency II and IORP would not only offer diversification benefits, but would enable institutional and retail investors to fund SMEs and infrastructure. These steps will attract global capital, create jobs, and position Europe as a hub for innovation. Funding Infrastructure and Resilience: Deeper capital markets can channel resources into projects that underpin community wellbeing such as housing, transport, and clean energy. The Presidency should advance securitisation reform to revitalise this market, freeing up bank balance sheets and expanding lending capacity. Promoting blended finance models can combine public and private capital to accelerate strategic projects, while exploring safe asset solutions can enhance market stability and liquidity. These measures will ensure that capital markets play a central role in financing Europe’s green and digital transitions, supporting local development and resilience. In summary, the Presidency should position capital markets as engines of inclusive growth, helping savers build wealth, enabling businesses to innovate, and funding community priorities. A well-executed SIU agenda will not only strengthen Europe’s competitiveness but deliver tangible improvements in everyday financial wellbeing.

organisation: Gen Free: Free to be Kids (www.genfree.ie)
response_text: The protection of minors online A recent European survey showed that social media has a significant impact on young people, with one-third of young Europeans exhibiting signs of social media addiction [1]. In Ireland, research by CyberSafeKids shows that 24% of 6-year-olds in Ireland [2] and 93% of 8-12 year olds own their own smart device and 71% of this age group have their own social media and instant messaging accounts [3]. The range of online harms includes cyberbullying, exposure to violent, pornographic/ sexually violent material, content promoting eating disorders, self-harm and suicide, misogynistic content, radicalisation, gambling features, unwanted contact, child grooming, sextortion and the promotion and distribution of child sexual abuse material. Europe has taken significant steps to increase protections for minors online, but the measures introduced do not yet go far enough. During our presidency of the EU Council, Ireland must build on recent, encouraging momentum in this area, such as; the signing of the Jutland Declaration during the Danish presidency, the vote in the European Parliament in late November calling on the Commission to enforce the Digital Services Act (DSA) to its maximum, President Von der Leyen’s comments regarding the impact of social media on young people and the calling of an expert panel to make recommendations, the introduction in several European countries of minimum age legislation for access to porn websites and social media and the publication of the DSA guidelines, which serve to strengthen the regulation. Ireland must take a strong, proactive position on this topic and indeed, we have an obligation to do so, given that so many (15/25) of the largest social media platforms are headquartered in this country. Because of this, Ireland will play an outsized role in the enforcement of the DSA on behalf of all Europeans. In the past, Ireland’s regulation of Big Tech has been criticised by many in Ireland and Europe; we have an opportunity now to set the record straight through additional proposals aligned with and complementary to the DSA, as well as demonstrating a wide interpretation and robust enforcement of the existing regulation. Given that Ireland has the highest proportion of young people in Europe and that we have a sad history of failure in always adequately protecting children, we must act with the necessary urgency and commitment to ensure that the safety of minors is always prioritised, online and offline, regardless of the challenges. During Ireland’s presidency we have an opportunity to demonstrate leadership and to achieve meaningful progress towards Europe’s shared goal of ensuring safe, non-addictive digital environments in which young people can thrive. In a time of heightened political polarisation, we believe that the protection of minors online as a priority theme enjoys broad societal and cross-party political support, both in Ireland and across the EU, as evidenced by numerous surveys and the very strong engagement with, and backing for, the Protection of Minors Online proposal in the European Parliament in late November.

organisation: Gen Free: Free to be Kids (www.genfree.ie)
response_text: Ireland should demonstrate and model robust, swift and comprehensive implementation of the DSA (through Coimisiún na Meán), and bring further proposals in certain critical areas, some of which may require additional national or European legislation, including, for example; the urgent imposition of mandatory age- verification (in line with the DSA) for adult content accessed from Ireland, regardless of the domicile of the service provider, via DSA-aligned national legislation. A number of member states in Europe have already introduced this, most recently Italy. Ireland should implement this in advance of the development of a harmonised approach by regulators across Europe, as that will take too long the establishment of a mechanism to accredit independent, third-party age-verification technology providers (privacy preserving, such as via zero- knowledge- proof technology), to be made available alongside the government age- verification tool under development; to ensure that further user data is not concentrated in the hands of Big Tech that recommender systems be turned off by default for minors, or be based purely on explicit user signals, rather than implicit signals (such as “profiling”) and that they must never recommend content that, per the DSA, impairs the “the physical, mental and/or moral development of a minor” that platforms accessed by minors undergo yearly, independent risk assessments which determine the appropriate age rating for age-verification purposes, in contrast to the current opaque system of self-assessment classifying AI chatbots as high-risk for minors, under the AI Act, and stipulating a minimum age of 16 to access banning AI-powered “pornify”, “nudify” or deepfake apps that create sexualised imagery without consent. Consider following Denmark’s example in copyrighting one’s body, facial features and voice, to clamp down on the creation and dissemination of deepfakes. developing and presenting a blueprint of a comprehensive digital literacy programme for young people, parents, and all of society, perhaps similar to the Finnish model which embeds lifelong digital literacy skills

organisation: Gen Free: Free to be Kids (www.genfree.ie)
response_text: The UN Convention on the Rights of the Child, adopted in 2021, includes the right to participate but also the right to be protected from harm, to not be exploited, the right to privacy and the right to true and accurate information. These rights are undermined every time children go online. The effects of experiencing harmful content or contact can be profound, with some experiencing severe distress, anxiety and emotional withdrawal. Anxiety and depression rates among young people have increased significantly [4] and there is a positive correlation between higher social media use and loneliness, with Irish teenagers particularly lonely [1]. Higher use is defined as 2+ hrs per day; whereas 25% of Irish teenagers spend 4+ hrs and 21% spend 6+ hrs per day on social media [5]) and 64% of 12-15 year olds think they spend too much time online [3]. The consumption of porn is at record levels (regularly viewed by up to 71% of senior cycle students [4] due to ease of access and the deliberate, addicting features of online porn today, with numerous harmful implications for both individuals and society at large. Surveys of Irish parents show that only a small minority feel equipped to help their children manage online risks and about 30% say they never discuss social media use with their children, while in many cases giving them unfettered access (58% can go online whenever they choose, 79% of parents can’t see what their kids do online [2]). For all these reasons, the benefits to young people of better regulation and enforcement cannot be overstated. We believe that the introduction of our proposed measures would bring about meaningful improvements, in terms of young people’s online experiences but also on their mental health and quality of life generally, and would have notable long-lasting, positive effects also for their schools, families, communities, and ultimately all of society. Importantly, the impacts also on businesses operating in this sphere could be positive as there is currently a lack of clarity regarding interpretation of the regulation, too much discretion left to the platforms (which opens the door for legal challenges), a lack of harmonisation in the enforcement regime across Europe and much negative publicity surrounding the industry. Greater clarity, decisiveness, harmonisation and standardisation, all of which would result from the proposals we make above, would ultimately benefit the industry. We welcome recent statements from the government regarding considering a minimum age for access to social media. Any such measure, however, must be mandatory (and no lower than 16 yrs), rather than giving parents an option to allow access (such as between 13-16 yrs) as otherwise nothing will change, i.e. minors will be subject to the same peer pressure and parents will give in to their pleas, as they do now, even though in many cases it is against their better judgement. We would view age verification as just a start on the journey towards safe online environments for young people.

organisation: Gen Free: Free to be Kids (www.genfree.ie)
response_text: Parents (and young people) across Ireland and Europe are very concerned, frustrated and angry about the addictive nature and harmful effects of social media, gaming and porn. Reports of harm are frequent and widespread. For that reason, “hold-off” and “delay” groups are springing up (here and in other countries), whereby groups of parents in a school agree to not give their child a smart device until, in most cases, the start of secondary school or a year later. These initiatives are much needed because regulation and enforcement have been so lacking. However, holding off, while very welcome, only delays the inevitable problems by a year or two. Frustration and disillusionment with politicians and regulation are on the rise, partly due to concern at increasing levels of regulation without obvious benefits and the sense that our political classes lack decisiveness and a vision. We know that the DSA is a landmark piece of regulation that Europe’s politicians are proud of, and Ireland has its Online Safety Code. However, we believe that if there is not an obvious, significant reduction in online harms experienced by young people, and if these are not felt in the near future, there will be increased levels of frustration and disillusionment with both Irish and European lawmakers and the overall regulatory framework. This could further erode commitment to, and support for, the European project. Additionally, there is a suspicion that Ireland’s government is afraid to stand up to the tech industry here, given their very important contributions to employment and tax revenues, and we note also the Minister’s comments about being disappointed that Europe has not acted more robustly in the area of online safety for minors. However, this ignores the fact that Ireland has the authority to introduce its own minimum age verification, in a way that is aligned with the DSA. Ireland cannot continue to profit from technologies which harm children and must legislate with urgency to address regulatory gaps and meet our obligations under the DSA, with urgency. We believe that lawmakers across Europe, and the Irish government during the presidency of the EU Council, have an opportunity to demonstrate that they are listening to the electorate and taking their concerns seriously. The protection of young people is an emotive issue and close to people’s hearts. It has the power to be a unifying topic. Definitive, meaningful action by Ireland and Europe, regardless of the challenging economic and political backdrop, could help restore the electorate’s faith in the European project, prove that we are stronger when we work together, re-confirm Europe’s commitment to its values and instill pride in our leadership for standing up for what is right, particularly in the context of U.S. attempts to undermine us.
