geography:
Our geographical focus is all-of-Island on the Island of Ireland in operational expertise and both EU-wide, and global  in terms of strategic influence and reach.
Operational Focus (Island of Ireland): As the designated strategic partnership, our work encompasses all of Ireland, targeting the entire Further Education and Training (FET) and ACE sector, including rural and urban areas and parallel organisations in Northern Ireland. We work with a broad range of relevant bodies (e.g., AONTAS, Irish Rural Link) to reach a diverse population of practitioners and learners across the Island.
Strategic Focus (EU-wide): The purpose of this submission is to leverage the Irish Presidency to champion a policy that promotes an EU-wide standard. The focus for a Council Recommendation on Professionalising Adult Education Practitioners for Critical Media Literacy is intended to establish a common, continent-wide framework for quality-assured GCE practice, directly aligning with the EU Strategic Agenda's goals for democratic resilience across all Member States.
response_text: Ireland’s Presidency should adopt the overarching theme of "Fortifying Democracy: Investing in European Societal Resilience from the Ground Up." This theme directly addresses the core objective of the EU Strategic Agenda 2024–2029, which commits the Union to "strengthen our democratic resilience" and explicitly calls for "tackling foreign interference and countering attempts at destabilisation, including through disinformation and hate speech". As an honest broker, Ireland is uniquely positioned to champion a whole-of-society approach to this challenge. The Adult and Community Education (ACE) sector, with its deep community roots, is the most effective existing channel for reaching diverse and potentially vulnerable adult populations (including those not engaged in formal tertiary education) who are primary targets of malicious information campaigns. Ireland’s priority must therefore be to professionalise the ACE workforce to become the European Union’s frontline trainers in critical Global Citizenship Education and media literacy. This ensures that the fight against disinformation is not solely a top-down legislative or technology issue, but a bottom-up, empowering educational movement. By focusing on Global Citizenship Education (GCE), which promotes critical, independent thinking on complex global issues, the Presidency would deliver a tangible commitment to strengthening European values—namely, "freedom, democracy, equality," and the commitment to a "more democratic Union for our citizens". This focus translates an abstract geopolitical priority into a concrete, people-centred benefit.

geography:
Our geographical focus is all-of-Island on the Island of Ireland in operational expertise and both EU-wide, and global  in terms of strategic influence and reach.
Operational Focus (Island of Ireland): As the designated strategic partnership, our work encompasses all of Ireland, targeting the entire Further Education and Training (FET) and ACE sector, including rural and urban areas and parallel organisations in Northern Ireland. We work with a broad range of relevant bodies (e.g., AONTAS, Irish Rural Link) to reach a diverse population of practitioners and learners across the Island.
Strategic Focus (EU-wide): The purpose of this submission is to leverage the Irish Presidency to champion a policy that promotes an EU-wide standard. response_text: The Irish Presidency should focus its work under the Education, Youth, Culture and Sport (EYCS) Council configuration. The key legislative focus should be to propose a Council Recommendation on Professionalising Adult Education Practitioners for Critical Media Literacy. Policy Alignment and Goals: Anchoring in NEAAL: The Recommendation should be directly anchored in the implementation of the Council Resolution on a New European Agenda for Adult Learning (NEAAL) 2021–2030. This leverages an existing EU framework and aligns with the Strategic Agenda's commitment to "invest in people's skills, training and education throughout their lives". Mandate for Quality: The Recommendation should propose an EU-wide standard for mandatory, funded Continuous Professional Development (CPD) for all Adult Learning and Education (ALE) practitioners in the domain of GCE and critical media literacy. This addresses the established organisational requirement for "meaningful space and time" and "funding pathways" for tutors to engage in GCE courses. Financial Mechanism: Ireland should aim to secure agreement on a proposal for dedicated, ring-fenced EU funding (e.g., via ESF+ or Erasmus+) to cover both the cost of providing the specialist CPD and the cost of paying practitioners for their time to take these courses. This elevates the importance of the ACE educator role. Presidency Achievement: The Irish Presidency is an excellent opportunity to secure a Council consensus and adoption of this recommendation, effectively establishing a common EU standard and resourcing commitment to create a network of skilled educators capable of consolidating social cohesion, strengthening democracy, and addressing the megatrends of misinformation and disinformation, and the concomitant rise of damaging political ideologies at a community level.

response_text: Focusing the Presidency’s work on professionalising Adult Education practitioners is one of the most effective means to generate a substantial positive impact that is felt at the local, grassroots level. Impact on People and Communities: The direct beneficiaries are the millions of adult learners and citizens reached by highly skilled practitioners. The core function of GCE is to enable "informed, active citizenry" who can "critically explore" global issues and "challenge stereotypes". Equipping educators with media literacy skills directly translates into: Enhanced Societal Resilience: Communities become better equipped to identify and reject foreign manipulation, polarisation tactics, and hate speech, thereby protecting social cohesion and trust in democratic institutions. Active Citizenship: Critical literacy provides people with the knowledge and skills to address pressing issues like inequality and climate crisis with an empathetic and informed global mindset. Impact on Business and the EU as a Whole: A strong, resilient democracy is the essential foundation for a "stronger, more prosperous and more democratic Union". When citizens are less susceptible to disinformation, businesses and the wider economy benefit from: Stability and Trust: Reduced political and social instability fosters a more predictable and trustworthy environment for investment and economic growth. Skilled Workforce: The policy reinforces the commitment to "strengthening human capital". Critical digital and media literacy is an increasingly vital professional skill required to navigate the digital transition, making the workforce more adaptable and competitive.

geography:
Our geographical focus is all-of-Island on the Island of Ireland in operational expertise and both EU-wide, and global  in terms of strategic influence and reach.
Operational Focus (Island of Ireland): As the designated strategic partnership, our work encompasses all of Ireland, targeting the entire Further Education and Training (FET) and ACE sector, including rural and urban areas and parallel organisations in Northern Ireland. We work with a broad range of relevant bodies (e.g., AONTAS, Irish Rural Link) to reach a diverse population of practitioners and learners across the Island.
Strategic Focus (EU-wide): The purpose of this submission is to leverage the Irish Presidency to champion a policy that promotes an EU-wide standard. The focus for a Council Recommendation on Professionalising Adult Education Practitioners for Critical Media Literacy is intended to establish a common, continent-wide framework for quality-assured GCE practice, directly aligning with the EU Strategic Agenda's goals for democratic resilience across all Member States.
response_text: The policy of "Investing in Europe's Educators" is highly communicable and generates tangible ownership by demonstrating that the EU's power is deployed to protect citizens' agency. Communication Strategy: 'The Critical Citizen's Defence' The communication should frame the policy not as a bureaucratic training exercise, but as a "Citizens' Defence" initiative. Translate Policy to Skill: Avoid jargon like 'GCE'. Communicate the benefit: "The Irish Presidency is funding your local adult education centre to give you the skills to tell fact from fiction online, protecting you and your community from those who seek to divide us." Highlight Local Impact: Promote the local ACE practitioner as a trusted community champion. Feature educators who have completed the new CPD modules, telling their stories of how they empower local learners to navigate disinformation. This creates an authentic narrative of benefit. Values-Driven Narrative: Link the policy directly to fundamental EU values. The message is that the EU is proactively promoting "freedom of thought" and "democratic dialogue" by ensuring citizens, not algorithms or foreign actors, control their own information environment. Creating Ownership: Ownership is created by ensuring the Presidency's impact is visible in the local ACE/FET centres. The policy mandates and funds a direct transfer of power and resource to local communities across all Member States. By supporting CPD, Ireland ensures that its Presidency delivers on the NEAAL goals and leverages the deep community connections of organisations like Saolta and its partners (e.g., Aontas, Irish Rural Link) to make the EU’s actions relevant and tangible to every citizen.

geography:
Our geographical focus is all-of-Island on the Island of Ireland in operational expertise and both EU-wide, and global  in terms of strategic influence and reach.
Operational Focus (Island of Ireland): As the designated strategic partnership, our work encompasses all of Ireland, targeting the entire Further Education and Training (FET) and ACE sector, including rural and urban areas and parallel organisations in Northern Ireland. We work with a broad range of relevant bodies (e.g., AONTAS, Irish Rural Link) to reach a diverse population of practitioners and learners across the Island.
Strategic Focus (EU-wide): The purpose of this submission is to leverage the Irish Presidency to champion a policy that promotes an EU-wide standard. The focus for a Council Recommendation on Professionalising Adult Education Practitioners for Critical Media Literacy is intended to establish a common, continent-wide framework for quality-assured GCE practice, directly aligning with the EU Strategic Agenda's goals for democratic resilience across all Member States.
response_text: To make the Council Recommendation immediately actionable, the Irish Presidency could champion a pilot structure for the proposed Continuous Professional Development (CPD), based on proven GCE models: Core Competency Framework: Develop an EU-recognised framework for GCE/Critical Media Literacy competencies for adult educators, focusing on practical skills such as identifying cognitive biases, analysing information provenance, and facilitating non-polarising community dialogue. Blended Learning Model: The CPD should utilise a blended delivery model (online modules for theory, in-person training for dialogue facilitation) to ensure maximum accessibility and scalability across the EU. Community of Practice (CoP) Funding: Crucially, dedicated funding must be allocated for practitioners to engage in facilitated Communities of Practice (CoPs). As detailed in the Saolta submission, CoPs provide the necessary ongoing support for educators to adapt GCE methodologies to emerging disinformation threats and specific local contexts.

respondent_type: ACADEMIC – PROFESSOR OF HUMAN RIGHTS LAW
sector: CONSTITUTIONAL LAW, HUMAN RIGHTS LAW, EQUALITY
response_text: Foundational values of the EU are under threat in Europe and across the world. We are not simply defending an abstract idea but practical principles, obligations and values that make a genuine difference to the lives of people and have the potential to transform our world for the better. These include shared values that make successful, sustainable, peaceful and stable democratic societies possible. The protection and promotion of human rights and equality are at the heart of this and fundamental to any credible rules-based order. We are living through a time when institutions and individuals who defend these basic values are themselves at risk. The EU has an opportunity to demonstrate genuine leadership by living up to its own foundational principles in this perilous moment of challenge and change. As a global leader in the field of human rights, for example, Ireland is exceptionally well placed to take the initiative. This is underpinned by the reality of a relatively successful peace process on this island, where there are lessons for Europe and the world, including how peaceful and democratic constitutional change can be made possible. Connected to this overarching vision of Irish leadership, it is likely, for example, that Ireland will be undergoing a process of transition in the decades ahead, as envisioned by the anticipated choice in the Good Friday Agreement. The promise made by the European Council in April 2017 to Northern Ireland - on automatic EU return - retains its power and relevance today. Conversations should be commenced during this time to ensure that whatever happens next on this island is managed responsibly and well. Given our extensive history with processes of peacebuilding, anchored in shared values, Ireland is well placed to lead an EU-wide conversation about defending our collective principles and obligations in times of threat and crisis. Everyone has a formidable interest in defending multilateral systems that live up to their foundational principles and fundamental values.

respondent_type: ACADEMIC – PROFESSOR OF HUMAN RIGHTS LAW
sector: CONSTITUTIONAL LAW, HUMAN RIGHTS LAW, EQUALITY
response_text: Ireland should take a leadership role in defending human rights and equality within the EU. In particular, against the rollback on foundational values that are hardwired into the EU legal order. In doing this the Irish Presidency could make clear that these guarantees are linked to healthy, successful and sustainable democratic societies. In other words, our commitments to human rights and equality make us fairer and better places for people to live. That will include ensuring FRA and IHREC are given their rightful place in ongoing dialogues and that more is done to raise awareness about the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights. Ireland’s approach to the Presidency should demonstrate this approach in words and deeds. By ensuring the inclusion of relevant institutions and ensuring civil society has a clear role. As indicated above, Ireland should also commence discussions during this EU Presidency with European partners on the potential transition on this island and its implications. The choice on constitutional change promised in the Good Friday Agreement is on the horizon and this with unfold within an EU member state. There are implications for the EU, Ireland has a responsibility to ensure these are considered well in advance. This could include, for example, sponsoring expert roundtables or seminars on constitutional transitions within Europe and the lessons as one way to advance this work. More work is also needed to bring Northern Ireland back more fully within the EU frame in the here and now. That includes, for example, advancing proposals on observer status in the European Parliament.

respondent_type: ACADEMIC – PROFESSOR OF HUMAN RIGHTS LAW
sector: CONSTITUTIONAL LAW, HUMAN RIGHTS LAW, EQUALITY
response_text: See above answers regarding a robust public defence of the foundational values of the EU and its associated institutions.

respondent_type: ACADEMIC – PROFESSOR OF HUMAN RIGHTS LAW
sector: CONSTITUTIONAL LAW, HUMAN RIGHTS LAW, EQUALITY
response_text: The EU retains the potential to be a force for good in a world where repressive authoritarianism is on the march. This is only possible if we do not give up on the values that we are all responsible for defending. Our own peace process and peace agreement demonstrate that values matter. Peaceful, stable, safe, secure, successful and prosperous societies – that people want to inhabit – are underpinned by the foundational values of the EU. We should make no apologies for saying that anywhere in the world. A rules-based order of regulation, with associated values and independent institutions, makes for fairer, safer and better places to live and will send a clear signal globally.

organisation:
International Federation of Reproduction Rights 
Organisations (IFRRO)
response_text: As Ireland prepares for its Council Presidency in 2026, it has a unique opportunity to advance forwardlooking priorities that reinforce the EU’s competitiveness, democratic values, and cultural identity. A central theme should be the support and empowerment of Europe’s Cultural and Creative Sectors and Industries (CCSIs) in the digital age. The European Council’s Strategic Agenda (2024–2029) highlights the importance of promoting cultural diversity and heritage as essential elements of safeguarding European values within a free and democratic Union. It also underscores the crucial role of free, pluralistic media and cultural and linguistic diversity. According to the Declaration on the necessity of culture and media as a safeguard for our European democracies, initiated by the Danish Presidency, which has been co-signed by Patrick O’Donovan the Irish Minister for Culture, Communications and Sport, at a time when protecting the resilience of our democracies is more important than ever, the intrinsic value and transformative power of our culture, cultural heritage, and independent media must be fully recognised. These sectors play a vital role in upholding European values and strengthening democratic resilience. The European CCSIs, including the media sector, are central to the EU’s economic and cultural strength. They provide around 17 million jobs and contribute roughly 7% of EU GDP. Beyond their economic impact, these sectors express the heart of Europe’s identity, diversity, and democratic principles. Europe’s longstanding leadership in art, media, and culture has shaped its global influence. Yet this position is increasingly under pressure due to rapid technological change, especially the rise of AI and other frontier technologies, without said change being accompanied by fit-for-purpose legal protections allowing rightsholders to exercise and enforce their copyright and related rights. EU policy must evolve toward a digital environment that is both innovative and fair, one that protects and promotes European creativity. The unauthorised use of large quantities of creative works for AI training and other copyright-relevant AI-related purposes poses real risks for the sector’s sustainability and for the livelihoods of authors, artists, publishers, and other rightsholders. In many cases, creative content has been copied, processed, and monetised without permission or payment, undermining the exclusive rights guaranteed by EU copyright law. This disrespect of EU rules not only threatens the economic foundations of creative professions but also weakens public trust in technology. Ireland could therefore prioritise the theme: “Culture, Creativity, and Fair Innovation in the Digital Era” Under this banner, the Presidency could work to strengthen the protection of authors, artists, publishers, and rightsholders by promoting robust implementation and enforceability of the EU copyright acquis; ensuring full, actionable transparency in content used for AI purposes; promoting licensing; and exploring fair remuneration models when creative works are used by generative AI models and systems. With input from the relevant parties, Ireland could explore incentives and initiatives that motivate tech platforms to engage in constructive discussions with rightsholders, including practical steps such as structured roundtables to identify opportunities for collaboration. It should also look at the full range of tools available to the sector to enforce its rights, extending beyond copyright law (such as the IPRED Directive – Directive 2004/48/EC) to include mechanisms under competition law. By focusing on this theme, Ireland would highlight core EU strengths: its vibrant creative industries, strong digital economy, and global leadership in copyright and cultural policy.

organisation:
International Federation of Reproduction Rights 
Organisations (IFRRO)
response_text: A key priority for the Irish Presidency in 2026 should be strengthening the EU copyright framework to ensure effective protection of authors, visual artists and artist in general, publishers, rightsholders and their creative works in the AI era. As generative AI technologies increasingly rely on large-scale ingestion and reproduction of creative content, the EU must reinforce rules that safeguard creators, preserve cultural diversity and support sustainable media and cultural ecosystems. Copyright is essential for fostering innovation, strengthening competitiveness and protecting our democracy, culture and fundamental values. Ensuring effective enforcement is equally a matter of upholding the rule of law. All of this work should be guided by the long-standing principles of international and EU copyright law. At the core is the three-step test, set out in the Berne Convention and embedded throughout the EU copyright system. Under this test, any exception to copyright must be limited to specific cases, must not interfere with the normal use of a work, and must not unfairly harm the legitimate interests of rightsholders. This remains the key standard for assessing any proposal to broaden exceptions or limitations. The Irish Presidency should make clear that this principle continues to apply to all EU policy developments, including those involving AI, text and data mining, and the digital use of protected content. In addition, the Presidency could assess and further examine the European Parliament’s proposal to establish an irrebuttable presumption that, for any general-purpose AI model or system placed on the Union market, copyrightprotected works and other protected subject matter have been used for training whenever the applicable transparency obligations have not been fully met.

organisation:
International Federation of Reproduction Rights 
Organisations (IFRRO)
response_text: First and foremost, the Presidency should prioritise open dialogues and inclusiveness with the directly impacted stakeholders (authors, artists, publishers, rightsholders in general and collective management organisations). Building on the work of previous Presidencies (the Danish and, before this, the Polish and Hungarian ones), Ireland could organize structured consultations, expert conferences, and targeted questionnaires to collect evidence and perspectives from across Member States and sectors to assess the impact of AI and digital technologies on Europe’s creative and information ecosystems. Ensuring that all voices (large and small businesses, CCSIs, civil society, and academia) are represented will strengthen the democratic legitimacy of EU policymaking and help achieve balanced and future-proof outcomes. Inclusive dialogue would also facilitate a more coherent implementation of existing EU frameworks. While much attention has been given to audiovisual and music industries, the text, image and publishing sectors, including journalism, literature, visual arts and translation, have faced some of the earliest and most profound disruptions. Generative AI is trained and subsequently built upon vast volumes of protected written and visual material, including press content, literary and visual works, often without authorisation, credit, or remuneration. This not only undermines the rights of authors and publishers but also distorts the market by enabling AI-generated content that is often misleading, unverified, and hallucinatory, competing unfairly with authentic, human-created work.

organisation:
International Federation of Reproduction Rights 
Organisations (IFRRO)
response_text: Social media is now a primary source of information for a majority of EU citizens. The Irish Presidency could take the lead by running an EU-wide awareness campaign that uses visuals, short videos, infographics, and personal stories to clearly explain what the EU has achieved and how its policies make everyday life better. People are more likely to feel connected to their European identity when they understand what it means and why it matters. Sharing regular, easy-to-follow updates on the Presidency’s priorities, decisions, and results, through the accessible channels mentioned above, can help make the Council’s work feel less distant or complicated. Showing how Ireland’s leadership is shaping EU policy on real-life issues like protecting culture and the creative workers would strengthen its image as a positive and influential voice in Europe.

respondent_type:
Collective Management Organisation for 
Performers / Non-Profit Representative Body
sector:
Music and Audiovisual Sector 
Copyright and Related Rights 
Performers’ Neighbouring Rights
geography: Our primary focus is national, but our work is inherently EU-wide and international.
response_text: The Strategic Agenda talks about a free and democratic Europe, a strong and secure Europe that can hold its own in a more confrontational world, and a prosperous, competitive Europe that manages the green and digital transitions, strengthens the single market and supports small and medium sized enterprises and workers. The Culture Compass for Europe sits alongside this and puts culture at the centre of EU decision making. It sets a straightforward test for success: Europe should be the best place to be an artist, which means tackling precarious working lives, rapid digital change and uneven access to funding, backed by investment and partnership with Member States and cultural stakeholders. RAAP supports the submission made by AEPO ARTIS and IMARA on behalf of performers. We do not repeat all of their points here. Instead we focus on issues where Ireland’s experience and RAAP’s role as the Irish performers’ organisation give us a particular angle. Within this framework RAAP suggests three cross cutting thematic priorities for Ireland’s Presidency. First, fair and sustainable digital markets for performers. Streaming and platforms are now the main way people listen to music and watch audiovisual works, yet most performers receive very little from these uses. As a founding member of IMARA, the new global alliance of performers’ collective management organisations, RAAP supports unwaivable equitable remuneration for streaming, strong transparency rules and effective collective management to make “appropriate and proportionate remuneration” real on the ground. Second, a cultural pillar in the EU’s agenda on AI and data. The Strategic Agenda recognises that new technologies bring both opportunities and risks and that Europe should lead in digital industries while holding to its values. The current text and data mining and AI framework does not yet strike that balance for performers. The Presidency should champion an approach where AI developers and platforms cannot free ride on performers’ work but must use properly licensed repertoire under clear rules on consent, transparency, attribution and remuneration. Third, cultural diversity and small markets. The Strategic Agenda commits the Union to promoting cultural diversity and heritage and to strengthening democratic resilience, including through pluralistic media. Ireland is a small music and screen market, with English and Irish language repertoire and a strong live scene. The RAAP v PPI judgment and the Irish legislative reform process show how international rules can affect small markets and performers with less bargaining power. Our aim is fair and sustainable outcomes for all performers, including those from third countries, while avoiding unintended disadvantages for EU performers in the absence of an EU level reciprocity framework. EU digital, AI and trade policies should promote European works, minority language content and local performers. Across these themes Ireland can use its Presidency to join up the Strategic Agenda and the Culture Compass in practice. Strong, independent collective management and unwaivable remuneration rights are tools that help deliver fair pay, competitiveness, cultural diversity and democratic resilience, ensure AI policy serves cultural objectives and advance these goals, not act as barriers to innovation.

respondent_type:
Collective Management Organisation for 
Performers / Non-Profit Representative Body
sector:
Music and Audiovisual Sector 
Copyright and Related Rights 
Performers’ Neighbouring Rights
geography: Our primary focus is national, but our work is inherently EU-wide and international.
response_text: Within this overall framing, we suggest that Ireland’s Presidency focuses on a small number of areas where it can move the dial for performers and the wider cultural ecosystem. Across all of these areas, the Presidency should ensure that performers and their collective management organisations have an effective voice wherever rights and revenues are shared. First, the DSM Directive review, music streaming and fair remuneration. Streaming and platforms are now central to how people discover and consume music, yet most performers see little from these uses. Through EYCS and COMPET, the Presidency should aim for conclusions that assess how the DSM rules on appropriate and proportionate remuneration and transparency are working in practice for performers, invite the Commission to examine unwaivable equitable remuneration for streaming collected by performers’ CMOs, and look at ways to address structural imbalances in bargaining power between performers and large services and right holders. Second, AI, copyright and performers’ rights. As the AI Act and related instruments are implemented, there is concern that existing text and data mining exceptions and transparency obligations do not adequately protect creative repertoire from unlicensed AI training and use. The Presidency should promote a coherent EU approach to AI and copyright that enables practical licensing solutions for the training and use of creative content, makes clear that opt outs and reservations must be technically workable, easy to exercise and respected in practice, and supports a strong EU position in international discussions so that AI systems cannot free ride on performers’ work without consent, credit and remuneration. Third, audiovisual performers, buy outs, Beijing Treaty and term of protection. Recent debates in Ireland on the Finance Bill and the Irish Film Board (Amendment) Bill have highlighted cross party concern about buy out contracts and forced waivers of residuals, particularly where productions receive State support. At EU level, the Presidency should work to advance ratification and implementation of the Beijing Treaty on Audiovisual Performances, open a discussion on the term of protection for audiovisual performers to address the current gap with phonogram performers, and encourage an approach in which State aid and tax relief schemes are aligned with unwaivable performers’ rights and do not facilitate coercive buy outs. Screen sector copyright frameworks, nationally and at EU level, should include performers’ CMOs alongside unions and producers. Fourth, representation, status of the artist and personality rights. Ireland’s experience with joint performer and producer rights in recorded music shows the importance of ensuring that performers have an equal voice wherever rights and revenues are shared. The Presidency should support continued Council work on an EU “status of the artist” that links fair remuneration and contractual protection with social protection, and open a structured discussion on personality rights for performers’ voice, likeness and identity in the digital and AI context, including whether a minimum level of harmonised EU protection is needed. Through these strands Ireland can help turn high level principles on fair pay, cultural diversity and responsible digital leadership into concrete outcomes during its Presidency.

respondent_type:
Collective Management Organisation for 
Performers / Non-Profit Representative Body
sector:
Music and Audiovisual Sector 
Copyright and Related Rights 
Performers’ Neighbouring Rights
geography: Our primary focus is national, but our work is inherently EU-wide and international.
response_text: If the Council uses the Irish Presidency to move these issues forward, people should feel the difference in their daily lives, not just see it in official announcements. For performers and other creators, fairer rules on streaming, AI and contracts would show up directly in how they work and how they are paid. Better implementation of the DSM Directive and follow up on the Parliament’s work on music streaming would help turn “appropriate and proportionate remuneration” into real money on real statements, not just a phrase in legislation. Performers would be more likely to see a fair share of the value generated on the major services they drive traffic to every day. Stronger safeguards around text and data mining and AI training, backed up by workable opt outs and proper licensing, would mean that a performer’s work is not quietly scraped into AI systems without their knowledge. Instead, there would be clear rules on consent, credit and pay. Work on audiovisual buy outs, the Beijing Treaty, term of protection and status of the artist would support better contracts and more secure residuals, especially for people who currently feel they have to sign away their rights in order to keep working. For businesses, and especially small and medium sized enterprises in the cultural and creative sectors, clearer and fairer EU rules would reduce uncertainty and help them plan. Collective licensing and statutory remuneration schemes can cut down on negotiations and legal costs and give SMEs a straightforward way to comply with EU law. Guidance at EU level on streaming, AI and performers’ rights would make it easier for smaller labels, producers, venues and platforms to operate on something closer to level terms with very large global players, instead of simply having to accept whatever conditions are offered. Aligning State aid and tax relief schemes with unwaivable performers’ rights would also support more sustainable productions. Public support would go hand in hand with respect for performers’ rights, which is better for investors, better for workers and better for audiences. For communities and the wider public, the impact would be felt in the depth and diversity of cultural life across the Union. When performers and other artists can earn a living and are not left behind by digital and AI driven change, local music scenes, independent film, regional broadcasters and venues are more likely to survive and grow. Stronger rules on fair remuneration and AI use would help ensure that the value created by European works is not drained away to a small number of global actors, but supports local jobs, minority language content and a genuinely diverse public space. If Ireland can help the Council join up its work on DSM implementation, streaming, AI, audiovisual rights, cultural policy and the status of the artist, the result should be that fair pay, cultural diversity and responsible digital leadership are not just aims on paper, but things that people, businesses and communities can actually see and feel in their daily lives.

respondent_type:
Collective Management Organisation for 
Performers / Non-Profit Representative Body
sector:
Music and Audiovisual Sector 
Copyright and Related Rights 
Performers’ Neighbouring Rights
geography: Our primary focus is national, but our work is inherently EU-wide and international.
response_text: From our point of view, the best way is to make it real and close to everyday life. If people can see how decisions taken in Brussels show up in their work, their communities and the culture they enjoy, they are more likely to feel that this is “ours” and not just something distant. For performers and other artists, the EU is very concrete. It is there in pay statements, contracts, streaming income and how AI systems are allowed to use their work. For audiences, it is there in what music and films are available, whose stories are told and in what conditions. The Presidency should lean into that and tell the story plainly. First, tell the story of EU wins for artists and cultural workers. Instead of talking only in terms of directives and regulations, explain in simple language how EU rules on fair remuneration, transparency, AI, status of the artist and audiovisual rights are meant to support fair pay, better contracts and cultural diversity. Short, concrete examples will land best. Showing how a specific EU rule has helped a working musician, actor or small producer will do more than general messaging. These examples should come from Ireland and from other Member States, to underline that this is a shared European effort. Second, make performers and other cultural workers visible in Presidency events. Cultural programmes, concerts, screenings and conferences linked to the Presidency should not just showcase work, but also give a little space to the people behind it. Short contributions from performers, unions and collective management organisations explaining how EU rules on streaming, AI, copyright and residuals affect them in practice would help people join the dots. Involving organisations such as RAAP, AEPO ARTIS, IMARA, SCAPR and their members would show that the Presidency is listening to those directly affected. Third, involve young people and future creators. Schools, youth organisations, local venues and regional broadcasters could host Presidency linked projects that look at creativity, work and technology in the cultural sector. Workshops on streaming, AI, copyright and fair pay, developed with artists and CMOs, would give young people space to ask questions and to see how EU decisions shape their future working lives. Simple explanatory material, jointly developed by Irish and EU institutions, could help build understanding and a sense that this is “our Presidency”. Fourth, use the Oireachtas as a bridge. Joint sessions between the relevant Dáil and Seanad committees and the Presidency team, with participation from performer representatives, would help keep the public narrative on streaming, AI, performers’ rights and cultural policy coherent. If TDs and Senators are engaged and confident on these issues, they can help explain to their constituents how Ireland is using its time in the Chair. If people can see that the work done during Ireland’s Presidency helps protect fair pay, cultural diversity and responsible use of technology in the arts, it will be much easier to communicate the value of EU membership and to build a genuine sense of shared ownership.

respondent_type:
Collective Management Organisation for 
Performers / Non-Profit Representative Body
sector:
Music and Audiovisual Sector 
Copyright and Related Rights 
Performers’ Neighbouring Rights
geography: Our primary focus is national, but our work is inherently EU-wide and international.
response_text: RAAP welcomes this consultation and the chance to feed into Ireland’s preparations for the 2026 Presidency. For us, the key is that work on streaming, DSM implementation, AI, audiovisual rights, cultural policy and the status of the artist is not treated in isolation. If these strands are joined up, the Council’s work can add up to a coherent, performer centred agenda rather than a set of separate discussions. Recent Oireachtas debates on copyright, finance and film have already shown strong cross party concern about performers’ rights, equitable remuneration, buy outs and residuals, and clear expectations that Ireland should use its EU Presidency to help deliver fair outcomes at European level. There is an awareness that EU follow up on copyright and related rights, if not handled carefully, could unintentionally undermine reforms now being put in place nationally and reverse hard won gains for marginalised performers. It will be important that the Presidency team is fully aware of this record and that there is a good two way flow between work in Brussels and work in the Oireachtas. In that context, one point deserves particular attention. Equal split provisions for equitable remuneration only really work if the law also makes clear how the performers’ unwaivable right is exercised in practice and who actually collects and manages the performers’ share. When this is left vague, it creates uncertainty for users and leaves performers depending on private arrangements that may not reflect what the legislator intended. Where revenues are collected and controlled by entities that mainly represent producers, there is a built in conflict of interest and a risk that performers do not receive the full benefit of the right. Even if the legal share is equal, decisions on tariffs, costs, distribution rules and dispute handling all shape what performers actually see. For that reason, it would be helpful if Ireland, during its Presidency, could encourage Member States to design systems that reduce these conflicts and protect the performers’ side of the bargain, while respecting the legitimate interests of producers as joint right holders, and to ensure that performers’ CMOs are genuinely representative of and accountable to performers and have an equal voice wherever rights and revenues are shared. Timing also matters. In the next few years the Union will revisit the DSM Directive, implement the AI Act and take forward the Culture Compass and other cultural initiatives. Ireland’s Presidency will sit in the middle of that cycle. There is an opportunity to make sure that work done in EYCS and COMPET pulls in the same direction on fair pay, cultural diversity and responsible use of technology, and that performers’ collective management organisations are properly included in the conversation. RAAP stands ready to provide evidence and experience to support the Presidency team and the Oireachtas. We work every day with performers, users and sister organisations across Europe and beyond, and we see directly how EU rules play out in contracts, income and access to markets, especially in smaller markets.
