sector: All sector and all areas of work
response_text: MCTU’s priority is decent work as articulated in SDG 8 and quality jobs for all. Both are co-dependent and are central to competitiveness, innovation and social cohesion. Quality jobs is core to the EU’s Strategic Agenda 2024-2029 and the European Commission President’s Political Priorities for the 2024-2029 European Commission. The latter commit a ‘Quality Jobs Roadmap’, developed with the social partners to support fair wages, good working conditions, training and fair job transitions for workers and self-employed people, notably by increasing collective bargaining coverage and to a Quality Jobs Act. The EU already has the foundation from which to deliver this Roadmap and Act, namely, the implementation of its Adequate Minimum Wage Directive. The ruling on 11th November last by the EU Court of Justice unequivocally confirmed the validity of the Directive’s core provisions promoting collective bargaining, ensuring that the fight for fair wages in Europe continues on firm legal ground. It is clear from this judgement can – and must act – on fair wages and quality jobs. As the Commission’s Roadmap says, access to quality jobs ‘strengthens territorial, economic and social cohesion, allowing individuals to enjoy a “right to stay” and thrive in their local communities and supporting long-term economic participation across regions. This is crucial for Meath which has one of the highest levels of commuting for work in the country. In addition, all EU countries are bound by the European Social Charter, which requires effective mechanisms to ensure fair and adequate wages and to promote collective bargaining. Across Europe economic and social divisions are growing and contributing to social and political destabilisation, as manifested in growing of xenophobia, resurgent far right political rhetoric and sustained attempts to row back on hard-won workers’ rights and rights of minorities. Income inequality is driving people apart and Europe’s housing crisis is fuelling these negative trends.

sector: All sector and all areas of work
response_text: Following on from our response to Question 1, the Quality Jobs Roadmap and the legislative proposal for a Quality Jobs Act should be a focus of work for the Irish Presidency. MCTU also underlines that current proposals such as the draft traineeships directive; the draft regulation on support to workers affected by imminent job displacement in enterprises undergoing restructuring (i.e. amending the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund); the draft regulation on the coordination of social security systems, and the sixth revision of the carcinogens, mutagens and reprotoxic substances directive (CMRD) may not be completed by the end of the Cypriot Presidency by June 2026. In such circumstances, the Irish Presidency should aim to do so during its term. We also underline the importance previously announced Commission commitments to a new action plan to implement the European Pillar of Social Rights, and the EU housing package consisting of the European Affordable Housing Plan, the review of state aid rules on services of general economic interest in order to better facilitate support for affordable housing and the housing construction. EU-wide progress on affordable homes for all is central to social cohesion and social wellbeing, not least for younger generations who are hit by economic precarity and reduced social mobility. MCTU underline’s its concern that ‘simplification' measures adopted by the EU Council and Parliament across various sectors, aimed at reducing administrative burdens on business and boosting competitiveness, do not undermine the right to collective bargaining, decent work and fair wages. In addition, and in the interest of value for tax payer’s money we are seeking the establishment of publicly owned construction company within the Municipalities that will build and service all social housing. This could be achieved and commence initially in a pilot format starting with one Municipality identified in each of our provinces. This progressive model also feed well into Question 1 above in the legislation for Quality Jobs Roadmap.

sector: All sector and all areas of work
response_text: The Irish Presidency of the EU Council in 2004 was historic in terms of EU enlargement with all the benefits for millions of European citizens. The 2026 Presidency requires equally bold vision and a clear articulation of European values. The challenges to the latter are manifold. The US National Security Strategy released last week posits a concerted attempt to ‘resist’ and undermine these values. Our presidency must not only articulate those values but endorse pathways to sustaining and deepening the Union’s values as set out - https://european-union.europa.eu/principles-countries-history/principles-and-values/aims-and-values_en Economic justice, decent work and quality jobs for all will not only sustain Europe’s economic innovativeness and competitiveness: they are also central to social cohesion premised on values, human rights and a focus on collective and individual well-being.

sector: All sector and all areas of work
response_text: Since the European Council’s Strategic Agenda 2024-2029 committed to address the ‘aspirations of our citizens’, the most effective way of Ireland doing this as far as workers are concerned would be by strengthening and developing the EU’s framework on social dialogue and collective bargaining during its Council Presidency. As the Council’s 2023 Recommendation on strengthening social dialogue points out, countries with ‘robust frameworks for social dialogue and a wide coverage of collective bargaining tend to have more competitive and resilient economies.’

sector: All sector and all areas of work
response_text: MCTU refers the Irish government to the EU Council’s ‘Conclusion’ on Gaza and the Occupied Palestinian Territories issued on 23rd October last. * If the Occupied Territories Bill, before the Houses of the Oireachtas since 2018 and contained in the last two Programmes for Government is not enacted in advance of assumption of the Presidency, the potential impact of the 2026 Irish Presidency will be undermined from the start. Our Taoiseach and Tanáiste have repeatedly condemned the genocide in Gaza and prior to that, in May 2021, the de-facto annexation of Palestinian territories accompanied by settler/IDF lethal violence and expulsion of Palestinians from their homes. It is time for sanctions against Israel, including suspending the EU-Israel Association Agreement. * https://www.consilium.europa.eu/en/policies/eu-position-situation-middle-east/#:~:text=The%20European%20Council%20reiterates%20the,Corridor%20to%20supplement%20land%20routes.

organisation:
University College Dublin (www.ucd.ie) and All-
Island Cancer Research Institute (www.aicri.org)
response_text: Ireland has a unique opportunity as a bridge builder between the EU and non-EU countries, particularly the US and the UK. Moreover, the model of post-conflict partnership across borders, as illustrated by the Good Friday Agreement and the Shared Island Unit, is an aspect that can be shared more universally across the EU, especially in times where geo-political tensions are rising. Given the recent launch of the EU Life Sciences Strategy and Ireland’s pending development of their own strategy in this area, there is a unique opportunity to focus on the theme of Life Sciences Innovation during our Presidency. This would also fit with the wider Strategic Agenda 2024-2029 in respect of development of a more prosperous and competitive Europe. This thematic focus is also timely given the recent launch of the ARC Hub for Therapeutics, which is co-funded by the Government of Ireland and the EU through the ERDF Southern, Eastern & Midlands Regional Programme 2021-2027. Such a focus on Life Sciences Innovation would also provide a platform to illustrate the need for strengthened health cooperation at European levels, as well as the need for appropriate investment in skills, training and education. An area of strength and opportunity that could be highlighted in this context would be Cancer, especially given the context of Europe’s Beating Cancer Plan and the EU Cancer Mission. Ireland has shown its ability to act as an international bridge builder in this particular area via the inaugural Joint Euro-American Forum on Cancer (https://euroamericanforumoncancer.org/) held in Farmleigh House on 25th-26th April 2024. This ‘Davos for Cancer’ event brought together 100 leaders in cancer research and policy from Europe and the US to discuss the key topics of lung cancer and cancer inequalities. This event was organised by the All-Island Cancer Research Institute (www.aicri.org), with support from the Department of Health and the National Cancer Control Programme. Given the Ireland’s current 10-year National Cancer Strategy is finishing in 2026, during the EU Presidency period, provides a key focal point for reflection on progress and a platform for EU wide discussion on an issue of shared importance to health and our economy.

organisation:
University College Dublin (www.ucd.ie) and All-
Island Cancer Research Institute (www.aicri.org)
response_text: A critical public health challenge relates to the increased incidence of chronic disorders, particularly cancer, in Ireland and across the EU. While considerable progress has been made under Europe's Beating Cancer Plan and the EU Cancer Mission, there is a need to better integrate research and policy in the cancer arena at both national and EU levels. In this context, the recent advent of National Cancer Mission Hubs and associated network across the EU and associated countries, as being developed under the EU Cancer Mission project, ECHoS (https://cancermissionhubs.eu/), provides a unique opportunity to address this key issue, particularly in relation to how best address cancer inequalities and take full advantage of the enormous advances that have taken place in the cancer research landscape for the benefit of our citizens. National Cancer Mission Hubs, which bridge research and policy, are currently being developed across the EU, and the timing of the EU Presidency in Ireland would be a key opportunity to mark the launch of our own Hub, as well as mark the progress of other Hubs around Europe. This topic is also highly timely given that our current National Cancer Strategy is ending its 10-year cycle in 2026, and we are now starting to look towards the next phase.

organisation:
University College Dublin (www.ucd.ie) and All-
Island Cancer Research Institute (www.aicri.org)
response_text: Ireland can champion the concept of mainstreaming innovation in the cancer research and policy ecosystem. We can also highlight the benefit of working with our colleagues in Northern Ireland to break down barriers, i.e. 'Cancer Knows No Borders'. Last year, we (the All-Island Cancer Research Institute) released an InterTradeIreland-commissioned report on the oncology industry ecosystem, which was jointly launched by the two Ministers of the Economy from respective jurisdictions. It showed a compelling story in terms of indigenous innovation, alongside our well-known successes in drug manufacturing (https://www.aicri.org/published-articles/allisland-oncology-industry-report). This report, which was jointly launched by two respective Ministers with economy portfolios from Ireland and Northern Ireland, is also feeding into the wider narrative around the development of a life sciences strategy in Ireland. This has now led to follow-on funding for a new All-Island Oncology Innovation Cluster, which will be formally launched in 2026. Finally, the focus of collaboration in the cancer space between Ireland and Northern Ireland has shown key international leadership in tackling an area of commonality despite challenging political circumstances. Indeed, this beacon of hope and clear demonstration of the 'health dividend of peace' is all the more pressing.

organisation:
University College Dublin (www.ucd.ie) and All-
Island Cancer Research Institute (www.aicri.org)
response_text: Cancer provides an ideal focal point to show how cross-border collaboration can directly benefit EU citizens. One in 2 people will be diagnosed with cancer in their lifetime and practically every family is either directly or indirectly affected. The current high-level focus within the EU on this topic is an aspect which can clearly resonate with the broader community.

All.Can recommends that Ireland place people centred, resilient and efficient health systems at the heart of its overarching Presidency narrative. Cancer care offers a compelling lens through which to advance these values because it exemplifies the intersection of demographic change, innovation uptake, workforce pressures and socioeconomic inequality. Person centred cancer care aligns strongly with the EU Strategic Agenda 2024 to 2029, which commits the Union to strengthening competitiveness, resilience and preparedness while improving quality of life for citizens. We recommend a set of interlinked high-level priorities: Delivering people centred services across the life course Ireland’s Presidency can foreground the importance of involving people in decisions about their health journeys and enabling services that are accessible, equitable and responsive. Cancer care provides established evidence on the value of shared decision making, psychosocial support, and the removal of system inefficiencies that compromise patient outcomes. A focus on person centredness also reinforces the EU’s pathway towards better prevention and early detection, key to achieving sustainable health expenditure. Building efficient and sustainable health systems through innovation and data Efficiency should be understood not as cost cutting but as making best use of resources to maximise patient value. Under the next MFF programming cycle, there is a critical opportunity to orient investment towards digital transformation, interoperable cancer data infrastructures, cross border clinical collaboration and evidence generation on real world outcomes. Ireland can champion the principle that efficient cancer care strengthens both fiscal discipline and population wellbeing. Ensuring resilience and preparedness through multi sector and multi country cooperation The Presidency can emphasise the relevance of integrated approaches to cancer and non communicable diseases. This includes addressing workforce shortages, supporting supply chain security for oncology products, strengthening prevention and screening programmes and advancing health equity. Ireland is well placed to steer consensus around implementation of Europe’s Beating Cancer Plan, drawing lessons from the EU Cancer Mission and the Pharmaceutical Strategy for Europe. These suggested priorities support a people centred and future oriented Presidency theme and contribute meaningfully to EU competitiveness, cohesion and societal resilience. A critical enabler of efficient, person centred cancer care is the implementation of meaningful efficiency metrics across the full care pathway. All.Can’s research consistently shows that inefficiency remains invisible without reliable, comparable data. Ireland’s Presidency can underline the value of EU level coordination on metrics that capture what truly matters to patients, including time to diagnosis, navigational burden, avoidable delays, quality of life and survivorship outcomes. Embedding such metrics in EU funding programmes and policy monitoring would strengthen accountability and promote system learning across Member States.

All.Can recommends that Ireland prioritise policy areas that support sustainable cancer care delivery, strengthen efficiency and reinforce patient centred approaches. Specific areas include: Implementation and future proofing of Europe’s Beating Cancer Plan During Ireland’s Presidency, the Council will likely consider several initiatives linked to the Plan's continued rollout under the next MFF. Ireland can facilitate progress on screening implementation, early detection, inequalities reduction and survivorship frameworks. Clear political commitment to long term financing will be essential. Supporting the next Multiannual Financial Framework with a strong health and research dimension Cancer is a strategic driver of innovation and competitiveness. The next MFF should ensure that EU4Health, Horizon Europe successor programmes, structural funds and digital programmes can continue to support Member State capacity for efficient and person-centred cancer care. Ireland can advocate for targeted investment in data infrastructure, workforce training, health system performance measurement and cross border cancer networks. Lastly, efficiency metrics that reflect patient experience and outcomes are essential for improving cancer care across the EU. Their implementation enables Member States to identify bottlenecks, benchmark cancer pathways, and evaluate the impact of reforms. Ireland’s Presidency is well positioned to advance discussion on standardised metrics and encourage their use in assessing EU funded reforms under the next MFF. Advancing policy related to data use, artificial intelligence and digital health The implementation of the European Health Data Space will require careful Council level coordination. Efficient cancer care depends on high quality data sharing, real world evidence and interoperable systems. Ireland’s Presidency can drive agreement on practical, trustworthy governance frameworks that empower patients and unlock innovation. Finalisation or strengthening of oncology relevant elements of the Pharmaceutical Package This includes ensuring that regulatory and access reforms support availability of oncology medicines, encourage innovation and address inefficiencies in current access pathways. Ireland can help broker balanced compromises that respect both public health priorities and sustainable innovation ecosystems. Progress on health workforce initiatives Cancer outcomes depend on a skilled and adequately distributed workforce. The Council should continue work on mobility, skills recognition and workforce planning. Ireland can highlight cancer care as a relevant use case for coordinated EU action. Ireland’s Presidency can thus help ensure the Council advances a coherent set of actions that embed person centred and efficient cancer care within broader EU policy priorities.

A Presidency that champions efficient, people centred cancer care can generate broad benefits across society and the economy. For people Improved access to timely diagnosis, comprehensive support and equitable care pathways leads to better survival, improved quality of life and reduced financial stress for families. By supporting prevention and early detection, Ireland can help the EU shift resources upstream and reduce the burden of avoidable suffering. Clear frameworks for patient involvement reinforce trust in institutions and democratic processes. For health systems and communities Efficiency improvements contribute to reduced bottlenecks, better resource allocation and improved workforce wellbeing. Cancer care accounts for sizeable portions of national health budgets. Efficient pathways free clinical capacity, reduce waste and enable investment in prevention and communitybased services. These reforms can be replicated across other non communicable diseases. For businesses and the EU innovation ecosystem Predictable, future oriented EU frameworks on health data, research funding, cross border collaboration and oncology regulation make Europe more competitive in life sciences and medical technologies. A strong MFF that supports health and digital transformation strengthens Europe’s relevance as a global innovation hub. For regional cohesion Cancer outcomes continue to vary significantly across regions. Council initiatives that support capacity building, digital connectivity and workforce development can help narrow inequalities and support inclusive growth. Ireland can therefore use its Presidency to demonstrate how people centred cancer care contributes directly to economic resilience, technological leadership and social cohesion across the Union.

Cancer affects every family in Europe, which makes it an accessible and unifying narrative for public communication during Ireland’s Presidency. Ireland could use cancer care as a real-life example of how EU cooperation improves citizens’ lives by: Highlighting tangible EU delivered benefits Examples include cross border access to expertise, EU funded screening and prevention programmes, research investments and digital infrastructure. Communicating these through human stories will make EU action relatable. Emphasising people centred decision making Ireland’s proposed overarching message focused on people and the future aligns closely with All.Can’s mission. Messaging should explain how EU Presidencies work and how consensus building protects citizens’ interests. Engaging patient organisations, youth groups and local communities Co creation with patient communities fosters legitimacy and helps citizens see themselves as stakeholders in the Presidency. Ireland could also showcase examples of community based cancer initiatives supported by EU funds. Ensuring clarity and accessibility in communication Materials should avoid institutional jargon and focus on simple narratives about prevention, early detection, patient empowerment and efficient public services. Cancer stories can be powerful vehicles for showing the EU’s added value. Leveraging digital and cultural channels Partnerships with cultural institutions, schools and local authorities would help broaden engagement. Storytelling formats can feature lived experiences, clinician voices and community perspectives. This approach reinforces understanding of the EU as a collaborative project that safeguards health and wellbeing.

All.Can would welcome Ireland’s commitment to a people centred Presidency. We encourage Ireland to consider cancer care not solely as a health issue but as an illustrative model for efficient public services, innovation driven growth and social fairness. Our coalition has extensive evidence demonstrating that inefficiencies in cancer care impose significant costs on health systems, delay diagnosis and compromise outcomes. Investing in person centred, efficient cancer pathways therefore yields a dual return: improved patient experience and better longterm sustainability. All.Can strongly encourages Ireland to also highlight the importance of EU wide efficiency metrics, which remain an underdeveloped but highly impactful policy tool. Efficiency should be measured not merely in financial terms but through metrics that reflect the full value delivered to patients. These include timely and accurate diagnosis, coordinated care planning, reduction of avoidable emergency presentations, smoother transitions between services, and real-world quality of life outcomes. Doing so would give Member States practical tools to identify waste, reallocate resources and scale best practices. Implementing agreed efficiency metrics across cancer care would significantly enhance transparency, support evidence-based policy and accelerate learning across the Union. We would be pleased to provide further technical input or share evidence from our international work, including insights from our cross-country efficiency studies, patient surveys and multi stakeholder policy dialogues.

The Danish Presidency of the Council (1 July – 31 December 2025) acknowledged that digitalisation and AI pose significant challenges for copyright (and intellectual property) frameworks. This is a matter of particular relevance to the Creative Industries. In this document when we refer to the Creative Industries or Creators we mean writers, songwriters, composers, performers, producers, publishers and all who depend upon copyright to protect their livelihoods and the output of their creative endeavour. ICIF hopes that the Irish Presidency will make copyright protection a cornerstone of its agenda and in particular in the following areas: - 1. Artificial Intelligence & Copyright We are in an era of rapid technology change, including GEN AI and the Creative Industries have a crucial role in fostering the development of smart knowledge-based economies founded on technological innovation with high-value output and based on human creativity and talent. Creative Industries embrace digital innovation and technological change and are at the forefront of recognising that the use of AI responsibly has the potential to enhance human artistry. We hope that the Irish Presidency ensures that EU policy discussions on AI meaningfully address the Creative Industries’ concerns about unlicensed AI training data, usage of copyrighted content, licensing of works for AI, attribution of output, provenance, and remediation for creators and that the Presidency will support existing transparency obligations on AI platforms that train on or generate creative works—requiring: disclosure of the source material used; disclosure of the licences/permissions obtained; disclosure of the terms under which outputs can be used, adapted or commercialised; mechanisms for creators to claim remuneration or control; compliance with the obligation for detailed record keeping – for the creative sectors this means per work level records when intellectual property has been used by AI services and compliance with the obligation to respect rights reservations by rightholders. With a strong regulatory history, a robust presence of technology companies, and thriving sectors where AI is making significant impacts—including music and pharmaceuticals—Ireland is uniquely situated to champion responsible, rights-aware AI development. Ireland should position itself to shape global norms for trustworthy and innovation-driven AI development. 2. The Three-Step Test. The ICIF hopes that the Irish Presidency will make a firm political commitment that any review, interpretation or reform of EU copyright law or the finalisation of the WIPO Broadcasting Treaty will preserve the integrity of the three-step test, and that exceptions or limitations will remain narrowly tailored, respect Creators’ legitimate interests and avoid undue prejudice to their exploitation rights. The Presidency will hopefully resist any proposals that would weaken the three-step test by introducing overly broad or unlimited exceptions, which could undermine investment, threaten Creators’ income and destabilise the creative ecosystem. The ICIF suggests that a dedicated Council working group under the Irish Presidency could review the role of the three-step test in the digital age, assess how exceptions are functioning in practice, and produce guidance or conclusions reaffirming its centrality.

There are a number of legislative proposals that will be a focus of work for the Irish Presidency as follows: The review of the Directive (EU) 2019/790 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 17 April 2019 on copyright and related rights in the Digital Single Market (DSM Review) will occur during the term of the Irish Presidency. This presents an opportunity to ensure that the DSM’s protections are actually working in practice and delivering fair outcomes, that freedom of contract and protection of exclusive rights will be a priority and that no exceptions to copyright law for the use of Text and Data Mining (TDM) will be introduced. In addition, the requirement for a licence agreement with rightsholders for TDM will be maintained. The Irish Government will hopefully ensure that Regulation (EU) 2024/1689 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 13 June 2024 laying down harmonised rules on artificial intelligence (AI Act) is implemented and applied in a meaningful way; that it maintains a commitment to licensing requirements and that it protects copyright; and that the Code of Practice on marking and labelling AI-Generated content is sufficiently robust. ICIF hopes for delivery on the EU Digital Services Act and support for the new infrastructure e.g. the DSC network through member states and at EU level. With respect to the Proposal for Regulation on simplification of the digital legislation (Digital Omnibus package), the Irish Government will hopefully ensure that the simplification of EU digital rules does not modify the core provisions of the AI Act. The current position regarding contract law, whereby platforms and rightsholders negotiate on a bilateral basis rather than any compulsory collective or centralised format should be maintained. Where there are divergences among member states, Ireland is in a strong position to balance these pressures, given the concentration of technology platforms residing here side by side with a prolific cultural sector. Hopefully the Irish Presidency will emphasise that a strong copyright framework is a vital enabler of the Single Market for creative content, cultural assets and digital services and underscore that protecting creators’ rights is not a regulatory burden but an investment in Europe’s creative economy, cultural diversity and global competitiveness. The Presidency might highlight that robust copyright protection helps safeguard Europe’s cultural sovereignty and control over how cultural goods are created, distributed and monetised in the digital age. This should include a focus on meaningful application of existing rules rather than the introduction of new legislation. The Irish Presidency might convene a high-level stakeholder dialogue between Member States’ copyright ministries, the Commission, creative sectors (including Irish Creative Industries), research libraries, cultural heritage institutions and technology platforms. It is vitally important to Creators that the Irish Presidency ensures that any simplification agenda (frequently cited in digital/AI policy) does not erode fundamental rights of Creators or undermine the legal certainty provided by copyright.

ICIF suggests that the Presidency maintains a human centred focus when dealing with issues of technology and innovation and ensures that any legislative advancement would enhance the protections for the cultural and Creative Industries.

The EU is a beacon for high regulatory standards, democracy and the rule of law. It is also a bastion for the protection of its cultural and creative communities. There is a concern that in the race for competitiveness that this will be lost or compromised. One way of communicating its values and benefits , and creating a sense of ownership would be to ensure that any Commission proposal or Member State initiative to reform copyright (including exceptions, licensing, remuneration mechanisms or AI‐specific measures) be subject to a detailed impact assessment on the Creative Industries, especially concerning how it affects creators ’ income, investment incentives and market structure and that any such impact assessment be done with Creators input. ICIF suggests that there should be a concerted effort to host events and initiatives outside of Dublin. A greater focus on the regions would ensure greater awareness of and involvement in Ireland’s Presidency. This would ensure more people and communities have an opportunity to participate in the activities and as a result would have an increased awareness of the EU, its work and its impact on their lives. Ireland’s cultural reputation is known, respected and appreciated throughout Europe and with the Presidency of the EU we have an unprecedented opportunity to showcase the very best of our cultural creativity to an audience way beyond our shores. Every event organised as part of the EU Presidency whether meeting, conference, discussion, exhibition or other should include an opportunity to demonstrate and share the very best of Irish culture and make the Presidency one that is truly Irish and unique in its content.

The ICIF is interested in hosting a conference on copyright and AI during the term of the Irish Presidency of the EU. This would be primarily for stakeholders and European counterparts and is not intended to cut across the work being planned by the EU Presidency. It is more to add to the conversation, expand the sources of information and increase the involvement of people, businesses and the wider creative community in the activities of the Irish Presidency. The ICIF would be very open to organising this conference in conjunction with the Department and is available for conversations to further the matter.

Tomorrow’s Europe, and Ireland’s moment to shape it. Europe is entering a decisive decade. The map of power, technology and capital is being redrawn and the countries that can turn uncertainty into momentum will shape the world that comes next. In July 2026, Ireland will take the helm of the Council of the European presidency at a time when the continent stands between eras: recovering from crisis, adapting to AI, redefining its place in a fractured global economy. For Ireland, it will not be a ceremonial rotation. It’s a strategic opportunity to shape Europe’s direction and to ensure Irish diplomacy, influence and pragmatism are felt on the continent’s biggest decisions. Every presidency leaves its fingerprint. We are building on a proud tradition. The reunification of Germany, the introduction of the euro, the admission of ten new member states, and agreement on a continental banking regulator are among the headline moments of the last four occasions Ireland held the presidency. It is against this backdrop that Ireland’s upcoming presidency should be about confidence, the confidence to modernise Europe’s rules, to lead on innovation and to show how smart regulation, unified markets and trusted tech can make Europe stronger Ireland is uniquely positioned to lead a European conversation around three themes: As a digital capital (home to the world’s leading tech firms and the regulators who shape them). As a gateway for investment, connecting European capital to global markets. As a bridge across the Atlantic, trusted in the US, respected in the EU. That combination of innovation, credibility and connectivity gives Ireland a voice that can make Europe work better for citizens, businesses and investors alike. The Presidency is Ireland’s chance to put that voice to work and to move Europe through policy into further progress. Deloitte Ireland sees this as Ireland’s chance not just to chair Europe’s agenda but to shape the conversation around competitiveness in three areas. Responsible AI and Digital trust. Europe’s next-generation resilience strategy through security. Turning untapped investment capital into growth. To understand the opportunity ahead, it’s worth remembering how far we’ve come. The last time we held presidency our priority was recovery. Over a decade later, our task is renewal, not to rebuild Europe’s foundations but to reinforce its future with Ireland at its heart.

Deloitte Ireland believes that Ireland is uniquely placed to reinforce the inherent strengths of the European Union, and the Presidency of the Council is a precious moment where European values can be furthered. In this way, Ireland has the potential to consolidate and enhance its role as a gateway between the US and EU not only geographically, but geo-politically. One aspect where Ireland can demonstrate this is in relation to balancing the regulatory priorities of the EU whilst promoting the pro-innovation agenda of the US. There are a number of practical measures that could support this which we touch on below. We would also be happy to provide additional practical suggestions as to how this can be achieved in forthcoming engagement with the Government. In responding to this consultation, we are advocating for an approach that maximises impact in a realistic timeframe. We believe that the Irish Presidency should prioritise promoting Responsible AI and Digital Trust. The current EU regulatory environment is complex and dense. We would like to see an Irish Presidency apply the “appropriate instrument” test from the Draghi report on these regulations. This review should see how the framework is working, how clear is the evidence base for the instrument and whether it is providing demonstrable benefit. During the Presidency, Ireland should bring forward a specific strategy to harness the power of AI. This strategy, again in line with Draghi principle of “balance”, should require the 15 designated competent authorities under the AI Act to implement pro-innovation initiatives and to regulate towards outcome based accountability. The Irish Presidency should seek to establish the extent to which there are interagency co-operation for those competent authorities who are responsible for the operation of these regulations, both within Ireland and at the EU level and to drive efficient and effective cooperation between these authorities. The Irish Presidency should also uphold safety and privacy as pre-requisites for the development of AI. This helps to encourage successful adoption of AI by enhancing the trust of society. It has become increasing clear that the EU, both in terms of its institutions and values are experiencing levels of risk, up to and including military risk, at a level which has not existed since the foundation of the Union. We believe that the Irish Presidency should seek to develop a next-generation resilience strategy with security at its core. To prioritise work on the simplification package to boost Europe’s defence industry and readiness. This package is progressing through the European legislative process, and we would like to see Ireland prioritise the ratification process. Ireland should progress initiatives where technology can be developed for a “dual-use” purpose. These are technologies that can be used in a civilian and military (non-lethal/ defensive) applications. Ireland should use its Presidency to foster deeper relationships between the UK and the EU on physical, cyber and social defence mechanisms. There is untapped investment capital into growth (Savings and Investment Union). The groundwork has been set with the Commission’s Competitive Compass, referred to by President von der Leyen as the “North Star” for the Commissions work over the next five years. The savings and investment union is an enabling strategy and seeks to achieve between €750 and €800 billion of additional investments in the EU per year. EU investment funds are 5 times smaller than the US funds and EU stock exchange capitalisation is 73% of EU GDP, 270% in the US and 130% in the UK (https://finance.ec.europa.eu/publications/market-integration-package_en). We believe that the Irish presidency can help champion initiatives to untap investment capital and to stimulate growth. Developing pragmatic proposals to simplify the securitisation framework, specifically seeking to reducing issuance barriers for European issuers and local investors. In tandem there is merit in preparing proposals to adjust prudential regulation to be more proportionate to the actual risk of each transaction. Prioritise the development of Savings and Investment Accounts (SIA’s). There is a need for a more uniform approach to legislation. EU laws, when transposed into local legislation should be done in a more uniform manner across the EU member states. With the primary intention to simplify and converge supervision rules and implementation, the continued push for a more unified approach as proposed under the capital markets integration package would facilitate the democratisation of investment opportunities and enable funds to trade more seamlessly across national borders. As the proposal seeks to amend over 15 pieces of existing financial services regulatory text, it signals conscious action to a more integrated Union by substantially reducing regulatory arbitrage, potentially replacing fragmented national supervision, and materially lowering cross-border access costs.

Drawing on the previous answer (see above),we believe that the Council can make the most positive impact by focusing on a small number of files and prioritising those areas where the Council can mitigate risk to the European Union whilst also responding to the challenge as set out in the Draghi report on competitiveness and the Letta report on developing the single market. We understand that the Irish Presidency will have to take input from a number of sources which will feed into the work programme for the Council in the second half of 2026. In making the above suggestions, Deloitte Ireland believe we are remaining consistent with the three transformations ahead for Europe as identified by Draghi: The need to accelerate innovation and find new growth engines. Bring down high energy prices while continuing to decarbonise and shift to a circular economy. React to a world of less stable geopolitics, where dependencies are becoming more vulnerable, and where Europe can no longer rely on others for its security. We should also take advantage of our position, physically, economically and diplomatically as a bridging post between Europe and the USA. Ireland’s Council Presidency and the policy areas we have suggested in answer to question 2 are, given the backing of our Council colleagues, appropriately ambitious and have the potential of strengthening the European Union. Ireland has a proud tradition of achievement during our previous terms of office, and we believe these policies would have the potential to build on that legacy of achievement.

Ireland’s Presidency of the Council is an opportunity to re-centre the core ideals that gave life to the European project and to explain their relevance in a world that is becoming more fractured, more volatile and less predictable. The European Union emerged from the devastation of the Second World War as a deliberate answer to a divided continent, built on the conviction that stability and prosperity could only be secured through cooperation grounded in law. Its founding principles are free movement, fair competition, shared standards and institutions designed to resolve disputes peacefully. These were practical safeguards against the return of the instability that had shaped Europe for generations. Communicating these values clearly and confidently is essential today because our global context has changed dramatically. Geopolitical risk has returned, global supply chains are being reorganised, and previous norms cannot be taken for granted. Ireland and Europe have to be deliberate in articulating our values. In the contemporary climate, the strengths of the European model become more visible, predictable rules for citizens and businesses, freedoms that enable mobility and opportunity, and an economic area that amplifies the ability of small countries like Ireland to shape global conversations. These benefits are often assumed, yet they remain central to Europe’s resilience. Ireland’s credibility rests on being outward-looking and trusted on both sides of the Atlantic. The aim should be to emphasise why a strong and coherent EU is in the interests of its citizens and its allies alike. Europe is a rules-based environment where innovation and cross-border cooperation can thrive. Reaffirming these principles helps anchor the Presidency with foundational values; the right to live and work across borders, the protections that come from harmonised standards, and the economic opportunities created by a market of hundreds of millions of people.
Nothing further to add at this time.

Taking into account the current geopolitical and socioeconomic context in Europe, we recommend that Ireland prioritise Health Protection, Citizen Safety, and Resilient Societies as core themes of its 2026 Presidency. Serious allergies and anaphylaxis are rising across Europe and place a growing burden on individuals, schools, workplaces, and public services. Addressing them fits naturally within broader objectives to protect citizens’ wellbeing and reduce preventable health risks. A Resilient and Prepared Europe The EU must be equipped to respond to emergencies—whether acute health events, natural disasters, or public safety threats. This requires harmonised emergency response systems, stronger communitylevel preparedness, and cross-border cooperation. Ireland is one of the few Member States that has taken concrete steps to improve preparedness for serious allergic reactions, including allowing pharmacists to supply emergency medicines without a prescription during anaphylactic events. This national practice demonstrates effective emergency readiness and provides a model for EU-level policy coordination, which could inform upcoming initiatives under the European Health Union framework aimed at strengthening preparedness, prevention, and rapid response across Member States. A People-Centred Union that Protects Embedding people-centred principles into EU policymaking ensures that vulnerable populations and individuals at risk of medical emergencies are not left behind. The Presidency could advance reducing health inequalities across the EU, highlighting uneven access to diagnosis, specialist care, and emergency response protocols. Positioning timely care for serious allergies and anaphylaxis within this agenda demonstrates a commitment to practical, measurable improvements in patient safety and inclusion, while protecting citizens’ rights to safety in everyday environments such as schools, childcare centres, workplaces, and public venues. 3. A Future-Oriented Europe Built on Innovation and Collaboration Ireland’s strong reputation in digital innovation offers an opportunity to promote Digital Innovation for Health, leveraging the European Health Data Space and interoperable, patient-centred tools. For individuals at risk of serious allergic reactions, seamless access to medical information across borders can prevent emergencies and support the free movement of people. The Presidency can also prioritise harmonised awareness-raising, institutional readiness, and capacity building, ensuring schools, businesses, and public institutions are equipped and trained to respond effectively to life-threatening health incidents.

Ireland could use its Presidency to champion health resilience, citizen protection, and emergency preparedness, leveraging its national leadership in anaphylaxis response as a model for EU coordination. Key priorities include: Health Protection and Emergency Preparedness Serious allergies and anaphylaxis present a growing public-health challenge. The Presidency could: Promote timely access to emergency medicines, building on Ireland’s approach where pharmacists can supply life-saving treatment without prescription. Encourage harmonised school and public-venue preparedness, using Ireland as an example. Relevant upcoming EU initiative: Global health resilience initiative (non-legislative, Q2 2026) – to strengthen EU capacity for rapid response to health crises. Digital Innovation for Health Cross-border emergencies require seamless access to patient data: Promote the European Health Data Space for secure, interoperable sharing of health information, enabling faster response to anaphylactic events across borders. Support digital tools for citizen-centred care, enhancing emergency response and patient safety. 3. Reducing Health Inequalities and Strengthening Citizen Rights The Presidency could advance equitable access to emergency care and citizen-centred policy: Link preparedness to strengthening the Child Guarantee (non-legislative, Q2 2026) and Citizens omnibus (legislative, Q4 2026), ensuring children in schools, childcare centres, and communities are protected and have their rights effectively enforced. Promote intergenerational fairness through the Intergenerational fairness strategy (nonlegislative, Q1 2026), ensuring emergency preparedness and health access benefit current and future generations equally. Highlight Ireland’s model as a practical, replicable approach for other Member States. Objectives Establish a model for EU-level anaphylaxis and emergency response coordination, based on best practices of Ireland. Ensure equitable access to life-saving treatments across the EU. Promote digital innovation for preparedness, information sharing, and cross-border patient care. Strengthen citizen rights and intergenerational fairness, ensuring public health policies reflect social equity. Position health resilience as a pillar of EU citizen safety and social cohesion, demonstrating tangible improvements in public health readiness. By focusing on these targeted initiatives, Ireland can use its Presidency to deliver practical, measurable impacts on citizen safety, health equity, and cross-border emergency preparedness while reinforcing the EU’s social and legal frameworks.

The Irish Presidency has the potential to deliver significant, tangible impact for EU citizens by advancing health resilience and consumer safety. For individuals with serious allergies, policies that improve emergency response, access to medicines, and accurate allergen information can be life-saving. For people, expanded access to emergency treatment, including pharmacy-enabled emergency supply across the EU, enhances safety in daily life. Citizens with serious allergies would be better protected in schools, workplaces, sports facilities, cultural venues, and during cross-border travel. For businesses, harmonised allergen-labelling and staff-training expectations reduce regulatory uncertainty, simplify compliance, and improve consumer trust by fostering safer public environments. For communities and institutions, EU-supported readiness measures ,such as common school protocols, public-venue guidelines, and accessible training ,would significantly reduce preventable emergencies, supporting all three Alliance objectives. Replicating Ireland’s best practice on emergency medicine access would ensure that life-saving intervention is available regardless of where a reaction occurs, reducing inequalities across Member States.

Ireland has a strong opportunity to communicate the value of EU membership by focusing on everyday benefits and practical improvements that resonate directly with citizens. The 2026 Presidency can show how EU cooperation protects people, strengthens communities, and makes daily life safer—particularly in areas such as emergency preparedness for serious allergies and anaphylaxis. Highlight Practical Examples of EU Solidarity Citizens understand the EU best when they see clear, relatable outcomes. Ireland can communicate EU values by highlighting how cooperation improves safety and wellbeing, for example: Safer environments in schools, restaurants, transport and public venues. Shared health information that makes travel within the EU safer and more predictable. Harmonised allergen-labelling rules that protect consumers wherever they are. More consistent access to emergency support for serious allergic reactions. Ireland’s own approach—allowing pharmacists to supply emergency treatment during a serious allergic reaction—provides a concrete example of national leadership that improves citizen safety. Propose Council Recommendations on Emergency Readiness To strengthen public understanding of the EU’s benefits, Ireland could lead on a visible, citizen-centred initiative: Develop Council Recommendations on broader readiness and access to emergency treatment for serious allergy and anaphylaxis. This would help encourage Member States to: Improve preparedness in schools, public venues, workplaces, and transport hubs. Ensure trained responders are available across community settings. Reduce inequalities in access to time-sensitive, life-saving care. Such an initiative is easy for citizens to relate to, directly improves safety, and demonstrates EU cooperation in a human, practical way. A simple message: the EU protects people By showcasing initiatives that make everyday life safer, including better emergency preparedness for serious allergic reactions, the Irish Presidency can reinforce a clear message: EU cooperation delivers real, practical benefits for families, children, workers, and communities. This people-centred framing will strengthen public trust, build ownership, and demonstrate the concrete value of Ireland’s leadership at EU level.

This submission is informed and guided by the remit of the Assembly. While recognising the broader strategic role of the Presidency, the submission focuses on the areas within the Assembly’s mandate. Ireland’s 2026 Presidency offers an opportunity to advance a European agenda that reflects both EU-wide priorities and the grounded experience of Ireland’s regions. EMRA recommends that Ireland’s Presidency be guided by four strategic themes, rooted in the Regional Spatial and Economic Strategy (RSES) objectives of healthy placemaking, climate action, just transition, economic opportunity and competitiveness, while also acknowledging the EU’s limited but meaningful role in addressing the housing crisis. Addressing the Housing Crisis While housing remains largely a national competence, Ireland’s Presidency can productively engage at EU level through: Promoting exchange of best practice on sustainable construction, land use management, and public housing delivery models. Supporting EU initiatives on state aid revision, construction sector productivity, skills shortages, and innovation in retrofitting, which directly influence housing supply and affordability. Advocating for targeted use of EU funds to support: energy-efficient renovation, compact urban development, ▪ brownfield regeneration, ▪ sustainable urban mobility. Strengthening Healthy Placemaking and Territorial Cohesion Ireland should champion an EU agenda that places well-being, accessibility, and balanced territorial development at its core. This includes: Advancing cohesion policy reform to ensure that all regions—urban, peri-urban, rural, and transitional— can achieve sustainable, inclusive growth. Promoting sustainable place-based planning frameworks that integrate transport, housing, public services, and nature-based solutions. Prioritising health, liveability, and spatial justice within EU regional policy, recognising the growing evidence linking the built environment to economic and social outcomes. Supporting investment into regional infrastructures that reduces disparities and enhances cross-border and inter-regional cooperation and competitiveness. Accelerating Climate Action and Delivering a Just Transition Ireland’s Presidency should prioritise the implementation of the European Green Deal, with a focus on: Strengthening the Just Transition mechanisms so that regions most affected by decarbonisation—such as former peat-based energy communities—receive targeted support. Promoting multi-level governance approaches that align local, regional, and national climate action. Supporting EU initiatives that embed biodiversity restoration and protection, paying particular attention to the issue of light pollution, climate resilience, and resource efficiency into regional development policy. Highlighting regional experience in aligning carbon budgets, land use, energy planning, and transport systems with climate neutrality goals. Supporting EU Competitiveness Through Regional Innovation and Smart Specialisation Ireland through the Presidency can play a leading role in shaping an EU competitiveness agenda rooted in regional strengths and smart specialisation, including: Advocating for the boosting of EU investment in innovation infrastructures, digitalisation, and skills, especially in sectors such as renewable energy, advanced manufacturing, and the circular economy. Highlighting the critical role of regions in delivering workforce transition, especially through alignment of education, skills, and innovation ecosystems. Advocating for cohesion policy and EU programmes (ERDF, Interreg, Horizon Europe) to remain strongly connected to regional economic strategies, enabling regions to attract investment and participate in strategic value chains. Promoting cross-regional cooperation to support resilient supply chains, research collaboration, and new technology deployment. Ireland’s 2026 Presidency should champion a European agenda that recognises regions as central to delivering climate goals, economic competitiveness, and social well-being. By foregrounding healthy placemaking, just transition, competitive and innovative regional economies, and sustainable solutions to the housing challenge, Ireland can demonstrate genuine leadership during its Presidency.

For the 2026 Irish Presidency, the focus should be on securing an ambitious, region-sensitive Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) and shaping a post-2027 cohesion policy that continues to prioritise territorial balance. Ireland should aim to guide negotiations toward an MFF agreement that protects adequate resources for cohesion policy funding while ensuring that regional needs—particularly for rural, peripheral, disadvantaged areas in towns and cities and transition regions—remain central to EU investment planning. Future of Cohesion Policy: The Presidency should work toward a political agreement reaffirming the regional dimension of cohesion policy, resisting pressures to centralise funds or dilute place-based approaches. Ireland can champion flexibility tools that allow regions to tailor investments to local development needs, while also supporting stronger links between cohesion policy funding, Just Transition objectives and innovation-led regional growth. Simplification Agenda: Ireland should aim for a Council outcome that delivers real, practical simplification for everyone involved in cohesion policy—from the Commission to national and regional authorities, intermediaries and beneficiaries. This means pushing for clearer, shared definitions and interpretations across the Commission, Member States and the European Court of Auditors; cutting back on audit and reporting demands; simplifying eligibility rules; and making greater use of proportionate checks. Importantly, simplification shouldn’t just shift the workload from one level to another or make things harder for a particular part of the system. It should genuinely reduce complexity across the whole delivery chain. The aim is a simplification package that offers more legal certainty, applies rules more consistently, and cuts unnecessary administrative hurdles while still protecting good financial management. Climate Agenda: Given the centrality of the green transition to all EU funding programmes, the Presidency should focus on progressing outstanding climate-related legislation and ensuring coherence across sectoral initiatives. Ireland can position itself as a broker, promoting strong climate ambition while ensuring that obligations remain practical, properly funded, and responsive to different regional starting points. This means advancing key climate legislation and aligning related EU policies, so the green transition is effective and manageable for all regions. Economic Competitiveness in Regions: The Presidency should promote a policy agenda that strengthens regional competitiveness by supporting innovation ecosystems, smart specialisation, SME productivity, digitalisation, skills development and infrastructure connectivity. A key objective should be to ensure cohesion and competitiveness policies reinforce each other, enabling regions to adapt to structural change and participate fully in the green and digital transitions.

The Irish Presidency can make a substantial positive impact for people, businesses and communities across the EU by championing an inclusive, transparent and territorially grounded approach to Council decision-making. This requires ensuring that legislative discussions consistently reflect the realities of Europe’s cities, regions and rural areas, and that the insights of the Committee of the Regions (CoR) and local and regional authorities (LRAs) are actively integrated into Council deliberations. Stronger stakeholder voice EMRA calls on the Irish Presidency to prioritise open, structured dialogue with civil society, businesses, social partners and regional actors throughout the legislative cycle. Early engagement, particularly on legislation affecting territorial development, cohesion, climate transition and competitiveness—will help ensure that proposals are shaped by those closest to their implementation and impact, resulting in more effective and broadly supported legislation. Elevating the role of LRAs and the CoR The Presidency can highlight the crucial role of the Local and Regional Authorities (LRAs) in delivering EU objectives on the ground by encouraging their systematic involvement in the development of national positions and promoting strong multi-level governance practices. The respect of the subsidiarity principle and making sure that decisions are taken at the level closer to the citizens will ensure the Presidency has a higher impact for all. Greater visibility for the Committee of the Regions’ (CoR) opinions in Council debates—especially on cohesion, green transition, regional innovation and public service delivery—would enhance the quality of deliberations. Ireland can also foster deeper cooperation between national delegations and CoR workstreams to strengthen institutional channels for territorial expertise. Outcomes for communities and businesses Embedding territorial perspectives and strengthening stakeholder participation will help produce legislation that is proportionate, implementable and responsive to diverse local conditions. This approach supports better public investment, serves to strengthen regional competitiveness, improves service delivery and ensures that EU policies deliver tangible and equitable benefits across all regions. Stronger involvement of LRAs will also enhance the delivery of EU competitiveness, climate and resilience objectives by ensuring that legislation is designed with practical implementation in mind. By integrating territorial realities and CoR expertise, the Council can help ensure that EU legislation and investment deliver stronger results in every region, contributing directly to the Strategic Agenda’s goals of a resilient, fair and competitive Europe. Our call to the Irish Presidency We urge the Irish Presidency to champion inclusive and transparent governance as a means of strengthening the Union’s capacity to deliver on its major strategic priorities—green, digital, industrial, security and territorial cohesion. Decisions taken during the Presidency should translate into practical, positive outcomes for communities and businesses across the Union. We also call on the Presidency to support structured opportunities for civil society, social partners and economic actors to contribute early and meaningfully to the work of the Council.

To communicate the values and benefits of EU membership and foster a genuine sense of public ownership over Ireland’s Presidency of the Council of the European Union, the most effective approach is to connect EU principles directly to people’s everyday lives. This involves clearly highlighting the Union’s core values—solidarity, democracy, sustainability, regional cohesion, and shared prosperity—while demonstrating, through relatable and concrete examples, how EU policy and funding positively shape communities across Ireland and the wider Union. Communicating EU values and benefits Ireland can help citizens understand the Presidency not as a remote institutional responsibility, but as a platform for influencing Europe’s direction in ways that matter locally. The latest Eurobarometer, published September 2025, shows that the EU is regarded as a place of stability, with 73% of Europeans stating that their country has benefited from membership. Communicating Ireland EU Presidency’s role in advancing the EU priorities—such as climate action, regional development, digital innovation, and social inclusion—through clear, accessible storytelling can strengthen trust and foster a deeper sense of belonging to the shared European project. Expanding outreach beyond traditional policy audiences is essential. Cultural initiatives, partnerships with local authorities, targeted social-media engagement and community-level dialogues can extend the message into everyday civic spaces and ensure that communication reflects the diversity of society. The Presidency’s platform can be harnessed to reach young people, rural communities, disadvantaged areas in towns and cities, migrants, and other groups less likely to feel connected to EU institutions. It can be the vehicle to enhance transparency and promoting two-way dialogue by inviting citizen input on EU priorities. Citizen panels, participatory workshops, or regional deliberative events during the Presidency can give people a sense that their views actively shape Europe. Draw on Ireland’s positive experience with EU membership (economic development, peace and cooperation, rural regeneration, rights protections) provides practical, positive experience. Present Ireland as a proactive, constructive EU member sharing its strengths—particularly in areas like sustainability, digital policy, and conflict resolution. Communications should avoid institutional jargon and instead highlight personal stories, before-and-after examples, and community voices. Showing tangible impact The Presidency communications should place strong emphasis on real, visible examples of EU investment that resonate with citizens. Initiatives such as the recent Just Transition Fest in Castletown Geoghegan, Co. Westmeath, highlight how EU support delivers regeneration, innovation, and community vibrancy at local level. Showcasing outcomes—such as job creation, enhanced public services, strengthened cultural offerings, and environmental improvements—helps citizens see the EU not as an abstract institution but as a practical partner in shaping their community’s future. A concerted effort to safeguard and articulate the principle of justice in the delivery of a Just Transition is essential for building trust among communities directly or indirectly affected by transition measures. Transparent communication on fairness, inclusion, and long-term local benefits will be central to securing public confidence and buy-in. This emphasis, reinforces and aligns with the Commission’s social model goals of ensuring that “no one is left behind”.

Regional Assemblies are Ireland’s EU–National–Local Interface Regional Assemblies are the statutory link between EU, national and local governance. They operate at the intersection of EU and domestic policy through EU programme management and communication (ERDF, JTF, Interreg, URBACT, EUI), spatial planning, and work with the Committee of the Regions. Strengthening their role in shaping the EU Presidency would ensure a programme grounded in lived territorial experience and informed by structures already interfacing with the EU. Strengthening Democratic Governance and Subsidiarity A Presidency grounded in LRAs would model multilevel governance, demonstrating democratic accountability, subsidiarity and policy coherence. Ireland’s comparatively weak regional tier makes this especially important. Effective delivery of the EU Green Deal, climate legislation, the biodiversity strategy, circular economy actions and cohesion policy depends on regional/local implementation, including: Alignment of local authority plans with carbon budgets, the Climate Action Plan, biodiversity targets and SDGs. Councillor oversight of spatial planning, infrastructure and land use. Local delivery of active travel, compact growth, public realm projects, climate action and Town Centre First— all aligned with EU urban and cohesion policy. Enhancing Democratic Legitimacy and Addressing Structural Challenges A Presidency shaped with strong regional/local inputs increases Ireland’s credibility in leading EU climate, cohesion and territorial agendas. LRAs are increasingly recognised by the EU as essential democratic actors. At the same time, Ireland’s major challenges—housing, population growth, infrastructure deficits, climate adaptation— are regional in scale. Fragmented delivery structures (NTA, TII, Uisce Éireann) often weakens alignment with EU obligations. LRA involvement improves coherence and reinforces democratic legitimacy. Supporting EU Cohesion Policy and Transition Priorities The EU Presidency will be expected to address cohesion policy, the Just Transition Fund, and future EU budget frameworks. Ireland’s Regional Authorities already manage major EU programmes and hold critical insight into how EU investment translates into regional development. Their involvement would strengthen Ireland’s negotiating position and ensure policy lines reflect real delivery experience. Strengthening Delivery of EU Legislation Upcoming EU obligations—Fit for 55, Energy Performance, Nature Restoration, Green Infrastructure, water and digital directives—depend on regional/local implementation. Spatial planning, climate action, infrastructure coordination and biodiversity restoration all sit at LRA level. A Presidency informed by LRAs ensures Ireland can articulate a credible, coherent national position across these files. Advancing EU Urban and Territorial Agendas The EU increasingly emphasises urban partnerships, smart regions and functional urban areas. Town-focused bodies can engage directly with initiatives such as the European Urban Initiative (EUI) and URBACT. EMRA’s experience as the National Contact Point for both of these programmes has highlighted that European partners benefit from town- or region-level structures. Strengthened LRA involvement positions Ireland as a leader in urban and territorial cohesion policy. Demonstrating Commitment to European Democratic Standards Ireland will be scrutinised during its Presidency on subsidiarity, governance quality and regional engagement. Strengthening Regional Assemblies, enhancing transparency and aligning with the European Charter of Local SelfGovernment will demonstrate Ireland’s commitment to European democratic norms and effective territorial governance.

organisation:
Irish Refugee Council. 
This is a joint submission also sent on behalf of:
Nasc
Doras
Immigrant Council of Ireland
Jesuit Refugee Service
Oxfam Ireland
LGBT Ireland
Spirasi
Irish Penal Reform Trust
response_text: Ireland should prioritise promoting and protecting democracy in the EU during its Presidency. Promoting and protecting democracy necessitates a range of actions including addressing economic inequalities, the cost of living crisis, people’s access to decision makers, the workings of the EU institutions, but this submission focuses on aspects related to migration, specifically promoting democracy by: Strengthening civil society Addressing harmful misinformation and hateful narratives on migration in both deed and action Improving social cohesion Strengthen civil society as protectors of democracy and EU values Civil society organisations (CSOs) amplify the voices of and defend the interests of vulnerable people in our political and policy making processes. As such, they are essential to a well functioning democracy. In order to carry out this function, civil society must be properly resourced. This means that EU funding should not restrict CSOs’ ability to advocate for human rights including towards the EU institutions. In too many EU countries, civil society actors including lawyers and humanitarians are being criminalised for their work with migrants including refugees. (see reports below). Ireland must protect the freedom of CSOs working with migrants. Combat harmful and false narratives on migration to protect the EU from anti-democratic forces Harmful narratives on migration, often based on misinformation, have propelled political forces that are anti-democratic. It is not possible to promote democracy in the EU without moving away from and addressing harmful framings of migration. Therefore, an integral part of protecting democracy is to not mimic these narratives but to instead work with people on the move, CSOs, academics and experts by experience to combat these framings and to tell the positive stories of migration that people are living all over the country and continent every day. The implementation of the proposed Democracy Shield must protect a vibrant and free civil society in the EU and fight misinformation with a focus on the role of tech companies and their responsibilities regarding the spread of anti-democratic and hateful content. Provide leadership on fighting the erosion of democracy Ireland can show leadership by using the Presidency as an opportunity to stop framing migration as a security threat. Movement of people, even irregularly, does not pose a threat to the safety of Europeans yet this reality is too often ignored. Framing migration as a security threat has contributed to the rise in anti-democratic forces within the EU. Ireland's presidency proposal should echo the language used by Spain in their presidency proposal which focused on ‘humane, responsible, compassionate’ policies. Language choice contributes to framing and signals intent. Ireland should show leadership by joining with like-minded member states to host an event in Brussels on the positives of migration and the need to combat harmful narratives. Aimed at perm reps, EU agencies and EU policy makers this would be a step towards protecting democracy in the EU. Any migration policy that erodes human rights and is not fully committed to international law is a threat to democracy. As such, all migration policies negotiated at EU level must embody a meaningful commitment to protecting human rights and non-refoulement for all people who come to and cross EU borders. As president of the Council, Ireland will be promoting democracy by chairing policy negotiations in this manner.

organisation:
