This is a joint submission also sent on behalf of:
Nasc
Doras
Immigrant Council of Ireland
Jesuit Refugee Service
Oxfam Ireland
LGBT Ireland
Spirasi
Irish Penal Reform Trust
response_text: Frontex review (legislative, Articles 77 and 79 TFEU, due Q3 2026) Ensure the Fundamental Rights Officer (FRO) has independence and the powers of investigation and scope of role necessary to uphold fundamental rights at our EU borders. Any discussion of potential expansion of the standing corps must also include mechanisms to hold Frontex to account. This is particularly important for upholding EU values and democracy in light of accusations of Frontex involvement in breaches of EU and international law. Accountability mechanisms should ensure FRO’s recommendations and opinions are followed up within a specified timeline and that Parliamentary scrutiny of Frontex is enabled. Frontex activities outside the EU must be limited given accountability is harder, risks are greater, and the purpose of operations remains opaque and dubious. Civil society and the EU Ombudsperson must be meaningfully consulted during the negotiations on the proposal on Frontex’s mandate. Multiannual Funding Framework Migration related spending must not be directed to border management at the expense of asylum and inclusion. Social cohesion goals must be prioritised and adequate funds allocated to integration measures. Safe and Legal pathways Mission letters to Commissioners, including Commissioner Brunner, re-commit the EU to achieving the SDGs. Ireland should use the Presidency to work towards SDG indicator 10.7.2, “Number of countries with policies to facilitate orderly, safe, regular and responsible migration and mobility of people”. Explore legal pathways for people seeking international protection. The Strategic Agenda commits to ‘explore the opportunities of migration, including through legal pathways’ and ‘break the business model of those who profit from’ smuggling as well as ‘consider new ways to prevent and counter irregular migration.’ Ireland’s presidency should use the JHA council to discuss how the way to achieve the EU aim of ‘breaking the business model of smugglers’ is to provide legal ways to enter the EU, thus removing people’s need to turn to smugglers. Considering new ways to counter irregular migration must be in line with EU values, international law obligations and the rule of law. Ireland should therefore show leadership in steering member states away from ‘solutions’ that involve a derogation of human rights obligations including return hubs, the informal but well established use of pushbacks and opaque deals with third countries. Instead, Ireland should promote humanitarian visas, expansion of visa schemes, resettlement and other legal pathways. Regarding implementation of the EU Asylum and Migration Pact, the Irish Presidency must focus on ensuring that all Member States uphold and respect the fundamental rights of people seeking asylum in the EU. This should include: Ensuring full adherence to the Pact’s regulations and directives. The Pact lays a floor, not a ceiling, for Member States’ asylum systems, and failure to comply with EU laws will further erode the European public’s trust in asylum systems. Ensuring effective access to asylum procedures. No person should be obstructed from accessing a territory or asylum procedure which may, in certain circumstances, result in that person being returned to a country where their life or freedom may be threatened, breaching the international principle of non-refoulement. An accessible asylum procedure is vital to uphold the Union’s values of democracy, human rights and solidarity. Ensuring fundamental rights monitoring bodies are fully independent of the asylum authorities; have a wide remit; and are properly resourced. An effective and independent fundamental rights monitoring system is preventative, as it reduces the risk of fundamental rights violations, improves transparency and accountability, and enhances trust in public authorities. Ireland’s term as president should aim to ensure that policies which affect the most vulnerable people in European society, including those seeking protection, are fundamental rights compliant. Protecting vulnerable applicants: It is important that special reception needs and special procedural guarantees for vulnerable applicants are safeguarded when the Pact is transposed as national level. Identifying This will help deliver a system which protects the most vulnerable people.

organisation:
Irish Refugee Council. 
This is a joint submission also sent on behalf of:
Nasc
Doras
Immigrant Council of Ireland
Jesuit Refugee Service
Oxfam Ireland
LGBT Ireland
Spirasi
Irish Penal Reform Trust
response_text: At a time of significant polarisation, it is imperative that the Council works towards improving social cohesion among all communities whilst improving public confidence in Member State’s asylum systems. These are not achieved by reducing rights for people seeking protection but by encouraging and resourcing integration initiatives and effectively communicating the democratic values underpinning our asylum systems. Foster integration: It is more important than ever that all communities are encouraged and resourced to integrate. Research shows that communities which come into contact with migrant populations see their attitudes towards migrants significantly improve. This benefits migrants, host communities and social cohesion among Member State’s populations. Ireland can use its role as President to encourage positive integration initiatives. Support social cohesion: Restricting asylum applicants to reception centres or limited geographic areas is likely to severely limit their ability to effectively integrate with host communities, including in access to healthcare, employment and educational opportunities. It also limits opportunities to meet their community, to volunteer and get involved with local groups. Restrictions of movement can paint an unfairly negative view of asylum systems among host communities, likely creating a psychological link between asylum and crime, and keeping communities apart. Freedom of movement allows people to meet their community and take part in civic life. Combat mis/disinformation: Communities are intentionally being driven apart by anti-migrant and far-right actors. Ireland can play a crucial role in limiting the voice that these actors have. Often, misinformation originates outside of the EU and does not represent the views of ordinary EU citizens, yet it is influencing their views and perceptions of vital democratic and EU institutions. It also plays a huge role in shaping EU citizens views on migrants and people of colour, and is partly responsible for the surge in racism seen across the EU. Proactively limiting the impact of misinformation should be a priority of the Irish presidency. Recognise that Migrants are vital to the economy in Ireland and across the EU. Migrant labour keeps our healthcare, hospitality and tech industries running. Yet, people seeking asylum are heavily restricted in their access to the labour market. Allowing asylum applicants to work from shortly after they apply for asylum allows them to contribute and give back to their host communities, as many of them are so keen to do. This benefits asylum applicants- many of whom will receive permission to stay and build lives in host communities- by preventing loss of skills and helps local businesses suffering from labour shortages.

Irish Refugee Council.

Nasc
Doras
Immigrant Council of Ireland
Jesuit Refugee Service
Oxfam Ireland
LGBT Ireland
Spirasi
Irish Penal Reform Trust
response_text: EU Strategic Agenda notes that ‘Our values and the rule of law are our compass, both internally and externally.’ Making this a reality for everybody, including for people at our borders and on our territory who are not EU citizens communicates to citizens that values are lived and enacted, not just for speeches and documents. A disconnect between what the EU says (upholds values of democracy, human rights and the rule of law) and what it has been found to do in some cases (violate human rights in policy and practices) undermines belief in EU values. Closing this gap by making policies that respect human rights, and ensuring that the practices of EU agencies such as Frontex respect human rights, communicates the values of EU membership. A sense of ownership over Ireland’s Presidency of the Council as well as membership of the EU will be achieved in tandem with increasing social cohesion. Given the cost of living problems that people in Ireland face, divisive rhetoric and actions that seek to blame the members of our communities who have migrated to Ireland, undermine social cohesion. Therefore, Ireland should use the Presidency to stop EU member states and institutions scape-goating migrants and to instead address the cost of living crisis fuelling divisions.

response_text: We note the following pieces of research. The European Commission on Racism and Intolerance, Sixth report on Ireland Has noted that: There are also recent documented examples of politicians’ reactions to events in local communities resulting in illinformed responses, fuelling hate speech and escalating tensions further. ECRI recommends that the authorities step up their efforts to encourage public figures, such as high-level officials, politicians … to take a prompt, firm and public stance against the expression of racist and LGBTI-phobic hate speech, react promptly to any such expression with strong counter-speech and alternative speech, and express solidarity with those targeted by hate speech. Available at: https://rm.coe.int/sixth-report-on-ireland/48802911ef ESRI, Community context affects attitudes towards immigration: Research found that more segregated areas (i.e. where migrants live in clusters rather than evenly spread across the area) show more negative attitudes towards immigration. This also suggests that positive social contact with migrants in communities may facilitate understanding. The research suggests that positive social contact can play a key role in improving attitudes and therefore social cohesion. The findings about pressure on services indicate that it may not be direct local experiences that impact attitudes, but may instead be concern about pressure on services in Ireland as a whole. Research available at: https://www.esri.ie/news/community-context-affects-attitudes-towards-immigration Irish Human Rights and Equality Commission, Human Rights Survey 2025: Found that: 80% of people agree that everyone should be treated equally regardless of who they are or where they come from, this belief is diminishing annually – from 85% in 2023 and 84% in 2024. Though the key support level remains high, this negative trend is a clear cause for concern. Asked about efforts to combat discrimination in Ireland, only four in ten people believe they are effective. That speaks to a crisis of confidence in our institutions and political leadership, and also indicates a level of concern about the direction our society might be moving in. 14% of respondents said they experienced racism in the past year, up from 10% in 2024. Among non-white Irish, the figure rises to a shocking 66%. Two in three non-white Irish people have directly experienced racism in just twelve months. Available at: https://www.ihrec.ie/news-press/nationwide-human-rights-survey-provides-crucial-insights-on-public-perceptions-of-cost-of-living-crisis-increasing-racism-and-discrimination-in-ireland

Regulatory simplification: The Irish EU Presidency will come at a critical time to deliver outcomes on the Digital Omnibus (published on 19 November 2025) and Environmental Omnibus (due in December 2025). Given the tight deadlines imposed to co-legislators for Omnibus I, the European Commission could aim to conclude both files by the end of 2026. Based on Ireland’s involvement in the D-9+ Group, the Irish EU Presidency should continue to push for further regulatory simplification in the digital area, which is also on the Commission’s agenda as part of the digital fitness check. Transatlantic relations: Following the EU-US Framework Agreement and the Joint Statement issued in the summer of 2025, the EU has an opportunity to follow up with the US and build cooperation in critical areas such as: removing barriers to digital trade; negotiating a Mutual Recognition Agreement in Cybersecurity; strengthening cooperation and alignment on economic security issues (e.g. export controls, critical raw materials, semiconductors). In the EU, Ireland is the second largest exporter to the United States after Germany. 53.7% of Ireland’s extra-EU exports went to the US in 2024, which is the highest across Member States. With this unique position, and based on historic ties with the US, Ireland is well positioned to act as a bridge between the EU and the US. Balancing Digital sovereignty with openness to international partnerships: Recent months have shown renewed interest in digital sovereignty in the European Commission and across some Member States. Following the European Digital Sovereignty Summit in November, we are expecting a series of connected policy developments on digital sovereignty in the beginning of 2026: the review of the Cybersecurity Act, the legislation underpinning the EU Cloud Security Certification Scheme (EUCS), which is expected to be reanimated early 2026; the Digital Network Act in January 2026; the review of the 2030 EU Digital Decade targets, and the release of the Cloud and AI Development Act, which will likely come with a non-binding recommendation to use European Cloud Services in the public sector. In this context, the Irish EU Presidency should ensure that sovereignty does not mean protectionism and that the EU remains open to cooperation and collaboration with international partners sharing common values.

Digital Omnibus (Nov 2025): Ensure that edits to the GDPR make it fit for repurposing personal data for AI training; ensure edits to the Data Act’s data-sharing provisions provide robust protections against trade secrets leakage; ensure the Commission’s ambitions around the Single Point of Entry for incident reporting are preserved in the final negotiated text; support a clear stop-the-clock for the implementation of high-risk AI provisions in the AI Act. Environmental Omnibus (expected Dec 2025): This should help create a unified market for waste and recycling, for example by maintaining green-list status for non-hazardous intra-EU e-waste shipments beyond 2027 and promoting greater harmonisation of the Extended Producer Responsibility (EPR) regime. Regulations on durability—such as the Right to Repair—should clearly differentiate between B2C and B2B ICT products to address the unique needs of enterprise solutions. Cybersecurity Act (CSA) revision (expected Dec 2025/Jan 2026): Fragmentation in national transposition of NIS2 should be addressed in the CSA revision; and practical, predictable and timely guidance provided on the Cyber Resilience Act (CRA). Additional measures on ICT supply chain security and Trusted Vendors across critical infrastructure would also be welcomed. Cloud and AI Development Act (March 2026): This should stimulate the buildup of AI and Cloud infrastructure by favouring a flexible approach that balances the needs for Europe’s infrastructure and the demand for sovereign solutions in specific use-cases. The proposal should clarify the need to ensure the resilience and security of cloud and AI infrastructure, by stimulating the uptake of AI security solutions that protect the infrastructure, and the development and deployment of AI. Additional measures on ICT supply chain security and Trusted Vendors would strongly reinforce digital resilience. Digital Networks Act (January 2026): Focus should be on AI-enabled networks, investments in innovation and fostering partnerships within the digital ecosystem; simplifying the telecoms rulebook; allowing scale for telcos; and having a technology neutral spectrum programme - both for WiFi and 5G/6G. Review of the EU Digital Decade Targets (2026): This should: 1) Drive investment into critical digital infrastructure capacities, notably in secure and energy efficient networks to prepare to become an AI continent; 2) Ensure public sector leads by example by investing in state-of-the art digital infrastructure and key technologies such as AI; 3) Boost the uptake of advanced AI, digital and cyber skills to secure the talent needed to develop, deploy and harness key digital technologies; 4) Allocate necessary funding in the future MFF (EU budget) for European SMEs to grasp the benefits of AI and Cloud technologies, and reduce red tape when trying to access the funding. Public Procurement Act (expected Q2 2026): The Presidency can initiate Council discussions on the proposal at the end of 2026. The Commission has repeatedly called for the inclusion of European preference criteria in the revised Public Procurement Directive. That would restrict choices for the European public sector, without necessarily producing the intended impact of local growth and jobs. This would also lead to higher costs and generate issues for bidding companies with highly integrated supply chains who may not be able to meet proposed local content requirements. Instead, the EU should aim to use a Trusted Partners List, including companies from allied countries with a strong business footprint in the EU. Implementation of the EU Defence Transformation Roadmap: The EU has identified capability gaps for European defence, including in areas like AI and cyber. As the EU implements the roadmap to boost innovation in the defence industry, it will be important to adopt commercial off-the-shelf best-of-breed technologies as the default, from a trusted international market, and to avoid introducing European preference criteria for the allocation of dedicated EU funding. Implementation of the EU International Digital Strategy: Next to the implementation of the EU-US trade framework, the EU should strengthen its digital partnerships with key partners through an agenda that fosters economic security innovations, supports joint deployment of secure AI-powered infrastructure, enhances global gateways for secure connectivity, establishes frameworks for data access requests and cross-border data flows, bridges the global talent gap with digital and AI skills, reinforces supply chain resilience, and advances energy security and clean innovation. ICT Supply Chain Security Toolbox: Steps to improve the resilience of critical infrastructure through the imminent Toolbox would be welcome, including in giving guidance to Member States on the use of trusted vendors in critical networks. The Presidency should look to progress any such measures.

For businesses – Progress faster on regulatory simplification. If businesses active in Europe do not feel a reduction in the regulatory and administrative burden by the end of this Commission mandate, the recommendations of the Draghi report will be left unaddressed. Further, we recommend the EU Commission to always prioritise regulations over directives to avoid regulatory fragmentation across Europe. Next to the EU simplification exercise, Member States should also lead a review of their existing regulations to remove outdated or conflicting requirements, and adopt a similar ‘futureproof’, agile approach to future national legislations implementing the EU acquis.

The EU Presidency can highlight Ireland’s critical role as a European tech hub, with many young innovators and a vibrant startup ecosystem which make an impact across all industry sectors. The Presidency can show citizens that Ireland is not only benefiting from the EU’s digital agenda but actively shaping it. This narrative ties local pride to EU-wide impact, making the Presidency feel relevant to everyday life through concrete examples such as digital skills, Digital Europe funding programmes, and tech-driven public services. For example, we welcome plans for a large digital/tech event, which should bring together Irish technology companies and major investors in Ireland and across Europe to reinforce the Government’s priorities as part of the Presidency. Youth-focused tech activities, and partnerships with universities, startups and tech companies, could also be explored.

Cisco issued last year a ‘Ten Tech Policies’ plan for Ireland available here. Note that Cisco’s European priorities are currently under view and will be available very shortly here. Cisco is very much looking forward to the Irish EU Presidency - we stand ready to support and contribute to its success!

sector: Our core business is to provide vision, leadership and value to the co-operative movement in Ireland.
response_text: The value of Ireland’s food, drink and horticulture exports increased by 5% last year to a record €17 billion, according to Bord Bia’s Export Performance and Prospects Report for 2024/25 published earlier this year. This includes dairy exports valued at €6.3bn produced by our co-operative members. Dairy farming remains our largest indigenous industry with over 17,000 dairy farmers. Dairy farming is exposed to fluctuations in global markets which means that those farmers face great uncertainty in 2026. Irish farming has proved its resilience in the past, but this cannot be taken for granted into the future and so requires the full attention of government in ensuring that global shocks, geopolitical tensions, fluctuating markets and unpredictable weather events do not threaten the vibrancy of the sector. Ireland enjoys a positive reputation globally as a food producing country. Our grass-based system gives us a great advantage in terms of protecting animal welfare and maintaining relatively extensive farming systems. There is a golden opportunity during the Irish Presidency to harness the positive image of Irish farming and food production and the huge economic contribution which our 120,000 farm families and co-operatives make to the rural economy. At a time where rural depopulation is an issue across Europe, the Irish Presidency can showcase how rural economies can continue to withstand the threat to rural areas by spotlighting the tremendous role which the Irish agrifood sector plays in ensuring vibrant rural areas and businesses. Investing in the future is key to supporting the future vibrancy of Irish food production. That brings us to the burning issue of young farmers. A generational renewal crisis in farming is happening not only in Ireland but right across Europe. Recent reports on this crisis have just been published at national and EU level. The Irish government must use the EU Presidency to prioritise this emergency by implementing proposals to tackle this very worrying trend. Approximately 6% of EU farmers are under the age of 35. Young people are leaving rural areas to pursue other careers due to the lack of certainty about the future of farming because of red tape and bureaucracy which is a unrelenting from the EU Commission. The Irish Presidency can lead the way in showing a real commitment to the future of farming across the EU by fast-tracking solutions and implementing recommendations from the recent reports on generational renewal which will make farming attractive as a viable career for younger people. They would like to farm but are prevented from doing so because of policy, access to land, access to finance and a lack of start-up supports among many other issues. Food security can only be cemented if there is a pathway for the next generation of farmers.

sector: Our core business is to provide vision, leadership and value to the co-operative movement in Ireland.
response_text: We cannot emphasise enough the importance of a guaranteeing a properly funded and solidly structured CAP. Without this, farmers and co-ops cannot prosper, and the three pillars of sustainability (economic, social and environmental) will collapse consequently. Farmers are on the front line in the face of climate change and yet it is our farmers and co-operatives who are doing the heavy lifting daily to implement EU policies under the EU Green Deal. Farmers and co-operatives are working hard to meet their climate change targets and improve water quality with hundreds of millions of euros invested in schemes and in R&D to meet climate targets. That work is continuing at pace. But this will be undone if the financial support is not there to make this happen quickly. The EU has unveiled a series of omnibus packages in 2025 with the aim of simplification of legislation. But we are not seeing any simplification, moreover, the daily work of farmers and co-operatives is being strangled by new layers of legislation and policy which in many cases is unworkable and unnecessary. Farmers and co-ops need to see simplification in action in order to be able to plan ahead. The Irish Presidency must make simplification happen by the end of 2026. EU farmers employ the highest standards in the world as things stand when it comes to sustainable food production. This can only continue with proper supports and sensible policy. The EUs Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism (CBAM) is an example of another layer of well-intentioned EU Commission policy with unintended consequences for farmers and consumers. At a time when the cost of living is hurting citizens in Ireland and across Europe, keeping the cost of food at an affordable level for hard pressed consumers is imperative. But now because of the CBAM which includes fertiliser, the cost of fertiliser could increase by as much as 50% by 2030. There is little doubt that this would impact on food price and impact on Irelands climate targets as the cost of protected urea would price farmers out of the market. We have called for a postponement of CBAM and will continue if necessary to fight against this food tax throughout 2026. This is not only and Irish concern but a concern for farm and co-operative organisations across the EU.

sector: Our core business is to provide vision, leadership and value to the co-operative movement in Ireland.
response_text: The EU Strategic Agenda 2024-2029 aims to strengthen its long-term competitiveness and to improve citizens’ economic and social well-being. This includes increasing their purchasing power, creating good jobs, and assuring the quality of goods and services including a sustainable and resilient agricultural sector. The council during the term of the Irish Presidency must prioritise and support the role of agricultural co-operatives and the contribution they make in terms of social, environmental and economic prosperity in rural areas not only in Ireland but right across the EU. ICOS is the umbrella organisation for the co-operative movement in Ireland – including dairy processing co-operatives and livestock marts – whose associated businesses have a combined turnover in the region of €16 billion, with some 175,000 individual members, employing 12,000 people in Ireland, and a further 24,000 people overseas. In total, there are some 1,000 co-ops in Ireland, and the largest 100 organisations employ approximately 40,000 people. Irish Co-operatives are progressive locally focussed businesses which adhere to strict corporate governance rules. Their continued robustness can only be assured by a recognition of the role they play in supporting farmers and businesses mainly in rural areas which are under constant pressure because of rural depopulation. However, the future viability of co-operatives is under pressure from overly burdensome “one size fits all” legislation and policies. For example, the well-intentioned EU Unfair Trading Practice proposal to impose mandatory contracts on dairy co-operatives is unnecessary in an Irish context and does not consider the well-functioning milk supply agreement contracts already established in Irish dairy co-operatives. Meanwhile the proposed drastic cut in the CAP budget under the recently announced MFF would inflict a sizable blow to farming and food production and in turn impact on co-operatives and livestock marts. The Council must ensure a fully funded and workably structured and ring-fenced CAP in the next MFF to underpin its commitment to ensuring food security across the EU. While cognisant of the EUs commitment to bolstering security and defence, it should not come at the expense of European farmers, co-operatives and rural dwellers. Recent Eurobarometer findings show an overwhelming support among Irish and EU citizens for the Common Agricultural Policy and the role it plays in ensuring safe, traceable, affordable food. The Council must listen to its citizens and cite these findings as good reason to guarantee a well-funded well-structured CAP which benefits consumers alongside food producers.

FCJ supports EJF’s position that Ireland’s 2026 Presidency should prioritise strengthening the EU’s economic competitiveness, consumer protection frameworks and legal certainty. Achieving these objectives requires addressing the growing divergence in national approaches to TPLF, a sector now recognised as a cross-border economic and legal risk. The UK’s experience is instructive. When the UK’s opt-out regime was introduced in 2015, government assessments anticipated limited scale. Instead, within a decade: more than 708 million class members were aggregated across claims (CMS Class Action Report 2025); over €155bn in damages were claimed (CMS); the UK Competition Appeal Tribunal received one new collective action per week (CMS); Independent economic analysis from ECIPE estimates that mass litigation could cost up to £18 billion in economic costs, including reduced innovation, lower capital investment and heightened risk profiles for regulated sectors (ECIPE - The Impact of Increased Mass Litigation in the UK, 2025). This experience shows that once profit-driven mass litigation models take root, they rapidly become structurally embedded through financial incentives, funder capital cycles and procedural norms, making reversal or meaningful reform extraordinarily difficult. The EU therefore has a narrow preventive window. Ireland’s Presidency should prioritise: 1. Reducing regulatory fragmentation in TPLF through EU minimum harmonisation. Strengthening economic resilience by ensuring that civil justice mechanisms promote, rather than deter, investment and innovation. Protecting consumers and SMEs from predatory or speculative litigation models that offer minimal real-world redress. Building trust in justice systems through transparency, accountability and proportionate oversight. The overarching aim should be to prevent the emergence in the EU of a litigation environment that mirrors the UK’s experience - a system characterised by escalating claims, limited consumer benefit, and growing macroeconomic implications.

FCJ fully supports EJF’s call for an EU level instrument regulating TPLF. FCJ’s additional evidence shows why the UK’s trajectory makes this a matter of urgency. In our recent submission to the UK Department for Business and Trade’s review, we submitted evidence demonstrating that the UK opt-out regime is now extremely costly, of questionable social utility, and primarily serves to enrich lawyers and litigation funders. Funders’ success rates approach 90%, reflecting a structural imbalance that incentivises the pursuit of high quantum claims with low evidential thresholds. Parallel analysis by Kendal Global Advisory (see here) shows that major employers now treat mass litigation as a board-level strategic risk, influencing decisions on capital allocation, new product launches, regulatory engagement and long-term UK investment. Based on this evidence, Ireland should steer Council discussions toward: 1. A Minimum Harmonisation Directive on TPLF Core elements should include: transparency obligations on funding agreements; restrictions on funder control of litigation strategy; conflict of interest safeguards; proportionate financial soundness requirements; an EU register of funders; annual reporting requirements and oversight mechanisms. 2. Complementary guidance on Representative Actions funding To prevent funders shaping redress mechanisms toward profit maximisation rather than consumer outcomes. Evidence-generation tools The UK experience shows the consequences of insufficient monitoring. EU-level annual data collection on funder returns, consumer compensation levels, settlement structures and economic impact would enable early policy intervention. Preservation of access to justice A regulated funding framework ensures that TPLF supports legitimate claims while preventing the pursuit of low-merit, high-aggregate-value actions that inflate legal costs and undermine judicial effectiveness. The UK’s inability to contain the unintended consequences of an initially narrow litigation reform demonstrates the need for preventive action at EU level, rather than reactive national remedies after systemic issues have crystallised.

The Council can deliver significant impact by enhancing legal certainty, ensuring fair access to justice and supporting economic competitiveness through coherent regulation of TPLF. Evidence from the UK shows that TPLF-backed mass litigation fails to deliver meaningful benefits for consumers. Participation and distribution rates are extremely low: In Justin Gutmann v. First MTR South WesternTrains Ltd, which settled pre-trial, less than one per cent of the £25m settlement has been claimed by class members. This is despite alleged efforts to inform those affected through advertising and the media. The claimant law firms and funders stand to receive 50 times more than consumers, underscoring the point that these types cases often benefit funders and lawyers over consumers. In Merricks v Mastercard, which settled in early 2025, the settlement Sum was £200m - less than 1.5% of the initial claim value (£14bn), reflecting that the settlement reached was "very far from a success" according to the Judge. Consumers are expected to receive as little as £2.26 in compensation (Law Society Gazette). UK-wide polling by Kendal Global Advisory shows only 8% of adults believe have ever been involved in a class action, despite hundreds of millions of people being automatically included in claims without awareness. This demonstrates that mass litigation, without safeguards, does not provide substantive consumer redress. For businesses, the economic consequences are substantial. Litigation costs, provisions, higher insurance premiums and increased cost of capital act as de facto regulatory burdens. Major firms report that mass litigation now affects decisions on where to invest, whether to launch new products and how to engage with regulators (Kendal Advisory, Institute of Economic Affairs). Communities and workers are indirectly impacted through reduced investment, slower innovation and diversion of resources away from productive activity. Public services have also become targets of mass claims, redirecting funds away from core service delivery. An EU-level framework for TPLF would: promote predictable legal environments, supporting cross-border investment; ensure consumer trust through accountable redress systems; protect regulatory cooperation, which is increasingly disrupted in the UK; reinforce economic security by preventing litigation driven risk inflation.

Ireland can highlight that protecting citizens and consumers requires not only facilitating access to justice but also shielding them from predatory litigation models. By acting early, the EU demonstrates foresight, accountability and a commitment to delivering outcomes that genuinely benefit people. Communicating that the EU has learned from the UK experience - and is acting to prevent similar systemic issues - will resonate strongly with citizens. Showing that EU action protects consumers from exploitation and businesses from economic uncertainty strengthens trust in EU institutions. A Presidency narrative grounded in fairness, transparency and proportionality will underscore the EU’s role as a guardian of both consumer welfare and economic stability.

The experience of the United Kingdom offers important lessons for EU policymakers as they consider how best to manage the growing role of TPLF and mass litigation within the internal market. FCJ’s analysis across multiple UK sectors indicates that once profit-driven litigation models become embedded in a legal system, the dynamics of the market make them extremely difficult to reverse or recalibrate. Three cross-cutting insights are especially relevant for Ireland’s Presidency: 1. Policy intent can diverge rapidly from policy outcome. The UK’s opt-out collective action regime was introduced with narrow objectives and modest expectations regarding claim volume, complexity and economic impact. Within a few years, however, the regime grew far beyond those projections, with very large class sizes, increasingly speculative claims and escalating litigation costs. This demonstrates that even well-designed procedural reforms can produce materially different real-world effects when combined with commercial litigation funding and entrepreneurial claimant practices. The distribution of financial outcomes is highly asymmetric. Despite the rhetoric of consumer redress, FCJ’s assessment of UK cases shows that consumers frequently obtain only minimal individual compensation, while funders and lawyers capture a disproportionate share of total recoveries. At the same time, businesses - many of which are major employers and long-term investors - face unpredictable, high-quantum exposure. This asymmetry raises questions about fairness, efficiency and the sustainability of a litigation model that prioritises investment returns over redress outcomes. Once mass-litigation incentives take hold, course correction becomes difficult and costly. The UK Government is now examining potential reforms, but any meaningful recalibration must contend with established financial structures, ongoing litigation, entrenched market expectations and the political sensitivity of altering a regime framed as consumer-protective. This underlines a critical point that preventive, proportionate regulation of TPLF is far more effective than attempting to redesign the system once large scale commercial incentives are entrenched. These insights strengthen the case for EU-level minimum standards that ensure transparency, independence, financial soundness and accountability for TPLF operators. They also reinforce the importance of monitoring litigation trends, economic impacts and consumer outcomes across Member States, something the UK lacked in the early years of its regime, contributing to the scale of today’s challenges. Ireland’s 2026 Presidency has an opportunity to advance a coherent and future-oriented EU approach that protects consumers, supports regulatory effectiveness and preserves Europe’s competitiveness.

Taking into account the current geopolitical and socioeconomic context in Europe, we recommend that Ireland prioritise Health Protection, Citizen Safety, and Resilient Societies as core themes of its 2026 Presidency. Serious allergies and anaphylaxis are rising across Europe and place a growing burden on individuals, schools, workplaces, and public services. Addressing them fits naturally within broader objectives to protect citizens’ wellbeing and reduce preventable health risks. A Resilient and Prepared Europe The EU must be equipped to respond to emergencies—whether acute health events, natural disasters, or public safety threats. This requires harmonised emergency response systems, stronger communitylevel preparedness, and cross-border cooperation. Ireland is one of the few Member States that has taken concrete steps to improve preparedness for serious allergic reactions, including allowing pharmacists to supply emergency medicines without a prescription during anaphylactic events. This national practice demonstrates effective emergency readiness and provides a model for EU-level policy coordination, which could inform upcoming initiatives under the European Health Union framework aimed at strengthening preparedness, prevention, and rapid response across Member States. A People-Centred Union that Protects Embedding people-centred principles into EU policymaking ensures that vulnerable populations and individuals at risk of medical emergencies are not left behind. The Presidency could advance reducing health inequalities across the EU, highlighting uneven access to diagnosis, specialist care, and emergency response protocols. Positioning timely care for serious allergies and anaphylaxis within this agenda demonstrates a commitment to practical, measurable improvements in patient safety and inclusion, while protecting citizens’ rights to safety in everyday environments such as schools, childcare centres, workplaces, and public venues. 3. A Future-Oriented Europe Built on Innovation and Collaboration Ireland’s strong reputation in digital innovation offers an opportunity to promote Digital Innovation for Health, leveraging the European Health Data Space and interoperable, patient-centred tools. For individuals at risk of serious allergic reactions, seamless access to medical information across borders can prevent emergencies and support the free movement of people. The Presidency can also prioritise harmonised awareness-raising, institutional readiness, and capacity building, ensuring schools, businesses, and public institutions are equipped and trained to respond effectively to life-threatening health incidents.

Ireland could use its Presidency to champion health resilience, citizen protection, and emergency preparedness, leveraging its national leadership in anaphylaxis response as a model for EU coordination. Key priorities include: Health Protection and Emergency Preparedness Serious allergies and anaphylaxis present a growing public-health challenge. The Presidency could: Promote timely access to emergency medicines, building on Ireland’s approach where pharmacists can supply life-saving treatment without prescription. Encourage harmonised school and public-venue preparedness, using Ireland as an example. Relevant upcoming EU initiative: Global health resilience initiative (non-legislative, Q2 2026) – to strengthen EU capacity for rapid response to health crises. Digital Innovation for Health Cross-border emergencies require seamless access to patient data: Promote the European Health Data Space for secure, interoperable sharing of health information, enabling faster response to anaphylactic events across borders. Support digital tools for citizen-centred care, enhancing emergency response and patient safety. 3. Reducing Health Inequalities and Strengthening Citizen Rights The Presidency could advance equitable access to emergency care and citizen-centred policy: Link preparedness to strengthening the Child Guarantee (non-legislative, Q2 2026) and Citizens omnibus (legislative, Q4 2026), ensuring children in schools, childcare centres, and communities are protected and have their rights effectively enforced. Promote intergenerational fairness through the Intergenerational fairness strategy (nonlegislative, Q1 2026), ensuring emergency preparedness and health access benefit current and future generations equally. Highlight Ireland’s model as a practical, replicable approach for other Member States. Objectives Establish a model for EU-level anaphylaxis and emergency response coordination, based on best practices of Ireland. Ensure equitable access to life-saving treatments across the EU. Promote digital innovation for preparedness, information sharing, and cross-border patient care. Strengthen citizen rights and intergenerational fairness, ensuring public health policies reflect social equity. Position health resilience as a pillar of EU citizen safety and social cohesion, demonstrating tangible improvements in public health readiness. By focusing on these targeted initiatives, Ireland can use its Presidency to deliver practical, measurable impacts on citizen safety, health equity, and cross-border emergency preparedness while reinforcing the EU’s social and legal frameworks.

The Irish Presidency has the potential to deliver significant, tangible impact for EU citizens by advancing health resilience and consumer safety. For individuals with serious allergies, policies that improve emergency response, access to medicines, and accurate allergen information can be life-saving. For people, expanded access to emergency treatment, including pharmacy-enabled emergency supply across the EU, enhances safety in daily life. Citizens with serious allergies would be better protected in schools, workplaces, sports facilities, cultural venues, and during cross-border travel. For businesses, harmonised allergen-labelling and staff-training expectations reduce regulatory uncertainty, simplify compliance, and improve consumer trust by fostering safer public environments. For communities and institutions, EU-supported readiness measures ,such as common school protocols, public-venue guidelines, and accessible training ,would significantly reduce preventable emergencies, supporting all three Alliance objectives. Replicating Ireland’s best practice on emergency medicine access would ensure that life-saving intervention is available regardless of where a reaction occurs, reducing inequalities across Member States.

Ireland has a strong opportunity to communicate the value of EU membership by focusing on everyday benefits and practical improvements that resonate directly with citizens. The 2026 Presidency can show how EU cooperation protects people, strengthens communities, and makes daily life safer—particularly in areas such as emergency preparedness for serious allergies and anaphylaxis. Highlight Practical Examples of EU Solidarity Citizens understand the EU best when they see clear, relatable outcomes. Ireland can communicate EU values by highlighting how cooperation improves safety and wellbeing, for example: Safer environments in schools, restaurants, transport and public venues. Shared health information that makes travel within the EU safer and more predictable. Harmonised allergen-labelling rules that protect consumers wherever they are. More consistent access to emergency support for serious allergic reactions. Ireland’s own approach—allowing pharmacists to supply emergency treatment during a serious allergic reaction—provides a concrete example of national leadership that improves citizen safety. Propose Council Recommendations on Emergency Readiness To strengthen public understanding of the EU’s benefits, Ireland could lead on a visible, citizen-centred initiative: Develop Council Recommendations on broader readiness and access to emergency treatment for serious allergy and anaphylaxis. This would help encourage Member States to: Improve preparedness in schools, public venues, workplaces, and transport hubs. Ensure trained responders are available across community settings. Reduce inequalities in access to time-sensitive, life-saving care. Such an initiative is easy for citizens to relate to, directly improves safety, and demonstrates EU cooperation in a human, practical way. A simple message: the EU protects people By showcasing initiatives that make everyday life safer, including better emergency preparedness for serious allergic reactions, the Irish Presidency can reinforce a clear message: EU cooperation delivers real, practical benefits for families, children, workers, and communities. This people-centred framing will strengthen public trust, build ownership, and demonstrate the concrete value of Ireland’s leadership at EU level.
Focus on technological sovereignty, focus on diplomacy and focus on stronger ties with the Global South, lead with integrity.

Maintaining our neutrality is key, we can be a real voice of diplomacy between world powers. We also need peace in order to thrive. Irish businesses need security so we need to stay out of wars at all costs. We cannot afford a wider war in any war so must do all we can to avoid it. We need to be strong and stand firm and a voice of reason in a new multipolar world. We need a strong focus on building a sovereign technology landscape in Ireland/Europe to break our reliance on American tech.

Drive European creativity, support local and indigenous businesses, peace and stability is key, keep the Triple Lock and stay out of NATO. The youth of the EU need to be able to prosper and develop their skills in a way that they can afford to live here and support themselves. Focus on enabling Europeans to thrive here and not rely on multinationals from abroad so much. We need a focus on European industry. We need to regulate strongly large monopolies so they dont stifle competition as we can see happening in the tech industry.
Allow citizens to become self reliant, reduce the impact or reach of Foreign monopolies, stay neutral and embrace and support creativity.

We need to be very cautious and wary of the influx of Data Centres in Ireland. We can see the devastating effects they are having in the US and we need to avoid getting to the stage where we lose our sovereignty here because we have allowed foreign monopolies to buy up large areas of land and destroy the nature and water around it. Please lead with integrity and push back on warmongering, fearmongering and large corporate interests. We have to realise the impending disasters coming to us regarding climate change and regulate businesses so they do not destroy us all for profit.

Technology, Data and AI, Digital and Cyber: positioning Europe’s move towards a secure, digital environment, cementing the foundations of data governance in the region Human Capital: EU-wide skills development agenda to progress employment opportunities Diplomacy: introducing more qualified majority voting in foreign policy instead of unanimity and stronger position for High Representatives to articulate positions on behalf of the Union

Digital Regulation and Online Safety: Key Files – Digital Services Act, Digital Markets Act, Digital Fairness Act, Age verification and child protection online frameworks. The aim should be to build consensus on the negotiating positions on new emerging digital proposals, and advancing cross institutional engagement on online harms, algorithmic transparency and age verification Migration and Asylum Policy: Implementing and fine-tuning the EU’s New Pact on Migration and Asylum (mid 2026) Aim should be to promote cooperative approaches to border management and legal pathways Progressing EU Budget for 2028-2034 aim should be to help ensure budget priorities match EU strategic ambitions, including innovation, digital transition, climate action etc. Security: Enhancing and strengthening EU readiness and resilience to hybrid threates and implementing the FDI Screening Regulation (post 2025 provisional agreement) aim to develop common frameworks for critical communication

The Irish Presidency can make the most substantial positive impact for people, businesses and communities across the EY by driving a programme highly focused on practical, higih visibility improvements; simplifying EU rules to reduce costs and accelerating implementation of digital reforms that create good jobs and modern services, strengthening protections for citizens online (particularly children) through balanced digital legislation, advancing migration and asylum arrangements that ease pressure on communities while upholding rights. By promoting competitiveness, inclusion and community level benefits and by building consensus across member states, Ireland can deliver a Presidency that unlocks economic potential and reinforces trust in the European project

We can best communicate the values and benefits of EU membership by making Ireland’s Presidency feel visible, human, and directly connected to people’s daily lives. By this, we can translate complex policy files into simple storylines about how the EU improves housing, jobs, travel, business opportunities, consumer protection, digital safety. It means opening the presidency to citizens through nationwide dialogue, school and university programmes and online platforms that invite ideas, questions and debate. It gives citizens opportunity to participate, influence and see themselves reflected in the Presidency.

organisation: Spanish Association for People with Food and Latex Allergy (AEPNAA)
respondent_type: NGO. Founded in 1996, AEPNAA provide support to people with food and latex allergy and anaphylaxis and their families in Spain to improve their safety and quality of life.
sector: Patients’ rights, Patients’ Safety, Food safety, Food allergen labelling, advocacy, education, international activity and advocacy.
response_text: Taking into account the current geopolitical and socioeconomic context in Europe, it is recommended that Ireland prioritise Health Protection, Citizen Safety, and Resilient Societies as core themes of its 2026 Presidency. The prevalence of serious food allergies and anaphylaxis is increasing across Europe, placing a growing burden on individuals, educational settings, workplaces, and public services. Addressing these conditions aligns closely with broader objectives to safeguard citizens’ wellbeing and to reduce preventable health risks. 1. A Resilient and Prepared Europe The European Union must be adequately equipped to respond to emergencies, including acute health incidents, natural disasters, and public safety threats. Achieving this objective requires harmonised emergency response systems, strengthened preparedness at community level, and enhanced cross-border cooperation. Ireland is among the few Member States that have implemented concrete measures to improve preparedness for serious allergic reactions, notably by allowing pharmacists to supply emergency medicines without a prescription in cases of anaphylaxis. This national practice illustrates effective emergency readiness and offers a valuable model for EU-level policy coordination. It could inform forthcoming initiatives under the European Health Union framework aimed at reinforcing preparedness, prevention, and rapid response capacities across Member States. 2. A People-Centred Union that Protects Embedding people-centred principles into EU policymaking ensures that vulnerable populations and individuals at risk of medical emergencies are not overlooked. The Presidency could advance efforts to reduce health inequalities across the Union, drawing attention to disparities in access to diagnosis, specialist care, treatments, and emergency response protocols. Framing timely care for serious allergies and anaphylaxis within this agenda would demonstrate a commitment to tangible, measurable improvements in patient safety and social inclusion, while upholding citizens’ right to safety in everyday environments such as schools, childcare facilities, workplaces, and public venues. 3. A Future-Oriented Europe Built on Innovation and Collaboration Ireland’s strong reputation in digital innovation provides a strategic opportunity to promote digital innovation in health, leveraging the European Health Data Space and interoperable, patient-centred tools. For individuals at risk of severe allergic reactions, seamless cross-border access to relevant medical information can prevent emergencies and facilitate the free movement of people. The Presidency could also prioritise harmonised awareness-raising, institutional preparedness, and capacity-building initiatives, ensuring that schools, businesses, and public institutions are adequately equipped and trained to respond effectively to life-threatening health incidents.

respondent_type: NGO. Founded in 1996, AEPNAA provide support to people with food and latex allergy and anaphylaxis and their families in Spain to improve their safety and quality of life.
sector: Patients’ rights, Patients’ Safety, Food safety, Food allergen labelling, advocacy, education, international activity and advocacy.
response_text: Ireland could leverage its Presidency to advance health resilience, citizen protection, and emergency readiness, building on its national leadership in anaphylaxis response as a reference point for enhanced EU-level coordination. In this context, the following priority areas could be highlighted: 1. Strengthening Public Health Safety and Crisis Readiness Serious allergies and anaphylaxis constitute an increasing public health concern across Europe. During its Presidency, Ireland could: Promote timely and equitable access to emergency medicines, ensuring that all individuals at risk can receive prompt and effective treatment. Encourage harmonised preparedness measures in schools and public venues, drawing on Ireland’s experience as a model of good practice. Relevant forthcoming EU initiative: Global Health Resilience Initiative (non-legislative, Q2 2026), aimed at reinforcing the EU’s capacity to respond swiftly and effectively to health emergencies. 2. Advancing Digital Solutions for Emergency Healthcare Effective management of cross-border emergencies requires seamless and secure access to patient information. The Presidency could therefore: Support the implementation of the European Health Data Space to enable interoperable and secure sharing of health data, facilitating faster responses to anaphylactic events across Member States. Promote digital, citizen-centred health tools that enhance patient safety and improve the effectiveness of emergency responses. 3. Promoting Equity, Inclusion and the Protection of Citizen Rights Ireland’s Presidency could also contribute to ensuring fair access to emergency care and reinforcing a rights-based approach to health policy by: Linking emergency preparedness to the strengthening of the Child Guarantee (non-legislative, Q2 2026) and the Citizens’ Omnibus initiative (legislative, Q4 2026), ensuring effective protection of children in schools, childcare facilities, and community settings. Advancing intergenerational equity through the Intergenerational Fairness Strategy (non-legislative, Q1 2026), so that preparedness and access to healthcare benefit both present and future generations. Showcasing Ireland’s approach as a practical and replicable model for other Member States. Strategic Objectives Establish a coherent framework for EU-level coordination on anaphylaxis management and emergency response, building on Ireland’s best practices. Guarantee equitable access to life-saving treatments throughout the European Union. Foster digital innovation to improve preparedness, information exchange, and cross-border continuity of care. Reinforce citizen rights and intergenerational fairness, ensuring that public health policies are grounded in principles of social equity. Consolidate health resilience as a central pillar of citizen safety and social cohesion, delivering tangible improvements in public health preparedness. By prioritising these focused actions, Ireland can use its Presidency to achieve concrete and measurable progress in citizen safety, health equity, and cross-border emergency preparedness, while simultaneously strengthening the EU’s social and legal foundations.

respondent_type: NGO. Founded in 1996, AEPNAA provide support to people with food and latex allergy and anaphylaxis and their families in Spain to improve their safety and quality of life.

response_text: The Irish Presidency has the capacity to deliver meaningful and tangible benefits for EU citizens by promoting health resilience and strengthening consumer safety. For individuals living with serious food allergies, policies that enhance emergency response systems, ensure timely access to medicines, and guarantee accurate allergen information can be decisive in saving lives. From a citizen perspective, expanded access to emergency treatments—including the availability of pharmacy-enabled emergency supply across the European Union—would significantly improve everyday safety. People with severe food allergies would benefit from stronger protection in schools, workplaces, sports facilities, cultural venues, and while travelling across borders within the EU. For economic operators and businesses, harmonised requirements on food allergen labelling and staff training would reduce regulatory fragmentation, facilitate compliance, and increase consumer confidence by contributing to safer public and commercial environments. At the level of communities and public institutions, EU-supported preparedness measures—such as shared school protocols, guidance for public venues, and widely accessible training programmes—would substantially decrease the incidence of preventable emergency situations. Extending and replicating Ireland’s best practices in access to emergency medicines across Member States would ensure that life-saving interventions are available when and where they are most needed, reinforcing a more resilient, safer, and more inclusive European Union.

response_text: Ireland has a significant opportunity to communicate the added value of EU membership by focusing on tangible, everyday benefits that resonate directly with citizens. Through its 2026 Presidency, Ireland can demonstrate how European cooperation protects individuals, strengthens communities, and enhances daily safety, particularly in areas such as emergency preparedness for serious allergies and anaphylaxis. 1. Making EU Solidarity Visible Through Concrete Outcomes Citizens engage most effectively with the European Union when its impact is translated into clear and relatable results. Ireland can therefore highlight EU values by illustrating how cooperation contributes to improved safety and wellbeing, for example through: Safer environments in schools, restaurants, transport systems, and other public spaces. Shared health information frameworks that make travel within the EU safer and more predictable. Harmonised food allergen-labelling rules that ensure consistent consumer protection across Member States. More reliable and equitable access to emergency support in cases of severe allergic reactions. 2. Advancing Council-Level Action on Emergency Preparedness To reinforce public understanding of the EU’s practical benefits, Ireland could take the lead on a visible, citizen-focused initiative by promoting Council Recommendations on preparedness and access to emergency treatment for serious allergies and anaphylaxis. Such an initiative would encourage Member States to: Strengthen readiness in schools, public venues, workplaces, and transport hubs. Ensure the availability of trained responders across a wide range of community settings. Address and reduce inequalities in access to time-critical, life-saving care. This type of action is readily understandable for citizens, delivers direct safety improvements, and illustrates EU cooperation in a concrete and human-centred manner. 3. Reinforcing a Clear Narrative: Europe as a Protector of Citizens By highlighting initiatives that make everyday life safer—such as enhanced emergency preparedness for severe allergic reactions—the Irish Presidency can convey a clear and compelling message: EU cooperation produces real and practical benefits for families, children, workers, and communities. Adopting this people-centred narrative would help strengthen public trust, foster a sense of shared ownership, and demonstrate in concrete terms the value of Ireland’s leadership at European level.
