organisation:
Davis College Mallow, Secondary School
eTwinning Ambassador Léargas
response_text: Ireland’s 2026 Presidency offers a unique opportunity to advance the European Union’s strategic agenda across its three overarching themes - a free and democratic Europe, a strong and secure Europe, and a prosperous and competitive Europe. To do this, initiatives that build stronger connections between young people and their European identities should be championed from an early age within the Irish education system. Ireland should prioritise the early and sustained introduction of European citizenship education across the Irish school system, recognising that meaningful engagement with European values and identity from the earliest years is essential to a resilient democratic future. The European Education Area (EEA) sets out a vision of creating a unified and inclusive space in which all EU citizens can access high-quality education and lifelong learning opportunities across borders. Its strategic priorities include raising the quality, equity, and inclusiveness of education and training systems; promoting lifelong learning and cross-border mobility; strengthening the skills, status, and motivation of the education workforce; and further developing and integrating the EU’s higher education sector. Where the Erasmus+ programme has provided support to the development of the EEA, there is scope to develop opportunities for experiential learning for all learners with targeted promotion of the resources available on the European Schools Education Platform and the potential connections forged across Europe through collaborative projects using eTwinning. eTwinning is an online platform funded by the European Union that enables schools, teachers and students across Europe to collaborate on shared educational projects. eTwinning is part of the EU’s Erasmus+ programme. It provides a safe, secure online space where teachers and students from different European countries can meet, work together and share ideas. It supports international school partnerships, digital learning, and cultural exchange. A key priority of the Presidency should therefore be the promotion of the eTwinning programme and the European Schools Education Platform in Ireland through the Department of Education and Youth. eTwinning and the European Schools Education Platform should be valued as essential resources for engaging learners in active citizenship from an early age to achieve the aims of the EEA.

organisation:
Davis College Mallow, Secondary School
eTwinning Ambassador Léargas
response_text: Ireland should make education for European citizenship, digital inclusion, and teacher professional development headline priorities of its Presidency by shaping implementation of the 2030 Roadmap on the future of digital education and skills due in Q3, 2026. It should secure explicit commitments to embed eTwinning and the European School Education Platform initiatives into Irish national policy and teacher professional development frameworks. The platform is a useful communication tool to disseminate information about the European School Alliances and 2030 Roadmap packages, and as such should be promoted more fully by the Department of Education and Youth to fully actualise its potential in Ireland and ensure that timely and relevant European level directives, resources and supports are communicated. We should aim to secure language in the Roadmap that prioritises inclusion from early years to higher education and explicit references to the collaborative platform of eTwinning. The use of SELFIE in schools should be promoted as a baseline measurement of digital competency within schools and to maximise use of the suite of resources on the European Schools Education Platform.

organisation:
Davis College Mallow, Secondary School
eTwinning Ambassador Léargas
response_text: The work of the Council during the term of the Irish Presidency can make a substantial and lasting positive impact for people, businesses, and communities across the European Union by placing inclusive participation, local engagement, and transparent decision-making at the centre of its agenda. Ireland has a unique opportunity to demonstrate leadership by ensuring that EU policy initiatives are grounded in the everyday realities of citizens and that the benefits of European cooperation are felt widely and fairly. A means of achieving this is through the active inclusion of ordinary people within Presidency events, dialogues, and sectoral meetings. By creating structured avenues for community members, civil-society groups, SMEs, youth organisations, and local representatives to engage directly with EU decision-makers, the Presidency can strengthen public understanding of the European project and broaden participation in a meaningful and timely way. Such an approach aligns strongly with the EU’s broader commitment to democratic engagement, citizen participation, and support for grassroots and community-level initiatives. By fostering a Presidency that is open, people - centred, and genuinely participatory, Ireland can help renew public confidence in the European Union, support resilient and prosperous communities, and reinforce the sense of shared purpose that defines what it means to be European. In doing so, the Council’s work will not only advance key legislative priorities but will also contribute to a stronger, more inclusive, and more connected Union for every citizen.

organisation:
Davis College Mallow, Secondary School
eTwinning Ambassador Léargas
response_text: Effectively communicating the values and benefits of EU membership and fostering a genuine sense of public ownership over Ireland’s Presidency of the Council of the EU requires a strategy that is transparent, people-centred, and grounded in meaningful participation. Citizens are more likely to feel connected to Europe when they see how the EU affects their daily lives and when they are offered authentic opportunities to contribute to shaping its future. It is important to ensure people understand the purpose and impact of the Presidency. The Irish Presidency should be presented as a national endeavour in which every citizen has a stake. By showcasing local initiatives funded or empowered by the EU, such as community development projects, climate-action programmes, cross-border cooperation, and youth exchanges, the Presidency can demonstrate Europe’s commitment to communities at every level.

organisation: Age Friendly Ireland Shared Service in Meath County Council (AFI)
respondent_type: Shared Service Office within Local Government under the Public Services Reform Oversight Group
sector: We are an appointed shared service to implement the WHO International Framework for Age Friendly Cities and Communities through local government in Ireland.
geography:
International, National, Regional and Local.
We are the appointed management service for all 31 local authority led local Age Friendly Programmes in Ireland.
Ireland is the first formally recognised fully affiliated Age Friendly Country in the world, as recognised by the WHO.
response_text: Creating Age Friendly Environments | Population Ageing and Demographic Change in Europe The European Commission Strategic Agenda 2024-2029 commits, inter alia, to take the lead in addressing global challenges. Chief amongst these is demographic change. Demographic trends globally point to an ageing, more urbanized, world. This is reflected in the direction of demographic change across the European Union. Eurostat estimated the population of the European Union, at 1 January, 2024, to be 449.3 million. Those aged 65 and over made up 21.6% of the population. This represents an increase of 2.9% over the previous 10 years. The median age of the EU’s population was 44.7 years on 1 January 2024, an increase of 2.2 years from a decade earlier. The old-age dependency ratio increased by 5.6 percentage points during the past decade, rising from 28.3% in 2014 to 33.9% in 2024. Eurostat’s populations projections for the period 2023 to 2100 show that the EU’s population is projected to continue to age. The share of those aged 80 years or above in the EU's population is projected to have a 2.5 fold increase between 2024 and 2100, from 6.1% to 15.3%. The European Commission Green Paper on Ageing – Fostering Solidarity and Responsibility Between Generations (COM 2021) notes: “In the last five decades, life expectancy at birth has increased by about 10 years for both men and women…. Europe is by no means the only continent with an ageing population, but the process is most advanced here. This trend is having a significant impact on people’s everyday lives and on our societies. It has implications for economic growth, fiscal sustainability, health and long-term care, well-being and social cohesion. But ageing also provides new opportunities for creating new jobs, fostering social fairness and boosting prosperity, for instance in the ‘silver’ and care economies.” With the correct interventions and a focus on developing Age Friendly communities, Europe can create a society that supports older people’s participation, contribution, independence, health and wellbeing, long into later life. Recent years have seen the development of a suite of EU policy documents recognizing the demographic changes Europe is experiencing. The European Commission’s Green Paper concludes that healthy and active ageing had a positive impact on the labour market and thus also on social security systems. The paper acknowledges the need for concrete and decisive action to support older people in all policy areas. The EU Care Strategy (September 2022) aims at improving childcare and long-term care for older people and people with disabilities. In October 2023, the EU Commission presented what it called a “demography toolbox” - a list of policies that EU member states can implement to manage the consequences of demographic change. The WHO Europe is preparing the WHO European Strategy on Ageing is Living: Promoting a Lifetime of Health and Well-being (2026–2030). We propose, as an International Leader, that Ireland should choose the Age Friendly agenda on Ageing as a high-level thematic priority for its Presidency of the Council in 2026. Ireland has a considerable amount of progress to showcase and contribute to European policy on ageing and older people, in terms of expertise in public policy areas such as Age Friendly Workplaces, Age Friendly Housing, Age Friendly Transport Infrastructure, Age Friendly Health and Wellbeing and many others.

organisation: Age Friendly Ireland Shared Service in Meath County Council (AFI)
respondent_type: Shared Service Office within Local Government under the Public Services Reform Oversight Group

response_text: A European Strategy for Older Persons Building on the policy initiatives referenced above, the work programme of the Spanish Presidency of the Council (July – December 2023), under the configuration of Employment, Social Policy, Health and Consumer Affairs, undertook to address the Commission’s proposals on demographics and ageing as a key dimension of the EU demographic challenge. In December 2022, the Spanish Presidency asked the European Economic and Social Committee (EESC) to draft an exploratory opinion on a possible future European strategy for older people. The key points of the EESC opinion are: a paradigm shift towards older people, moving away from a care-based approach to focus on empowering them, and eradicating ageist views; that the EU adopt a new European Strategy for Older Persons … with the objectives of protecting all their rights and ensuring their full participation in society and the economy; that the European Commission and the Member States urgently draft, develop, sign, implement and monitor a European Declaration on Older People to reflect the commitment to developing a European Strategy for Older Persons; that the European Commission organises a European Year of Older People, sets up a European Agency for Older People, Ageing and the Demographic Challenge and calls for the adoption of a UN Convention on the Rights of Older Persons. The Presidency subsequently convened a conference in Madrid (29 November 2023) to explore more broadly the development of a possible European strategy for older people. It advocated that a strategy “supported by national plans, will be the platform upon which to build dedicated initiatives and regulatory measures to reaping the benefits of demographic change.” In order to advance the recommendations of this conference, the opportunity exists for the EU and Members States to rethink and improve EU policies for older people and to seize the opportunities offered by demographic change. Age Friendly Ireland recommends that the Irish Presidency host a meeting of the Council of Ministers with a view to progressing an Age Friendly European strategy for older people, which we are in a position to co-design and host. A new European Commission strategy on ageing communities should align with the WHO framework and its eight domains for Age Friendly Communities. As a global leader working in this space Ireland has made significant progress in policy development, relative to ageing and older people, and evidenced through policy implementation, producing demonstrable benefits for older people in Ireland, through the vehicle of the Age Friendly Ireland Shared Service office.

organisation: Age Friendly Ireland Shared Service in Meath County Council (AFI)
respondent_type: Shared Service Office within Local Government under the Public Services Reform Oversight Group
sector: We are an appointed shared service to implement the WHO International Framework for Age Friendly Cities and Communities through local government in Ireland.
geography:
International, National, Regional and Local.
We are the appointed management service for all 31 local authority led local Age Friendly Programmes in Ireland.
Ireland is the first formally recognised fully affiliated Age Friendly Country in the world, as recognised by the WHO.
response_text: Addressing the challenges and embracing the opportunities of an ageing continent The demographic trend, at national, EU and global levels, will pose both economic and societal challenges. “[T]the number of people aged 75-84 will grow by 56.1% and the number of people aged 65-74 by 16.6%, while the number of people aged less than 55 will decrease by 13.5%. While this pressure is felt across the economy, it shows most strongly in the healthcare and old-age nursing sector… Under a paradigm of balanced public budgets and without strong countermeasures, this trend will require a relatively larger portion of Europe’s productive capacity to be diverted towards caring for older persons, leaving the rest of the economy with relatively less capital and human resources. This, in turn, would put an additional question mark to the global competitiveness of the European economy, which is already severely challenged due to skills shortages and high energy prices.” Societal challenges include a lack of access to services, loneliness and ageism and an increasingly digitalized society that risks leaving people behind. A European Strategy for Older Persons could address these challenges, while simultaneously promoting the opportunities an ageing demographic affords. It would support the achievement of the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (as they relate to older people), and the World Health Organisation’s Decade of Healthy Ageing goals. As referenced above, Ireland is recognised as a world leader in advancing the Age Friendly agenda. Programme for Government 2025 – Securing Ireland’s Future commits to the hosting of an International WHO Age Friendly Conference (which Age Friendly Ireland have proposed to host in County Meath). The hosting of a meeting of the Council of Ministers (conference) as part of the Irish Presidency with a view to progressing an Age Friendly European strategy for older people would be an excellent precursor to the proposed International Conference as set out in Programme for Government. This conference could explore how an EU strategy could drive the transition to a Europe that is inclusive, fair and sustainable, and that values and respects our older populations (nationally, regionally and globally). The opportunity exists to advance a European Declaration on Older People, based on the Dublin Declaration on Age Friendly Cities and Communities, as we move towards the end of the UN Decade of Healthy Ageing in 2030. In November 2025 AFI presented to a special conference, hosted by Nina Carberry MEP, in the European Parliament, and showcased how the Irish programme has supported older people to live more independently, stay socially connected and continue contributing to community life, sharing examples of successful local initiatives, which could be replicated across the EU. MEP Carberry commented that the European Parliament “must be more aware of ageing communities when making public policy.” A European Strategy for Older People could address the current gaps in EU policy for older people.
