response_text: Reaching a European and global audience Older People’s Councils are established in many Member States. A recent webinar hosted by the UN Standing Group on Ageing illustrated how Older People’s Councils are operating and highlighted techniques to grow their representative role. Ireland is in the fortunate position of having a strong National Network of Older People’s Councils under the Age Friendly Ireland Shared Service, that represents the authentic and diverse voice of older people across Ireland. This national network would act as a co-design partner in Ireland’s Presidency in relation to a European-wide Strategy on Ageing, in collaboration with Older People’s Councils in other member states. Age Friendly Ireland, as a global leader and affiliate of the WHO Global Network of Age Friendly Cities and Communities, can work with affiliates in other Member States and the European Union, to advance the development of a European Strategy. By harnessing the voice and lived experience of older people across the EU in framing the Strategy, we can address the challenges and embrace the opportunities which the demographic trends point to, while also supporting the emerging programmes and affiliates in the developing world.

organisation: Age Friendly Ireland Shared Service in Meath County Council (AFI)
respondent_type: Shared Service Office within Local Government under the Public Services Reform Oversight Group
sector: We are an appointed shared service to implement the WHO International Framework for Age Friendly Cities and Communities through local government in Ireland.
geography:
International, National, Regional and Local.
We are the appointed management service for all 31 local authority led local Age Friendly Programmes in Ireland.
Ireland is the first formally recognised fully affiliated Age Friendly Country in the world, as recognised by the WHO.
response_text: Should Ireland, during our term of the EU Presidency, choose the Age Friendly Agenda on Ageing as a priority theme, there is ample opportunity for Ireland to showcase our excellent progress in the development of an age friendly ecosystem encompassing Age Friendly Towns, Age Friendly Train Stations, Age Friendly Housing, Age Friendly Stadiums, Age Friendly Business and Workplaces, and the participative democracy process demonstrated in the operation of Older People’s Councils.

Ireland’s Presidency should be rooted in a values-led, human-rights–based vision of Europe, one that strengthens solidarity within and beyond the Union. Comhlámh recommends the following high-level thematic priorities: 1. A Human-Rights-Centred EU Response to Conflict, Genocide, Displacement, and Migration The EU urgently needs coordinated, principled, and rights-based approaches to conflict, genocide, forced displacement, and migration. Ireland should champion an EU response that centres international humanitarian and human rights law; prioritises civilian protection; and upholds the rights and dignity of displaced people, asylum seekers, and migrants. This includes challenging the increasing externalisation of EU border policy and promoting safe, legal, and humane pathways to protection. 2. Protecting and Strengthening the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR) At a time when fundamental rights are under increasing pressure, Ireland should place the protection of the ECHR at the heart of its Presidency. Safeguarding the ECHR architecture and resisting attempts to dilute existing protections is essential to maintaining the EU’s credibility as a rights-based project. 3. Advancing Peace, Justice, and Non-Militarised Approaches to Security Ireland’s long-standing commitment to peacebuilding, diplomacy, and neutrality positions it to play a leadership role in countering the escalating militarisation of the EU. The Presidency should prioritise conflict prevention, peacebuilding, and mediation, and ensure that EU security policy does not contribute to cycles of violence or undermine human rights. Collectively, these priorities would support a Presidency that strengthens the EU’s legitimacy, responds to global crises with justice and integrity, and aligns with Ireland’s own historical commitments to peace-building and solidarity.

To ensure a just, coherent, and human-rights–based EU agenda, Ireland’s Presidency should focus on progressing the following policy areas: 1. EU Trade, Sanctions, and Accountability Mechanisms Regarding Israel Ireland should work to advance EU-level measures that reflect international law, including: A ban on trade with illegal Israeli settlements, in line with the Occupied Territories Bill and international legal obligations. EU sanctions in response to grave and ongoing violations of international humanitarian and human rights law. These measures are essential to upholding EU commitments to justice, human dignity, and international law. 2. Protection of People Seeking Asylum in Europe Ireland should prioritise legislation and Council discussions that strengthen asylum protections and uphold the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights. Key actions include: Ensuring that EU asylum and migration policy aligns with the Refugee Convention and international human rights law. Ending the use of deterrence-based approaches and externalisation agreements that undermine the right to seek asylum. Embedding human dignity, safety, and due process at the centre of EU asylum systems. 3. Enforcement Mechanisms to Prevent Illegal Pushbacks at EU Borders Ireland should champion robust accountability mechanisms for Member States involved in illegal pushbacks on land and sea. This includes: Independent monitoring of border practices. Effective sanctions and infringement proceedings for violations. Ensuring that all Frontex operations uphold human rights and do not contribute to pushbacks or abuse at EU borders. 4. Ensuring Trade Policy Prioritises Fairness and Ecological Sustainability Ireland should use its Presidency to ensure that EU trade agreements prioritise human rights, environmental protection, and fair economic structures over extractive or destructive models of global trade.

A Presidency focused on justice, human rights, and ecological sustainability will deliver the most meaningful and lasting impact for people, communities, and future generations across the EU. First, Ireland should ensure that pro-Palestinian voices, as well as all voices advocating for human rights, peace, and accountability, can participate fully in EU-level debates without fear of exclusion, censorship, or discrimination. A democratic Union depends on open civic space and the ability of affected communities to speak for themselves. Second, Ireland’s long history of peacebuilding and military neutrality offers an important counterbalance to the growing militarisation of EU policy. By foregrounding diplomacy, conflict prevention, peacebuilding, and rights-based security approaches, Ireland can help ensure that EU policies reduce harm rather than deepen cycles of violence. Third, any attempt to articulate “positive impact” must acknowledge the interdependence of people and planet. Without embedding ecological sustainability at the core of all EU policy areas (trade, migration, security, and economic policy among them) the Union cannot claim to be acting in the interests of its citizens. Ireland should recognise that any meaningful positive impact for people, communities, and societies across the EU depends on prioritising ecological sustainability and a just transition. By this we mean a shift away from extractive, militarised and fossil-fuel-dependent systems towards models of living and working that are fair, inclusive, rights-based, and centred on global solidarity. By taking these steps, Ireland can help steer the EU toward a more just, sustainable, and peaceful future.

Effective communication of the values and benefits of EU membership must begin with an honest acknowledgement of the widening disconnect between the EU’s stated commitments to human rights and the reality of many current EU policies, particularly in areas such as migration, militarisation, and external action. Without naming this gap, any public engagement risks appearing superficial and exclusionary. Honesty is essential if Ireland’s Presidency is to communicate meaningfully with citizens and rebuild trust. Ireland should therefore promote a communication approach rooted in transparency, participation, and genuine dialogue. This means recognising that many people feel excluded from EU decision-making and that building a community genuinely rooted in shared values is slow, often uncomfortable work that cannot be reduced to simplified narratives or celebratory messaging. To do this, Ireland’s Presidency should: Create accessible, meaningful spaces where people, especially those most affected by inequality, racism, displacement, and marginalisation, can articulate their own visions for Europe. Facilitate civil-society-led initiatives, global citizenship education, and deliberative public forums that support people to engage critically and constructively with EU policies. Listen and respond, ensuring that insights from those rarely represented in EU policy debates are not merely collected but meaningfully shape the Presidency’s narrative and priorities. Rather than relying on narrow definitions of “EU benefits,” Ireland should invite deeper conversations about the values that should guide European cooperation. A Presidency rooted in humility, participation, justice, and accountability would not only strengthen democratic engagement but also model the kind of Europe many people want to see inclusive, rights-based, transparent, and committed to the wellbeing of all.

Comhlámh’s contribution to this consultation comes from fifty years of people learning, organising, questioning, and acting together in solidarity. Our work has always been shaped by relationships. It has grown through the experiences of returned volunteers, the commitments of our member groups, and the insights of partners in the Global South. At its core is the shared belief that justice is something we build with one another, not for one another. Values-led international volunteering, critical global citizenship education, and long-term activism shown us that people are ready to engage deeply when they are trusted, supported, and invited into meaningful conversation. This spirit runs through all of our responses in this consultation. Whether addressing migration, militarisation, trade, have human rights, or environmental sustainability, our perspective is shaped by what we have witnessed over decades: people want to act ethically, communities want to be heard, and policy is strong when it is informed by lived experience. Ireland’s 2026 EU Presidency provides an opportunity to bring these principles into the heart of European cooperation. A Presidency grounded in justice, participation, and transparency can bridge the gap between the EU’s stated values and current policies. It can promote rights-based approaches to migration, challenge the drift toward militarisation, strengthen human rights protections, and ensure ecological sustainability is embedded as a core principle rather than treated as an optional theme. Comhlámh will continue to champion solidarity that is reflective, grounded, and collective. We submit these responses in the hope that Ireland’s Presidency can help nurture a Europe that people across communities are calling for: inclusive, accountable, rights-based, and committed to the wellbeing of both people and planet.

Ireland’s Presidency of the Council of the EU in 2026 will take place at a critical moment for Europe’s competitiveness. Global markets are evolving rapidly, and the EU must ensure its Single Market remains a driver of growth, innovation, and resilience. Vodafone Ireland believes that competitiveness should be a core theme for the Presidency, and we strongly recommend that connectivity is embedded as a key pillar within that theme. Digital connectivity infrastructure is the foundation upon which Europe’s economic ambitions rest. Without modern, efficient networks, Europe cannot deliver on its goals for artificial intelligence, green transition, or industrial leadership. Connectivity enables every sector—from healthcare and education to manufacturing and public services—to innovate and thrive. The Presidency should therefore champion policies that create the conditions for investment in next-generation networks and reduce fragmentation in the telecommunications market. This is not about digital connectivity being a theme of the Irish Presidency; it is about recognising that competitiveness depends on connectivity. A strong Digital Networks Act will be central to this effort. By advancing this legislation, Ireland can help transform Europe’s telecoms landscape into a coherent single market, unlocking investment, reducing duplication, and creating sustainable growth. Embedding connectivity within the competitiveness agenda will deliver tangible benefits for citizens and businesses, from rural broadband access to advanced digital services. It will also reinforce Ireland’s reputation as a leader in shaping practical, forward-looking EU policy. In short, competitiveness without connectivity is incomplete—and Ireland’s Presidency can make that connection clear.

The Irish Presidency in 2026 presents a rare opportunity for Ireland to lead on a legislative file that will shape the future of a critical sector and Europe’s competitiveness for decades to come. The Digital Networks Act (DNA), expected to be published in January 2026, is not simply another update to telecoms rules—it is a once-in-a-generation chance to modernise a framework that, for over 20 years, has been geared toward voice calls and basic connectivity, not the AI-powered supply chains, smart applications, and high-capacity networks that now define Europe’s digital ambitions. Ireland is well placed to drive this agenda, but it will not be without challenges. There will be differing views on the best path forward for key elements of the Digital Networks Act and as with any major reform, there may be calls to moderate ambition or delay decisions. However, it is important to recognise that postponing meaningful change risks perpetuating fragmentation and underinvestment, ultimately leaving Europe less competitive on the global stage. The cost of inaction is clear—fragmentation, underinvestment, and a regulatory environment that stifles innovation and leaves Europe lagging behind global competitors. Delayed or heavily diluted implementation would not only limit opportunities for businesses to innovate and grow, but also slow the delivery of high-quality, affordable digital services to consumers—impacting everyday connectivity, access to new technologies, and the overall digital experience for people across Europe. The Irish Presidency should aim to build consensus, but also to maintain ambition. Ireland should champion a forward-looking approach that prioritises investment, scale, and the deployment of highquality networks—both in the medium and long term. This means advocating for a predictable, investment-friendly spectrum framework, with longer licence durations and coordinated release roadmaps that give operators the certainty needed to invest in next-generation infrastructure. Reform here is essential to unlocking the full potential of 5G Standalone, satellite connectivity, and future technologies. The Presidency should also encourage the DNA to address regulatory complexity and outdated obligations, streamlining rules to support innovation and competition. Europe’s digital future depends on a framework that enables operators to deliver advanced services, supports fair competition, and ensures that connectivity is a driver of growth, inclusion, and resilience. By leading on the Digital Networks Act, Ireland can demonstrate its commitment to a future-ready Europe—one where digital infrastructure empowers every sector, drives regional development, and supports the ambitions of citizens and businesses alike. The Presidency must seize this moment to push the legislation forward, resist efforts to dilute its impact, and ensure that Europe’s telecoms sector is equipped for the challenges and opportunities of the next decade. In doing so, Ireland will not only secure its own digital future, but also help shape a more competitive, innovative, and connected Europe.

The Irish Presidency offers an opportunity to champion a legislative initiative that will strengthen Europe’s ability to innovate, compete, and include all citizens in the digital age. The Digital Networks Act can serve as a catalyst for progress—helping to modernise Europe’s connectivity framework and create the conditions for investment in high-quality digital infrastructure. This is not about support for the telecommunications sector alone – this is about fostering innovation and growth, enabling businesses to expand and communities to benefit from new technologies and services by supporting the development of a more predictable, investment-friendly environment. The benefits of these reforms will extend beyond throughout all sections of society. Improved connectivity can enhance access to education, healthcare, and public services, making it easier for people to participate in the digital society and benefit from new innovations. While the needs of EU citizens are diverse and evolving, a modernised regulatory framework will help ensure that Europe is better equipped to respond to future challenges and opportunities—whether that means supporting remote work, enabling smart cities, or fostering digital inclusion. The Irish Presidency’s leadership in driving forward the Digital Networks Act and related reforms can help create a more enabling environment for progress, while respecting the unique circumstances and priorities of different Member States. By focusing on policies that support investment, innovation, and high-quality networks, the Council can help deliver tangible improvements for people, businesses, and communities across Europe—now and into the future.
N/A

Vodafone Ireland will provide a short brief alongside this submission. “The Digital Networks Act – securing Europe’s digital future,” explains why the Digital Networks Act is pivotal for competitiveness and for enabling AI, eHealth, and digital public services. It is based on three key themes: Unlocking the digital single market Same rules for same services Simpler regulation that unleashes innovation This document reinforces the core message of this submission: connectivity is not a luxury but a foundation for Europe’s economic and social future, and Ireland’s Presidency can lead the way by delivering a strong Digital Networks Act.

energy prices for households and businesses must remain central. Ireland should therefore focus its Presidency agenda on initiatives that advance energy affordability, strengthen energy efficiency, and diversify clean and secure energy options. In this context, the upcoming review of the recast Energy Efficiency Directive will be critical; Ireland should advocate for an approach that couples efficiency measures with carbon emission reductions, ensuring that policies deliver both cost savings and meaningful progress toward climate goals. A key priority should be ensuring that the forthcoming 2040 climate framework is supported by robust, deliverable policies and the necessary supports to maintain competitiveness, particularly for sectors and regions most exposed to transition costs. The Presidency should champion a technology-neutral approach, recognising that no single solution will meet Europe’s 2050 goals. The 2024 BusinessEurope energy study underscores this point, noting that while deep electrification will play a major role, the future system will rely on a broad mix of energy carriers, including biomethane and biomass products. In shaping negotiations on upcoming energy-efficiency measures, decarbonisation tools, and rural energy policies, Ireland should prioritise balanced energy choices that allow all regions, especially rural communities and businesses, to participate meaningfully and affordably in the transition. Liquid Gas Ireland emphasises that these communities face distinct challenges and must be explicitly included in policy design. Through its leadership in 2026, Ireland should aim to deliver a Presidency that: strengthens Europe’s competitiveness by reducing energy costs; embeds technology neutrality across climate and energy files; supports flexible, practical decarbonisation pathways; and safeguards the competitiveness and viability of rural homes, businesses, and industry. This approach will help ensure that the transition is fair, effective, and accessible for all of Europe’s citizens.

in relation to energy efficiency, heating, and clean fuel choices, will help ensure the transition is both fair and workable for all. The Irish Presidency can help deliver practical outcomes for people and businesses, providing the frameworks and supports needed to enable decarbonisation in a way that is affordable, flexible, and accessible to all.

A clear communications approach should focus on how EU membership directly supports people’s daily lives within their communities and businesses. For Ireland’s Presidency, this means highlighting the practical benefits of European cooperation. This includes measures that help manage energy costs, and the wider suite of options Europe is pursuing to ensure a fair, secure and sustainable energy transition for all citizens. European policy can have a direct impact on rural homes and businesses, which is why it is important that the energy transition reflects the need for choice, flexibility and a range of affordable, low-carbon energy options. By emphasising how EU policymaking strengthens Ireland’s regional development, and provides tools to address shared challenges such as decarbonisation, we can foster a stronger sense of ownership in Ireland’s role at the heart of the EU.

Ireland’s Presidency in 2026 has a unique opportunity to strengthen Europe’s resilience, food security, competitiveness and public health by championing efficient food production for direct human nutrition. Drawing on Food Vision 2030, Origin Green, Bord Bia and domestic research expertise, Ireland can show how complementary cropping, entrepreneurship, manufacturing and farmer viability can reinforce one another. This approach lowers healthcare burdens, supports rural communities, enhances autonomy, and delivers visible benefits to citizens. Structured policy work across CAP, CMO, procurement and R&I, paired with targeted Presidency showcases in Ireland, will translate this insight into practical EU-level outcomes. 1. High-level priority Ireland’s Presidency in 2026 comes at a moment when the EU must pivot from policy ambition to delivery on food security, public health, strategic autonomy and competitiveness. A credible and unifying priority is: Efficient food production for direct human nutrition, safeguarding resources for future generations. Ireland is uniquely placed to lead this, given its: Trusted agri-food expertise, Food Vision 2030 framework, internationally recognised sustainability model (Origin Green), export excellence (Bord Bia), and ability to bridge rural and innovation interests. We propose organising the Presidency’s agenda around three mutually reinforcing pillars: (1) Efficient and resilient food systems Europe should prioritise using agricultural resources in the most efficient way possible to feed people directly with healthy foods. This reduces pressure on land and water, strengthens autonomy, enhances preparedness, and supports future generations. Increased use of crops for direct food consumption complements existing livestock sectors and contributes to system-wide resilience. Sustainable Competitiveness & Rural Opportunity Resilient food systems are essential for Europe’s strategic autonomy and economic security. They create highquality jobs, foster entrepreneurship, and unlock export potential while providing stable markets for farmers through diversified cropping, processing, logistics, and manufacturing. Ireland, with its strong agri-food sector, climate-smart practices, and global reputation for quality, is well positioned to lead this agenda during its Presidency. Clear and predictable policy frameworks will give European companies the confidence to invest, scale, and innovate. To accelerate progress toward resilient and sustainable food systems, the Council could explore ways to reduce existing regulatory and fiscal obstacles—such as outdated schemes, inconsistent taxation, and restrictive product naming rules—that limit innovation and accessibility. Simplification efforts should focus on smarter, more efficient regulation that strengthens competitiveness and sustainability, rather than unintentionally weakening the green transition. Rolling back ambition risks undermining investor confidence and slowing company-led progress and incentives. Public health through nutritious, fiber-rich foods Increasing access to fiber-rich, nutritious food is one of the most cost-effective public health strategies available to the EU. Improving diets reduces disease burden and healthcare costs while supporting economic productivity. Procurement reform is one of the fastest ways to deliver visible progress to citizens.

Ireland can provide EU-level structure by championing efficient nutrition, driven by both farm and business innovation. Strengthening value chains for nutritious foods Using CAP, CMO, the EU School Scheme, and the forthcoming Public Procurement Act to: increase access to nutritious, fiber-rich foods create stable and diversified markets for farmers support rural communities enhance food security and autonomy encourage efficient resource use Business ecosystem for innovation and scale Delivering efficient nutrition requires a supportive environment for entrepreneurship and manufacturing. Sectorneutral, innovation-driven approaches should: enable SMEs and start-ups to move from innovation to market by supporting scale-up and removing legislative and fiscal barriers that hinder the development of affordable, nutritious foods made from European-grown crops promote investment certainty Support businesses in creating healthy, shelf-stable foods that improve food security and reduce waste leverage exports and global competitiveness Research & innovation priorities EU R&I should focus on: agronomy and cropping diversification and resilience suited to European conditions nutrition, including bioavailability shelf-stability and storage efficiency for preparedness • consumer insight research to drive uptake of healthier diets D) Farmer-oriented just transition Diversification must be framed as an opportunity. Advisory services, risk tools, agronomic support and market clarity will ensure benefits accrue directly to farming communities and complement livestock sectors.

A Presidency agenda focused on efficient nutrition offers practical gains: For citizens more nutritious and affordable daily food choices reduced diet-related disease burdens and improved quality of life visible improvements in schools, hospitals and public canteens For farmers and rural communities diversified income streams with stable demand lower exposure to volatile global markets complementary, not competitive, to livestock sectors strengthened agricultural resilience and environmental outcomes For Europe’s competitiveness and autonomy new industry and R&I capacity scalable entrepreneurship and manufacturing lower dependency on external supply chains improved preparedness to shocks and crises For public health cost-effective prevention reduced healthcare expenditure the strongest link between nutrition and long-term wellbeing Companies delivering nutritious, shelf-stable foods play a decisive role in this system. Supporting entrepreneurial scale-up strengthens farmer livelihoods, improves access to healthy foods, and increases Europe’s food autonomy.

This agenda makes Europe tangible to its citizens. It offers: healthier and more affordable food every day resilient rural economies stable farmer incomes reduced long-term healthcare costs practical preparedness and autonomy By grounding the Presidency’s message in everyday benefits, and using citizen dialogues and transparent communication, Ireland can strengthen trust and democratic legitimacy across the Union.

Showcasing Ireland’s leadership: suggested site visits To demonstrate practical, scalable approaches, the Presidency could host visits to: Origin Green-certified producers – showing traceability, sustainability and market impact Bord Bia innovation/export hubs – demonstrating how nutrition and competitiveness reinforce each other Farm-level diversification pilots – highlighting complementary models alongside livestock systems Schools or hospitals using nutritious procurement – showing visible benefits to citizens Research clusters (Teagasc/UCD) – illustrating food system innovation, agronomic progress and farmer advisory support These visits would underscore that Ireland’s experience is credible, is scalable, and offers practical insights for the entire EU

sector: Businesses that employ up to 50 people
response_text: Strengthening the Single Market: Small businesses often face barriers when trading across EU borders due to fragmented regulations. Ireland should champion legislative proposals that reduce compliance costs, harmonize standards, and simplify VAT and customs procedures. This would make it easier for small firms to expand beyond their domestic markets. Access to Finance: Many small businesses struggle to secure affordable credit. Ireland could push for the expansion of EU-backed guarantee schemes, microfinance instruments, and venture capital initiatives tailored to small businesses. Legislative work on the Savings and Investment Union (SIU) should prioritise small business-friendly financing channels. Digital Transformation: The EU is advancing legislation on artificial intelligence, data governance, and cybersecurity. Ireland should ensure these frameworks are small business-compatible, with proportionate obligations and support for adoption. Proposals to expand the Digital Europe Programme and small business-focused digital training hubs would help small firms compete in the digital economy. Trade and Investment: Ireland can use its presidency to advance EU trade agreements and ensure small businesses benefit from them. Simplified rules of origin, small business chapters in trade deals, and better access to export support services should be prioritized. This would open global opportunities for small firms. Skills and Workforce Development: With rapid technological change, small businesses need access to skilled workers. Ireland should highlight EU initiatives on reskilling and upskilling, particularly in digital and green sectors. Legislative proposals on recognition of qualifications across Member States would also ease mobility for small business employees. Legislative Proposals to Prioritise Reform of the Savings and Investment Union (SIU) to expand small business financing tools. Implementation of the AI Act and Data Act with small business-friendly provisions. Simplification of sustainability reporting under the Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive. Updates to the Internal Market Emergency and Resilience Act (IMERA) Instrument to protect small business supply chains during crises. Expansion of the Digital Europe Programme and Horizon Europe SME instruments. Inclusion of small business -focused chapters in upcoming EU trade agreements. Ireland’s presidency offers a chance to position small businesses at the heart of EU competitiveness. By focusing on these areas, Ireland can ensure that small businesses—often the backbone of local economies—are empowered to thrive in the digital and green transitions, access finance more easily, and expand across borders. This agenda would not only benefit Irish Small businesses but also strengthen resilience and inclusivity across the European Union.

sector: Businesses that employ up to 50 people
response_text: The Irish Presidency of the Council of the EU in 2026 can make the most substantial positive impact on small businesses in Ireland by prioritising regulatory simplification, access to finance, digital and green transitions, and cross-border trade opportunities. Ireland’s presidency of the Council of the EU offers a unique opportunity to shape the European agenda in ways that directly benefit small businesses. The Council’s role in negotiating legislation, setting priorities, and coordinating Member States’ positions means Ireland can champion policies that reduce barriers and create opportunities for small businesses—the backbone of Ireland’s economy. Small businesses often struggle with the complexity of EU regulations. During its presidency, Ireland can push for streamlined compliance frameworks, particularly in areas such as VAT, customs, and sustainability reporting. Simplifying the Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive for small businesses would reduce administrative burdens while still encouraging responsible practices. This would free up resources for innovation and growth rather than paperwork. The Council will continue discussions on the Savings and Investment Union (SIU) , which aims to deepen financial integration across the EU. Ireland can ensure that reforms prioritise small business-friendly financing tools, such as microcredit, venture capital, and EU-backed guarantee schemes. By advocating for easier access to affordable finance, Ireland would help small firms invest in expansion, digitalization, and green technologies. Legislation such as the AI Act and Data Act will be central to Council negotiations in 2026. Ireland should champion small business-friendly provisions, ensuring obligations are proportionate and support mechanisms are in place. Expanding the Digital Europe Programme to include small business-focused training hubs would help Irish small businesses adopt advanced digital tools, boosting productivity and competitiveness. Ireland can use its presidency to advance measures that strengthen the Single Market. Streamlining customs procedures, harmonizing product standards, and reducing compliance costs would make it easier for small businesses to expand across EU borders. This is particularly important for Ireland, given its reliance on exports and its geographic position at the edge of Europe. The Council will also address EU-wide initiatives on reskilling and upskilling. Ireland can ensure these programs are tailored to small businesses, helping them access skilled workers in digital and green sectors. Recognition of qualifications across Member States would ease mobility and recruitment for Irish small businesses. By focusing on these areas, Ireland’s presidency can deliver tangible benefits: reduced regulatory burdens, improved access to finance, greater digital adoption, stronger participation in the green transition, and expanded trade opportunities. These outcomes would not only strengthen Irish Small businesses but also enhance their resilience in a competitive global economy.

sector: Businesses that employ up to 50 people
response_text: 1. Tailored messaging Highlight practical benefits: Emphasise how EU membership directly supports small businesses— access to the Single Market, funding opportunities, reduced trade barriers, and protections during crises. Use relatable examples: Showcase Irish small businesses that have successfully expanded into EU markets or accessed EU innovation funds. • Simplify complex policies: Translate EU legislation into clear, business-friendly language, focusing on how it reduces costs, opens opportunities, or enhances resilience. Digital Outreach Use webinars, podcasts, and short explainer videos to reach busy business owners who may not attend in person. Creating Ownership Small business advisory panels: Invite small business leaders to contribute to Ireland’s Presidency agenda, ensuring their voices shape priorities. Storytelling campaigns: Feature small owners as “EU Ambassadors,” sharing how EU membership has helped their businesses grow. Practical Support Initiatives EU funding clinics: Provide hands-on guidance on accessing EU grants and programs, demystifying the process. Trade readiness programs: Help Small businesses prepare to expand into EU markets, with simplified guides and mentoring. Green and digital toolkits: Offer practical resources showing how EU initiatives can help Small businesses adopt sustainable and digital practices. Values-Based Communication Community and solidarity: Stress that EU membership is about collective resilience—small businesses benefit from being part of a larger bloc during crises. Innovation and opportunity: Position the EU as a driver of innovation, with small businesses at the heart of Europe’s digital and green transitions. Voice and influence: Emphasise that Ireland’s Presidency gives Irish small businesses a unique chance to shape EU priorities, reinforcing their role as stakeholders in Europe’s future. By combining clear messaging, direct engagement, and opportunities for participation, the Irish Government can ensure small business owners see EU membership not as abstract policy but as a tangible driver of growth. Creating a sense of ownership over the Presidency will empower small businesses to feel part of Ireland’s leadership role in Europe, strengthening both national and EU identity.

sector: Businesses that employ up to 50 people
response_text: cases, respondents must provide a summary of the additional information under the ‘Any other comments’ question. This summary should also be limited to a maximum of 500 words. The SFA represents all companies that employ up to 50 people. While the SFA is a part of Ibec, it has a separate membership base. However, in terms of broad policy positions, the SFA and Ibec are completely aligned when it comes to Ireland’s presidency of the EU. Arising from that, the SFA supports the Ibec campaign for Ireland’s EU Presidency. Making a Resilient, Competitive EU a Reality: The Business Ambition for Ireland’s EU Presidency. In its six policy papers, the campaign sets out the strategic themes that should form the basis of the Government’s EU Presidency Programme: Trade and Investment: Strengthening relationships, maximising opportunities (published 12/11) Single Market and Simplification: Turning ambition into action (published on 19 November) Labour Market and Social Policy: Skills, innovation and EU added value (published on 26 November) Enterprise and Economy: Create the conditions for competitiveness (published on 3 December) Security and Defence: Pillars of a resilient Europe (due to be published 8-12 December) Digital and AI: Simplification, adoption and innovation (due to be published 8-12 December)

geography: National, EU-wide, and international (e.g. global climate and biodiversity)
response_text: The Environmental Pillar is proposing “Resilience” as the theme of Ireland’s Presidency of the Council of the European Union in 2026. This could be reflected in a slogan such as “Thriving together in a turbulent world” or “Thriving together in turbulent times” either of which could be shortened to Thriving Together. The Government could speak about the theme like this: We live in increasingly uncertain and turbulent times, globally. Resilience will be key to thriving in the coming decades and beyond. Many of the building blocks of the modern economic and political order can no longer be taken for granted, from global trade to international alliances, from secure energy supplies to a stable climate. Around Europe and the world we continually see people demonstrate resilience, courage and creativity in the face of these challenges. We saw it here Ireland in the wake of Storm Eowyn last year, when neighbours and communities came together to respond even before official aid could arrive. It showed the truth of the old Irish saying “Ar scáth a chéile a mhaireann na daoine” – we live in each other’s shadows, sharing shelter and shade. That’s why during our EU Presidency we want to celebrate, support and strengthen the institutions and infrastructure - natural and social, physical and political – that underpin the resilience that Europe’s citizens, businesses and communities need to adapt and succeed in a changing world. We think “Resilience” as a theme chimes with new and existing narratives and initiatives being adopted by the EU. You hear repeated discussion of the need for the EU to develop its “Strategic Autonomy”, reflecting a number of concerns: a push for Europe not to depend on others for its security and defence for example, but also the need to stop relying on imported fossil fuels from unreliable regimes around the world, and the understanding that developing a more circular economy reduces our reliance on volatile supply chains for critical materials. The EU’s 2025 Strategic Foresight Report is actually called “Resilience 2.0: Empowering the EU to thrive amid turbulence and uncertainty” and captures the challenge well. Resilience as a framing has also received a significant push and much scientific underpinning from the recent work of the European Environment Agency (EEA). In their recent five-yearly State of the Environment report the agency appeals for “a broad understanding of security” that “captures not only defence, but also the resilience of vital societal functions that depend on our natural environment”. We think resilience provides a comprehensive, resonant and positive framing for Ireland’s Presidency of the Council of the European Union. It reflects, in a proactive way, the need to support people’s inherent ability to cope with the increasing uncertainty and volatility by strengthening our institutions and infrastructure to match the spirit of community Europe’s citizens demonstrate so often. For us in the Environmental Pillar this is part of wider transition that centres the elimination of pollution and the promotion of wellbeing as key metrics of successful, flourishing economies and societies.

geography: National, EU-wide, and international (e.g. global climate and biodiversity)
response_text: We propose a particular focus on the following policy and legislative areas and outcomes: Simplification must not mean deregulation The Commission is currently on a drive to “simplify” EU regulation, including reviewing very recently adopted measures that form part of the European Green Deal. While seeking to ensure regulation achieves its objectives efficiently is theoretically uncontroversial, in practice the process so far has been accompanied by a strong deregulation push that clearly risks undermining standards and outcomes for EU citizens and the environment. Some companies, industry alliances and their well-paid lobbyists (especially fossil fuel companies, big tech and chemical companies) are using this political pivot from the Commission to seek wholescale deregulation (in a “shock doctrine” style manipulation of current geopolitical and geo-economic turbulence). However, many experts, institutions and agencies, including the ECB for example, are warning that this is not in fact good for business as a whole, who benefit from regulatory certainty, and is essentially punishing those businesses that have invested in transition, is rewarding laggards and undermines the EU’s transition to long-term sustainability and prosperity. The Irish Presidency has a duty and an opportunity to uphold the future-oriented standard-setting that has epitomized EU innovation and protects citizens, our environment, and our common future. The new Multilateral Financial Framework must ensure adequate and dedicated funding for: nature restoration, to deliver the nature restoration law in partnership with farmers, communities and environmentalists; economically, socially and environmentally sustainable agriculture, including a “fully funded Pillar Two of CAP, including LEADER” as Minister Byrne put it to us recently; civil society and active citizenship, including continuing LIFE funding. The Circular Economy Act This is a real opportunity to enact legislation that makes a positive practical difference for consumers struggling with built-in obsolescence and entitled to a right-to-repair, addresses the supply chain challenges and critical-import dependence of European businesses, while also contributing to more sustainable resource use. 2040 Climate Package The Commission may table the formal proposals for the climate regime to achieve the 2040 climate target during the Irish Presidency. That is the equivalent of the Fit for 55 package for 2030, “Now for 90”? It is essential that the 2040 package is robust, does not weaken or unravel the current regime, and does not widen loopholes and flexibilities in a way that delays action or reduces momentum. It must also frame and deliver the transition is way that is fair, transparent and clearly addresses people’s immediate material concerns. That is both an imperative of a Just Transition and essential to avoid opportunistic opponents of climate action driving social division through disinformation and weaponization of climate measures based on fear and false information.

geography: National, EU-wide, and international (e.g. global climate and biodiversity)
response_text: As outlined in the answers to Questions 1 delivering a Presidency agenda that supports and strengthens the inherent resilience capabilities of “people, businesses and communities across the EU” would have a substantial positive impact. As would delivering practical, positive progress in the policy and legislative areas outlined in our answer to Question 2. And it must be progress that does not sacrifice transition, sustainability and resilience on the altar of short-term supposedly populist “vice signalling” or succumb to the pressure from huge business interests that want the EU to safeguard and serve their profits over the public good, or to pressure from state actors to the east and west that are seeking to undermine the European project and its stated values. Supporting civil society participation both on its own merits and to bolster the legitimacy and resonance of the European project is essential and we very much welcome Minister Byrne’s stated commitment in his meeting with the Environmental Pillar to championing the role of civil society across Europe, and his dismissal of some anti-civil society tropes as nonsense. Civil society space is under attack in various places around Europe, both geographic and ideological, and it is positive and essential that the Government is signalling its intention to uphold the long tradition of positive engagement with civil society during the Irish presidency of the EU. Supporting the development of the European Democracy Shield recently announced by Commissioner McGrath would be positive, especially the Stakeholder Platform of the new European Centre for Democratic Resilience to “to facilitate dialogue with trusted stakeholders such as civil society organisations, researchers and academia, fact-checkers and media providers” on three dimensions of the work: Safeguarding the integrity of the information space Strengthening our institutions, fair and free elections, and free and independent media Boosting societal resilience and citizens' engagement And supporting Irish civil society to ensure it has the capacity and opportunity to participate and contribute to the advancement of the three objectives under Commissioner McGrath’s EU Civil Society Strategy: Fostering engagement: A new Civil Society Platform will be established by 2026 to further facilitate dialogue on the protection and promotion of EU values. Support and protection: … including urgent assistance to organisations under threat, and coordination of available protection measures in Member States. Sustainable and transparent funding: … including the Commission [proposal] to significantly increase the financial support to CSOs, with €9 billion foreseen for the AgoraEU programme alone … as well as planning measures to facilitate access to different funding sources.

geography: National, EU-wide, and international (e.g. global climate and biodiversity)
response_text: Conferences of the Parties (COPs) on both biodiversity and climate While Ireland holds the Presidency of the Council of the EU there will be both the 17th Conference of the Parties (COP17) to the UN Convention on Biological Diversity (CBD) and the 31st Conference of the Parties (COP31) to the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC). The Presidency plays an important role in forging consensus negotiating positions among the 27 member states. In line with the rest of this submission we would urge the Irish government to: Demonstrate and promote timely, structured and meaningful engagement with civil society before and during the COPs, at national and EU level, including ensuring civil society space is protected and supported at the COP venues. Seek EU negotiating positions and strategies that fulfil and advance the agreed objectives of the Conventions with urgency and in a manner that enables people and nature to thrive. Getting our own house in order We believe the run into the Presidency is an opportune moment to pull out all the stops to ensure Ireland has its own house in order on legal compliance before it presides over one of the Union’s three legislative branches. We look forward to engaging further on this in the coming months with regard to cases such as the “transposition deficit” in the energy area highlighted by the Climate Change Advisory Council in relation to the Fit for 55 package, and the issues highlighted below: We want to reiterate the issues raised by our partner, the Fair Seas Campaign: Despite repeated commitments over the past five years, Ireland currently ranks among the lowest-performing EU Member States in both the designation and effective management of MPAs. This gap between commitment and implementation undermines Ireland’s credibility at a time when the EU is looking for concrete action to match political pledges. For Ireland to hold the Presidency with authority on marine issues, it is essential that the Government advance strong, fit-for-purpose national MPA legislation in advance of 2026. Such legislation is critical to ensuring that Ireland can meet its 30x30 obligations, and it will provide a solid foundation for shaping wider EU policy conversations during the Presidency. Equally important is the need to improve the management and conservation effectiveness of Ireland’s existing Natura 2000 marine sites under the Birds and Habitats Directives. Without significant enhancement of implementation and enforcement within these existing sites, achieving a meaningful 30% MPA network will not be possible. Progressing MPA designation, management and wider marine conservation reforms is not simply a matter of compliance. It is an opportunity for Ireland to demonstrate genuine leadership at both national and EU levels, to build credibility as an advocate for ocean protection, and to show that Ireland can deliver on the commitments it has championed publicly. Doing MPAs properly, i.e., their designation and management is grounded in science, community engagement and effective and ongoing management, would position Ireland as a respected and ambitious leader during its EU Presidency. For these reasons, we urge the Government to prioritise marine conservation and MPA implementation as a core workstream in the lead-up to, and throughout, Ireland’s EU Council Presidency in 2026. We equally want to reiterate the issues raised by our partner, the Sustainable Water Network (SWAN) Ireland’s record on water quality remains a persistent concern. The most recent EPA Water Quality in Ireland report shows that nearly half of monitored rivers and lakes are in less-than-good ecological status and the number of these is growing, while nitrate and phosphate pollution pressures are rising in many catchments. As a Presidency, Ireland will be expected to coordinate and advance negotiations on various water environment related files. However, ongoing EU infringement proceedings against Ireland under the WFD, the Habitats Directive, Drinking Water Directive and the Urban Waste Water Treatment Directive risk undermining our credibility in convening discussions on Europe’s water future. Before taking the helm, the Government should take demonstrable steps to show progress in tackling agricultural pollution, upgrading wastewater infrastructure, and preventing physical damage to our waters. The recent ruling by the ECJ that Ireland is in breach of its obligations under the EU Water Framework Directive (WFD) is a case in point. Two significant steps Ireland could take in addressing this breach are: The exemption threshold for abstraction is way too high and should be dropped to at least 10m3 Review the Arterial Drainage Act as promised in the Water Action Plan so as to reduce the physical damage to our waterways in Ireland, such as dredging, draining and damage to habitats. Furthermore, Ireland must transition farmers off the nitrate’s derogation over the next three years. The science shows that Ireland’s water quality is declining and there are no evidence-based measures in Ireland’s Nitrates Action Programme that will improve water quality in three years to ensure Ireland gets the derogation again. This is unfair to farmers who will be once again brought to a cliff-edge economically. Ireland cannot hold credibility if it continues to plan to seek derogation while its lakes and rivers are dying, such as Lady’s Island’s lake, whose green polluted waters can be seen from space.

Ireland’s Presidency should champion ‘Securing the Future of European Farming and Food Systems’ as a core theme. Agriculture underpins food security, rural economies, and environmental sustainability, yet it faces a demographic crisis: the average EU farmer is 57, and only 12% of EU farmers are under 40. Without generational renewal, Europe risks losing millions of farms by 2040, threatening food supply and rural vitality. The Presidency offers a unique opportunity to align with the EU Strategic Agenda 2024 – 2029 and the Green Deal by prioritising: Generational renewal in agriculture by advocating for measures that make farming accessible to young people and support the Commission’s goal to double the share of farmers under 40 by 2040 (12% to 24%). Climate-resilient food systems through advancing policies that embed regenerative agriculture and soil health into the post-2027 CAP. This would help ensure farming adapts to climate extremes while maintain productivity. Competitiveness and innovation – position agriculture as a driver of green growth through digital tools, precision farming, and sustainable practices, helping ensure that farmers can thrive economically while meeting environmental targets. Farming forms a key part of Ireland’s economy, society and cultural identity. It is a major contributor to the national economy, particularly through exports, and employs a significant portion of the domestic workforce. This situates Ireland’s Presidency perfectly to provide a clear leadership message: the future of farming is central to Europe’s resilience, sustainability, and prosperity.

Key policy areas should include: Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) Post-2027 Reform Ensure CAP reflects generational renewal as a binding priority, with member states mandated to dedicate an amount corresponding to at least 6% of their payments budget to support young farmers. Simplify administrative burdens for farmers, as proposed in the ‘Omnibus III’ package, while also safeguarding green ambitions. EU Strategy for Generational Renewal in Agriculture Drive adoption of measures such as the Young Farmer Starter Pack (With a potential €300,000 cap), improved access to credit via the European Investment Bank (EIB), and create a European Land Observatory to track land prices and combat speculation. Promote gender equality and rural young engagement through initiatives like Rural Youth Ambassadors. Regenerative Agriculture and Soil Health Embed regenerative practices into EU law and CAP eco-schemes. Advocate for transitional support, including technical assistance and fair pricing, to help farmers adopt sustainable methods. The Presidency should aim to sucre political agreement on these priorities and ensure that Europe’s farming sector is future-proofed against demographic decline and extreme weather.

By focusing on farming’s future, the Council can deliver tangible benefits: • For people, safeguard food security and rural livelihoods by making farming viable career for young Europeans. This means addressing financial barriers and creating pathways for new entrants. For business, it would strengthen supply chain resilience through supporting sustainable sourcing and innovation. McDonald’s are a key supporter of regenerative agriculture which reduces input costs, improves soil health, and enhances climate resilience. For communities, it revitalises rural areas by promoting generational renewal and digital connectivity. An Irish Presidency that prioritises agriculture will not only protect Europe’s food system but also drive economic stability, environmental protection, and support rural communities.

By linking EU action to the everyday realities for consumers: food on tables, thriving rural communities, consumer choice, and climate resilience. This could be done through various means, but please see some suggested approaches below: Storytelling through farmers – share real stories like Sophie Thompson’s (Link here) which outlines the uncertainty to opportunity through McDonald’s Progressive Young Farmer programme. This will illustrate how EU policies could enable young people to build careers in farming. Youth engagement – launch a ‘Future of Farming’ campaign during the Presidency, involving schools, agricultural colleges, Irish farmers, and Rural Youth Ambassadors to showcase EU support for generational renewal. Open dialogue – use social media, regional events, and other platforms to explain how CAP reform, sustainability initiatives, and rural development policies can benefit European citizens directly.

sector: Health/Pharmaceuticals/Agriculture (veterinary medicines, vaccines and animal health tools)
response_text: Disease Prevention (animal disease prevention can be encompassed in a more general “One Health approach” promoting disease surveillance and monitoring, and vaccination), Competitiveness of the agricultural value chain, starting from the essential role livestock plays for a competitive agri-food sector (includes topics related to simplification, the EU Livestock Strategy, Vision for agriculture) An innovative health sector (including advances in animal health technologies and the role they play in sustainable food production/One Health, the essential role of the future EU Biotech Act).

sector: Health/Pharmaceuticals/Agriculture (veterinary medicines, vaccines and animal health tools)
response_text: EU Vaccination Strategy: Animal diseases which were once only reported outside of Europe’s borders are now more frequently occurring on European soil, and not solely in the continent’s southern climes. Where vaccines are available, vaccination should be mandatory and should be supported by public authorities. As Ministers of Agriculture have repeatedly stated, it is time for the EU to have a harmonised approach to animal vaccination. Such a strategy could help to lift “internal trade barriers” between Member States on vaccinated animals, promote support for the “free with vaccination” status globally, and promote preventive vaccination; EU Biotech Act 1 – Important for improving the competitiveness of the animal health sector, and for increasing and retaining innovation in medicines, vaccines and other animal health products in the EU (highly needed as explained above, even more as it seems that the Omnibus on “Food and Feed” won’t tackle the EU rules on veterinary medicinal products); EU Livestock Strategy: due to be published around Spring 2026. It has a potential to better highlight the essential role of livestock in Europe and to support the livestock sector. We believe that it can help livestock farmers with the necessary recognition and support needed to protect Europe’s herds/flocks against animal disease outbreaks; Financing: MFF (Multiannual Financial Framework) and CAP (Common Agriculture Policy) negotiations will take place during the Irish Presidency. We call on the Presidency to ensure that animal disease prevention and management receives sufficient funding (for farmers to invest in preventive monitoring tools, support with vaccination, and where needed – sufficient “crisis mechanisms” funding). Financing animal health will be one of the topics of the next General Assembly of the World Animal Health Organisation (WOAH). It seems that the evaluation of the Animal Health Law (to be finalised in Spring) will also suggest that reflection is needed on financing animal health. REACH proposal: under existing legislation, medicines are exempt from authorisation, but not from restrictions. This is creating numerous issues, mostly at manufacturing sites. In many cases, substitution is not (legally) possible, and restrictions therefore can severely disrupt manufacturing and supply of medicines – with the proposed PFAS restriction potentially driving manufacturing completely out of the EEA. Exempting medicines and their manufacturing from restrictions and maintaining the benefit-risk approach from Reg 2019/6 would be a solution to these issues. Global access to medicines: Animal health products were caught up in the US Administration’s “Section 232” investigation into pharmaceuticals. AnimalhealthEurope strongly believes that veterinary medicines were not the target of the US Administration. This is why we believe that veterinary medicines should be exempted from US tariffs intended to be imposed on human medicines, as they may face the imposition of the same tariffs as medicines for human use. This would otherwise have negative consequences on veterinarians, farmers and families with pets. For the same reason, it is essential to ensure the continued access to veterinary medicines in Northern Ireland.

sector: Health/Pharmaceuticals/Agriculture (veterinary medicines, vaccines and animal health tools)
response_text: By tackling the different aspects of animal disease prevention and management, the Irish Presidency would protect: animals (animal health and welfare), citizens (the World Health Organisation estimates that 60% of human infectious diseases are zoonotic, and additionally, 75% of the new and emerging infectious diseases are of zoonotic origin. In addition, some initiatives such as the EU Biotech Act have the potential to make the EU animal medicines industry more competitive and to attract and retain more talent and it is essential to include a more “One-Health – One Welfare” approach to policies), farmers (farmers who lose their herds/flocks to disease lose much more than their revenue, as farmers also lose years of investment in genetic selection), community (farmers who lose their animals due a disease outbreak might decide to leave the farming community altogether. In addition, managing disease outbreaks creates significant costs for public authorities and therefore for taxpayers – Commissioner Varhelyi recently stated that €1 spent in disease prevention is worth €3 in disease management). The animal health industry is a cornerstone of the EU economy, generating €8.9 billion in sales in 2024 in Europe, and supporting around 50,000 jobs in the region. Like for human medicines, the EU is also a global manufacturing hub for veterinary medicines (including vaccines) which are exported globally, including to the US. Veterinary medicines, vaccines and other animal health products extend to 300,000 veterinarians dependent on medicines for their daily work, helping 166 million European households with pets (that are often considered as part of the family and can deliver numerous health benefits for individuals and the society and should be supported by more pet inclusive policies), and supporting 3 million farms with livestock in keeping their animals protected against disease. However, there are not enough veterinarians, especially in some rural areas. Ensuring access to veterinary care and supporting a thriving veterinary sector therefore is essential.

sector: Health/Pharmaceuticals/Agriculture (veterinary medicines, vaccines and animal health tools)
response_text: Thank you for organising such a survey. Such an initiative is an excellent way to increase ownership for EU citizens. National campaigns, openly and clearly communicating on how key EU initiatives and legislation can impact and benefit the citizens of Ireland, and each of the other Member States, can help bring the EU to a more tangible level. By demonstrating, through events, media, education, etc. how EU initiatives bring positive outcomes to the nations, this can in turn create a sense of ownership for national citizens to engage with EU topics.

Because European creative industries and in particular publishing are key to the democratic cohesion in Europe and that the use of creation without permission leads to an impoverishment of the sectors at a time where culture should be at the center of attention and reading even more. Because the tools we have at our disposal in matters of enforcement are insufficient and new tools have to be developped to allow cultural sectors to protect their creation.

Copyright enforcement. Transparency is essential not only to incentivise copyright compliance but also to build trust and foster the development of an ethical AI ecosystem. Given that such transparency is not a standard for AI providers and that the standard of proof for rightsholders to exercise their rights is high, complementary measures would be necessary to rebalance this situation. The Council should explore - 1. the introduction of a presumption of reproduction of works by AI providers as part of judicial procedures where there are enough indications supporting the likelihood of such use. 2. a Know Your Business Consumers obligation for platforms that serve as intermediaries between their users and AI providers to acquire training datasets (whether for free or sale). 3. setting up a discovery procedure to compel the disclosure of evidence.
By addressing the issues above and finding legislative solutions, the Itish Presidency would compel the institutions to provide cultural sectors with appropriate solutions to protect their rights.

Europe’s cultures are key to communicate the values and benefits of EU membership. To provide its players with solutions to enable them to protect their works and continue offering the benefits of culture to European citizens, the Itish presidency would support an essential sector.

The EU is emerging from an unprecedented regulatory cycle, yet still struggling with low productivity, uneven tech adoption, and sluggish growth. Ireland has a rare opportunity to reorient the conversation: from regulatory accumulation to regulatory performance, from defensive industrial narratives to a proactive, pro-competitiveness agenda that actually delivers for European businesses and consumers. Double-Down on Tech Regulatory Simplification The strongest economies are those that deploy and consume digital technologies at scale. Cloud, AI, cybersecurity, data-driven services, and next-generation connectivity are not “sectors,” they are multipliers across the entire economy. Ireland should champion a Presidency centred on accelerating digital deployment as the EU’s primary competitiveness tool. This requires acknowledging a simple truth: many recent and upcoming EU tech rules are not yet fit for purpose. Implementation issues, internal inconsistencies, and overlapping obligations, across the DSA, DMA, Data Act, AI Act, sectoral rules, and national add-ons, create drag on innovation, compliance teams, and ultimately on Europe’s ability to scale new technologies. For consumers, this translates into patchy protection as companies are forced to guess their way from abstract prescriptions to meaningful and actionable steps built into functional products. Ireland should lead a systematic effort to examine what’s working and what needs corrective action. This should entail facilitating structured, continuous, cross-working-party discussions that match the scale and pace of the tech regulatory tsunami. The recent digital and AI “omnibus” proposals are only a start. The 2026 Presidency should focus on doubling down on simplifying, unifying, and clarifying rules so as to land on a coherent approach to enforcement and guidance. The goal: restore predictability, coherence, and a functioning Digital Single Market. Make Europe a Customer-First Digital Market The current push for “Buy European” mandates and other forms of technology protectionism such as network usage fees might be politically opportune for a few actors, but economically self-defeating for all. Aggressive procurement quotas or access restrictions would inflate public-sector costs, limit access to cutting-edge cloud and AI solutions, and deepen the EU’s technological lag. They would offer no meaningful “sovereignty,” just higher prices and slower innovation on the market for customers. Real digital sovereignty comes from diversification and choice. Europe should prioritise open markets, competitive procurement, and interoperability that prevents vendor lock-in. Sovereignty should never become a subsidy for firms that failed to compete or innovate. Customer buy-in is competitive companies’ north star, and industrial policy built on artificial mandates rather than genuine market demand will fail. Tailored solutions for mission-critical use cases will always exist where customers need them. But while Europe’s concerns about supply-chain risks, extraterrititorial data-access laws, and economic sanctions spillovers are understood, unilateral market-access restrictions will be ineffective, especially for European businesses operating abroad which are subject to foreign laws by definition. The upcoming Irish Presidency should advance discussions with Member States, urging the Commission to pursue coordinated legal architecture with like-minded international partners to resolve cross-border legal tensions at their source, set predictable guardrails, and establish cooperative channels that keep essential digital services from becoming collateral damage.

Ramping up simplification and competitiveness The upcoming Irish Presidency should drive comprehensive simplification across the EU’s regulatory landscape. Legislative focus: The Presidency should advance simplify and ensure coherence across digital rules, including through a swift adoption of the proposed Digital Omnibus and ensuring that the EU Council actively contributes to the broader Digital Fitness Check. Furthermore, upcoming legislation such as the Delivery Act and the Product Act should ensure greater legal certainty. Work on the Environmental Omnibus and Circular Economy Act must focus on simplifying green policies to actively support Europe’s competitiveness. Achievement aim: The Presidency should play a significant role in keeping up the momentum towards greater simplification of EU digital rules and ensure efforts translate into tangible results: cutting red tape, harmonising enforcement, and strengthening Europe’s global competitive standing. Ensuring a stable and open digital single market Maintaining the stability and principle-based nature of the Digital Single Market is paramount. Legislative focus: A key task will be coordinating the Council’s response to the DMA Review to ensure that implementation and enforcement are predictable and fair. The Presidency should convene several thematic working party meetings to discuss the various aspects of DMA implementation and enforcement, building upon the initial discussion hosted by the Cypriot Presidency following the publication of the DMA Review report. The Presidency should also encourage careful scrutiny of the upcoming Digital Networks Act (DNA) during negotiations, ensuring it adheres to the principles of net neutrality and firmly rejects proposals that would covertly introduce network usage fees. The Presidency is also urged to ensure thorough scrutiny over revisions of consumer laws such the upcoming Digital Fairness Act (DFA), to prioritise enforcement of existing rules and avoid duplication. The Presidency should ensure that the Council weighs in on the review of the Foreign Subsidies Regulation (FSR) to slash over notification of financial contributions to ensure that limited enforcement is focused on truly distortive practices. • Achievement aim: The Presidency must safeguard a level playing field by firmly rejecting nontechnical or exclusionary market restrictions, such as sovereignty criteria (relevant to discussions around the Cybersecurity Act or the Cloud and AI Development Act) and discriminatory financial data access rules (FiDA), which only raise costs and reduce choice for Europeans. 3. Advancing a safe and responsible online environment Regulatory discussions on online safety must be harmonised, risk-based, and evidence-based. Legislative focus: The Presidency will need to manage challenging negotiations on the protection of minors online. It must champion a unified, risk-based approach to minor protection that maintains the primacy and coherence of existing frameworks, specifically the Digital Services Act (DSA), as well as effective implementation. The Presidency should also oversee discussions on the AVMSD review and issues related to AI & Copyright and EMFA. Achievement aim: The Presidency should ensure that online safety measures are effective, proportionate, and rights-respecting. It must champion a cohesive, risk-based approach to youth protection and content regulation, ensuring any new measures are evidence-based and do not undermine the Single Market or the operational effectiveness of online services.

The upcoming Irish Presidency has the opportunity to shift the Council’s work from regulatory accumulation toward real-world outcomes. The biggest positive impact will come from advancing Europe’s digital and green rules that are simpler, clearer, and genuinely pro-growth. Three overarching actions would deliver the most value for citizens, businesses, and communities. 1. Deliver a coherent and predictable regulatory environment The single biggest barrier to competitiveness today is complexity. Layers of new rules, from DSA, DMA, AI Act, Data Act, and cybersecurity laws, to consumer and environmental rules, are creating uncertainty, inconsistent enforcement, and operational friction for organisations of all sizes. The Council can make a real difference by: Expanding the EU’s simplification drive beyond narrow Omnibus packages and embedding it across all digital, competition, and sustainability files. Synchronising implementation timelines and avoiding contradictory obligations that particularly strain SMEs and public administrations. Driving enforcement coherence, ensuring regulators in all Member States apply rules consistently so businesses no longer need to navigate 27 interpretations of the same law. For citizens, this translates into safer, more reliable digital services. For businesses, it means the ability to invest, innovate, and scale in Europe rather than abroad. Safeguard an open, competitive, demand-driven Digital Single Market Communities benefit most when they have access to high-quality digital infrastructure, competitive cloud and AI services, and affordable connectivity. The Council should therefore: Reject discriminatory market-access restrictions, sovereignty quotas, and network fees that raise costs and reduce choice for schools, hospitals, small companies, and local authorities. Keep policymaking grounded in technical evidence, not industrial protectionism. Support the Digital Networks Act and connectivity initiatives in a way that accelerates cloud and AI deployment and preserves net neutrality. An open, competitive Single Market ensures people everywhere, from rural regions to major cities, gain access to the best technologies at the lowest cost. Build trustworthy, safe, and inclusive digital environments The Presidency can strengthen online trust by ensuring that future child-safety, privacy, and cybersecurity workstreams remain risk-based, interoperable, and consistent with existing frameworks like the DSA. Fragmentation or overreach would undermine rather than enhance safety. Ireland should champion: Evidence-based youth protection, empowering young users without forcing intrusive ageverification regimes. Proportionate cybersecurity rules that raise resilience without shutting out international providers essential to public-sector continuity. Implementation clarity on the AI Act, providing guidance that helps small organisations adopt AI responsibly and confidently. In short, the Council can deliver the greatest positive impact by making the EU’s rulebook work in practice, reducing friction, preserving choice, enabling deployment, and ensuring that every community can benefit from fast, safe, innovative digital services.
