response_text: Thank you for your work on bringing the Presidency to Ireland. Can you please help us to protect young people and the planet by using the Presidency to control tobacco? Trinity, with the guidance of the Irish Heart Foundation, ASH Ireland and the EU Smoke Free Partnership has been a Living Lab for Tobacco Free Ireland since 2016 and has achieved a 79% reduction in observed smoking since then. However, social smoking is very high in Trinity, and among young people generally; most people who smoke in Trinity started over the age of 18, i.e. while they were students in the university. We are also a Living Lab for vaping. Discouragingly, observed vaping on campus in Trinity has doubled since 2022 and we have three times the national vaping prevalence. I

organisation: Irish Natura & Hill Farmers Association INHFA
response_text: During Ireland's Presidency, negotiations on the Common Agriculture Policy for the period from 2028 to 2034 will reach a critical stage. In assessing the Commission's CAP regulation and supporting documentation, there is no doubt that we are looking at the most radical reform for over twenty years. Ireland is currently receiving €1.5 billion per annum under both Pillar 1 and Pillar 2. Under the current proposals for the period 2028/2034, this figure could substantially fall to €1.17 billion. Ireland should be campaigning for an increased CAP budget, over and above the current budget, to take account of inflation. This figure is critical as we determine what level of funding is possible, and we must ensure during these negotiations that, as well as protecting Ireland’s agricultural exports, we also protect our farming families, their way of life and their communities.

organisation: Irish Natura & Hill Farmers Association INHFA
response_text: Article 9 of the CAP Regulation specifies specific EU Council Directives that relate to land designations (special areas of conservation –SAC, and special protected areas –SPA). We note that there is allowance here to support farmers who have been impacted through these designations, as they were in previous CAP Plans. Due to the disproportionate burden borne by farmers, farming on high nature value farmland, these farmers need to be properly compensated for the restrictions imposed on their farming practices. In some cases, entire holdings are subjected to restrictions due to Land Designations, GAEC2 or other LIFE projects.

organisation: Irish Natura & Hill Farmers Association INHFA
response_text: Under Article 4(3)(c). Currently, there are two definitions for a farmer, and the view of the INHFA is that there should be a clear definition that encapsulates farmers (part-time and full-time) who are carrying out an agricultural activity. Two definitions of farmers based on their level of production will not serve Ireland well and could have devastating effects on rural communities on our western seaboard. Farmers here who carry out extensive farming methods produce quality food products on our uplands, as well as promote biodiversity and maintain the environmental condition of their land.

organisation: Irish Natura & Hill Farmers Association INHFA
response_text: Ireland's farming community has always had a positive view of the value and benefit of EU Membership. We are a food-producing country, and we must continue to put food security as our priority when farming our upland areas, whilst at the same time delivering for biodiversity and nature. Droughts are becoming more prevalent in Southern Europe, and from a climate point of view, we must promote the importance of farming in our uplands as resilient food production areas not prone to flooding or droughts.

Climate change, biodiversity loss, and environmental degradation are existential threats to Europe and the world. Threats to human health and well-being, to food production and security, and to energy security, are clearly described in the European Environment Agency (EEA) European Climate Risk Assessment (EEA Report 01/2024), and in United Nations Environment Programme (2025); Global Environment Outlook 7: A future we choose – Why investing in Earth now can lead to a trillion-dollar benefit for all. The UNEP report urges us to tackle the interconnected crises of climate change, biodiversity loss and land degradation, and pollution and waste as one. The European Green Deal aims to transform the EU's economy for a sustainable future. EU climate and energy policies should better integrate both climate mitigation and adaptation into the planning and implementation of measures in the energy sector. This will help actors at EU, national, local, community, and at individual level, to meet objectives on energy system decarbonisation and security of supply (European Climate Risk Assessment Report). The development and implementation of policies that increase resilience to climate change need to be an essential part of EU climate and energy actions, including integrated national energy and climate plans (NECPs). The EU Strategic Agenda 2024 to 2029 includes a suite of objectives for making a success of the green transition, providing a stable and predictable framework and a more supportive environment for scaling up Europe’s manufacturing capacity for net-zero technologies and products. Policy coherence will be very important to achieve the 2024 to 2029 objectives, in the context of atmospheric levels of greenhouse gases that are still increasing, accelerating climate change and the associated risks and existential threats reported by UNEP and EEA. There is considerable potential for zero carbon renewable (green) hydrogen (Renewable Fuel of Non-biological Origin RFNBO) to replace fossil and other greenhouse gas emitting fuels, to assist in meeting increasingly onerous 2030, 2040 and 2050 climate action decarbonisation targets. It is submitted that the Irish Presidency of the Council of the European Union should prioritise the implementation of policy actions that accelerate the production, distribution, end uses, and storage of zero carbon renewable (green) hydrogen (RFNBO). Greenhouse gas emissions abatement can be facilitated by the use of both electricity and green hydrogen as zero carbons fuels, in all sectors of the European economy. Green hydrogen production can support and balance renewable electricity generation and energy grid systems, making use of curtailed renewable wind and solar power. Direct non-grid connected green hydrogen electrolysis using renewable wind and solar energy should also be enabled, to facilitate zero carbon fuel production where electricity grid is absent or inadequate. Ireland should promote these measures for immediate implementation throughout the European Union.

The EU Strategic Agenda 2024 to 2029 should be updated to promote and facilitate the use of green hydrogen as a zero emission transport fuel. Green hydrogen refuelling infrastructure is urgently required at scale throughout the EU, to make hydrogen a viable and cost efficient zero carbon fuel for both light and heavy duty vehicles, and to support and provide certainty to hydrogen Fuel Cell Electric Vehicle (FCEV) and hydrogen Internal Combustion Engine (ICE) vehicle developers and manufacturers in the European Union (Global Hydrogen Mobility Alliance). Europe shouldn’t rely on one technology for transport. Combining green hydrogen and battery technologies is faster, cheaper, and more resilient, as well as saving up to €500 billion in infrastructure cost. The current policy focus on Battery Electric Vehicles (BEV) also excludes many fleet and individual vehicle operators from decarbonising their transport, because their range, payload and vehicle availability requirements cannot be met by BEVs. The current policy of restricting end uses of renewable hydrogen places greater demand on electricity production and increases long term hydrogen storage requirement. In many sectors, it may be more efficient and cost effective to use hydrogen directly as a zero carbon fuel. The development and implementation of the Public Procurement Act, scheduled for 2026, should promote and provide access to zero carbon green hydrogen as well as to zero carbon electricity as fuels and energy carriers. The provision of supports to the production, distribution and use of these zero carbon fuels should be facilitated by policy initiatives, and supported by the phase out of fossil fuel subsidies which is scheduled to commence during Ireland’s Presidency of the European Council, transferring funds to zero carbon energy and materials. Making financial flows consistent with a climate neutral and climate resilient future is an objective of the EU submission of an updated Nationally Determined Contribution (NDC) to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) 14929/25, Brussels, 5 November 2025.

Policies and actions promoting the availability of two alternative zero carbon energy sources, green hydrogen and electricity, will assist in providing resilience and adaptation in the context of climate change and the existential risks described by the EEA and UNEP. Storm, heat wave and other disruptions to electricity grids and supply are increasing in frequency. These policy measures can contribute to the development of the EU climate package for the decade ahead. Evaluation of the fertilising products Regulation should consider the risks to cross-compliance and policy coherence of promoting artificial fertiliser production and use as part of a green hydrogen economy. Existing Climate Action Land Use, Land Use Change and Forestry (LULUCF) objectives at risk include: Agriculture sector nitrous oxide emission reduction targets low/no N fertiliser systems targets for organic farming (10% by 2030) resilience and biodiversity measures including use of mixed swards risk of being not consistent with Global Biodiversity Framework or Nature Restoration requirements, and requirements for the protection of soils. With regard to biofuels, it would be useful for the Irish Presidency of the European Council to confirm that biofuels are not zero carbon fuels. Biofuels do emit greenhouse gases when used as fuels, and they do not contribute directly to decarbonisation. Their classification as renewable depends on consideration of potential policy coherence risks. UNEP reporting notes that large-scale deployment of biofuels generates trade-offs related to land, water, and fertilizer demand with implications for food security and biodiversity conservation, which may substantially constrain sustainable expansion of bioenergy cropland with or without carbon capture and storage (IPCC 2023b; Deprez et al. 2024; Braun et al. 2025). Bearing this in mind, and given the adverse climate change related impacts on food production in the EU, particularly in Southern Europe which grows and exports food throughout the EU, policy development should not expect that biofuel production can be expanded either within Europe or globally. While locally biofuels do contribute to the circular economy, biofuels should no longer be seen as a beneficial transition away from fossil fuels, to be followed in the longer term by the decarbonising fuel green hydrogen. Green hydrogen policies must be implemented within the European Union now, as a matter of urgency, and scaled up rapidly during the remaining period of the 2024 to 2029 Strategic Agenda. The development of the climate package for the decade ahead should include significant upward revision of national targets for green hydrogen production and use in decarbonising all sectors of the European economy.

Citizens will note beneficial results if they see actions and infrastructure that will improve their energy security and resilience, in the context of mounting evidence of the adverse impacts of climate change. Implementation of Alternative Fuel Infrastructure Regulations (AFIR) with widespread availability of green hydrogen and electricity re-fuelling (e.g. at 60km intervals) will support citizens in investing in zero carbon transport options. Green Public Procurement of hydrogen FCEVs and ICE vehicles for various public services such as buses and coaches, trains, construction equipment, light commercial and passenger vehicles would provide information and confidence in these new technologies to citizens. Hydrogen FCEVs may be particularly well-suited to ambulances, fire tenders, police fleet, taxis, public transport, first responders and other emergency services, because with quick re-fuelling, these vehicles can support multiple work shifts /24 hour availability, thus reducing vehicle purchase costs. There are various non-transport uses for renewable hydrogen that would be relevant to citizens, including: dispatchable generation, combined heat and power plant, hydrogen cookers, boilers, water heaters, and hydrogen gas space heaters. Hydrogen ready equipment and appliances are available and could be included for consideration in GPP under the following category- Energy Related Products, Heating Equipment, Indoor and Outdoor Lighting. The potential role of renewable hydrogen fuelled back-up power generation could be considered in the context of providing climate change resilience to the provision of public services, as well as to communities and individual citizens.

References https://www.eea.europa.eu/en/analysis/publications/european-climate-risk-assessment European Environment Agency (EEA) European Climate Risk Assessment (EEA Report 01/2024) 2 https://www.unep.org/resources/global-environment-outlook-7 United Nations Environment Programme (2025); Global Environment Outlook 7: A future we choose – Why investing in Earth now can lead to a trillion-dollar benefit for all. Nairobi. 3 https://climate-adapt.eea.europa.eu/en/eu-adaptation-policy/key-eu-actions/european-climate-risk-assessment/eucra-viewer-major-risks 4 Global Hydrogen Mobility Alliance (globalh2mobilityalliance.org)

For its 2026 EU Presidency, Ireland should prioritise sustainable energy, rural resilience, and communitycentred governance. In particular, the rapid scaling of biomethane under REPowerEU highlights the urgent need for independent impact assessments, strict environmental safeguards, and oversight of public subsidies to prevent unsustainable industrial-scale biogas projects. Ireland can lead by embedding legally binding rules on feedstock use, digestate management, and spatial planning, ensuring local communities have a real voice in decision-making rather than bearing disproportionate social and environmental costs. By championing a model that balances climate, biodiversity, and rural development goals, Ireland can set a European benchmark for fair, sustainable energy transitions. Prioritising transparency, equitable benefitsharing, and preventative regulation will help avoid repeating mistakes seen elsewhere in Europe, reinforcing trust in decarbonisation policies. These thematic priorities will position Ireland as a leader in creating energy strategies that are both ambitious and socially responsible.

The European Commission’s REPowerEU action plan has set biomethane production on a course of massive upscale as part of efforts to increase EU energy independence, fixing a target of 35 billion cubic meters (bcm) per year by 2030 – up from 4,1 bcm in 2023. However, until this day, no Impact Assessment was carried out on the target. As biomethane production continues to grow rapidly both in Ireland and Europe (with a currently 21% year-over-year growth), so do concerns about its associated environmental and social risks as well as the irresponsible use of taxpayers money. While biogas production from sludge or collecting the gas that is produced in landfills is appropriate, there are particular concerns about the effects of large-scale biogas production on the use of limited agricultural land, the continuation of polluting industrial animal production, harm to local communities, and the effects of methane leaking from biogas facilities. Further concerns arise when looking closer at promoted use cases for biomethane such as heating or transport which are often inefficient, expensive, and lock Europe into existing fossil infrastructure. The Irish Presidency should therefore prioritize conducting an independent, interdisciplinary impact assessment to evaluate the feasibility and sustainability of this target, ensuring it aligns with climate, biodiversity, and rural community goals. Emphasis must be placed on implementing strict economic, environmental, and social safeguards for biogas and biomethane production. With reference to the Commission’s 2026 Work Programme as well as the wider EU Strategic Agenda that highlights the need to secure Europe’s energy independence, we therefore encourage the Irish Presidency to: Advocate for an independent impact assessment of the EU’s 35 bcm biomethane target, as a prerequisite to develop further any expansion of biomethane production as part of relevant policy files in 2026, such as the Circular Economy Act, Bioeconomy Strategy, Livestock Strategy, Energy Union Governance Upgrade, and Common Agricultural Policy. This includes prioritizing truly sustainable feedstocks, efficient use cases, and avoiding lock-ins of fossil infrastructure. Include the voices of local communities in the debate. In order to expand biomethane production rapidly, the 2025 REPowerEU roadmap foresees a “tripartite contract to better address the diverging needs in different areas of the EU and include national and local stakeholders”. However, a focus has been set on facilitating dialogue between the EU Commission, EU Member States’ governments as well as industrial stakeholders; and no commitment has been made to give a role to local communities themselves that are affected by such projects. In line with its “peoplecentred” approach, the Presidency should therefore intensify its efforts to give the Irish people and local communities across Europe a greater say in the development of fair and sustainable biomethane strategies. Scrutinise public subsidy schemes for unsustainable biomethane production. This is critical to prevent perverse incentives that undermine the EU’s climate, food security, and energy independence goals. Current subsidies often favour industrial-scale biogas projects reliant on unsustainable feedstocks - such as manure from factory farming or energy crops competing with food production - which lock in polluting practices as well as animal welfare violations, and divert resources from truly circular solutions. Without strict oversight, these subsidies risk distorting markets, inflating demand for unsustainable livestock farming, and sidelining local, communityled projects that deliver genuine environmental and social benefits.

Ireland’s presidency provides a unique opportunity to develop and promote a gold standard indigenous biogas industry that is sized and scaled to meet community needs. Learning from EU countries with an established biogas industry, Ireland can avoid the pitfalls of social acceptance that are consistently documented as barriers to bioenergy projects across the EU (Mancini & Raggi, 2022). Current regulatory gaps and weak planning assessments underestimate the cumulative impacts on rural infrastructure. Public health and safety questions about hazardous gas storage, particular emissions and emergency service access are heightened when regulatory oversight is perceived as reactive rather than preventative. Research has highlighted that digestate management and changes in feedstock mixes are critical risk vectors that demand much stronger regulation than is currently applied (Piadeh et. al, 2024). Ireland, through its presidency, can set the standard by developing industry-specific planning regulations that include community engagement at its core. The National Biomethane Strategy points directly to a highly industrialised model aimed at rapid development across rural Ireland. Within this model, revenue accrues to outside multi-national agriinvestors while costs are borne by host communities in terms of road damage, odour, environmental degradation, and reduced property values. Communities demand transparent environmental impact assessments, accessible monitoring data and enforceable operating limits. The development of industryspecific planning regulations aligned with benefit-sharing mechanisms has the potential to provide a blueprint for use across the EU, while maintaining community engagement and the highest environmental standards. Meaningful community engagement, spatial planning that respects local carrying capacity, strict feedstock limits, alongside legally binding digestate management plans, are safeguards that would increase local acceptance. Rapid roll-out risks polarising rural communities, undermining trust in decarbonisation policy, and producing environmental and social harms that outweigh local benefits. Ireland has an opportunity through its EU presidency to either lead and develop new industry standards or to repeat mistakes already impacting the rural communities and the environment across Europe.

Ireland’s Presidency of the Council in 2026 offers an opportunity to shape a forward-looking, community-centred European agenda. FORUM Connemara recommends that Ireland’s high-level themes reflect Ireland’s strengths as a rural, coastal and community-driven nation, and address the long-term social, economic, and environmental challenges facing the EU. We propose the following three thematic priorities: 1. Thriving Rural and Coastal Communities in a Balanced Europe As an island nation with a strong rural identity, Ireland is well positioned to champion an EU vision that places rural and coastal communities at the centre of policymaking. This theme would prioritise territorial cohesion, local development, and the implementation of the EU Long-Term Vision for Rural Areas. It would highlight the role of community-led local development (CLLD), social enterprise, and digital infrastructure in ensuring that rural citizens enjoy equitable access to opportunities. A Presidency under this theme would promote inclusive policies that reduce regional disparities, strengthen rural economies, support island and coastal communities, and ensure that no area of Europe is left behind. 2. A Just and Community-Led Climate Transition Ireland can lead by advocating for a climate transition that is socially fair, locally grounded, and economically inclusive. This theme would address the practical realities faced by rural communities as Europe moves toward decarbonisation, biodiversity restoration, and climate adaptation. It would place emphasis on nature-based solutions, sustainable agriculture, community energy projects, and climate resilience for remote regions. Central to this priority is the principle that communities must be partners in environmental transformation, with clear supports, funding, and guidance that enable them to adapt while maintaining sustainable livelihoods. 3. Social Inclusion, Skills and Opportunities for All Communities Building an inclusive Europe requires policies that support vulnerable groups, enhance skills, and ensure access to essential services. Ireland could use its Presidency to prioritise lifelong learning, digital inclusion, youth engagement, labour market activation, and the development of social enterprises that strengthen local economies. A focus on inclusion would also help address challenges linked to demographic change, migration, and persistent disadvantage in both urban and rural areas. By elevating social inclusion as a core EU priority, Ireland would reaffirm the principle that sustainable economic growth must be accompanied by strong, resilient communities. These three high-level themes—rural and coastal thriving, a just climate transition, and social inclusion and skills—are mutually reinforcing and reflect Ireland’s values, strengths, and national priorities. Together they provide a forward-looking, people-centred vision of Europe that supports balanced regional development, empowers communities, and equips citizens and local areas to meet the challenges and opportunities of the decade ahead.

FORUM Connemara welcomes the opportunity to contribute to the Government’s consultation on Ireland’s approach to the 2026 EU Presidency. As a community development organisation working across a geographically peripheral, rural, and Gaeltacht region, we believe Ireland is uniquely positioned to champion policy areas that strengthen territorial cohesion, social inclusion, and sustainable rural futures across the European Union. 1. Rural Development, Territorial Cohesion & the Future of Community-Led Local Development (CLLD) Ireland’s Presidency should support a renewed EU-wide emphasis on rural and remote communities through the implementation of the Long-Term Vision for Rural Areas and the evolution of CLLD post-2027. The Presidency could seek to advance legislative proposals that enhance multi-funded CLLD approaches, increase local decision-making powers, and reduce administrative burdens that currently inhibit community organisations from delivering programmes effectively. In line with the Multi-Finaical Framework (MFF) Ireland should prioritise a more flexible, outcomes-based regulatory framework in the next CAP and Cohesion Policy periods, ensuring that rural development tools genuinely reflect local contexts and enable innovation. 2. Climate Adaptation, Biodiversity & Just Transition for Rural Areas The Presidency should emphasise policy mechanisms that help rural regions adapt to climate change in ways that are socially and economically equitable. FORUM Connemara encourages a focus on scaling nature-based solutions, community-led climate adaptation projects, and support for low-carbon local enterprises. Legislative progress is needed in implementing the EU Nature Restoration Law, particularly in providing clear guidance, dedicated funding, and community engagement structures that ensure rural stakeholders are partners—not bystanders—in environmental change. Ireland can also lead on defining what a Just Transition means for small and peripheral communities, beyond the current sector-focused approach. 3. Social Inclusion, Skills & Community Empowerment The Irish Presidency should work to strengthen EU frameworks supporting social inclusion, adult and lifelong learning, youth engagement, service for people with disabilities and services that address persistent disadvantage. Legislative priorities may include enhancing ESF+ measures for upskilling people distant from the labour market, expanding access to digital and community services, and promoting models of social enterprise that generate local employment. Ireland could also champion an EU-level commitment to supporting community infrastructure in rural and island regions, improving equal access to services and opportunities. 4. Blue Economy, Islands & Coastal Communities As an island nation with extensive coastal and fishing communities, Ireland can use its Presidency to highlight the needs of the EU’s maritime periphery. Renewed emphasis is needed on sustainable fisheries, marine biodiversity, and diversification opportunities for coastal economies. Ireland should promote legislative proposals that ensure rural and island communities share in the long-term value created by the blue economy. The 2026 Presidency offers Ireland a strategic opportunity to shape an EU that is more inclusive, balanced, community-led, and sustainable. FORUM Connemara encourages a Presidency programme that puts rural communities, social cohesion, and local empowerment at the centre of Europe’s future policy direction.

FORUM Connemara believes that the Irish Presidency can deliver the most meaningful positive impact by championing policies and approaches that place communities—especially those in rural, coastal, peripheral, and Gaeltacht regions—at the heart of EU decision-making. Ireland has deep experience in balancing economic, social, cultural, and environmental priorities in rural regions, and this experience can help shift EU policy towards more equitable, resilient, and community-driven outcomes. 1. Embed Community-Led Local Development (CLLD) as a Core Mechanism Across EU Policies Ireland’s success with LEADER and place-based community development offers a model for the wider EU. By elevating CLLD within the Council’s agenda, the Presidency can demonstrate how empowering local partnerships leads to stronger economic resilience, better social inclusion outcomes, and more effective rural and regional development. To maximise impact, the Presidency could work to advance proposals that simplify multi-funded approaches, reduce administrative burden, and formalise local decision-making structures within future EU frameworks. This would ensure that EU programmes reach the communities they are designed to support, improving both efficiency and outcomes. 2. Promote Rural and Coastal Innovation and Equal Access to Opportunities Across the EU, rural and coastal areas face demographic decline, limited services, and infrastructure gaps. The Irish Presidency can drive progress by encouraging targeted investment in digital connectivity, local enterprise supports, transport solutions, and community infrastructure. Ireland can model how remote and coastal regions—like Connemara—can become hubs of innovation in the rural economy, blue economy, sustainable tourism, bio circular economy, nature-based solutions, and creative industries when supported appropriately. Championing these approaches at Council level can help ensure that businesses and communities in every region of Europe have opportunities to thrive. 3. Advance a Just, People-Centred Climate and Biodiversity Transition Communities across Europe are experiencing climate impacts, yet rural and coastal regions often bear the greatest pressures. Drawing on Ireland’s community and environmental experience, the Presidency can drive policies that enable local participation in climate action. This includes promoting community energy initiatives, supporting climate adaptation plans at local level, and ensuring that the Nature Restoration Law and other climate measures are implemented through partnership with communities rather than imposed on them. A just transition that supports livelihoods and empowers local action will strengthen social acceptance and long-term sustainability. 4. Strengthen Social Inclusion, Skills and Lifelong Learning FORUM Connemara’s work in supporting people distant from the labour market, providing training, and empowering marginalised groups positions Ireland to prioritise inclusive growth. The Presidency can champion Council outcomes that increase competitiveness, expand access to skills programmes, support social enterprises, enhance digital literacy, and invest in services for vulnerable groups. Such initiatives create long-term benefits for both people and businesses across the EU. The Irish Presidency can make its most substantial contribution by shaping an EU that listens to its communities, invests in its regions, and supports people to participate fully in economic, environmental, and social progress. With its experience in community-led development, rural innovation, and social inclusion, Ireland is well placed to lead the Council toward policies that deliver real, practical benefits for communities across Europe.

To communicate the values and benefits of EU membership effectively, Ireland must connect EU actions directly to the daily lives, aspirations, and challenges of its people. FORUM Connemara’s long-standing experience working with rural communities, coastal regions, Gaeltacht areas and people experiencing disadvantage demonstrates that engagement is most successful when it is local, accessible, and rooted in lived experience. 1. Bring the EU to Communities through Local Engagement and Storytelling Citizens understand Europe best when they see how EU funding and policies improve their own communities. Ireland should prioritise area-based communication that highlights tangible benefits: community centres built through EU programmes, LEADER initiatives supporting local enterprises, training funded under ESF+, and environmental projects enhancing local landscapes. FORUM Connemara’s model—working directly with communities on the ground—shows that stories from local people resonate far more than abstract explanations of EU structures. The Presidency could therefore promote more extensively the “EU in My Region” initiative, amplifying locally-led examples from rural, island, coastal, and Gaeltacht regions. 2. Use Community-Led Organisations as EU Bridges Community organisations like FORUM Connemara are trusted, embedded, and experienced in translating policy into practical outcomes. They are well placed to act as intermediaries between citizens and EU institutions. Ireland should involve local development companies as active partners in Presidency communications. This would not only broaden participation but also reinforce a sense of ownership among communities who see their work reflected in national and EU priorities. 3. Promote the EU as a Supporter of Rural, Coastal and Peripheral Regions Citizens in rural or geographically remote areas often feel distant from European institutions. Yet many EU values—solidarity, inclusion, sustainability, and cohesion—speak directly to their needs. Ireland can use its Presidency to showcase EU policies that support rural economies, fisheries communities, environmental restoration, broadband investment, and skills development. FORUM Connemara’s work exemplifies how EU programmes can sustain local jobs, enhance social inclusion, and support environmental stewardship. Highlighting these successes will strengthen public understanding of how EU membership benefits places sometimes overlooked. 4. Create Opportunities for Direct Citizen Participation in the Presidency Citizens develop a sense of ownership when they feel they are part of shaping decisions. Ireland should create accessible, community-based dialogue events, youth panels, and thematic workshops linked to the Presidency’s themes—especially in rural and Gaeltacht regions. FORUM Connemara would be happy to assist in the organisation of these events in the Connemara area. Digital platforms could complement this engagement, but in-person, locally facilitated forums are essential for reaching those less connected to national debates. 5. Communicate EU Values Through Practical Outcomes, Not Just Messages Core EU values—cooperation, equality, cultural diversity, environmental sustainability—should be communicated by showing their impact. FORUM Connemara’s work in inclusion, training, community-led development and environmental protection provides concrete examples of these values in action at local level. To build ownership and understanding, Ireland should focus on community-level engagement, trusted local messengers, and real-world examples of EU support. Through approaches grounded in experience and partnership, the 2026 Presidency can bring Europe closer to its citizens and ensure that they see themselves reflected in Ireland’s leadership at EU level.

FORUM Connemara wishes to highlight the Dúlra Project as an example of how a CLLD project can deliver meaningful ecological, social and economic benefits for rural communities. Operating across multiple SACs in Connemara and South Mayo and funded through EU-linked mechanisms via Wild Atlantic Nature LIFE IP and National Parks and Wildlife Service Dúlra shows how community-based conservation can advance Ireland’s environmental obligations while strengthening rural livelihoods and local engagement. Community Engagement, Education and Knowledge Exchange A central strength of Dúlra is its emphasis on community involvement and awareness-building. The project works closely with local residents, landowners, schools and community groups to foster understanding and support for environmental restoration and EU biodiversity goals. Key engagement results include: Community events and workshops, including school programmes, local forums, site demonstrations, knowledge-exchange sessions and contributions to national conferences. Collaboration with a broad network of partners including NPWS, LAWPRO, Inland Fisheries Ireland, County Councils, academic institutions and local organisations. Clear communication of restoration benefits, including biodiversity protection, improved water quality, enhanced climate resilience and strengthened community stewardship of natural landscapes. This engagement-led approach has built strong local ownership, helping communities see first-hand how EU-supported actions lead to real improvements in their environment. Environmental Restoration and Invasive Species Control Dúlra has implemented one of the most extensive rhododendron control and habitat restoration programmes in the region. Major achievements include: Over 616 hectares of new rhododendron clearance in Connemara and South Mayo. More than 100 hectares of retreatment carried out to secure long-term ecological recovery. Restoration actions delivered in priority sites under the Habitats Directive. Peatland restoration on a local farm to raise water tables, improve habitat condition and support climate and biodiversity objectives. Development of Restoration Action Plans (RAPs) to guide ongoing peatland recovery and carbon sequestration efforts. Notably, FORUM Connemara has a peatland restoration site less than one mile from our head office in Clifden, providing an accessible demonstration location for visiting officials and policymakers to observe restoration work in practice. Community Employment, Training and Skills Development The project has created a strong community-led employment model that integrates rural jobs with environmental goals. Achievements include: A dedicated field team delivering high-quality restoration work across challenging upland terrain. Over 130 participants trained in 2025 through DAFM-supported programmes such as chainsaw skills, tractor safety, manual handling and Working at Heights. Ongoing professional development for supervisors, ecologists and GIS/mapping specialists. Strengthened partnerships with local landowners, commonage groups and community organisations. This model demonstrates how EU-supported restoration can stimulate rural employment, develop skills and build long-term local capacity. A Scalable and Replicable Model Dúlra provides a clear example of how locally delivered restoration, supported by EU mechanisms and strong partnerships, can achieve substantial ecological gains while building community involvement and trust. The approach is cost-effective, scalable and directly aligned with EU biodiversity, climate and rural development priorities.

Reducing the drive to war. Lead the way through diplomacy, specifically the Istanbul agreement in relation to Russia-Ukraine, and forcing Israel through EU sanctions and hardline diplomacy to withdraw to 1967 borders. Those supplying armaments are complicit and shredded the thin veil of decency the EU had up until recently. Please recognise that EU partners are not acting in our interests, or even the interests of their own countries, resource wars have become the norm, and this cycle needs to be broken.

Legislation that will make (warm) home ownership affordable again. There is a retrofit scheme in Italy which targets older homes, usually occupied by older inhabitants. The retrofit scheme is 100 per cent state funded, and there is an infrastructure in place so that new entrants to the industry are constant to keep up with the demand for retrofit contractors. The affordability crisis in Ireland and Europe is knitted into every aspect of our daily lives. Ordinary citizens cannot get sufficient mortgages, the estate agents list too few homes for sale, of course most don’t have the cash or borrowing capacity for a retrofit. People are renting and owning cold homes not by choice, and the consumption of gas is therefore higher than it needs to be. There needs to be a total moratorium on the mass purchase of homes by investors. EU wide. If the EU keeps failing like this, future generations will inherit poverty stricken elders. The state should be the only mass investor until the situation is regularized.

Consider the fact that people, businesses and communities across the EU need to reside on the planet, breathe clean air, drink clean water and eat safe food. Nobody needs a dramatic-sized wardrobe. Tackle an environmental issue created three decades ago by your predecessors. Treat it in a way that doesn’t put the onus on addicted consumers. Fast fashion and the accompanying constant growth models, including the illusion of green growth in other sectors is killing us. Textile recycling bins for fast fashion are a method of freely disposal of waste which is then put on ships and dumped on foreign beaches. If clothes are to be cheap, then our consumerist society must endure the consequences of dealing with the waste on our shores, by incineration and dealing with the health consequences we bring on ourselves.

Listen to the People. The European Union was originally established as a Peace Project after the devastation of Europe in the Second World War. Ireland is in a unique position to lead the European Union back to this wonderful vision and heritage. We believe that many of the current European Leaders are out of touch with their people and that the citizens of the European Union (in particular, the younger citizens) have become disillusioned by the policies of their governments in relation to militarism, international law and justice, and the protection of the natural environment – their planet. The EU must live up to its peace-project identity and aims by listening to the people, talking peace, not war; bringing an end to militarization, practising and modelling good international relations and statecraft and promoting diplomacy. Movement away from the militarization of the European Union will release resources back into social and environmental funds for the welfare of the citizens and people of the union. A move away from militarization with its vast expense will also release funds for the protection of the best of our patrimony – our land, water and air, and will enable the people of Europe to develop ways of protecting our continent from climate change and global warming.
Citizens of the EU should not have to compete with data centres for basic infrastructural needs. (Water and Electricity)

The Irish Presidency should focus on strengthening health resilience and prevention, as it is a cross-cutting enabler of the EU’s Strategic Agenda 2024-2029 and has been neglected in recent presidencies. The Irish Presidency has the opportunity to lay a foundation for its successors by making prevention, screening and data-driven policymaking central themes. Without healthy societies, the EU cannot achieve its other aims of boosting competitiveness, resilience and democratic legitimacy. With the upcoming negotiations on the Multiannual Financial Framework, Ireland could champion a forward-looking EU budget that recognises health as a foundation of economic resilience, paving the way for achieving the aims of the strategic agenda by 2029. Prevention: Disease prevention is the most cost-effective way to strengthen resilience and preparedness, as called for in the EU Strategic Agenda. Many drivers of ill health stem from factors outside the healthcare system, including environmental exposure, working and living conditions, and socioeconomic inequalities, meaning disease prevention needs to be addressed holistically across policy areas. Actions should be taken in the areas of tobacco control (high risk factor for kidney and bladder cancer), gender neutral HPV vaccination, which will also result in lower incidence for penile cancer, and environmental carcinogens (eg, PFAS and other chemicals). The Irish Presidency should champion action on these root causes rather than downstream symptoms, helping to build long-term resilience and protect social and economic stability from future health shocks. This approach would strengthen population resilience, reduce long-term system costs, and support citizens’ wellbeing, participation and productivity. Cancer Screening: Equitable, quality-assured screening programs are essential to detect high-burden diseases earlier and improve survival rates. If developed and implemented properly, early detection programs not only save lives, but also reduces healthcare expenditure, contributing directly to Europe’s competitiveness. Screening initiatives also embody the Strategic Agenda’s call for fairness and inclusion, ensuring that all citizens benefit from advances in health policy regardless of geography or income. EU project screening pilots have provided a blueprint for organising more impactful and cost-effective screening (e.g. PRAISE-U, which includes a pilot in Ireland). Turning lessons learned into widespread implementation across the EU is now essential. The European Commission Initiative on Prostate Cancer is anticipated to be launched in early 2026 which will start work on guidelines and quality assurance. Big data: Harnessing health data and real-world evidence will transform EU health outcomes in the near future, as long as it’s considered a political priority. This requires coordination on collection, interoperability, and secure use of health data. Data-driven insights also support innovation in healthcare, digital health solutions, and AI-enabled decision-making, while providing a foundation for evidence-based policy that improves outcomes, strengthens health systems, and creates opportunities for research and responsible business development across Europe.

EHDS (Supporting a data-driven research ecosystem): The successful implementation of the European Health Data Space needs political momentum to create a framework that ensures data holders have clear incentives (not only obligations) to share high-quality health data securely and efficiently across borders, to support Europe’s leadership in biotech and digital health. The incentives need to be tangible for citizens and healthcare professionals, public institutions and non-profit research organisations as well as for commercial users. The result will be a huge positive impact on health research, making use of data we have (only 3% is currently used) to change diagnostic and treatment guidelines by analysing real world data, where the need for randomized clinical trial is reduced, screening programs, and preventive measures for a healthier and more productive societies. Non- Communicable Diseases (NCDs): NCDs remain the leading cause of morbidity and mortality in Europe, undermining resilience and competitiveness. The Irish Presidency should focus on broadening the EU’s NCD agenda beyond traditional priorities such as cardiovascular disease and diabetes, integrating stigmatised conditions that significantly affect quality of life, social participation, and productivity. We recommend, next to the Genito-urinary cancers, the addition of Continence Health into the NCD agenda - between 55 to 60 million Europeans suffer from Urinary Incontinence, and it currently poses a burden of almost €70 billion. Ireland has recently introduced an effective model to address the burden of continence health across Ireland through the introduction of community based continence health nurses. Sharing knowledge with other EU Member States on continence health will be highly valuable. Ireland can help reduce the societal and economic burden of NCDs, support healthier ageing, and strengthen overall resilience of health systems across Europe, through promoting prevention, early detection, and equitable access to care within Council conclusions and health promotion strategies. Gender-based research: The EAU calls for a greater understanding of the intersectionality between gender and health. We strongly encourage Ireland to work on initiatives to understand the influence of gender on social, economic, environmental, political and cultural determinants of health, influencing exposure to risk factors and interactions with health systems. Evidence based frameworks and strategies that work for men, women and LGBTQI+ communities rely on this approach, which requires specific and explicit actions and commitments. For example, research indicates that men experience a disproportionately higher impact from cancer compared to women, both in terms of how often it occurs and the likelihood of death. This disparity arises not only from biological differences but also from issues linked to cancer prevention. The Urinary Incontinence burden in women is four times higher than in men and that the prevalence of UI is generally experienced at a younger age in women than men, largely due to pregnancy and the postpartum period. It is for this reason that the EAU is endorsing the Irish based European Institute on Women’s Health and the strategic approach to women’s health across the EU. We also lead the European Cancer Organisation’s Inequalities Network, and work on men and cancer. Given that Ireland is one of the first European countries to have its own National Men’s Health Action Plan, it should use its leadership and expertise to encourage other Member States to doing the same.
