organisation: European Federation of Psychologists’ Associations AISBL (EFPA)
response_text: The European Federation of Psychologists’ Associations AISBL (EFPA), in collaboration with our colleagues in the Presidential trio countries of Ireland, Lithuania and Greece, wish to express our support for the mental health priorities of the upcoming Irish Presidency of the Council of the European Union. We appreciate the leadership role that Ireland has played both nationally (i.e. Sharing the Vision – A Mental Health Policy for Everyone) and internationally (i.e. Ireland’s recent support of the UN General Assembly Political Declaration of the fourth High-Level Meeting on Noncommunicable Diseases (NCDs) and Mental Health). We hold a commitment to improving mental health outcomes by promoting evidence-based interventions, early identification, comprehensive care systems and by recognising the impact of digitalisation on mental health. We acknowledge the importance of health promotion and disease prevention in mitigating mental health challenges.

organisation: European Federation of Psychologists’ Associations AISBL (EFPA)
response_text: We are hopeful that the topic of mental health will feature highly on the Irish EU Presidency agenda, with related high-level meetings and policy development work. We also highlight the opportunity for the showcasing of existing and up and coming initiatives, with the inclusion of the voices of mental health professionals as well as those with lived experience. We are available to guide, support and to help implementation of the Presidency’s mental health agenda.

organisation: European Federation of Psychologists’ Associations AISBL (EFPA)
response_text: As engaged stakeholders in the current EU-level activities and discussions surrounding mental health, we look forward to contributing to the Presidency’s agenda and fostering a resilient, healthy Europe. EFPA’s Full Member, the Psychological Society of Ireland, will host on the second semester of 2026 the EFPA Semester of Psychology, providing an ideal platform to integrate the Presidency’s activities with the participation of national psychology associations, researchers, and practitioners. In this context, we would be grateful to be included on the distribution list for consultations or draft Presidency outputs relating to health, youth, digital wellbeing, and workforce issues.

organisation: European Federation of Psychologists’ Associations AISBL (EFPA)
response_text: We would also be pleased to co-host an expert roundtable—potentially outside Dublin on a topic of a common interest, and to involve the Ministry of Health in giving a keynote at the EFPA Council meeting, where representatives from all European national associations of psychology will convene in the Autumn of 2026. Please do not hesitate to contact us to consider how we might support the opportunities for mental health as part of the opportunity that Ireland’s Presidency of the Council of the EU presents.

organisation: European Federation of Psychologists’ Associations AISBL (EFPA)
response_text: EFPA has identified seven priority 'pillars of action' in Mental Health and six priorities as principles to underpin societal engagement with advancing technology as particularly important to guide future EU-level action: EFPA MH pillars of action: A focus on mental health and its social determinants should feature in all EU policies. It should address the foundations of 1—Commitment to mental health in all policies development in childhood and across the lifespan. It should be properly funded, resourced and measured. Mental health practitioners´ training should 6—Mental health training standards and regulation be based on a recognised standard, properly funded, and regulated in the EU. Citizens should be engaged as partners and 7—Equality of access to mental health including have equal access to appropriate and high- digitalisation quality mental healthcare. Digital and physical contexts should receive equal consideration. EFPA´s priorities as principles to underpin societal engagement with advancing technology: Psychologists and those with lived experience should actively shape 1-Co-Production of and evaluate legislative and regulatory frameworks for technologies Regulation with societal impact or health implications.

Ireland’s Presidency comes at a time when the EU’s competitiveness is more important than ever. By championing the adoption of emerging technology and demonstrating use cases, the EU can develop and capitalise on new opportunities for growth, driven by a dynamic culture of innovation and implementation. In advancing the EU’s competitiveness, the Presidency must focus on the advancement of the simplification agenda, and ensuring the benefits Ireland has realised, as a small, open economy, are mirrored on the European stage. It is essential that efforts to advance Europe’s competitiveness are underpinned by priorities including simplification, particularly with regard to the digital rule book, investment in skills and talent, an open approach to digital sovereignty that resists protectionism and support for innovation through balanced and proportionate regulation. Measures to prevent the unintended consequences of currently unregulated third-party litigation funding would be beneficial. Such measures would support competitiveness, providing safeguards and certainty for business, consumers and court systems, reinforcing the rule of law and enhancing the EU’s attractiveness for investment. Ireland should progress work to achieve advancement of an EU Single Market that enables businesses to grow at scale, fosters innovation and strengthens open markets, furthering the EU’s status as a premier global location to operate in. With changing EU population trends, and the growing demand for skills, underscored by the development of emerging technologies, Ireland, through the EU, can lead progress in life-long learning, a focus on a skills- based economy, and greater talent mobility. These measures can develop a talent pool that is flexible, mobile and has the capacity to harness the potential of disruptive technologies. During Ireland’s Presidency, substantial focus on AI and digital is expected and Ireland’s planned AI Summit in October 2026 represents a significant opportunity to showcase global leadership, and to shape the EU’s future view on AI. This provides a platform for Ireland to bring together cross-sectoral actors and take an allof-society approach to showcase the beneficial and transformative impact that AI adoption, utilisation and innovation can have in all facets of the Irish, and European, economies. It can serve as a means for Ireland to lead conversations on AI frameworks, sandboxes, and regulatory coordination in a manner which builds upon Ireland’s position as a digital regulatory hub within the EU. In supporting R&D, for instance, in life sciences, it is paramount that there is a strong emphasis on enhancing the EU’s capabilities, and scientific output, alongside the Union’s industrial foundations. Significant economic opportunity exists with policy decisions that improve the RD&I ecosystem, enhance the EU’s attractiveness as a location for leading clinical trials, and protect and support the EU as a home for IP. This can support citizens by ensuring the development of, and access to, innovative medicines and new technologies to support patient care and long-term health outcomes. The Draghi Report highlighted the need for a more strategic and innovation-driven Europe. Ireland can advocate for competitive state aid reform, strategic investment in future industries, a stronger Horizon successor programme, and a pro-innovation policy environment.

Life sciences It is key that files including the Biotech Act and the Critical Medicines Act are focused on supporting innovation whilst addressing regulatory burdens and complexities. A desired outcome of key files is a simplified regulatory landscape for clinical trials to make the EU a more competitive location for research. The Presidency should work to provide regulatory clarity for business, and advance measures which facilitate better patient outcomes and economically benefit the EU. Potential changes to EU pharmaceutical legislation and global IP frameworks pose risks to competitiveness. It is critical that Ireland continues to use its voice at EU level to defend pharmaceutical IP, Regulatory Data Protection, and market exclusivity frameworks from being weakened. In supporting preventative healthcare, measures to address communications challenges around vaccine safety to support vaccine uptake, and investment in healthcare infrastructure and preventable health would be beneficial for European society and the wider EU economy. Digital Since publication of the Draghi Report, just 1 in 10 of the recommendations have been implemented. On digital matters, just 5 of the 47 recommendations have been delivered. Focus should be on the implementation of existing digital regulation to address compliance and administrative burdens, rather than pursuing new regulations. Regarding EU AI Act implementation, a pause in enforcement could be beneficial considering the complexity of provisions on general purpose AI models. Advancing investment in, and delivery of, vital digital infrastructure will also be key. Ireland should lead efforts in identifying technology domains where Europe can best grow AI industrial strength, in partnership with the global AI ecosystem, leveraging existing strengths in software and applications. The Digital Networks Act will represent a key legislative file for Europe’s digital future aiming to support connectivity and investment while providing regulatory certainty. Ireland and the EU should avoid overregulation and instead focus on demand-side, consumer-focused public policies to drive adoption of advanced connectivity. Adapting the telecoms framework for efficient spectrum allocation and prioritising the provision of pan-EU services that directly benefit consumers, will support a competitive telecoms market, AI ambitions, digital public services, and emerging digital technologies. Other important issues include recognition of the importance of digital advertising, finding the correct balance on copyright law between digital innovation and rights-holders, continuing efforts and engagement with stakeholders regarding reducing online fraud and scamming, and ensuring a balanced approach on the regulation of batteries. The Presidency should advance policy development on openness as a driver of competitiveness and innovation, including through open digital sovereignty as the basis for cloud and AI policy under the Cloud and AI Development Act, preserving access and partnership opportunities for European industry with global technology providers. Competitiveness Key in supporting the EU as a place to do business is protecting the tax sovereignty of Member States. Measures providing safeguards in relation to third-party litigation funding would be beneficial. By acting on oversight measures and transparency, the Presidency can support a responsible approach to third-party litigation funding regulation at EU level, for instance, through a Directive focused on minimum harmonisation. In relation to the food supply chain, a fair-trading environment must be promoted for all actors under the Unfair Trading Practices Directive. It will be important that coercive commercial practices are addressed. It should be evaluated as to whether more tools are needed to regulate territorial supply constraints, with consideration given to potential impacts on the FMCG sector. Implementing changes in public sector purchases technology represents an opportunity to modernise how the Public Procurement Act impacts on technological adoption. By working with European businesses and trusted global partners, to focus on ensuring the best value-for-money, rather than the best price, greater efficiencies can be driven in the public sector, resulting in greater, more effective digitalised services delivery. Cybersecurity The Presidency should consider measures regarding reviewing the Cybersecurity Act. The EU should employ a risk-based approach, providing for the highest standards in security, while allowing trusted partners continue to contribute to economic development. Avoiding protectionist measures will enhance the EU’s competitiveness for investment and innovation.

In line with the European Commission’s goals to ensure the regulatory regime is fit-for-purpose, to reduce the administrative burden and to simplify legislation, it is important that Ireland examines its own transposition of EU directives. Ireland should ensure that the transposition of obligations under EU directives is completed in a manner which is consistent with other Member States and does not lead to the introduction of additional requirements, increasing administrative and compliance costs or duplicating requirements for business. In supporting business, it would be beneficial to ensure that economic impact assessments are required for new legislative packages, with a view to ensuring investment and growth is not hindered or adversely impacted. Such an approach would support people in accessing new technologies and innovations that are available in other markets, whilst also enhancing the EU’s reputation as a location in which to innovate. Furthermore, such action would work to address the compliance burdens faced by businesses, which can be detrimental in terms of growth, given the resourcing requirements created by increased compliance and administration needs. Action to address fragmentation amongst Member States with regard to issues which impact legal certainty, cooperation across borders, and which could adversely impact the confidence of investors will be key to supporting businesses across the EU. As the Draghi Report recommended, pursuing approaches, for instance sectoral agreements, to support RD&I and the growth of key sectors within the EU would be beneficial. This would also be beneficial for Ireland given the significant presence of world-leading companies in sectors including life sciences, digital, advanced manufacturing, and financial services. Further, it is key that investment in talent and skills is to the fore in supporting people, businesses and communities across the EU. As we look to future business growth, AmCham members have identified their greatest skills gaps as being in the areas of digital and data, machine learning and AI, and engineering. Ensuring the development of these key skills, to support business growth into the future, will be essential in supporting the EU in attracting future waves of investment in new and innovative products, technologies and services. Addressing barriers to EU funding supports will also be integral in supporting business, and making sure the EU is best placed to grasp the opportunities of the future. For instance, with regard to the EU Horizon Funding framework, persistent barriers exist. This is particularly the case in terms of Cluster 3 (Civil Security for Society) and Cluster 4 (Digital, Security and Space). Such barriers include eligibility limits (Article 22.5 of the Horizon Europe regulation), guarantee mechanics, administrative overheads, unclear IP/public-private rules, awareness limits in industry, domestic process gaps at government agency level, and onerous and unnecessary application procedures. These factors hold back broader participation in the RD&I landscape by business, academia and research. Addressing these factors would further unlock the cascading benefits of thriving industry clusters and support what is already a highly skilled talent base.

Developing a sense of ownership and shared effort requires continued, meaningful engagement that creates shared purpose and direction. Building on this consultation the development of clear strategies and a roadmap for growth, competitiveness and productivity can provide for a common goal in which citizens and businesses can share with Governments. Championing skills and talent, as well as life-long learning opportunities within the EU can further strengthen the EU’s opportunity offering at home and abroad. This will result in greater talent attraction and retention while also facilitating future investment in the EU. Actions that build further skills mobility and opportunity can demonstrate that the EU recognises the innovation, ingenuity and value that citizens bring to the economy. Balancing growth and competitiveness, while also providing for the highest standards in protection and safety, is key to building confidence through communication. It is therefore important that changes pursued under an ambitious simplification programme are clearly communicated to citizens and demonstrate the shared benefits of such measures.

Ireland faces a timely opportunity to shape the future of Europe’s health, digital, and internal market agendas. For the European Association of E-Pharmacies (EAEP), Ireland’s Presidency of the Council of the EU should focus on three interlinked high-level thematic priorities: a true Single Market for Digital Health and Medicines, the resilience and security of pharmaceutical supply chains, and a patient-centred, sustainable health policy framework. Digital health transformation will remain a core EU priority in 2026, with the European Health Data Space (EHDS) entering critical implementation phases, as well as the role out of the European Digital Identity Wallet (EUDIW). Ireland is well positioned to champion the operationalisation of cross-border digital services, including e-prescriptions, telepharmacy, and secure health data exchange. For e-pharmacies, harmonised rules for digital identification, cross-border dispensing and e-prescriptions are essential to unlock innovation while protecting patients. Ireland’s Presidency should prioritise practical guidelines for market implementation, interoperability standards and cybersecurity in health services. By doing so, the EU can move from fragmented national systems towards a truly integrated digital health market that improves access, affordability, and continuity of care for citizens across borders. Additionally, recent global crises have exposed Europe’s strong dependence on third countries. Ireland should make pharmaceutical security a cornerstone of its Presidency, advancing the implementation of the EU Pharmaceutical Strategy and the Critical Medicines Act. Finally, it is important to point out that Europe’s health systems face dual pressures: demographic ageing and fiscal constraints. Ireland should prioritise policies that reinforce primary care, prevention and digital access while maintaining cost efficiency. E-pharmacies already contribute to this goal by improving medicine adherence, facilitating chronic disease management and extending access in underserved areas. Ireland’s 2026 Presidency comes at a pivotal moment for Europe’s health and digital policy landscape. By focusing on digital integration, supply chain resilience, and patient-centred care, Ireland can deliver a strategic and future-proof Presidency. For the e-pharmacy sector, these priorities would not only strengthen the Single Market but also ensure that innovation directly translates into safer, more accessible and more resilient healthcare for all European citizens.

For the EAEP, Ireland’s 2026 Presidency should concentrate on policy areas that can significantly improve healthcare access, reinforce the Single Market, enhance patient safety, and support innovation in digital health. The focus should be on advancing legislation, accelerating implementation, and harmonising rules. A central priority should be the implementation of the European Health Data Space. By 2026, the EHDS will be moving into practical roll-out, making Ireland’s role in driving interoperability, cybersecurity, eprescription and electronic health records uptake particularly important. For e-pharmacies, the EHDS is essential to enable secure (cross-border) patient authentication and continuity of care in and between Member States. Equally relevant is continued progress on the CMA and the broader reform of the Pharmaceutical Legislation. Cross-border healthcare should also be a core focus. While the legal framework already exists, citizens still face fragmented rules, administrative burdens, and low awareness of their rights. An update to the current cross-border healthcare directive should be part of the policy discussions under the Irish Presidency. A further strategic priority is the growing healthcare workforce shortage across Europe, particularly among pharmacists and primary care professionals. Ireland should promote digital and innovative solutions as part of a broader response to workforce sustainability, including telepharmacy, remote pharmaceutical services and the recognition of new professional competencies. Finally, the strengthening of the Single Market should be a core horizontal ambition of the Irish Presidency. Fragmented enforcement and uneven implementation of EU rules continue to undermine both citizen rights and business investment. Ireland should champion stronger Single Market governance, reduced regulatory divergence and faster resolution of cross-border barriers affecting online players.

The work of the Council during Ireland’s Presidency can generate lasting, tangible benefits for people, businesses and communities across the European Union by focusing on delivery, coordination and trust. Many EU initiatives are going to be on their way to being adopted or entering implementation phases, including the EHDS and the CMA. A key opportunity for Ireland’s Presidency is to ensure that these policies move from regulation to real world delivery. This means prioritising secondary legislation, implementation guidance and stakeholder alignment, enabling national administrations, healthcare providers, SMEs and digital businesses to apply EU rules with clarity and harmonisation. Furthermore, Europe’s economic resilience depends heavily on its small and medium-sized enterprises. The Irish Presidency can maximise positive impact by placing competitiveness, regulatory simplicity and innovation support at the heart of the Council’s work. This includes reducing administrative burden, improving access to finance, and enhancing digital infrastructure. Lastly, digital transformation must be inclusive to create real value. The Irish Presidency can ensure that vulnerable groups, rural communities, and ageing populations are not left behind by Europe’s digital and health transitions. Expanding access to digital public services, e-health tools and cross-border healthcare solutions strengthen social cohesion and territorial equality. E-pharmacies already play a key role in improving medicine access for remote and underserved populations and Council positions that support digital connectivity, health literacy, and interoperable e-prescription systems would directly enhance quality of life for millions of EU patients.

To effectively communicate the values and benefits of EU membership to citizens communication must move beyond institutions and policies and clearly demonstrate how the EU improves daily lives. From the perspective of the EAEP, healthcare access, digital innovation and patient safety offer some of the most tangible points to connect EU action with citizens’ experience. The EU’s role in ensuring medicine safety, regulating pharmacies, fighting counterfeit medication and enabling cross-border healthcare must be communicated in simple and relatable terms. Citizens should understand that EU frameworks are what allows for their safe online pharmaceutical services, especially through the EU Common Logo. Ireland’s Presidency should actively showcase success stories in digital health, e-prescriptions, medicine traceability and pharmacy regulation as concrete examples of how EU cooperation directly protects citizens. Ireland’s Presidency of the Council is a unique opportunity to make these benefits visible and concrete. A dedicated public event, developed in partnership with Inish Pharmacy as an Irish member of the EAEP, would demonstrate in practice how EU frameworks protect patients and modernise healthcare. This event could bring together pharmacists, regulators and citizens to explore how EU cooperation enhances safety and access in e-pharmacy services. A stakeholder such as Inish Pharmacy’s involvement would illustrate how a local Irish pharmacy applies EU rules every day to guarantee medicine safety and trusted digital services for patients. A crucial element of communication is ensuring that citizens are fully aware of their rights and able to actively exercise them. One of the strongest examples is the right to cross-border healthcare, which allows EU citizens to access medical treatment, prescriptions and pharmacy services in other Member States. However, despite its potential, awareness of this right remains low among the general public. Ireland’s Presidency should prioritise making EU health rights visible, understandable, and usable. This includes clearer communication on how citizens can benefit from cross-border prescriptions, reimbursements, and access to medicines while travelling abroad. At the same time, regulation must become more harmonised, transparent, and equitable. Fragmentation between national systems and channels creates confusion for patients and healthcare providers, limiting the practical use of rights that already exist.

The NTWF supports the Community and Voluntary Pillar’s vision for a high-level thematic priority based on building a Social Europe. This is consistent with the EU Strategic Agenda’s objective to build a ‘free and democratic Europe’ based on the founding values of the EU, which include ‘respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights, including the rights of persons belonging to minorities.’ Ireland’s presidency should focus on promoting equality, inclusion and social rights for the Traveller and Roma communities and other groups that experience marginalisation across the EU.

The NTWF advocates for gender equality and intersectionality to be core priorities in Ireland’s work programme for the Presidency of the Council. We strongly recommend that the Government works to promote the rights of Traveller and Roma women across the EU through the Council’s legislative work programme in 2026. The Irish Presidency can progress the development and implementation of key equality strategies including the next EU Gender Equality Strategy, the next EU Anti-Racism Strategy, the next EU LGBTIQ Equality Strategy, updated Strategy for the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, the Anti-Poverty Strategy and the Strengthening of the Child Guarantee, which are included in the European Commission’s work programme for 2026. The NTWF advocates for the interests and perspectives of Traveller women to be represented in these strategies, and ongoing engagement with national and local Traveller organisations will be key to achieving this objective. Furthermore, the Irish Presidency should champion the need for robust, disaggregated equality data collection across all Member States, including the collection of voluntary, self-identified ethnicity data. This harmonisation is essential to accurately measure the progress of the EU Roma Strategic Framework for Equality, Inclusion and Participation 2020-2030 and future Anti-Racism Strategies. Without reliable, comparable data, effective policy monitoring and targeted resource allocation to address systemic inequalities impacting Traveller and Roma women across the EU will remain impossible. We also call on the Government to agree the adoption of the European Commission’s proposal in relation to extending the list of EU crimes to hate speech and hate crime (COM (2021)777 final 9.12.2021). The EU Strategic Agenda aims to ‘strengthen social dialogue, uphold equal opportunities and reduce inequalities’. The Irish Presidency can demonstrate leadership in this area by promoting the rights of minority groups, particularly the Traveller and Roma communities, as part of its commitment to building a Social Europe. The Government can re-affirm its commitment to implementing the strategic objectives of the EU Roma Strategic Framework and encourage EU-wide action to address anti-Traveller racism and discrimination. The effective implementation of the National Traveller and Roma Inclusion Strategy II 2024-2028 (NTRIS II) will be key to advancing this work and ensuring that it has a meaningful impact on policy outcomes in the Traveller community. Furthermore, it is important that key issues impacting Traveller women are raised in the work of the Employment, Social Policy, Health and Consumer Affairs Council configuration (EPSCO), particularly in policy areas including access to housing, education, healthcare and employment, which are discussed in further detail in Question 5.

The Irish Presidency can make the most substantial positive impact for the Traveller and Roma communities across the EU by actively engaging with Traveller representative organisations, prioritising the implementation of the EU Roma Strategic Framework and NTRIS II, and mainstreaming the perspectives of Traveller and Roma women into the policymaking process. To ensure meaningful and substantial impact, the Irish Presidency should establish a mechanism, such as a High-Level Dialogue on Traveller and Roma Inclusion, that guarantees the active participation of Traveller and Roma organisations, particularly women’s groups, in the Council's EPSCO and JHA discussions. This would ensure policies are grounded in lived experience. The Council should also seek to support the active participation of civil society organisations (CSOs) to the greatest extent possible in events, conferences and meetings held as part of the Irish Presidency. The NTWF would welcome a particular focus on including Traveller and Roma representative organisations in high-level policy discussions and events related to women’s rights and gender equality.

The Irish Government should lead inclusive outreach to wider society on Ireland’s role as part of the Presidency and how individual citizens can be involved. This could include public awareness-raising campaigns, education programmes and townhall meetings. Alongside inclusion in mainstream initiatives, the Department should organise targeted outreach sessions in collaboration with Traveller and Roma organisations. Emphasising a shared vision of a Social Europe, which includes the protection of minority rights, would increase citizen engagement with the EU and create a sense of ownership over Ireland’s Presidency of the Council of the EU.

As a national organisation, the NTWF advocates for the inclusion of Traveller women’s voices and perspectives at all levels of political decision-making. In the context of Council policymaking, the NTWF advocates for increased awareness and commitment at an EU level to addressing the key issues impacting Traveller women, which include: Accommodation: Housing is likely to be a prominent theme during the Irish Presidency, and it is important that these discussions extend to the disproportionate level of housing deprivation and homelessness impacting Travellers. The Irish Government has faced criticism from international human rights bodies including the Council of Europe on the consistent under-delivery of Traveller accommodation programmes and the lack of progress in delivering new builds of Traveller specific accommodation including provision for nomadism. For Traveller women, the housing crisis is compounded by their overrepresentation as primary carers in homelessness, resulting in a disproportionate length of time spent in inadequate, unsafe, and culturally inappropriate emergency accommodation. Healthcare: The mortality rate for Traveller women is three times that of the rate for women in the general population, with Traveller women having a life span that is on average 11.5 years less than that of settled women. Traveller women are more likely to suffer from chronic health conditions and disabilities. EPSCO should work to progress access to affordable and culturally appropriate healthcare for ethnic minorities. Education: Traveller women and girls experience lower rates of school completion, which can be linked to systemic racism and discrimination in the education system, as 46 percent of Irish Travellers have reported experiencing discrimination at school. In 2022/2023, 74 percent of Traveller children and 64.7 percent of Roma children entered junior infant classes in primary school from the ECCE programme or other preschool setting, compared to 92.3 percent of the general population. Only 27 percent of young Travellers in Ireland have completed at least upper-secondary education, compared to 97 percent of the general Irish population. Furthermore, barriers to higher education remain with only 4.7 percent of Travellers completing third-level education. Employment: Census 2022 showed that only 18 percent of Traveller women were employed, compared to 51 percent of women in the total population. Racism and discrimination are significant barriers to accessing employment, with 84 percent of Travellers reporting experiencing discrimination when looking for work. 96 percent of Travellers in Ireland are at risk of poverty, compared to 12 percent of the general population. Addressing these barriers to accessing employment is in line with the EU Strategic Agenda which seeks to widen participation in the labour market and increase rates of youth employment. Political Representation: Advancing the participation of Traveller and Roma communities in political life is a key objective of the EU Roma Strategic Framework. Although Travellers have been elected to local councils in the past, there are currently no Traveller political representatives at a local level. This lack of representation is also reflected at national level, where Senator Eileen Flynn is currently the first and only Traveller woman to serve as a national representative.

organisation: The Irish Federation of University Teachers IFUT
geography: Our membership work within the Republic of Ireland and our trade union has worldwide affiliations.
response_text: Ireland’s Presidency in 2026 represents an opportunity to champion a European Union that is socially resilient, knowledge-driven, and capable of delivering sustainable prosperity for all its citizens. IFUT recommends that Ireland prioritise three mutually reinforcing themes that reflect both national strengths and pressing EU-wide challenges. 1. Strengthening Europe’s Knowledge and Skills Ecosystem A thriving EU depends on robust education, research, and innovation systems. Ireland should focus on policies that reinforce higher education as a public good, ensuring sustainable investment in universities . Central to this priority must be a clear commitment to quality employment within higher education, recognising that excellence in teaching, learning, and research is inseparable from fair, secure, and properly resourced academic and professional roles. Ending the widespread precarious employment that undermines both staff well-being and institutional capacity should be championed as an EU objective. 2. Delivering a Socially Just and Inclusive Europe Ireland should position social justice at the core of its Presidency agenda by supporting EU initiatives that enhance workers’ rights, promote collective bargaining, and ensure decent working conditions across all sectors. Higher education—one of Europe’s foundational public sectors—should be used as a case study demonstrating the need for fair working conditions as a prerequisite for social inclusion and economic resilience. Policies addressing the cost of living, access to education, and barriers faced by marginalised communities should be foregrounded. 3. Building a Sustainable, Future-Ready Europe A future-oriented EU must prioritise climate action, digital transformation, and long-term economic resilience. Ireland can lead by promoting coordinated, evidence-based policy frameworks that harness the expertise produced within Europe’s higher education and research institutions. Ensuring that these policies are underpinned by structured engagement with sectoral stakeholders, including trade unions, academic staff, students, and civil society organisations, will be essential. By adopting these priorities, Ireland can articulate a Presidency programme that is forward-looking, socially conscious, and firmly rooted in Europe’s shared commitment to fairness, knowledge, and sustainable development. A Presidency that champions high-quality employment, combats precarious work—including in higher education—and places meaningful sectoral engagement at its centre will contribute to a stronger and more cohesive European Union.

organisation: The Irish Federation of University Teachers IFUT
geography: Our membership work within the Republic of Ireland and our trade union has worldwide affiliations.
response_text: Ireland’s 2026 Presidency should prioritise policy areas and legislative proposals that reinforce the EU’s social, educational, and economic resilience. Ireland should champion EU initiatives that enhance structured engagement with trade unions, education sector representatives, and civil society across all relevant policy domains. Ireland should advocate for ensuring that in cases where public and/or EU funding is being provided that decent work conditions must be applied. This includes ensuring that EU-funded projects cannot rely on insecure or underpaid academic labour and that funding mechanisms reward institutions that uphold fair employment practices. Focus should be put on ensuring that agreements reached at Council level are applied in each of the membership countries without dilution and that there is a responsibility on the ministries that sign up to these agreements to ensure that the terms of the agreements are applied domestically. This can only be done where there is sectoral engagement involving trade unions.

sector:
Digital Asset Service Provider / Digital 
Finance
response_text: Ireland’s 2026 EU Presidency represents a great opportunity for both Ireland and the whole European Union to advance competitiveness, deepen the Single Market, and respond to rapid technological and geopolitical change. Kraken believes Ireland should focus on three overarching themes that reflect the Union’s collective needs while offering a forward-looking vision for Europe’s economic and social future. A Competitive and Innovative Europe: The Presidency should advance measures that enhance the EU’s global position and strengthen the Single Market, modernise financial and digital infrastructure, and support capital markets reform under the Savings and Investments Union (SIU). Europe’s markets remain fragmented, and EU citizens invest too little in productive assets. Digital tools such as tokenisation can increase efficiency, transparency, and market access. Emphasising innovation as a practical driver of resilience will help build consensus across Member States. Building Trust and Resilience in the Digital Economy: With MiCA and other digital frameworks entering implementation, Ireland can promote coherent, predictable rollout and reinforce consumer protection and market stability for all European citizens. A trustworthy regulatory environment is essential for businesses and citizens to adopt new technologies confidently. Empowering People With Skills and Access: Aligned with the EU Strategic Agenda 2024-2029, the Presidency should prioritise digital skills, financial literacy, and workforce readiness. Citizens need the tools to understand and benefit from the digital transition, including new ways to participate in capital markets under the SIU. Together, these themes offer a balanced and future-oriented foundation for the Presidency. They support EU unity and competitiveness, promote trust and stability in digital markets, and ensure that citizens have the skills and confidence to participate fully in Europe’s economic future.

sector:
Digital Asset Service Provider / Digital 
Finance
response_text: Ireland’s 2026 Presidency will coincide with significant EU-level work in digital transformation, financial regulation, capital markets, and competitiveness. Kraken believes the Presidency can deliver progress in a balanced manner while supporting initiatives that strengthen the Single Market and prepare the Union for long-term economic resilience. Digital finance and tokenisation. Tokenisation can increase transparency, reduce settlement times, and expand market access. It is both a digital and financial innovation that can broaden retail participation and help redirect Europe’s significant household savings into productive investment, advancing SIU goals. The Presidency should encourage evidence-based discussion on whether current frameworks allow adequate experimentation and whether targeted adjustments could support safe innovation. Capital markets deepening. Strengthening access to private capital and modernising post-trade infrastructure remain essential for Europe’s competitiveness. During its Presidency, Ireland will also advance key elements of the Savings and Investments Union (SIU) legislative agenda, including proposals to strengthen retail investor frameworks and simplify cross-border investment. These initiatives are vital to making it easier for EU companies to raise capital and for citizens to access long-term investment products. Digital tools and infrastructure like the blockchain and improved data systems can help integrate markets and close Europe’s investment gap. Skills, literacy, and inclusion. A people-centred strategy requires improving digital and financial skills to help citizens navigate new services confidently. Stronger literacy supports inclusion and contributes to deeper, more liquid capital markets.

sector:
Digital Asset Service Provider / Digital 
Finance
response_text: During Ireland’s Presidency, the Council’s work has the opportunity to make a substantial positive impact by ensuring that EU policies deliver real benefits to citizens, businesses, and communities across the Union. A central objective should be to support initiatives that strengthen economic opportunity and deepen trust in the digital and financial transitions.Digitalisation should be framed not as a goal in itself, but as a means to modernise financial services, improve access, and help Europeans invest more in their own future. For citizens, digital and financial literacy is crucial. As new frameworks take effect, people must understand how to use services safely and effectively. Better literacy supports informed decisions, broader market participation, and stronger long-term financial resilience. Public-private cooperation can help deliver practical, accessible education. For businesses, predictability and regulatory coherence matter most. Consistent implementation reduces fragmentation and enables firms to operate and raise capital more efficiently. A modernised, digital Single Market aligns directly with SIU objectives. For communities, innovation should reinforce inclusion and regional development. Technologies in payments, identity, and capital markets can expand access to services and reduce disparities. Ireland can help ensure that innovation supports cohesion as well as competitiveness. Focusing on skills, trust, competitiveness, and inclusion will allow the Presidency to strengthen Europe’s long-term resilience.

sector:
Digital Asset Service Provider / Digital 
Finance
response_text: Communicating the value of EU membership requires making the work of the Union visible, relatable, and meaningful to citizens. Ireland’s Presidency should focus on clarity, accessibility, and participation to help people understand how EU decisions affect their daily lives. Clear, accessible language is crucial. Many policy areas such as digital regulation or financial frameworks can be made more understandable by framing them around fairness, opportunity, and transparency. Ireland can highlight how the Presidency is advancing policies that protect people, expand their choices, and strengthen economic prospects including giving citizens easier ways to save and invest as part of the EU’s SIU. Ireland should also emphasise on practical everyday stories and examples that show how EU initiatives improve everyday life for workers, students, businesses, and communities. These stories can come from across the Union and can be shared through digital channels, traditional media, community events, and educational partnerships. Participation is key to building ownership. Open dialogues, youth forums, and community outreach help people feel connected to EU policymaking. Connecting EU policies to improve financial well-being, access to investment opportunities, and economic mobility will resonate strongly with citizens.

organisation: The European Institute for Animal Law & Policy
geography: We operate on an EU-wide level
response_text: Sustainability of EU Agriculture During the previous legislative term, sustainability was a central priority and guiding principle for legislative initiatives, rooted in the Green Deal and its cornerstone, the Farm to Fork Strategy, with the overarching aim of placing the EU on a path toward long-term sustainability. In the current term, however, policy attention has shifted predominantly toward enhancing competitiveness. In practice, this shift has resulted in the effective abandonment of the Farm to Fork Strategy and its replacement with the Vision for Agriculture, which does not build upon the previous strategic direction. Consequently, we have entered a period marked by a strong emphasis on the “simplification” of legislation, including in areas affecting environmental protection. Each year, Europe experiences record-breaking temperatures, with countries increasingly affected by extreme heatwaves. Europe is now the fastest-warming continent in the world. The agricultural sector is among the first to be impacted by this crisis, yet little has been done to transform EU agriculture in a manner that ensures its long-term sustainability and resilience in the face of climate change. At the same time, agricultural exceptionalism, which continues to exempt the sector from more environmentally sustainable practices, not only persists but intensifies under ongoing deregulation. We urge the Irish Presidency to recognize the urgent need to transform our food system, equipping it to withstand the inevitable challenges of the future, and to support measures that offer long-term solutions rather than short-term fixes that risk incurring greater costs and consequences over time.

organisation: The European Institute for Animal Law & Policy
geography: We operate on an EU-wide level
response_text: Animal Transport The European Commission adopted a proposal to revise Regulation 1/2005 on the protection of animals during transport in December 2023. Prior to this initiative, the ANIT Committee of the European Parliament - established to investigate alleged infringements in the implementation of EU legislation on animal transport - found that the Regulation fails to provide animals with effective, tangible protection. Insufficient enforcement continues to contribute to significant animal suffering, particularly during longdistance journeys both within the EU and beyond its borders. Despite the proposal having been published two years ago, negotiations in both the European Parliament and the Council of the European Union are progressing at an unacceptably slow pace. This does not meet the expectations of EU citizens, who have consistently called for stronger protections for animals during transport. For this reason, it is essential that the AGRIFISH Council, under the Irish Presidency, completes the negotiations should the outgoing Cypriot Presidency be unable to finalize them. We emphasize the importance of grounding legislation in evidence-based recommendations rather than assumptions or inflated worst-case assessments that overlook the benefits of higher animal welfare. EU animal welfare legislation is now outdated, and we urge policymakers to align the revised transport rules with the latest scientific evidence, including the European Food Safety Authority’s 2022 opinions. While economic and social considerations must be considered, certain practices cause unavoidable, intensive suffering to animals. Their continued authorization is incompatible with Article 13 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union and contrary to citizen expectations for strengthened live animal transport standards. The revised transport rules must also be enforceable and legally sound, recognizing the EU’s enforcement limitations. In practice, this means that the revised Transport Regulation should set a clear path for the transition from the export of live animals toward trade in meat, carcasses, and genetic material, which offers economic, ethical, and environmental benefits. Finally, we urge the Irish Presidency to ensure that the adopted legislation is future-proof, providing adequate protection for animals in light of climatic and social challenges over the next years or even decades. We invite you to consult our policy brief on this topic, which outlines key evidence-based priorities for this legislative file, available here.

organisation: The European Institute for Animal Law & Policy
geography: We operate on an EU-wide level
response_text: Circling back to our responses to questions 1 and 2, it is important to emphasize the need for long-term, sustainable, and robust solutions that are evidence-based and deliver enduring positive impacts. Currently, the EU strategic direction tends to prioritize short-term objectives and often resists measures with long-term benefits due to their immediate costs, overlooking the potentially far greater costs of inaction. It is essential that policymaking is guided by the latest scientific evidence and grounded in the principles enshrined in the EU Treaties, including the precautionary principle. Only through responsible, forward-looking legislation can the EU ensure resilient, future-proof policies that serve citizens’ interests, safeguard the environment, and uphold the vision of a sustainable and prosperous Europe.

organisation: The European Institute for Animal Law & Policy
geography: We operate on an EU-wide level
response_text: If the Irish Presidency is to lead the Council in a manner that responds to citizens’ expectations and priorities, it must once again reiterate the need to focus on animal welfare, particularly in relation to the file likely still under negotiation when Ireland assumes the presidency. A wide array of surveys, petitions, European Citizens’ Initiatives (ECIs), and other tools of participatory democracy demonstrate consistent support among EU citizens for strong animal welfare legislation. For example: 91% of EU citizens agree that the welfare of farmed animals (e.g., pigs, cattle, poultry) should be protected in a way that ensures decent living conditions (Eurobarometer, 2023). For Ireland, this figure reaches 96% - the third highest support for strong animal welfare legislation after Luxembourg’s 98% and Sweden’s and Finland’s 97%; Nearly 1.4 million EU citizens signed the “End the Cage Age” ECI, and 89% of EU citizens believe that animals should not be kept in individual cages (Eurobarometer, 2023); 83% of citizens agree that travel time for the transport of live animals within or from the EU should be limited (Eurobarometer, 2023); 94% of respondents to the 2022 public consultation on the revision of animal welfare legislation support prohibiting the transport of vulnerable animals, such as pregnant and unweaned animals, as well as animal exports. In light of this overwhelming public support, the Irish Presidency should ensure that animal welfare remains a priority, reinforcing EU leadership in responsible, humane, and future-oriented food and farming policy.

geography: Ecocem is a global leader in high-efficiency use of cementitious materials for the rapid and low-cost decarbonisation of the cement industry. We are headquartered in Dublin, with plants in Ireland, France and the Netherlands and a world-class Research & Innovation Centre in Paris. Our products are already in use on flagship projects such as the Aviva Stadium, Grand Paris metro and HS2 in the UK.
response_text: We fully agree that Ireland holding the Presidency of the Council of the European Union in the second half of 2026 represents a key opportunity for “Ireland to play an important role in shaping the EU’s policy and legislative agenda in a way which responds to the overall interests and needs of the Union and its Member States”. In line with the EU Strategic Agenda 2024-2029, Ireland’s high-level thematic priorities for the 2026 Presidency should focus on supporting a prosperous and competitive Europe, with a particular emphasis on strengthening EU capacity in key net-zero technologies. Boosting capacity in this field will enhance Europe’s competitiveness whilst accelerating industrial decarbonisation. As an open and highly innovative economy, Ireland is well placed to advance this agenda. More specifically, Ireland should make housing and construction a high-level thematic priority. The Draft Council Conclusions of 20th November acknowledge shared challenges across Member States and highlight the need for a coordinated approach. While housing is primarily a national competence, the EU can play a facilitative role by reducing cross-border bottlenecks and supporting investment frameworks. Ireland could leverage the Presidency to steer this agenda and make sustainable construction and affordable housing a key European priority.

geography: Ecocem is a global leader in high-efficiency use of cementitious materials for the rapid and low-cost decarbonisation of the cement industry. We are headquartered in Dublin, with plants in Ireland, France and the Netherlands and a world-class Research & Innovation Centre in Paris. Our products are already in use on flagship projects such as the Aviva Stadium, Grand Paris metro and HS2 in the UK.
response_text: We propose that the Irish Presidency prioritises three key policy areas central to Europe’s competitiveness, climate objectives and social agenda: (1) creating demand for low-carbon products, advancing EU action on sustainable construction and affordable housing, and strengthening carbon pricing. First, the Presidency should drive progress on delivering on the soon to be published Industrial Accelerator Act (potentially in trilogues in the second half of 2026), the Public Procurement Act (Q2 2026), and the Circular Economy Act (Q3 2026). These files are essential for creating demand for low-carbon products, including cement, and establishing a market for recycled materials. The Irish Presidency should aim for ambitious non-price procurement criteria that accelerate EU cleantech manufacturing capacity. Ireland has led the way in introducing such criteria with its implementation of a clinker substitution mandate, requiring a 30% clinker substitution for all publicly procured concrete. Second, on housing and construction, the Presidency should build on the upcoming European Strategy for Housing Construction and the European Affordable Housing Plan (both expected to be published in December 2025), as follow-up (legislative) initiatives will be crucial to address Europe’s housing crisis. The Draft Council Conclusions of 20th November highlighted the need to foster innovation in sustainable construction, including by promoting low-carbon solutions and developing harmonised standards under the new Construction Product Regulation. These areas are opportunities for the Irish Presidency to advance affordable housing initiatives and drive sustainable and innovative construction practices which would inherently build lead markets for lowcarbon products and support scale-up of cleantech manufacturing in this sector. Finally, targeted revisions of the Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism (Q4 2025, potentially in trilogues in the second half of 2026) and the EU Emissions Trading System (Q3 2026) will be essential to strengthening carbon price signals and incentivising industrial decarbonisation. A strong CBAM is also one of Europe’s strongest tools to drive global decarbonisation. The Irish Presidency should aim to stay the course on the current trajectory of both files, including full CBAM phase-in and the phase-out of EU ETS free allowances by 2034.

geography: Ecocem is a global leader in high-efficiency use of cementitious materials for the rapid and low-cost decarbonisation of the cement industry. We are headquartered in Dublin, with plants in Ireland, France and the Netherlands and a world-class Research & Innovation Centre in Paris. Our products are already in use on flagship projects such as the Aviva Stadium, Grand Paris metro and HS2 in the UK.
response_text: First, by advancing files such the Industrial Accelerator Act, Circular Economy Act, Public Procurement Act and EU ETS and CBAM, the Irish Presidency can help create demand for low-carbon products, including cement, and incentivise industrial decarbonisation. This will strengthen Europe’s competitiveness in cleantech and low-carbon manufacturing, while benefiting EU citizens and communities through new employment opportunities in cleantech sectors and cleaner living environments. In turn, this will also support businesses, as increased demand for low-carbon products will create a domestic market for both upcoming cleantech producers, as well as traditional industry seeking incentives to adopt clean technologies. Greater clarity on future demand will also enhance investor confidence, improve project bankability and help scale innovative European value chains. By making decarbonisation and innovation in housing and construction a key priority, the Presidency can improve access to affordable and more sustainable housing. This will have a direct positive impact on people and communities across Europe (e.g. cost of living benefits).
