We are headquartered in Dublin, with plants in Ireland, France and the Netherlands and a world-class Research & Innovation Centre in Paris. Our products are already in use on flagship projects such as the Aviva Stadium, Grand Paris metro and HS2 in the UK.
response_text: We have no specific feedback we wish to provide in response to this question at this point.

geography: Ecocem is a global leader in high-efficiency use of cementitious materials for the rapid and low-cost decarbonisation of the cement industry. We are headquartered in Dublin, with plants in Ireland, France and the Netherlands and a world-class Research & Innovation Centre in Paris. Our products are already in use on flagship projects such as the Aviva Stadium, Grand Paris metro and HS2 in the UK.
response_text: Decarbonisation of the construction sector, and particular cement, is now recognised as a key challenge that must be urgently tackled at EU level. Reducing clinker use in cement is the most effective way for Europe to decarbonise cement at scale. We plan to organise a joint event on Low Carbon Cement Innovation & Decarbonisation in Dublin during Ireland’s Presidency to bring key players (EU and Irish Government, industry, academia and researchers) together to discuss EU policy frameworks to support innovation, competitiveness and decarbonisation in the buildings and construction sector. We are aiming to have an EU Commissioner and EU Officials in attendance, in addition to Irish Government representatives. We firmly believe that this event would be of value and relevance to all Member States and of the Union as a whole. We propose that this event includes a Site Visit to demonstrate the adoption of low carbon cement and is attended by stakeholders from across the construction ecosystem. We plan to organise this event, with other stakeholders, for September/ October 2026. We ask that you consider inclusion of this event as part of the schedule of events during the Irish Presidency term. This Event would align with key legislative developments centred on buildings and construction innovation and decarbonisation in 2026, of relevance to Ireland’s Presidency of the Council of the EU including the EU Housing Construction Strategy and Affordable Housing Plan, the EU Industrial Accelerator Act and EU Circular Economy Act and EU Public Procurement Act. It will also tie into progress on delivering Ireland’s Action Plan on Housing and Climate Action Plan. We wish to thank the Irish Government for the opportunity to provide feedback on this important Public Consultation and to feed into the development of the Priorities and Policy Programme for Ireland’s Presidency of the Council of the European Union 2026 We look forward to the publication of the summary thematic report from these responses, and Ireland publishing its priorities and policy programme for its 2026 EU Presidency, in due course.

sector: All forms of sexual violence including human trafficking for sexual exploitation.
geography: Our submission reflects the combined perspective of several rape crisis centres and a specialist sexual violence support service, operating in both urban and rural areas across Ireland. While our frontline experience comes from working directly with victim/survivors at local level, the issues we outline require solutions at national and EU level.
response_text: This submission recommends ‘Fostering an Equal Future’ as Ireland’s high-level thematic priority for the 2026 Presidency of the Council. At a time of global uncertainty, prioritising equality and human rights would demonstrate a clear commitment to safeguarding fundamental freedoms, strengthening the rule of law and ensuring that the actions of the EU deliver meaningful benefits for all citizens. Central to this must be a stronger focus on tackling violence against women and girls, including sexual exploitation, both online and offline which continues to undermine the safety, equality and participation in public, political and economic life across the EU. Ireland should prioritise addressing online and technology-facilitated gender-based violence (TFGBV) during the Presidency. This aligns with the EU Strategic Agenda 2024–2029 commitment to protect citizens’ rights, ensure a safe digital environment and uphold rule of law values. Using the Justice and Home Affairs and the Transport, Telecommunications and Energy Council formations, Ireland can progress a coordinated EU-wide response to image-based abuse, deepfakes, cyberstalking, online harassment, bullying and other forms of TFGBV that increasingly transcend borders and cannot be addressed effectively by Member States alone. Ireland’s Presidency also offers a key opportunity to lead renewed action on addressing human trafficking for the purpose of sexual exploitation, at a time when the current EU Anti-Trafficking Strategy is ending. Human trafficking for sexual exploitation remains one of the most severe and persistent forms of violence against women, driven by organised crime, a tolerance for the highly gendered and racialised purchase of ‘sexual services’, inadequate victim/survivor protection and cross-border cooperation. This Presidency could drive political momentum for a more ambitious successor strategy that places victim/survivor centred approaches, prevention and international cooperation at its core. The 2026 Commission work programme includes proposals to address digital safety and regulate emerging technologies. Ireland should ensure these initiatives are victim/survivor-centred and close gaps in legislation, including within the Digital Services Act and the Artificial Intelligence Act, neither of which currently regulate or prohibit the creation of non-consensual AI generated intimate images. Ireland should also advocate for the consistent and rapid removal of non-consensual intimate images as a minimum standard across the EU. A further priority could be advancing shared EU definitions for online abuse to strengthen comparability and cross-border cooperation. At present, differences in terminology make it difficult to measure prevalence, monitor trends or evaluate the impact of EU law and policy. Coupled with this, there is a need for more investment in research examining online sexual harm and the offline impacts including the publication and exchange of findings across Member States. This will support future legislative proposals under the Commission’s work programme and help ensure that new digital, AI and online platform regulations are informed by a gender-sensitive understanding of harm.

sector: All forms of sexual violence including human trafficking for sexual exploitation.
geography: Our submission reflects the combined perspective of several rape crisis centres and a specialist sexual violence support service, operating in both urban and rural areas across Ireland. While our frontline experience comes from working directly with victim/survivors at local level, the issues we outline require solutions at national and EU level.
response_text: Ireland’s 2026 Presidency should focus on advancing EU policy and legislation that strengthens digital safety, addresses TFGBV and tackles human trafficking for sexual exploitation. These issues are deeply connected as online platforms and digital tools are increasingly used to facilitate exploitation. Prioritising these areas align with the Commission’s 2026 work programme, particularly initiatives on digital safety, AI governance, platform accountability and the regulation of emerging technologies. The Presidency should prioritise legislative progress on online platform regulation and digital governance, ensuring strong protections against online and TFGBV. Ireland should aim to secure Council agreement on measures requiring technology companies to prevent and swiftly address online harms and provide clear, reporting mechanisms for users. Progress could be advanced through the JHA and the TTE Council formations, ensuring that digital policies and cybersecurity strategies explicitly reference gender-based violence, strengthen protections for victim/survivors and provide policing authorities with effective digital investigation tools. Ireland should also highlight the impact of increasingly violent and degrading pornography, including depictions of strangulation and choking, which shape harmful sexual behaviours and attitudes, particularly among young people, and the role it plays as a gateway to CSAM (child sexual abuse material). The Presidency could promote stronger regulatory measures prohibiting the creation, publication and distribution of violent pornography and require platforms to proactively detect and remove such content. The Presidency should seek Council conclusions that commit Member States to: Adopting shared definitions of cyber and TFBGV to ensure consistent implementation of EU law and accurate measurement of prevalence; Aligning data categories to improve comparability, allowing the EU to track trends more effectively and strengthen it evidence base; Investing in EU-level research on online harms and their offline impacts and ensure the findings are shared to inform legislative and policy development; Strengthening regulation of AI-generated materials, including CSAM and other non-consensual or fraudulent content, with criminalisation not dependent on the victim evidencing harm; and Recognising the role of pornography in the proliferation of VAW and TFGBV and reviewing necessary measures to prohibit violent content. Alongside online abuse, human trafficking for the purposes of sexual exploitation requires urgent EU-wide action. Organised networks use digital platforms to recruit, advertise and control victims therefore, addressing online abuse and strengthening anti-trafficking measures must go hand-in-hand. Ireland should therefore prioritise: Disrupting criminal networks through enhanced financial investigations, including their use of AI-based tools; Reducing demand by addressing the role of sex buyers and online platforms that advertising ‘sexual services’ involving trafficking victims; Improving identification, protection and long-term support for victims/survivors; and Strengthening cross-border investigations and judicial cooperation across Member States. Ireland’s Presidency should seek to establish a roadmap for the successor to the current EU Anti-Trafficking Strategy, which would also see a strengthening of collaboration with Europol and national law enforcement bodies and support binding minimum standards for victim/survivor protections and access to justice. Together, these priorities would position Ireland in a leadership role, delivering tangible progress on digital safety, gender equality and protection from violence and exploitation.

sector: All forms of sexual violence including human trafficking for sexual exploitation.
geography: Our submission reflects the combined perspective of several rape crisis centres and a specialist sexual violence support service, operating in both urban and rural areas across Ireland. While our frontline experience comes from working directly with victim/survivors at local level, the issues we outline require solutions at national and EU level.
response_text: The Irish Presidency can deliver substantial positive impact for people, businesses and communities across the EU by prioritising digital safety, gender equality and victim/survivor protection in a rapidly evolving technological landscape. The expansion of online platforms and AI-generated content has created new forms of harm that affect individuals, communities and businesses. Ireland is well placed to lead the Council’s work in ensuring that emerging EU legislation and digital policy frameworks provide effective, and protective responses. Firstly, progress on digital safety, including stronger measures to address cyber violence, deepfakes, cyberstalking and other forms of TFGBV, would strengthen citizens' trust in the digital single market, particularly for women and young people who experience these harms at disproportionately high rates. By progressing work on platform accountability, better digital investigative tools and systems that allow Member States to cooperate across borders; the Presidency can help create a safer online environment for people and businesses alike. Ireland could also draw on the work already carried out by the AI Advisory Council which specifically addressed the impact of AI on the economy, workforce and citizens and recommended measures such as the introduction of ‘a personality right’ and creating a specific offence for the creation of deepfakes without consent. Secondly, tackling human trafficking for sexual exploitation would have clear positive effects for people and communities across Europe. Human trafficking networks increasingly operate through online platforms, which means stronger EU-wide rules on prevention, detection and content removal would reduce exploitation and protect those most at risk. Strengthening cross-border investigations, improving victim/survivor identification and ensuring access to specialist support services would help more women and girls exit exploitation safely, rebuild their lives and participate fully in society. Thirdly, if all Member States use the same definitions for online abuse and collect data in the same way, the EU will have more accurate, comparable and reliable data. This is turn will help identify trends, understand what kinds of online abuses are increasing and decide where resources are most needed. It will also benefit businesses and online platforms, as consistent rules and definitions across the EU give clarity on what must be monitored, reported and removed, eliminating the need to navigate different requirements for each Member State. Strengthening research and supporting the publication of EU-wide studies on online harms would further guide future legislative work. By championing these priorities, Ireland’s Presidency can help shape a safer digital environment, strengthen equality across the Union and support communities through improved protection and more resilient systems. With a strong focus on addressing digital violence and human trafficking for sexual exploitation, Ireland can use its Presidency to galvanise EU-wide action at a critical policy juncture. This approach would affirm the EU’s commitment to advancing human dignity, safety, equality and democratic values in a tangible and impactful way for some of the most vulnerable women and girls in Europe.

sector: All forms of sexual violence including human trafficking for sexual exploitation.
geography: Our submission reflects the combined perspective of several rape crisis centres and a specialist sexual violence support service, operating in both urban and rural areas across Ireland. While our frontline experience comes from working directly with victim/survivors at local level, the issues we outline require solutions at national and EU level.
response_text: Ireland’s Presidency offers a significant opportunity to communicate the practical value of EU membership by focusing on issues that directly affect people’s daily lives. Digital safety, gender equality, action against human trafficking for sexual exploitation and the protection of victim/survivors of violence. These are areas where the EU can deliver visible and meaningful improvements that EU citizens can clearly recognise. Digital safety is a growing concern for families, women and girls, businesses and communities across Europe. By prioritising stronger rules for online platforms and better protections and coordinated action on cyber violence, Ireland can demonstrate how the EU helps create a safer, fairer digital environment for everyone. Clear public communication can highlight the benefits of EU-wide standards in holding tech companies accountable, reducing harmful content online and supporting the safer use of AI and emerging technologies. Highlighting EU-funded research on online harms and how it informs safer digital environs can also help the public to see why coordinated EU action matters. Addressing human trafficking for sexual exploitation is also critical. Trafficking affects communities across rural and urban areas, often facilitated through online advertising and cross-border criminal networks. Ireland can use its Presidency to show how EU cooperation disrupts organised crime, improves victim/survivor identification and ensures access to protection and long-term support. Communicating how EU-level action can help to safeguard vulnerable women and girls can illustrate the human value of EU membership. Public engagement should be a key feature of Ireland’s Presidency. This could include providing accessible explanations of EU initiatives, partnering with civil society organisations and frontline services and sharing lived experiences that show how EU action improves people’s lives. Highlighting lived-experiences and real-world outcomes would help make the work to the Presidency feel relevant to people and communities. When people see how decisions result in greater safety, equality and justice it may deepen their understanding of the EU’s impact By focusing on these priorities, Ireland can show how the EU reflects public values, responds to real concerns and protects people’s rights, fostering a stronger sense of ownership and connection among all citizens.

sector: All forms of sexual violence including human trafficking for sexual exploitation.
geography: Our submission reflects the combined perspective of several rape crisis centres and a specialist sexual violence support service, operating in both urban and rural areas across Ireland. While our frontline experience comes from working directly with victim/survivors at local level, the issues we outline require solutions at national and EU level.
response_text: Ireland’s Presidency is an opportunity to showcase the important work we are doing nationally to address sexual violence and exploitation. It will allow Ireland to demonstrate on a European stage the strides we have made, particularly though outlawing the purchase of sex, to bring the goal of equality and fairness closer. This could be further amplified through Ireland’s convening of high-level Member State meetings in particular on technology-facilitated gender-based violence (TFGBV) and human trafficking for the purposes of sexual exploitation. To support the points raised in this submission, we have included links to research that may offer further detail and context: UN Women (2023), Technology-facilitated Violence against Women: Taking stock of evidence and data collection; EIGE (2024), Combating cyber violence against women and girls; Developing an EU Measurement Framework; The European Women’s Lobby (2024), Report on Cyber Violence Against Women; (2025) Strasbourg Call; Institute for Addressing Strangulation (2025), Strangulation During Sex in the UK; Creating a Safer World – the Challenge of Regulating Online Pornography (2025) Bertin Review on Online Pornography.

geography: Operating at EU and global levels, and nationally through the extensive network of National Cardiac Societies within the ESC.
response_text: With the publication of the European Cardiovascular Health Plan expected on 16 December 2025, followed by careful monitoring of its implementation and the roll-out of initiatives and dedicated actions, the ESC believes that cardiovascular health should be a high-level thematic priority during the Irish Presidency. Cardiovascular disease (CVD) remains the leading cause of death in Europe, claiming millions of lives each year and imposing an economic and social burden of approximately €282 billion annually. Ireland now has an opportunity to lead on this issue by building on the Cypriot Council Presidency’s work and ensuring that the EU delivers on its commitment to improve cardiovascular health across all Member States through the ambitious proposals outlined in the Plan. Equally, gender equality in cardiovascular health must be a high-level thematic priority. CVD kills more women than every cancer combined, accounting for 37% of female deaths in Europe. Women experience higher mortality rates and worse outcomes following acute cardiovascular events, yet are less likely to receive timely diagnosis and evidence-based treatments. Women-specific risk factors, including pregnancy, menopause, and hormonal influences are often overlooked, and women remain underrepresented in clinical trials. Given the significant opportunities in this area and the level of awareness it warrants, the ESC believes that the Irish Presidency should prioritise ensuring that a gender dimension in cardiovascular health is featured as a high-level thematic priority during its term. Another critical priority is advancing stronger tobacco and nicotine control measures. Tobacco use, including novel products such as e-cigarettes, heated tobacco, and nicotine pouches, constitutes a global health disaster, causing 7.7 million deaths annually worldwide, with over two million attributable to cardiovascular disease. No nicotine product is safe for the heart: “less harmful” does not mean safe. Alarmingly, e-cigarettes are not replacing smoking but creating a new generation of nicotine users, with up to 40% of European adolescents trying them and 75% of young adults who vape having never smoked before. This trend threatens to reverse decades of progress in tobacco control and will increase the long-term burden of chronic disease. Ireland has already demonstrated leadership in this area, calling for an overhaul of the Tobacco Products Directive to address loopholes in marketing, social media promotion, and youth-targeted advertising. The ESC strongly supports revising the Tobacco Taxation Directive to ensure equal taxation across all nicotine products, indexing duties to inflation, and implementing a unified excise structure based on nicotine content. Higher taxes, combined with plain packaging, flavour bans, and strict online sales restrictions, are proven measures to reduce consumption and protect young people. By prioritising cardiovascular health, comprehensive tobacco and nicotine control and gender equality during its Presidency, Ireland can deliver transformative change, saving lives, reducing health inequalities, and strengthening societal resilience. These actions will place the EU at the forefront of prevention and public health, ensuring that the ambitious goals of the European Cardiovascular Health Plan translate into measurable benefits for all citizens.

geography: Operating at EU and global levels, and nationally through the extensive network of National Cardiac Societies within the ESC.
response_text: Ireland’s upcoming Presidency of the Council in Q2 2026 presents a pivotal opportunity to accelerate progress on key health policy areas and legislative proposals that will shape the future of cardiovascular health across the EU. While continuing the work kick-stared by its predecessor, Cyprus, the Irish Presidency can play a key role by advancing ambitious initiatives and ensuring effective cooperation on the legislative files and initiatives outlined in the European Cardiovascular Health Plan and the Commission’s 2026 Work Programme. Incorporating gender equality in cardiovascular health The Irish Presidency can ensure cardiovascular health is recognised as a priority within the EU’s broader gender equality agenda, through the revamped Gender Equality Strategy and the forthcoming EU Cardiovascular Health Plan. This includes supporting tailored strategies for women, improving awareness, early detection, and research on female-specific risks, and promoting equitable access to care. Targeted data collection and inclusion of CVD in gender policies will help close gaps and advance health equity across the EU. Modernising tobacco and nicotine control Ireland has demonstrated leadership in tobacco regulation and is committed to advancing the revision of the Tobacco Products Directive and Tobacco Taxation Directive. For this reason, the Presidency should prioritise swift action, setting an example for Member States by tackling youth-targeted marketing of vapes and novel nicotine products, harmonising taxation, and strengthening advertising restrictions, especially on social media and online sales. Continuing the work around the Council Recommendation on health checks for cardiovascular diseases Building on the groundwork initially laid by Cyprus, Ireland should champion the adoption and implementation of an EU protocol on health checks for CVDs by the end of 2026. This will enable early detection and screening for high-risk conditions such as hypertension, atrial fibrillation, and inherited cardiomyopathies, helping to harmonise preventive care and reduce inequalities across Member States. Leveraging AI, data, and digital innovation: Ireland should promote the deployment of interoperable digital infrastructures and trustworthy AI solutions as part of the European Health Data Space. Enhanced data collection and cross-border collaboration will drive personalised prevention, early detection, and optimised treatment, reducing disparities and improving outcomes. Initiating discussions on the Revision of Medical Device Regulation (MDR) and proposal for a Biotech Act Timely access to innovative cardiovascular treatments and technologies is crucial. The Irish Presidency should support streamlined regulatory pathways for breakthrough devices and foster research and development in cardiovascular medicine, ensuring that all patients benefit from the latest advances. In pursuing these priorities, the Irish Presidency should strive to achieve measurable improvements in cardiovascular disease prevention, research, treatment, and care. By fostering cooperation on legislative files under the CVH Plan, Ireland can ensure coordinated progress and effective implementation. Maintaining momentum on tobacco and nicotine control, with a focus on youth protection, will help reduce risk factors. Advancing harmonised health checks and screening protocols will standardise early detection and preventive care. Promoting digital transformation and AI integration will enable more personalized and efficient care. Securing meaningful budget allocations for cardiovascular health in the next Multiannual Financial Framework will provide the resources needed for lasting impact across Europe.

geography: Operating at EU and global levels, and nationally through the extensive network of National Cardiac Societies within the ESC.
response_text: The Irish Presidency can make a substantial impact by positioning cardiovascular health into a strategic investment for Europe’s future. A recent WHO report shows that every euro invested in CVD management delivers an eightfold return. This is not just a health statistic: it is also an economic imperative. CVD costs the EU economy €282 billion annually in healthcare expenses, lost productivity, and social care. Without decisive action, this burden will continue to grow, undermining competitiveness and threatening the sustainability of our healthcare systems. Given this visible and pressing challenge, the Council has a clear opportunity to act decisively, for example by embedding cardiovascular health priorities within the EU’s broader economic and competitiveness agenda and emphasising their value as a sound investment. Investing in cardiovascular health is one of the smartest choices Europe can make. It means fewer premature deaths, healthier workforces, and stronger communities. It also means reducing pressure on healthcare systems that are already stretched to their limits. By prioritising prevention, early detection, and better management of CVD, the Council can help EU countries save billions in avoidable costs while improving quality of life for millions of citizens. This is not only about health but also about Europe’s future prosperity. A healthier population drives productivity and innovation, while businesses benefit from reduced absenteeism and a more resilient workforce. Communities thrive when resources are freed from avoidable healthcare costs and reinvested in education, infrastructure, and social programs. In short, tackling CVD is a win-win for people and the economy. The Irish Presidency can lead by ensuring that cardiovascular health is recognised as a strategic investment, not a cost. This means supporting adequate funding for strategies like the European Cardiovascular Health Plan, calling for proper funding for the EU’s biggest killer under the new Multiannual Financial Framework, and encouraging innovation through data-driven solutions and AI. As Europe has the capacity to be a global leader in health technology, starting with its biggest health challenge will send a powerful signal that the EU is serious about both wellbeing and competitiveness. By championing cardiovascular health as a shared investment, the Irish Presidency can unite Member States around policies that deliver measurable benefits, meaning healthier citizens, stronger workforces, and sustainable healthcare systems. This leadership should help ensure Europe’s future prosperity and resilience in the face of a challenge that continues to be posed by CVDs across the Union.

geography: Operating at EU and global levels, and nationally through the extensive network of National Cardiac Societies within the ESC.
response_text: Ireland can best communicate the values and benefits of EU membership by showcasing tangible outcomes that improve citizens’ lives and by highlighting Ireland’s leadership during its Presidency of the Council of the EU. A powerful way to do this is through real examples of EU cooperation delivering measurable benefits and showcasing best practices. For instance, the 2024 approval by EU health ministers and subsequent implementation of the Council Conclusions on improving cardiovascular health in the EU demonstrates how membership enables countries to work together on shared challenges, resulting in stronger health recommendations and better outcomes for citizens. Communicating these successes in clear, relatable terms, such as improved access to care and healthier communities, helps citizens see the EU as a driver of positive change. Ireland’s Presidency offers an opportunity to create a sense of ownership and pride by championing initiatives that matter to people’s everyday lives. Another striking example would be the upcoming European Cardiovascular Health Plan, to be published on 16 December 2025 and expected to set out a roadmap for improving cardiovascular health across Europe. Following’s Cyprus’ initial work, Ireland can lead its rollout and emphasise how EU-level action translates into national benefits, reinforcing the message that EU membership is not abstract but practical and impactful. Collaboration with trusted voices is also essential. The ESC and its network of national cardiac societies, including in this case the Irish Cardiac Society, play a fundamental role in communicating progress achieved at EU and national levels. By partnering with these actors, Ireland can amplify messages about how EU initiatives, such as the Health Cardiovascular Health Plan and Council Conclusions, strengthen cardiovascular health policies and improve citizens’ lives at national level. These partnerships make communication credible and relatable, bridging the gap between policy and people. Finally, the Irish Presidency may consider the deployment of accessible and engaging channels, such as social media storytelling, community events, and collaborations with health professionals and experts in the field. Linking these achievements to broader EU values, including solidarity, cooperation, and shared prosperity, reinforces the message that EU membership delivers concrete benefits and that Ireland’s Presidency is shaping policies that matter.

sector:
Mines Advisory Group (MAG) operates across the humanitarian-development-peace continuum through humanitarian mine action and explosive threat mitigation. Since 1989, we have specialized in releasing land from explosive ordnance (including non-technical and technical survey, clearance, and explosive ordnance disposal), explosive ordnance risk education, victim assistance, and advocacy. Our work extends to weapons and ammunition management and small arms and light weapons control. In 1997, MAG shared the Nobel Peace Prize for the international campaign to ban antipersonnel landmines. In 2025 we received the Hilton Humanitarian Prize in recognition of our ongoing contributions to protecting civilians from explosive threats. Our work addresses the immediate life-threatening risks posed by explosive ordnance while building sustainable national capacity for long-term threat management. MAG currently operates in over 40 countries, and employs around 6,000 staff.
MAG's work has benefited from financial support from Ireland for over 20 years. Irish Aid currently contributes to funding our operations in South Sudan and Myanmar, demonstrating Ireland's longstanding commitment to humanitarian mine action and civilian protection in conflict-affected contexts.
geography:
MAG operates in over 40 countries worldwide, spanning all continents. Our geographical scope includes:
Conflict-affected contexts globally: Acute crises (Gaza, South Sudan, Myanmar), protracted conflicts (Mali, Burkina Faso, Niger, Nigeria, Lebanon, Syria), and legacy contamination environments (Angola, Zimbabwe, Cambodia, Laos, Vietnam, Iraq)
EU neighbourhood regions: Ukraine and Bosnia and Herzegovina and the Middle East, where our work directly impacts stability in regions critical to EU security interests
Global advocacy and standard-setting: Contributing to international mine action standards, IHL implementation mechanisms (including Ireland's leadership in hosting the Dublin Conference on Explosive Weapons in Populated Areas), and disarmament treaty development that shape the global protection architecture
While MAG's operational presence focuses outside EU member states, where internal capacity typically exists to address explosive ordnance threats, our work directly serves EU external action priorities: protecting civilians, supporting post-conflict reconstruction, strengthening partner nation capacity, and upholding international humanitarian norms. Prioritising mine action and weapons management enables families to return home safely, farmers to reclaim agricultural land, and children to attend school without fear. By clearing contaminated land and restoring access to livelihoods, humanitarian mine action directly addresses extreme poverty ensuring conflict-affected communities can rebuild economic foundations essential for sustainable development.

Our submission addresses how Ireland's Presidency can leverage EU influence to advance these shared objectives globally while maintaining principled commitment to human security in an increasingly fragmented world.
response_text: Ireland's 2026 Presidency arrives at a pivotal moment when the international rules-based order is under unprecedented strain. The Commission's 2026 Work Programme, themed "Europe's Independence Moment," rightly emphasizes sovereignty, security, and competitiveness. However, MAG urges Ireland to advance a complementary interpretation: true European independence means looking outward, not turning inward—working with partners globally, supporting those most in need, and demonstrating that sovereignty is strengthened, not diminished, by principled commitment to protecting civilians and upholding international norms. We propose that Ireland embrace "Human Security in a Fragmented World" as an overarching theme, positioning the Presidency as a thoughtful counterpoint to the prevailing drift toward abandoning global norms and commitments. Core Thematic Priorities: 1. Upholding International Humanitarian Law and Disarmament Frameworks This Presidency should champion the enduring relevance of IHL and existing disarmament treaties - the Anti-Personnel Mine Ban Convention, Convention on Cluster Munitions, Arms Trade Treaty, and Geneva Conventions - as essential infrastructure for human protection. These frameworks represent decades of consensus-building and must be reinforced, not sidelined, in an era of great power competition. 2. Human-Centred Security and Protection Traditional state-centric security models have manifestly failed to protect civilians in contemporary conflicts. Ireland should advance a human security paradigm that prioritises civilian protection, addresses the long-term humanitarian consequences of weapons use, and recognises that true security flows from meeting people's basic needs for safety, livelihood, and dignity. 3. Sustainable Peace Beyond Military Solutions Ireland's tradition of active neutrality - characterised by constructive engagement in conflict resolution - offers a valuable alternative to seeking peaceful resolution of disputes. The Presidency should emphasise conflict prevention, civilian crisis management, and the essential role of humanitarian mine action and reconstruction as precursors and enablers of sustainable peace. Sustainable peace requires addressing the weapons ecosystems that perpetuate insecurity: indiscriminate weapons use, poorly managed arsenals, weapons proliferation and diversion all extend armed violence beyond battlefields, while uncontrolled stockpiles pose risks long after ceasefires. Ireland should champion humanitarian mine action, arms control and weapons and ammunition management as peace infrastructure - practical measures preventing rearmament cycles and reducing weapons availability that sustain conflict and armed violence. The Irish Presidency offers a strategic opportunity to ensure adequate MFF funding for these commitments, as Ireland will steer crucial budget discussions determining the EU's capacity to deliver on civilian protection priorities. 4. Equitable Global Solidarity While Ukraine rightly commands attention, the Presidency must resist selective concern. Since 2022, Ukraine has received disproportionate mine action funding - $308 million in 2023 alone, representing 30% of global resources - while contexts like Gaza, Myanmar, South Sudan, and the Sahel face shrinking support. Persistent funding gaps undermine broader stability efforts, increasing pressures linked to forced displacement, insecurity, and weakened resilience - all factors shaping Europe's wider neighbourhood and migration patterns long-term. Ireland can model principled multilateralism by ensuring EU external action serves all conflict-affected populations, including reinvigorating the EU-Africa partnership when other major powers are disengaging, demonstrating Europe remains a reliable partner addressing root causes of instability and displacement.

Our submission addresses how Ireland's Presidency can leverage EU influence to advance these shared objectives globally while maintaining principled commitment to human security in an increasingly fragmented world.
response_text: MAG's recommendations align with the Commission's 2026 Work Programme theme of "Europe's Independence Moment" while offering a distinctive interpretation: true independence requires not just military capability but principled commitment to civilian protection and the rules-based order. Precisely because Europe experiences war, it must voice the priorities and concerns of all communities in conflict, demonstrating that Europe's own challenges heighten rather than diminish its commitment to those caught in conflicts worldwide. Our recommendations focus on the Foreign Affairs Council (FAC) and General Affairs Council (GAC): External Relations and Development Cooperation Advocate for sustained, predictable funding for humanitarian mine action as essential infrastructure for humanitarian assistance, post-conflict reconstruction and development Champion integration of explosive weapons in populated areas (EWIPA) commitments into EU external action, ensuring IHL compliance is systematically assessed with Gaza demonstrating the devastating consequences when these protections fail Ensure EU development and reconstruction funding in conflict-affected contexts includes mandatory explosive hazard assessments and clearance capacity Strengthen conflict sensitivity mainstreaming across EU external action, ensuring robust implementation in fragile contexts where research has identified significant policy-practice gaps While the Commission's 2026 Work Programme emphasizes "Readiness 2030" for defence capabilities, Ireland should ensure the FAC balances military readiness with civilian protection infrastructure. Ireland should push for review of EU HMA Guidelines and ensure the post-2027 Multiannual Financial Framework explicitly recognises mine action as cross-cutting priority within external action - foundational to achieving SDGs in conflict-affected states, not merely security concern. B. Common Foreign and Security Policy (CFSP) Resist narrowing security policy to hardware and military capability, ensuring adequate resources for civilian protection, peacebuilding, and humanitarian assistance Ensure increased military assistance to partner nations is accompanied by robust weapons and ammunition management capacity, including diversion prevention, stockpile management, and unplanned explosion mitigation, embedding responsible through-life management as prerequisite for security cooperation Lead renewed commitment to existing disarmament frameworks, demonstrating adherence to international standards remains possible and strategically advantageous amid great power competition The Commission's 2026 Work Programme centres on building "strong and secure Europe" through Readiness 2030. Ireland's Presidency must demonstrate effective security policy protects civilians from conflict-related harm, including long-term explosive threat effects from state or non-state armed groups. With over 150 non-state armed groups operating worldwide, security approaches must address the full spectrum of civilian threats. By championing disarmament norms when others abandon them, the EU can assert moral leadership and strengthen the rules-based order serving European security interests. C. Neighbourhood and Enlargement Policy Ensure EU support for Ukraine's reconstruction includes comprehensive, long-term mine action programming with sustainable national capacity development, drawing on global expertise and lessons from diverse contexts Support mine action capacity development across neighbourhood regions - Middle East, Western Balkans, Eastern Europe - recognizing each requires tailored approaches informed by sector knowledge Integrate conflict preparedness and explosive threat management into EU civil protection mechanisms for mutual member state support addressing legacy contamination or emerging threats Ireland's Presidency should support integration of mine action and weapons management capacity as criteria for neighbourhood stabilization and accession readiness.

response_text: Ireland's Presidency can translate the Commission's 2026 Work Programme into tangible human security outcomes by ensuring that Council deliberations maintain focus on civilian protection alongside traditional security priorities. The Council's work under Irish leadership can deliver tangible benefits through: For Conflict-Affected Communities Globally: Prioritising mine action and weapons management enables families to return home safely, farmers to reclaim agricultural land, and children to attend school without fear. Ireland can ensure EU external action delivers this foundational security, allowing communities to rebuild livelihoods and access essential services. For the Rules-Based International Order: By championing existing disarmament frameworks and IHL compliance, Ireland reinforces the multilateral system that has served European security interests for decades. In an era when power politics threaten to override law, Ireland can show that small states committed to principle can still shape global norms. A foreign policy that upholds IHL protects European values and interests. Businesses and citizens alike benefits from stability. In post-conflict environments cleared land, and preventing weapons proliferation are required for businesses to function, for citizens to return, for societies to thrive. Ireland can demonstrate that principled engagement, supporting the rules of war, protecting a human-centred and human security approach and investing in civilian protection, creates stable conditions for sustainable economic engagement. Practical Delivery Mechanisms: Direct FAC and GAC working groups to integrate civilian protection assessments into all EU crisis response Establish standing coordination between EU humanitarian aid mechanisms, foreign policy instrument and mine action operators for rapid response to emerging conflicts Create reporting mechanisms on IHL compliance tied to EU security and development assistance Ensure that the Commission's proposed defence procurement simplification measures (part of the 2026 Work Programme's "new era for European Defence and Security") include provisions for explosive ordnance disposal and weapons management capacity as eligible security investments Strengthen Inter-Parliamentary Union linkages to foster coordinated parliamentary responses to post-conflict interventions, ensuring democratic oversight and unified approaches to reconstruction and stabilization efforts

sector:
Mines Advisory Group (MAG) operates across the humanitarian-development-peace continuum through humanitarian mine action and explosive threat mitigation. Since 1989, we have specialized in releasing land from explosive ordnance (including non-technical and technical survey, clearance, and explosive ordnance disposal), explosive ordnance risk education, victim assistance, and advocacy. Our work extends to weapons and ammunition management and small arms and light weapons control. In 1997, MAG shared the Nobel Peace Prize for the international campaign to ban antipersonnel landmines. In 2025 we received the Hilton Humanitarian Prize in recognition of our ongoing contributions to protecting civilians from explosive threats. Our work addresses the immediate life-threatening risks posed by explosive ordnance while building sustainable national capacity for long-term threat management. MAG currently operates in over 40 countries, and employs around 6,000 staff.
MAG's work has benefited from financial support from Ireland for over 20 years. Irish Aid currently contributes to funding our operations in South Sudan and Myanmar, demonstrating Ireland's longstanding commitment to humanitarian mine action and civilian protection in conflict-affected contexts.
geography:
MAG operates in over 40 countries worldwide, spanning all continents. Our geographical scope includes:
Conflict-affected contexts globally: Acute crises (Gaza, South Sudan, Myanmar), protracted conflicts (Mali, Burkina Faso, Niger, Nigeria, Lebanon, Syria), and legacy contamination environments (Angola, Zimbabwe, Cambodia, Laos, Vietnam, Iraq)
EU neighbourhood regions: Ukraine and Bosnia and Herzegovina and the Middle East, where our work directly impacts stability in regions critical to EU security interests
Global advocacy and standard-setting: Contributing to international mine action standards, IHL implementation mechanisms (including Ireland's leadership in hosting the Dublin Conference on Explosive Weapons in Populated Areas), and disarmament treaty development that shape the global protection architecture
While MAG's operational presence focuses outside EU member states, where internal capacity typically exists to address explosive ordnance threats, our work directly serves EU external action priorities: protecting civilians, supporting post-conflict reconstruction, strengthening partner nation capacity, and upholding international humanitarian norms. Prioritising mine action and weapons management enables families to return home safely, farmers to reclaim agricultural land, and children to attend school without fear. By clearing contaminated land and restoring access to livelihoods, humanitarian mine action directly addresses extreme poverty ensuring conflict-affected communities can rebuild economic foundations essential for sustainable development.

Our submission addresses how Ireland's Presidency can leverage EU influence to advance these shared objectives globally while maintaining principled commitment to human security in an increasingly fragmented world.
response_text: Ireland's Presidency offers a unique opportunity to reconnect EU citizens with the Union's founding purpose: preventing conflict and protecting human dignity. Frame the Presidency around Ireland's distinct contribution, a tradition of peacekeeping that embodies rule-governed, human rights-aligned action, demonstrating the EU's values through concrete engagement with those most in need rather than passive observance. Communication Approaches: Human Stories: Share testimonies from mine action operators and survivors of explosive ordnance, make abstract IHL principles tangible through individual experiences that demonstrate the real-world impact of EU foreign policy choices Youth Engagement: Bring young voices from Gaza, Syria, Ukraine, Myanmar (and elsewhere) to dialogue with European youth about the real-world impact of EU foreign policy choices. Leverage existing networks such as the European Youth Forum, World Association of Girl Guides and Girl Scouts (WAGGGS) Advocacy Champions, World Organization of the Scout Movement (WOSM) youth representatives, and the Inter-Parliamentary Union Forum of Young Parliamentarians to create structured engagement opportunities that give young people genuine ownership over policy discussions Values-Based Framing: Position adherence to IHL and support for disarmament frameworks not as constraint but as strategic advantage, the source of EU moral authority and influence Opportunity to create ownership: Commission public consultations on what European citizens expect from EU foreign policy in an era of multiple conflicts. Most polling suggests Europeans want their Union to be a force for peace and humanitarian action, not a military power. Ireland can validate these instincts while demonstrating that principled positions require sustained commitment and resources.

Our submission addresses how Ireland's Presidency can leverage EU influence to advance these shared objectives globally while maintaining principled commitment to human security in an increasingly fragmented world.
response_text: Ireland assumes the Presidency at a time when the temptation to abandon principled multilateralism for short-term security expediency has never been stronger. We urge Ireland to resist this drift. The disarmament architecture built over decades - the treaties banning landmines, cluster munitions, regulating conventional weapons - is not outdated. It is more essential than ever. Russia's extensive use of landmines in Ukraine, Myanmar's deployment of antipersonnel mines around civilian infrastructure, and the proliferation of explosive weapons in populated areas across multiple conflicts demonstrate precisely why these norms matter. A Different Approach is Possible Previous Presidencies have understandably focused on economic recovery, internal cohesion, or immediate crisis response. Ireland in 2026 can offer something different: moral clarity about the kind of international order worth defending, and the practical expertise to operationalise that vision. This means: Ensuring that rising EU defence budgets do not eclipse humanitarian and development assistance Recognising that the long-term consequences of weapons use - contaminated land, destroyed livelihoods, traumatised populations - demand the same strategic attention as immediate military threats Understanding that sustainable capacity development in conflict-affected states, including mine action institutions and weapons management systems, is itself a form of conflict prevention Ireland's Unique Authority Ireland brings unmatched credibility to this agenda. No other EU member state can claim 67 unbroken years of UN peacekeeping. No other has maintained principled neutrality while remaining deeply engaged in conflict resolution. No other holds such authentic standing with both Western partners and Global South nations navigating between power blocs. This authority should not be squandered on safe consensus positions. Ireland's 2026 Presidency can demonstrate that peace is still achievable, that international law still matters, and that human security - not state power - is the foundation of genuine stability.

geography: We are a national organization with 20 local member youth services in a federation. We have a strong presence in all towns and rural areas through a network of funded youth projects and approximately 300 local youth clubs the latter often being in very rural areas
response_text: We believe Ireland should draw extensively on the first priority of the European Council’s Strategic Agenda 2024-2029 “a free and democratic Europe” for its overall priority/slogan. With so much going on in Europe and the world we need to ground Europe in high level principles such as human rights, the rule of law and EU values, most particularly; “We will protect and promote our founding values – respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights, including the rights of persons belonging to minorities – which remain the cornerstone of our Union” This field is most relevant to our work where we focus on the rights of young people and their need to access quality local youth work and supports in their community. It also covers other strategic issues on competitiveness, climate, security and more. Few of the EU’s objectives can be realized if these overarching rights based values are let slide. Effectively a slogan/theme like “Furthering our Values and Rights” sums this up well. There is more room for diversity in three potential policy themes. We believe one of these must be rooted in the need to ensure the continuance of social Europe consistent with he European Pillar of Social Rights. There is considerable pressure at the EU and national level to reduce these protections and they figure less and less in EU processes. Yet for young people these are key to their development, whether it be in accessing local voluntary services, the housing crisis, mental health, and other areas. Tangible progress associated with the European project in these areas does more than all the treaties or declarations in the EU. Similarly the European Green Deal is constantly subject to dilution as witnessed at COP 30. A theme revolving around social, environmental and human progress then would serve the Irish Presidency well where relevant files and policy areas could be monitored and progressed by the Council to serve such a heading.

geography: We are a national organization with 20 local member youth services in a federation. We have a strong presence in all towns and rural areas through a network of funded youth projects and approximately 300 local youth clubs the latter often being in very rural areas
response_text: Below are key areas relevant to young people for Irelands Presidency largely in the EYCS and EPSCO configurations which would be relevant under a social and environmental theme. Consistent with the EU Youth strategy, “Engaging, Connecting and Empowering young people: a new EU Youth Strategy 2019-2027” youth is seen as a cross-cutting issue as witnessed by the overall youth dialogue and the individual Commissioners Youth Policy Dialogues. This is similar to youth policy at a national level. The following are the key policy and legislative areas in the above configurations and related fields; EU Youth Strategy This strategy will cease at the end of 2026. The strategy has pioneered the cross sectoral approach to youth. We believe there should be a rights based approach to youth work providing for access to youth work as a social right in policy and legislation. However, more emphasis may be needed on national delivery and levelling up local provision by member states. National programmes should facilitate and encourage mobility and other activities supported by the ERASMUS+. There should be a culture of parity of esteem between the formal and informal education systems. Another key issue is strengthening and supporting quality Youth Information particularly in a time of disinformation and fake news. This is also a cross cutting field. Our work with the European platform ERYICA, which we plan to showcase during the Presidency, has much to offer here. We are working locally and at the European level with partners and the Council of Europe (Strasbourg) on prioritising quality youth spaces for young people. Such practical initiatives should certainly feature in the EU Youth Strategy. ERASMUS and the MFF There will be a role for the trio and Presidency in supporting a strong budget allocation for ERASMUS+ particularly for the youth (as distinct from 3rd level) aspects. This is the part of the programme that achieves most in terms of inclusion and needs “earmarking” as called for by the European Economic and Social Committee. The Intergenerational Solidarity Strategy is due in 2026, it should not represent any dilution to support for youth or major youth issues such as youth work, education, housing, and mental health. Commissioner Micallef’s Mission letter from President Von der Lyen stated “We must ensure that decisions taken today do no harm to future generations” Other Cross Cutting Issues There are huge issues relating to mental health, online safety and the protection and delivery of the Digital Services Act. The Cyber Bulling Strategy is due early in 2026. The European Parliament and Maria Walsh MEP have done valuable work on an EU strategy for Mental Health. The development of EU policy relating to housing will remain a focus in late 2026 and affordability, particularly in the rental market, is critical for young people In employment and social affairs youth interests must be a focus on initiatives such as; EU Anti-Poverty Strategy Quality Jobs Act Fair Labour Mobility package Education Package Employment Guidelines 2026 & 2027 Traineeship Directive Equal treatment Directive

geography: We are a national organization with 20 local member youth services in a federation. We have a strong presence in all towns and rural areas through a network of funded youth projects and approximately 300 local youth clubs the latter often being in very rural areas
response_text: It is inevitably challenging to bring somewhat arcane legislative and other procedures to the public at any time. There is however enhanced media and communications opportunities to enable at least increased impact. The events programme has the ability to link with local communities and civil society organisations to illustrate the actual work and how it impacts on everyday life. Certain files or policy areas may be more amenable to this. Local radio and local connections and visits can also help a lot. While the Commission and Parliament have advanced dedicated youth participation programmes these are less common with the Council meetings, particular outside of Education, Youth, Sport and Culture. The Presidency could be an opportunity to showcase quality youth participation in the policy making process in Ireland aligned to particular meetings and events. Similarly local events could also connect with local youth services in this fashion or through visits or fact finding activities. All these activities could also showcase the diversity of Ireland and connect all groups to the EU integration process. While respecting sensitivities the Presidency should be open to engagement with groups from Northern Ireland in some of its meetings and activities in venues in the south. This would maintain a connection with the EU and Northern Ireland and also possibly be appropriate to the re-entry or alignment of the UK with the ERASMUS+ Programme By promoting mobility and non-formal learning, the Presidency can help expand opportunities for skills development, cross-cultural exchange and innovation. These benefits extend beyond individual young people to employers, regional development and the wider EU economy. A Presidency that centres young people’s rights and strengthens the youth work sector will make a deep and lasting contribution to social and economic wellbeing across the Union.

geography: We are a national organization with 20 local member youth services in a federation. We have a strong presence in all towns and rural areas through a network of funded youth projects and approximately 300 local youth clubs the latter often being in very rural areas
response_text: In many respects this is linked with the previous question. There will be media and PR opportunities clearly. Some of these should perhaps take more the form of debate and discussion about the EU and it’s priorities rather than mere “flags and balloons” events. With young people, youth services and schools there may be many possibilities here and these should be linked to actual Council meetings or activities. While not and EU event the EPC meeting in Ireland should also feature in such activity. Key sectoral partnerships related to the Council configurations could also help with local debate and discussion events related to some of the more engaging policy issues and files. There are clearly a number of sectors and even interest groups with different views on numerous topics. The work previously carried out by citizens assemblies may also be instructive here Once more local events and activities are very much in the Irish culture and these can also find national expression for major set piece events. Local “adoption” of events or issues akin to the Special Olympics is an approach that seems to work well. We are confident that local youth services and young people would be more than happy to contribute or be involved in such activities A dedicated Youth approach to the Presidency would be a new departure and a huge benefit, it could include; Youth-friendly, factual communication delivered through reliable youth information services and youth workers as the trusted intermediaries who can translate complex EU policy into accessible, relevant content. This is essential to counter disinformation and strengthen democratic engagement. Creating participatory mechanisms for young people to directly shape Presidency-related discussions, such as youth dialogues, micro-grants for youth-led civic projects, and youth participation in thematic events. Highlight stories from across Ireland and the EU where EU membership has tangibly improved young people’s lives, from access to mobility, education, employment supports, digital rights, environmental protections and anti-discrimination frameworks. Use high-quality youth spaces such as arts centres, youth clubs, libraries, community hubs etc.. as local sites for Presidency engagement. These spaces are democratic infrastructures where inclusive and meaningful dialogue with young people can happen. Collaborate with youth organisations to design communication that is culturally and linguistically inclusive, accessible to all and tailored for diverse communities.

response_text: We would refer to some key EU platforms and activities connected with our work European Civic Forum https://civic-forum.eu/ pan-European network of nearly 100 associations and NGOs across 29 European countries. The International Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Trans, Queer and Intersex (LGBTQI) Youth & Student Organisation https://www.iglyo.org/ LGBTQI issues at the European and international level.
