For its 2026 EU Presidency, Ireland should prioritise sustainable energy, rural resilience, and community-centred governance. In particular, the rapid scaling of biomethane under REPowerEU highlights the urgent need for independent impact assessments, strict environmental safeguards, and oversight of public subsidies to prevent unsustainable industrial-scale biogas projects. Ireland can lead by embedding legally binding rules on feedstock use, digestate management, and spatial planning, ensuring local communities have a real voice in decision-making rather than bearing disproportionate social and environmental costs. By championing a model that balances climate, biodiversity, and rural development goals, Ireland can set a European benchmark for fair, sustainable energy transitions. Prioritising transparency, equitable benefit-sharing, and preventative regulation will help avoid repeating mistakes seen elsewhere in Europe, reinforcing trust in decarbonisation policies. These thematic priorities will position Ireland as a leader in creating energy strategies that are both ambitious and socially responsible.

The European Commission’s REPowerEU action plan has set biomethane production on a course of massive upscale as part of efforts to increase EU energy independence, fixing a target of 35 billion cubic meters (bcm) per year by 2030 – up from 4,1 bcm in 2023. However, until this day, no Impact Assessment was carried out on the target. As biomethane production continues to grow rapidly both in Ireland and Europe (with a currently 21% year-over-year growth), so do concerns about its associated environmental and social risks as well as the irresponsible use of taxpayers money. While biogas production from sludge or collecting the gas that is produced in landfills is appropriate, there are particular concerns about the effects of large-scale biogas production on the use of limited agricultural land, the continuation of polluting industrial animal production, harm to local communities, and the effects of methane leaking from biogas facilities. Further concerns arise when looking closer at promoted use cases for biomethane such as heating or transport which are often inefficient, expensive, and lock Europe into existing fossil infrastructure. The Irish Presidency should therefore prioritize conducting an independent, interdisciplinary impact assessment to evaluate the feasibility and sustainability of this target, ensuring it aligns with climate, biodiversity, and rural community goals. Emphasis must be placed on implementing strict economic, environmental, and social safeguards for biogas and biomethane production. With reference to the Commission’s 2026 Work Programme as well as the wider EU Strategic Agenda that highlights the need to secure Europe’s energy independence, we therefore encourage the Irish Presidency to: Advocate for an independent impact assessment of the EU’s 35 bcm biomethane target, as a prerequisite to develop further any expansion of biomethane production as part of relevant policy files in 2026, such as the Circular Economy Act, Bioeconomy Strategy, Livestock Strategy, Energy Union Governance Upgrade, and Common Agricultural Policy. This includes prioritizing truly sustainable feedstocks, efficient use cases, and avoiding lock-ins of fossil infrastructure. Include the voices of local communities in the debate. In order to expand biomethane production rapidly, the 2025 REPowerEU roadmap foresees a “tripartite contract to better address the diverging needs in different areas of the EU and include national and local stakeholders”. However, a focus has been set on facilitating dialogue between the EU Commission, EU Member States’ governments as well as industrial stakeholders; and no commitment has been made to give a role to local communities themselves that are affected by such projects. In line with its “people-centred” approach, the Presidency should therefore intensify its efforts to give the Irish people and local communities across Europe a greater say in the development of fair and sustainable biomethane strategies. Scrutinise public subsidy schemes for unsustainable biomethane production. This is critical to prevent perverse incentives that undermine the EU’s climate, food security, and energy independence goals. Current subsidies often favour industrial-scale biogas projects reliant on unsustainable feedstocks - such as manure from factory farming or energy crops competing with food production - which lock in polluting practices as well as animal welfare violations, and divert resources from truly circular solutions. Without strict oversight, these subsidies risk distorting markets, inflating demand for unsustainable livestock farming, and sidelining local, community-led projects that deliver genuine environmental and social benefits.

Ireland’s presidency provides a unique opportunity to develop and promote a gold standard indigenous biogas industry that is sized and scaled to meet community needs. Learning from EU countries with an established biogas industry, Ireland can avoid the pitfalls of social acceptance that are consistently documented as barriers to bioenergy projects across the EU (Mancini & Raggi, 2022). Current regulatory gaps and weak planning assessments underestimate the cumulative impacts on rural infrastructure. Public health and safety questions about hazardous gas storage, particular emissions and emergency service access are heightened when regulatory oversight is perceived as reactive rather than preventative. Research has highlighted that digestate management and changes in feedstock mixes are critical risk vectors that demand much stronger regulation than is currently applied (Piadeh et. al, 2024). Ireland, through its presidency, can set the standard by developing industry-specific planning regulations that include community engagement at its core. The National Biomethane Strategy points directly to a highly industrialised model aimed at rapid development across rural Ireland. Within this model, revenue accrues to outside multi-national agri-investors while costs are borne by host communities in terms of road damage, odour, environmental degradation, and reduced property values. Communities demand transparent environmental impact assessments, accessible monitoring data and enforceable operating limits. The development of industry-specific planning regulations aligned with benefit-sharing mechanisms has the potential to provide a blueprint for use across the EU, while maintaining community engagement and the highest environmental standards. Meaningful community engagement, spatial planning that respects local carrying capacity, strict feedstock limits, alongside legally binding digestate management plans, are safeguards that would increase local acceptance. Rapid roll-out risks polarising rural communities, undermining trust in decarbonisation policy, and producing environmental and social harms that outweigh local benefits. Ireland has an opportunity through its EU presidency to either lead and develop new industry standards or to repeat mistakes already impacting the rural communities and the environment across Europe.

Ireland’s Presidency should prepare the EU to address its major strategic challenges. The 2026 Commission Work Programme highlights the need for Europe to strengthen its competitiveness, reinforce its security and defence capacity, and accelerate the green and digital transitions. These ambitions require substantial and sustained private investment. Demographic pressures are also reshaping Europe’s social and economic landscape, increasing the importance of effective long-term savings systems that can support citizens and sustain Europe’s social model. Vanguard proposes three high-level themes on financial services for the Irish Presidency of the EU: Harnessing long-term investment by European citizens. The first pillar of the Savings and Investment Union strategy focuses on citizens and is critical to funding Europe’s economic transition. The introduction of Savings and Investment Accounts (SIAs) internationally has demonstrated how well-calibrated tax incentives, combined with simple and accessible account structures, can support citizens as they move from saving to investing. Consistent with our mission to take a stand for all investors, Vanguard supports policy reforms that enhance the position of retail investors. The Retail Investment Strategy has left significant unfinished business and the Irish Government has an opportunity to evolve the discussion on key success factors for EU retail markets. Potential topics include the investor journey, cost transparency and expanding the spectrum of advice options, building on excellent technical work by the Irish authorities in implementing the Funds Sector 2030 action plan. Promoting retirement security. As highlighted by the Draghi and Letta reports, shrinking workforces and rising dependency ratios are placing growing strain on public finances and pension systems in many Member States. The Presidency could advance the SIU agenda by emphasising the role of funded and supplementary pensions in ensuring sustainable retirement incomes and supporting long-term financial and economic resilience. Council discussions on the subject of retirement systems should both advance the Commission’s pensions package and spotlight positive reforms to retirement systems across the EU27. Efficient and integrated capital markets. Deeper capital markets can help mobilise private investment to support critical investments in sectors such as technology, infrastructure, clean energy and defence capabilities, while offering new financing opportunities for businesses, startups and scaleups. A stronger culture of saving and investing among households can improve financial wellbeing and support a more resilient European economy. In this context, the Savings and Investment Union (SIU) provides an important set of levers to help advance many of the EU’s wider policy goals.

As a major hub for international financial services, Ireland is well placed to guide the Council’s work on developing deeper and more efficient EU capital markets during its Presidency. The SIU sets out a broad agenda to widen retail participation, support long-term saving, and reduce the structural barriers that limit the flow of private capital across the Union. The Irish Presidency can play an important role in encouraging coordinated progress among Member States and ensuring that work across these files contributes to a more competitive and investment-ready European economy. Vanguard proposes three policy and legislative priorities on financial services for Ireland’s EU Presidency: Integrating EU capital markets: Fragmented capital markets limit the ability of firms to operate across borders. The Council’s work on files such as the Market Integration and Supervision Package (MISP) offers an opportunity for the Irish Presidency to demonstrate leadership in advancing the EU’s capital markets agenda. The success of the package should be measured against its ability to remove barriers, enhance efficiency, and expand market participation. Working with the incoming Cypriot Presidency, we would encourage the Irish Presidency team to front-load negotiation on aspects of the MISP which have most direct investor and market impact; notably the proposals to remove barriers to cross-border fund distribution and enhance the interoperability of post-trade market infrastructure. Savings and investment accounts (SIAs): The introduction of SIAs internationally has demonstrated how well-calibrated tax incentives, combined with simple and accessible account structures, can support citizens as they move from saving to investing. The Commission’s blueprint sets out a positive and pragmatic reform agenda for the Member States. The Irish Presidency should maintain the political momentum on this topic and highlight the significant contribution that SIAs can also make to retirement savings. Retirement savings for citizens: As Europe’s demographic shift accelerates, growing pressure on public pension systems makes it vital to strengthen the availability, accessibility, and attractiveness of retirement savings and funded pensions. The Commission’s blueprint on Supplementary Income Arrangements (SIAs) and its Communication on auto-enrolment offer natural entry points for the Irish Presidency to show leadership by fostering dialogue among Member States, sharing best practices, and helping to elevate these initiatives to the EU level. In parallel, the Commission’s forthcoming package on supplementary pensions, including the IORP II and PEPP revisions, will remain an important focus. These reforms aim to build stronger, more efficient private pension markets across Europe.

Ireland’s 2026 EU Presidency presents a strategic opportunity to elevate sport and physical activity as central contributors to Europe’s health, wellbeing, social cohesion, and green transition. The following thematic priorities position Ireland as an ambitious and credible leader—offering both political resonance and practical deliverables under the Council Work Plan for Sport. In relation to sport and physical activity the following areas; Healthy Communities and Increased Physical Activity Sport as a Driver of Social Inclusion, Equality and Community Cohesion Sport and Sustainability Innovation, Digital Transformation, and Skills in Sport Strengthening Evidence and Data for Policy in European Sport
Please see Any other comments Please see Any other comments
Please see Any other comments
Please see Any other comments

. 1. Integrity, Safety and Values in Sport Ireland has an opportunity to champion a Europe where sport is safe, fair, and built on genuine respect. This priority isn’t just about rules—it’s about protecting the people who make sport what it is. We can focus on stronger governance in sporting organisations, better cooperation on anti-doping, and practical safeguards for athletes, especially children, vulnerable adults, and anyone who speaks up when something is wrong. Tackling discrimination, racism, online abuse, and all forms of violence in sport must also remain front and centre. Why Ireland? Ireland has made real progress in recent years on governance reform and safeguarding. That experience gives us credibility—and the confidence to help raise standards across Europe. 2. Healthy Communities and Increased Physical Activity (HEPA) Across Europe, people want healthier, more active lives. Ireland can lead a renewed push to make everyday physical activity part of normal life at every age—from school right through to older adulthood. This includes supporting active travel, more liveable and movement-friendly towns and cities, and tackling inequalities that stop some people from taking part—whether due to disability, income, or where they live. Local initiatives across Europe could be scaled more easily with shared EU funding and knowledge. Why Ireland? Ireland already has strong national strategies focused on health and physical activity, and we have experience working across departments. That practical approach is something we can share at EU level. 3. Sport and Sustainability: Driving Europe’s Green Transition Sport has an important role to play in Europe’s climate ambitions. This priority places sport firmly within the green agenda—from how facilities are built and upgraded to how events are run and how communities adapt to climate change. Areas of focus could include more sustainable infrastructure, shared guidelines for hosting environmentally responsible events, and better planning for the climate risks facing outdoor recreation. There is also huge potential in using sport to promote environmental awareness among young people and volunteers. Why Ireland? Ireland’s sports sector, especially through initiatives like the GAA’s Green Clubs Programme, is already taking meaningful steps on sustainability. That experience gives us a strong foundation to lead a conversation on “green sport” across the EU. 4. Sport as a Driver of Inclusion, Equality and Community Cohesion Sport has a unique ability to bring people together. As Europe continues to change and diversify, sport can be a powerful tool for connecting communities and supporting people who might otherwise feel excluded. Ireland could highlight the role of sport in integrating migrants and minority communities, advancing gender equality, and ensuring that people with disabilities can participate fully through better design and adapted sport. Supporting local clubs and volunteers is key, because that’s where inclusion really happens. Why Ireland? Ireland’s strong equality frameworks—and the deeply rooted community model of sport delivered through Local Sports Partnerships and national organisations—offer valuable lessons for other Member States. 5. Innovation, Digital Transformation and Skills in Sport Sport is changing quickly, driven by technology and data. Ireland can play a central role in shaping this future. Digital tools can help people become more active, and AI can offer new ways of analysing performance or improving governance—provided it’s used safely and ethically. There is also real potential to support sport-tech start-ups and modernise the skills of coaches, volunteers, and administrators. Why Ireland? Ireland’s reputation as a European tech hub—and its strong research and industry networks—make it an ideal leader for this conversation. 6. Strengthening Evidence and Data for Policy in European Sport Good decisions depend on good information. Ireland can help the EU improve how it gathers, shares, and uses data on sport and physical activity. This includes better cooperation on Sport Satellite Accounts, clearer and more consistent HEPA indicators, and making better use of Eurobarometer and other datasets. Strengthening peer learning between Member States would help everyone benefit from what works. Three Suggested Presidency Priorities To provide a clear and focused message during the Presidency, Ireland could bring together the themes above into three broader pillars: Integrity, Safety and Values in Sport Healthy and Active Communities (HEPA & Inclusion) Sport and Sustainability (Green Transition & Climate Resilience) These three themes reflect Ireland’s strengths, align with EU priorities, and offer real opportunities for meaningful progress during the Presidency.

EU Economic Security: The EU must enhance the protection of its market while deepening the Single Market. This requires safeguarding existing industries and promoting ambitious growth strategies. The EU Chips Act 2.0 and the Biotech Acts I and II exemplify strategic priorities with significant potential to drive economic growth and reduce dependencies. Moreover, partnerships with third countries should be viewed as essential opportunities, not just risks, to ensure smooth supply chains and robust R&D capabilities. Strategic resilience is vital for the EU to absorb shocks across critical sectors, including pharmaceuticals, digital infrastructure, and public health. Global Trade: The Irish Presidency will need to address the critical issue of trade barriers. Tariffs are currently under negotiation with the USA, creating a complex environment for the biotech and biomanufacturing industries, where tariffs, Section 232 investigations, and Most Favored Nation (MFN) status generate considerable uncertainty. The impact is expected to be particularly felt by the biopharmaceutical industry in Ireland, possibly more so than in other Member States. It is crucial for EU decision-makers to achieve a zero-for-zero tariff on medicines and pharmaceutical ingredients, benefiting both Europe’s industrial base and patients on both sides. Non-tariff barriers will also be of great importance. Industrial Competitiveness: Economic prosperity is at stake, and key regulations and initiatives from the Commission will require the active support of the Presidency to ensure fast and smooth procedures. Simplification measures, along with cross-sectoral and sectoral initiatives, must advance during the Irish Presidency to improve economic sustainability and enhance our industries' ability to invest and innovate. Sustainable development should be prioritized. Manufacturing and R&D activities in the EU must rapidly integrate AI components. Strong alignment and cooperation between policymakers in Brussels, Member States, and industrialists will position Smart Manufacturing as a key opportunity for the EU to close the gap with other regions. Addressing Demographic Challenges and Fertility Declines: Europe’s fertility rate continues to decline, making the fertility gap a crucial issue for our health and social agenda. Eurostat statistics reveal alarming data: Europe’s fertility rate stands at just 1.38 live births per woman, far below the 2.1 needed to sustain population levels. The trend of late parenthood indicates changing lifestyles, necessitating policy adaptations. With age, fertility declines; later parenthood limits options and reduces the opportunity to have the desired number of children. Reports from the European Central Bank warn of the risks posed by demographic challenges to European growth, potentially reducing economic growth in the euro area to levels below those seen during the 2007/8 global financial crisis. Emotional Health and Youth Engagement: Ireland’s 2026 Presidency presents an opportunity to address emotional health challenges among Europe’s youth—a critical pillar for social resilience and competitiveness. Only 44% of young Europeans feel their voices are represented in policy debates, while 83% desire greater involvement. Emotional well-being intersects with demographic concerns: three in ten young Europeans do not intend to have children. Prioritizing emotional health alongside mechanisms for youth participation would strengthen Europe’s social fabric and enhance its competitiveness.

areas? Merck emphasizes the need for Ireland's Presidency to focus on the following policy areas: EU Chips Act 2.0 and Critical Raw Materials Act: These initiatives are essential for securing supply chains for critical raw materials vital for innovation. EU Biotech Acts I and II: These acts present the EU’s first opportunity in decades to implement new and sustainable structural measures, as well as financial instruments, to rapidly restore the EU's leadership in research, innovation, and biomanufacturing. Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) Negotiations: Continued discussions are necessary to enable greater financial support for critical sectors in the EU, directly impacting resilience in public health and food security. This includes talks on the European Competitiveness Fund, emphasizing the need for increased investments in health infrastructure, research and innovation capacity, and biopharmaceutical manufacturing. Regulatory Simplification: Accelerating simplification measures and omnibus proposals will help reduce regulatory burdens. EU Beating Cancer Plan (EBCP): The Irish Presidency should continue focusing on the EBCP and the EU Cancer Mission, along with national cancer control plans, through sustained focus and budget allocation. Additionally, the implementation of the EU Cardiovascular Health Plan should begin in synergy with the EBCP by adopting the Council Recommendation on health checks. Innovation and management of Rare Diseases: Support for innovation, management, and infrastructure in the rare disease sector is crucial, particularly for early diagnosis capabilities. Merck supports EU Parliament’s call to develop EU Rare Disease Action Plan. Demographic and Fertility Challenges: To address these issues, the Presidency could promote key actions: Support equitable access to fertility care without out-of-pocket payments and ensure necessary funding, including adopting new eligibility criteria. This includes timely diagnosis and equitable access to innovative fertility care with appropriate budgets (including in the MFF). Implement comprehensive reproductive education across generations. Introduce inclusive and family-friendly workplace policies that support individuals' reproductive choices, involving both employers and governments. Women’s Health: The Irish Presidency should prioritize women’s health across all healthcare agenda items. Championing a dedicated EU Women’s Health Strategy will help close persistent gaps in access, research, and outcomes. Initiatives like ClosinGap, driven by Merck, illustrate how addressing gender health disparities can unlock economic growth and improve well-being, reinforcing the EU’s equality and competitiveness agenda. 9. Urban Wastewater Treatment Directive (UWWTD): The implementation of the revised UWWTD should be postponed. The Presidency should revisit this directive to ensure fair and proportionate implementation, as current provisions impose disproportionate costs on pharmaceuticals and cosmetics. Merck advocates for a science-based, toxicity-driven model aligned with the polluter-pays principle, emphasizing that the directive's obligations contradict key principles of the EU Treaties: the polluter-pays principle, proportionality, and nondiscrimination.

Merck believes that the Irish Presidency of the Council in 2026 has a unique opportunity to create substantial positive impacts for people, businesses, and communities across the EU. By focusing on strategic initiatives that enhance competitiveness and resilience, Ireland can demonstrate the tangible and transformative benefits of EU cooperation. Establishing a European Pharmaceutical Taskforce: Ireland should lead the creation of a European Pharmaceutical Taskforce, bringing together the European Commission, Member States, and industry partners. This Taskforce can deliver a high-level Political Declaration that reaffirms the strategic importance of the research-based pharmaceutical sector. By committing to investing in this sector, the EU can secure its position as a global leader in innovation, ensuring that Europe does not become dependent on external sources for ensuring the well-being of its population and critical advancements. Enhancing Regulatory Pathways: The Irish Presidency can significantly reduce time-to-treatment gaps by advocating for predictable and efficient regulatory pathways. By embedding patient voices in health technology assessment (HTA) and regulatory processes, Ireland can ensure that innovative treatments reach those who need them most, improving health outcomes across the Union. Strengthening Health & Sustainability Initiatives: Prioritizing disease-focused initiatives—such as cancer care, cardiovascular health, rare diseases, fertility and brain health —will drive earlier diagnosis and treatment, ultimately reducing health inequalities. Promoting and supporting sustainability initiatives such as use of ePI with removal of paper and reduction of animal testing will decrease carbon footprint and promote maximum ethical standards. Promoting Digital Health Transformation: The Presidency should champion digital health advancements and position EU as unique for leveraging data through EHDS for transparency in decision making based on robust and risk based science, including via interoperable patient records and AI-enabled care pathways. These innovations will not only drive efficiency but also empower patients, facilitate geographical mobility and create new opportunities for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and innovators. 5. Regional Impact of the Life Sciences Sector: The Irish Presidency can highlight the regional impact of the life sciences sector by showcasing how EU policies support job creation, training, innovation and research capacity in communities beyond major urban centers. By pursuing these initiatives, the Irish Presidency can make a lasting positive impact on the lives of citizens, the success of businesses, and the vitality of communities across the EU. Through strategic choices now, Ireland can help close the innovation and gender gap, transform our society and build a sustainable future for all.

Merck believes that effectively communicating the values and benefits of EU membership during Ireland’s Presidency of the Council is essential for creating a sense of belonging and improving health literacy among citizens. Clear Narrative: The Presidency should adopt a clear and relatable narrative that connects EU membership with visible improvements in health, safety, and economic opportunity. This theme emphasizes how collaborative efforts within the EU translate into better healthcare literacy, access, health outcomes, enhanced security, and increased competitiveness for businesses. Showcasing Success Stories: Highlighting specific success stories related to EU membership can illustrate its direct impact on citizens. For instance, the transformative effects of the Single Market on the science & technology sector, or EU Beating Cancer Plan and promoting patient screening awareness and opportunities. Additionally, the benefits of the European Medicines Agency (EMA) in ensuring timely approvals of innovative medicines can serve as a powerful testament to the advantages of EU collaboration.However, it remains essential to further simplify the approval process for medicines in Europe and to propose innovative regulatory pathways that encourage the industry to prioritize submitting their groundbreaking medicines in Europe. Citizen-Centered Dialogues: Facilitating dialogues that center around citizens, including youth, and patient experiences is crucial. Organizing patient roundtables can help policymakers understand the reallife implications of their decisions, fostering a sense of connection between EU initiatives and individual lives. With the FutURe program, Merck is connecting the reality of Gen Z and Millennials with policymakers through round tables across European capitals and at the European Parliament. The Presidency of the Council is an excellent opportunity to continue this conversation going so that the concerns and aspirations of the European youth are fully incorporated in the future of the European Union and Merck is willing to continue supporting that. Considering Commissioner Michael McGrath's remit, it would be particularly relevant for the FutURe Project to support the process when a Youth Policy Dialogue is held in Ireland. Digital Storytelling: Utilizing digital storytelling to showcase practical examples of improvements— such as earlier cancer diagnoses, and AI-driven clinical decision support—can illustrate how EU cooperation directly benefits families and communities. Communicating Strategic Resilience: Emphasizing the EU's role in safeguarding critical supply systems and digital & data sharing infrastructure will help citizens appreciate the ongoing relevance of EU actions. In that regard, actions to address demographic challenges and support inclusive actions by design and family friendly workplace will stress the specificity of ‘the European way of life’. Starting debates on how European policies can support work-life balance and address competitiveness and prosperity in a holistic way by starting from people can further support the promotion of EU values and high-standard of life and welfare in public opinion. Inclusive Outreach: Collaborating with stakeholders, including industry representatives, clinicians, and patient organizations, ensures that the outreach efforts are inclusive and reflective of diverse perspectives and backgrounds.

The European Union is at a pivotal moment where the life sciences sector can significantly contribute to both economic prosperity and transformative health system advancements. The upcoming 2026 EU Presidency presents a unique opportunity to build upon the existing EU Life Sciences Strategy and lead on competitiveness, innovation, and health equity across the Union to increase citizens’ wellbeing. To maximize the impact of this strategy, the EU must focus on several key areas that reinforce its objectives and enhance collaboration among Member States, industry, and research institutions: Strengthening the Regulatory Framework: The EU should continue to streamline regulatory processes to facilitate faster access to innovative therapies and diagnostics. Enhancing regulatory harmonization and establishing robust frameworks for health technology assessments will ensure that patients benefit from timely access to new treatments while maintaining high safety standards. Promoting Investment in Research and Development: The EU must prioritize investment in R&D to close the innovation gap with global competitors. By creating favorable conditions for investment, including tax incentives and funding opportunities for public-private partnerships, the EU can stimulate growth in the life sciences sector and reinforce its position as a global leader in medical research. Championing Disease-Focused Initiatives: The EU should actively promote disease-focused agendas, such as the EU Beating Cancer Plan, the forthcoming Cardiovascular Health Plan, and strategies for addressing rare diseases, fertility and brain health. Coordinating efforts across Member States will enhance integrated care pathways and improve health outcomes for patients and their caregivers. Embracing Carers is a Merck global initiative, in collaboration with leading organizations around the world, to increase awareness, discussion and action about the oftenoverlooked needs of carers. Harnessing Digital Health and Data: The integration of digital health solutions and the European Health Data Space (EHDS) is fundamental to modernizing healthcare delivery and gaining efficiency. The strategy should emphasize the importance of interoperable health data systems, AI-driven tools, and digital health innovations that empower patients and healthcare providers alike. Fostering a Skilled Workforce: Developing a skilled workforce that meets the evolving needs of the life sciences sector is essential. The EU should invest in education and training programs that equip professionals with the necessary skills to thrive in a rapidly changing landscape, ensuring that Europe remains at the forefront of life sciences innovation. Addressing demographic challenges will be critical to ensure that with a shrinking population, any EU competitiveness strategy also includes people and the demographic crisis that Europe is facing (clearly stated in Letta report). By enhancing the existing EU Life Sciences Strategy, the EU can effectively communicate its commitment to fostering a vibrant life sciences sector with sustainable practices that benefit citizens, businesses, the planet and communities across the continent. This approach will not only enhance the EU's credibility and leadership in health and innovation but also serve as a foundation for collaborative efforts that drive sustainable economic growth. In conclusion, strengthening the EU Life Sciences Strategy is crucial for harnessing the full potential of the life sciences sector, ensuring that the 2026 Presidency delivers lasting positive impacts for patients and society as a whole.

sector: Representing 34 local, regional, multi-city and national radio stations in Ireland
geography:
IBI focus:  Rural, urban and national – within Ireland
We are also active members of an EU-wide organisation representing 5,000 station in Europe.
response_text: In Ireland and across Europe, we now face major geo-political, social, economic and environmental change and uncertainty, with a higher risk of disruption thank has been the case in decades. Any of those issues could bring major challenges for the citizens of the European Union and all of its Member States, and therefore there is a need for preparedness and societal resilience. The European Commission has recognised this in its 2025 Strategic Foresight Report. A major risk is constituted by the ability of the social media/web platforms to promote and distribute misinformation and disinformation, who could confuse, deceive or inflame populations and cause major difficulties for public authorities in managing crises. We therefore believe that the unique aspects of radio in promoting trust, in delivering accurate information, and in creating cohesion have huge potential to assist policymakers. Radio is highly trusted as shown by surveys including Eurobarometer. It is the “together-medium” because it involves listeners collectively tuning in. This fits with the definition of “broadcasting” and is vital for cohesion and is a bulwark against division. Radio is also the only real-time medium, because it can respond to and cover issues quickly. Very importantly it is free of charge to listeners. The first theme we suggest for Ireland’s Presidency is: “Promoting resilience by protecting trusted media in Europe” As a result of imposition of barriers to free trade, European businesses are now facing major challenges. One of the major ways this has impacted them is the radical difference between regulatory barriers and structures in Europe. The European Union has recognised this through the simplification process, and this now needs to be expanded to the media sector where European media organisations lack a level playing-field as they compete against very large platforms which have almost no regulation of editorial content or of commercial advertising or operations. In contrast, the licensed radio sector (as an example) faces more than 26 separate restrictions in those areas. Therefore, a move to proportionate, risk-based and equitable regulation which allows broadcasters to be nimble and agile is needed. Similar extension of simplification required for all European businesses. As part of this, the European Commission is going to be reviewing the issue of State Aid restrictions on the broadcast media in Europe. Those restrictions have caused major difficulties for measures to support the Irish radio sector but could if reformed, contribute to a more supportive environment and help protect this crucial sector. In line with this, the second proposed theme we proposed for Ireland’s Presidency is: “Progressing a level playing-field in regulation for European businesses” The above two topics are ones which are new and “meaty” with potential to be expanded and to fit with European strategic objectives. They have not been addressed in the last five EU Presidencies so there is potential for Ireland to make its mark as a smaller Member State but one with expertise and knowledge, and a commitment to democracy and open markets.

sector: Representing 34 local, regional, multi-city and national radio stations in Ireland
geography:
IBI focus:  Rural, urban and national – within Ireland
We are also active members of an EU-wide organisation representing 5,000 station in Europe.
response_text: Radio is key vector or pillar to help measures in EU for upholding democracy & the rule of law (trusted news is key to countering foreign information manipulation and disinformation, and radio contributes directly to achieving the objectives of the European Democracy Shield initiative on “integrity of the information space, societal resilience, and free elections”). It is also highly consumer friendly: free at the point of access, universally available, doesn’t require users to be digital savvy, caters to people of differing abilities, provides entertainment, local news and companionship. It plays a key preparedness role in times of crisis. In times of crisis, broadcast radio provides a highly resilient communications channel for public authorities to reach citizens, as we saw in Portugal and Spain (the only way people were able to get news updates on the situation was by listening to broadcast radio – many did so in their cars). It is not surprising that radio is included in the EU’s population preparedness survival kit. More than 1 million radio sets were sold in Spain in the 24 hours after the major power grid outage. However, the future of radio in cars is at risk: Listeners could be excluded by car manufacturers in a process already underway and radio is becoming increasingly dependent on platforms, manufacturers and technology operators to be in the car. Vehicle makers are starting to remove broadcast radio receivers from cars. These policy areas are within the portfolio of Commissioner Michael McGrath and EVP Virkkunen and directly relevant to Commissioner Lahbib’s responsibilities. EU action is required in order to secure radio’s presence and findability in cars over the longer term. The policy solutions: (1) mandate broadcast radio in cars by updating art 113 of the European Electronic Communications Code (which regulates DAB+ radio in cars); (2) designate virtual assistants under the Digital Markets Act (VAs – think Apple Car Play and Google Android Auto – intermediate access to radio in cars, in addition to smart speakers); (3) issue guidance on the implementation of article 20 of the European Media Freedom Act (configuration of the user interface) to ensure that radio remains easily accessible and findable via in-car user interfaces. There is potential in 2026 for an “omnibus” approach to all of the above, as well as the Digital Networks Act. The Irish Government has the opportunity to contribute to a review of the broadcasting State Aid rules, so that radio stations in Ireland and across Europe could receive funding to help deliver the public service content such as news and current affairs which is so vital and which cannot currently be supported. The Irish Presidency can also utilise these themes to progress simplification of business regulations and therefore help create economic growth in the indigenous business sector in all Member States.

sector: Representing 34 local, regional, multi-city and national radio stations in Ireland
geography:
IBI focus:  Rural, urban and national – within Ireland
We are also active members of an EU-wide organisation representing 5,000 station in Europe.
response_text: The Irish Presidency of the Council of the European Union has the potential to add value through placing a focus of the themes we have suggested. These themes are not ones that would in any way cause division because there are radio stations in each and every Member State and awareness of the value they provide. The themes would, accordingly, have support from other EU Members and they are firmly within EU policy objectives and strategic areas, where the Members and the Council are in agreement (democracy, resilience and economic growth, in particular by European SME’s). The Independent Broadcasters of Ireland (IBI) is a member of the Association of European Radios (AER) whose member associations in total represent 5,000 commercial radio stations in Europe. IBI and AER also collaborate on these issues with the large state broadcasters across the European Union through the “Radio Ready” initiative to protect access to radio. Therefore, this will have broad industry support. That support will be very useful because all of the stations in Europe understand the vital nature of the issue (up to 50% of listening to radio is in cars across Europe). There is also widespread support for action on these issues within the Irish political landscape and among Irish MEPs, as IBI can attest have met a wide range of political representatives in Ireland and in Brussels. A number of pieces of European legislation which we have mentioned earlier will come to critical stages in their development during the period of the Irish Presidency and therefore there is potential for Ireland to make concrete progress on these issues and have a significant number of milestone achievement. Ireland’s reputation for constructive leadership, a reputation as an honest broker in complex negotiations and its history a bridge between east and west and north and south in Europe will put it in good stead to manage these issues successfully.

sector: Representing 34 local, regional, multi-city and national radio stations in Ireland
geography:
IBI focus:  Rural, urban and national – within Ireland
We are also active members of an EU-wide organisation representing 5,000 station in Europe.
response_text: We believe that communication of Ireland’s themes and initiatives will be vital and can be assisted by a clear and effective programme of initiatives. We support the holding of an event in Ireland during the Irish Presidency of the Council of the EU on the topic of “EU democracy, resilience and preparedness: radio as a key enabler”. In the run-up to Ireland’s Presidency of the Council of the EU. there will also be potential for IBI to cooperate with the Irish Permanent Representation in Brussels on briefings and a potential briefing event. Then during the Presidency, in co-operation with the Irish Government we are suggesting that one Irish event on these themes would take place in Limerick and would consist of a conference opened by Minister Patrick O’Donovan leading the Council on these issues where the regulatory and policy issues around promoting resilience, protecting trusted media, and putting in place a level playing-field for European media organisations, could be discussed and analysed. This could involve a large number of Irish independent radio stations from all over Ireland bringing the Outside Broadcast vans to Limerick and hosting their morning current affairs shows simultaneously, demonstrating the value of the medium. Possibly this could take place in July and there is definite potential for the involvement of other European stations in this initiative, drawing attention to the vital role that radio plays across the whole of the EU. The radio sector across Europe has thousands of stations and hundreds of millions of listeners, and the sector in Ireland also has a total listenership of 70 per cent of radio listeners, measured daily. Local radio in Ireland is the jointly most trusted medium in Ireland. We believe that the themes/topics and policy objectives are ones which will resonate with citizens and reflect well on Ireland’s Presidency of the Council of the EU.

sector: Representing 34 local, regional, multi-city and national radio stations in Ireland
geography:
IBI focus:  Rural, urban and national – within Ireland
We are also active members of an EU-wide organisation representing 5,000 station in Europe.
response_text: The Independent Broadcasters of Ireland, as a leading representative group in the Irish media sector believes that the above themes and topics, and policy objects fit in well with EU Strategic Agenda 2024-2029, in particular as it relates to the objective of Upholding European values within the Union. It is also in line with President von der Leyen’s State of the Union address which was strongly supportive of media resilience and simplification of regulation. In the President’s State of the Union letter of intent, she said: “Our work on internal security will go hand-in-hand with measures to reinforce the resilience of our democracies and societies, from strengthening our collective capacity to withstand threats to tackling information manipulation.” “We will simplify the regulatory environment with a single harmonised set of rules and work to improve access to venture capital – so our companies can find what they need to grow right here in Europe.” The latest Programme for Government in Ireland is also very strongly supportive of the themes and actions proposed in this submission. It sets out the following policy objectives: “Explore options to maintain access to local and commercial radio.” and “Ensure accessible funding for local radio and print media to support the provision of objective news and current affairs content, taking into account Coimisiún na Meán recommendations.” Based on the above, we believe that this submission is worthy of consideration and we would be delighted to provide further information and to work with the Department of Foreign Affairs or the Department of Media to progress these ideas.”

organisation: Irish Coalition for Business and Human Rights
geography: The ICBHR is concerned with both the national and EU-wide context, and how these contexts impact upon the regulation of transnational companies in relation to human rights and environmental harm, as well as ensuring access to justice for those impacted by corporate abuse of human rights and the environment.
response_text: (1) Protecting human rights and environmental standards and the Green Deal The Omnibus I process and the resulting gutting of the Corporate Sustainability Due Diligence Directive (CSDDD) was a clear show of deregulation. The “competitiveness agenda” has been used to prioritise business interests over basic protections for workers, human rights defenders and communities affected by corporate abuse who are now likely to face insurmountable barriers to access justice for harms caused by companies headquartered or operating in the EU. Moreover, the process resulted from undue corporate influence, in particular, the interests of fossil fuel and extractives. This approach undermines the EU’s credibility and the core values it claims to uphold. The Irish Presidency must work to ensure that EU’s strategic agenda commitment to “respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights, including the rights of persons belonging to minorities” does not continue to be breached. Ireland has a responsibility to ensure that future Omnibus processes do not follow this same deregulatory approach. Ireland must prioritise rights-centred policymaking, ensure meaningful consultation with impacted stakeholders throughout all stages of the lawmaking process, including workers, communities, human rights defenders, and environmental organisations, and protect what remains of the Green Deal. Ireland must champion rights-centred policymaking and insist that these consultations are substantive and transparent. It is essential that Ireland support the full implementation of the European Green Deal and resist attempts to weaken existing environmental and human rights standards under the guise of “simplification.” Ireland must correct the narrative around “competitiveness” and “simplification” and ensure that business interests do not continue to be prioritised over essential protections for workers, communities and the environment. These terms are increasingly being misused to justify lowering protections rather than strengthening long-term resilience, responsible business conduct, and a sustainable, fair economy. (2) Protecting civil society space Ireland must prioritise the protection of civil society space and address the growing problem of corporate capture in EU policymaking. The process for Omnibus I has shown how disproportionate industry influence can distort policy outcomes, marginalise affected communities and prevent them from accessing justice and undermine public trust. A true democracy requires strong, independent civil society organisations that can advocate for human rights and environmental protection without undue pressure or exclusion. Ireland must ensure transparent and balanced stakeholder engagement processes across all files, and champion initiatives that safeguard the role of civil society and human rights defenders within the EU. (3) Rebuilding democratic legitimacy and transparency Ireland must act as a stabilising force during its Presidency by strengthening democratic legitimacy, transparency and accountability in EU decision-making. The backlash against the CSDDD and other Green Deal files exposed a growing disconnect between EU institutions and the public, fuelled by undue corporate influence, opaque negotiations, last-minute political deals and alignment with far-right parties in breach of the longstanding “cordon sanitaire” in place for the protection of democratic norms. Ireland should advocate for transparent, democratic legislative processes, better access to information, and robust oversight of Council decision-making. Greater transparency and meaningful engagement with impacted stakeholders will help restore trust, ensure evidence-based policymaking, and reaffirm the EU’s commitment to its founding principles of democracy, human rights and the rule of law.

organisation: Irish Coalition for Business and Human Rights
geography: The ICBHR is concerned with both the national and EU-wide context, and how these contexts impact upon the regulation of transnational companies in relation to human rights and environmental harm, as well as ensuring access to justice for those impacted by corporate abuse of human rights and the environment.
response_text: Ireland must ensure that its 2026 Presidency prioritises legislative areas where strong human rights, environmental protections, and democratic governance are most at risk. The Presidency must play a central role in safeguarding the remaining elements of the European Green Deal, strengthening protections against corporate abuse, and rebuilding trust in EU institutions through accountability and transparency. 1. Defending and completing the Green Deal files Ireland must prioritise the completion and effective implementation of key Green Deal files that remain vulnerable to political dilution or delay. This includes defending climate, biodiversity, and environmental legislation that has come under pressure from deregulatory agendas. 2. Preventing deregulation through future Omnibus processes Ireland must ensure that no future Omnibus initiatives repeat the untransparent, undemocratic deregulatory approach taken by the institutions. The Presidency must promote transparent, standalone legislative processes, proper impact assessments, and meaningful consultation with affected stakeholders—including workers, communities, and civil society organisations. 3. Strengthening enforcement mechanisms Ireland must build robust enforcement mechanisms for existing human rights and environmental legislation, ensuring that laws already on the books deliver real-world protection. This includes supporting strong national oversight bodies, promoting cooperation between Member States, and ensuring that enforcement guidance for directives is build on the needs of workers and communities in the Global South who face the most severe impacts of corporate abuse. 4. Safeguarding and advancing key regulatory frameworks Ireland must take a proactive role in defending and advancing critical regulatory frameworks that underpin human rights, environmental protection, and social justice. Key areas include: Deforestation Regulation: ensuring full and timely implementation of the EU Deforestation Regulation, resisting efforts to narrow its scope, weaken enforcement, or allow loopholes that would undermine forest protection and Indigenous rights. Chemicals, food and feed safety, and critical raw materials: safeguarding robust EU chemicals policy (REACH), pesticide regulations, and food safety standards is essential to prevent deregulation that could endanger workers, communities, and ecosystems. The Presidency should support strong enforcement, oversight, and transparency in these areas, ensuring that risk assessments and regulatory decisions are guided by scientific evidence and public interest. Digital and investment frameworks: Ireland should defend regulatory measures that protect citizens’ digital rights, privacy, and access to essential services. In the context of trade and investment, the Presidency must scrutinise investment court systems and dispute settlement frameworks to ensure they do not undermine environmental, social, or human rights protections. Global Gateway and external action: Ireland should ensure that the Global Gateway strategy and EU external action uphold human rights, environmental standards, and democratic values. Civil society in Europe and the Global South has so far had minimal participation, undermining transparency and accountability. The Presidency can lead efforts to embed meaningful stakeholder engagement, public scrutiny, and impact monitoring, ensuring that decision-making is guided by both European and, crucially, Global South civil society. A UN Treaty on Business and Human Rights: The Presidency must take a position in support of a strong UN Binding Treaty on Business and Human Rights (UNBT), championing the priorities of Global South civil society groups to ensure enforceable corporate accountability, effective remedies for affected communities, and the inclusion of human rights considerations in all corporate-related EU legislation. “28th Regime” and human rights enforcement: The Presidency must prioritise embedding human rights and social protections into EU regulatory initiatives, including new financial or investment frameworks (sometimes referred to as the “28th regime”), ensuring that human rights due diligence is central to corporate and investment activities.

organisation: Irish Coalition for Business and Human Rights
geography: The ICBHR is concerned with both the national and EU-wide context, and how these contexts impact upon the regulation of transnational companies in relation to human rights and environmental harm, as well as ensuring access to justice for those impacted by corporate abuse of human rights and the environment.
response_text: The Irish Presidency can make the greatest positive impact by ensuring that EU policymaking centres on people, communities, environmental protection and climate action rather than prioritising business and growth in all aspects of its policymaking. This requires strengthening rights protections, engaging with rightsholders, safeguarding democratic processes, and ensuring that laws already in place deliver meaningful outcomes. 1. Put human rights, workers’ rights and environmental safeguards at the centre of Council work For people and communities to benefit, EU legislation must maintain the highest possible standards of protection. The Irish Presidency can play a decisive role by ensuring that Council discussions prioritise workers and communities affected by corporate harm, and those most vulnerable to climate breakdown and environmental degradation. A rights-centred Council agenda will help ensure that EU law offers protection for individuals negatively impacted by the activities of corporate actors. 2. Rebuild trust in democratic processes Recent years have seen growing public concern about opaque processes, last-minute amendments, and undue corporate influence. The European Ombudsman recently decided that the Commission’s undemocratic environmental rollbacks through Omnibus I amounted to “maladministration”. Enhancing transparency, meaningfully engaging with rightsholders, improving access to documents, and clearly communicating Member State positions would help improve democratic legitimacy. 3. Ensure that laws already adopted work in practice Ireland must lead on strong implementation and enforcement of existing human rights, labour and environmental laws, including resisting efforts to delay or weaken enforcement obligations. 4. Protect remaining standards on human rights and environmental protection Ireland must guarantee that no further laws are eroded through deregulatory processes that prioritise business interests and “competitiveness” and degrade legal certainty for those impacted by corporate abuse. 5. Protect civil society space so that policymaking reflects real needs Ireland must begin to defend civil society space throughout Council processes and ensuring diverse stakeholder engagement to address power imbalances, counteract undue corporate influence and ensure that the experiences of workers and communities impacted by corporate abuse are reflected and protected in EU-lawmaking.

organisation: Irish Coalition for Business and Human Rights
geography: The ICBHR is concerned with both the national and EU-wide context, and how these contexts impact upon the regulation of transnational companies in relation to human rights and environmental harm, as well as ensuring access to justice for those impacted by corporate abuse of human rights and the environment.
response_text: Ireland’s Presidency can best communicate the values and benefits of EU membership by ensuring that EU policies are shaped in a way that directly reflects citizens’ needs and priorities and places workers and communities at the centre of its agenda. It must ensure that the EU’s Strategic Agenda commitment to “‘reduce the bureaucratic and regulatory burden at all levels” does not continue to impinge on the rights of workers and communities or on the aim of achieving a just and fair climate transition. Meaningful engagement with stakeholders including civil society organisations, trade unions, local communities, and vulnerable groups is essential to demonstrate that the EU works for the people it represents, not just for business interests. Irish media has highlighted concerns about the privileging of corporate interests over civil society and unions in EU legislative processes, including around the Omnibus I simplification package, with internal lobbying strategies by multinational firms exposed in leaked files. Civil society plays a vital role in safeguarding the public good. Unlike private actors accountable to shareholders, civil society represents the collective interests of citizens, advocating for human rights, social justice, environmental protection, and fair labour standards. Ireland’s Presidency can lead by example by systematically including civil society and citizen representatives in Council discussions, consultations, and preparatory working groups, ensuring that EU decisions reflect diverse perspectives and lived experiences. A concrete step would be to institutionalise structured dialogues with stakeholders on key EU initiatives, making these engagements transparent and actionable. For instance, during negotiations of legislation such as Omnibus I, the exclusion of civil society eroded trust. By actively creating spaces where workers, local communities, and civil society organisations can influence policy outcomes, Ireland’s Presidency can show that EU decision-making is participatory, inclusive, and responsive.

organisation: Irish Coalition for Business and Human Rights
geography: The ICBHR is concerned with both the national and EU-wide context, and how these contexts impact upon the regulation of transnational companies in relation to human rights and environmental harm, as well as ensuring access to justice for those impacted by corporate abuse of human rights and the environment.
response_text: The EU should adopt a clear and ambitious mandate to support the negotiation of a strong, legally binding UN treaty on business and human rights that ensures transnational corporations are held accountable for human rights abuses and environmental harm. A robust treaty is necessary to close the accountability gaps left by voluntary standards and fragmented national laws, and to provide real access to remedy for affected communities, particularly in the Global South, where corporate impacts are most acute. This approach complements the EU’s own due diligence initiatives while amplifying the voices and priorities of Global South groups who are leading calls for enforceable international standards, effective extraterritorial regulation, and mechanisms that safeguard human rights defenders and gender-responsive protections.

From our perspective, and acknowledging the role the Republic of Ireland plays in these topics, we would like to propose the following priorities: − Enhancing animal health in the Union, by increasing the availability of high-quality veterinary vaccines and therapeutics, reducing the administrative burden that may affect their availability, and prioritising initiatives that can boost innovation (such as the Biotech Act) − Creating a climate that fosters sustainable manufacturing in the EU with a view on strategic autonomy, in particular for veterinary vaccines and (bio)pharmaceuticals. Apart from the Omnibus initiatives, this would include a review of horizontal legislation interfering with sectoral legislation or even with each other (e.g. the EUDR, the PPWR and certain restrictions under REACH, such as the PFAS restriction).

There is a need to streamline EU legislation in general and reduce the administrative burden, which is one of the stated aims of the various Omnibus efforts currently ongoing. However, it seems that the current approach is rather fragmented, with a lack of attention to which impacts cross-sectoral legislation may have on specific sectors. For example, while it is recognised that veterinary medicines availability in the EU already is an issue, restrictions under REACH may have a profound impact on our ability to innovate or even manufacture and supply existing veterinary medicines, vaccines and biopharmaceuticals in the EU. New legislation such as the EUDR and the PPWR is imposing an unprecedented administrative burden on several sectors including veterinary medicines, which once more may affect medicines availability, especially those with limited markets. Therefore, an overarching review of potential unintended consequences of these separate legislations, even when simplified, would be welcomed. The long-awaited REACH proposal may also present opportunities. By the same token, there are legislative activities which may boost innovation in the EU, for example the Biotech Act currently under preparation. Support from the Irish Presidency for a comprehensive, cross‑sectoral Act aiming for biotechnology to seamlessly move from the laboratory to the market would be welcomed. A comprehensive Biotech Act must ensure veterinary innovation is fully within its scope under a One Health approach. Another area of focus that could support availability and access to medicines is the digital, data and AI space where discussion on the EU-wide adoption of eLeaflets for medicines and AI approaches to support manufacturing and enhancing R&D and regulatory productivity could all bring benefits. EU Biotech Act: The Presidency should steer the Council’s work toward a cross‑sectoral approach, which explicitly includes veterinary biotech and provides proportionate and science-based tools shortening time‑to‑access without lowering safety. REACH Proposal: Under the current legislation, medicines are exempt from authorisation, but not from restrictions. This is creating numerous issues, mostly at our manufacturing sites. In many cases, substitution is not (legally) possible, and restrictions therefore can severely disrupt manufacturing and supply of medicines – with proposed restrictions potentially driving manufacturing completely out of the EEA. Exempting medicines and their manufacturing from restrictions and maintaining the benefit-risk approach from Reg 2019/6 would be a solution to these issues. Antimicrobial Resistance (AMR): The Presidency should make AMR a top priority under a One Health approach and drive full implementation of the 2023 Council Recommendations to strengthen stewardship, surveillance and innovation across veterinary and food‑producing sectors. The Presidency should explore mechanisms to support and accelerate R&D and regulatory approval of medicines and tools that address AMR.

For farmers, vets, and animal owners: Faster, more predictable access to preventive biologics and innovative therapies improves animal health, welfare and productivity, stabilises food supply, and reduces AMR pressures. The focus should be in policies that reduce timelines to support solutions reaching veterinarians and livestock farmers. For businesses (and employment): Strong support for innovation in the EU (e.g. a truly cross‑sector Biotech Act), and coherent horizontal chemical and environmental legislation (e.g. REACH, PPWR, EURD and others) will sustain investment and manufacturing in Europe. Zoetis’ footprint in the EU (R&D centres, mAb and API production sites in Ireland, Belgium, Spain, Germany, Italy, Denmark and Norway) shows Europe’s capacity to innovate for the EU citizens and export innovation globally when the regulatory environment is predictable.

Healthy animals are essential to society – from healthy, productive livestock contributing to a safe, secure food supply to healthy pets whose companionship enrich our lives at home. In Europe, approximately half of the citizens live with a pet, meanwhile 94% of pet owners globally consider their pets to be part of their family. This is a clear signal that the human-animal bond is both mainstream and relevant to everyday wellbeing and social cohesion. Loneliness is now recognised as a public-health priority. Evidence shows that contact with companion animals can reduce loneliness, relieve stress and anxiety, and support health ageing, complementing social care and mental health strategies. Surveys have found that in Europe 85% of respondents believe that interaction with a companion animal can help reduce loneliness. Additionally, a study showed that adult pet owners have about 15% fewer annual doctors visits than non-owners. Against this context, the human-animal bond (HAB) is a practical, people-centred approach for EU policymaking. The HAB is the mutually beneficial, dynamic relationship between people and companion animals. This relationship is shaped by behaviours that are essential to the health and wellbeing of both. Viewed through policy, HAB offers a practical, people‑centred lens because its benefits span mental, physical and social health for families and communities, while also improving animal welfare. The Irish Council Presidency has the opportunity to champion initiatives that can help realise the HAB and improve conditions for both humans and pets by: Making Europe more pet‑inclusive by addressing structural barriers that prevent people from realising the benefits of the HAB, such as housing policies. The EU could promote pet‑friendly standards and guidance and encourage Member States and cities to pilot pet‑inclusive urban programmes. Improving access to veterinary care and better support veterinarians. This could include targeted support for underserved communities, better affordable care options, and innovations in how veterinary services are delivered (e.g. through better digital solutions). Embedding One Health-One Welfare thinking in social and public health policy. For instance, by considering companion animals in disaster preparedness and public health strategies, preventing families to choose between safety and their animals. Access the Zoetis Human-Animal Bond Handbook here.

Building a European Future via Cooperation. Education, Dialogue , Innovation and (CEDI) The general theme is up to the government to choose, but the above captures many themes. I want to show why the Erasmus+ Program at TU Dublin, which will take place from 1st-3rd July (and a bit longer if we can get more funding), acts as a wonderful opportunity for the Government to showcase these features in terms of what TU Dublin has got right in working with colleagues in institutes across Europe for the last four years.
See Question 1and 2 .

Showing young people from different counties working together to solve future EU and world issues is the best way to communicate this. See following link of the BIP in Darmstadt . [REDACTED UNDER GDPR] Some photos shown below [REDACTED UNDER GDPR]

Please see this project as an exceptional showcase opportunity that promotes numerous successes: TU Dublin's excellence, international collaboration, the Erasmus scheme's impact, cutting-edge engineering education, and advanced ESA OSNMA technology. Building on three years of proven success in Valencia, Cluj, and Darmstadt, a superbly organized ( and adequately funded ) Dublin event with strong government support will highlight the very best of the EU, Ireland, and TU Dublin on the world stage.

The Irish Presidency should prioritize the development of Distributed Networks for Innovation, Competitiveness through Openness, and Cybersecurity via Global Intelligence. Distributed Networks for Innovation: To enable innovation in Europe, the networks of the future need to be distributed, interoperable, and highly interconnected. Surging advances in artificial intelligence (AI) and evolving infrastructure demands are coinciding to define the Internet’s next frontier. The success of the European innovation economy relies on robust, universal connectivity that can handle massive machine-to-machine exchanges, as well as on distributed edge networks to enable very low latency interactions. Public policy should support the development of these distributed networks without creating barriers to innovation or artificial hurdles. The EU needs a seamless integration of the ecosystem, where traffic flows smoothly to consumers without regulatory barriers that fragment the Internet. Competitiveness through Openness: The EU must close its innovation gap to regain its competitiveness on the world stage. This requires an economy where companies and individual developers can easily build new applications that everyone wants and needs. The Presidency should support the Commission’s objective to simplify and streamline EU legislation in the digital policy space. The focus should be on creating less regulation and red tape, not more. A competitive digital ecosystem depends on openness, choice, and interoperability. Protectionist measures and limiting choice toEU-only solutions risk causing economic stagnation, reducing resilience and security, and increasing costs for European businesses. Cybersecurity via Global Intelligence: Effective cybersecurity protection inherently requires a global network and reach. Cyber threats are growing each year, and distributed networks play an important role in stopping attacks close to where they originated. "Sovereignty" in this context should mean the freedom to choose the most secure and interoperable systems. Policies must allow European entities to leverage global datasets of malicious cyber indicators to effectively detect and mitigate risks using AI and machine learning, rather than being limited by non-technical geographical restrictions.

The Irish Presidency should focus on ensuring the Digital Networks Act (DNA), Cloud and AI Development Act (CAIDA), and the Cybersecurity Act (CSA) revision support innovation and avoid unnecessary interventions. Digital Networks Act (DNA): The Presidency should recognize that the IP interconnection market in Europe is healthy, sustainable, and competitive. Regulatory intervention, such as dispute resolution mechanisms, would act as "network fees through the backdoor" and increase costs for European businesses. The Presidency should caution against such heavy-handed intervention and instead focus on streamlining and simplifying existing obligations to facilitate high-quality connectivity in Europe. Expanding the scope of telecom rules to cloud and content delivery networks would lead to increased costs for operators and end users, less incentives to invest in infrastructure and be contrary to the goals of simplification and reducing red tape. Cloud and AI Development Act (CAIDA): European companies need sustained access to fast and reliable distributed edge networks to reap the benefits of AI innovation. To strengthen the EU’s cloud and AI capabilities, the Presidency should prioritize an approach that fosters an open, competitive, and innovative digital ecosystem. This means promoting freedom of choice, interoperability, and diversification over forced localization or strict establishment criteria. The Presidency should encourage "multi-model" AI strategies and multi-cloud architectures to prevent vendor lock-in and ensure resilience. Public procurement rules should encourage competition and the ability to use the best service for the government's needs, avoiding non-technical exclusion criteria. Cybersecurity Act (CSA) Revision: For the CSA revision, the Presidency should aim for targeted regulatory intervention that makes the adoption process of European cybersecurity certification schemes more open, transparent, and inclusive. Crucially, the Presidency must ensure that certification schemes are strictly limited to technical requirements. Non-technical "sovereignty" criteria, such as ownership restrictions or data localization, should be explicitly excluded, as they can harm cybersecurity by limiting the ability to pool global threat intelligence and mitigate large-scale attacks.

The Council can make a substantial positive impact by fostering an environment where digital infrastructure is efficient, secure, and sustainable, directly benefiting people, businesses, and communities. ● For Businesses and Innovation By prioritizing distributed edge capabilities, the Council can empower European organizations to make their employees, applications, and networks faster and more secure everywhere. Businesses need the right conditions to flourish, including access to non-gated and open-source AI models and global infrastructure. Removing unnecessary red tape and avoiding new administrative burdens, such as extending telecom rules to cloud and content delivery networks, will allow European startups and SMEs to focus on innovation rather than compliance. A pro-competition environment that avoids vendor lock-in will lower costs and improve access to world-class technologies. For Security and Resilience The Council can best achieve these goals not through forced localisation or protectionism, but through a commitment to multi-cloud architectures, open standards, interoperability, and a competitive, non-discriminatory market. True sovereignty is realised through freedom of choice and a diversified, resilient supply chain can protect communities by ensuring governments and businesses have access to best in class technologies. For People and Communities The networks of the future will bring computing power closer to the end-user, slashing latency and enabling innovation in real-time applications like autonomous vehicles and advanced healthcare tools. Supporting the development of distributed edge networks also advances the EU’s sustainability goals. Edge computing mitigates concerns regarding the geographical concentration of large data centers and their associated strain on local natural resources, such as energy and water. By processing data closer to the source, these networks improve energy efficiency and reduce the environmental footprint of digital services.
