geography: RGDATA’s members trade nationally but are significantly impacted by EU considerations. At an EU level, RGDATA is part of Independent Retail Europe (IRE)
response_text: From the perspective of RGDATA, we believe that the high level thematic priorities for the Presidency should include; Local economies & vibrant communities - Strengthening local economies by advocating policies and initiatives that support SME businesses and contribute to vibrant local communities. Fair rules - Ensure proportionate, fair and workable rules on the circular economy, food chain fairness and digital markets. Reduced regulatory burden Support a reduction in administrative and regulatory targets. Regeneration - Guide EU considerations on town centre regeneration towards creating and supporting sustainable, viable and dynamic local communities. Tackling Retail Crime – take an EU-wide approach to identify best initiatives to reduce retail crime including shoplifting; abuse of retail staff and fraud.

geography: RGDATA’s members trade nationally but are significantly impacted by EU considerations. At an EU level, RGDATA is part of Independent Retail Europe (IRE)
response_text: RGDATA believes that the policy and legislative proposals to be a focus of work for the Irish Presidency in 2026 should include; A. Fair and Resilient Grocery Supply Chains Update of Unfair Trading Practices (UTP) rules in the food chain (Q3 2026) Opportunity to strengthen protections for small retailers and suppliers, address buyer power, and improve transparency in the agri-food supply chain. Late Payment Regulation (pending) Critical for SME cashflow. Ireland should promote a balanced, workable approach that tackles harmful late payments while preserving necessary flexibility in the food sector. B. Strengthening Town-Centre Viability and Local Economies Initiative on Short-Term Rentals (Q2 2026) Town-centre footfall and retail diversity rely on stable resident populations. Ireland can steer Council work towards stronger local-authority tools, better data-sharing, and a balanced approach to tourism and housing. European Strategy for Sustainable Tourism (Q2 2026) An Irish Presidency could emphasise living town centres, integrating retail, culture and community into European tourism thinking. Construction Services Act (Q4 2026) Potential to support urban regeneration, renovation of vacant premises and reuse of upper floors in town centres. Ireland can advocate explicit recognition of regeneration and mixed-use objectives. C. A Competitive and Fair Single Market for SMEs and Local Retail Circular Economy Act (Q3 2026) A flagship file likely to open under the Irish Presidency. High relevance for packaging, waste, reuse and EPR schemes, which disproportionately affect small retailers. Ireland can champion SME-sensitive implementation and ensure rules support viable, circular town centres. European Product Act & Market Surveillance Updates (Q3 2026) Important for a level playing field between high-street shops and online platforms through stronger enforcement against non-compliant imports and marketplace sellers. EU Delivery Act (postal and parcel services) (Q3 2026) Affects the cost and competitiveness of e-commerce for small retailers. Ireland can promote fair access and non-discriminatory parcel pricing for SMEs. Digital Fairness Act (Q4 2026) Relevant where online platforms compete with local retailers. Strong rules on dark patterns, ranking transparency and misleading pricing will help ensure fair competition. D. Horizontal SME Competitiveness and Better Regulation Public Procurement Act (Q2 2026) Ireland can advocate for simpler procurement procedures and better SME access, including for local retail and food businesses in public catering and community services. Omnibus Taxation Package & SME Tax Files (e.g., Head Office Tax System) Opportunity to reduce administrative burdens and compliance costs for SMEs. Administrative Burden Reduction Targets The Commission plans significant simplification in areas such as environment, food and feed safety, and taxation. Ireland can push for practical, sector-specific simplification benefiting small retailers.

geography: RGDATA’s members trade nationally but are significantly impacted by EU considerations. At an EU level, RGDATA is part of Independent Retail Europe (IRE)
response_text: Ensure that measures taken at Council level, which by their nature can be very high level given the application across 27 Member States, are positioned in a way that they can directly relate to the daily lives of EU citizens rather than pitched constantly at macro level. At a very practical level and in the context of the focus of RGDATA, to achieve this, the Irish Presidency can focus on;  Champion an “SME and Town-Centre First” approach across relevant Council formations, including Competitiveness, Agriculture/Fisheries, Environment, Ecofin and Telecom.  Ensure new rules on circular economy, food-chain fairness, and digital markets are proportionate and workable for independent retailers.  Advance Council conclusions on town-centre regeneration, linking EU legislation, cohesion policy and sustainability goals to vibrant local economies.  Promote balanced, competitive market conditions between bricks-and-mortar retailers and large online platforms.  Embed territorial and community impacts into negotiations on short-term rentals, tourism and regeneration measures.

geography: RGDATA’s members trade nationally but are significantly impacted by EU considerations. At an EU level, RGDATA is part of Independent Retail Europe (IRE)
response_text: This can be achieved by a range of different approaches; Ensuring that the practical benefits and positive implications of co-ordinated EU measures and activities are adequately conveyed to citizens in member states, through engagement with relevant civic, community and business networks Ensuring that the work of Irish Ministers and officials in supporting the Presidency during the 6 month period is highlighted domestically and fully understood. Ensuring that Ireland’s MEPs communicate effectively on their activities and engagements particularly during the Presidency. From an Irish perspective to ensure that positive developments in Ireland that have a wider resonance are showcased during the course of the Presidency – we have much to be proud of from our indigenous food and independent retail sector that should be showcased.

geography: RGDATA’s members trade nationally but are significantly impacted by EU considerations. At an EU level, RGDATA is part of Independent Retail Europe (IRE)
response_text: Independent retailers and town centres are core to Ireland’s social and economic fabric. The 2026 EU legislative agenda presents a unique opportunity for Ireland to guide the Council toward policies that ensure fairness in the grocery supply chain, revitalise town centres, and support SME competitiveness across the EU.

organisation: Move EU - The European Association of On-Demand Mobility
response_text: Ride-hailing - digital platforms that connect passengers with licensed private hire vehicles (PHVs) - has become an essential part of daily mobility for millions of Europeans. It provides flexible, on-demand transport, improves connectivity where public transport is limited, and supports greener mobility through high utilisation and rapid fleet electrification. Yet the experience for passengers varies widely across the EU because services remain governed by fragmented, pre-digital rules. These inconsistencies directly affect consumers through longer waiting times, higher prices and uneven availability. Ireland’s Presidency offers an opportunity to focus on themes that strengthen the Single Market, support the green and digital transitions and improve the regulatory environment for digital services. These priorities are central to ensuring the EU remains competitive, cohesive and capable of delivering tangible benefits to citizens and businesses. 1. Enhancing the Single Market for citizens and businesses The Single Market remains one of the EU’s most powerful assets, yet is still held back by administrative and regulatory barriers, especially in services. Removing unnecessary national obstacles is essential for economic cohesion and for ensuring citizens and businesses can benefit fully from cross-border opportunities. Sector example: In passenger mobility, the Single Market does not yet operate as intended. A person may use the same ride-hailing app anywhere in Europe, but the service received can differ dramatically depending on local rules. In some cities, a vehicle arrives within minutes; in others, passengers face long waits due to restrictions such as return-to-garage rules, licence caps or advance booking requirements. These inconsistencies create uncertainty for consumers and limit competitiveness. A Presidency priority on strengthening the Single Market for services would help align rules, reduce fragmentation and ensure citizens can expect accessible, predictable and affordable services wherever they travel. 2. Advancing a competitive, green and digital transition Europe’s transition to a more sustainable and digital economy requires coordinated action. Mobility services - public transport, taxis, PHVs and emerging digital solutions - play a key role in reducing emissions, improving efficiency and enabling multimodal travel. Sector example: When operational rules allow drivers to operate efficiently, mobility services can reduce empty kilometres, accelerate electrification and strengthen first- and last-mile connections. Removing outdated restrictions improves environmental outcomes and user experience. A Presidency focus on supporting competitive, sustainable mobility ecosystems would reinforce EU objectives on climate, innovation and digitalisation. 3. Improving regulation for digital services Digital services are integral to how citizens interact with transport, accommodation, retail and public services. Ensuring that rules remain transparent, coherent and future-proof is essential for maintaining trust and enabling innovation. EU legislation such as the Digital Services Act, AI Act and Platform Work Directive introduces important standards for transparency and accountability. However, fragmented national implementation risks creating divergent rules and an uneven experience for users. A Presidency priority on consistent, transparent and user-centred digital regulation would help ensure platforms meet clear expectations across the EU, consumers benefit from reliable information, and the Single Market remains a competitive environment for digital innovation.

organisation: Move EU - The European Association of On-Demand Mobility
response_text: The European Commission has acknowledged the importance of removing barriers in the services sector through its 2025 Single Market Strategy, which highlights the need to address long-standing bottlenecks that restrict cross-border provision of services. As Presidency, Ireland should build on this momentum by initiating Council Conclusions on the actions required to complete the Single Market, with a particular emphasis on sectors where fragmentation is most visible to citizens - such as mobility and digitally enabled transport services. These conclusions should identify priority areas for reducing administrative burdens, ensuring regulatory coherence, and bringing services more fully into the Single Market framework. Within this broader effort, the Irish Presidency should focus specifically on the persistent fragmentation affecting private hire vehicles (PHVs) and ride-hailing services. The Commission’s Notice on well-functioning and sustainable passenger transport-on-demand already acknowledges that outdated, disproportionate national and local rules impede the sector’s ability to support EU mobility, competitiveness and climate objectives. Yet progress remains limited, and Member States continue to apply divergent rules that undermine the functioning of the Single Market. This fragmentation has significant implications for citizens and businesses. By 2030, around 190 million Europeans are expected to use ride-hailing services, and each €1 spent generates €1.10 in wider economic value - supporting tourism, local commerce and service sector employment. Ride-hailing vehicles also electrify twice as fast as private cars and emit 34% less CO₂ per kilometre, demonstrating clear alignment with EU climate ambitions. However, the sector cannot realise these benefits fully under the current patchwork of rules, which increase waiting times, raise prices and limit availability in suburban and underserved areas. Advancing modern, coherent rules for PHVs The Irish Presidency should therefore ensure progress on a Council-led process to reduce fragmentation in passenger mobility services. This should form part of the Presidency’s broader Single Market agenda and include the following elements: ● Follow up the Single Market Strategy with Council Conclusions identifying regulatory barriers in PHV markets and outlining the steps needed for modernisation and coherence across Member States. Promote mutual recognition of professional licences, allowing qualified drivers to operate across administrative boundaries without repeated or duplicative processes. Address outdated entry requirements, such as legacy map-reading exams or paper-based procedures, which slow down market entry and reduce service availability. Ensure operational rules are proportionate and evidence-based, including booking-time requirements, return-to-garage obligations, lane access rules and other local restrictions that currently distort competition. Guarantee consistent treatment of traditional taxis and digital intermediaries, avoiding regulatory asymmetries that create inefficiencies for consumers. Practical benefit for citizens: shorter waiting times better availability during peak hours more affordable rides Improved coverage in suburban and rural areas more efficient, lower-emission operations in urban centres

organisation: Move EU - The European Association of On-Demand Mobility
response_text: The work of the Council during the Irish Presidency can deliver substantial, visible improvements by addressing the regulatory fragmentation that affects mobility services across Europe. A coordinated EU approach would make a real difference for people, businesses, and communities, particularly in how they access and benefit from daily transport. 1. Impact for People (passengers and citizens) Across the EU, passengers face inconsistent service levels because local rules restrict the supply of licensed private hire vehicles (PHVs) and create artificial delays. These barriers translate directly into higher prices, longer waiting times and reduced reliability - especially for those who depend on on-demand transport outside major city centres. Issues affecting people today: Higher prices caused by licence caps and limited supply. Longer waits due to mandatory pre-booking times (e.g., 3-hour minimum booking in Greece, making spontaneous trips impossible). Reduced availability, especially at peak times or in suburban areas. Limited accessibility, as rules restrict PHV pick-up points or access to lanes used by taxis (e.g., Brussels, where passengers cannot be picked up directly at train stations). Uneven safety and convenience, particularly for women, late-night travellers, and those with reduced mobility. Benefits of EU-level action: A more coherent framework across Member States would mean shorter waiting times, more predictable service, more competitive pricing and better accessibility for vulnerable groups. Passengers would experience reliable mobility regardless of where they travel in the EU. 2. Impact for businesses (drivers, SMEs and platforms) Drivers and mobility businesses face significant administrative burdens due to fragmented licensing, duplicative exams and inconsistent operational rules. Issues affecting businesses today: High entry barriers (multiple licences, lengthy exams, outdated requirements). Operational inefficiencies such as forced return-to-garage rules, creating unnecessary empty kilometres. Uneven competitiveness where traditional taxis and PHVs operate under different obligations. Difficulty scaling across regions, especially when rules change between neighbouring municipalities. These barriers reduce earning opportunities for drivers and undermine innovation for platforms and SMEs. Benefits of EU-level action: Proportionate, evidence-based rules would reduce red tape, allow drivers to work more efficiently, and increase income potential. For example, removing return-to-garage obligations can reduce empty kilometres by up to 40%, improving both driver earnings and passenger availability. A more predictable Single Market also supports SMEs offering dispatch, fleet, or mobility-related services. 3. Impact for communities (cities, regions and local economies) Fragmented rules affect not only individuals and businesses but the wider functioning of cities. Issues affecting communities today: Congestion and pollution, driven by inefficient operational requirements. Reduced accessibility, especially in areas with limited public transport. Slower transitions to clean mobility, as today’s restrictions discourage fleet electrification. Lost economic potential for tourism, hospitality and nightlife. Benefits of EU-level action: Smart, harmonised rules - such as allowing continuous operation instead of empty returns and ensuring PHVs can use the same priority lanes as taxis - lead to fewer unnecessary kilometres, cleaner air and more efficient traffic flows. Improved mobility also supports local businesses, cultural venues, airports, hotels and tourism, making cities more welcoming for residents and visitors alike.

organisation: Move EU - The European Association of On-Demand Mobility
response_text: A powerful way to communicate the values and benefits of EU membership is to show that Europe delivers practical improvements in citizens’ everyday lives. When the EU removes barriers, simplifies rules and creates a true Single Market, people feel the results directly: services become more reliable, prices fall, and opportunities expand. A strong example is aviation liberalisation, where common EU rules opened air travel to citizens across Europe. Flights became cheaper, faster and safer, competition increased, and Europeans could suddenly move freely across the continent. It also enabled Irish companies - such as Ryanair - to grow into European champions, connecting smaller cities, boosting tourism and supporting local economies. This is Europe at its best: harmonisation that delivers clear benefits for citizens while empowering businesses to scale across borders. Ireland’s Presidency can use this narrative - Europe that delivers - to illustrate why deepening the Single Market remains central to people’s daily experiences. Just as aviation harmonisation transformed long-distance travel, a modern approach to mobility services can improve how people move within and between cities. Whether heading to an early hospital appointment, getting home safely after an evening out, or accessing transport where public options are limited, millions of Europeans depend on reliable mobility - but today their experience varies widely because of fragmented rules. Demonstrating that EU coordination can make mobility more available, affordable and sustainable helps citizens see how the EU directly improves their daily options. Human stories make these benefits tangible. A parent getting home faster because transport is more predictable; an older resident accessing dependable door-to-door mobility; someone in a rural or suburban area finally having access to transport after public services end for the day - these examples show how EU action supports inclusion, safety and convenience. They help citizens understand that EU policymaking is not abstract but something that can make everyday life easier. Ireland can also highlight how EU-wide digital legislation - from the Digital Services Act to platform transparency rules - protects consumers and workers by ensuring clear information, accountability and safeguards across borders. Many citizens do not realise that the transparency they expect when they book travel, order a service or use a digital platform is guaranteed by common EU rules. Making this link explicit strengthens trust and demonstrates the real-world value of EU membership. Finally, a sense of ownership can be built through local engagement and concrete evidence. Presenting before-and-after improvements - such as shorter waiting times, more accessible mobility for people with reduced mobility, or increased availability of electric vehicles - allows citizens to see the results of EU coordination in their own communities. When improvements are visible and practical, people feel pride in Ireland’s role and greater confidence in the EU as a project that delivers for them.

organisation: Move EU - The European Association of On-Demand Mobility
response_text: The attached study, Green Lights for Growth - How Smart Ride-Hailing Rules Can Accelerate Europe (October 2025), examines how outdated and inconsistent national rules across the EU limit the availability, affordability and sustainability of ride-hailing services. It highlights the significant cost of regulatory fragmentation and identifies the economic, social and environmental benefits that a more harmonised approach could unlock. Ride-hailing is used daily by millions of Europeans and is projected to reach 190 million users by 2030. The sector already contributes substantially to the wider economy: every €1 spent on a trip generates €1.10 in broader economic value, supporting local businesses, tourism and tens of thousands of indirect jobs. It is also a fast route to greener mobility, with ride-hailing fleets electrifying twice as quickly as private cars in many cities. However, progress is constrained by a patchwork of pre-digital rules. In two-thirds of Member States, barriers such as licence caps, long licensing processes, mandatory “return-to-garage” requirements, minimum fares or restrictions on booking times reduce the number of available drivers and inflate costs for consumers. This results in longer waiting times, reduced availability at peak hours, and higher prices - especially affecting people who rely on ride-hailing at night, in suburban areas, or where public transport options are limited. The study draws on new modelling by Ricardo, showing the scale of the opportunity if Europe were to modernise and align its rules: ● Create up to 219,000 additional driver income opportunities could be created in six cities alone if licence caps were removed. Driver incomes could rise by 5-10% where unnecessary operational restrictions (like return-to-garage rules) are eliminated. CO₂ emissions could fall by up to 29% in cities where empty kilometres are significantly reduced. Sector revenues could increase by 11% in cities where pricing restrictions are relaxed and supply can better meet demand. These findings illustrate that smarter regulation - not deregulation - can deliver significant improvements in service availability, driver earnings and environmental performance. To address these challenges, the study recommends three actions: Develop an EU-wide framework for ride-hailing and taxi services to ensure consistent, modern rules across Member States. Create a level playing field by aligning rights and obligations for taxis and ride-hailing, removing outdated restrictions that distort competition and reduce consumer choice. Promote upfront pricing as a European standard, ensuring passengers have transparent, predictable fares before they book. Overall, the study concludes that Europe has a clear opportunity to build a more connected, efficient and sustainable mobility market. Harmonisation would make services more reliable and affordable for citizens, improve working conditions for drivers and support EU objectives on competitiveness, inclusion and the green transition.

Taking into account the current geopolitical and socioeconomic context in Europe, we recommend that Ireland prioritise Health Protection, Citizen Safety, and Resilient Societies as core themes of its 2026 Presidency. Serious allergies and anaphylaxis are rising across Europe and place a growing burden on individuals, schools, workplaces, and public services. Addressing them fits naturally within broader objectives to protect citizens’ wellbeing and reduce preventable health risks. A Resilient and Prepared Europe The EU must be equipped to respond to emergencies—whether acute health events, natural disasters, or public safety threats. This requires harmonised emergency response systems, stronger communitylevel preparedness, and cross-border cooperation. Ireland is one of the few Member States that has taken concrete steps to improve preparedness for serious allergic reactions, including allowing pharmacists to supply emergency medicines without a prescription during anaphylactic events. This national practice demonstrates effective emergency readiness and provides a model for EU-level policy coordination, which could inform upcoming initiatives under the European Health Union framework aimed at strengthening preparedness, prevention, and rapid response across Member States. A People-Centred Union that Protects Embedding people-centred principles into EU policymaking ensures that vulnerable populations and individuals at risk of medical emergencies are not left behind. The Presidency could advance reducing health inequalities across the EU, highlighting uneven access to diagnosis, specialist care, and emergency response protocols. Positioning timely care for serious allergies and anaphylaxis within this agenda demonstrates a commitment to practical, measurable improvements in patient safety and inclusion, while protecting citizens’ rights to safety in everyday environments such as schools, childcare centres, workplaces, and public venues. 3. A Future-Oriented Europe Built on Innovation and Collaboration Ireland’s strong reputation in digital innovation offers an opportunity to promote Digital Innovation for Health, leveraging the European Health Data Space and interoperable, patient-centred tools. For individuals at risk of serious allergic reactions, seamless access to medical information across borders can prevent emergencies and support the free movement of people. The Presidency can also prioritise harmonised awareness-raising, institutional readiness, and capacity building, ensuring schools, businesses, and public institutions are equipped and trained to respond effectively to life-threatening health incidents.

Ireland could use its Presidency to champion health resilience, citizen protection, and emergency preparedness, leveraging its national leadership in anaphylaxis response as a model for EU coordination. Key priorities include: Health Protection and Emergency Preparedness Serious allergies and anaphylaxis present a growing public-health challenge. The Presidency could: Promote timely access to emergency medicines, building on Ireland’s approach where pharmacists can supply life-saving treatment without prescription. Encourage harmonised school and public-venue preparedness, using Ireland as an example. Relevant upcoming EU initiative: Global health resilience initiative (non-legislative, Q2 2026) – to strengthen EU capacity for rapid response to health crises. Digital Innovation for Health Cross-border emergencies require seamless access to patient data: Promote the European Health Data Space for secure, interoperable sharing of health information, enabling faster response to anaphylactic events across borders. Support digital tools for citizen-centred care, enhancing emergency response and patient safety. 3. Reducing Health Inequalities and Strengthening Citizen Rights The Presidency could advance equitable access to emergency care and citizen-centred policy: Link preparedness to strengthening the Child Guarantee (non-legislative, Q2 2026) and Citizens omnibus (legislative, Q4 2026), ensuring children in schools, childcare centres, and communities are protected and have their rights effectively enforced. Promote intergenerational fairness through the Intergenerational fairness strategy (nonlegislative, Q1 2026), ensuring emergency preparedness and health access benefit current and future generations equally. Highlight Ireland’s model as a practical, replicable approach for other Member States. Objectives Establish a model for EU-level anaphylaxis and emergency response coordination, based on best practices of Ireland. Ensure equitable access to life-saving treatments across the EU. Promote digital innovation for preparedness, information sharing, and cross-border patient care. Strengthen citizen rights and intergenerational fairness, ensuring public health policies reflect social equity. Position health resilience as a pillar of EU citizen safety and social cohesion, demonstrating tangible improvements in public health readiness. By focusing on these targeted initiatives, Ireland can use its Presidency to deliver practical, measurable impacts on citizen safety, health equity, and cross-border emergency preparedness while reinforcing the EU’s social and legal frameworks.

The Irish Presidency has the potential to deliver significant, tangible impact for EU citizens by advancing health resilience and consumer safety. For individuals with serious allergies, policies that improve emergency response, access to medicines, and accurate allergen information can be life-saving. For people, expanded access to emergency treatment, including pharmacy-enabled emergency supply across the EU, enhances safety in daily life. Citizens with serious allergies would be better protected in schools, workplaces, sports facilities, cultural venues, and during cross-border travel. For businesses, harmonised allergen-labelling and staff-training expectations reduce regulatory uncertainty, simplify compliance, and improve consumer trust by fostering safer public environments. For communities and institutions, EU-supported readiness measures ,such as common school protocols, public-venue guidelines, and accessible training ,would significantly reduce preventable emergencies, supporting all three Alliance objectives. Replicating Ireland’s best practice on emergency medicine access would ensure that life-saving intervention is available regardless of where a reaction occurs, reducing inequalities across Member States.

Ireland has a strong opportunity to communicate the value of EU membership by focusing on everyday benefits and practical improvements that resonate directly with citizens. The 2026 Presidency can show how EU cooperation protects people, strengthens communities, and makes daily life safer—particularly in areas such as emergency preparedness for serious allergies and anaphylaxis. Highlight Practical Examples of EU Solidarity Citizens understand the EU best when they see clear, relatable outcomes. Ireland can communicate EU values by highlighting how cooperation improves safety and wellbeing, for example: Safer environments in schools, restaurants, transport and public venues. Shared health information that makes travel within the EU safer and more predictable. Harmonised allergen-labelling rules that protect consumers wherever they are. More consistent access to emergency support for serious allergic reactions. Ireland’s own approach—allowing pharmacists to supply emergency treatment during a serious allergic reaction—provides a concrete example of national leadership that improves citizen safety. Propose Council Recommendations on Emergency Readiness To strengthen public understanding of the EU’s benefits, Ireland could lead on a visible, citizen-centred initiative: Develop Council Recommendations on broader readiness and access to emergency treatment for serious allergy and anaphylaxis. This would help encourage Member States to: Improve preparedness in schools, public venues, workplaces, and transport hubs. Ensure trained responders are available across community settings. Reduce inequalities in access to time-sensitive, life-saving care. Such an initiative is easy for citizens to relate to, directly improves safety, and demonstrates EU cooperation in a human, practical way. A simple message: the EU protects people By showcasing initiatives that make everyday life safer, including better emergency preparedness for serious allergic reactions, the Irish Presidency can reinforce a clear message: EU cooperation delivers real, practical benefits for families, children, workers, and communities. This people-centred framing will strengthen public trust, build ownership, and demonstrate the concrete value of Ireland’s leadership at EU level.

1. Research and Innovation Horizon Europe & Successor Programmes: In context of EU competing with US and China, advocate/demonstrate the value of associate Country participation – specifically UK (Northern Ireland) to EU competitiveness. Cross-border Research Networks: Strengthen partnerships between UK universities, Irish universities, and EU institutions to address grand societal challenges such as climate change, health, AI and digital transformation. In particular ensure the success of the Queen’s University Belfast partnership with the Dundalk Institute of Technology to strengthen all-island academic and economic connectivity in this critical region. Innovation Ecosystems: Promote EU policies that support university-industry collaboration, particularly in advanced manufacturing, life sciences, AI and digital technologies. Remove barriers to innovation through regulatory innovation and ensuring regulatory frameworks can support clinical trials. 2. Education and Mobility Erasmus+ Participation: Encourage mechanisms that sustain student and staff mobility between Northern Ireland, Ireland, and the wider EU. Skills for the Future: Align EU Presidency priorities with the development of green, digital, and entrepreneurial skills, ensuring graduates are equipped for Europe’s evolving labour market. Inclusive Access: Support initiatives that widen participation in international education opportunities, particularly for underrepresented groups. 3. Climate and Sustainability Green Transition: Champion EU Presidency priorities that accelerate the transition to net zero, with universities as key partners in research, innovation, and skills development. Sustainable Campuses: Share best practices from universities’ sustainability strategies, including carbon reduction, biodiversity, and circular economy initiatives. Policy Leadership: Advocate for EU frameworks that integrate academic expertise into climate policymaking and showcase island of Ireland as a testbed for EU renewable technologies.

Peace, Reconciliation, and Civic Engagement Shared Island Initiatives: Leverage the EU Presidency to highlight the role of education and research in fostering reconciliation and cross-community collaboration. Seek EU support to ensure the success of the Queen’s University Belfast ~ Dundalk Institute of Technology partnership. Demographic growth, regional inequality, and expanding economic opportunity particularly within the Dublin–Belfast Corridor create a shared imperative to expand provision, enhance innovation, and strengthen educational pathways. The Queen’s University Belfast ~ Dundalk Institute of Technology partnership aligns closely with national policy priorities in both jurisdictions, including: The need for increased higher education capacity in the Northeast region of Ireland; The desire for more flexible cross-border training, skills development, and research collaboration; The opportunity to strengthen the innovation economy through shared investment and research infrastructure; The importance of accelerating sustainability and climate action initiatives across the island. EU Values and Civic Dialogue: Promote the Presidency as a platform for advancing democratic engagement, human rights, and social cohesion across Europe, highlighting our experience in Ireland of peace building. Border Region Development: Ensure EU policies continue to support sustainable development and cooperation in border regions, building on the success of PEACE and INTERREG programmes. The Queen’s University Belfast ~ Dundalk Institute of Technology partnership has the potential to be transformative in the border region with the ambition of becoming an exemplar for EU members in supporting regional growth, cross-border promotion of innovation and delivering high-quality educational pathways.

Queen’s University Belfast can support Ireland’s EU Presidency by contributing expertise, fostering collaboration, and advancing common interests. We believe that education and research are central to addressing Europe’s challenges and opportunities, and we welcome continued dialogue with the Irish Government to ensure the Presidency delivers lasting impact.

The Neurological Alliance of Ireland understands that Ireland’s 2026 Presidency will need a coherent cross cutting theme that accommodates the files from the previous Presidency but also reflects current and emerging EU priorities across healthcare as they impact on the wider EU economy and society. By choosing “Knowledge Based Healthcare” this theme recognises the unique strengths that Ireland brings as a knowledge based economy to the healthcare challenges facing the EU. We recommend that brain health is featured as a key priority under this theme. Neurological disorders represent one of the most significant health challenges facing the European Union affecting millions of Europeans and carry substantial societal and economic costs. As Europe’s population ages, the prevalence and impact of neurological disease will continue to grow. Neurological disorders affect more than 41% of the global population, are the leading cause of disabilityadjusted life years (DALYs) in Europe and one of the top causes of death. The economic burden, including direct healthcare costs, long-term care, productivity losses, and informal caregiving, has recently been estimated to amount to €1.7 trillion annually within the EU, according to a soon to be published survey by the European Academy of Neurology. Europe’s demographic trajectory will amplify this pressure. Focusing on brain health during the Presidency allows Ireland to push for coordinated EU action in prevention, early detection, research funding, and health-system preparedness. Ireland has a positive narrative to share in terms of developing healthcare policy approaches to the management of neurological disease including clinical frameworks aimed at identifying and responding to these conditions at the earliest stages. Ireland’s growing strength as a hub for advanced neuroscience research positions it to drive innovation and highlight EU-level opportunities for scientific collaboration in this area. Prioritising brain health strongly aligns with several ongoing EU initiatives aimed at strengthening collective resilience against major health challenges, addressing long term care needs for ageing populations, boosting research and innovation and promoting data driven health solutions. Leadership in brain health also aligns with Irish priorities: supporting ageing populations, addressing rare disease, integrating care through Sláintecare reforms, and promoting innovative health technologies while implementing a human rights based approach to the needs of people with disabilities. The EU has endorsed the WHO’s Intersectoral Global Action Plan on Epilepsy & Other Neurological Conditions and the Parliament is pressing the Commission for a dedicated EU brain strategy, in response to the calls of EU wide umbrella organisations including the European Federation of Neurological Associations, the European Brain Council and the European Academy of Neurology with strong support from Irish MEPS who are members of the MEP interest group on brain health and neurological conditions. Ireland has a unique opportunity to position itself as a leader in brain health, responding to the calls of its own citizen advocates at European and national level for greater action to address the needs of people living with neurological conditions while also availing of the opportunity to showcase the best of what our knowledge economy has to offer in mobilising innovative research and technology responses to one of Europe’s greatest healthcare challenges.

The overarching priority for Ireland’s Presidency in 2026 should be to recognise the growing political momentum, strongly supported by Irish MEPs in response to the work of Irish patient advocates and patient organisations at EU level, for a unified response to brain health and neurological conditions. Ireland should use its Presidency to advance the call for an EU wide brain health strategy to link the commitment to implement the WHO Intersectoral Action Plan on Epilepsy and Other Neurological Conditions to EU policy and integrate research and other initiatives in this area across the EU. Ireland should also use its Presidency to support and advance the following key policy areas to develop and strengthen the EU wide response to neurological conditions By delivering on its commitments under the UNCRPD, Ireland can send a strong signal of its support for those living with neurological and other disabilities throughout the EU. Specifically, Ireland should prioritise the implementation of its National Neurorehabilitation Strategy to directly advance human rights goals for people with a neurological disability. Ireland should aim to show leadership by using the opportunity of the Presidency to launch a comprehensive and ambitious Life Sciences Strategy. A national life sciences strategy is needed for Ireland to drive innovation, attract investment, and create high-skilled jobs in a rapidly growing global sector. A comprehensive Life Sciences Strategy is critical to provide the funding, collaboration, infrastructure and regulation needed to position Ireland as a growing hub for neuroscience research across the EU. Ireland should aim to show leadership by prioritising its implementation of the European Health Data Space legislation to enhance patient care through secure and seamless access to health data across the EU. This legislation is critical to enable and support diagnosis, treatment and research in neurological conditions. Ireland remains the only country without a national Electronic Health Record limiting digital health adoption and data driven R & D. Ireland should aim to show leadership by prioritising the implementation of its Rare Disease Strategy launched in 2025, critical to ensuring equitable access to specialised services, genetic testing, and emerging therapies for rare neurological conditions and to support and develop Ireland’s research infrastructure as a growing hub for research and treatments for rare neurological disease. The EU Artificial Intelligence Act (AIA), in force since August 2024, recognises that AI has huge potential in the treatment of complex health conditions such as neurological conditions but only if implemented safely and ethically. Ireland should aim to show leadership in this area by implementing the findings of the 2025 IPPOSI Citizen Jury on AI in Healthcare including the creation of a statutory regulator to oversee AI use in healthcare in Ireland, the development of a 5 year strategy addressing workforce preparedness, ethical safeguards and integration of AI technologies, safeguarding of patient autonomy and data security, public engagement and dedicated funding. Implementing Ireland’s 2024 Strategy for Accelerating Genetic and Genomic Medicine in Ireland is critical for advancing brain health and in positioning Ireland as an EU leader in precision medicine.

Neurological conditions have a substantive and increasing impact on people, businesses and communities across the EU, affecting the health, quality of life, social participation and employment of millions of individuals living with neurological conditions and the family members who care for those increasingly disabled by their condition. Neurological conditions represent a major economic as well as an individual and societal issue across the EU. To address these challenges, an EU-wide action plan for neurological health is needed which would co-ordinate the EU response to these conditions across policy, research, healthcare delivery, and societal support. During its presidency of the EU Council in 2026, Ireland should aim to drive the agenda for brain health by prioritising neurological health as a thematic focus, organising dedicated Council working group meetings and stakeholder consultations to gather input from national health ministries, patient organisations, scientific experts, and industry representatives. These consultations would inform the scope and objectives of the action plan, ensuring it addresses key areas such as early diagnosis, access to care, research and innovation, workforce training, and public awareness. Ireland could also facilitate the drafting of a Council Recommendation on brain health, setting out shared EU-level objectives while respecting national competencies in healthcare delivery. This recommendation would provide a framework for member states to align policies, share best practices, and establish common indicators for monitoring progress. The Council, under Ireland’s presidency, could also task the European Commission with supporting implementation through funding programs, such as Horizon Europe for research initiatives, the European Social Fund for workforce development, and EU4Health for improving access to high-quality neurological care. Ireland’s presidency could ensure that multi-sectoral engagement is embedded in the action plan. This involves collaboration between public health authorities, healthcare providers, patient advocacy groups, academic institutions, and industry partners. Such engagement would promote innovation in treatment, diagnostics, and digital health solutions, while fostering publicprivate partnerships that enhance access to therapies and improve care pathways across the EU. By prioritising brain health, the Council of Europe during Irelands presidency could take the first positive steps towards the development of a co-ordinated EU-wide action plan for neurological conditions which would have substantial benefits for people, businesses and communities across the EU. For individuals with neurological conditions and EU wide action plan would mobilise EU states to improve access to diagnosis, treatment, rehabilitation and long term supports for people with neurological conditions and their families. Communities would benefit from co-ordinated action at EU level to reduce inequalities in access to neurological care across the EU and promote greater inclusion and participation of EU citizens with neurological conditions. Businesses would benefit from policies aimed at supporting and enabling workforce participation for people with neurological conditions and family carers and developing and strengthening the growing position of the EU as a global leader in research and medical technology in brain health.

By prioritising brain health as a thematic focus for its Presidency of the European Union in 2026, Ireland has the opportunity to take leadership in a policy area that impacts directly on the one out of every six Europeans who live with a neurological condition, their families and wider communities. For people with neurological conditions and their families, the focus on neurological health sends a message of recognition and validation. It acknowledges the social, economic, and emotional challenges they face while promoting inclusion, accessibility, and support. It also sends a message to communities across the EU to reduce stigma and enhance public understanding and recognition of neurological conditions. Research by the European Federation of Neurological Associations highlights the impact of a neurological diagnosis on the health, social participation and employment of Eu citizens. According to the 2022 EFNA survey with over 1000 respondents from 30 countries across Europe, only one in five of those living with a neurological condition have access to affordable treatments that satisfactorily manage their condition. 84% said they experienced stigma or discrimination in areas including employment, education and obtaining insurance or mortgage cover while condition specific research points to lower levels of workforce participation and a high percentage of people with neurological conditions leaving the workplace due to their condition. These findings are echoed here in Ireland, with the over 860 respondents to the 2024 Neurological Alliance of Ireland Patient Experience Survey highlighting significant deficits in access to diagnosis, specialist care and rehabilitation and the impact of their neurological condition on mental health, employment and financial wellbeing. The growing burden of neurological conditions represents a huge challenge for healthcare systems, economies and societies across the EU. Member states, and Ireland in particular, are however increasingly mobilising their healthcare and life sciences sector towards a greater focus on neurological health with the potential to position the EU as a world leader in this area. By adopting brain health as a key priority, Ireland can achieve tangible benefits from its Presidency to leave a lasting legacy in an emerging priority area for health, economic and social policy across the EU.

Ireland has a timely opportunity to champion brain health as a thematic priority for its 2026 Council Presidency of the European Union. Neurological conditions are among the leading causes of disability across Europe, and EU-level momentum on brain health is growing rapidly. By placing neurological health at the centre of its Presidency agenda, Ireland can help shape a coordinated European response that strengthens prevention, early diagnosis, treatment pathways, and long-term supports for millions of its citizens. The Neurological Alliance of Ireland (NAI), with its membership of 39 neurological patient organisations, offers Government a strong, experienced partner with deep connections across Europe. NAI works in partnership with EU-level umbrellas representing neurological and brain health organisations, all of whom play a central role in advancing the EU agenda through their stewardship of the MEP Interest Group on Neurological Conditions and Brain Health. These partnerships provide Ireland with immediate access to expertise, networks, and advocacy capacity to focus on the brain health agenda during Ireland’s Presidency. Focusing on brain health also aligns strategically with Ireland’s strengths. It showcases Ireland as a leader in healthcare research and innovation, supporting growth in neuroscience, digital health, medical technologies, and patient-centred innovation. Prioritising brain health would therefore deliver both societal impact and economic opportunity while reinforcing Ireland’s reputation as a forward-looking, research-driven EU member state. Ireland’s neurological community is exceptionally strong, dynamic, and innovative, characterised by a depth of expertise and collaboration that positions the country as a leader in neurological care, research, and advocacy. At its core is a highly skilled cohort of specialists many of whom have trained and worked in leading institutions across Europe, North America, and beyond. This international experience enriches Irish clinical practice with global standards and cutting-edge insights, fostering a culture of excellence that benefits patients and fuels research. Complementing this clinical strength is Ireland’s growing reputation in neuroscience research, anchored by internationally recognised investigators and research centres driving advances in areas such as neurodegeneration, brain injury and rare neurological diseases. Vital to the strength of Ireland’s neurological community is its vibrant and proactive patient advocacy sector. Irish neurological patient organisations are highly engaged, informed, and influential, playing a central role in shaping national policy, research priorities, and service improvement. Their presence is strongly felt at European level as well, where Irish advocates contribute to key platforms and advisory groups, ensuring that the perspectives and needs of people living with neurological conditions in Ireland are represented in broader European initiatives. This active participation underscores the maturity and credibility of Ireland’s patient voice, which is recognised as an essential partner in the development of effective neurological strategies. At the centre of this community is the Neurological Alliance of Ireland (NAI) and its member organisations, uniquely positioned to bring together clinicians, researchers, industry leaders, and patient organisations to mobilise Ireland’s action during the Presidency to prioritise brain health as a strategic pillar of public health policy across Europe.

Ireland’s 2026 Presidency of the Council offers a timely opportunity to demonstrate leadership on a fair, practical and innovation-driven energy transition. As an island nation with a strong rural base and significant off-grid energy demand, Ireland is well placed to champion an approach to EU energy, transport and climate policy that is both ambitious and grounded in the realities facing households, businesses and communities across Europe. DCC recommends that Ireland focuses its Presidency around the following overarching themes: A fair, inclusive and technology-neutral energy transition Ireland should lead efforts to ensure that EU decarbonisation policy is centred on emissions outcomes rather than technology mandates. A technology-neutral, market-based approach, which allows renewable liquids, renewable gases and electrification to compete on equal terms is essential for delivering the most efficient and cost-effective pathways to net zero. Ensuring fairness also means recognising the needs of rural, off-grid and hard-to-electrify communities, where high retrofit costs or system replacements are not feasible in the short term. Renewable drop-in fuels such as HVO, BioLPG and biomethane can provide immediate emissions reductions using existing infrastructure, supporting a practical and inclusive transition, while supporting countries achieve their Effort Sharing Regulation targets. Ireland’s experience in developing the Renewable Heat Obligation positions it well to contribute to EU discussions on how renewable heat can be scaled in a flexible and consumer-focused way. Strengthening Europe's energy security and resilience Recent years have underscored the importance of resilient, diversified and domestically sourced energy. Ireland should champion the role of EU produced biomethane and renewable gases in strengthening Europe’s energy security, particularly for peak demand, rural industries and sectors reliant on process heat. These fuels reduce dependence on imported fossil energy and support an orderly, secure transition. Boosting industrial competitiveness and innovation By elevating renewable gases and renewable liquid fuels within Europe’s broader industrial strategy, Ireland can help support EU value chains, manufacturing and innovation. A supportive policy framework will unlock investment in sustainable fuels production, storage, logistics and distribution - creating skilled employment and enhancing Europe’s long-term competitiveness. Ensuring cohesion and a just transition across all regions Finally, Ireland should embed rural cohesion across all Presidency priorities. The transition must work for all communities, including islands, remote regions and off-grid households. Policies that provide choice, flexibility and affordability are essential to ensuring that no region is left behind. Together, these themes position Ireland to drive a Presidency that is ambitious, equitable and grounded in real world solutions - delivering meaningful progress for Europe’s climate, energy security and economic resilience.

Ireland’s Presidency comes at a pivotal moment for the EU’s climate and energy agenda, with several major legislative files entering negotiation or revision. At the same time, EU countries are not meeting their emissions reduction targets such as those in the Effort Sharing Regulation with foreseen measures having little impact on these. Therefore, the Presidency can add significant value by ensuring that policies relevant to heating, renewable fuels and energy security are advanced so that they deliver on EU policy objectives. Heating & Cooling Strategy and Electrification Action Plan A central priority should be ensuring that the Heating and Cooling Strategy is properly implemented and quickly delivers on reducing emissions. Upcoming policies focused on electrification will not deliver sufficient reductions by 2030, so renewable fuels must be deployed wherever needed. Heating and cooling account for half of the EU’s energy use, and legislative measures flowing from the strategy must reflect the realities faced by consumers in both urban and rural areas. Ireland should seek strong Council Conclusions reaffirming Member States’ commitment to a technology-neutral approach to increasing renewable energy and reducing GHG emissions in heating, sending a clear signal that all viable renewable solutions have a legitimate role in the transition. Ireland should work to secure a policy framework that: Recognises the contribution of renewable liquid and gaseous fuels, alongside heat pumps, district heating and energy efficiency, within a technology-neutral approach. Addresses the needs of off-grid households, rural regions and industrial sites. Establishes a practical, sector-specific pathway that reflects Europe’s diverse building stock and infrastructure. The Presidency should support progress toward an EU-wide renewable heat obligation in RED, modelled on Ireland’s RHO. A harmonised obligation, with ambitious but realistic, gradually increasing targets, would drive investment while giving Member States flexibility in how they deliver outcomes. Energy Union Package: Renewable Energy Frameworks The Renewable Energy Directive sets ambitious targets. Renewable liquid and gaseous fuels, such as HVO, BioLPG, rDME and biomethane, can make a significant contribution to achieving the objectives of the legislation, provided they meet the sustainability standards. These include strict GHG emissions- saving thresholds of 65–80% depending on the sector, and comprehensive rules on feedstock sustainability, land-use change and biodiversity protection. However, while such targets have helped stimulate renewables in easier-to-decarbonise sectors, they have not been sufficient to drive progress in heating, where structural and cost barriers persist. Additional clarity and flexibility are needed to ensure that heating contributes effectively to the EU’s decarbonisation effort. Ireland’s Presidency can support refinement of the renewable energy framework in a way that remains technology-neutral, affordable and inclusive of all viable renewable fuels. Delivering a practical and inclusive policy landscape By advancing these files with a strong focus on technology neutrality, practical delivery and rural inclusion, Ireland’s Presidency can help shape a policy framework that accelerates decarbonisation while remaining realistic, flexible and affordable. Clear, consistent rules and recognition of a broad suite of renewable technologies will support investment, strengthen energy security and enable communities across the Union to participate fully in the transition.

Ireland’s Presidency can deliver meaningful benefits for citizens and businesses by prioritising an energy transition that is inclusive, affordable and grounded in technological and regional diversity. By emphasising real-world implementation and the diverse needs of EU regions, Ireland can help shape Council outcomes that accelerate climate action while supporting societal cohesion and economic resilience. Supporting an inclusive transition for all communities A substantial share of Europe’s population, including 137 million people living in rural areas and millions of off-gas-grid households and businesses, faces different realities and higher barriers to clean heating than urban consumers. Many live in older buildings or operate as SMEs where deep retrofits or full electrification are technically difficult or financially out of reach. The Council can help ensure that EU policy recognises this diversity by enabling a wider set of decarbonisation pathways, including renewable drop-in fuels such as HVO, BioLPG and renewable DME, which reduce emissions quickly and with minimal disruption. Reducing costs and disruption for households and businesses Cost remains one of the biggest obstacles to the transition. In many regions, heat pump installation and associated fabric upgrades can cost €30,000-€50,000, putting them out of reach for many households. By contrast, renewable liquid and gaseous fuels can be adopted with minimal up-front investment while delivering substantial emissions reductions. The Council can support people and small businesses by encouraging Member States to prioritise low-cost, low-disruption decarbonisation measures, reducing energy poverty risks and keeping the transition fair. Strengthening Europe’s energy security Recent energy crises have shown the need for diversified, resilient and domestically sourced energy. The Council can emphasise the contribution of EU-produced biomethane and renewable liquid gases to reducing fossil fuel imports, stabilising supply, and ensuring reliable energy for rural communities and industry. These solutions enhance security while supporting local economies. Upholding high sustainability standards As Europe scales up renewable fuels and heating solutions, maintaining robust sustainability criteria is essential. Renewable liquids and gases already meet strict EU thresholds for emissions savings, feedstock sourcing and biodiversity protection. The Council can reinforce the importance of credible, verifiable sustainability rules so that communities and consumers can trust that the energy they use genuinely contributes to Europe’s climate goals. Providing predictable, technology-neutral policy to drive innovation Consumers and businesses benefit when EU policy is stable, technology-neutral and focused on outcomes. The Council can support a framework that allows electrification, renewable liquids, renewable gases and hybrid systems to compete on equal terms. Such clarity will unlock investment in renewable heat, biomethane and energy services, supporting innovation and economic resilience across the EU. By prioritising inclusivity, affordability, sustainability, energy security and technology neutrality, Ireland’s Presidency can help ensure that EU policy delivers substantial positive impacts for people, businesses and communities across Europe.

Ireland’s 2026 Presidency presents a major opportunity to strengthen public understanding of the EU by demonstrating how European cooperation delivers real, practical benefits for communities. Clear, grounded communication, rooted in relatable stories and inclusive dialogue, will be key to ensuring citizens feel connected to the Presidency and to the wider European project. Demonstrating real-world benefits through local projects The most effective way to make EU action tangible is to showcase real examples of how European frameworks support climate, economic and social progress. The Presidency can highlight Ireland’s growing biomethane sector, off-grid households successfully transitioning to HVO or BioLPG, and SMEs reducing emissions through renewable fuels. These stories show that EU climate policy is not abstract - it is enabling cleaner, more affordable and more resilient energy solutions in everyday settings. Public-private partnerships should also feature prominently. Investments such as DCC’s biomethane development with Flogas and Neiphin Energy illustrate how EU-aligned policies mobilise private capital, support farm incomes and stimulate regional job creation. Spotlighting these collaborations reinforces the message that the EU, Member States and businesses are working together to deliver real outcomes. Engaging companies, farming organisations, community groups and social partners as messengers will help ensure the Presidency’s communication resonates across diverse audiences and reflects trusted local voices. Communicating a fair, flexible and inclusive transition A central message for the Presidency should be that the EU’s energy transition is designed to be inclusive and flexible, not prescriptive. Citizens should understand that the EU supports multiple decarbonisation pathways allowing households and businesses to choose the solutions that best match their buildings, budgets and infrastructure. This approach is particularly important for rural, island and off-gas-grid communities. Discussing practical decarbonisation options shows that EU policy recognises regional diversity and supports a just transition where no area is left behind. Connecting climate action to energy security and local economic value Communications should also emphasise that EU climate action strengthens Europe’s security and economic resilience. Investments in domestic biomethane and renewable liquid gases reduce dependence on imported fossil fuels, keep more economic activity within local economies and support strategic autonomy. Framing climate measures as contributing to both sustainability and sovereignty will help broaden public support and highlight the wider benefits of EU cooperation.

areas? Formation of the CAP should be the main priority Increasing the budget of the CAP in line with security and food security is as important. Priority for active farmers. It must simplify the workings of the institutions Competitiveness of European exports and European goods that stay within the bloc are less competitive to other producers due to the tight regulations on European products.
