Ireland needs to focus on a small number of achievable targets over the course of the six months. ICMSA have outlined areas above that Ireland should prioritise.

Ibec’s priorities for Ireland’s Presidency of the Council of the EU in the second half of 2026 are set out in detail in our campaign Making a Resilient, Competitive EU a Reality: The Business Ambition for Ireland’s EU Presidency. To bolster competitiveness in this new context, Europe must think in systems: open markets, secure supply chains, adaptive regulation, and an innovation ecosystem that can withstand shocks while driving growth. This will determine our ability to grow and prosper, trade internationally and attract investment, provide job opportunities and raise living standards. Resilience has become the defining capability of Europe’s future prosperity. It is no longer a theme beside competitiveness or sustainability but a system that connects and strengthens them. Resilience is how Europe anticipates disruption, adapts to change, and sustains open, competitive economies in a more uncertain world. Energy, digital, skills, innovation, and security and defence are core pillars of this resilience. During Ireland’s EU Presidency, Ibec will champion a European approach that makes resilience the foundation of competitiveness, an outward-looking, confident, and investment-ready Europe that delivers stability and opportunity for business and citizens alike. Ibec recognises the leadership opportunity of the Presidency to influence the direction of EU policy on everything from regulatory simplification and advancing the Single Market, to decarbonisation and sustainability, leading on digital and AI transformation, furthering trade and investment, and countering protectionism. Dealing with geopolitical uncertainty, EU enlargement and supporting Ukraine requires a coherent resilience agenda and securing agreement on the Multiannual Financial Framework 2028- 2034 to support competitiveness in the years ahead. Irish business wants to play a central role in collaboration with Government to ensure the Presidency’s success. The vision of Irish business for a successful EU Presidency is one that drives forward an EU that is more competitive, resilient, innovative, simplified, focused, ambitious and outward looking, grounded in resilience. Ibec’s priorities for Ireland’s Presidency of the Council of the EU in the second half of 2026 are set out in detail in our campaign Making a Resilient, Competitive EU a Reality: The Business Ambition for Ireland’s EU Presidency.

Ibec has published six papers covering the strategic policy areas that should be the focus of the work of the Irish Presidency: Trade and Investment: Strengthening relationships, maximising opportunities Single Market and Simplification: Turning ambition into action Security and Defence: Pillars of a resilient Europe Labour Market and Social Policy: Skills, innovation and EU added value Enterprise and Economy: Create the conditions for competitiveness Digital and AI: Simplification, adoption and innovation Ibec’s priorities for Ireland’s Presidency of the Council of the EU in the second half of 2026 are set out in detail in our campaign Making a Resilient, Competitive EU a Reality: The Business Ambition for Ireland’s EU Presidency.
See responses to question 1 and 2.

The economic benefits of EU membership have been and are substantial for Irish businesses and citizens. Through our campaign Making a Resilient, Competitive EU a Reality: The Business Ambition for Ireland’s EU Presidency, Ibec will be emphasizing this including the contributions of business in Ireland. We would welcome opportunities to collaborate with Government.

As part of the Strategic Agenda, the objective to A free and democratic Europe is vital to harmonise all people, minorities, marginalized and underrepresented, especially those impacted by deprivation, discrimination and inequality. Travellers in Ireland are impacted historically and intergenerationally from equities in accommodation and housing, health, education, employment and enjoyment of other social and fundamental rights, of representation and decision making, cultural protection and visibility. Commission’s work programme 2026 - Objective 27. Fairness 1, 2 and 3. We ask that Ireland ensures Travellers are identified within those themes as a group most impacted by intergenerational inequity, poverty and child specific poor outcomes. And that Ireland recommits to Traveller children during the EU Presidency and in dialogue at the Commission on the EU Child Guarantee. The EU/ Ireland Child Guarantee. • Poverty: Advocacy for targeted measures to reduce child poverty through a Child Income Support Payment (CISP) and an increase to core social welfare rates by a minimum of €27.50 did not culminate in the current or previous Budgets. • Despite National Measures and Targets defined in the Roadmap for Social Inclusion RSI to address poverty reduction, there are no Traveller specific targeted approaches or evidenced based assessments to frame policy making. • The National Traveller and Roma Inclusion Strategy NTRIS was named as corelating to the RSI Strategy, but poverty reduction is not a thematic goal of the NTRIS and its Traveller employment focus was limited • Baseline assessment methods to drive the change and protective measures enshrined under the Guarantee for Traveller children in Ireland as described therein, is not aligned and integrated foundationally and specific research is needed to achieve those intended objectives. In housing and accommodation 1,556 Traveller families (over 6,000 people) are living in unsafe, inadequate conditions in unauthorised sites or sharing housing and over half are under 24 years. In 2024 1,044 Traveller applicants qualified for social housing support, two thirds couples or singles with children, and a half overall was couples with 1–3 children. Just 96 new units were built for Travellers nationally of 774 overall (TAP 2019-2024) and from an original target of 3,060 units and delivery rates grossly at odds with the rate of supply of other housing forms. The age profile (young)and housing type status of Travellers is not being factored into housing and accommodation strategies and plans at national or local points, of the very specific cultural dynamic features of early marriage and childbirth. This exacerbates the need for housing support and causes undue burden on families to live in grossly inadequate and overcrowded conditions. In education: Financial supports are not Traveller specific (and should follow the Traveller child throughout the education life cycle, to ensure access unimpeded, and approaches designed longitudinally to redress intergenerational exclusion from education.

As part of the coalition of Irish NGOs, trade unions, and civil society organisations, we welcomed the EC’s intention to develop an EU Civil Society Strategy, in addition to the European Parliament resolution on shrinking civic space in Europe ((2021/2103(INI)), and the final report of the Conference on the Future of Europe. We raised the importance of sustaining open and vibrant democracies, being codependent on civic society partners who play a fundamental role in upholding the democratic foundations of the EU, and the importance of holding policymakers to account, monitoring and advocating for human rights, ensuring citizens’ voices are represented in policymaking, especially Travellers who are typically excluded. During the Irish Presidency we ask for A stronger monitoring and accordance with, reports and recommendations of the Committees to EU human rights treaties, covenants and institutions. A strengthened alignment with Traveller NGOs’ in Ireland linked to the EU wide Traveller and Roma Inclusion Strategies, and appropriate sectoral investment to implement the Action Plans in Ireland for Traveller and Roma. The new Civil Society Strategy and the EU Democracy Shield Pillar - ‘Safeguarding the integrity of the information space’ We ask for Ireland to assert the need for Travellers to be safeguarded in all related plans across Europe with a shared and explicit understanding of cultural identity, as unique, within all the framing contexts. That in the upcoming review of the Audiovisual Media Services Directive, that when the Commission assesses ways to strengthen the prominence of media services of general interest, Ireland seeks to ensure broad inclusion and diversity standards to be applied across the sector, and taking account of the plurality needed in delivery of content, visibility in content creation and stringent standards which mitigate again harm in the media space for Travellers and ethnic minority groups. Pillar 3 – ‘Boosting societal resilience and citizens' engagement’-That in countering information manipulation, that the Commission’s roll out of measures to foster media and digital literacy for all ages along with guidelines to strengthen citizenship education in schools. Will ensure specific anti-racism and human rights standards are formed within these and a requirement for EU Member state’s attention to Travellers and minority groups within their territories.

That Ireland under the Presidency will advance Traveller inclusion across the EU Strategy for Civil Society, and in particular we ask Under the Commission’s plans to step up its engagement with civil society, and support and protect civil society organisations in their work, will advocate for strengthened Traveller sector in Ireland to support local and national Traveller bodies. That within the three key objectives: We ask that Ireland will Fostering engagement: seek or facilitate a space on the Civil Society Platform being established in 2026 Support and protection: under the further protection measures being explored, such as urgent assistance to organisations under threat, and coordination of available protection measures in Member States, Ireland will seek to ensure Traveller sectoral bodies are earmarked for supports. Sustainable and transparent funding: Under the proposal for the new Multiannual Financial Framework Ireland will advocate for its fair share under the EU funding programme for cross-border education, training and solidarity, youth, media, culture, and creative sectors, values, and civil society, with a focus on Ireland’s most marginalised communities, including Travellers, especially through the AgoraEU. Facilitate processes for CSO investment from The EU Citizens, Equality, Rights and Values Programme (CERV) with financial supports. Deliver on the Recommendations of The European Commission against Racism and Intolerance for Travellers Nov 2025. Irish authorities take decisive action to implement Traveller Policy (NTRIS) and adequate funding to Traveller and Roma-led community development organisations Adequate funding to Traveller and Roma-led community development organisations to ensure their full and effective participation in research, policy implementation and monitoring across a variety of sectors, including education, employment, housing, and healthcare. Objective 32. Media Travellers and Roma were not defined in the Online Safety and Media Regulation Act, or the first draft of Ireland’s Safety Code. We ask that Ireland Will support further protection of Traveller children, as minors impacted by hate directed online content. And an overarching protection be incumbent on all digital platforms for Safety by Design and Recommender Feeds tobe switched off. A broader definition of harm across EU Online Safety and Media Regulations. Seeks to ensure higher standards for our digital regulation, especially to the absence of safeguarding via Automated discrimination Fully transposes the provisions of the EU Framework Directive on hate speech. Digital platforms continue to facilitate identity based harmful content which may not be inciting, but is pervasively stereotyping, perpetuating and racist, but technically is still in compliance with the Code, due to the threshold of Article 21 of the FR. There is an absence of safeguarding via Automated discrimination and social media algorithms which act as vectors of harmful content, especially to children, with “reinforcement and amplification’ of content attuned to a systemic bias and stereotyping of minority groups such as Travellers without human involvement. The matter of Hate speech is corelated to online harm, and In November ‘25 the European Commission against Racism and Intolerance (ECRI) recommended Ireland strengthen hate speech legislation “without delay”.

We ask that Ireland Commits, during and after, to enhanced community engagement and education especially for typically underrepresented communities – such as Travellers, in participative dialogues across a ranges of matters under the EU Presidency, in voting in European elections, and to accessing European structures. Seeks it fair share of investment from Europe to facilitate and support engagement of minority communities including Travellers, attending EU structure meetings and dialogues.

 We strongly encourage Ireland to prioritise protecting human rights and environmental standards and the Green Deal. The Omnibus I process and the resulting gutting of the Corporate Sustainability Due Diligence Directive (CSDDD) was a clear show of deregulation. The competitiveness agenda has been used to prioritise business interests over basic protections for workers, human rights defenders and communities affected by corporate abuse who are now likely to face insurmountable barriers to access justice for harms caused by companies headquartered or operating in the EU. This approach undermines the EU’s credibility and the core values it claims to uphold. The Irish Presidency must work to ensure that EU’s strategic agenda commitment to “respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights, including the rights of persons belonging to minorities” does not continue to be breached. We strongly encourage that a key priority thematic and operational priority is support for civil society including environmental activists and groups in Ireland. Friends of the Earth is a member of the Environmental Pillar which met with Minister Byrne in November. We very much welcomed his commitment to championing the role of civil society across Europe, and his dismissal of some anti-civil society tropes. Civil society space is under attack in various places around Europe, both geographic and ideological, and we strongly support that Ireland should uphold the long tradition of positive engagement with civil society before and during the Irish presidency of the EU. Ireland must not shy away from the growing problem of corporate capture in EU policymaking. The process for Omnibus I has shown how disproportionate industry influence can distort policy outcomes, marginalise affected communities and prevent them from accessing justice and undermine public trust. A true democracy requires strong, independent civil society organisations that can advocate for human rights and environmental protection without undue pressure or exclusion. Ireland must ensure transparent and balanced stakeholder engagement processes across all files, and champion initiatives that safeguard the role of civil society and human rights defenders within the EU. The backlash against the CSDDD and other Green Deal files exposed a growing disconnect between EU institutions and the public, fuelled by undue corporate influence, opaque negotiations, last-minute political deals and alignment with far-right parties in breach of the longstanding “cordon sanitaire” in place for the protection of democratic norms. Ireland should advocate for transparent, democratic legislative processes, better access to information, and robust oversight of Council decision-making. Greater transparency and meaningful engagement with impacted stakeholders will help restore trust, ensure evidencebased policymaking, and reaffirm the EU’s commitment to its founding principles of democracy, human rights and the rule of law. The Environmental Pillar has also proposed the theme of Resilience as a timely and resonant theme, capturing as it does the need for the Union to support people’s inherent ability to cope with the increasing uncertainty and volatility by strengthening our institutions and infrastructure to match the spirit of community Europe’s citizens demonstrate so often. The fact that the EU’s Strategic Foresight report, the European Environmental Agency’s latest flagship report and NextGenerationEU all centre resilience in their framing of the challenges ahead gives Ireland robust foundations to build on.

As EU Council President at COP31, Ireland will play a crucial role in driving fossil fuel phase-out and ensuring civil society inclusion, and must be vociferous in supporting a global fossil fuel phase-out roadmap and endorse the development of Fossil Fuel Non-Proliferation Treaty. Ireland and the EU must demand a full phase-out of fossil fuels without caveats such as “unabated” fossil fuel or defining gas as a “transition fuel,” and avoid reliance on costly and unproven CCUS technologies. They should champion differentiated global phase-out timelines based on equity and CBDR-RC principles, scale up finance, technology, and capacity support for developing countries, and clearly delineate fossil fuel phase-out trajectories. Ireland and the EU must also exclude participants with vested industry interests in delegations. Ireland and the EU should also lead in safeguarding human rights and enabling meaningful participation of civil society and frontline communities. The EU Council’s recent agreement on a 2040 climate target includes a heavy emphasis on flexibilities, which raises significant concerns. The use of carbon credits, a biennial review that risks creating a shifting “ranged” target, sectoral flexibilities that allow reduced effort, and the option to lower the 2040 goal if land-use underperforms threaten to weaken EU climate ambition by diverting resources from domestic action, undermining investment certainty, and removing incentives for genuine emissions reductions. As trilogue negotiations with Parliament begin, it is important to ensure that this deregulatory trend does not become embedded or replicated in future EU climate legislation. Although the Council’s position cannot now be reopened, the Commission will soon start preparing revisions to the sectoral policies needed to achieve the newly adopted 2040 target, expected in Q3/Q4 next year, and it is crucial that the Irish Presidency does not all for any further dilution of ambition. The text in the recent Council agreement on the 2040 target also acknowledges the particular characteristics of agriculture, but it does not explicitly endorse changing methane emissions metrics. Reports that parts of the Irish Government pushed for special treatment through alternative methane metrics are deeply concerning, as this would weaken accountability, hinder climate action, and contradict scientific consensus. By focusing political effort on securing exemptions rather than advancing real emissions reductions, Ireland risks serious reputational damage and a return to its past status as a climate laggard. We strongly urge Government not to accept or repeat this approach. Ireland must ensure that its 2026 Presidency prioritises legislative areas where strong human rights, environmental protections, and democratic governance are most at risk. Ireland must prioritise the completion and effective implementation of key Green Deal files that remain vulnerable to political dilution or delay. This includes defending climate, biodiversity, and environmental legislation that has come under pressure from deregulatory agendas. Ireland must ensure that no future Omnibus initiatives repeat the untransparent, undemocratic deregulatory approach taken by the institutions. The Presidency must promote transparent, standalone legislative processes, proper impact assessments, and meaningful consultation with affected stakeholders—including workers, communities, and civil society organisations.

Regular (at least monthly) meetings regarding negotiations before and during the Presidency between relevant Irish attaché’s and civil society organizations. We would welcome the opportunity to facilitate such meetings together with other eNGOs. Council agendas and informal meetings should prioritise implementation challenges, funding gaps and delivery capacity under existing EU climate and energy legislation, rather than reopening recently agreed laws. This includes sharing best practices between Member States on energy poverty reduction, building renovation, and renewable deployment. Recent years have seen growing public concern about opaque processes, last-minute amendments, and undue corporate influence. The European Ombudsman also decided that the Commission’s undemocratic environmental rollbacks through Omnibus I amounted to “maladministration”. Enhancing transparency, meaningfully engaging with rightsholders, improving access to documents, and clearly communicating Member State positions would help improve democratic legitimacy and public engagement. The Presidency must play a central role in safeguarding the remaining elements of the European Green Deal, strengthening protections against corporate abuse, and rebuilding trust in EU institutions through accountability and transparency. The Irish Presidency can make the greatest positive impact by ensuring that EU policymaking centres on people, communities, environmental protection and climate action rather than prioritising business and growth in all aspects of its policymaking. This requires strengthening rights protections, engaging with rightsholders, safeguarding democratic processes, and ensuring that laws already in place deliver meaningful outcomes. A rights-centred Council agenda will help ensure that EU law offers protection for individuals negatively impacted by the activities of corporate actors.

 As noted by the Hope and Courage Collective, the EU presidency needs to say what it is for and articulate its shared values. EU communication should be: -Develop a range of value lead statements focusing the role of values of rights under attack - minority rights, civil society, digital rights and not least environmental rights -Center people’s voices -workers, families, young people, communities. Ireland should facilitate: -Local forums / town halls where people can speak directly into EU priorities. -Community-led conversations supported by civil society. -Engagements that reach groups typically excluded from national-level dialogue. Ireland must correct the narrative around “competitiveness” and “simplification” and ensure that business interests do not continue to be prioritised over essential protections for workers, communities and the environment. These terms are increasingly being misused to justify lowering protections rather than strengthening long-term resilience, responsible business conduct, and a sustainable, fair economy. The Environmental Pillar welcomed Minister Bryne’s openness to reflecting the position of Northern Ireland as subject to EU law during Ireland’s EU Presidency. We understand the jurisdictional constraints on the location of official events but we would encourage DFA to explore the option of inviting relevant stakeholders from the North to participate in Presidency events as appropriate. As noted, Ireland must strongly reject the deliberate misleading simplification (i.e. deregulation) approach which serves to undermine, rather than promote, EU law among citizens. The Commission is currently on a drive to “simplify” EU regulation, including very recently adopted measures that form part of the European Green Deal. While seeking to ensure regulation achieves its objectives efficiently is theoretically uncontroversial, in practice the process so far has been accompanied by a strong deregulation push that clearly risks undermining standards and outcomes for EU citizens and the environment. Some companies, industry alliances and their well-paid lobbyists (especially fossil fuel companies, big tech and chemical companies) are using this political pivot from the Commission to seek wholescale deregulation (in a “shock doctrine” style manipulation of current geopolitical and geo-economic turbulence), However, many experts, institutions and agencies, including the ECB for example, are warning that this not in fact good for business as a whole, who benefit from regulatory certainty, and is essentially punishing those businesses that have invested in transition, is rewarding laggards and undermines the EU’s transition to long-term sustainability and prosperity Ireland has a responsibility to ensure that future Omnibus processes do not follow this same deregulatory approach. Ireland must prioritise rights-centred policymaking, ensure meaningful consultation with impacted stakeholders throughout all stages of the lawmaking process, including workers, communities, human rights defenders, and environmental organisations, and protect what remains of the Green Deal. Ireland must champion rights-centred policymaking and insist that these consultations are substantive and transparent. It is essential that Ireland support the full implementation of the European Green Deal and resist attempts to weaken existing environmental and human rights standards under the guise of “simplification.”  We would have grave concerns regarding any re-opening of the Energy Efficiency Directive requirements including energy saving requirements. Given the Commission’s 2026 Work Programme signals an upcoming examination and potential updating of the EU energy efficiency framework, the Irish Presidency should work to ensure that any future review does not weaken the robust binding elements of the 2023 Energy Efficiency Directive, which are vital to reducing energy demand and fossil fuel dependence, and should prioritise delivery and enforcement over rolling-back ambition.

The run into the Presidency is an opportune moment to address the transposition deficit in the energy area highlighted recently by the Climate Change Advisory Council in relation to the Fit for 55 package. The Council expressed strong concern over Ireland’s slow transposition, noting it is “extremely disappointed and deeply concerned that transposition and other important deadlines are being missed.” In particular, delays relate to transposition of the Renewable Energy Directive, the Energy Efficiency Directive, and the requirement to submit a social climate plan by June 2025, which is crucial for addressing energy poverty and supporting vulnerable households. [https://www.climatecouncil.ie/councilpublications/annualreviewandreport/CCAC-AR2025-Crosssectoral-final.pdf ] Ireland’s Presidency should promote a clear EU-wide pathway to halving energy demand and delivering a fully zero-carbon energy system, by driving ambition beyond minimum requirements under existing energy efficiency and renewable energy legislation, accelerating fossil fuel phaseout. We have particular concerns that the Government’s approval of a state-owned LNG terminal and continued facilitation of the Shannon LNG project will be progressed during the Irish Presidency notwithstanding Ireland’s national and EU climate obligations . The risk of reputational damage to Ireland should not be underestimated in this regard. With National Building Renovation Plans being finalised during Ireland’s Presidency at the end for 2026, the Council focus should prioritise ambitious and socially just delivery in the built environment. This includes promoting “worst-first” deep renovations, the phase-out of fossil fuels in buildings, and the integration of renewable heating and cooling, while ensuring strong social safeguards to protect affordability and prevent displacement. Empowering local authorities and aligning EU funding instruments, including the Social Climate Fund, will be essential to translating EU climate and energy law into warmer homes, lower energy bills and quality jobs. The Irish Presidency must ensure that EU climate and energy law negotiations reflect the recent ICJ Advisory Opinion, which affirms that the Paris Agreement’s 1.5°C goal should guide climate action based on the best available science, considering states’ historical responsibilities and the principle of common but differentiated responsibilities. The Opinion also emphasizes that state obligations extend beyond climate law to human rights, environmental, and customary international law, with breaches potentially triggering liability for restitution, compensation, or ecosystem restoration. It also notes that a state can be held internationally accountable for failing to regulate or limit emissions from private actors under its jurisdiction, including through fossil fuel production, consumption, licensing, or subsidies.

organisation: NORA e. V. (network for online registration of anaphylaxis
response_text: - better understand treatment - improve availibility of adrenaline e. g. at schools work places. Taking into account the current geopolitical and socioeconomic context in Europe, we recommend that Ireland prioritise Health Protection, Citizen Safety, and Resilient Societies as core themes of its 2026 Presidency. Serious allergies and anaphylaxis are rising across Europe and place a growing burden on individuals, schools, workplaces, and public services. Addressing them fits naturally within broader objectives to protect citizens’ wellbeing and reduce preventable health risks. A Resilient and Prepared Europe The EU must be equipped to respond to emergencies—whether acute health events, natural disasters, or public safety threats. This requires harmonised emergency response systems, stronger communitylevel preparedness, and cross-border cooperation. Ireland is one of the few Member States that has taken concrete steps to improve preparedness for serious allergic reactions, including allowing pharmacists to supply emergency medicines without a prescription during anaphylactic events. This national practice demonstrates effective emergency readiness and provides a model for EU-level policy coordination, which could inform upcoming initiatives under the European Health Union framework aimed at strengthening preparedness, prevention, and rapid response across Member States. A People-Centred Union that Protects Embedding people-centred principles into EU policymaking ensures that vulnerable populations and individuals at risk of medical emergencies are not left behind. The Presidency could advance reducing health inequalities across the EU, highlighting uneven access to diagnosis, specialist care, and emergency response protocols. Positioning timely care for serious allergies and anaphylaxis within this agenda demonstrates a commitment to practical, measurable improvements in patient safety and inclusion, while protecting citizens’ rights to safety in everyday environments such as schools, childcare centres, workplaces, and public venues. 3. A Future-Oriented Europe Built on Innovation and Collaboration Ireland’s strong reputation in digital innovation offers an opportunity to promote Digital Innovation for Health, leveraging the European Health Data Space and interoperable, patient-centred tools. For individuals at risk of serious allergic reactions, seamless access to medical information across borders can prevent emergencies and support the free movement of people. The Presidency can also prioritise harmonised awareness-raising, institutional readiness, and capacity building, ensuring schools, businesses, and public institutions are equipped and trained to respond effectively to life-threatening health incidents.

organisation: NORA e. V. (network for online registration of anaphylaxis
response_text: Ireland could use its Presidency to champion health resilience, citizen protection, and emergency preparedness, leveraging its national leadership in anaphylaxis response as a model for EU coordination. Key priorities include: Health Protection and Emergency Preparedness Serious allergies and anaphylaxis present a growing public-health challenge. The Presidency could: Promote timely access to emergency medicines, building on Ireland’s approach where pharmacists can supply life-saving treatment without prescription. Encourage harmonised school and public-venue preparedness, using Ireland as an example. Relevant upcoming EU initiative: Global health resilience initiative (non-legislative, Q2 2026) – to strengthen EU capacity for rapid response to health crises. Digital Innovation for Health Cross-border emergencies require seamless access to patient data: Promote the European Health Data Space for secure, interoperable sharing of health information, enabling faster response to anaphylactic events across borders. Support digital tools for citizen-centred care, enhancing emergency response and patient safety. 3. Reducing Health Inequalities and Strengthening Citizen Rights The Presidency could advance equitable access to emergency care and citizen-centred policy: Link preparedness to strengthening the Child Guarantee (non-legislative, Q2 2026) and Citizens omnibus (legislative, Q4 2026), ensuring children in schools, childcare centres, and communities are protected and have their rights effectively enforced. Promote intergenerational fairness through the Intergenerational fairness strategy (nonlegislative, Q1 2026), ensuring emergency preparedness and health access benefit current and future generations equally. Highlight Ireland’s model as a practical, replicable approach for other Member States. Objectives Establish a model for EU-level anaphylaxis and emergency response coordination, based on best practices of Ireland. Ensure equitable access to life-saving treatments across the EU. Promote digital innovation for preparedness, information sharing, and cross-border patient care. Strengthen citizen rights and intergenerational fairness, ensuring public health policies reflect social equity. Position health resilience as a pillar of EU citizen safety and social cohesion, demonstrating tangible improvements in public health readiness. By focusing on these targeted initiatives, Ireland can use its Presidency to deliver practical, measurable impacts on citizen safety, health equity, and cross-border emergency preparedness while reinforcing the EU’s social and legal frameworks.

organisation: NORA e. V. (network for online registration of anaphylaxis
response_text: The Irish Presidency has the potential to deliver significant, tangible impact for EU citizens by advancing health resilience and consumer safety. For individuals with serious allergies, policies that improve emergency response, access to medicines, and accurate allergen information can be life-saving. For people, expanded access to emergency treatment, including pharmacy-enabled emergency supply across the EU, enhances safety in daily life. Citizens with serious allergies would be better protected in schools, workplaces, sports facilities, cultural venues, and during cross-border travel. For businesses, harmonised allergen-labelling and staff-training expectations reduce regulatory uncertainty, simplify compliance, and improve consumer trust by fostering safer public environments. For communities and institutions, EU-supported readiness measures ,such as common school protocols, public-venue guidelines, and accessible training ,would significantly reduce preventable emergencies, supporting all three Alliance objectives. Replicating Ireland’s best practice on emergency medicine access would ensure that life-saving intervention is available regardless of where a reaction occurs, reducing inequalities across Member States.

organisation: NORA e. V. (network for online registration of anaphylaxis
response_text: Ireland has a strong opportunity to communicate the value of EU membership by focusing on everyday benefits and practical improvements that resonate directly with citizens. The 2026 Presidency can show how EU cooperation protects people, strengthens communities, and makes daily life safer—particularly in areas such as emergency preparedness for serious allergies and anaphylaxis. Highlight Practical Examples of EU Solidarity Citizens understand the EU best when they see clear, relatable outcomes. Ireland can communicate EU values by highlighting how cooperation improves safety and wellbeing, for example: Safer environments in schools, restaurants, transport and public venues. Shared health information that makes travel within the EU safer and more predictable. Harmonised allergen-labelling rules that protect consumers wherever they are. More consistent access to emergency support for serious allergic reactions. Ireland’s own approach—allowing pharmacists to supply emergency treatment during a serious allergic reaction—provides a concrete example of national leadership that improves citizen safety. Propose Council Recommendations on Emergency Readiness To strengthen public understanding of the EU’s benefits, Ireland could lead on a visible, citizen-centred initiative: Develop Council Recommendations on broader readiness and access to emergency treatment for serious allergy and anaphylaxis. This would help encourage Member States to: Improve preparedness in schools, public venues, workplaces, and transport hubs. Ensure trained responders are available across community settings. Reduce inequalities in access to time-sensitive, life-saving care. Such an initiative is easy for citizens to relate to, directly improves safety, and demonstrates EU cooperation in a human, practical way. A simple message: the EU protects people By showcasing initiatives that make everyday life safer, including better emergency preparedness for serious allergic reactions, the Irish Presidency can reinforce a clear message: EU cooperation delivers real, practical benefits for families, children, workers, and communities. This people-centred framing will strengthen public trust, build ownership, and demonstrate the concrete value of Ireland’s leadership at EU level.

organisation: Diversity and Inclusion in Erasmus+ iMplementation (DIEM) project
response_text: How to make Erasmus+ more Inclusive for students with fewer opportunities. As topics of diversity and equity continue to be priorities in the Erasmus+ programme and understanding that Irish Higher Education institutions have pioneered inclusion supports for both incoming and outgoing students. The topic of Erasmus+ and Inclusion is relevant for the Irish Presidency as it can promote Irish and European best practices and power change at the EU-level for Erasmus+ mobilites,

organisation: Diversity and Inclusion in Erasmus+ iMplementation (DIEM) project
response_text: Erasmus+ regulation/MFF discussion. The Irish Presidency should involve stakeholders and policymakers in creating a more inclusive Erasmus+ programme at individual, institutional and European level. The Irish Presidency can be a forum for programme change to ensure that best practices at these levels are shared with policymakers and practitioners alike.

organisation: Diversity and Inclusion in Erasmus+ iMplementation (DIEM) project
response_text: The Erasmus+ programme has over 500 000 student participants per year, through the Irish presidency, many advancements can be made to open the programme to people who have historically been left behind. Erasmus+ is more than just a study mobility, it strengthens European skills, fosters European collaboration in higher education and supports mutual understanding through cultural exchange. ED&I is a priority in the Erasmus+ programme, the Irish Presidency can support policy developments on this aspect. The DIEM project has developed strong policy recommendations to contribute to the debate on how to improve the Erasmus+ programme for future generations.

organisation: Diversity and Inclusion in Erasmus+ iMplementation (DIEM) project
response_text: Erasmus+ is one of the EU’s most popular programmes. European surveys find that investing in Education is the most popular EU-level investment. https://europa.eu/eurobarometer/surveys/detail/3355 It supports students and citizens civic participation, through non-formal learning methods including volunteering or service-learning that allow mobility and international students to directly connect and create meaningful change in their host communities. As a result, millions of European students and local communities and employers feel a stronger sense of ownership, belonging and integration within the EU and develop a shared understanding of key values.

FoodCloud recommends that Ireland prioritise climate action and social cohesion during its Presidency of the EU Council with food security as the central cross-cutting theme. At a time when global commitment to shared values, democracy, equality and human rights is weakening globally, Ireland has an opportunity to champion the EU’s collective ambition for a resilient, inclusive and sustainable future. Food security is critical to achieving the EU Strategic Agenda, supporting a democratic, secure, prosperous and competitive Europe. As former President Michael D. Higgins stated, responding to global hunger and vindicating the right to food are among the most urgent contemporary challenges. The UN WFP’s Global Report on Food Crises identifies climate-related weather extremes as the second-largest driver of acute food insecurity, affecting over 96 million people. Addressing food systems stability and food security is fundamental to both climate action and social cohesion. Ireland is well placed to lead this agenda. With approximately 80% of Ireland’s food imported, the country is acutely exposed to external shocks. Yet Ireland is also recognised as a leader in sustainable food systems. Strengthening domestic horticultural production, reducing waste and building circular food systems will not only enhance Ireland’s food sovereignty but also contribute to EU-wide goals of resilience, sustainability and competitiveness. Reducing food waste globally and increasing food sovereignty are also essential to progress on the SDGs (especially SDG 12.3 and 2) and Agenda 2030. To advance these aims, Ireland should champion the following priority areas across the EU work programme: 1. Building circular and resilient food systems Ireland should lead efforts to promote circularity, ensuring edible surplus food is redistributed first for human consumption in line with the food waste hierarchy. Ireland can push for ambitious measures, enhanced reporting, and dedicated support for redistribution infrastructure and digital innovation. Strengthening domestic, diversified and climate-resilient production Ireland should support climate-resilient production systems including targeted support for horticulture, supporting sustainable diversification options for farmers and promoting agricultural recovery schemes that improve returns for small and medium producers, thereby enhancing farm incomes. These initiatives contribute to rural development, climate adaptation and long-term food availability. Enhancing community resilience and social cohesion Ireland should advocate for continued and robust ESF+ food support funding in the next Multiannual Financial Framework. ESF+ food support is essential for tackling poverty and reducing food insecurity and supporting vulnerable households, thereby reinforcing the EU’s broader goals of community resilience and social cohesion. Driving global leadership through ODA Ireland should continue to champion overseas development assistance as a means of promoting security and stability. Ireland can explore how technological advancements can empower developing nations to become more independent and resilient. For example, Irish Aid has funded FoodCloud’s virtual food-banking project in Africa. This enables food banks there to facilitate efficient redistribution without central warehouses. Since November 2023, FoodCloud’s technology has enabled the sharing of over 5.6 million meals in Kenya, demonstrating the transformative potential of digital redistribution in strengthening communities and reducing waste. By prioritising climate action and social cohesion through the lens of food security, Ireland can help steer the EU towards a more resilient and inclusive future, supporting communities at home, strengthening strategic autonomy across Europe and contributing to global food security.

As an organisation dedicated to reducing food waste and strengthening community resilience through food redistribution, FoodCloud recommends that Ireland’s 2026 Presidency prioritise policy areas that enable maximisation of food resources. Food redistribution can directly advance the EU Strategic Agenda’s goals on climate action, social cohesion, competitiveness, and strategic resilience. The Presidency offers a critical opportunity to highlight the importance of following the food use and waste hierarchy and to champion practical, socially beneficial solutions that reduce emissions, support vulnerable communities, and improve food security. 1. Waste Framework Directive (WFD) Work on the revised WFD, including implementing acts and monitoring frameworks, will continue through 2026. Ireland should prioritise advancing Council progress on binding food waste reduction targets across manufacturing, processing, retail, food service, and household sectors. The Presidency should champion strong donation and redistribution provisions to ensure surplus food is directed to feed people wherever possible, fully aligned with the food waste hierarchy. Strengthening measurement, accountability, and reporting systems will be essential for all Member States to meet these targets. Circular Economy Action Plan (CEAP) The next CEAP is expected to evolve during the Irish Presidency. Ireland should ensure that food waste reduction and redistribution are clearly embedded as priority areas within the Plan. Redistribution not only prevents unnecessary waste and reduces the emissions embedded in food production but also delivers immediate social impact by supporting communities. Ireland can use the Presidency to promote innovative models of redistribution and strengthen resource efficiency measures that contribute to the EU’s competitiveness and resilience. Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) With FoodCloud appointed as an SDG Champion for 2026–27, we strongly support integrating SDGs across EU policymaking. Ireland should ensure that SDG 12.3, halving food waste by 2030, is reflected in relevant Council conclusions and discussions. Promoting harmonised reporting and monitoring approaches linked to SDG targets will improve transparency and help Member States progress towards 2030 commitments. International Climate Leadership and COP 31 Ahead of COP 31 in Turkey, Ireland can help shape a strong, unified EU position. The Presidency should encourage the inclusion of food loss and waste reduction - and the associated saving of wasted emissions in Nationally Determined Contributions, strengthen momentum behind Axis 3 of the COP 30 Action Agenda on food loss and waste, and promote EU support for the Declaration on Reducing Methane from Organic Waste and the No Organic Waste Initiative. Ireland should champion the commitments made by signatories, including Ireland, to the COP28 UAE Declaration on Sustainable Agriculture, Resilient Food Systems, and Climate Action. Leadership in these areas will reinforce the EU’s global climate credibility. Social Cohesion and ESF+ While defence and security considerations will shape MFF negotiations, it is vital that social cohesion remains protected. Ireland should advocate for continued ring-fenced support for ESF+ food support programmes. Reductions in this area would disproportionately affect vulnerable households and undermine broader EU objectives of stability, fairness, and resilience. Conclusion By prioritising these areas, Ireland’s Presidency can drive meaningful progress on food waste reduction and redistribution, delivering climate benefits, improving food security, and strengthening community resilience across the EU.

Europe is entering a period of significant uncertainty, with long-established economic and geopolitical assumptions now under pressure. As the European Commission’s 2026 work programme highlights, the EU must respond to this “independence moment” by strengthening stability, competitiveness, and strategic resilience. The Irish Presidency has a critical opportunity to contribute to these objectives by advancing practical, people-centred initiatives that make Europe’s food system more circular, more efficient, and more secure. A focus on food waste reduction and food redistribution, aligned with the priorities outlined in Question 2, offers one of the most immediate and substantial positive impacts for people, businesses, and communities across the EU. These issues sit at the intersection of Europe’s major policy challenges: climate action, social cohesion, competitiveness, and resource security. By prioritising them in Council deliberations, Ireland can support outcomes that deliver tangible benefits for millions of Europeans. Impact for People Reducing food waste and expanding food redistribution directly improves food access for vulnerable households while lowering the cost burden on public services. Supporting the development of circular food infrastructure, such as efficient donation and redistribution channels, ensures that surplus food is used to feed people rather than being lost or wasted. This reduces inequality, strengthens community resilience, and contributes to the EU’s social fairness agenda. Continued protection of ESF+ food support programmes will be essential to sustaining these benefits. Impact for Businesses Businesses stand to gain significantly from more circular, efficient food systems. Reducing waste lowers costs, improves productivity, and increases competitiveness, key goals of the EU Strategic Agenda. Initiatives such as FoodCloud’s Growers’ Project demonstrate how farmers can capture greater value from their crops by ensuring that more of what they produce reaches consumers. Encouraging circular practices across supply chains supports economic resilience, reduces exposure to volatile global markets, and helps businesses meet growing regulatory expectations under EU climate and waste legislation. Digitisation further amplifies these benefits. FoodCloud’s Foodiverse platform has already demonstrated how technology can streamline redistribution, measure impact, and help food banks and businesses rescue more food effectively. By promoting EU-wide uptake of digital tools and ensuring flexible access to innovation funding, the Presidency can accelerate the modernisation of Europe’s food system while supporting SMEs and social enterprises. Impact for Communities Communities benefit when circular systems are normalised and supported. Strengthening redistribution networks, improving local food security, and reducing avoidable waste all contribute to social cohesion and local resilience. Circularity keeps value circulating within communities, reduces environmental pressures, and supports climate objectives by preventing the emissions embedded in food production from being wasted. Conclusion By championing circularity, food waste reduction, and innovation in food redistribution, the Irish Presidency can help build a Europe that is more secure, competitive, and resilient. These actions will deliver immediate and visible benefits for people, businesses, and communities, while reinforcing the EU’s long-term goals on climate action, resource efficiency, and social cohesion.

Communicating the values and benefits of EU membership requires making Europe real and relevant to people’s daily lives. Too often, the EU is perceived as distant or abstract, despite the profound impact its policies and programmes have on communities across Ireland and the wider Union. As Ireland prepares to assume the Presidency of the Council of the EU, there is an important opportunity to build understanding, pride, and a sense of ownership by showcasing practical examples of how EU cooperation improves lives. FoodCloud is a mission-driven organisation committed to transforming surplus food into opportunities to make the world a kinder, fairer place. Our values, kindness, collaboration, enterprise, and action align closely with the core values of the EU: human dignity, freedom, equality, democracy, the rule of law, and respect for human rights. At the heart of our mission is a belief that everyone has the right to food and the opportunity to thrive. Strengthening the connection between these values and the lived experience of EU membership is vital to building public support and engagement. In a global context where protectionist and individualist narratives are gaining traction, communicating the EU’s benefits must be done in a positive, honest, and relatable manner. People connect most with real stories - stories of individuals, families, businesses, and communities whose lives are improved through cooperation, solidarity, and shared purpose. FoodCloud, as part of Irish civil society and as an SDG Champion for 2026–27, is committed to helping tell these stories in ways that resonate and inspire. Many people who benefit from EU programmes are not aware that these supports stem from EU decisions, funding, and shared values. For example, thousands of community groups across Ireland receive food support through the ESF+ programme, yet many individuals receiving this food may not know it is part of an EU initiative. Making these connections visible is essential for fostering public understanding and pride. FoodCloud proposes that Ireland’s Presidency include an event highlighting the community-level impact of ESF+. Building on the ESF+ launch event planned for May 2026, such an event could bring together EU policymakers, national officials, civil society organisations, and programme beneficiaries. By showcasing the real-world outcomes of EU social investment—families supported, food saved from waste, communities strengthened—the Presidency can illustrate the tangible, human impact of EU solidarity. Beyond a single event, communication should emphasise accessibility and participation. This includes using clear storytelling, digital content, and community-led engagement to demonstrate how EU policies on food waste, circularity, climate action, and social inclusion translate into real benefits for people and businesses. It also means involving citizens directly, inviting community groups, young people, and beneficiaries of EU programmes to share their experiences and perspectives. By grounding the Presidency in real stories of cooperation and impact, Ireland can help citizens across the EU understand not only what Europe does, but why it matters. This approach fosters a sense of ownership, pride, and connection, ensuring that the values at the heart of the European project remain meaningful, relevant, and shared by all.

FoodCloud welcomes the opportunity to contribute to Ireland’s preparations for the 2026 Presidency of the Council of the EU and would be eager to support wider civil society engagement throughout the Presidency. We understand that a civil society event is planned for October 2026 and would be very keen to participate, whether through a community-based event such as the ESF+ impact gathering proposed earlier or through another format that aligns with the Presidency’s priorities. As an organisation rooted in collaboration and community impact, we believe we can add meaningful value by sharing practical examples of how EU policies translate into real benefits for people, businesses, and communities. FoodCloud will also serve as an SDG Champion during the overlapping period of the Presidency (2026– 27). We see this as a timely opportunity to help elevate the Sustainable Development Goals throughout the Presidency’s programme. While our work is most closely aligned with SDG 2 (Zero Hunger), SDG 4 (Quality Education), SDG 12 (Responsible Production and Consumption), SDG 13 (Climate Action), and SDG 17 (Partnerships for the Goals), we are committed to promoting the integrated nature of all 17 Goals. We would welcome opportunities to support Presidency events, outreach activities, or communications that highlight the SDGs’ relevance to EU cooperation, community wellbeing, and strategic resilience. FoodCloud is ready to engage constructively with Government and EU partners to help demonstrate the value of collaboration, circularity, and shared European action throughout the Presidency year.

We believe the most important high-level priority for the Irish presidency should be the simplification of the regulatory burden and reduction in cost in order to boost the competitiveness of the EU. We believe at a time when Europe faces intense international competition from established economies like the United States and emerging economic forces like China, the EU must immediately adapt and make doing business as easy as possible. This should not be interpreted as a call for deregulation. It remains imperative that Europe maintains high standards. However, high standards and regulatory simplification are not mutually exclusive and can ensure that the EU becomes more attractive to investment.

We would draw the Department’s attention to issues relating to the Medical Devices Regulation (MDR), in particular for medical devices used in out-of-hospital settings. We believe it is appropriate that devices should be regulated by MDR and should not be regulated by consumer-orientated regulations. Further, Solventum would like to see an accelerated approach to getting electronic instructions for use for medical devices used under professional direction in the community (i.e. on prescription or other direction of a medical professional). At the moment, only devices used in professional settings such as hospitals can have electronic instructions for use and we would like to see this expanded. In wound care, it is not unusual for the same product to be used in hospitals and in the community – but currently electronic instructions for use can only be used for products used in hospitals. This is especially critical given the growth in the use of medical devices in community settings under the direction of healthcare professionals. The shift in healthcare delivery from hospital to out-of-hospital care is vital to reducing the cost of care. Receiving professional care in the home environment is also generally preferred by patients. Patients living with diabetes, incontinence, stomas or recovering from major surgery are increasingly treated at home. They use professional medical devices under the direction of a medical professional, but they do so at home. More generally, there are systematic challenges related to the interplay between MDR, consumer and environmental legislation that need to be addressed. Provisions of EU consumer and/or environmental legislation create misaligned compliance requirements, regulatory duplication and inflated costs. In line with strategic goals to achieve regulatory simplification and improve European competitiveness, finding solutions for these regulatory challenges is essential. A few examples of such misalignments include unique identifier requirements duplication or the Right to Repair Directive, which conflicts with MDR rules specifying that only trained professionals may repair devices. Broader consumer and environmental frameworks (Ecodesign for Sustainable Products Regulation and Batteries Regulation) also apply by default to medical devices, increasing complexity and inconsistencies across Member States. Improving the interplay between the MDR and consumer legislation is crucial to unlock the potential of out-of-hospital care, improve patient outcomes and deliver more sustainable healthcare services. Secondly, we believe that the Irish Presidency should prioritise trade and strive to develop a stronger and more stable trading relationship with the USA on behalf of the EU. Ireland is uniquely placed among EU members to drive an improvement in trading terms with the US. Specifically, this should be to seek an exemption for EU-origin medical devices from Section 232 tariffs (as UK has done) and also to reduce the current 15% tariff rate on medical devices exported from the EU to the US. We also believe the simplification of the EU Deforestation Regulation (EUDR) should be completed in good order to ensure confusion and the over-burdening of industry on the matter is dealt with.

Strong co-operation between the private and public sectors are invaluable to a properly functioning economy and vibrant society. Both sectors have a common interest at heart and share the objectives of safety and sustainability - and regulation should always be fair, balanced and communicated effectively. With this in mind, we believe that communication from the Commission and national governments to business needs to be substantially improved. For example, the biggest issue in implementing the EUDR for many businesses has been the constant changing of policy - whilst the world has been watching. This has led to, at times, confusion and misunderstanding about the Commission’s policy positions, which is not only far from optimal, but can lead to ineffective implementation and adherence to important regulation. We recommend that the Commission adopt more of a hands-on approach to effective communication with business on policy development to ensure greater understanding. Solventum suppliers have been quoting back to us that EUDR is delayed – when actually this is merely an aspiration or a position taken in a debate. These suppliers are not willfully misinterpreting what is happening – it’s because communication is poor. Business needs time to implement change – because many companies have huge and complex supply chains stretching across the world. And it needs crystal clear communication.

We would suggest a coordinated approach to communicating with different groups. Whilst consumers and citizens will be keen to be reminded of the benefits of membership, business and industry will be keen to hear and understand those benefits through a different lens. There are many pieces of legislation with extra-territorial aspects eg EUDR, CSDDD. It cannot solely be the job of companies like Solventum to communicate EU policy to vast, complicated supply chains across the globe. If the EU insists on extra-territorial aspects to its regulations, then it needs to be prepared to communicate better with stakeholders in these other countries – with industry associations, via national governments and potentially with individual companies. Further, we propose that Ireland’s Presidency should establish a new forum for discussion and communication between business and the Commission that lasts into the future, long after the Irish Presidency has ended. Business often feels that ‘things are done to them’ – that they have little opportunity to discuss the implications of regulations before they are decided. For regulation that impacts business in a significant way – or adds costs, then mechanisms should be put in place to enable business to co-create future regulation. “No decision about us, without us”. The Commission generally does a good job of consulting – but it consults after the proposal is crafted….and business needs to be involved at concept stage. Too often, the EU forces behaviour change with a great big (costly) stick – carrots also work. This would be a fitting legacy.

geography: Our members are based across the Island of Ireland
response_text: Ireland should choose Culture, Identity, Sustainability, Security and Fair Technology as priorities.

geography: Our members are based across the Island of Ireland
response_text: Fair Technology – Ireland’s presidency intersects with the evolution and rapid growth of the unprecedented new technologies involved in AI. These technologies will cause huge disruption across all EU citizens lives, in every sector and industry some of this disruption will be of huge shared benefit and some will create new threats and risks that will affect all, with some being more vulnerable than others. The companies providing and servicing these technologies will have enormous power, policy and active transparent leadership from policy makers is crucial. Ireland as a host country to so many of the key players in technology should ensure that our presidency represents the key role of policy and regulation in ensuring a safe future for all citizens when it comes to the scope of these technologies and the companies who seek to profit from them.

geography: Our members are based across the Island of Ireland
response_text: Achieve full Implementation of The EU Artificial Intelligence Act ensuring authors have access to opt out mechanisms and can rely of protection of existing copyright legislation. Delivery on the EU Digital Services Act Robust review of Directive on Copyright in the Digital Single Market with particular attention to its success in creating a fairer landscape for Authors and Performers, collective bargaining and alternative dispute resolution and level of adoption of transparency obligations. Strong support for EU cultural policy including Creative Europe and Music Moves Europe. Policy to protect creators, authors, performers from international media and music industry oligarchy and develop pathways for sustainable national creative and media industries which are not undermined or over shadowed by huge media players.

geography: Our members are based across the Island of Ireland
response_text: Through ensuring that citizens voices are heard, through demonstrating the benefit of EU membership in policy and action which puts people ahead of corporations and culture, creativity, sustainability and well-being ahead of profits and corporate greed. Culture and access to culture which can both underpin national identity whilst aiding in developing acceptance and understanding of other nationalities is crucial to supporting cohesive communities. Clear policy and regulation which helps address the players including large media or technology companies which are driving division.
