response_text: It would be good to see this used as an opportunity to both showcase and fully exploit the wonderful arts, culture and media talent we have available in this country to support a successful presidency and to measure the true value of a sustainable and invested in creative industry to drive further investment.

Theme: “Europe from the Ground Up: Empowering Communities to innovate for a Resilient Rural Europe” Drawing from the EU's long-term Vision for Rural Areas and Rural Pact, Ireland should lead a Presidency that embeds community-led principles across EU policy, and which strengthens rural areas as inclusive, vibrant and active engines of competitiveness, security, and democracy, demonstrating that a resilient Europe must be built from the ground up on the values of solidarity and equal participation. Thematic priorities: These priorities would position Ireland as a facilitator of inclusive growth: Localising the Green Deal: Community-Led Climate Action To progress action toward the EU’s climate neutrality goals, Ireland’s Presidency should focus on the "social acceptance" of the Green Deal. Ireland should prioritise legislative and policy frameworks that facilitate a transition to community-led climate, energy and circular economy initiatives. EU investment in governance models that enable greater levels of citizen engagement and CLLD will ensure that investments in renewable energy and biodiversity generate tangible economic returns for local populations rather than extraction by external organisations. This supports a "Just Transition" by making empowering citizens to become active stakeholders in energy security. Social Innovation and Demographic Revitalization Addressing the "geography of discontent" requires a focus on social cohesion. Ireland’s Presidency should prioritise investment in community animation, activation and capacity building resources to develop and support a strong culture of community led Social Innovation and Social Enterprise, as critical drivers of rural revitalisation and renewal, particularly in areas facing demographic decline and service withdrawal. Progressing implementation of the EU Social Economy Action Plan should focus on state aid modernisation and funding simplification that support social enterprises to fill gaps in public and private service provision (care, housing, transport, circular economy, energy). This will empower communities to co design solutions to critical problems such as housing, aging demographics and youth migration. 3. The “Smart Rural” Agenda: Digital Equity and Competitiveness Connecting to the EU competitiveness agenda, Ireland’s Presidency should advocate for a shift from purely infrastructural metrics (broadband coverage) to capacity building (digital adoption) and smart village led innovation. A strong focus on community animation, activation and capacity building to empower citizens to identify priorities, co design and develop solutions, and build social capital will help reduce the urban rural digital divide, help unlock the rural economy, and ensure rural areas are integrated into the Single Market as dynamic areas of innovation, rather than peripheral areas of decline.

Ireland’s Presidency should focus on implementation of policies that strengthen rural resilience, empower communities, and ensure equitable access to EU opportunities, enabling rural communities to thrive and actively contribute to Europe’s future. Cohesion Policy & Territorial Cooperation Post-2027 Champion the mandatory expansion of Community-Led Local Development (CLLD) across all Structural Funds. These models have proven effective in mobilising communities and citizens and delivering integrated place based solutions that are sustainable. Simplification & Accessibility Lead on reducing the administrative burden and cost through advocating for outcome focused auditing, for "Safe to Fail" innovation pilots, and for mandatory adoption of Simplified Cost Options (SCOs) and lumpsum funding and reporting. Create a national match funding scheme for Civil Society Organisations Follow other EU countries example and create and invest in a Civil Society Match Fund initiative for Irish organisations participating in competitive EU programmes such as Interreg, where the EU cofinancing rate is 60%. Lack of cofinancing is a major barrier, limiting Ireland’s ability to successfully participate and draw down EU funds.

The Irish Presidency can make a lasting difference by championing community led approaches that empower citizens through active participation, that support entrepreneurs through localised innovation, and that facilitate resilient, sustainable, and inclusive communities. Promote Bottom-Up Policy Design Leverage Community Led Local Development methodologies to involve rural communities in EU processes such as CAP and cohesion policy reforms. This will ensure policies reflect local needs, empowering people through participatory forums, and will enhance ownership, reduce urban rural disparity and foster social cohesion. Support Innovative Funding Mechanisms Advocate for dedicated EU funds in the next MFF (post-2027) for community led and community driven initiatives in rural development, inclusion, digitalisation, green transitions, and skills development. 3. Address Cross-Cutting Challenges: Integrate rural perspectives into security and migration policies, using social innovation to facilitate inclusive integration programs.

Enhancing citizen ownership of Ireland’s upcoming Presidency of the Council should centre on facilitating citizens and communities to communicate the tangible, local impacts of the values and benefits of EU membership. A funded call for community led communications campaigns, placing citizens and communities as co-owners rather than passive recipients, could focus on the values of democracy, solidarity, sustainability, rule of law, and respect for human dignity and could include the following: Visibility Through Local Action: showcase EU funded projects that improve daily life across social services, enterprises, climate initiatives etc. delivered by locally led organisations. These tangible examples demonstrate the EU’s commitment to rural communities. Outreach of the Presidency: Support for delivery of community led public participatory events where citizens play an active role in setting the agenda. Community Engagement: Use of local development networks and organisations to animate participation and explain EU benefits in practical terms. Storytelling Campaigns: Support the development of community led audio and visual case studies and stories, led by community members explaining in their own words how EU partnership has improved their quality of life, and the positive impacts which have accrued to their communities. Peer Ambassadors: Identify communities, young people, disadvantaged groups, business people etc, as EU Presidency Ambassadors to animate peers around presidency priorities and facilitate peer to peer conversations.

1. Investment in Community Animation, Activation and Capacity Building A gap in EU policy implementation is inadequate investment in community animation, activation and capacity-building. Communities possess vision but often lack dedicated facilitation, training, and mentoring support to translate potential into action. Ireland's Presidency should recognise the critical role that outreached animation and capacity building play in democratic participation and policy implementation, and advocate for substantial EU level allocations to support core community development work, local animation and capacity building programmes, and community-led local development delivery methodologies. 2. Investment in a National Civil Society Match Funding Scheme for EU Competitive Funds A critical barrier preventing Irish civil society organisations from accessing EU competitive funding is co financing requirements. While the EU typically funds 60-70% of project costs in competitive funding calls, Civil Society Organisations must source the shortfall from other sources. This is a significant challenge for organisations with limited revenue streams, and results in Ireland drawing down far less EU investment than potentially available and limits civil society participation in and learning from EU programmes and partners. Ireland should establish a national match funding scheme administered by the Regional Assemblies. This mechanism would unlock substantial EU investment while enabling grassroots organisations to contribute to EU priorities.

CITIZEN. The place and the role of the citizen. Are we catering for citizens’ needs (a quality of life, opportunities, affordability). At the same time are citizens engaged intellectually and emotionally with governing. Do they have a meaningful input into decisions that effect them? TECHNOLOGY. Europe as a global technology leader. Europe needs to build competitors and alternatives to US and Chinese social media and AI platforms. It needs to do this at great scale.

Arising from A, we need: Consider development of the built enviironment (in particular housing and infrastructure) to address the needs of people. It is far too slow to develop infrastructure in Europe. We need to get the public involved at an early stage in planning for the future, not at the very end and this needs to become a European norm. Consider making mechanisms like the Citizens Assembly a standard part of the consultation process To review how we deal with basic essentials – housing, transport, education, jobs market. Develop short and medium-term plans to address the issue of affordability and to combat inflation where these issues are at the EU level (many issues around grocery and resource prices can be addressed to some degree at EU level). This increased care and consultation at the beginning can be matched with a reduction in delays from legal problems at the end. The opportunity to deal finally with legal problems will be during the planning and consultation, not during the development itself. TECHNOLOGY. Arising from B, new investment mechanisms are needed. There has to be a focus, and there has to be joint purchasing. An example of a focus would be AI and data analysis technologies for government. This market is currently dominated by a US player, Palantir. EU governments are beginning to purchase Palantir products and services at scale. An EU alternative should be developed over the next 10 years to focus the use of the latest AI technology on solving problems in government, with a particular emphasis on european values like respect for privacy and diversity. This would be a venture on a similar scale to the development of EADS/airbus.

By creating real value for citizens, showing that the EU put the citizen’s needs first. By showing that we have a plan for technology leadership, so that Europe and its constituent countries are not to be left beholden to other powers. By showing that we are going to develop infrastructure and housing faster, and that environmental concerns will be dealt with in a fair and proportionate manner but will not slow down the delivery of things people need.

The EU has to be about respect for and care for the citizen. Initiatives that reflect this will build respect. Initiatives for snooping on private information, impinging on personal’s rights and so on will all reduce respect for the EU.
DPENDR and Department of the Taoiseach have done extensive work in the area of a framework for public engagement and participation. This could play a substantial role in developing a theme.

Position gender equity and inclusion as a central thematic priority Focus on inequalities in health and healthcare leadership affecting women and minority groups Emphasise the right to health as a fundamental human right Build on Ireland’s tradition of human rights leadership and global health action Link this priority to Ireland’s international commitments and UN Human Rights Council ambitions Highlight Ireland’s role in promoting inclusive, rights-based EU policies

Refer to the Issues at Stake - EU Tools listed in the table on page 16 of the policy brief Prioritise proposals that strengthen gender equality in health systems Support diversity in healthcare leadership and governance Focus on universal, inclusive and affordable access to healthcare Aim to reduce health disparities for women and marginalised communities Emphasise practical implementation and measurable progress across Member States Call for accelerated legislative progress and political alignment

Highlight the timing of Ireland’s Presidency during Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) negotiations Advocate for gender equity and social inclusion as core principles of EU funding Emphasise rights-based investment in health, social protection and community resilience Stress the importance of protecting and advancing human rights in a changing global context Link equitable policies to economic stability and business sustainability Reference key themes from the main policy recommendations in the brief

Frame public health as essential to social justice, economic resilience and democratic stability Emphasise that universal access to quality healthcare reflects core EU values Highlight concerns about rollbacks in women’s health and rights Stress the importance of visible EU leadership on equity and inclusion Promote systematic involvement of civil society in policymaking Include participation of: Women’s rights and women’s health organisations Gender equality organisations Migrant and Roma communities LGBTIQ+ groups Disability and carers’ organisations Emphasise co-creation, consultation and ongoing monitoring Highlight that inclusive participation builds trust, ownership and democratic engagement

As a joint organiser abd contributor to the policy discussions, I helped inform the development of the below linked policy brief. I wish to submit this policy brief as supporting evidence for my submission: https://globalhealth.ie/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/IGHN-EIWH-Policy-Brief-FINAL_TOC-Dec-9.pdf

Active Retirement Ireland recommends that Ireland’s Presidency adopt a people centred, rights based and future oriented vision for the European Union that places inclusion, equality and intergenerational solidarity at its core. A suitable overarching theme is: A Europe for All Ages: Dignity, Participation and Solidarity. Three priority themes are proposed. First, Rights and Inclusion Across the Life Course, recognising that ageing is a lifelong process and that policy should ensure opportunities, supports and protections at all stages of life. A rights based approach should underpin this work, guaranteeing dignity, participation, access to services and protection from discrimination, including ageism. Second, Sustainable and Inclusive Societies, supporting Member States to anticipate demographic change, strengthen social protection, promote ageing in place and invest in age friendly environments. This includes financial sustainability that does not frame older populations as a burden but sees demographic change as an opportunity for innovation, participation and economic resilience. Third, Intergenerational Solidarity and Engagement, encouraging structured dialogue between generations, and recognising older people’s contributions through volunteering, caring, mentoring, civic engagement and cultural enrichment. This approach aligns with the EU Strategic Agenda 2024 to 2029, reinforces fairness and cohesion and positions Ireland to demonstrate leadership on rights based and inclusive policymaking across the Union.

ARI recommends that Ireland prioritise social policy, health, employment, digital inclusion and education during its Presidency, particularly through the EPSCO, ENVI, COMPET and TTE Council configurations. The Presidency should support progress on EU level measures that enable independent living, ageing in place, integrated community supports and age friendly environments. Key priorities include combating ageism, promoting intergenerational fairness, supporting lifelong learning and ensuring digital transformation policies do not exclude older people. A focus on digital accessibility, digital skills and universal design is essential to prevent widening inequalities. Ireland should encourage long term planning for pensions, healthcare and social supports that balances sustainability with dignity and rights. The Presidency can also strengthen the implementation of the European Care Strategy, promote the integration of preventative health measures and highlight best practice in community-based supports. The Presidency should champion evidence-based policy, ensure that demographic considerations are mainstreamed across EU work programmes and involve civil society in policy formation. Programmes addressing these areas should embed life course thinking and support participation, cohesion and wellbeing across generations.

The Irish Presidency can deliver substantial positive impact by integrating rights based and life course approaches across Council deliberations. Prioritising fair and inclusive policies in social protection, health, employment, digital and education fields will support stronger outcomes for individuals and communities across the European Union. Strengthening measures that support ageing in place, community based care and preventative health will improve quality of life and reduce isolation. Coordinated EU action on demographic change will help Member States plan sustainably for health systems, labour markets and social protection. This will contribute to economic resilience and social stability. Promoting intergenerational initiatives will encourage civic participation, strengthen community ties and highlight the contributions of older people. The Presidency can promote collaboration, knowledge exchange and inclusive policymaking that supports fairness, participation and wellbeing across all generations.

To foster public ownership of Ireland’s Presidency, ARI recommends inclusive and accessible communication that highlights the real world benefits of EU membership and the relevance of the Presidency to daily life. Positive narratives about ageing and intergenerational solidarity should be promoted, showing the EU’s role in safeguarding rights and supporting social inclusion. Engagement should involve online outreach, town halls, local forums and civil society partnerships. Community organisations are well placed to translate EU priorities into meaningful local stories and examples. Communications should emphasise how the EU supports fairness, cohesion, health, digital access and social protection across all ages. This will help citizens see themselves reflected in the Presidency and feel a sense of shared ownership.

Ireland’s Presidency is a significant opportunity to promote a forward looking, inclusive and rights based approach that values the contributions and needs of all generations. Effective consultation with civil society, particularly organisations representing older people, will help ensure that policies are equitable and sustainable. Embedding human rights and life course frameworks across all Council work will strengthen fairness, resilience and public trust. Recognising and highlighting the diverse contributions of older people reinforces the value of intergenerational solidarity and supports inclusive policymaking across the Union. Active Retirement Ireland is available to advise on ageing, social inclusion and intergenerational policy and to engage in dialogue that supports a Presidency framed around dignity, participation and equality for people of all ages.

Closing the gender gap in health, relating to EU Strategic Agenda 2024-29 on “EU and Member States will aim to strengthen social dialogue, uphold equal opportunities and reduce inequalities” (page 8, ‘Advancing Together’ section) and related to EU Gender equality strategy 2026-2030. Ensuring faster access to new, life-enhancing drugs (particularly for cancer patients) across the EU, relating to EU Strategic Agenda 2024-29 to “further strengthen health cooperation at European and international level and improve access to medicines across the Union” (page 8, ‘Advancing together’ section). Promoting the importance of gynaecological health, breaking the stigma surrounding this (see ESGO) and promoting the Cervical Cancer Elimination Campaign goals to ensure the EU meets WHO targets by 2030.

Stronger Cross-border medicines authorisation. If something is authorised in one EU country it should be authorised and available in another. Not an application required for each country and at the pharmaceutical company’s/licensed company’s request. This can be related to “further strengthen health cooperation at European and international level and improve access to medicines across the Union” (page 8, ‘Advancing together’ section). Surrogacy regulation to ensure support, safety and legal certainty for all those involved. Women’s health is more than maternity support. A whole of life approach to health is needed, greater support for gynaecological health and cancer prevention education and promotion. Relates to Gender equality strategy 2026-2030. WHO’s Cervical Cancer Elimination Campaign targets met across the EU by 2030. This aligns with international efforts and should align with the EU’s new proposed Global Health initiative in terms of reducing preventable disease and vaccination targets. Health literacy – strengthen health literacy among EU residents, relating to EU Strategic Agenda 2024-29 on “EU and Member States will aim to strengthen social dialogue, uphold equal opportunities and reduce inequalities” (page 8, ‘Advancing Together’ section) as differing health literacy levels can lead to differing experiences of health care. It should also align with the new proposed EU Global Health initiative in terms of tackling health disinformation.

Good health is the cornerstone to a happy life, to the economic productivity required to sustain EU populations (particularly given EUs aging populations), and should be available to all, through comprehensive education, outreach and health care delivery.

Show the impact of EU funds and cooperation at the local level. Our focus in this regard would be health – for example, showing how cross-border cooperation between states allows for EU citizens’ access to the best health care. Be honest. What needs more work? Where has the EU failed recently, particularly through lens of the Irish public? What can be done to change this? Listen to young people. It is their future we are currently setting up.
We are more than happy to be contacted and provide more information at any time.

Higher education as investment in the long term future of the continent. The best way for the EU to become more independent is to strengthen its own economy by preventing brain drain. For this to happen the European Union must invest into the future of its youth by making education a priority and the younger generations an impetus to pursue higher education in Europe. European Economic power, prosperity, social cohesion and independence lie in a strong higher education that is well-equipped to respond to tomorrow’s challenges. The Erasmus+ programme is the biggest international student mobility programme worldwide. It allows around 500,000 European students each year to participate in academic mobility, making it the flagship programme for higher education in Europe. International mobility experiences foster a sense of European values while also deepening intercultural and interpersonal competences among those who participate. . Guided by the principles of equity and inclusion, the programme reflects the democratic values cherished in our societies, but which are increasingly undermined by actors within and outside of the EU. In this context, the programme stands as a vital instrument for strengthening our democratic fabric, expanding civic trust, and keeping the Union resilient. In 2023 alone, Ireland supported over 35 000 Erasmus+ students in incoming and outgoing mobility, demonstrating a pioneering approach to inclusive student mobility. For this reason the Irish Presidency can make an important contribution to the success of the Erasmus+ programme by ensuring inclusion and resilience in (higher) education.

Safeguarding the role of (higher) education in the next Multiannual Financial Framework. The proposals for the EU’s next long-term budget and the regulation establishing the Erasmus+ programme (2028-2034) provide very little clarity on what education as a sector can anticipate in the next funding period. Through a restructuring of the programme and new policy priorities, a greater focus will be placed on developing skills and attracting and retaining talent, thereby shifting the emphasis away from the societal benefits of higher education and its role in personal development of an entire continent. Higher education plays an essential role in ensuring the resilience and safety of the continent, especially in the currently uncertain geopolitical situation. Development of critical skills, independent research, and freedom of thought foster an engaged and informed citizenry. Thus the next Multiannual Financial Framework needs to reflect that role with a sufficient budget allocation that is significantly higher than in the proposal made by the European Commission. Regulation establishing Erasmus+ programme (2028-2034) and the subsequent Work Programme and Programme Guide for 2028. The flexibility of the programme and streamlining of the processes cannot come at the expense of stability and predictability for the higher education institutions and other beneficiaries. Additionally, the regulation for the Erasmus+ programme needs timely adoption to ensure there are no delays for the next funding period and higher education institutions will not experience any disruptions to their international activities. The Irish Presidency should also aim to bring together various stakeholders, such as national Erasmus+ agencies, civil society organisations and higher education practitioners to work together and shape the future of the Erasmus+ programme. For this, the questions of inclusion in the programme, programme governance and its stability during the transition period would make up much welcomed debates/working groups. The Erasmus+ programme can be elevated on the agenda of the European Union through this work, and Ireland can play an important role in ensuring a smooth transition between the programme periods and have a significant influence on its future.

Sufficient funding that matches the political ambition. Prevent structural under-funding of the Erasmus+ programme. The proposal presented by the European Commission for EU’s next long-term budget, while presented as having a 50% increase, is nominal, and maintains the same progression of funding for Erasmus+ programme when compared to the current Multiannual Financial Framework. At the same time, new actions are added to the successor programme, including the integration of the European Solidarity Corps under the Erasmus+ umbrella, de facto decreasing funding allocation for existing actions that are already structurally underfunded. Approximately 50% of student mobilities cannot be funded due to lack of funding. Only 10% of cooperation partnership project applications fuelling bottom-up initiatives in higher education are funded, to name a few examples. The budget proposal not only mismatches the demand for the EU’s flagship initiative, it also falls short of the ambition put forward by the Member States of reaching the mobility targets. To attain the targets set out in the Council Recommendation “Europe on the Move”, Erasmus+ budget for student mobility would have to increase at least by 55% compared to the current budget allocation. Ensuring continuity of the Erasmus+ programme and avoiding disruptions. The Erasmus+ programme is a unique European programme funding 500,000 student mobilities every year and functions as a crucial stream for project funding for European higher education institutions. For this reason, the beneficiaries, namely Higher Educational Institutions, need to be able to anticipate the impact of proposed policies on their institution. Due to the disruptions witnessed during the previous transition period in 2021 with a late start of the programme, many HEIs and beneficiaries are concerned that the same will occur in 2028.. Similarly, HEIs need predictability and timely information when it concerns changes in existing actions, i.e. the requirements for project applications, mobility funding allocations, IT systems updates and developments, etc. With the changes foreseen to the Erasmus+ successor programme and new actions coming into focus, HEIs need to be consulted and have a say in the upcoming changes to ensure the developments are fit for purpose, simplification measures serve the higher education community, and funding allocations are not meeting unexpected cuts. Safeguard and support cross-border collaboration opportunities enabling bottom-up initiatives in the next Erasmus+ programme. Cooperation Partnership projects, currently under KA2 in Erasmus+ programme, have proven to have high added value and long-lasting impact beyond the project timeline and scope of the deliverables. Despite the action being rated as one of the most (cost-)effective in the current funding period, the sharp decrease in its budget, combined with significantly increased interest from the higher education community, is driving success rates below 10% and causing many high-quality proposals to be rejected. In times when HEIs are experiencing national budget cuts, Erasmus+ can serve as an opportunity to further the cross-border collaboration that otherwise might not be possible.

Strengthen civil society actors representing citizens at European level and their involvement in policy making at times when their contribution to the ongoing democratic processes is challenged by more authoritarian states and actors at the European and global levels. Involvement of civil society organisations and grassroots actors in the policy discussions ensures that decisions taken and policies adopted reflect the needs of the community, that changes are better anticipated for practical implementation of the policies, and that feedback loops are closed. As a result of meaningful involvement in ongoing processes, civil society organisations can serve as multipliers of the policies and priorities of decision-makers, and establish communication channels with grassroots organisations and society. These practices would also support creating a sense of ownership and ensuring the Erasmus+ programme is adopting good governance. Direct involvement of the beneficiaries and broader higher education community in the decision making process and shaping of the programme ensures that people’s voices are well represented in the implementation decisions taken by the European Commission.

The European University Foundation remains at the disposal of Ireland's Presidency to the Council of the EU for further discussions about the future of the Erasmus+ programme and learning mobility in Europe. As a network of higher education institutions, EUF has long standing experience and extensive expertise in internationalisation of higher education. One of the priority areas identified by EUF is inclusivity of the Erasmus+ programme with an outlook to medium term solutions, as well as long-term. As funding remains one of the main deterrents to student participation in credit mobility, EUF together with partner universities, students and rectors’ council, has developed a proposal for new semester-long mobility grant calculation methodology that would ensure transparency to the beneficiaries, equal treatment of all participants regardless of their background and enable more students to pursue mobility opportunities. In addition, the proposal, if implemented, would also foster simplification of the mobility administration processes, allowing international relations offices to dedicate more of their time and resources to quality aspects of the mobility instead of administrative tasks. The methodology is based on allocation of a baseline grant to all students participating in long-term credit mobility (currently KA131), that would be topped up with a cost of living supplement should the student choose a host city that is more expensive than their home city. This grant would better reflect the expenses incurred by students during their mobility periods, changing the perception of the students regarding the affordability of learning mobility. Detailed information available here - https://zenodo.org/records/11145764

sector: Sexual and reproductive health and rights
response_text: Priority 1: Champion sexual and reproductive health and rights (SRHR) within EU policies on overseas development and humanitarian assistance—ensure a focus on SRHR within the EU’s obligations to ensure gender equality and promote, protect and fulfil women’s human rights and eradicate discrimination towards women, adolescents, people with disabilities, LGBTQI+ communities and migrants. Ireland has implemented progressive laws and policies and been an increasingly strong champion of SRHR within EU and UN multilateral spaces in recent years. As Ireland takes as place on the UN Human Rights Council and the UN Commission on Population and Development, as well as its EU role, and at a time when EU values are being attacked and policy and legal advances in support of the rights of marginalized groups are under threat in many parts of Europe and the world, Ireland’s support for SRHR, as essential to sustainable development and the attainment of the SGDs and as critical to the realization of human rights and democracy will be more important than ever. This requires both proactively reiterating the human rights values of the EU states with respect to SRHR and international human rights law (IHRL), and, at the same time, challenging both roll-back on these rights and their undermining through initiatives such as the Geneva Consensus Declaration (GCD). The GCD aims to create false equivalences between the normative framework of IHRL and a non-negotiated statement that (1) attacks sexual and reproductive rights under the guise of a purported defence of “traditional families” and (2) aims to limit the application of IHRL by privileging national sovereignty over the principle of the indivisibility, interdependence, inalienability and universality of IHRL. Ireland should use its role as the EU’s diplomatic voice in multilateral arenas to promote human rights and gender equality, foster stronger coordination among like-minded partners (including global south governments), and build coalitions to promote SRHR and to counter anti-rights and anti-gender narratives. Priority 2 Champion the role of civil society and advocacy organisations (CSOs) as critical to the development of EU policy Ireland should use the presidency to endorse the vital role of civil society organisations and human rights defenders in sustaining democracy, including their contribution to safeguarding EU values. Ireland should use its agenda-setting role to ensure that the 2025 EU Civil Society Strategy delivers on its promise to foster a vibrant civic space that helps make democracy work for all and reaffirm its call for the EU to engage CSOs in developing, implementing, and evaluating public policy and to provide them with adequate funding and protection. Ireland should support the continuation and strengthening of the Citizens, Equality, Rights and Values (CERV) Programme as a stand-alone instrument within the MFF, under direct management, equipped with an appropriate budget, and maintaining distinct sub-strands for gender equality and women’s rights including sexual and reproductive health and rights (SRHR), equality and non-discrimination including LGBTIQ equality. Advocacy must remain an eligible activity in the future CERV programme, as a core function of CSOs and essential to democratic resilience.

sector: Sexual and reproductive health and rights
response_text: Ireland can set the agenda for development cooperation so that the EU takes bold and coordinated action, including: Uphold and strengthen the EU’s political and financial commitments to gender equality and global health, including SRHR, through increased and sustained funding in the current and future MFFs (including through the current NDICI and the future Global Europe Instrument). Increase flexible, direct and accessible funding to women’s rights organizations and grassroots human rights groups operating at the local level, who are on the frontlines defending rights and delivering essential services. Reaffirm financial and political support for UN agencies, including UN Women, UNFPA (both through core funding and support to the UNFPA Supplies Partnership), UNITAID and UNICEF which play a crucial role in advancing gender equality and access to SRHR. Set a tone of support for the mandates of UN Women and UNFPA as critical to the success of reform of UN80 and ensure UNFPA has a seat at the table. Recommit to the Team Europe Initiative (TEI) on SRHR in sub-Saharan Africa, by scaling up funding to ensure long-term, predictable support for comprehensive, rights-based SRHR programming, including new jointly-funded SRHR programmes with the European Commission and/or other Member States; reinforce leadership in coordination with European actors and allies and partners in Regional Economic Communities; and ensure meaningful involvement of civil society - especially local organizations - as essential partners and advocates for gender equality, SRHR and human rights; Make strong commitments to the upcoming replenishments of the Global Fund to Fight HIV, Tuberculosis and Malaria, and Gavi, the Vaccine Alliance, to ensure continuity of life-saving services and equitable health access. Engage with like-minded Member States to ensure that Gender Action Plan IV is as ambitious as GAPIII and retains its three key principles (intersectionality, human-rights based approach and gendertransformative approach), its targets for both gender mainstreaming and gender-targeted actions, and its inclusion of SRHR. Monitor the implementation of the Global Health Strategy by the European Union and Member States, including when it comes to UHC and SRHR. For policies relevant to EU countries: Adopt an ambitious Trio Declaration on Gender Equality – with commitments on SRHR. Ensure the implementation of the directive on violence against women and domestic violence: the implementation workshop on prevention planned in September 2026 should include comprehensive sexuality and consent education and should draw on civil society expertise. Implement the new Gender Equality Strategy and other Equality Strategies. Propose and adopt Council Conclusions on the Union of Equality Agenda, gender equality issues, including SRHR, CSE, combating all forms of SGBV. Encourage the European Commission to publish Recommendations to Member States on the provision of SRHR, comprehensive sexuality education, and combating all forms of SRHR violations and obstetric and gynaecological violence, and endorse them. MFF: Ensure funding for civil society through CERV+ strand of AgoraEU, including operating grants and funding for advocacy, with sufficient and earmarked funds for CSOs, and for gender equality / GBV. Contribute to a gender-responsive implementation of the Civil Society Strategy and the Democracy Shield.

sector: Sexual and reproductive health and rights
response_text: Strong political leadership for gender equality and gender-transformative policymaking Active prioritisation of gender equality, bodily autonomy, and SRHR issues, e.g. through organisation of high-level events on these topics. Counter anti-rights opposition in the Council of the EU and systematically support gender equality and SRHR language in Council’s documents. Monitor and condemn any negative developments pertaining to women’s rights in EU Member States. Work with and support civil society organisations Meaningfully consult, engage with, give a platform to diverse civil society voices, and speak out in defence of CSOs under attack. Reject any harmful narratives against CSOs, their advocacy, or their funding. Funding The most substantial positive impact the Council can make is through adopting a good position on the MFF and especially on relevant programmes for SRHR and gender equality (AgoraEU and Global Europe Instrument). Support the budgets proposed by the EC for Global Europe and CERV+ and make sure that SRHR and gender equality are sufficiently funded in those two programmes. Ensure gender budgeting through the MFF and conditionality based on respect for fundamental rights and the rule of law.

sector: Sexual and reproductive health and rights
response_text: Public communications Develop a values-based communication strategy that consistently reinforces Ireland’s commitment to IHRL, democracy, civil society space and multilateralism. Ensure these values are clearly articulated in the terms of reference for all presidency comms and integrated into statements, socials, images, events and media. Promote and defend international human rights law as non-negotiable Consistently defending the values of the EU and the norms of IHRL in all spaces where Ireland has a chairing or agenda-setting role. Using the presidency and the diplomatic channels this will open, clearly and robustly draw attention to: attacks on IHRL, DEI, on the ECHR and on EU values; the intent of such attacks to roll back progress in rights, diminish respect for marginalised groups and to reinforce prejudice and discrimination, whether directly or indirectly, within systems, structures, policies and laws; and the harms of such attacks to the most marginalised, disadvantaged and vulnerable women and girls, LGBTQI+ individuals, people with disabilities and vulnerable migrants.

sector: Sexual and reproductive health and rights
response_text: Public support for Ireland to champion gender equality and SRHR is strong. A Red C omnibus online poll of 1003 adults conducted between 4th and 10th September 2025 shows strong public support for the priorities proposed in this submission. The poll included six statements relating to Ireland’s global role with respect to gender equality and sexual and reproductive health and rights. Statement 1 60% of respondents agree that Ireland should prioritise funding for global development programmes that support the rights and empowerment of women and girls in other countries. This sentiment is shared by men (58%) and women (61%), with equal levels of support in urban (59%) and rural (61%) areas. Support for this statement is in the low 60% for Dublin, rest of Leinster and Munster, with lower support in Connaught/Ulster (48%). Statement 2 67% of respondents agree that gender equality should remain a core part of Ireland's foreign policy. There is stronger support amongst women (73%) than men (61%). Support is higher in urban (69%) than rural (62%) areas. At regional level, support is in the 60s, ranging from 69% in Dublin to 63% in Connaught/Ulster. Statement 3 66% of respondents agree that Ireland should use its influence in international organisations like the United Nations (UN) to promote gender equality worldwide. This sentiment is supported by 63% of men and 69% of women. Support is the same regardless of whether people live in urban (66%) or rural (67%) areas. Regional support ranges from a high of 71% in Munster to 58% in Connaught/Ulster. Statement 4 70% of respondents agree that Ireland has a responsibility to support the rights of women and girls globally, including their right to make decisions about their own bodies and health. There is a noticeable gender difference in support, with 76% of women in agreement, compared with 64% of men. Support is similar amongst urban (71%) and rural (69%) dwellers. Regional support is 74% in Munster, 72% in Dublin, 70% in Rest of Leinster and 62% in Connaught/Ulster. Statement 5 57% of respondents agree that Ireland should continue to fund programmes around the world that support reproductive rights. Support for this sentiment is similar amongst men (56%) and women (58%). 58% of urban dwellers and 55% of rural dwellers agree with this statement. Regional support ranges from 60% in Munster to 55% in Connaught/Ulster.
